column2: Dr. Harry W. Laidler, Socialist candidate for Governor, set forth the Socialist program on civil liberties last night in several addresses in Queens.

The demand for stocks increased yesterday as traders took cognizance of the continued reports of business gains and of the buying rather than selling of our securities by European investors. Stocks closed around the best levels of the day with leading issues up from fractions to 3 points.

BERLIN, Oct. 6. -- Unwillingness of holders to part with their securities continue today to give the Boerse a firm basis. On the other hand the relative scarcity of liquid capital and the fact that Germany enjoys controlled economy keeps down the activity.

NANKING, China, Wednesday, Oct. 7. -- The arrival of Kazue Kuwashima from the Japanese Foreign Office does not signify the least change or moderation in Japan's policy toward China, according to a spokesman of the Japanese Embassy here.
Tt is not possible to determine the value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, since a fixed parity for the new French franc has not been established.

The final touches were being given yesterday to the landscaping around the new two-acre lake created by the City Park Department at the lower end of the old reservoir site in Central Park just north of the Seventy-ninth Street roadway.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 7. -- "Probable chances for survival of the newborn cannot be judged by apparently successful respiratory efforts, but by an analysis of the oxygen content of the blood which will immediately indicate the true progress of the respiratory activity," said Sir Joseph Barcroft, English physiologist, in the final lecture under the Terry Foundation at Yale today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7. -- Slightly smaller hog receipts and a better demand combined today to lift prices about 5 cents a hundredweight, taking the market as a whole, with sales ranging from steady to 10 cents above yesterday's prices.

The moods of horses have driven players to something approximating distraction for a long time, with the result that a kind of philosophy has been evolved so that upsets and setbacks may be explained without the use of reason.

In accepting the guardianship of the Free City of Danzig, Poland has done more than relieve the League of Nations temporarily of a burdensome charge. It has accepted the major and direct responsibility in one of Europe's "danger spots." This transfer of responsibility from Geneva to Warsaw is the direct result of the persistent National Socialist attempts to Nazify Danzig, and the recent violent lazi opposition to the League High Commissioner, SEAN LESTER.

The conflicting claims of unions representing officers of American merchant ships caused the Regional Labor Board to intervene yesterday in an election which is proposed by employes of the Grace Lines and the Seas Shipping Company to determine the union entitled to represent them in wage negotiations.

The General American Investors Company reported as of Sept. 30 net assets applicable to its outstanding securities of $35,408,516, equal to $5,364.92 for each $1,000 of debentures, and after providing for the debentures at par, to $369.34 a share for the preferred stock and to $16.15 a share for the common stock.

Production of steel ingots in the first nine months of this year was nearly 40 per cent larger than the output in the corresponding period in 1935 and exceeded the production in all of last year, according to figures issued yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

Peace in the factional conflict between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization was advanced last night as William Green, president of the A.F. of L., conferred with two spokesmen of the C.I.O., after he had delivered an impassioned appeal for amity at the convention of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers International Union at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7. -- What will happen at Republican National Committee headquarters if The Literary Digest poll should begin to reflect the pro-Roosevelt leaning of other vote samplings is a meditation from which the tender-hearted must shrink. A visit to the Railway Exchange Building, where Chairman Hamilton directs the national campaign when he is in town, brings this thought strongly to mind.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 7. -- Following is the text of Secretary Hull's address here tonight:

Batting down passes and rushing the kicker were two phases of football to which the Fordham team devoted itself yesterday at Fordham Field in anticipation of a severe aerial assault by Southern Methodist at the Polo Grounds on Saturday.

LIGONIER, Pa., Oct. 7. -- Taking the lead after a stirring battle in the first half mile, Eastern Shore, F. Ambrose Clark's black gelding, thundered home to an easy victory in the Rolling Rock Hunt Cup, feature event of the opening day's racing at the annual Rolling Rock meeting today.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 7. -- The sixteenth annual Orange Morse Show will be held Friday and Saturday on the lawn of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club in Ridgewood Road here.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 7. -- In preparation for the Rutgers game, the Princeton squad today was sent through its longest drill of the week on University Field. A forty-five-minute scrimmage under floodlights between the varsity and freshman elevens concluded the session.

The Appellate Division heard argument yesterday and reserved decision on the appeal by Sheriff William F. Brunner of Queens from the order granted to Frank J. Prial by Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag for a partial recanvass of the votes cast in the Democratic primary for President of the Board of Aldermen, in which, on the face of the returns, Brunner was the winner by 24,714 votes.

Governor Landon of Kansas, Republican Presidential nominee, holds the lead in the "grass roots" Presidential poll conducted by 3,000 country newspapers in cooperation with the Publishers Autocaster Service and the American Press. Seventh week returns were made public yesterday.
IT was during batting practice before the last world series game that Al Schacht said right out loud:
Those cowboys and cowgirls who performed last night in Madison Square Garden at the opening of the eleventh annual World's Championship Rodeo were never still.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 7. -- Mrs. Henry A. Francis and Mrs. Clifford Francis were in charge of the annual tea and donation party this afternoon at the Berkshire County Home for Aged Women at Pittsfield, of which Mrs. Samuel Gilbert Colt is president.

MOSCOW, Oct. 7. -- THE text of the Soviet note threatening to withdraw from the Spanish nonintervention agreement, issued tonight by Samuel Kagan, Russian representative on the non-intervention committee, follows:

One of the impressive events of the early season will take place tonight at the Empire Theatre, which, in its time, has seen a good many of them. It is the opening of "Hamlet," with John Gielgud, who created a furore in London in the part, in the title role, and with a cast including Judith Anderson, Arthur Byron, Lillian Gish, Malcolm Keen, John Emery, Harry Andrews, Morgan Farley and others.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- A telegram to the Federal Communication Commission, asking that it bar Earl Browder, general secretary of the Communist party in the United States, and other Communists from further radio broadcasts was sent today by the Daughters of the American Revolution of New York State.

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- Operations boomed today on the London Stock Exchange, heavy buying sending many industrials to new high record prices. British funds were fairly steady. German issues strengthened in the foreign market. Home rails were more active and higher, Canadian Pacific stocks rose further and Argentines declined.
With New York's state of civil war declared at an end amid a riotous celebration that proclaimed the Yankees the new world champions, baseball moved swiftly yesterday into its period of hibernation.

Fernando de los Rios, Spanish Ambassador to Washington, repudiated yesterday the belief that the present Madrid government is dominated by Communists and asserted that its only ideal was to further justice, liberty and democracy.

Not many minutes before the big liner was ready to sail yesterday, Miss Pamela Barton, London girl who won the women's United States golf championship last week, boarded the Cunard White Star Queen Mary en route for home.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 7 -- Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Moreland entertained today at luncheon on the Casino Terrace. Their guests were Mr. and Mrs. John J. Hicks Kerr, George H. Flinn Jr., Mr. and Mrs. George McLaughlin and Stewart McClintic.
BOSTON, Oct. 7 (AP). -- The Boston Shamrocks conquered the Pittsburgh Americans, 16 to 7, to gain their third straight American Football League victory before 5,300 tonight at National League Park.

In the last of the one-day tournaments of the Women's Long Island Golf Association, held at the Oakland Country Club in Bayside yesterday, Mrs. Henry March of North Shore was returned the winner with a gross score of 40, 46 -- 86, Thirty-one started in the field, but only eight posted cards.

Some of the substantial gains that magazines have been making in linage and circulation this year were attributed yesterday to the aggressive advertising campaigns of many publications and their "dressing up" programs. Just a year ago, when the linage of most leading national magazines was slumping below that of 1934, executives gave considerabie thought to their competitive problems, created by radio, newspaper magazines and the steady growth of the pulp, movie and other cheaper publications.

Apropos the editorial in THE TIMES "Foreign Lending," it has doubtless occurred to many people that the President in his Pittsburgh speech was somewhat influenced by the foreign fulminations of the C.N.P.

Appeals have been sent to members of the New York Yacht Club, it was learned yesterday, for subscriptions to the fund for the new America's Cup yacht planned to be built for defense of the trophy next July against T.O.M. Sopwith's Endeavour II.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7. -- A formal demand was submitted today to officials of the Rock River annual conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church in session here, that the Rev. Dr. Harry F. Ward be brought before a church court to answer allegations affecting his standing as a minister.
Re-entry into the realty field by operators formerly active featured the Bronx trading reported yesterday.

VIENNA, Oct. 7. -- Major Emil Fey, who was expelled from the Fascist Heimwehr by Prince Ernst von Starhemberg, made an impassioned defense today to foreign correspondents against the Prince's insinuations that he was guilty of cowardice when Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss was slain by Nazis in Vienna in 1934.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., Oct. 7. -- Establishing a new individual record for the lay-out, Jimmy Hines, Garden City Country, paired with A1 Brosch of the home club to carry off the honors in the invitation pro-pro tournament sponsored by the Long Island Professional Golfers Association today over the difficult Bethpage State Park blue course.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas showed a gain of 6 per cent for the week ended on Oct. 3, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The figure is the same as that reported for the previous week.

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- When almost within sight of the Irish coast after a flight across the Atlantic from Floyd Bennett Field, N.Y., Kurt Bjorkvall, baffled by headwinds and with a failing fuel supply, came down on the sea alongside the French trawler Imbrin at 8:50 o'clock tonight (3:50 P.M. Eastern standard time) and was hauled safely aboard.

An intensive addiction of women to poker, one of the last games believed to be exclusively male, was revealed yesterday with the arrest of twenty women in a raid on a mass poker game in a five-room apartment on the sixteenth floor of an apartment house at 175 West Seventy-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- The Republican National Committee's charges against the Works Progress Administration in Pennsylvania, made in statements by the committee and in radio broadcasts by William Hard, were branded as "false and misleading" tonight by Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- Spokesmen for the Panama Canal administration, testifying today at a hearing on the government's proposal to substitute a single basis of estimating tolls gave it as their opnion that a satisfactory method of measuring vessels and assessing tolls would be adopted in the near future.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7. -- Colonel Frank Knox, Republican Vice Presidential nominee, appealed tonight to organized labor to fight its own battles and not put its reliance on "a temporary and irresponsible Federal administration."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- In a fit of despondency because of his inability to find a job, J.D. Wilson, 36 years old, an electrician from Atlanta, slashed both his wrists at the entrance to the White House Executive Offices today, entered the building with blood streaming from the wounds and asked to see Marvin McIntyre, one of President Roosevelt's secretaries.
WITH GOVERNMENT FORCES AT VAMOJADO, Spain, Oct. 7. -- Loyalist forces tonight fought off insurgents attempting to march on Madrid along the Maqueda-Madrid highway.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- On behalf of the Radio Corporation of America, protests were made to the National Labor Relations Board today against a recommendation that the United Electrical and Radio Workers Union, an outside organization, be certified as the exclusive bargaining agency in the company's Camden plant.

The President's power to devalue the dollar by an additional 15 per cent (below the present level) expires by limitation next Jan. 30. In a press conference he has expressed his conviction that this power should be continued for use in an "emergency." The primary purpose of our currency policy, he holds, has been to "protect domestic values."

An offering of $30,000,000 of Commercial Credit Company 3 1/4% per cent debentures, due on Oct. 1, 1951, will be made today by a group of forty-seven investment houses headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. and the First Boston Corporation. The debentures are priced at 101 and the accrued interest, to yield 3.17 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7. -- Squeezing of Democratic campaign contributions from Works Progress Administration workers in Pennsylvania in three ways was charged tonight by William Hard, commentator for the Republican National Committee, in the third of a series of broadcasts dealing with the WPA situation in this State.

Irregular price changes characterized trading on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday as traders prepared for publication of the October crop estimate of the Crop Reporting Board of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics at 11 A.M. today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- Great Britain has proposed to the United States and Japan a renewal of Article XIX of the Washington Naval Limitation Treaty of 1922, which provides against increasing fortifications and naval bases in the Pacific, but the American Government has not indicated whether it will adopt the suggestion.

Tendencies were moderately weaker yesterday in leading markets for commodity future excepting strength shown in cocoa and coffee, which made gains. In the cash trading cocoa reached a new high mark as hides, oats and silk also advanced.

The stock market yesterday had its first 3,000,000-share day since February. Following a strong opening, prices advanced steadily until early afternoon when fairly steady profit-taking ensued so that the closing was irregular. However, all of THE NEW YORK TIMES averages, rail, industrial and combined, rose to new highs for the year simultaneously for the first time since July 28.

KAY BOYLE speaks again for the negative, and again her writing is more interesting than her characters. A novel of detailed, unhappy lives, "Death of a Man" (Harcourt, Brace, 82.50) is at once an immersion in neuroticism and a new statement on the waste land. One of the two main characters has nothing better to offer his life to than Hitlerism.

I wish to lodge a complaint with THE NEW YORK TIMES against a news story from Augur which purported to deal with "inside information" on the Spanish situation and its relationship to Communist Russia and the Communist International. That THE TIMES should print such a story leads me to fear that it has forsaken its impartial position for one of a definitely anti-Soviet, anti-People's Front point of view.

Gifts to Columbia University, totaling $145,697.94, for the advancement of laboratory research, for the support of tuition and residence halls, scholarships, and for salaries in several departments, were announced yesterday.

A syndicate headed by the Chase National Bank won yesterday the award of $1,300,000 of bonds of the city of Yonkers with a bid of 100.197 for the issue as 2 1/2s, 3s and 3 1/4s, at a net interest cost to the city of 2.692 per cent.

MADRID, Oct. 7 (AP). -- Socialist and Communist defenders dug in tonight for "last-ditch" street fighting if their comrades outside the capital should fail to stem the advancing Rebels. To speed the work of scoring the streets with trenches and throwing up barricades, the government set up a fund of $650,000.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 7. -- Turning to defense tactics, Head Coach Ducky Pond today divided the Yale varsity football squad into two groups.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 7. -- With four hundred dogs on the benches, the Danbury Agricultural Society this morning opened its fifty-third annual show on the historic fair grounds. One of the oldest canine exhibitions in the country, it usually attracts one of the strongest entries of the year.

Governor LEHMAN'S speech of acceptance was naturally based largely upon his official record at Albany. What he has done during the past four years is the best indication of what he will try to do, if elected, during the next two. This is an entirely legitimate form of political argument, and that it will strongly appeal to the people of this State there could be no doubt.

Jerome A. Jacobs, 48 years old, a lawyer for twenty-five years, was sentenced to a Sing Sing term of four to eight years by Judge Morris Koenig in General Sessions yesterday for extorting $2,000 from Harry Bannister, former husband of Miss Ann Harding, the motion-picture actress.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 7. -- Minimum American requirements for men qualifying to "sail before the mast" are "a travesty on safety at sea." Captain J.H. Tomb, U.S.N. (retired), said here today in an address at the National Safety Congress and Exposition.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7. -- Scattered liquidation developed today in the wheat market in sympathy with a sharp recession in prices in Liverpool and on reports of rains in Argentina and Australia, where the new crops will be greatly benefited.

NANKING, China, Thursday, Oct. 8. -- With the approach of the fateful conference this afternoon between General Chiang Kai-shek, Chinese dictator, and Ambassador Shigeru Kawagoe of Japan, it was clear that only a substantial backdown by the Japanese from their firm front could avert collapse of the current Chino-Japanese negotiations.

MOSCOW, Oct. 7. -- Karl Radek, famous Soviet journalist and for long the Kremlin's foremost journalistic spokesman, will soon go on trial, accused of complicity in the alleged plots of the Trotsky faction against the Stalin regime.

DETROIT, Oct. 7 (AP). -- I.B. Babcock, president of the Yellow Truck and Coach Manufacturing Company, announced today receipt of a $6,800,000 order from the Greyhound Lines and affiliated companies for 505 highway coaches. He described the order as the largest ever placed for such equipment.

The Hebrew Sheltering Society of New York has sold two four-story dwellings at 139-41 West 126th Street, used as its offices for the last twenty-five years, to the Jacob Goodman Realty Corporation. The sale was for cash above an $11,500 mortgage.

LISBON, Portugal, Oct. 7 (By Telephone From Toledo, Spain). -- Action started today at four widely separated points on a huge semi-circle around Madrid in the Rebels' "big push" on the capital. The drive is under the personal direction of Generalissimo Francisco Franco.

The Union Oil Company of California reported yesterday for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 a net profit of $4,400,000 after all charges, taxes and reserves for depletion and depreciation, equal to $1 a share on the 4,386,070 capital shares outstanding.

At a stormy meeting last night the Funeral Chauffeurs Union, Local 643 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which has as members 1,400 drivers of funeral coaches in Manhattan and the Bronx, voted to strike this morning for a $5 weekly pay rise.

As the rebellious troops of General FRANCO press on in their drive to capture Madrid, fears for the Prado Museum will be heightened. It contains one of the finest collections of paintings in all of Europe, largely the gifts of royal patrons of art, from Emperor CHARLES V down through a long line of Spanish Kings.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- President Roosevelt decided today to leave Washington tomorrow about noon, instead of on Friday, as he had intended, for a campaign speaking trip which will take him through ten States in the Western and North Central part of the country.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- Charles W. Kress of Binghamton has gone to court to prove that he is not "Charley" Kress as one avenue of escape from nomination as a Communist, with which he has been unwillingly saddled by a single voter.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7. -- The United States has reached its present degree of recovery despite New Deal theories that prosperity depended on rising prices, said Dr. Harold G. Moulton, president of the Brookings Institution, in an address made before the Association of Commerce today.

WASHINGTON. Oct. 7. -- Hans Luther, Ambassador of Germany, gave a dinner tonight at the embassy for Bishop August Marahrens of Hanover, Bishop Hans Meiser of Bavaria and Hanns Lilje, general secretary of the Lutheran World Convention, who arrived last night from New York and will leave tomorrow for San Antonio, Texas.

Mrs. Frederic A. Cammann gave a luncheon yesterday at her home at 1,105 Park Avenue for a group of women active in the sale of boxes and seats for the opening performance of the Ballet Russe the night of Oct. 29 at the Metropolitan Opera House, which has been taken over for the benefit of the Church Mission of Help.
BERLIN, Oct. 7. -- An intensified campaign to prevent rising prices resulting from the recurrent shortage of certain foods has now been initiated by the police authorities in Berlin and other cities.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 7. -- Give a Michigan football man a good center and a kicker and immediately he sees the world through rose-colored glasses.

Retailers were advised yesterday in a statement by Irving C. Fox, counsel for the National Retail Dry Goods Association, "not to become frightened into accepting cancellations by manufacturers of contracts for merchandise in effect prior to June 19 last, the date of the signing of the Robinson-Patman Bill, merely because the manufacturer makes a gratuitous statement that the contract is discriminatory and illegal under the terms of the law."

Mayor La Guardia's indignation over vice conditions in Harlem resulted in a series of police raids Tuesday night and early yesterday morning in which twenty Negro women were arrested on charges of prostitution and four on charges of loitering and three landlords were accused of having rented apartments for purposes of prostitution.

The Welfare Council of New York City has leased 20,000 square feet of space in the W.F. Kenny Building at 44-60 East Twenty-third Street, it was announced yesterday by the Charles F. Noyes Company and Francis L. Corcoran, the brokers. The council is now in 122 East Twenty-second Street.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 7. -- The board of directors of the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad approved today a proposal to amend the company's charter to authorize the issuance of a new limited preference stock from time to time.

ALBANY, Oct. 7. -- Lester W. Herzog, WPA Administrator for up-State New York, today replied to the attack of Justice Bleakley, Republican candidate for Governor, on the administration of work relief in the State.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- Army's plebe eleven hammered out a hard-fought 6-0 victory over the Bucknell University freshmen in Michie Stadium today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7. -- Contending that adequate market facts are essential to successful selling, the National Industrial Advertisers Association today adopted a resolution urging Federal financial support for the completion and publication of an "Industrial Market Data Handbook."

Mary Pickford and Jesse L. Lasky's second and last cooperative film production, "The Gay Desperado,'' a romantic comedy starring Nino Martini and featuring Ida Lupino, Leo Carrillo, Harold Huber and Stanley Fields, will have its local premiere today at the Radio City Music Hall.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 7. -Colonel Francis L. V. Hoppin, who. with Mrs. Hoppin, is still at his Summer home, Auton House. observed his sixty-seventh birthday anniversary today. Colonel and Mrs. Hoppin entertained with a birthday dinner tonight.
The Federal duck stamp is a goose stamp this year, says the United States Bureau of Biological Survey.

BAGHDAD, Iraq. Oct. 7. -- With exasperating sluggishness, a four-motored Imperial Airways biplane brought me here tonight on the 876 mile flight from Alexandria, Egypt. The flight began before dawn and ended after dark.

Although Jesse I. Straus, diplomat, philanthropist and merchant, who died last Sunday, made a will in 1933 leaving large bequests to charitable, philanthropic and educational organizations, he attached a codicil to it in 1934 revoking all these bequests because of the new estate taxes.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 7. -- John Barrymore will resume his screen career as the opera impresario in Metro's film version of "Maytime." For a time it was feared illness would make his withdrawal permanent. The picture which started out under Director Edmund Goulding, but halted by the death of its producer, Irving Thalberg, is about ready for the cameras aoain.

Secretary HULL replied last night to Governor LANDON'S attack on the Administration's reciprocal trade treaties, and replied in words which are certain to carry great conviction. With concrete evidence he showed that specific accusations made by the Republican candidate in his address two weeks ago at Minneapolis were based upon inadequate information.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today summaries of eight registration statements Act of 1933.

ROME, Oct. 7. -- The reopening today of the Italian Stock Exchanges, which had been closed since Sept. 25, was not marked by the violent and unbalanced disturbance that many people had expected as a result of the devaluation of the lira. Industrial stocks, as was to be expected, rose in value, but there was no general rush to sell fixed-interest bearing State securities, which were well supported and maintained their positions.

BERLIN, Oct. 7. -- The League of Nations resolution requesting the Polish Government to investigate the Danzig situation and report on ways to halt "obstruction" of and "disrespect" for the Danzig government, the League, its High Commissioner and the Free City Constitution guaranteed by the League has been answered by Danzig National Socialist authorities with defiance.

Consumption of apparel class wools in the first thirty-four weeks of this year totaled 173,250,000 pounds, compared with 190,000,000 pounds in the corresponding period last year, according to the monthly report issued yesterday by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers.

ON BOARD THE CHINA CLIPPER, Bound for Honolulu, Oct. 7. -- Out over the Pacific tonight, high above a cloud carpet and under a blue-black starlit sky, the China Clipper is flying to Hawaii. On board are thirteen persons, seven of them members of the crew and the others newspaper and news service correspondents and one representative of Pan American Airways.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 (AP). -- T.M. Girdler, chairman of the board and president of Republic Steel Corporation, told the Farm Equipment Institute today that the American farmer received more steel products in 1936 for his farm products than he did in 1929.

MOSCOW, Oct. 7. -- The Soviet government issued a formal warning today that it would regard itself no longer bound by the agreement not to intervene in the Spanish civil war unless certain other powers signatory to this agreement-- meaning Germany, Italy and Portugal--immediately ceased giving military aid to the Spanish Rebels.

Governor Lehman demanded yesterday an amendment to the Federal Constitution, if necessary, to permit enactment of State Minimum Wage Laws for protection of women and children in industry. In another address he struck back at criticism of his fiscal policies voiced by William F. Bleakley, his Republican opponent.
Former Senator James A. Reed of Missouri charged last night that President Roosevelt once threatened to "pack" the Supreme Court by increasing its membership.

GENEVA, Oct. 7. -- The steering committee of the Assembly of the League of Nations decided tonight to establish a commission including all League members to deal with League reform. The Assembly is expected to adopt this proposal tomorrow afternoon when it meets to fill World Court vacancies.

Miss Anna Glen Butler gave a luncheon yesterday at Le Coq Rouge for members of the junior committee for the "Only Yesterday" supper dance which will mark the formal opening Thursday, Oct. 15, of the Mirror Room of Le Coq Rouge for the benefit of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York.

Repeating of testimony before grand juries after it had been heard in magistrates' courts was responsible for overcrowding of the Tombs, Benjamin E. Greenspan, former magistrate, contended yesterday in a letter he sent to E.R. Cass, general secretary of the New York Prison Association.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7. -- Mrs. John J. Mitchell 3d of Merion came through with a surprising victory over Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare in the quarter-final round of the annual Berthellyn Cup golf tournament at Huntingdon Valley today. The defending champion and six times national titleholder was eliminated by a score of 2 and 1.

The Student Board of Columbia College, by a vote of four to three, approved the decision of Dean Herbert E. Hawkes refusing readmission to Robert Burke, who was expelled for his part in the anti-Nazi demonstration held in front of Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler's home last May.
United States Department of Adculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Sales gains ranging from 3 to 80 per cent for August and from 6 to 50 per cent for September, compared with the 1935 months, have been reported by leading dry goods wholesalers throughout the country to the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute, according to a survey released yesterday by the organization.

There is an air of quiet confidence about the confines of Baker Field, where Columbia is working steadily to finish preparations for Saturday's game against Army at the Yankee Stadium. The team yesterday ran through an ordinary light scrimmage drill,

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 7. -- Dr. Francis E. Townsend, founder and leader of the Townsend Recovery Plan, in a telegram to Edward J. Margett, California director, called upon the California organization today to support Governor Landon in the Presidential election.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor, will leave by airplane for the Pacific Coast tomorrow in a renewed effort to break the deadlock in the negotiations over a new agreement for maritime workers.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 7. -- The Greenbrier regional garden clubs gave a luncheon today for national and State club delegates, now in convention here, in the Tangerine Terrace at the Casino. Tables, arranged in horseshoe form, were decorated in garlands of bittersweet and Fall asters.

LAKEHURST, Oct. 7. -- The airship Hindenburg, in command of Captain Ernst A. Lehmann, dropped her mooring lines at the naval air station here at 9:10 o'clock tonight, 55 hours 35 minutes out of Frankfort, for the second fastest westward crossing of the season.

City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr., co-sponsor with Samuel Seabury of the $436,000,000 transit unification plan now before the Transit Commission, is scheduled to testify in support of the proposal when public hearings are resumed this morning.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 7 (AP). -- The South won back the Middle Atlantic States intercollegiate tennis title tonight, Penn State's team falling before North Carolina University's netmen, 6 -- 4, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3, in the doubles final.

BERLIN, Oct. 7. -Purchases of stocks with blocked marks based on the conviction of foreigners that Germany eventually will devaluate its currency continued on a modest scale today, with the result that the i Boerse as a whole showed a slight advance.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 7. -- Unless the Republicans of Missouri can expand the vote fraud disclosures recently made in St. Louis and now going on in Kansas City into a foundation-shaking scandal on the Democratic party, political prophets predict that President Roosevelt will sweep the State on Nov. 3 by a plurality less than that in 1932, but one which nevertheless may run as high as a quarter of a million.

RIVERDALE, N.J., Oct. 7. -- Victor Ghezzi of Deal tied the course record of 68 set by Denny Shute in 1934 to deadlock with Craig Wood of Crestmont at the end of thirty-six holes in the New Jersey P.G.A. championship today.

The Metropolitan Opera Guild yesterday afternoon officially started its membership drive for the coming season. Members of the organization, presided over by Mrs. August Belmont, the chairman, held at its first general meeting at the Hotel Pierre.

Registration in the city for the November election crossed the million mark yesterday, the third day. The total recorded in the city was 1,157,411, brought about by the registration on the third day of 375,773 persons.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 7. -- Some idea of the speed that may be attained in the running of the Vanderbilt Cup automobile race over the Roosevelt Raceway next Monday was disclosed today when Tazio Nuvolari, ace of the Italian Ream, hung up a new high mark for the course in making his qualifying test.

President Roosevelt "dumped" the Democratic party in Minnesota to prepare the way for a "united front" of discarded Democrats and radicals affiliated with the Farmer Labor party, John D.M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, declared in an interview yesterday at the eastern headquarters of his committee in the Liggett Building.

BERLIN, Oct. 7. -- The approaching opening of the academic year has brought a number of more or less veiled protests against the situation created in the universities by the political fanaticism of National Socialist students who refuse to cease agitating and settle down to learning.

Trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday was broad and active. Prices of domestic corporation issues, particularly rails and convertible bonds, advanced, in many cases to new high levels, while United States Government securities were generally lower.

BERLIN, Oct. 7 -- A movement that is wholly inconspicuous at present but involves possible important developments in the European diplomatic alignment has originated among the smaller European States. They are organizing a neutral non-military bloc in which their joint prestige would afford a counterweight to the major powers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- State member banks of the Federal Reserve System, as instrumentalities of the United States, and their employes are exempt from the unemployment and old-age pension taxes imposed by the Social Security Act, the Internal Revenue Bureau ruled today.

John D. Rockefeller Jr. filed a mortgage foreclosure suit in the Supreme Court yesterday against the Paul Laurence Dunbar Apartments, Inc., erected at the northwest corner of Seventh Avenue and 149th Street for occupancy by Negroes.

HAVANA, Oct. 7. -- Investigation of the mistreatment of Representative Jose Grau Augero and other citizens while under arrest and punishment of the guilty police have been entrusted to Secretary of Justice Estanislao Cartana by President Gomez and the Cabinet, it was announced in a palace communique this afternoon.

WHITEMARSH, Pa., Oct. 7. -- John Strawbridge's Rockicy, capably ridden by his son George, gained permanent possession of the Wissahickon Cup by outlasting William C. Outland's Routlad in the feature event at the Fall race meet of the Wissahickon Farms today.

Mrs. Sarah P. Duke, widow of Benjamin N. Duke, power and tobacco capitalist, who died at Blowing Rock, N.C., on Sept. 2, last, bequeathed Duke University, at Durham, N.C., $1,000,000 and $500,000 to the Angier B. Duke Memorial, also at Durham. Eleven other institutions receive sums ranging from $2,000 to $15,000 each.

Reports that local exporters were forming a Landon-for-President League, due to dissatisfaction with the reciprocal trade policies of the present administration, left the foreign trade community here completely mystified yesterday.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 7 (AP). -- The Bomar Stable's busy sprinter, Billy Bee, won his eighth race in twenty-four starts this year in the Grade A Handicap, feature event of the midweek program at Laurel today. Capably handled by Jockey M. Peters, Billy Bee bounded to the wire two and a half lengths ahead of A. Pelleteri's Where Away, the heavily played favorite.
TOKYO, Oct. 7. -- The Foreign Office tonight had not received thet British Government's communication regarding continuation of Article XIX of the Washington naval treaty.

I commend your editorial "Foreign Lending" and your criticism of President Roosevelt's inaccurate description and indiscriminate classification of our foreign loans, as also the misstatement as to their recovery. This is hardly in accord with the much advertised good neighbor policy.

EASTON, Conn., Oct. 7. -- Because Ellery Huntington, a New York attorney, wants to live in Easton but finds that the home he recently bought is just over the line in Redding. Easton officials are preparing to barter with Redding so that Mr. Huntington may have his wish fulfilled.

A new vacuum tube of novel construction, expected to have "far-reaching effects" in the development of television and other services on the ultra-high-frequency waves, was described last night at a meeting of the Institute of Radio Engineers, 33 West Thirty-ninth Street, by A.L. Samuel and N.E. Sowers of the Bell Telephone Laboratories.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 7. -- Lack of training of the young in the schools by governmental agencies and business firms and in the CCC camps was stressed at the opening session of the New England Women's Conference here today.

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- The strongly worded note submitted by the Soviet Charge d'Affaires in London to the international supervisory committee of twenty-four nations on non-intervention in Spain, now meeting here, was regarded here tonight as clearly implying a threat that Russia would send immediate help to the hard-pressed Madrid government unless the Fascist powers lived up to their pledges.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 7. -- Colonel Frank Knox brought the second day of his two-day speaking tour of New Jersey to a climax today with an attack on New Deal policies at a luncheon of 600 adherents at the Hotel Traymore here.

Governor Landon in his recent speech attacking the administration's reciprocal trade treaties, while approving reciprocal agreements, said, "It is a basic principle of reciprocity that such treaties be used to handle only those situations which cannot be met satisfactorily in the general tariff program.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP). -Labor's Non-Partisan League, campaigning for the re-election of President Roosevelt, reported to the clerk of the House today that it had received contributions totaling $28,145 up to Sept. 1 and that its expenditures amounted to $16,644.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- Rudolph C. Culver of 13 Fox Meadow Road, president of the New York real estate firm of Culver, Hollyday Co., killed himself with a revolver between Monday and this morning on a wooded knoll in the town of Mount Pleasant, near Thornwood, the State police ascertained today.
LONDON, Oct. 7. -- Most of the islands of the Pacific will remain unfortified during the lifetime of the new London naval treaty, if the British Government has its way.

Japanese exporters will be severe sufferers from the currency changes which have occurred in Europe in the last ten days, exporters and importers agreed here yesterday. Deprived of the price advantage she has enjoyed for more than five years the Japanese suppliers will begin late this Fall to feel the increasing competition from European manufacturers whom they had succeeded in crowding from the American market.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7. -- A challenge to Secretary Hull to divulge, for the information of the dairying industry especially, the terms of a new trade agreement with Great Britain said to be pending in Washington, was issued today from Republican national headquarters.

Joe Louis ended hard training for tomorrows ten-round bout with Jorge Brescia at the New York Hippodrome with six rounds of boxing against three sparring mates and some bag punching and rope skipping at Pompton Lakes yesterday.

DANSVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- William F. Bleakley, Republican candidate for Governor, lost no time today in attacking Governor Lehman's acceptance speech. He said he found it to be a tacit admission of assumption of dictatorial power, and to this he added the observation that "the pupil in Albany has well learned the lesson from his master in Washington."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, resuming today its investigation of investment trusts and investment companies, inquired into the operations of the Shawmut Bank Investment Trust and the Shawmut Association, both of which are sponsored by the National Shawmut Bank of Boston.

Under cover of strength in oil and public utility stocks, fairly heavy realizing sales were apparently being made yesterday in steels, motors, rails and other issues which had led the recent upturn. This development did not alter the basic optimism of brokers, who felt that a moderate reaction might be expected at any time, in view of the gains of ! the last week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- Total exports of chemicals and related products from the United States in August were valued at $12,661,300, compared with $12,204,000 in August of 1935, and $10,612,000 for the same month in 1934, the Department of Commerce announced today.

ROME, Oct. 7. -- Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano is expected to visit Berlin soon, although Italian officials declare they are unable to confirm the reports, explaining "nothing has yet been fixed officially."

The pound sterling, continuing the downward trend which it began when the gold-bloc nations were devalued at the end of last month, fell yesterday to $4.88 7/8, the lowest price since Oct. 5, 1935. At this level sterling was only a little more than 2 cents above its old dollar parity of $4.8665 and bankers and foreign exchange experts here suggested that it probably was close to a temporary steadying point.

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- Sir John Simon, the Home Secretary, today virtually invited his critics to pass a new law against "provocative" demonstrations if they wished to prevent a repetition of last Sunday's Fascist and anti-Fascist rioting in the East End of London.

Mistaken for a thief as he drove away in an automobile he had repossessed, Amos Shulzbach, 30 years old, a mechanic of 344 Oakland Street, Brooklyn, was wounded last night by a policeman at North Moore and Beach Streets. He was taken to Bellevue Hospital and arrested on a charge of grand larceny. His condition is serious.

BOSTON, Oct. 7. -- It was quite a night at the Colonial Theatre, the opening of Vinton Freedley's new musical comedy, "Red, Hot and Blue!" Every one was there who could get in and those who could not sit stood three deep at the back of the house.
MOSCOW, Oct. 7 (AP). -- The fate of Karl Radek, brilliant former journalistic "mouthpiece" of Joseph Stalin, may hinge on the swaying power of his last newspaper article penned in his own defense.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 7. -- Lemac, driven by A.S. Rodney, trotted two miles in the fastest time of the day on a heavy track at the Danbury fair today to take the 2:13 trot from Isolas McElwyn, winner of the first heat. Rodney's horse was a surprise winner in the field of six starters.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 7. -- Suit for $500,000, plus a percentage of Shirley Temple's earnings, was filed today by Jack Hays, an independent movie producer, who described himself as the discoverer of the 8-year-old screen celebrity.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Oct. 7. -- Mounting the platform where only two weeks ago Governor Landon accused the Democrats of selling the farmer "down the river," Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, tonight replied to the Republican Presidential candidate's attack on the administration's reciprocal trade treaties.

If the Giants succeed in elbowing their way into another world series in 1937 they will not be the same Giants who on Tuesday were almost blown out of the Polo Grounds by the big baseball cyclone from the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP). -- Chairman Nye of the Senate Munitions Committee, who ordered publication yesterday of a deposition saying President Roosevelt's son Elliott contracted in 1934 to sell military planes to Russia for a $500,000 commission, said today the incident was closed.

With backlogs of unfilled orders at the highest level since 1929, and with a renewal of heavy ordering, steel ingot production has risen to 75 1/2 per cent of capacity, a new peak for this year, according to the Iron Age. The situation is in some respects more favorable than in 1929, the magazine points out, since present commitments do not include speculative ordering.

Father Divine's followers, under their "spiritual" names, were found yesterday to be among the signers of nominating petitions for six independent candidates on file with the Board of Elections. The petitions were filed late Tuesday night.
An Olympic boxing champion went down to defeat before an American Golden Gloves winner last night in as stirring a bout as an amateur tournament has produced in years.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Oct. 7. -- Michael Fugmann, a 52-year-old miner of Hanover Township and a former German Army veteran, must die in the electric chair for the Good Friday bomb murder of Thomas Maloney, president of the defunct Anthracite Miners of Pennsylvania, a Criminal Court jury decided late today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7. -- The quarterly statement of the First National Bank of Englewood in Chicago disclosed for the first time that J.M. Nichols, its president, has taken out to the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago all his bank's reserve funds not required by law to be pledged with the reserve funds.

BOSTON, Oct. 7. -- Scoring New Deal legislation providing for a forty-hour week, opposing the 1936 Revenue Act because it "places an arbitrary penalty on corporate reserves," and demanding that the government build a tariff wall against Japanese imports, leaders of the national cotton industry today heard plans for a gigantic corporation embracing and regulating the entire industry without violating the Anti-Trust Act.

Building plans filed yesterday included a $216,000 house for seventy-eight families on a Brooklyn corner and dwelling groups in Richmond Hill and Bayside, Queens, to cost a total of $130,000. Details of the projects were as follows:

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Oct. 7. -- A Spanish woman with a touch of the Scottish brogue, inherited from her Scottish mother, did more today to win the support of British workers for the Madrid government than all the arguments that had been made in the last month against non-intervention.

Cardinal Pacelli, Papal Secretary of State, is due to arrive today from Rome on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia on a visit. This is the first time in history that a Papal Secretary of State has visited the United States. He is accompanied by his secretary, Professor Enrico Galeazzi.

Give a prominent place among the indices of economic recovery to a baseball world series that rolls up the second largest attendance on record. The gate for only six games was but a few thousand dollars short of the highest receipts for a whole series.

Apartment leasing continued brisk yesterday with all classes of accommodation in good demand. All sections were represented in the activity: upper East Side, west of Central park over to Riverside Drive, midtown and the village, the East Side being most favored. Rentals included the following:

TOPEKA, Oct. 7. -- In more direct criticism of his opponent than has been his custom, Governor Landon declared today that President Roosevelt was wrong in asserting in his recent speech at Pittsburgh that the $1,500,000,000 paid to World War veterans as a bonus was no longer a future obligation of the government.

Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, declared last night that the basic principles of the outlawed NRA were just and sound, and she predicted that a way would be found to execute them. She said also that she regarded the present Social Security Act as a "stone on which our children will build."

BERLIN, Oct. 7. -- Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano of Italy will arrive in Berlin toward the end of the month for a conference with Chancellor Adolf Hitler and Baron Constantin von Neurath, German Foreign Minister, on matters connected with the proposed five-power conference which is to draft a western security pact to take the place of the defunct Locarno treaty.
Value of Dollar in Exchange It is not possible to determine the value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, since a fixed parity for the new French franc has not been established.

The merit of an 11 per cent cut in rates for electricity supplied to manufacturers was questioned yesterday by Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission, at a public hearing on the application of the electric companies of the Consolidated Edison Company, Inc., to make such rates effective.
MOSCOW, Oct. 8 (AP). -- The Kremlin, informed sources said tonight, has not yet decided to send munitions into Spain to aid the Spanish Government against the insurgents.

Heavy gold imports, combined with continued Treasury disbursements in excess of income, lifted the excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System $110,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the reports of the system published yesterday.

Grover A. Whalen, President of the New York World's Fair for 1939, in a formal statement yesterday invited "all the people of the world" to attend the fair. He said that the fair would point the way toward "the creation of a better, easier and more abundant life -- the advancement of human welfare."

They have seen "Hamlet" well bestowed at the Empire, where he produced last evening. They have brought to America John Gielgud, whose Hamlet has a prodigious reputation in London, and surrounded him with a cast that includes Judith Anderson, Lillian Gish, Arthur Byron, Malcolm Keen and John Emery.

WITH GENERAL MOSCARDO'S ARMY, OUTSIDE SIGUENZA, Spain, Oct. 6 (by courier to Valladolid). -- Under command of former Colonel Jose Moscardo, who was promoted to general after his rescue from the Alcazar, the Rebel forces are renewing activity on this front. They are pressing toward Guadalajara, thirty-five miles northeast of Madrid.

NANKING, Friday, Oct. 9. -- Whether Chino-Japanese relations are destined to become better or worse continues uncertain, despite yesterday's conversation here of General Chiang and Ambassador Kawagoe, which, according to official announcements, was confined to an exchange of general views.

John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers and chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, joined yesterday in the moves for peace between the American Federation of Labor and the C.I.O. He declared he was ready to enter into negotiations with the executive council of the A.F. of L. provided the council, now in session at Washington, rescinded its order suspending ten of the twelve unions affiliated with the C.I.O.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- A proposal that the American Federation of Labor reaffiliate with the International Federation of Trade Unions will be presented to the next annual meeting of the A.F. of L., according to an announcement today by President William Green.

STE. ANNE DE BEAUPRE, Que., Oct. 8. -- Fire starting in the kitchen of the Frontenac Hotel, a stone's throw from the celebrated basilica destroyed fifteen buildings this morning and damaged several others, with a loss estimated at $150,000 to $300,000.

Fulvio Suvich, dynamic aide to Premier Mussolini and said to be one of the closest of all Italian leaders to Il Duce, arrived yesterday on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia to present his credentials as the new Ambassador to the United States.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 8. -- Mrs. Walter King of New York gave a dinner at Kate's Mountain Lodge tonight for Mrs. Donald Hastings, Miss Katherine Anderson and Miss Edith Harrison. Bennett Ellison honored Dr. W. Murray Ennis with a birthday party there, the guests including James J. McLoughlin.

Directors of Carib Syndicate, Ltd., approved yesterday a contract, subject to a vote of stockholders, for the sale of 20,868 shares of the capital stock of the Colombia Petroleum Company to a private group here for $2,000,000. The shares represent Carib Syndicate's interest, of about 21 per cent, in the famous Barco concession covering approximately 500,000 acres of prospective oil lands in Colombia.
LAKEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 8. -- After a four-month stay at Golf House, his estate here, John D. Rockefeller Sr. left today for his home in Ormond Beach, Fla.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 8. -- The tenth biennial congress of the Cooperative League of the United States opened here today, enthusiastic over the expressed belief of its leaders that the present profit system of business can be displaced promptly and "without shock."

The proposal for an extra dividend on the common stock of Chesapeake Ohio Railroad yesterday was the principal influence in the most spectacular price movements in the listed bond market. Chesapeake Corporation convertible 5 per cent bonds stood out as the most active as well as the strongest issues with the 1944 loan rising 8 1/2 points and that of 1947 closing higher by 9 1/8 points.

GENEVA, Oct. 8. -- Professor Manley O. Hudson of Harvard University was elected to the World Court bench today to fill one of the vacancies caused by the resignation of Frank B. Kellogg, former Secretary of State of the United States, and the death of Dr. Walter Schucking of Germany.

An outside bidder, the Pargray Realty Corporation of 285 Madison Avenue, yesterday bought a half interest in 720 Lexington Avenue, southwest corner of Fifty-eighth Street, for $21,050 above a $60,000 mortgage. Thirty-five bids for the parcel were received by Henry Brady, the auctioneer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- The American Telegraph and Telephone Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment giving the names of forty-seven underwriters who will distribute $150,000,000 of the $175,000,000 issue of 3 1/4 per cent debentures, due on Oct. 1, 1961, for which a registration statement was filed on Sept. 24 under the provisions of the Securities Act of 1933.
I am for the re-election of President Roosevelt for the following reasons, among others:
PARIS, Friday, Oct. 9 (AP). -- The Figaro reported today the Spanish Government was moving the entire gold reserve of the Bank of Spain to France.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 8. -- Government interference in the competent management of American railroads was roundly scored here today by Fitzgerald Hall, president of the Nashville, Chattanooga St. Louis Railroad, at the forty-first meeting of the Atlantic States Shippers Advisory Board.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., Oct. 8. -- The upward surge in general business conditions this year has been accompanied by substantial gains in advertising volume, averaging about 15 per cent over 1935, delegates attending the opening session of the three-day annual convention of the Association of National Advertisers at the Green Brier Hotel, declared today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 8. -- Although Harvard's drill today closed with a short offensive scrimmage for the first and second teams against a combination of the third varsity and scrubs, most of the session was devoted to various forward-pass plays and a defense against that attack that Brown has shown in its early games.

A $50,000 libel suit against Brig. Gen. Walter A. De Lamater, acting Civil Works Administrator in New York City from Jan. 6 to Feb. 22, 1934, was disclosed in the Supreme Court yesterday when United States Attorney Lamar Hardy applied to have the case transferred to the Federal court.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 8. -- Yale closed contact work for the Penn game with a scrimmage drill of less than an hour today. The letdown will be followed tomorrow by a signal rehearsal and conditioning exercises.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

ALBANY, Oct. 8. -- Governor Lehman announced today that he would do no campaigning outside the State, thus seeting at rest reports that he would go out on the stump in other States for the national ticket.
PARIS, Oct. 8 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

Earl Carroll, for many years a leader in the musical show field of Broadway and now employed by the Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation as a producer in Hollywood, filed a plea in bankruptcy yesterday in Federal court.

Last year Dr. BERNHARD RUST, HITLER'S Minister of Education, complained that universities were not spiritually keeping pace with the rest of Germany. The expected academic revolution was lagging. Though he had the faculties primarily in mind, the students too were castigated.

The 1936 duck shooting season gets under way in the northern zone tomorrow. Three Eastern States are included in the zone -- Maine, New Hampshire and Vermont. The others are Michigan, North Dakota, South Dakota, Minnesota, Montana and Wisconsin.
LONDON, Oct. 8 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling.
The total investment in the New York World Fair of 1939 probably will be $125,000,000, it was announced yesterday.

NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 8. -- A field of twenty-seven horses was ready today for the renewal next Wednesday of the Cesarewitch Stakes over a distance of two and one-fourth miles. The Cesarewitch was first run in 1839.
It is not possible to determine the value of the dollar on the local for- eign exchange market, since a fixed parity for the new French franc has not been established.
TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 9. -- The risk of a breakdown has been definitely removed from the foreground of Chino-Japanese negotiations by General Chiang's conversations with Ambassador Kawagoe.

The main purpose of the New York World's Fair of 1939 is to show the "tools of today" with which America is preparing to build a "better world of tomorrow," according to a statement of the "theme" of the fair made public yesterday.

As a result of heavy settlements incident to the first of the month, bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday gained 26.2 per cent over 1935. These settlements were included a week earlier in 1935 and consequently clearings last week declined 13.3 per cent in the same comparison.

A plan of reorganization that would reduce the Chesapeake Ohio Railway's $8,000,000 investment in the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railway is to be submitted soon by the company to Jesse Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, it was disclosed yesterday.

VICTORIA, B.C., Oct. 8. -- Stirred to speech by exhortations recently made to Canadians by persons to whom he referred as "itinerant imperialists." Captain Ian MacKenzie, the Dominion's Minister of Defense, has issued a statement defining the principles on which Canada will frame its defense policy.

IF a suggestion from this corner is well received, Frank Stevens will have his scorecard vendors operating from the back of a truck loaded with thick red volumes at the Roosevelt Raceway on Monday morning and the revised slogan will be "Here yah! Here yah! Ya can't tell the players without a Burke's Peerage!"
CHICAGO, Oct. 8. -- Owner Phil K. Wrigley wasn't fooling when he told Manager Charlie Grimm to trade any or all of his Cubs in seeking "punch and color" for 1937.

RIVERVALE, N.J., Oct. 8. -- A blazing finish which enabled him to complete the seventy-two-hole test seven strokes under par gave Vic Ghezzi of Deal the New Jersey P.G.A. championship at the Rivervale Country Club today with a total of 281.

The board of design responsible for the plan of the New York World's Fair consists of seven prominent architects and engineers who have had charge of the work of design, which has gone on for several months. They are:
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8. -- Following is the text of the speech delivered by Alfred E. Smith tonight at the Metropolitan Opera House:

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 8. -- The trend in national and international affairs was discussed today by a group of prominent speakers at Adelphi College here at the second Review of the News conference under the auspices of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- The General Capital Corporation of Boston, which started ten years ago as a private trust with about $257,000 capital and which in 1929 became the General Capital Corporation with a paid-in capital of approximately $15,000,000, had a brief hearing before the Securities and Exchange Commission today in connection with the SEC's investigation of investment trusts.

BOSTON, Oct. 8. -- After a brief hearing in the United States District Court this morning Federal Judge Sweeney approved amendments to the plan of reorganization of the American Writing Paper Company under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy act.

The board of directors of the New York World's Fair of 1939 met yesterday and formally approved the general plan and theme for the fair as prepared by the board of design. The meeting was held in the executive and administrative offices of the fair in the Empire State Building.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- President Roosevelt is being urged by one set of advisers to proceed immediately with negotiations looking to neutralization of the Philippine Islands, under international guarantee, while another group of counsellors is as resolutely opposing any steps in the matter for some time to come.
ON BOARD THE TRAWLER IMBRIN, Oct. 8. -- Only now, after a brief hour or two of sleep, do I feel able to tell of the hours of agony through which I passed, hours that seemed never-ending.

BERLIN, Oct. 8. -- The National Socialist Student League, a source of constant political agitation in the universities, has answered the recent warnings from both Minister of Education Bernhard Rust and the noted German surgeon, Professor Ferdinand Sauerbruch, with a fiery attack on the older generation and the suggestion that it mind its own business.

Secretary of State Hull's statement at Minneapolis on Wednesday night that the American farmer had benefited from the foreign policy of the Roosevelt administration ignored Federal Government statistics, Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Landon-Knox campaign manager in the East, said yesterday.
ELMIRA, N. Y., Oct. 8. -- William F. Bleakley asserted his determination tonight to make the people of New York State "tax conscious" and pledged an "economy conscious" administration if elected.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8. -- Over a rain-pelted course two Western champions, Mrs. Opal S. Hill of Kansas City and Miss Dorothy Traung of San Francisco, reached the final round in the Berthellyn Cup golf tournament today at Huntingdon Valley.

The following film programs, which will be shown over the weekend, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of young persons in local private and public elementary and high schools:

DANZIG, Oct. 8. -- Ten prominent members of the Socialist party in this Free City, arrested during the last few days, were brought to trial today for the illegal storing of arms. The prosecuting attorney tried to prove that the Socialists had been preparing for an uprising against the Danzig Government and were hiding arms for that purpose.

DETROIT, Oct. 8 (AP). -- I.B. Babcock, president of the Yellow Truck and Coach Manufacturing Company of Pontiac, Mich., announced today that a special meeting of stockholders at Portland, Me., on Nov. 4 would act on proposals to reduce the capital and change the capital stock structure of the company.
Only two new films are scheduled to reach Broadway today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- Senator Clark, Democratic member of the Munitions Committee, criticized Chairman Nye today for making public testimony offered to one of its investigators by Anthony H.G. Fokker, Dutch airplane designer, concerning an alleged sales contract he once held with Elliott Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- The War Department announced today allocation of $23,000 for removal of shoals in the Bronx River to provide a channel 10 feet deep and 100 feet wide from its junction with the East River to the head of navigation at East 172d Street.

Alderman Newbold Morris, Republican nominee for Aldermanic President, has received the endorsement of the Citizens Union. Raymon V. Ingersoll, Borough President of Brooklyn and an independent Democrat, added yesterday his endorsement to that of the Citizens Union for the candidacy of Mr. Morris.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- In a decision vigorously denouncing holding-company control of one corporation by another the Interstate Commerce Commission today refused permission to the Pennsylvania Railroad to purchase an Ohio trucking concern through an operating subsidiary until it had established direct control over the latter instead of through holding-company acquisition.

Notices were mailed yesterday to its customers by the Viscose Company announcing that it will terminate all quantity discounts on shipments after Jan. 1. Other leading rayon producers had dropped the quantity discount as of Oct. 1, because of the provisions of the Robinson-Patman law.

The total outstanding credit of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City declined $87,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the condition statement of the banks published yesterday. The larger part of this shrinkage was due to the retirement of $57,000,000 of loans to banks which consisted of temporary financing connected with the recent large gold shipments.
Speaking of the soldiers' bonus in his address at Pittsburgh, President ROOSEVELT said:

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 8. -- In a setting suggestive of the Williamstown Institute of Politics and other sessions which have attracted scholars here from all parts of the nation, the Mark Hopkins Centenary celebration will open tomorrow evening and continue through Monday.

Advertising activity is on the upswing in the Union of South Africa, according to Miss Lucille Thompson of Johannesburg, who is here to arrange contacts between American and South African advertising agencies and business organizations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- The 1936 cotton crop of the United States was forecast by the Government's Crop Reporting Board today at 11,609,000 bales on the basis of Oct. 1 conditions averaging 61.8 per cent of normal and an indicated yield of 186.9 pounds to the acre.

Columbia had its final heavy workout yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for its major battle with Army tomorrow at the Yankee Stadium. There were spirit and dash to the Lions' drill that indicated the Blue was confident for its renewal of the football rivalry with the Cadets after an eleven-year lapse.

CEBREROS, Spain, Oct. 8. -- Rebel soldiers drove General Julio Mangada's government troops out of Navalperal, their mountain redoubt northwest of Madrid, in a final bloody rush today that crowned two weeks of constant attacks.

HENDAYE, France, Oct. 8. -- Spanish Rebel forces today captured Navalperal, a Loyalist stronghold about fifty miles northwest of Madrid, after heavy fighting. The Rebel leaders at Burgos also report the effective occupation of San Martin del Valdeiglesias, thirty-five miles west of Madrid, by a column commanded by General Emilio Mola.

The plans for the opera season to be given at Covent Garden, London, in celebration of the coronation of King Edward VIII were disclosed by Giovanni Martinelli, the Metropolitan tenor, on his arrival from Europe yesterday on the liner Conte di Savoia.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8. -- Assailing the New Deal and President Roosevelt for breaking the promises on which he was elected to office in 1932, former Governor Alfred E. Smith declared before a large audience here tonight that his party had walked away from him and other old-time Democrats.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- "Phony affidavits," was the statement made today by Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, when he was asked to comment on the affidavits being read every evening by William Hard.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 8. -- Attacking the activities of the Federal Housing Administration as an effort to "regiment and regulate the entire mortgage loan business of the country on a proved unsound basis," L.A. McLean, president of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, addressing the organization in its national convention here today, challenged the constitutionality of the Federal Housing Act.

BERLIN, Oct. 8. -- The German Foreign Office has not yet been informed officially of the Soviet note to the committee on non-intervention in Spain now sitting in London and pending action by the committee on the note an official statement will not be forthcoming.

Current orders for greeting cards are up 12 1/2 to 15 per cent compared with the corresponding period a year ago, with every indication that the industry will close the year with a gain of 20 per cent or more, manufacturers here to attend a meeting of the Greeting Card Association said at the Hotel Commodore yesterday.
Park Commissioner Robert Moses announced yesterday his resignation as a member of the board of directors of the New York World's Fair Corporation.

The State of Mississippi awarded yesterday a new issue of $5,600,000 of highway bonds to a banking group composed of John Nuveen Co., B.J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., and Equitable Securities Corporation and associates. The group bought the bonds as 3s for the 1938 to 1941 maturities, 3 3/4s for the 1942 to 1956 maturities and as 3 1/2s for the 1956 to 1960 maturities.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 8. -- A challenge to Universalists to continue to be champions "for righteousness, justice and peace in human affairs" was voiced by the Rev. Dr. Fred C. Leining of Syracuse, superintendent to the New York State Convention of Universalists, at the annual session here today.

In a campaign to restore salary cuts, maintain State aid for education and protect tenure rights, the Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations will question Democratic and Republican candidates for State office and submit their answers to teachers throughout the city as a guide to voting on election day.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 8 (AP). -- The light blue and brown of C.V. Whitney and the white and green of E.R. Bradley clashed in a thrilling feature today at Laurel, with the former's colors triumphant. Piccolo, son of Whichone, was the winner over Bootless, a son of Black Toney, in a battle that had 8,000 persons standing on the seats.

Joseph E. Davies was named yesterday as chairman of the executive committee of the Democratic National Campaign Committee and accepted his new post with an assertion that the re-election of President Roosevelt was vital to the country.

TOPEKA, Oct. 8. -- The controversy over the alleged withholding of WPA records, which caused Governor Landon to charge that the Roosevelt administration had established a "censorship over the sources of news" to prevent disclosures of waste and extravagance, was continued today by John G. Stutz, executive director of the Kansas Emergency Relief Committee, who started it.

Joe Louis will test the punch-absorbing powers of Jorge Brescia, giant Argentine heavyweight, in a ten-round fight at the New York Hippodrome tonight. The Brown Bomber from Detroit, apparently well started on the road back to the pugilistic glory that he enjoyed before Max Schmeling knocked him out last June, and Brescia will help open the Hippodrome as a professional boxing establishment under the promotion of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 8. -- Representative Allen T. Treadway gave a large luncheon at Heaton Hall, Stockbridge, today. He had 735 guests. Speakers were Representative Bertrand H. Snell of Canton, N.Y.; Miss Marian Martin, Republican National Committee-woman from Maine, Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. and Leverett Saltonstall of Boston.

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe, after hearing arguments yesterday against foreclosure by the government of a $2,537,000 mortgage against the Munson Steamship Line, granted an adjournment until Dec. 15. By that time, attorneys for the line said, they hoped that the line would be on a solid financial basis through adjustments arranged before the recently created United States Maritime Commission.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended October 7, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,480,000,000, an increase of $5,000,000 compared with the preceding week and unchanged from the corresponding week in 1935.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- Lawyers for Winston Guest, international polo player, tried to persuade Justice Jennings Bailey in the District of Columbia Supreme Court today to find that Mr. Guest was a natural born American citizen.
SHANGHAI, Friday, Oct. 9. -- Japan surprisingly revealed herself in a somewhat conciliatory mood yesterday when Ambassador Shigeru Kawagoe called upon Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek at Nanking.

Many dinners were given last night in conjunction with the opening for the season of the Russian Eagle of the Sherry-Netherland for the benefit of the Stepney (Conn.) Fresh Air Camp, which also will be the beneficiary of the preview of "Tovarich" on Tuesday night at the Plymouth Theatre.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 8. -- Champion Nancolleth Marquis, superb white-and-liver pointer dog owned by the Giralda Farms of Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge of Madison, N.J., and handled in the ring by McClure Halley, this afternoon won the title of best in show at the final session of the fifty-third annual dog show of the Danbury Agricultural Society.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- Rapid changes in the international exchange situation, resulting from the tri-partite accord of Washington, London and Paris, have taken place with a minimum of disturbance to world finance and commerce, a high administration official declared today.

Registration in the city for the November election reached 1,607,916 yesterday, when 450,505 persons went to the registration booths and qualified themselves to vote. This is 397,893 higher than the previous record for the first four days, set in 1932, when 1,210,023 persons registered in that period.

PARIS, Oct. 8. -- Hitting at "illegality" on both the Left and the Right, the French Government through the police today forcibly ejected strikers from a chocolate factory they had occupied and raided the offices and home of Colonel Francois de la Rocque, leader of the French Social party, formerly the Croix de Feu.

Exports and imports from and into the United States by classified groups in August have been announced by the Department of Commerce; they are here compared with those of the preceding month and with August, 1935. Exports as given in the tables that follow cover only domestic exports, not foreign goods re-exported.

A hearing to determine the validity of the guarantee by the Bush Terminal Company of a $7,000,000 issue of preferred stock of the Bush Terminal Buildings Company was begun yesterday before Judge Robert A. Inch, in the Federal Court, in Brooklyn. The Bush Terminal Buildings Company is the wholly owned subsidiary of the Bush Terminal Company. Both companies are in reorganization in the Federal Court in Brooklyn.

ROME, Oct. 8. -- The Soviet threatI to intervene actively in Spain has] been heard in Italy with amaze-I merit not unmixed with a certain r apprehension. It is thought that! the threat, if carried out, will bringi about a totally new and extremely i dangerous situation.

The nose finish in the featured Kew Gardens purse at Jamaica yesterday in which Sgt. Byrne was disqualified into the victory after losing a hair-line decision to The Fighter served to throw into higher relief than ever the difference between the old and the new rules in racing.

Large apartments figured prominently in rentals yesterday. A cooperative apartment on the fifteenth floor at 455 East Fifty-seventh Street was leased to Gordon Harrower for Mrs. Charles S. Whitman by Port Burke, Inc., who also report leasing in 1,035 Park Avenue to Mrs. H. Lawrence Dowd for Culver, Hollyday Co., Inc.; and at 17 East Ninety-sixth Street to Whittemore Littell for Douglas L. Elliman Co.

For more than two hours yesterday the Transit Commission sat in silence while City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr., directly and by inescapable inference, charged it with repeated and persistent refusal to cooperate with himself and Samuel Seabury in negotiating and drafting a transit unification plan.

LONDON, Oct. 8. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange today became more quiet, with prices irregular and considerable profit-taking based in part on uncertainty over the Russian protest regarding Spain. British funds were dull, with the prospect of further borrowing by corporations.

PARIS, Oct. 8. -- Out of the 17,000,000,000 francs increase in the value of the gold reserve in the Bank of France resulting from the lowering of the gold content of the franc, 10,000,000,000 have been set aside as provided by the devaluation law for setting up an exchange stabilization fund.
Plans of a $275,000 apartment house for the Bronx and a $300,000 structure for Kew Gardens, Queens, were among the projects filed yesterday, as follows:

DETROIT, Oct. 8 (AP). -- Dayton Dean, two-gun killer whose disclosures of Black Legion terrorism aided the State's fight to stamp out the hooded night-riders, was sent to prison for life today for murder by Judge Joseph A. Moynihan, who said Dean's victim was "a martyr to the cause of civil and religious liberties."
