An increase of 488,000 bales in the government's estimate of the cotton crop failed yesterday to disturb the cotton market, and prices on the Cotton Exchange ended with net changes ranging from a gain of 4 to a loss of 3 points after active, irregular fluctuations over a quarter-cent range.

MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Oct. 8. -- Scoring a one-over-par 38 to the turn, Mrs. Emmet Whalen of Westchester Hills turned in a final 81 to win another of the weekly Westchester-Fair field Association one-day tournaments at the St. Andrews Golf Club today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8 (AP). -- A shipwreck within a stone's throw of a famous San Francisco landmark drew thousands of persons today to the south shore of the Golden Gate where the freighter Ohioan, wedged between two rocks, apparently was fighting a losing battle against the pounding sea.

The theft of jewelry valued at $30,000 from Miss Barbara Field, debutante daughter of Marshall Field, banker and sportsman, was disclosed yesterday when the police arrested a free-lance awning hanger as he was about to dispose of a pearl necklace said to be worth $16,000.

Demolition of two tenement groups to make way for one-story business structures was announced yesterday in connection with reports of Manhattan sales. Various other housing deals in the borough also were reported.
Any hopes politicians may have to bring back such profitable devices as slot machines are doomed, Mayor La Guardia predicted yesterday morning.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Oct. 8. -- If Governor Landon's train is five minutes late leaving Grand Rapids next Thursday morning or if President Roosevelt's train arrives five minutes early their campaign paths will cross in the Union Station here.

BERLIN, Oct. 8. -- The report, said to have originated in Washington, that, despite protestations, Germany is planning to devalue the mark was quickly echoed back here in inquiries to bankers and business men.

Moderate gains were made by several staples on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. Tallow, silk, wool tops and copper eased slightly, with trading fairly heavy. On the cash markets Rio and Santos coffee were lower, with eggs, while cocoa made a new high price and gains appeared in the grains, lard, cotton, rubber and tin.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 8. -- Atkins, brown gelding, owned by Walter Blair of Lake George, N.Y., took three straight beats in the 2:21 pace today at the Danbury Fair, although pressed in each brush by Highlight. These two horses and Phil Hall finished in that order in all three clashes.

BERLIN, Oct. 8. -- Buying with blocked marks continued today to push prices slowly upward on the Boerse, with a limited amount of domestic liquid capital flowing in the same direction. The tendency of investors to shift toward issues of mines and other direct producers of raw materials is viewed here as significant.

Manhattan will touch off the fireworks for the first big metropolitan football week-end of the 1936 campaign tonight when it engages North Carolina State's powerful eleven in an intersectional battle under the Ebbets Field arclights. A crowd of 15,000 is expected at the game, which will start at 8:30 P.M.

The report of the Bank of France as of last Friday, published yesterday, which gave effect to the revaluation of the bank's gold, showed an increase in its holdings from 50,112,000,000 francs on Sept. 25 to 57,358,000,000 francs on Oct. 2. Behind this change monetary experts were able to trace several shifts in the "profits."

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 8. -- Fully 1,500,000 young people who planned to marry have had their hopes blighted by the depression and problems created by their failure are acute, Professor Mark May, of Yale University, told the New England Conference of Women's Clubs today.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings, the reserve note circulation and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date. The ratio of reserve for the New York bank also reached a new high figure for the year.

For the last four weeks Hubert Willard Eldred, a middle-aged employe in the local Procurement Division of the United States Treasury Department, has been working on a plan to organize a National Veterans Reserve Corps.

Frankfort is 150 years old this week and is commemorating the anniversary. So lovely a town deserved a less unlovely founder than General JAMES WILKINSON, yet much may be forgiven him for the sake of this his child. He was an outlander, and nobody now would give him a character; but seldom has there been a wilier old bird; and we are grateful to him because he introduced us to Frankfort.

PARIS, Oct. 8. -- Communist cries of "Prison for la Rocque!" rang through Paris tonight with the opening, after a series of lightning raids on thirty-seven Fascist Social party centers, of an inquiry against Colonel Francois de la Rocque and his chief lieutenants.

HONOLULU, Hawaii, Oct. 8. -- The Pan American Airways' China Clipper, with thirteen persons on board, alighted at 6:43 A.M. on the quiet waters of Pearl Harbor, close to the naval base, after a flight of 17 hours 48 minutes from San Francisco, her first regular passenger trip.
A drive to organize by groups support for President Roosevelt was started last night by the American Labor party. Two meetings were held in Manhattan and one in Brooklyn.

$. H. [res An extra dividend of 25 cents besides an initial quarterly dividend of 25 cents on the new common stock of S. PI. Xress Co. was declared yesterday. On Aug. I a similar extra was paid folloying the two-for-one split-up.

The universities were hailed as the most responsible trustees of democracy in an address last night by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia, at the university's annual dinner of welcome to new members of the faculty at the Columbia University Faculty Club.

LONDON, Oct. 8. -- Behind the smoke screen created by the animated exchanges and diplomatic broadsides in the battle over non-intervention in the civil war in Spain, work is proceeding quietly to prepare the ground for the proposed conference of the five "Locarno" powers.

OMAHA, Oct. 8. -- President Roosevelt's visit to Nebraska, with speeches scheduled here for Saturday and at Lincoln, is depended on by the New Dealers more than anything else to swing an otherwise doubtful State into the Democratic column and to clinch the re-election of Senator Norris.
AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 8. -- Like Lord Geoffrey of song and story, Lloyd Jordan is "a soldier of the king."

CHICAGO, Oct. 8. -- Tentative proof that cosmic rays come from great distances in space and that they "bombed the Northern Hemisphere" has been established as the result of experiments conducted last Summer, said Dr. Arthur H. Compton, University of Chicago physicist, in a statement today.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 8. -- Within a radius of 200 miles of this bustling city lies the heart of the livestock and corn belts. Were politics not inborn among the stock-raisers, and among their sons who migrated to the cities hereabouts and made them great, all thoughts would be on the improvement of business which has restored to Kansas City much of the volume and pace of its industry.
LONDON, Oct. 8. -- During the last week the Russian Navy has enjoyed a blaze of publicity in sharp contrast to the obscurity with which it hitherto had been surrounded.

" Come to the point!" "Take him out!" "Sit down!" "You're a liar!" "Nuts!" Boos, cheers. Any old observer of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations knows from these energetic expressions that the Democrats are holding a State convention. Governor GREEN was nominated for Senator "on a voice vote."
Dealings in the foreign exchange market yesterday were quiet and quotations of the leading currencies were steady without the requirement of extensive intervention of the various stabilization funds.

The opening of the New York World's Fair on April 30, 1939, will commemorate the 150th anniversary of George Washington's inauguration as first President of the United States. In addition, it will exhibit America's progress since that date in science, art, education, production and other fields.

TOPEKA, Oct. 8. -- Governor Landon left tonight on the fourth and next to the last of his campaign trips to speak in the four "battleground" States of Illinois, Indiana, Ohio and Michigan in the hope that he may win their eighty-eight electoral votes so necessary for victory at the Nov. 3 election.

WHITEMARSH, Pa., Oct. 8. -- Mr. and Mrs. M. Robert Guggenheim of Babylon, L.I., scored in the opening session of the Wissahickon Horse Show today when their veteran of the ring, Firenze Red Tape, won top honors in the class for model hunters.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Oct. 8. -- The Centennial Fund program at Mount Holyoke College received additional impetus today through the receipt of a $100,000 gift for scholarship endowment from an anonymous donor. Announcement of the gift will be made by President Woolley tomorrow morning in Mary Lyon Chapel, where less than two weeks ago the student body learned that another benefactor had agreed to make gifts to the college which might eventually total $1,000,000.

A venerable landmark in New York's theatrical history, the Civic Repertory in Fourteenth Street has been bought outright by William and Harry Brandt and will be transformed into a film house, William Brandt said yesterday. The four walls will be left standing, but the present gallery, balcony and stage will be replaced, and modern features, including an air-conditioning plant, will be installed.

BERLIN, Oct. 8. -- Now that Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels has restored the swallowtail coat and white tie as respectable evening wear for National Socialist heroes, the "HJ," the official organ of the Hitler Youth, today restored the evening gown as equally respectable dress for National Socialist girls, but with qualifications.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 8. -- As a result of the rain which held up all qualifying tests today for the 300-mile Vanderbilt Cup even to be run over the Roosevelt Raceway Monday, there will be a rush of qualifiers tomorrow, since only fifteen out of a field of sixty-six entrants have as yet had their trials.

Plans for the first great religious demonstration in pageant form ever to be held at St. Paul's Cathedral in London, with hundreds of delegates representing every church in the world, were advanced yesterday at a meeting of the American section of the World Conference on Faith and Order at the Hotel George Washington.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 8 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin asserted tonight that President Roosevelt was "communistic," but denied ever having called the Chief Executive "a Communist."

OTTAWA, Oct. 8 (Canadian Press). -The weekly statement of the Bank of Canada, issued today, said notes Lu circulation increased $2,773,227; reserve in sterling unds totaled $1,478,537, compared with $137,513 in the preceding week, and reserve in United States funds amounted to $729,700 against $2,943,543.
MADRID, Friday, Oct. 9 (AP). -- Buildings along several streets in Oviedo, in Northwestern Spain, were said to be aflame today as government forces were reported pushing into the Rebel-held city.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 8 (AP). -- Black layers of soil in Nebraska's badlands, Dr. Erwin H. Barbour, Professor of Paleontology at the University of Nebraska, said today, have yielded evidence pointing toward the existence of American civilizations 15,000 to 30,000 years ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8. -- A ball preceded by dinner at the Ritz Carlton Hotel tomorrow night will climax the second day of the Wissahickon Horse Show, which opened this morning at Wissahickon Farms, Whitemarsh. The permanent beneficiary of both the ball and the horse show is The Seeing Eye organization at Morristown, N.J.

LISBON, Portugal, Oct. 8. -- The Spanish insurgents tonight captured Navalcarnero, the last big Loyalist stronghold outside of Madrid on the road from Maqueda. The town, which is seventeen miles southwest of the capital, was taken in a flanking movement.

The WPA Federal Music Project yesterday announced that the outdoor concert season which terminated on Sunday attracted combined audiences totaling 1,612,826 persons, who attended a total of 1,256 musical performances in city parks and playgrounds.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 8. -- Pointing out that more deaths have occurred in the first thirty years of the twentieth century on July 4 than resulted in the whole War of Independence, a proposal was submitted today to the annual convention of the National Safety Council for State-wide and interstate cooperation for a safe and sane Fourth.

The board of governors of the New York Curb Exchange approved yesterday the listing of securities of five corporations. Of the group, two were original listings, two were substitutions for previously listed issues and one was an additional listing of shares already traded on the Exchange.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 8. -- Scrimmaging was eliminated from Princeton's drill today as the Nassau players worked on Rutgers offensive and defensive formations for the final forty-five minutes of the practice. Three Black elevens alternated against the scrubs, who employed the Purple's plays.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- Application by the Tennessee Electric Power Company, a subsidiary of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation of Delaware, for authority issue and sell $4,728,500 additional first and refunding mortgage gold bonds, 5 per cent series, due on June 1, 1956, has been approved by the Federal Power Commission, subject to certain terms and conditions intended, the commission said, to protect consumers and investors.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- Replying to charges made by Francis P. Garvan, president of the Chemical Foundation, Inc., that balance of trade figures published by the Commerce Department were "deceptive" and "garbled," Secretary Roper yesterday defended the department and himself by repeating three charges and making answers.

With the election less than a month away, the Presidential campaign is becoming daily more enlivened. For some time after the meeting of the national conventions there was an impression of political listlessness and indifference. It was said that Americans were taking little interest in the campaign.

ON BOARD ROOSEVELT SPECIAL TRAIN EN ROUTE TO ST. PAUL, Oct. 8. -- President Roosevelt started today on a ten-day campaign covering some 5,000 miles by means of which he hopes to assure Democratic victories in at least thirteen States which he carried in 1932.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt would make no predictions nor hazard any opinions today as to the outcome of the forthcoming Presidential election.

VIENNA, Oct. 8. -- Austrian and foreign newspaper men were invited tonight by Finance Minister Ludwig Draxler to hear emphatic declarations from himself and Dr. Viktor Kienboeck, president of the National Bank, that there would be no devaluation of the Austrian schilling, whatever other countries might do.
It was a great shock to read the news dispatch from Toledo published Oct. 3 in THE TIMES.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8. -- Wheat prices were on the upgrade today on fairly general buying induced by strength in Liverpool, rumors that Argentina had prohibited further sales of old-crop grain, and the revival of an aggressive export demand for Canadian cash wheat.

The committee on bonds of the New York Stock Exchange raised yesterday from nine to fourteen bonds the limit on bond orders which, with certain exceptions, must be executed by members on the Exchange rather than over the counter.

When Father Coughlin states, "We are a Christian organization in that we believe in the principle of love thy neighbor as thyself; with that principle I challenge every Jew in this nation to tell me that he does or does not believe in it" -- it simply proves that he does not know the Bible as befits an ordained minister of the church.

Detective Thomas P. Mason of the narcotic squad, who during his career as a detective has assumed numerous roles in order to track down peddlers of narcotics, was promoted yesterday by Commissioner Valentine to the rank of first grade detective, with an increase of $740 a year in salary.

Above cities and towns of six States the airship Hindenburg will cruise today for ten hours, as a gesture of farewell before she sails at midnight from Lakehurst on her last eastward passage across the North Atlantic for the season. The cruise, which will cover about 618 miles on a roughly elliptical course, ranging from Boston to Philadelphia, will start from the Naval Air Station at 7 A.M. and end there at 5 P.M.

A group of American amateur boxers took very good care of themselves in an international tournament at the New York Hippodrome last night. Opposing a team of European warriors made up of five Italians and one Hungarian, the battlers wearing the Red, White and Blue scored an impressive team triumph, registering four victories.

WHITEFIELD, N.H., Oct. 8. -- Mr. and Mrs. J. Tracy Lay gave a dinner at Sunrise Cottage, Whitefield, for his sister, Miss Harriet Lay, and Mrs. Harry Lay of Philadelphia, who are at the Mountain View.

Thousands of women in this city are wearing stylish millinery which, in the millinery industry, are known as "ash-can" hats, James J. Wilson, Assistant District Attorney in charge of the Commercial Rackets Bureau, was informed yesterday.

Elizabeth Smith of 696 Melrose Avenue, the Bronx, the 18-year-old girl who is on trial in the Bronx County Court for the murder of a boy baby, less than half an hour after it had been born to her, testified for more than three hours yesterday in her own behalf.

Controversial details of the new wage agreement between the International Longshoremen's Association and the ship lines operating from Atlantic ports in the deep-sea trades have been cleared up, but no formal agreement has been signed, it was learned yesterday.

The well-known mathematician, teacher and philosopher, DAVID EUGENE SMITH, has given us a new translation of the stanza of OMAR KHAYYAM, the Persian mathematician and poet, about "grasping the sorry scheme of things entire," in these lines:

Hope for a truce today in the strike of hearse drivers for higher wages seemed bright last night, when leaders of the union agreed to meet representatives of the employers for an all-night conference.

MADRID, Oct. 8 (Passed by the Censor). -- The newspaper Ahora today observes: "Official and private information seem to confirm our impression regarding the general trend of the war. Our [government] troops' entry into Oviedo indicates the fall of that city is imminent.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., Oct. 8 (AP). -- Two seeded women contenders and one of the selected men players fell today in the Greenbrier Golf and Tennis Club's annual Autumn tennis tournament.

The silver cup for the most attractive window display of the more than 400 shops along Madison Avenue that have been observing the avenue's centennial this week was awarded yesterday to the dress shop of Jane Engel, 1,025 Madison Avenue, at Seventy-ninth Street.

The General Motors Corporation reports that sales of cars to consumers in the United States last month totaled 85,201, compared with 66,547 in September, 1935, and 133,804 in August, 1936. Introduction of new models two months earlier than usual in 1935 and this year is responsible for the sharp reduction in September sales, compared with those for August, it was said.

For the sixth consecutive trading session, the stock market advanced yesterday under the leadership of steel issues. Trading was less active than the preceding day and the slowest so far this week. The turnover on the Stock Exchange aggregated 2,230,000 shares compared with 3,027,000 on Wednesday, which was the most active day since February.

Noted authors frequently advise beginners in letters. And they speak in mournful numbers as a rule. Only recently, such a one advised beginning writers to "hold a second job, and maybe you'll get by." He added that no one reads books any more. Almost literally, they don't sell.

Senator Josiah W. Bailey, Democrat, of North Carolina, and Ogden L. Mills, former Republican Secretary of the Treasury, debated last night what the two major parties intended to do for the 63,000,000 holders of life insurance policies in the United States.

Walter Woods of Astoria, 160 1/4, outpointed Casper La Rosa of Canarsie, 157 1/2, in the feature eight-round bout at the Mecca Sports Arena last night. James J. Braddock and Benny Leonard were among the 2,000 spectators at the opening show of the new club.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court affirmed unanimously yesterday the decision of Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag granting a partial recount of the ballots cast in the Democratic primary for President of the Board of Aldermen. The decision held that the charges of fraud and improper counting made by Frank J. Prial, defeated by 24,714 votes by William F. Brunner, organization candidate, justified such action.

FARAMINGDALE, L.I., Oct. 8. -- The opening round of the tenth annual Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship at the picturesque Bethpage State Park course found a good many of the headliners on the sidelines today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- Statements that President Roosevelt was a supporter of communism were termed "ugly, cowardly and flagrant calumnies" by Mgr. John A. Ryan of Catholic University tonight in a radio address over a National Broadcasting Company hook-up.
LONDON, Oct. 8. -- Russia's threat to end her neutrality in the Spanish civil war seemed destined tonight to be lost in a maze of procedure without provoking a dangerous European crisis.

Japan will do everything in its power to make the 1940 Olympics at Tokyo an outstanding success, but it is not likely that Nippon will attempt to outdo Germany, under whose direction the games last Summer assumed the proportions of the greatest athletic extravaganza in history.

Fred' Morris Dearing, United States Ambassador to Peru, sails today on the Grace Liner Santa r Lucia, which leaves for West Coast [ports of South America. The Santa Lucia will also have on board Mr. land Mrs. Charles Collier, Mr. and Mrs. Gustave Helfmann, Juan Fer: nandez Raffo, Prosley Norton, Mrs. Burr Wheeler and Mr, and Mrs. i A. I. Tweedy.
Believing that a team is at its best on its home field, the football Giants returned to the Polo Grounds yesterday and made final plans of attack for the battle with Brooklyn there on Sunday.

MOSCOW, Oct. 8. -- No official information was available today regarding the time, place and manner of the trials of Karl Radek and other prominent Soviet figures accused of a Trotskyist conspiracy against the Stalin regime.

IT was only yesterday that the morning papers carried two important dispatches regarding the Far East. One dealt with the impending Nanking conference between General Chiang Kai-shek and Shigeru Kawagoe, Japanese Ambassador to China; the other with the British proposal to maintain existing limitations upon forts and naval bases in the Pacific.

ST. PAUL, Oct. 9. -- President Roosevelt devoted his first day of active campaigning in the Middle West and Northwest to delivering four speeches and making public appearances at which he could see and be seen by as many persons as possible.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 9. -- Yale and Pennsylvania practiced in the Bowl today for tomorrow's game, the visitors following the home eleven at about 5 P.M. and remaining until dusk. Only signal rehearsal and conditioning were undertaken.

IN 1926 Colonel E.M. House wrote to Count Bernstorff, former German Ambassador to the United States, as follows: "You are the one man in Germany who occupied a great office during the War who had an understanding of the situation not only during the War, but later, during the trying period of reconstruction. If Germany had followed your counsels a different story might have been written today."

Representative Vito Marcantonio, Republican, of the South Harlem Congressional District, was indicted yesterday by the New York County grand jury on a second-degree felonious assault charge in an attack last Wednesday night on Solomon Silver, temporary post office employe and Tammany watcher in the registration.

DETROIT, Oct. 9 (AP). -- Seven members of the Black Legion received life terms in prison for murder today after "Colonel" Harvey Davis charged that Prosecutor Duncan C. McCrea was a member of the secret order and that one of the trial jurors had perjured himself.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin's campaign against President Roosevelt met yesterday a temporary setback in Albany, where all Statewide candidates of the Union party, backed by the priest, filed with the Secretary of State declinations withdrawing their candidacies.

Martin (Buggsy) Goldstein, Brownsville gangster, with a record of thirty-two arrests and two convictions, was in Queens County jail last night with three others, charged with conspiracy to maintain a "kickback" racket on $1,000,000 worth of school painting jobs in Brooklyn and Queens and with coercing union painters to prevent interference with the racket.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 9. -- A par-equaling 72 by Howard Schanzeer of Metropolis today spread-eagled a record field of 105 players in the final eighteen-hole amateur tournament of the season sponsored by the Westchester Golf Association at the historic Apawamis Club.

Dr. John R. Mott, chairman of the International Missionary Council and president of the World's Alliance of Young Men's Christian Associations, will spend some months in an extended tour of India in the interest of those organizations.

Addressing the annual convention of the New York Junior Chamber of Commerce in Syracuse yesterday, Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne declared fish and game constituted the State's greatest single recreational asset and pleaded with the young business men to interest themselves more deeply in the preservation and expansion of our natural resources.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administration chief, declared tonight in a radio address over a Columbia network that, of nearly 100,000 projects, the opponents of the WPA program had attacked fewer than one half of 1 per cent, and that these attacks had been refuted.

Small flurries of snow relieved the warmth of Indian Summer yesterday in the immediate vicinity of Twenty-second Street and the East River, when Mayor La Guardia put on a demonstration of four snow-removal machines which used 300-pound ice cakes for fodder.

ARCOLA, N.J., Oct. 9. -- Mrs. F.A. Neuberg of Hackensack snared low gross over the difficult Arcola Country Club today in a women's New Jersey Golf Association one-day event which attracted seventy-one players, the largest field of the year. She had 41, 43 -- 84 to defeat such stars as Mrs. Maureen Orcutt Crews, runner-up to Miss Pam Barton for the national championship a week ago, and Mrs. William Hockenjos, New Jersey ruler.

American churches, particularly the Protestant, would erect fewer questionable buildings if courses in church architecture were offered in the theological seminaries, prominent members of the clergy emphasized at the North American Conference on Church Architecture and Allied Arts yesterday at the Synod House of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 110th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

Dean GILDERSLEEVE, who led the attack at a hearing before the Board of Education on the new plan for the licensing of teachers in the public schools, has discussed the subject at greater length and with convincing effect in the Autumn number of The American Scholar. She is, in this article, not attacking in particular the New York requirements, but she deplores the general tendency which is evident here. though not at its worst.
BERLIN, Oct. 9 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Oct. 7 shows the following changes from the preceding weeks in thousands of marks:

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 9. -- Flashing 266 miles across mountain and desert, power from Boulder Dam was brought to Los Angeles this evening, flooding the city with light and opening a municipal celebration anticipated since completion of the dam.

In sequence to adoption of the measure for devaluation of something like 30 per cent in the gold value of the franc, Thursday's statement of the Rank of France reports increase of 7,247,000,000 francs in its gold reserve. This does not mean an immediate inflow of gold from foreign markets or from hoarders, whose withdrawals had reduced the bank's gold holdings 21,800, 000,000 francs as compared with a year before.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 9. -- With the growing power of science on the earth, man is endangering his very existence, Professor Marston T. Bogert of Columbia University said this afternoon in an address at the dedication of the new $500,000 chemistry building at Trinity College.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- A new regulation under the Commodity Exchange Act, governing the execution of buying and selling orders in hand at the same time from different principals of the same commission firm or floor broker, was announced today by the recently created Commodity Exchange Administration.

ROME, Saturday, Oct. 10 (AP). -- High Italian sources said today the Italian Ambassador to London had accused Britons as well as Russians of aiding the Spanish Government against the Spanish Rebels, although Great Britain and Russia both are parties to the agreement for non-intervention in Spain.

WITH REBEL CAVALRY IN THE AVILA SECTOR, Oct. 7 (by Courier to Hendaye, France). -- Cavalry forces under Colonel Monasterio cleaned up the foothills of the Guadarrama and Gredos mountain ranges and the lowlands between these mountains.

TOKYO, Oct. 9. -- Japanese officials declared today that the conference between Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and Ambassador Shigeru Kawagoe did not warrant optimism for settlement of the Chino-Japanese crisis.

The main body of domestic corporate bonds continued to move upward yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange in the face of some profit-taking. The momentum of the advance carried several secondary rail liens and also some of the selected industrial issues to new high levels on a somewhat larger turnover.

Corporate borrowing resumed the lead in new bond financing this week and lifted the total of offerings of all classes to $59,710,000. This compares with only $19,561,500 in new bonds, mostly tax-exempt issues, placed on the market last week. A year ago this week new bond flotations amounted to $19,740,000.
Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, who has "walked out" on the leadership of President Roosevelt, has turned his back on another old friend and political associate, Governor Herbert H. Lehman.

WHITEMARSH, Pa., Oct. 9. -- Sand Den, outstanding chestnut gelding owned by Mrs. Ellsworth H. Augustus of Willoughby, Ohio, today annexed blue ribbons in three hunter classes at the Wissahickon horse show. Mayring added another first for the stable by taking the Troop A Challenge Trophy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- Reflecting the effect on the reserve position of member banks of the 50 per cent increase in reserve requirements, which became effective on Aug. 16, the Federal Reserve Board issued today a table showing that while the required reserves of these banks on Aug. 31 were $4,400,000,000, they held $1,852,000,000 above the legal requirement.

Passengers sailing today on the French liner Ile de France include Gaston Morawiecki, French Minister to Cuba, and Mme. Morawiecki, Baron Raymond de Luze, C. Cyril Sharp, Jacques Brugnon, Yvon Petra and Pierre Pelizza, French tennis players; Dr. and Mrs. Rene Beckers, Senator Leon Perrier, Dr. Homer C. Fuller, Paul Fatzer, banker, with Mrs. Fatzer; P. Jean Ricard, Mr. and Mrs. Jean Aubert, Joseph Duffault and Roger Durand.

Mayor La Guardia extended the city's thanks yesterday to a large group of school children who won prizes in the city-wide essay contest on fire prevention and told them he was considering legislation requiring automatic fire alarms in every old-law tenement.

BOSTON, Oct. 9. -- President Roosevelt requested Governor James M. Curley today to withhold the expenditure of a $10,000 State fund which the Governor's Council yesterday authorized for a reception to the President when he visits Massachusetts two weeks hence.

LAKEHURST, Oct. 9. -- Coming in under an overcast sky which grounded plane service, the airship Hindenburg dropped her mooring lines at the naval air station here at 5:17 this afternoon after completing her first special cruise in the United States.

Edward Nock, 65 years old, of 45 Prospect Place, Tudor City, was killed shortly after 10 o'clock last night in a ten-story fall from the bathroom window of his apartment to the street near Forty-third Street. He had jumped or fallen to his death, the police of the East Fifty-first Street station reported.

PARIS, Oct. 9. -- For the first time since the Popular Front government was formed the Communist party has come into open conflict with Premier Leon Blum. Just as the Premier had a showdown with the extreme Right organization of Colonel Francois de la Rocque last Sunday so this week-end he is going to have one with the Communists.

For the first time since 1928 the residential total in the thirty-seven States east of the Rockies exceeded last month the totals for non-residential construction and heavy civil engineering, the F.W. Dodge Corporation reported yesterday. This, it is held, indicated that "the much-needed recovery in residential building, believed by observers as necessary to support the wide gains in business generally, is here."

Six new museum internes, three men and three women, have been chosen for the coming year at the Brooklyn Museum, according to all announcement by Director Philip N. Youtz. The internes will study museology for a year under a grant from the Rockefeller Foundation.

PARIS, Oct. 9. -- Selling continued on the Bourse today and the session was the least favorable generally since devaluation of the franc. Political influences were regarded as mainly responsible for the situa tion, among which Russian the move regarding non-intervention in Spain was the most important.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 9. -- Meeting the University of Virginia here tomorrow, the Navy completes its home series, and will start a line of six away-from-home games next Saturday b meeting Yale in Baltimore. Virginia is strong and its friends see the best chance it has had in recent years of winning from the Navy.

DAYTON, Ohio, Oct. 9. -- James M. Cox, former Governor of Ohio and Democratic Presidential nominee in 1920, entered the present campaign tonight with an attack on the foes of President Roosevelt. He declared that the Roosevelt administration had saved the nation in the dark days when civilization itself was challenged and had "turned economic night into day" for the American people.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 9 (AP). -- Slum clearance projects of governmental agencies were characterized as "a failure" and a "menacing interference" by Charles G. Edwards of the Central Savings Bank of New York in an address to the New England Regional Convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards today.

Accepting a compromise offer of a $3 weekly increase in wages in lieu of $5 asked, the Manhattan and Bronx Local No. 643 of the Funeral Chauffeurs Union, affiliated with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and Chauffeurs, voted last night to end its strike of 800 drivers.
LONDON, Oct. 9. -- The text of a communique issued today by the Committee for Non-Intervention in Spain at the close of its session follows:

MERCERSBURG, Pa., Oct. 9. -- Mercersburg began the celebration of its centennial this afternoon with a historical address by Dr. Boyd Edwards, headmaster, covering the "century of educational enterprise." He pointed out that the three permanent factors in the landscape of the school were mountains, trees and grass.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 9. -- Unless American business develops the statesmanship necessary to temper the forces driving government regulation further and further into the area of private enterprise, the country will be forced relentlessly to a point endangering our economic life, Professor Raymond Moley, editor of Today and former chief of the Roosevelt "brain trust" warned members and guests of the Association of National Advertisers in convention here today at the Greenbrier.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- Collections of Internal Revenue for the fiscal year ended on June 30, 1936, amounted to $3,520,208,381, an increase of $220,772,808 or 6.7 per cent, the Treasury Department announced today.

Scholastic football activity extends its scope considerably today for a number of teams, principally prep school elevens, are slated to start their schedules and to furnish some of the highlights of the current season's busiest Saturday thus far.

To put an end to "chiseling" and "fixing" in the Brooklyn Traffic Court, Chief City Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. announced yesterday that he had named six magistrates because of their "special qualifications" to rotate in that court, beginning next Tuesday.

A report has been published in England from New York attributing to Dr. F.N.D. Buchman the words. "I thank God for Adolf Hitler, who has built a front-line defense against the antichrist of communism. * * * Spain has taught us what godless communism brings.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- A process of concentrating and freezing whole milk, which enables it to be shipped to tropical climates and distributed over long periods without losing the original milk qualities, has been perfected by the Bureau of Dairy Industry of the Agriculture Department.

The City of New York finds itself one of the football capitals of the country today on an afternoon when high explosive shells burst on gridirons throughout the land. New England, the Middle West, the South and the Far West all have engagements of major status.
Sales and leases of housing properties in various sections of Manhattan were reported yesterday.

A prize contest is announced in connection with the forthcoming publication of "The Best Loved Poems of the American People," an anthology compiled and edited by Hazel Felleman, who for more than fifteen years has conducted the Queries and Answer Page of THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 9. -- Earl Howe, British peer who is one of the most daring of the European drivers, finally got up to his qualifying trial today for the 300-mile Vanderbilt Cup race at Roosevelt Raceway on Monday. With his time officially checked the entire English team has now taken the test for the race.

TOPEKA, Oct. 9. -- State pride and party tradition have been seized upon in all earnestness by Republican leaders in Kansas in an effort to "save" the State and its nine electoral votes for Governor Landon in the face of a strong New Deal sentiment.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 9. -- West Point's horse show team scored a clean sweep in the military individual jumping championship, first of the title events at the sixteenth annual Orange horse show and final class of the first day's judging at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club today. The exhibition will conclude tomorrow with eighteen classes scheduled for the all-day program.
Governor Lehman will be the principal speaker at Tammany Hall next Wednesday night as the braves gather for a ratification rally for the entire Democratic ticket.

DES MOINES, Oct. 9. -- Here in the capital of the Corn Belt, where the President and Governor Landon held their drought-relief conference and -- in the words of Senator Capper of Kansas -- "harmony dripped so steadily from every rafter that I fully expected one of the candidates to withdraw," the politicians and the political observers are sensing a pro-Roosevelt swing.

Manhattan College scaled the barrier of major football opposition for the first time last night, but before the Jaspers had their intersectional battle with North Carolina State safely tucked away by a 13-to-6 margin every one of the 20,000 spectators at Ebbets Field was limp, exhausted and on the verge of nervous prostration.

LISBON, Portugal, Oct. 9. -- That the principal European powers which have not given material war aid to the Spanish Rebels, as have Germany and Italy, will recognize the insurgent government immediately if and when General Francisco Franco's forces take Madrid was indicated by diplomatic feelers put out purely in an unofficial manner here during the last two days.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 9. -- Dr. Edward Anderson is leading an experienced Holy Cross team into Dartmouth's Memorial Stadium tomorrow that has been acclaimed the greatest collection of manpower in the East.

PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil, Oct. 9. -- After nine days of torrential rainfall this city and its suburbs were flooded today, with water rushing through the streets in places twenty-five feet in depth. Houses were being swept away and many persons had lost their lives, but the number of casualties had not been estimated.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, today accepted the proposal for a truce in the inter-union warfare that was made by the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers Union to the CIO and to the American Federation of Labor's executive council.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- Substantial improvement in field crops remaining unharvested and a virtual complete recovery of pastures previously burned out by drought was reported today by the government Crop Reporting Board. The corn crop was estimated at 1,599,362,000 bushels, 51,067,000 more than last month's forecast, but with all wheat, with an indicated output of 627,233,000 bushels, represented a 3,000,000 bushel decline since Sept. 1.
HENDAYE, France, Oct. 9. -- All reports from the interior of Spain today show the insurgents are slowly but surely closing in on Madrid.

In the course of his speech at Philadelphia on Thursday evening ex-Governor SMITH announced that he is going to see this campaign through to the end. He is prepared to make several other speeches before it is over. Not content with one decisive utterance of his dissatisfaction and entire disagreement with the Roosevelt Administration, he proposes to go on attacking it week after week, whether men will hear or forbear.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 9. -- The Duquesne University Night Riders crushed Geneva College tonight in a sea of mud, 33 -- 0. Duquesne scored early in the opening period, when Boyd Brumbaugh returned a Geneva punt 55 yards to a touchdown.

Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins granted yesterday the application by fifteen followers of Father Divine to compel election inspectors of East Harlem district to permit them to register under their "spiritual" names.

The profit-and-loss statement of Hearn Department Stores for the eleven months from Sept. 1, 1935, to July 1, 1936, shows a net profit of $554,482 after provision for Federal income taxes and all other charges. No mention, however, was made of Federal surtax on undistributed profits.

Without pretending to any greater knowledge or wisdom than the average man's in the complex affairs of contemporary politics -- indeed, I have made an incredible number of mistakes in political judgment -- I consider the issues of the present campaign so fundamental that I should like to stand up and be counted on both the issues and the candidates.

ST. PAUL, Oct. 9 -- The reciprocal trade treaties made by the United States with Canada and other foreign countries were pictured by President Roosevelt in a speech here tonight as aiding in the rehabilitation of agriculture and helping to assure world peace.

SPOKANE, Wash., Oct. 9. -- Senator William E. Borah, independent Republican dean of the Senate, announced here today he would make no campaign speeches for any Presidential candidate, but would confine himself to discussing national "issues" in Idaho addresses.

Today is the last day for registration in New York City for the November election. Residents who fail to register will lose the opportunity to vote for President, Governor, members of the State Legislature, Representatives in Congress, to settle the fate of the new city charter, and other matters on the voting machines Nov. 3.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 9. -- Accused of violating the Registration Laws, James G. Legnard resigned today as chairman of the Pittsburgh Registration Commission. Though insisting he was "innocent of any wrong-doing," he asked Governor Earle to relieve him of his job and the Governor immediately did so.
ST. PAUL, Oct. 9. -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's speech tonight at the Capitol:

That Japan will make every effort to avoid conflict in order to stage the Olympic Games in 1940 in Tokyo was asserted yesterday by Professor Jigoro Kano, honorary head of the Japanese Amateur Athletic Association and a member of the International Olympic Committee.

The statement of Captain James H. Tomb, superintendent of the New York State Merchant Marine Academy, that safety requirements at sea, such as boat drills, were neglected and that insufficient training was required for able-bodied seamen was assailed yesterday by shipping men.

THE TIMES quotes Postmaster Goldman of New York and Postmaster Sinnott of Brooklyn as stating that as an indication of the "gradual restoration of normal business conditions," the receipts of the New York Postoffice, covering Manhattan and the Bronx, increased 23 1/2 per cent during the past three months, while those of Brooklyn increased 20 per cent.

You may be interested in hearing about a baseball which is in my possession and which formerly belonged to my father, Irving D. Smith. This ball is unusual in that the horsehide cover is in one piece and not in two pieces as now used. It has another unusual feature in that it bears an inked inscription which reads: "Wallkill A. vs. Star, Oct. 6, 1866."
A reduction in the time interval of traffic lights to speed the movement of east and west bound vehicles was announced yesterday by Harold Fowler, First Deputy Police Commissioner.

With a revised line-up containing five new starting players, the New York University football team will make its first appearance before a local gathering today when it encounters the Pennsylvania Military College eleven on Ohio Field at 2:30 P.M.

A letter from Dr. George Ryan published in THE NEW YORK TIMES concerning education in Kansas is very misleading. Mr. Ryan would have us believe that the State takes no responsibility for education, that Kansas children are deprived of an elementary education, and that if elected President. Governor Landon would destroy the American public school system.

Lou Little and Gar Davidson, pessimistic to the core in previous seasons, have made sudden about-faces this year and it will be with high hopes that the pair will send their Columbia and Army football teams on the Yankee Stadium turf this afternoon in a battle that will mark the resumption of the gridiron relations between the two schools after an eleven-year lapse.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals only $17,049,300, with two States and 114 municipalities represented. This compares with the revised total for this week of $20,927,575. The weekly average for new offerings for the year to date is now $28,039,973.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 9. -- Byrnes MacDonald, Deputy Crime Commissioner of New York City, urged 400 delegates to the annual New England Conference of State Federations of Women's Clubs at their closing session here today to substitute crime prevention for crime punishment.
The City Art Museum of St. Louis has bought from M. Knoedler Co., Inc., a painting of St. Paul by the Spanish artist El Greco.

Moving at the same pace that characterized trading on the previous day, the stock market yesterday had a final burst of strength in the leading steel, motor and rail shares, then eased slightly in the last half-hour and closed irregularly higher on the day. The volume on the Stock Exchange was 2,235,000 shares, compared with 2,226,000 the day before, with trading extending over a broad list.
Joe Louis weighed 202 pounds and Jorge Brescia 205 1/2 for the fight at the Hippodrome last night. The referee was Arthur Donovan and the judges were Joe Agnello and Jack Britton.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Oct. 9. -- A belief that the safety movement in the United States will not show really satisfactory progress until the nation's youth becomes "safety conscious" through special instruction in the secondary schools was expressed here today by speakers at the closing session of the twenty-fifth annual national safety congress, sponsored by the National Safety Council.

The United Corporation reported for the third quarter of 1936 yesterday a net income of $2,091,809, which was equal, after preferred dividends, to 1 1/2 cents a share on 14,529,324 common shares, compared with $2,125,020, or 1.8 cents a share, in the same period last year.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday moved over a range of 6 to 13 points in quiet trading to close 5 points lower to 8 points higher compared with Thursday. The outside interest was restricted and the market consequently reflected the influence of trade and foreign buying in the morning and increased hedge selling in the afternoon.

Our learned Mr. JOHN KIERAN yesterday was much intrigued by the presence of a British peer among the competing drivers in the Vanderbilt Cup race on Long Island next Monday. The gentleman in question is the fifth Earl HOWE and he was born in 1884.

ATLANTAC CITY, Oct. 9. -- The proposed merger of the three Methodist denominations in the United States into one Methodist Church with 8,000,000 members received another setback here today when the Eastern Conference of the Methodist Protestant Church voted 69 to 32 against the move.

The Maemere Farm's Maedic, winner of five in a row at Saratoga, will make his first New York appearance since the upstate racing when he goes to the post today in the Remsen Handicap, one of two features scheduled by the Metropolitan Jockey Club at Jamaica. The other is the Belgrade Claiming Stakes for older horses, but principal interest centers in the 2-year-olds.

ALBRIGHT vs. C.C.N.Y. -- Who would have thought that Don Vernon Gomez would win two games in the world series and Cholly the Red Ruffing none at all? One light vote for Albright and three cheers for the Lavender.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 9. -- The oldest football rivalry in the country will be renewed at 2:30 P.M. tomorrow in Palmer Stadium when the Princeton and Rutgers elevens meet in the thirty-fourth contest of a series which dates back to 1869.

Registration in the city for the November election crossed the 2,000,000 mark yesterday when 461,253 persons went to the registration booths to qualify themselves to vote. The total for the five days of registration thus far is 2,069,169.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 9. -- Hopeful signs in world affairs were outlined today by experts on world affairs at the third Review of the News Conference held under the auspices of THE NEW YORK TIMES. About 1,200 women attended the all-day meeting in the clubhouse of the New Rochelle Woman's Club.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9. -- While the hog market was generally quoted as steady compared with yesterday's sales, it was more or less irregular. Some early sales of pigs, under-weights and sows were regarded as at advances of 10 cents. The finish was weak and late business showed prices off as much as 5 cents.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- Secretary Ickes today rejected bids on the Public Works Administration's slum-clearance project in Schenectady on the ground that they were excessive and adverse to public policy and sent out an invitation for new bids.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railway, through the Virginia Transportation Corporation, a subsidiary, increased its holdings of New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad 6 per cent notes by $252,500 par value between Jan. 1, 1935, and Sept. 30 last, report to the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed yesterday.

A nine-story and basement addition will be made to the present building of Ruseks Fifth Avenue, at the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Thirty-sixth Street, on the plot now occupied by the Wise Shoe Company building, at a cost of approximately $150,000, Max Weinstein, president of Russeks, announced yesterday.

VIENNA, Oct. 9. -- Austria received an unexpected and apparently unappreciated honor this morning in the shape of a visit of Air Minister Hermann Goering of Germany, who arrived early this morning and left late this afternoon.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 9. -- The thirty-eighth meeting on the football field between representatives of Harvard and Brown will take place in the Harvard Stadium tomorrow, with the Crimson favored to annex its thirty-first triumph in the series.

GALESBURG, Ill., Oct. 9 (AP). -- Senator Gerald P. Nye, chairman of the Senate Munitions Committee, tonight made public a telegram replying to Senator Bennett C. Clark, who said yesterday he was "amazed" that Senator Nye had disclosed certain documents concerning an unfilled contract involving Elliott Roosevelt, son of the President.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- Twenty-six years will have passed tomorrow since Charles Evans Hughes became a member of the Supreme Court over which he now presides as the nation's eleventh Chief Justice.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

" Swing Your Lady!" that Kenyon Nicholson and Charles Knox Robinson saga about the lady wrestler, won't open tomorrow night after all. Set it down for a week from Sunday, or Oct. 18, at the Booth Theatre. The proprietors had hoped it would be ready in time for the original date, but decided late yesterday afternoon that a week's further practice would do no harm.

A definite proposal for peace between the craft and industrial union factions in the American Federation of Labor was forwarded yesterday to the executive council of the A.F. of L. and to the Committee for Industrial Organization by the convention of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers Union, meeting here at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., Oct. 9. -- It is not often that a golfer meets his boss in a match, especially in a professional tournament, yet when the curtain is raised on the quarter-finals of the Metropolitan P.G.A. championship tomorrow, two of the rivals will be Paul Runyan, the pro, and Fred Anunziato, his assistant, at the Metropolis Country Club.

ALBANY, Oct. 9 (AP). -- In a four-hour session at the Executive Mansion today, more than 150 Democratic legislators and new candidates for State Senate and Assembly mapped plans for the campaign in which they hope to recapture control of the Legislature.

Efforts to eliminate the evil of excessive smoke, fumes and gases resulting from bus operation in the city streets, according to reports submitted to General Sessions Judge Cornelius F. Collins and the members of the additional grand jury yesterday by the Transit Commission, cannot be entirely successful until all other motor vehicles using the streets are subjected to regulation on the same score.
Mayor La Guardia directed thirteen city officials yesterday on a whirlwind inspection tour of motion-picture theatres catering to children in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 9. -- The Mortgage Bankers Association of America ended its convention here today after adopting resolutions condemning the new undistributed corporation profit tax and the competition of the government with private lending agencies through the mediums of the FHA, the HOLC and other bureaus.

Commodity futures prices fluctuated narrowly here yesterday and closed with slight changes either way in quiet trading on the eve of a three-day holiday in most of the local markets. In the cash markets, cotton declined, while the grains, lard, eggs, silk, rubber and tin advanced.
New York became acutely aware yesterday that Southern Methodist's Mustangs were in town to battle with the Fordham Rams on the gridiron of the Polo Grounds this afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9. -- The Philadelphia Orchestra opened its season of 1936-37 this afternoon in the Academy of Music with a sold-out house and between 300 and 400 turned away. Eugene Ormandy conducted the organization as a permanent instead of visiting conductor.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9. -- Attacking Franklin D. Roosevelt as having failed to keep his promises, both as candidate and as President, Governor Landon tonight gave an unequivocal pledge to the American people to balance the Federal budget if elected President.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9. -- Miss Dorothy Traung, 22-year-old San Francisco golfer, who holds the Western amateur title, carried off the Berthellyn Cup by defeating Mrs. Opal S. Hill of Kansas City in the final round at the Huntingdon Valley course today. The Coast star was 1 up after nineteen holes.

Charges of disorderly conduct placed against twenty women arrested in a poker raid were dismissed yesterday when the women were arraigned before Magistrate H. Stanley Renaud in West Side Court. Sam Katz, 31 years old, alleged proprietor of a gambling establishment at 175 West Seventy-ninth Street, where the women were arrested last Wednesday, was held in $500 bail for the grand jury on the charge of maintaining a gambling resort.

With holdings amounting to $3,070,000, the National City Bank leads the list of beneficial holders of Florida East Coast Railway first and refunding 5 per cent bonds of 1974 contained in a statement filed by a committee for the bonds with the Securities and Exchange Commission and made public yesterday. The report shows the amounts of bonds deposited by holders with the committee.

OLEAN, N.Y., Oct. 9 (AP). -- St. Bonaventure scored its first victory of the season tonight, overwhelming Davis and Elkins College, 51 to 6. St. Bonaventure scored three touchdowns on passes by Labas to O'Donnell and Odorisio in the first period and registered five more before the end of the game.

PARIS, Oct. 9. -- If the Spanish insurgents enter Madrid and seek to set up a government over the country, they may find that all the gold reserve of the Bank of Spain has disappeared and that there is no cover left for even the existing currency.
PARIS, Oct. 9. -- Police re-enforcements were rushed into Alsace-Lorraine tonight after the shooting of an Italian Fascist at Metz sharpened tension between Communists and Rightists.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 9. -- Hundreds of San Franciscans, perched on a cliff overlooking the Golden Gate, today watched a thrilling rescue at sea, performed less than 300 feet from where they sat.

The Lehman Corporation reported yesterday a gross asset value of $93,545,428 as of Sept. 30, equivalent, after prior liabilities, a net value of $132.22 to a share on 683,632 shares of capital stock then outstanding, comparing with $119.25 a share on June 30. The latest figure is after deducting dividends payable yesterday.

Republican candidates on the national and State tickets moved into New York yesterday for a double attack upon the "big New Deal" in Washington and the "smaller New Deal" in Albany in a rally at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 9. -- Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase of New York University, Dr. Rufus D. Smith, provost of the university, and other speakeres joined here today in praising the accomplishments of the year-old Nassau-Hofstra College and declared it had found a "permanent place of usefulness" on Long Island.

SHARJAH, Arabia. Oct. 9. -- Having just about reached the half-way mark on my dash around the world, I take off from here early today for Jodhpur and Calcutta on the next leg of my journey with every expectation of returning to New York in the planned time of twenty and one-half days.
PELAYOS, Spain, Oct. 9 (AP). -- From this bleak village, forty miles west of Madrid, government forces tonight launched an encircling offensive to recapture important posiContinued on Page Three

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 9. -- Dr. Henry Merritt Wriston, president of Lawrence College at Appleton, Wis., was elected president of Brown University today to succeed Dr. Clarence A. Barbour. He will be Brown's eleventh president since New England's third oldest university was founded 172 years ago.
With twenty-one entries, the New Rochelle Yacht Club's special cruising race, the last of the season, was started last night at 10:30 o'clock off Hicks Ledge Buoy, Echo Bay, New Rochelle.

Note two new pictures for today's calendar: "Student-Romance," an English version of the operetta, "I Lost My Heart in Heidelberg," at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse; its principal players are Grete Netzler, Viennese star, who was recently signed by Metro, and Patric Knowles.

At another hearing before Peter B. Olney, Federal referee, intended to show whether the present management should continue to operate the Schulte Retail Stores Corporation in reorganization proceedings, Arthur S. Meyer, its vice president, described the purchase of two large distilling companies, which later were sold at a big profit.
CHICAGO, Oct. 9. -- Following is the text of Governor Landon's address here tonight:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 9. -- Having abandoned "Roaming Around" as its first vehicle for Joe Penner and Parkyakarkas, RKO has placed the comedians in "Convention in Cuba," which will afford John Beal an opportunity to become a singing romantic figure.

Monday being Columbus Day, many pastors will preach patriotic sermons tomorrow, drawing lessons on the duty of peace, with special reference to Spain. Also, there will be a nation-wide observance tomorrow of the centennial of the crossing of the Rockies by the first Protestant missionaries and their arrival in Oregon.

MADRID, Oct. 9 (AP). -- Spanish Government leaders tonight pinned desperate hopes on possibility of Soviet aid to save Madrid from the insurgent drive. They acknowledged the fall of strategic towns in the Sierra de Gredos and Guadarrama mountain passes, key gateways to Madrid from the northwest, and admitted aid must come quickly if it was not to be too late.

Scene of theatrical pageantry that made history, the famous old Hippodrome last night was dedicated to professional boxing under the auspices of the Twentieth Century S.C. with a scheduled ten-round battle in which Joe Louis, Detroit Bomber, mowed down the giant, gorge Brescia of the Argentine, in the third round.

Partial recount of the ballots cast in the recent Democratic primary contest between Sheriff William F. Brunner and Frank J. Prial for the party nomination for President of the Board of Aldermen, a contest that Sheriff Brunner apparently won by more than 25,000 votes, was begun yesterday by the Board of Elections.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 9. -- A swampy gridiron and a drizzle of rain were the setting predicted tonight for tomorrow's battle between the prowling Panthers of Pitt and the battling Buckeyes of Ohio State, the No. 1 game on the national football front this week-end.

J. Frank Brooks, 39 years old, of Maplewood, N.J., and his brother, Edward, 29, formerly of 55 Park Avenue, who operated J. Frank Brooks Co., investment brokers, 32 Broadway, were sentenced to Sing Sing yesterday by Judge George L. Donnellan in General Sessions.

BURGOS, Spain, Oct. 9. -- The Rebel attack centered today on Aranjuez, about twenty-five miles south by east of Madrid, where the insurgents fought to cut rail communications between the capital and Alicante. They believed government leaders would attempt to flee to Alicante should Madrid be shelled.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 9. -- Moon Side, Edward Kane's 4-year-old gelding, registered his fourth straight victory today when he defeated three rivals in the Tuscarora Purse, the feature at Laurel.
NANKING, China, Oct. 9. -- China's military dictator, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, proclaimed tonight China's ability to map her own destiny without foreign interference.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9. -- The October ball for debutantes was given tonight at the Hotel Warwick. The 500 guests were received by twelve patronesses, Mrs. C. Louis Borie 3d, Mrs. John Bromley, Mrs. Logan M. Bullitt, Mrs. George S.G. Cavendish, Mrs. John P. Chapman, Mrs. Caleb Cresson, Mrs. George H. Houston, Mrs. Joseph Wharton Lippincott, Mrs. Henry Pepper Norris, Mrs. William Winsot Philler, Mrs. William Baker Whelen, and Mrs. Charles Stewart Wurts.

LONDON, Oct. 9. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange continued firm today, although some profit-taking continued and business became quieter. British funds weakened slightly, while foreign bonds were dull. Home rails were quiet. The international list went higher, reflecting the brighter reports from Wall Street.

Simpson, Thacher Bartlett, counsel for the Electric Bond and Share Company and other defendants in the suit of the Securities and Exchange Commission to compel registration under the Public Utility Act of 1935, filed yesterday a brief for the defendants in the Federal court here, replying to the three briefs of the SEC on facts, on the scope of the issues and on the constitutional issues.
LONDON, Oct. 9. -- The American bid to control the powerful Gaumont British Picture Corporation has finally fallen through and the company will remain in British hands.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9. -- A slightly bearish construction was placed by the grain trade on the government estimate of 1,509,362,000 bushels for this year's corn crop. It was 37,000,000 bushels above the average of the recent private returns. Total available supplies of corn for the 1936-37 season, including the crop, farm reserves and the visible supply, amounts to 1,687,000,000 bushels.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 9. -- A defense of the Puritans' seriousness of mind, as exemplified a hundred years ago in New England colleges such as Williams, in contrast with the later day liberal attitude of open-mindedness, was presented here tonight by Professor William E. Hocking, Harvard philosopher, at the general convocation which opened the four-day celebration of the centenary of Mark Hopkins.

Two hours before they were to have been married in San Francisco two years ago, Robert Max Herbst, chemist, of Mount Vernon, N.Y., who was her fiance, announced that he had changed his mind, Martha E. Catching, former art student, testified yesterday in her suit for $52,429 against Herbst for alleged breach of promise.

In THE TIMES "News of the Week in Review" last Sunday there was an item entitled "La Guardia Budgets." You state that "most of it (1937 budget) will be met by the tax on real estate." Also: "Manhattan, which once sold for $24 is worth today $8,014,570,260, according to the assessors."

It is painful to notice here and there evidences of discouragement and little faith among Republicans. From the very bosom of the Landonite crusade Mr. WILLIAM ALLEN WHITE has changed from a cheerful warbler to a bird of night. The Kansas Republicans must get busy, he tells them, or they are dished.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9. -- More vigorous and outspoken than he has been heretofore, Governor Landon today promised to give President Roosevelt a continuous fight from now until election. He asserted in speeches at Freeport and Rockford, Ill., while enroute in Chicago, that the Roosevelt political machine was using billions of the taxpayers' money for a campaign fund.

For the fifth consecutive week President Roosevelt continued to make gains in the Literary Digest Presidential straw vote. In the sixth installment which appears in today's issue of the Digest, the lead of Governor Landon, Republican Presidential nominee, has been decreased to somewhat less than 3 to 2.

LONDON, Oct. 9. -- The meeting of the international non-intervention committee today turned out to be a seven-hour diplomatic brawl during which furious charges and counter-charges flew back and forth across the conference table.
It is not possible to determine the value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, since a fixed parity for the new French franc has not been established.

In a program nicely calculated to display a pianist's sense of musical values and gratefully free from display pieces, Laura Dubman, a gifted child of eleven, made her debut before a large audience in Town Hall last night. From the start she aroused and held the interest of a gathering including many prominent musicians by playing of more than ordinary promise.

GENEVA, Oct. 9. -- The Assembly's commission on League of Nations reform today decided to establish a commission of twenty-eight members to study "the application of the principles of the covenant and problems connected therewith."

Mrs. Angelina Bonfrisco, 44 years old, who has an office and home at 1,946 First Avenue, surrendered yesterday in District Attorney Dodge's office on three indictments charging she extorted money from three women residents of East Harlem in an alleged "loan shark" business.

The total number of persons on relief rolls, apart from those on emergency conservation work, increased from 4,475,000 in July, 1935, to 4,482,000 in June, 1936, according to figures made public yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.
The local Works Progress Administration dropped 1,562 relief workers from its rolls in September because of "continued absence." Those dropped included many skilled workers.
LAKEHURST, N.J. (Saturday), Oct. 10. -- In a drizzle of rain the Hindenburg sailed for her final for crossing of the season to Germany at 12:31 this morning.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- Demanding that "Alfred E. Smith should practice what he preaches and separate facts from political bunk," Howard R. Tolley, head of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, charged tonight that the former New York Governor either had no understanding of the farm problem or was attempting to mislead metropolitan voters on the facts of the administration's agricultural policy.

The Republican National Committee is desperately in need of money, as the campaign is entering upon its final and most costly stage. While party leaders responsible for the conduct of the Landon-Knox fight are loath to admit it, it was learned last night on good authority that this body is "in the hole" to the extent of at least $500,000 and probably somewhat more.

Two interesting facts may be remembered with reference to the Negro members of the 1936 American Olympic team. One is that all of these athletes were students in leading American colleges and universities. The second fact is that not one of them came from what might be called a strictly Negro school.

Fred Perry of England and Miss Helen Jacobs of Berkeley, Calif., rule the tennis roosts of the world, in the opinion of A. Wallis Myers, British authority, who lists seven Americans in his "first ten" rankings for 1936.
MIDWAY ISLAND, Oct. 9. -- The China Clipper landed on the lagoon here at 3:09 this afternoon [10:09 P.M. New York time], completing the 1,380-mile flight from Honolulu in 9 hours and 52 minutes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- The Hearn Department Stores, Inc., has filed an amendment to its registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 45,000 shares of 6 per cent $50-par cumulative convertible preferred stock and 400,000 shares of $5-par common.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 9. -- The Chief problems of delegates attending the annual convention of the Association of National Advertisers at the Greenbrier here are rising advertising rates for both mazagines and newspapers and the threat of a wide open circulation race among mazagine publishers.

BERLIN, Oct. 9. -- Blocked marks disappeared from the Boerse today and stocks dropped sharply, although they picked up slightly near the market's close. Heavy industrial shares again dominated the trading.

Retail trade in the metropolitan area this week was described as good. Weather conditions were somewhat of a handicap, but department store volume was estimated as showing a slight gain over the comparative 1935 figures. Inclusive of the heavy volume last Saturday, the results for the month to date were said to indicate an increase of 3 to 5 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- New York State today protested to the Supreme Court against the Federal Government's attempt to lay an income tax upon the salary of the chief engineer of the Bureau of Water Supply of New York City.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 9. -- Edward A. Filene, Boston merchant, announced here tonight his final separation from the existing profit system, which has made him wealthy.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 9. -- In a speech here tonight at the Good Neighbor Conference, Secretary Ickes declared that there was "friendly cooperation" between Father Coughlin and the Republicans, and added that Representative Lemke was merely a "Coughlin-Landon stooge."

Common stock of the Norfolk Western Railway jumped 3 points yesterday to 302, the highest price on record, which compared with previous highs of 300 for this year and 290 for 1929. The possibility of the management's declaring an extra dividend in response to the tax on surplus motivated the rise, which, however, could be accepted as an index of the extent to which the railroads have brought their recovery.

PARIS, Oct. 9. -- Despite a Russian threat to abandon the Spanish Neutrality Commission in London, France will not waver in her policy of non-intervention in Spain. Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, was so informed today by Premier Leon Blum in a long conversation.
MIDWAY ISLAND, Oct. 9. -- The China Clipper landed on the lagoon here at 3:09 this afternoon [10:09 P.M. New York time], completing the 1,380-mile flight from Honolulu in 9 hours and 52 minutes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- The Hearn Department Stores, Inc., has filed an amendment to its registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 45,000 shares of 6 per cent $50-par cumulative convertible preferred stock and 400,000 shares of $5-par common.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 9. -- The Chief problems of delegates attending the annual convention of the Association of National Advertisers at the Greenbrier here are rising advertising rates for both mazagines and newspapers and the threat of a wide open circulation race among mazagine publishers.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 10. -- A large assemblage attended the dinner dance in the Colonnades at the Greenbrier tonight. Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Back were dinner hosts for Mr. and Mrs. John Y. Yost, Mr. and Mrs. D. Claude Handy, Mr. and Mrs. Theodore L. Haff and Mr. and Mrs. Glenn Charlton.
STORRS, Conn., Oct. 10. -- The Connecticut State football team turned back Massachusetts State today, 13 -- 0.
WESTBROOK PEGLER has been the Mickey Mouse of the syndicated columnists for about two years. But despite all the nice things he has heard about himself, the praise has not gone to his legs.

When Laura found herself completely fed up with Greenwich Village, work, parties, big cities in general -- and to top it all, out of a job -- she resolved to walk to the mountains. She felt that real mountains, as a change from the Palisades and Bear Mountain, would bring her contentment.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 10. -Carrying his election drive into Ohio, Governor Landon declared today that the present political campaign cut across party lines and that Abraham Lincoln Republicans and Thomas Jefferson Democrats were united to oppose the New Deal in a fight for the welfare of the American people.

Miss Josephine Schain, who returned last week from the Universal Peace Conference at Brussels, was accorded one of the highest honors paid a woman delegate when she was made head of the Commission on Women's Organizations, comprising 600 feminine delegates.

OMAHA, Oct. 10. -- President Roosevelt in a speech here tonight declared that his farm program was designed to bring permanent prosperty to the farmer and denounced the Republican plan as one which could only lead the farmer back to the conditions of 1932.

The first complaints filed under the Robinson-Patman act by the Federal Trade Commission highlight the quantity discount as the "most troublesome" phase of the new law, according to views expressed by authorities here yesterday.

The New York World's Fair of 1939, celebrating the 150th anniversary of George Washington's inauguration in New York City as President of the United States, will be a $125,000,000 exposition, one of the greatest spectacles of its kind ever projected.

WARRENTON, Va. -- The season of the Warrenton Hunt, Amory S. Carhart, M.F.H., will begin on Nov. 7. As was the case last year, the hunt will have the run of the Casanova territory, and members of the Casanova Hunt, which is temporarily suspended, will ride with Warrenton.

Your editorial in which you align yourself with Franklin Delano Roosevelt piques my curiosity. It is, of course, understandable why an old Democratic paper, even though independent, should favor lower tariffs -- I have an inkling that such is the real reason for the editorial. But what about the pole-star of the Democratic party since its foundation: a minimum of bureaucracy and of concentration of power in the Federal administration?

THE Model T driver flew blind -- but he was a man enthroned. As he roosted brooding on the gasoline, knowing that he could take off faster than anything on the road, what was it to him that he "didn't know the speed of his engine, the amount of his fuel, or the pressure of his oil?"
Miss Virginia C. Gildersleeve, dean of Barnard College, believes that any student wishing to prepare herself for an active interest in politics should study the science of government in college.

By way of driving straight toward its objectives with as few as possible waste motions, the League of Women Voters of New York State plans to "streamline" its program during its annual convention at Syracuse on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday of this week.

WHEN Napoleon was exiled to St. Helena that little island rocked with excitement. Among its handful of British colonists apprehension and hatred were mingled with a pleased consciousness that their island had become the center of world interest, but curiosity dominated all emotions.

BUDAPEST, Oct. 9. -- Although it will be possible only after the formation of the new government to establish the effects the death of Premier Julius Goemboes will have on the political situation in Hungary, the present indications are that it will not mean any startling changes.
