SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Oct. 10. -- A series of lectures on the political and economic issues of the Presidential campaign and informal talks by some of the national or State candidates themselves are included in the political program mapped out by the students at Mount Holyoke College for this month.

MERCERSBURG, Pa., Oct. 10. -- Dr. William Mann Irvine, founder of Mercersburg Academy, was honored here today by the dedication of a memorial seat as a part of the events marking the annual Fall reunion of the alumni. Dr. Irvine's daughter, Mrs. Jack West of Winchester, Mass., was the guest of honor.

MADRID, Oct. 10. -- Government troops today succeeded in checking the Rebel advance on the central front at San Juan Pass, three and one-half miles from San Martin de Valdeiglesias. The latter town was taken by the Rebels yesterday.

The drawing last week of the names of women for the jury panel for the November term of the United States District Court, District of New Jersey, is being widely acclaimed by leaders of women's civic organizations in the metropolitan area, for the term will be the first occasion that women will serve on Federal juries in that State.
POTTSTOWN, Pa., Oct. 10. -- In a seesawing game Brooklyn's Poly Prep defeated the Hill School here today by a 6-0 score.

STRASBOURG, France, Oct. 10 (AP). -- Special police inspectors tonight arrested two men charged with plotting the assassination of speakers at tomorrow's scheduled Communist propaganda meeting. The names of the men were withheld.

Battalion Chief John L. Holian, commander of the Eighth Battalion, and his driver were injured at 1:20 o'clock this morning when the Fire Department automobile in which they were speeding to an alarm from Madison Avenue and Fifty-third Street overturned after being in collision with a coupe at Fifty-first Street and Park Avenue. The call later was found to be a false alarm.

LIVING family skeletons rattle sinisterly in this novel. For the Maisley sisters, withering virgins, dressed in perpetual mourning, cloistered in their gloomy ancestral house, have a good deal of the grave about them and their grip upon their brother promises to be a deathly one.

The original Vanderbilt Cup, which proved a great boon to the automobile industry in its infancy, was donated by William K. Vanderbilt, who was one of the early motor enthusiasts. The cup for the race, which will be held tomorrow at Westbury, has been donated by George Vanderbilt, cousin of the donor of the original trophy.
Your editorial of Oct. 1, "A Reasoned Choice," announcing your support of President Roosevelt, perfectly carries out the promise of its title.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 10. -Recently strived from war-threatened Northern China, Miss Hsien-Chin Hu of Peiping has undertaken a year of quiet work at the Radcliffe Graduate School.

Discussing the relationship of municipal debt to Federal debt and urging that the two be regarded as separate items, Arthur M. Lamport, head of the firm of A.M. Lamport Co., Inc., in a recent summary said that "few of our people realize that municipal debt during the last four years of the depression has remained practically static."

While trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange lacked the buoyant activity of recent sessions many of the secondary corporate issues worked irregularly higher on fair volume. Some week-end profit-taking was evident among a few of the recently favored convertible industrial loans, but these movements were more than offset by continued strength in the list of second-grade railroad liens.

French and English eighteenth century furniture, Oriental rugs and art, tapestries and English porcelains, comprising property of the estates of Helen Davies Lanpher, Commodore W.C. Eaton, U.S.N., and other owners will be offered at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Friday and Saturday afternoons.

ROME, Oct. l0. -- The thirteenth general assembly of the International Institute of Agriculture ended today. The president of the assembly, Dr. Henry C. Taylor, expressed his satisfaction with its work.

A Flemish tapestry, regarded by art experts as "an important piece, not only from the artistic point of view, but from the point of view of the history of Flemish tapestry," has been returned to its country of origin from a New York City art dealer.

HERE is a work that fills a crying need. Of philosophies in the nineteenth century there are aplenty, but a synthetic view of them has been singularly lacking. Outwardly this abundance of philosophies has borne the aspect of chaos.

SO rich in international memoirs is this autobiography by the Countess de Chambrun it seems unfortunate that a title should not have been found that called attention to what is clearly the distinguishing feature of the book.

ALL the great composers of them past -- perhaps there are no living ones -- are included in the scope of this book: twenty-nine, whose lives have been written by nineteen different men. They stand on a remarkably high level of excellence.

The Women's Aid Society for the Relief of Widows and Orphans, Mrs. Frederick A. Muschenheim president, will be the beneficiary of a Halloween luncheon, card party and fashion show to be held on Oct. 29 in the new ballroom of the Astor. The organization, founded in 1844, provides necessities for needy families.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 10. -The Springfield College football team defeated Northeastern University, 9 -- 7, today. Springfield scored a field goal in the third period and a touchdown in the fourth before the visitors registered in the final two minutes of play.

THESE nine subtle and superior long and short stories are no mere by-product of Grace Flandrau's African experiences, which she celebrated in her travel book, "Then I Saw the Congo." They are about a few white men and women scattered among those "outposts of progress" that lie in the path of empire.

EN ROUTE WITH BLEAKLEY CAMPAIGN CARAVAN, MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- William F. Bleakley, Republican candidate for Governor, pledged today that if he was elected he would "rid the State of any civil service employe who violates his oath of office by encouraging communism."
TROY, Oct. 10. -- A new emphasis on the importance of student activities outside the classrooms is being stressed at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute.

At a meeting and luncheon held recently at the Architectural League, leaders were appointed for the committees of the annual Beaux-Arts Ball, which s to take place on Dec. 4 at the Hotel Astor. Pierpont M. Hamilton and George Hepburn will be in charge of production.

The four-day National Chrysanthemum Show and Horticultural Exhibition, sponsored by the Chrysanthemum Society of America, will open on Nov. 5 at the State Armory, Hartford, Conn. With the increasing interest in the newer types of hardy chrysanthemums this show is of ever-widening interest to the amateur gardener.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Political "explosions" in various parts of the country in the last week have filled the atmosphere with what apparently will continue to be one of the main campaign issues: the question of relief and its administration under President Roosevelt and his New Deal aides.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 10 (AP). -Washington's vaunted Huskies, living up to a rating as one of the most powerful football teams in the Pacific Coast Conference, defeated a battling University of California at Los Angeles eleven today, 14 to 0, before 50,000 spectators.

AMONG collectors of jazz the Frenchman Hugues Panassie has long been respected as an authority on swing music. He was one of the first to formulate a critical approach to "Chicago style," and such other manifestations of the jazz strain as could be catalogued and classified.

In less active trading, the stock market yesterday registered its eighth consecutive advance. During most of the abbreviated session, pre-holiday influences dominated and fluctuations were small. A sudden wave of buying in steel, motor and rail shares during the last half hour carried many issues to new high levels for the year.

ALBANY, Oct. 11. -- Three stakes were completed today in the fifth annual field trial meeting of the Albany Cocker Club, which opened this morning in the covers of Gallogly Farm at Feurabush, a few miles west of this city, and which will be completed tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 (AP). -- Northwestern University, using little more than straight football and numerous reserves, overwhelmed North Dakota State, 40 to 7, before 20,000 spectators at Dyche Stadium today.

SUMMER, with its camping season, offers the older Scout opportunities to pass some of the stiffest requirements for scouting's highest rank -- that of Eagle. Fall, with its rallies and indoor gatherings, is the season when the badge of that rank -- a silver eagle suspended from a red, white and blue ribbon -- is most frequently presented.

WHEN British royalty comes or goes, so also the French chef. Britain has a new King and Buckingham Palace a new chef. Queen Mary has taken up her abode at Marlborough House and she has taken Amelo with her -- Amelo, who was first assistant in the royal kitchens.

WITH the inauguration of the new and fast transatlantic liners, the fortnight vacation -- which formerly afforded too little time for extended ocean voyages -- now serves as a sufficient period for a round of Continental sightseeing.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 10. -- Lehigh's football team, harassed by fumbles and penalties, nevertheless was good enough to defeat Johns Hopkins today when the embryo surgeons came here to revive football after a lapse of one year.

EASTON, Pa., Oct. 10. -- An automatic safety was the only score in a keen struggle between Lafayette and Gettysburg today as the Battlefield team ruined the opening home appearance of the Maroon by winning, 2 to 0. Gettysburg was the third team to hold Lafayette scoreless this Fall.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., Oct. 10.--The Westchester and Long Island open titleholders will pit their skill against each other tomorrow for the Metropolitan Professional Golf Association championship as a result of competition in the tenth annual event held today over the blue course of the Bethpage State Park.
I need not tell you that habit is a powerful thing or that the reading of one newspaper for more than twenty-five years is indeed a powerful habit.
CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Oct. 10 (AP). -- Two 26-yard scoring plays with Art Ditt of Lebanon, Pa., doing the tallying both times gave the University of North Carolina a 14-to-0 victory over Maryland today.

PARIS, Oct. 10. -- How grave is the problem that the government faces in holding down prices following the devaluation of the franc can be seen from the official price indices for September, which were issued today.

IN the process of his exhaustive researches for the Tercentennial History of Harvard, Professor Morison has achieved a documentary knowledge of early New England in general which is unapproached by any other historian; and he summarized it in a series of lectures delivered in 1934 at the Washington Square Center of New York University.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 10. -- Declaring that "we never know what the law is until the Supreme Court tells us," Judge John J. Gore of the Federal District Court took under consideration this afternoon the suit which will again take the question of the Tennessee Valley Authority's validity to the highest court of the land.

The empty box from the Twenty-first Election District of the Second Assembly District, Manhattan, discovered in a partial recount of ballots in the recent primary contest between Sheriff William F. Brunner and Frank J. Prial was disclosed yesterday to be the actual box of the district and not merely a container for waste paper and discarded ballots.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 10. -The $775,000 contents of Gloria Crest, forty-five-room mansion on North Woodland Street here, known as the "White House of Englewood," will be sold next week at public auction on the premises from Monday to Saturday at 1:30 daily.
YEAR after year the desert has been encroaching upon and obliterating the graves in one of the most unusual cemeteries in America -- Boothill Cemetery at Tombstone, in Arizona.

JAMESTOWN and Plymouth long have been patriotic shrines while Roanoke Island, site of the first English colony in the New World, birthplace of America's first baby of English parentage and scene of one of the great mysteries of American history, has remained almost forgotten.

THE quota of 144 new students admitted annually at the Eastman School of Music has been filled for the coming season. The entrants come from thirty-three States and were chosen from more than 200 applicants. Two hundred and fifty-six students, representing thirty-six States, were recipients of student aid awards from Howard Hanson, director of the school.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 10 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin tonight reiterated his assertion that President Roosevelt has "communistic tendencies" and offered "as proof" the charter of a corporation which, he said, was formed in Delaware under New Deal auspices.

Cooperation between the Domestic Relations Court and the Emergency Relief Bureau has saved the city $130,000 in relief funds in the last five months, Miss Charlotte E. Carr, executive director of the ERB, reported yesterday.

ONE of the most brilliant estimates of Horace ever written has come from the pen of Agnes Repplier and was published recently in The Atlantic. To read Horace is something unusual. To appreciate him places one apart.

ROME, Oct. 10. -- Premier Benito Mussolini, in his capacity as Minister of the armed forces of the State, acquainted a Cabinet council held this morning with the progress that has been made toward realization of the huge rearmament program on which the Fascist government embarked soon after the breaking of the Italo-Ethiopian controversy.

THERE are always racial troubles in the Holy Land, either brewing or boiling over, but at no time since the war have they seethed more portentously than in 1920, when the issues of the Arab-Jewish question in Palestine, and the confirmation of mandates in the Near East to Britain and France were still under consideration of the peace conference.

KINGSTON, R.I., Oct. 10. -Rhode Island State College defeated Tufts, 7 to 0, today on a 44-yard drive in the second period. Bobbie Mudge scored the touchdown, smashing through his own left tackle for the last two yards. Bob Albanese place-kicked the extra point.

I have been a continuous customer and advocate of your newspaper for the last fifteen years, and I realize that it is not news when a Democratic paper comes out for a Democratic candidate, but it is news of a very serious nature when a Democratic paper becomes internationally minded to such an extent that it cannot follow logical reasoning to maintain its broad standard of fighting for a national point of view.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10. -- New high levels for the season were established today on all deliveries of wheat in Liverpool, and the October and December futures in Winnipeg rose to new high levels as the result of further tightening in the world's statistical position.

The Student Self-Government Association of Hunter College will celebrate its silver jubilee this year with a broadening of extracurricular activities, including a student song contest and a peace conference.

BERLIN, Oct. 10. -- The Catholic Bishops of Germany have released a third pastoral letter which is to be read in various dioceses tomorrow. It deals exclusively with the recent trials of members of a Catholic monastery at Waldbreitbach near Coblenz who are charged with immoral conduct.

With more than 100 students participating in the work of nineteen social welfare agencies, the Social Research Laboratory of the Department of Government and Sociology at City College began its eighth year this semester. Professor Samuel Joseph of the department is at the head of the laboratory.

Celebration of the election of Miss Anne Houston Sadler as president of the Association of Bank Women, at its recent convention in San Francisco, will take the form of a dinner Friday night at the Hotel Chatham, under auspices of the middle Atlantic division.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Forty-six per cent of the cotton classed by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics in the week ended on Thursday was white middling and better in grade, and 68 per cent of the cotton classed in this crop season was of these grades, the bureau said today in its weekly report.

TO help American composers the American Academy of Teachers of Singing has prepared a third list of 100 songs by native composers, published since 1915. The list, which is distributed free of charge, consists of lyrics chosen by a special committee appointed by the academy.
AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 10. -- Amherst swamped the Norwich eleven, 46 -- 0, today. The Jeffs scored in every period but the third and used forty players.

Declaring that the peace proposal of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers Union aiming to end the conflict between the A.F. of L. and the Committee for Industrial Organization was "more than a gesture," William Green, president of the A.F. of L., said last night that it would receive careful consideration from the federation's executive council when it reconvenes in Washington tomorrow.

THE appearance at the Criterion last week of Twentieth Century-Fox's Technicolor version of "Ramona" has set us wondering when Hollywood intends to complete the initiation of the color film and make it a full-fledged member of the club.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- With both Gubernatorial candidates maintaining residences in this county, Westchester becomes a focal point in the State campaign. The disposition of Westchester's 200,000 votes may prove an election key, in the opinion of observers here.

A festive evening has been planned by a special arrangements committee for the formal opening of the new Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria, Oct. 27, which will be a benefit for the New York Exchange for Woman's Work. A varied entertainment will feature the program.
