BOSTON, OCT. 9. REMEMBERING the success of "Anything Goes!" Boston put on its best bib and tucker Wednesday night to catch the first glimpse at the Colonial of the latest work of Cole Porter, Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse in "Red, Hot and Blue!"
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10. -- Chairman Farley will be honor guest at a dinner on Oct. 20 at the Penn Athletic Club, with plates priced at $100 each.

SOME years ago Elisabeth Marbury, Robert Milton and I were having lunch and we were discussing a book by Carl Van Vechten in which it was brought out that there were thousands of Negroes so white in tint and feature that they could and did live as white people.

Japan hopes to entertain 100,000 foreign visitors, including Americans, at the 1940 Olympic Games in Tokyo in the traditional Japanese manner, it was disclosed by Baron Kisitiro Okura, a member of the Japanese Olympics Committee, who arrived here from Europe last week on the Cunard-White Star liner Queen Mary.

Your editorial "A Reasoned Choice" sets forth some things concerning the Roosevelt administration that are worthy of consideration by independent Democrats like myself. But there is much that could be said against giving a second term to an administration that has upset the values usually associated with good government and the common welfare.

Women of America today are facing a Presidential campaign that involves the greatest moral issue in their voting history. It lies within their power to determine whether this country shall continue as a great Republic based on the philosophy of government by laws or government by bureaucracy controlled by men.

MIDTOWN Sixth Avenue is torn up for the new municipal subway. Construction sheds and mountains of timbers and metal sheeting have since early Summer possessed the scene from Bryant Park for several blocks north. Giant steel mains that a man might creep through rise from the earth to cross high above the elevated road.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 10. -- Tulane unloosed three spurts of offensive power to score three touchdowns and a 19-0 victory over Centenary today before 13,000 spectators. During the other moments of the battle the Greenies held the vaunted attack of the visitors completely in check.

THE texture of this fine book is as a Persian carpet. There is material under foot. But it is magic to the eye. We walk firmly on what we are bound to believe, we look at what transcends belief, and the question is how we can rend the credible from the incredible without tearing asunder the whole design.

A new instrument, known as a heliodon, which will enable architects to design buildings so that they will achieve maximum solar light and heat in Winter and maximum shade in Summer has been constructed in the town-planning studio of the Columbia University school of architecture, Dean Leopold Aranud announced yesterday.

I have read with interest your editorial in which you reaffirm your allegiance to Mr. Roosevelt and his administration. You express the view that the affairs of the nation will be much better administered by Mr. Roosevelt than by Mr. Landon and the Republican party; and that the encroachments of communism will disappear and that in his second term Mr. Roosevelt will turn definitely to the right and become more conservative.
Your editorial "A Reasoned Choice" is a masterpiece of fearless independent thinking.

DEALING with the "adventurous future" and "weighing the imponderables of television," a group of spokesmen for radio broadcasting met in Washington during the past week with the Federal Communications Commission "to secure maximum service in the public interest."
LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Oct. 10. -- Lawrenceville's fighting football team met its second defeat of the season at the hands of a fast and powerful eleven from Tome School by 12 -- 6 today.

THE elements with which Chief Inspector French has to deal in this story are: First, a secret chemical process which is expected to make its inventors and their backers fabulously rich; second, the disappearance of Reginald Platt, who has vanished from a steamer bound from Belfast to Liverpool while on his way to report to his employer the result of his investigation of the process.

THAT branch of our air defense known in the Air Corps as "Observation" is taking on new importance. Ever since the World War, save by a few far-sighted officers, the observation branch has placed last in importance.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 10. -- The tenth biennial meeting of the Cooperative League of the United States, representing about 3,000,000 consumers, closed its sessions here today by calling for a general expansion of the loans which the government is now making to consumer-owned enterprise in limited fields.

JAMES E. WATSON, sometime Senator from Indiana, Congressman, Republican regular, spent about thirty years on Capitol Hill, and now is ready to tell all about it. He has not written a great book, as political recollections go, but perhaps he tells more than he intended, for in an unconscious way he discloses a good deal about the sort of thinking that has gone on in high places.

A government agent relying on faith in his ability to analyze handwriting, and on two ancient photographs, to trace a man suspected of defrauding the Federal Housing Administration recognized success Friday in a neat signature in the register of the Prince George Hotel, 14 East Twenty-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University and president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, was appointed by President Roosevelt today chairman of an executive committee to submit a panel of names for a new national committee to assist in plans for the monument to be erected at Santo Domingo (now Ciudad Trujillo) in honor of Christopher Columbus.

Under the pressure of ever-growing curricula and increasing enrollments, New York University is now in the midst of its greatest expansion period in many years. Last Friday a new classroom building was dedicated on the Nassau-Hofstrau College campus in Hempstead, Long Island.

Pushing vigorously ahead under the stimulating influence of the steady rise in retail distribution, major branches of trade and industry marked up substantial gains last week in most of the Federal Reserve districts. In some areas, retail trade suffered to some extent as the result of high temperatures, but sales figures as a whole showed favorable gains over the volume in the corresponding period last year.

ELEVEN million gunners are taking the field during these Autumn weeks. Nearly a half-million of them will hunt in the State of New York. What wild targets will this army find? What live things will be left, when shooting days are over, for non-sportsmen to enjoy?
HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 10. -- A forward pass which found its resting place in hands for which it never was intended spelled the hair-line difference between two great football teams today.
A total of $34,286 was realized from the first gallery sale this season by the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street. It was held Friday and yesterday afternoon.

FROM London come reports that "the age of etheric silence and innocence" is ended. The air of Europe is drenched with propaganda, and Americans with all-wave receivers are getting a sample of what is called "pernicious ilk," for the powerful short waves loquaciously pray their suave and subtle words all over the globe.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP). -- Benjamin Franklin, who got a thousand dollars a year for being the country's first Postmaster General, will soon be honored by a marble likeness in the new Postoffice Department Building.

Impressive gains in retail trade will be shown in the preliminary United States summary of the retail census to be issued about the middle of this week, it was learned here yesterday. The retail data form part of the current census of business, covering operations in 1935.

AS "Factus," in the English monthly Musical Opinion, Mr. Dunn reports on the operatic activities of terrified amateurs. Last month in that periodical he stated that during the season he had witnessed separate productions and that five of the six works heading the list, with four or more performances each, were from the Savoy repertoire.

ANDOVER, Mass., Oct. 10. -- The Phillips Andover Academy football team scored a 12-0 victory over the Yale freshmen here today, with the visitors not once being able to penetrate beyond midfield. At the start of the second period Seymour went through center for a touchdown from the 1-yard line.

OMAHA, Oct. 9. -- Before this campaign is over it is going to be hard to tell which is of paramount importance in this State, the election of a President of the United States or a Senator for Nebraska.

Headed by Mrs. E. Marshall Field, a committee of board members of the Maternity Center Association has taken over the performance of the new musical show, "Red Hot and Blue," at the Alvin Theatre for the night of Oct. 22 as a means to advance the work of the association.

WHEN the Metropolitan Opera season of 1036-37 opens in December it will be time to speak in detail of the singers who have been engaged, and various attendant matters. What invites comment now is a subject even more fundamental to those who attend opera in order to hear music as well as singing.

Glamour in one's evening outfit comes as much from well-chosen accessories as from gown and cloak -- and one's coiffure is an important part of the finished picture. Thus women are likely to be interested in bejeweled short combs and barettes to place in strategic points in one's headdress in order to give it a focal point of interest, hold curls in place gracefully and lend the coiffure its evening glitter.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 10.-Many parties have been planned by members of society who have made reservations for the automobile racing at the Roosevelt Raceway on Columbus Day, but the times of the breakfasts that will precede and the teas and dinners which will follow the program have not been fixed because of the anticipated traffic jams.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 10. -- The number of living alumni of Princeton University now stands at 17,967, an increase of 1,250 in the last three years, according to the fifteenth triennial directory just published by the graduate council under the direction of its secretary, Donald W. Griffin of the class of '23.

It has been a long time since the ethereal miss with tubercular tendencies has been a favorite figure of romance. In "Glittering Heights" she comes into her own again. Emmy is a fragile beauty of 18, recovering from a two years' siege of illness in a delightful schloss in Switzerland. Her dear friends.

Valiant Is the Word for Carrie -- A faithful, but overlong, transcription of Barry Benefield's novel about the gallant prostitute who adopted two orphans and dedicated herself to their happiness. Grandly done in the first half by Gladys George and young Jackie Moran, but trailing off when the waifs grow up.

IN POLITICS: In 1930, when his father was Governor of New York and he was only a beginning law student at Boston University, James Roosevelt was asked for what career he was preparing. "It's politics," he replied, "and of course with the Democratic party."

Your comment upon the withdrawal of the Democratic candidates in Minnesota is accurately and clearly stated. However, there is a factor which was not mentioned, by the withdrawing Democrats or your editorial. That is our stupid system which permits election by mere "plurality," when we boast of having government by majority rule.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 10. -Gerard Swope arrived at the Homestead last evening, accompanied by Mrs. Isaac G. Swope, his daughter-in-law.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 10. -- Apparently inspired news dispatches from Tokyo declaring that Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and Shigeru Kawagoe, the Japanese Ambassador, had agreed on the basic details for Chino-Japanese negotiations were specifically denied by officials here yesterday as Chiang Kai-shek made a three-hour visit.

The Securities and Exchange Commission delivered yesterday to Federal Judge Julian W. Mack a scathing brief in its suit to compel the Electric Bond and Share Company, five other defendants and sixteen intervening defendants to register in conformity with the Public Utility Act of 1935.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 10. -- Far superior offensively, the Tiger ruled supreme in his Palmer Stadium lair today as Princeton churned out a 20-to-0 triumph over Rutgers in the thirty-fourth edition of intercollegiate football's oldest rivalry, but the victors did not prance through the scrappy Scarlet squad with any great amount of ease.
Real estate offers an expanding field for women at the present time, according to Ralph E. Cramp, an attorney at 149 Broadway and Assistant Professor of Finance at New York University.
The most serious accusation which our critics make against the trade-agreements program is that under its operation the American farmer has been sold down the river.

SAINT-MALO, France, Oct. 10. -On board the transport ship Aude the bodies of Dr. Jean Baptiste Charcot and twenty-one officers and men who perished with him in the wreck of their exploration ship Pourquoi-Pas were brought back today to this old port, from which they had so often sailed forth.

THE second season of Philharmonic-Symphony Chamber Orchestra concerts, under Hans Lange, for the benefit of the scholarship fund of Bennington College, opens Nov. 9 in Town Hall. Among the old works figuring on the programs will be a divertimento by Dittersdorf, "Il combattimento dell' umana passione"; a fantasia by Orlando Gibbons and a four-voice ricercar by Gabrielli.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Oct. 10. -- Twenty army camp kitchens were distributed throughout Porto Alegre today to serve hot food to thousands who lost their homes in the vast flood. The State government rushed aid to the Pelotas, Sao Gabriel, Taquary and Gravatahy districts where the floods are severe.

In so far as Luigi Criscuolo's letter in THE TIMES advocates an open-minded attitude toward an adjustment of the Italian debt question, it should be received with approval. Nevertheless, Mr. Criscuolo should not confuse the fundamental issues raised by what is reported to be the attitude of the Italian Government.
It was a joy to read your editorial giving your reason for the choice of Roosevelt for President. I am proud to be allied with a paper of such wisdom and fairness in the opinion you express.

LISBON, Oct. 9. -- General Francisco Franco is finding it very easy to gain converts on the Rebel side in the Spanish civil war and exceedingly difficult to convince the masses on the other side that surrender would mean a better Spain despite propaganda dropped from planes and passed through surreptitiously to the Leftist side.
Your decision to support President Roosevelt for re-election impresses Midwestern liberals with whom I have discussed it as fundamentally sound.

DETROIT, Oct. 10. -- Sentences ranging up to one of ten to twenty years were imposed by Circuit Judge Joseph A. Moynihan today on four more men, the last of the eleven convicted of the Black Legion "execution" of Charles A. Poole, whose death exposed the activities of the hooded organization.

THAT London, from being a hotbed of crime, has become one of the most orderly cities in the world is, without question, chiefly due to the metropolitan police, which now has its headquarters at New Scotland Yard. It is not an old institution, dating back no further than 1829, when Sir Robert Peele's Metropolitan Police Bill became a law.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- (AP). -- An untried cog in the nation's election machinery -- the Norris "lame duck" amendment to the Constitution -- was oiled today by Edwin A. Halsey, secretary of the Senate.
The second annual "Exposition of Progress" sponsored by the Staten Island Chamber of Commerce will open on Friday afternoon in the George Cromwell Center, Tompkinsville, S.I.

More than 4,000 Negro men, women and children paraded three and one-half miles through Harlem yesterday afternoon as a protest against rent increases and housing conditions there. Later the marchers assembled in Rockland Palace, 155th Street and Eighth Avenue, where speakers urged them to reject any increased rent demands of the landlords.

LOOKING down on the harbor last Tuesday morning from a palatial American Airlines plane as the Santa Paula came slowly up the bay bearing those honeymooning screen players, Dick Powell and Joan Blondell, to Gotham, we thought we saw the Macom.

THE roaring-road days, when goggles and linen dusters were standard motoring accessories and gasoline was sold at drug stores, will be portrayed in modern dress tomorrow as international road racing comes back to America.

The underlying facts about some of New York's most famous families came to the top yesterday afternoon when James J. Doherty celebrated the completion of forty-five years as a carpet measurer with Arnold Constable Co. by recalling his experiences in the homes of the wealthy.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Oct. 10. -Miss Mildred McAfee will be inaugurated as president of Wellesley College Friday afternoon at simple and all but private ceremonies in Alumnae Hall. Only members of the college community will attend.

The annual Horse Show Ball to be held in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on the night of Nov. 7 will be the outstanding event in the series of social functions arranged in connection with the National Horse Show, which will run its course at Madison Square Garden from Nov. 4 to 10.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10. -- The sixteenth season of the Philadelphia. Forum will open next week and continue through March, with thirty-five events "running the entire range of a well-ordered life" listed on the program.

THE United States Department of Agriculture and other branches of the Federal Government concerned with the protection and conservation of forests and lands are making increasing use of aviation. The Forest Service has found the planes invaluable in checking fires.
OVIEDO, Spain, Oct. 10 (AP). -- Besieged insurgents fought grimly tonight to hold a few scattered buildings as dynamite-tossing Asturian miners blasted their way to the heart of the city.

In a recent communication of Representative Bloom to THE TIMES, relative to the commemoration of the 149th anniversary of the Constitution, he made the statement that the Constitution went into effect and became operative on March 4, 1789. This is a current but mistaken opinion.

One of the oldest field trial organizations in America will hold its annual meeting this week. At Putnam, Conn., the Brunswick Foxhound Club tomorrow morning at 6 o'clock will send away candidates in its derby stake, inaugurating its forty-sixth consecutive annual field trials.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 10. -The exterior of the century old residence on the Wesleyan University campus which was occupied by every president of the college until 1904, and since then by the several deans, has been remodeled during the Summer, greatly changing the appearance of this campus landmark.
BURGOS, Spain, Oct. 10 (AP). -- General Francisco Franco, supreme military leader of the insurgents, toured his front lines tonight to decide when he would start the final Madrid attack.

PEOPLE, in novels and out of them, become intelligible by their objectives, by their ambitions. The major activities in a man's life are channeled and directed by the goal upon winch his eyes are set. Whether his purpose is the making of money, the attainment of power, the wooing of a woman or the contemplation of God, it molds his life in direct proportion to its fixity.

On next Thursday morning, at Grand Rapids, Mich. (famous for furniture), Franklin D. Roosevelt and Alf M. Landon will cross paths. The President's campaign special will be pulling into the city's railroad yards just as Governor Landon's will be leaving. Within twenty-four hours the citizens of Grand Rapids will have heard from the candidates themselves (1) why they should elect Landon for President and (2) why they should re-elect Roosevelt.

One hundred years ago MARK HOPKINS became President of Williams College. The centenary of that event is being suitably celebrated at Williamstown. The place which he held in philosophy will be indicated and appraised by several competent speakers. Others will measure his long services as a teacher, and will dwell upon the high position in American college life which he held for more than forty years.
LONDON, Oct. 10. -- Mrs. Curtis Brown, president of the American Women's Club here, returned to London after passing the Summer as usual at Peck Farm in New York.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 10. -- I should be obliged if you will correct a serious error concerning myself in Mr. O'Connor's dispatch published in your columns Oct. 10. He says that in my speech I stated I was definitely separating myself from the existing profit system, which means that I am getting out of my present business connections.

An episode in the triumph of knowledge over ignorance has been described with pardonable relish by Dr. Rosenbach, who happens to be the hero of the tale. Sitting in at one of the sessions of the Britwell Court sale in London in 1923, his attention was attracted by a fragile little volume of pious verses.

LISBON, Portugal, Oct. 10. -- A protest is being sent to the International Organization for Intellectual Cooperation of the League of Nations by a committee of Portuguese poets, journalists, artists and authors against the imprisonment in Madrid, Barcelona, Valencia and Alicante of their colleagues for mere suspicion of not agreeing with the government of Spain.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 10 (AP). -- Although uncorking startling strength in the final period, a stubborn Washington University eleven lost to the favored Notre Dame team by a 14-to-6 margin today before approximately 22,000 fans.

CAR manufacturers moved into their most active preseason period the past week. While factories were busy smoothing out manufacturing operations preparatory to huge productions, sales executives were absorbed in a series of previews and meetings of distributors and dealers.

A varied and interesting program has been announced for the annual convention of the three New York State nursing organizations for which registration begins tomorrow at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Mrs. Homer Wickenden of Tuckahoe, N.Y., chairman of the lay committee of the New York State organization for public health nursing, heads the committee in charge of the special program and plans for the entertainment of lay guests.

ARMONIK, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- A driving rain failed to hinder residents of North Castle this afternoon in opening a three-day celebration of the 200th anniversary of the township. A historical pageant which was to have been presented on open acreage across Whippoorwill Road from the Armonk grade school was transferred to the school auditorium, into which 600 observers were packed.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 9. -- The sudden resignation this week of Pittsburgh's "unpredictable" Mayor, William N. McNair, has left in its wake a campaign factor that has the political soothsayers puzzled.

Statistics released by the WPA Federal Music Project yesterday revealed that in the period from Jan. 1 to Sept. 15 WPA orchestras gave concerts before an attendance of 32,000,000 persons throughout the United States. The announcement disclosed that on Oct. 1 the WPA Music Project, headed by Dr. Nikolai Sokoloff, ended its first year of stewardship of the musical phase in the Federal Government's four arts relief program.

THE schedule of exhibitions to be held during the 1936-37 season has been revised by the Museum of Modern Art. The projected exhibition of American architecture covering the last five years has been postponed until another season, a show of modern English architecture replacing it.

ALBANY, Oct. 10 (AP). -- Secretary of State Flynn notified objectors to petitions of the Union party today that he had overruled their protest and would certify all of the party's petitions for a place on the New York State ballot Nov. 3.

The contribution of the early Dutch settlers of this city to the establishment of its religious tradition will be marked at a "Dutch Sunday" to be held at St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie Church, Tenth Street, west of Second Avenue, next Sunday afternoon at 4 o'clock.

THE RIVER PASTURE" is a collection of sketches from the day-by-day life of a girl who runs a cattle ranch in Southern California. But, reader, it is not what you think. Cast all your preconceived notions from your mind, reader, and be prepared, in surprise and keen rejoicing, for a book of wise and mellowed albeit fresh and unaffected beauty, not only rare and individual, but unique.

The couplet was true in a sense other than the ironic one of his intention. The critics were too nearly right; and what they shouted is even truer today. Bierce has become an illustrious example of the major writer who has still to achieve contact with his natural and destined reading public.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- During the fiscal year ended June 30, American taxpayers were granted refunds of nearly $39,000,000, according to figures made public this week by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, Guy T. Halvering. The sum included interest.

Debutantes of this and recent seasons will act as manikins in the fashion show, a feature of the entertainment at the luncheon to be given in behalf of the Children's Village on Tuesday at the Versailles. Mrs. Herbert McGrey Hanscom is in charge of the arrangements for the fashion revue.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 10. -- The Navy won by 35 to 14 from Virginia today, the game running in the same groove as the three others of the present series.

How to understand and enjoy pictures will be explained to members of the Jamaica Women's Club Wednesday afternoon by Carlton H. Palmer of Manhattan, authority on painting. He will display a group of paintings on the stage, following a business meeting, at the Y.M.C.A. Building, Parsons Boulevard and Grove Street, Jamaica.

The travel industry is having its most prosperous October in many years and trade and monetary conditions indicate that the situation will be continued through the Winter, according to a survey made by the American Express Company.

SIEGFRIED SASSOON'S story will always be that of the war. It took him from his tennis and hunting and verse writing and made him a poet and public figure, a captain of men and a soldier who won the Military Cross, a pacifist and a strange martyr to two different kinds of loyalty.

SPECIFICATIONS for the passenger cars and trucks of the American Bantam Car Company of Butler, Pa., were made public last week. The 1937 line includes a quarter-ton truck chassis, $275; chassis with panel body, $295; with pick-up body, $385; business coupe, $335; de luxe coupe, $385; standard coupe, $365; standard roadster, $385; custom built roadster, $445 and up.

BERLIN, Oct. 10. -- For the first time this season certain sections of Berlin saw today the spectacle of queues of women standing in the streets waiting to buy scarce food stuffs. The queues were short and were to be seen only at a few stores during the morning and early afternoon.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- A meeting of the Elmira College Alumnae Council here today was marked by the presence of one of its most distinguished members, Mrs. Benjamin Harrison of New York City, widow of the former President. Mrs. Harrison, '79, is one of the five advisers of the Alumnae Association.

THIS collection of papers by twenty-four of the leading American workers in the fields of crime prevention is both a valuable and an enlightening book. It is valuable, obviously, because of the pressing importance of its theme and the care, completeness and authoritative study of its treatment here.

The editorial in THE TIMES of Oct. 1 shows unbiased judgment and thinking in discussing the real issues confronting the country. To all right-thinking men, the question of politics is a side issue, and in the light of reason what this country wants is relief from the heavy burdens thrust upon her by certain predatory interests that guided the unsavory destiny of the Republican party, bringing near-ruin upon the American people.

BOSTON, Oct. 10. -- A survey of available statistics leads to the inevitable conclusion that business in New England, both manufacturing and retailing, is having the best fourth quarter since 1929. Department stores sales are running 12 to 1 per cent ahead of a year ago.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 10. -- Despite ankle-deep mud made by last night's heavy rains and an intermittent drizzle today, outstanding jumping performances marked the second and final day of the sixteenth annual Orange Horse Show at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 10. -- Wesleyan continued its unscored on record today, defeating the Bowdoin eleven, 20 to 0. Bowdoin threatened in the fourth quarter, when the Polar Bears carried the ball to Wesleyan's 25-yard line, where Fullback Holzer intercepted a forward pass to recover the ball for the Cardinals.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Oct. 10. -- John L. Pratt of New York City and Falmouth, Va., retired vice president of the General Motors Corporation, and Dr. David R. Lyman, superintendent of the Gaylord Farm Sanitarium at Wallingford, Conn., have been named departmental chairmen of the Alderman Alumni Fund of the University of Virginia to aid in obtaining gifts as a memorial to the university's first president, Edwin Anderson Alderman.

PAYMENT of "treaty money" to a king's children is no fairytale phrase. It is a picturesque annual ceremony that the Canadian Government has carried out since 1763, the year in which New France was ceded to Great Britain, and the Indians received compensation "for the surrender of their hunting grounds."

The World's Fair Corporation announces that 356 drawings were submitted in its contest for the best design of a building for the exposition. The entry date expired Friday. Many prominent architects are said to have submitted designs.

ALL the best authorities seem to concur that Winter coats must display waistlines. They are seamed into a princess silhouette, belted or wrapped around in order to emphasize shapeliness. There's a fine swing to most of the skirts; on occasion it is quite exaggerated.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 10 (AP). -- Indiana University's resourceful football team, dark horse in the Western Conference race, kicked the University of Michigan's hapless Wolverines out of the title picture today with a 14-to-3 victory.

DALLAS, Oct. 10. -- Fall trade in the Eleventh Federal Reserve District hit its full stride this week under the influence of a number of encouraging factors. The opening of schools and the return of vacationists have created demands for merchandise not felt during the Summer months.

YOUNG PETE, born in the Texas Panhandle, was orphaned at 2 and was doing a man's work at 12 when he shot his foster-father, who, filled with corn whisky, had knocked him down. Then he fell in with a gang of rustlers and horse thieves, but while he would risk his life scouting for that outfit, he would never steal anything other than cattle.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., Oct. 10 (AP). -The Fayette County Grand Jury indicted tonight District Attorney James A. Reilly and six others on charges of murder in connection with the "third-degree" death of Frank C. Monaghan, a hotel man.

Two sure thrusts by a quick-striking Theodore Roosevelt High School eleven yesterday turned back a De Witt Clinton High School team which failed to show a successful scoring punch until it was too late.

The New York Football Giants, with what Coach Steve Owen frankly terms "the best bunch I've had in years," will open their twelfth home season in the National Football League today against the Brooklyn Dodgers in their traditional interborough rivalry at the Polo Grounds.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Copies of the Works Progress Administration's long expected booklet explaining the government's work relief program were on view here today. The pamphlets will be put into general distribution on Monday, according to present plans.

Transplanting Oriental poppies is an Autumn "must" on the gardener's calendar. Any time from the period of maturity is good, but the earlier in late Summer or Fall the better, so that roots may become well-established and anchored before frost.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 10. -- Big Andy Uram gave the Minnesota-Nebraska game a Dick Merriwell finish today with a sensational 75-yard touchdown run in the last sixty-eight seconds of play for the Golden Gophers' nineteenth consecutive gridiron triumph.

IT is unlikely that Professor Linn, veteran instructor of English, would consider "Winds Over the Campus" a novel, for the trappings of fiction barely conceal a personal memoir beneath. It is no secret that as in his novel "This Was Life," published last January, the institution of higher learning which provides the setting is his own University of Chicago.

COME January, or maybe February, Carl Laemmle Jr. will set out in earnest on a career of his own in motion-picture production, with the hope that, in time, people may stop calling him Junior the way everybody does now. With his illustrious father now definitely in retirement and the old Universal organization in new hands, the young man feels free to step out for himself.

MEXICO, D.F., Oct. 10. -- The University of Mexico eleven held Occidental College of Los Angeles to a score of 19 to 6 in the National Stadium today. Occidental excelled in passing, but Mexico stopped its running attack. Ten thousand saw the game.
The new headquarters of the National Council of Jewish Women, occupying the entire ninth floor of the building at 221 West Fifty-seventh Street, will be formally opened on Oct. 21.
Two old ladies registered for the first time on Friday and both declared yesterday that their first votes are going to President Roosevelt.

VIENNA. TOSCANINI'S suggestion of a new Festspielhaus for Salzburg (or, failing that, a reconstruction of the present one) and the intimations that he himself might be ready to contribute to it seem to dispose of rumors which cropped up persistently this past Summer that the master was fed up on the place and would henceforth wash his hands of the festival, thereby sealing its fate.

THOUSANDS of parents and children all over the country are looking enviously toward Hollywood. There, to their ecstatic view, dwell the child movie stars in a kind of Elysium, trailing clouds of gold and glory. All this raises questions highly interesting, not only to parents, but to moviegoers in general.

ABOARD ROOSEVELT SPECIAL TRAIN, Oct. 10. -- After planning originally to conduct his campaign for re-election by means of a few speeches in key cities, President Roosevelt is now "barnstorming" through the Middle West on a 5,000-mile trip calling for visits to twelve States.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10. -- Retail trade suffered somewhat from the mild temperatures and occasional rain this week, and the volume was down from the preceding seven days as a result. The women's apparel lines were the hardest hit, and a little worry over inventories is developing with some of the stores.

IN his late teens Barry Haveril took up his rifle, knife and belt ax and walked away from his home and went into the woods beyond the spur of Indian Mountain to build his own log cabin. He belonged to a widely scattered clan, the Haverils, who were reputed a folk not to be antagonized with impunity

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 10. -- Rumania's new Foreign Minister, Victor Antonescu, arrived here today to pay an official visit to his country's ally. Yugoslavia. He had a long conference with Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch today and informed his colleague on the situation at Geneva.

This country is being asked to make a false sacrifice of personal liberties in order to provide economic security, said Colonel Frank C. Knox, Republican candidate for Vice President, at a luncheon meeting yesterday of the Harmonie Club, 4 East Sixtieth Street.
CLINTON, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- The Hobart College football team defeated Hamilton College today, 33 to 0.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 10. -- Senator William E. Borah has apparently answered the question that has so long agitated the Pacific Northwest -- his position toward the Presidential candidates in the present campaign. The Senator announced yesterday that he would make no speeches for Governor Landon or President Roosevelt, but that he would confine himself to issues which in some cases "cut across party lines."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- As a step in trying to realize President Roosevelt's plan of pooling transmission facilities for electric energy generated by public and private agencies, the Tennessee Valley Authority and the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation agreed today to extend their existing relations for three months.

ATLANTA, Oct. 10 (AP). -- Propelled by a hard-charging line that paved the way for a scintillating display of football "razzle-dazzle," the Engineers of Georgia Tech rolled up an unexpected 34-to-0 decision over a haphazard band of Kentucky Wildcats today before approximately 30,000 fans.

Miss Alice Andre and a committee of young women of society are active in preparations for the dinner dance to be given on Thursday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador, in behalf of the Russian Nobility Fund Association.
The undergraduates and alumnae of Barnard College earned more during the last year than at any time since 1928-1929, reports Miss Katherine S. Doty, head of Barnard's Occupation Bureau.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9. -- Pennsylvania's position as a pivotal State in the Presidential campaign has received renewed emphasis this week with registration figures reaching record-breaking totals in the leading cities, and with Republican orators on all fronts charging a first-class scandal in the Workers Progress Administration in this commonwealth.

VIENNA, Oct. 10. -- After a hard struggle throughout a Cabinet meeting that lasted from 4 P. M. yesterday until 6 A. M. today, Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg succeeded in concentrating all power in his hands and emerged as personal dictator of Austria.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 10. -- Closer integration of the work of the New Jersey State Board of Education and Rutgers University and the need for greater endowments for the latter "to create a backlog of financial security and strengthen the university's contribution to its partnership with the State" were stressed by Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers, in his annual report issued today.

The Clyde Mallory Lines announced yesterday the retirement of Captain F.G. Avery, commodore of its fleet after fifty-two years of service. Captain Avery was guest of honor last night at a dinner in New Haven tendered by more than 200 persons who recently accompanied him on a cruise aboard the liner Iroquois, it was announced.

AUTUMN days summon the vagabond to tread the woodland path Then the dirt kicks freer beneath the hiker's boot, there is a pleasant coolness to the air and the sky, bright blue by day, is splashed at sunset with the wildest color.

Automobile road racing will come back to America and to Long Island, where it flourished in the early years of the century, with the staging tomorrow of the Vanderbilt Cup Race over the new and expansive Roosevelt Raceway at Westbury, L.I.
Again the American people have been given a demonstration of the absolute independence of the editorial policy of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

OUR readers are so well acquainted now with the monumental work of Jules Romains, "Les Hommes de Bonne Volonte," through the substantial reviews of the English translations published in this magazine that we need not dwell upon the general characteristics of the two new volumes, XI and XII of the French edition (Flammarion, 318 and 288 pages, 12 francs each ).
Those who live by the pass sometimes also perish by the same instrument turned against them.

A SEVENTEEN-FOOT figure representing a master mechanic holding aloft a replica of a streamlined car will greet visitors to the 1936 National Automobile Show at Grand Central Palace on Nov. 11. The figure, placed against a background of black velvet, will stand at the head of the grand staircase leading from the main exhibition floor to the mezzanine, and above it will be the inscription, "Pacemaker for American Industry."

LONDON. THE three choirs of Hereford, Gloucester and Worcester met this year at Hereford, and the task of arranging the programs and conducting them fell, accordingly, to the organist of Hereford Cathedral, Dr. Percy Hull.

ESCANABA, Mich. -- Recalling the ease with which a constitutional amendment limiting the property tax levy to 15 mills was carried in the 1932 election, Michigan citizens are interested in two more proposals for drastic changes in the tax structure, which will be submitted to the people on Nov. 3.
CHICAGO, Oct. 10 (AP). -- Elmer Stuart of Chicago today held the grand award for United States nineteenth and twentieth century stamps in the Chicago Philatelic Society's golden jubilee exhibition.

WHITEMARSH, Pa., Oct. 10. -Despite the fact that he has only been out of the barn twice this season Rockicy from the stables of John Strawbridge and ridden by his son, George, won a second leg on the Pennsylvania Hunt Cup, a three-and-a-half-mile timber race at the Fall meet of the Whitemarsh Hunt Club today.

WE arrived in Moscow at the very end of the season but still in time to see performances by the Vakhtangov and the Realistic Theatres, two of Moscow's most popular troupes. Both these theatres stem from the Moscow Art Theatre; one directly, the other indirectly.

BERLIN, Oct. 9. -- While other European nations are coming into line with newly devalued currencies or, having already devalued, are busy meeting the problems raised by the new alignment, Germany is still sticking, though somewhat unsteadily, to the present domestic parity of the reichsmark and to strict control of foreign exchange.

TENORS are as scarce as hen's teeth. That was Edward Johnson's conclusion after searching through Europe for additions to his company. He was especially interested in finding leading tenors for the Italian and French repertoire. "Even in Italy," Mr. Johnson said, "voices were not adequate."

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 10. -Enlargement of the psychological laboratory at the University of Rochester under the direction of Dr. Leonard Carmichael, new chairman of the psychology department, provides new facilities for research by both graduate and undergraduate students.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 10. -The University of Buffalo eleven rammed across four touchdowns while holding the University of Rochester to a lone safety in defeating the Yellow Jackets, 29-2, today.

Registration in the city for the November election topped the 2,900,000 mark, returns indicated at 3 o'clock this morning. The total figures will be about 570,000 above the 1932 record of 2,338,804, it was indicated.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- The financial emergency is a thing of the past, as far as the need for loans by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in distress cases is concerned, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the agency, declared today, adding that banks were in "fine condition" and the demand for loans by banks and business had dwindled until it was now very small.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Oct. 10. -More than 150,000 persons lined the streets of the Hungarian capital today when the body of Premier Julius Goemboes was carried from the Parliament Building, where it laid in state for twenty-four hours, to the cemetery.

Within two and a half months -- at the end of 1936 -- two treaties limiting naval armaments will expire, and with them will die, unless extended in the meantime, Article XIX of the Washington treaty of 1922, which for fourteen years has prevented the strengthening, and has maintained the status quo, of the fortifications and naval bases of the United States, Great Britain and Japan over a vast area of the Pacific.

Industrial nations, hoping to benefit from the re-shuffling of international markets which has followed the currency developments of recent weeks, are engaged in the keenest competitive struggle witnessed in foreign trade in years, exporters and importers agreed here yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10. -- Ray Buivid, the Guepe twins and Ray Sonnenberg put on their celebrated lateralforward passing act just about as advertised today and Marquette scampered over St. Louis, 32 to 6, before 10,000 spectators at Soldier Field.
KENT, Conn., Oct. 10. -- The Kent School football team opened its season today on Alumni Field, defeating the Loomis eleven, 24 -- 6. Losee scored all the Kent points.

MOSCOW, Oct. 10. -- The Tass, official Russian news agency, reported tonight that Germany had announced she would consider herself "free to act" should Russia denounce the Spanish non-intervention pact.

The "Colored Womanhood of the State of New York," at a meeting held at Republican State headquarters, 41 East Forty-second Street, last week, adopted resolutions denouncing the Roosevelt administration for "planning" or "permitting" discrimination against Negroes both in placement on WPA and ERB jobs and in administration of the Social Security Act which excludes from benefits under its Old Age Security provisions domestic, agricultural and casual workers.

The scheduled appearance of Governor Lehman at the Columbus Day celebration, to be held in Columbus Circle tomorrow morning under the auspices of the Sons of Italy and Il Progresso, Italian daily newspaper, will "only serve to advance the Fascist cause and not patriotism," Girolamo Valenti, editor of La Stampa Libera, Italian labor newspaper, and chairman of the Italian Anti-Fascist Committee, declared yesterday.

I have been a daily reader (including Sunday) of THE NEW YORK TIMES for many years. As a reader and an American citizen, I was pleased with your sound and dignified editorial endorsing the candidacy of Franklin D. Roosevelt.

Having invented a new motive for murder and a new method of destroying human life -- so far as we know, both are unique -- the author who calls himself Timothy Brace might have been expected to turn out something exceptional in the line of detective fiction.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 10. -Yale battered its way to a triumph by a single touchdown over the University of Pennsylvania eleven today. The warriors in blue thrilled a gathering of 17,000 fans who braved the low-hanging clouds by registering their second major conquest in as many games this season.

ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- Interest in this section centers on the annual fox hunt conducted by the Tri-State Fox Hunters Association, which will be held for three days beginning Wednesday afternoon at Andrews, near here. Fox hunters from three States have registered for the hunt, which will be preceded by a dog bench show on Wednesday.

Cardinal Pacelli, Papal Secretary of State, who arrived here from Italy on Thursday, spent yesterday visiting in New York City. He had luncheon with Cardinal Hayes and visited two Roman Catholic churches.

THIS slim volume is neither a formal biography of Selma Lagerlof, the first woman to win the Nobel Prize for Literature and to this day Sweden's most popular author, nor a critical evaluation of her work. Rather, it is a sentimental pilgrimage, a tribute to a writer who the age of 78 has found a place in the hearts of the people of many countries secure against the haggling of critics.

LIKE a mandarin's hat, lofty Purple Mountain is topped with a gleaming button -- the silver dome of Chinas National Observatory. Nanking, capital of the Republic of China lies at the base of this famous peak. A broad sweep of the wind-whipped waters of the treacherous Yangtse River marks the northern limits of the city.

JULIUS J. and Philip G. Epstein, who have come out of Hollywood with the hope of conquering Broadway with their first play, "And Stars Remain," in which Clifton Webb and Helen Gahagan will open the Theatre Guild's nineteenth season tomorrow night, look enough alike to be twins.

Mrs. Charles S. Whitman, wife of the former Republican Governor of New York, will speak on the same platform with Governor Lehman, in support of the Democratic ticket, at Valley Stream, L.I., on Tuesday, the Lehman-Bray Independent Citizens Committee announced yesterday.

Facing the title page of this book is the usual statement that all the characters in the book are fictitious and are intended to portray no one. After reading the book, it is impossible to take this statement without a liberal quantity of salt.

WITH each book it becomes clear that the immense popularity of Lloyd Douglas's novels among women readers does not depend upon his creative technique, though he writes easily enough. He develops his frankly inspirational plots, and their numerous ramifications, in a straight-forward though wordy manner, obviously interested first in expounding his doctrines, then in telling his story, and not at all in his words.

Some 1,560 students of New York University's twelve degree-conferring schools and colleges are receiving aid from the National Youth Administration, Dr. Harold H. Axworthy, director of the university Bureau of Community Service and Research, announced yesterday.

The strong Boys High School football team registered its second consecutive victory yesterday when it downed Samuel J. Tilden High, 28 -- 0, at Boys High Field in Brooklyn. The setback was the second straight for Tilden.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 9. -- With continuing indications, in the final campaign month, that Ohio's vote will be close in the Presidential fight the State is hearing mostly from a rival election attraction, the contest between Governor Martin L. Davey, Democrat, and Attorney General John W. Bricker, Republican, for the Governorship.

HAVING just completed a trip of more than 8,000 miles over them, this correspondent is in a position to state from first-hand observation that the vaunted transcontinental highways of America exist only in imagination.

THE sounds and odors of open-air markets are slowly being banished from the streets of New York and the city authorities look forward to the day when the pushcart as an institution will be extinct. Recently Commissioner Morgan of the Department of Public Markets, Weights and Measures announced plans for four new enclosed retail markets in Manhattan, which will provide stalls for about 900 food vendors.

"One of the most desirable medieval sculptures ever acquired" by the Metropolitan Museum of Art has been presented to that institution by Mr. and Mrs. Frederic B. Pratt and will be placed on exhibition this morning in the room of recent accessions.

IN any Presidential year the Governorship of the State of New York becomes a matter of national as well as of regional importance. A strong Gubernatorial candidate may not only carry his State but swing enough marginal votes to give his party the State's forty-seven ballots in the Electoral College.

GENEVA, Oct. 10. -- The seven-teenth League of Nations Assembly closed tonight, with Charles Spinasse of France sounding a hopeful note on the economic situation. He presented the three-power currency declaration as a step back toward gold.

Satisfaction with the manner in which motion-picture theatres of the city are living up to the ordinance requiring matrons and special children's sections was expressed yesterday by Mayor La Guardia after surprise visits to ninety-four theatres throughout the city made by him and other city officials Friday.

Permit me to commend most sincerely the editorial appearing in today's NEW YORK TIMES under the caption "A Reasoned Choice." It is, in my opinion, a highly intelligent diagnosis of the political and economic situation now before the American public.

Recent investigations concerning the growth cycles of trees and shrubs have shed much light on the question long discussed in horticultural circles of Fall versus Spring planting for this type of garden material. Extensive experiments carried on by several Eastern agricultural stations have demonstrated that many woody plants, especially the commoner shrubs, can be planted with equal success in either Fall or Spring, but that some individual species are best transplanted only in Spring.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- The discovery today of a young woman's body a few feet from the northbound tracks of the New York Central Railroad about a mile north of here presented a baffling case to the police who are attempting to determine whether the woman fell from a train or was pushed off.

The State Department of Labor has established a field laboratory in a granite quarry at Letchworth Village, Rockland County, for testing dust control equipment to be used in the silicosis prevention campaign, Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews announced yesterday.

The Commodity Corporation, a mutual trust organized a year ago to invest in commodities, reported yesterday that on Sept. 30 it had a liquidating value of $30.81 a share, against $27.96 on June 30, and $26.18 on Oct. 16, 1935, when initial investments were made.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 10. -Yale's Division of General Study, a distinct departure from the traditional graduate school work in the United States, has just begun its second year with enrollment doubled and with such varied occupational membership as an art critic, an orchestra leader, several museum workers and newspaper men.

ATLANTA, Oct. 10. -- Industrial activity continued at a brisk pace in the Sixth Federal District this week. Although rains in several leading centers of the area slowed trade somewhat, retail sales were maintained from 15 to 25 per cent greater than in the corresponding period a year ago.
READING, Pa., Oct. 10. -- The Albright Lions conquered Benny Friedman's City College of New York warriors, 31 to 0, on a slippery gridiron before more than 4,000 spectators today.

The oil barge Russell 23, of a new type representing the most revolutionary development in barge construction in many years, was launched yesterday afternoon at the foot of Columbia Street, Brooklyn, by the Russell Erie Basin Shipyards, Inc.

JEWISH communities throughout the world are awaiting with interest the development of Italian policies in Ethiopia, particularly the policies that will involve the future of the Falashas, or black Jews. This part of Ethiopia's population, numbering some 50,000, forms a distinct racial and religious unit and, as such, constitutes one of Italy's problems of administration within the borders of her recent conquest.

Wagner College went down to its second defeat yesterday, bowing to the Panzer eleven, 20 -- 0, at Wagner Field, Grymes Hill, S.I. Jerry Bonavita's 70-yard touchdown romp after intercepting a pass in the last quarter was the highlight of the game.

PARIS, Oct. 8. -- In her latest evening coiffures, Reboux is featuring gorgeous color combinations in the metallic greens and blues of a dragon fly's wings. She shows horseshoe-shaped feather diadems, or velvet bandeaux, trimmed with double sprays of bi-colored paradise or peacock feathers.

PARIS, Oct. 10. -- Covering their retreat with accusations against "Hitler's agents, in France," the French Communist party today backed down on its bold words of yesterday and yielded to the government's order that they limit to ten the propaganda meetings organized for tonight and tomorrow in Alsace and Lorraine.

BERLIN, Oct. 10. -- The Boerse resumed its upward movement today. Domestic stocks, which were in demand, rose 5 points and more. Foreign issues, however, dropped sharply, AKU declining 4 3/4 points and Chade 20 marks.

ALBANY, Oct. 10 (AP). -- A prediction of increased milk production in New York State was coupled today with a statement by an up-State dairy leader that producers shortly would "bear down" on the Republican governorship candidate, William F. Bleakley, for a statement on milk control.

EVEN those who prefer a factual portrait, however unlovely, to one touched up to imaginative handsomeness must concede the charm of this admirably brief romance built around a man concerning whom historians have written so voluminously.
TORONTO, Oct 10. -- More than five times as much in dividends is paid to United States investors in Canadian mining companies as to British investors here, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reports.
LANCASTER, Pa., Oct. 10 (AP). -The Franklin and Marshall football team scored a 13-0 victory over Richmond before a crowd of 2,500 on a muddy field today.

The formal opening of La Salle du Bois, 36 East Sixtieth Street, on Oct. 28 will aid the Stuyvesant Square Thrift Shop Association, an organization maintained for the benefit of various philanthropies. There will be divertissements by professional entertainers during the luncheon, tea and dinner hours, a generous percentage of the proceeds will be donated to the association.

There are more crooks than honest people in this story of a three-sided struggle for the possession of a marvelous collection of opals, the property of a senile Hungarian baron who intends to present them to a dancing girl in Paris. But before he is able to do that the opals are stolen and a man is murdered.

DUBLIN, Oct. 10. -- For the first time since he hopped off from New York, Kurt Bjorkvall stepped on land at Valentia, County Kerry, this morning. Looking fit and brown, jauntily sporting a white beret with a brown leather jacket and white canvas shoes, Mr. Bjorkvall confessed that his most urgent need of the moment was a bath and some civilized food.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- John B. Reynolds, Secretary of the Communications Commission, has replied to the criticisms of organizations which have condemned the action of the commission in investigating the alleged refusal of Station WCAE of Pittsburgh to broadcast a speech by Earl Browder, Communist candidate for President.

Claims for unpaid Federal taxes ordinarily take priority over the claims of all other creditors. Moreover, the amount of tax is a lien in favor of the United States upon all property and property rights belonging to the delinquent, both real and personal.

MADRID, Oct. 10. -- New charges that some signatories to the international non-intervention agreement were continuing to send war materials to the Spanish Rebels while all nations were withholding such aid from the government were made in the Madrid press today.

While weather conditions were not particularly helpful, retail trade in the metropolitan area maintained a fairly active pace last week. Department store sales were estimated as showing a slight increase over the comparative 1935 week. Tomorrow, Columbus Day, is expected to see the traditional early peak of Fall shopping, provided weather conditions are favorable.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 9. -- This week will mark intense political activity in Michigan. Governor Landon will enter the State Tuesday from Ohio to make a major address in Detroit and swing westward on Wednesday toward Chicago. President Roosevelt will enter Michigan Thursday from the West and in Detroit conclude a day of campaigning.

Anthony Fokker, airplane builder, declared last night that a contract with Elliott Roosevelt, son of the President, to aid in selling planes to Russia, was "an ordinary business deal" that had been "misinterpreted for purposes of political propaganda."

The impending investigation of Newark city affairs is the climax of a troubled municipal situation that has existed for more than a year and has been marked by grand jury investigations, trials of city officials and considerable bickering.

IT is some time now since a reviewer was moved to write, concerning a reference to the late Mr. Dillinger in one of Miss Boyle's earlier works, that a reference to Senator Borah in the New Testament could not be more astonishing.

BOLT: High school football players, practicing at Canton, Ohio, last week under the direction of two coaches, were struck by a bolt of lightning. One boy was killed and nine others and the coaches were injured.

With nearly six months left to go, the contractors at work grading the Flushing Meadows Park in Queens, preparing it as the site for the 1939 World's Fair, have completed more than one-third of their "cut-and-fill" operations, according to an announcement by Park Commissioner Robert Moses.

Asia's skies are thick with New York reporters winging their way around the world. Statesmen hitherto dedicated to isolationism hail the revival of traffic and trade among the nations. War clouds over the nations are thinner than they have been for some time; and people are willing to pay a price for peace.

MOSCOW, Oct. 9. -- A naval race now appears to be under way in the Baltic. This seems to be the only possible interpretation of the Soviet's declaration this week that it is a sea power and that it intends to win as dominant a position afloat as its strong Red Army gives it on land, and the almost simultaneous launching in Hitler's presence of a 26,000-ton warship, apparently intended for service in the Baltic.

IT is difficult for the industry to appraise its product in advance of release. The history of the town is full of notations on "sleepers," those films made without fanfare and hope, which, to the astonishment of the studios, are hailed by the public as milestones.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 10. -- Various women's organizations are organizing two peace conferences to be held here on the eve of the Pan-American peace conference proposed by President Roosevelt. Both conferences expect to present their resolutions to the official conference in December as expressions of public opinion of the American nations toward peace.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 10 (AP). -- Two youngsters, Gordon Robinson and John Foreman of the University of North Carolina, came within two points today of upsetting the veteran David Jones and J. Gilbert Hall in the doubles play of the Greenbrier tennis tournament.

IF you are interested in wild animals, this is your book. Photography has very largely superseded big game hunting in recent years, says Mr. Jearey, as a "means of contact between man and the wild." He modestly refrains from emphasizing the importance of his own work and influence in that forward step of civilization; but his book speaks for itself.

THIS is the chronicle of a comedian who, after clowning on the fringe of hitdom's Elysian fields for many years, arrives with a vengeance -- and a nostalgia for Coney Island -- in the community's newest musical success.

IS France heading along the road toward civil war between the "Whites" and the "Reds" that Spain has traversed? Or will she, out of the devaluation of her money, win a new prosperity in the way the United States and England have done?

Another regular reader of THE TIMES expresses herewith his appreciation of your fairness to both sides in the present political controversy. One suspects that you are a careful student of history and do not give too much credit for recovery or too much blame for depression to the "reigning" party.

Conditions of overcrowding in the Tombs seem to be worse than ever, and that is saying a good deal. The official capacity of the prison is 555. Within the last few days its actual population has run as high as 915, according to the Prison Association. It is inclined to blame the judges of the criminal courts for the congestion; they insist it is not their fault.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 10 (AP). -The Boilermakers of Purdue battered their way to a 35-to-14 victory over Wisconsin today before 18,000 home-comers and on a gridiron made slippery by a rain which alternated between a drizzle and a driving downpour.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 10. -- Virginia Polytechnic Institute scored twice in the third quarter to conquer the William and Mary Indians today, 14 -- 0, before 9,000 spectators. It was the twenty-third renewal of their gridiron classic.

INTERESTING on several counts is the exhibition of German art from the fifteenth century to the twentieth, which opened last week at the Pennsylvania Museum in Philadelphia and will later travel about the country. This exhibition, composed altogether of material lent by museums in Germany, was organized under the auspices of the Oberlaender Trust, Carl Schurz Memorial Foundation, Inc.

As a reader of your excellent paper, I wish to congratulate you upon your decision to support the great and gallant Roosevelt for re-election. Millions of people will welcome your decision, which is certain to have a far-reaching effect. Mr. Roosevelt should be re-elected, and he is going to be, notwithstanding all the hatched-up unfair opposition.

IT was predicted by Mr. E.R. Bowen, secretary of the Coop erative League of the United State of America, to this reviewer two months ago that Horace Kallen of the New School for Social Research soon would be out with a book which might be to consumer cooperation what Karl Marx's "Das Kapital" is to communism.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 10 (AP). -- A powerful and experienced Auburn football machine, stalled by dogged Tennessee Volunteers until the closing moments of the game, uncorked a dazzling run-and-pass combination and thrust over a score in the fourth period to win, 6 and 0.
Mrs. Byron C. Foy has accepted the chairmanship of a professional women's committee to assist in the campaign for $250,000 begun last week by the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service.

The reciprocal trade policy of the Roosevelt administration has equipped the United States with an effective tariff bargaining implement and has brought the country into "realistic" trade relationship with other nations, according to an article in the current issue of The Foreign Trader, published yesterday.

Hungary today has one-third the territory it possessed before the World War. Few realize that it is one of the focal points of European diplomacy. When there is discussion of the Danubian pact, the attitude of Hungary must be known. When there is mention of the growth of fascism in Europe, the position and leanings of Hungary must he considered.

Though the donkey may seem to crass humans an inherently comic creature the business of being a burro is a serious matter. Young Carlos, little gray son of Pablo and Chiquita, found it and so, and down among the Sierra Madre Mountains of Mexico he received a thorough schooling in the arts and accomplishments expected of a burro.

J.W.N. SULLIVAN'S fine study, "Beethoven: His Spiritual Development," is so keen and cognitive an exposition of the master's inner illumination that it seems incredible that, since its publication in 1927, only a comparatively few copies of the American edition have been sold.

ACCORDING to a letter received by Coward-McCann from Eugene Gay-Tifft, who is translating Knut Hamsun's new book, to be published next Spring, the distinguished Norwegian novelist has, so far as the theme of his book is concerned, abandoned the peasantry, which he portrayed so skillfully in "Growth of the Soil" and other novels, and has gone in for modern, sophisticated city life.

LIBERTY, Neb., Oct. 10 (AP). -- Carried by two sturdy feet and a well-arched thumb, Charles Vogt Jr. of Liberty, 28-year-old candidate for the Legislature, pressed forward today in his house-to-house campaign of two Nebraska counties.

If an award were given for the most sincere and non-partisan consideration of the issues in the current Presidential campaign -- no more worthy recipient could be chosen than THE TIMES for its editorial, "A Reasoned Choice." Endeavoring to continue in the same non-partisan vein, I propose to show that you could have extended the editorial, further justifying your choice of Mr. Roosevelt.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 10. -- Supreme Court Justice Charles W. Parker ordered a sweeping court investigation of Newark's municipal government today after hearing arguments on a series of 134 specific charges of malfeasance and other illegal acts on the part of the five city commissioners, filed by a taxpayers' group headed by Charles Becker, a lawyer.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- Engrossing the attention of Cornell University's 6,000 students is a movement for the organization of all non-fraternity men as the Cornell Independent Association. Plans developed during the Summer reached their fruition this week at a mass meeting at which several hundred students adopted a constitution and a six-point program.

Five amateur sleuths, guided more or less by Septimus Dodds, who is a detective by profession but not connected with the police, take on the task of discovering who killed Hedley Whitworth, whose demise is unanimously un-regretted.
Educators will gather at Antioch College in Yellow Springs, Ohio, Friday and Saturday to honor the memory of the father of America's public school system -- Horace Mann.

Fifty-four new community libraries have been started this year in rural New York by boys and girls in their late teens and early twenties employed by the National Youth Administration. Up in the Colorado mountains, down in the byways of Mississippi, at crossroads in Pennsylvania and Illinois, dozens of similar libraries are being established largely through the efforts of this army of new young library workers, 500 of whom are being used in Mississippi alone.

In a speech at a dinner of the Bronx Chamber of Commerce last night at the Concourse Plaza Hotel, Mayor La Guardia said that he would support President Roosevelt for re-election, but added that he would not vote a straight ticket.
HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 10. -- Dr. Ernest Martin Hopkins passed the twentieth milestone of his presidency of Dartmouth College this week, rounding out one of the longest such tenures in the country.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 10. -- Villanova remained undefeated today by flashing a powerful running attack that stopped Penn State, 13 -- 0, before 13,000 fans. Andy Stopper, Wildcat halfback, scored both touchdowns.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- Colgate's Red Raiders conquered the St. Lawrence eleven today, 26 -- 6, with Coach Andy Kerr using many substitutes, to save the regular for the game against Tulane in New York next Saturday.

A YOUNG South African, Daniel P. Brimble of Cape Town, is attempting to scale Africa's highest peak, Mount Kilimanjaro, thus repeating the remarkable performance of Dr. Ludwig Krapf, who discovered the 20,000-foot snow-clad summit in 1848.

MOSCOW, Oct. 10. -- Additional evidence of the improvement in Soviet-Japanese relations was given this evening when representatives of the Commissariat of Heavy Industry signed with representatives of the Japanese oil concession operating in the Soviet's half of Sakhalin Island an agreement extending Japanese rights of oil prospecting for five more years.

HOLLYWOOD. SINCE the screen assumed the aspect of culture and "Pony Boy" on a player piano in the nickelodeon gave way to Tchaikovsky on the sound track, music has become an elemental part of film manufacture.

WITH the production of "St. Helena" last Tuesday evening in the cozily redecorated Lyceum the serious work of the drama season has properly begun. At any rate, the Max Gordon season has begun, and creditably, too, for the play is an earnest portrait of Napoleon's last years, and the stage work represents superior craftsmanship.

In announcing your support of Mr. Roosevelt, you state your belief that he will make his second administration, if he gets it, more conservative than his first, because of the pressure of public opinion. I have no doubt that Mr. Roosevelt will do whatever he believes will be popular in terms of votes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP). -- Estimating that the government spent $585,000,000 for relief between July 1 and Sept. 30, the Chamber of Commerce of the United States today said that this was 30 per cent more than in the same period last year.

Robert Van Gelder, in reviewing John Dos Passos's novel, "The Big Money," some time ago, ended his article with these words: "Readers are particularly urged to give full attention to the biographical sketches. Those on Taylor and Veblen are exceptionally well done."

LONDON. AT Sound City, on the banks of the Thames, they are filming "The Mill on the Floss." An old mill, with bent gables and weathered walls, looking as if it had withstood centuries of the English climate, stands on the river bank.

Harts Island, City Island, the East Bronx and the surrounding waters were searched vainly by squads of police last night when a check-up at 8 o'clock in the Reformatory Prison on Harts Island disclosed that a prisoner had disappeared after he had had supper.

EVERY one even remotely interested seems to have known for months that Arturo Toscanini left behind a recording of Beethoven's Seventh symphony, and that it was next for release has apparently been an open secret since the Wagner album saw the light.

Rolling up 33 points in the first half, the Grover Cleveland High School eleven trounced a hapless Brooklyn College junior varsity squad, 45 -- 0, before 3,000 fans at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, yesterday.

SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 9. -- Officials of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints, who five months ago began a campaign in organized stakes of the church to remove all Mormons from direct relief rolls of governmental agencies, now plan to expand the program to embrace the church membership throughout the world.
AS a contribution toward the solution of some Atlantic air service problems, a correspondent, Walter J. Harris of New York, writes to this department as follows:
The John Adams High School eleven subdued Brooklyn Prep by 7 to 0 before 3,000 persons at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 10. -- The steamer North Wind, chartered by Pan American Airways as a supply ship, has sailed on a three-month cruise to complete the string of bases and accommodations began about eighteen months ago by the steamer North Haven.

DURHAM, N.C., Oct. 10 (AP). -Duke's dashing Blue Devils, varying power plays with deceptive performances, slid through deep mud to a decisive 25-to-0 victory over a fighting Clemson team today before 5,000 fans. It was the Southern Conference champions' fourth straight victory.
