Bainbridge Colby, former Secretary of State, accused President Roosevelt of breach of faith on two counts in an address last night over Station WJZ and a nation-wide NBC network. The talk was sponsored by the National Jeffersonian Democrats.

WOODBURY, L.I., Oct. 10. -Colonel and Mrs. Francis L. Robbins were hosts tonight at Ben Robyn Farm, their country home in the West Hills colony, to 400 members of society of Huntington, Cold Spring Harbor, Oyster Bay and the North Shore colonies in and around Glen Cove and the Westburys, at the annual West Hills race ball in aid of the North Shore Holiday House.
WAKE ISLAND, Sunday, Oct. 11. -- The China Clipper, on her way from San Francisco to Manila, alighted today on the lagoon here, 1,200 miles from Midway Island and still 3,000 miles from Manila.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 10. -- Anthony Pelleteri's Bottle Cap, a son of Bostonian, proved best over a sticky track today to win the twenty-fifth running of the Richard Johnson Handicap, feature of the program at Laurel.
When a woman wants to go into the political field and work for a party I suggest to her that she arrive at her conclusions on the basis of fact.

MONTREAL, Oct. 10. -- Newsprint and pulp manufacturing plants in the Province of Quebec have been permitted to grow through the use of crown forests at such a rate as to encourage overproduction and the provincial government intends to put a halt to such overextension, Premier Maurice Duplessis announced yesterday after a Cabinet meeting in Quebec City.

SPOTTY reports were again heard from trade centers last week, although the peak buying period of the season has been reached. Weather conditions were blamed once more, warm temperatures persisting in many sections.

Scientific teaching methods over a period of only five months have produced normal pupils out of a former group of slow learners at the Speyer School, the experimental units started last Feburary by the Board of Education and Teachers College, Columbia.

Thoughtfully issued at the time when gardeners are lovingly patting down the earth over next Spring's bulbs this story begins in September with Peter and Penny's first steps in garden-making. City-bred, the children didn't know, when they first moved to the country, that they could start a garden in the Fall, but under Grandfather's wise direction they were soon setting out perennial plants and bulbs.

The usual week-end accumulation of Southern hedge-selling orders and an absence of outside buying interest in advance of the two-day holiday caused cotton prices to ease further yesterday on the Cotton Exchange. Final quotations showed net declines of 6 to 10 points with the December and January positions at the lowest levels since early September.

RADIO program directors continue to add new acts to their schedules, and it will probably be mid-November before the nation-wide show settles down to the usual Winter routine. Broadcasting will be more or less unsettled until after election day, but after that time radio's crowded hours will adhere closer to a fixed formula, although, of course, special events will be given time on the air.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 (AP). -- Cardarrone, owned by Jack Newman of Chicago, captured the Marquette Handicap at Lincoln Fields today as the twenty-eight-day meeting came to an end. Cardarrone, extreme outsider at 33 to 1 in the field of eight, scored by two and a half lengths over Countess Ann, with Bandalore third.

Collections of real estate taxes for the second half of 1936, up to the close of business yesterday, were more than $9,000,000 ahead of the total collected by the same date in 1935 although the levy for this half year is about $8,000,000 less than the 1935 assessment.

Upward of 500,000 boys and girls in the city's public and parochial schools are expected to compete in the 1936 prize essay contest now being held under the sponsorship of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York in cooperation with the Board of Education, the chamber has announced. The subject of this year's essay is "The Opportunities That This Country Affords to Make Good."
SWARTHMORE, Pa., Oct. 10. -Scoring early in the first quarter, the Swarthmore College eleven won its first game of the season over Union, 7 -- 0, this afternoon on the victor's field.

Mayor La Guardia will address two large mass meetings under sponsorship of the American Labor party in its campaign for the reelection of President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman. He will speak at a rally in Madison Square Garden the night of Oct. 27 and at a gathering in Convention Hall in Rochester the night of Oct. 29.

ATLANTIC City, Oct. 10. -- With 150,000 feet of floor space in the municipal convention hall set up with equipment valued at $1,500,000, the ninth annual Dairy Industries Exposition will open here Monday.

The remarkable increase in rock gardening in America has brought to many flower lovers a new opportunity to become acquainted with the merits and the peculiar charm of many of the "little bulbs" for early Spring bloom -- dainty but charming flowers not grown before or seen to disadvantage in competition with more vigorous plants, or mud-spattered by driving rains.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 10. -- Creation in the laboratory from dead matter of a substance that behaves in the manner of the wall which surrounds the living cells of man and animal was reported here today before the Mark Hopkins centenary at Williams College by Dr. Irving Langmuir, Nobel Prize winner in chemistry and associate director of the General Electric Company's research laboratories.

Newtown High School's cross-country runners captured two group runs yesterday while Curtis High won the other in the final series of conditioning races before the start of the championship season at Van Cortlandt Park. Next Saturday the Manhattan College interscholastic run will be held.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Oct. 10 (AP). -The University of Oregon's Webfeet and Stanford's Indians battled to a 7-to-7 tie today in a Pacific Coast Conference football game distinguished by many intercepted passes and blocked punts before 18,000 fans.

Few plants in the entire range of garden material offer such a wide range of usefulness as the familiar daffodil or narcissus. With the greater range of color and form now obtainable in the new varieties, the possible service of this fine flower is still further extended.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Broadening its offensive against counterfeiters, the Treasury has called a group of Secret Service agents to Washington to attend a new government school. About 200 agents will take the course, in successive groups.

ON crisp Autumn days the hobbyist who loves the outdoors gathers bouquets of twigs, berries, dried seed-pods of weeds from meadows and gardens or marsh rosemary from the beaches. From them, with the aid of cement-dipped wet newspaper and ink, he creates attractive dish arrangements.

CALCUTTA, India, Oct. 10. -- After spending ten days traveling from Times Square over the ocean, Europe and Africa, thence to the Arabian Desert in four days over the richest land in India, I arrived here tonight.

AS a literary figure and as a man, Sherwood Anderson has felt the rough and tumble of the big, noisy, growing America about which he has written so ardently for two decades. He has seen his books destroyed by the witch-burners and cherished wherever civilization has made the mildest inroad, his reputation cried up and howled down with a vehemence reserved only for the great of the earth or political candidates.
COLLEGEVILLE, Pa., Oct. 10. -- The Ursinus Bears defeated the Red Devils of Dickinson in the opening game of the Eeastern Pennsylvania Collegiate Conference today, 7 -- 0.

Wendell L. Willkie, president of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, believes that President Roosevelt's summoning of a southeastern power pool conference at the White House on Sept. 30 was an act of political statesmanship calling for an equal degree of business statesmanship on his part, as representative of the largest group of public utility companies which operate in the Southeastern States.

THE National Book Council certainly lacks neither vigor nor initiative. It devised, for instance, the "book-tokens" scheme, which has become increasingly popular year by year, especially at the Christmas season. Its latest enterprise is, perhaps, the boldest; namely, the construction of a documentary film with the object of stimulating public interest in books.

The number of buyers in the wholesale market here increased last week over the week previous, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. Mail orders slackened in some departments.

DURING the week beginning today Lynchburg, in Virginia's historic belt, will celebrate its 150th anniversary, taking this occasion to show visitors its shrines and natural beauty. With costumes depicting varied epochs in the history of the city, so closely bound up with that of the State, more than 1,000 persons will take part in pageants and dramatic presentations making vivid the changing ways of life from the days of long ago to the present.

The audience in the Times Square Theatre, a second-run motion-picture house at 215 West Forty-second Street, a short distance west of Broadway, was routed at 9:30 o'clock last night by the noxious fumes of a gas believed by the police to be home-made tear gas.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- Baldwin Wallace's highly touted aerial circus from the Ohio Conference lived up to its reputation today by passing and running Syracuse into submission, 19 to 7.

FREYA STARK is the only European woman who has ever traveled alone into the interior of Southern Arabia. Only two other European women have ever been there at all; and in those strange high-piled palaces, white skyscrapers of the desert, where she talked with the close-sheltered inmates of the harem, she was the only foreign woman that they had ever seen.

Price changes generally were small and erratic in the markets for commodity futures here in the week ended on Friday, with strength in cocoa and coffee futures, which led in the trading. In the cash markets, cotton, coffee, butter and tin eased, while all grains, flour, lard, eggs, wool tops, cocoa, silk and rubber advanced.
LIGONIER, Pa., Oct. 10. -- Running at a furious clip over the exacting three and one-half-mile brush course, Eastern Shore, with J.D.H.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 10. -- Calling the Robinson-Patman anti-price discrimination law a "golden rule" for business, Representative Wright Patman today voiced confidence in the constitutionality of the legislation and assured members of the Association of National Advertisers that he will be prompt to remedy any injustice caused by the law.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Oct. 10. -- The new academic year at Bryn Mawr College has brought a significant development in the graduate school, the establishment of a definite basis of a new plan for the exchange of students between Bryn Mawr and universities and colleges in France, Spain, Italy and Germany.

CAMP VERDE, Ariz., Oct. 10 (AP). The Indians of this small Apache community which for several decades was ruled by the venerable Major Smiley, famed army scout and capturer of Geronimo, prayed to the gods today for his safe deliverance to the happy hunting grounds.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 10. -George Dixon of the National Golf links of Southampton, who was runner up in the French amateur in 1933 and his son-in-law, Stuart Scheftel of Sands Point, winner of the boys golf championship of England in 1928, collaborated in producing a par 70 to top a qualifying field of thirty-nine teams in the invitation best ball tournament at the Meadow Brook Club today.

RICHMOND, Oct. 10. -- Retail trade in the Fifth District in September was only 7 per cent higher than that month a year ago, compared with the national gain of 14 per cent. This was due, it was pointed out by the Richmond Bank, to a district gain of 14 per cent for the 1935 month over the previous year, while the national average was only 11 per cent.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 9. -- Dr. Francis E. Townsend's declaration for Governor Landon on Wednesday was a good deal of a dud in California, where the doctor's personal dislike of President Roosevelt was well known.
IN the campaign talk of the Middle West this year the traveler listens almost in vain for unflattering allusions to New York City. It was not thus of old.

The political debate which has been in progress since the national conventions has clarified some of the issues now before the country, but on certain major points the position of the two principal parties and their candidates remains obscure. Does any one know, three weeks before the election, what formula for relief of unemployment the Republican party would propose in the event of its return to power?

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Oct. 10. -Southern California, led by a dynamic quarterback, 165-pound David Davis, mauled Illinois, 24 to 6, today before 33,000 spectators who sat beneath a dreary sky and in a dripping rain to witness the inter-sectional contest.

WARSAW, Oct. 9. -- In Geneva the League of Nations Council has put off until the January session the final decision on the Danzig question and the appointment of a new high commissioner in succession to Sean Lester. In Danzig mass arrests of Socialists continue and violent anti-League speeches are made by the Senate president and other dignitaries.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 10. -- Michael Gordon, 33-year-old sign painter of Piscatawaytown, and six youngsters of his neighborhood picketed an intersection this afternoon on the suepr-highway near here in protest against the fatal injury of Gordon's aged father, who was struck by an automobile at the intersection last Sunday.

THE heading of next to the last chapter of this book is "Newspaper Men Can Do Anything," and no one reading to that point would doubt it. No one, moreover, would stop short of the last page, so of Mr. Vaughn's own omnipotence there can be no question.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., Oct. 10. -With a margin of 1 hour, 16 minutes and 44 seconds, W.H. Wheeler Jr.'s Class Q sloop Cotton Blossom won the New Rochelle Yacht Club's closing race of the season.

The foreign exchanges continued steady and quiet yesterday, with the pound sterling up 1/4 cent to $4.90 7/8 and the French franc down 1-16 point to 4.66 15-16 cents. Compared with a week ago the pound was off 2 1/4 cents and the franc 1/4 point.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10. -- Drexel defeated Susquehanna University, 19 -- 12, in a hard-fought game today.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 10. -- In immediate reply today to Governor Landon's budget speech in Chicago last night, President Roosevelt improvised a parable of a man who borrowed $800 with which to increase his annual income by $2,000.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- Many visitors are expected in the Poconos to take part in the opening of the foliage festival, which will be observed throughout this week. Most of the hotels have had large advance bookings for the Columbus Day week-end and have made special preparations to accommodate big crowds.

With election day less than a month away, the financial markets have shown no disposition to become "jittery" concerning the outcome. On the contrary, confidence in the post-election trend of business and of the markets is being reflected day by day in higher security prices and in steadily expanding volume of trading on the Stock Exchange.

Completing the required mechanical changes ahead of schedule, all of the traffic lights below Fifty-ninth Street on north-south avenues of Manhattan, with only a few stretches excepted, were changed yesterday to the new and quicker time cycle in an effort to achieve a faster flow of east-west traffic.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 10 (AP). -- William F. Bleakley, the Republican candidate for Governor, struck out again tonight at what he termed "politics" in relief, charging the Democratic administration with "planning and cleverly executing a campaign to use WPA funds to buy New Deal votes."

MORE than century ago, before London had its night police, the streets of Clapham and Lambeth were patrolled by night watchmen whose headquarters were in snug little watchboxes along the roads. One after another the watchboxes have disappeared until only one remains.

IN the course of the delivery of his message on the budget in the House of Commons last year, Mr. Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the British Exchequer, turned aside for a moment from questions immediately affecting the balanced budget to look with "considerable apprehension" upon the imbalance of population figures in the British Empire.

Foreign traders have come to the defense of Secretary Daniel C. Roper and the Department of Commerce in the interpretation placed upon this country's balance of trade for the first six months of this year. They characterized the statement of Francis P. Garvan, president of the Chemical Foundation, Inc., criticizing the Secretary and his department, as "an obvious campaign document."

All last week the Rebel armies in Spain forged their ring ever more tightly around Madrid, battering down the Loyalist defenses. While the military factions fought out the issue with steel and bomb and rifle fire, the diplomats of Fascist and Communist Europe, gathered in London, waged a wordy duel over the question of foreign intervention.
TROY, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- The Rensselaer Poly Tech football team scored its second victory of the season by defeating Brooklyn College, 19 -- 6, today.
LONDON NOT only is the Royal Air Force being increased in strength, but its officers and men now appear in new uniforms.

Those "Hell's Kitchen Artists" -thirty-nine of them who, while unemployed more than a year ago scrubbed floors, washed windows and became house painters to set up their own "studio" in a machine shop two blocks west of Tenth Avenue in preference to going on relief --are going to run a cut-rate sale this week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Fulvio Suvich, the new Italian Ambassador, said today after conferring with Secretary Hull that one of his first tasks will be to discuss the resumption of negotiations for an Italo-American reciprocal trade agreement.

ROME, Oct. 10 (AP). -- Charges by the Italian Ambassador, Dino Grandi, that Great Britain "completely ignored" non-intervention committee rules in leveling accusations of neutrality violations at the London conference were revealed here tonight with the publication of Mr. Grandi's speech.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Contrary to seasonal trends, residential mortgages accepted for insurance by the Federal Housing Administration on new construction during September showed a rise of 147.8 per cent over the same month last year and 5.1 per cent over August, 1936, Deputy Administrator William D. Flanders reported today.

LONDON, Sept. 25. MISS LESLEY STORM, the author of "Follow Your Saint," presented at the Queen's Theatre last night, gets some mighty fine dramatic effects, but watching her get them, the impression deepens that we are playing cards with some one who follows a set of rules slightly but definitely different from that established by customary practice.

It is not alone the thrill of stalking big game, the exhilaration and physical well-being that comes with roughing it in the vast silences, that induces men to pack in to the big woods. Bagging the trophy stands as the main goal, but there is always a sense of adventure in experiencing the strange sights and sounds peculiar to the wilderness.

PARIS, Oct. 9. -- Premier Leon Blum's government has survived the devaluation of the franc and has adjourned Parliament until some time toward the middle of next month. It has survived, too, Colonel Francois de la Rocque's effort last Sunday to "prevent a revolution."
AMHERST, Oct. 10. -- After nearly three years of intermittent construction effort, the new women's athletic field at Massachusetts State College has been completed and will be dedicated Oct. 23.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 10. -Foreign drivers continued to be the big threat in the 300-mile Vanderbitl Cup race which will be held on Monday as automobile pilots almost cluttered up the Roosevelt Raceway today in a rush to qualify for the contest.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 10. -Mrs. E. Parmalee Prentice has 150 guests this afternoon at Mount Hope Farm, Williamstown, for her fifth musicale of the season. Archer Gibson was the organist. As Mrs. Prentice is a convalescent from a recent appendicitis operation, Colonel Prentice welcomed their friends.

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- Next week's openings are these: On Sunday the Embassy's Sunday night group is staging "Expedition" by the late T.P. Saville, with William Devlin in the cast. Tuesday the Queens will see Helen Jerome's dramatization of "Jane Eyre," with Curigwen Lewis in the title role.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- Members of the Artists and Writers Golf Association, New York, will bring their golf clubs this week to participate in their annual frolic at Greenbrier in White Sulphur Springs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- The cries of "Roosevelt luck" and the Democratic jubilation over the monetary agreement among this country, Great Britain and France have been followed by more sober thoughts in administration circles as President Roosevelt's experts have begun to reflect upon its possible effects on the internal economy of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Encouraged by the success of the Hindenburg's round-trip flights to the United States and assured of "sympathetic treatment" in the coming session of the new Congress, J. Monroe Johnson, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, is preparing an amendment to the 1936 Maritime Act to encourage the development and construction of lighter-than-air ships by American companies.

FOR some reason -- possibly because the committee of award are unable to agree upon each other's first choices and settle down in the end to a good safe second choice -- prize novels in general are apt to be excellent as far as technical performance goes, and rather mediocre and lifeless otherwise.

Only about one-fourth of the book is needed to carry the narrative through 1823, the Monroe Doctrine year, and only about as much more for the period from that date until the end of the war with Spain.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- The cornerstone of Williamsburg Houses, in Brooklyn, largest of the Public Work Administration's fifty low-rent housing projects, will be laid next Wednesday, it was announced here today. The project, when completed, is to house 1,463 low-income families, with park space, playgrounds and a new public school provided by the City of New York.

AS election day approaches, even the nation's parlor games are taking on a political aspect. Boondoggling, that controversial topic among both politicians and lexicographers, is the latest issue to invade the family game room.

In 1933 and 1934 our legislators at Washington and Albany, pressed for new revenues, boosted substantially the taxes on estates. Thereupon Jesse I. Straus, then Ambassador to France, prominent merchant and philanthropist, attached a codicil to his will, which was made public last week after his death on Sunday from pneumonia.

Convinced that it has worked out a system for extra compensation which is compatible with the dignity of labor and devoid of any elements of patronage, the National Brewing Company of Baltimore yesterday made public details of a "labor dividend" plan for its 200 employes.

Mrs. Vincent Astor since her recent return from Europe has been supervising arrangements for several functions planned in behalf of the Musicians Emergency Fund, one of these events being the gala dinner dance and entertainment on Wednesday at the St. Regis, opening the new Iridium Room for the season.

THE French style of interior decoration, interpreted with individuality and restraint, is in favor this season. As rendered in exhibition rooms and in private homes, this important mode no longer suggests the ornate luxury of the Palace of Versailles but follows the more subdued decoration of Parisian houses and French country chateaus.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 10. --Capitalizing on a majority of its breaks, Harvard's football team gained a 28-to-0 victory over Brown before 12,000 spectators today at the Harvard Stadium.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 10. -- Western Maryland turned back Providence College, 13 -- 6, in a hard-fought game today and remained in the undefeated class. A blocked punt accounted for the invaders' first tally and a 35-yard run late in the final quarter by Sadowski netted the second with less than a minute to play.

SALEM, N.H., Oct. 10 (AP). -- Watersplash, sporting the silks of Childs and Walker under a feathery impost of 92 pounds, captured the White Mountain handicap by three lengths before 15,000 persons at Rockingham Park today.

Thirty-one more names were added last week to the authors who will appear on the auditorium programs at THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair to be held at Rockefeller Center from Nov. 5 through the 19th. These acquisitions brought the latest total to fifty-nine, most of whom will speak afternoons or evenings and all of whom will be seen and heard in at least a word of greeting.
THE new season will be officially opened with the series of four performances by the Jooss European Ballet at the Alvin Theatre on Saturday and Sunday.

A young woman and her escort, who had attended the Strand Theatre at Forty-seventh Street and Broadway, fell from their seats on the mezzanine floor to the orchestra early today, injuring themselves and two persons on whom they landed.

To prove that there might be thousands more on the dole if men didn't prefer to work at almost anything, a curious investigator recently compiled a list of the obsolete, whimsical, unheard of avocations followed in London. Among them were dozens of purveyors of long-antiquated goods and services to the Royal Family, candle-snuffers, snuff-makers, wool-gatherers, tasters.

CORDELL HULL, Secretary of State, advocate of international trade, took the recent "gentlemen's agreement" for the steadying of currencies as but part of the day's work. While other officials praised highly what had been done, he remained strangely unperturbed. It was not that the agreement displeased him, but that he had been convinced all along that such a step would ultimately be taken.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Distilled liquor withdrawals from bonded warehouses, considered to represent consumption, amounted to 110,631,778 tax gallons in the fiscal year ending June 30, 1936, the highest figure since 1917, when cellars were stocked in anticipation of national prohibition.

BUENOS ARIES, Oct. 9. -- The conflict between Bolivia and Paraguay exploded again this week and South American diplomatic circles reluctantly admit their uneasiness regarding the final outcome. President Toro at La Paz announced that Bolivia would not participate in any further peace negotiations until Paraguay relinquished its present military positions straddling Bolivia's mainline road between Villa Montes and Santa Cruz de la Sierra.

Carrying out a program of expansion, the Childs Company has leased for twenty years large store and basement space in the seventeen-story building at the southeast corner of Seventh Avenue and Forty-ninth Street. The lessor is the 727 Seventh Avenue Realty Company.

THIS volume is the first step toward meeting the long-felt need for good translations of the classics into modern English. These two young poets give us a highly readable version of one of the great dramatic classics of all time, of the play which is generally considered Euripedes's best.

THAT "one man's meat is another man's poison" is a saying peculiarly applicable to some books. "The Heart Awakes" is one of these. It may well be calculated to send the right reader into raptures; it is quite certain to make the wrong reader swear.

Sinking fund operations which involved small lots of bonds, particularly those of municipalities, featured the announcements last week of bonds called for redemption before maturity. The volume of retirements was smaller than in the preceding week and confined mostly to the industrial, municipal and public utility groups.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- A sharp rise in stock prices, an upturn from the September low level in automobile production and a further gain in steel ingot production featured domestic business in the week ended .on Oct. 3, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey.

Whatever aspirations the loyal corporal's guard in the Maedic camp had for that son of Bostonian to become juvenile champion received a severe jolt at Jamaica yesterday when 15,000 saw the Maemere Farm color bearer finish out of the money back of Clodion, Night Bud and Dogaway, which crossed the line as named in the Remsen Handicap.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- A report proposed today for adoption by the Interstate Commerce Commission recommended denial of the application of the Keeshin interests, who are one of the dominant factors in the trucking field, to acquire control of the Seaboard Freight Lines, Inc., and its subsidiaries.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Oct. 10. -- A cell-mate of Charles Harris today linked him and Emerson Jennings,a Wilkes-Barre civic leader, with the bombing of the automobile of Judge W.A. Valentine during the insurgent strike at collieries of the Glen Alden Coal Company last year.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 9. -- With power from Boulder Dam, 270 miles away across desert and over mountains, now flowing into the transmission lines of the Los Angeles Municipal Bureau of Power and Light, this city has practical evidence at long last of a big job completed.

Through action by the executive board of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, resumption of the five scholarships formerly sponsored by the organization will be submitted to the Fall convention next week, after a lapse of three years.

IVAN DZERZHINSKY is at work on a second opera based on a Sholokhoff novel. The first was "And Quiet Flows the Don," which aroused favorable comment in the Soviet last season. The new work, which the composer declares follows the same trend as its predecessor, has a plot founded on that of Sholokhoff's "Seeds of Tomorrow."

The "Night in Poland" Ball, annual festival of the Kosciuszko Foundation, will be held on the night of Feb. 3 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The function, marking the eleventh anniversary of the foundation, which was named in memory of General Thaddeus Kosciuszko, Polish patriot and a hero of the American Revolution, will be featured by a colorful pageant of fourteenth century Poland and the coronation of Queen Jadwiga.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 10. -By the exclusive and convincing use of old-fashioned football Pittsburgh's Panthers overpowered Ohio State today, 6 to 0, and took the high road leading toward national championship heights.

Prosperity, in the form of new streams of eager students, has unquestionably returned to the colleges of this country from coast to coast. Rising moderately in the East, this Fall's swelling student tide has become a flood beyond the Alleghanies, carrying enrollment records to new high levels from Ohio to Oregon, according to a survey made by THE TIMES of more than 100 colleges and private schools throughout the nation.

CALVIN COOLIDGE was an "over-conservative and notably economical man," as we all know, but he had one consuming extravagance: his wife's clothes. He never wanted her to wear the same gown twice to a State reception, and "the handsomer and more elaborate Mrs. Coolidge's dresses were, the better he liked them."

THIS is the story of the Jewish resettlement both urban and rural in Palestine, as Dorothy Ruth Kahn has seen it. The word "story" is used advisedly in the above sentence; for Miss Kahn not only presents her impressions in narrative form; she writes with the concentrated human interest, the vivid personal awareness, that make a novel good.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Oct. 10. -- The annual Smith College Alumnae Week-End will take place this year from Friday to Sunday next. For the first time, many features of School Day, usually held in the Spring, will be combined with the activities of Alumnae Week-End.

Cosmopolitan's well-balanced eleven, unbeaten all of last season, scored its ninth straight triumph by turning back the surprising challenge of the Orioles in the feature game of the New York Field Hockey Association matches at Prospect Park yesterday.

In one respect the decision of THE NEW YORK TIMES to support the Candidacy of Mr. Roosevelt was, to me, very disquieting: it will influence many persons. In another respect, it was not disquieting: it will not influence the news columns of THE TIMES.
Headquarters of the eastern division of the Republican national campaign made public here yesterday a message from Governor Landon of Kansas, nominee for President, to the Negroes of this city.

The first formal session of the twenty-second annual convention of the Girl Scout National Council will open in Cincinnati on Wednesday. Mrs. Herbert Hoover, president of the national organization, will preside. The delegates, who will assemble from every State in the union, will be welcomed by Mrs. Roscoe B. Crabbs, Commissioner of the Cincinnati and Hamilton County Council, and by Mayor Russell Wilson.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Considerable improvement in business conditions in Great Britain, France and Germany, with commercial activity and industrial production running well ahead of indexes for recent years, was indicated in the Federal Reserve Bulletin for October.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- In a territory twice devastated by floods within two years, William F. Bleakley, the Republican candidate for Governor, tonight recommended "flood prevention" as the only fair method of dealing with the problem of how to keep swollen rivers out of people's homes.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 10 (AP). -Steve Sebo broke through a valiant Carnegie Tech defense with a 49-yard touchdown pass and then kicked the goal to give Michigan State a 7-to-0 victory before a crowd of 15,000 fans today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- The movement for cooperation between the Securities and Exchange Commission and State regulatory bodies in a joint endeavor to safeguard the interests of investors in issuing and selling securities has received an important impetus from deliberations at the recent convention of the National Association of Securities Commissioners in Denver, officials here are convinced.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 10. -- The long-awaited martial law may, after all, not come to Palestine. It is almost certain that the Arab strike will be called off some time next week as the result of the appeal being issued by King Ibn Saud of Saudi Arabia and other Arab kings, the text of which already is in the hands of the Arab High Committee here.

TURNING from the college gridiron to the professional field, tourists report that the sensation of the post-graduate campaign to date has been the work of the Pittsburgh Pirates, coached by Joe Bach, who was one of the Seven Mules up ahead of the Four Horsemen some years ago at Notre Dame.

In your editorial "A Reasoned Choice" you say: "No responsible Republican any longer froths at the mouth in charging that President Roosevelt is setting out to be a dictator after the style of Stalin or Hitler. The wild assertions that he intends to tear up the Constitution and destroy the Supreme Court are not heard today from any serious speaker."
EXETER, N.H., Oct. 10. -- Phillips Exeter, by starting a fast attack in the first two periods, defeated the Harvard freshmen 14 to 7.

Chain store sales in September showed the largest percentage gain since the depression, according to the monthly survey by Hammons Co., and Childs, Jeffries Thorndike, Inc. The first twentyfive chains reporting, according to the compilation released yesterday, did an aggregate business of $221,688,563, an increase of $37,774,981, or 20.5 per cent over the total in the same month a year ago.

At the end of one of the Review of the News Conferences held this week for clubwomen of the metropolitan area under the auspices of THE TIMES a man visitor came up to the platform to inquire if the program was a sample of the realistic approach to public questions to which American women were accustomed.
In a recent issue of The Kansas City Star I read that you are aligned with Roosevelt. I am happy to know that some one has both of his feet on the ground.

"Circumstances made you a trained nurse, old thing; but by the grace of God you are first of all a woman." When Susanna Hart received this note and a jeweled wrist watch as a parting gift from a movie actress, she scorned the watch and resented the implication that she was merely a starched-cambric bit of efficiency.

THERE is nothing important or revealing in this volume of character sketches, merely an agreeable escape from a world harassed by striving for economic security into the hearts of uncomplicated people.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- Columbus Day at Hot Springs, coming as it does at the height of the Autumn season, will be marked by numerous luncheons and dinner parties both at the hotel and at the estates throughout the valley.

WHEN James C. Wilson explained in sign language on leaving a Tuareg camp that he and Flood were going to cross the Sahara on their motorcycles "even the camels laughed." Every French outpost commander had but one comment: "C'est impossible!"

AFTER five busy months in England (one month of writing, four months of conferences) Robert Sherwood, the playwright and scenarist, is back home again, full of admiration for the British people, and even for their methods of film production, which include a meal wheeled in on the set every couple of hours.

New York University's football team came back from its disastrous rout of a week ago at Columbus, Ohio, to trim the Pennsylvania Military College eleven, 26 to 0, yesterday at Ohio Field before a crowd of 8,000 persons. After a futile opening half, the Violet returned to punch across four touchdowns, with two of them being credited to big Ed Williams.

FOR a generation Professor Sir Joseph Barcroft, Nobel Prize winner, has been studying man in relation to his environment. For part of this time the particular man was none other than himself. He has climbed mountains in the Andes to 16,000 feet and there noted how the blood transports oxygen and carbon dioxide between the lungs and other tissues.
In declaring or Roosevelt, THE NEW YORK TIMES has made, in my judgment, the greatest mistake of its great career.

BURGOS, Spain, Oct. 10 (By Courier to Hendaye, France). -- Baron Carl von Haartman, the "Hollywood General" is headed with his "suicide column" for the Bilbao front, where he will lead his men into battle against the equally desperate and valiant Asturian miners defending Bilbao.

Members of the Board of Registry in the Thirteenth Assembly District in Manhattan decided yesterday to live up to the exact letter of the election law, to the exasperation of college teachers and students who were vainly trying to convince them that they could read and write the English language.

THE approach of the Florida season will bring the inauguration of the Ocean Highway, New York to Florida route along the Atlantic Coast, as the first "public service" highway offering new facilities for the comfort and safety of its users.

AWAITING a visitation by his wife, Lady Jane -- she has been in England -- to his African domain, mighty Tarzan learns that Jane and her companions, en route to him by airplane, are beset by sinister dangers somewhere in the unexplored jungles.

The fifteen largest banks in this city, including J.P. Morgan Co., reduced their aggregate holdings of United States Government securities by $358,772,000, or 7.33 per cent, in the third quarter this year, according to their statements of condition as of Sept. 30.

DYSART, the towering young Scot, whose tumultuous career as a soldier of fortune has been chronicled in other Wren volumes, here transfers his scene of action to Annam, changing his role in the French Foreign Legion from that of infantryman to secret agent in the north country, where jungle warfare is still being waged against the conquering French arms.
New York City's plan to hold a great World's Fair in 1939 took visible shape last week when the sponsoring corporation issued formal announcement of its purposes and program.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 10. -- A strong Williams eleven, held to one touchdown in the first half by a valiant Haverford squad, staged a sustained drive in the last two quarters today to triumph by 46 -- 0.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 10. -- Boston University snatched a University of Toledo fumble on the 11-yard line in the third period of a hard-fought football game today and in three plays lunged to a touchdown for a 6-to-0 victory. It was the second time in as many engagements that the Terriers have beaten the Rockets by a single score.

When two brothers -- one a terribly attractive, irresponsible artist and the other a plodding, true-as-steel doctor -- both love the same girl, the veteran reader of light fiction is likely to offer heavy odds on the doctor's winning. In Edith Fotser's case the situation is slightly complicated.

LIDA LARRIMORE writes with bright charm and understanding sympathy of the problems of young love. But her new novel isn't as much fun to read as "No Lovelier Spring" because her latest heroine continues in a monotonously agonizing state of mind throughout the story.

Recalling the ancient culture of Ireland, which provided the world's teachers during the age of Charlemagne, Michael MacWhite, Minister of the Irish Free State, told last night at the Hotel Astor of how a rebirth of that ancient culture was going hand in hand with material progress in Ireland.

More than 2,500 members of the Building Trades Council of New York City applauded James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, last night when he attributed returning prosperity to the policies of the Roosevelt administration and predicted the re-election of President Roosevelt.

PARIS. SUITS are blossoming forth into so many new and varied forms this Autumn that they are likely to predominate in any smart gathering between the hours of 9 A.M. and 9 P.M. Evening suits continue very popular. They are quite different in appearance from those of last season.

More than 2,500 members of the Building Trades Council of New York City applauded James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, last night when he attributed returning prosperity to the policies of the Roosevelt administration and predicted the re-election of President Roosevelt.

PARIS. SUITS are blossoming forth into so many new and varied forms this Autumn that they are likely to predominate in any smart gathering between the hours of 9 A.M. and 9 P.M. Evening suits continue very popular. They are quite different in appearance from those of last season.
I wish to congratulate you on your decision to support the re-election of President Roosevelt and your courage in coming to the front, as well as the excellent reasons you gave for your decision.

THIS is, as Mr. White calls it in his subtitle, a "reporter's story of the early campaign of 1936." It is also, as he states in his preface, "frankly partisan." In all that it says in regard to Governor Landon, it is a men's portrait of his friend.

Dismissal of the $100,000 damage suit brought against Chairman James A. Farley, the other members of the Democratic National Committee and Publicity Director Charles Michelson for use of the slogan "Forward With Roosevelt," is asked in a brief filed with the New York Supreme Court, the committee announced yesterday.

THE most impressive thing in this latest book about Lola Montez is its bibliography. This list fills five and a half pages, and at the end of it the author states that he has forborne to "catalogue stray items from periodicals."

DESERTING Spanish atmosphere, which she handles so lavishly, the author of "Matador" and "The Tavern" has written a wholly different kind of book. The easiest way to tag it is to call it a novel about the problem of euthanasia.

ST. PAUL, Oct. 9. -- The withdrawal of the Democratic candidates for Governor and United States Senator continues the policy of fusion with the Farmer-Labor party first adopted in 1932 by the Wolf faction of the State Democratic party and repeated in 1934.

NOTABLE advance has been made during the last two years in the field of American mural painting. Government sponsorship has resulted in nation-wide activity, mural work having been produced in abundance under both the Treasury Department Art Program and the Federal Art Project of the Works Progress Administration (WPA).

CHICAGO, Oct. 10. -- Governor Landon's election seems assured, John D.M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, declared tonight after analyzing confidential reports received at headquarters from party workers.
Directors of the Manhattanville Alumnae Association will give a supper dance on Friday at Sherry's for members of the senior class at the college.

SEVERAL countries besides our own have used as the motif in certain postage stamp designs the Statue of Liberty, the semi-centenary of which we celebrate on Oct. 28. It first appeared in our gray 15-cent stamp in the 1922-26 general stamp.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- Thousands of visitors are here for the Columbus holiday period and many hotels, night clubs, ocean piers and theatres are providing special entertainment programs. Golf tournaments, horseback riding on the beach, Boardwalk bicycling, fishing and boating are competing for the attention of resort guests.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP). -- A contention that face powder, rouge and lipstick "are not of such grave public concern as to bring them within the class of commodities affected with a public interest" was advanced today in the Supreme Court.

PERHAPS the most striking thing about this book is the format. These two short novels, or long novelettes, have been bound together in a somewhat unusual fashion. One of them is printed upside down, with its own title page in what would have been, under more normal circumstances, the back of the book.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 11. -- William F. Bleakley, Republican candidate for Governor, returned to his home here today for a week-end rest with the belief that the record registration in New York City enhanced his outlook for an anti-New Deal victory in the State.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 11. -- Ellison (Tarzan) Brown, 22-year-old, full-blooded Narragansett Indian of Alton, R.I., who competed for the United States in the Olympic Games, gave a sterling exhibition of stamina and courage today to win the twelfth annual Port Chester National Marathon.

EN ROUTE FROM CALCUTTA TO BANGKOK, Oct. 11. -- The story of the last twelve hours is the most adventurous thus far of my tour around the world. It includes a visit to the Calcutta markets to seek tropical clothing, a night spent in a chair because of an insect-infested bedroom, an exciting predawn ride to the airport, a blind take-off in the fog and a misty flight over trackless Bengal jungles toward Akyab.

The Abbott E. Kittredge Club for Girls at 440 East Fifty-seventh Street will start its forty-eighth season tomorrow. The year's social program includes concerts, dances, bridge parties and participation by the members in the activities of the glee club and the dramatic group, both of which are under professional direction.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11. -- Plans for a parade in the Loop in honor of President Roosevelt Wednesday afternoon, before his scheduled campaign speech at the Chicago Stadium, were announced today by the Democratic County Central Committee.

Comparatively few surprises were recorded during the past week-end in the scholastic football ranks as a number of Eastern prep school elevens joined the long string of active squads, but several results of an upset nature involved standout teams of the 1935 season.

NEW HAVEN, Oct 10. -- A report on studies of 105 children who have appeared in the police courts and have been compared with their non-delinquent brothers and sisters, is made by Dr. William Healy and Dr. Augusta F. Bronner of the Judge Baker Guidance Center of Boston in a volume just published by the Yale University Press called "New Light on Delinquency and Its Treatment."

The importance of the church year as a means of discipline and spiritual refreshment was stressed by the Rev. William N. Guthrie, rector of the Episcopal Church of St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie, Tenth Street and Second Avenue, in his sermon yesterday morning.

Late dispatches from both sides have tended to clarify confusions attending the campaign of the Spanish Rebels to capture Madrid. Exaggerated claims have been made, but the black line shows the approximate position of the armies.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11. -- Farmers in Illinois, Iowa, Maryland and Ohio have shifted their allegiance since midsummer from President Roosevelt to Governor Landon, while those in Michigan and Oregon have deserted the Republican Presidential nominee to support Mr. Roosevelt, according to a table of percentages made public today in The Farm Journal's farm-to-farm straw vote.

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 10. -- The Dutch Exchange Stabilization Fund has been established at the maximum of 300,000,000 guilders to be raised by placing Treasury paper either on the market or with the Netherlands Bank. The fund probably will not be of influence, in the long trend, on the guilder rate.
The West Hills hunts meet will be held today at Huntington, L.I., with an attractive program of four events. Three races will be steeplechase contests, while the fourth will be run on the flat.

Besides the Metropolitan Museum's exhibition of glass, reviewed above, the current week offers a number of important events, some of them of outstanding interest. The Carnegie International opens to the public on Thursday in Pittsburgh and will be commented upon in these columns on that day.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 11. -- Full denials were made today by Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein and his four colleagues on the Newark City Commission concerning the 134 alleged illegal acts which formed the basis of Supreme Court Justice Charles W. Parker's decision yesterday calling for a sweeping court investigation of the municipal government.

Two detectives who chanced upon a hold-up in front of 1,570 Webster Avenue, the Bronx, at 3 o'clock yesterday morning caught one of the alleged hold-up men after a chase. In Bronx magistrates court he said he was Samuel Rosenblatt, 26 years old; unemployed, of 1,530 Plimpton Avenue, the Bronx.

CARMEL, N.Y., Oct. 11. -- Nearly 100 voters in Putnam County made affidavits today that their names appearing on photostatic copies of the Lemke nomination petitions were fraudulent. The affidavits were obtained in connection with the Albany County Supreme Court action brought by William E. Drislane and Dr. O.A. Brenenstuhl, challenging the validity of the signatures.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 11. -- The cotton market here started last week with a fair degree of activity and steadiness in prices, but it gradually lost its edge as the date for release of the government forecast based on Oct. 1 conditions approached. Because of better weather in the interior, particularly in the Western and Central States, it developed a slightly easier tendency on the fear that the Census Bureau's estimate would show some improvement.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP). -- The Washington Post says that Mgr. John A. Ryan of Catholic University tonight accused the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, Detroit radio priest, of misquoting writings of Pope Pius XI.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., Oct. 11. -- Asserting that international banking "stands much lower in valuation than the business of agriculture," the Rev. Dr. William H. Fineshriber of Philadelphia pleaded at the National Farm School today for a nation-wide back-to-the-soil movement as a means of bettering conditions throughout the country.

It would provide an interesting and instructive comparison to note how the chorus of complaint against the New Deal has risen in close relation to the rise in our national profits. Al Smith's assertion that the whole country was with Mr. Roosevelt in 1933 is correct. But once business began to find its way out of the red, national unity disappeared.

HOUSTON, Texas, Oct. 11 (AP) -- "This season has been a pleasant puzzle," said Sam W. Gumpertz, general manager of Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus today. "We've had our best year since 1929, and Presidential election years long have been the hardest seasons for the circus.
BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Oct. 11. -- Jack Forrester and Bill Breslin of Hackensack today won the New Jersey P.G.A. one-day pro-amateur tourney with a par-smashing 67 at the Forest Hill Field Club.

WAKE ISLAND, Monday, Oct. 12. -- The China Clipper is being delayed here one day because of a typhoon in the vicinity of Guam. The Clipper alighted on the lagoon here yesterday afternoon after a flight of eight hours forty-one minutes from Midway Island.

LONDON, Oct. 11. -- The royal commission on private manufacture of arms, appointed last February under the chairmanship of Sir John Eldon Bankes to inquire into alleged munition scandals following disclosures before the Nye committee in Washington, has decided against the nationalization of the British arms industry.

NORRISTOWN, Pa., Oct. 11. -- Ralph Beaver Strassburger, publisher of The Norristown Times-Herald and a delegate to the Republican National Convention that nominated Governor Landon for the Presidency, announced today that he would support President Roosevelt for re-election.
STRASBOURG, France, Oct. 11. -- The threat of steel-helmeted Mobile Guards today kept a feared Communist propaganda tour from turning into battles with Rightist forces in Alsace and Lorraine.

New York's new traffic-light timing is primarily, and justifiably, designed in the interest of crosstown movement. Bus riders have complained that one can do better walking from one side of the town to the other.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 11 (AP). -- Santa Clara coupled crushing power with its opponent's miscues today to defeat the University of San Francisco, 15 to 7, in their annual football battle before 35,000 fans.

The clans of Erin gathered yesterday at the St. Nicholas Palace, 69 West Sixty-sixth Street, for the fourth annual Feis of the United Irish Counties Association. More than 3,500 persons were present to meet old friends, exchange gossip, and, between-times, witness competitions in the old tradition, ranging from story-telling in Gaelic to saber contests in which the finalists were Jose and Miguel de Capriles.

LONDON, Oct. 11. -- While all available police were shepherding a march of 5,000 Communists through the East End tonight a group of gangsters, shouting Fascist slogans, raided Jewish shops in Mile End Road.

The long diplomatic isolation of the Soviet Government, ended when Russia entered the League of Nations, has been succeeded by a period of great activity, lately greatly intensified, on the international stage. Although Russian membership has coincided with the League's weakest and least glorious period, Moscow has made the most of the Geneva sounding board.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., Oct. 11. -- President Roosevelt, speaking to a soldier audience at the army post here, declared today that "this nation is setting an example of peace for the world," the statement being accompanied with the observation that "the army particularly agrees with me" that that is a "very fine thing."

The Citizens Charter Campaign Committee began last night the first week of an intensified drive on behalf of the proposed new city charter, upon which the voters will pass on Nov. 3. The committee's program for the week ending Oct. 17 includes twenty-eight meetings of political, social, church and civic groups in Manhattan, at which speakers will urge support of the charter proposal and preferential voting.

As I was perusing the editorial "Bonus Arithmetic," the pleasing thought came to me that here at last was an expression of THE TIMES'S opinion of such glaringly twisted statements which have been broadcast by those in Washington who have the business affairs of the nation in their charge.

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 9. -- Devaluation of the guilder will undoubtedly prove a boon to tourist trade in the Netherlands. While much, of course, depends on the ultimate measure of the devaluation (which still is highly uncertain), it is believed here that the mere psychological effect of a cut in the guilder already is favorably influencing tourist prospects for Holland.

Eugenio, Cardinal Pacelli, Papal Secretary of State, who arrived here from Italy last Thursday, presided at pontifical mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. It was the observance of the twenty-sixth anniversary of the consecration of the church, which was last Monday.

It was for some time denied that ex-Governor COX of Ohio, Democratic candidate for the Presidency in 1920, would speak for Mr. ROOSEVELT in this campaign. He resolved all doubts by his speech of last week, which was a sane and sagacious defense of the Administration.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 11. -- Rumania's Foreign Minister, Victor Antonescu, who arrived here yesterday morning, will stay until tomorrow. His visit will be followed promptly by the Hungarian Premier, Dr. Koloman Daranyi, the Bulgarian Premier, George Kiosseivanoff, and the Turkish Foreign Minister, Tewfik Rushdu Aras.

Bed occupancy in the voluntary general hospitals of Greater New York reached a new five-year record during the first seven months of this year, Stuart M. Crocker, chairman of the United Hospital Campaign Committee, reported yesterday.

ORANGEBURG, N.Y., Oct. 11. -- Horses from the stables of Frank H. Bell of Bedford Village and F. D. Hawkins gained three blues each in today's third annual Hunter Show conducted by the Orangeburg Hunt Club. The thirteen-event program attracted outstanding horses and riders of New York and New Jersey.

TOKYO, Oct. 11. -- Expecting a world economic conference will be called by the United States or Great Britain after the Presidential ele ction the Japanese Foreign Office has begun informal preparations by sending Commercial Counselor Shuto to Osaka to seek the views of the commercial community.

Members of the Board of Managers of the Women's Auxiliary of the Union Settlement have taken over the performance of "Tovarich" on the night of Nov. 4 at the Plymouth Theatre to raise funds for carrying on the work of the settlement.

After advancing in the previous week cotton prices showed a moderate decline last week, active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange being 4 to 22 points net lower. The decline was greater on the near-by deliveries and less on the distant positions.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith may become president of the Consolidated Edison Company, Inc., soon after election day, Justice Jacob Panken of the Family Court declared yesterday, addressing 300 delegates to an organization meeting of the American Labor party in the new Labor Theatre, 106 West Thirty-ninth Street.

Gleanings from notebook and mailbag: Bill Fagen, one of the little group of fishing guides that pioneered big-game angling on the Atlantic Coast, has arrived in town from Bimini to catch up on his rest after a Summer of hunting the great blue marlin and to attend the annual dinner of the Beach Haven Tuna Club at the Hotel New Yorker next Thursday evening. . . .

CHICAGO, Oct. 11. -- Prices of hogs and fresh pork here held last week within narrow ranges. The top for hogs was $10.50 a hundredweight, or the same as the week before. The daily average ranged from $9.70 at the opening $9.85 at the close.

James Burghlie, 73 years old, of 203 East Forty-fourth Street, was attacked, beaten and robbed by three men in the washroom of Loew's Ziegfeld Theatre, Fifty-fourth Street and Sixth Avenue, shortly before 6 P.M. yesterday.
President Roosevelt praised the Young Men's Christian Association yesterday afternoon for the "valiant service" given unemployed young men during the depression.
Tribute will be paid today to the memory of Christopher Columbus in a series of celebrations throughout the city.

Speeding up preparations for its international game with Ireland next month, the New York Field Hockey Association gave an impressive exhibition in conquering the North Jersey eleven, 10 -- 3, in a test game at Prospect Park yesterday.

Many reservations have been made for the pre-opening performance of "Tovarich," adapted from the French of Jacques Deval, with Marta Abba and John Halliday in the leading roles, tomorrow night at the Plymouth Theatre for the benefit of the Stepney Fresh Air Camp of the East Side Settlement House.

MOSCOW, Oct. 11. -- The determination of the Soviet Union not to countenance any pussyfooting by the London committee on non-intervention in Spain was emphasized today in strongly worded editorials in Pravda and Izvestia.

LITCHFIELD, Ill., Oct. 11. -- The Rev. L. A. Crown, whose "worst sin" contest has brought hundreds of replies from over the nation, tonight told his congregation that the world's "most horrible sin" was "the abuse of high privilege."

MADRID, Oct. 11 (Passed by the Censor). -- According to refugees reaching Barbastro on the northern front from the Jaca citadel, held by Insurgents, Pio Diaz, an elderly and venerated supporter of the Jaca revolt in 1930, has gone over to the insurgents.

BOSTON, Oct. 11. -- The General Federation of Women's Clubs has thrown open to political advertising the columns of its official organ, The Club Woman, for the first time in its more than forty years of existence. The current issue, received by subscribers yesterday, carries full page advertisements in behalf of Governor Landon and President Roosevelt.

Republicans and Democrats alike yesterday claimed the unprecedented city registration of 2,899,123, recorded during the past week, to be favorable to their respective causes. The total was higher than any one had believed possible before registration started.

ABOARD THE PRESIDENT'S TRAIN, CHEYENNE, Wyo., Oct. 11. -- A public felicitation from her husband, given before massed hundreds on the Fort Francis E. Warren parade grounds, marked Mrs. Roosevelt's fifty-second birthday celebration today.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, Oct. 11. -- Mr. and Mrs. Le Roy B. Giles gave a luncheon today for Dr. and Mrs. W.W.S. Butler in the Casino. Other luncheon hosts included Mr. and Mrs. Richard K. Le Blond, Mr. and Mrs. H.H. Davis, Mr. and Mrs. P.B. Zimmerman, Mr. and Mrs. R.T. Stafford, Mrs. Rollin H. White Jr., Douglas Nicholson, G. Fred Henry and David N. Jones.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 11. -- William Lockhart Clayton of Chattanooga and Houston, Texas, the world's largest cotton merchant, in a statement here to The Chattanooga Times announced today that he has changed his original views and will vote for President Roosevelt in the November election.

Up in Fifty-second Street tonight the Theatre Guild begins another season, this one the nineteenth. The inaugural honors fall to the comedy called "And Stars Remain," by Julius J. and Philip G. Epstein, and among those important in it will be Clifton Webb and Helen Gahagan.

THAT was a thriller the Army and Columbia turned in at the Yankee Stadium. It was the open game at its best. There were long and short forward passes, fine runs, slashing tackles and magnificent kicking. Columbia had more finesse, but the Army had greater reserve power and finally wore the Lions down.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 11. -- Tomorrow morning at 11 o'clock forty-five trim racing cars and their daredevil drivers will be sent away on the first running of the 300-mile Vanderbilt Cup race over the new Roosevelt Raceway.

The duty of Christians to make for solidarity in a world torn by racial and national antagonisms was proclaimed by the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of the Union Theological Seminary, in a sermon yesterday morning from his former pulpit at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Seventy-third Street.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11. -- Conditions in the world's wheat markets are regarded by close students as the strongest in recent years. Supplies are more closely adjusted to requirements and, while the trade is not heavy, selling pressure is comparatively light but of sufficient volume to check price upturns every few days and cause moderate setbacks.

BERLIN, Oct. 9. -- While official and inspired pronouncements assume that devaluations aggravate tension in the Reich's foreign trade and balance of payments, independent experts take a more optimistic view of the situation.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 11. -- Governor Landon will continue tomorrow his campaign to win the twenty-six electoral votes of Ohio, generally regarded as a doubtful State.

LONDON, Oct. 10. -- The Board of Trade's index of wholesale prices in September, based on the average of 1930 as 100, was 96.1, which compares with 95.2 for August, 89.6 for September, 1935, and 88.4 for September, 1933. The September rise followed larger gains in the two preceding months, making the aggregate increase for the quarter almost 4 per cent.
LIMA, Peru, Oct. ll. -- Peru chose a President, Senators and Deputies today in an unusually quiet election. The legally inscribed voters numbered 490,000, of whom 120,000 reside in the Lima district.

Chief City Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr., who announced on Friday that he was assigning six "specially qualified" magistrates to rotate in Brooklyn Traffic Court, beginning tomorrow, to put an end to "chiseling" and "fixing," made public yesterday an analysis of traffic cases indicating the reason for the move.

The Board of Elections in a notice dated Oct. 5, relative to the questions to be presented to voters on Nov. 3, contains an abstract of Question No. 1 which has to do with the revision of the City Charter.

The current newsreels collected for the Embassy's program include football scenes from the Princeton-Williams, Notre Dame-Carnegie Tech, Ohio State-N.Y.U. and Yale-Cornell games, and glimpses of the final world series baseball contest. Other shots show Kurt Bjorkvall on his take-off from Floyd Bennett Field for Sweden (a flight which ended in the sea off Ireland), the Dick Powell-Joan Blondell honeymoon welcome here and scenes from the Spanish civil war. . . .

Because the general leasing situation requires most New Yorkers to move on or about Oct. 1, many of them find that they cannot vote in the November elections. Those who have moved on Oct. 1 from one borough to another are not allowed to register for the reason that on election day they will not have resided within their new borough for a required period of four months.

A blanket increase of $10 monthly in the wages of all tugboat workers in this harbor prompted the Associated Marine Workers of America to abandon last night plans for a strike which shippers feared would tie up the transportation of coal, oil and food and impede the docking of liners here.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11. -- Despite surveys reported by John D. M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, as showing "unmistakable trends" in pivotal States toward a Republican victory in Illinois, New York and Pennsylvania, with Ohio and Michigan "swinging into line," the party's campaign is suffering from a lack of funds.
It was reported in THE TIMES that a man was held in Traffic Court for hitting a dog and leaving the scene of the accident without ministering to the animal, or easing the pain.

BERLIN, Oct. 9. -- The German and Belgian steel markets are exceptionally active. German mills refuse to deliver steel bars in less than six to eight months, and the Steel-Works Syndicate even refuses to book orders unless the customer can prove that his need is urgent.

The four persons who were injured in an accident in the Strand Theatre at Forty-seventh Street and Broadway at 12:15 A. M. yesterday while a motion picture was being shown were still in Polyclinic Hospital last night, but their condition was said to be good.

LONDON, Oct. 11. -- King Edward officially took up residence today in Buckingham Palace, home of Britain's rulers for 100 years, and another link with his more carefree life as Prince of Wales was broken.

LIMA, Peru, Oct. 11. -- Following the recent governmental decree, the City Council today issued an ordinance defining the classes of goods which may be peddled through the streets, as well as restricting the area in which the hawkers may work.
CHICAGO, Oct. 11 (AP). -- Dignitaries of the Episcopal Church arrived here today from throughout the Western Hemisphere for the opening tomorrow of a seven-day world peace conference.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 11 (AP). -- St. Mary's Galloping Gaels rolled over Loyola University's luckless Lions, 19 to 7, before 50,000 football fans today.

SAVANNAH, Oct. 11 (AP). -- Discovery in pine trees of fat, containing the same properties as animal flesh, was announced today by Dr. Charles H. Herty, director of the pulp and paper laboratory of Savannah.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 11. -- Grand Duchess Marie of Russia was a Newport visitor over the week-end. She was the guest of Mr. and Mrs. Vladimir Behr, who gave a luncheon in her honor yesterday at their home.
JERUSALEM, Oct. 11. -- Tomorrow, the day completing its twenty-fourth week, the Arab strike will end.

ALBANY, Oct. 11. -- Before a gallery of about 500 enthusiastic field-trial fans, the final awards were announced late this afternoon in the fifth annual meeting of the Albany Cocker Club in the covers of Gallogly Farm.

Mayor La Guardia and members of the Honor Legion of the Police Department paid tribute yesterday afternoon to the memory of twenty-nine policemen of the legion who died during the year, five of whom were killed in performance of their duty.

Thelma Spear, soprano, appeared in recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon in a program that did her credit for its freshness of approach and seriousness of purpose. There was first a group of songs "of Shakespearean inspiration" which included two, "Heighho for a Husband" and "Heart's Ease," that are mentioned in the plays and four that are culled from them.
A tablet in memory of Judge Otto S. Rosalsky was unveiled by Federal Judge Julian W. Mack yesterday afternoon at the Home of the Daughters of Jacob, 167th Street and Findlay Avenue, the Bronx.

Giant and Dodger attacking powers passed each other at half-time yesterday as the two interborough rivals opened the twelfth home season of the Eastern champions of the National Football League at the Polo Grounds before a wildly excited gathering of 25,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11 (AP). -- The Detroit Lions, displaying a fast-charging line, two sets of fleet backs and capable reserves, defeated the Philadelphia Eagles, 23 -- 0, in a national Professional Football League game before 17,000 today.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 11. -- Favored teams were shunted to the sidelines today as two brother combinations, Hugo and Winthrop Rutherfurd of New Jersey and Dudley Roberts Jr. of Garden City and H. Steele Roberts of Silver Springs, advanced to the final round of the third annual best-ball invitation golf tournament at the Meadow Brook Club.

PLOTS and sub-plots crowd the new Jalna novel. More and more Mazo de la Roche fills her books with angrily raised voices, with departures of wives from bed and board, with requests by young men for the return of engagement rings. She never has been a drama-dodging writer. A screaming woman or a cursing parrot, a gravely embarrassed, bullied minister or a family row, receive her fullest attention every time.
SEOUL, Korea, Monday, Oct. 12. -- Russian and Manchukuoan troops clashed today on the Soviet-Manchukuoan border after a month of comparative quiet along the frontier.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 11 (AP). -- Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor, said today that he had asked the newly created United States Maritime Commission to come here immediately and use its powers toward settlement of the new crisis threatening a shipping tieup.

Flaming brands made of clothing soaked in gasoline probably saved the lives of two men early yesterday morning when their cabin cruiser was on the verge of sinking in a choppy sea half a mile off the south shore of Long Island at Far Rockaway, Queens.

PARIS, Oct. 11. -- Premier Leon Blum went to the mining town of Lens today to inaugurate a new hospital and took the occasion of his first visit to the industrial north to emphasize to the workers that if they were to get the benefit of the social legislation of recent months they must be united.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- The rise in agricultural income for the nation during the years from 1932 to 1935 was almost exactly paralleled by the increase in railway shipments from industrial States to farm States, the Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today in making public a study of railway traffic in that period.

BASEL, Switzerland, Oct. 11. -- The governors of the big European central banks met here today for their monthly meeting as members of the World Bank board -- their first contact since the tri-power declaration and the gold bloc devaluation.

With the exception of a few special light boxes, most of them located at complicated avenue and street intersections, particularly those involving Broadway, the traffic light system of Manhattan was changed yesterday, the two-minute cycle being shortened to a minute and one half.

ALBANY, Oct. 11. -- New York State in August had the lowest death rate, 9.3 per 1,000 population, on record for any month, Dr. J.V. DePorte, director of the Division of Vital Statistics of the State Health Department, reported today. The death rates from suicide, 12.9, and automobile accidents, 21.1, were the lowest for August in nine and eight years respectively.

" For their outstanding contributions to the art of dancing" Florence and Hattie Rogge of Radio City Music Hall were made honorary members of the New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc., at its October meeting, held yesterday at the Hotel Astor.

The first in the series of Friday Junior Dances for this season, arranged for debutantes of forthcoming seasons and young men at home from schools and colleges for the holidays, will be held the afternoon of Dec. 28 at the Savoy-Plaza.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11. -- Dr. Francis E. Townsend, head of the Townsend National Recovery Plan, threw all of his strength today behind Governor Landon in those States in which the name of Representative William Lemke, third party candidate for President, will not appear on the Nov. 3 ballot.

When Mayor LA GUARDIA cut sharply into the Park Department's estimates for next year he knew that Commissioner MOSES was unlikely to acquiesce meekly in the announced result. He could hardly have expected, however, such a devastating counterblast as that issuing from the Arsenal this morning.

The reduction of more than $3,000,000 in the executive budget on the Park Department's 1937 budget request for $9,750,000 will mean a reduction of 30 per cent in the department's work in parks, parkways and playgrounds, Commissioner Robert Moses declared in a letter to the Board of Estimate, made public yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 10. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 83.8, which compares with 84 the week before, 84 two weeks before, 84.1 three weeks before and 84.2 four weeks before.
In sermons inspired by Columbus Day, two clergymen yesterday drew lessons from the life of the discoverer of America.

General buying activity in the wholesale market was good last week, a considerable volume of reorders and fill-in orders being received. Better dresses were in demand, indicating a growing consumer interest in higher priced goods.

MADRID, Oct. 11. -- The enemy, it is conceded here, is nearing Madrid. Tonight's communique mentions fighting near Robledo de Chavela, twenty-five miles west of the capital and ten miles from Escorial. Should the Rebels progress much further at that point, the positions so stoutly held below Leon Pass for nearly three months would be outflanked.

The first definite claim that Ohio's twenty-six electoral votes would be in the Democratic column on election day was made yesterday by Democratic National Chairman James A. Farley in a press interview in which he outlined President Roosevelt's campaign plans between now and election.

With preliminary moves completed over the week-end, negotiations between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization designed to bring peace between the craft and industrial union factions in the A.F. of L. are expected to be under way before long.

William Morrow Co. have placed fifteen of their books in the first transpacific "Flying Libraries," made up by Pan American Airways for each of their Clipper flying boats in the California-Orient passenger service. Five of the fifteen books are detective stories and one is a juvenile.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 11. -- S.J. Briskin of RKO has bought the rights here to "L'Equipage," from which Anatol Litvak made a notable French picture several years ago which had limited circulation in this country. Mr. Litvak, who is due in New York on the Normandie, has been engaged to direct it with Herbert Marshall as the star.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 11 (AP). -- Miss Ida Osborne, 60 years old, of 222 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn, N.Y., was killed and three other women, including her sister, were injured at Kingston today when their automobile smashed head-on into a tree.

A five-story factory for the production of visual teaching aids, the first of its kind in the country, has been established by the WPA and the Board of Education in the south wing of Public School 21, Mott and Spring Streets.

In a normal year, industrial activity always reaches its high point during October. There have been exceptions; steel production, for instance, decreased during this month in 1929, 1930, 1931 and 1933, and loadings of railway freight in October of 1929, 1933 and 1934.

ALBANY, Oct. 11. -- Factory employment advanced 3.7 per cent and payrolls rose 0.9 per cent in the State from the middle of August to the middle of September, Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews announced today. These increases followed an advance of 3 per cent in employment and 5 per cent in payrolls in the period from the middle of July to August.

New York City, which is more horseshoe-pitching conscious than most non-addicts believe, developed two metropolitan open titleholders yesterday in simultaneous tournaments four and a half miles apart.

A special exhibition of glass will open at the Metropolitan Museum with a private view for members at 2 o'clock tomorrow afternoon and to the public on Wednesday. All of the material belongs to the Metropolitan and it has been superbly installed in the three intimately communicating second-floor galleries known as D 6.

You published a letter from General O'Ryan giving reasons why he is going to vote for the re-election of the President. Perhaps you will be willing to publish this letter from a business man, giving his reasons why he is going to vote for Governor Landon.

MOUNT OLIVE, Ill., Oct. 11 (AP). -- Thousands of coal miners bared their heads today before a new monument erected in the miners' cemetery here to the memory of "Mother" Mary Jones, their leader for sixty years, and pledged themselves to heed her famous war cry of "Get out and fight!"
