CHICAGO, Oct. 11 (AP). -- The powerful Chicago Bears were forced to come from behind today to win their fourth straight National Professional Football League game, downing the unexpectedly stubborn Chicago Cardinals, 7 -- 3, on Jack Manders's second-period touchdown.

Governor Lehman praised President Roosevelt last night as the "great leader of our nation" and declared that he is gaining strength daily because the people of the country are realizing that his administration is bringing the country out of the depression and that the Democratic party is the party of humane progress.

No longer, crowned with green leaves, full of breakfast sausage, good hope and a bursting vocabulary, does Emporian WILLIAM WHITE, sitting in his word-works, carol and caper, finding everything good in Kansas and the rest of the world. His skies are overcast. The maple leaves cheer his esthetic eye no more.

Effective with brilliant three-quarter line passwork, a picked Canadian fifteen representing the Quebec English Rugby Union proved too puzzling for a hard-rushing New York Rugby Club team in an international rugby match at Randalls Island yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 10. -- The return of the Bank of France for Oct. 2 shows the changes resulting from revaluation of the gold reserves and foreign balances. The profit on revaluation, which cannot be computed exactly, must amount approximately to 17,000,000,000 francs but the return records an increase of only 7,000,000,000. The counterpart of half the latter appears in a decrease in the item of loans to the State.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 11. -- Brandy and Sweet, a 6-year-old brown gelding, had pretty much of a field day of it as the sixth annual Saxon Woods Hunt Club's two-day exhibition got off to an auspicious start today on the club grounds.
In his drive for clean streets Sanitation Commissioner William F. Carey has been assured of active cooperation by License Commissioner Paul Moss, it was announced yesterday.

Renting of space for retail shops featured the business leases announced by brokers yesterday. East Side space appeared to be in heavy demand and several stores were taken on Madison and Lexington Avenues.

SAN MARTIN DE VALDEIGLESIAS, Spain, Oct. 11 (AP). -- Insurgent forces, hopeful of capturing Madrid within ten days, forged forward today against the increasing ferocity of the capital's defenders, whose desperation is more apparent than ever before.
BOSTON, Oct. 11. -- Boston's American League Shamrocks won their fourth victory of the campaign today before 10,000 spectators, turning back Brooklyn, 10 to 6.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 (AP). -- The Republican National Committee issued a statement tonight "thanking President Roosevelt for proving in his Omaha speech last night one of the main points which Governor Landon made at Chicago Friday night -- that spenders can't be trusted to balance the budget."

PARIS, Oct. 10. -- It is generally conceded to be impossible to estimate the amount of French capital that has been repatriated, but a continuous flow certainly persisted this week, especially from London, this last because most of the exported money went to England and comparatively little to New York.

BERLIN, Oct. 9. -- Banks here warned their clients last week that devaluation of the mark, as far as can be seen, was "impossible" and that bullish stock operations based on the contrary expectation were perilous. Nevertheless, the advice was ignored and the wave of buying on the Boerse here continued.

ST. PAUL, Oct. 11. -- At the end of the tangled skein of political strategy which has led to the pooling of interests in Minnesota between the major Democratic organizations of the State (there are two) and the Farmer-Labor party, only these facts can, with any assurance be discerned:

FAIRFIELD, N.J., Oct. 11 (AP). -- Bert Seeger of Newburg, N.Y., won the second annual trapshooting championship of the North Jersey Gun Club today, defeating John D. Rake of Monroe, N.Y., last year's winner, breaking 49 out of the 50 targets, in a shoot-off. Rake hit 48.

Commemorating the 157th anniversary of the death of General Casimer Pulaski at the siege of Savannah in the American Revolution, members of the United St. Stanislaus Societies, of 101 Seventh Street, and the New York State Conference of Polish Clubs, gathered in City Hall Park yesterday afternoon and contributed to Statewide observances of the day.

Increasing demand by the automotive manufacturers brought about an increase of a half-point in steel operations last week, carrying the national rate to 75 per cent of capacity, according to the weekly summary of the magazine Steel, issued yesterday.

FLORAL PARK, L.I., Oct. 11. -- Mrs. May Hofmann, 21 years old, of 281 Jericho Turnpike, this village, was killed instantly here about 4 o'clock this morning when an automobile driven by her husband, George, smashed through the Long Island Railroad gates at the Plainfield Avenue grade crossing and struck the side of the first car of an electric train.
West Side properties were involved in most of the Manhattan realty deals reported over the weekend. Several residences were taken under lease.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., Oct. 11. -- Playing superbly with his irons, Paul Runyan of Metropolis extended his reign for another year as the Metropolitan Professional Golf Association champion today, defeating Charley Lacey of Lakeville in the thirty-six-hole final at Bethpage State Park.
OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 11. -- With W.G. Holloway and Billy Reynolds playing well up front, the Long Island polo team defeated Westbury, 8 to 7, in today's match at Bostwick Field.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 11. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated at 76 per cent of capacity, unchanged from the preceding week. The rate in actual tonnage output is the largest since September, 1929, with the possible exception of the following February.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 11. -- Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton M. Chase gave a reception and tea for seventy guests at their home here today in honor of Mr. and Mrs. John Lawson Johnston of England. Mr. and Mrs. Johnston have been visiting at the home of Mrs. Johnston's parents, Mr. and Mrs. W. Herbert Wiley of Greenwich.

MANILA, Monday, Oct. 12. -- At least 109 persons were killed by a typhoon that swept across Luzon Island Friday and Saturday. Four hundred were reported missing today and were believed to have been washed away by flood waters.

Displaying a well-rounded technique and a balanced combination of the quick passing game, which is their specialty, and timely mass attacks, the Maccabees, soccer champions of Palestine, encountered a professional team of local stars representing five clubs in the metropolitan division of the American Soccer League at Ebbets Field yesterday in the third match of their North American tour.

Foreign exchanges exhibited a greater degree of stability last week, a sequel to the official devaluation in certain of the European currencies which had been overhanging the market for the last month. The business involved was done along more orderly lines, representing as it did the legitimate requirements of commercial interests with virtually little or no evidence of the speculative activity of previous weeks.

The Holy Name Societies of Jersey City turned out 35,000 members for a parade and rally yesterday afternoon and more than 100,000 persons viewed the spectacle. Twenty-seven units were represented in the parade, one of many held in the State.

As a first voter I found registering a traumatic experience. I took along proof of New York birth, but was not asked for it. I did not take along proof that I could read and write, and was yanked from the head of the line in order to climb three flights of stairs to take a literacy test.

LONDON, Oct. 9. -- Because of the British non-intervention policy, Spanish affairs do not interest the city but receive some prominence through demands of the Labor party convention that Britain should help the Madrid Government against the armies of General Franco.

BABYLON, L.I., Oct. 11. -- Four WPA employes, three of them foremen engaged on Long Island State Park Commission projects, have been discharged by Chief Engineer Arthur E. Howland after an investigation that revealed deception in the registration of names.

As the first of the series of Sunday Wagner matinees scheduled by the Hippodrome Opera Company, "Lohengrin" came to performance yesterday afternoon. Considering the vast audiences which have greeted the previous offerings of the company this season, the number of listeners at this initial Wagnerian production proved surprisingly small.

Miss Josephine Roche, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, speaking last night to more than 1,200 persons in the Brooklyn Academy of Music at a meeting of the American Labor party, warned that "the Republican campaign presents to us the same masters in control as ruled in the privilege-dominated decade of 1920-1930."

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 11. -- Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton Pell gave a luncheon at the Cascades Club today for Mr. and Mrs. Martin M. Foss and Miss Ann Degnon. Mr. and Mrs. Theodore C. Schaeffer entertained at the club for McKinnon Ellis and Frank E. Rutan. Mr. and Mrs. John J. Hicks Kerr had as their luncheon guests in the Colonial Room Charles Delavan Wetmore, William White and Mr. and Mrs. William Wetmore.

Colonel Frank Knox, Republican Vice Presidential nominee, will leave New York today for an invasion of two Southern States, Virginia and North Carolina. Colonel Knox had spent the week-end in town, at the Waldorf-Astoria.
ATHENS, Ga., Oct. 11. -- Five University of Georgia students have met their housing problem by pressing into service two automobile trailers and a discarded carnival "hot-dog" stand.

Following one of the best mid-October Saturdays that intercollegiate football has seen in a good many moons, the nation-wide issue begins slowly to take shape. It is possible now to point with something akin to logic toward leading teams in practically every part of the country, thus yielding to the supposedly avid demand for championships, even though these championships usually must be qualified by that vague term mythical.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 11. -- Williams College, which is celebrating the centenary of the election of Mark Hopkins as its fourth president, today took several hundred alumni and undergraduates on a reverent pilgrimage to the past, reviving for a day, amidst a little changed environment, the spiritual atmosphere of oldtime New England.

WHITEMARSH, Pa., Oct. 11. -Holystone, owned by the Dilwyne Farm, was adjudged hunter champion at the final session of the Wissahickon Horse Show today. The reserve award went to Mrs. M. Robert Guggenheim's Firenze Red Tape.

Lying in a bed in Fifth Avenue Hospital yesterday Anna Halovka, 22 years old, of 374 East 152d Street, the Bronx, told detectives how she leaped from a window on the third floor of an apartment house at 171 East 106th Street to avoid being attacked by a young man, who was subsequently arrested on a charge of attempted criminal assault.
VIENNA, Oct. 11. -- Although police and military precautions against possible trouble by the Heimwehr were maintained, today passed perfectly calmly in Austria.

SUFFERN, N.Y., Oct. 11. -- Max Kaesche of Ridgewood led the field into the semi-final round of the first invitation tournament at the Houvenkopf Country Club today. He defeated J.H. Milburn of Suffern, 6 and 5. His opponent tomorrow is Alex Henderson of Pelham, who beat Dr. W.F. Hayes of Mahopac in the second round, 5 and 4.

Open bidding for the farm vote by the two parties threatens to set a bad example of that cutthroat competition from which the nation was said to have been delivered. In this instance, unfortunately, the throats to be cut would be those of taxpayers and consumers. Governor LANDON has gone so far as to startle and shock the President himself by the proposal of a large expenditure for the farmers.

LONDON, Oct. 9. -- Among the principal repercussions of devaluation of the franc is the flow of capital in three broad movements: First, to the United States; second, repatriation of funds to France, and third, investment money going to the London, Paris and New York stock markets.

The plan of the World Fair for 1939 in New York City was both praised and criticized from the pulpit yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Joseph P. McComas, vicar of St. Paul's Episcopal Chapel of Trinity Parish, Broadway and Fulton Street, said:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- An impartial course was credited to the Federal Trade Commission by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States in its "Washington Review" today in regard to the first five complaints brought by the regulatory body under the Robinson-Patman anti-price-discrimination act passed at the last session of Congress.

GREENFIELD, Ind., Oct. 11 (AP). -- Three small-sized Indiana hoodlums who had bragged they would outdo the late John Dillinger and his murderous gang today overpowered the Sheriff and escaped from the Hancock County jail where they were awaiting trial for the murder of an Indianapolis police sergeant.

GREENFIELD, Ind., Oct. 11 (AP). -- Three small-sized Indiana hoodlums who had bragged they would outdo the late John Dillinger and his murderous gang today overpowered the Sheriff and escaped from the Hancock County jail where they were awaiting trial for the murder of an Indianapolis police sergeant.

BERLIN, Oct. 10. -- The advance in prices on the Boerse here continued through the week, albeit at a somewhat slacker pace. Occasional reactions developed through switching by profit-takers into bonds.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. ll. -- Compulsory chapel attendance, long a subject of criticism at Princeton as well as other universities, has been approved by a small margin by the Princeton freshman class in a poll conducted by The Daily Princetonian, undergraduate newspaper.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 11. -- A gift of $255,000 from John D. Rockefeller Sr. and John D. Rockefeller Jr. saved their old church from financial difficulties today and embarked it upon a program designed to bring it new prominence.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 11. -- Before 50,000 Holy Name Society marchers who had formed one of the largest street parades ever witnessed in Newark, the Rev. Dr. James F. Kelley, president of Seton Hall College, declared at exercises in Lincoln Park this afternoon that "America has not been sold down the river to communism."

Dedication ceremonies for a new illuminated clock, installed 125 feet above the ground in a tower of the Rubsam Horrmann Brewery to replace a timepiece that had served as a landmark from 1878 to 1930, were held yesterday at Stapleton, S.I.
NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 12. -- Mr. Watt, trotting colt from the Newbrook Stables, set a new world record for a 2-year-old trotter over a half-mile track at Weequahic Park today. He went the mile in 2:05.

The following table gives the comparative volume of business in leading lines of distribution, together with the percentages of change between 1935 and the preceding censuses of 1933 and 1929, according to the summary of the census of distribution for New York State, issued yesterday by the Bureau of the Census of the Department of Commerce:

JERUSALEM, Palestine, Oct. 12 (AP). -- Crowds flocked today into Arab shops, open for the first time in twenty-five weeks, under the watchful eye of British troops alert to curb any renewal of the violence that took more than 400 lives during the Arabs' general strike.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 12. -- Before 250 members of the Society of Motion Picture Engineers today Dr. Howard H. Hanson, director of the Eastman School of Music, endorsed a direct tax on radios for the subsidy of entertainers.

ABOARD ROOSEVELT TRAIN EN ROUTE TO WICHITA, Kan., Oct. 12. -- President Roosevelt's invasion of Kansas began late this evening after he had crossed the border on his way East from Denver. After two incidental stops at Syracuse and Garden City, his train entered Dodge City, famous frontier town of an earlier day, where about 20,000 persons cheered him.

Montgomery Davis, young California baritone, made his New York debut in a recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. His program included two Mozart arias, Rose's "Star Vicino," a group in French by Hahn, Debussy, Tremisot and Holmes, a German division by Brahms, Wagner, Erich Wolff and Strauss and a final section in English by Carpenter, Buzzi-Peccia, Head and Wilbur Chenoweth, who played the accompaniments.

Dedication exercises for the new $250,000 parochial school of St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church at Jasmine Street near Parsons Boulevard, Jamaica, Queens, were held yesterday in the auditorium of the school. More than 1,000 persons were present.

BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 12. -- Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, one-time queen of tennis, and Don Budge, America's ace internationalist, won the Pacific Coast mixed doubles championship today by gaining a third set 6-4 victory over Miss Helen Hull Jacobs, Wimbledon titleholder, and Henry Culley of Santa Barbara.

LONDON, Oct. 12. -- Despite threats of American legal action an agreement has been signed and a 24,000,000 film deal partly completed between John Maxwell and the brothers Ostrer for acquisition of the Gaumont-British Picture Corporation, Ltd., according to a joint statement issued tonight.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 12. -- The entire Princeton football squad was in uniform today, contrary to the usual procedure for Monday practices, and went through a two-hour drill emphasizing fundamentals and assignments.
WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 12. -- The eye is the only one of man's five senses that serves as the medium by which he perceives all sporting events -- that is, all but automobile racing.

DES MOINES, Oct. 9. -- The detailed history of national conventions is ever in dispute. Did the President say jocularly over the long-distance telephone from Albany to Chicago in June, 1932, when the question was on the terms Mr. Hearst would require to release the California delegation: "Promise him the White House"?

Mrs. Anna Widmer, 60 years old, of 35-27 Sixty-first Street, Woodside, Queens, was killed by an automobile about 11 A.M. yesterday at Eightieth Street and Northern Boulevard, Jackson Heights, Queens, after she had alighted from a street car.

Benjamin J. Rabin, counsel to the State Mortgage Commission, will be the chief speaker at a luncheon of the Real Estate Club on Wednesday in the Hotel Commodore, Emil Leitner is chairman of the group.
Suburban dwellings held the chief interest of the realty market as trading yesterday in Manhattan was restricted because of the holiday. Several deals were closed in Brooklyn.

SAIGON, French Indo-China, Oct. 12. -- This tour around the world almost ended this morning at Bangkok, Siam. My plane, headed toward Penang, Straits Settlements, had been flying only twenty minutes when one of the engines failed. We flew back to the airport on three engines rather than risk a flight of 500 miles over the open sea.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 12. -- The Eastern Conference of the Methodist Protestant Church, closing its twenty-sixth annual session in the Trinity Methodist Protestant Church at Ventnor today, protested what it termed "traces of socialism in the program of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America."

Five hundred youthful "salts" assembled at Conservatory Lake in Central Park yesterday morning for the eighth semi-annual model sail and motor boat regatta sponsored by the Department of Parks and R.H. Macy Co. In their eagerness a majority of the youngsters were on hand several hours early, testing and rearranging the rigging on their craft for the best results.
The long-continued book starvation of the Public Library is an illustration of the strange workings of the official mind.
The record registration in this city last week of almost 2,900,000, which was 560,000 in excess of the previous mark established four years ago, has mystified political leaders of both major parties.

A woman whom the police identified as Mrs. Marjorie Voorhies Whatlley, 30 years old, a guest the last six months at the Pick-wick Arms Hotel, 230 East Fifty first Street, attempted suicide last night in her room at the hotel by slashing her wrists and throat.

BERLIN, Oct. 12. -- While something like a devaluation psychosis is beginning to spread through Germany, forcing prices upward on the Boerse and in butcher shops and making Germany's economic situation more acute, Rudolf Hess, Chancellor Adolf Hitler's deputy party leader, has proclaimed that the National Socialist regime will not capitulate either to economic starvation or a threat of armed force.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 12. -- The white-haired Gar Wood waved a green flag and started what seemed to be the greatest racket on earth. At least, the greatest racket on earth since they stopped the World War. As forty-five low-slung racing autos shot away in pursuit of the George Vanderbilt Cup on this new Roosevelt Raceway the spectacle was stunning and so was the noise.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- Money in circulation at the end of September amounted to $6,266,739,650, the Treasury reported today. This was an increase of $40,003,823 over the total on Aug. 31 and $583,610,683 over Sept. 30, 1935. The average per capita circulation was $48.72, compared with $48.43 on Aug. 31 and $44.49 a year ago.

LONDON, Oct. 12. -- A new visit by Ambassador Sir Robert Clive to the Tokyo Foreign Office today was a sign of renewed anxiety among many British business men over Japanese activity in the Yangtse Valley of China.

" We don't mind taking two lengths the worst of things according to the rules, but four lengths is more than any owner has a right to ask a game horse to make up." That is the way Victor Emanuel spoke following the finish of the six-furlong Interborough Handicap at Jamaica yesterday in which his fleet filly, Miss Merriment was beaten a short head by Bill Farnsworth.
BOSTON, Oct. 12. -- The veteran Glenn Warner's husky football team from Temple beat the Boston College Eagles, coached by another old timer, Gil Dobie, at Fenway Park today before 20,000 spectators.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- Arizona today lost its plea in the Supreme Court for a rehearing of its petition for permission to sue California and five other States for a final determination of water rights on the Colorado River.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP). -- A plea for preservation of American fundamentals for freedom was made here today by Secretary of State Cordell Hull in a Columbus Day address.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 12. -- The unemployment insurance bill drawn by the New Jersey Social Security Commission is attacked as "injurious to industry and commerce" in a memorandum sent to members of the New Jersey Press Association by that group's Social Security Committee and made public here today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 (AP). -- A "moral collapse was engulfing mankind," Bishop George Craig Stewart of Chicago declared tonight on the eve of the opening of the Pan-American Congress of the Episcopal Church, adding, "unification of Christian forces alone will destroy the enemies of civilization."

The Rev. George Drew Egbert, pastor of the First Congregational Church of Flushing, Queens, and president of the Society for the Prevention of Crime, and Samuel Marcus, counsel to the organization, made public yesterday charges filed last Friday with Governor Lehman calling for the removal of District Attorney John T. Delaney of Albany County.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor today accepted in part the proposal made by the convention of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers International Union for peace in the dispute with the Committee for Industrial Organization.

The Merchants Association, through its president, Louis K. Comstock, sent a letter yesterday to twenty-five other commercial organizations, asking them to join with it in supporting the new city charter.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- Described by attaches as probably the oldest attorney to be presented to the Supreme Court, James Melville Monserrat, 82 years old, of Honolulu, was admitted to practice today.
LYNCHBURG, Va., Oct. 12. -- Lynchburg today honored John Lynch who 150 years ago founded this city on the seven rugged hills of the James River. Guests were here from all parts of the country.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 12. -- The Mark Hopkins Centenary at Williams College ended today with a colorful academic procession, the award of nine honorary degrees and an address by President Tyler Dennett in which he announced bequests totaling $2,400,000 from Samuel Hopkins, New York cotton merchant and cousin of Mark Hopkins, who died in New York City in June.

In the face of the rapid expansion of Brazil's cotton program and a 25-fold increase in Japanese purchases of the staple from that country since June, the United States must follow a "give-and-take" policy in foreign trade or sell a diminishing share of its raw cotton output, Benjamin Adler, cotton authority, declared here yesterday.

In recognition of Columbus Day, Governor Alfred M. Landon of Kansas, Republican nominee for President, yesterday sent messages to Edward Corsi, former Commissioner of Immigration, and to Nicholas H. Pinto, president of the Columbian Republican League.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Oct. 7 shows decreases for the week of $75,000,000 in total loans and investments and $123,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, increases of $94,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and $113,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks, and a decrease of $14,000,000 in deposit balances of foreign banks.
SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Oct. 12 -- The 62,113 relief cases in drought-ridden South Dakota hold the answer to the outcome of the national and local elections in this State on Nov. 3.

Strong northwest winds, whipping at times with the force of a gale, moved the first cold snap of the Fall toward the city yesterday. A twenty-degree drop in temperature to a low of about 35 is expected this morning. The cool weather probably will continue for a few days.

At the funeral services for Frank Presbrey in the Central Presbyterian Church, 593 Park Avenue, at 11 o'clock this morning, the honorary pallbearers will be Daniel Carter Beard, Robert Bridges, Henry Bruere, Thomas A. Buckner, Frank Crane, Frederick H. Ecker, Phillip L. James, George McNeir, John L. Merrill, C.C. Paulding, John J. Pulleyn Howard W. Starr, Reginald L. Sweet and Dr. James E. West.

Lord and Lady Tennyson, Sir John Wardlaw-Milne, Miss Irene Ward, M.P., Mrs. Bourke Cockran and Captain and Mrs. David C. Hanrahan are among those due today from Southampton via Cherbourg on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania.

Austria is moving toward a greater degree of unity and perhaps also of real independence. Following an eighteen-hour Cabinet meeting which ended Saturday morning, Chancellor KURT SCHUSCHNIGG emerged with even a greater degree of absolute power than that held by Chancellor DOLLFUSS.
BERLIN, Oct. 12. -- One of this city's most distinguished hotels was the scene yesterday of a whale meat luncheon, given by Dr. Herman Reischle, departmental chief of the German Nutritive Guild.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- Figures of the cost of the Works Progress Administration program were made public today for the first time by Harry L. Hopkins, Administrator.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 12. -- On his way to Cleveland today Governor Landon continued to attack the New Deal in speeches at Mount Vernon, Millersburg, Orrville and Akron.

BERLIN, Oct. 12. -- The Roman Catholic Bishop of Berlin, Count von Preysing, protests in a new pastoral letter against repeated suppression by the secret police of declarations and documents issued by Catholic Bishops of Germany.

MOCEJON, Spain, Oct. 12. -- Hard-driving government forces, protecting the vital railroad junction of Castillejos, eighteen miles northeast of Toledo, succeeded tonight in pinning the Insurgents to the north side of the Tagus River and moved up almost to the gates of Toledo itself.

Mail orders received in the wholesale markets here yesterday were heavy, reflecting the increased activity in retail trade last week. Coats, dresses, accessories, children's wear and home furnishings were in active demand to replenish retail stocks.

So rapid are the advances being made in medicine that there is every justification for believing that the next fifty years will bring even greater triumphs in medical science than the fifty years just past, Dr. Lewellys F. Barker, emeritus Professor of Medicine of Johns Hopkins University, predicted last night in a lecture at the Brooklyn Jewish Center.

Showing an utter disregard for his rival's superior boxing ability, and forcing the fighting throughout, Joe Vignali, Waterbury, Conn., lightweight, held Ralph (Indian) Hurtado to a draw last night in the feature bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct 12. -- Making a brilliant comeback after a disappointing showing yesterday, Sand Man, 6-year-old chestnut gelding, was named hunter champion as the sixth annual two-day Saxon Woods Hunt Club horse show came to a successful conclusion today.

MANILA, Philippines, Oct. 12 (AP). -- Floods intensified tonight the horrors of a destructive typhoon that swept five provinces of the Philippine Archipelago, killing some 400 persons, leaving hundreds of others unaccounted for and isolating whole districts.

The letter from Earle Hooker Eaton concerning the separate postoffices in New York and Brooklyn expresses the sentiments of many persons who have been inconvenienced by unintentionally sending mail bearing insufficient postage between these two points.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 12. -- Professional football, President Joe F. Carr of the National League said today, is enjoying its greatest season.

The Gilbert and Sullivan folk have almost reached the end of their repertory; not, of course, the end of their welcome, that being endless. But last night they gave "Princess Ida" before the amiable crowds at the Martin Beck, and in another ten days they will provide the final chapter for the season with "Ruddigore."

BERLIN, Oct. 12. -- A large number of international aeronautic experts have arrived in Berlin for a two-day conference under the auspices of the Lilienthal Society for aeronautic research, which will open at the Kroll Operhaus tomorrow.

LONDON, Oct. 12. -- News that the United States, Great Britain and France had made a further important agreement supplementing the recent exchange agreement between the three countries was given out here in the following statement by the Treasury:

Supporters of democracy in Germany are cowards not to call the bluff of the Hitler dictatorship, for if they did the Nazi regime soon would end, Ernst Toller, radical German playwright and author, declared yesterday on his arrival on the French liner Normandie.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 12. -- Perhaps one of the reasons for the success of the Italian cars in the auto race today was their marvelous equipment. For one thing, they had hydraulic brakes, a feature which enabled them to slow down at the turns or at any time they chose and pick up speed immediately thereafter.

Several large apartments on the East Side were reported among yesterday's leases. Among these were thirteen rooms and five baths in River House, 435 East Fifty-second Street, to Joseph R. Swan, stock broker, and an apartment at 75 East Fifty-fifth Street to W. Forbes Morgan, both by Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., the latter for the Edmar Realty Company.

I should be obliged if you will correct a serious error concerning myself in a dispatch published in your columns Oct. 10. It says that in my speech I stated that I was definitely separating myself from the existing profit system, which means that I am getting out of my present business connections.

The trustees of the Corcoran Gallery of Art announce that the Fifteenth Biennial Exhibition of Contemporary American Oil Paintings will open to the public on Sunday, March 28, 1937, and will continue through Sunday, May 9. The exhibition will be confined to original oil paintings by living American artists and not previously publicly exhibited in Washington.

THE name of Georges Duhamel is better known in France than in this country, but for various reasons it is fairly familiar here. Two volumes of his Pasquier cycle have already been published in the United States; in 1931 there appeared his "America the Menace," a bitter criticism of our civilization; he was recently named to the French Academy and thereby rendered officially august.

Immediate wage increases varying from $1 a week to $5 and $8 a week were granted last night to garage employees by Ben Golden, associate director of the Regional Labor Board, who was appointed by Mayor La Guardia to act as arbitrator following the strike of garage workers three weeks ago.

After long years of patient servitude, this column has learned never to take the Theatre Guild's first play seriously. This season the dram academy in Fifty-second Street has thoughtfully put its worst foot forward with a comedy entitled "And Stars Remain," by Julius J. and Philip G. Epstein, brothers in the iniquity of factitious playmaking.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Oct. 12. -- Any long-range program of crime prevention must set up as one objective the clearance of slum areas, declared Dr. William Grady, Associate Superintendent of Schools in New York City, before the Association of Teachers College and Normal School Faculties meeting in conference here today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12. -- Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, answered tonight Republican charges of mismanagement of the WPA with the assertion that "we make no apology for the money we have spent or the way we have spent it."

Clark M. Eichelberger, director of the League of Nations Association, who returned yesterday on the Normandie from the recent World Peace Congress in Brussels and the Assembly of the League of Nations, said that as a result of currency stabilization reduced tariff barriers were being effected, bringing Europe closer to peace and prosperity.

Distributions from funds of the New York Community Trust in the first three-quarters of this year totaled $104,161, compared with $101,943 in the first nine months of last year, according to a report issued yesterday. The Visiting Nurse Service took first place among recipients.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- Cardinal Hayes blessed Butler Hall, the new $400,000 dormitory and administration building of Marymount College on the occasion of its official opening today. Hundreds of parents, friends and members of religious orders visited the elaborate building.

DETROIT, Oct. 12. -- The hum of industry has risen to a roar in this city and the same happy sound is to be heard in the other industrial centers of Michigan. And, on the farms of the lower peninsula and mines of the upper better times have come also.

Spokesmen here for organized labor and for consumers, commenting on the Supreme Court's action in the Minimum Wage Law case, declared yesterday that some way must be found by legislation or constitutional amendment to protect women and children in industry.

Susan Bernstein, a dimpled, 4-year-old miss who has been riding a tricycle for nearly two years, became the youngest false alarmist in the Bronx yesterday. Her act was the result of a fleeting impulse which Susan herself could not explain.

PARIS, Oct. 12. -- Prices on the Bourse resumed today their strong upward trend after Friday's depressing session. Technical and political reasons contributed to the restoration of confidence. Opening prices were strong and the list generally finished at the highest levels of the day.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12. -- A charge that Acting Secretary of War Harry H. Woodring, while Governor of Kansas, was responsible for advocating legislation to cut appropriations to schools was made today in a radio speech by Dr. Ernest F. Pihlblad, a member of the Kansas Board of Education.
DENVER, Oct. 12. -- The text of President Roosevelt's speech here today was as follows:

PARIS, Oct. 12. -- Official comment here treats the Morgenthau announcement of the decision of the British, French and American equalization funds to exchange gold as a completion of the tri-power declaration of last month.

DURHAM, N.C., Oct. 12 (AP). -- Baseball's "brown derby" was called into play with the opening of the minor league draft season when the destinies of two players had to be decided by a drawing from a hat.

Mrs. William W. Fleming, who heads the executive committee for the December ball in behalf of the Grosvenor Neighborhood House to be held Dec. 3 in the ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton, will give a tea today at her home, 850 Park Avenue, for the chairmen of the various committees aiding her in the plans for the benefit.

LIVERPOOL, Oct. 12 (AP). -- A spurt in wheat futures in the last five minutes of trading today lifted prices about 2 cents a bushel to the highest levels in six years. The December advanced to the equivalent of $1.24 1/2 a bushel and March to $1.17 1/2, based on the exchange rate of $4.90 3/4 for the British pound.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 12. -- Following are the prepared speeches delivered today by Governor Landon:

Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, announced yesterday that he had approved and forwarded to Washington the suggestion of the Board of Education that a project for remedial teaching in high schools be set up in place of the recently disapproved High School Tutoring Project.

LONDON, Oct. 12 (AP). -- Down in the kitchens of Buckingham Palace King Edward's new French chef, Mr. Legros, busied himself over the royal menu today. Selected at the monarch's command by Sir George Clerk, British Ambassador to Paris, Mr. Legros has earned the reputation of being one of the best cooks in France.
LONDON, Oct. 12 -- For the first time in history railway travelers from Paris to London slept their way in luxury tonight across the English Channel.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- Thege cases were among those lost by appellants through action by the Supreme Court today:
A ban on women on either side of a bar "in the interests of temperate drinking" was urged yesterday by bartenders affiliated with the International Geneva Association.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- Chief interest in the Supreme Court actions today centered on the Minimum Wage Law, because the decision that the New York statute was unconstitutional had echoed into the Presidential campaign.
MADRID, Oct. 12 (Passed by the Censor). -- The Minister of the Interior today ordered the requisitioning of blankets and mattresses in private homes.

Contradicting Park Commissioner Robert Moses's prediction that park, parkway and playground work would have to be cut 30 per cent next year because of the $3,000,000 reduction in his departmental budget request, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday that "there will be no curtailment of any kind" by the department.
Governor Lehman will launch his active speaking campaign for reelection tonight as he invades Nassau County for an address at Valley Stream.

In a strongly worded letter condemning the recent authorization of uniform fines for traffic violations, City Magistrate Michael A. Ford accused Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr., yesterday, of trying to reduce magistrates to the status of "rubber stamps."

The creation of Bishops in the Lutheran communion in the United States will be asked at the tenth biennial convention of the United Lutheran Church in America at Columbus, Ohio, opening tomorrow evening and continuing a week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- Acquisition of 1,000 shares of capital stock of the Amoskeag Industries, Inc., in addition to water rights and hydroelectric properties in New Hampshire by the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, was authorized today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which held that the selling company was not a public utility organization and that purchase by the Public Service Company would benefit the citizens of Manchester.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 12. -- Society's prominent sports enthusiasts and their guests viewed the Vanderbilt Cup race today from their roof terrace boxes of the three-story clubhouse. Painted blue with touches of green and rimmed with fluttering flags of the five nations participating in the 300-mile event, the clubhouse made a bright setting for the assembly of social notables and fashion array.

On the approach of Columbus Day school children as well as grown-ups will have their annual privilege of listening to orations in the course of which the great explorer will be credited with the discovery of the earth's sphericity.

Speaking before 6,000 garment workers at a Columbus Day celebration in the Hippodrome yesterday, Governor Lehman welcomed the decision of the Supreme Court to review the principle of minimum-wage legislation by reconsidering the law of the State of Washington.

An attempt to introduce and popularize "beer evenings" as a rival to cocktail parties will be made by brewing interests at the annual convention of the United States Brewers' Association in Chicago, Oct. 20-21. Run along formal lines, the beer evening will be featured by an attempt to "take beer parties out of the slightly bucolic setting of picnic grounds and red-checkered tablecloths," according to the advance notices of the affair.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Oct. 12. -- Bloomfield High School's Bengals went on a scoring spree today to register a crushing 68-0 triumph over South Side High of Newark. The victors' goal line never was threatened.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- Postal officials said today that despite "disturbed conditions" in Spain and the establishment of an almost complete ring of Insurgent forces around Madrid, American mail was "filtering through" into the Spanish capital.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- The Republican National Committee, resuming its attacks upon the Post-office Department today, charged that James A. Farley as Postmaster General had "fired" 510 out of 850 "service" postmasters "who had worked their way up under the merit system."

SUFFERN, N.Y., Oct. 12. -- Max Kaesche, veteran tournament star from the Ridgewood Country Club, won the first invitation tournament of the Houvenkopf Country Club today, defeating Bill Fenn, a member of the home club, 3 and 2, in the final.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- The Supreme Court refused today to grant a rehearing of the case in which the New York Minimum Wage Law for women was rejected by a five-to-four decision last June as unconstitutional.
YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 12. -- William F. Bleakley, Republican candidate for Governor, pledged himself today to make a campaign of good faith in which the promises made would be kept.
BERLIN, Oct. 12. -- The Boerse here staged another upward rush today. The turnover was limited by a marked lack of offers. Raw-material producers, utilities and allied shares led the market.

Frank J. Prial, former Acting Controller, who lost the Democratic nomination for the Presidency of the Board of Aldermen to Sheriff William F. Brunner of Queens, announced yesterday that he had abandoned his court fight to have his name appear on the voting machines on election day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- The United States has entered into a reciprocal arrangement with Great Britain and France for the purchase and sale of gold through stabilization funds of the respective countries in a move to reduce further the fluctuations of the leading international currencies -- the dollar, the pound and the franc.

Mr. BORAH has been discovering his constituents in Idaho, many of whom must have come to regard him as a permanent resident of Washington and a perpetual Congress of One there sitting. He is skilled to touch the social and "genial" stops. He has acquired a strong new affection for Idaho, so long a strange land to him.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 12. -- Holy Cross defeated Harvard in both varsity and freshman cross country this morning. The varsity score was 21 to 34, but the freshman race was much closer, 27 to 28.
LONDON, Oct. 12. -- Germany has raised objections to the Russian reservations in the draft of the Anglo-Russian naval treaty, recently communicated to interested naval powers.

BOSTON, Oct. 12. -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin asserted tonight that Governor Curley had "admitted" over the telephone to him that he was threatened with defeat by Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. in the Senate race unless Thomas C. O'Brien, Union party Senatorial candidate, withdrew.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 12 -- Further police investigation of charges of illegal practice against Dr. George Harley, whose offices at 175 Milford Avenue here were raided last Friday, revealed today a club plan of birth control in which at least 800 women participated at $2 a month each, according to the authorities.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 12. -- Tazio Nuvolari, whose sensational racing feats have stamped him a most daring driver, proved again today that he merits the reputation of "the man without nerves." In an amazing exhibition of skill and courage he thrilled a crowd of 50,000 at the new Roosevelt Raceway as he swept home an easy winner of the first George Vanderbilt Cup auto race.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12. -- Restricted supplies and higher prices for meats for the next few years were foreseen today as packers assembled here for the annual convention of the Institute of American Meat Packers.

The same sort of fixity of purpose that has enabled women to invade most masculine prerogatives carried men nurses to victory yesterday in a protracted campaign to escape professional domination by their more numerous feminine colleagues.

WOODBURY, L.I., Oct. 12. -Many members of society attended this afternoon the fifteenth annual meeting of the West Hills Racing Association on the estates of Colonel Henry L. Stimson, former Secretary of State, and Thomas F. White.

NEWARK, Oct. 12. -- William H. Smathers of Atlantic City, candidate for United States Senator, repeated his "slush fund" charge against the Republicans in an address made at a Democratic rally of women from Essex, Union and Morris Counties at the Essex House today.

BERLIN, Oct. 12. -- The Propaganda Ministry said tonight the German Government had ordered its Ambassador in Paris to lodge a formal protest against an alleged insult to Chancellor Hitler by Maurice Thorez, secretary general of the French Communist party.
Formation of a Labor League for Norman Thomas was announced yesterday by Socialist headquarters, with A. Philip Randolph, president of the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters, as chairman.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 12 -- The National Dairy Industries Exposition got under way here today with conventions of allied groups, a contest of college teams in judging grades of dairy products and a series of awards to milkmen for deeds of heroism while covering their routes.

LONDON, Oct. 12 (AP). -- For three years a small army of government clerks has been checking up the estate left by Sir John Ellerman, little-known "richest man in England's history" -- and they are still hard at it today.

SAN MARTIN DE VALDEIGLESIAS, Spain, Oct. 12 (AP). -- Loyalist bombing planes, attempting to drive Rebel troops from their positions, bombarded their own forces today in two air attacks. The bombardment occurred while government militiamen were attempting counter-attacks on the Rebel columns.

LONDON, Oct. 12. -- The stock market here was firm today, although British funds again were dull because of nervousness over the international situation. German securities weakened in the foreign market. Home rails were narrow and the foreign issues irregular.
HENDAYE, France, Oct. 12. -- The tragic struggle between Loyalist Asturian miners and the remnants of the besieged Rebel force in Oviedo, Spain, continued today with unabated violence.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 12. -- Dick Harlow and his assistant coaches at Harvard were in good spirits today as they began preparing for Saturday's game with Army. No injuries developed from last Saturday's game with Brown.
Among the tributes paid to Edwin Blashfield yesterday were the following:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- Mrs. Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney and other executors of the estate of Harry Payne Whitney, lost a fight today to obtain a Supreme Court review of their contest to recover an additional assessment of $287,385 and interest on income taxes due for the year 1926.

A complaint was filed yesterday with the shipping board bureau of the Department of Commerce by Phelps Brothers Co., Inc., of 17 Battery Place, charging that four ship lines operating to the Near East were attempting to create a freight monopoly in that trade in violation of the Shipping Act of 1916.

Production of rubber tires this year is expected to reach a total of 52,000,000 units, the largest output since 1930, according to P.W. Litchfield, president of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company. In a statement made public today Mr. Litchfield said that the return of normal business conditions and the gains made by the automobile industry since 1932 have combined to bring about this increasing demand.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12. -- Senator Joseph T. Robinson conceded here tonight that Alfred E. Smith had the right to "take a walk" in the present campaign, but he declared that the loss of the former New York Governor by the Democrats had been overcome by defections from Republican ranks.

The exhibition opening yesterday at the Brooklyn Museum, entitled "Four Centuries of Portraiture in Prints," might well have been subtitled "From Duerer to Moholy-Nagy." It was arranged by Carl O. Schniewind, curator of prints and drawing, and is one of the most rewarding exhibitions in this medium that the museum has yet put on.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 12 (AP). -- Colonel Frank Knox, Republican Vice Presidential nominee, began his quest for Democratic votes from the "solid South" by asserting in a speech here tonight that to re-elect President Roosevelt "may easily destroy the Democratic party."

A solemn high mass of requiem was celebrated yesterday morning for the Rev. Dr. James E. Noonan, pastor of St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church, Barclay and Church Streets, who died last Friday as a result of a nervous breakdown after the celebration a year ago of St. Peter's sesquicentennial.
Auditions for membership in the Community Orchestra will be held at the music school of the Henry Street Settlement tonight.

Hailing it as a "real American holiday which should be celebrated by all the people of the Americas," Governor Herbert H. Lehman, speaking yesterday at one of the city's largest gatherings commemorating Columbus Day, declared half the courage displayed by Columbus would resolve the problems of this generation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP). -- A Democratic complaint that money was being raised in Wall Street to be used in an unlawful attempt to buy New Jersey votes for Republican candidates brought a promise of investigation today from the Senate committee on campaign expenditures.
DENVER, Oct. 12 (AP). -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt perched on the foot of a bed at Fitzsimons Hospital today and visited Anna V. Herendeen, former newspaper writer.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 12 (AP). -- Secretary Roper said tonight that Governor Landon's political strategy was "to frighten the American people with the specter of bankruptcy, the very thing from which the Roosevelt administration has saved us."

AUBURN, N.Y., Oct. 12 (AP). -- General Hugh Johnson said at a Democratic rally here tonight that "if Al Smith had known a little more about the farm problem, he wouldn't have been kicked out in 1928."

MADRID, Oct. 12 (AP). -- Government defenders of Madrid sloshed over rain-drenched roads tonight to give battle to advancing Rebels at Navalperal de Pinares, Valdemaqueda and Caba del Quejido -- important points in the defense of the capital.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- The United States imported 48,179 tons of iron and steel valued at $2,242,409 in August, compared with 38,350 tons valued at $1,691,396 in July and 29,936 tons valued at $1,399,636 in August of last year, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Unless Kentucky's gridiron rivals get together and do something about stopping Bob Davis, the half-back flash threatens to run away not only with the Southeastern Conference scoring title but with national honors as well, according to The Associated Press.

From Chicago come doleful reports about both parties having run into a shortage of campaign funds. If this is the case, it is because both of them have pitched their hopes and their budgets too high. It has been credibly stated that the Republicans intended to collect and to spend $8,000,000.

Enthused at the prosect of its first road game since the end of the 1932 season, Manhattan's football team launched preparations for its battle with Holy Cross at Worcester Saturday in a two-hour morning drill at Innisfail Park yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum for the week ended on Oct. 3 amounted to 294,349,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines. This represents a decrease of 219,000 barrels from the previous week.

It would not be short of sacrilege if the New York State World War Memorial at Albany were not to be the best work of art that the architectural genius of this State or nation can produce. The proposed structure with its adornment to be placed upon the capital's acropolis must be one in which beauty is the supreme element.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12. -- Eventual application to automobile and other accidents of the principle of compensation now operating in industrial accidents was forecast tonight by Owen B. Hunt, Pennsylvania Insurance Commissioner, addressing the annual convention of the National Association of Mutual Insurance Companies.

MOSCOW, Oct. 12. -- Indignantly denying the charge of Dino Grandi, Italian Ambassador to London, that the Soviet ships Neva and Kuban were smuggling munitions to Spain under cover of food shipments, the captain of the Neva has challenged officers of the Italian war vessels at Alicante to inspect the unloading of his ship there to see for themselves.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12. -- The setting up of an American Newspaper Institute to assist advertisers and agencies in the advertising use of newspapers was approved by the Newspaper Advertising Executives' Association today at the opening session of a two-day convention.

Alfredo Salmaggi's opera company gave matinee and evening performances at the New York Hippodrome yesterday, playing to a full house in the afternoon and to a near-capacity audience in the evening. More than 8,000 persons heard both bills.

The boys were talking about novel and hazardous fishing spots. Immediately the tall, dark young man we know as Tom cast his vote for the Rockaway Jetty as the place most likely to give the intrepid angler a full quota of chills and thrills.

An acute delivery situation in the better dress field is bothering retailers and to some extent is hampering retail dress sales throughout the country, merchandising executives here reported yesterday. Leading style houses are promising delivery in from two to four weeks, and in some cases six weeks.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12. -- The cattle market today was swamped by the heaviest receipts of "commercial" stock in five years, including some of the largest receipts or record from the Western range States. About 55 per cent of the 29,000 head received came from the ranges.

President Roosevelt will receive a plurality of between 1,000,000 and 1,100,000 in New York City on election day, Democratic National Chairman James A. Farley predicted yesterday. He made his prediction after his staff had analyzed, district by district, the unprecedented registration of 2,900,000 voters recorded last week.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 12. -- Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf, former Superintendent of the New Jersey State police and a principal figure in the investigation of the Lindbergh baby kidnapping, has entered private business. He is executive vice president of the Middlesex Transportation Company of this city, which conducts a trucking business between New York and Philadelphia.

The Green Bay Packers and the Boston Redskins have succeeded in ousting the Chicago Bears from the lead as the best offensive team in the National Football League, according to the statistics released yesterday. The Packers have amassed 1,116 yards to take the lead, with Boston, gaining 1,034 yards, for second place.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 12. -- Lehigh is already numbered among the beaten teams of the season, but regardless of its 20-6 setback by Dickinson, any future opponent that holds the Engineers lightly may pay dearly for the presumption.

Outplayed for the greater part of the game, Erasmus Hall's plucky eleven made its own breaks to down a heavier James Madison High School team, 9 -- 7, before 14,000 persons at Ebbets Field yesterday in their annual Columbus Day classic.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 12. -- Speaking in the municipal auditorium in which four months ago he was nominated for the Presidency, Governor Landon tonight condemned the Roosevelt method of administering relief as a failure and a national scandal, and proposed a program of Federal aid under State and local direction.

The courage of Columbus is needed today to offset the tide which is running against faith in our national welfare, Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo said yesterday in a Columbus Day address over radio Station WOR.
Policies and achievements of the New Deal have been analyzed and appraised by The Economist of London in a special twenty-three-page supplement to its Oct. 3 issue, which has just been received here.

The Supreme Court refused yesterday to reconsider its decision of last June holding unconstitutional the New York State Minimum Wage Law, and one element of uncertainty has now been removed from a situation which has caused confusion.

The report of the United States Building and Loan League's Committee on FHA, adopted yesterday at a meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, says that the necessity for such a governmental enterprise as the Federal Housing Administration has passed and there are real dangers from the point of view of the public credit cost to the government should it continue permanently.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 12. -- Despite the din raised by airplanes streaking through the sky and high-geared automobiles speeding over the adjoining Roosevelt Raceway in the 300-mile Vanderbilt Cup-race, three of the four flights in the third annual Meadow Brook Club invitation best-ball tournament completed play today.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12. -- "Forbidden Melody," described as "a modern musical," was presented by Jack Kirkland and Sam H. Grisman at the Erlanger Theatre here tonight in its premiere performance.

DENVER, Oct. 12. -- In the bluntest campaign speech he has yet delivered, President Roosevelt today recited to a great audience here an outline of economic changes under his administration, and asked voters of the West to choose between these acts and the "two-faced" promises which he said were being made by his Republican opposition.

Retail trade in New York City last year totaled $2,685,435,000 an increase of 20 per cent over the figures for 1933, but 27 per cent below the 1929 total, according to the preliminary retail summary for this city and New York State issued yesterday by William L. Austin, director of the Bureau of Census of the Department of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- The government won a tactical victory today when the Supreme Court agreed to review the administration's fight to stave off all legal attacks on the constitutionality of the Public Utility Act until the Electric Bond and Share case has been decided.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 12. -- Infantry, a 3-year-old gelding from the Millsdale Stable, and winner of only one other race this year, captured the Easton Purse, feature event of today's program at Laurel.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Oct. 12. -- The Long Island Hunt Cup, feature of the fifteenth annual meeting of the West Hills Racing Association, went to the Old Mill Farm's Rod today after the Northwood Stable's Pimochio had been disqualified.

BASLE, Switzerland, Oct. 12. -- The World Bank directors unanimously adopted today a resolution urging general monetary stability and merely noting noncommittally the Anglo-Franco-American declaration of last month and subsequent developments. The resolution reads:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- California, Oregon and Washington had a retail sales volume amounting to $3,172,261,000 last year, according to an announcement today by the American Retail Federation on the basis of figures obtained recently in the United States business census of the Department of Commerce. This was an increase of 39 per cent over the 1933 sales total.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- The government won a tactical victory today when the Supreme Court agreed to review the administration's fight to stave off all legal attacks on the constitutionality of the Public Utility Act until the Electric Bond and Share case has been decided.

Retail trade in New York City last year totaled $2,685,435,000 an increase of 20 per cent over the figures for 1933, but 27 per cent below the 1929 total, according to the preliminary retail summary for this city and New York State issued yesterday by William L. Austin, director of the Bureau of Census of the Department of Commerce.
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 13. -- July 31 may be the date for the first of the America's Cup races next year between the American defender and T.O.M. Sopwith's challenger Endeavour II.

Regulations which will fully protect the consumer were strongly advocated by Harry L. Lourie, executive secretary of the National Association of Alcoholic Beverage Importers, Inc., at the annual meeting of the organization at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night.
ALBANY, Oct. 13. -- A new slate of Union party candidates for State offices was filed with the Secretary of State tonight to replace candidates who withdrew last week.

Results of operations of the various industrial companies that announced yesterday earnings for the first nine months of this year showed without exception substantial gains over the corresponding period of 1935.
DETROIT, Oct. 13. -- Following are the prepared texts of the two addresses made by Governor Landon today:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- A decline of about 1,500,000 bales in the indicated supply of domestic cotton for the 1936-37 season, compared with last year, was reported today by the Bureau of Agricultural Economies. The indicated supply was placed at 18,100,000 bales, the smallest since the 1924-25 season.

The agreement among the United States, Great Britain and France whereby the operations of their respective stabilization funds will be facilitated through purchases and sales of gold was welcomed in banking circles here yesterday as a further step in the direction of monetary stability.

FLINT, Mich., Oct. 13. -- Substantially reduced prices on the two smaller lines of Buick cars for 1937 were announced here today by W.F. Hufstader, general sales manager. The feature of the "Forty" series is a four-door, five-passenger sedan, with enlarged luggage compartment, priced at the factory at $845, a reduction of $40 under the same model in the 1936 line.
The More Game Birds Foundation recently predicted the best duck hunting season in five years and estimated the 1936 wildfowl crop at 48,000,000. an increase of 15 per cent over last year.

A conference was called yesterday by Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews to determine what New York State can do toward minimum-wage regulation for women and minors in view of the Supreme Court's denial of the State's application for a rehearing on the constitutionality of the State Minimum Fair Wage Act.

The Board of Aldermen, in a brief meeting yesterday, solved its dispute with Mayor La Guardia over the purchase of new snow removal machinery by voting to divide an appropriation of $965,250 evenly between the Snogo machine and the Joy snowloader.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- The American Federation of Labor's executive council met today with both sides in The Seattle Post-Intelligencer labor dispute, in which a strike sponsored by the American Newspaper Guild forced the paper to suspend publication.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Oct. 14. -- A two-and-a-half-hour conference yesterday between Kao Chung-wu, chief of the Asiatic Affairs Department of the Foreign Office, and Consul General Yakichiro Suma of Japan failed to result in any agreement on conditions for formal resumption of Chino-Japanese negotiations between Foreign Minister Chang Chun and Ambassador Shigera Kawagoe.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP). -- Early approval of a plan to remove railroad tracks from the main street of Passaic, N.J., was urged upon Public Works Administration officials today by Nicholas Martini, Passaic commissioner.
GUAM ISLAND, Wednesday, Oct. 14. -- The China Clipper, with nineteen men on board, alighted here this afternoon after a 1,526-mile flight from Wake Island in 9 hours and 52 minutes.

DETROIT, Oct. 13. -- The memory of Samuel Gompers, who for many years was president of the American Federation of Labor and consistently refused to tie trade unionism to any political party, was invoked today by Governor Landon in a speech at Toledo.

NUTLEY, N.J., Oct. 13. -- A birdie 3 on the last hole enabled Mrs. William Hockenjos of Crestmont, New Jersey champion, to win the final one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association with an 88 at the Yountakah Country Club today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 (AP). -- The first four-week period in Sears, Roebuck Co.'s history in which sales exceeded $50,000,000 has just been concluded, the company reported today. Their mail-order and retail sales for the ninth period, from Sept. 11 to Oct. 8, totaled $50,388,116, compared with $37,710,648 in the corresponding period last year.

Alexander Sklarevski, a musician of serious purpose and solid attainments, gave a piano recital at the Town Hall last night, his first in New York in fifteen years. He began with a clean-cut, graceful, satisfying performance of Haydn's Sonata in E minor.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13. -- Taxes which are designed to stifle business competition strike at consumers and limit the market for farm products, H.C. Merritt Jr., chairman of the California Canning Peach Stabilization Committee of San Francisco, warned today at the annual meeting of the Food and Grocery Chain Stores of America, Inc.

The first program of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, which will open its ninety-fifth season on Nov. 5 at Carnegie Hall, was announced yesterday. John Barbirolli, British conductor, who will direct the first ten weeks of the orchestra's season, will arrive on the Aquitania on Oct. 27.

Visiting buyers recorded in the market during the week ended yesterday numbered less than in the preceding week and the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES. The arrivals for the week were 905, as against 975 in the preceding week and 1,083 in the same period last year.

A sentimental and philosophical James J. Walker lamented last night the decline of New York City and evoked a swift kaleidoscope of the horse-cars days when the city was at "its greatest, because there was a neighborhood spirit." The former Mayor spoke as Jimmy, a member of the Grand Street Boys Association, to the members at a meeting at the clubhouse, 106 West Fifty-fifth Street.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 13. -- There are still 2,700 cows producing milk in New York City for local consumption, Dr. John R. Rice, Health Commissioner for New York City, told the International Association of Milk Dealers in convention at the Chalfonte-Haddon Hall here this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- Conspiracy and coercion on the part of officials of the Public Works Administration and the Tennessee Valley Authority to compel Tennessee and Alabama State and muncipal officers to buy TVA electric current is charged in a suit filed in the Federal District Court today by the West Tennessee Power and Light Company, whose main officers are in Jackson, Tenn.

EMPORIA, Kan., Oct. 13. -- President Roosevelt and William Allen White, editor of The Emporia Gazette and currently an adviser of Governor Landon, surprised each other today when Mr. Roosevelt stopped here on his campaign tour of Kansas.

Unprincipled judges serving as political puppets and the trend of legal theory away from the natural law toward pragmatism are reasons for a growing distrust of the judiciary, the Very Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University, declared yesterday in a sermon at the annual red mass for lawyers at St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Church, Duane Street and Cardinal Place.

At its Forty-eighth Street home Artef began its season last night with a hop, skip and a jump. Devoted though it is to plays of the Left, this Jewish workers' art theatre presented an antic comedy by Sholom Aleichem which even comfortable bourgeois can enjoy.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13. -- The Baldwin Locomotive Works announced today that the dollar value of orders taken in September by it and subsidiary companies, including the Midvale Company, totaled $2,532,734, compared with $1,140,788 for September, 1935.

A banking group headed by Lazard Freres Co., Inc., obtained the award yesterday of a new issue of $1,500,000 of State of Maryland emergency certificates of indebtedness on a bid of 107.889 for 2 3/4s. The bonds, dated Oct. 15, 1936, and maturing in 1939 to 1951, were re-offered at prices to yield from 0.90 to 2.00 per cent, according to maturity.

Demands for increased educational appropriations for 1937 were made upon Mayor La Guardia and the Board of Estimate yesterday at the first public hearing on the 1937 tentative budget, held in City Hall with an audience that occupied every available seat and overflowed into the corridors.

BOSTON, Oct. 13. -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin told a press conference tonight that he had taken up with editors of The Boston Globe an incident at Providence last night which brought him into physical conflict with a reporter for that paper.

As superintendent of the United States Naval Academy I am writing to you to request space in which to comment on certain criticisms of the academy. These criticisms were typified in an article "Annapolis -- Stronghold of Mediocrity," by James Oliver Brown, published in the October issue of The Forum. From time to time they have arisen from other sources.
Purchase and leasehold deals in various parts of Manhattan were included in the urban realty turnover reported yesterday.

The opening part of the President's speech in Kansas yesterday sounded like a strain from the oratorio of "Elijah." He begged his hearers not to be frightened at all the bogies and ghosts and werewolves and hobgoblins of all varieties that were being paraded before their eyes by Republican committees and speakers.

CARNARVON, Wales, Oct. 13. -- A dour Welsh pastor testified today that he and two other Welsh nationalists were justified in burning buildings of a British bombing school because:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13. -- A prediction that wheat, corn and cotton would be the three major crops to receive the attention of Federal officials in the event of the passage of a crop insurance bill at the next session of Congress was made here today by Roy M. Green of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics.

Charges of two textile manufacturers in the Madison Square district that hundreds of Communist labor agitators in the last week had carried on riots in front of their plants, assaulting and abducting some of their employes, will be laid before the grand jury today.

The "tripartite agreement" between the United States, France and Great Britain, published yesterday and designed to promote the stabilizing of the three nations' currencies and foreign exchanges, was a natural first step toward effecting the purposes already announced by the Governments on Sept. 25.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Oct. 13. -- Playing an unbeatable brand of golf on both nines, Herman Barron and Saul Lantzis of Fenway collaborated to manufacture a surprising 62 and capture the honors in the Westchester County Professional Golfers Association one-day pro-amateur best-ball event on the links of the Ardsley Country Club today.

An exhibition of the work being done by 40,000 white collar workers on New York City Works Progress Administration projects was opened last night at the 369th Regiment Armory, Fifth Avenue and 143d Street.

Clarke G. Daily, president of the Alliance Realty Company, was elected president of the Real Estate Board of New York at a meeting of the board of governors yesterday. He succeeds William J. Demorest and is the first "owner-member" chosen to head the organization since it was formed in 1896 as a brokers' organization.

The story told to Mr. Krock about Mr. Hoover and reported by Mr. Krock in your paper this morning is pure fiction, as I can personally testify. It is true Mr. Krock did not vouch for it, but he did give it the color of fact. For that reason you may care to know what the facts are.

Evidence that buying orders had accumulated in brokers' offices during the two-day holiday was provided yesterday morning by the nature of the initial transactions in key stock issues on the Stock Exchange. Standard Brands opened a half point higher on a block of 15,000 shares, Woolworth opened 3 1/2 points up on a sale of 10,000 shares.

While the Republican National Finance Committee for New York City was preparing for a Victory Week drive for funds to replenish the nearly empty Landon-Knox campaign coffers, an investigator for the Senate committee investigating campaign contributions and expenditures called on the committee yesterday afternoon and spent an hour or more examining its records.

OLYMPIA, Wash., Oct. 13. -- A delegation of 400 women from various parts of the State, meeting on the Capitol steps today, petitioned Governor Clarence D. Martin to end "the sway of radicals and racketeers" in the State's agricultural and other industries.

The Knickerbocker Greys, junior military organization which includes in its roster the scions of many of the best-known families in New York, began its fifty-sixth year yesterday with registration of thirty-eight new recruits at the 107th Infantry Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- The Supreme Court today heard arguments in the case of the three Neidecker brothers, the issue evolving interpretation of a twenty-seven year old extradition treaty with France.

Originally started as a small candy factory by William F. Schrafft in Boston, where only chocolate creams, hard candies and pure gum arabic drops were produced, Schrafft's will start a month's celebration today of its seventy-fifth anniversary.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- Revocation of the license of the National Broadcasting Company for allowing the use of its facilities by Earl Browder and James W. Ford, Communist candidates for President and Vice President, is demanded in a brief filed today with the Federal Communications Commission by the National Civic Federation.
It is not possible to determine the value of the dollar on the local forelgn exchange market, since a fixed parity for the new French franc has not been established.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13. -- The peril of government press dictatorship under the guise of supposedly beneficial legislation was pictured today by a publisher and a lawyer before the Inland Daily Press Association.
PARIS, Oct. 13. -- Banking and stock market circles today showed most favorable reactions to the gold exchange accord among France, the United States and Britain, announced yesterday.

The twelve-block housing project under the sponsorship of the PWA in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn already has resulted in extensive improvements to properties in that neighborhood, Dwight L. Hoopingarner, associate director of the housing division of the PWA, declared last night in a broadcast over WEVD preliminary to the cornerstone ceremonies to be held today.

The new tri-partite gold agreement stimulated foreign and commission-house buying on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, prices rallying 15 to 19 points. Although hedge selling continued in heavy volume, the Southern offers were absorbed on moderate partial reactions and final prices were within a few points of the best for the day, with advances of 15 to 17 points from the close on Saturday.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13 (AP). -- William N. McNair withdrew his resignation as Mayor today, but the new city administration ignored his request for reinstatement.

DETROIT, Oct. 13. -- The village of Royal Oak lies north of Detroit on Woodward Avenue, serene in the foggy sunlight of October. Approached by motor from the metropolis, it at first presents no aspect different from that of other towns along the road to where the hills begin.

James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, left late yesterday afternoon for Chicago, where he will consult with party leaders. He will return Saturday. He said he was confident of a large Roosevelt victory in Illinois and that he was certain Ohio would be in the President's column.
DETROIT, Oct. 13. -- Governor Landon had luncheon today with Henry Ford at the latter's Dearborn home and afterward inspected the early American village which the auto maker has reproduced near by.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 13. -- Following are the texts of President Roosevelt's speeches in Wichita, Kan., and in this city:

City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr. continued yesterday, at a public hearing before the Transit Commission, his section-by-section exposition of the $436,000,000 definitive plan of rapid transit unification. He began last Thursday his detailed explanation of the 193-page document submitted to the commission by himself and Samuel Seabury, special counsel to the Board of Estimate in transit matters.

OSWALD MOSLEY may boast of one revolutionary change which he has already brought about in England. The street ruffians in London now use razors. A dozen persons had to he treated for cuts on the face after last Sunday's outbreak of Fascist hooliganism in the East End of London.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP). -- Cottonseed crushed in the two-month period, Aug. 1 to Sept. 30, was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 695,271 tons, compared to 580,645 in the corresponding period a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- The Cumberland County Power and Light Company of Portland, Me., filed today an amendment to a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $9,500,000 of first-mortgage bonds, 3 1/2 per cent series, due in 1966, and 10,000 shares of 5 1/2 per cent preferred stock, par value $100.

PARIS, Oct. 13. -- Prominence was given today to the devotion to the principles of liberty, democracy and peace that links the United States and France when William C. Bullitt presented to President Albert Lebrun his letters of credence as United States Ambassador to France.

The General Public Service Corporation, an investment trust, reported yesterday a market value of assets amounting to $9,946,851 as of Sept. 30. This was announced to be equivalent to $2.79 a common share after deducting the par value of debentures and preferred shares and the dividends accumulated on the latter.

Although the intentions are laudable in "The Laughing Woman," the results are lamentable.
