For Gordon Daviot has been writing a play about the private lives of artists, which is a subject that should be mentioned cautiously in the theatre. In her own private life Gordon Daviot is Agnes MacIntosh, one-time author of "Richard of Bordeaux," a drama of considerable eminence.

LONDON, Oct. 13. -- The presentation at the Queen's Theatre tonight of the dramatization of Charlotte Bronte's "Jane Eyre," first produced at the Malvern Festival last Summer, gives Helen Jerome a second West End adaptation to her credit.

BERLIN, Oct. 13. -- Having decided against what Rudolf Hess, deputy Nazi party leader, called "capitulation" to a hostile outside world, Nazi Germany displayed little interest today in the "new type of gold standard" announced by Henry Morgenthau Jr., United States Secretary of the Treasury.

The National Carbon Company has sold its plant in the Lafayette section of Jersey City to the Air Reduction Sales Company of New York. The plant consists of a six-story concrete building and a two-story brick structure on the block bounded by the National Dock Railroad, Johnson Avenue, Pine and Monitor Streets.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,024,950 barrels, compared with 2,987,800 in the preceding week, an increase of 37,150, the American Petroleum Institute announced yesterday. An increase of 24,900 barrels in California was the most important change.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 13. -- The Princeton football team turned its attention to Pennsylvania formations today in preparation for Saturday's contest, opposing the scrubs for more than an hour in an offensive dummy scrimmage.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 13. -- Judge Paul Jones of the United States District Court said late today that tomorrow he would sign tentative approval of the plan submitted by the Van Sweringen interests for the reorganization of the Cleveland Terminals Building Company and its parent company, the Van Sweringen Corporation.

A death from diphtheria, the first in seven weeks, was listed by the city Health Department in its weekly summary made public yesterday. The total number of deaths for the week rose to 1,393, an increase of 169 over the preceding week, and the births declined to 1,949, a decrease of 68.

Frank K.M. Rehn reopened his gallery for the new season this week, and offers as the initial attraction a one-man show of oils and water-colors by Patrick Morgan. It is this American artist's first solo appearance. The work will remain on view until Oct. 24.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:
WATERLOO, Iowa, Oct. 13 (AP). -- A threefold program for the working farmer was advanced tonight by Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 13. -- Color films taken over a surgeon's shoulder as he performs an operation, and safety film for preserving files of newspapers, documents and other records were cited today as extensions of the film industry at the Fall convention of the Society of Motion Picture Engineers.

Best Co. declared yesterday a dividend of 62 1/2 cents a share on the common stock, payable Nov. 16 to stock of record of Oct. 26. Previously the company paid 50 cents quarterly. On February 15, an extra dividend of 50 cents was disbursed.

BASLE, Switzerland, Oct. 13. -- The Morgenthau statement on the three-power gold agreement is warmly welcomed in the World Bank as a step in the right direction, although it is one that does not yet bring about that "general stability of exchanges" that the bank's board stressed yesterday as urgently necessary.

New York University's football squad spent almost three hours at Ohio Field yesterday in an intensive effort to tune its offensive for its encounter with the undefeated University of North Carolina eleven on Saturday at the Yankee Stadium.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13. -- Wheat prices on the Board of Trade here advanced early today in sympathy with Liverpool and Winnipeg, but eased later when the professional element turned to the selling side as the result of the failure of the outside interest to broaden.
LONDON, Oct. 13. -- The little cockney boy who became known to all the world as H.G. Wells heard his fellow-authors acclaim him at a dinner tonight as one of the glories of English literature.

SALEM, N.H., Oct. 13 (AP). -- The winning daily double combination at Rockingham Park today was worth $1,545.40 for $2. Among the 4,500 fans who braved a chilly afternoon five combination tickets on Glassy Blonde and Grandma's Boy, winners of the first and third races respectively, were sold.

While Frank J. Prial was completing the formalities of dropping his court fight for a recount of the Democratic primary vote for Aldermanic President, headquarters of Newbold Morris, Republican candidate, announced yesterday that several of Prial's campaign leaders had gone over to Mr. Morris.

A large standing army of able-bodied but unemployed workers can be expected to continue in the United States for years to come, according to Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, in a book entitled "Spending to Save: the Complete Story of Relief," published today by W.W. Norton Co., Inc.

Miss Elizabeth W. Scovill was a luncheon hostess yesterday at Sherry's for Mrs. John B. Watkins, the former Miss Anna Livingston Jones. The other guests included Mrs. Pierson Mapes, the Misses Anna Stoddard, Nancy Church, Janet Williams, Elizabeth Sillcocks and Jane Miller.

The Forty-fourth Street Theatre gets this evening's premiere -- Robert Turney's "Daughters of Atreus." Eleonora Mendelssohn has come over to make her American debut in the piece, and the other featured players are Maria Ouspenskaya -- and it is the twenty-fifth anniversary of her entry into the theatre -- and Joanna Roos.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- The possible next moves in the C.I.O. controversy will be discussed here tomorrow by John L. Lewis, chairman of the C.I.O., and Max Zaritsky, president of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers Union.

While passers-by gathered up and made off with $121 of the loot, a man accused of trying to rob the cashier of a Harlem motion picture threatre was overpowered by others and arrested last night on a charge of grand larceny.

HAD the name Sherwood Anderson been missing from the title page of "Kit Brandon: A Portrait" (Scribner's, $2.50), this reviewer would not have read the book. It is well to be perfectly honest about it -- "Kit Brandon" was, so far as the jacket blurb showed, simply another story of a mountaineer girl who became a rum-running queen.

George L. Smith, president of the G.R. Kinney Company, Inc., has notified holders of fifteen-year 7 1/2 per cent secured notes due on Dec. 1, of which less than $650,000, or about 25 per cent, of the original issue remains outstanding, that the company will extend their notes to Dec. 1, 1941, with interest at 5 1/2 per cent per annum.

LONDON, Oct. 13. -- King Edward made another assault on tradition tonight when he authorized the issuance from Buckingham Palace of an order permitting peeresses to design their own dresses for next Spring's coronation ceremony.

Max Zaritsky, president of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers Union and member of the Committee for Industrial Organization, left for Washington last night. He will confer today with John L. Lewis, chairman of the C.I.O., and William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, on the proposal of the hatters' convention designed to bring peace between the craft and industrial union factions in the A.F. of L.

Aldo Spoldi, Italian lightweight, stopped Maxie Fisher of Newark last night in 1:31 of the eighth round of a listed ten-round feature at the New York Coliseum before a crowd of 6,000 persons. Spoldi weighed 135, Fisher 132 1/2.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- Class I railroads, which account for more than 77 per cent of railway operating revenues, had in September an estimated operating revenue of $276,012,576, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 13. -- Mr. Thomas H. Blodgett was a dinner hostess at Great Pine Farm, Great Barrington, tonight for Mrs. Arthur E. Whitney of Garden City, L.I., who is the guest of Mrs. Rodney S. Jarvis at Wheelbarrow Hill Farm.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13. -- The Rev. Dr. Albert H. Eggleston, a Presbyterian pastor of Kansas City, is the winner of the first prize of $500 in the nation-wide letter-writing contest on "Why I Changed from Roosevelt to Landon," sponsored by the Republican National Committee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- Mayflower Associates, Inc., of New York, an organization that its sponsors assert is not an investment trust in the accepted sense of that term but one that has for one of its major objectives "to undertake hazardous ventures," to pioneer new enterprises, and to develop new sources of minerals and raw materials, disclosed today the story of its operations before the Securities and Exchange Commission.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 13. -- Mrs. William H. Taylor entertained with a luncheon today for 200 women at the Casino.

Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. advised Magistrate Michael A. Ford yesterday that the system of uniform traffic fines contains "provisions to safeguard judicial freedom" and merely requires magistrates who depart from the schedule to endorse their reasons for doing so on the outside of the complaint.

I sincerely hope Congress will review and modify in some respects the 1936 Revenue Act when it meets in January. * * * Especially I would like to see an amendment to this act that would encourage expenditures for modernization of all character; for replacement of plant, machinery and equipment; for rebuilding; and one that would make some further provision for institutions laboring under debt.

About 2,000 garage service employes went on strike in Brooklyn last night following a breakdown of negotiations with their employers. Another 3,000 are expected to join the strike today. More than 1,200 garages will be involved if the strike movement spreads.

Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachusetts, Landon-Knox campaign manager in the East, yesterday pronounced as ridiculous the claim of James A. Farley, Chairman of the Democratic National Committee, that this State would be carried by a plurality of a million or more for President Roosevelt.

New life insurance in September rose 10.8 per cent above the total for the same month a year ago, according to a report made yesterday by the Association of Life Insurance Presidents to the Department of Commerce. The cumulative total for the first nine months of this year, however, was 2.2 per cent less than for the same period last year.

VALLEY STREAM, L.I., Oct. 13. -- Governor Lehman opened his active speaking campaign for re-election here tonight with the direct charge that William F. Bleakley, his Republican opponent, opposed writing into a law a program of social security.

Two more foreign teams will compete in the nightly international jumping contests at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden from Nov. 4 to 10, inclusive. The entry list was increased to seven nations when the entries of France and Sweden were received yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- The Public Works Administration was ordered today in United States District Court to show cause on Nov. 12 why it should not be required by mandamus to consider an application of the Metropolitan Bridge Company for a loan and grant for the construction of a tube and bridge across San Francisco Bay.

NIAGARA FALLS, Oct. 13. -- Niagara had about 1,000 unusual visitors today in several flocks of wild geese southbound after summering in the North. They alighted on the river above the falls and seemed unmindful of the current which hurried many of them down stream and over the Horseshoe.

ALBANY, Oct. 13. -- The attempt to give voters of New York City an opportunity to vote to put the city Fire Department on a three-platoon basis, providing an eight-hour day and one day of rest in seven for its members, was blocked in the Court of Appeals today.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 13. -- Former Governor John H. Trumbull of Connecticut won the skeet and the trapshooting contests at the Homestead skeet field yesterday. Max McGraw was runner-up in both divisions. Mrs. James E. Watson won the women's event.

Tazio Nuvolari, Italian driver who won the 300-mile automobile grind Monday at Roosevelt Raceway, yesterday received the rewards of victory. They took the form of a bundle of checks, a replica of the huge George Vanderbilt Cup and overwhelming praise from those who gathered at the Ambassador Hotel to honor him.

DETROIT, Oct. 13. -- Expenditures in excess of $25,000,000 are being necessitated by the introduction of the new "unisteel" turret top Fisher body that will feature the 1937 line of General Motors cars, it was disclosed today by Edward F. Fisher, general manager of the automotive concern's body-building division.

MARSEILLES, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Customs guards frustrated an attempt to blow up the Spanish sailboat Cala Pi at the docks of this French port early this morning. The crew of the Cala Pi is loyal to the Madrid government.

BERLIN, Oct. 13. -- The Reich Colonial League, which absorbed all existing German colonial units when it was organized last Spring and which was intended to become the official spokesman of the National Socialist drive for colonies, will soon be dissolved.

Crossbow II, son of Crusader, lunged for the line with the power of a pressure-flung bolt, and won a purse at Jamaica yesterday that practically all of those who saw the finish thought he had lost. From the days of Saladin to the present, men and women have relied on the human eye to know what is going on, but with the photographic finish in racing all that is changed.

At Cleveland Governor LANDON gave the country a clearer picture than it had before of the way in which the Republican party would handle the relief problem. Administrative responsibility would be returned to the States. With it would go authority for each community to decide for itself whether it favored "work relief" or "direct relief" or some combination of the two.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- The General Electric Company, the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, seven other concerns and the Heat Exchange Institute, a trade association with headquarters in New York, have been made respondents in a complaint issued by the Federal Trade Commission alleging collusive bidding and the fixing and maintenance of uniform prices in connection with the manufacture and sale of turbine generators and condensers.

Columbia's first concentrated efforts toward preparing its football forces for the Virginia Military Institute game on Saturday took place yesterday at Baker Field with a scrimmage between the Lion varsity and freshman elevens while the Blue reserves were battling the Manhattan second-string outfit.

A reminder of fads and fancies of the post-war decade, the "Only Yesterday" supper dance to be held tomorrow night at Le Coq Rouge has received a large advance subscription from younger members of society. The party is being given under the auspices of the junior committee of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York and it will serve to formally open the new Mirror Room of the restaurant for the season.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 13. -- With an 81 that would do credit to any championship, Mrs. Edward Stevens of Round Hill today won the first medal round of the annual two-day women's national senior golf tournament at the Westchester Country Club.

TRENTON, Oct. 13. -- Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, State Democratic leader, in effect told the Republican campaign managers in New Jersey today either to "put up or shut up." They did not choose to put up, however, but instead tried to "laugh off" what observers regarded a bit of smart politics.

The great advantage of a college education is that the student may be taught enough of the ways of the world that he may choose his leaders wisely, said Dean Herbert E. Hawkes of Columbia College in his address yesterday to the freshman class at the weekly orientation lecture.

ROCKVILLE CENTER, L.I., Oct. 13. -- Crashing through with a record-breaking 29 on the inward nine holes at the Rockville Country Club today, Willie Klein of Wheatley Hills and Bert Edwards, the home club champion, scored a dazzling 65, seven under par, to win the top honors in a pro-amateur tournament of the Long Island Golf Association.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Oct. 13. -- Sir Samuel Hoare, First Lord of the Admiralty, announced in a speech here tonight that the subcommittee of the Committee of Imperial Defense which investigated the "battleship versus aircraft" question had unanimously recommended in favor of the capital ship and against the substitution of bombing planes.

It is pleasant to see the decencies of speech preserved by political competitors. Governor LEHMAN, by way of doing something to keep the classics in memory, says that Judge BLEAKLEY, if elected, "will lie supine before the Legislature." Not resenting in the least the adjective with all the look of a hot gerund "hurled" at him, the Westchesterian puts this gloss on it:
ROME, Oct. 13. -- A much-disputed letter, in which Abraham Lincoln supposedly envisaged Rome as the capital of "the United States of Europe," was labeled a fake today.

Higher prices were made by most staples on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. Hides eased and sugar was quiet. On the cash markets, however, all the grains, refined sugar, lard and tin declined, while cotton, wool tops, cocoa, eggs and silk advanced.
FARGO, N.D., Oct. 13. -- To Representative William Lemke, Coughlin candidate for President, is given little chance of carrying his home State in the election Nov. 3.

WITH REBEL FORCES, Near San Martin de Valdeiglesias, Spain, Oct. 13 (AP). -- Government planes bombed Insurgent troops today in an attempt to break the Rebel advance on Madrid. Three planes dropped more than fifty bombs on concentrations of Moorish cavalry outside San Martin de Valdeiglesias.

Through the efforts of the Red Cross the civil war in Spain is being "humanized," but the danger of international war hangs so ominously over Europe that the mobilization of the Red Cross, both as a force for peace and as a relief agency in the event of hostilities, is essential, Ernest Swift, vice chairman of the American Red Cross, warned last night.

LONDON, Oct. 13. -- Premature disclosure that the British Government's export credits guarantee department was contemplating granting credits to facilitate British trade with China has delayed official announcement of the scheme, which may not now be revealed in detail before next week.

LONDON, Oct. 13. -- Following her sharp protest last week over what Soviet Russia asserted to be a breach by other nations of their agreement not to export arms to Spain during the present civil war, Samuel M. Kagan, Soviet Charge d'Affaires, today delivered in London to Earl of Plymouth, acting chairman of the non-intervention committee on Spain, concrete proposals designed to prevent violations of the non-intervention agreement in the future.

PARIS, Oct. 13. -- After a firm start the Bourse became irregular in tone today. The last half of the session saw much unloading for profit-taking, but many stocks, nevertheless, managed to make gains. The tri-power stabilization fund accord was defined as a stimulus to the market, which accepted the news with great satisfaction, but it was counteracted by nervousness over the German protest on the speech of the Communist leader Thorez.

The Detroit Lions, 1935 champions of the National Football League, will risk their undefeated, unscored-upon record against the rejuvenated Dodgers, who defeated them here last year, at Ebbets Field tonight. The contest, which is expected to attract Brooklyn's banner crowd of the season, will start at 8:30 o'clock.

TROY, Oct. 13. -- William F. Bleakley, the Republican candidate for Governor, opened a two weeks up-State tour today with three speeches devoted to taxes, "broken Democratic promises" and the necessity for a comprehensive highway program.

Since the exciting game of Saturday between the Army and Columbia there has been considerable discussion of the forward-pass play which Army used to start one of its trips back from apparent defeat to its ultimate victory.

A reduction in the tax burden on real estate as a relief to the individual taxpayers and "to promote efficiency in governmental operations," was recommended at yesterday's session of the annual convention of the United States Building and Loan League, which opened on Monday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The broad advance in domestic corporate bonds, after continuing in early trading yesterday, met considerable resistance later, and the market closed mixed in undertone generally. Much of the speculative enthusiasm of last week for secondary and convertible issues was lacking, while trading in United States Government and other investment bonds came virtually to a standstill.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13. -- The nation's banking structure was pictured here today by J.F.T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, as being on a firmer basis than "ever before in its history."
r$. Betty- W. Sternfeld. in 40 W. 6Ttll St.; Shep Fields, in 322 W. 72d St-: Edith M. Caekett, in 310 W. ?7xl St-; Arthur E. Reyman, in 440 Riverside Drive; Pease Elllman, Inc., brokers.

Business failures increased to 164 for the week ended Oct. 8, marking the fourth consecutive weekly rise, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The current total, which compares with 147 in the previous week, has not been touched since July 30, when the figure stood at 175.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 13. -- With President James Rowland Angell an interested spectator for the first time this season, Head Coach Ducky Pond today sent the varsity through an hour's scrimmaging in preparation for the Navy game in Baltimore Saturday.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 13. -- Campaigning across Kansas today and into Missouri this evening, President Roosevelt told the citizens of Governor Landon's State that the election offered them the choice between a program of "security" as sponsored by the present administration and the promises of his Republican opponent.

DETROIT, Oct. 13. -- Asserting that President Roosevelt has started on the road that leads to dictatorship, Governor Landon declared tonight that, if elected President, he would recommend to Congress the repeal of all acts giving what he regarded as autocratic powers to the executive.

LONDON, Oct. 13. -- Trading on the London Stock Exchange today was quieter than yesterday's operations, although the price undertone remained firm. After early weakness, British funds strengthened. European issues were steady in the foreign department, with the German list improved.

HENDAYE, France, Oct. 13. -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco withheld the order for a general Rebel advance on Madrid today because of the immobilization of a large part of his forces by the heavy rain that has fallen continuously in the past forty-eight hours, making many roads impassable.

ON BOARD THE STEAMSHIP PRESIDENT PIERCE, en route to Manila, Oct. 13. -- This reporter, having set out to make a trip around the world by using only established commercial transportation facilities open to any traveler, is now steaming toward Manila exactly on schedule.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 13 (AP). -- Making her first start after a Summer campaign in the North, E.D. Shaffer's Evening Tide scored a neck decision in the Rodgers Forge Purse, juvenile feature of today's program.

One of the largest restaurants in the Times Square district, the tenth in the Longchamps chain, was opened last night in the Broadway Continental Building, Broadway and Forty-first Street, with business executives and celebrities of the stage and screen in attendance.

EASTON, Pa., Oct. 13. -- With a new director of athletics, a new coaching staff and its best squad in recent years, Lafayette College is definitely headed up the football ladder to the position it enjoyed under Dr. Jock Sutherland and in the early part of Herbert McCracken's regime.

While the reserves scrimmaged with Columbia, Manhattan's first-stringers went through a strenuous two-hour drill on offensive and defensive fundamentals at Innisfail Park yesterday in preparation for their battle with powerful Holy Cross at Worcester Saturday.

A luncheon and fashion show were held yesterday at the Versailles to aid the Children's Village, Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. The committee in charge was headed by Mrs. Herbert Lee Pratt Jr. and Mrs. R.T. Taylor Jr. The latest fashion creations were modeled by a group of manikins recruited from society.

Representative Vito Marcantonio of the South Harlem Congressional District pleaded not guilty in General Sessions yesterday to the second degree assault indictment returned against him and three other men in an alleged assault on a Tammany watcher during registration week.
Board of Election officials expressed confidence yesterday that despite the 560,000 increase in registration, voters would not be unduly delayed at the city's polls on Nov. 3.

BERLIN, Oct. 13. -- The first scientific assembly of the Lilienthal Society for Aeronautic Research, organized last June under the patronage of Air Minister Hermann Goering, drew more than a thousand foreign and German aviation experts to the Kroll Opera House today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13. -- Although admitting that the party was having difficulty in getting the funds needed for the final drive of the campaign and election day, National Chairman Hamilton reiterated today that the Republicans would carry every State north of and east of the Mississippi, plus West Virginia and Wisconsin.

In the region of the Philippines the air is hot, calm, humid. Warmed by the sun, it rises through cooler and heavier layers and begins to whirl. In the East men speak of a typhoon when this occurs; in the West, meaning the Caribbean and the Gulf of Mexico, of a hurricane.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 13. -- After a week of unexplained friction between Director James Flood and Producer Edward Small, Flood withdrew today from the production of "Coast Patrol," and left the RKO lot. Preparations for the picture are being carried on, anyway, and it is probable that Maureen O'Sullivan will be borrowed from Metro to serve as leading lady for Victor McLaglen and Preston Foster.

It is up to the leading organizations and their spokesmen to decide upon the plan for a single association in order to fight trade evils in the dress industry as urged by Mortimer Lanzit, executive director of the National Dress Manufacturers Association, it was stated yesterday by Harry Uviller, impartial chairman for the industry.

Eddie Cantor, the latest addition to the Twentieth Century-Fox star roster, and Jack Haley are tentatively scheduled for the film production of Dorothea Brand's book, "Wake Up and Live," in which, as a cinematic counterplot, Walter Winchell, columnist and news commentator, and Ben Bernie, orchestra leader, will continue their five-year radio feud.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 13. -- Donald Daughters, who last Fall was the outstanding wing on Harvard's freshman team, today was placed at left end on Dick Harlow's varsity.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 13. -- Donald Daughters, who last Fall was the outstanding wing on Harvard's freshman team, today was placed at left end on Dick Harlow's varsity.
Harold Riegelman, counsel to the Citizens Budget Commission, hailed the decision banning the referendum as a "signal victory for home rule."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- Confidence that President Roosevelt would be "entirely willing" to have Congress review the Revenue Act of 1936, especially if it could be demonstrated that there were inequities or that any provision in it retarded capital expenditures, was expressed tonight by Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, in an address carried by the National Broadcasting Company.
The new Madison Square station of the New York Postoffice, for which the cornerstone will be laid tomorrow, will contain 100,000 square feet of space, Postmaster Albert Goldman announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- The tangible results of the investigation made last Spring by a special House committee into the financing of the Townsend old-age pension plan have turned out to be three citations for contempt, almost five months old, which have never been presented to a grand jury, and one report of the committee, completed, but now in a state of suspension and shrouded in mystery.

Mrs. Marshall Field and her daughter, Miss Barbara Field, 20 years old, who reside at the River House at the foot of East Fifty-second Street, declined in Felony Court yesterday to sign papers as complainants accusing John Carroll, 37, of the theft of $30,000 in jewelry from Miss Field's automobile on Oct. 5.

After almost two years of outward harmony, Mayor La Guardia and Controller Frank J. Taylor split yesterday over the Mayor's proposal to obtain Federal aid for an electric generating plant for Brooklyn College at a cost of about $400,000.

Merchant ships under construction throughout the world total 2,111,457 tons, according to the quarterly report of Lloyd's Register of Shipping, which was published yesterday. The figures do not cover tonnage in the yards of Russia, for which data have not been available in recent years.

William Weinstein, 49 years old, and his daughter, Mrs. Beatrice Harris, both of 1,108 Grand Avenue, the Bronx, were arrested yesterday at the new Accident Fraud Bureau, in its first life insurance fraud inquiry, on charges of attempted grand larceny, perjury and subornation of perjury.

Janet Beith, who won a $20,000 prize with her first novel, "No Second Spring," has a new book called "San Castle" on the Stokes list for next month. Scotland and Manchester supply the settings, and the story tells of the rise of the cotton trade through the war, boom, and a part of the depression.

Fordham University's eleven resumed its drills at Fordham Field yesterday following its holiday on Monday the first given it by Coach Jim Crowley since training sessions began in September. Although Waynesburg College is scheduled as the Rams' opponent this Saturday at Randalls Island, part of the session was devoted to preparing for the encounter with St. Mary's a week from Saturday.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Oct. 13 (AP). -- Colonel Frank Knox wound up his Southern trip tonight by telling North Carolina that a Democratic vote this year was one for "more boondoggling" and "government by guess."

Automobile manufacturers are expected to spend between $85,000,000 and $95,000,000 in advertising their 1937 models in the coming year, it was estimated here yesterday. Production schedules call for increases of 10 to 25 per cent and, since advertising volume is based on the number of cars sold, the budget for promotion should be stepped up accordingly.
DETROIT, Oct. 13. -- Governor Landon, invading industrial Michigan for the third major speech of his campaign in the Lake States on "freedom of enterprise," spent this afternoon with Henry Ford.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13. -- Supplies of hogs were somewhat above trade expectations today and the market declined 5 to 10 cents a hundred-weight under yesterday's prices and 10 to 20 cents under those of Friday. Offerings of sows were small, and met with a fair demand at steady to strong prices.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct. 14. -- When officials were hastily sounded by telephone early today regarding the plans for a British loan to China, their first impression was that Japan would object to political loans, but would not oppose "constructive loans intended to promote Chinese recovery."
MADRID, Oct. 13. -- In the expectation of a siege the Madrid authorities were preparing the populace today to make every sacrifice in favor of the active defenders.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 13. -- Mrs. William F. Bleakley, self-styled "home body," wants no part of politics and hopes her husband, the Republican candidate for Governor, does not get the habit of campaigning, as it keeps him away from home, she said today in her first formal press interview.

The Gallery of Arthur H. Harlow Co., Inc., ought to call itself the House of Entrances. With two more just acquired it now possesses five -- one accommodating visitors who approach through the sunken plaza of Rockefeller Center, one from the long section of the plaza that extends to Fifth Avenue, two admitting those who come in by way of the main corridor of the British Building, and one entrance from Fiftieth Street.

An endeavor to obtain a modification of the State Excise Law to permit the installation of bars in local theatres is included in the program for activity during the coming year by the League of New York Theatres, it was revealed yesterday with the reading of the secretary's report at the annual meeting of the organization.

A bill providing for the three-platoon system in the Fire Department, which is now on a two-platoon basis, was adopted by the Municipal Assembly during the closing days of the O'Brien administration. It was subsequently vetoed by Mayor LA GUARDIA, who could not lay his hands on sufficient funds to put it into effect; it has been calculated that the change would involve an increase in the city budget of something like $10,000,000 a year.

Baby Salvy Saban, Greenwich Village welterweight, registered a surprise one-round knockout victory over Eddie Dempsey of Syracuse in the feature bout, set for eight sessions, at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night. Saban weighed 145 3/4 and Dempsey 140 1/2.

Puerto Rico's purchases of passenger automobiles and trucks from Continental United States during the fiscal year 1935-36 were the largest in ten years and 26 per cent more than the preceding twelve months, according to the Puerto Rico Sugar Producers Association, of which J.A. Dickey is director.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- High Treasury officials expressed the opinion today that the United States, Great Britain and France would hold the whip-hand over countries that did not adhere to the tripartite money accord, so far as the shipment of gold was concerned.
The Concourse So.Ice Station. Inc.. gave a mortgage to Israel Kamerman for $4,120, due -qelt 1, 1027, at 6 per cent on the south coraer of West and W. 10th Sts., 52.8x30.

With the aid of scaling ladders, devices seldom used in fighting fires, firemen rescued yesterday three persons, one an 84-year-old bedridden woman, who were cut off from escape when a fire started in a four-story building at 243 East Thirty-fourth Street, near Second Avenue, which houses the St. John the Baptist Greek Orthodox Church and apartments.

After opening sharply higher on an accumulation of buying orders caused by the overnight news of the establishment of a new type of gold standard, the stock market encountered profit-taking yesterday. The softer tone of the market was shown by the fact that 458 of the 931 issues dealt in on the New York Stock Exchange closed with net declines; only 296 closed higher and 177 were unchanged.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 14. -- Governor Cross today issued a call for a special session of the Legislature for two stated purposes, one of them theoretically affecting the result of the approaching Presidential election. The Senators and Representatives will assemble Nov. 5 because, according to the Governor's proclamation, "a twofold emergency confronts the State."

LONDON, Oct. 14. -- Mrs. Ernest Aldrich Simpson is suing for a divorce from her husband, manager in London of the New York shipping house of Simpson, Spencer Young, it was learned today. Both are personal friends of King Edward VIII.

BERLIN, Oct. 14. -- Rumors are again gathering about the person of the Rev. Martin Niemoeller, militant leader of the Confessional Synod. It is reported on good authority that another attempt will be made to force him out of the parish of Dahlem, which has become known, not only nationally but throughout the world, as a center of resistance to the government's church policy.

ALBANY, Oct. 14 (AP). -- Opponents of the Union party of New York went to the courts in their effort to keep its electors and State candidates off the election ballot today and won an order delaying actual printing of the names until after Oct. 20.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 14. -- A demand for access to all records of the Works Progress Administration here showing the names of administrative employes, their duties and salaries, was served on William H. J. Ely, administrator for New Jersey, tonight, by George Guy Gabrielson, headquarters executive of the Republican campaign committee, and Daniel E. Pomeroy, Republican National Committeeman from New Jersey.

DUBLIN, Irish Free State, Oct. 14. -- The Free State Government has refused permission for the German Lufthansa interests to use Galway Bay as a base for their proposed air-mail service to the United States.

The Hirsch Jacobs technique in training horses was nicely illustrated yesterday, when he sent Night Sprite to the post at Jamaica to come home as his 146th winner of the season. One more and Jacobs will equal Cowboy Irwin's American record.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14. -- Insurance men were pictured here today as believing that crop insurance was "not a matter of legislation" and as favoring the insuring of farm crops "if the government doesn't run the business."

THE idea of putting plate scraps in pails for the worthy unemployed was broached in Washington early in January, 1931, according to "Spending to Save" (Norton, $1.50), by Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Emergency Relief Administrator.

At long last Robert Turney's "Daughters of Atreus" has reached the stage of the Forty-fourth Street Theatre, where it was acted last evening. It is the first work of a young American writer who has been living under the spell of the House of Atreus legend, and who has fashioned it into a single verse play.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14. -- Financial records of the Republican State Committee were scrutinized and some of them were seized here today by a Senate committee investigator, but attempts to gain possession of the city committee's data met with rebuffs.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith was asked yesterday to go to California and deliver an address against the New Deal and for the election of Governor Landon. The message was brought East by James W. Mellen, leader of the Jeffersonian Democrats in California and a Smith man since 1920.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 14. -- Professor Arthur M. Schlesinger of Harvard, historian and author, made public today a list of eighty-one Harvard faculty members who, he said, had pledged support to President Roosevelt's re-election.

Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. was bitterly criticized yesterday by three Brooklyn magistrates for his action last week in designating six "specially qualified" magistrates to rotate in Brooklyn Traffic Court in an attempt to eliminate "chiseling" and "fixing."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 14. -- In an endeavor to find Croatian leaders who will adopt a less intransigent attitude than Vladimir Matchek, who refuses all discussion and sticks to his theoretical "minimum demands" of full autonomy in every respect for Croatia, Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch has decided to recall a large number of men exiled as traitors when King Alexander instituted the dictatorship in 1929.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14. -- Regardless whether the American Episcopal Church is soon to have an Archbishop at its head, such as in England, Canada, the West Indies, Ireland and elsewhere, the House of Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church, in session this week at Evanston, made it plain today that the presiding Bishop or Archbishop, if he received that title, was going to have greater powers.

Ground was broken yesterday afternoon for the new $5,000,000 Queens general courthouse which will occupy the block bounded by Sutphin Boulevard, Eighty-eighth Avenue, 149th Street and Eighty-ninth Avenue in Jamaica. Thomas F. Malone, president of the Jamaica Chamber of Commerce, presided.

DULUTH, Oct. 14. -- The once fond hope of the Republican high command of stirring up the agricultural States of the West over the administration's program of reciprocal trade treaties appears headed straight for the limbo of lost causes, so far as the current Presidential campaign is concerned.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 14. -- The cheers of scores of thousands of persons, composing one of the greatest demonstrations given to President Roosevelt, sped him on his way this morning as he wound up his campaign in Missouri and prepared to enter Illinois for a day of rapid fire campaigning in that State.
GRAND RAPIDS, Oct. 14. -- On arriving here at 7:20 P. M. Gov- ernor Landon was driven in an open car down streets packed with spectators and fringed with red flares.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 14 (AP). -- Repudiating a gospel of leisure, President F.H. Knubel of New York opened the biennial convention of the United Lutheran Church in America tonight by attacking "this mania which causes men to get things and to do things the easy way."

SYRACUSE, Oct. 14. -- Aiming to improve labor conditions in the garment-making field, the New York State League of Women Voters urged its members today to buy only such clothing as was produced under proper labor conditions.

THE NEW YORK TIMES quotes Justice Jacob Panken of the Family Court in addressing a meeting in support of the Democratic ticket as saying: "I venture to say that Al Smith will be president of the Edison Electric Company after this election day. It has been reported on good authority."

With Ace Gutowsky as the kingpin of their two touchdown drives, the Detroit Lions remained undefeated in National League competition by downing the Brooklyn Dodgers, 14 to 7, in their football encounter before 8,000 fans at Ebbets Field last night.

Jascha Heifers gave a recital at Carnegie Hall last night in which music was the thing and virtuosity merely incidental. It is a point worth stressing. There are a limited number of artists who can fill Carnegie Hall without benefit of papering, and even fewer who will not descend to the easy triumph of the showpieces of the repertoire.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 14. -- The first official hunt opening the sixth season of the Bath County Hounds met this morning. The drag was laid over Colonel William McKee Dunn's place, Gwin Farm. A hunt breakfast at The Yard, home of Mr. and Mrs. Fay Ingalls, climaxed a brisk run.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14. -- President Roosevelt ploughed into the political soil of Illinois today during a six-hour ride from St. Louis. He was accompanied by Governor Henry Horner and Senator Lewis, candidates for re-election, and other local politicians.

Trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange was again marked by profit-taking in the secondary and convertible corporate issues, which gave a highly mixed tone to the market most of the day. The trading pace slackened somewhat, sales amounting to $14,253,900, compared with $19,009,900 on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP). -- The Bureau of Public Roads reported today that it was well along toward the halfway mark in its grade crossing elimination program started last year, on which $200,000,000 is being spent.

Increased governmental interest in curing and curbing leprosy was reported yesterday at the opening of the annual two-day meeting of the American Mission to Lepers, 156 Fifth Avenue, by fifty missionaries from all parts of the world where the disease is prevalent.

For days and days Mr. FARLEY hid his prophetic horns. Hardly a word escaped the hedge of his teeth. He had been reformed, it was thought, by the spectacle that Mr. JOHN HAMILTON was making of himself. The more JOHN prattled, the thicker JAMES'S muffling seemed to be.

Offering to the public will be made today by a nation-wide banking syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc. of a new issue of $150,000,000 of American Telephone Telegraph Company 3 1/4 per cent debentures due on Oct. 1, 1961. The debentures will be offered at 101 and accrued interest, to yield about 3.19 per cent.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 14 (AP). -- The Pittsburgh Pirates scored in the first and third periods of their only home night game of the season tonight to defeat the Philadelphia Eagles, 17-0. in a National Football League contest. The official crowd was 10,042.

The man on the phone said that he lived in one State and hunted in four. When, he asked pleasantly, could he shoot quail in Jersey, turkeys in Pennsylvania, grouse in Connecticut and bear in New York?

Because of its inability to obtain the proper child players, Selznick International has decided to postpone production of "Tom Sawyer" until next year, hoping meanwhile that two youngsters suitable for the roles of Tom Sawyer and Huck Finn will just happen along.
DETROIT, Oct. 14. -- Henry Ford came out for Governor Landon today, saying that he admired and believed in the Kansan and hoped that he would be elected.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Oct. 14. -- William F. Bleakley, the Republican Gubernatorial candidate, tonight accused Governor Lehman of unjustly misconstruing the stand of the Republican party and its candidate in regard to social security. Every one favored it, Mr. Bleakley declared, but the issue lay in the manner of its administration.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 14. -- Princeton's preparation for Saturday's contest with Penn continued apace today as two Black elevens were simultaneously sent through an hour's defensive scrimmage against scrub teams employing Red and Blue plays.

SAN MARTIN DE VALDEIGLESIAS, Spain, Oct. 14 (AP). -- Fresh hordes of Moorish reinforcements swept on against retreating government troops tonight as weary Rebel soldiers flung down their arms for a sleep of exhaustion in this mountain village forty miles west of Madrid.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14. -- The leather goods industry, while doing a volume business, cannot continue to sell at little or no profit for the benefit of the shoe industry, Percival E. Foerderer of Philadelphia, chairman of the board of the Tanners' Council of America, said today at the council's annual convention.

Many parties were given last night in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre, which was formally opened for the season with a gala program of entertainment. Randolph F. Burke was a dinner host there to Mr. and Mrs. David Brooks, who returned recently from their wedding trip to Honolulu.
LONDON, Oct. 14 (AP). -- The seventh Duke of Leinster ruefully testified today that an unsuccessful "prospecting" trip for a wealthy American bride had availed him naught save an emptied pocketbook.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 14. -- Navy is threatened with the loss of Frank Case, its field general. An injury in the Virginia game last Saturday, regarded as slight, has been giving him trouble, and he has spent the last two days in the hospital.

Price changes were irregular, but mostly on the firm side, in commodity futures markets here yesterday. Few wide shifts were recorded despite active trading. In the cash markets wheat, rye and cocoa made new high marks, and corn, flour, cotton, silk and rubber also gained.

Despite objections by some leaders that the matter should be handled by the executive committee, the city committee of the City Fusion party endorsed Newbold Morris, Republican candidate for President of the Board of Aldermen, at the annual meeting of the committee last night at the Hotel Biltmore.

The first in a series of Thursday morning lectures on current events by ]Dr. William Starr Myers for the benefit of Stony Wold Sanatorium will take place Oct. 22 in the ballroom of the Delmonico. Subsequent lectures arranged by members of !Auxiliaries and 6 will be given I Oct. 29 and Nov. 5 and 12.
The Chase National Bank has been appointed transfer agent for the capital stock of the Majestic Radio Television Corporation.

Abraham Levy, a plumber, of 380 South Fourth Street, Brooklyn, testifying in General Sessions yesterday at the trial of John J. Hassett, former member of the abolished Board of Examining Plumbers, accused Hassett of extorting $500 from him in 1933 to grant him a master plumber's license.

PANAMA, Republic of Panama, Oct. 14. -- The National Assembly adopted a resolution yesterday for an investigation of the handling by William Nelson Cromwell of Panama's so-called constitutional fund, which was originally $6,000,000, part of the payment by the United States for the canal concession.

Steven Kennedy, a young baritone from Pittsburgh, made his debut in a song recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon. His program opened with a group of early Italian selections by Scarlatti and Legrenzi, after which came a sheaf of German lieder, including "Die Mainacht" and "Botschaft," by Brahms; Erich Wolff's "Du bist so jung," Jensen's "Marie" and Strauss's "Schlagende Herzen."
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Oct. 14. -- The text of Governor Landon's speech here tonight was as follows:

The plan to move the headquarters of the Board of Education from 500 Park Avenue, at Fifty-ninth Street, to the Elks Building in the Borough Hall section of Brooklyn was approved yesterday by the board over the objections of the two Manhattan members.

Coach Chick Meehan concentrated on forward passing and defensive line play yesterday as Manhattan's football team went through its final hard workout before the important battle with Holy Cross at Worcester Saturday. The Jaspers practiced for more than two hours, darkness ending the drill at Ebbets Field.

Raymond Moley, editor of Today and former member of the Roosevelt Brain Trust, charges in an editorial published in his magazine that while Democratic campaign orators deduct $6,000,000,000 of recoverable assets when estimating the increase in the national debt, payments reducing these assets are counted in the government's daily receipts and are not used for debt reduction.

When the history of these times is written, Williamsburg Houses, dedicated yesterday, will be set down as symbolizing one phase of the pioneer epoch in American efforts at slum clearance and rehousing. That phase had certain outstanding characteristics. Reliance was placed almost entirely on Federal loans and grants; neither locality nor State participated in any substantial way in the vast subsidies involved.

Foreign holdings of United States Steel common stock declined more than 15,000 shares in the quarter ended on Sept. 30, the corporation announced yesterday. Common stock held in brokers' names in this country increased 69,553 shares.

Protection of the investments of workers of modest means in home loans was advocated by President Roosevelt in a letter to the annual convention here of the United States Building and Loan League. The letter was read at yesterday's session.

Another step in consolidating its forces in Hollywood was taken yesterday by the Actors Equity Association when it indefinitely suspended some of the screen's front-rank performers in a group of twenty-four for not joining the Screen Actors Guild, a sister organization.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- The Treasury Department is well pleased with the domestic and internal reaction to the second step in the tri-partite agreement by which gold will be exchanged among the United States, Great Britain and France through stabilization funds, as necessary to keep currencies on an even keel.

Directors of the Federal Water Service Corporation will consider tomorrow a plan for the reclassification of shares under which a new series of common stock would replace all outstanding preferred and common shares of the company. The $6,912,500 convertible 5 1/2 per cent debentures would remain undisturbed under the plan, which has been discussed with bankers for the company.

MEDIA, Pa., Oct. 14. -- William MacKenzie's Greg Ormont, 6-to-1 outsider, won the Foxcatcher Plate, for 3-year-olds and up, over a two-mile brush course at the opening of the Rose Tree Hunt Club's Fall meet near here today. Threatening weather held the crowd to 5,000.

Wallace Spence broke the American fifty-yard short course breast stroke record by nine-tenths of a second at the first meet of the Metropolitan A.A.U. indoor season held in the Park Central swimming pool last night. Racing against time, the New York Athletic Club star, former senior national medley titleholder, negotiated the distance in 0:28, to shatter the old standard of 0:28.9 that Paul Friesel of the Dragon Club created last year.

A series of sessions to be known as "The World Economic and Monetary Conference" was started yesterday at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel, to be continued every Wednesday and Thursday "until all the important subjects shall have been given consideration."
The grand jury began yesterday an investigation of alleged "strongarm" tactics by Communist members of a textile union in front of two non-union shops in the Madison Square district.

The directors of the Tide Water Oil Company and the Tide Water Associated Oil Company approved yesterday the merger of these two companies and the Associated Oil Company into the Tide Water Associated Oil Company. The merger plan will be submitted to the directors of Associated Oil Company on Oct. 16, following approval of which special meetings of stockholders of the three companies will be held to vote on the plan.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- Already on record for "government protection" for widows and orphans and dependants of deceased World War veterans, the American Legion executive committee within the next few weeks probably will be asked to consider a proposal to demand continued payments, in the form of a pension, or "insurance" soon to expire.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14. -- Business men of America were told by President Roosevelt tonight in straight-from-the-shoulder language that his administration had saved them from ruin, rather than hurt them. The address, one of the major speeches of the President's campaign for reelection, was delivered from the same platform where he accepted the nomination in 1932.

In an overtime discussion of recent world monetary moves, export credit men, meeting yesterday in the Hotel Pennsylvania for their regular monthly exchange of views on credit and collection conditions abroad, expressed the opinion that the international gold exchange plan announced on Tuesday by this country, Great Britain and France will be a stabilizing factor in world trade.

The new Iridium Room of the St. Regis was thronged last night for a gala dinner dance arranged in behalf of the Musicians Emergency Fund which for several years has aided thousands of musicians, principally by creating remunerative work for them.

The gathering tonight will be at the Plymouth, where Gilbert Miller will be installing "Tovarich," derived by Robert E. Sherwood from a French play by Jacques Deval. Marta Abba is making her American debut in one of the two leading roles, John Halliday holding the other.

NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 14. -- Fet, a gray 5-year-old gelding, today won the historic Cesarewitch Stakes, with last year's winner, Near Relation, only a neck behind in second place. Third was Greynam.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- The telegram which the Federal Maritime Commission sent to the secretary of the joint negotiating committee of the maritime unions today read as follows:

letail package deliverles in the metropolitan and suburban areas increased 11 per cent for the week ended Oct. 10, it was announced yesterday by the United Parcel Service. Reflecting the sharp gain in retail trade last week, the increase is the largest for any weekly period since the latter part of August.

The following film programs, which will be shown over the weekend, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local private and public elementary and high schools.

LONDON, Oct. 14. -- France and Italy have now accepted the clause embodied in Part IV of the London Naval Treaty of 1930 providing that except in a case of persistent refusal to submit to visit and search, submarines in future wars may not sink or disable a merchant vessel without first placing her company and passengers in a place of safety.

Purchase Commissioner Russell Forbes announced yesterday his acceptance of the resignation of Ambrose B. Acker, director of purchase in the department, who has been in ill health for many months. Mr. Acker offered his resignation last June. He has drawn no city salary since July 1.
CHICAGO, Oct. 14. -- The texts of President Roosevelt's speeches here and in St. Louis were as follows:

Although production of steel ingots declined a half point this week to 75 per cent of capacity, backlogs of unfilled orders are growing, and steel shipped is going into consumption, the magazine Iron Age said in its weekly summary, issued yesterday.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 14 (AP). -- Kentucky's bluegrass region, whose rolling pasture lands, dotted with luxurious, white barns, carry an investment of some $30,000,000 for the breeding of thoroughbred horses, hails the return of the sport of kings tomorrow after a lapse of three years.

In a modern world of confused ideals and harsh realities, the problem of mental health is becoming increasingly acute and to meet it a greater amount of work of a creative, stimulating nature is needed to keep the average person mentally healthy and young, according to Dr. Jay B. Nash, Professor of Education at New York University.

The board of directors of the New York County Lawyers Association announced yesterday its stand on the various candidates for judicial offices at the coming election. It endorsed both Harlan W. Rippey, Democrat, and James P. Hill, Republican, the two principal candidates for election to the Court of Appeals.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 14. -- King Leopold, in a statement to a Cabinet council here today, announced Belgium had severed her military alliances and was resuming her pre-war neutrality.

TOKYO, Oct. 14. -- The British announcement of commercial credits for China not only awakens Japan's ceaseless distrust of Western enterprise in China, but it is felt to be especially inconvenient at this moment when delicate negotiations are proceeding.

BERLIN, Oct. 14. -- Prices on the Boerse continued to Fall today, the opinion still prevailing that, since Germany is not going to devalue her currency, the listed stocks are not worth what has been paid for them recently. Near the close, however, the market showed sudden signs of indecision and a scattered tendency to gain.

Eric Seelig, German middleweight, entered the ring of the Hippodrome at 10 o'clock last night before about 5,000 fight fans a prospective challenger for the world's middleweight title. Two minutes later he was on the way to his dressing room, his title hopes shattered, a disillusioned fighter with his first knockout charged against him and his third defeat on the record in a career of five years.

Motor fuel stocks in the United States, including the amount of unfinished gasoline contained in naphtha distillates, at the end of last week were 57,448,000 barrels, compared to revised figures of 58,299,000 at the close of the preceding week, a drop of 851,000, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

All classes of commercial locations were in good demand yesterday as brokers reported leases to a variety of enterprises. Merchants, manufacturers, jobbers, professional men, schools, makers of novelties and specialists were among the tenants, and all sections, downtown, lower Broadway, the garment center, Rockefeller Center and Lexington Avenue, were represented.

The advance in cotton futures on the Cotton Exchange was extended 15 to 17 points yesterday morning, but increased realizing and continued hedge selling at levels $1.60 to $1.75 a bale above the lows of last Saturday caused reactions later.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP). -- Cotton consumed during September was reported by the Census Bureau today to have totaled 629,727 bales of lint and 67,859 of linters, compared with 574,289 and 65,382 in August this year and 450,647 and 61,362 in September last year.

Pennsylvania will go Democratic by a plurality of more than 250,000, it was predicted yesterday by Senator Joseph F. Guffey of that State. Senator Guffey was functioning as spokesman for the Democratic National Committee in the absence of Chairman James A. Farley from the Biltmore headquarters.

Coach Lou Little of Columbia is taking no chances on having Virginia Military Institute upset the Lions at Baker Field on Saturday. Yesterday, in a three-hour drill, the varsity battled the strong freshman squad as the Blue reached the peak of its training for the game.

BOSTON, Oct. 14. -- In the nine-month report of State Street Investment Corporation, Paul C. Cabot, president, says that to qualify as a mutual investment company and thereby to have exemption from the normal corporate income tax of 15 per cent and the surtax on undistributed earnings, the company intends to distribute to stockholders not only dividends and interest received, but also net gains from sales of securities.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:
The governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange adopted yesterday the recommendations of the committee of stock list to list he following securities:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- The possibility of an early conference of subcommittees on peaceful adjustment of the controversy involving the executive council of the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization depended tonight on what the council would do with the request made by the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers' convention that the ten suspended C.I.O. unions be permitted to enter the federation's convention at Tampa.

Prominent women educators who have accepted membership on a committee to promote the reelection of President Roosevelt were announced yesterday by the women's division of the Democratic National Committee, which has appointed as chairman Dean C. Mildred Thompson of Vassar College.

Not many weeks ago the Board of City Magistrates, by a vote of 24 to 4, adopted a schedule of uniform fines for speeding and other traffic offenses. The purpose of this schedule is clear. It is to prevent discrimination in the levying of fines and to reduce to a minimum the practice of trying to get a case before a particular magistrate supposed to be especially lenient or friendly.

LONDON, Oct. 14. -- Lord Plymouth, acting chairman of the Spanish non-intervention committee, tonight turned down the Soviet Government's "virtual ultimatum" demanding that the committee be reconvened immediately to discuss alleged neutrality violations by Portugal, Italy and Germany.
SALEM, N.H., Oct. 14 (AP). -- Furfiber, running in the colors of Mrs. William R. Flemming, raced off with the mile Colonel's Handicap by two lengths at Rockingham Park today.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 14. -- With the Army squad leaving for the Belmont Country Club tomorrow, where it will remain until shortly before Saturday's game with Harvard, Head Coach Gar Davidson used today's practice entirely for the purpose of perfecting the defense against Crimson plays.

The possibility that one or more groups of holders of securities of the privately operated rapid transit lines might hold out for better terms than those provided in the unification plan drawn by Samuel Seabury and A. A. Berle Jr., City Chamberlain, was discussed yesterday at an adjourned hearing before the Transit Commission.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Oct. 14. -- Premier George Kiosseivanoff's return from his long absence in Geneva and Belgrade has made the latent government crisis acute. Behind the crisis are the intrigues of Fascist groups supporting the former dictator, Professor Alexander Tsankoff, who is reported planning a new Fascist dictatorship.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 14. -- Fearing a powerful Navy attack, Yale today was on the defensive throughout its final long practice in preparation for the game in the Baltimore Municipal Stadium on Saturday.

ALBANY, Oct. 14. -- Sixteen Republican lawyers, named by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., to serve as Asssitant Attorneys General to investigate alleged registration frauds in Albany, were stripped of their power today when they defied the State's law officer.

For the first time since Oct. 1, the stock market declined yesterday. At no time was there any noticeable pressure on representative issues and losses were small in less active trading. General business indices were favorable, with the weekly steel output around the peak and electric output the third highest in the history of the industry.

Sterling, Inc., which operates a chain of seven retail installment furniture stores in this area, yesterday purchased the household furniture business of J.W. Greene, Inc., of Jersey City Edward A. Thomson, president and general manager, announced.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 14. -- Bridgton Academy upset the Army Plebes, 12 to 6, in Michie Stadium today by coming from behind in the last five minutes of play to score the winning touchdown.

MOSCOW, Oct. 14. -- The Soviet Government has demanded the establishment of a munitions blockade of Portuguese ports by the British or French navy, or both acting jointly, as the minimum guarantee of non-intervention in the Spanish Civil War which would be acceptable to the Soviet.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 14 (AP). -- In the face of a demand by the Federal Maritime Commission for an indefinite waterfront truce, maritime labor leaders asked their members tonight for authority to call a coast-wide shipping strike Oct. 28 "if necessary."

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 14. -- There will be thirty-five women among the 100 jurors who will be called for the first two weeks of the November term of Federal court here, opening Nov. 4, it was announced today.

PARIS, Oct. 14. -- King Leopold's declaration of Belgium's resumption of neutrality has created a profound sensation in France, where it is not believed all hope of reviving Franco-Belgian cooperation is lost. The news of the Belgian Cabinet meeting was received late this evening, and pending receipt of formal notice from the Belgian Government official comment is withheld.

President ROOSEVELT affirmed last night his faith in the "individualism" of American business and discussed at some length the proper relations between business and the Government. Much that he said was highly reassuring. But he did not deal specifically with certain questions which Governor LANDON had raised the previous evening.

Condemning the substitution of "ballyhoo" for reason in political campaigns, Dr. Harry W. Laidler, Socialist candidate for Governor, in a campaign speech last night sharply criticized "rationalizing intellectuals," who, he said, support Democratic and Republican candidates with whom they disagree fundamentally.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- Out of twenty political news writers asked to pick the winner in the Presidential race, only one has selected Governor Landon, according to News Week. Averaging the predictions, the writers think President Roosevelt will be re-elected by 374 electoral votes to 157, and with a popular plurality of 8,625,000.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 14. -- A lengthy proclamation issued today by Mayor Howard W. Jackson designated the Navy-Yale football game here Saturday as the official opening of the Baltimore Stadium season.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 14. -- Coach Dick Harlow of Harvard has made no effort to conceal the fact that he is mighty fearful of the forward passes that Charles (Monk) Meyer of Army is likely to throw in the Stadium on Saturday.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Oct. 14. -- The craftmanship of the furniture makers of Grand Rapids was used tonight by Governor Landon as an illustration of the advisability of retaining something of old designs even while improving on them by adopting new ones.

An appeal to Governor Lehman to call a special session of the Legislature to amend the Election Law so that the polls in New York City could stay open fifteen hours instead of twelve on election day was under consideration yesterday by the Board of Elections.

ALBANY, Oct. 14. -- Problems which face the farmers of the State were discussed informally today by Governor Lehman and a group of farm leaders who met at the Executive Mansion and had luncheon with Mr. Lehman. Not only were immediate problems discussed but several long-range matters were also brought up and the Governor's guests had an opportunity to give their views.
Columbia's Lou Little, weary of all the sectional and technical classifications of football, said yesterday there are really only two kinds of football -- good and bad.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- Beginning an investigation of Calvin Bullock, Inc., of New York City, and its twelve member investment trust and management companies, the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today that this investment group sustained 1927-1935 losses of more than $42,000,000.

LONDON, Oct. 14. -- Cheerfulness marked today's operations on the London Stock Exchange. British funds strengthened further. European securities weakened in the foreign department and Brazilians remained firm. Southern gained with Northeastern among the home rails, while Argentines also went higher.

GLASGOW, Oct. 14 (Canadian Press). -- Fifty thousand spectators at Ibrox Park, home of the Glasgow Rangers, saw Scotland score two goals in the second half to defeat Germany, 2 -- 0, today in an international soccer match.
Warning against increasing costs imposed upon the city by the State, Mayor La Guardia suggested yesterday that the Legislature make appropriations for expenditures required by mandatory laws.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 14. -- Forty-two members of the senior class at Princeton University have qualified provisionally for the "no-course" plan of departmental study, according to an announcement today by Professor Robert K. Root, dean of the faculty.

GUAM, Thursday, Oct. 15. -- After three hours and fifteen minutes of bucking headwinds and seeking vainly to fly around a typhoon building up rapidly athwart her course, the flying boat China Clipper, en route from Guam to Manila, returned to Guam this morning to await better weather.

NAVAS DEL REY, Spain, Oct. 14 (AP). -- Spanish Government forces defending the Pelayos Gorge, across the Alberche River, west of here, battled grimly against Rebels streaming down on them from Pelayos and San Martin de Valdeiglesias tonight.

A plan to eliminate all arrears of dividends on the preferred stock of the Barker Brothers Corporation has been approved by the directors and will be voted upon by all the stockholders at a special meeting on Nov. 25.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 14 (AP). -- Mrs. Herbert Hoover, wife of the former President, wielded the gavel at the national convention of the Girl Scouts of America today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 14. -- Following spirited competition and bidding, Paramount today bought Faith Baldwin's "Woman Interne" for Claudette Colbert. Production, however, will be deferred until the latter part of the season. Meanwhile, misfortune continues to dog "Maid of Salem."
MANILA, Thursday, Oct. 15. -- This globe-girdling reporter arrived in Manila at 8:30 A. M. today after a rather rough voyage from Hongkong aboard the steamship President Pierce.

HENDAYE, France, Oct. 14. -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco today ordered the strengthening of certain points in the Rebel arc west of Madrid before a general attack begins. Despite the heavy rain and the poor condition of many roads, hundreds of guns and tanks were moved up with a view toward gaining command of government communications between Madrid, Valencia and Murcia.

MONTREAL, Oct. 14. -- Before packed galleries Premier Maurice Duplessis yesterday summarized the accomplishments and intentions of his Provincial government of National Union. The main efforts, he intimated, would be directed to restoring agriculture and re-colonizing the Province.

Eight appointments to the teaching and administrative staff of Columbia University were announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university. Six new professors and lecturers will direct graduate studies and research in chemistry, engineering, sociology, international relations, education and psychiatry.

Except for the guilder which advanced sharply, the leading foreign exchanges yesterday continued their gradual and orderly decline in terms of the dollar. The French franc fell to 4.65 3/4 cents, the lowest price since the suspension of the gold standard, and closed at 4.66 cents, off 3/4 point.

Building projects filed yesterday included a $600,000 apartment house for Brooklyn, a $175,000 multifamily structure for Woodhaven and a $225,000 house for Forest Hills. Details of the filings were as follows:

LONDON, Oct. 14. -- Although Samuel Kagan, counselor of the Soviet Embassy, accompanied by Ivan M. Maisky, the Soviet Ambassador, who has just returned to his London post, went to the Foreign Office again today asking that the Spanish non-intervention committee be summoned forthwith to take action on the Soviet neutrality demands, no assurance on that point was given to them.

ALBANY, Oct. 14. -- With the number of suspensions and revocations of auto operators' licenses nearly 1,000 higher than at the same period last year, Charles A. Harnett, State Motor Vehicle Commissioner, announced today that six motorists would be forced to drive in the future with speed governors on their cars.

Ten Manhattan properties, including a fifteen-story apartment house at the southeast corner of West End Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street, were bought in yesterday by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales as follows:

The General Electric Company reported yesterday a net income of $26,533,667 for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 after depreciation, taxes and charges. This was equal to 92 cents a share on the capital stock. It compared to $17,205,332, or 60 cents a share, in the same period in 1935.
NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 14. -- After five and a half months of travel, the hat owned by Albert E. Wickey, retired St. Louis express handler, was returned to him at the Newark Airport this afternoon.
CHICAGO, Oct. 14. -- James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, raised the ante today on John D. M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14. -- The market for hogs was strong to 10 cents a hundredweight higher in the early trading today, but weakened later when leading buyers refused to follow the advance, and the close was mostly 5 to 10 cents under the average level yesterday.

A settlement of small claims in the estate of Edward West Browning, real estate operator, revealed that the estate is worth less than $4,000,000, according to a petition filed yesterday by Joseph V. McKee, attorney for The Title Guarantee Trust Company, executor of the estate.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Oct. 14. -- A sensation was caused in this country today when it became known that a Finnish-born woman, Miss Sally Salminen, a domestic servant of a wealthy family in Massachusetts, had won the first prize of 50,000 marks in a literary contest.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Oct. 14. -- Ed Honeycomb, porter in a cafe here, who was buried in a pauper's grave after his death five months ago, was the heir to a farm in Cornwall, England worth $15,000, it was revealed today.

MADRID, Oct. 14 (Passed by the Censor). -- The continued Loyalist attack on Oviedo, in the northwest, is changing to a certain extent the general perspective of the civil war, since the Rebels now find themselves obliged to direct serious attention to a front they believed invulnerable.

James L. Kilpatrick, president of the New York Telephone Company, reported yesterday to stockholders that telephone revenues of the company for the first eight months of 1936 were $131,177,743, compared with $124,073,703 for the same period in 1935, and net telephone earnings were $24,424,591, compared with $20,549,313.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 14. -- The 1936 Carnegie International Exhibition of Modern Paintings will open tomorrow in the galleries of Carnegie Institute occupied each year by this show, one of the most important shows of the season. Prize winners will be announced Thursday evening and broadcast (WJZ at 11 P.M.).

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 14. -- Mrs. Edward Stevens of Round Hill, in her first year as a member of the National Women's Senior Golf Association, won the two-day annual medal-play championship of the organization with a thirty-six-hole score of 174.

First honors in brand-new inter-borough gridiron rivalry went to the New York Yankees as they overpowered the Brooklyn Tigers, 17 to 6, under the floodlights at Randalls Island last night. It was the second victory for the Yankees in three American Football League starts.

Directors of the Raymond Concrete Pile Company declared yesterday a dividend of $3.75 a share covering arrears to date in addition to the regular quarterly payment of 75 cents on the $3 cumulative convertible preferred stock. The company declared also a dividend of 25 cents on the common, the first since 50 cents was paid on May 1, 1931.

BERLIN, Oct. 14. -- Veiled appeals for foreign credits voiced repeatedly by Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics, were backed up publicly today by the Frankfurter Zeitung in a front-page article discussing the international credit situation.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman went before the assembled braves of Tammany Hall last night and struck back at charges of his Republican opponent that there had been politics in relief and waste in government during his terms as Chief Executive of the State.

Controller Taylor of New York City will consider sealed bids on Oct. 26 for an issue of $30,000,000 of one-to-five-year serial bonds of the city, it was announced yesterday. Proceeds from the sale of these bonds will be used for the payment at maturity of $30,000,000 of 4 per cent revenue notes, due Nov. 1, 1936.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- Thirty foreign countries bought fewer American products in August than in July, although at $178,314,000 the value of the month's foreign shipments represented an increase of more than $6,000,000 over those of the corresponding month last year, according to detailed figures made public today by the Department of Commerce.
IT was in a football gathering and Sam Cordovano was sitting on the outskirts of the group discussing a forward pass play used by the Army against Columbia.

PARIS, Oct. 14. -- Prices on the Bourse were strong today from the opening until the close, with some sensational gains being made by French shares. The turnover was unusually large, and the activity never flagged, although a few stocks were not able to hold their best levels of the day.

The criticism that was raised over the fact that Sid Luckman had been singled out and showered with such flattering praise before he had played a game of varsity football was pretty well answered last Saturday by the young man himself.

The trade agreements program of the national administration is setting an example to other nations which might lead to the breakdown of "the whole system of strangulation of world trade," Francis B. Sayre, Assistant Secretary of State, declared last night.

Counsel for Harley Clarke, for years president of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, served notice yesterday through the Sheriff of New York County on the Atlas Corporation, Floyd B.
