Odlum and the Manufacturers Trust Company of a suit in equity seeking extension of an option to purchase the Atlas Corporation holdings in Utilities Power and Light and affiliated companies.

The City of New York expects to build the largest asphalt plant in the world this Winter on the western shore of Flushing Bay within the World's Fair zone. Plans for the development were filed yesterday at the Bureau of Public Buildings, Long Island City, following approval by the Municipal Art Commission.

Governor LANDON devoted his Detroit speech to the question of democratic liberty, and his words emphasized a paradox of the campaign. It is this: We may deny that the preservation of American liberty is an issue in the election and yet welcome the stress laid upon it by the Republicans.

At long last a truce has been made in Palestine. Through the initiative of the Arab Kings of Iraq, Yemen and Saudi Arabia and the Emir of Trans-Jordan, the general strike of Palestine Arabs against the British authorities to force the discontinuance of Jewish immigration was called off last Monday after twenty-four weeks of disorder, strife and death.

The gross revenue from operations of the properties of the Port of New York Authority for the year ended Sept. 30 was $12,611,524, an increase of 5.7 per cent over the preceding year, according to a report published yesterday. The net income was $3,950,866, an increase of 17.5 per cent.

Although the Crescent Athletic Club finished first in the annual championship series of the New York and Metropolitan District Cricket Association, members of the Staten Island team carried off most of the individual honors during the season just ended.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- A summary of registrations filed recently under the Securities Act of 1933 was made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, as follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- After a 50 per cent decline from 1929 to 1933, American retail business reached in 1935 a total of $32,790,267,000, or nearly two-thirds of the $49,114,653,000 peak reached six years before, according to results of the National Business Census announced today by William L. Austin, director of the Census Bureau.

There can be only acclaim for the convincing manner in which the Deutsche Zeppelin Reederei has concluded the experimental service by airship across the North Atlantic which it began last May. On Monday the Hindenburg, largest aircraft constructed by man, docked at her home port of Frankfort at the end of her tenth round trip with passengers, mail and freight.

Dr. Juan Luis Rodriguez, director of the Inter-American Trade-Mark Bureau of Havana, who is here on a visit, made public yesterday proposed resolutions to be adopted by the forthcoming Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace, urging all of the twenty-one American republics which have not yet done so to ratify the pending convention and protocol of 1929 for trade-mark registration and protection.

Survival of hunting and fishing on a large scale depends upon the support American business men and sportsmen will give to conservation on lands now used for agriculture and grazing, two speakers agreed yesterday at a luncheon of the American Wildlife Institute at the Downtown Association, 60 Pine Street.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14. -- The Rose Tree Fox Hunting Club, founded in 1859, opened its seventy-seventh annual Fall race meet today at the famous dumb-bell course near Media.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14. -- A huge parade, estimated by some to include 150,000 marchers, moved through two miles of crowd-packed Chicago streets tonight in a mass scale tribute to President Roosevelt. The parade was led by John Fitzpatrick, president of the Chicago Federation of Labor.

Dr. Will Durant's inclination Rooseveltward is based, presumably, upon his statements of the Republican and Democratic arguments on the basic issues. Those arguments, thus stated, are I believe, quite comprehensive and representative of the respective positions.

DUBLIN, Irish Free State, Oct. 14. -- At its first meeting since the start of the Spanish conflict the Irish Catholic hierarchy, sitting at Maynooth College yesterday, with Cardinal MacRory presiding, issued a pronouncement on the situation in Spain.

That Endeavour II, British challenger for the America's Cup, and the proposed American defender will have stronger, heavier masts for next Summer's races was indicated by W.A.W. Stewart, commodore of the New York Yacht Club and head of the cup committee, yesterday.

Testimony to show that the railroads were losing revenue to freight consolidating and forwarding companies was elicited yesterday from evidence derived from the Boston Maine and Boston Albany Railroads by William J. Walsh, attorney for the Interstate Commerce Commission's bureau of investigation, at a hearing in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

The use for the first time of perjury indictments as a weapon against State income tax evaders was disclosed yesterday with the announcement here of the arrest in Miami, Fla., of Dr. Joseph Karger of 1,727 Forty-seventh Street, Brooklyn.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 14. -- A petition in bankruptcy was filed here today by the Hofbrau Haus in Hoboken, N.J., one of the best-known German restaurants in New Jersey and one of the oldest of its kind in the United States.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 14. -- Recognition of a life spent in advancing photography from a hobby to a science came tonight for Dr. C.E. Kenneth Mees, vice president in charge of research at the Eastman Kodak Company. To him was awarded the progress medal of the Society of Motion Picture Engineers at its banquet here.

The Composers' Forum-Laboratory, a WPA Federal Music Project unit, sponsoring contemporary American music, last night inaugurated its second series at the Federal Music Project headquarters, 110 West Forty-eighth Street. The program was devoted to the works of Lazare Saminsky, New York composer.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 14. -- Conditions in Palestine are virtually normal again after six months of disturbance. Arab shops are open, Arab-operated taxis and buses are running, peasant women are carrying baskets of vegetables from villages for sale in towns, intimidators in front of Arab shops have disappeared and curfew regulations gradually are being withdrawn.

Aroused over the implication that nineteen infants had died last month in Harlem Hospital because of a shortage in the nursing staff, Mayor La Guardia said last night that the Hospitals Department had provided for 407 nursing positions in the 1937 budget which would be filled as soon as nurses could be found for them.

DANZIG, Oct. 14. -- The arrest of more than 100 members of the Social Democratic party followed the dissolution of that party today. This morning the city's police chief issued a decree prohibiting the Socialist party and late this evening most of its leaders, including several Deputies in the Diet, were placed in "protective custody."

JERUSALEM, Oct. 14. -- Conditions in Palestine are virtually normal again after six months of disturbance. Arab shops are open, Arab-operated taxis and buses are running, peasant women are carrying baskets of vegetables from villages for sale in towns, intimidators in front of Arab shops have disappeared and curfew regulations gradually are being withdrawn.

Aroused over the implication that nineteen infants had died last month in Harlem Hospital because of a shortage in the nursing staff, Mayor La Guardia said last night that the Hospitals Department had provided for 407 nursing positions in the 1937 budget which would be filled as soon as nurses could be found for them.

DANZIG, Oct. 14. -- The arrest of more than 100 members of the Social Democratic party followed the dissolution of that party today. This morning the city's police chief issued a decree prohibiting the Socialist party and late this evening most of its leaders, including several Deputies in the Diet, were placed in "protective custody."

LONDON, Oct. 14 (AP). -- The following are the Board of Trade figures for the month of September: Total imports, 71,890,000; exports of British products, 36,960,000; reports, 3,850,000; total exports, 40,810,000; excess of imports, 31, 080,000.

C.E. Groesbeck, president of the Electric Bond and Share Company, told stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday that he "earnestly hoped" some satisfactory solution of the problem of Federal competition with public utilities may be evolved from the conferences initiated recently in Washington by President Roosevelt.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 15. -- "The possibility of any favorable understanding resulting from interviews between Ambassador Shigera Kawagoe and Foreign Minister Chang Chun are not bright," declared General Seichi Kita in an interview last night.

LONDON, Oct. 14. -- The long Summer quiescence of the British Government ended today with the first meeting of the Baldwin Cabinet since July and with speeches tonight by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and several other Ministers.

William Enequist carded a 92 -- 24 -- 68 to take the low-net laurels and the President's Cup in the annual Long Island Real Estate Board golf tournament at the Pomonok Country Club, Flushing, yesterday. C. Otis Smith turned in a 93 -- 18 -- 75 to annex the second prize for the eighteen-hole morning round, which saw only seven players tour the course because of the inclement weather.
The address of Governor Herbert H. Lehman at Tammany Hall last night follows:...
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 14. -- Zay, short in name and diminutive of stature, proved long on heart today in the running of the Grade B Handicap which featured the program at Laurel.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 14. -- A program of expansion of educational activities and enlargement of facilities for student welfare calling for a fund of $12,500,000 was ordered by the Corporation of Massachusetts Institute of Technology at its Autumn meeting here this afternoon.

The committee for Missouri Pacific Railroad first and refunding 5 per cent bonds, which is headed by John W. Stedman, vice president of the Prudential Insurance Company, spent $27,109 between July 1, 1935, and July 25, 1936, according to a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission made public yesterday.

The announcement of arrangements among the stabilization funds of the United States, Great Britain and France to buy and sell gold from and to each other stirred up fresh talk yesterday of the possibilities of setting up in this country a free gold market such as exists in London.

Frank Palmentere, driver for the Terminal Cab Company, Forty-sixth Street and Twelfth Avenue, did his best to give back a tip of $4.65 on a 35-cent fare, but his good luck held and he could not. The incident was revealed yesterday at the East Fifty-first Street station when Lieutenant Frank Smith made a report.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 14. -- Flour millers here were taking steps today to refund to their direct customers millions of dollars in AAA Processing taxes that had been received by them after the AAA was invalidated by the United States Supreme Court.
Seven arrests for disorderly conduct, one for felonious assault and several street fights marked the first day of the strike of Brooklyn garage workers yesterday.

The Chicago North Western Railway showed a net income after charges in September for the first time this year, according to preliminary estimates, Fred W. Sargent, president, said yesterday. He added that gross revenues in September were about $8,478,000, up 14 per cent from September, 1935, and that net operating income was about $1,300,000, against $860,000.

Mayor La Guardia and Senator Robert F. Wagner yesterday laid the cornerstone of the $12,783,000 housing project which the Federal Public Works Administration is raising in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

A controversy between the New York Central Railroad and the Baltimore Ohio Railroad precipitated by an alliance made by the B. O. with the Keeshin trucking interests culminated yesterday in the disclosure that the New York Central soon would divert to the Pennsylvania Railroad freight formerly shipped from here to Baltimore over the B. O.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 14. -- Merlin H. Aylesworth, chairman of the board of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation, predicted tonight an increase in motion picture theatre admission prices and the abolition of the "double-feature" program, which he called "a wasteful, injurious practice."

A new marigold,, called "Crown of Gold," was given a private "preview" yesterday in Horticultural Hall, Rockefeller Center. With its chrysanthemum-like bloom it is said to be the answer to all gardeners who want marigolds that bloom early "and bloom continuously with new and interesting types of flowers."
I think it is a mistake to belittle, as in your editorial "Bus Gas," the pestilential nature of these new buses in Manhattan.

Miss Alice Andre heads a group of younger members of society aiding in the plans for the dinner, dance and entertainment in behalf of the Russian Nobility Fund Association tonight in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador.

Jacob Gould Schurman, former United States Ambassador to Ger- many; Robert Goelct and Lauritz Melchior, tenor of the Metropolitan Opera Company, are among those arriving today from Europe on the North German Lloyd line Europa.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14. -- Army bid invitations from now on will include several additional clauses intended to make clear some provisions of the Walsh-Healey Government Contracts Act and its supporting regulations issued by the Department of Labor.

The record registration of voters in the city definitely assures adoption of the proposed new charter by an overwhelming margin, George Brokaw Compton, campaign manager of the Citizens Charter Campaign Committee, said yesterday.
VALLADOLID, Spain, Oct. 15. -- Somewhere in Spain today the writer interviewed Generalissimo Francisco Franco, leader of the Insurgent forces and probably the busiest man in Europe.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 15. -- Fawzi Bey el Kaougji, commandant of the Military Training College of Iraq, who resigned his post there to aid the Arabs in Palestine, has left the country and is returning to Iraq.

Miss Sally Salminen, a quiet, charming young woman who came to this country six years ago from the Aaland Islands, midway between Sweden and Finland, to seek adventure, related last night how she had spent a year writing her first novel at night after working as a housemaid during the day.

The final registration figures show the unfair method of representation in the legislative branch of the government. One district in Manhattan has 15,890 registered voters and another district in Queens has 150,317. Each of these districts has one Assemblyman, though the Queens district has almost ten times the voters of the Manhattan district.

Continued but not pronounced gains for President Roosevelt in the Literary Digest's Presidential straw vote was a feature of the seventh installment of returns which appears in this week's issue of the magazine. Only two more installments are coming, one on Oct. 24 and the final on Oct. 31, three days before election.

The Equity Corporation reported yesterday total net assets of $28,829,083 as of Sept. 30 before deducting the face amount of debentures. This was equal to $9,093.28 on each $1,000 of debentures outstanding, to $100.16 a share on the convertible preferred stock and to $2.73 a share on the 4,956,629 shares of common stock outstanding on Sept. 30.
Purchase of apartment house sites in the Bronx and industrial deals in Manhattan were among the urban realty transactions reported yesterday.

The movement among representative Stock Exchange firms to extend the daily trading session one hour, by changing the closing time from 3 P. M. to 4 P. M., received impetus yesterday when members of the board of governors of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms indicated their approval of the plan.

TOKYO, Oct. 15. -- With the launching at Kobe today of the cruiser Kumano, which is of 8,500 tons and has fifteen 6-inch guns, Japan completed her newest squadron of four light cruisers, each designed to carry heavier armament than any others of their type.
Sailing tonight for London on the Europa, Gilbert Miller lets fall an item or two about his plans, as follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- Bids received on thirty-eight issues of bonds of municipalities, counties and districts and a group of 4 per cent warrants of various counties and cities in Alabama with an aggregate face value of approximately $4,650,000 were made public tonight by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Charlie O'Connell started the Ohio State and P.M.C. games for N.Y.U. as varsity center, but when the Violet clashes with North Carolina at the Yankee Stadium tomorrow that same Charlie O'Connell will be at fullback. The awesome reports that have drifted north from Chapel Hill about the phenomenal punting ability of Tom Burnette yesterday prompted Coach Mal Stevens to switch his best kicker to the back field.

LONDON, Oct. 15. -- A direct link exists between King Leopold's historic declaration on neutrality, made yesterday, and publication in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Aug. 12 of a message from London announcing that the Belgian Government was preparing to move toward a return to pre-war conditions.
GENEVA, Oct. 15. -- Belgium's announced neutrality policy is causing much concern in League of Nations circles, where it is held to raise very important questions regarding Belgium's League policy.
EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 15. -- A plea to save the world from war was voiced today by the Rt. Rev. James E. Freeman, Bishop of Washington, D. C., and the Rt. Rev. John Cragg Farthing, Bishop of Montreal.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 15. -- Four sons of former Senator Hiram Bingham, grandson of the late Charles Tiffany of New York City, today combined backgrounds of art, science, literature and law in entering the dairy business.

The Citizens Union, in making public yesterday its recommendations for judicial candidates in New York City, endorsed Morris A. Koenig for re-election to the General Sessions bench, termed Saul S. Streit, Democrat, "qualified," and ignored Judge Cornelius F. Collins, Democrat, who, like Judge Koenig, has the nomination of major parties.

The Biltmore Theatre at 261-65 West Forty-seventh Street and a seven-story building on the easterly Washington Street block-front between Cedar and Liberty Streets were among the four Manhattan properties sold yesterday at foreclosure auctions.

After having maintained his palatial private home at 10 West Fifty-fourth Street for more than a quarter of a century, John D. Rockefeller Jr., will move next Spring into a large apartment at 740 Park Avenue, it was learned yesterday.

Out of the numerous queries as to how the new agreement on international gold shipments will operate, one unanimously conceded fact stands out. By the terms of the pact, the world's adherence to the gold standard is distinctly asserted. In England, where free gold payments, abandoned during September, 1931, have not yet been resumed, official groping after the vaguely so-called "managed currency" seemed not long ago to exist.

A request by North Carolina University students who will attend a football game between their team and the New York University eleven Saturday in Yankee Stadium to stage an old-fashioned bonfire pep rally in Times Square on Friday evening was politely refused yesterday by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine.

Prosperous trade conditions in the Far East, despite a need for reciprocal agreements with Australia and Japan, were reported yesterday at the thirty-ninth annual meeting of the American Asiatic Association in India House, Hanover Square.

LONDON, Oct. 15. -- The reply of the Earl of Plymouth, acting chairman of the international non-intervention committee on Spain, to Russia's demand that the committee be convened immediately to establish control over Portuguese ports for preserving neutrality is a sharp note refusing to summon the committee at present. His note was made public today.

Last week's record registration of voters, reaching a peak of 2,900,000 in New York City and establishing new highs in all parts of the country, puzzles political leaders in both major parties. Various explanations are advanced for an enrollment of from 15 to 20 per cent in excess of that of four years ago.
LONDON, Oct. 15 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 15. -- Coincident with the revelation that Governor Frank F. Merriam is making a thorough investigation of the taking of motion pictures behind the walls of San Quentin prison it has been brought out that a near-riot was precipitated among the inmates when the cameras were trained upon them.

Following its pace of the previous day, the stock market yesterday moved slightly lower in quiet trading. Losses were confined to fractions for the most part; many issues, however, moved against the trend and established new high prices for the year.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- New charges of "corruption" in the expenditure of WPA funds in Pennsylvania were made today in two statements by the Republican National Committee.

Public offering will be made today of 22,200 shares of Oklahoma Natural Gas Company convertible 6 per cent preference stock at $100 a share by a banking group headed by Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc.

The Republican National Committee made public yesterday the text of a printed slip which is being attached to WPA payroll slips in this city. The slips were signed by the "City Projects Council, 139 West Twenty-second Street, N.Y.C." It reads:

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 15. -- Republican leaders who yesterday demanded access to records of the Works Progress Administration here, showing the names, duties and salaries of administrative employes, were referred today by William H.J. Ely, State WPA director, to Harry L. Hopkins, the National Administrator.

DETROIT, Oct. 15. -- Speaking before 100,000 persons crowded into Cadillac Square tonight, President Roosevelt called on automobile manufacturers and other industrialists to make plans to increase their employes' yearly earnings.

For the third consecutive day, Columbia worked on perfecting its defense against forward passes yesterday at Baker Field. In a two-hour dummy scrimmage against the freshman squad, Lou Little's varsity outfit was put to a severe test as the cubs fired long and short passes into the regulars' territory.

PARIS, Oct. 15. -- Speaking, as Ambassador to France, for the development of President Roosevelt's good neighbor policy, William C. Bullitt, in addressing the American Club of Paris, contended today that the recent collaboration of the United States Government with the governments of France and Great Britain in the field of international monetary cooperation was clear evidence of its desire to reconstruct a basis for an orderly and happy international life.

PARIS, Oct. 15 (AP). -- The Bank of France's stockholders cast ballots today for two directors, or counselors, in the first exercise of their new franchise. The election was conducted in the Salle Pleyel, one of Paris's largest auditoriums.

ALBANY, Oct. 15 (AP). -- Walter J. Fitzpatrick testified at a hearing before the Public Service Commission today that seven operating companies of the Associated Gas and Electric System contributed $326,138.09 to oppose the Wheeler-Rayburn Holding Company Act.

A list of contributions made thus far by members of the du Pont family, and by some of their business associates, to Republican National and State committee campaign funds, totaling $383,000, was made public yesterday by Senator Joseph F. Guffey of Pennsylvania, chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee.

CICERO, Ill., Oct. 15. -- Jockey H. Hauer dominated the riding at Sportsman's Park today, winning with four mounts and finishing in the second notch astride two others. Hauer started his string of winners by scoring astride Dark Prince in the second event.

DETROIT, Oct. 15. -- Coming through Michigan today on a rapid one-day campaign trip, President Roosevelt was so encouraged by his reception that at Pontiac, the last of four wayside stops, he predicted that he would carry the State in November.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Oct. 15 (AP). -- Norman Thomas, Socialist Presidential nominee, said in a speech here today that both Governor Alfred Landon and President Roosevelt were avoiding the "real issues" in their Presidential campaigns.

A scrimmage between the varsity and freshman teams occupied the Fordham football forces yesterday at Fordham Field as the Rams put the finishing touches on their offensive for the meeting with Waynesburg at Randalls Island Stadium tomorrow.

One of Europe's most distinguished skiers, Walter Prager of Switzerland, arrived yesterday on the Europa of the North German Lloyd line eager to take up his duties as ski coach and trainer at Dartmouth College.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15. -- High Republican leaders, conferring here today, were inclined to stress as issues in the final weeks of the campaign the administration's taxation policy and alleged radical support.

One of the surest harbingers of Winter came to the city last night when the New York Skating Club held its first session of the new season at the Ice Club atop Madison Square Garden. The session was devoted to dancing to the club orchestra and to greeting several out-of-town guests.
The 1937 varsity football schedule for Fordham was announced yesterday by Graduate Manager Jack Coffey. Again it looms as one of the most ambitious arranged for an Eastern eleven.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor, through a sub-committee named yesterday, will press some of the unions affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization to break away from the leadership of John L. Lewis, chairman of the C.I.O., it was learned today.

Reading that the theme of the World's Fair of 1939 is to be "the building of the better world of tomorrow * * * with our tools of today" and that the philosophic concept of group-effort is to underlie it, is very gratifying.
The Democratic county chieftains are opposed to charter revision and proportional representation, but they have not decided on how they should inform their followings, it was learned last night.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 15. -- Yale's passing and punting were stressed today in the team's final appearance on the home practice field before departing for Baltimore to play Navy.

The Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad undercharged the Acme Fast Freight, Inc., $140,000 in recent years for freight movement, according to testimony introduced yesterday by E.J. Powers, special agent of the Interstate Commerce Commission, at a hearing of the commission in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 16. -- The Rev. Dr. J. Spencer Kennard, American Baptist missionary, when attempting to land at Yokohama yesterday from the liner Asama Maru on his return from a furlough in the United States, was barred from entering Japan on the grounds that he is a pacifist and a Communist.

RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 15. -- A feature of the Monmouth County Hunt Meet on Saturday at Woodland Farm, Red Bank, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Amory L. Haskell, will be the fourth annual race meet ball at the Rumson Country Club that evening for the benefit of the Monmouth Memorial Hospital of Long Branch.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 15. -- Harvard finished its preparations for the Army game today with some hard tackling down the field under kicks, but there was no other chance-taking against eleventh-hour injury.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- Original negatives of two photographs of Abraham Lincoln, probably taken between his election to the Presidency and his inauguration, have been added to the photographic collection of the Smithsonian Institution.

Eight of the most common fire hazards in the home and in industry were presented in a theatrical fashion on a miniature stage in the New York Museum of science and Industry, in the RCA Building, Rockefeller Center, last night.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 15 (AP). -- Sailors' union officials announced tonight that their locals were rejecting a proposal for a strike vote as proposed by the joint representatives of waterfront unions in the current shipping labor crisis and that the organization would give the Federal Maritime Commission "absolute and unrestricted cooperation."

Increased hedge selling against heavy transactions in spot cotton depressed prices of cotton futures yesterday on the Cotton Exchange. Although trade and foreign buying continued fairly active, it was only sufficient to absorb the offers at slowly declining prices.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 15. -- Prizes awarded by the jury in connection with the 1936 Carnegie International Exhibition of Modern Paintings were announced here this evening, when the show opened in the galleries of Carnegie Institute.

After a year's absence during which he paid extensive visits to England, Germany, Switzerland and other countries, Jacob Gould Schurman, Ambassador to Germany from 1925 to 1928 and former President of Cornell University, returned yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa. He spent three months in Switzerland, two in England, and visited Germany three times for a total of about three months.

Louise Dean, 19 years old, who hopes some day to be able to walk "with two braces, like President Roosevelt," but who at present has to depend on crutches, is so anxious to contribute what she can to seeing Mr. Roosevelt re-elected that she has spent $10 from her savings for the purpose, and is willing to part with one of her most cherished possessions.

Chapter 40 of the proposed new charter has not received the attention it deserves. Dealing with the city's officers and employes, it contains a number of provisions, some of a far-reaching character, designed to fortify honest administration and put an end to recognized abuses.

The Hamburg-American liner Hamburg will arrive today from Europe with Dr. Karl Merck, Dr. Otto Dalmer, Sydney Redecker, Mr. and Mrs. Ludwig Bauer, Dr. Hermann J. Boldt, Mr. and Mrs. Siegfried Gaebel, Dr. Gerhard Kaellner and Mr. and Mrs. H. Little.

With coffee, cocoa and some sugar futures stronger in active dealings yesterday, other commodity futures were irregular or weak in the local markets. In the cash markets cocoa and printcloths reached new high levels, while declines appeared in cotton, wheat, corn, rye, oats, butter, rubber and tin.

Take two parts of gay-heartedness and an equal measure of sentiment and there you have a most palatable comedy, "Tovarich," which was lightly acted at the Plymouth last evening. It is the work of Jacques Deval, author also of "Her Cardboard Lover"; and for the past three or four years it has kept one part or another of the Continent laughing in succession.

Bank clearings in twenty-two principal cities in the week ended on Wednesday were 6.7 per cent below the figures for the corresponding week last year, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The decline followed a gain of 26.2 per cent the week before, which was due to heavy payments incident to the first of the month, which fell in another week last year.

The New York County grand jury investigating rioting and alleged attacks by Communists on non-union textile workers ordered yesterday that "informations" be filed in Special Sessions against four officers of Trimmers Local 2440 of the International Knitgoods Workers Union.
Alice M. Mattison conveyed to I. Charles Lifland a ten-room frame house assessed at $9,200 at 17 Duncan Av., Jersey City. D.E.C. Somers, Inc., was the broker.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 15. -- With the final break-up of the Pickford-Lasky combination, Jesse L. Lasky has joined RKO-Radio to produce six films a Year, the first to star Lily Pons and Nino Martini. Mr. Lasky has had a run of pictures either-mediocre or so good that they failed to make money, and the industry has felt that the mediocrities were caused by conditions beyond his control.

George R. Fearon, Republican leader in the State Senate, will preside at the Landon rally at Madison Square Garden on Oct. 29, which will be the climax of the party's national and State campaign, it was announced last night.

HONOLULU, Oct. 15. -- The era of commercial aviation in the Pacific was opened formally today with the arrival on board the flying boat Philippine Clipper of Juan Trippe, president of Pan American Airways, and seven other American business executives on the first lap of an air journey from Alameda, Calif., to Manila.

EATON, Ohio, Oct. 15 (AP). -- Secretary of Agriculture Wallace credited President Roosevelt tonight with having taken the "economically sound course" over what he said might have been the "politically safest" in starting programs of direct relief and public works.

With more than 200 business men, railroad officials and reporters and guests on board, the new Denver Zephyr of the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad, after a demonstration run from Philadelphia, rolled leisurely into the Pennsylvania Station yesterday morning shortly after 11 o'clock.
Mayor La Guardia said last night he was confident that city firemen would get one day off a week under an arrangement he is now working out with Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott.

WASHINGTON. Oct. 15. -- Development of a mask affording "complete protection" against silicosis, often acquired by workmen engaged in sand-blasting and such work, was announced today by the Navy Department. The mask was designed by W.P. Biggs, departmental safety engineer, and has been tested for several months in navy industrial establishments.

The Metropolitan Savings Bank has completed renovation of old tenements at 93 Madison St., between Catharine and Market Sts. and 126 Madison St., southeast corner of Market St. The house at 93, formerly rented for $3.50 a room, is now fully rented at an average of $11, according to the James Nash Webb Co., the agent.
DETROIT, Oct. 15. -- The text of President Roosevelt's prepared address tonight was as follows:

Brooklyn police were charged yesterday with obstructing the course of the garage workers' strike by interfering with the "peaceful picketing" of the strikers and by preventing them from organizing non-union workers.

With more than 30,000 applications for old-age assistance pending in the State under the new Federal and State Social Security Laws, the Division of Old-Age Assistance of the State Department of Social Welfare has been forced to seek larger quarters and to increase its staff.

MADRID, Friday, Oct. 16. -- Police last night began a house-to-house search for Rebels in Madrid. It will be continued nightly until the government is satisfied that a thorough round-up of dissidents has been made.

Lauritz Melchior, heroic tenor of the Metropolitan Opera Company, returned yesterday with Mrs. Melchior on the North German Lloyd liner Europa after a Summer on his German hunting estate. While abroad the Danish singer was honored by the award of the Danish medal "Ingenio et Arti," issued on the occasion of the birthday of the King of Denmark.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP). -- From the "Beaches of the Dead," in Honduras, scientists have brought back a ghost story and a theory that northern South America gave birth to the greatest civilization ever known in aboriginal America.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- When the tripartite monetary agreement went into effect on Tuesday the United States gold supply at $11,001,612,000 had attained a new high record through imports and purchases, the Treasury revealed today.

Scholastic football activity is scheduled on a small scale in several sections of the metropolitan district today and, although the program lists less than twenty contests, several features are included on it.

A continued shrinkage of brokers' loans and a continued rise of commercial loans were reported in the condition statement of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City for the week ended on Wednesday, which was published yesterday.

The Adams Express Company reports a net asset value of $45,629,151 on Sept. 30, based on market values of that date, equivalent to $19.19 a share on the common stock, compared to $13.04 a share on Dec. 31, 1935, and to $9.20 a share on Sept. 30, 1934.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- Hugh Bullock, vice president of the Calvin Bullock group of fixed and management type investment trusts, told the Securities and Exchange Commission at the hearing today that the investors in these trusts should have a voice in their affairs comparable to the size of their respective holdings.

Frank Horn is a jockey with high cheek bones, bony shoulders and the tall, spare figure of a rider who is getting too large for his profession. The worry about keeping the balance between strength to ride and sufficient lightness to get mounts, has had its effect on this lad who is considered a veteran of the tracks even though he is only about 30.

C.E. Denney, president of the Erie Railroad, said yesterday that its loadings of freight were running 10 per cent ahead of last year's levels. He estimated that September operating revenues were about equal to the $7,204,872 reported in August.

Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan and Samuel Fassler, Commissioner of Buildings, will be witnesses today before the New York County grand jury in an investigation of objectionable conditions in the old Criminal Courts Building, in which the grand jurors and the courts of General Sessions, Special Sessions and the Tombs and Felony Magistrates' Courts are housed.
PARIS, Oct. 15 (AP). -- The weeklystatement of the Bank of France

SYRACUSE, Oct. 15. -- A national campaign for better personnel in government service, as part of a twelve-point program adopted by the New York State League of Women Voters today, was urged upon the convention by Mrs. Douglas M. Moffat of New York City, State chairman, in her annual report. The program also declared in favor of tariff cuts through reciprocal trade agreements, and other steps designated to aid world peace.
LONDON, Oct. 15. -- Lord Nuffield, motor car manufacturer, today offered Oxford University 1,250,000 for the establishment of a post-graduate medical school.

MANILA, Friday, Oct. 16 (AP). -- Communication lines were restored in the typhoon-harassed northern part of Luzon Island yesterday and over the wires came tales of destruction that shot casualty lists up to 546 deaths and 1,045 missing.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 15. -- Her third consecutive day of tournament golf this week ended in another victory for Mrs. Edward Stevens of Round Hill, who, after winning the women's national senior title competition at the Westchester Country Club on Tuesday and Wednesday, proceeded to take low gross honors in the Westchester-Fairfield Association weekly one-day event today.

The December selection of the Literary Guild will be Webb Miller's reminiscences of his twenty years as a foreign correspondent. The title of this book has been changed from, "I Wish I Were in Walden," to "I Found No Peace," and publication has been set for Armistice Day by Simon Schuster.

The Nazification of Danzig is nearly complete. The arrest on Wednesday of more than one hundred Socialists and the dissolution of their party is expected to be followed almost immediately by the expulsion of the thirteen Socialist members from the Diet. This purge would give the Nazis their desired two-thirds majority in the Diet preparatory to going through the farce of "legally" changing the Constitution of the Free City.

GUAM, Friday, Oct. 16. -- The Pan American Airways China Clipper, which turned back to Guam yesterday after flying 356 miles out to sea on the way to Manila, is still held here today by typhoons on the course.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 15 (AP). -- Two leaders of the Lutheran Church in Germany, visioning a world union, told the Tenth Biennial Convention of the United Lutheran Church tonight that there was no decided trend in their country for a "free" church entirely independent of the State.

With New York gunners preparing for the opening of the upland game season on Monday, this is an appropriate time to issue a final warning against careless habits in the field. Every season takes its toll of human lives. Now, before the first shot is fired, each shooter should resolve to do his utmost to prevent an accident.

Buyers and other retail executives from stores in the Middle and Far West reported yesterday there is little or no doubt but that Christmas volume in those sections will rank with or above that of 1929. In their advertising and promotional displays for the holiday period these stores will spend much more money than a year ago, feeling that the expected sales increase will more than justify the outlay.

The most effective and vote-winning speech thus far made by the President in this campaign was delivered by him in Chicago on Wednesday evening. Even those who challenge some of the economic reasoning in it must admit that it was a fine example of the political art.

The New York Young Democratic Club, in a letter to P.W. Litchfield, president of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company of Akron, sponsor of this year's Literary Digest poll, yesterday termed the poll inaccurate, and set forth the reasons it believes the trend it indicates is wrong. The letter said:

Plans of a $150,000 two-story office, store and loft building for the easterly Eighth Avenue block front between Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Streets, opposite the Grand Opera House, were filed yesterday. A $120,000 apartment house for the Bronx also was projected.

OGDENSBURG, N.Y., Oct. 15. -- Reverting to the old-fashioned, informal kind of campaign, made up of handshaking and personal greeting, William F. Bleakley, the Republican candidate for Governor, sped along the Canadian border from Rouses Point, in the upper right corner of the State, to this city today.

Writers of the world, as represented by the delegates from forty-one nations who attended the recent fourteenth annual convention of the PEN literary clubs at Buenos Aires, are in complete disagreement as to whether they should participate professionally in the world social and economic conflict, it was reported yesterday by Haruki Shimazaki, one of Japan's leading novelists.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 15. -- Making all her own pace from start to finish, Myrtlewood, Brownell Combs's great filly, accounted for the first running of the Keene Handicap as thoroughbred racing came back to the heart of the Blue-grass today after a three-year lapse.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 15. -- Walter P. Chrysler, who owns an estate on the Eastern Shore, and twenty-five others were charged today in information laid before the Federal District Court with violations of Federal Migratory Game Laws in Maryland.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 15. -- Football practice at Navy was unexpectedly thrown open today and was attended by the Midshipmen and the academy band. Tomorrow a brief secret practice will end the preparation for Yale.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP). -- Spokesmen for the Agricultural Adjustment Administration today said that the first benefit payments under its soil-conservation program probably would be mailed next week or the week thereafter to farmers in twelve States.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 15. -- Sharp criticism of both the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin and Mgr. John A. Ryan over their political speeches is contained in an editorial of the Catholic Review of the Archdiocese of Baltimore in its issue of tomorrow, revealed here today.

Admiral David Glasgow Farragut rode through the dusk-filled canyons of Madison Avenue yesterday, staring at the darkening sky. His sword was gone and the scabbard, too, but he clung grimly to his binoculars.

The WPA Federal Music Project yesterday announced that it will in the immediate future establish a central theatre of music for all its concerts, chamber music, grand opera and other performances. Officials of the project said that negotiations are under way for the rental of a midtown theatre which will also include office space to serve as administrative headquarters for the project.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- Determined to maintain an estimated $100,000,000 of freight revenues threatened by expiration at the end of the year of so-called emergency surcharges, American railroads will soon ask the Interstate Commerce Commission for the first time in the history of Federal regulation to suspend the "maximum reasonable" rates that now govern 90 per cent of the existing freight-rate structure.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 15. -- Opening his final up-State campaign for re-election here tonight, Governor Lehman stood firmly behind a policy of cooperation with the Federal Government and challenged William F. Bleakley, his Republican opponent, to give a bill of particulars on what parts of such a program he would eliminate.
BERLIN, Oct. 15. -- Germany's profound satisfaction with the change in Belgian policy back to neutrality received little advertising here today aside from headlines such as: "Consternation in Paris."

Elizabeth Smith, pale 18-year-old girl who had been accused of murdering her newly-born baby last April 9, was convicted of manslaughter in the second degree last night by a jury in the Bronx County Court.

For the follower of college football who finds his own university playing too far away to see, New York offers something of a special exhibit tomorrow when two of the best teams of the country, Colgate and Tulane, meet each other at the Polo Grounds.

Los Angeles the other night staged a premiere which dwarfed the biggest of Hollywood efforts in this field. When the film producers put on one of their Arabian first-nights they consume a good deal of candle-power in various forms of illumination and display.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 15. -- King Leopold's proclamation of Belgium's resumption of neutrality met with only favorable comment today. Although the full extent of that policy remains somewhat in doubt there is no doubt that the thing people here in general desire is just that -- neutrality.

MOSCOW, Oct. 15. -- Resolutions demanding that "effective aid" -- meaning, naturally, munitions -- be provided for the Spanish Government forces unless Germany, Portugal and Italy are effectively restrained from sending war materials to the Spanish Rebels have been adopted here by two groups of workers.

PARIS, Oct. 15. -- About 1,300 of the Bank of France's 40,927 shareholders met today in an optimistic atmosphere to elect two counselors and three censors to the new governing board. Also, as an additional hopeful stimulus, the stockholders had just learned that the bank's general council had lowered the discount rate for the second time in two weeks to 2 per cent, against 2 1/2 per cent last week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Oct. 14, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,487,000,000, an increase of $7,000,000, compared with the preceding week and a decrease of $2,000,000, compared with the corresponding week in 1935.

Yesterday Judge BLEAKLEY began his travels among the up-State farmers. They are used to praise from politicians and know all the virtues that are habitually attributed to the rural population. Judge BLEAKLEY told them no news when he spoke of their self-reliance, love of freedom and other noble traits as per copybook.

Operations of the Johns-Manville Corporation and its subsidiaries in the first nine months of this year resulted in a net profit of $3,093,560 after deductions for depreciation, depletion, Federal income taxes and other charges. No allowance was made for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings.

The world economic situation continued generally to improve during August, according to the monthly review of foreign conditions in the fourth quarter review and forecast number of The Annalist (New York), published today. International trade suffered a slight loss and primary commodity stocks increased slightly, it is stated, but these appeared to be only temporary setbacks in the prevailing trend.

Writing in the current issue of Science, journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, J.V. Schwind of the Loyola University School of Medicine, Chicago, describes an operation in which he succeeded in grafting a leg of an albino rat upon the body of another rat in such a way that the transplanted limb retained its muscular activity.

Buddy, dean of the scientifically educated dogs who guide the blind in the United States, celebrated her tenth birthday yesterday by proudly showing her adeptness in leading her master, Morris S. Frank, through the corridors and ballrooms of the Hotel George Washington.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Lester Schumer, a former temporary Tenement House Department inspector and Brooklyn beer saloon owner, was the principal State witness yesterday at the General Sessions trial of John J. Hassett, former member of the abolished examining Board of Plumbers, on a bribery indictment.

Max Zaritsky, president of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers Union, said at his office here last night he would immediately transmit to his associates in the Committee for Industrial Organization a letter sent to him by a new subcommittee of the executive council of the American Federation of Labor.

An appeal to the 14,000 licensed physicians in this city to become the "shock troops" in the battle which the city's Health Department is waging to reduce syphilis, of which there are now 378,000 cases here, was made yesterday by Dr. Charles Walter Clarke, director of the Bureau of Social Hygiene of the New York City Department of Health.

LODI, N.J., Oct. 15. -- A two-year-labor contract was signed today by officials of the United Piece Dye Works of this borough, largest dyeing and printing unit in the country, and the Dyers and Finishers Union. The contract settled a dispute which has existed for several months and which on Aug. 31 led to the complete shutdown of the silk printing plant, which at peak times employed as high as 7,500 persons.

Net earnings of Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., in July were $194,529 and in August $215,632, said a letter sent to stockholders yesterday by Barton Haselton, chairman, and C. Donald Dallas, president, outlining the proposed reclassification plan.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15. -- Miss Carlile Porter, daughter of Brig. Gen. and Mrs. David D. Porter of Washington and this city, was introduced to society this afternoon at a tea which her parents gave at the Acorn Club.
PARIS, Oct. 15. -- Explanations of how Belgium's neutrality policy will affect her position in international affairs were requested tonight by France of the Belgian Government.

ALBANY, Oct. 15. -- Dr. Albert Einstein tonight branded as pseude-scientific the doctrine that Darwin's theory of the struggle for existence and the survival of the fittest justifies the teaching of the necessity of competition between individuals in a "destructive economic struggle."

CHICAGO, Oct. 15. -- A decline of 1/2 to 1 cent a pound in fresh pork loins restricted buying of hogs by local packers to some extent today and sales were generally 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight lower, although the market was somewhat irregular.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Oct. 15. -- Count Esterhazy, with whom Prince Ernst von Starhemberg is staying, makes surprising announcements concerning the Heimwehr leader's plans in the newspaper Pesti Naplo.

More than 300 persons saw W.W. Howes, Acting Postmaster General, lay the cornerstone of the Madison Square Station of the New York Post Office, 149-53 East Twenty-third Street, near Lexington Avenue, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- All costs of elections, including campaign expenditures, should be met by Federal, State and local governments in order to give all citizens an equal opportunity to run for office, Senator Lonergan, chairman of the Senate committee investigating campaign funds, asserted today.

The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices declined to 127.4 on Tuesday from 127.5 the Tuesday previous. For five weeks the trend has been slightly downward, losing 1.3 points since it stood at 128.7 on Sept. 8.

One of President Roosevelt's outstanding accomplishments is the Republican national platform of 1936, Lithgow Osborne, State Conservation Commissioner, told a dinner of the New York Young Democratic Club last night.

Today's new pictures at Broadway houses include "The Devil Is a Sissy," with Freddie Bartholomew, Jackie Cooper and Mickey Rooney, at the Capitol; "The Longest Night," with Robert Young and Florence Rice, at the Rialto, and "15 Maiden Lane," with Claire Trevor and Cesar Romero, at the Palace.
AVILA, Spain, Oct. 15. -- Insurgent armies tonight stand within sight of Escorial and Navalcarnero, which their leaders regard as the last remaining obstacles on their road to Madrid.

The Bell System came within 9 cents of earning the full annual dividend requirements of $9 a share on 18,678,488 shares of A.T. T. capital stock in the twelve months ended on Aug. 31. For the three months ended on Aug. 31 the earnings were 5 cents more than the quarterly dividend, comparing with $6.38 and $1.56 a share earned, respectively, in the previous corresponding twelve and three month periods.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 15 (AP). -- Two Yale University scientists announced today the results of experiments tending to show how much of the healthful mineral substances contained in spinach can be absorbed into the human body.

COLUMBUS, Oct. 15. -- To carry Ohio the Republicans will have to reverse the trend which in neighboring States of far more consistent Republican record -- Michigan and Pennsylvania, for example -- has made them so hotly disputed that candid private claims made in both rarely run above 50,000 for the President or his chief rival.

ALBANY, Oct. 15. -- The special meeting of stockholders of the New York Central Railroad was adjourned today for two weeks because there was an insufficient number of proxies on hand to constitute a quorum. Responsibility for this was laid by inference to the Securities and Exchange Commission by Willard F. Place, vice president, who presided at the meeting.

DANVILLE, Ill., Oct. 15. -- Governor Landon replied tonight to President Roosevelt's Chicago speech by challenging the President to repudiate those in his administration who advocate the doctrine of scarcity and regimentation of all phases of American life by an all-powerful administration at Washington.

SUMMIT, N.J., Oct. 15. -- Walter E. Gude, 59 years old, for many years an executive of O.J. Gude Co., outdoor advertising concern, was found dead of carbon monoxide poisoning in the garage of his home at 130 Beechwood Road here at 6:30 o'clock tonight.

Smeary with the red spatter of aged tomatoes, tattered remnants of Landon and Knox placards dripping from its gashed sides, and minus its proudly fluttering flags, the sound truck of the Young Women's Organization of the Women's National Republican Club came back last night to its base of operations, the clubhouse at 3 West Fifty-first Street. Its first day at the political wars was over, its crew stimulated rather than dismayed.

The first meeting of the Manhattan section of the men's and women's divisions of the $250,000 fundraising campaign of the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service was held yesterday at the organization's headquarters, 99 Park Avenue. Mrs. Charles S. Brown, vice chairman of the campaign, presided.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 15 (AP). -- Ridden by Apprentice Jockey Hubert Le Blanc, who scored a triple, Suncrax survived a grueling front-running effort to emerge the winner in a blanket finish at Laurel today. The camera showed that she had won her third race of the year in seventeen starts by a head from the Brandon Stable's Tonianna, with Veiled Lady third, a like margin away.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 15. -- The days from 1836 to 1936 were reflected in styles of Century Fashion Show presented tonight in the Greenbrier Auditorium by A. Gordon Foster.

TRENTON, Oct. 15. -- A lot depends on the way you say it. If you are a teacher and are angry when you call your pupils nitwits, nincompoops and dizzy-headed James, that's one thing, but if you do it in a "rather friendly way as a kindly reprimand for lack of attention or carelessness," that's something else.
GIBRALTAR, Oct. 15. -- General Gonzalo Queipo de Llano, Spanish Rebel commander at Seville, broadcast today a report that twenty airplanes had bombed Madrid, damaging the militia barracks.

MANILA, Oct. 15. -- Arriving here on schedule on my trip around the world, I found that another globetrotter, H.R. Ekins, New York World-Telegram reporter, had left on the Hawaii Clipper as a member of the crew. He is now speeding toward Midway Island.

SALEM, N.H., Oct. 15 (AP). -- The Oak Trees Stable's Keokee led from flag fall to finish to capture the six-furlong fourth race by a head in the best offering on the card at Rockingham Park today. He paid $4.70 for a $2 mutuel ticket.
HENDAYE, France, Oct. 15. -- The Spanish Rebel forces moving ...
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 15. -- Miss Caroline Grosvenor was introduced to society here today. She will be honored at a dance in Boston in December.

Manhattan's football squad of thirty players will entrain this morning for Worcester, Mass., where tomorrow it will face the powerful eleven of Holy Cross, which it battled to a 13-13 tie last year. The men selected for the trip were named yesterday by Coach Chick Meehan at the conclusion of the Green's last home workout at Innisfield Park.

George L. Harrison, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, who is chairman of the special gifts committee in the roll-call of New York Chapter, American Red Cross, appealed yesterday for contributions for the chapter's $325,000 budget for 1937.

The excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $120,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $2,070,000,000, the highest figure reached since the 50 per cent increase in reserve requirements on Aug. 15, according to the weekly Federal Reserve report issued yesterday.

This Penn-Princeton gridiron debate is keeping the sideline quarterbacks in a long huddle. They can't make up their minds. Penn has some husky veteran ball-carriers, including one Kurlish, who is no harder to stop than a five-ton truck on a down-grade.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- National securities Exchanges will be required to submit annual financial statements for themselves and their subsidiaries and affiliates at the conclusion of each fiscal year as the result of a ruling made today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Leaders in the banking field and other financial groups advised delegates to the annual convention of the United States Building and Loan League yesterday to rely upon direction and supervision of their business rather than upon legislation in conferences held during the day at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

S.S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, charged yesterday that "agitators" have grossly misrepresented nursing conditions in Harlem Hospital. He was referring to statements made Wednesday at a budget hearing before the Board of Estimate that a shortage of nurses in the institution had caused the deaths of a number of infants.

A continued demand for large units and penthouses was indicated in yesterday's list of apartment rentals. A ten-room furnished apartment at 983 Park Avenue was leased to Mrs. Mary R. Gunther of Baltimore, for Miss Edith Mason, through Warren L. Marks-Daniel Brener, Inc.

Joseph A. Solovei, former attorney for the murderers of Samuel Drukman and named in the trial as a conspirator in the case, explained yesterday his refusal to sign a waiver of immunity before the special grand jury by charging that the Drukman inquiry was "political'' and that Special Prosecutor Hiram C. Todd was "gunning for me."

Three new playgrounds will be opened without ceremony by the Park Department at 3 P.M. today as part of the general playground program of the department. The addition of the three will make 180 playgrounds established since January, 1934.

LONDON, Oct. 15. -- For the time being, the British press has imposed an unofficial censorship upon itself regarding the divorce action that Mrs. Ernest Aldrich Simpson, close personal friend of King Edward, is bringing against her husband, manager in London of the New York shipping house of Simpson, Spencer Young.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Oct. 15. -- A new organ with eighty-six stops and three manuals, installed in the Memorial Chapel at Wellesley College during the Summer, will be dedicated Sunday afternoon with a recital of selections by Carl Weinrich, head of the organ department of the Westminster Choir School of Princeton and instructor in organ at Wellesley.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 15 (AP). -- Silence in the movie colony today followed the action of the Actors Equity in suspending twenty-four film players for failure to join the Screen Actors Guild.

FROM where I sit chained to my typewriter I can see a large electric theatre sign reading "Helen Hayes in Victoria Regina." The sign was set up last Winter, I believe, and one day not so long ago a man was climbing in and out of it to clean off the city grime, so that the legend could face its second season glittering.

Moderate strength in United States Government and other high-grade investments was the feature of an otherwise irregular bond trading session yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The market for Treasury loans exhibited renewed support as gains ranging. from 1-32 to 5-32 point ruled throughout the list at the close.

To aid in the final work on the Federal writers' "New York City Guide," and for inclusion therein, there has been prepared a very complete chronology of important events in city history. Data contained in this list have been contributed by five groups of workers on the writing end of this WPA venture.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 15. -- The United States Steel Corporation will begin work here immediately on a $29,000,000 improvement program, including a tin plate mill and auxiliary plants for the Tennessee Coal, Iron and Railroad Company.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15. -- Temple University, aiming for its fifth straight victory of the season, meets Carnegie Tech at the Owls' stadium tomorrow night. This is the last night appearance of the year for the Cherry and White squad.

LONDON, Oct. 15. -- It was announced today that United States interests had broken off negotiations with John Maxwell, chairman of the Associated British Picture Corporation, who is seeking control of Gaumont British Picture Corporation. Sidney Kent, president of Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, issued the following statement: ...
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP). -- The government reported progress today in its efforts to provide better housing for quail.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- Wholesale prices weakened slightly in the week ended on Oct. 10, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The decline, attributed largely to a falling-off in the prices of farm products and foods, made the bureau's index (based on the 1926 weekly average as 100) 81.2, compared with 81.3 the preceding week and 80.7 a year ago.

Joseph A. Solovei, former attorney for the murderers of Samuel Drukman and named in the trial as a conspirator in the case, explained yesterday his refusal to sign a waiver of immunity before the special grand jury by charging that the Drukman inquiry was "political'' and that Special Prosecutor Hiram C. Todd was "gunning for me."

Three new playgrounds will be opened without ceremony by the Park Department at 3 P.M. today as part of the general playground program of the department. The addition of the three will make 180 playgrounds established since January, 1934.

Joey Wach, East Side featherweight, defeated Al Reid of the Bronx in a savage eight-round bout that featured the boxing program at the Mecca Sports Arena last night. A crowd of 2,500 persons saw the doughty rivals fly at each other to wage a battle that was packed through with thrills.

H.A. Batten has been elected president of N.W. Ayer Son, Inc., nationally known Philadelphia advertising agency, succeeding the late Wilfred W. Fry, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Batten was vice president, director and chairman of the management committee of the board of directors designated by Mr. Fry to administer the business during his last illness.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP). -- Despite silence at the Treasury on proposals by Jesse H. Jones for revision of the corporate undistributed profits tax, Congressional experts were busy today studying possible changes in the much-debated law.

Bainbridge Colby, Secretary of State under Woodrow Wilson, in a nation-wide broadcast last night from Station WJZ addressed to all Democrats, accused President Roosevelt of betraying his own party and declared that the Farmer-Labor party which has become the mainstay of his support in Minnesota, through its communistic affiliation, is committed to Negro control in the South.

An endorsement of Governor Landon and Justice Bleakley by the German-American Alliance, voiced yesterday by Fritz Kuhn as leader of the hyphenated group, has caused a stir at the German Embassy in Washington, according to a dispatch from the capital.

Governor Lehman had reached no decision last night on the plea of the local Board of Elections for a special legislative session to amend the election law to allow the polls to stay open three hours longer on election day so that the registered voters of New York City might have an opportunity to use voting machines.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Friday, Oct. 16 (AP). -- Miss Jean Batten, daring New Zealand aviatrix, conquered the perilous Tasman Sea today to complete a 1,100 mile hop from Australia and end a record-breaking solo flight from England to New Zealand.

Several changes in the standing of the first ten automobile drivers to finish in the 300-mile George Vanderbilt Cup race at Roosevelt Raceway Columbus Day, but not affecting the first four, were announced yesterday. These were made after a complete check-up by the scorers had corrected some errors made at the time the race ended.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 15 (AP). -- Colonel Frank Knox demanded tonight that President Roosevelt deny or confirm that he plans to raise wages and shorten hours by a Federal law, if re-elected.

A model of the new telescope for Mount Palomar, Calif., which will be twice the size of the largest in the world, now operating on Mount Wilson, was exhibited here last night for the first time at the Museum of Natural History.

Control of the union activities of the employes of tugboats and lighters operating in the Port of New York again became an issue yesterday when the Harbor Tug Boatmen's Union, an affiliate of the International Longshoremen's Association, announced that it would meet Sunday to consider demands for a new wage contract.
If one retains one's sense of humor there is indeed much to amuse in the daily output or outpouring of campaign propaganda.

Simultaneously with the price of copper abroad reaching the level of 10 cents a pound for the first time since April, 1931, the members of the international copper curtailment agreement announced yesterday an increase in mine output from 80 to 85 per cent of capacity, effective immediately.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and the reserve note circulation to be at the highest of the year to date. No other important item in the system reached a new high or low point for the year.

I agree with many, in fact with most, of the main points in Dr. Durant's analysis of the issues of the present campaign, published in your issue of Oct. 10. There are a few, however, in which I find it somewhat difficult to follow him.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15. -- The ovation given to President Roosevelt by the crowds that lined the route of the parade here last night and the reception at the Stadium encouraged Democratic leaders today to predict that Illinois would be Democratic in November.

BERLIN, Oct. 15. -- Prices on the Boerse were variable today in a very limited turnover. The trading has not returned to the state of almost complete stagnation and insignificance that for a time was typical of the Berlin market, but operations seem to be under the domination of conflicting rumors that have discouraged trading and created a general atmosphere of uncertainty.

On a population basis there is relatively less leprosy in the world today than there was ten years ago, Dr. Victor G. Heiser, president of the International Leprosy Association, and an authority on the treatment of the malady, said yesterday.

Declaring that government expenditures have been "a small price for the significant recovery that has taken place," Secretary of Commerce Daniel C. Roper, yesterday predicted that the lines of falling Federal expenses and rising revenue would "in the near future cross in a balanced national budget."

More than 250 prominent citizens of the United States and Canada urged the public of both countries, in a statement yesterday, to support the voluntary or philanthropic hospitals in their communities.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 15. -- General Otto H. Falk gave a luncheon in the Empire Room of the Homestead today. His guests included Mrs. W.S. Way, Mr. and Mrs. Chester C. Smith, Mr. and Mrs. G.T. Shoemaker, Mr. and Mrs. A.G. Kieckhefer, Mrs. A.D. Bailey, Mrs. A.E. Bettis, Mrs. G. W. Vanderzee, Mrs. A.C. Flory and Mrs. Harold Koch.
PARIS, Oct. 15. -- French Foreign Office circles tonight saw "another moral blow" to the peace structure of Europe in King Leopold's speech !against military aid to noher i power.

With the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association having expressed its approval of the program for promoting newspapers as advertising media to the "United Front" committee, details of organization and financing must now be worked out for presentation to the board of directors of the publishers' association, it was said here yesterday.

The city of Portland, Me., will consider sealed bids on Oct. 26 for a new issue of $500,000 of water district bonds, to be dated Nov. 2, 1936, and maturing on Nov. 1, 1956. The bonds will carry a fixed rate of 2 1/4 per cent.

MUNICH, Oct. 15. -- Nazi police agents today raided the home of Archbishop Alberto Vassalla-Torregrossa, former Papal Nuncio to Bavaria, supposedly in a search for evidence against Catholic youth organizations.

HAVANA, Oct. 15. -- A new Constitution establishing a semi-parliamentary form of government and greatly modifying the provisional Constitution now in force was approved by the House of Representatives tonight.

The widely held opinion that devaluation of the gold-bloc currencies would bring a strong efflux of foreign money from this market, carrying with it a substantial part of the government's huge gold reserves, now appears to be far wide of the mark.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 15. -- A long signal drill on plays and formations marked the final practice today on University Field for the Princeton football squad before it departed for the Penn game.

One of the outstanding leases of commercial space reported yesterday involved eight floors, comprising about 60,000 square feet in 151-55 West Thirtieth Street, taken by Lampson, Fraser Huth, furriers, for a long term at a reported aggregate rental of about $180,000.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 16 (AP). -- The Tennessee Valley Authority lost today its first skirmish with private utility interests seeking to halt its power program on constitutional grounds.

A second major step in the refunding program of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company will be taken late next month, it was learned yesterday. It will follow the distribution this week of $150,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent debentures.

The Republican National Committee's accusation that WPA payroll checks were being distributed with New Deal propaganda affixed by the City Projects Council was branded yesterday as "absolutely false and without foundation" by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local WPA Administrator.
PARIS, Oct. 16. -- Diplomatic exchanges that took place today in London, Brussels and Paris cleared up to some extent the definition of Belgium's announced return to her pre-war neutrality.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 16. -Pauline Frederick, star of such silent pictures as "Madame X," "When Knights Were Bold" and "Zaza," will have the ro1e of the mother in RKO's production of "Michael Strogoff." The assignment of so substantial a part to a former star is a departure from the usual Hollywood policy of using the once-greats as bit players and then attempting to capitalize on their past successes in publicizing the picture.

The case of the missing ballots of the Twenty-first Election District of the Second Manhattan Assembly District lapsed back into the mystery stage yesterday less than twenty-four hours after the original mystery was supposedly solved.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 16. -- The mysterious poisoning of two relatives of Mrs. Lawrence W. Churchill, 64-year-old widow, following the sudden death of her husband, a New York lawyer, in Florida last January, resulted today in charges of assault with intent to kill being lodged against her 36-year-old Korean butler and chauffeur, Chang Soo Lee.

In the case of substitutes used in the Army-Columbia football game the number of names is about the same for both sides, but Army made many more substitutions than the Lions. Most of the Columbia substitutes went in during the last minutes of play to replace exhausted men.

The political campaign waxes hot. Many sarcastic, biting and harsh speeches are made. The pressure is on, and the ballyhoo is speeded up. Yet, out of all the irrelevant matter there emerges only one real issue:

Every voter in the city will be able to record his choices by means of voting machines on Nov. 3, provided the Legislature extends the voting day by three hours, Board of Elections officials said yesterday.

Two hundred and forty years of church history will be celebrated tonight and tomorrow when the Fordham Manor Reformed Church, Kingsbridge Road and University Avenue, the Bronx, will mark the anniversary of its founding in 1696 by William III, Prince of Orange.
James Oliver Brown, in his article in The Forum covering the educational facilities of the United States Naval Academy, comments rather bitterly on the lack of a cultural education.

Fordham's freshman football team had its first opportunity to depart from the role of varsity buffer yesterday and made the most of it. The Maroon cubs struck through the air in the final minute of the game, pushed one touchdown over the line and emerged triumphant over St. John's Prep of Danvers, Mass., 7 to 0, at Fordham Field.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 16. -- The Navy's final preparations for its clash with Yale, set for tomorrow in the Baltimore Stadium, consisted of a short formation drill at Annapolis today under Head Coach Tom Hamilton and his aides. Like most of the practices of the week, it was behind closed gates.

A number of football games of great importance to the teams concerned will form today's chapter of the season of 1936. In every part of the country there are major contests, the results of which will more or less measure the success of the remainder of the campaign for the colleges involved.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16. -- Asserting that the country was drifting in "an inflation current," Professor Edwin W. Kemmerer of Princeton University warned here today that nothing but an aboutface and "a powerful pulling on the oars of rigid economy acn take us out of the current and save us from the inflation rapids."

What was it that Admiral FARRAGUT thought as he rode from Madison Square to the storage yard in Central Park? He will rest there while Madison Square is being reconstructed, swept and garnished after the model of Bryant Park.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 16. -- In summarizing the ground for his decision overruling the motion made by the Tennessee Valley Authority, Judge Gore said today:

Only a small percentage of the $100,000,000 of General Motors Acceptance Corporation debentures offered to the public on Aug. 20 remained in the hands of underwriters on Aug. 31, it was disclosed yesterday in the company's registration statement filed with the New York Stock Exchange.

A 67-year-old woman, passing along the sidewalk on her way to buy food, was knocked down and fatally injured about 8 o'clock yesterday morning when a horse, terrified after the breaking of part of its harness, ran wildly through several streets in the vicinity of the Bronx County Building.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor will not suspend the International Typographical Union and the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers International Union, ruling these organizations have not affiliated themselves with the committee for Industrial Organization, it was announced this evening by President William Green of the A.F.of L.
BERLIN, Oct. 16. -- The Boerse showed some strength again today in limited activity. The opening was mixed, however, and uncertainty prevailed to some extent throughout the session.

After hearing Police Commissioner Valentine and Thomas P. Cummings, secretary of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, the local laws committee of the Board of Aldermen decided yesterday to report favorably on two local bills increasing the salaries and pensions of veteran police captains.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 16. -- The prepared texts of the speeches of President Roosevelt here and in Cincinnati today were as follows:

The coming national election will be the theme of some of the sermons preached in the city's pulpits tomorrow. It will be annual "Missionary Sunday" in both Roman Catholic and Protestant communions. In the former support will be asked for the work of the Society for the Propagation of the Faith in non-Christian lands.
May I encroach on your space to beg publicly that the Roosevelt Raceway be left as it is for future races?
PARIS, Oct. 16. -- One of the most important administrative reforms of the Blum Popular Front government got under way today when the Cour des Comptes (Court of Accountancy) met for the Fall term.

One of the specters which the Republican party views with more alarm is the increase of farm imports. Towering figures are cited to show that the American farmer is being robbed of his domestic market and, as Mr. LANDON put it, being "sold down the river." The comparison ordinarily invoked for this purpose is between 1936, under Mr. ROOSEVELT and the Hull tariff treaties, and 1932, the last year of Republican control.

WITH GOVERNMENT FORCES, BRUNETE, Spain, Oct. 16 (AP). -- Retreating government forces, falling back on this bleak village, only nineteen and one-half miles west of Madrid, tonight halted a Rebel attack.
ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 16. -- Coach Carl Snavely kept his Cornell squad at work until after dark tonight, seeking to strengthen the varsity's defenses against the Syracuse offensive.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- Names, addresses and salaries of WPA workers will not be given out "for commercial or political purposes," Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, said today in denying the request for payroll figures made on behalf of the New Jersey Republican campaign committee by Walter E. Edge, chairman.
