AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Oct. 16. -- Ten hours and thirty minutes after leaving the Richmond Airdrome at Sydney, I landed at Auckland, New Zealand, arriving at 5:05 P.M. today. This was the end of a flight which began at Hatfield, England, ten days and twenty-one hours previously.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 16. -- A three-point welfare relief program for New York State was urged today by Hugh R. Jackson, assistant general secretary of the State Charities Aid Association, in an address before the convention of the New York League of Women Voters here.

The last so-called minor game of the season will be played by Columbia today when it faces Virginia Military Institute's eleven at Baker Field at 2 o'clock. After this contest the Lions meet five major rivals, starting next week with Michigan.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16. -- Senator Borah, who has declined to speak for any candidate, assured Dr. Townsend today that he favored bringing the Townsend plan before Congress and that he was a strong adherent of the principles underlying the old-age pension proposal.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- Six million postal cards bearing quotations from the speeches of Governor Landon calculated to embarrass him in his Presidential campaign are to be sent out in the near future under Democratic frank, it was learned today.

The annual campaign for the United Hospital Fund will be on in November, as announced a few days ago, and there is reason, personal and social, why every citizen should take an interest in this private undertaking for the public good. But before that comes, there is a smaller fund that should be provided.

Last night in Detroit Governor Landon called upon the President to disclose what constitutional amendments he had in mind. From my own personal observation of the President's conduct and from his speeches, I think he is more interested in the carrying out of injunctions contained in two other historical documents than he is in worrying about amendments to the Constitution.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 16. -- Washington College won by 8 to 7 in its football game with Johns Hopkins tonight played in the rain.

OTTAWA, Oct. 16 (Canadian Press). -- An immediate start on the cooperative plan of the Dominion Government and chartered banks to assist a $50,000,000 housing repair and modernization program was announced today.

A resumption of the advance in almost all classes of the more speculative loans was a feature in trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. On a heavier turnover, prices of the secondary and most of the convertible corporate issues were carried up fractionally to about 3 points.

ELMIRA, N. Y., Oct. 16. -- Governor Lehman announced tonight that he was issuing a call for an extraordinary session of the Legislature to convene next Tuesday to enact measures to extend the hours of voting in the State due to the heavy registration and to insure submission to New York City voters of the referendum on establishment of the eight-hour work day for firemen.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 16. -- The white and green silks of E.R. Bradley were borne to their second victory of the Fall season in Maryland today when Bootmaker scored a smashing and surprising victory in the Annapolis Purse, feature at Laurel.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- A survey showed today that the Communist Presidential ticket will be represented on the ballots in at least thirty-one States on election day, Nov. 3.

Net profit of $9,641,996 was reported yesterday by the Owens-Illinois Glass Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30. This, it was announced, was the largest amount earned in a year in the history of the company.

LONDON, Oct. 16. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange remained cheerful today. British funds were steady but quiet because of the new municipal borrowing. Foreign bonds also were quiet. Home and foreign railway shares were firm, Argentines strengthening further.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16. -- The sixtieth anniversary of intercollegiate football at the University of Pennsylvania will be celebrated tomorrow when the Red and Blue meets Princeton in this city for the first time since 1893.

Using the slogan "Guard the Nation's Profits," the National Association of Credit Men is launching a nation-wide campaign for constructive credit development, it was announced here yesterday. The drive is expected to cut down the estimated credit loss of $1,000,000,000 annually.

A duplex apartment comprising twelve rooms and four baths in the cooperative building at 39 East Seventy-ninth Street was leased to Mrs. Frederica Frelinghuysen Carleton by Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., who also report rentals at 14 Sutton Place South to Bruce Brodie, at 103 East Eighty-sixth Street to Stephen W. Bobo, at 346 East Fifty-second Street to John H. Hilliard and at 114 East Fortieth Street to John R. Johnson.

United States Senator James F. Byrnes of South Carolina charged last night that in 1932 President Hoover was so alarmed over the possibility of violence in this country that he took steps to guard against disgruntlement in the enlisted personnel of the army, navy and Marine Corps.

The new chancel in the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, at the entrance to Rockefeller Center, will be used tomorrow for the first time in its completed form, and it will be dedicated at a special service Nov. 1, All Saints Day.

TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 16. -- Making a sudden decision, as in the case of his trip to Maine, Governor Landon announced today that he was going to the Pacific Coast and would speak in Los Angeles Tuesday evening, Oct. 20. He will leave Topeka Sunday night on his special train.

A record-breaking Christmas shopping season to start immediately after the national election was forecast yesterday by Carl Whiteman, vice president of General Foods Corporation, in an address before the closing session of the two-day National Sales Executives Conference, arranged by the International Association of Sales Executives at the Hotel Biltmore.

Test boring to determine the exact nature of the East River bottom, through which the new Queens Midtown Vehicular Tunnel will pass, will be started next week under a contract just awarded by the New York Tunnel Authority.
PARIS, Oct. 16. -- Paris was wiped off the face of the earth tonight for fifty minutes in the first citywide test of passive air defense since the World War ended.

PARIS, Oct. 16. -- Air Minister Pierre Cot announced tonight that all factories manufacturing airplanes and aviation motors under government contracts would be nationalized by the Air Ministry. This includes nearly all large aviation companies in France.

ELMIRA, Oct. 16. -- Invading the southern tier of counties, Governor Lehman tonight met the attacks on his fiscal policy by William F. Bleakley, his Republican opponent, with a warning against "loose promises" of tax reduction. He then went on to point to his own handling of State finances as "sane and sound."

Letters appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES regarding the removal of publications from New York to other cities on account of the labor costs involved in the printing thereof, in which reference was made to the rate of postage applicable to copies addressed for delivery at this office that has resulted in having many readers believe that a more favorable rate is obtainable for publications at Chicago than at New York.

The threat of strike on towboats and lighters operating in the harbor, which was made on Thursday by the Harbor Tugboatmen's Union, is not taken seriously by the lighterage interests or by the Associated Marine Workers, according to Captain William Maher, head of the latter body.

In a deposition filed in Federal court yesterday in connection with a stockholders' suit, Henry L. Doherty, president of the Cities Service Company, expressed the opinion that no candidate had a chance of winning the Presidency from Franklin D. Roosevelt.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Oct. 16. -- Down an aisle of cheering students that wound a quarter-mile across the campus, Miss Mildred H. McAfee walked this afternoon from her offices to the platform of Alumnae Hall to be inducted as the seventh president of Wellesley College in an unpretentious ceremony.

Employment during last year lagged behind the gains in production largely because producers formerly operating plants on a part-time basis increased their work weeks to normal length, the National Industrial Conference Board said yesterday in announcing that industrial production during the first eight months of this year averaged 15 per cent below the 1929 level, while employment stood at 19 per cent below that year's figures.

Staten Island's second annual Exposition of Progress opened last night in the George Cromwell Recreation Center, on Pier 6, Tompkinsville, with eighty-five exhibits of local commercial, industrial and civic organizations.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 16 (AP). -- The State Municipal Finance Commission today accepted an order of the supreme court directing Asbury Park to distribute $310,000 to its creditors. It recommended, however, that the city disburse $700,000 additional to security holders to pay all interest owing up to a definite date.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today a series of moves in cases of alleged violation of the Securities Act of 1933, as a result of which two persons in California and one in Georgia had been taken into custody, and a preliminary injunction had been obtained against a company and its secretary in Denver.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 16 (AP). -- Martin H. Carmody, Supreme Knight of the Knights of Columbus, asserted tonight that the attitude of R.E. O'Malley, Missouri State Superintendent of Insurance, in suspending the order's license to do business in that State, reflected "political considerations and partisan politics."

After years and years of turnip munching on behalf of "Tobacco Road," Sam Byrd this evening launches a personal career as an actor-manager. The National Theatre is the place, and the play would be Samson Raphaelson's "White Man," the story of a Negro who passes himself off as white.

CARLISLE, England, Oct. 16 (AP). -- A decree nisi from his actress wife, Gladys Cooper, was granted today to Sir Neville Pearson, British publisher, who named the actor Philip Merivale as corespondent.

Holders of $1,000,000 of defaulted Florida East Coast Railway Series D 5 per cent equipment trust certificates are to meet in the Bankers Trust Company here next Friday to discuss the distribution of between $350,000 and $450,000 realized from the sale of the rolling stock that had secured the certificates.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- A substantial increase in lumber exports from this country was reported today by the Department of Commerce for the first eight months of this year, compared with the same period in 1935. Total shipments of hardwood and softwood sawed timber, boards, planks and scantlings amounted to 901,883,000 board feet, compared with 837,877,000 a year before.

Delegates to the annual convention of the United States Building and Loan League unanimously opposed further intervention by government bureaus dealing with housing and mortgage loans in resolutions adopted yesterday at the closing session held in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
City College will open football relations with a new rival at the Lewisohn Staudium today, when it clashes with the Susquehanna University eleven. The kick-off is set for 2:30.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 16. -The Princeton varsity and freshman harriers opened their seasons today with victories over the Rutgers cross-country squads. The varsity tallied a 20-35 triumph over the four-mile distance, with the cubs winning by 22 -- 33 on a two-and-a-half-mile course.

The international Rugby game between the New York Rugby Club and Canada last Sunday received scant attention. A small crowd, sympathetic but, on the whole, ignorant of the rules, looked on. The referee's decisions were not fully understood but were not questioned; the finer points of the game excited smiles; a good tackle aroused a murmur of sympathy for the physical discomfort of the tackled.
The President constantly compares his best year with his predecessor's worst? Is this fair? Why not the average of four years?

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it had filed in the Supreme Court in Albany a petition asking that the Bronx Gas and Electric Company be compelled to make effective the reduced electric rate schedule ordered by the commission and to refund to customers excess amounts collected since the order.

MOSCOW, Oct. 16. -- Although Joseph Stalin's declaration last night to Spanish Communists that the Soviet was justified in rendering all possible assistance "to the revolutionary masses of Spain" completely joins the issue of fascism versus the working class on a world-wide basis, it does not mean that the Soviet Union will give the Madrid government armed aid either in munitions or in military personnel.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16. -- For the first time in twenty-seven contests, going back to 1930, Temple University's football Owls met defeat in a night game in Temple Stadium tonight.

Four former officers of Trimmers Local 2440 of the International Knitgoods Workers Union surrendered yesterday in Special Sessions on two "informations" charging coercion and conspiracy in recent alleged Communist attacks on two textile shops in the Madison Square district.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

ON BOARD THE CHINA CLIPPER, Saturday, Oct. 17. -- With the constellations of the Great Dipper and Southern Cross both visible this morning, the flying boat China Clipper taxied out on Apra Harbor at Sumay, Guam, for another start for Manila.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals only $8,307,337, representing one State and forty-five municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $17,299,300 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now is $27,784,242.

Seen and heard at the annual dinner of the Beach Haven Tuna Club, Thursday night, at the New Yorker: Fisherman Lou Gehrig, puffing a pipe and swapping yarns of Florida sailfishing with his table companion on the dais, Francis Low, the club president.

LONDON, Oct. 16. -- Postmaster General G.C. Tryon presented the millionth telephone to be installed in the London area -- a gold-colored instrument with an inscribed plaque replacing the dial -- to Lord Mayor Sir Percy Vincent for the Mansion House today.

The Brooklyn Prep eleven conquered Fordham Prep, 20-0, before a crowd of 2,000 at Boys High Field yesterday, Tommy Miles accounting for the three touchdowns. The victory was the Blue and White team's second in three starts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- Application by the Crane Company of Chicago for authority for withdrawal from registration and listing on the Chicago Stock Exchange of its common and preferred stocks brought today before the Securities and Exchange Commission in an important case -- the question just how far the commission's powers to intervene in such a matter extend under the provisions of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

Colgate and Tulane, both proponents of wide-open, pulse-quickening football, will meet at the Polo Grounds today in their annual classic, which may be young in years but is old and rich in exciting moments. It will be the fourth clash between these two intersectional rivals, with the Green Wave from the South ahead in games won, 2 to 1, but behind in total point, 26 to 25.

J.J. Byrne, vice president of traffic of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, defended the arrangements between that company and the Acme Fast Freight, Inc., a freight consolidating and forwarding agency, at hearings yesterday before examiners for the Interstate Commerce Commission in the Pennsylvania Hotel.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16. -- Following is the text of former President Hoover's address here tonight:

Mr. Krock's dispatch from St. Paul says: "Only in 1932, in recent times, has Minnesota given its electoral vote to a Democrat." The dispatch would have been accurate if it had said that 1932 was the only election in which the State gave its electoral vote to the Democratic nominee.

LONDON, Oct. 16. -- Addressing his constituency in Epping Forest tonight, Winston Churchill said that it was to be hoped in Britain that King Leopold's speech on neutrality was merely an expression of the anxieties of the Belgian people and not a decision of policy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- The Senate committee investigating Presidential and Senatorial campaign expenses made public today a list of contributions to anti-New Deal organizations by Ernest T. Weir of Pittsburgh totaling $35,500 and another list of contributions and loans from J. Howard Pew of Philadelphia, president of the Sun Oil Company, totaling $61,050.

The list of the Cunard White Star motorship Britannia, sailing today for Ireland, France and England, includes Justice and Mrs. P.H. Rogers of Boston, the Rev. Finbar O'Callaghan, the Rev. James E. O'Mahony, the Rev. William P. Harty, C.J. Sabiston, Dr. Henri Welti, Mr. and Mrs. Peter Pirnie Jr., Dr. Thomas Cochrane and Miss E.G. St. George.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16. -- Herbert Hoover asserted here tonight that "if any income taxpayer or corporation kept books like this administration, that is, if they showed similar morals in juggling their accounts, they would be put in jail."
' Collective Policy' Declared Vital in Any Parleys to End Rift With Federation.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 16. -William F. Bleakley, the Republican candidate for Governor, continued his attack upon Governor Herbert H. Lehman and the New Deal today, asking if the Governor could say that he had never "had any connection, interest or alliance with any milk company," and charging the AAA with waste and extravagance.

Yesterday dawned bright and clear, and to 2,500 young and old Bellevue Hospital patients it meant that the eleventh annual world's championship rodeo would be held on the grounds of the institution. Dressing hurriedly, most of the shut-ins assembled on the riverfront campus, while hundreds of others craned their necks from balconies to watch for the arrival of the long-awaited riders, ropers and clowns.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 16. -- Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, owner of a large string of race horses, announced today he had purchased an interest in the Maryland Jockey Club, operator of Pimlico, the State's oldest race track.

The Presbyterian Hospital receives a bequest of $20,000 and the Charity Organization of the City of New York the residuary estate of Mrs. S. Augusta Mora, late of 101 West Eighty-fifth Street. This became known yesterday when her will was filed in Surrogates' Court.

MADRID, Oct. 16. -- A decree in today's Official Gazette appoints Premier Francisco Largo Caballero "supreme chief of the military forces of Spain." At the same time Julio Alvarez del Vayo was appointed "General Commissioner for War" with four assistants representing the Communists, the Syndicalists and the Socialist unions.

VIENNA, Oct. 16. -- Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg's dramatic Cabinet coup last Saturday was a necessary preliminary for the great Fatherland Front rally fixed for the coming week-end. The demonstration will begin tomorrow night with a rally of officials of the Fatherland Front in the Parliament Building and will be concluded Monday morning with the swearing in of the first Austrian conscripts on the great Schmelz military parade ground.

Absorption of relatively large Southern offerings by domestic and foreign trade interests imparted yesterday a steady undertone to prices on the Cotton Exchange. Demand for both textiles and spot cotton influenced mill price-fixing. The list closed with gains of 4 to 11 points over Thursday.

The United States and Foreign Securities Corporation reported yesterday that on Sept. 30 its net assets were worth $41,605,000, with securities valued at market prices, or at the nominal value of $1 where market quotations were not available.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 16. -Milton J. Budlong and his daughter, Miss Frances Budlong, gave a farewell party today in the Homestead Club for Mr. and Mrs. George A. Ranney and their daughters, Miss Cornelia Ranney and Mrs. Gaylord Donnelly. Mrs. James B. Weir and Mr. and Mrs. Kent S. Clow were also in the party.

DETROIT, Oct. 16. -- John H. O'Donnell of Pittsburgh, a member of the National Union for Social Justice and a liberal contributor to its trust fund, filed in Circuit Court today a bill asking the removal of the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin and other trustees from the union.

New York University's football team meets its second intersectional opponent of the season today when it engages the University of North Carolina eleven at the Yankee Stadium. A crowd of 20,000 persons is expected to be present for the opening kick-off at 2:30 P.M.

Traditional education, in spite of the precepts of a long line of educational reformers, has always relied too much upon printed words on paper. Formerly educators were satisfied when these words were learned by rote, even though MONTAIGNE warned centuries ago that "to know by heart is not to know."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 16. -- There will be more than 40,000 spectators in the stadium tomorrow to watch Harvard's efforts to break down the Army rush, which has brought four successive gridiron victories against Crimson elevens.

PARIS, Oct. 16. -- In the first step toward wiping out private profit in the manufacture of arms, Air Minister Pierre Cot announced tonight he would immediately nationalize all factories producing airplanes and accessories for national defense.
For the second time in his remarkable career, Lou Gehrig, burly first baseman of the Yankees, yesterday was named the American League's "most valuable player" by the Baseball Writers Association.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 16. -- A biennial budget of $4,000,000 for 1938-39 was adopted today for the United Lutheran Church by its convention here.

Alderman Morton Moses, who has been waging a one-man campaign against the transportation of large packages and bundles in the subways, wrote yesterday to William G. Fullen, chairman of the Transit Commission, describing a new nuisance he discovered yesterday.

WITH GENERAL JOSE VARELA'S REBEL ARMY, approaching Madrid, 8:30 P.M., Oct. 15 (delayed) -- This evening's most exciting incident was the capture of a government aviator who earlier had bailed out of his burning plane above General Varela's command post.

The successful efforts of Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler and City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr. in saving the $491,166 of Police Relief Funds invested in defaulted mortgage certificates were marked by a unique ceremony yesterday at the City Hall.
The following are among the books of a religious and inspirational character that have recently been published:

There must be some, there may be many, faithful souls who, clinging to old friendships, remember affectionately the day when Colonel KNOX signed the ship's articles and proudly took the title of Governor LANDON'S First Mate. From that day to this his admirers have followed his travels from State to State, an operation that required a good deal of pin-moving on the map.

As a means to reduce what is described as an unwarranted return of thousands of wash frocks yearly from retail stores to manufacturers, an educational campaign enlisting the aid of dress manufacturers, distributors, laundries, dry-cleaning establishments and producers of deodorants and depilatories was recommended yesterday by the vendors' relations committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

As was the case last season, a very impressive figure is being cut again this Fall in the field of nocturnal entertainment by those highly imperial Russian spots which go in heavy for the atmospheric touches -- lustrous decorations, subdued lights, flaming spits of shashlik, otchi tchornyia and lots of uniforms.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16. -- Prices of hogs generally showed little change here today, although some late sales of weights under 170 pounds appeared to be a shade lower. Demand showed improvement and the day's top was unchanged at $10.25 a hundredweight, while the day's average was steady at $9.65.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 16. -- Mr. and Mrs. R. Earl Fisher gave a luncheon today at the Greenbrier for Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Appleton, Mr. and Mrs. Matthew O. Troy, Mr. and Mrs. E.O. Shreve and Mr. and Mrs. R. Ginn.
VALLADOLID, Spain, Oct. 16. -- Three motorized columns of Insurgents spread out fanwise tonight only twenty miles west of Madrid.

After two days of declining prices, the stock market, in the second heaviest trading of the week, yesterday resumed its upward course. Leading stocks advanced 1 to 4 points, while most of the secondary issues participated in the upswing.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- Trade practice rules for the rubber tire industry, with a capital investment of $2,000,000,000 and an aggregate volume of business annually of $750,000,000, were promulgated today by the Federal Trade Commission under its trade practice conference procedure.

Announcement of the establishment of an annual award of $100 to a woman graduate of the American Institute of Banking was made last night at the Hotel Chatham, where forty-five women attended a dinner of the Middle Atlantic Division of the Association of Bank Women.

PARIS, Oct. 16. -- Prices on the Bourse were strong at the opening today, but profit-taking and unloading later sent quotations down to yesterday's levels or below. After the sensational gains of the last few days it was considered natural by market observers that speculators should take profits just before the week-end.

The Salmagundi Club opens today an exhibition of etchings, pencil drawings, black and white illustrations, lithographs, sketches in sanguine, wax crayon drawings and wood-block prints by members. It will be current until the end of the month.

The question of the hourly rate of wages versus the total income of labor came up again in the President's address on Thursday night at Detroit. He spoke of a machinist in the automobile industry who in the Spring of 1934 told him that he was making $1.25 an hour, or $10 a day.
Arrangements were made yesterday for the transfer of a membership in the New York Stock Exchange for $132,000, an advance of $2,000 over the price at which a seat last changed hands on Sept. 9.

Alfredo Salmaggi's third offering of Bizet's "Carmen" last night at the Hippodrome Theatre was minus the debut of Mickey Walker. Mr. Walker, once known as the toy bulldog in the ring when he held the welterweight title, was to have essayed the role of a matador, fighting "bulls of Spanish pedigree."

MUNICH, Germany, Oct. 16. -- In spite of assurances by numerous responsible Nazi personages that there is no intention of fighting the Christian churches, there is no sign of lessening tension between the party and the Catholic Church in Munich, which is both the Catholic stronghold of Germany and the national headquarters of the National Socialist party.

Mr. and Mrs. F. Shepard Cornell were among those who entertained at dinner last night at the opening of the Trianon Room of the Ambassador. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. Marshall M. MacLeod, Miss Judith Hamlin, Miss Mary Emma Pioda, Percy Melville and de Forest Smith.

Former State Senator John V. Sheridan, Bronx campaign manager for Frank J. Prial, who unsuccessfully sought the nomination for Aldermanic President, announced yesterday he had joined other Democrats who are now supporting the Republican candidate, Newbold Morris.

MANILA, Saturday, Oct. 17. -- The reception I have been receiving here ha been well worth traveling half way around the world for. All Manila is turning the city over to my fellow world-traveler, Dorothy Kilgallen, New York Journal reporter, and me.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 16. -- Defection of the Negro vote in a large proportion from its ancient party mooring in Indiana and the plain intention of workers in the cities and the Calumet steel region to vote Democratic by an even larger majority have persuaded competent observers and even the Republican workers here that the President will carry Indiana by 60,000 to 75,000 votes.

The Brooklyn garage strike was settled yesterday afternoon at a conference lasting more than five hours. The Brooklyn branch of the Garage Workers and Polishers Union, Local 272, and the Brooklyn Garage Council were satisfied with the terms and nearly 4,000 workers will return to work this afternoon and tomorrow morning.
That which happened to the Giants in the world series seemed almost worse than that which occurred in their flop-acts in the 1934 and 1935 pennant races.

MADRID, Oct. 16. -- President Manuel Azana pledged in an interview yesterday that the Spanish Republic would maintain political and religious liberty and would never be converted into a Communist dictatorship.

TRENTON, Oct. 16. -- After a public hearing today, at which labor interests and newspapers joined in sharp criticism of the State Social Security Commission's proposal for a New Jersey unemployment compensation act to operate independently of the Federal program, the commission decided tonight to draft a new bill for presentation to the 1937 Legislature.
Another season of squash tennis, which will last through the Winter months, opened last night with the first scheduled team matches in Class C of the Metropolitan League.

Having kidnapped a truck driver and held him a prisoner for three hours, thieves stole Persian lamb pelts valued at $20,000 shortly after they had arrived at the foot of West Twentieth Street on a United States Line steamer yesterday.

With former Governor Alfred E. Smith making the presentation, George Coyle, 19-year-old usher at Radio City Music Hall, received last evening a four-year scholarship in Manhattan College. The scholarship was bestowed at the Center Club, 120 Central Park South.

Three factories, a flying field and hangar and a seaplane assembly base at Farmingdale and Amityville, L.I., have been purchased by the Seversky Aircraft Corporation, giving the company facilities to expand its output, it was announced yesterday by Major Alexander P. de Seversky, president.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 16. -- A charge that Wall Street was using the money of corporation stockholders to finance propaganda against his re-election was made by President Roosevelt here tonight in a speech that closed his 5,000-mile campaign tour through the Middle West.

DETROIT, Oct. 16. -- Automobile manufacturers and business leaders of this city took exception today to the statement of President Roosevelt in his speech here that many relief dollars had "finally come to the city of Detroit in the purchase of automobiles."

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 16. -- A 63-yard march culminated by a pass from Tom Barnicle to Bill Lane brought the Princeton jayvee football team a 7-0 victory over the Lehigh junior varsity on University Field today.

Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, reviewing the operation of the Workmen's Compensation Law since the addition fifteen months ago of the so-called "medical abuse amendments," reported yesterday that 13,559 physicians had been authorized to practice under he law and that the moral effect of the statute was sufficient to cure many of the evils that caused its promulgation.

Hoping to strengthen the statutes governing nursing in this State so that there will be "greater safeguard for life and health," the New York State Nurses Association yesterday adopted an amended Nurse Practice Act at the closing session of its annual convention.

While retail trade here started off excellently on Columbus Day, the recurrence of warm weather on the later days of the week slowed turn-over appreciably. This was particularly the case so far as apparel was concerned. Home furnishings held up well and an active consumer demand for domestic floor coverings was reported.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16. -- Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, declared here today that President Roosevelt was following the philosophy of the Roman Emperors who gave the people bread and circases and predicted that this would lead to the collapse of the American system just as it did to the downfall of Rome.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 16. -Acting as spokesman for his party, William F. Bleakley, Republican candidate for Governor, agreed today with Governor Herbert H. Lehman that a special session of the Legislature should be called immediately to extend voting hours to care for the huge increase in voters and to make possible a referendum in New York City on an eight hour day for firemen.

Sharp increases in institutional advertising in newspapers, in order to get across the story of American business, were revealed here yesterday by a survey of the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association. The association's booklet, which is entitled "Business Begins to Talk," contains a large and representative collection of examples of institutional advertising by a wide variety of business organizations.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 16 (AP). -Maritime unions reaffirmed their "solid front" relationship tonight and began voting on whether to authorize a coast-wide strike to be called Oct. 28 unless shipowners meet their basic demands.
EMMETT, Idaho, Oct. 16. -- Senator Borah said in a speech tonight he would not "apologize for any vote" he cast in the Senate during the Roosevelt administration.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- George Washington University scored an upset tonight by bowling over the favored University of Arkansas eleven, 13 -- 6, in one of the most exciting gridiron battles ever waged at Griffith Stadium. The victors had to come from behind to triumph after Sloan passed to Benton for the Razorbacks' touchdown mid-way in the first period.

The teachers' oath movement is not only a threat to the independence of American universities, but is dangerous to the nation as a whole, Dr. Isaiah Bowman, president of Johns Hopkins University, declared last night in an address at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 16. -Addressing delegates to the annual conference of the Public Ownership League of America, in the second day of its sessions in this city, Dr. John Bauer of New York, director of the American Public Utilities Bureau, asserted tonight that the government must directly assume the responsibility for providing work for every one.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Of incalculable consequence to every citizen of these United States is the result of November's election. Not merely will the present generation experience the effect but the future of our nation is involved.
Additional purchases of apartment sites featured the Bronx trading reported yesterday.
AMHERST vs. Rochester -- For some reason there seems to be a lull in the production of books on football. Was it the authors who became discouraged or the publishers? One light vote for Amherst.
West Side housing purchases led the Manhattan activity in real estate reported yesterday.

Prices on the local commodity futures markets were firmer yesterday, with few exceptions. Sugar, silk and coffee made sizable gains. In the cash markets, wheat, cotton, printcloths and coffee advanced, while corn, rye, lard and tin declined.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- A statement that "a majority of our trusts show a profit to original investors" and that since 1929 they had "paid out over $22,000,000 in cash dividends" was put today into the record of the Securities and Exchange Commission's investigation of investment trusts by Hugh Bullock, vice president of the Calvin Bullock group of fixed and management-type investment trusts.
EASTON, Pa., Oct. 16. -- Dr. William Mather Lewis, president of Lafayette College, conferred four honorary degrees today at Founders' Day exercises in Colton Memorial Chapel.

Miss Sally Salminen, the young Finnish woman who completed a prize novel in her spare hours from kitchen work, decided to flee early yesterday afternoon to spend the rest of a hectic day with friends in Brooklyn.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 16. -- Joseph C. McGarraghy, Washington attorney, has been retained by the New Jersey Republican Campaign Committee to represent it in efforts to compel the WPA to release records of administrative employment in New Jersey.

The New York County Grand Jury Heard Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan for an hour yesterday in its investigation of unsanitary and other objectionable conditions in the old Criminal Court Building. Afterward it extended invitations to Mayor La Guardia and Controller Taylor to appear before it.

World stocks of refined copper at the end of September amounted to 379,720 tons, compared with 405,570 at the end of August, a decline of 28,850 tons, according to reports in the trade. In the United States stocks were 188,720 tons, against 205,730, a decrease of 17,010.

Alfred E. Smith and Alf M. Landon will meet for the first time and have a heart-to-heart talk on Oct. 28, when the Republican nominee for President arrives in this city preparatory to his appearance as chief orator at the Madison Square Garden on the following day, which will mark the climax of his campaign.

Almost ninety gallons of boiling syrup were released from an elevated copper kettle in a Brooklyn sugar refinery late yesterday afternoon as a section of the kettle gave way, scalding six women and a man, two seriously.

James E. Finegan, Civil Service Commissioner, a life-long Democrat and a member of the La Guardia administration, deserted yesterday President Roosevelt, who is receiving the support of the Mayor, and announced his support of Governor Landon as President and William F. Bleakley, former Supreme Court justice, Republican, as Governor of the State.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 16. -- Mrs. Anna Bading, secretary to Ellis H. Parker Sr., chief of Burlington County, N.J., detectives, and Clinton Zeller, a member of Parker's staff, were held today in $5,000 bail each for the Federal grand jury on perjury charges.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16. -- Lower prices for wheat were recorded in leading markets early today, but the downturn was short lived. A scramble for Canadian cash wheat by countries in Europe and by United States mills resulted in heavy buyings of futures at Winnipeg to remove hedges and a rally followed with the close at the top.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16. -- Mr. and Mrs. W. Plunket Stewart gave a dinner dance tonight for Mrs. Stewart's nieces, Miss Elizabeth Harriman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Roland Harriman, and Miss Kathleen Harriman, daughter of W. Averell Harriman, both of New York.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Oct. 16. -Making her first appearance of the season in a one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association, Miss Charlotte Glutting of Rock Spring, Curtis Cup star, today shot a brilliant 79 to capture low gross honors in the weekly event at the Baltusrol Golf Club.

A business man has a harder task in winning public support than has a politician, Samuel W. Reyburn, chairman of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, told alumni and students of the New York University School of Retailing last night at a dinner at the Washington Square center of the university.

BOMBAY, India, Oct. 16. -- The Bombay provincial government was prepared tonight to call out troops to deal with furious Hindu-Moslem disturbances which have broken out here. They started yesterday and continued today even more seriously.

The story of a burglar who was so adept at breaking into houses he never left a trace of how he did it but who could not conceal a hunted look was related last night by triumphant detectives of the Poplar Street station in Brooklyn, whose lives have been made miserable for five months by his elusive activities.

New bond financing this week reached $157,560,000, the largest volume for such a period since the week ended on June 26, when new issues for $178,559,955 were marketed. This week's total compares with $59,714,000 last week. A year ago this week flotations aggregated $131,724,000.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 16. -Two undefeated elevens, Manhattan and Holy Cross, will clash tomorrow on Fitton Field in the sixth renewal of a rivalry which reached fever heat last year when the teams battled to a spectacular 13-13 tie.

Special sessions of the Legislature are not unusual in this State. Its citizens have grown accustomed to the sight of Senators and Assemblymen hurrying back to Albany in the Summer or Fall, sometimes against their wills, as the behest of the Governor. It was not expected this year, however, that any emergency would require such a summons, save only in the unlikely event that the voters should disapprove the pending unemployment relief bond issue.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 16 (AP). -- A.S. Albrecht, special master, will conduct a hearing here on Nov. 19 on a plan for reorganization filed by Cheney Brothers of Manchester, silk manufacturers. Judge Edwin S. Thomas of the Federal District Court yesterday granted the company permission to issue a pamphlet to parties interested detailing the reorganization plans.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 16. -- Governor Landon has crossed Maryland off the list of States in which he will speak during the campaign.

LONDON, Oct. 16. -- There is increasing evidence that the Baldwin Cabinet is making up its mind to do something to nip British fascism in the bud by putting some control on the excesses of Sir Oswald Mosley's Black Shirts.

Gloria Perkins, 11-year-old violinist from Winston-Salem, N.C., made her debut in a recital at Town Hall last night. She is a pupil of Louis Persinger and not without some experience on the public platform, having appeared twice as soloist with the National Symphony Orchestra in Washington and also with the Reading Symphony Orchestra.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16. -- Chairman Hamilton of the Republican National Committee sent a telegram to Senator Lonergan today, demanding that the Senate committee investigating campaign expenditures, act at once on the charges emanating from Pennsylvania.

An English statesman once said that most political speeches lie dead and buried until some ghoulish person digs them up in order to cut out a passage awkward for its living author to confront. This process has been busily going on in the United States for the past few months.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 16 (AP). -Scores of fires burned through tinder-dry forests in Northern California tonight, leaving three persons dead, two towns scorched and extensive property damage.

Four pastors were appointed yesterday for churches in the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn by Bishop Thomas E. Molloy. An administrator was named to St. Leonard's Church, 199 Jefferson Street; three assistants were transferred and one priest was added to the faculty of the Diocesan Schools of Nursing.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 16. -- The Navy scored first in the dual engagement it has with Yale, its B squad defeating the Yale B eleven today, 20 -- 12. The feud will be continued by the varsities tomorrow in the Baltimore Stadium.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16. -- Eugene Ormandy, now permanent conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra and soon to be heard in that capacity in Carnegie Hall, directed his second Friday concert here this afternoon in the Academy of Music, with a program which attracted an immense audience, and which, at least in the instance of certain familiar compositions, evoked cordial applause.
HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 16. -- Dartmouth and Brown will meet tomorrow on Memorial Field, the first contest between the Indians and Bears here since 1928.

Members of the governing committee of the Stock Exchange were patently irked yesterday by dispatches from Washington stating that the Exchange had not filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission its financial statements for 1934 and 1935.

The engagement of $3,000,000 of gold in England "at some previous date" for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank by local commercial banks. For several days the price of gold in London has made purchases of gold there for shipment here unprofitable, but banks here are still receiving word of consignments arranged by their correspondents abroad at an earlier date.

Budget increases of at least $10,000,000 will be needed to set up new city departments if the proposed city charter is adopted, Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens, charged last night in an address urging the charter plan's defeat. .He spoke over radio station WABC.

Studded with a number of traditional games, involving several undefeated teams, today's football program in the Eastern prep school circles is the most attractive one of the current campaign thus far. As usual, there will be important contests on numerous out-of-town gridirons, while Peddie and Poly Prep meet over in Brooklyn in another highlight of the day's card.

The richest stake of the meeting, the $5,000 added Continental Handicap, will be decided on the getaway program at Jamaica today. Seven races are listed, with the Continental fifth on the card. It will be the last day of the sport this season on Long Island, except for the one-day United Hunts meet.

With tales of high adventure in Tawi Tawi, Balimbing, Malasa and the Louisiades and more than 57,000 miles of travel entered in his log book, Captain Alan Villiers returned to this port yesterday in his square-rigged ship, Joseph Conrad, on the last leg of a two-year cruise around the world.

Engagement of $800,000 gold in Belgium for shipment here was announced yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This was the first export of gold arranged in Belgium for this country since devaluation of the belga by 28 per cent on April 1, 1935, and adoption there of a managed gold standard similar to that of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- The record of Franklin D. Roosevelt from 1911, when he was a member of the New York State Senate, up to his action on labor bills while President is declared entirely favorable to the cause of organized labor in a report of the American Federation of Labor's National Nonpartisan Political Campaign Committee, made public today.

Increasing prosperity with accompanying decrease in unemployment and increased taxes from other sources is leading retailers to believe that the crest of State tax legislation may have been passed. This view is held despite the fact that another State, Louisiana, on Oct. 1 put into effect a sales tax on so-called luxury products.

IT is an oddity in the history of sience that, while alchemy gave birth to chemistry, the dream of the medieval alchemists -- transmutation of the elements -- has been accomplished not by chemists but by physicists.

FOR a tense situation in which anything can easily happen George Gibbs has picked the dire case of a passenger plane with its able pilot suddenly gone berserk. Determined to kill the girl who has thrown him over and the man who is now her lover, he decides to crash the plane.

EARLY Autumn broadcasts "rate higher than usual," according to the latest report of the Women's National Radio Committee, which has resumed its reviews of programs. For example, the WABC network's symphonic concerts on Sunday nights at 9 o'clock are applauded for "improvement in the orchestra color, quality and precision."

Public schools should not try to train boys and girls for specific jobs, a conference of representatives of the National Industrial Conference Board, the American Federation of Labor, various government departments and associations of manufacturers and social workers reported last week to the American Youth Commission.

Only the greatest art arrives at simplicity. This was the invaluable secret Fritz Kreisler's violin imparted to the vast throng which spent the afternoon at Carnegie Hall yesterday listening to the sovereign preachment from his magic strings.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 17 (AP). -- A fighting band of Tennessee Volunteers held Alabama to a scoreless tie today before 15,000 spectators in weather almost torrid and threatening rain at times.

OVER the rugged hills of war-torn Spain the foreign legion of General Franco's army is fighting, as legionnaires invariably fight, with a fine disregard of their adversaries. The world had heard little about this foreign legion until civil war broke out in Spain; in fact, the force is relatively young; but it has made its traditions and it attracts to its colors the man to whom adventure is the wine of life.

In many a garden which is otherwise well-equipped, a cold-frame is conspicuous only by its absence. The most successful gardeners, however, do not handicap themselves by attempting to get along without this simple and effective aid to plant growing.

Miss Bertha Terry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Terry Jr., has been appointed chairman of the junior committee for the opening for the season of the new Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria on the night of Oct. 27. The opening has been planned as a benefit for the New York Exchange for Woman's Work.

There is no doubt a great deal of waste in relief, and there may be administrative waste in the agricultural bounties the administration is paying as well, but there is not enough waste there to account for the sort of deficits we have been having. Moreover, while there may be opportunities for retrenchment in regular expenditures, it remains to be demonstrated that a large contribution to budget balancing can be made in this direction.

MEDIA, Pa., Oct. 17. -- The Old Mills Farms' Rod, capably ridden by Sid Hirst, came through in the stretch to win the Rose Tree Hunter Challenge Cup, feature event of the Rose Tree Hunt Club's final racing card today before 10,000 spectators.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- Elmer Johnson of Illinois today demanded that the Supreme Court take steps to force Governor Horner and other officials of that State to place the names of Earl Browder and James W. Ford, Communist Presidential and Vice Presidential candidates, upon the ballot.

GILBERT FRANKAU is probably the most representative English novelist now writing. There are, necessarily, many of his fellow-countrymen not represented by him; but he does, indubitably, stand for the ordinary, normal Englishman of the well-to-do classes.

TOPEKA, Oct. 17. -- Governor Landon's swing this week through the three doubtful States of Illinois, Ohio and Michigan has, in the minds of the Republican Presidential candidate and his personal advisers, resulted in a distinct gain for the ticket.

A rare Egyptian sarcophagus carved from a five-ton block of rose granite 3,000 years ago has been purchased by the Brooklyn Museum, it was learned yesterday. The piece will be the largest in the collection assembled by Professor Jean Capart with the aid of the Wilbour endowment.

Reflecting expanding demand for fuel oil and the lengthening of the motor season, the petroleum industry in the United States is regarded now as having reached a degree of stability equaled by only a few of the other important industries. These developments have largely eliminated the wide seasonal fluctuations that previously characterized the demand for petroleum products.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 17. -- A fighting line that stopped the rival running attack and a secondary that batted down all passes but one enabled Lehigh to defeat a heavily favored Penn State team today, 7 to 6. Lehigh outrushed State to register seven first downs to three.

The general improvement in business conditions has not yet been reflected in the employment problems of college students who must have part-time jobs to sustain themselves, according to a report by Mrs. Dean Smith Schloss of the Bureau of Occupations at Hunter College.

The formal luncheon opening of the Caprice Room of the Weylin will take place on Tuesday with a Fall fashion revue as a feature. Young women of society who will take part in the fashion show include Mrs. Alfred Wagstaff 3d, Mrs. Kenelm Winslow, the Misses Barbara Hoge, Florence Sullivan, Susanne Murray, Marie Rose Cassard and Frances Whitall.

THE driver, the car and the highway occupied the center of attention at the twenty-fifth annual National Safety Congress at Atlantic City. Embodied in no formal report but evident from talks with leading highway and safety engineers was a general belief that out of this congress had come a broader approach to the motor accident situation.

SELFRIDGE FIELD, Mount Clemens, Mich., Oct. 17. -- First Lieutenant John M. Sterling of New York led nine other crack pilots of the Army Air Corps across the finish line in record time today to win the John L. Mitchell Trophy, symbolic of speed supremacy.

A large plurality for the entire Democratic State ticket was predicted last night by Thomas F. Farrell, chairman of the Independent Citizens Committee for the re-election of Governor Lehman and Lieut. Gov. Bray.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Oct. 17. -- The Speech Department of Wellesley College introduced into the academic curriculum this Fall a course in choral speaking which is unique not only in the field of voice training but in the entire system of pedagogy.
Reuben Fine, young New York chess expert, continues to gather European laurels, according to information received yesterday at the Marshall Chess Club.

ALICE GALL and Fleming Crew, authors of "Flat Tail," one of the distinguished books of 1935, and of other nature books which have been popular with boys and girls for several years, have now turned their attention to still smaller creatures.

Our nation may be said to have reached that stage in 1783 when our independence was acknowledged by the world. We could then sign documents, such as treaties and in general manage our own affairs by ourselves as a man can do when he becomes 21. But by "maturity" and "coming of age" we mean more than that.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- Under the most dispiriting conditions the first field meeting of the Women's Bench and Field Club was opened this morning in the covers of the Armory farm, scene of many memorable pointer and setter competitions.

Degrees and certificates have been voted by the City College faculty and the Board of Higher Education to 196 students upon their completion of the four-year college course. These degrees, which will be awarded at the regular annual commencement exercises in June, 1937, have been earned by virtue of class work taken during the 1936 Summer session. The recipients of the degrees follow:

NOW the bird-feeder begins to cultivate his hobby. He will not reap in a day, of course; rather he sows in the Fall for a harvest that shows some weeks later. Millions of wild birds are on the wing, journeying to Florida or Texas from Summer homes in the North.

ALBANY, Oct. 17 (AP). -- Mrs. D. Leigh Colvin, president of the State Woman's Christian Temperance Union, asked members of the organization today to raise a $60,000 educational fund to be used not "to bring about the return of prohibition'' but "to save Americans from drinking habits being fostered by the liquor industry."

NICOSIA, Cyprus. -- Islanders here are recalling that it is an ill wind that blows fair for nobody. The common belief in Cyprus is that the international crisis of last Winter will prove to have brought fortune to the island by deciding its future as a British air or naval base.

RICHMOND, Oct. 17. -- Retailers are still keeping ahead of last year's sales, but are anxiously waiting for a cold snap to put impetus behind heavy goods. Lines that are a little slow are clothing, house furnishings and fuel. Automobiles and accessories, along with furniture, are among the most brisk lines.
LAKEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 17. -- Two Brooklyn residents are among thirteen Georgian Court College students who will take part in the induction of class officers on the local campus Monday evening.

United States Senator Joseph F. Guffey of Pennsylvania, chairman of the Democratic Senatorial campaign committee, made public yesterday contributions by New Yorkers and others, totaling $29,250, to the Republican State Committee of Maine in the recent campaign there which he said were so listed as to conceal the names of the donors.
Ten students are studying at Barnard College on Fellowships this year. Foreign countries represented are Hungary, Belgium, Germany, France, Bolivia, China and Italy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- The rate of business activity for October is likely to be above that for September, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly review of the domestic situation. Whether the gains now in progress will equal or exceed seasonal proportions for the full month cannot be determined yet, although for industrial production, at least, an in crease of output in excess of current seasonal allowances seems to be indicated.

After being crushed by an automobile that skidded on the wet pavement and mounted the curb at Webster Avenue and 183d Street, the Bronx, 8-year-old Anna Torician of 2,272 Webster Avenue, the Bronx, died at 4:20 o'clock yesterday afternoon in Fordham Hospital.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17. -- The twenty-sixth annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons will open Monday for a week of clinical demonstrations, lectures and symposia, in which scores of leading surgeons from the United States, Canada and abroad will discuss and demonstrate the latest advances in surgery.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 17 (AP). -- Fires raced through dry timber, brush and grass tonight from Central California to West Central Oregon. They were uncomfortably close to San Francisco Bay resort areas despite control operations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP). -- Five trade associations, described officially as representing a "substantial portion" of all manufacturers and jobbers of automobile parts and accessories in the United States, were accused by the Federal Trade Commission today of forming a combination to control the market for their products.
The Citizens Union made public yesterday its recommendations on candidates for State Senator in the five counties of the city.

A "Carnival on Wheels" will be held on the night of Nov. 13 in the Mecca Temple Casino, West Fifty-fifth Street, as the annual benefit for the Vocational Service for Juniors. A floor show and games of skill, as well as fancy skating exhibitions by professionals, will feature the entertainment. Subscribers desiring to skate will be provided with skates by the committee.
VATICAN CITY, Oct. 16. -- A state of war exists between the Vatican and the Soviet Union.

At the first Fall meeting of the National Committee on the Cause and Cure of War tomorrow at the Y.W.C.A., 600 Lexington Avenue, the entire day will be devoted to plans for the annual conference to be held in Chicago next January.

CARLISLE, Pa., Oct. 17. -- A cen- tury-old Dickinson institution ended on Friday afternoon at 4 o'clock when the famous old Cumberland Valley train took its last trip through the college campus and down the main street of Carlisle. As one drowned-out chapel speaker once ruefully admitted, it was "no use to try to buck a railroad."

WASHINGTON. -- Under a recent $3,600,000 grant to the State of Louisiana, PWA funds will help rebuild the Charity Hospital in New Orleans, said to be the oldest hospital in the United States. The present main building, more than a hundred years old, has been condemned.

UNLESS so advised in advance, one making the round at Pittsburgh would be unlikely to remark that the 1936 Carnegie International contains forty-two pictures less than were contained in the International last year.
Soviet Russia states that if the nonintervention agreement is violated she shall not consider herself bound by it.

ENGLISH writers with wit, style and erudition appear to have a fondness, perhaps a weakness, for turning out extravaganzas in which they can use their pretty tricks to satirize the present state of civilization. It is a tempting mark, and Mr. Marmaduke Dixey has written a bright and softly shining sample of this sort of fantasy.
UVALDE, Texas, Oct. 17. -- The text of Vice President Garner's speech tonight was as follows:

LONDON, Oct. 17. -- Friends of Mrs. Ernest Simpson talked more than ever tonight about the possibility of a royal romance when they heard reports the American-born woman again was a guest of King Edward at his country estate thirty-five miles from London.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 17. -- Further increases in production schedules were evident in manufacturing circles this week, as many plants received automobile parts orders in larger volume than for some time. As a result steel mill operations were further advanced in several centers and there were eight more blast furnaces in production in early October than in September.

LONDON, Oct. 1. ONE of the great theatrical occasions in pre-war London was Reinhardt's production of "Oedipus Rex" at Covent Garden Opera House. The same production on the same stage with Sir John Martin-Harvey in his original part was received this week with comparative calm.

PARIS, Oct. 17. -- French Government spokesmen tonight expressed fears that Belgium was lost to France forever as a military ally, despite Belgian assurances that for the present Brussels regards all its treaty obligations as in effect.

SAY this country has held its national election. And say that the leaders -- visible and invisible -- of the minority parties decide to start killing Americans who voted for the popular side. Say they plan to go on killing them until they have abolished our form of government.

PARIS, Oct. 16. -- Belgium's decision, announced by King Leopold on Wednesday, to pursue a policy exclusively Belgian, with the object of keeping war away from her territory, has changed the equilibrium of Western Europe as it had existed since the end of the war.

PEEK-A-BOO hats -- those are the things that are going to take the girls' eyes, and the boys', too, for that matter. They are mere wisps, light as a feather. From bandeaux of many descriptions flutter cobweb-lace veils, falling well below the tip of the nose.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 17 (AP). -- Myrtlewood, queen of the Western sprinters, hurled another challenge at Miss Merriment, pride of the East, when she galloped to her second stakes victory of the meeting in the Ashland Stakes, today's featured attraction at the new Keeneland track.

Harold Jacobi, chairman of the committee presenting "Night of Stars" at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night, Oct. 28, under the auspices of the United Palestine Appeal and Joint Distribution Committee, announced yesterday that representatives of all faiths were included in the sponsoring committee and actors.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- The prestige of fraternity and sorority political machines has apparently been re-established at Syracuse University. Students selected only one independent candidate this week in choosing sixteen class offi- cers in an election marked by block voting, coalitions, and the heaviest balloting in years.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- For the first time in history the Civil Service Commission this Fall will hold an examination for blind persons to supervise in part a survey of employment opportunities for the blind, for which Congress made provision in legislation passed last session.

Plans were completed last week for the exhibition of nineteenth and twentieth century American and English first editions, association copies and authors' manuscripts which will form a part of the panoramic picture of the world of books to be presented at THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair in the International Building, Rockefeller Center, from Nov. 5 to 19.

MOSCOW. ARTISTS in Soviet Russia are known as "engineers of the human soul." Stated more mundanely, the Bolsheviks believe that no matter how much an artist proclaims his credo of art for art's sake, his work, once it is given to the public, becomes a factor in molding the mind of the man who reads, listens and looks.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- Hotels here continue to plan special activities for their guests during the early Fall days. The Buck Hill Falls Inn has arranged a series of golf tournaments between the guests of the inn and those of Sky-top and Pocono Manor.

A bronze statue of General Philip Henry Sheridan, the Civil War cavalry officer, will be unveiled tomorrow afternoon at 4 o'clock in the little triangular plot known as Christopher Street Park, adjoining Sheridan Square, in Greenwich Village.
HARTFORD, Oct. 16. -- The first lame-duck session of the Connecticut General Assembly, at least since biennial sessions started in 1887, has been called by Governor Cross to meet Nov. 5.

The Jooss European Ballet officially opened the local dance season yesterday afternoon with the first of four performances at the Alvin Theatre. A large and cordial audience signified its pleasure at the return of the company for its third American visit and called the dancers before the curtain repeatedly at the close of the afternoon.

THIS book is written by one who can still hear "the strong engines and smell the tang of the burnt oil"; who remembers "the grass blowing down as the engines are run up"; and who recalls "swallowing to stop deafness in a dive."

A Hollywood story that combines dignity and romance is an unusual tour de force. Perhaps this novel angle on the cinema capital sprouts from the fact that the hero, a famous movie star, is not only handsome and fascinating but also English and stone deaf.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- How is the Union party making the grade as the campaign's last lap approaches? There are curious contradictions in the evidence, as various competent and more or less materially interested observers of the 1936 political scene view it.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- Port Chester High School's powerful football team remained undefeated, untied and unscored upon as it topped White Plains High, 7 -- 0, at Port Chester Stadium today in the opening W.I.A.A. clash for both elevens.

Crude rubber consumption in the United States in September amounted to 46,330 long tons, compared with 46,657 in August and with 37,086 in September, 1935, according to the Rubber Manufacturing Association.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17. -- Governor Landon's election by more than 315 electoral votes and control of the next House of Representatives was predicted tonight by John D.M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee.

I WANT to explain here not why we are now appearing and playing on the screen but why we did not do so before this our cinema debut in Paramount's "The Big Broadcast of 1937." With my orchestra I pioneered in recording symphony music for the phonograph.

In the rotogravure section of THE TIMES of Oct. 11 I noticed a photograph of the Mall in Washington and a reference to the completion of the plan which was laid out by Major l'Enfant, a Frenchman, for the city of Washington.

THERE is significance in the announcement of last week that air freight service, utilizing special planes equipped as flying box cars, would be started by Transcontinental and Western Air on its line tomorrow. According to Jack Frye, president of the line, multi-motored all-metal airplanes with a payload capacity of 3,500 pounds will be used.
