Coiffures drawn from paintings of famous women of Napoleon's day, but tempered with a sleek modernism, are the handiwork of a Parisian hair stylist now visiting New York. These coiffures reflect the glamour of Napoleon's court without sacrificing trimness; indeed clothes and hair styles are harmonious in line and swing.
BRYN MAWR, Pa., Oct. 17. -A picture of Bryn /iawr College's present-day activities will be of. feted to graduates during an alumnae week-end, the first alumnae gathering of this type on the campus.

THE settlement of the West is a saga of such romance, the men who achieved it were such indomitables, that it must serve as a constant reservoir of inspiration from which succeeding generations of Americans may draw courage and strength to surmount their inevitable problems -- problems which may be different in form, but which, to face, require an equal firmness.

IN a general way historians have long been familiar with the arguments which ante-bellum Southerners employed in defense of their "peculiar institution," and in fact it is a poor history of the years before the war that does not devote considerable space to the arguments used on both sides of the slavery controversy.

Prices of bonds on the New York Stock Exchange continued yesterday toward higher levels, despite the usual week-end curtailment of trading activity in the two-hour session. Secondary railroad and convertible industrial loans led the upswing, although the improvement spread to the higher-grade issues and to numerous foreign-dollar bonds.

If the people of the United States elect Governor Landon in November, they will not get a showy President, nor one with a sympathetic bedside manner, nor one disposed to soothe their minds with glowing promise and tickle their ears with pretty phrases.

An almost unprecedented interest in the opening meeting this season of the Westchester County Federation of Women has been manifest since the announcement of its headline feature -- a symposium presenting representatives of all but one of the accredited political parties.

ALBANY, Oct. 17. -- Governor Lehman was host tonight to President Roosevelt at dinner after a long tour from Elmira, during which he declared that he would give his detailed views on milk control in a speech to be delivered in Watertown next Wednesday night.

The Opportunity Shop, at 46 West Forty-seventh Street, which for years has been a mart for articles resold to raise funds for anti-tuberculosis activities, has just opened a special department featuring articles suitable for gifts. A junior committee, headed by Mrs. Hyatt Dehn, is in charge of the new department, with debutantes serving as salesgirls.
BERLIN, Oct. 17. -- Dr. Franz Guertner, Minister of Justice, has issued instructions to judicial authorities to join the police in the "ruthless" extermination of profiteers.

At the Boston Symphony Orchestra concerts in Symphony Hall, I Boston, last week, Serge Iplayed for the first I time in this country an orchestrali score by a composer from the Pa-:i risian group, "La Jeune France." i This composition was "Les Of-I frandes OubliSes," by Olivier 1V[es{ siaen.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 17. -- A little band of black-jerseyed warriors from Duquesne University upset the mighty Pittsburgh Panthers, 7 to 0, today with one sudden scoring thrust by a substitute halfback, who streaked 72 yards for a touchdown in the second period.

WHEN the Irish gained political control of Boston, they were already 100 per cent American; they had adopted the boss system. So "Ward Eight," the story of Boston, Boston's Irish and Boston's politicians, becomes the story of most American cities and most American political bosses.

Preliminary steps have been taken for the revival of Manhattan College's Quarterly, a student literary magazine which flourished and gained considerable notice as a Catholic publication between 1904 and 1918, when it was discontinued because of the World War.

Captain Oskar Scharf, master of the Europa, started his twenty-sixth year with the North German Lloyd Line when his ship sailed early yesterday morning for the Channel ports and Bremen. In his quarters aboard ship he has scores of messages of congratulations from friends, including Hans Luther, German Ambassador to the United States, and former passengers, on his completion of a quarter of a century of service.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- The open season for Berkshire pheasant and partridge, or wild grouse, begins on Tuesday and continues for a month. The Berkshires sportsmen's clubs have liberated many pheasants from Federal and State hatcheries in South Berkshire covers, and several clubs, such as the new Marlboro Game Association, have stocked their preserves to such an extent that there is an overflow into nearby woods.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 17. -- The ashes of Lawrence W. Churchill, 73-year-old New York lawyer, who died suddenly in Florida last January, will be analyzed for traces of lead acetate as a result of the mysterious poisoning of two relatives in the Churchill home here last week, it was announced today.

DURING the current year the number of tercentenary celebrations of the founding of American towns, States and institutions has posed vividly for many thoughtful people the questions whether we really have "come of age" and what is meant by that phrase as applied to a nation and people. After all, three centuries is a short period.

DEDHAM, Mass., Sunday, Oct. 18 (AP). -- Patrolman Robert E. Green of Dedham police reported that two Wheaton College girls were killed just after midnight in a collision of two automobiles on the Boston-Providence super-highway.

BOSTON, Oct. 16. -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, after a two-day visit here which included a speech before a characteristically devoted audience, an altercation with a reporter, the consequent guarding of the priest by a squad of heavily armed police and a bewildering list of endorsements of several Democratic candidates for Congress, has returned to Detroit.

Polly Forbes-Johnson, a 19-year-old college girl of 144 West Thirteenth Street, returned yesterday on the Santa Rosa of the Grace Line after making a 6,000-mile motor-cycle tour through Mexico and Guatemala. She brought back two motor cycles, the second one having been presented to her by President George Ubico of Guatemala, who is a cycle enthusiast, she said.

Hardy chrysanthemums, brought into bloom by the cooler weather, have now added their beauty to that of the displays of roses and of dahlias which for several weeks past have been attracting many visitors to the New York Botanical Garden.

PARIS REBOUX'S Autumn opening is always one of the important fashion events of the new season. Reboux is to the millinery mode what Vionnet is to dressmaking. Both occupy a place removed from all that is merely superficially smart, and each season finds them setting new rec ords in the stratosphere of style creation.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17. -- Retail business in department, specialty and other stores this week was approximately even with the corresponding period last year, influenced by unseasonable weather. Household goods and domestics were active, but men's and women's wear lagged considerably.

LONDON, Oct. 17 (Canadian Press). -- A lucky Portsmouth team is supreme in English football today. Lapses by Derby County and Brentford, its rivals in the race for the championship, allowed the Southerners to push into a two-point lead through a 2-1 victory over Manchester United.

A hunt ball will be given under the auspices of the Willoughby House Junior Board on the evening of Nov. 6, in the ballroom of the Towers, Brooklyn, for the benefit of Willoughby House Settlement, 97 Lawrence Street, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- Forty per cent of the cotton classified in the week ended on Thursday by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics was white middling or better in grade, the weekly cotton grade and staple report showed today. Sixty-five per cent of the cotton of this year's crop classed so far has been white middling or better.

As all great ports, New Orleans attracted the dregs of every nation, and, because it was overwhelmingly Latin, made no effort to hide its vice as a more Puritanical, Anglo-Saxon community would have done.

MORGANTOWN, W.Va., Oct. 17 -- Taking an advantage of all the breaks afforded by a slippery ball and wet playing field, the West Virginia University eleven defeated an ancient rival, West Virginia Wesleyan, 15 -- 0, at Mountaineer Field today.

Ray Trail, youthful Mohawk Indian cross-country star of Mont Pleasant High School, Schenectady, led home a field of more than two hundred starters to win the fourteenth annual Manhattan College interscholastic run at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

Governor George H. Earle of Pennsylvania, scheduled to address the opening session tonight of the national convention of Hadassah in the Benjamin Franklin Hotel in Philadelphia, will be the first of an impressive list of civic and religious leaders to come before that gathering.

One hundred and seventy-five detectives, twenty-nine subjects for the daily line-up at headquarters and incidental police officials were delayed forty-two minutes yesterday because Tige, the greenest-eyed cat that ever came to Centre Marketplace, had quadruplets near the fingerprint file room at 3:02 A.M.

WASHINGTON. -- In an initial move to develop Indian arts and crafts and expand the markets for the products of Indian craftsmen, a meeting of silversmiths and silver-craftsmen, traders and dealers was held at Albuquerque, N.M., under the sponsorship of the Indian Arts and Crafts Board.

The music section of THE TIMES of Sept. 20 contained Mr. Downes's most fitting tribute to the life and musical influence of Ossip Gabrilowitsch. I am moved to add a word concerning the supreme art of Mr. Gabrilowitsch as a pianist. When a young girl I heard Anton Rubinstein.
The following article is the third of a series by Mr. Rice.

A PALE blue sky, resting like a light dome over the crisp, clean air of Autumn; overcoats, steamer rugs, vacuum bottles, lunch boxes; gay crowds, familiar faces shouting recognitions! Special railroad trains; highways jammed with cars, their colors splashed with contrasting hues of pennants or toy-balloons.

Organized labor was charged with discrimination against Negroes in this city yesterday by James H. Hubert, executive director of the New York Urban League, an organization interested in the welfare of the Negroes of this city.

DETROIT, Oct. 17. -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin's speech before 5,000 members of his National Union for Social Justice was momentarily broken up today when a man dressed in red and wearing a cap decorated with Indian feathers broke in on his platform and started showering him with feathers.
BERLIN, Oct. 17. -- The German Foreign Office today categorically disavowed a statement published by Friedrich Kuhn in the New York German language newspaper Der Weckruf.

THIS is the story of a house, and of the site of the house. It is also to some extent the story of famous men who have lived in this house or have made it their working headquarters. And though it adds no material detail to our knowledge of the British Empire and its leading statesmen, the book's pleasant and chatty pages are entertaining, and some of its memories have real flavor.

BERNARD NEWMAN, author of spy fiction, presents this record as, probably, fact. He is not, he says, entirely sure about it. He began to check up on what was told him and then he decided that it really didn't matter. "This is the way in which a clever spy would set to work.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 17. -- A passenger plane larger and more powerful than the China Clipper and her sister ships now in the Pacific service is being built at the Glenn L. Martin plant for Russia. The contract involves more than $1,000,000, company officials stated.

TROY, Oct. 17. -- Middlebury College won its fourth consecutive football game today, defeating Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, 13 -- 0. Rensselaer's captain, Marty Gavetti, was out of the game after the beginning of the second quarter, having received a dislocated collarbone when tackled.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 17. -- Largely because of greater success achieved with their overhead attack at opportune stages, the St. John's College eleven defeated the American University of Washington today, 12 -- 6.

IT is important to begin the review of this book by a consideration of its title. First, because the four words of the title standing alone are somewhat obscure. Second, because the title reflects a bias which no doubt in large part explains many of the queer statements and odd conclusions to which Mr. Peek gives voice.

When DARWIN'S theories of natural selection and the survival of the fittest were at last firmly established it became the fashion to apply them to human affairs. Men may not kill one another on sight out of sheer hatred or fear, but they compete in other ways, runs the argument.

More than eighty-five debutantes, including many from Philadelphia, Baltimore, Washington and other near-by cities, as well as a large group from this city, have accepted invitations to participate in the cotillion at the "Velvet Ball" and Debutante Election Cotillion to be held on Oct. 30 at the Waldorf-Astoria.

THE New Jersey Opera Association, under William Spada, will present "La Traviata" this Wednesday in Newark, N.J., with a cast headed by Ina de Martino, Lawrence Power and Angelo Pilotto; "Il Trovatore," Nov. 4, with Leonora Corona. Rocco Pandiscio and Pasquale Ferrara, and "Don Pasquale" Nov. 18.

IN the mid-nineteenth century Canadians looking south saw covered wagons streaming across the United States toward the Pacific, and "rails thrust out to the great plains"; but to the north and west on their own horizon was "only a chartered company, endowed with nearly two centuries of privilege and monopoly."

The tremendous pre-election registration in New York City, which smashed all records so far as New York State is concerned, has become the great unknown quantity in the final stage of the campaign. The political leaders of both major parties are puzzled.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Oct. 17. -- Northeastern University of Boston scored a surprising 13-to-7 victory over the St. Lawrence University eleven at Huntington Field today. What proved to be the winning Northeastern touchdown was scored by Gus Rook when he returned the second half kick-off 90 yards.
The Census Bureau issued figures last week for the retail business of 1935. They showed that New York was well on its way from the low level of 1933.

LISBON, Portugal (by telephone from Toledo, Spain), Oct. 17. -- Madrid's last rail line to the sea-coast was cut today at Castillejos, nine miles southwest of the Leftist secondary defenses at Aranjuez and thirty-four miles from Madrid, Rebel field headquarters here reported tonight.
THE splendid exhibition of glass, covering a span of some thirty-four centuries, which opened at the Metropolitan Museum last week, is commented upon by Mr. Storey in THE TIMES Magazine today.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Oct. 17. -- Hampden-Sydney handed the Swarthmore eleven its first defeat of the season today, 14 -- 6. The visitors scored their touchdowns on short-line smashes by Rich Richardson in the last quarter.

Mrs. Howard F. Shattuck, chairman of the committee for the benefit performance of "Tovarich" on the night of Nov. 4 at the Plymouth Theatre, will give a tea for members of her committee on Tuesday at her home, 160 East Seventy-eighth Street. The theatre party has been arranged to aid the Union Settlement.

Bonds of several Federal Land Banks and religious institutions were features last week in the announcements of bonds called for payment before maturity. Notices were fewer than in the preceding two weeks of this month and the payment dates were nearly all for future months, only some small amounts of municipal loans being listed for October.

TELEVISION pictures on a screen three-foot square are said to be possible through a new invention of Telefunken Gesellschaft, Germany, according to Andrew W. Cruse, chief of the Electrical Division, United States Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 16. -- Although the Arab strike is ended in Palestine and violence and shooting are diminishing, the Arab-Jewish problem is becoming more aggravated than ever. The air is thick with mutual animosity, with little hope, of any change.

DURHAM, N.C., Oct. 17. -- An inspired band of Duke Blue Devils, directed in attack by Captain Clarence (Ace) Parker, drove to a 19-to-6 triumph over Georgia Tech today before 32,000 cheering spectators. It was a battle of unbeaten Southern teams.

SWITZERLAND'S art galleries have assembled their choicest examples in honor of the delegates to the fourteenth International Congress of Art, who are making a tour of Swiss cities this month. Tourists who happen to be passing through the country at this time will have an opportunity to see not only the special museum collections but the many fine paintings in private homes which are not usually accessible to the public.

Most attractive of the field trial events of the year for admirers of the working spaniel is the annual meeting of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association, which will open on Friday morning and continue through Sunday.

BERLIN, Oct. 16. -- National Socialism, unlike bolshevism, is based not on economic but on political doctrine. Herr Hitler himself has no particular convictions about economics, except one that politics, not economics, determines the destiny of a nation.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 17. -- The belated demand for Fall goods is overflowing in the Eighth Federal Reserve District and retail sales have attained heavy proportions, in many sections exceeding 22 per cent over last year. Rural stores are particularly prosperous, as the result of the improving farm situation, due to high prices of farm products.

The Cunard White Star motor-ship Britannic, which sailed yesterday for the Channel ports, is the first British passenger vessel to come here since the new regulations, effective Oct. 1, that the crew be employed on a three-watch system. Formerly there were two watches and the men were worked four on and four hours off duty.

A joint meeting of the men's and women's divisions in the $250,000 fund-raising campaign of the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service will take place at a large dinner on Wednesday at Sherry's. Several hundred acceptances have been received for the function, at which the speakers will include Mrs. Ogden Reid and Dr. George E. Vincent, former president of the Rockefeller Foundation.

WE ARE SOCIAL: Does the Darwinian theory provide scientific basis for the belief that between men there must be destructive economic competition? To Dr. Albert Einstein's mind it does not. Speaking in Albany last week he said: "Man owes his strength in the struggle for existence to the fact that he is a socially living animal.

Tree surgeons have been searching for many years for a practicable, durable wound dressing for trees. Many substances hav been tried and few have been found satisfactory. The simplest dressing for wounds is orange shellac. In Lindley's "Theory of Horticulture," which was published in 1841, shellac was recommended.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- New Rochelle High began the defense of its W.I.A.A. championship today by downing Roosevelt High of Yonkers, 12 -- 0, on the loser's gridiron. The game also was the initial one in the tournament for Roosevelt.

In announcing that in two weeks Maurice Barber begins rehearsal on "the George Sand play by Marie Jenney Howe and Rose Young," you refer to the play as "the one that used to bear the somewhat unlikely title of 'The Cigar Smoker.'"

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- "An American concerned with the future will vote for the re-election of President Roosevelt," said John L. Lwis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, in a radio address tonight over the NBC network under the auspices of Labor's Non-Partisan League.

THE mere spectator has at last discovered the fox-hunting country of Virginia and the Carolinas. For many years tourists bound for the Civil War battlefields, and garden week trippers, have sped through the Piedmont, appraising it as a fair, rolling country softened by the haze of the Blue Ridge, but crediting it with scant showmanship.

BOTH sections of Columbia's two-record "X" album series receive additions this month. In the lower numbers a reissue of Debussy's sonata for 'cello and piano, played by Gaspar Cassado and Mme. Mendelssohn-Gorgidiani, with the 'cellist's own Aragonesa retained as a filler (X-41), was mentioned here at the time of its original release.

CHEERING reports of concert managers and those who purvey opera indicate that music as well as industries, farms, , have turned the financial corner. The Metropolitan advises that its sale for the coming season is certain to be considerably larger than it was last.

Education in the United States faces an issue on which opinion is acutely divided. Many technicalities are involved, but the fundamental question is simple: What are the proper qualifications for a teacher in public schools? Should her training largely consist in prescribed courses in the technique of teaching?

Any unbeaten aspirations that the Poly Prep School eleven may have entertained for this season were lost yesterday at Dyker Heights when the Brooklynites were conquered by the powerful Peddie Institute team of Hightstown, N.J., 6 -- 0, in the tenth meeting between the rivals.

THE live target in this campaign is not Mr. Roosevelt or Mr. Landon. It is not the New Deal or the G.O.P. high command's substitutes for it, or Mr. Roosevelt's objections to the substitutions, or Mr. Landon's criticism of Mr. Roosevelt's criticisms of the substitutes.

A 13-year-old boy, playing on the roof of the Columbia Broadcasting System Playhouse at 251 West Forty-fifth Street, was shot and critically wounded about 10 o'clock last night when he was mistaken for a burglar.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Oct. 17. -- While attending the buffet supper and dance given last night for her niece, Miss Virginia Brand, by Mrs. Gordon Smith of Casa Maria near Greenwood, Lady Astor brought down the house when, turning to the orchestra, she asked the musicians to play "God Save the Queen."
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 17. -- Paced by the diminutive Monk Meyer, their streamlined halfback, Army's football warriors sild through to a 32-0 triumph over Harvard today.
Nick Pecora led the New York Aggies to a 17-7 football victory over Wagner College yesterday on the Wagner field.

THE late Colonel Edward H.R. Green, stamp collector extraordinary, left to posterity a treasure of philatelic gems many of which are unique and almost priceless. Before he died last June he remarked on various occasions that his stamps would never be put on the market, and in his will, which is now being probated, he provided that his great collection be placed with some museum where the public may have access to it.

YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, Oct. 17 (AP). -- Dr. Karl T. Compton, president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, told the Horace Mann centennial conference here today that "the danger of expecting miracles from science is no less serious" than that of seeking to discredit science.

Concerted action by President Roosevelt and Democratic National Chairman James A Farley to break up the Democratic organization in the city and supplant it with the newly organized American Labor party is charged in a statement by James C. Cleary, head of the hotel men's division in the Democratic national campaigns of 1928 and 1932.

CARLETON BEALS is one of the most remarkable knight errants in contemporary journalism. Before he was 38 his desire for adventure and understanding had led him to life on peon and patrician levels in some twenty-two countries, particularly Latin America.
John Marin, the 66-year-old American painter whost work of the last thirty years is to be exhibited this week by the Museum of Modern Art, objects to being divided into periods.

EVENTS now taking place in the Far East confer a peculiar timeliness on this volume from the pen of Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of State from 1929 to 1933. The Far Eastern crisis which originated during his term at the State Department is still with us; if anything, the form which it takes today is more serious than ever.

THE directors of the Academy of Vocal Arts have announced a competition for a free scholarship to celebrate their entrance into a new building in Philadelphia. The scholarship is open to any young woman or man possessing a voice and other characteristics necessary for an artistic career and who is unable to pay for a vocal education.

MOST of the news this morning deals with contemporary operas and their composers. Richard Hageman, who wrote "Caponsacchi," the native opera which will have its American premiere at the Metropolitan during the coming season, writes that the latest report of his illness has been exaggerated.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- A complaint charging five trade associations composed of manufacturers and jobbers of automobile parts and accessories with forming a combination to control the market and to fix and maintain resale prices of these products has been issued by the Federal Trade Commission.

MANILA, Sunday, Oct. 18. -- The Pan American flying boat China Clipper alighted in Cavite Harbor yesterday afternoon at 3:37 after a 1,600-mile flight, completing from Guam her 8,200-mile voyage from San Francisco.

The contents of the residence of the late Dr. Fenton B. Turck, 14 East Fifty-third Street, comprising furnishings and art property, will be offered at auction on the premises under the management of the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., Tuesday morning and afternoon, following exhibition tomorrow.

Are Europeans destined to regain control of leading American corporations and is New York's supremacy in the financial world to be sacrificed? These are vital questions to American industry. That such a possibility even is suggested may seem surprising, but the fact that the danger has attracted so little attention is the more surprising.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 17. -- Massachusetts State gained its first victory of the season today, downing Rhode Island State, 13 -- 8. The Massachusetts touchdowns came in the second period. Niden and Towle went over after fine drives through the line.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- The Greenbrier Hotel is at the peak of the biggest season it has over enjoyed, and reservations indicate that it will be busy well into November. The social and sports program, with special celebrations arranged for Halloween.

TIME AND TOYS: In 1895 there appeared an amazing account of a "Time Machine" with which one might travel backward and forward through the fourth dimension. But the invention of that machine was fictitious, and one-way time has caught up with the author, Herbert George Wells.

ONCE upon a time there were Gibson Girl corsets, Gibson Girl spoons, Gibson Girl china plaques, shirt waists, skirts, shoes, pompadour rats, hats, riding stocks. Wallpaper for bachelor apartments was made out of hundreds of Gibson Girl heads.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -Georgetown University, with Tommy Keating directing, uncorked a sensational aerial game today to turn back the Bucknell University eleven, 19 to 0.

What does the widely heralded "truce" between the Tennessee Valley Authority and the private utilities really amount to? Technically it rests on a narrow base and has sharply limited objectives. Two years ago the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation entered into a somewhat makeshift contract with the TVA for the interchange of power in the Southeastern area.

Southern hedge selling increased yesterday on the Cotton Exchange here with the return of more favorable weather over the Cotton Belt, and although fairly active foreign and domestic trade demand continued, prices gradually gave way from moderate initial advances to close steady at a decline of 3 points to an advance of 1 point.

Alfred E. Smith, speaking at Philadelphia, scoffed at Mr. Roosevelt as a pretended Jeffersonian. H.F. Pringle has called Mr. Roosevelt "an heir of whom the Monticello sage would almost certainly disapprove violently." This now common view will be questioned by any one who is familiar with the political writings and career of the third President.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- Unleashing a powerful attack in the first two minutes, Union College scored its first trumph of the football season today over Vermont, 8 to 0. The visitors used a revamped line-up.

RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 17. -- S.S. Janney Jr.'s Justinian II galloped through mud that was fetlock deep in places today to capture the eleventh running of the Monmouth Gold Cup, which was the feature of the annual meeting of the Monmouth County Hunt Racing Association held on the estate of Amory L. Haskell.

Tonight and tomorrow three more foreign field hockey teams will arrive to participate in the conference of the International Federation of Women's Hockey Associations, which begins a ten-day session at the Philadelphia Cricket Club on Tuesday.

LONDON, Sunday, Oct. 18. -- The Sunday Referee, which on many occasions has taken a different line from other London newspapers, is publishing today an article on the first page under the heading "The King May Marry by Spring." It thus breaks a censorship which the press has imposed on itself since announcement was made that Mrs. Ernest Simpson, friend of King Edward VIII, was about to divorce her husband.

The connection between the New York Central Railroad and the Universal Carloading and Distributing Company, largest of freight-forwarding and consolidating concerns, was disclosed here last week at hearings of the Interstate Commerce Commission to be maintained through a loan of $15,314,759 extended by a subsidiary of the railroad to a company which controls Universal.

Prompted by widespread complaints on shipments of industrial supplies, the National Association of Purchasing Agents in a telegraphic survey yesterday uncovered the fact that delivery conditions are rapidly becoming acute in the coal market and have reached a difficult stage in a number of other commodities.

Stuart M. Crocker, chairman of the United Hospital Campaign's executive committee, announced last night that seventy-five persons already had volunteered to serve on the committee that is still in the process of formation.

Boys High struck through the air in the final quarter to top a heavy Manual Training High School football team, 7 -- 0, at Boys High Field in Brooklyn yesterday. The triumph was the third in as many contests for the Red and Black.

LONDON, Oct. 14. -- Next week's openings are these: Sunday at the Arts the Lancashire actor, John Burch, will play the title role of his own comedy "The Palmist," with Hilda Bruce-Potter returning to the stage therein. On Monday, the Embassy will get Rodney Ackland's "Plot Twenty-one," which is the revised version of his "Birthday," a failure several seasons ago.

On the last evening of October suburbanites will carry clothes-poles into their cellars, hide ash cans and move porch furniture into the house for safekeeping. It will be Halloween, the night when usually well-conducted children turn vandais for a few hours and go about trespassing against property in a prankish way.

A ONCE over-worked word is creeping back into the girl's vocabulary. "I just about swooned with delight!" she exclaims; but she only says it. She doesn't reach for her smelling salts as her grandmother did; she lights a cigarette.

EN ROUTE WITH PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT, Oct. 17. -- President Roosevelt and his official associates on the Western campaign trip have expressed the cheerful feeling -- in fact, a jubilant one -- that this tour figuratively nailed down the head of the barrel in which the election result is encased.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- Registration figures in Westchester County continued to mount today. Political leaders said the four-day total would be more than 20 per cent ahead of the previous record, established in 1932. The registration period closed at 10 o'clock tonight and final figures will be available tomorrow.

PAULETTE GODDARD, the gay, if silent, gamin of Charles Chaplin's "Modern Times," is an extremely charming young woman. She is also an extremely guarded young woman, especially when it comes to answering queries about her oft-reported marriage to Mr. Chaplin.

Louis Waldman, State chairman of the People's party, has written to Mayor La Guardia demanding an investigation of the conditions in Harlem Hospital under which nineteen infants died last month in an epidemic of infantile diarrhea.

The need for simplification of income-tax laws forcibly presents itself from time to time in the course of tax litigation. A complex statute is sometimes made more complicated by regulatory interpretations, and fine distinctions may become so refined that the basic intent of the law is no longer expressed by the regulations.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 17. -- A very effective program, including an American premiere of surprisingly brilliant music by Richard Strauss, signalized the opening Saturday night concert of the forty-third season of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra this evening in Music Hall.

Sixteen thousand students are packing the corridors and jamming the stairways of 107 centers in New York City as the Federal Music Project of the WPA goes into its 1936-37 season. It is a record response to a new educational idea of "music for all the people."
HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 17. -- Everybody expected that Dartmouth's football team would run roughshod over Brown today, but the spectators were hardly prepared for the weather.

The old bugbear of home study has been completely eliminated by a new device in the seventh and eighth grades of the Anacostia Junior-Senior High School of Washington, D.C. In the ninth grade it has been cut down to approximately one-half its former length.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 16. -- When Rear Admiral H.G. Hamlet arrives here Sunday as representative of the new Maritime Commission, he will find the maritime unions highly suspicious of the commission's intentions and determined on a strike Oct. 28 unless, in the meantime, they are assured of retaining what they call their "fundamental union rights."

VIENNA, Oct. 17. -- On the eve of a great gathering of the Fatherland Front militia, for which some 60,000 persons from all parts of Austria have already arrived here, Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg delivered tonight at City Hall a speech on his intentions to local leaders of the organization.

Here is an author for boys who realizes that sport and games and all school activities will have greater reality, and a livelier appeal if they are combined with genuine characterization. Within the limits of a tale of boarding school life Mr. Haines has worked out a well-balanced plot, with an eventful series of happenings, and has drawn boys real enough to remain in the memory after the book is closed.

GENEVA, Oct. 17. -- Figures showing the shift in the world's visible gold reserves during the first nine months of the year -- the period preceding and including the gold bloc devaluation -- are published in the current monthly bulletin of statistics of the League of Nations given out today.

BERLIN, Oct. 17. -- Germany's foreign trade established several records during September, the last month before the new devaluation wave upset all calculations and forced readjustments for the future.

MONTREAL, Oct. 16. -- Alberta will apparently have to default on another bond issue on Nov. 1, an event which may be expected to give the coup de grace to the external credit of that Province. In compensation, Premier Aberhart seems likely to establish a system of social credit by Dec. 1, well within the eighteen-month estimate he made at the time of his accession to office.

Looking at the 1860 Abraham Lincoln photograph, of which the Smithsonian Institution has just acquired the negative, one can hardly blame Republicans and Democrats for both claiming him, as they regularly do by now.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 17. -- The $775,000 contents of Gloria Crest, former sumptuous home of Count and Countess Stefan Ponyatovsky and known as the "White House of Englewood," brought a total of $109,262 in an auction on the premises that ended today after having been in progress daily since Monday.

ART magazines as well as galleries have been redecorating and remodeling for the season just begun. The Art Digest, which, with the Oct. 1 issue (Vol. XI, No. 1), enters upon its second decade of usefulness, appears in fresh attire -- "new kilties and a bonnie new bonnet."

Under the leadership of motor and steel shares, stocks continued to advance in fairly heavy trading yesterday. General business conditions remain the principal factor of the market. Exceptionally good third-quarter earnings, a favorable output of steel and a sustained pace in carloadings are indicative of this trend.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17. -- Asserting that nearly one million women, or 972,000, are working in the campaign for Governor Landon, Mrs. Robert Lincoln Hoyal, assistant to John D.M. Hamilton, National Republican Chairman, declared today that it was the largest political army of women workers ever brought together.

MISS WADDELL is a gleaner in the fields of the Middle Ages, but a very special gleaner, one with the gift for discovery. With the divining rod of her enthusiasm held lightly between the balls of her thumbs, she walks ground which has been searched for centuries.

No one can charge the United States Chamber of Commerce with dealing out New Deal propaganda. Yet the routine reports of that institution this month, coming on the eve of the Presidential election, are the most convincing vindications that the policies of President Roosevelt have received.

CARDIFF, Wales, Oct. 17 (Canadian Press). -- For the second successive year Wales has proved its superiority over England at soccer. Before 45,000 cheering fans at Ninian Park today the Welsh team duplicated the 2-1 verdict obtained last year at Wolverhampton, to chalk up its ninth victory against England since the international series began in 1879.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17. -- Trading in wheat futures today in leading markets was considerably restricted. Reports of rains in Argentina and in parts of Australia took the bull edge off the markets, both here and abroad, and prices receded moderately.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- As darkness descended today upon the concrete horseshoe that is Schoellkopf Field, followers of the Cornell eleven had plenty of reason for jubilation, for the Ithacans had just completed the task of subduing a desperate, hard-charging Syracuse team, 20 to 7, and with the triumph came Cornell's first major victory since 1934.

The last meeting of the metropolitan racing season, that at Empire City, which will get under way tomorrow to run twelve days until Oct. 31, will be featured by five stake events. In all there will be $18,500 in added money, a larger sum than has been thus put up at the Yonkers Fall meeting in years.

THE 1937 edition of the Standard Postage Stamp Catalogue presents a striking object lesson not only of the enormous popularity of stamp collecting but the remarkable growth in the issuance of adhesive stamps for postal use since Great Britain brought out the first stamp of that character, the historic "penny black" in 1840.

This is the story of a 16-year-old Russian girl's adjustment to life in America. As the story opens we find Masha, her father and mother, and other refugees from the Russian revolution, watching the outline of the skycrapers against a gold and crimson sunset, from the deck of the ocean steamer as it slowly makes its way into New York Harbor.

WALTER PRICE, once the Indianapolis public school principal who did his best as the Deacon in "Run Little Chillun" and later as the slave from the South in George Abbott's "John Brown," is to emerge on Wednesday, Oct. 28, as an actor playing the role of Uncle Tom without having seen any version of "Uncle Tom's Cabin," either tented or double-bloodhounded.

MR. GIELGUD is at the roper age to play Hamlet. According to Shakespeare's reckoning, the young Prince of Denmark is 30, and Mr. Gielgud is 32. Far from being "fat and scant of breath," as his mother describes Hamlet in the fencing scene, Mr. Gielgud is slender and sound enough of wind to speak the lines like a hurricane t in his moments of anguish.

SOME time after Christmas, probably in January or February, the heavy wooden doors of the Groote Kerk, the Great Church of The Hague, will swing open to the first royal wedding they have known in thirty-five years. While the bells are pealing in the redbrick tower, the guests will flow into the old church in a stream of cocked hats, dress overcoats and jingling swords.

The first of nearly 200 sessions of the Institute of Arts and Sciences of Columbia University, which will be held this Winter and Spring, will take place tomorrow evening, it was announced yesterday by Russell Potter, director of the institute.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- Despite an expected all-time peak in the popular vote for President this Fall, Simon Michelet is convinced that this country has "the silliest election machinery you could think of."

Asserting that the reciprocal trade agreements policy was the only practical way out of the situation in which this country found itself in 1934, when we stood in imperative need of outlets for surplus agricultural and industrial products, C.G. Pfeiffer, president of the National Council of American Importers and Traders, Inc., yesterday held that continuance of the program is essential to domestic prosperity and to world peace.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- The high season at the Homestead continues. Tennis courts, golf courses and riding trails are thronged by day. To accommodate the revival of carriage driving, the construction of some new carriage roads is being contemplated.

BERLIN, Oct. 17. -- Prices on the Boerse closed firm today without having shown any particularly significant turnover. Bruderus gained 2 points in the advance of heavy industrial shares. Among the firm potash stocks Kalichemie rose 2 1/2 points.
WEST CHESTER, Pa., Oct. 17. -- Two substitute ends, Jim Schrader and Elmer Leyrer, gave Pennsylvania Military College an 8-0 victory over the West Chester State Teachers College eleven today.

WARRENTON, Va. -- Of interterest to the larger farmers and land owners of this county will be the show and sale of pure-bred cattle to be held tomorrow at the barns of North Wales Farm by the Virginia-Maryland Aberdeen-Angus Breeders Association.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 17. -- The cataloguing of the treasures in the Museo Cristiano at the Vatican, considered to be the finest collection of minor art objects in Europe, has advanced to the stage of publication, it was revealed today by Professor C. Rufus Morey, chairman of the department of art and archaeology of Princeton University.

PASADENA. RICHARD LERT has just accepted direction of the Pasadena (Calif.) Civic Orchestra, a volunteer, non-paid ensemble. Dr. Lert, a refugee from Germany, has been in California for some time. He has conducted orchestras in Berlin, Frankfort, Hanover, Darmstadt and Paris and in several American cities, including particularly San Francisco.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission reopened today the proceedings in connection with its order requiring seven Class I railroads to stop furnishing warehousing facilities at the port of New York at less than cost and extended the effective date of the order from Dec. 1, 1936, to Feb. 1, 1937.

The campaign finally has got around to the point where the trading of punches is direct and immediate. What Mr. Roosevelt and Mr. Landon say one day is pounced on the next day by Mr. Landon and Mr. Roosevelt respectively. At last each candidate openly admits that he is running against another candidate and that he reads the other fellow's speeches.

BARRING those sections where unseasonal weather continued to hold down demand, retail trade maintained or improved upon its gains over last year in the week. The South, Midwest and New England sent in the best reports. Lower temperatures were immediately followed by an upturn in sales.

A meeting to organize an association of leading investment and savings institutions sponsoring individual living trusts will be held at the Yale Club here on Tuesday at 2 P.M. Several informal meetings were held in the last month. The association is intended to provide a medium for exchange of ideas and coordination of activities, and also to compile statistics and act as a clearing house for educational and other information.

FOR the first time, I believe, in memory, Mr. O'Brien has abandoned his role of preceptor and guide. The introduction to his current anthology merely repeats his familiar principles of judgment. There is no commentary, caustic or otherwise, on the state of the British short story; no charting of prospects, no lauding of white hopes.

MOSCOW, Oct. 16. -- Not only do William Randolph Hearst's charges that the American Communist party is really supporting President Roosevelt for the present bring indignant denials here, but there are indications the Kremlin has passed down word to the Soviet press to "soft-pedal" the American election.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17. -- Villanova remained in the undefeated ranks today, gaining a 13-to-0 victory over Western Maryland at Shibe Park before 5,000 spectators.

BERLIN, Oct. 17. -- German opinion seems to regard with satisfied equanimity the situation in Danzig. Everything is going according to plan, and there is little fear of Polish diplomacy wholeheartedly taking the place of the League of Nations and attempting to bring Danzig Nazis to book.
In the final chapter of his new book, "Spending to Save," HARRY L. HOPKINS, the Federal Emergency Relief Administrator, writes this remarkable paragraph:

The injection of the issue of communism into the race between the major parties -- an issue which President Roosevelt called a "false" one -- has served to direct attention both to the strength of the Communist party in the United States and to its strategy during this campaign.

LONG after the close of the Civil War, the Virginia counties below the James River which were known as the Southside continued to suffer from complex conditions of economic depression, from which developed the Populist movement of the Old Dominion.

LONDON, Oct. 17. -- The self-imposed censorship of British editors on all news concerning the uncontested divorce action of Mrs. Ernest Aldrich Simpson, close friend of King Edward, has, up to the time of writing, been as tight as any imposed by the autocratic British Press Bureau during the World War.

WITH THE REBEL ARMY, Between Navalperal and Escorial, Spain (By Courier to Valladolid), Oct. 17. -- A formidable army of Insurgents is nearing Escorial and threatening the Spanish Pantheon from four directions. Meanwhile Madrid itself is being attacked by General Emilio Mola's army from the west and south.

Gains led in the closing prices of commodity futures here in the week ended on Friday, although hides and tin were depressed and some other staples were erratic. In the cash markets wheat, cotton, print cloths, silk, eggs, wool tops and coffee gained, while corn, oats, rye, lard, butter, hides, rubber and tin declined.
IOWA CITY, Iowa, Oct. 17 (AP). -- Illinois, heavily outweighed but far from outgamed, battled Iowa's sturdy Hawkeyes to a scoreless tie in a homecoming football game before 39,000 persons.

Although gains over a year ago were registered in retail trade here last week, the fast pace of turnover on Columbus Day was not maintained, as the recurrence of warm weather slowed up for the call for heavier apparel. Estimates put average department store volume for the half month at about 6 to 8 per cent ahead of the comparative 1935 period.

Mrs. Philip Ammidon heads a group of young women aiding in the plans for the formal opening of La Salle du Bois, at 36 East Sixtieth Street, Oct. 28, when a percentage of the proceeds of the luncheon, tea and dinner hours will be donated to the Stuyvesant Square Thrift Shop Association.

DALLAS, Texas, Oct. 17 (AP). -- Stephen F. Voorhees of New York, president of the American Institute of Architects, said in an address here today that architects and government officials are developing a plan to open the field of public architecture to private practitioners.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Oct. 16. -- Southern criminal court procedure has been impeded by the issue of Negroes on grand juries. Here murder and all other indictments have been quashed and the forming of a new grand jury must await legislation next year.

An Autumn storm of rain and wind swept up the Atlantic Coast from Georgia yesterday, uprooting trees, swamping small boats and adding to the hazards of city life by loosening signs and cornices and snarling traffic. Generally fair and cooler weather was the Weather Bureau's forecast for today.

Five years of guerrilla warfare in international monetary affairs having culminated in the downfall of the pre-depression gold standard in its last strongholds -- France, Switzerland and the Netherlands -- the leading nations have now turned to the cooperative task of rebuilding a system of ordered currency relationships.

The Board of Examiners of the public school system has announced an examination for license as school psychologist, open to men and women applicants. Nov. 13 is the final date for receipt of applications. Vacancies for school psychologist now exist in two departments of the school system.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Oct. 17. -- In a contest marked by the brilliant off tackle drives of Emilio Daddario, who gained close to 100 yards and scored his team's two touchdowns, Wesleyan's undefeated eleven registered a 12-to-6 victory over Haverford today.

The scene of the thrilling adventures recorded in this book is a fleet of former German liners, now in the custody of the United States Shipping Board and lying idle at their moorings. But strange things are happening aboard these ships -- strange and terrible things that make it difficult to find men bold enough to undertake the job of watchmen.

GEORGES CLAUDE, who made a fortune out of liquid air, synthetic ammonia and the neon lights that glow on every Main Street, and whose commercially unsuccessful attempt to extract energy from warm tropical seas was duly reported by this vigilant commentator, rose before the French Academy of Sciences recently to recount his latest Wellsian effort -- getting gold out of sea water.
When the rodeo went to Bellevue Hospital on Friday, Ray Whitley's Range Ramblers and Betty Keene, a cowgirl, went up to see John Barron, because he could not come down to see them.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Oct. 14, which included only five business days in most of the reporting centers, aggregated $7,290,000,000, or 23 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 5 per cent below the total for the corresponding week last year, which also included only five business days in most of the reporting centers.

Despite a thrilling last-period rally by New York University's vastly improved football forces, the University of North Carolina's first New York City gridiron invasion was concluded in successful style at the Yankee Stadium yesterday, hut only through the slim margin of a single point.

PARIS, Oct. 17. -- By a decree published today in the Official Journal, Premier Leon Blum created an inter-ministerial commission for "action and information abroad." Its aims are to coordinate the efforts of various organizations, including diplomatic, commercial, intellectual and tourist services, which France maintains in foreign countries.

SALEM, N.H., Oct. 17 (AP). -- Perfectly handled by the veteran Joe Rosen, Phil Bieber's Chancing held off all challengers to capture the mile and a sixteenth General Green Handicap by half a length at Rockingham Park today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17. -- Bickley Stevens of Drexel tallied nine points in the third period to enable, Drexel Tech to score a 9-0 victory over Lebanon Valley College today. It was a third victory out of four starts for the Dragons.

PETER FLEMING, accompanied by Ella Maillart (the "Kini" of this book), a Swiss girl who has already made a name for herself as a traveler in Soviet Central Asia, went up last year from China along the fringes of Tibet and into the province of Sinkiang or Chinese Turkestan.
Grete Stueckgold, soprano, of the Metropolitan Opera, is the guest soloist with the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, Antonio Modarelli, directing: WABC, 2-2:45 P.M.

Gray dawn breaking over wooded ridges.... Spirited bird dogs racing across brown and golden fields. . . . The hot scent, the frozen figure of a dog on point, the cautious flush and roar of wings.... Waving cattails and goldenrod.... Swamps and brambles and clothes-ripping briar patches....

WARSAW, Poland, Oct. 17. -- An authoritarian system of government for Poland is advocated by a powerful group of General Edward Rydz-Smigly's followers, who are founders of a new government party that soon will begin activities.

The executive council of the United States Building and Loan League recommended yesterday that the question of public housing be divorced from the unemployment problem and that government ownership and management of housing projects be drastically curtailed.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Oct. 17. -- Speaking on the subject "Education in a Changing Social Order," Dr. Frank Kingdon, president of the University of Newark, today delivered the final address at Bucknell University's annual conference on education, attended by more than 300 educators from all the Eastern States.

Confident that Tuesday's special session of the Legislature, formally called yesterday by Governor Lehman, will grant a three-hour extension of voting hours on election day, the Board of Elections put in the entire day speeding up plans to cope with an anticipated record vote in the city.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 17. -- Mrs. E. Norman Scott, who recently arrived in Greenwich after two years in Peiping, China, was entertained at a Chinese dinner given by Mrs. George McM. Godley of Long House, Valley Road, Greenwich, last night.
LAWRENCE, Kan., Oct. 17 (AP). -- The rugged, hard-charging Oklahoma Sooners cleared their first Big Six football hurdle today by defeating Kansas before 6,000 fans, 14 to 0.

SOME years ago some one remarked, in a burst of enthusiastic prophecy, that the road which Robert Edmond Jones took in the pursuit of his career would be the one which the American theatre, plodding patiently along, would eventually follow.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 17. -- Two undefeated football teams, Washington State and University of Southern California, played each other to a standstill and a scoreless tie today before 25,000 spectators huddled in the rain-soaked stands of the Memorial Coliseum.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Oct. 17. -- Trailing 7 to 0 going into the final period, Muhlenberg put on three long marches to score three touchdowns and defeat Gettysburg 19 -- 7 today in the home-coming game before 2,200.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- James P. Warburg, New York banker, who was an adviser of President Roosevelt early in his administration, but later turned against the President, will vote for Mr. Roosevelt "unless there is a fundamental change in the alignment between now and Nov. 3."

" The country," says Jack Storm, "is a nice place to visit." Whereupon his wife immediately replies: "But I wouldn't live there if you gave it to me." You can't blame them after the terrifying experiences they have gone through at Crockford, Conn., beginning with the discovery that the stranger they have transported from New Haven is dead in the rumble seat of their car.

WASHINGTON, -- With the ratio of accidental deaths reduced from one every 3,700,000 hours of exposure under the old CWA to one every 7,000,000 hours under the present WPA program, Federal work relief operations have achieved a high level of safety.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 17. -- Taking advantage of every break offered, refusing to crumble in the face of a savage Navy defense that stopped her attack cold in the second half, Yale turned back the Midshipmen, 12 to 7, today in a wildly exciting game that had all sorts of good and bad football jammed into its sixty minutes of play.

Widespread interest always attaches to the annual distribution of prizes and awards in the Carnegie International Exhibition of Modern Paintings at Pittsburgh. The 1936 show put on by Carnegie Institute opened there Thursday evening. Six nations are represented this time, as against sixteen in 1935.

With the outlook for Spring business the best since the depression, the cotton textile industry should find no cause for concern in the fact that their markets have absorbed the full two-shift production of gray goods mills for the last three months, Sidney H. Scheuer, of Scheuer Co., textile brokers and consultants, said here yesterday.

Many stories have been written of the gold rush days but few strike as human a note as this account of Seth Hosmer, who at 17 leaves his uncle's home in search of the father who, six years before, had set out for the gold country in California.

UNIVERSITY, Va., Oct. 17. -- Maryland's sturdy football team, strengthened by the return of its leading backfield star, Bill Guckeyson, who has been on the injured list for three weeks, won from Virginia today, 21 to 0. The Cavaliers were outplayed except in the third period.

The British Government, recovering from its Summer quiescence, turned its attention last week to the question of defense. In a speech at Sheffield, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, referring to the recently adopted policy of rearmament, said:

THE man who sets himself the task of writing sectional history is faced immediately with serious obstacles. A section of the country, unless its boundaries are as clearly marked as in the case of New England or of the Old South, is difficult to define, and even if boundaries can be fixed, it is still harder to find the forces which give the section its apparent unity.

The radio beacon and fog signals of twenty-nine Eastern lighthouse stations and lightships will be in continuous service daily for a ten-hour period starting tomorrow and continuing through Saturday, in an experiment designed to aid shipmasters in the synchronizing of the signals as a direction-finding factor at sea.
Various types of accidents and their prevention, particularly those pertaining to children and the home, will have a definite place on the programs of women's clubs in New Jersey this year.

MADRID, Oct. 10 (By Courier to Paris, Delayed, But Uncensored) -- Madrid is getting hungry. The only supply routes are the railway from Valencia and the Cuenca road, which goes in nearly the same direction.

As part of the fiftieth anniversary activities of the Horace Mann School the alumnae association will hold a fashion show in the school auditorium, 551 West 120th Street, on Friday at 8:15 P.M. to raise money for an anniversary, scholarship fund.
TOKYO, Oct. 17. -- The construction of machinery to eradicate border disputes was advanced by an important and probably decisive stage yesterday.

CONTAINING nine of Mr. Kyne's workmanlike short stories, this book be classified in four sets of tales: Three of the army, two of our merchant marine, two of the West and two of the thoroughbred dogs and their master.

Your critic in his notice of "St. Helena," by R.C. Sherriff and Joanna de Casalis, while commenting on the veracity, and truth of this play, its fidelity in recounting incidents so that they reveal character, (as actually presented events must) complains that the piece loses dramatic value and interest because the authors do not "let us know what they think of Napoleon."

REGULAR passenger air service between the United States and Manila will start next Wednesday, when a Pan-American clipper ship flies out through the Golden Gate at San Francisco with paying passengers for Honolulu and points west.

Officers, committee members and delegates from far and wide will assemble in New York the last week of this month for the series of meetings of the American Power Boat Association, culminating on Friday, Oct. 30, in the annual election of officers.

I confess to having read your editorial "Patents and the Courts" with the critical -- and perhaps prejudiced -- eye of a patent lawyer. THE TIMES is seemingly one of "those who hold that the patent system has outlived its usefulness and that it should be reshaped to suit the social and economic needs of our time."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct, 17. -- Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Townsend of Bryn Mawr introduced to society Mrs. Townsend's daughter, Miss Nancy Montgomery Dallam, this afternoon at a tea dance at the Bellevue-Stratford.

NO estimates are available as to the amount of settings and costumes destroyed in the recent Berlin State Opera storehouse fire. But the losses were not severe enough to interfere with the scheduled performances, which have not been interrupted.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17. -- Ten million votes will be cast by Townsendites, according to estimates by Townsend leaders. These voters, Dr. Townsend declares in the current issue of his national weekly, will control the Presidential election and swing the decision in a great many House contests.
AS we Australians listen in on broadcasts from New York I often wonder if New Yorkers ever realize on the other side of the earth people are also enjoying the same concert.

VOTARIES of decorative glass -- and there are many -- have a wide field to select from, with many old forms being rediscovered and new and pleasing designs being evolved by modern artists in cooperation with glass makers.

The spectacular Chicago Cardinals, victors over the New York Giants, 14 -- 13, a year ago on a last-minute 80-yard touchdown run by Phil Sarboe, will meet the Eastern champions of the National Football League at the Polo Grounds this afternoon with the kick-off scheduled for 2:30.

Alli Ronka is to be commended for her attempt to bring songs by eight of Finland's composers to attention at her debut recital in Town Hall last night. For the realm of the Finnish lyric has been so seldom invaded by vocalists in this country that even examples by Sibelius which figured on the program were in the nature of novelties.

PARIS, Oct. 16. -- Events in Western Europe now show clearly that communism is losing ground. After the French elections last May Communists believed they were near the dawn of a world victory. Two months later their hope had become to them a certainty.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Oct. 16. -- After William N. McNair's sudden resignation as Mayor of Pittsburgh last week, there was the spectacle this week of detectives on guard to forestall a possible attempt by his forces to seize the office for him again.
GENEVA, N.Y., Oct. 17. -Depending on power and deception, the Hobart College eleven conquered Trinity today, 26-6.

GERMANY is rapidly becoming a land of surprises which send shivers down the backs of the rest of the world. The rulers of the Third Reich have adopted surprise and the fait accompli as the best strategy in political struggle and thus are revolutionizing the old rules of politics and diplomacy in much the same way that Napoleon revolutionized the rules of warfare in his day.
ANDOVER, Mass., Oct. 17. -- Phillips Andover took advantage of a break in the third period today and defeated the Northeastern Freshmen, 7 to 0.

The Women's Division of the American Labor party issued a statement yesterday charging that Republican leaders were spreading propaganda for removing or rendering ineffective labor legislation already on the statute books in New York and other States.
A special study of students who leave school before graduation is under way as part of the State-wide Regents' inquiry into the character and cost of public education.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 17. -- The unpleasant impression created in Belgrade by the abstention of the Bulgarian delegate in the Geneva vote on the Yugoslav motion to stamp out international terrorism has been completely removed by the unqualified statement of Premier George Kioseivanoff of Bulgaria during his stay in Belgrade.

IT'S about time to warm up the candidates for the James E. Sullivan Memorial Trophy. This annual award amounts to the D.S.O. for amateur sport, and the previous winners, in order, have been Bob Jones, Barney Berlinger, Jim Bausch, Glenn Cunningham, Bill Bonthron and Lawson Little Jr.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 17. -- The Princeton freshman football team opened its season by defeating Mercersburg Academy, 7 -- 0, on University Field today.

YOUNG writers who are making their first venture into the field of fiction are in danger just now of suffering from swelled head. At any rate, they have received two unsolicited testimonials that are likely to give them a good conceit of themselves.

PARIS, Oct. 16. -- Molyneux's new collection of town clothes is a forerunner of the coming midseason. He is launching a novel and useful evening wrap for women to wear when going from one night club to another at Winter sports resorts.

STORSAND, Norway, Oct. 9 (AP) (By Mail). -- In a comfortable white villa by the sea lives Leon Trotsky, guarded day and night by the police. He was brought to the villa one sunny afternoon, and for the first time he saw the magnificent view along the Oslo Fjord.

BEAVER FALLS, Pa., Oct. 17. -- Geneva and Davis-Elkins battled through four scoreless periods in a steady drizzling rain that transformed the field into a virtual sea of mud today. It was Geneva's home-coming day game.

WHEN, last Spring, the Germans announced that they would operate ten round trips between the Reich and the United States during the Summer season, carrying passengers, mail and freight on the Hindenburg, world's largest airship, the statement was received with mixed emotions.

Mrs. Mary Childs Draper of 61 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, will give a luncheon at her home on Wednesday for members of the board of directors of the People's Institute-United Neighborhood Guild, of which Mrs. Tracy Voorhees is president.

MEXICO, D.F., Oct. 17. -- Despite Mexico's official policy that comment from here on political proceedings in other countries of the Western Hemisphere is undesirable, the leading newspaper, Excelsior, discusses the importance to Mexico of the result of the American Presidential election in an editorial this morning.
EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 17. -- The "principles" of the League of Nations were endorsed by the Pan-American Conference of Episcopal and Anglican Bishops at its closing session here today.

Bishop Manning will open the ceremony at 3 P.M. tomorrow when the cornerstone for the new $1,200,000 Eli White Memorial Nurses Home and School of St. Luke's Hospital is laid at 114th Street near Amsterdam Avenue.

EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 17. -- Two dashing Dons of the gridiron -- Don Geyer and Don Heap -- twice brought Northwestern from behind today to conquer Ohio State, 14 to 13, in a raging gridiron offensive battle. The defeat sent the Buckeyes' Western Conference championship hopes down to keep company with their thwarted national title dreams.
PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 16. -- Like his fellow-Republican, Borah of Idaho, Senator Charles L. McNary of Oregon has yet to announce unequivocal support of the Presidential candidacy of Governor Landon.

GENEVA, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- Students of Hobart College are participating in a competition designed to strengthen their bodies and sharpen their wits. This program, conceived by the students themselves, has for its object the furthering of good feeling and social intercourse among campus groups.

TOKYO, Oct. 17. -- The refusal of the police to readmit into this country the Rev. Dr. J. Spencer Kennard, American Baptist missionary, has thrown a bombshell into the missionary camp in Japan. Some allege the police have a blacklist of other American missionaries suspected of anti-war or labor sympathies.

BENNINGTON, Vt., Oct. 17. -- More than 150 men and women who gave money toward the building of Bennington College were called to the campus today for a "donors' luncheon" and to have an accounting of how their money has been spent.

After frittering away three opportunities to score on a stubborn Susquehanna eleven from Selins Grove, Pa., the City College football team punched over a touchdown with forty-five seconds left to play in the fourth qaurter yesterday.

The swimming teams of James Monroe, Textile and De Witt Clinton were the only ones to weather with clean slates the third series of dual meets for the Manhattan-Bronx-Richmond senior high school championship of the P.S.A.L., staged in the 75-foot Clinton pool yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 17 (AP). -- Mae West missed being robbed by rainutes, and eight residents of her apartment house who were victimized were thankful.

Supreme Court Justice Edward J. McGoldrick denied yesterday an application for a writ of mandamus to compel the Board of Education to reduce by fifty-five minutes daily the working schedule of teachers in vocational high schools. He took the stand that rigid time limitations would reduce the teaching profession to the status of day labor.
RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 17. -- The University of Richmond trounced the Emery and Henry eleven, 20 to 6, today, avenging defeats for two consecutive seasons.
