If all amateurs realized how easily the common Spring flowering bulbs such as daffodils, tulips, hyacinths and even the smaller things like crocuses and grape hyacinths can be prepared for Winter bloom and how certain the results are, no home would be without them.
PORTLAND, Oregon, Oct. 16. -Oregon bankers are worried at the referendum to be voted on at the November election providing for the establishment of the State owned and managed "Bank of Oregon."

Under this administration we made the poorest record in our history in recovering from hard times. Those nations who did not try to squander their way out of the depression are much further along the road to recovery than our own. They have less unemployment today than at any time since the great war ended.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17. -- The Republican National Committee demanded today that President Roosevelt corroborate or deny the statement attributed to his son James that the President intended to seek a constitutional amendment to carry out the principles of NRA.

The detective who does the plain and fancy sleuthing in this lively yarn is a strip artist -- not a burlesque queen, but a chap who draws what used to be called comic strips before the artists began to go in for crime and adventure.

MANILA, Sunday, Oct. 18. -- Before the arrival of the China Clipper yesterday Dorothy Kilgallen and I had lunch with President Manuel Quezon. We found him an active conversationalist and much interested in air transport.

BROADCASTERS measure the strength of their "voices" in watts, and ever since broadcasting started the craving has been for more and more watts. The more stentorian the transmitter the less chance of even a whisper being absorbed and lost in space.

Two distinguished Wellesley alumnae -- Ruth Baker Pratt, '97, National Republican Committeewoman from New York and a trustee of the college, and Mary W. Dewson, '98, vice chairman of the National Democratic Committee -- will sit side by side Wednesday night on the platform of the New York Wellesley Club political meeting, while a Democrat and a Republican debate the present campaign before the assembled members.
AUSTIN, Texas, Oct. 17 (AP). -- The Baylor Bears staged an amazing comeback to score three touchdowns in the final fifteen minutes today and defeat University of Texas, 21 to 18.

In a bid for the Negro vote, no longer considered the undisputed property of the Republican party, Governor Landon has assured Robert R. Church, Negro business man and politician of Memphis, of his desire to "devise some legal means which will be effective in ending" lynching.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP). -The Air Commerce Bureau reported today that a sudden turn made at "extremely low altitude" was responsible for the crash of an air liner Aug. 5 near St. Louis in which eight persons were killed.

THE seasonal avalanche of American dealers' catalogues is on. With the major auction houses tactfully veiling their intentions during the election campaign, the irrepressible booksellers have not scrupled to advertise their wares.

THE temper of the rural American Midwest has undergone a complete change. In the Presidential campaign four years ago the farmer was angry. He felt that he had been spurned, that he had asked for bread and been given a stone. But today, however doubtful, displeased or disgusted he may be, he is no longer in the mood to spill the milk.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 17. -- Mr. and Mrs. Percy L. Hance of New York were hosts tonight at dinner in the Colonnades at Greenbrier. Their guests were Mr. and Mrs. James L. Ward, Mrs. Augustus F. Kountz, Dr. Robert Emery Brennan, Ray Kemsley, A.E. Paulsen, Henry G. Dalton and Arthur J. Singer.
OMAHA, Oct. 16. -- President Roosevelt's prospects for carrying Nebraska have been visibly improved during the past few weeks.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 17. -- Expressing satisfaction with the system of comprehensive examinations, Harvard officials pointed today to a steady improvement in scholarship since its general adoption by the college in 1919.

ROME. -- As the time for the United States Presidential election draws nearer, the interest of Italians grows keener and the political philosophies at stake in the campaign are discussed in the light of the repercussions that the victory of one party or the other might have on Italy's welfare.
THE TIMES'S recent editorial "Arab Terrorism Answered" calls for a clarification of the causes and underlying factors of the present revolt.

ROUBEN MAMOULIAN is one one of those revolutionary Russians who disturb the dreams of Hamilton Fish and the Merriam myrmidons in California. He carries no bombs and he has been of Broadway and Hollywood too long to be a factor in the Third International, but he is a horn-rimmed radical for all that.

MADRID, Oct. 17 (Passed by the Censor) -- Three months to the day from the outbreak of the civil war in Spain, Madrid today was bending every effort to save the capital from drives by Rebel forces pushing in from several directions.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 17. -- Taking advantage of the misplays of the American International College eleven, Brooklyn College emerged victorious by 13 to 0 today in a contest played on a gridiron covered with water and mud.

WITH his "Scandals" in lucrative residence on the West Coast, George White is planning to go across the country any minute and have a look at it; and, as he travels, he will ponder still another work of art, as is the way of showmen.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 17. -- Blocked kicks, one by each team, resulted in a deadlock at 6-6 between the Rutgers freshmen football team and the Columbia University yearlings today on a rain-drenched field.

Andrew G. Pierce 3d, heir of a New Bedford woolen company official, left the county jail in $25,000 bail at 6 o'clock last evening, saying he was determined to seek a divorce from his wife, the former Mrs. Marion Hughes Whitehead. She caused his arrest the preceding evening in a separation suit filed last month.
LISBON, Oct. 16. -- There is every indication that if the Rebels take Madrid they will be able to dominate Catalonia and the rest of the government territory at their leisure.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- The Supreme Court of the United States mapped out this week its work for the Winter. Among the fifty-six cases in which it will hear arguments there are possibly fewer than twenty involving matters of general public interest. Seven of the cases arise under New Deal legislation.

EXETER, N.H., Oct. 17. -- In a driving rainstorm today, Phillips Exeter defeated Tilton School, 7 to 0. The only score of the game came at the outset of the second period after Exeter recovered a Tilton fumble on the 2-yard line and on the next play Bob Jackson plowed through for a touchdown.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 17. -- Pushing over two touchdowns in an early display of power and then withstanding the late onslaught of a valiant Manhattan eleven, Holy Cross turned back the Jaspers, 13 to 7, on rain-swept Fitton Field today in a grimly fought battle of mighty lines.
AURORA, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- The inauguration of William Ernest Weld as the eighth president of Wells College will take place Friday morning in the auditorium of Macmillan Hall.

An unemployed truck driver, his wife and their eight children, all of whom have been near starvation in Brooklyn since Oct. 9. when their names were stricken from the home relief rolls because the father had earned a few dollars outside, received aid yesterday afternoon from an unexpected source.
BOSTON, Oct. 17 (AP). -- A fast-starting Boston University eleven, pushing over a touchdown before the field became a swamp, defeated Washington University of St. Louis, 6 to 0, today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- A proposed report to the Interstate Commerce Commission today recommended approval by the commission of the acquisition by the Keeshin interests of the trucking business of Charles T. Durand, operating as the National Transfer and Storage Company.

In the campaign of Governor Lehman, the Democratic candidate who seeks re-election, and William F. Bleakley, his Republican opponent, the as-yet-unanswered problem of milk control will have an important effect upon the nominally Republican up-State farm vote.

A card party and tea in behalf of the McMahon Memorial Temporary Shelter for Children will he held on NOV. 24 at the home of Mrs. John D. Ryan, 3 East Seventy-eighth Street. The entire proceeds will be donated to the shelter at 128 East 112th Street which cares for children between the ages of 3 months and 6 years, whose homes for various reasons have been broken.

The return of the vogue of lavender walks, knot gardens, plots of simples and herbs and the mint pool constitutes a welcome addition to the list of hobbies for gardeners. Old fashioned as such gardens may be, once they are started interest in them never flags.

BRUNSWICK, Me., Oct. 17. -- A brilliant 50-yard dash by Jack Reed on a run-back of a punt gave Bowdoin an unexpected 6-0 victory over Williams today. Perfect interference aided Reed in his last-period run.

DUBLIN, Oct. 17 (Canadian Press). -- Germany suffered its second soccer loss in four days today when a team representing the Irish Free State turned in a 5-2 victory before 30,000 spectators. Scotland defeated the touring German team, 2 -- 0, last Wednesday.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 17. -- Several hundred alumni from all parts of the East returned to the Rutgers University campus today for an annual Homecoming Day program, which included intercollegiate sports, a dinner, an Alumni Council meeting, committee reports and fraternity house parties.

Headed by Cardinal Hayes, Catholic clergymen, prominent laymen and members of the Columbia University faculty will take part in the dedication of the new Corpus Christi Church, 529 West 121st Street, at 11 o'clock next Sunday morning.

EASTON, Pa., Oct. 17 -- Five successful forward passes in a row gave Lafayette a touchdown in the closing minutes of today's battle with Dickinson and the Maroon scored its first victory in four starts, 7 to 0.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 17. -- Notre Dame's gridiron legions swung into a touchdown march in the second half today and rolled over the Badgers of Wisconsin, 27 to 0, before a chilled throng of 25,000 spectators.

The increase in traffic recently may force the railroads to buy 150,000 freight cars within twelve months, according to Railway Age. The magazine asserts that railways and shippers "have been experiencing lately their first car shortage since 1923."

HIGH school bands throughout the country are now within tuning range of expert instruction through a series of weekly program-lessons conducted by Dr. Joseph E. Maddy, founder of the National Music Camp at Interlochen, Mich.

SEATTLE, Oct. 17 (AP). -- The University of Washington Huskies swept triumphantly along the Pacific Coast Conference gridiron trail today with a 19-to-7 victory over the Oregon State College Beavers. However, Joe Gray, "Gray Ghost" of Oregon State, and his teammates gave the Huskies a terrific battle through the first half.

SAARBRUECKEN, Germany, Oct. 17 (AP). -- Dr. Alfred Rosenberg, high priest of the Nazi Weltanschauung [World Outlook], tonight delivered a counterblast to the anti-Hitler strictures of Maurice Thorez, French Communist leader.

Once more Kathleen Moore Knight brings us a tale of Penberthy Island, somewhere near Cape Cod -- a tale of strange doings at Lost Brook Farm, the home of the Bassetts, and of sleuthing by Elisha Macomber, the selectman-detective, and others.
STORRS, Conn., Oct. 17. -- The Connecticut State eleven downed Worcester Tech, 19 -- 6, today.

Associated Gas and Electric interests have formally notified the committee representing secured debentures of the National Public Service Corporation of their wish to proceed with the petition for reorganization of the corporation under Section 77-b of the National Bankruptcy Act.

HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Oct. 17 (AP). -- Mrs. Juliette Buffington Enslow, 63 years old, daughter of Huntington's first Mayor and widow of one of the city's wealthiest citizens, was found slain in her bedroom today.

LONDON, Oct. 16. -- The British Government has adopted for its foreign policy the spirit if not the exact words of the campaign slogan "safety first" with which Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin fought and lost his electoral fight in 1929.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 17. -- H.C. McGehee's Fair Knightess, given a clever ride by Charlie Kurtsinger, nosed out J.W.Y. Martin's Dark Hope in the one-mile $5,000 added Laurel Handicap today in muddy going. E. Sachsenmaier's Roman Soldier, the favorite, was third, two lengths away from the leaders.

EVERY Saturday morning the city's railroad terminals are filled with football enthusiasts. Crowds of smartly dressed men and women, young and old alike, with university colors displayed in flowers, banners and feathers, rush here and there in last-minute preparations before boarding the "football special."

Criticism of Harlem ministers for alleged hindrance of the church youth movement and a plea for action in obtaining increased social legislation were features of the fourth annual Harlem Church Youth Conference yesterday afternoon at the Harlem Branch Y.M.C.A., 180 West 135th Street.

Three hundred and twenty-three schools and academies in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut enrolled in THE NEW YORK TIMES Constitution Essay Contest during the first two weeks of registration. The competition is open to all secondary school students in the tri-State territory and is sponsored by THE TIMES as one of its contributions to the nation-wide celebration in 1937 of the 150th year of the adoption of the Constitution in 1787.

SAVE for a brief dissertation on semi-precious stones, Philo Vance displays very little of his encyclopedic learning in this book, but to make up for this he has added a new accomplishment which may endear him to those readers who have regarded him as too highbrow to be a real he-man.

BURGESS MEREDITH, the suburban agriculturist, will be the first to admit it if he fails to "click" in his first motion picture assignment ("Winterset" for RKO) and will retire, almost with gratitude, to his Nyack farm and the comparative obscurity of the New York stage.
MADRID, Oct. 17. -- Pounded by three Insurgent columns, government militia fought desperately tonight to halt the advance closing in on the capital.

The District Attorneys of thirty-five counties in the southern part of the State, where coal bootlegged from the Pennsylvania mines has been sold, were invited yesterday by District Attorney William C. Dodge to a conference in his office next Friday.

WHO can think of the bonny Scottish hills stripped of their heather? Yet such a prospect has been disturbing the lovers of the highlands and the lowlands for thirty years now, and lately more than ever. For recent grouse bags have not come up to expectations and in many districts the reason is found in the harm done to the heather by a beetle.

Lower purchase prices and reduced cost of operations will feature the office equipment to be shown at the thirty-third National Business Show, which opens tomorrow at Commerce Hall. Eighth Avenue and Fifteenth Street. A total of 150 exhibitors will display some 2,000 items of equipment at the show, which will continue throughout the week.

WARSAW, Poland, Oct. 17. -- The Polish Foreign Office will not state what, if anything, Poland is going to do in Danzig to halt the Nazis, who are converting the Free City into a totalitarian State. It regards dissolution of the Socialist party as Danzig's internal affair.
Another step was taken last week in furthering the currency entente of the United States, Great Britain and France.

A pre-election meeting tomorrow to give opportunity for a complete discussion and explanation of the proposed New York City Charter and the Proportional Representation Amendment will be sponsored jointly by the American Woman's Association and the League of Women Voters for members and friends of both organizations.

THE screen is in the annoying predicament of having become in recent years such a meritorious institution that it dares not lapse, even for a breathing spell, into the careless methods of the past. For the exhibitors, after two years of forthright films which have brought the customers and prosperity back to the theatre, are resentful of indifferent pictures and are rebelling against the rentals charged for them by the releasing concerns.
AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 17. -- Playing before a rain-drenched crowd of 1,000 fans, Amherst scored a 41-6 victory over the Yellow Jackets of Rochester today on a muddy field.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17. -- A broadcast by Senator Vandenberg which used phonographic recordings of utterances by President Roosevelt was tonight cut off by many Columbia network stations, chiefly in the Eastern half of the country.

READING this lurid tale of an atrocious crime and its formidable aftermath, one is reminded of certain sensational American murder cases which in part the novel clearly parallels. The author has built his grim story upon the violation and murder of a 15-year-old girl of the working class, in a large Georgia city of today, her corpse flung to the bottom of an elevator shaft in the building where she has been attending business school.

While industrial movements continued steady thoughout the nation last week, trade results in some sections were spotty, particularly in the retail field, as the result of the unseasonable weather conditions. The holiday on Monday brought a heavy volume of buying, but distribution slowed down during the remainder of the week, with Fall and Winter apparel lines being especially affected.

Representative dress houses that prepare Southern resort wear lines, to be shown this week, will operate simultaneously on that merchandise and Fall and Winter garments until the end of the year, Morris Kolchin, executive director of the Affiliated Dress Manufacturers, Inc., declared yesterday.

UTICA, Oct. 17. -- Pledging a State-wide war on racketeers if he is elected Attorney General, Justice Nathan D. Perlman of New York City, the Republican candidate, speaking before the Oneida County Bar Association, said today:

LOVERS of the drama are tolerant souls and it will probably cause them no anger to learn that the most famous scene in American stage history has always been miscast. The scene? Eliza crossing the ice a short length ahead of the blood-hounds in "Uncle Tom's Cabin."

Franklin Wilson uses the peculiar situation in Minnesota to point out that we continue to use "our stupid system which permits election by mere plurality, when we boast of having government by majority rule." He proposes the alternative vote system once championed by Lloyd George.
Fordham, looking ahead to the St. Mary's game, met unexpected opposition from Waynesburg yesterday.

LEXINGTON, Va., Oct. 17. -- The University of Kentucky Wildcats, without Bert Johnson and Sands, defeated Washington-Lee's football team on the General's home field this afternoon. 39 to 7. Bob and Dameron Davis, Kentucky touchdown scoring halfbacks, led the attack.

THE Boy Scouts next Saturday will make the seventeenth of their annual pilgrimages to Oyster Bay, L.I., in honor of Theodore Roosevelt's birthday, which falls on the following Tuesday. These trips, which Daniel Carter Beard, 86-year-old National Scout Commissioner, has led since the beginning, now attract more than 5,000 Scouts.

The hand may be quicker than the eye but Colgate's razzle-dazzle style of attack held no terrors and no bewilderment for rugged Tulane yesterday as the Green Wave from the South engulfed the Red Raiders from the Chenango, 28 to 6, before a gathering of 25,000 at the Polo Grounds.

LANCASTER, Pa., Oct. 17. -- Ursinus surprised the F. and M. team by playing a 0-0 tie in an Eastern Pennsylvania Collegiate Conference game today before 4,000. Last year the Bears were crushed, 59 -- 0.

A GROUP exhibition made up of work by thirty-five American artists who are not included in this year's Carnegie International is being held concurrently in Pittsburgh, at the Gillespie Galleries. The list was arranged and the pictures were selected by A.D. Gruskin, director of the Midtown Galleries in New York.

FOUR news lines of cars for 1937 have been announced by the Buick Motor Company. They differ widely in appearance from the 1936 models. Horse-power has been increased in all models with a resulting increase in acceleration and general performance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- The Roosevelt administration's relief program has given this country "peace and rapid recovery" instead of "riots and tear-gas" declared Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, in a radio address tonight over a chain of the National Broadcasting Company.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct. 17 (AP). -- Michigan State's football opportunists remained undefeated by scoring a 13-0 victory over a sturdy but loose-fingered Missouri eleven before a homecoming crowd of 15,000 spectators today.
READING, Pa., Oct. 17. -- Albright defeated the Moravian eleven, 6 -- 0, today to register the Lions' third consecutive triumph of the season.

NANKING, China, Sunday, Oct. 18. -- Plans for joint defensive preparations against threats of external aggression were the chief matter under discussion at an important conference held in Hangchow today.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- Vassar college undergraduates fail to he excited about the coming Presidential election. In a straw vote conducted recently by The Miscellany News, student newspaper, only 521 of 1,400 students took the trouble to state their political preferences.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- The College of New Rochelle, the largest Roman Catholic college for women in the United States, will hold its founder's day exercises next Saturday.

TOPEKA, Oct. 17. -- Colonel Frank Knox called on Governor Landon today, approved his decision to go to California, declared that the party's national ticket would carry that State and challenged President Roosevelt to say whether his son, James Roosevelt, was correct in asserting that he intended to seek a constitutional amendment to make possible re-establishment of the NRA.

UVALDE, Texas, Oct. 17. -- Vice President John N. Garner declared tonight in his first speech of the campaign that the administration's program represents "the highest type of true American conservvatism" and that "the safest thing that could happen to this country is the re-election of President Roosevelt."

THE program of expansion planned by the Radio Division of the WPA Federal Theatre project in New York calls for a fuller radio schedule, a new studio and workshop, and a larger staff of players and writers. More than twenty new programs will be developed this Winter with George Asness, A. Winfield Hoeny, Frank Curran and other directing.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP). -- Two touchdown thrusts through the air in the first half gave Catholic University's Flying Cardinals a 12 its 7 victory today over De Paul.

THIS is a novel of Republican Spain which presents in its own dificult and symbolical fashion the story of a revolutionary outbreak in Madrid in which anarchist, syndicalist and Communist workers attempt to organize and direct general strike.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 17. -The transfer of the Gest library of 130,000 volumes on the Far East from McGill University to the Institute for Advanced Study here, to which the books were given last Summer, has been completed.

TORONTO, Oct. 17. -- Already the dominant factor in the world's nickel markets, Canada has discovered a new and promising nickel mining field in the Northwest territories, according to a report issued this week by the Federal Department of Mines.
The New York University cross-country team defeated Columbia, 24 to 31, yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park. Johnny Wilson of the Lions crossed the line first, with Edgar Tait of the Violet second.

MOSCOW, Oct. 17. -- The rapidly mounting anger of the Soviet Union at what it considers inexcusable dillydallying in London over intervention in Spain appeared tonight to be approaching the boiling point.

A special sale for the benefit of the Silver Cross Day Nursery will be held Wednesday at the Nearly New Shop, 917 Eighth Avenue. Useful articles of all kinds -- clothing, housefurnishings, jewelry, books and china -- are needed for the forthcoming sale.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17. -- Original drawings, water-colors, books and prints by William Blake, from the collections of Lessing J. Rosenwald and A. Edward Newton of this city, will be on public view from Monday to Friday in the Furness Library on the University of Pennsylvania campus.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Oct. 17. -- With the finishing of the third in the group of Pitt Hall buildings Swarthmore College has completed another phase of its expansion and improvement of dormitory living conditions to care for an increased student body.
READING, Pa., Oct. 17. -- Albright defeated the Moravian eleven, 6 -- 0, today to register the Lions' third consecutive triumph of the season.

ATHENS, Ga., Oct. 17 (AP). -- Rice Institute laid aside its hocus pocus against Georgia today and fashioned a 13-6 victory from alert and hard-hitting football.

BOSTON, Oct. 17. -- James Roosevelt in a statement today declared that remarks he made at Gardner last night had been incorrectly quoted. He was quoted as having said that his father planned to seek restoration of the principles of the NRA through a constitutional amendment.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- Hope that the Supreme Court will reverse itself on minimum wage legislation by upholding the Washington State statute finds not even the tiniest echo here. To the contrary, there is nearly unanimous opinion that another icy blast from the high bench will blow this new leaf from the struggling tree of social reform into the same heap where the New York law was tossed last Spring.

President Roosevelt, Andre de Laboulaye, the French Ambassador, and Count Robert van der Straten-Ponthoz, the Belgian Ambassador, have accepted invitations to serve as honorary patrons of the eighteenth Victory Ball, to be held on Armistice Eve, Nov. 10, at the Plaza.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17. -- Retail trade was very active, except in some of the heavier ready-to-wear lines, particularly women's coats, where summery temperatures discouraged purchases. Retail volume bettered last week's slightly and ran about 15 per cent ahead of last year for the larger stores.

The annual Russian Students Ball will take place on Nov. 13 in the main ballroom of the Plaza. As this Winter will mark the centenary of the death of Alexander Pushkin, the great Russian poet, the executive committee for the ball has decided to open the ball with a scene from Tchaikovsky's opera "Pique-Dame," after the story by Pushkin.

Neutrality laws are effective as a makeshift, but the task of American women is to develop collective responsibility in order to insure the neutrality of nations. This is the belief of Mrs. Arthur Brin of Minneapolis, president of the National Council of Jewish Women, named by Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt as one of the ten outstanding women of 1935.

After a long argument yesterday between the government and a defense attorney, Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey deferred until next Saturday the sentencing of Frank J. Denniston, former district director here of the United States Shipping Board, who pleaded nolle contendere to an indictment charging fraudulent income tax reports for 1931, 1932 and 1933.

ALBANY, Oct. 17. -- A series of short visits to five New York cities in the up-State region closed today President Roosevelt's campaign tour in which he traveled 5,000 miles and entered twelve States in ten days.

John V. Baptiste, 36 years old, who said he was an industrial engineer, was arraigned in Bronx Magistrate's court yesterday charged with stealing last August three valuable holographs from the Bronx home of Dr. Mather Cleveland, chief orthopedic surgeon at St. Luke's Hospital.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 (AP). -- In a game that terminated forty-four years of gridiron rivalry, Purdue walloped Chicago, 35 to 7, before 15,000 chilled spectators at Stagg Field today to remain undefeated in the Western Conference championship race.

The New York University College of Medicine will expand the work of its Department of Forensic Medicine, established three years ago to train physicians in scientific crime detection, and will open certain courses to police officers and other laymen interested in law enforcement, Dean John Wyckoff of the School of Medicine announced yesterday.

To Mrs. John D. Hertz's Count Arthur went the main portion of the prize in the $6,660 Continental Handicap over a sloppy track as the Jamaica Fall meeting closed yesterday, with 15,000 persons braving the rain. Count Arthur, the favorite at 9 to 5, received a warm round of applause when he came back to be unsaddled after crossing the line first by a length.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 17. -- Springfield defeated Rutgers, 6 to 0, today before a small homecoming crowd of 5,000. A muddy field hampered both teams, but the game was featured by the remarkable punting of Wally Pringle of the Scarlet and Warren Huston of the winners.
COLLEGE STATION, Texas, Oct. 17 (AP). -- Texas A. and M. used the air lanes to beat an eleven-year football jinx in scoring an 18-to-7 victory over Texas Christian today.

WASHINGTON, -- In a second-floor office on a short corridor of the Department of Justice Building half a dozen young men sit day after day bending over labels. The labels are advertising and commercial selling devices for whisky, gin, rum, brandy and the more exotic spirituous liquors, and the young men get weary eyes and hunched shoulders looking at them.

TOLEDO, Spain, Oct. 17 (AP). -- Spanish Insurgent infantry advanced rapidly today toward Aranjuez, on the road to Madrid, while Rebel planes bombed Castillego, a strategic railroad junction [twenty miles northeast of Toledo and only about six miles from Aranjuez].

During a recent broadcast entitled Good-Will Court a father presented a case to said court concerning his boy of 17 who, the father stated, would not go to school, would not work, and preferred to steal. The father told the judge that he thought the army would be a good place to reform the boy, and the judge agreed with him.

JOHANNESBURG, Union of South Africa. -- The rise in South African farm produce prices and government loans to distressed members of the farming community have eased a situation which, at one time, seemed extremely critical. The crisis was brought on by a devastating drought which converted large sections of the Transvaal Province almost into a desert and wiped out flocks and herds.

The initiation during the week of a far-reaching program of research in child neurology, as the result of a "very large grant" made recently by the Friedsam Foundation, was revealed here yesterday by Dr. Bernard Sachs, one of the world's outstanding authorities in the field and former president of the New York Academy of Medicine, who is the director of the new research project.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17. -- George W. Norris, former Governor of the Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank and a lifelong Democrat, stated today that he would vote for Landon for President, "believing that his views and those of his party come much nearer to Democratic principles as declared in the unrepealed Democratic platform of 1932 than do those of the present administration."

LONDON, Oct. 15. TRAVELERS have a new way to cross the English Channel -- by train. For generations they have crossed those rough waters by steamboat, and since the World War the airplane has been an added means of carrying Englishmen to France and Frenchmen to England.

THERE can be no doubt that Fannie Hurst has given her readers their money's worth in "Great Laughter." It is a long novel, nearly 500 closely printed pages, and it contains all her best-known characters and situations. They are arranged in new combinations and in slightly unfamiliar sequence, but here they are nevertheless.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 17. -- A system of proficiency examinations designed to encourage students of high scholastic aptitude has been instituted at Rutgers University, Dr. Walter T. Marvin, dean of the College of Arts and Sciences, announced today.

I cannot be hut unpleasantly amused by constantly reading of the "scarcity of experienced young actors in the theatre," when the stupid treatment accorded -- and uncertain remuneration -- just about, drive any self-respecting young fellow out of the profession.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 17. -- More than one and a half billion quarts of skim milk a year now are dried and powdered for infant feeding, confections and baking, according to George E. Wallis of Chicago, president of the Dairy and Ice Cream Machinery and Supplies Association.

BOSTON, Oct. 17. -- Practically all reports covering business conditions for the various important centers in New England continue to make cheerful reading. Retail trade is running along at an estimated level of 12 to 18 per cent above a year ago.

FOUR car manufacturers already have unveiled their 1937 models to the public and four more companies will join their ranks the coming week-end. Enough has been revealed to indicate what the public may expect in innovations and car refinements at the automobile shows next month.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- The United States is in the process of spending from $20,000,000 to $25,000,000, perhaps more, on its big quadrennial political show Unless present estimates suffer shrinkage, this year's show will be the most costly in American history.
ORONO, Me., Oct. 17. -- The University of Maine eleven, despite frequent fumbles, triumphed over a scrappy Lowell Textile team, 21 -- 0, today on Alumni Field.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 17 (AP). -- Washington and Jefferson, previously undefeated this year, lost a muddy gridiron fray to the Case School of Applied Science today, 19 to 0.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 17. -- Dr. Harlow Shapley, director of the Harvard Observatory and President of the American Association of Variable Star Observers, in an address tonight at the annual dinner of the association at the Harvard Faculty Club, reviewed the most interesting events in the astronomical world during the past year.

Librarians from Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens mill meet tonight in the Lenox Gallery of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second'Street, to l devise plans for pensions in the! Public Library system. It is expected that 1,000 persons will attend.

Mrs. William F. Bleakley, wife of the Republican nominee for Governor, will have her first meeting with Republican women leaders tomorrow, when she will be a guest at a tea and reception to be given by Mrs. Robert Low Bacon, vice chairman of the Republican State Committee, and the women members of the Republican State Executive Committee.

THE season about to open promises to be one of the most remarkable London has had for many a year. The Viennese Symphony Orchestra is expected in a few weeks and a chamber orchestra from Cologne will visit us later.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 17. -- An inspired Nebraska football team, nine points behind at the half, wrested a 13-to-9 triumph from the Indiana Hoosiers before a Dad's Day crowd of 31,000 fans in Memorial Stadium today.

In the give and take, the claims and counter-claims of election weeks, a moot point is the number of women voters who have crossed party lines, and sometimes family allegiances, to aid one or the other of the two dominant candidates for the Presidency.

Charges that the chains are driving the independent retailers out of business do not find any substantial degree of support in the preliminary United States retail distribution summary of the 1935 census, issued last week, according to retail and marketing authorities here.

HOBBY shows are sponsored by department stores, company employes, service clubs, churches and various other groups, but the "granddaddy" of them all is the Chicago Hobby Show. This was started six years ago, and commands wide interest.

Behind the growing recovery of today is a story of deliberate government acceptance of responsibility to save business, to save the American system of private enterprise and economic democracy, a record unequaled by any government in history.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17. -- The tradition of a great team's invincibility was shattered on Franklin Field today and thousands of Penn undergraduates and alumni riotously poured out on the battle-scarred turf in celebration of a dearly prized conquest of the Princeton Tiger on the sixtieth anniversary of Red and Blue football.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 17. -- Battling in mud and rain, Worcester Academy and Harvard Freshmen football elevens played a 6 to 6 tie this afternoon on Soldiers Field.

UTICA, N.Y Oct. 17. -- William F. Bleakley, Republican candidate for Governor, charged here tonight that Governor Lehman's attitude of sympathy toward the workingman was insincere and cited as proof his record on the efforts to obtain an eight hour law for State institution employes.

Careful examination shows Carlos J. Videla supports what I have said, while seeming to question it. For example: I cited destruction of Moorish universities. Mr. Videla gives the dates of the few existing Spanish universities. They were all founded after the period of destruction. Naturally, since the originals were reduced to ashes.

In a straw poll taken at Long Island University the Communist party received twenty-four votes; the Democratic party, twenty-two and the Republican party none. The poll was taken after sixty-eight students has listened to speakers in a symposium on the principles and the platforms of the various parties.

DUBLIN, Irish Free State, Oct. 16. -- The restoration of political peace in the Free State has not, as might have been expected, led to a carefree existence for President Eamon de Valera's administration. A new source of anxiety that has been manifesting itself in the past few months has been the regular succession of labor disputes and strikes, which are calling constantly for the intervention of the Ministry of Industry and Commerce.

BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 17 (AP). -- Out of the air the Bruins of the University of California at Los Angeles snatched a football victory today, 17 to 6, over their so-called "big brothers," the University of California Golden Bears. Their feat was cheered by 30,000.

THIS enormous novel, which deals with more than a decade of conspiracy, romantic love and militarism during the Thirty Years War, has been compared by Thomas Mann to "War and Peace," Herr Mann, who is usually a sensitive critic, has been much, much too generous, but it is not difficult to see why M. Durych's work should have provoked the European response it did.

It is a pleasure to know that some of the seldom sung operas are to be revived by the Metropolitan management. Some have not been given for so long, or have been given so infrequently, that many of us newer operagoers have known of them only by hearsay or have imagined their beauty from excerpts.

Isn't it about time to inaugurate a new method of legislation that would do away with the necessity of costly appeals to the high courts of our States and especially appealing to the Supreme Court of the United States for the rendering of a decision as to the constitutionality of a law enacted by Congress or State Legislatures?

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP). -- The Rev. Gerald L.K. Smith, former associate of Huey P. Long in the share-the-wealth movement, will start a "$1,500,000 nationalist front against communism" from New York Tuesday, it was announced today by Mr. Smith's representative, Harry Costello.

DETROIT, Oct. 17 (AP). -- Auburn's Plainsmen seized a last-period break to defeat the University of Detroit Titans, 6 to 0, in an intersectional battle today. Ten thousand fans braved wintry winds and overcast skies to watch the game.

DETROIT, Oct. 17. -- In a radio address tonight Father Coughlin denied that he had struck a reporter in New England, as had been reported, and denied also that he had waited in Boston to "get" the man.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- Officials at the Postoffice Department and the Government Printing Office asserted today that there was no more activity this year by members of Congress in sending out campaign material to constituents under their franking privileges than is usual in Presidential years.
Exercises commemorating the 240th anniversary of the founding of the Fordham Manor Reformed Church were held last night at the church, 71 West Kingsbridge Road, the Bronx. About 200 persons attended.

The pace in the New York art galleries continues unabated this week with more than a score of exhibitions -- several opening over the week-end and the others announced for the next day or two. A number of the shows are of unusual interest; still others mark the reopening of galleries for the season.

This story has a double moral. Fresh from the eager lips of THE NEW YORK TIMES naturalist in the Brownsville-East New York district, it teaches that the younger generation -- even among gray squirrels -- is a problem and that the country is in for a hard spell of Winter.

Ritchie Fontaine, speedy lightweight from Missoula, Mont., will meet Lew Feldman, veteran Brownsville campaigner, in the feature bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace tonight. In the eight-round semi-final Baby Casanova, featherweight and lightweight champion of Mexico, will clash with Stumpy Jacobs of Richmond, Va., while a third eight-rounder will show Baby Salvy Saban, hardpunching Greenwich Village welterweight, against Irish Jimmy Brady of Jersey City.

William Church Osborn, chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission, sent a letter yesterday to the legislative leaders of both major parties, opposing the proposed referendum on the three-platoon system for firemen as a violation of city home rule.

LONDON, Oct. 17. -- The British Treasury's insistence that the' ground for sterling be kept free is taken here to indicate that the tripartite monetary pact is nothing more than an extension of the original three-power monetary agreement following French devaluation.

Fugues held an important place in the first half of the program of Dalies Frantz, the gifted young pianist, who gave a recital in Town Hall last night. His program opened with the Bach prelude and fugue in F minor from the second book of "The Well-Tempered Clavichord.

BERLIN, Oct. 17. -- The Boerse here opened the week firm with substantial advances in steels, electricals, textiles and potashes. Thereafter until Saturday, stocks moved irregularly, heavy industrials being relatively inert except lignites and potashes, which advanced rapidly.

Making it plain that he considered President Roosevelt's trend too radical, Amos R.E. Pinchot, lawyer, publicist and outstanding liberal, yesterday announced that he had abandoned the Democratic nominee, whom he supported in 1932, and would vote for Governor Landon.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 18. -- [ Featuring the three women's fieldI hockey matches today at thel Greenwich Academy Field was the second game in which Manhattan-/ [ville won from Westchester by aI 1-to-O score. With five minutes toI go, Miss Marjorie Powers regis-] tered to decide the honors.

An order issued by Edward P. Mulrooney, State Commissioner of Correction, forbidding paid admissions at public spectacles in the institutions under his authority throughout the State, caused Sing Sing yesterday to suspend its football program.

LONDON, Oct. 17. -- Trade reports issued this week indicate that British exports are maintaining the position they held in September, which was the second best in 1936. Sales arc more active than at the beginning of the year and for the third quarter of 1936 were 6 1/2 per cent larger than a year before.

W.E. GUDE was a pioneer with his brother O.J. GUDE in the outdoor advertising business, in signboards and in electric boards. By way of the latter he helped to create the Great White Way. But it is to be noted that Broadway nowadays is not often called by its once world-famous nickname.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 18 (AP). -- Eighteen persons were injured, three seriously, in an explosion of gas-filled balloons today at the St. Mary's-University of San Francisco football game.

The Lynchburg (Va.) News in its special edition in celebration of the sesquicentennial of Lynchburg carried on its front page a picture of Senator GLASS (in his shirt-sleeves) in the composing room of his two papers placing the last "stick" of type in making up the last page.

Edward Moran, 13 years old, of 527 West Fifty-first Street, who was wounded Saturday night by a rifle bullet fired by Henry Follmer, 39, a waiter, of 862 Third Avenue, was placed under arrest last night at the Polyclinic Hospital, charged with juvenile delinquency on the complaint of Clyde Miller, owner of Ye Eat Shoppe, at 732 Eighth Avenue.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 18. -- Edward Farrell got into his automobile at 4 o'clock this morning in front of the Newark Elks Club and drove forty miles to his home in South Amboy, only to find that he would have to drive back to Newark again.

The Tri-Continental Corporation and its affiliated investment trusts: Selected Industries, the Broad Street Investing Company, Inc., and the Capital Administration Company, Ltd., reported yesterday increases in net assets in the first nine months of this year.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 18. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 76 per cent of capacity, unchanged from the two preceding weeks. The tonnage rate has been the highest since September, 1929, with the possible exception of February, 1930, when a bulge occurred, but the percentage comparison is not altogether so favorable because capacity has increased.

BURNS LAKE. B. C., Oct. 18. -- Arthur Gammon, a prospector, lay on a hospital cot here today and told how a bear had protected him from coyotes for two weeks while he dragged himself through the wilderness seeking treatment for a broken leg.

WHITE pLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 15. Figures for the four-day registration. period in the our cities and seventeen towns of Westchester County show an increase, of frem l 15 to 20 per cent throughout the county, bringing the total registration to 230,119.

Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador to the United States; Viscount Astor, Lord Bethell, Lord and Lady Greville, Sir Mark and Lady Sheldon, Sir Felix Pole, Sir John Bayley and Count Stanislaw Potocki, Polish Ambassador to the United States, and the Countess Potocki are some of the prominent persons due to arrive today from Southampton via Cherbourg on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.

" The Affair of the Scarlet Crab," by Clifford Knight, has been selected as the winner of the Dodd, Mead-Forum detective story prize contest as the best detective story entered in this contest by an American or Canadian author, it is announced by Dodd, Mead today. Five hundred detective novels were submitted.

The bards of antiquity, who are said to have fed on little more than butterfly hearts and humming-bird tongues, have been replaced by a more sturdy race of poets who admit that they appreciate good food. One of these, Joseph Auslander, was the speaker at the first dinner of the season to be given by the Gourmet Society yesterday at 1:30 at the Stockholm Restaurant, 27 West Fifty-first Street.

A landslide for President Roosevelt was predicted yesterday by James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, on his return to headquarters at the Hotel Biltmore, after having accompanied President Roosevelt on his trip eastward from Chicago.

In an effort to reduce fire hazards caused by accumulated rubbish and the storage of fuel oil, city firemen made 121,457 inspections of old-law tenements from the middle of November, 1935, to Oct. 1, of this year, Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott announced yesterday.

Fraudulent concealment of regular employment and of assets inherited from his father last August was the reason given by the Emergency Relief Bureau yesterday for the dropping from the relief rolls of John Eave, his wife and eight children.

Colonel J.E. Spingarn, president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, and a life-long Republican, came out yesterday for the re-election of President Roosevelt in a statement in which he declared the President had done more for the Negro than any Republican President since Lincoln.

MOSCOW, Oct. 18. -- The Soviet Union's withdrawal from the agreement pledging non-intervention in the Spanish civil war now appears to be only a day or two away. What form the Soviet's aid to the Spanish Government will take, whether it will consist in the actual shipment of munitions despite the distance and the difficulties of granting credits which would enable Spain to purchase munitions from other countries, is still undisclosed.

BERLIN, Oct. 17. -- The tripartite gold agreement has not affected the German markets and, in general, the influence of the international currency situation on the Boerse has abated. Nevertheless, there was continued buying this week of investment stocks.

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 17. -- The new tripartite gold agreement by the United States, Great Britain and France is explained here as supplementary to the September agreement and necessary after the French gold embargo, with Great Britain deriving the greatest benefit, as the effectiveness of the operations of London's Equalization Fund were threatened.

Prices on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced last week 20 to 27 points in contrast to losses of 4 to 22 points in the previous week. Since the middle of September active contracts have held within a range of 11 3/4 to 12 1/4 cents, declining and advancing in alternate weeks.

The country's industrial activity continued last week to present a pleasing picture. Movement of railway freight, which at this time normally reaches high mark for a year, rose to the largest weekly figure since November, 1930. This indicates that current railway net earnings must be running well beyond those which, in 1931, produced $134,000,000 above fixed charges.

The Rev. Dr. Allan Knight Chalmers, pastor of Broadway Tabernacle Congregational Church, Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street preached a sermon yesterday which he admitted was frankly political. In it he said he would "greatly regret it if the country should turn its back on what seems to me a hopeful -- though often haywire -- experiment in social progress and should elect Governor Landon."

CHARLES R. GAY, president of the New York Stock Exchange, has been contending in recent months that the 55 per cent margin requirements demanded by the Federal Reserve Board, and other governmental restrictions, have unduly restricted security trading and have made our stock market "thin" and "illiquid."

The International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, Local 3, is not discriminating against Negro electrical workers who wish to enroll in the union, as charged on Saturday by the New York Urban League, according to Bert Kirkman, president of the local.

Younger members of society, headed by Miss Ruth Mary Ruxton, are aiding Mrs. William J. Tingue and her committee in the sale of seats for the performance of "Red, Hot and Blue," the new musical comedy, the night of Nov. 4 at the Alvin Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the West Side Day Nursery.

Six hundred homeless men, recruited from New York's park benches and municipal lodging houses, have been placed in private jobs after periods of rehabilitation at Camp La Guardia in Orange County, William Hodson, City Commissioner of Public Welfare, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- Representative Robert L. Bacon of New York charged today, in a statement issued through the Republican National Committee, that the administration was increasing its payments to farmers on the eve of the national election.

Magistrate Anna M. Kross, in Washington Heights Court, sharply rebuked the police yesterday for what she described as "lawless law enforcement" in making raids on private homes without warrants and failing to obtain sufficient evidence for convictions.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18. -- The Republican National Committee today demanded from the Columbia Broadcasting System a rebroadcast of Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg's Saturday night "debate" with the recorded voice of President Roosevelt which became involved in a welter of confusion.

The committee on local candidates of the Citizens Union made public yesterday its recommendations in the contests for the Assembly in New York and Bronx Counties. According to the committee, the choices are based on qualifications of character, experience, training, ability and aptitude for the positions sought "without regard to partisan or factional considerations."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18. -- Governor Landon continues to lead. President Roosevelt in The Farm Journal's Presidential straw vote taken among the nation's farmers, according to the latest tabulation made public today. Seventeen States included in the figures give Governor Landon a plurality and the President leads in thirteen.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- Edward Winkler of the legal division of the Bureau of Navigation and Steamboat Inspection was drowned early today in a yachting accident off the eastern shore of Maryland in Chesapeake Bay, and two of his companions on beard the vessel are missing.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Oct. 18. Emerson Jennings, Wilkes-Barre civic leader, and Charles Harris of Scranton today were found guilty of bombing the automobile of Judge W. Alfred Valentine during the insurgent strike at the collieries of the Glen Alden Coal Company last year.

There is so much muddy thinking going on with reference to the political campaign now being waged that I would like to recall to your readers a most revealing letter that appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES on June 3 last over the signatures of Newton D. Baker, Lewis Douglas and Leo Wolman.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 18.-Mrs. Rudolph R. Loening gave a luncheon at the Cascades Club today for Mr. and Mrs. Samuel H. Gilbert. Mr. and Mrs. S. B. Casey's I guests were Mr. and ]Firs. George P. I Rhodes Jr. John L. Goodbodygave a luncheon for Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Allen, Mr. and Mrs. E. J. Hartman and S. Farnsworth.

Margaret Halstead, dramatic soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Association, who made her local debut in Town Hall six years ago, gave her second song recital here in the same auditorium yesterday afternoon. Miss Halstead, a granddaughter of the distinguished editor, Murat Halstead of Cincinnati, has spent much of her life in Europe, where her father, Albert Halstead, held important posts in the American diplomatic service.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 18 (AP). -- The favored St. Mary's football team was held to a scoreless tie by the University of San Francisco in an upset today. The outcome delivered a crushing blow to the national championship hopes of the Gaels just before their departure for New York to meet Fordham next Saturday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18. -- Hogs sold at $10.45 a hundredweight in the middle of last week in the local market. The opening on Monday was $10.40, and the lowest was on Friday at $10.25. A week ago the top was $10.55 and the close $10.50. A year ago the top was $10.90 at the opening and $10.70 at the close.

Denouncing charlatans in religion and quacks in medicine, the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish, president of the Associated Clinic, conducted by the Brooklyn Church and Mission Federation at Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Clinton and Montague Streets, Brooklyn, declared yesterday morning in a sermon there that it would be impossible for either physicians or ministers to heal every type of illness.

Three hundred officers and men of the First Battalion, New York Naval Militia, heard their chaplain, the Rev. W. Jusserand de Forest, denounce communism at their annual church service yesterday afternoon in St. Stephen's Church, Sixty-ninth Street, west of Broadway.

Subject, of course, to the whims of the theatre managements, the schedule of the film fare for the current week runs something like this: "Rakoczi Indulo," a Hungarian film with Paul Javor, opens today at the Hungarian Playhouse at Eighty-first Street and Third Avenue.

PARIS, Oct. 17. -- The movement of French commodity prices since the recent devaluation of the franc has been sharply upward. The wholesale price index for the week ended on Oct. 10 was 438, compared with 426 on Oct. 3 and 402 on Sept. 19.

Between the beginning of 1933 and July 1, 1936, the Jewish population of Germany decreased from approximately 517,000 persons to about 405,000, according to figures sent by Dr. Michael Traub of Berlin, director of the Palestine Foundation Fund of Germany, to the United Palestine Appeal and made public yesterday by the latter group.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18. -- Interest in oats here was limited last week. Processors were moderate sellers on bulges, presumably hedging against purchases of the cash grain. New interests were lacking. Trade largely professional. Futures closed 1 to 1 1/4 cents a bushel lower, with December the weakest at 40 5/8 cents.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Oct. 18. --Miss Betty Harris of Port Chester was selected as champion exhibitor in the first annual Westchester amateur horse and pet exhibition on the grounds of the Kentucky Riding Academy today. The youngsters of Westchester came into their own in this interesting event for girls and boys not over 18.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 18. -- Governor Hoffman is expected to call a special session of the Legislature after the general election next month to receive the report of the Commission on Revision of the Laws, now practically completed, and to consider the State Social Security Commission's proposal that New Jersey test in the United States Supreme Court the unemployment compensation provisions of the Federal social security program.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 18. -- William F. Bleakley, the Republican candidate for Governor, came out flatly today for "full State aid for education" and for the "immediate restoration of salary cuts" for teachers.

Blaming a freedom from prejudice for that lack of conviction which has caused the ruin of German universities, the Rev. Dr. Gould Wickey, executive secretary of the board of education of the United Lutheran Church in America, told students of Columbia University in St. Paul's Chapel yesterday morning that prejudices are important in a progressive world.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct. 18 (AP). -- Pounding back with an unbelievable finish after the Detroit Lions rallied to take a fourth period lead, the Green Bay Packers fought their way to victory over the National Football League champions today before 13,500 spectators.

SCRANTON, Pa., Oct. 18 (YPL-Scoring twice in the third period after trailing 6 -- 0 at the half, the football team of St. Mary's University of San Antonio, Texas, registered a 13-to-6 victory over St. Thomas College in their intersectional duel before 6,000 today.

In historic St. Paul's Chapel on lower Broadway, with the grains, fruits, vegetables and leaves of Autumn and British and American flags and uniforms lending a colorful setting, the fifteenth annual observance of the traditional British harvest festival was held yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- The Bureau of Mines recommended today that the daily average production of crude oil throughout the country should be 2,870,300 barrels in November to care for the expected demand. This figure was 28,000 barrels higher than the recommendation for October, because no withdrawal from crude oil stocks was recommended.
PARIS, Oct. 9 (By Mail). -- Hats shaped like East Indian war shields or embroidered like field marshals' helmets sound a military note in new French millinery.

Assured by officers of their citizens' committee that the city administration views sympathetically the creation of a pension system for librarians here, 300 library workers voted last night to go before the Board of Estimate and seek admission to the State pension system.
CLEVELAND, Oct. lg (2P). -- ]oston, the unbeaten leader of the new American Professional Football Leas%is, defeated {:he Cleveland Rams, 9 to 0, today.

ROME, Monday, Oct. 19. -- Fire aboard the Italian motorship Vulcania, which requested assistance shortly after having sailed from Naples for New York, was reported extinguished today in a message from the vessel's master.

Communism seeks to destroy organized government and to lower the dignity of man, the Rev. Francis X. Talbot, editor of America, a Jesuit weekly, declared yesterday at the communion breakfast of the Giuditta Council of the Cenacle of St. Regis at the Hotel Biltmore. The 500 young women in the organization, received communion at a mass celebrated by Mgr. J. Francis A. McIntyre, Chancellor of the Archdiocese of New York.

VIENNA, Oct. 18. -- Today witnessed the triumph of Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg as personal dictator in Austria with a big parade of the Fatherland Front on the Schmelz parade ground, where the late Emperor Franz Joseph used to review his imperial forces every Spring.

The New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor helped 16,596 persons in 4,361 families to regain self-support and reached approximately 37,000 others through its health centers, medical and dental clinics and nutrition service during its ninety-third fiscal year ended on Sept. 30.

MADRID, Oct. 18. -- In Madrid, with General Francisco Franco's armies approaching the city from three sides, the daily round continues for the rank and file of citizens. But at its heart is a nervous hurry that betrays a crisis. Below the surface Madrid is near to being a madhouse.

The current dance season has begun early to produce a congestion of events, for yesterday's schedule contained no less than four performances. Two of these were by the Jooss European Ballet in its final Manhattan appearances at the Alvin Theatre, one was the New York debut of Harry Hamilton at the Guild Theatre, and the other was the first solo recital hereabouts of Laser Galpern in the Carnegie Chamber Music Hall.

BERLIN, Oct. 17. -- German bankers continue to affirm that any devaluation of the mark would not be real unless accompanied by a complete freeing of the present transfer arrangements. This is out of the question at present. Nevertheless, there is unofficial talk of a partial liberation of payments to foreign countries in exchange for an acceptable consideration.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 18. -- Mrs. Ida L. Churchill, still firm in the belief her Korean servant had nothing to do with the poisoning of two of her relatives, critically ill in the White Plains Hospital, was under the care of a nurse and a physician today in the latter's home, the victim of a nervous upset over the situation.

The array of foreign teams in this country to compete in the third triennial tournament of the International Federation of Women's Hockey Associations, scheduled to start at the Philadelphia Cricket Club Wednesday, was increased to five with the arrival last night of the Irish and Scottish contingents on the S.S. Transylvania of the Anchor Line.

One must always make allowances for the necessary haste of interviewing visitors arriving from foreign shores. But there are several inaccuracies in the account of an interview with me published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 13 which I feel require correction.

Fred King, Hobart fullback and co-captain, tallied eight points in his team's victory over Trinity on Saturday and is showing the way in the individual scoring in the East. King has five touchdowns and six conversions for 36 points, six more than his nearest rival, Monk Meyer of Army.

LISBON, Portugal, Oct. 19. -- Spanish Rebel troops, continuing their sweeping advance, today broke through the Loyalist secondary defenses outside Madrid and tonight were only eighteen miles due south of the capital, the closest they have yet been.

The church has fallen into disrepair and is sorely in need of rebuilding, the Rev. Charles C. Cole said yesterday morning, but it is foolhardy to say that it will not overcome this crisis even as it did on previous occasions. Mr. Cole delivered the sermon at the Grace Methodist Episcopal Church, 131 West 104th Street.

The Episcopal Church of St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie, standing, according to its records, on the oldest continuous church site on Manhattan Island, at Tenth Street and Second Avenue, where in 1660 Peter Stuyvesant established a chapel for his farm workers, celebrated yesterday the 137th anniversary of its incorporation and the 344th anniversary of the birth of New York's first Governor.

Disbarment of a New York lawyer is in the hands of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court. The charges are usually referred by it to a referee, who holds a hearing on them and makes a report to the court. Ordinarily these hearings are private. The theory appears to be that if a lawyer is unjustly accused and therefore cleared, it is an injury to him to have any of the facts made public.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 18. -- Miss Mollie P. Collum, who recently opened her cottage here, entertained tonight with a dinner for her house guests in the Colonnades. Among those present were Mr. and Mrs. William Walker Kennedy, Miss Elizabeth Churchill, Melville P. Hall and Frederick Narryat of New York.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 18. -- If experience counts, the Long Island Field Hockey Association should have one of its most successful campaigns, for the selection committee today picked eight of last year's first team and three former reserves for its first all-Long Island eleven.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18. -- Eight main requirements advocated by the American College of Surgeons as being "the most conducive to the proper care of maternity patients" and in the material lessening of mortality and morbidity were set forth here tonight on the eve of the opening of the twenty-sixth annual clinical congress of the college by Dr. Malcolm T. MacEachern of Chicago. associate director.

The Council of Fraternal and Benevolent Organizations, consisting of delegates from 500 societies in New York City, voted at a meeting yesterday afternoon in Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, to organize a volunteer committee to solicit funds for the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, which will open a campaign next month to raise $3,000,000.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Oct. 18. -- A smooth-striding 19-year-old Manhattan errand boy, Victor Dirgela, captured the 15,000-meter metropolitan A.A.U. championship today in a thrilling running duel over the pavements of Long Beach before 5,000 persons.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Oct. 19. -- Japanese newspapers here publish reports on the conference of Chinese leaders at Hangchow Saturday which indicate the impossibility of an agreement coming from the negotiations, set for today, between Foreign Minister Chang Chun and Shigeru Kawagoe, the Japanese Ambassador.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 18. -- Ken Strong led the New York Yankees to a 13-0 victory over the Syracuse Braves in an American Football League game today before a crowd of 4,000.

PARIS, Oct. 18. -- Any danger that the Radical Socialist party, which is meeting at Biarritz in its annual congress on Thursday, might be led, as some hoped and others feared, to cut loose from the Popular Front and destroy Leon Blum's government was parried today by the Premier.
BUFFALO, Oct. 18. -- The Canisius College eleven defeated St. Vincent, 19 -- 0, today to score its third victory of the season.
FITCHBURG, Mass., Oct. 18. -- James Roosevelt, son of the President, giving what he said was his personal opinion in reply to a question at a Democratic forum here today, said:

For the first time in figure skating history the national championships have been awarded to a club west of the Alleghanies. At the meeting of the executive committee of the United States Figure Skating Association at the Bar Association Building last night, it was voted to hold the national events for seniors, juniors and novices in the new Chicago Arena, under the auspices of the Figure Skating Club of Chicago, on Feb. 12 and 13.

The New York Giants plumbed the depths of ineffectiveness and helplessness in the first half of their game with the Chicago Cardinals at the Polo Grounds yesterday, but came whipping hack with the inevitability of a boomerang in the last two quarters, played the Cards off their feet with a whirlwind attack and won, going away, 14 to 6.

BOMBAY, India, Oct. 18. -- Troops of the Durham Light Infantry patrolled the streets of Bombay tonight after savage Hindu-Moslem rioting had taken a toll of fifty killed and 490 injured during the last four days. Troops swept through the deserted streets littered with debris from the day's fighting and helped restore confidence to an uneasy city.

PETER FLEMING, the "Brazilian Adventure," "One's Company," travel book writer, is back on the publication lists today, this time with a report of what he insists was a pleasant journey on yak-back, camel-back, horse-back, in third-class Chinese railroad cars, and on foot, through 3,500 miles of Central Asia, with much of the route made dangerous by undeclared but vicious civil war.

The city's Independent Subway System, representing a total expenditure of $696,943,947 up to June 30,1936, earned during the fiscal year ended on that date a total of $2,516,844 for the capital reserve fund, established to meet depreciation requirements and the interest and amortization on city debt incurred through construction of the lines.

A comprehensive, adequately financed plan for the care and prevention of mental illness in this city, including "greatly increased facilities for hospital observation and treatment of children with behavior problems before they get into the realm of delinquency and mental disease," was urged yesterday by the New York City Committee on Mental Hygiene of the State Charities Aid Association.

DES MOINES, Oct. 18. -- President Roosevelt's prospects for carrying the farm States west of the Mississippi have been greatly increased by his campaign trip into this section if the standard barometers of political opinion are to be believed.

Consistent buying activity was noted in the wholesale market last week, with the greatest interest noted in ready-to-wear. Black-and-white dresses were ordered generously for November selling. Street dresses sold in wool and silk, and some interest was shown in street-length metallics for undercoat wear.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- The Republican National Committee declared today that the special Senate committee investigating campaign expenditures was attempting to intimidate employers who urged their workers to vote the Republican ticket, while it ignored alleged attempts of relief officials to force WPA workers into the Democratic camp.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18. -- An appeal to this country to be on guard "against those who would pit one religious or racial group against another" was voiced tonight by Governor George H. Earle of Pennsylvania, who spoke at the opening session of the annual convention of Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization of America.
BERLIN, Oct. 18. -- Statuary in Germany is becoming light-headed under the stress of Adolf Hitler's new four-year plan.

Despite Mayor La Guardia's anti-noise campaign, police of the city found themselves powerless yesterday to aid the hundreds of indignant citizens who have protested in the last few days the noises made by cruising sound trucks blaring forth the virtues of political candidates.
ELIZABETH CITY, N.C., Oct. 18 (AP). -- Atlantic City amassed 61 1/4 points today to win the team of four trophy in the national moth-boat regatta.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 18. -- A parade from the Pasadena Station and a public reception in his hotel here will precede Governor Landon's address at the Coliseum.

Although the week-end's extensive and far-reaching scholastic football program was curtailed somewhat because Saturday's unfavorable weather conditions necessitated many postponements, numerous results of special significance were recorded despite the fact that there was a scarcity of major upsets.

At about this stage in a Presidential campaign one ancient rite is always solemnly performed. It is the counting of noses in the streets and at public meetings. As in duty bound, chairmen of committees and political reporters point to the great crowds which run after and cheer a candidate as a sure sign of his coming election by an overwhelming vote.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Oct. 18. -- After an extremely long day of competition, Gauner v. Fleesensee, George McKay Schieffelin's smooth black miniature, was named the best dachshund as the fourth field trials of the Dachshund Club of America were held on the estate of Gerald M. Livingston today.
BOMBAY, India, Oct. 18. -- British troops were called into action today to surpress mass rioting between Hindus and Moslems stretching into the fourth day.

HYDE PARK, Oct. 18. -- With his ten-day campaign tour into the West just concluded, President Roosevelt turned today to plans for a two-day invasion of New England, in which he will seek the electoral votes of Rhode Island, Massachusetts and Connecticut.

Offering will be made today of one issue each of bonds and preferred stock of the Cumberland County Power and Light Company aggregating $10,500,000. Proceeds from the sale of these securities will be used to redeem an issue of higher coupon bonds.

Denouncing communistic thought as selfish and self-absorbed, the Very Bey. Mgr., J. Francis A. McIntyre, Chancellor of the Archdiocese of New York, advocated yesterday daily reading of the Bible as an antidote to it and to the "sophistication of the modern idea".

Some time having elapsed since "Sailor, Beware!" first put to sea, Kenyon Nicholson and Charles Robinson have taken "Swing Your Lady!" out of an adjacent cabinet. It was put on at the Booth last evening with a good deal of comic energy.

Georges Barrere, flutist, and his Little Symphony Orchestra yesterday inaugurated the first of a series of late Sunday afternoon "pop" concerts at the American Music Hall. The audience was small but its enthusiasm equaled that of a large assemblage.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 18. -- The St. Anselm eleven came from behind to defeat Providence College, 7 to 2, today in a game postponed from yesterday. The losers were the first team to score on St. Anselm this season.

Although the flask for more than a decade has been considered by many raccoon-coated football rooters as part of their traditional equipment, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, opened a campaign yesterday to end drinking at intercollegiate gridiron contests by banning liquor at games under the university's auspices.
TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 19. -- The Nichi Nichi correspondent at Nanking lists Japan's seven demands on China as follows:

ALBANY, Oct. 18. -- Confident of re-election after an initial swing through the Southern Tier of counties, Governor Lehman mapped final plans today for another week of up-State campaigning, during which he will adopt an aggressive attitude toward William F. Bleakley, his Republican opponent.

VENICE, Italy, Oct. 18. -- Two strong earth tremors shook Venice Province and a wide area surrounding this morning, doing extensive damage and causing loss of life. Venice was rocked twice by the quake.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- Praise of what it called "the Hull trade program" was given by the Foreign Policy Association in a report made public today, written by David H. Popper of its research staff. The report held that tariff reductions have been handled with "such caution and technical skill that it appears no efficient industry has been substantially injured."

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. l8. -- Despite the Columbus Day holiday on Monday, the volume of trading in the cotton futures market here last week was fairly brisk. Traders complained, however, of the absence of the speculative demand usual at this season which helps materially to absorb the customary hedge selling incident to the movement of the crop in volume and the large spot transactions.
MANILA, Oct. 18. -- Another thirty hours will find this traveler again aloft, beginning the second half of his trip around the world.

Communism was denounced in many sermons yesterday afternoon by Roman Catholic priests at rallies for members of Holy Name Societies throughout the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, covering all Long Island.

BERLIN, Oct. 17. -- German exporters are seeking increased markets in Russia while political leaders continue their almost daily attacks on communism and the Moscow leaders. The anti-Soviet drive was begun by Chancellor Adolf Hit ler at the National Socialist party congress in Nuremberg last month.

Sation and Miss Merriment, rated at the top in the sprinting division, will clash in a field of seven as the Empire City meeting, last of the Jockey Club season, opens this afternoon. The former is top weight of the eligibles for the $4,500 New Rochelle Handicap, which will feature a schedule of six races.

The New Deal has had so much in common with Socialist policies that for the President to have "strong support among the several varieties of collectivists is only natural," said Borough President Raymond V. Ingersoll of Brooklyn last night.
BOSTON, Oct. 18 (AP). -- The Boston Redskins' new offense clicked for a 17-7 triumph over the Philadelphia Eagles in a National Football League contest played today before 4,000 at Fenway Park.

A proper understanding of the real issues of the present campaign is hindered by what may be termed the anemia of the English tongue. Our language with its over 400,000 words fails to provide descriptive names for the wholly new attitudes assumed by the personalities who tread the political stage.

The foreign exchange market showed comparative steadiness last week. Business was in fair volume, representing as it did buying by commercial interests in preparation for legitimate requirements, coupled with covering by "shorts" who had overstayed the market in anticipation of lower values.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18. -- Industrial and distribution problems will be discussed by national leaders at a two-day conference of business men of this area that will open tomorrow in the Manufacturers and Bankers Club. The conference has been planned by the Philadelphia Chamber of Commerce, which expects an attendance of more than 1,000 persons.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 18 (AP). -- In view of intensive recent buying a slight decline in demand is expected in the steel industry, although backlogs are ample to cushion the drop, the magazine Steel said today.
ALBANY, Oct. 18 (AP). -- Northern New York lay under a blanket of snow today after sinking temperatures brought a new reversal in a week of quick-change weather.

GREAT NECK, L. I., Oct. 18. -- A powerful aggregation representing the Meadow Brook Club of Westbury today defeated Deepdale and Piping Rock in the second annual triangular team golf matches for the Walter P. Chrysler Trophy at the Deepdale Club.

TOPEKA, Oct. 18. -- With misgivings among some of his advisers, but with none of his own. Governor Landon started at 7:30 tonight for Los Angeles in an attempt to win the twenty-two electoral votes of California, conceded to President Roosevelt until recently by most political observers.
