PITTSBURGH, Oct. 18 (AP). -- The legal phase of industry's campaign to coordinate the nation's knowledge of silicosis and other occupational diseases was summarized today in a report disclosing sharp conflict in the courts and Assemblies of the States.
GARDINER, Me., Oct. 18. -- On Gardiner's City Common, where Edwin Arlington Robinson played in his youth, a tablet to the poet was unveiled today in the presence of more than 500 persons.
STRASBOURG, France, Oct. 18 (AP). -- President Albert Lebrun invited Germany's friendship in a speech today at dedication of a monument to Strasbourg's World War dead.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 18. -- The Pittsburgh Americans made an artistic success of their home inaugural in the American Football League at Forbes Field today, when they came from behind in the third period to push over the winning touchdown and capture an exciting see-saw game by a 17-13 margin from the Brooklyn Tigers. About 2,000 fans watched the contest.

ROME, Oct. 18. -- Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano is expected to leave tomorrow for Berlin, where on Tuesday he will discuss with Chancellor Adolf Hitler and other German leaders the principal Italo-German problems now pending.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- Since its establishment, the Public Works Administration has pledged itself to buy about $962,000,000 worth of bonds issued by States, cities and counties to cover their share of the cost of construction of PWA projects, Secretary Ickes announced today.

Bronx apartment properties held the center of realty trading interest over the week-end. Several private dwellings in that borough also figured in deals. A corner building site was reported assembled on Marion Avenue.

Thronging the grand ballroom and balconies of the Hotel Astor, more than 4,000 persons attended last night a military benefit ball sponsored by the New York County District Council of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States.

Governor CURLEY of Massachusetts demonstrates in a long advertisement that he has given "due recognition of "the rights of the newer races to con- "sideration in appointments to posi- "tions of responsibility and of prom- "nence." From Armenian to Zulu, he has left no deserving race, ancient or modern, in the cold.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 17. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 83.8, which compares with 83.8 the week before, 84 two weeks before, 84 three weeks before and 84.1 four weeks before.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 18. -- The announcement late last week by R.-K.-O. Radio that Jesse L. Lasky would join its producer ranks, and that his first production would bring together Lily Pons and Nino Martini, opera stars with Hollywood leanings, brought forth immediate protest from the producer, and Miss Pons as well.

The Rev. Dr. John T. Reeve of the South Presbyterian Church, Syracuse, N.Y., is scheduled to be elected Moderator of the Synod of New York tonight as the annual conference opens in Brooklyn. Tomorrow's session will launch a campaign to guarantee a minimum salary to every minister in the State.

For years Sam Byrd chewed turnips and bounced a rubber ball against the Tobacco Road home of the worthy Jeeter Lester, Tiring of that -- but not until he had outlasted a whole series of Jeeters -- he decided to ally himself with the Walter Hampdens of this world, and become an actor-manager.

In the rain and mud that prevailed generally throughout the country, football's foundation slid away on Saturday, leaving behind a scene of desolate wreckage of championship hopes in which were buried the beautiful theories of the assayers of form.

PARIS, Oct. 17. -- The report of the Bank of France dated Oct. 9, shows an increase of 5,000,000,000 francs in its gold reserve. The mere fact that this entry for gold is a round figure without any fraction of a billion proves that it does not correspond to operations on the market by the equalization fund, so it is impossible to reach any precise conclusion from such data.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 17. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 83.8, which compares with 83.8 the week before, 84 two weeks before, 84 three weeks before and 84.1 four weeks before.

In the rain and mud that prevailed generally throughout the country, football's foundation slid away on Saturday, leaving behind a scene of desolate wreckage of championship hopes in which were buried the beautiful theories of the assayers of form.

PARIS, Oct. 17. -- The report of the Bank of France dated Oct. 9, shows an increase of 5,000,000,000 francs in its gold reserve. The mere fact that this entry for gold is a round figure without any fraction of a billion proves that it does not correspond to operations on the market by the equalization fund, so it is impossible to reach any precise conclusion from such data.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 18. -- Argentina has begun diplomatic conversations designed to organize the Latin American republics for a united attempt to save the lives of hundreds of Spaniards who have sought refuge in South American States' embassies and legations in Madrid.

The port interests of New York and New Orleans, which are engaged in a bitter fight over rail rates between the Middle West and their rival waterfonts because of their effect on export shipments, will be united in opposing ratification of the proposal to develop the St. Lawrence waterway if the matter comes before the next Congress.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18. -- Bullish sentiment rules in the world's wheat markets and prices here moved upward last week to around new high levels, or to within a fraction of them. While there was liberal buying late in the week, the finish was at moderate reductions from the top price levels, with wheat off 3/8 to 1/2 cent a bushel, and 3/8 cent to 1 1/2 cents in outside markets, the latter on Duluth durums.

In a letter to THE TIMES Mrs. Marie Collins Rooney states that the new charter would "set up a council, the election of which would be on a proportional basis. This would eliminate the district idea, as we now have it."

Registration in thirty-six up-State cities and towns, where personal registration is required, shows an increase of about 10 per cent over the figures for the same communities in 1932, a tabulation showed yesterday. Registration there closed late Saturday night.

ROSLYN, L. I., Oct. 18. -- Arthur Williams, who is at Brook Corners, his place in Roslyn Harbor, for the Autumn, gave a luncheon today in honor of former Justice and Mrs. Morgan J. O'Brien of New York.
Connecticut's sportsmen will take to the brightly painted woods and fields tomorrow, twenty-four hours after the opening of the upland game season in New York.

Special services commemorating the 240th anniversary of the founding of the Fordham Manor Reformed Church, 71 West Kingsbridge Road, the Bronx, were held yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Dr. Theodore F. Bayles, Professor of Homiletics at the New Brunswick Theology Seminary, preached the anniversary sermon.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Oct. 18. -- Patrick Cardinal Hayes, Archbishop of New York, presided at a solemn pontifical mass in St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church here today, marking the centennial of the local parish. The Most Rev. Stephen J. Donahue.

In his several capacities as designer, director and producer, Norman Bel Geddes starts his season tonight with "Iron Men," which is otherwise the work of Francis Gallagher. The Longacre Theatre will be its home and, if the Geddes tradition runs true to form, it will contain a pretty spectacular setting -- in this case, nothing less than a skeleton skyscraper.

William J. Colbert, 25 years old, a rookie patrolman of three months, realized for himself the desire of hundreds of other young Police Department appointees early yesterday morning when, after several days of personal detective work, he arrested Edward Young, alias Edward Brandt, 27, who escaped Oct. 8 from Comstock State Prison where he was serving a fifteen-year term for robbery.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- The first regulations of the United States Maritime Commission, the functions of which will become operative Oct. 26, were made public today. They concerned the manner of registration with the commission of officers, agents, attorneys and employes of shipbuilders and ship operators who have business with the commission.
LONDON, Oct. 18. -- Germany has hammered still another nail into the coffin of the proposed Locarno powers' conference, it became known tonight.

The essence of Mr. HOOVER'S sharp criticism of the Roosevelt Administration's bookkeeping is, first, that it employs methods which conceal the total amount of the Government's expenditures, and, second, that it particularly conceals a recent rise in routine costs, wholly aside from "emergency" outlays.

PARIS, Oct. 17. -- The new tripartite gold agreement is considered here as a factor the importance of which need not be overestimated, but rather as a measure which was absolutely indispensable in order to avoid a chaotic state of the foreign exchanges which, if measures had not been taken, would have been the consequence of the suppression of the free circulation of gold in the last countries where it still existed.
CANEVA DI SACILE, Italy, Monday, Oct. 19. -- Approximately thirty square miles of Northeastern Italy were dotted with ruins today, as a result of yesterday's sharp earthquake.

ALBANY, Oct. 18. -- Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, today made public a list of persons whom he has requested to attend a conference on minimum-wage legislation on Friday, Nov. 6, at the State Department of Labor offices, 80 Centre Street, New York City.
CANEVA DI SACILE, Italy, Monday, Oct. 19. -- Approximately thirty square miles of Northeastern Italy were dotted with ruins today, as a result of yesterday's sharp earthquake.

ALBANY, Oct. 18. -- Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, today made public a list of persons whom he has requested to attend a conference on minimum-wage legislation on Friday, Nov. 6, at the State Department of Labor offices, 80 Centre Street, New York City.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 18. -- The George N. Clemson Memorial Challenge Trophy, chief award in the open all-age stake of the first field trials of the Women's Field and Bench Club, was captured today by the white and liver pointer dog Elstone Spring owned by J.A_ Dunn of Philadelphia and handled by Mrs. Frank H. Dayton of this city.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 18. -- Eighteen crew members and a woman passenger of the Canadian ship Sand Merchant were drowned last night when the 252-foot sand-sucker rolled over, in a fifty-mile gale which swept across Lake Erie, fourteen miles northwest of Cleveland.

Construction activity in New York, as measured by the estimated cost of work for which permits have been filed with the Departments of Buildings in the five boroughs, is running 62 per cent ahead of last year.

From the beginning of this Presidential campaign there was no doubt that it would cut deeply into old party allegiances. Several prominent Democrats early made it known that they could not vote the party ticket this year. A smaller number of Republicans announced that they had been won over by the Roosevelt policies.

William B. Bell, chairman of the Republican National Finance Committee, in a letter sent out appealing for funds, expresses the belief that "we have a far better chance to win this campaign than most of us have dared to hope."

CHICAGO, Oct. 19. -- More than $4,000,000 has been spent by the Republican National Committee since the Cleveland convention. This will be shown in the report of C.B. Goodspeed, treasurer of the committee, which will be filed this week with the clerk of the House at Washington.

Two famous thoroughbreds bade farewell to the strife of the race course as Empire City began its Fall meeting yesterday, one to take up the pastoral life in the Bluegrass of Kentucky while the other went to whatever Valhalla is reserved to heroes of the turf when they pass on. In the featured New Rochelle Handicap the veteran Sation broke his leg while charging in full stride through the stretch and had to be destroyed.

Members of the Fulton Riding Club, holding a cocktail party yesterday to celebrate the improvements to the Central Park bridle paths, were less jubilant when William R.C. Wood, director of maintenance of the park, informed them that if the present budget cuts go through the maintenance of bridle paths will be discontinued.
Senator Vandenberg, in an interview at Republican national headquarters here yesterday morning, said:
Lew Feldman, veteran campaigner from Williamsburg, defeated Ritchie Fontaine of Missoula, Mont., in the feature bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

After fuller consideration, the European chancelleries are apparently less disturbed than at first about the effects of Belgium's unilateral declaration of intention to return to its pre-war status of neutrality. That announcement of "a policy exclusively and entirely Belgian," made by King LEOPOLD III last Wednesday at the first Cabinet meeting over which he presided, is now interpreted as an indication of a new long-range orientation rather than as a sharp break with France.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 19. -- Larry Kelley, Yale's brilliant end, found himself in the spotlight today as the author of a football play that promises to be discussed for many weeks to come -- but neither the Elis' captain nor Head Coach Ducky Pond wanted any credit for it.

ON BOARD THE LANDON SPECIAL TRAIN EN ROUTE TO LOS ANGELES, ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Oct. 19. -- In a twofold appeal to the ranchmen and residents of the Southwest, Governor Landon pledged himself anew in a speech here today to further an international policy which would not "trade off the farmer," and urged support of the Republican national ticket to preserve the American system of freedom.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:
ALBANY, Oct. 19. -- A 19-year-old youth was killed tonight by an explosion during a political parade and demonstration in the campaign for the re-election of Governor Lehman.

MANILA, Philippines, Tuesday, Oct. 20. -- Confessions obtained from five Sakdalistas today revealed the failure of a carefully laid plot to overthrow the Commonwealth Government, which was inaugurated last year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- J. Edward Jones of New York, dealer in oil royalties, who won a victory over the Securities and Exchange Commission in the Supreme Court in April, lost today in his suit to test the constitutionality of the Securities Act of 1933.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 19 (AP). -- A survey of twenty-seven New York communities, including New York City, disclosed today an average increase of more than 20 per cent in registration of voters this year over registration in the same cities for the 1932 Presidential election.

EASTHAMPTON, Mass., Oct. 19. -- Williston Academy's football team defeated the Springfield College freshmen today in a tight 7-6 battle. At the beginning of the third quarter, Stepczyk of Williston ran the ball from the 35 to the 4-yard line, and Whittemore carried the ball over on a line buck. Stepczyk kicked the extra point.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 19. -- The "hex" is being banished at last from Pennsylvania, public instruction authorities said today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19. -- The nation's business men were urged here today by John W. O'Leary of Chicago, an industrial leader, to "convince the public that the only way back to prosperity for all is through increased production."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- The possibility of official action by the Committee for Industrial Organization in connection with the recent moves to bring about peace in the controversy with the American Federation of Labor's executive council was postponed for three weeks today when John L. Lewis, C.I.O. chairman, announced that his group would meet in Pittsburgh on Nov. 9 and 10 jointly with the steel workers' organizing committee.

Acting upon representations by receivers for the Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad Company that its common stock "for all practical purposes must be considered as of no value," the committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange suspended the issue from dealings yesterday.

The usual course of a Prime Minister, or other head of a Government, who finds his policy thwarted in Parliament is to threaten to appeal to the country in order to strengthen his hands. It would appear that Premier BLUM of France is making a threat in exactly the opposite way.

GENEVA, Oct. 19. -- The building of bombproof shelters for portraits and restoration of the medieval sanctuary system for statues are recommended to all countries by the League of Nations international museums office in a report issued here today.

PARIS, Oct. 19. -- The Bourse opened strong today, showing a tendency to continue the favorable trend of last week, but soon offers began to weigh upon the market and quotations gave ground. With a slight let-up around 2 o'clock, the pressure continued all day and nearly all French values closed at the lowest levels of the session and well below Friday's figures.

The Texas Corporation has notified the New York Stock Exchange that on July 2 it transferred its shareholdings, with option agreements entitling it to buy the remaining shares, of the Texas Company (Australasia), Ltd.; the Texas Company (China), Ltd.; the Texas Company (India), Ltd.; the Texas Company (Philippine Islands), Inc., and the Texas Company (South Africa), Ltd., to the Bahrein Petroleum Company, Ltd., a Canadian company.
BARCELONA, Spain, Oct. 19. -- President Manuel Azana and three of his Cabinet Ministers came to Barcelona tonight from Madrid, which was harassed by a constantly tightening ring of Rebel troops.

Sixty-three pairs started play last night at the Park Central Hotel in the second annual metropolitan Greater New York contract bridge championships of the American Bridge League. The qualifying sessions of the pair championship will continue through today and tomorrow.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., Oct. 19. -- Reports that airplanes on fire fell into the sea in Fortune, Placentia and Trinity Bays soon after 2 o'clock this afternoon disclosed that a shower of meteors had fallen.

The increasing mechanization of society, bringing with it occupational diseases and injuries, has created a situation "of primary importance" to the community which demands from medical science and medical leaders far more attention than is now being given, according to Dr. Eugene H. Pool, president of the New York Academy of Medicine.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Whether it should grant to a Stock Exchange unlisted trading privileges in a security fully registered and listed on another Exchange in cases where substantial distribution of and public trading in such security in the vicinity of the applicant Exchange is shown, was studied today by the Securities and Exchange Commission at the opening of hearings on applications by the Pittsburgh Stock Exchange covering twenty-five stocks and bonds.
MADRID, Oct. 19 (AP). -- The sorely pressed government defenders of Madrid tonight mobilized a "taxicab army," similar to that employed by the French in the first Battle of the Marne.

From now on junior members of Actors Equity Association will not become senior members until they have behind them fifty weeks' actual paid experience on the stage -- rehearsal and playing time both being counted in the totals. For the tellers yesterday completed Equity's referendum on the subject and found an overwhelming administration victory; the proposal was carried by almost 79 per cent to 21.

LONDON, Oct. 19. -- The nine months of court mourning for the late King George V -- six months of full mourning and three months of half-mourning -- will end Wednesday. This marks the beginning of what is expected to be the most brilliant social season ever seen in London.
General business in New York City has shown a substantial improvement over last year, Controller Frank J. Taylor said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Secretary Morgenthau declared in a statement today that there is no such thing in the United States Government as a double budget nor is there any system of double bookkeeping, and denied assertions of former President Hoover that the Treasury has been guilty of "intellectual dishonesty" and "pernicious deceit" in its reports.

Mayor La Guardia was on the witness stand about an hour yesterday in the investigation by the regular New York County grand jury into the dilapidated condition of the forty-year-old Criminal Courts Building, facing Center Street, in which the grand jurors' quarters are situated.
Many reservations have been made for the "Night Picture Hunt" tonight which will end on the Pierre Roof, proceeds of which will be donated to the Girls' Vacation Fund.

Men employed by the railroads on lighters, tugs and similar craft in the Port of New York have organized a new union, to be affiliated with the International Longshoremen's Association, it was announced yesterday. A charter will be presented to the new union at a meeting next Sunday in Jersey City.

ALBANY, Oct. 19. -- Hailed with a demonstration by 40,000 paraders, Governor Herbert H. Lehman replied tonight to the charge of "rabble rouser" made against him by William F. Bleakley, his Republican opponent. The Governor called the charge an "insult" to the people of the State.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19. -- A new operation for the three most serious forms of heart disease, angina pectoris, coronary thrombosis and coronary sclerosis, was described here tonight at the presidential meeting of the annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons.

BOSTON, Oct. 19. -- There was quite an occasion at the Opera House tonight when Leslie Howard made his first bow to the classics -- excluding his recent screen venture -- in the title role of Shakespeare's "Hamlet."

Competition in Class B of the Metropolitan Division of the National Squash Tennis Association was launched last night, with the New York Athletic Club, the Princeton Club and the City A.C. being returned the victors in their respective matches.

Premier Hirota's success in checking the project of the Japanese army to reform the Tokyo government has an important bearing on the Chino-Japanese crisis. The position of the moderate Premier, who has pledged there will be no war while he is in office, is strengthened and that of the militarists is correspondingly weakened.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19. -- The "fine humanitarian work" done in Palestine by Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization of America, was praised by President Roosevelt in a letter read today at its annual convention here.

Magistrate Michael A. Ford accused Chief City Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. yesterday of "attempting to substitute his own will for the law." His statement was a result of his transfer from the Manhattan Traffic Court, where he had been scheduled to sit this week, to Part 2 of the Bronx Magistrates Court.
ARMONK, N. Y., Oct. 19. -- What the outdoor reporter covering the opening of the upland hunting season hopes to learn, primarily, is: How much game is around, if any?

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 19. -- Brud Harper, a reserve halfback on the Princeton football squad, starred today in an hour and a half's scrimmage between a makeshift varsity and the scrub team, in which the Black eleven emerged victorious, 12 -- 6.

The National City Bank of New York won the award yesterday of an issue of $350,000 of temporary loan notes of the city of Syracuse, N.Y., at an interest rate of .30 per cent, plus a premium of $13. The issue is dated Oct. 21, 1936, and will mature on April 21, 1937.

A delegation of three persons, including a Roman Catholic priest, arrived yesterday aboard the Queen Mary to travel through Canada and the United States, lecturing in behalf of the Spanish Government in its struggle against the Rebels.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 19. -- Elbert T. Gallagher, Chief Assistant District Attorney of Westchester County, disclosed this afternoon he had in his possession diaries kept for the last few years by Chang Soo Lee, 36-year-old Korean servant of Mrs. Ida L. Churchill, wealthy resident of Prospect Park, this city, which shed light on the poison plot with which he is charged.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 19. -- Diplomatic quarters here today characterized as critical the situation that has arisen between the Spanish Government and South American republics as a result of the insistence of the Latin-American governments on their right to extend asylum to political refugees in Madrid.

A two-month term in the City Prison was imposed yesterday by Judge Jonah J. Goldstein in General Sessions on Dr. Rubin Klein, 39 years old, of 92 Humboldt Street, Brooklyn, on his plea of guilty to conspiracy in a fraudulent indemnity accident claim.

VALLADOLID, Spain, Oct. 18 (Delayed). -- Bullfighting came back to Rebel Spain this afternoon when 20,000 fans, from grandees to sheepherders, gathered in the local arena at a corrida in aid of the Red Cross.

I wish to express publicly my appreciation to Rear Admiral D.F. Sellers, Superintendent of the United States Naval Academy, for his discussion of the academy which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 14. He has rendered a great service to the people of the United States by presenting to them an answer to my article, "Annapolis -- Stronghold of Mediocrity," which appeared in the October issue of The Forum.

A suit to restrain the Board of Elections and the Charter Revision Commission from placing on the ballots and voting machines in the coming election the question of electing by proportional representation the councilmen provided in the proposed new charter was started yesterday in Supreme Court by Mrs. Catherine C. Mulville of 427 Forty-first Street, Brooklyn.

SCARSDALE. N.Y., Oct. 19. -- A campaign to persuade Governor Lehman to rescind an order by Corrections Commissioner Mulrooney prohibiting prisons from charging the public admission fees to its sports contests and other entertainments was begun here today by Harry E. Von Kersburg of Scarsdale.

Domestic corporate bonds were generally firm in active trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, although the turnover was less than on Friday. United States Government issues generally were higher, with gains of 1-32 to 6-32 point, although a few declined 1-32 to 3-32.

SUMMIT, N.J., Oct. 19. -- Scoring a par-shattering best ball of 68, Jim Martucci of Rivervale and Tom O'Connor of Bloomfield today won the one-day tournament for pro teams conducted by the New Jersey P.G.A. at the Summit Golf Club.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Commissioner Eugene O. Sykes said today that the Federal Communications Commission would "look into" complaints against the interruption of a radio "debate" Saturday night between Senator Vandenberg and the recorded voice of President Roosevelt.

Mr. Geddes is still interested in scenery. In "Iron Men," which he staged at the Longacre last evening, he has used the theatre for his personal laboratory, set himself a daring problem, solved it, and now he may as well rest for a little while.

A capacity gathering of 800 spectators in the New York A.C. gymnasium last night saw the start of the All-American Metropolitan A.A.U. Amateur Boxing Tournament. Eleven of the bouts ended by knockouts.
Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, reported yesterday that the infant mortality in New York City for the week ended last Saturday was the lowest in seven weeks.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the proposed admission of Frederick M. Kauffman to Bull Eldridge and Raymond J. Denyven and James J. Sullivan to Francis Brothers Co., the changes to become effective on Nov. 1.

The fourteenth exhibition by New York artists at the Temporary Galleries of the Municipal Art Committee, 62 West Fifty-third Street, will open with a preview today and to the public tomorrow. Four groups of resident artists, one to each floor, provide one of the most interesting shows the gallery has launched. It will be current through Nov. 6.
The foreign policies of President Roosevelt, Governor Landon and Norman Thomas were presented one after another by their representatives here last night.

The customary "light Monday" was passed up yesterday as Columbia started preparation for its intersectional encounter with Michigan at Ann Arbor Saturday. Every man on the squad had a busy afternoon as the varsity scrimmaged against the freshmen and the reserves battled with the Manhattan substitutes.

Interference paved the way for Jamaica's first football victory over Grover Cleveland High before 3,000 spectators at the Jamaica Stadium yesterday. The Red and Blue won, 6 -- 0, after having been turned back three previous years by the Ridgewood eleven.
Four men were arrested and $20,000 worth of stolen Persian lamb pelts were recovered late yesterday by detectives led by Police Lieutenant John Cordes.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Charges by Representative Bacon of New York that the AAA was speeding up benefit payments to farmers for political effect were denied today by J.B. Hutson, Administrator.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19. -- Wheat markets made a firm start and a weak finish today, closing prices being about at the lowest level. Fractional advances were recorded on the Board of Trade and at Winnipeg at the opening in sympathy with strength in Liverpool, but there was no snap to the buying and later commission houses became good sellers and uncovered stop-loss orders.
THE Times published a news article, "City Speeds Fight on Social Disease," a speech by Dr. Clarke of the City Department of Health.
Thirteen persons received injuries on the Queen Mary on the voyage across from Southampton via Cherbourg, it was learned yesterday morning when the ship docked at the foot of West Fiftieth Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- A challenge of the constitutionality of the New York mortgage moratorium law, which was to have been argued in the Supreme Court tomorrow, was withdrawn today through sudden agreement of attorneys on both sides to dismiss the suit of Joseph and Angelina Loporto against the Druiss Company.

For a musical comedy to undertake to prove that nurture is more important than nature in shaping human character sounds like pretty serious business, but "Yoina Seeks a Bride," which was presented last night at the Second Avenue Theatre, doesn't put it quite so abstractly.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 19 (AP). -- Some 1,300 students of little Duquesne University celebrated noisily today the upset 7-0 football victory of the Dukes over the powerful Pitt Panthers.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19. -- Uncertainty of public-spirited citizens as to the future, diversion of moneys formerly given to hospitals to youth movements "aimed to save the Republic," and high estate taxes imposed by the Federal and State Governments, were cited as the chief reasons for the financial plight of hospitals of the country by Dr. Frank E. Adair of Memorial Hospital, New York City, at a conference on hospital standardization here today.

A prediction that the World's Fair of 1939 would benefit business far beyond the boundaries of New York City was made yesterday by Grover Whalen, president of the World's Fair Corporation. Addressing 400 members of the Sales Executive Club in the Hotel Roosevelt, he reiterated his forecast that 50,000,000 visitors would spend $1,000,000,000 at the exposition.

Deaths from automobile accidents in New York City last week increased more than 32 per cent compared with the corresponding week in 1935, according to a report yesterday by First Deputy Police Commissioner Harold Fowler, in charge of traffic.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that indictments had been returned in a United States District Court in Michigan against seven individuals, alleging that they had defrauded a large number of persons in Michigan through misrepresentation and market manipulation in the 6 per cent convertible cumulative preferred stock of the Old Dutch Refining Company.

LONDON, Oct. 19. -- Major Clement R. Attlee, leader of the Labor Opposition, sent a message to Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin today requesting the immediate convening of Parliament "in view of the increasing gravity of the situation" with reference to non-intervention in the Spanish civil war.

ABOARD THE CHINA CLIPPER, Tuesday, Oct. 20. -- We are now 150 miles out of Manila, homeward bound. This immense flying boat rose from Cavite harbor just as a faint promise of dawn streaked the sky over the Clipper's black nose.

Artist instructors of the Federal Art Project free classes, WPA, to the number of nearly one hundred, are represented in the exhibition which opened yesterday at the Federal Art Project Gallery, 7 East Thirty-eighth Street. Oils, watercolors, graphic work sculpture and ceramics are included.

Maxie Berger, 135 1/4, Montreal, and Pete Caracciola, 140 1/2, Bensonhurst, battled to a draw in the main event of eight rounds at the opening boxing show at Stauch's Arena in Coney Island last night.

Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, received sheafs of telegrams, and many telephone calls yesterday commending him on his request that "all persons refrain from the use of alcoholic beverages" while attending football games and other athletic contests under the auspices of the institution.

BOMBAY, India, Oct. 19. -- Sixty Hindus and Moslems convicted of rioting have been ordered whipped. Six were flogged today and sent out of jail to be an example to others. This action is expected to be a deterrent to hooligan elements.

American business will spend more than $500,000,000 in the next twelve months for office equipment, according to exhibitors participating in the twenty-third annual Business Show which was opened by Mayor La Guardia yesterday in Commerce Hall of the Port Authority Building.
Seven WPA workers were injured, three seriously, in St. George, S.I., when they were showered yesterday by two tons of chipped concrete which had fallen from a height of twenty-eight feet.

Gains were the rule in local commodity futures markets yesterday, although hides, wooltops, some coffee contracts and cottonseed oil declined against the general trend. On the cash markets cocoa made a new high and tin, rye, silk, wooltops and rubber gained, while wheat, corn, oats, flour, lard and cotton declined.

TORONTO, Ont., Oct. 19. -- Mrs. Ernest Simpson is being ignored by the press of Canada. While United States dailies devote columns of space to her future, some Canadian newspapers have yet to present her past.

MOSCOW, Oct. 19. -- It was strongly hinted in Soviet circles today that the Kremlin had devised a program of aid that it was confident would save the beleaguered Popular Front factions in Spain, even though Madrid falls. It was indicated that the Kremlin would announce its decision in a manner that would stir the world.

ROME, Oct. 19. -- Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano delivered yesterday to the British Ambassador in Rome the Italian reply to the British note of Sept. 20, submitting tentative agenda for a Locarno conference and inviting the interested governments to make comments and suggestions.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 19. -- Producer Sol Lesser is anxious to present baseball's current No. 1 home run hitter, Lou Gehrig, as the super jungle man in the "Tarzan" series, which he acquired recently from Metro. Negotiations have been started with Christy Walsh, who handles the business end of Gehrig's artistic and cultural endeavors, and if screen tests and terms are satisfactory the pictures will be made between seasons.

William F. Carey, Sanitation Commissioner, at his weekly conference with representatives of civic organizations, yesterday won support for his plan to enforce sanitary code provisions in snow removal work next Winter.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- A contest over $5,405,428 in estate taxes, made in connection with two trusts set up by William Waldorf Astor for two sons, lost today in the Supreme Court, which denied a review.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Oct. 19 (AP). -- A column of Italian soldiers tonight tracked down Ethiopian tribesmen in "mass reprisal" for the killing of thirteen Italian aviators last July.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 19. -- The Rev. Dr. William Hiram Foulkes, pastor of the First Church of Newark, was elected Moderator of the Synod of New Jersey, Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A., here today, to succeed the Rev. Dr. Rockwell S. Brank of Summit.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 20. -- A plan for State control of the electric power industry, as amended at conferences among the Ministers of Finance, Communications, Com merce and Railways, will be presented to the Cabinet today.
PALERMO, Sicily, Italy, Oct. 19 (AP). -- Four persons died in the mysterious blaze that swept the third-class quarters of the Italian liner Vulcania early this morning.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 19. -- Mrs. Addison Stillwell took a party to Fassifern Farm for luncheon today. Her guests included Mrs. Homer A. Stillwell, Mrs. Edgar H. Bright, Mrs. Thomas W. Vardell, Mrs. Vardell Johnson and William F. White.

Riding back from Baltimore after the defeat there of Navy by Yale's team, the scout of one of the Eli's future opponents looked up from the football extra he was reading and shook his head. "Better keep explosives away from Princeton next Saturday.

Francis Lederer, the bounding Czech, has signed with Columbia to play the role of the Polish composer and pianist in the biographical film "Chopin," which Frank Capra plans to place before the cameras around Jan. 1. At the moment Mr. Capra is engaged in cutting and editing his transcription of James Hilton's "Lost Horizon."

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 19. -- Mr. and Mrs. Percy L. Hance gave a farewell dinner in the Colonnades at the Greenbrier last night for Mr. and Mrs. James L. Ward, who are returning to New York this week. Dr. Robert Emery Brennan of New York also was a guest.

One point on which Democratic and Republican campaign orators disagree frequently and flatly is whether the United States has achieved as much progress toward industrial recovery as other important nations have achieved, or whether we are lagging behind in the procession.

HAVANA, Oct. 19. -- The condition of William F. Kenny, New York contractor, who was taken off the steamship Rotterdam and placed in the Anglo-American Hospital here yesterday, is regarded as serious. He is suffering from a gall bladder ailment.

Travelers between London and Paris can now be ferried across in their sleeping cars without disembarking. For people around New York Harbor this is far from being a novelty; it is almost a forgotten practice.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Oct. 14 shows a decrease for the week of $39,000,000 in total loans and investments and increases of $64,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted, $130,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks, $14,000,000 in deposits of foreign banks, $87,000,000 in balance with domestic banks and $131,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 19. -- While the stand taken by President Dodds of Princeton against drinking at football games was generally endorsed at Yale today, the question was expressed here as being merely part of a larger problem. that of disorder at football games.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19. -- The demand for hogs was not aggressive and the general market today was quoted as steady to 10 cents a hundred-weight lower than Friday. Pigs declined 25 to 50 cents. The top of $10.20 was 5 cents under Friday's best level, while the day's average was 5 cents lower at $9.60.

TOKYO, Oct. 19. -- Leaving as his last message a scrap of paper inscribed, "Long live the imperial family; apologies and gratitude," Captain Wataru Tanaka, talented young officer connected with the Showa restoration movement, who supported, though he did not actually participate in, the February rebellion, committed suicide today with a revolver.

The favored Erasmus Hall High eleven was held to a scoreless tie by a fighting Thomas Jefferson team at Erasmus Field in Brooklyn yesterday. Erasmus entered the game with two victories in as many starts.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19. -- Miss Joan Peabody, daughter of Mrs. Peter A.B. Widener 2d, was introduced to society this afternoon by her step-grandfather, Joseph E. Widener, at a tea which he gave at Lynnewood Hall, his Elkins Park home.

VALENCIA, Spain, Oct. 19. -- The hunt among suspected Rightist families in Madrid has now turned against women. On Wednesday night nearly 1,000 women in the aristocratic Salamanca quarter and elsewhere were seized and confined in two expropriated houses.

The additional New York County grand jury yesterday directed Harold W. Hastings, Assistant District Attorney, to invite Police Commissioner Valentine to appear before them within the next few days for testimony in their investigation of alleged attacks on non-union shops in recent months.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 19. -- Senator Daniel O. Hastings jumped today into the controversy over the Vandenberg broadcast. He sent a message to the Columbia Broadcasting System questioning whether that concern had not obtained insurance from James Roosevelt, the President's son.

NANKING, China, Tuesday, Oct. 20. -- The willingness of the Japanese officials here to continue the negotiations for settlement of Chino-Japanese differences, despite the firm attitude adopted by the Chinese Government on the North China problem and other issues involving questions of sovereign rights, is viewed here as the most hopeful aspect of the current conversations which Foreign Minister Chang Chun and Ambassador Shigeru Kawagoe reopened yesterday.

The Rev. Gerald L.K. Smith, who learned political science from Huey P. Long and studied economics under the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin and Dr. Francis E. Townsend, announced last night that he would lead a new nationalist organization combining the best features of his mentors' schemes and designed ultimately to "seize the government of the United States."

European sanction for the George Vanderbilt Cup race next year was given yesterday in the approval of Labor Day as the date for holding the 1937 speed classic at Roosevelt Raceway by the Association of International Automobile Racing Clubs.

THERE are two ways to write autobiography. One is to wait until you stop growing -- until you are seventy or so and, as Laurence Housman says, you know what you do know and don't know and what you have to be thankful for. It is probably well not to hold off all writing until this late date, for memory wanes and energies lag, but publication itself can be postponed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Returning today from Hyde Park for a two-day stay, President Roosevelt closed his doors to all but two callers and set to work writing the major address which he will make at Worcester Wednesday evening. He did not go to his office, but worked in the library on the second floor of the White House.

The State Mortgage Bank of Yugoslavia, through Radoye Yanikovitch, Yugoslav Consul General here, has notified holders of its secured 7 per cent bonds, due in 1957, that it will pay, on a modified basis, four interest coupons maturing from Oct. 1, 1935, to April 1, 1937.

Long runs were the order of the day as Curtis High School's football team opened its season with a 25-to-6 victory over Abraham Lincoln of Brooklyn at Thompson's Stadium, Stapleton, S.I., yesterday before a crowd of 3,000.

Leroy Anspach appeared in recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon and made it clear that he is a pianist who prefers the personal, intimate approach in his interpretations. His choice of compositions seemed to be well arranged to bring out his gifts of delicacy, clarity and sincerity.

MOORESTOWN, N.J., Oct. 19. -- The 1936 English touring field hockey team made an auspicious start in defense of its world honors by defeating the American touring team, which competed abroad in 1933, 4 -- 0, at the Moorestown Field Club today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 19. -- Several tentative changes were made in the Harvard first-team line-up today when the Crimson varsity squad gathered for its first practice since the 32-to-0 rout by Army last Saturday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 19. -- Fines totaling $750,000 have been imposed by the Yugoslav Finance Ministry on a ring of former high officials of the Foreign Office who were convicted of large-scale smuggling operations involving Persian carpets, old masters, antique furniture and other high-priced goods.

Mrs. Charles S. Whitman, wife of the former Republican Governor, sent a telegram yesterday to the Democratic National Committee denying that she formerly had been a Democrat. Mrs. Whitman is supporting President Roosevelt.

Statistical honors in the National Football League belong to the Chicago Bears. According to the figures released yesterday, the Westerners, with 1,423 yards gained, with 107 points scored and with 22 points allowed, hold the edge over their rivals in these important phases of play.

Although many of the mightiest already have fallen, the season's first check-up by The Associated Press on the undefeated and untied football teams of the nation shows fifty-four with clean slates. Of these, an even dozen, including one team that has played only a single game, are entitled to add un-scored on.

BERLIN, Oct. 19. -- Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Italian Foreign Minister, will arrive in Berlin tomorrow for a three-day visit, accompanied by Ministerial officials, who will participate in discussions of matters affecting Italo-German political and economic relations.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 19 (AP). -- Closing with a tremendous rush, C.V. Whitney's Roustabout captured the Experimental Handicap, a $1,000 added dash at six furlongs, the feature of today's program at Keeneland Park.

Harry Jacobson of Chicago, owner of 100 shares of common stock of the General Motors Corporation, brought suit yesterday in Federal Court to recover more than $500,000,000 which he alleged had been paid to officers and directors of the corporation in illegal stock bonuses since 1918.
A mother was killed yesterday in Brooklyn in a futile attempt to save her 5-year-old daughter from death under the wheels of an automobile.

Testimony to show that the New York Central Railroad received almost all the freight solicited by the Universal Car Loading and Distributing Company was introduced yesterday by William J. Walsh, attorney for the Interstate Commerce Commission, at hearings by examiners for the commission in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

A 100 per cent increase in fraudulent registration in this city and widespread illegal registration throughout the East were charged yesterday. The accusations as to this city came from the nonpartisan Honest Ballot Association. The other allegations were made at Eastern headquarters of the Republican National Committee.
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Oct. 19. -- Following is the text of Governor Landon's speech here today:

The Massachusetts Investors Trust reports total assets as of Sept. 30 of $86,569,033, and net assets equal to $27.89 a share for 3,948,466 shares, compared with $26.30 a share as of June 30, 1936, and $24.03 a share, after Federal income tax not now applicable, at the close of last year.

The Guaranty Trust Company of New York, as trustee for the New York, Westchester Boston Railway Company first-mortgage bonds due in 1946, has called a meeting of bondholders at its offices at 35 Nassau Street, at 10 A.M. on Friday to afford them an opportunity to discuss steps to be taken with respect to the company's affairs, with particular reference to proceedings under Section 77b of the National Bankruptcy Act.

In the presence of white-clad nurses, blue-uniformed probationers and guests, the cornerstone of the Eli White Memorial, the new nurses' residence of St. Luke's Hospital, 114th Street near Amsterdam Avenue, was laid yesterday afternoon.

The franchise of the New York Americans was assumed by the National Hockey League yesterday. The decision to take over the affairs of the star-spangled sextet was made at a meeting of the board of governors at the Hotel Commodore following the club's failure to comply with a formal demand for payment of its indebtedness to the league.

With sales this year running 14 1/2 per cent ahead of 1935, the National Association of Ice Industries, through its subsidiary, National Ice Advertising, Inc., will launch a $2,000,000 advertising campaign for 1937 in newspapers, magazines and over the radio.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Oct. 19. -- The puzzling greens of the Lakeville Golf and Country Club's course provided plenty of trouble for the forty-three teams that turned out for the Long Island Golf Association's final fixture of the 1936 season today.

The South African women's team, sixth and last of the invading contingents that will take part in the international field hockey meet at Philadelphia, arrived yesterday aboard the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary. Other arrivals were four more Welsh players and a group of English delegates.

Interest in the quarterly meeting of directors of the United States Steel Corporation on next Tuesday is being whetted by the rise of the company's preferred stock. The issue advanced 1 1/2 points yesterday to 145 1/2, or 1 1/4 points above the highest level of 1929.

The Hair Dressers and Cosmetologists International Union announced yesterday that it had called a strike of beauty shop workers in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens for this morning after failure of negotiations with the New York State Hair Dressers Association.

Although the church cannot take sides in a political campaign, Presbyterians were urged yesterday, in a report to the fifty-fourth annual meeting of their New York Synod, to condemn in politics the "bitterness which pins false labels on opponents" and to make their political choice on a "higher basis than that of narrow class interest which may run counter to the welfare of the masses of the people."

In twenty-one American cities populations equal those of the twenty-one neighborhoods served here by the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service, the number of nurses available and the total operating budgets are almost twice as large as those of the local organization, according to a report made public yesterday.

Louis H. Pink, Superintendent of Insurance, announced yesterday the completion of his investigation into charges by Mayor La Guardia that seven civilian telephone operators in the Fire Department were bribed by certain fire adjusters' agencies for immediate reports on locations of fires.
LIMA, Peru, Oct. 19. -- Growing impatience and general protest expressed in the press and political circles over delay in canvassing the vote in the recent national election has brought this reply:
Statues of Alexander Hamilton and General Philip Henry Sheridan were dedicated yesterday in ceremonies held in two parts of the city.

In a form letter sent yesterday to several of its suppliers, the Amtorg Trading Corporation, commercial agency here of the Russian Government, advised the companies that future transactions must be carried on directly with Moscow and with the particular organization there buying their goods.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 19 (AP). -- Stirred by the plea of a New York churchman, delegates to the biennial convention of the United Lutheran Church refused today to vote authority for creation of a Negro synod in the South.

After a strong and active opening, the stock market declined fractionally in less active trading yesterday. Despite the generally lower trend of prices, several issues closed higher on the day. Compared with recent sessions, it was a relatively quiet day; from a technical standpoint, brokers found it encouraging that trading turned dull on the decline.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday announced that on Saturday $9,975,000 of gold had been set aside under earmark for foreign account. In accordance with the Reserve Bank's practice, no indication was given as to the identity of the foreign central bank or government for whom the gold was earmarked.

H. Roslyn Ekins, reporter for the Scripps-Howard newspapers, returned to New York yesterday from a flight of 25,794 miles around the world. He was back in the office of The World-Telegram Build ing at 11:14 A.M., 18 days, 14 hours and 56 minutes after his departure from the building at 8:17 P.M. on Sept. 30.

ALBANY, Oct. 19. -- As the stage is being set for the extraordinary session of the Legislature which will be called to order at 1 o'clock tomorrow afternoon, there is every prospect that it will get through with its work and adjourn sine die before night falls.

Transportation of large bundles and packages in the subways to the inconvenience of passengers is definitely a violation of the rules of the Transit Commission, according to a letter received yesterday by Alderman Morton Moses from William G. Fullen, chairman of the Transit Commission.

Carrying a certified check for $1,000 to prove that he is not a vagrant. Earl Browder, Communist candidate for President, left last night for Terre Haute, Ind., with plans to make a public address there today. Three weeks ago Mr. Browder was arrested in Terre Haute on a charge of vagrancy before he left his train.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19. -- Secretary Ickes, in a speech at the Academy of Music tonight, accused former President Hoover of citing "erroneous" figures in his address here last week in which he assailed the Roosevelt administration for "intellectual dishonesty."
James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, charged yesterday that the Republicans had justified his prediction that "this would be a dirty campaign."

BERLIN, Oct. 19. -- Colonel General Hermann Goering was appointed today as a commissar with dictatorial powers for execution of the four-year plan of economic development announced at the Nuremberg Nazi party congress in September.

More than 15,000 checks, aggregating nearly $10,000,000, will be mailed today to investors in debentures of the International Match Corporation throughout the world by the Irving Trust Company, trustee in bankruptcy, and by depositaries of the various protective committees.

PARIS, Oct. 19. -- First steps toword organization of an international health service to deal with the problem of epidemics were taken today at the twenty-third Hygiene Congress now being held at the Pasteur Institute.

The first victims of minor infractions of the new Traffic Law adopted Sept. 1, which provides mandatory jail terms for three-time offenders, were sentenced yesterday by Magistrate Bernard Mogilesky in Traffic Court.

Norway's challenges for the Seawanhaka Cup and the Scandinavian Gold Cup, two leading prizes competed for by six-meter boats, were accepted by the trustees of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club of Oyster Bay at a meeting last night at the Knickerbocker Club.

Vice Chancellor Charles M. Egan in Jersey City yesterday took under advisement an application of Carl K. Withers, State Commissioner of Banking and Insurance, asking the court to take jurisdiction of the liquidation of the Mechanics Trust Company of Bayonne and to advise and instruct him in the liquidation.

Rumblings of revolt against delay by John L. Lewis in calling a meeting of the Committee for Industrial Organization to act upon the proposal of the convention of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers Union for peace between the A.F. of L. and the C.I.O., and its acceptance in large part by the executive council of the A.F. of L., reverberated in C.I.O. circles here yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19. -- In surgery, as well as in medicine, diagnosis will be more accurate and treatment more effective if the patient's psychic and emotional reactions receive mature consideration, Dr. James S. McLester of Birmingham, Ala., told the Clinical Congress of the American College of Surgeons here today.
Leroy C. Palmer was elected president and director of Franklin Simon Co., Inc., by the board late yesterday afternoon at the store at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street.

The bill ordering a city referendum on the three-platoon system for firemen, which the Legislature will receive at its special session today with an emergency message from Governor Lehman, was endorsed yesterday by Sheriff William F. Brunner of Queens, Democratic candidate for Aldermanic President, and by United States Senator Royal S. Copeland. It was opposed by the New York State Economic Council, which sent telegrams of protest to the Governor and legislative leaders.

BERLIN, Oct. 19. -- Stock quotations here rose again today without a great amount of activity appearing, although the turnover generally was heavier than last week. The Boerse still is largely under the influence of devaluation and non-devaluation rumors and general uncertainty.

LONDON, Oct. 19. -- The leisurely legalistic approach of Sir John Simon, Home Secretary, to consideration of the problem raised by British fascism has been quickened by Sir Philip Game, Commissioner of Metropolitan Police. He is now demanding some Cabinet decision in the near future on which to base his plans for protecting the people of East London against physical attack and oratorical abuse by Sir Oswald Mosley's Black Shirts.

The unemployed may look forward to "the most miserable kind of dole" if Governor Landon is elected and responsibility for relief is turned back to local communities, Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Works Progress Administrator, told 350 social workers yesterday at a luncheon of the Good Neighbor League at the Hotel Commodore.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 19. -- The Federal grand jury which has been inquiring into the alleged kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel, former Trenton lawyer, handed up to Judge Guy L. Fake today an indictment which was reported to have named five men in the case.

MONTREAL, Oct. 19 (Canadian Press) -- Holders of the Ottawa Valley Power Company's 5 per cent first-mortgage bonds approved today a plan to postpone until April 1, 1938, the semi-annual interest coupons due on Oct. 1, last, and on April 1, 1937, and to cancel the sinking-fund installments of onehalf of 1 per cent due on Oct. l, 1936 and 1937.

PERTH, Australia, Oct. 19 (Canadian Press). -- The touring Marylebone Cricket Club team today defeated West Australia by an innings and 180 runs, but the victory proved costly, two of England's players receiving injuries that will keep them out of the game for some time.

The Standard Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the year ended on Aug. 31 a consolidated net income of $3,818,987, against $1,435,312 in the preceding year. This was after all deductions. For August, the net income was $18,842, against $43,212 a year ago.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 19. -- Carl Hubbell, sensational left-handed pitcher whose baffling "screwball" won twenty-six campaign victories and the 1936 pennant for the New York Giants, was unanimously chosen today as the year's most valuable National League player by a committee representing the Baseball Writers Association of America.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19. -- Pennsylvania came out of the 7-0 victory over Princeton in fairly good physical condition.
TALAVERA DE LA REINA, Spain, Oct. 19 (AP). -- Rebel forces tonight hammered along two high roads leading into Madrid.

It is unfortunate that the reciprocity treaties have been made an issue in this campaign. The wise and economically sound policy of bartering with foreign countries over tariff arrangements was recently moving out of the sphere of partisan politics. For over forty years the Republican party has favored reciprocity treaties, while the Democratic party has frowned upon them.
BUFFALO, Oct. 19. -- Before a large audience in this city tonight William F. Bleakley, Republican candidate for Governor, made a general attack upon the New Deal.

Reorders in the women's apparel and accessory markets here yesterday were again heavy, with the volume indicating the wholesale season is fast approaching its seasonal peak. Despite the fact that weather conditions in some sections again proved a handicap, the business in fur-trimmed cloth coats continued to show improvement.

Continued Southern selling and liquidation of December contracts caused cotton futures to decline from slight early advances on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday. Favorable weather and continued good mill demand were said to be bringing a larger amount of cotton out of the interior in the South.

By a landslide vote, Minnesota's Gophers, who now enjoy the longest string of victories in major college football circles, were elected to hold the No. 1 spot in the consensus national ranking list compiled yesterday by The Associated Press.

Reorders in the women's apparel and accessory markets here yesterday were again heavy, with the volume indicating the wholesale season is fast approaching its seasonal peak. Despite the fact that weather conditions in some sections again proved a handicap, the business in fur-trimmed cloth coats continued to show improvement.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 20. -- Expansion of government welfare projects constitutes no threat to the private agency, whose work must continue to be care of the public before misfortune reaches "its rawest climax," Miss Clare Mr. Touseley, assistant general director of the Charity Organization Society of New York, told 1,000 delegates at the New York State Conference on Social Work today.

Extensive changes likely to take place in Manhattan's midtown West Side district under the rezoning program now before the Board of Estimate were outlined at a luncheon meeting of the West Side Association of Commerce yesterday in the Hotel Astor.

Although John Golden's new production, "Punches Judy!" is now trying out at the Boulevard, Jackson Heights, the identity of its author remains a mystery. It was first thought to be Frank Craven, who had written a play called "Bunch and Judy," which Mr. Golden was considering.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 20. -- Mr. and Mrs. Irving T. Bush of New York were luncheon hosts today in the Tangerine Room at the Greenbrier Casino. Mrs. Augustus F. Kountze of New York entertained with luncheon for a small group at the Casino.

Daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 3,077,300 barrels daily, compared with 3,024,950 in the preceding week, an increase of 52,350, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Gains of 23, 050 barrels in Oklahoma, 16,000 in Kansas and 15,350 in Texas were the important changes.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20. -- An assertion that more than $5,000,000 appropriated for relief in Missouri has "apparently been diverted into unexplained channels," was made today in an affidavit by Edwin E. Jones, a certified accountant, formerly employed as auditor for the Resettlement Administration in Missouri.

The retirement of Professor Thomas Scott Fiske of Columbia University, who is completing his thirty-fifth year as secretary of the college entrance examination board, was announced yesterday. Professor George Walker Mullins, also of Columbia, will succeed him on Oct. 28 at the annual meeting of the board.

On a day nearly fifty years ago HELEN KELLER, the blind and deaf child whom ANNE SULLIVAN had undertaken to teach, had put into her hand (literally) the key to the universe. MRS. MACY, whom ANNE SULLIVAN came to be, tells of the day of the miracle when HELEN, with a new light in her face, learned the word for "water ":
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20. -- Halfback Edward J. Warwick of Trenton was today appointed acting captain of the Penn eleven for the game with Brown here on Saturday.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 20. -- A municipal budget for 1937 of about $4,000,000 was adopted unanimously by the White Plains City Council at a meeting in the City Hall here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Angelo Herndon, the Negro Communist of Atlanta, again appealed to the Supreme Court today in an effort to escape a sentence of eighteen to twenty years imposed under a Georgia law of the reconstruction period.

DETROIT, Oct. 20. -- "Business is going to be somewhat better in 1937 than it has been in 1936," Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the General Motors Corporation, declared tonight at a dinner given here in connection with an advance showing of next year's models of Cadillac and La Salle cars.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Three diplomats of important nations presented letters of credence to President Roosevelt at the White House today in assuming their duties as the official representatives of their countries in the United States, and all, in their formal remarks, made references to important questions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Colonel Henry Anderson, counsel for the insurance companies' protective committee in the proposed reorganization of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad, announced today that a new plan of reorganization of the road would be presented to the Interstate Commerce Commission for its approval.

ABOARD THE CHINA CLIPPER, En Route to Wake Island, Wednesday, Oct. 21. -- At 6:28 this morning [3:49 P.M. Tuesday, Eastern Standard Time] Captain Ralph Dahlstrom scudded the China Clipper along the crests of a considerable sea swell and fifty-nine seconds later the giant airliner slapped against the last crest and vaulted into the air.

Trading in the stock market contracted again yesterday as prices continued to decline slowly. In the face of the general downward trend of industrials and rails, several specialties went to new high levels for the year. Utility and oil stocks also went against the general trend.
LONDON, Oct. 20. -- Officials here were worried today by the renewal of threats from Moscow that the official Soviet policy of neutrality in the Spanish civil war would be abandoned.

Carl (Red) Guggino, Tampa (Fla.) lightweight, won a close decision from Phil Baker of Norwalk, Conn., in the feature eight-round bout at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx last night before 6,000 spectators. The victor proved a capable substitute for Lou Fox of the East Side, who was unable to appear on account of an injury.

Net profit of the National Biscuit Company was $3,659,769 for the third quarter of this year, after deductions for depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges. After dividend requirements on the 7 per cent preferred stock, the profit equaled 51 cents each on 6,289,448 shares of $10 par common stock.

Dividend Shares, Inc., reported yesterday that its total assets on Sept. 30, with securities valued at market, were $32,253,648, an increase of more than $3,000,000 since June 30. In the period the asset value by share increased 6.26 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- The Republican National Committee charged today that the broadcasting division of the Federal Communications Commission had made "an outright gift" of $500,000 to The St. Louis Star-Times when it approved the application of that paper for permission to construct a full-time 1,000-watt radio station.

The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, will open to the public today its retrospective one-man show of work by the distinguished American artist, John Marin. It is directed by Alfred Stieglitz, who has from the beginning been Marin's representative and loyal "persuasive advocate."

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 20. -- The Maemere Farm's Maecloud boosted her stock for next Saturday's $10,000-added Selima Stakes by winning impressively from eight other juvenile fillies in the Bolivar Purse, feature race today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Charges of Edwin E. Jones, former auditor, that $8,914,127 was received to carry out relief and rural rehabilitation activities in Missouri and that only 153,601,809 was accounted for in his auditing were denied tonight by officials of the Resettlement Administration.

LONDON, Oct. 20 (AP). -- Great Britain, offering the use of her fleet to transport hostages from war-torn Spain, in messages tonight to both the Madrid government and the Rebel high command, expressed fear of "wholesale massacre" of hostages unless their safety were assured.

The gradual decline in the foreign exchanges which had been in progress for several days was halted yesterday. Leading European currencies rallied moderately, but dealings continued quiet and there was apparently no important intervention by the exchange stabilization funds.

WABASHA, Minn., Oct. 20 (AP). -- Senator Elmer Benson, Farmer Labor candidate for Governor, proposed in a political speech yesterday to increase taxes of iron mining companies in Minnesota $10,000,000 annually if he defeats his Republican opponent, Martin A. Nelson, in November.

Ten charitable and humane institutions share equally in the residuary estate of Caroline S. Harman, late of 309 West 104th Street, it was learned yesterday when her will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court. The decedent died on June 14 last, leaving an estate formally valued at "more than $10,000."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 20. -- In a session marked by sharp debate, the United Lutheran Church in America, in convention here, decided today by a 3-to-1 vote that women members had a right to share with men in the government of the church.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 20. -- It looks as though Barbara Stanwyck would hurry off to London to take over the Bette Davis role in Toeplitz's "I'll Take the Low Road." Immediately after the court decision enjoining Miss Davis's presence in the film was handed down, cables to Miss Stanwyck and to Anna Sten began pouring in.

UTICA, Oct. 20. -- Governor Lehman ranged himself solidly behind President Roosevelt and his New Deal policies in an address here tonight as he swung westward through the State on his campaign tour for re-election.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Oct. 20. -- Connaught O'Connor, 3-year-old daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas O'Connor of 52 Reid Avenue, this village, was drowned while swimming in Manhasset Bay this morning when she struck her head on a rock and floated face down in scarcely more than one foot of water.

The city's first yearbook, called "New York Advancing," to which Mayor La Guardia, as well as his commissioners, contributed, has met with disapproval at the Board of Education as a text for supplementary reading in high school civics classes.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20. -- Delegates to the annual convention of Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization of America, cheered today the reading of a cablegram from Palestine announcing that ground had been broken on Mount Scopus, Jerusalem, for the Rothschild Hadassah University Hospital and Medical School, the first Medical Center in Palestine.

Coach Mal Stevens put the New York University eleven through a three-hour workout yesterday at Ohio Field in preparation for the encounter with Georgetown's undefeated and untied eleven on Saturday at the Yankee Stadium.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 20. -- Governor Landon issued a statement tonight in reply to Secretary Ickes, who declared tonight in Washington that the Republican nominee was a Socialist in that he advocated State-owned telephone and natural gas distribution systems.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20. -- Repudiation by leaders of the Townsend National Recovery Plan and the Union party of any association with the Rev. Gerald L.K. Smith were announced here tonight. The action followed reports from New York that Smith had disclosed his intention to lead a nationalist movement in the United States.

ST. MARTINS, Pa., Oct. 20. -- The grounds and clubhouse of the Philadelphia Cricket Club took on an increasingly international aspect today, as 165 field hockey players, delegates and guests from all parts of the world gathered for the start of the third triennial conference of the International Federation of Women's Hockey Associations.

The effect of transit unification upon the city's borrowing capacity within the constitutional debt limit, under the $436,000,000 plan proposed by City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr. and Samuel Seabury, is none of the Transit Commission's business, but a matter for the Board of Estimate alone to decide, Mr. Berle told the commission at a hearing yesterday.

Remarking that aliens must get over the notion that this country is full of grafters who can twist the law at will for a price, Federal Judge John C. Knox sentenced Romualdo Cossano, 48 years old, radio and opera singer, of 417 West Thirty-ninth Street, to serve six months in the Federal House of Detention.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20. -- One of the important factors which keeps the present maternal mortality rate in the United States higher than that in any other country is the lack of conservatism in performing Caesarian operations, the annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons was told here tonight by Dr. Frank W. Lynch of San Francisco.
I want to express my appreciation of your editorial "Mr. Hoover on the Budget."

HENDAYE, France, Oct. 20. -- News sent to THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday from Valencia that women in Madrid are being arrested and incarcerated in two buildings in the capital, possibly as hostages, has gravely disturbed the governments of Europe, according to advices received at the temporary embassies established here.

For the third successive year Lawrence Marx will head the annual deficit campaign of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, according to an announcement made last night by Felix M. Warburg, chairman of the board of trustees of the federation.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 20. -- Judge Edward J. Quinlan adjourned Superior Court today to the front lawn of Franklin P. Adams's estate in Weston so that he might familiarize himself with the questions involved in the suit brought by Mrs. Adams against the Town Selectmen and a counter-suit brought by the Selectmen against Mrs. Adams.

Five executives of the Keystone Steel and Wire Company received for the fiscal year ended on June 30, last, salaries of $30,445 each, it was disclosed yesterday in the company's annual report to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Postmaster Goldman in your columns by implication denies "that a more favorable rate is obtainable for publications at Chicago than at New York." The fact is, as every publisher must know, that any publication moving from New York to Chicago can save a great deal on its postage bill.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Oct. 20. -- Thirty-four persons were drowned this morning when the steamship Van der Wijck of the Royal Packet Line of Amsterdam capsized in the Java Sea, Netherland India, between the towns of Surabaya and Semarang.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation has called for bids to be opened Nov. 5 on a $4,624,000 issue of 4 per cent equipment-trust certificates of the New York, Chicago St. Louis Railroad Company and fifty-six issues of securities of municipalities, counties and school districts of twenty-one States and the Territory of Alaska, aggregating $3,186,500, all paying 4 per cent interest.

The executive committee for the annual series of Yorkville dinner dances met yesterday at the home of Mrs. Gerardus P. Herrick, 51 East Ninety-first Street, and fixed the dates for the new series of two dances, which will be held on Dec. 1 and Feb. 2 in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Secretary Hull again attacked Governor Landon today for his criticisms of the reciprocal trade agreements' program. Replying to the New Mexico speech of the Republican Presidential candidate, Mr. Hull charged him with "wild misrepresentations of the whole scope, nature and effects of the program."

Beauty shop employes went on strike yesterday in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens in an effort to enforce demands for higher wages, shorter hours and recognition of their organization, the Hairdressers and Cosmetologists Union.

About 60 per cent of all injuries are due to transportation hazards, particularly those caused by automobiles, Dr. John J. Moorhead, Professor of Clinical Surgery of the New York Post-Graduate Medical School of Columbia University, last night told the second-day meeting of the ninth annual graduate fortnight of the New York Academy of Medicine.

The trustees for Margaret E. Zimmerman sold a three-story building at 132 Ninth Avenue to Samuel Goldenberg, who intends to erect a new structure for his own occupancy. The plot is 22 by 80 feet. The Cruikshank Company was the broker.

BERLIN, Oct. 20. -- The amazing progress made in the expansion and technical development of German aviation in the past three years was shown last week to three representatives of American aeronautics.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 20. -- Seven Yale regulars who played in the winning game against Navy Saturday today were sent through a long scrimmage in practice for the Rutgers game.

When the Central Savings Bank sold to Broadfield Equities, Inc., Henry Schaub, president, the flats at 215 W. 140th St., 28x100, for a stated consideration of $19,500, the bank took back a mortgage for $18,.500, payable five years hence, with quarterly amortization of $50 beginning two years from now.

C.J. Brister, vice president of traffic of the New York Central Railroad, told examiners for the Interstate Commerce Commission at a hearing in the Pennsylvania Hotel yesterday that he believed private companies could consolidate and forward less-than-carload freight over the railroads more efficiently than could the railways.

Telegrams assuring Governor Lehman of their hearty endorsement of the action keeping polls open until 9 P.M. on election day were sent to Albany yesterday by spokesmen for package liquor store owners. The retailers added that, despite the fact that they would incur some financial loss by keeping stores closed three hours longer than usual, they considered it a privilege to help in any plan serving the convenience of the public at the polls.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 20. -- The text of Governor Landon's address here tonight was as follows:

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 20. -- Charging that President Roosevelt and members of his administration have attempted unsuccessfully to bring the Supreme Court into disrepute, Governor Landon urged the voters of the United States tonight to support the Constitution and warned them that the re-election of the President would be taken as an endorsement of his program of planned economy and abandonment of the free American system.

Thirty-eight society amateur photographers, including some of the season's debutantes, equipped with cameras and photo-flash lamps, left the Hotel Pierre last evening at 7 o'clock with their escorts to search for the best and most interesting subjects to be photographed in various sections of the city.

With Earl Walsh, assistant coach, back from scouting St. Mary's, Fordham University's football team began preparations yesterday for its encounter with the Galloping Gaels on Saturday at the Polo Grounds.
MADRID, Oct. 17 (Uncensored Dispatch, Delayed). -- Madrid is an open town. Its remoteness is its best defense against foreign enemies, but in a civil war that is different.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 20. -- Mayor Jasper McLevy of Bridgeport and the Right Wing Socialist faction won in Superior Court today and the McLevy ticket will go on the ballots, under the Socialist label instead of the ticket headed by De Vere Allen of Wilton.
