ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Oct. 20 (AP). -- A fierce battle, involving an artillery duel, between the Italian division of General Geloso and an Ethiopian regiment under Dedjaz Abai was disclosed today in dispatches reaching Addis Ababa.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20. -- H.A. Batten, president of N.W. Ayer Son, Inc., made the following statement today:

Registration of visiting buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday was the highest for any week since Sept. 9, when 1,213 were reported. This high total was also well above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.
The Citizens Union made public yesterday its recommendations to the voters on the candidates for the State Assembly in Kings, Queens and Richmond Counties.
WITH INSURGENT ARMIES, near Illescas, Spain, Oct. 20 (AP). -- Motorized columns of Spanish Insurgents today swung the tips of their crescent-shaped line closer to Madrid.

After a lively debate on the church's attitude toward freedom of speech and teachers' loyalty oaths, the New York Presbyterian Synod went on record yesterday in opposition to the oaths and in support of full freedom of expression for all, including advocates of dissenting political creeds.

Having listened on various occasions to an expounding of the theory that a political party platform is a solemn covenant from which no President can justifiably deviate, I am impressed with the conflict between this reasoning and the constitutional plan for the Executive to be free of all restrictions save the Constitution itself.

The final elimination round in the Metropolitan Contract Pair Championship of the American Bridge League for the Oswald Jacoby Trophy was played last night at the Park Central Hotel. At the end oil session thirty-one of the sixty-three teams were eliminated and play will continue to determine the champions.

Flying Banner won the third race at Empire City yesterday after an incident in the stretch which shows that the jockeys are paying close attention to the stewards' rules, or at least Wayne Wright is. The stewards insist that each rider shall keep his course, and swerve neither to the right nor to the left.

ALBANY, Oct. 20. -- The extraordinary session of the Legislature, which met at 1 o'clock this afternoon pursuant to a call from Governor Lehman, adjourned three hours later after passing two bills recommended by the Governor by unanimous vote in both the Democratic Senate and the Republican-controlled Assembly.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Oct. 20. -- The confusion of our social order is reflected in the church and if we took a cross-section of the clergy of America we would find confusion on both the method to be used and the message to be proclaimed, the Rev. Dr. Hugh T. Kerr of Pittsburgh, former Moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States, said today.

By unanimous vote, the Board of Aldermen branch of the Municipal Assembly adopted two local laws yesterday to increase salaries and pensions of police captains with more than five years' service in that rank.

NEWARK, Oct. 20. -- Following the demand made at Washington for access to WPA records, former Ambassador Edge, chairman of the Republican State Campaign Com mittee, tonight sent a demand to John R.M. O'Connor, State manager of the Home Owners Loan Corporation, for access to the lists of home owners who have obtained mortgage loans from the corporation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- President Roosevelt subscribed today to No. 1 membership in the American Red Cross. Admiral Cary T. Grayson, president of the organization, enrolled the President, and Miss Hebe Reynolds, daughter of Major Gen. Charles R. Reynolds, Surgeon General of the Army, pinned the insignia to his lapel.

TRENTON, Oct. 20. -- Former Assemblyman Frederick Von Neida, Mayor of Camden for more than a year, was named to the position illegally by the City Commission, the Court of Errors and Appeals ruled today. The office goes to Commissioner George E. Brunner.

Two new musical productions will invade the Times Square area this morning. The newcomer at the Paramount is "The Big Broadcast of 1937," featuring such radio entertainers as Jack Benny, Burns and Allen, Bob Burns, Benny Fields, Martha Raye, Benny Goodman and his swing orchestra and Leopold Stokowski and his symphony orchestra. . . . The new tenant at the Criterion is "Follow Your Heart," presenting Marion Talley, former Metropolitan Opera singer, and Michael Bartlett.
Lou Gehrig has offered his talent to Hollywood. He is willing temporarily to swap the "Iron Man" nickname for "Tarzan."

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 20. -- An hour's dummy scrimmage against the defensive formations of Navy occupied the main attention of the Princeton football players today, with the entire squad taking part in the practice.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 20. -- Figures released by the Dartmouth athletic council today show that a surplus of $10,806 was on hand at the end of the fiscal year ended June 30, in striking contrast to the deficit of $36,000 for the previous year.

Licenses to teach should be forfeited by all school teachers advocating dostrines subversive to the Government of the United States, Frederick K. Stevens, former member of the Department of Education of New York State, said yesterday before a New York conference of fifty clergymen and laymen at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The McRoberts committee representing holders of notes and debentures of the Standard Gas and Electric Company and the Gerard committee representing prior-preference stocks of the company are cooperating in preparing a "comprehensive" plan for reorganizing the $885,000,000 holding company for presentation soon to all interested parties, it was announced yesterday by J.K. Javits of Javits Javits, counsel for the McRoberts committee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- For the first time in any initial quarter of any fiscal year since 1928, internal revenue collections for the July-September period passed the billion-dollar mark, the Treasury announced today. These collections amounted to $1,009,994,623, an increase of $164,523,370 over the corresponding months last year.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 20 (AP). -- Running right back to her smashing second to Myrtlewood on opening day, Howard Oot's Marica accounted for today's Slickaway Purse in a small but select field at Keeneland Park.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Oct. 20. -- Citizens blocked both front and rear entrances of radio station WBOW here tonight, hurled rotten eggs at Earl Browder, Communist candidate for President, and prevented him from entering the station to make a scheduled radio campaign speech.

OSHAWA, Ont., Oct. 20 (Canadian Press). -- Learning definitely that the National Hockey League had taken over the franchise of their club, the New York Americans went through another stiff workout today, paying little apparent attention to the change in the club's status.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20. -- Prices of hogs slumped today 10 to 20 cents a hundredweight as the result of the largest receipts since last January. This unexpected development and a decline of 1/2 cent in the price of fresh pork loins tended to restrict buying.

Championship pennants in sixteen of eighteen classes that competed in the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound title series during the recent sailing season were confirmed yesterday in official figures sent out by Van S. Merle-Smith, Y.R.A. president.

Bankers here evidently have found a way to shave the costs of gold shipments from England or else they are willing to allow themselves a reduced rate of interest on the funds tied up in such shipments, for several engagements of gold in London have been reported lately when the price of bullion there did not appear to make shipments profitable.

Enrolled Republicans who have organized the Progressive Republican Committee for Roosevelt sent yesterday to former President Hoover a "protest against your sporadic and misleadingly phrased attacks on the President." They severely arraigned the record of the Hoover administration.

Harold Riegelman, counsel for the Citizens Budget Commission, which has steadfastly opposed a three-platoon referendum, last night termed the action of the Legislature a political gesture designed to win votes for both major parties.

Whenever St. Mary's uncovers a football freak (which it does every year), he can always be relied upon to be a more phenomenal phenomenon that any one else ever had. This season's model is Lester Groux, 198-pound halfback. His nickname is "Jes'" and when that is combined with the phonetic sound of his last name it strikes the ear as Jes' Grew -- sort of like Topsy.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 20. -- Former United States Controller John Raymond McCarl urged the American business men today to continue their fight for a balanced national budget.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Alfred E. Smith refused an opportunity to engage in a phonographic-radio debate with President Roosevelt such as was staged last Saturday night by Senator Vandenberg, it was learned yesterday in radio circles.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 20. -- Aiming to enlist the support of organized labor, William F. Bleakley pledged himself tonight to champion its causes of collective bargaining, minimum hours and wages and working conditions, and he assailed the New Deal tariff policy as having lowered the economic position of workers.

Virility and incisiveness were the predominating characteristics of the pianism put forth by Frank Glazer at his debut recital last night in Town Hall. The newcomer, who stems from Wisconsin and is now resident in Boston, was heard by an audience of goodly size which responded heartily to the music he elicited from the keyboard.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Negotiations for a settlement of the strike by members of the American Newspaper Guild which forced The Seattle Post-Intelligencer to suspend publication ended without result today, but they may be resumed if all parties to the dispute accept a proposal to be offered tomorrow by the executive council of the American Federation of Labor.
HAULING a package of maps out of his pocket, Farmer Frank Frisch of New Rochelle said:

The price movement in the bond market on the Stock Exchange was mixed yesterday. Corporate issues were hesitant and less active whereas foreign bonds were firm in increased trading. French Government 7 1/2s, Belgium 6s, Irish Free State 5s and sundry Buenos Aires issues were strong.

BARCELONA, Spain, Oct. 20. -- A general mobilization of all males between 18 and 40 has begun here. They are required to sign enlistment cards and will be called as needed. Catalonia evidently is preparing for a protracted war regardless of the outcome in other parts of Spain.

After listening to Judge Thomas D. Thacher and Charles Evans Hughes Jr., both members of the Charter Revision Commission, explain the proposed city charter, the Association of the Bar of the City of New York at a quarterly meeting last night voted unanimously to approve its adoption.

Department store trade in the metropolitan area during the first half of October showed an increase of 8.4 per cent over the corresponding period last year, according to figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 20. -- Two of yesterday's changes in the Harvard first team were made definite by Coach Dick Harlow today before an hour and a half scrimmage between the varsity and the first rank of substitutes.

LONDON, Oct. 20. -- Amy Johnson Mollison confirmed tonight that she and her husband, Captain James A. Mollison, had amicably agreed to part. Miss Johnson, as she wishes to be known, made the disclosure under dramatic circumstances after she had been injured in an airplane crash.

Strong support of the ice industry's advertising program for 1937 and the establishment of adequate research to strengthen the field against competition were urged yesterday by speakers at the nineteenth annual convention of the National Association of Ice Industries, opening for a four-day session at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

BERLIN, Oct. 20. -- The Hitler Youth organization, by arrangement reached with a broadcasting chain in the United States, will conduct a series of broadcasts for American youth this Winter. The American radio chain will organize an exchange of youth broadcasts between America and Germany.

LONDON, Oct. 20. -- The story of how Gregory Zinovieff, Leon Kameneff, Professor Smirnoff and the other victims of the August "treason trial" in Moscow were executed has reached London by a roundabout route.

Arturo Godoy, South American heavyweight, will make his initial start in a local ring tonight when he opposes LeRoy Haynes, Negro contender from Philadelphia, in the feature ten-round bout at the New York Hippodrome. Haynes has to his credit a pair of victories over Primo Carnera.

BERLIN, Oct. 20. -- A reception as resplendent as any given visiting royalty in pre-war days awaited Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister and son-in-law of Premier Benito Mussolini, when he reached Berlin early this evening for a three-day visit.
The American Labor party, supporting President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman, announced yesterday that New York Typographical Union, No. 6, had affiliated with the new political body.
Directors of the Electric Boat Company yesterday declared a dividend of 60 cents a share on the common stock. This is the first dividend declared by the company since it was organized in May, 1925.

In an attempt to stop the epidemic of burglaries in the residential Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, Acting Captain Patrick Concannon of the Empire Boulevard station announced yesterday that policemen under his command would receive two days or more time off for each burglar they succeeded in catching.
" A team that has been beaten once is dangerous, one that has lost twice doubly dangerous and one that has not won a game out of its last three is positively a menace."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- The hearing ended today before the Securities and Exchange Commission on the application of the Pittsburgh Stock Exchange for unlisted trading privileges in twenty-three issues of stocks and debentures that are fully registered and listed on other Exchanges, most of them on either the New York Stock or the New York Curb Exchange.

AMSTERDAM, Netherlands, Oct. 20. -- The consensus in the Netherlands regarding King Leopold's declaration of neutrality in case of a European conflict in which Belgium is not directly involved is that the Netherlands as a neighbor State can only rejoice in this development.

ALBANY, Oct. 20. -- Following is the text of the bill passed by the Legislature and signed by Governor Lehman under which polling places throughout the State will be kept open for three additional hours:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Contributions of $298,470.67 between Sept. 1 and Oct. 16 were reported to the Clerk of the House today by the New Jersey Republican National Finance Committee. Disbursements of the committee for the same period were $284,828.11.

BERLIN, Oct. 20. -- Relatively speaking, the Boerse boomed today the most notable characteristic being the extent of the interest centered on stocks of producers of raw materials. Transactions in the market indicate that operators appear to be convinced that with either devaluation or undervaluation staples are going up.

MADRID, Oct. 20 (Passed by the Censor). -- The Spanish Government forces launched a fierce counter-attack today against the Rebel column pressing toward Madrid along the main highway from Toledo, and although the result of the fighting was still in doubt tonight, heavy losses were suffered by both sides.

PARIS, Oct. 20. -- The Bourse today repeated yesterday's bad performance. Prices started off firm, then quickly weakened and closed at the lowest levels of the day, with losses substantial among French securities.

LONDON, Oct. 20 (AP). -- Since Mrs. Wallis Simpson filed her divorce suit against Ernest A. Simpson, friends said tonight, she has not seen King Edward so often as she did during the Summer, when she was a frequent royal houseguest.
The text of the radio address delivered last night by John W. Davis, Democratic candidate for President in 1924 and former Ambassador to Great Britain, follows:

Striking with the precision and force that characterized his assaults on the vice and loan shark rings, Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey smashed yesterday at a restaurant racket that has been taking $2,000,000 a year from owners.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 20. -- More than 100 educational leaders representing Midwestern colleges held the first session of a two-day conference at St. Mary's College this afternoon.

Passengers departing for Europe today on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary include Lord Lothian, Lady Bethill, Sir Patrick Hannan, Colonel Harry Day, Sir John Dyer, Lady E.J. Campbell, Countess M. Orlorvska, Countess M. des Monsteirs Meirinville, Sir Reginald Craddock and Sir Ian Hamilton Benn.

John J. Delaney, president of the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, announced yesterday that he had written to William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, protesting the proposal to organize a local union of railroad harbor craft employes as an affiliate of the International Longshoremen's Association.

The resolution adopted last night by the Bar Association, in accordance with the recommendation of its Judiciary Committee, takes the form of a reproach to both political parties in this State. A vacancy in the Court of Appeals is to be filled at the election in November.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 20. -- After assailing critics of his attempted use of electrical transcriptions of President Roosevelt's 1932 and 1933 speeches, Senator Vandenberg in an address here tonight declared he would continue his attacks on the New Deal.

There are 125,000,000 people in the United States and pulling them out of the 1932-33 economic abyss has cost at most -- without making several large and quite justifiable deductions -- $14,000,000,000. That is $112 per person.

An envelope bearing the name of the Republican National Committee brings a communication over the name of John D.M. Hamilton, chairman, explaining "why the Republicans need funds," from which I quote the following:

Carl M. Loeb, stock broker of 910 Park Avenue, won a final victory yesterday over the Treasury Department, which back in 1922 began pestering him when it decided that there was something wrong with his 1917 income return and that he still owed $245,517.48 for that year.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 20. -- Governor Landon was both cheered and booed this afternoon as he entered Los Angeles, reputedly a Roosevelt stronghold.

The three young daughters of Detective Daniel Sullivan took the witness stand against him yesterday in the Kings County Court, where he is being tried on a charge of first-degree murder for the death of his wife, Helen, on the morning of Sept. 15, 1935.

Starting at scratch in 1931, the ice refrigeration industry has today reached the status of a national advertiser and looks forward to the sale of some 600,000 air-conditioned ice refrigeration units in 1937. Advertising campaigns, begun in a small way in 1932, will be sharply increased for next year and will be carried in newspapers throughout the country and in many national magazines.

Why did a million Chicago people come out in the streets to see and hear President ROOSEVELT? They could see him in the news reels and listen to him on the radio. That Chicago parade comes to mind when Senator VANDENBERG says that American liberty is in danger of being throttled by the broadcasting magnates.

From the Republican National Committee at Chicago comes another report of financial worry. Not half the planned budget of $8,000,000 has come in, and the sorrowful explanation is added that few "large gifts" to the campaign fund are at present being made.
Commercial rentals reported by brokers yesterday indicated a demand for store space.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 20. -- Amendment of the Robinson-Patman Anti-Price Discrimination Act "to lift the burden of a constant fear of violation from the business man" was urged here today by Irving C. Fox, counsel of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, before a retail merchandising institute of upper New York State merchants.

The quarterly meeting of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, attended by more than 200 members, adopted by acclamation last night resolutions condemning both the Democratic and Republican parties in this State as being guided by "political considerations" in nominating candidates for the vacancy in the Court of Appeals.
BARSTOW, Calif., Oct. 20 -- Following is the text of Governor Landon's address here today:

Most futures were lower in generally light trading on the local commodity markets yesterday, although hides and wool tops improved slightly. On the cash markets silk rose, while wheat, corn, oats, cotton, rubber, cocoa and tin declined.

A political symposium at which Earl Browder, Communist candidate for the Presidency, and Harry Laidler, Socialist candidate for Governor, were to speak, and a protest meeting for Robert Burke, dismissed Columbia student, were banned from the City College campus yesterday by Dr. John R. Turner, dean of men.

Preparing for its intersectional battle with the University of Detroit at Ebbets Field Saturday, the Manhattan football team reviewed its passing offense and defense in a scrimmage against the freshman eleven at Innisfail Park yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP). -- The Republican National Committee asserted tonight that PWA grants from Sept. 8 to Oct. 10 showed "an increase where the New Deal figures an increase might be politically beneficial," and that it went mostly to "so-called doubtful States."

In an effort to symbolize the antiquity of New York City's charter, members of the City Club arrived at City Hall at noon yesterday in a fifty-year-old horse-drawn bus with two new streamlined buses alongside to provide contrast.

LONDON, Oct. 20. -- The Associated British Picture and Gaumont-British Picture Corporations issued further statements tonight concerning their deal for Associated British Picture's control of Gaumont-British.

Reports of more favorable cotton crop prospects in parts of the South caused additional liquidation and some foreign selling yesterday but with Southern hedge selling moderating and the trade fixing prices at each point decline, quotations gave way slowly on the Cotton Exchange.

After adding about $1,000,000 yesterday to the 1937 executive budget prepared by Mayor La Guardia, members of the Board of Estimate fixed the top limit of the tax levy budget next year at $554,998,917.

Led by Ken Strong, the New York Football Yankees will make their first appearance tonight at the Yankee Stadium with the Pittsburgh Americans as their opponents. The opening kick-off is scheduled for 8:30 o'clock. This, incidentally, marks the first night football game to be staged in the Bronx ball park and an entirely new lighting system has been installed.

A man identified by his fingerprints as Joseph Jacobs, 35 years old, an ex-convict whose last address was 131 Jackson Avenue, Nyack, N.Y., was found shot to death last night in front of an apartment house at 8 West Sixteenth Street, half a block from St. Francis Xavier's Roman Catholic College.

LONDON, Oct. 20. -- The British Government completed arrangements with six companies today for the erection of factories for the production of airplane engines in the event of a war situation. The factories will go into permanent operation only when an emergency arises.

Referee John P. Cohalan, presiding in Supreme Court Building yesterday in disciplinary proceedings against J. Richard Davis, who was attorney for the late Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer and other policy racketeers, denied a Motion by Irving Ben Cooper, representing the Bar Association, for open proceedings.
Two hunters are dead and a dozen others suffered wounds during the first day's hunting for small game in New York State woods and fields.

William F. Bleakley, Republican candidate for Governor, was heavily indebted to Westchester County banks while he was on the Supreme Court bench in that county and sat in a case in which the Westchester Trust Company of Yonkers, one of the banks to which he owed money, was a defendant, according to charges published yesterday by The New York Post.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 20. -- Officials of the Resettlement Administration and the State Conservation Commission outlined plans today for converting 30,000 acres of sub-marginal farm and woodland in nine areas into game preserves.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20. -- Scattered liquidation by tired holders of wheat contracts was met by steady absorption by commission houses, resulting in prices on the Board of Trade holding within narrow limits and net changes at the and were confined to small fractions.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20. -- Thirteen hundred Democrats sat down to dinner at the Penn Athletic Club tonight and thereby added at least $130,000 to the party's campaign fund in Pennsylvania.

A syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers won the award yesterday of a new issue of $2,200,000 of water works bonds of the city of Los Angeles, Calif., on a bid of par plus a premium of $100 for the issue as 2 3/4s and 3 1/2s, The winning bid represented a net interest cost to the city of 2.923 per cent.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 20. -- City Commissioner George Brunner, Democratic State Committeeman from Camden County, expects to take the oath of office as Mayor of Camden within the next ten days as the result of today's court decision ousting Frederick Von Neida, Republican, from the post.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 20. -- George Reeves, retired Indianapolis merchant, was reported improved at White Plains Hospital today, and Mrs. Reeves, niece of Mrs. Ida Lilly Churchill of 15 Prescott Road, White Plains, remained in a serious condition as authorities delayed presentation to the grand jury of charges of a poison plot that sent them to the hospital.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- In a speech tonight on the subject "Is Landon Sincere?" Secretary Ickes declared that in February of last year Governor Landon suggested that Mr. Ickes, as administrator of the PWA, obtain authority to make loans to States for public Statewide telephone systems.
HAMBURG, Germany, Oct. 20. -- Dr. Walter Hoffmann, director of the Hamburg-American Line, states that German shipping companies are not really making profits despite improved transatlantic business.

TRENTON, Oct. 20. -- Warren Eaton of Bloomfield, N.J., a woolen goods salesman, petitioned the Court of Errors and Appeals today to dismiss the appeal of Mrs. Mabel Eaton of Montclair from the decree of divorce awarded to him by the Court of Chancery.

Possibly in reply to those who have criticized the Republican point of view in the present campaign as too narrowly national, Governor LANDON asserted in the first speech of his new Western tour that "the most important problem" now facing the United States is the recapture of our lost export markets.

DETROIT, Oct. 20 (AP). -- Chester P. O'Hara, Assistant State Attorney General, asserting that Wayne County Prosecutor Duncan C. McCrea had taken the oath of the Black Legion, intervened today in a common pleas court examination of twenty alleged nightriders charged with criminal syndicalism.

Attorneys exchanged taunts, stenographers' pencils shortened and a glossy limousine waited outside the County Court House yesterday while Father Divine gently but effectively rebuffed efforts to learn his part, if any, in the business affairs of his Harlem and Ulster County "heavens."

CHICAGO, Oct. 20. -- Every surface indication favors the Democrats this year in their effort to win, as in 1932, the twenty-nine electoral votes of Illinois -- third largest of the delegations that make up the so-called "college." The structural strength of one of the most powerful political organizations in the United States is also on the President's side.

MOSCOW, Oct. 20. -- The Madrid government, its back to the wall, is pressing the Soviet Union to rush airplanes to Spain, and although the Soviet plan of action is still closely guarded it is widely believed here that this will be one of the measures by which she expects to save the Spanish Popular Front regime.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Former Ambassador Walter E. Edge and three other New Jersey Republicans obtained a show cause order today in the Federal District Court here on their petition for a writ of mandamus to compel Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, to grant access to WPA records before Nov. 3.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20. -- An organized effort by the nation's business concerns to combat "gigantic government expenses" was called for today by Colonel Clarence O. Sherrill, president of the American Retail Federation, at the regional business conference sponsored by the Philadelphia Chamber of Commerce.

A "hopeless deadlock" of the Jury resulted last night at the mock trial of a fictitious case under the Robinson-Patman Anti-Price Discrimination Act, held under the auspices of the Sales Executives Club of New York in the Hotel Astor.

John W. Davis, Democratic candidate for the Presidency in 1924, in a radio speech last night which marked his entrance into the political campaign this year, bitterly attacked the Roosevelt administration and indicated his intention of voting for Governor Landon on election day.

CARMEL, N.Y., Oct. 20. -- It's the second day of the New York upland game season. . . . The slanting rays of an Indian Summer sun brighten the rapidly fading foliage on the Putnam hillsides. . . . And speaking of colors and gunning, you are reminded of that bird of dazzling plumage, the ringneck pheasant. . . .

Because of high estate taxes the late JESSE ISIDOR STRAUS, a man noted for his charities, added to his will a codicil revoking eighteen philanthropic bequests amounting to about $1,000,000. Dr. FRANK E. ADAIR told the Clinical Congress of the American College of Surgeons that "more such codicils have "been attached to wills during the past "five years than in the previous fifty."
WARSAW, Poland, Oct. 20. -- General Edward Rydz-Smigly, commander-in-chief of the Polish Army, is to be named Marshal of Poland on Independence Day, Nov. 11.

John D.M. Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, held his final campaign conference with New York State leaders of the party yesterday afternoon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Mr. Hamilton arrived here in the morning, had lunch with the leaders, and the talk lasted through until the dinner hour.

The Hon. SIMON MOULTON HAMLIN, Representative in Congress of the First Maine District, has a clear right, if any man ever had, to draw up a bill of complaint against ingratitude, thou marble-hearted fiend. He is the first Democrat sent to Washington by that district since 1862.

LENOX, Mass., Oct. 20. -- R. Jay Flick of New York today declined re-election as president of the Lenox Horse Show Association, at the annual meeting held at the Lenox Club, and Robert G. Stewart was named in his place, Mr. Flick accepted election as vice president.
All sections were represented in apartment leasing yesterday, the activity taking in the East and West Sides, midtown and Greenwich Village. The new tenants included the following:

FORT DODGE, Iowa, Oct. 20 (AP). -- Colonel Frank Knox, Republican Vice Presidential nominee, advanced his Midwestern campaign tonight by asserting that President Roosevelt, in business life, had always "associated with money-changers, stock operators and rich men."
Thirty-two pairs entered the final rounds for the Metropolitan Pair Championship of the American Bridge League last night at the Park Central Hotel. The final session will be held tonight.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 21 (AP). -- The Rev. Dr. William Appleton Lawrence, rector of Grace Church, Providence, today was elected Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Western Massachusetts to succeed Thomas F. Davies, who died Aug. 25.

BOSTON, Oct. 21 (AP). -- Summing up what he called the dangers to the immediate future of American business in the one word "uncertainty," C.M. Chester, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, today urged business men to "rout out from among us that small minority which has been responsible for providing any basis for popular disapproval of American industry."

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 21 (AP). -- Memory Book, carrying the popular silks of Mrs. Payne Whitney's Greentree Stable, proved a handy winner today of the first running of the Breeders' Stakes, a mile and a quarter test for 3-year-olds and upward excluding geldings, the top offering of the Keeneland inaugural meet.

The main problem now confronting the city concerning parks and playgrounds is to raise the necessary funds for proper maintenance, Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger, president of the Park Association of Hew York City, Inc., declared yesterday at a luncheon in the course of the association's tenth annual tour of parks in Queens.

Archbishop Athenagoras of the Greek Orthodox Church in North and South America, at a special service yesterday afternoon in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, formally presented to Bishop William T. Manning an icon of St. John the Divine.

MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 21. -- A statement attacking the American Labor party as "communistic" was issued today by the Republican organization of Nassau County, following a local political dispute over the barring of the Labor party from holding a rally in a public building.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 21. -- Thomas Hitchcock's Rioter, perfectly handled by Rigan McKinney, the gentleman rider, today annexed the twenty-fifth running of the Chevy Chase Steeplechase Handicap, feature event of the Maryland Fair, Inc., program.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 21. -- Governor Lehman denounced William F. Bleakley, his Republican opponent, here tonight as a spreader of a "malicious rumor" that he was tied up with financial interests opposed to the dairy farmers.

Genial Jim Crowley, his face wearing a look of solemn concentration like a small boy at his homework, conducted class at Fordham Field yesterday afternoon. It was the practice session of the Fordham eleven, which on Saturday faces St. Mary's at the Polo Grounds, but there was more the atmosphere of the classroom about the field than of the regular football practice.

Ellis H. Parker was depicted in the Newark Federal grand jury's indictment against him yesterday as an overambitious county detective who had hoped to hoodwink the public and make "big money" by writing a book on how he had "solved" the Lindbergh case.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Oct. 21. -- Crashing through with a record-breaking second round, Walter Scheiber, tall Cedarwood professional, today captured the Long Island Professional Golfers Association title.

An underwriting group headed by Brown Harriman Co., Inc., will offer today at $97 a share, to yield about 5.15 per cent, a new issue of 150,000 shares of 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock of $100 par value, with common stock purchase warrants, of Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., a Canadian corporation.

A Brooklyn bus driver, who is a skilled airplane pilot, took a young friend aloft for a joy ride at dusk yesterday, made a forced landing in the wilds of New York City and lived to tell the story over juicy steaks in a Canarsie restaurant after their rescue by one of nearly half a dozen relief expeditions.

IT probably was a good thing for Princeton that it lost to Penn, though it would have been hard to convince the Tiger cheering section on that point just after the downfall of the Crisler-coached eleven on Franklin Field. But it's a good thing for every college team to lose once in a while. Otherwise, football success looms too large on the campus horizon.

Navy has never crossed the Princeton goal line during Fritz Crisler's regime as coach of the Tigers, but the Midshipmen, still smarting from the close setback at the hands of Yale last week, will make a valiant bid to break this jinx when they invade Palmer Stadium on Saturday.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 21. -- Premier George Tatarescu of Rumania arrived here this morning for an unexpected visit that every endeavor was made to surround with secrecy.

LISBON, Portugal, Oct. 21. -- The capture of Navalcarnero today by Spanish Rebel forces was accomplished in one of the pincer movements by which Generalissimo Francisco Franco has been gradually forcing his way toward Madrid. Troops moved on the town simultaneously from the northwest, west and south.

Seventy-one men and women in the professions have joined in an appeal for support of Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President. They included physicians, teachers, editors, writers, artists and several clergymen.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 21 -- About 70,000 Slav refugees from Italy who are now living in Yugoslavia are threatening a mass movement away from the Roman Catholic Church to the Orthodox Church and are protesting the re-removal of the Catholic Bishop of Trieste, Dr. Foger.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21. -- A survey by the American College of Surgeons of the medical services of 1,593 industrial establishments in the United States and Canada, conducted during twelve months ending Sept. 30, reveals that 776 industrial plants having 500 or more employes each, or a total of nearly 2,500,000 workers, do not have adequate medical services.

The Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation issued yesterday its financial statement for the third quarter of this year, showing a net income of $8,111,897 after interest, depreciation, provision for income and other charges. The income equals 90 cents a share on 9,000,743 shares outstanding.

Mrs. Eleanor Holm Jarrett, smarter in the ways of the world and even prettier, is doing all right by herself since the day she was removed from the American Olympic team for drinking too much champagne. Dollars are rolling in along with offers that promise to make her wealthy and independent -- if any one believes Mrs. Jarrett ever was anything but independent, The Associated Press reports.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21. -- Receipts of hogs again were above trade expectations today, and with prospects of a good movement continuing, prices declined 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight, with lights showing the most weakness. The top dropped 10 cents to $9.90, a new low level since May, while the day's average was off 10 cents at $9.40.
In a study of Mr. HULL'S trade treaties prepared by the Foreign Policy Association there occurs this interesting statement:

Miss Constance Thurlow, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Thurlow of 830 Park Avenue, and Russell E. Pierce won the first prize of $150 for their flashlight photograph of "the tired feet of a laundry horse" in the "Night Picture Hunt," it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 21. -- News reached the British Government tonight that all prisoners held by the Spanish Loyalist forces at Cartagena had been summarily shot in reprisal for Insurgent air attacks there yesterday.

The expression "a one-horse stable" usually makes the listener think of some struggling horseman who cannot afford oats and feed for more than that number. But there are a surprising number of members of the Union, Racquet and Tennis, Brook and other swank clubs who still have one horse to keep their connection with racing.
HENDAYE, France, Oct. 21 (AP). -- The wife of President Azana arrived at Toulouse from Spain by air today and left immediately for Paris.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Three questions have been bothering me for some time, and to date I have noticed no discussion of them.

The Citizens Committee on the Control of Crime in New York, suggested last August by the extraordinary grand jury that investigated vice and racketeering, was formally organized yesterday at 120 Broadway, with Harry F. Guggenheim as chairman.

NANKING, China, Thursday, Oct. 22. -- A conference between Foreign Minister Chang Chun of China and Ambassador Shigeru Kawagoe of Japan failed yesterday to ease the Chino-Japanese diplomatic tension, and it appeared probable today that the negotiations would not be resumed unless Tokyo abandoned its demands for Chino-Japanese cooperation against communism in China.
WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 21. -- Following are the texts of the addresses made by President Roosevelt today in this city and at Boston:

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 (AP). -- Secretary Ickes asserted tonight that Governor Landon had "confessed" in a statement from Los Angeles that "he plotted to set up a $35,000,000 corporation in Kansas without the knowledge or consent of the people to engage in the business of producing and marketing natural gas."

With the total demand for white-collar workers in the metropolitan district showing an increase of 19.9 per cent during the first nine months of this year over the comparative 1935 period, "realization is spreading that a shortage of skilled office workers under 30 years old is a current market fact," according to the semi-annual survey to be issued today by the National Employment Exchange.

That modern ice refrigeration comprises the third stage in the development of refrigeration in this country and surpasses the old wooden ice box and the newer mechanical unit, the first two stages, will be contended in the extensive advertising campaign the National Association of Ice Industries will start in 1937, Hurley G. Hurst, advertising director of National Ice Advertising, Inc., announced yesterday at the group's annual convention in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21. -- A charge that the Communist Party in this country had received direct orders from the Third International to give President Roosevelt "indirect support" in the present campaign was made tonight by Norman Thomas, Socialist nominee for President.

TORONTO, Oct. 21 (AP). -- A few hours after calling the Max Baer-Dutch Weimer fight here Monday "a fake, a fiasco and a disgrace to the sport in this Province," Premier Mitchell F. Hepburn today appointed P.J. Mulqueen chairman of the Ontario Athletic Commission to succeed Dr. J.A. Faulkner, Minister of Health.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Reading in THE TIMES of the difficulties confronting the New York, Westchester Boston Railway revives my prediction made at the time the road was opened, that it would never meet with any measure of success without adequate terminals. I repeat that today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am interested in letters recently published in THE NEW YORK TIMES under caption of "Favoring Mr. Roosevelt," signed by General John F. O'Ryan; also a contribution by Dr. Will Durant under caption "Sizing Up the Campaign." Few men in our national or civic life have attained or deserved a greater measure of respect than General O'Ryan and Dr. Durant.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 21. -- President Angell of Yale University today denied that the failure of the Yale Corporation to reappoint Dr. Jerome Davis, Associate Professor of Practical Philanthropy, in the divinity school constituted a dismissal or involved academic freedom.

BERLIN, Oct. 21. -- Something more impressive than a polite exhibition of diplomatic-back-scratching will issue from the conversations progressing at the Foreign Office between Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Italian Foreign Minister, and Baron Constantin von Neurath, the German Foreign Minister, it is expected in neutral diplomatic quarters here.

Arturo Godoy, the Chilean heavyweight who stopped Luis Angel Firpo's comeback march, made his first New York appearance last night and fought a ten-round draw with LeRoy Haynes of Philadelphia at the Hippodrome.

David A. Schulte, testifying yesterday, because of illness, in his home at 1 East Eighty-eighth Street before Federal Referee Peter B. Olney, described an intercompany deal which resulted in the sale of the Dasco Realty Corporation, representing an original investment of $13,000, for $2,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- The political fight in Pennsylvania inspired contributions to the Republicans totaling $574,367.34 outside of the Pittsburgh district, the Clerk of the House was informed today in a report made by Jay Cooke, treasurer of the finance committee of the Republican National Committee and of the Republican State Committee.

Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins decided yesterday that teachers in Columbia University have a right to register and vote and also ruled that persons otherwise entitled to vote should not be barred because they happen to live in college dormitories.

The engagement of $6,328,000 of gold in England for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank by local commercial banks. Of this amount, $896, 000 was taken on Tuesday. These engagements brought to about $51, 000,000 the total of gold taken in England for shipment here since the suspension of the gold standard in France.

Miss Lucile Thieriot has enlisted the aid of several younger members of society to serve with her in behalf of the membership drive for funds to further the work of the social service department of the Cancer Institute at 124 East Fifty-ninth Street.
OTTAWA, Oct. 21. -- After years of postponement, indecision and tacit reliance for protection on the Monroe Doctrine, Canada has decided to carry out a more adequate policy of national defense.

ON THE ESCORIAL FRONT WITH LIEUT. COL. RODA'S INFANTRY, Oct. 21. -- Sixty Loyalists are trapped in a mile-long tunnel just north of Robledo. They are the crew of an armored train that was sent against Rebel forces in this sector.
Hit-and-run automobile drivers were warned yesterday afternoon in Traffic Court by Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio that the traffic laws protect both animals and humans.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 21. -- Behind the recent neutrality declaration of Belgium is an internal struggle now threatening to split the country into two blocs.

Glenn Morris and Jesse Owens, outstanding among America's Olympic heroes, are waging a close battle in the preliminary balloting for the 1936 award of the James E. Sullivan Trophy, voted annually to the athlete "who by his performance, his example and his influence as an amateur and a man has done most during the year to advance the cause of sportsmanship."

The theory of "rugged individualism" is "visionary" and the cooperative spirit based on the "Sunday thinking" of the churches provides the only practical course for business, Edward A. Filene, Boston merchant, told members of the New York Presbyterian Synod last night at their dinner at the Towers Hotel in Brooklyn.

Edwin Howland Blashfield, noted American mural painter and for thirty-eight years president of the National Academy of Design, who died last Oct. 12, bequeathed $25,000 to the academy and directed that upon the death of his wife one-half of his residuary estate be distributed among fifteen charitable, educational and religious institutions.

Demand for a few selected public utility loans marked otherwise routine trading in mixed undertone in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The utility price average was lifted 0.30 point by gains in Indianapolis Power and Light 4s, International Telephone and Telegraph issues, Interborough 7s and Third Avenue adjustment 5s.

Scrimmaging for the second day in succession, Manhattan's football team yesterday completed heavy preparations for its intersectional battle with the University of Detroit at Ebbets Field Saturday. The Jaspers went at it for more than two hours at Innisfail Park, with every player on the squad seeing action.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor overruled today the objections of the spokesmen for the American Newspaper Guild and the Seattle Newspaper Guild and transmitted to all parties in the dispute a proposal designed as a possible basis for peace in The Seattle Post-Intelligencer strike.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- In a registration statement filed today under the Securities Act of 1933 for a proposed issue of $25,000,000 of bonds for the purpose of raising new capital, the Republic Steel Corporation of Cleveland announced that it had under consideration expenditures exceeding $30,000,000 for expansion and improvements.

Magazine publishers were wondering yesterday whether the decision of the Richmond, Va., safety director to censor all magazines shipped into that city would be a help or a hindrance to them. According to reports from Richmond, Safety Director John A. Cutchins said he would appoint a committee of five citizens to do the censoring.

HENDAYE, France, Oct. 21. -- After a preliminary aerial and artillery bombardment the Spanish Rebel forces launched a general offensive on the defenses of Madrid this afternoon. Navalcarnero, one of the last important government strongholds near the capital, fell before the Insurgent drive and apparently gave the Rebels a clear road into the capital from the southwest.

James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, who previously had qualified his predictions that President Roosevelt would win New Jersey and Delaware, claimed both States positively yesterday.
SHANGHAI, Oct. 21. -- Chinese circles here see in the newest appoint ments in North China efforts at extension of Japanese influence there.
PHOENIX, Oct. 21. -- The text of Governor Landon's speech here was as follows:

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 21. -- Announcement was made today at the annual meeting of the Berkshire Symphonic Festival, Inc., held at the home of Miss Gertrude Robinson Smith, president, that the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Dr. Serge Koussevitsky, conductor, will return next August for six concerts over two week-ends, if the festival association provides a music shed.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 21. -- A picture of the State's financial condition which is "fictitious, false, and deliberately misleading," has been given to the voters and taxpayers by Governor Lehman, William F. Bleakley charged here tonight.

The Radio City Music Hall provides Manhattan with its only new film today. It is "Adventure in Manhattan," with Joel McCrea and Jean Arthur. The newest edition of "The March of Time," a part of the program, presents a screen discussion of the rift in the American Federation of Labor over the formation of the Committee for Industrial Organization by John L. Lewis.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 21. -- The Yale veterans who were fought almost to a standstill in sinking a stubborn and well-drilled Navy eleven last Saturday, 12 to 7, were nearly all excused from practice today. They have had no severe football since the struggle at Baltimore.

Richard Whitney, Felix Warburg, Mrs. Ogden Reid, Dr. George E. Vincent and other speakers united last night in praising the work of the Visiting Nurse Service of the Henry Street Settlement as indispensable to the community, vital to the patients, and of "missionary" value to the world.

John D.M. Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, in an interview here yesterday, charged that the Roosevelt administration, if re-elected, will "dump" the regular Democratic organizations in New York City in favor of the American Labor party and Mayor La Guardia, with the patronage going to them.

Miss Constance Armstrong entertained at luncheon yesterday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin for Lady Sheldon. Other guests were Mrs. Frank Evans, wife of the British Consul in San Francisco; Mrs. Paul T. Kammerer Jr., Mrs. John E. M. Aniff and Miss Teresa R. O'Donohue.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Oct. 21. -- Reports that Rumania is about to adopt an anti-Russian policy likely to lead to a break-up of the Little Entente are regarded here as premature and exaggerated. They arise from the fact that Victor Antonescu, the new Foreign Minister, was put in office because of King Carol's desire to break with Nicolas Titulescu's policy.

A new opera by Dr. Walter Damrosch entitled "A Man Without a Country" will be produced by the Metropolitan Opera Association at its next Spring season in 1937, Dr. Damrosch disclosed yesterday. Edward Ziegler, assistant general manager of the Metropolitan, said that no definite date during the Spring season had been picked and the cast had not yet been selected.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 21. -- A philosophy of social security as well as laws are needed if the nation is to develop an adequate social program, Jane M. Hoey, director of the Bureau of Public Assistance of the Federal Security Board in Washington, told the State Conference of Social Work tonight.

MOSCOW, Oct. 21. -- Today was the third of the three which Soviet officials, in discussing possible Soviet action against intervention by Fascist countries in Spain, said would be critical in European history. It passed without anything happening as far as could be learned and without a hint of how the Soviet would aid the Spanish Government after the Soviet withdraws from the neutrality agreement.
Practically every top flight trotter and pacer in the country has been named for the Tour rich stake events to be added to the 1937 Grand Circuit program.

LONDON, Oct. 21. -- The dramatic completeness of the change in the European situation is well illustrated by news which a year ago would have been dismissed as incredible but which today people calmly discuss as quite probable: the famous League of Nations Union of Great Britain is facing, if not dissolution, at least radical transformation of its activities.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 21. -- The "Millionaires' Alimony Defiance Society," a nation-wide "protective" organization of wealthy men being or have been sued by their wives, is being formed by Samuel Willis Rushmore of 777 Belvidere Avenue, this city, a wealthy inventor with experience in marriage and divorce.

PARIS, Oct. 21. -- Most of the debate in the foreign affairs' commission of the Chamber of Deputies today centered on Spain. Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos defended France's neutrality, although hotly pressed by criticisms from the Right and Left.

An unusual mural for children, entitled "Puppets and Marionettes," designed and executed by Max Spivak, a WPA artist, has just been completed, according to information received from the Federal Art Project, 6 East Thirty-ninth Street. The work makes use of the make-believe world of puppets as a point of departure for caricature and fantasy.

Commodity futures generally were higher yesterday. Sugar and rubber, however, were under pressure and showed sizable losses. In the cash market, wheat, corn, rye, oats, cocoa, butter and wool tops were higher, while cotton, silk, tin and rubber were lower.

Before 26,000 enthusiastic fans, many of whom swarmed onto the field in the closing stages and delayed the game, the New York Yankees defeated the Pittsburgh Americans, 7 to 6, in their American Football League game at the Yankee Stadium last night.

The Junior League of Brooklyn, of which Miss Arrietta Smith is president, met for the first time this Autumn yesterday at luncheon in the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn. Mrs. William P. Earle Jr., a member of the New York City Charter Commission, was the guest of honor and speaker.

Tenders will be considered on Oct. 29 by officials of Union Free School District 18 of Hempstead, L.I., for a new issue of $450,000 of school bonds, dated Nov. 1, 1936, and maturing Nov. 1, 1937 to 1956. Bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 6 per cent.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 21. -- Mahlon B. Smith, claimant to the title of "Oldest Erie Commuter," celebrated his eighty-ninth birthday tonight with a small party for neighbors at his home, 393 Prospect Avenue, here, where he lives with his sister, Miss Mabel Smith.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Oct. 21 (AP). -- Expressing disgust after being thwarted for the second time in three weeks in his effort to make a campaign address here, Earl Browder, Communist candidate for President, left today for New York with the parting statement that he hoped "the Constitution may eventually be enforced in Terre Haute."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21. -- Pennsylvania coaches concentrated on reserve back field and end material today in a long scrimmage in wihch Dick Crosson scored a touchdown against the junior varsity on a 30-yard run through left tackle.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 21 (AP). -- Closing an eight-day biennial meeting, the United Lutheran Church in America selected Baltimore today as the place of its twentieth anniversary convention in 1938.

Resubmission to stockholders of the refunding plan of the Central Hudson Gas and Electric Corporation to comply with a ruling of the Securities and Exchange Commission was announced yesterday by Ernest R. Acker, president of the company.

As a nation-wide search was launched yesterday for the five fugitives who have been indicted with nine other men in the $2,000,000 restaurant racket the identities of two of the missing men were made public at the headquarters of Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of rackets.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 (AP). -- Out on the Pacific Coast they call them the Galloping Gaels, but the squad Slip Madigan brought into Chicago today, carrying St. Mary's colors on a 7,000-mile jaunt across the country and back again, was more fitted for hobbling than galloping. That is, if you believe Coach Madigan.

LONDON, Oct. 21. -- The first mention in any publication in the United Kingdom of the divorce action that the King's friend, Mrs. Ernest A. Simpson, is bringing against her husband on the ground of infidelity appeared tonight in two London weekly publications.
J.V. Selover of Milltown, N.J., reminds us that on Nov. 1 several thousand followers of the nocturnal sport of coon hunting will take to the wooded swamps and mountain country of New Jersey.

Igor Stravinsky, composer, has accepted a commission from the American Ballet to write a new ballet for its repertoire, it was announced yesterday. The ballet, the announcement said, will have its premiere in New York next Spring at which time it is hoped that a program of three of Mr. Stravinsky's ballets will be performed with the new work included.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21. -- Delegates to the convention of Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization of America, pledged themselves today to plant 10,000 trees in Palestine as a tribute to Justice Brandeis on his eightieth birthday on Nov. 13.
The National Council of Jewish Women opened yesterday its new headquarters on the ninth floor of 221 Wrest Fifty-seventh Street.

PARIS, Oct. 21. -- After three days of receding prices the Bourse reversed its trend today, French stocks progressing and international shares becoming irregular. The franc, however, showed marked weakness, and rentes generally lost ground slightly.

ALBANY, Oct. 21. -- Justice Gilbert V. Schenck issued an order today restraining the Secretary of State from putting the Union party ticket on the State ballot for the Nov. 3 election, and an appeal was taken immediately to the Appellate Division. The case will be argued tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP). -- The cotton-spinning industry was reported by the Census Bureau today to have reached a higher percentage of activity during September than in any month since June, 1933.

The Railway Express Agency, which the railroads of the country bought for $32,000,000 in 1928, is losing traffic as a result of arrangements between individual railroads and freight consolidating companies, according to evidence introduced by William J. Walsh, attorney for the Interstate Commerce Commission, before examiners for the commission in the Pennsylvania Hotel yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- Charges made by Arthur M. Curtis, assistant to the chairman of the Republican National Committee, that there was a shortage of $5,000,000 in relief funds in Missouri, were branded as false today by Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator.

James A. Beha, who was New York State Superintendent of Insurance from 1924 to 1928, was elected yesterday general counsel for the Association of Casualty and Surety Executives and the National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters at their annual meeting held at 1 Park Avenue.
LONDON, Oct. 21. -- Germany angrily pleaded not guilty today to charges that she had violated her pledges of non-intervention in the Spanish civil war.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

To the Editor of The New York Times: I do not think any one will question your view that rents in the Williamsburg Housing Project are too high to permit the tenants of the old buildings to live there. I wonder whether any appreciable number of these families would willingly live in the new buildings even though the rent were no higher.

The following film programs, which will be shown over the weekend, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local private and public elementary and high schools:

The Central Hudson Gas and Electric Corporation's mix-up with the Securities and Exchange Commission, which necessitated resubmission yesterday to stockholders of the company's preferred stock refunding plan, means that stockholders will have to act quickly.

Japanese civilian authorities, in their perennial jockeying with the high military command for control of national policies, have won at least temporary gains on two fronts: In China, where the negotiations between the Japanese Ambassador and the Chinese Foreign Minister for the settlement of the chief differences between the two countries have proceeded amicably, despite repeated public pronouncements of Japanese Army officers that decisive military action was imminent.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 21. -- The definite transfer of Joseph Nee, rangy Boston junior, from guard to tackle was made today when Nee made his initial appearance on the first Harvard team at right tackle as the Crimson started applying the finishing touches on its preparation for Dartmouth.
Alderman Morton Moses, crusader against bundle-carrying in the subways, found his mail box swollen yesterday with letters expressing varying reactions to his efforts.

Coach Mal Stevens quickened the pace for the New York University football team yesterday at Ohio Field in preparation for the encounter with the Georgetown eleven on Saturday at the Yankee Stadium. Three hours of intensive drilling were spent on Hoya plays.

ALBANY, Oct. 21. -- With a well nigh impregnable Democratic organization here, dominated by the O'Connell brothers, Albany County is perhaps the blackest spot in the State, outside of New York City, from a Republican point of view.

An indication of the interest in the coming National Horse Show, scheduled for Nov. 4-10, was evidenced by the announcement yesterday by Ned King, manager of the exhibition, that all 391 stalls available in Madison Square Garden have been booked.

The retirement of David Lindsay, assistant general passenger traffic manager of the International Mercantile Marine Company and an employe of the company for forty-four years, was announced yesterday. Mr. Lindsay will quit his post at the end of the year, because of illness.

Although the stock market showed a firmer tone yesterday, the volume of trading contracted for the third consecutive session. The trend was irregular; leading stocks were fractionally higher, but an analysis of all stocks dealt in on the Stock Exchange showed that more issues declined than advanced.

MADRID, Oct. 21. -- When this correspondent went to the fighting front south of Madrid today he found the Loyalist forces, reinforced by fresh men, had moved their lines beyond Torrejon on the road to Toledo and were only a few miles outside Illescas.

A membership drive which will result in the establishment of the Musicians Emergency Fund as a permanent organization was outlined by officials of the fund at its fifth anniversary luncheon yesterday at the Hotel St. Regis. Mrs. Vincent Astor, president of the fund, presided over the luncheon.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- The Republican National Committee charged today that the Democrats in Nebraska were assessing postmasters 5 per cent of their pay as contributions to the party cam paign fund. In support of the charge the committee made public the purported text of a letter written by Dr. James E. Willis of the Democratic State Finance Committee, which was addressed to a Republican county chairman by error.

Favorable comment was expressed generally yesterday on the quick change of traffic lights which has been in operation for ten days, but there were some doubts that the change had materially aided the faster movement of traffic, particularly in highly congested areas.
In the military setting of Governors Island, the Giants yesterday loaded their guns in anticipation of the return battle with the Philadelphia Eagles, who descend on the Polo Grounds Sunday.
ON GOVERNOR LANDON'S SPECIAL TRAIN, EN ROUTE THROUGH ARIZONA, Oct. 21.-- Governor Landon treated a slightly sore throat during the day, while speeding across Southwestern grazing and desert lands.

Representatives of more than fifty taxpayers organizations of the city met yesterday at the Hotel Commodore and formed the Home Rule League Against Proposed Charter, to work for the defeat of the new city charter plan at the polls on Nov. 3.

The city's debt as of Sept. 1 was within $337,585,736 of the limit of its constitutional debt-incurring power, Controller Frank J. Taylor announced yesterday. Actually, he explained, the debt margin on this date was only $201,328,537, since $136,257,199 in city securities yet to be issued has already been pledged.

Reports that the Board of Education had disapproved the city's year book, "New York Advancing," as a text for supplementary reading in the high schools were branded as "erroneous" yesterday in a statement issued by Henry C. Turner, president of the board.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21. -- Republican leaders base their predictions of victory two weeks hence on expected accessions from conservative Democrats and from Townsendites in California and West Virginia as well as in other parts of the country.

A squad of thirty-one Columbia football players will entrain this evening at 5:35 o'clock from Grand Central Station for Dearborn, Mich., where the Lions will make their headquarters before the game with Michigan at Ann Arbor on Saturday.

This is the evening on which the occasionally postponed "Stage Door" finally is to open at the Music Box. George S. Kaufman and the novelist, Edna Ferber, wrote it, and Margaret Sullavan, lured away from Hollywood, is playing the leading role.

Pietro Yon, musical director of St. Patrick's Cathedral, gave an organ recital before a large audi- ence at Carnegie I-Iall last night. @Ir. Ton, who has the distinction of being honorary organist to the Vatican in Rome, was largely re- sponsible for the specifications of the huge instrument at the console of which he presided with a sure sense of control.

The Bishop of London, Dr. WINNINGTON INGRAM, who was in New York a few weeks ago, on returning to Liverpool by way of Canada is reported to have said in his landing interview that Canada (like Australia and New Zealand) is "hungry for men," and that his own country should send ten million Britons to the spacious land to the north of us.

BERLIN, Oct. 21. -- The Boerse today showed less activity than yesterday, besides some signs of weakness. Shares of heavy industrials opened firm, but fell off near, the finish, Rhinestahl losing one point. Chemical issues, however, showed such strength at the start that they were generally stronger for the day, I.G. Farben gaining three-quarters of a point and Goldschmidt 5. Electrical shares, which had displayed some strength, ended weak. Shipping shares gained slightly.

Standard tests to aid in the selection and training of office personnel were recommended yesterday by business executives who addressed a conference held under the auspices of the American Management Association at the Hotel Commodore.

A Kings County jury, after acquitting Detective Daniel Sullivan of first-degree murder for shooting his wife in the presence of their children, was rebuked by County Judge John J. Fitzgerald yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21. -- Secretary Ickes, excepting only one, assailed the Chicago newspapers "of general circulation" and their publishers tonight as "Roosevelt haters" engaged in keen competition "to excel in misrepresentation and calumny."

BERLIN, Oct. 21. -- A new move toward welding Italo-German youth into a bulwark of European resistance against bolshevism was announced this afternoon by Baldur von Schirach, Reich Youth Leader, in the presence of Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister, and 20,000 Hitler Youths in the Sportpalast.

To the Editor of The New York Times: For whatever suggestions they might contain for others who are still debating their vote, may I give very simply my reasons for voting for Mr. Roosevelt next month?

Extension of the strike of beauty shop employes in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens was reported yesterday by officials of the Hairdressers and Cosmetologists Union, an A.F. of L. affiliate, who said more than 4,000 men and women in 1,400 shops were participating in the walkout.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 21. -- The administration's tax program was pictured by President Roosevelt here tonight in a major campaign speech as a weapon to preserve America's democracy in taxation while paying off quickly debts created by emergencies.
PARIS, Oct. 21. -- Members of the Society of Medical Meteorology discussed the progress of their work at the twenty-third session of the Hygiene Congress at the Pasteur Institute today.
PARIS, Oct. 21. -- Before the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Chamber of Deputies today, Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos gave assurances that Belgium has not denounced her treaty obligations.

MADRID, Oct. 21 (Passed by the Censor). -- Thousands of women marched through the streets of Madrid in a demonstration intended to inspire the men not already mobilized in the government army to go to the front to defend the capital.

President Roosevelt will have the last word on the radio on election eve, according to plans arranged by the Democratic National Committee, which has "tied up" the major networks of the country for an hour rally from 11 o'clock to midnight.
Patrolman Frank Barrett settled a pushcart strike virtually single-handed in lower First Avenue yesterday morning.

The State Mortgage Commission began yesterday a survey of the equities claimed by mortgage guarantee companies in certificated issues, following notice from Albany that the Court of Appeals had sustained the ruling of Supreme Court Justice Frankenthaler in the FW-1 and 545 West End Avenue cases, holding that the interests of certificate holders was prior to that of the issuing companies which held unsold or repurchased parts of these issues.

Endeavoring to develop discriminating taste among students in their choice of motion pictures, the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of parents and teachers, has invited teachers affiliated with it to attend a private showing today of the Gaumont-British film "Nine Days a Queen" and two educational shorts.

Postponement until after the election of numerous construction projects using structural steel, both private and government-financed, has lowered production of steel ingots to 74 per cent of capacity, from 75 1/2 per cent in the first week of October, the magazine Iron Age said yesterday.

Mr. ROOSEVELT is a master of the art of saying the right thing or the proper thing. His New England speeches yesterday distributed compliments gracefully, blended with the expected but not excessive amount of propaganda. His speech on Boston Common was a little masterpiece.

Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State Chairman, charged yesterday that teachers in the public schools are being intimidated and coerced into voting for President Roosevelt. Mr. Eaton spoke at a luncheon of the naturalized citizens division of the Republican State Committee at the Hotel Webster, 40 West Forty-fifth Street.

Cotton prices continued to decline yesterday on the inclination to raise crop ideas somewhat and under a continuous flow of hedge selling orders from the South, which increased in volume in the late trading. The market closed off 4 to 11 points from Tuesday's final quotations.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21. -- The field hockey teams of England, Scotland, Australia and the United States triumphed today in the four opening games of the international tournament, which is being played this week and next at the Philadelphia Cricket Club, in connection with the holding of the triennial conference of the International Federation of Women's Hockey Associations for the first time in this country.

BOSTON, Oct. 21. -- Speaking to a cheering crowd of 125,000 persons on Boston Common today, President Roosevelt asserted that the New Deal policies had given to New England's industries greater protection and opportunity than they had ever enjoyed under Republican leadership.
The first contract for actual construction for the New York World's Fair of 1939 was signed yesterday afternoon in the office of Grover Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- Authority to continue in control of the Pacific Greyhound Corporation through ownership of its capital stock was sought today by the Greyhound Corporation in an application to the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Miss Marion Burbank will give a tea this afternoon at her home, 6 East Seventy-eighth Street, for members of the debutante and junior committees aiding in the sale of tickets for the all-star amateur boxing tournament at the Madison Square Garden on Nov. 23 for the benefit of the West Side Hospital.
LONDON, Oct. 21. -- Officials showed today that they had taken great pains to protect Mrs. Ernest A. Simpson, friend of King Edward, from being annoyed by the curious.

The former Queen of Spain, Victoria, Duchess of Toledo, believes that the deposed monarchy will be returned to rule the people of Spain and that her younger son, Juan, Prince of Asturias will sit upon the throne.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 21. -- Princeton University's Theatre In-time opened its undergraduate dramatic season before an enthusiastic audience in Murray Theatre this evening with the production of Oscar Wilde's "The Importance of Being Earnest." The effort was well polished.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 21. -- Mrs. Jacobs, was for years a leader in social and philanthropic activities of this city. In 1920, Mrs. Jacobs appeared in Baltimore politics for the first time when she became vice chairman of the Republican City Committee.

Offering to the public will be made today by a banking group headed by Blyth Co., Inc., of a new issue of $35,000,000 of Pacific Gas and Electric Company first and refunding 3 1/2 per cent bonds, Series I, due in 1966. The price will be 102 3/4 and accrued interest.

LONDON, Oct. 21. -- Reluctantly and with many misgivings, Great Britain is about to enlist the giant resources of the American aircraft industry in an effort to give herself 1,500 more first-line planes with full war reserves before 1939.

TOKYO, Oct. 21. -- Hopes for rapid settlement of the Siberian-Manchukuoan border disputes were again postponed when Foreign Minister Hachiro Arita objected to several points in Ambassador Constantin Yureneff's proposal which the Russian completely expounded last night.

Borough President Harvey of Queens filed yesterday with Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. a petition asking that the Communist party be barred from the ballot of the State of New York at the election Nov. 3.

Madrid's Military Morale. What the Madrid Government needs is something more than war planes. It needs the men to fly them. But it is a question whether even foreign airmen in foreign planes would be enough. Leadership, discipline and cooperation are needed; and of these, as an uncensored Madrid dispatch in our paper yesterday makes painfully clear, there has been a tragic lack on the Loyalist side.

Joseph P. Kennedy, banker and former chairman of the Securities Exchange Commission, urged the "average business man" last night to vote for President Roosevelt and, above all, not to let "all business get jockeyed into a position of antagonism to the rest of the nation because a few stuffed shirts have lost their silk hats."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 21. -- Lee Tracy is to get another fling at the impetuous sort of characterizations that made him famous. RKO has purchased "Women Are Poison" by George Beck and in it Tracy will be allowed free rein in the portrayal of a newspaper reporter, a role similar to the one he played in "Blessed Event."

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 21. -- Kicking continued to form a major part of the Princeton football team's practice today for Navy, as Coach Fritz Crisler attempted to equalize the tremendous advantage Penn had over the Tiger in this department last Saturday.

Charges that at least 240,000 fraudulent enrollments are included in New York City's record registration of voters were made yesterday by Monroe Percy Bloch, attorney for the Honest Ballot Association. His organization, Mr. Bloch said, will do all in its power to prevent vote frauds on Nov. 3.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas showed an increase of 12 per cent for the week ended Oct. 17, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The gain compares with a rise of 11 per cent for the preceding week and covers the heavy shopping which featured the Columbus Day holiday.

The squash tennis season in Class A of the Metropolitan League team championship opened last night at four clubs in the city, with last year's leader, the Columbia Club, included among the winners. The wearers of the Blue and White played at their home courts against Short Hills and swept through to a 5-to-0 triumph.
Despite the handicap of bad weather, college football shows an 11 per cent gain in attendance over last year, a survey by The Associated Press revealed yesterday.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 21. -- U.S. Grant Hallett "left off" forking hay into a baling machine today to tell Mrs. Dorothy M. Beck, regional director of the Resettlement Administration, how it felt to be the first farmer in the East resettled by the Federal agency.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 21. -- The N.Y.U. freshmen were defeated by the Army plebes in a hard-fought game on Michie Stadium gridiron today. The score was 13 -- 7, a last-minute touchdown deciding the honors after the visitors had staged a spirited rally.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The student of politics gradually comes to the reluctant conclusion that the human race never does quite so well as could be wished; that no political organization is altogether untouched by human frailty, no political program is entirely faultless, no statesman, however wise and patriotic, ever perfect.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21. -- Declaring the country needs the facilities of both railroads and trucks, L.E. Muntwyler, chairman of the traffic group of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, said here today that the American retailer, as the largest user of common carrier transportation service, "cannot help but view with concern the speed with which the rail carriers are acquiring ownership and control of an ever-increasing number of independent motor carriers."
