LONDON, Oct. 21. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange were made irregular today by profit-taking, while the international outlook caused nervousness and trade was restricted because of tomorrow's settlement. British funds were weakened further by prospects of new corporation loans soon.

Commissioner MOSES was largely successful in his tilt with the city's budget authorities over funds for the parks. They gave him an additional $500,000 outright for personal service -- playground directors and other park workers. They agreed to provide another $100,000 to supplement a new WPA relief project of $425,000 to take care of much-needed road repair work in the parks.

Noise is a major hazard of modern existence and is an important contributing factor to excessive fatigue, which, in turn, frequently brings on chronic ill health and premature old age, Dr. Foster Kennedy, Professor of Clinical Neurology at Cornell University Medical College, told the ninth annual graduate fortnight of the Academy of Medicine last night.

LONDON, Oct. 21. -- The British Government is determined to prevent further acts of provocation by Sir Oswald Mosley's Fascists and probably will announce drastic action as soon as Parliament reassembles next week.

LONDON, Oct. 21. -- The British Government is determined to prevent further acts of provocation by Sir Oswald Mosley's Fascists and probably will announce drastic action as soon as Parliament reassembles next week.

To the Editor of The New York Times: With much interest my husband and I have followed Mr. Kieran's trip around the globe, recognizing his purpose of making the quickest possible connections and not of seeing the world. His concluding paragraph on Oct. 14, however, written on shipboard between Hongkong and Manila, came as something of a shock after our first reaction of surprised amusement.

Old liquor, vintage wine and the comforts of a modern cellar playroom brought about the downfall last evening of 35-year-old Frank Moskovich. The police called Moskovich a homeless burglar and booked him as such; Moskovich, however, insisted that he was just an unemployed gentleman who likes nice things.

ON GOVERNOR LANDON'S SPECIAL TRAIN, EN ROUTE THROUGH ARIZONA, Oct. 21. -- The Roosevelt administration regards the decisions of the Supreme Court ruling out some of its plans only as a minor barrier to be circumvented if it cannot be hurdled, Governor Landon declared tonight in a rear-platform speech to about 7,000 persons at Phoenix, on his way East from California.

Arthur Billings Hunt, baritone, a native of Fargo, N.D., gave his first New York recital last night at the Town Hall. The recitalist, who studied with Herbert Witherspoon, Oscar Seagle and Frank La Forge, has sung over the radio for several years and has been a choral director.

Twenty-five members of the old Fox Hills Golf Club of Staten Island, one of the oldest golfing associations in the country before it disbanded last year, participated in a tournament that served as a reunion yesterday.

Evidence that the Stock Exchange will continue its experimental policy of listing the issues of smaller and younger corporations than in former years was seen yesterday in the announcement that Gar Wood Industries, Inc., had applied for listing of 349,554 shares of $3-par capital stock.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- The Chilean Army team which is to compete at the national fixture in Madison Square Garden, New York, next month showed its worth today in the opening session of the four-day inter-American horse show at the Meadowbrook Saddle Club.

Reductions aggregating $17,319,658 in the 1937 budget, including elimination of the $5,000,000 carried for partial pay restorations next year, were urged before the Board of Estimate at City Hall yesterday by Harold Riegelman, counsel for the Citizens Budget Commission.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22. -- Prices on hogs held steady early today, but demand was slow and the market weakened later, some sales near the end showing l0 cents decline. The extreme top of $9.85 was 5 cents off for the day and 30 cents under a week ago, while the day's average, $9.35, was 5 cents under Wednesday.

HARRISBURG, Oct. 22 (AP). -- Governor Earle wrote to Governor Lehman of New York today that "it would be a violation of both established precedent and home rule" for the State to detail State police to break up mining by un-hired workers in Pennsylvania without specific request from the county authorities.

The first eight railroads to report earnings for September showed a gain of 31.2 per cent in net operating income, compared with September, 1935. The following table shows how earnings of these companies j in September compared with those in September of 1935 and 1934, with the percentage gains in each case:

ALBANY, Oct. 22. -- The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Third Department, today affirmed unanimously the ruling of Justice Gilbert V. Schenck barring the Union party from the New York State ballot in the November election.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 22. -- Using the "ghost" ball for the first time in the dark, the Dartmouth football squad had its final home tune-up for the Harvard game today and will leave for Cambridge tomorrow noon.

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, announced yesterday that he planned to continue his efforts to organize units of maritime workers in the port of New York under the American Federation of Labor. He seeks to offset efforts of other groups to create a Maritime Federation of the Atlantic similar to the federation which operates on the Pacific.

Holders of guaranteed mortgage certificates sold by the New York Title and Mortgage Company won $165,565 yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler directed State Superintendent of Insurance Louis Pink to pay this sum to the holders of thirty-seven issues.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Oct. 22. -- Jim Dante of Braidburn and Jim Martucci of Rivervale, the defending champions, were dethroned today in the first round of the second annual New Jersey P.G.A. pro-pro championship at the Forest Hill Field Club.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22. -- Tomorrow the United States field hockey team faces its first real test of the international tournament when it meets the gold-tuniced, brown-stockinged players from Australia at 3 o'clock on the fields of the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

Republican State Chairman Melvin C. Eaton made public yesterday a letter on the stationery of the American Labor party, which, he said, plainly indicated that coercive tactics were being used by that organization toward members of labor unions.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP). -- Secretary Ickes today announced Presidential approval of grants totaling $7,998,551 and loans of $1,033,200 for ninety-seven PWA projects in thirty-four States.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date. The reserve ratio for the New York bank also reached a new high figure for the year.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22. -- The Republican National Committee received $5.037,654 in contributions from June 1 to Oct. 17, according to the report of C.B. Goodspeed, treasurer of the Republican National Committee, which was sent today to the Clerk of the House of Representatives.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 22. -- "Czechoslovakia is well aware that the value of her alliances with France and Little Entente members has been greatly reduced in consequence of Germany's rearmament," Dr. Kamil Krofta, Foreign Minister, declared today before the Czechoslovak Parliament in a statement on the foreign political situation.

The Republican candidate for Governor, Judge Bleakley, announced that if elected he would restore the salary cuts of teachers which resulted from legislation in the depth of the depression in 1932. In another address Judge Bleakley said that he would not attempt to coerce the Legislature on any legislation, but would simply indicate to them his desires.
For the second time in two days a Kings County Court judge found occasion yesterday to criticize the action of a jury in acquitting a policeman charged with a serious crime.
THE Princton-Navy game should provide a line on the Yale-Princeton debate later on. Navy had a thin edge over Yale in the Baltimore battle until Larry the Great Kelley put his foot in it.

BERLIN, Oct. 22. -- Activity decreased on the Boerse today, and stocks generally became softer, with some signs of strength near the end of the session. Such firmness as appeared was attributed solely to purchases of blocked marks.

In a new departure for racing in this country, the Saratoga Association has decided to make a breeders' award in each of its thirty-six stakes during the 1937 meeting. In addition there will be the equivalent of $500 in awards to breeders in each of Saratoga's sixteen guaranteed money stakes.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 22. -- Governor Landon will make two short addresses in New Jersey next Wednesday, it was announced today by the Republican State campaign committee. His special train will stop at Trenton and at Newark on the way from Philadelphia to New York.

PARIS, Oct. 22. -- In a tumultuous opening session of the Radical Socialist Congress at Biarritz today, Edouard Daladier, the party's leader, called upon the organization to stand by the Popular Front government. It was a sentiment to which all the leaders gave voice during the day.
In accepting a second-degree murder verdict in General Sessions late yesterday afternoon against four men in a payroll hold-up, Judge George L. Donnellan told the jurors:

A three-point program for research in the ice industry was proposed yesterday by George Lange, vice president of the American Ice Company, and chairman of the technical department of the National Association of Ice Industries, at the organization's annual convention at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Ind., Oct. 22 (AP). -- Mrs. Ruth Bryan Owen Rohde, whose campaign tour in behalf of President Roosevelt was interrupted when she fractured a leg near here several weeks ago, resumed her speaking tour with an address broadcast through a microphone brought to her hospital room.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 22 (AP). -- An internal gland defense against infantile paralysis, the first ever recorded in medicine, discovered in experiments on twenty-four monkeys, was reported today by Dr. W. Lloyd Aycock of the Harvard Medical School to the American Public Health Association.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- A revamping of the national freight-rate structure was proposed today by the nation's railroads in a move designed to offset the loss of more than $100,000,000 in annual revenues through expiration on Dee. 31 of emergency freight surcharges.

ABILENE, Texas, Oct. 22 (AP). -- A bullet interrupted R.M. (Bob) Curtis's telephone conversation with a friend in New York early today and a hotel bellboy who investigated found the former Chicago stockbroker dying, shot through the head.

New York University, making ready for one of its hardest games of the season, spent three hours on Ohio Field yesterday making last-minute improvements in its attack for the game with Georgetown at the Yankee Stadium tomorrow.

President Roosevelt, Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau and other speakers will address a chain of dinners tonight by radio. The dinners will be held under the auspices of the Good Neighbor League. The event in this city will be at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
DETROIT, Oct. 22. -- The vacancy left by Senator Couzens's death will be filled by appointment by Governor Frank D. Fitzgerald, the appointee to serve until the new elective term starts in January.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22. -- In the face of a depleted treasury and failure of party contributors to give for election day expenses, John D. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, estimated today that Governor Landon's electoral vote would reach 302, which is thirty-six more than sufficient to elect.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today a summary of eleven registration statements filed under the Securities Act of 1933, involving $17,956,414, of which $13,986,514 represents new issues. The group is divided as follows: Commercial and industrial issues, $13,986,514; voting trust certificates, $260,000; certificates of deposit, $3,739,900.

Edward Metzler, a middle-aged business man who lives at 1,703 East Fourteenth Street, Brooklyn, was held in bail of $1,000 for the Federal grand jury yesterday by Garrett W. Cotter, United States Commissioner, on a charge of sending a threatening letter to Matthew T. Murray Jr., secretary of the Guaranty Trust Company.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22. -- Here in the city where President Roosevelt four years ago won the Presidential nomination that he was seeking, former Governor Alfred E. Smith tonight made his second appeal of this campaign for the election of Governor Alfred M. Landon of Kansas.
The Interborough Rapid Transit System carried 79,291,087 passengers during September, according to the monthly report made yesterday by Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver.

The Bremen of the North German Lloyd Line will arrive today from Bremen, Southampton and Cherbourg with a large list of passengers, including Nelson Doubleday, publisher, with Mrs. Doubleday; Katharine Cornell, actress; W. Ledyard Mitchell, Chrysler executive; Dr. Clark B. Millikan, who has been in Germany on an official mission to study developments in aeronautics; Mary Garden, former opera singer, and Virginia Cherrill, actress.
The Fire, Police and Sanitation Departments will cooperate, it was announced yesterday, in an attempt to prevent election night bonfires and to extinguish them quickly if and when they do occur.

A sharp decline in the French franc, which was met and turned back by vigorous intervention by the Bank of France, yesterday shook the foreign exchange market out of the dullness that had enveloped it for the past two weeks. Selling abroad, based on French political developments, had weakened the French exchange before the opening of business here.
Full responsibility for the ferreting out of illegal registration and the prevention of voting frauds was placed on the Police Department yesterday by Mayor La Guardia.

ROME, Friday, Oct. 23. -- Reliable sources said early today a protocol would be signed in Berlin today embodying an Italo-German accord on six points. The agreement, it was said, will relate to the following subjects: ...

ALBANY, Oct. 22. -- Governor Lehman today proclaimed Oct. 27 as Theodore Roosevelt Day, the seventy-eighth anniversary of his birth. He requested that flags be flown from all homes, public buildings and places of business throughout the State and that the day be otherwise devoted "to the memory of this great man."

For the time being George S. Kaufman and Edna Ferber are standing guard at the "Stage Door" in a comedy bearing that title and put on at the Music Box last evening. Some years ago in "The Royal Family" they fired a salute in honor of the theatre and the mad folks who keep the theatres lighted.
ON PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT'S SPECIAL TRAIN, STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 22. -President Roosevelt issued the following statement tonight on the death of Senator Couzens:
PENSACOLA, Fla., Oct. 22 (AP). -- Two naval training planes crashed at 1,000 feet today, killing Cadet E.T. Hogenauer of New York City and seriously injuring Cadet M.L. Gourley.

A bill of about $800,000 Will be presented to the various political parties by the National Broadcasting Company for time on the air during the 1936 campaign, it was revealed yesterday. In radio circles it is believed the total expenditure for political broadcasts throughout the nation this year will exceed $2,000,000.

QUEBEC, Oct. 22. -- Charges that employes of the Provincial Treasury Department speculated with debentures belonging to the government (about $15,000,000 worth in all) were made today by Edgar Vezina, Provincial Auditor, in giving evidence before the Public Accounts Committee.

The WPA will continue unaltered for the current school year the educational projects in operation under the Board of Education, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, WPA administrator, announced yesterday after "extended discussions" with the works projects committee of the board.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP). -- A possibility of further delay in construction of the liner which the United States Lines agreed in 1935 to build or forfeit $1,000,000 to the government arose today with a Maritime Commission ruling that new bids were necessary if the ship was to get a Federal subsidy.

Nanny Annibali, Italian mezzo-soprano, made her American debut in a recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. She disclosed a serviceable voice and considerable experience in its use. She sang a program of Italian, German and French songs with discrimination and excellent taste.

Restoration of earning power has enabled the railroads in the United States to reduce their loans from the Railroad Credit Corporation from $73,691,368 originally to $28,382,168 on Sept. 30, according to a report by E.G. Buckland, president, at the annual meeting here yesterday.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 22 (AP). -- Colonel Frank Knox, Republican Vice Presidential nominee, told a Toledo rally tonight that "four more years" of such "merry-go-round" government as he attributed to the Roosevelt administration may destroy both constitutional government and free enterprise.

OMAHA, Oct. 22. -- Five Republican women wearing sunflower pins had the Douglas County court house in an uproar today when they plastered windows of Democratic office holders with Landon pictures beside the Roosevelt pictures which were already there.

A broad decline in almost all classes of domestic issues was the outstanding development in bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The turnover was the heaviest since Oct. 9, total transactions amounting to $16,459,000, compared with $12,195,700 on Wednesday.
TALAVERA, Spain, Oct. 22. -- From a hill one kilometer west of Navalcarnero I witnessed and photographed the capture of that Loyalist stronghold by the Insurgents in their relentless drive on Madrid.
PARIS, Oct. 22 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

Financing to the extent of $9,957,070 will be undertaken today on behalf of the Gulf States Steel Company. Of this amount, public offering will be made by a banking group composed of Hallgarten Co., Lazard Freres Co., Inc., Lehman Brothers and Kuhn, Loeb Co., of an issue of $7,000,000 of first mortgage sinking fund 4 1/2 per cent bonds, dated Oct. 15, 1936, and due Oct. 15, 1961.

The Workers Alliance of America, headed by David Lesser, is distributing circulars among WPA employes which Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, WPA Administrator, believes might be interpreted as meaning that his office favors the alliance above other organizations as spokesman for WPA employes in matters concerning working conditions.

After the President's Syracuse address the public generally seemed to welcome the overdue demise of the canard linking President Roosevelt to elements reputed to be seeking the destruction of fundamental American institutions.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 22 (AP). -- The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation rejected today a demand by employe representatives of its Homestead plant for a $1.12 a day wage increase.

PARIS, Oct. 22. -- France is working with all her force to prevent the crystallization of two blocs of rival dogmas in Europe, Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos told the American Club of Paris today at its weekly' luncheon.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 22. -- Driving more than 100 miles through Connecticut over a winding route on the final lap of his two-day campaign tour through New England, President Roosevelt passed today through city after city where enthusiasm rose to such a pitch that the police were unable to control the crowds and where the official procession of cars repeatedly was broken into wandering units.

The picture that the President drew in his Worcester speech of the history of Federal taxes and other finances since the war and of their present state must be supplemented and modified in several important respects.

Announcement is made of the extension of two exhibitions now current. Paintings by Hans Boehler, at the Artists Gallery, 33 West Eighth Street, will be held over until Nov. 7. The show of paintings by Lawrence Lebduska, at Contemporary Arts, will be continued until Oct. 28.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 22. -- The Princeton board of trustees, meeting in the faculty room of Nassau Hall this morning on the 190th anniversary of the founding of the university, made nine appointments to the Princeton faculty.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22. -- Charles W. Nash, chairman and founder of the Nash Motor Company, confirmed today the report of negotiations for a merger of the company with the Kelvinator Corporation. That negotiations were in progress became known yesterday when officials of the two concerns met in a closed conference here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- President Roosevelt has addressed a recommendation to the heads of more than 100 schools and colleges throughout the country asking that engineering courses be so balanced "as to give coming generations of engineers the vision and flexible technical equipment necessary to meet the full range of engineering responsibility" and to equip them to meet the "social responsibility" of their profession, the White House announced today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 22. -- An application was filed today in Supreme Court by G. Charles Geiss, Republican County Committeeman of Elmsford, to bar the registration of thirty-nine men in the transient camp at Elmsford, maintained under the National Park Service. Justice Frederick P. Close reserved decision.

The C.W. Kraushaar Art Galleries have moved from 680 to 730 Fifth Avenue. In this venerable establishment, holding its place among the front-row galleries of New York, business was carried on at the old address for seventeen years. Two or three seasons ago John F. Kraushaar, head of the firm, put through an extensive job of refurbishing.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 22. -- Alfred A. Anderson, 60 years old, a leader in Jamestown's industrial and civic life, was instantly killed at his home today by the accidental discharge of a shotgun he was taking from an automobile to clean, preparatory to a hunting trip with his son.
STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 22. -- The Ailsa Craig, her garboards sound, her keel still firm and her bow set resolutely to the wind, settled last night to her last anchorage.

A good maxim, like any other good tool, requires judicious handling. ABRAHAM LINCOLN'S "half slave and half free" is no exception to the rule. MARK SULLIVAN in yesterday's Herald Tribune begged to remind President ROOSEVELT that a country can no more be half socialistic and half free initiative than it could be half slave and half free in LINCOLN'S time.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- Secretary Morgenthau will discuss the possibility of balancing the budget in the 1938 fiscal year, and touch on the tax question in his speech tomorrow night before the Good Neighbor League at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York City.

The fifty-fourth annual meeting of the New York Presbyterian Synod closed yesterday with a warning against ministers taking part in "healing the sick" and a declaration in support of the work of the Lord's Day Alliance. The synod's sessions have been held since Monday at the First Presbyterian Church, 124 Henry Street, Brooklyn.
The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices continued its slow decline last week, dropping 0.6 point to 126.8 on Tuesday from 127.4 on the preceding Tuesday.

In this present campaign much is being said and written about the menace of communism and the danger of its spreading in this country should President Roosevelt be re-elected. The supporting reasons for this theory are not given, and memory seems to expose a fallacy in the statement.

Gains predominated yesterday on the local commodity futures markets, although sugar, cocoa and copper were slightly weaker than on Wednesday. On the cash markets, wheat, corn, rye, oats, lard, silk and rubber advanced, while cotton, flour and tin declined.

John X. Hassett, former chairman of the Municipal Examining Board of Plumbers, disbanded in 1934, following an investigation of grafting by Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, was convicted yesterday by a jury in General Sessions of bribery.

KALGAN, Chahar Province, China, Oct. 22. -- A trip along the Chahar and Sulyuan frontiers shows that the Chinese authorities are entertaining no hope that peace will be prolonged more than a short while.

MOSCOW, Oct. 22. -- The boy who burned down the schoolhouse to get out of second grade apparently has been outdone by a Soviet judge, who is formally accused of having burned down a court house to destroy evidence of graft.

NAVALCARNERO, Spain, Oct. 22 (AP). -- The Rebel legionnaire and Moorish troops of General Jose Varela marched into Navalcarnero last night in the wake of a battering artillery and aerial barrage on Leftist defenders. Insurgent commanders paid the government militiamen a compliment for their stubborn resistance, saying they retired only when threatened with a flanking movement.
A national third party or a new alignment of liberals against conservatives will form the 1940 political scene, in the opinion of Governor Hjalmar Petersen of Minnesota.

Behind the excitement attending the arrival of the Galloping Gaels, the Moraga Marauders, Madigan's Manglers or St. Mary's, a game which has for a number of years built up a tradition of its own in the city is coming closer. It is the meeting between New York University and Georgetown tomorrow.

Eighteen women and nineteen men teachers, arrested on charges of disorderly conduct for refusing to leave the office of the Emergency Relief Bureau at 902 Broadway after invading it with demands for jobs, were found guilty yesterday in Yorkville Court.

The Metropolitan Commercial Building, a twelve-story structure at the northeast corner of Broadway and Prince Street, was sold yesterday by Horace Havemeyer and the trustees of Henry O. Havemeyer to the Downtown Investing Corporation, Elias A. Cohen, president.

The E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. in its pamphlet report issued yesterday showed a net profit for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 of $62,567,019, equal after dividends on the debenture stock to $5.31 a share on the average number of common shares outstanding during the period.

This morning THE TIMES published a statement of the Association of American Railroads headed "No Freight Car Shortage." As a matter of fact, there were two days this month when cars were not available at our mines on the B. O. of any type in which we could load coal.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 22. -- Yale has lost the football services of David Colwell of Loveland, Colo., for the season. He was operated on today for appendicitis.

ALBANY, Oct. 22. -- The distribution of $9,372,122.81 of alcoholic beverage license fees and taxes for the quarter ending Sept. 30 was the largest since the repeal of prohibition, Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, announced today. It brings the total distributed to date to $56,833.270.16, and under the Alcoholic Beverage Law the State has received a similar amount.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 22. -- Sickness and accidents outside industry still exact a heavy toll in economic breakdowns, John A. Lapp, national referee of the International Building Trades Union, told the New York State Conference on Social Work tonight.

Earnings of the Procter Gamble Company and subsidiaries in the quarter ended with September reached a new high record with a net profit of $6,629,564 after providing for depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges, but before allowing for Federal surtax on undistributed income, the company reported yesterday.

The refusal to grant a permit for an American Labor party rally in the Nassau County police auditorium at Mineola was rescinded yesterday after former District Attorney Elvin N. Edwards called on the local police authorities to reconsider in the interests of "fair play."
HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 22. -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's address here today:
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 21. -- For the third time this week Coach Fritz Crisler emphasized various phases of the Princeton kicking game on University Field today.

At the beginning of the Spanish civil war the sympathizers with the Madrid government tried to make believe abroad that General Franco's movement was purely a rebellion of the military clique, but it has become known that this strife has divided the Spanish population into two camps, irrespective of their being military men or civilians.

As an initial step in the collection of the unpaid interest coupons that have matured on several defaulted dollar bonds of the departments, municipalities and mortgage banks of the Republic of Colombia, the Bondholders Committees for Republic of Colombia have decided to proceed with legal action in the Colombian courts with respect to the bonds of the Department of Antioquia, it was announced yesterday.
BRUSSELS, Oct. 22. -- Despite an order of the Belgian Cabinet forbidding the demonstration, the Fascist Rexist party today announced its intention to assemble in a Brussels suburb Sunday.

At 8:40 o'clock this evening at the St. James Theatre Sidney Kingsley starts a new career as a producer and continues his old one as a playwright. "Ten Million Ghosts" is the business at hand -- something bitter about the international armaments people, they say -- and among those acting it will be: Lee Baker, George Coulouris, Orson Welles, Barbara O'Neil, Otto Hulett, Martin Gabel, J. Carroll Ashburn and Dodson L. Mitchell.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Banks credit outstanding during the week ended Oct. 21, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,487,000,000, unchanged from the preceding week, and an increase of $2,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1935.
Headed by Edward Patrick (Slip) Madigan, Notre Dame '20, one of the greatest football parties in the game's history arrived in New York yesterday.

Sidney Rusinow and Benedict Jarmel won the contract bridge pair championship last night at the second annual metropolitan championship tournament of the American Bridge League held at the Park Central Hotel. Mr. Rusinow and Mr. Jarmel scored 569.8 points. They received the Oswald Jacoby Trophy for their victory.

Between rounds of skeet at the Campfire Club of America in Westchester the other day Foster Yawger was telling us about the wonderful pheasant shooting being enjoyed by Rochester sportsmen. The story he told may point a moral to New York gunners who grumble about conditions in this area, yet fail to join outdoor organizations, such as the Southern New York Fish and Game Association, which seek to increase the supply of fish and game.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 22. -- What the Roosevelt administration has done for the banking structure of the nation was reviewed here tonight by J.F.T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, replying to critics of government spending in the field of banking.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 22. -- Mrs. Edward Stevens, national senior champion, accounted for the chief honors in the one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association at the picturesque Sleepy Hollow Country Club today.

Following a mock trial of more than three hours, William Randolph Hearst, newspaper publisher, was found guilty last night by a public jury of 6,500 of perverting the news, breeding war, breaking strikes, fascism and destroying liberty.

Mr. and Mrs. William Gallagher, who have lived all of their fifty married years in the same house at 529 West Thirty-ninth Street, between Tenth and Eleventh Avenues in Hell's Kitchen, attended a solemn high mass celebrated for them on their anniversary yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Raphael on West Forty-first Street.

Instead of being a horrible instrument of war, as generally supposed, poison gases represent the "most humane" type of modern warfare and make "for the future security and peace of the world," two army officers told 600 physicians last night at the ninth graduate fortnight of the Academy of Medicine.

BREWSTER, N.Y., Oct. 22. -- Lewis W. Douglas, former director of the budget, announced here tonight that he would vote for Governor Landon. Mr. Douglas was appointed by President Roosevelt in 1933 but resigned Sept. 30, 1934. Previously he had served as a Democratic member of the House from Arizona for six years.
LONDON, Oct. 22. -- The British Air Ministry has already ordered 300 military airplanes from the Boeing Canadian branch factory in Vancouver, this correspondent learned today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22. -- Evidence that the use of quinine, alcohol and the drugs of the salicylate group by expectant mothers has been the reason for a number of children being born deaf was presented here today before the annual clinical Congress of the American College of Surgeons.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:
DETROIT, Oct. 22. -- James Couzens, Michigan's senior United States Senator, died in Harper Hospital at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon. He was 64 years old.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 22. -- Governor Lehman made his first attack of the campaign on Governor Landon tonight, charging the Republican candidate for President with being in reality a foe of social security in the guise of urging exclusive State control of the problem.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 22. -- The Yale Alumni Weekly will say tomorrow that President Angell will retire in June and that the corporation, or trustees board, has discussed for several months already the question of his successor.

GARY, Ind., Oct. 22. -- Not knowing of a better industrial laboratory for a political test this year than Gary (the sooty Aladdin's Palace of the United States Steel Corporation and home of Dr. William A. Wirt of "Roosevelt-is-a-Kerensky" memory), this correspondent came here today to discover local equations from which a nation-wide industrial voting division might be reckoned.

The State of California yesterday awarded a new issue of $700,000 of harbor bonds to a banking group composed of R.H. Moulton Co., the First Boston Corporation and Dean Witter Co. at 118.192 for a fixed rate of 4s. The bonds will mature on July 2, 1989, and are optional in 1955.

Standardization of printed forms is essential to "the saving of millions of dollars to American business," Frank M. Knox, head of a printing company in Pittsburgh, told members of the American Management Association yesterday at the close of a conference of the office management division at the Hotel Commodore.

Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey announced yesterday that he would stand on his original decision of July 7 in refusing to surrender to the New York authorities his lifelong friend, Ellis H. Parker Sr., who is under indictment in Brooklyn for the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel.

The National Labor Relations Board announced yesterday that it had certified the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association as the exclusive bargaining agency for licensed engineers on the four steamships which the Panama Railroad Company operates between New York, Haiti and the Canal Zone.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22. -- Boos and cheers greeted Alfred E. Smith here this morning when he stepped off the Twentieth Century Limited wearing his famous brown derby and smoking a cigar tilted at a belligerent angle. He arrived to the tune of "The Sidewalks of New York," played by a band.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Watson Jr. entertained at dinner last night at their home, 34 East Sixty-ninth Street, for Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Woolley-Hart, Mr. and Mrs. Cuthbert Stewart and Mrs. Charles A. Cartwright. Other guests were Miss Eva F. Burnside, Hubert Gerstner, Herman Sartorius and Starr Anderson.

WITH THE INSURGENT TROOPS OF LIEUT. COL. RADA, Advancing on Escorial, Spain, Oct. 22 (AP). -- Insurgent guns at El Espinar dropped 6-inch shells on the defenses of Escorial today as the drive to give the northern army a chance at Madrid gained momentum.

CORTLAND, N.Y., Oct. 22. -- William F. Bleakley, the Republican candidate for Governor, today continued his attack upon Governor Lehman's administrative record, with stress upon four points. These were farm problems, his attitude toward labor, his effect upon business, and State Finances.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 22. -- Playing before a State fair crowd of 19,000 persons, Clemson College today clearly demonstrated its superiority over the University of South Carolina, winning by 19 to 0. It was the thirty-fourth annual contest between the two teams, started forty years ago.

Political prophets abound in the land and flatly contradict each other. No one of them knows exactly what is going to happen on Nov. 3. But one prediction most of them would agree to in common. It is that this Presidential election is to be less one-sided than that of 1932.
LONDON, Oct. 22. -- A sudden change came over the European situation tonight with clear indications that Soviet Russia was abandoning her fight to expose the Fascist powers' activities in Spain.

Commenting on reports from Washington yesterday relative to American participation in transatlantic airship operations, F.W. von Meister, special American representative for Deutsche Zeppelin Reederei, operating company of the Hindenburg and Graf Zeppelin, issued the following statement:

On the ground that the Court of Appeals already had decided the issue, Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins denied yesterday the application by Mrs. Catherine C. Mulville of 427 Seventy-first Street, Brooklyn, for an injunction restraining the Board of Elections and the Charter Revision Commission from submitting the question to the voters at the coming election.

Trading on the Stock Exchange expanded yesterday as the market declined for the third time this week. It was the most active session since last Friday, the turnover aggregating 1,974,000 shares, compared with 1,632,000 shares on Wednesday.

The trend in bank clearings improved in the week ended on Wednesday, with the total for twenty-two leading cities, as reported to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., 6.5 per cent larger than a year ago, contrasted with a loss of 6.7 per cent in the preceding five-day week.

Today's schedule lists six films, three of Hollywood origin, two from Germany and one from Hungary. The domestic films are "The Magnificent Brute," with Victor McLaglen and Binnie Barnes, at the Roxy; "The Big Game," a football story with screen play by Irwin Shaw (who wrote "Bury the Dead"), at the Rialto, and "Daniel Boone," with George O'Brien and Heather Angel, at the Palace.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 22. -- Young Bill Ingram, who is playing such a great game in the Navy back field this year, will find himself among friends when he plays against Princeton Saturday. Ingram played at Lawrenceville and usually finds old team-mates in the opposing line-up of almost any Eastern college.

The spokesmen for the privately operated rapid-transit lines, with whom the city's representatives negotiated the unification plan now before the Transit Commission for public hearings, insisted upon control and operation of the lines by a Board of Transit Control which would not only be non-political in make-up but also beyond the power of any city administration to change or modify, it was disclosed yesterday.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, Oct. 22. -- In a dramatic audience at the palace today, King Boris refused to entrust to Gregori Tsankoff, Fascist leader, the formation of a new Cabinet.
Governor Landon, speaking in Albuquerque in reference to restored foreign markets for the American farmer, certainly "soars through the air with the greatest of ease."

DES MOINES, Oct. 22 (AP). -- George N. Peek, first administrator of the AAA, declared tonight that support of the administration's reciprocal trade pacts "springs from the international banking interests centering about New York."

HONOLULU, Oct. 22. -- After a flight of 9 hours and 42 minutes the China Clipper landed twenty-one persons at Pearl Harbor at 5:12 P.M. today. The flying boat arrived from Midway Island, 1,380 miles away.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- The daily prayer of Pope Pius XI is for the peace and prosperity of the world, Cardinal Pacelli, Papal Secretary of State, told the National Press Club today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22. -- The European political situation came to the fore as a market influence in grains today. Wheat prices declined early on scattered selling induced by weakness in Liverpool and on favorable crop comments from Argentina.

New York City got rid of all but two of its antiquated trolley lines last June but the new buses that supplanted them brought a flood of counterfeit quarters to the debut. Passengers were assured yesterday, however, that they would no longer have to bite into doubtful-looking coins jiggled out to them by drivers of the New York City Omnibus Corporation.

Kenesaw Mountain Landis, commissioner of baseball, officially cut the largest world series melon in history yesterday when he mailed checks to the Yankees and Giants and players of the other first division clubs in each league.

The sailing of Commodore Vanderbilt's Nautilus, the first steam-propelled ferryboat to ply between Manhattan Island and Staten Island, Oct. 22, 1817, was commemorated yesterday as part of the 275th anniversary of the permanent settlement of Staten Island.
Winning streaks are much more difficult to compile in present-day major college football than they were in the days of the turtle-neck jerseys and chrysanthemum haircuts.

After a brief workout at Baker Field, Columbia's football squad entrained last night from Grand Central Station at 5:35 o'clock for Dearborn, Mich., where the Lions are making their headquarters until they meet the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor tomorrow.

Francis T. Hunter, formerly second ranking tennis player in the country and once publisher of The White Plains Daily Press, filed a plea in bankruptcy yesterday in Federal court, reporting liabilities of $1,286,355 and assets of $11,450.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- Taking issue with the management of the Consolidated Film Industries, Inc., of New York City, as to the adequacy of information placed before its stockholders in calling and soliciting proxies for a meeting scheduled for tomorrow to consider a proposed plan for recapitalization, the Securities and Exchange Commission today made a detailed statement explaining its criticisms.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP). -- Two governmental inquiries were ordered today into charges by a shipbuilders' union that shipyards were deliberately laying off workers "to arouse antagonism against the administration."

France is not likely to "go communistic" and the French will not tolerate a dictatorship of any kind, Dr. B. Weill-Halle, director of the School of Child Welfare of the Faculty of Medicine, in Paris, said here in an interview Wednesday.

Assuming that the re-election of President Roosevelt is certain, Major George L. Berry, president of the International Printing Pressmen's Union and head of labor's Nonpartisan League, urged last night that steps be taken to prevent a Congressional retreat from liberalism.

Directors of the Mid-Continent Petroleum Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of 75 cents a share, payable on Dec. 1. On June 1 a dividend of 40 cents was paid. In 1935. 40 cents a share was distributed and in 1934, 50 cents a share. No dividends were paid in 1933 or 1932.

If a current trend to shift the responsibility for maintaining the community hospital system to the government is to be checked, the income of private hospitals must be increased by voluntary contributions from a larger part of the citizenry of this city, Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the hoard of the Chase National Bank, told a gathering of 300 trustees of private hospitals yesterday.

Concerted action to combat the growing tendency of consumers to condemn all advertising because of its misuse by a small minority of unethical advertisers is planned by representatives of women's advertising clubs in the East and Middle West.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- The special Senate committee investigating campaign expenditures today asked the Democratic National Committee to explain all the money raised from advertisements by corporations in the "Book of the Democratic Convention of 1936" with a view to discovering if the advertisements were a subterfuge for obtaining funds.

Federal regulation of freight forwarding and consolidating companies was approved yesterday by O.S. Lewis, general freight traffic manager of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, and Edgar D. Hilleary, vice president in charge of traffic of the Reading Company, at hearings before examiners for the Interstate Commerce Commission in the Pennsylvania Hotel.
LONDON, Oct. 22 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

CINCINNATI, Oct. 22. -- A gift of $100,000 by B'nai B'rith, a non-Zionist organization, to the Jewish national fund for the purchase of 1,000 acres in Palestine was announced today by Alfred M. Cohen, president of B'nai B'rith.

MADRID, Oct. 22. -- Government troops today are resisting Rebel pressure from the direction of Navalcarnero at a point a few miles south of Mostoles, which is ten miles southwest of Madrid. Here a stand will be made to defend the Guadarrama Valley.

James A. Farrell, chairman of the National Foreign Trade Council and steel man, declared yesterday that the return of world prosperity depended upon the removal of nationalistic trade barriers to permit the resumption of world trade. Speaking at a luncheon in the Hotel Pierre, given by Baron K. Okura, Japanese industrialist and member of the house of Okura Co., Mr Farrell said:
CHICAGO, Oct. 22. -- Following is a stenographic transcript of the address of Alfred E. Smith here tonight:

LONDON, Oct. 22. -- The London Stock Exchange was occupied today in one of the largest settlements on record, causing a slowing down of activity, although the undertone remained firm. British funds were better, notwithstanding the prospect of more corporation borrowing soon. Foreign bonds were quiet, as were some rails, while South American railway stocks were supported.
PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Oct. 22. -- Clinton County, of which this city is the political center, is witnessing an unusually lively campaign even for a Presidential year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 22. -- With negotiations for Cecil B. De Mile's new two-year contract almost completed, Paramount has disclosed that the producer-director will return to the biblical drama after completion of "The Plainsman" and will make "Samson and Delilah," an item which has been on and off the De Mille schedule for some time.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 22. -- The Veterans of Future Wars have dropped their fight for a $1,000 bonus with interest, payable from 1965 retroactively to 1935, it was indicated here today with the announcement that letters had been sent out temporarily revoking the charters of the 500 posts throughout the United States.

OTTAWA, Oct. 22 (Canadian Press). -- Although the form of the Bank of Canada's weekly statement is laid down in the Bank of Canada Act, the government in the interest of clarity passed an order-in-council yesterday authorizing slight changes, which become effective today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP). -- Cabinet officers, Senators and others high in official life joined tonight in praising the career of Senator James Couzens. His death came as a shock to his friends here, despite the recent reports of his serious illness, because of the frequency with which he had pulled through similar crises in the past.

Tito Schipa, Italian opera singer, returned from Europe yesterday on the Italian liner Rex, having passed the Summer abroad. He passed two months in Rome making his second film. "Come Back, My Little One," and now will have a series of concert and opera appearances in the United States.
Ernest W. Barr, a Negro about 56, who had done valet work for me for many years, was stricken with a heart attack in my apartment yesterday afternoon.

The report that the British Air Ministry, in the effort to speed up air defense, is planning to order a large number of planes from manufacturers in the United States, while not confirmed, is not denied by Government spokesmen in London. The proposal is significant for more than one reason.
Various residential and business property sales by banks were included in the Brooklyn realty turnover reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP). -- Possibility of an American trans-atlantic air service, using lighter-than-air craft, was announced today with word from the Commerce Department that Germany was willing to build a dirigible for that purpose.

PARIS, Oct. 22. -- The franc weakened strikingly in the foreign exchange market today, affecting the Bourse, where rentes and domestic stocks lost ground. The pound sterling and the dollar made sensational rises to, respectively, 106.05 francs against 105.16 yesterday, and 21.66 francs against 21.4925. Forward discounts against the franc rose sharply, as they had done yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia appealed last night for approval of the new city charter at the polls on Nov. 3 so as to set up governmental machinery which will "permit the city to operate its government efficiently and economically."

LISBON, Portugal, Oct. 22. -- The swift moving light tanks with which Generalissimo Francisco Franco's army is now crushing the government defenses outside Madrid smashed through barbed wire and trenches protecting Navas del Marques, a few kilometers west of Escorial, today.

Retail credit collections during September showed a decrease of 0.21 per cent, according to the index of twenty local key stores issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York. rhilei this is the third consecutive month-I ly decrease, the average collectionI percentage for the year is 0.30 per Z cent over the same period of 1935.

The Ernest Kempton Adams Fellowship for research in physics, valued at $1,250, has been awarded to Professor Shirley L. Quimby of the Department of Physics in Columbia University, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 22. -- Hanging on with determination, Finance, a gelded son of Bull Dog, survived a blanket finish to win the Grade A handicap which featured today's Laurel program.

The members of the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company last evening worked over the final added starter in their series of Gilbert and Sullivan revivals. Call it "Ruddigore" and say that once again chose, faithful ones of the Martin Beck roiled, discreetly, in the aisles. The British visitors, perhaps suspicious of "Ruddigore's" lengthy first act, penciled it in for only half a week; but that move seems to have been simply England's notorious conservatism.
BERLIN, Oct. 22 (AP). -- Germany and Italy have reached an accord on a united stand in the Spanish civil war, it was authoritatively reported today.

ON BOARD GOVERNOR LANDON'S TRAIN EN ROUTE TO OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 22. -- In reply to President Roosevelt's speech on taxation at Worcester last night, Governor Landon charged this evening that the President was "using the people's money directly and indirectly to secure his re-election."

Although a cold wave and rains in the Western Cotton Belt created apprehension over prospects for the late cotton crop, the demand for cotton futures yesterday only developed in sufficient proportions to check the decline after prices on the Cotton Exchange had sold off 5 to 8 points and December had touched the 11 3/4 cent level.

A sequence of eleven losing favorites was broken at Empire City yesterday when Warren Wright's Four Eleven, a daughter of Haste, got home first by half a length, with ten others strung out behind her, in the Carmel Purse. It was with a sigh of relief that form players greeted the dark brown filly when she crossed the line on the head end, as most of the bettors had gotten into the doldrums.

Large Treasury disbursements in excess of income were responsible for a further rise of $60,000,000 in excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the weekly report for that period published yesterday by the Reserve Board.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- J.P. Morgan Co. today notified the Supreme Court that they objected to being classified with the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in claims arising from the bankruptcy proceedings of the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company.

MOSCOW, Oct. 22. -- All indications here tonight point to the Soviet Union's t entering tomorrow's meeting of the London committee on non-intervention in Spain in a softer mood than has been displayed recently.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- Private employment in manufacturing and non-manufacturing industries surveyed regularly by the Bureau of Labor Statistics increased last month by about 355,000 workers and weekly payrolls by more than $2,500,000, compared with August, Secretary of Labor Perkins announced today.

The engagement of $6,870,000 gold in England at some previous date was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York by commercial banks here, bringing to about $58,000,000 the amount bought in London for American account since the suspension of the gold standard by France.

BOSTON, Oct. 23. -- Professor Johan Hjort, oceanographer, who came from Norway last Summer with a hypothesis that shrimp in commercial quantities awaited fishermen off Maine's rocky coast, proved it today as he made port aboard a schooner laden with 300 pounds.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23. -- At the end of the second series of international field hockey games today only two teams remained undefeated. The United States eleven, which scored a driving 5-4 victory today over a stubborn Australian eleven was one, and the English squad was the other.

FOR all our superior scorn of the nineteenth century and its foibles and shortcomings, it remains, for many of us, the most comprehensible of centuries. The eighteenth or the seventeenth is too removed, the twentieth is too close at hand. We can at this time understand what Cobbett meant, or Marx, or Whitman, or Wagner, far better than we can grasp the ultimate meaning of our distinguished contemporaries.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Oct. 23. -- Fleet running and nimble pass receiving by Knute Rockne Jr. led Miami Military to a 6-to-0 victory today over South Broward High School.

Michael E. Di Ielsi, who describes himself as a Bishop, and six other persons were convicted in the Court of Special Sessions in Brooklyn yesterday of conspiring to defraud persons by soliciting funds for non-existing charitable organizations.
BARCELONA, Spain, Oct. 23. -- After two days' shelling of Huesca, government militia is reported to be consolidating its positions in new advances.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Oct. 23. -- For the second year in succession, Ralph Leaf of the North Hills Golf Club came through with colors flying in the third annual Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association Scotch foursome championship.

SKYTOP, Pa., Oct. 23. -- Passage of a new food and drugs law in the next session of Congress was predicted today by James F. Hoge, counsel for the Proprietary Association, in an address to members of the drug, chemical and allied trades section of the New York Board of Trade at their Autumn meeting here.
LONDON, Oct. 23. -- The British Government, it is now admitted, is already using the technical resources of the United States aircraft industry in its gigantic program of rearmament in the air.

Federal Judge John C. Knox made final allowances yesterday in the receivership proceedings of the Spreckles Sugar Corporation of Yonkers and its affiliate, the Syrup Products Company, Inc. His opinion disclosed that general creditors for $6,070,000 will get nothing, while only $337,500 is left for preferred claimants seeking $13,582,000.
Helen Worden, who has been writing society news for fifteen years, has now written a book about New York society which Covici, Friede will publish on Nov. 17 under the title "Society Circus."

BERLIN, Oct. 23. -- The Italian diplomatic mission headed by Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano, which has been conferring in Berlin with Baron Constantin von Neurath, German Foreign Minister, and other government leaders since Wednesday, left for Berchtesgaden tonight, where its members will be the week-end guests of Chancellor Adolf Hitler.

The drum of fortune "beat" in Dublin yesterday, and its echoes reached the ears of 471 lucky Americans, who will win at least $1,250,000 after the running of the Cambridgeshire in Newmarket, England, next Wednesday.

PARIS, Oct. 23 (AP). -- The Spanish Government tonight notified Carlos Saavedra Lamas, Argentine Foreign Minister, that it had granted authorization for the departure from besieged Madrid of Spanish women and children refugees sheltered in the Argentine Embassy.
ROCHESTER, Oct. 23. -- Governor Lehman speaking here tonight demanded ratification of the child labor amendment and challenged the Republican opposition to meet the issue.

With the current unseasonably warm weather causing no end of annoyance to the average person, what could be more appropriate or refreshing than a cool subject -- skiing, for instance? Although it will be many weeks before swirling flakes will transform highways and hidden paths into snowy slopes and trails, the vast army of skiers already has begun to lay plans for the approaching season.

I have noted the letters in last Saturday's TIMES which complain about the $3.30 minimum for seats at the Army-Columbia game and that general admissions should have been made available at a much lower price.

DUBLIN, Oct. 23. -- In pageantry and colorful display, the Irish Sweepstakes promoters excelled themselves when the draw on the Cambridgeshire race opened at the Mansion House here today. The entrance to the Mayoral rooms was transformed into a spectacular entry to Valhalla, while Germanic giants from Wagner's "Ring of the Nibelung" towered above.

The Galloping Gaels of St. Mary's and the Rambling Rams of Fordham, both meeting unbeaten for the first time since their spectacular and colorful series started six years ago, will clash once more at the Polo Grounds today in a game of national interest.
The Columbia University Club went into a triple tie with the Yale and Harvard Clubs for the lead in Class C of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League last night.

Cardinal Pacelli, Papal Secretary of State, the highest official of the Vatican ever to visit the United States, will leave Roosevelt Field, L.I., at 10 o'clock tomorrow morning on a five-day air tour of the United States.

The first double stake program of the Empire City meeting will present two of the best-balanced handicap fields of the Fall, with twelve entered in the Scarsdale for older horses and ten in the Ardsley for juveniles at Yonkers today. In the Scarsdale, which is the richer race, Snow Fox will be put to the acid test.
The address of Secretary Morgenthau, delivered last night at the business men's dinner under the auspices of the Good Neighbor League, follows:

How does one mistreat a 60-foot motor yacht? The owner of such a boat, after building her himself and sailing her for thirty years, sank her in Long Island Sound rather than sell her to a stranger who might mistreat her.

District Attorneys or their assistants of fifteen counties in this State joined State officials and local police yesterday in a conference in District Attorney Dodge's office in a drive to end bootlegging into their territories of coal stolen from mines in Pennsylvania.

Six of the seven privately owned American shipyards which are engaged in the construction of naval vessels have increased their working forces in the last six months, it was announced yesterday by H. Gerrish Smith, president of the National Council of American Ship-builders.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23. -- The American College of Surgeons ended its annual clinical congress tonight with colorful convocation ceremonies in which 518 younger surgeons from the United States, Canada and foreign countries were initiated as fellows of the college on chanting in unison the impressive fellowship pledge.

Today the scholastic football procession draws up to the half-way juncture for a large number of the Eastern prep school teams. To mark the occasion there will be important battles on virtually every hand, with many involving unbeaten squads.

Bond flotations this week amounted to $63,215,000, of which $59,850,000 was for industrial and public utility companies. Last week they were $157,560,000, and the feature was the marketing of $150,000,000 of American Telephone and Telegraph debenture 3 1/4s. A year ago this week new bond financing amounted to $61,782,088.

Manhattan will risk its unblemished home record against a formidable University of Detroit eleven at Ebbets Field today. The Jaspers, who lost to Holy Cross last week after taking three straight, will seek to get back into winning stride against the air-minded Titans.
RUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 23. -- The government is proceeding with serious measures to prevent disorders on Sunday.

The semi-final report of the Literary Digest on its Presidential straw poll shows Governor Landon leading President Roosevelt by nearly 11 to 8 in the popular vote, the magazine revealed yesterday. In the Electoral College, Governor Landon would receive 370 votes to 161 for President Roosevelt, on the basis of the returns.

THE HAGUE, Oct. 23. -- Sir Henri Deterding, presiding genius of the vast Royal Dutch Petroleum Company, is resigning at the end of the year from his office as general managing director, it was announced tonight.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 23. -- Following is the text of Governor Landon's statement issued yesterday in reply to President Roosevelt's Worcester speech:

The cost of living since 1929 shows a greater drop in the United States than in many other major countries, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday on the basis of a study just published.

The General Motors Corporation will dissolve several of its subsidiary companies engaged in selling individual products and will group their activities into a new company to be called the General Motors Sales Corporation, according to an announcement yesterday by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president.
SCRANTON, Pa., Oct. 23 (AP). -- Colonel Frank Knox declared tonight that it was "effrontery" for President Roosevelt to "go about the country telling the people he brought recovery."

The Public Service Commission authorized yesterday the Rochester Telephone Corporation to issue not to exceed $5,000,000 of first and refunding 3 1/2 per cent bonds, to be dated July 1, 1936, and to mature July 1, 1961. The commission also fixed redemption dates and prices.

Doubling its 1936 appropriation, the Cadillac Motor Car Company will spend more than $2,000,000 in advertising its 1937 Cadillac and La Salle lines, F.J. Denney, advertising manager, said yesterday at a meeting of metropolitan distributors and dealers at the Essex House.

Yesterday's report of the Labor Department on manufacturing employment in September emphasizes the conflict of inference between the department's compiled reports and the familiar offhand estimates of relief bureaus. Campaign speakers are still basing arguments on the presumption that the number of unemployed in receipt of public help is nearly or quite as great as in 1932.
GENEVA, Oct. 23. -- The furious rearmament race among nations of the world, League of Nations experts estimated today, brought forth an expenditure of $9,295,000,000 in 1935.
LIMA, Peru, Oct. 23 (AP) -- A new Peruvian Cabinet took office today following the resignation of the old group last night in the midst of uncertainty over the recent Presidential election.

DENVER, Oct. 23. -- Streaking 1,017 miles across four States from daylight to dusk, the Burlington's stainless steel Denver Zephyr established a world's long distance speed record for railway trains today by pulling into this city at 8:12 1/2 P.M. (Eastern standard time) twelve hours and twelve and one-half minutes out of the Chicago Union Station.

That the recurrent invasions of district relief bureaus of the ERB by unemployed pickets, with their resultant arrests and injuries, are not sporadic outbursts, but are part of a concerted plan of attack, was admitted yesterday by the Workers Alliance of America, Greater New York Council.

A Renoir exhibition has opened at the Durand-Ruel Galleries, 12 East Fifty-seventh Street, to remain until Nov. 14. It is composed entirely of canvases painted after 1900 and thus concerns the last part of this great French artist's life. The period stretching between the turn of the century and his death, however, is a long one.

Joseph V. McKee, former Acting Mayor of New York and former President of the Board of Aldermen, has accepted appointment as national "coordinator," or "czar," of the music-publishing industry and counsel for the Music Publishers Protective Association, it was announced yesterday by the association.

LAS NAVAS DEL MARQUES, Spain, Oct. 23. -- For the first time in the Spanish civil war government troops are taking the initiative in a series of counter-attacks in the Madrid sector. The clash is bitterest around Escorial, where the Leftists are fighting with their backs against the wall.

William Rosenwald, son of the late Julius Rosenwald, the philanthropist, entertained at a dinner dance last night at the Waldorf-Astoria. He was assisted in receiving the guests by his sisters, Mrs. David M. Levy of this city and Mrs. Alfred K. Stern of Chicago, and his sister-in-law, Mrs. Lessing J. Rosenwald of Philadelphia.

GENEVA, Oct. 23. -- An eight-hour day for merchant marines was approved by 57 to 17 today by the maritime session of the International Labor Organization conference here, which for the past three weeks has been discussing an international convention on hours and manning.

After fishing for more than an hour with buckets lowered into a storm sewer opening at the northwest corner of Eighty-ninth Street and First Avenue last night, while more than 100 passers-by looked on with burning curiosity, members of Police Emergency Squad 6 struck "pay dirt" in the form of a leather purse containing two diamond bracelets valued by the police at between $3,500 and $5,000 together.

Christian Mobilization Week for 1936 in the metropolitan area will begin tomorrow under the sponsorship of the Eastern Division of the Association of Christian Youth Movements of America, with headquarters in Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Interest in bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday subsided, as the market generally turned highly irregular on a comparatively light turnover. Although the decline in corporation bonds, which was a feature of trading on Thursday, was arrested, the pivotal issues exhibited little abiilty to rally to any extent.

For the nine months ended on Sept. 30, the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company reported yesterday a net income of $3,580,813 after debenture interest, depreciation and normal Federal income taxes but before provision for Federal surtaxes on undistributed earnings.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- Labor's Nonpartisan League, of which Major George L. Berry is the head, charged today that Republican employers of labor were using the pay envelopes of their employes in an effort to compel those employes to vote the Republican national ticket.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- Less than twenty-four hours after its submission, the Interstate Commerce Commission granted today the request of the nation's railroads for a temporary setting aside of more than 1,000 past freight rate decisions and opened the door to a general readjustment of the national freight rate structure.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 23. -- Alfred E. Smith was welcomed with a brass band, red fire and a parade, including about 400 men and women wearing brown derbies, when he arrived here tonight from Chicago, where he made the third in a series of anti-New Deal addresses last night.

New municipal financing scheduled for next week will amount to $35,802,270, to be represented by fifty-three municipalities. This compares with a revised total of only $8,807,337 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for this year to date is $27,342,919.
Miss Mary Haman, 65 years old, of 89 Crooke Avenue, in a fashionable residential section of Brooklyn near Prospect Park, died yesterday in Kings County Hospital of malnutrition.

While warm weather retarded expansion of retail trade here somewhat during the week, gains over a year ago were nevertheless scored on practically every day by leading department stores. Estimates put volume for the week at 8 to 9 per cent over last year.

Elizabeth Smith, 18 years old, who has been in the Bronx County Jail annex since her arrest last April for the killing of her newborn son, was set free on a suspended sentence yesterday by Judge Harry Stackell in the Bronx County Court.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- Three campaign gifts from William Randolph Hearst totaling $30,000 headed the larger contributions revealed in the report of the Republican National Committee filed with the Clerk of the House today under the Corrupt Practices Act. The report covers the period from Sept. 1 to Oct. 18.

LONDON, Oct. 23. -- King Edward had an intimate talk with his mother tonight across the dinner table at Marlborough House. This was the first time he had dined alone with her since Wednesday of last week just before the news became known that his friend, Mrs. Ernest A. Simpson, was seeking a divorce.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23. -Hog receipts continue to exceed trade expectations today. This, with the continued easiness in the fresh pork market, gave an advantage to buyers and prices were steady to 10; cents lower than yesterday. The top was off 15 cents at $9.70 a hundredweight and came within 10 cents of the inside figure of the year.

DETROIT, Oct. 23. -- An effort to turn the Middle West's labor vote away from the New Deal, by pay envelope warnings that President Roosevelt's re-election will mean an automatic wage deduction as of Jan. 1 because of the social security program, has been started by industrial employers in this area, working in cooperation with the Republican National Committee.

PARIS, Oct. 23. -- Indalecio Prieto, the Spanish Minister of Marine and from the beginning one of the principal powers behind the stubborn resistance of the government forces to the Insurgents, nag left Madrid. This news was oppressed in the Spanish capital and was communicated through special channels.

Julius Mercz was sentenced to pay a fine of $50 and his driver's license was suspended for six months by Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio, for the "leaving of the scene of an accident," after his car killed a terrier.

ON BOARD THE CHINA CLIPPER EN ROUTE TO SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 23. -- After an overnight stop on Waikiki beach, Honolulu, we took off from Pearl Harbor at 12:17 P.M. today, leaving Hawaii basking in the sunlight, and began the longest regular overwater airplane jump in the world.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23. -- Two further court actions developed today in the involved litigation concerning the Utilities Power and Light Corporation for control of which utility system its president, Harley L. Clarke, and the Atlas Corporation are battling.
TULSA, Okla., Oct. 23. -- Following are the texts of Governor Landon's addresses today in Oklahoma City and Tulsa:

Plans for new buildings filed yesterday centered largely in Queens, where architects submitted specifications for a large number of brick and frame dwellings. The projects, which cover a wide area, will be undertaken in such communities as Forest Hills, Laurelton, Richmond Hill, Springfield and Elmhurst.

Orrie Kelly, Anthony J. Kerin and Pliny W. Williamson, as trustees, sold for cash a one-story taxpayer containing eight stores at Albany Post Road and Brook Street, Croton. The assessed value is $38,000. Kadel, Van Kirk Trencher, attorneys, represented the buyer.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 23. -- Notwithstanding Harvard's rout in last week's game with Army, it is expected that there will be at least 45,000 in the Soldiers Field Stadium tomorrow for the annual battle between the Crimson and the Dartmouth Indians.

Mary Garden, operatic soprano, who first appeared at the Manhattan Opera House on Nov. 25, 1907, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen. She plans to adapt opera for the moving pictures and train singers for them.

That the demand for new bonds of the better grade continues unabated regardless of the meager yields afforded was illustrated again this week by the manner in which the $59,850,000 of new corporate loans were distributed readily by underwriting groups.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., Oct. 23. -- The favored team of Clarence Clark, home club pro, and Victor Ghezzi of Deal, the Jersey P.G.A. champion, today gained the final of the second annual pro-pro golf championship of the New Jersey P.G.A. by defeating Johnny Kinder of Plainfield and Maurrie O'Connor of Branch Brook, 1 up, in a thrilling semi-final match at the Forest Hill Field Club.

The Lucille B. Harris Trophy for the women's pair championship at the second annual metropolitan contract bridge tournament of the American Bridge League was won yesterday afternoon by Mrs. Edith Russell and Miss Ruth Chase at the concluding session of a two-day play at the Park Central Hotel.

BLAIRSTOWN, N.J., Oct. 23. -- Blair Academy's lead of 13 points in the first half proved too much for the hard-fighting Horace Mann School eleven to overcome today and the New York City team went down to defeat, 13 -- 6.

Within two days of each other two prominent men made political speeches on the same subject. Both Mr. JOHN W. DAVIS and ex-Governor SMITH spoke as lifelong Democrats who could not approve or follow the direction and control of their party by the present Administration.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- Four major speeches will be made by President Roosevelt in the final week of the campaign, according to a schedule made public today by the White House.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- As an important step in forwarding its program for partial segregation of the functions of brokers and dealers on national securities exchanges, the Securities and Exchange Commission made public today an analysis showing the scope of members' trading for their own accounts, by weeks, on the New York Stock and the New York Curb Exchanges, on and off the floor from March 30 to Sept. 26.
I do not think Ex-Giant Fan looked at the record when he wrote to you recently that what the Giants needed was not a McCarthy to play first base but a McCarthy, to manage the team.

TORONTO, Oct. 23 (Canadian Press). -- Eight days before the contesting mothers cross the finish line in Toronto's stork derby and, probably, go on to courts of law, Premier Mitchell F. Hepburn of Ontario announced today that his government would supervise the finish of the $500,000 race.
A half dozen properties -- four in Manhattan and two in the Bronx -- were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure sales yesterday. Houses comprised the bulk of the auction offerings.

ROME, Saturday, Oct. 24 (AP). -Concerted action by Italy, Germany and Portugal for non-recognition of any Leftist government in Spain if and when the Rebels take Madrid was predicted early today by informed persons.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 23. -- Yale and Rutgers, old rivals who began playing football in 1873, will renew relations tomorrow after a lapse since 1890. Yale will present several substitutes in its starting line-up, Felix Caracciolo at left guard, Al Wilson at quarterback, Bud Humphrey at left half and Tony Mott at fullback.
All station employes of the I.R.T. subway were instructed yesterday by officials of the system to prevent passengers carrying large bundles from entering the subway.

DETROIT, Oct. 23. -- Prices of new Plymouth cars for 1937, with safety glass as standard equipment on all models, will start at $510 as heretofore. The Plymouth business coupe will be priced at that figure.

Having established some sort of record, certainly, for both the quantity and quality of their nocturnal offerings during the past month, the beaming bonifaces will bring October to a close next week with a few less entries in the field of events but with no less promise of brilliance.

Stockholders of Consolidated Film Industries, Inc., approved yesterday the management's proposal for a readjustment of capitalization after a three-hour stormy session, according to The Associated Press.

The desire for well-being far outweighs any profit motive and medical experience shows that the "repeated assertion" that injured persons seek to lengthen their disability to obtain money has been very much exaggerated, Dr. Israel Strauss, neurologist of Mount Sinai Hospital, told the graduate fortnight of the Academy of Medicine last night.

Incorporated Investors reported yesterday that its net assets on Sept. 30 amounted to $74,543,954, which was equal to $26.07 a share on 2,859,496 shares of stock. For June 30, last, it reported net assets of $64,000,000, equal to $23.23 a share.

The law enacted two years ago to stop favorites of politicians from displaying city and State shields on their automobiles, had an ex-convict as its first victim yesterday when Max W. Federbush was convicted by Justices Nolan, McDonald and Salomon in Special Sessions.

President Roosevelt, in an address broadcast last night from Washington to business men gathered at dinners here and in other cities arranged by the Good Neighbor League, declared that no administration in the nation's history had done more than his to preserve private enterprise and private profit.
ALBANY, Oct. 23. -- The Court of Appeals today unanimously ruled the Union party and Social Labor tickets off the official ballot in this State.

COLBY vs. BOWDOIN -- The phone rang and a voice said: "So you're going to see Harvard and Dartmouth? Tell Dick Harlow that he'd be safer in New York with his fine-feathered friends of the Audubon Society who are holding their annual convention at the American Museum of Natural History. He can't charm those Dartmouth Indians with bird songs.

The stock market rallied on dull trading yesterday. The turnover on the Stock Exchange was 1,514,000 shares, the smallest for any five-hour session this month and about half that of the most active day in the early part of the month, when the trend was more consistently upward.

AURORA, N.Y., Oct. 23. -- More than a score of college presidents, many deans, representatives of foundations and others witnessed the ceremonies today incident to the induction of Dr. William E. Weld as the eighth president of Wells College.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 23 (AP). -- Purdue's gallant football warriors throw themselves at the gridiron's immovable object, Minnesota, in a Big Ten championship showdown tomorrow.
