While mild and inclement weather retarded retail distribution in some parts of the country this week, particularly in seasonable apparel, orders to wholesalers were maintained at a steady rate, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Republican leaders and investigators charged yesterday extensive registration frauds not only in New York but in other Eastern cities. In Brooklyn alone, it was asserted by A. David Benjamin, chairman of the Kings County Republican Committee's law committee, there are at least 150,000 fraudulent registrants.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 23. -- Commercial banking in this country has for a long time been undergoing fundamental changes which have carried it far from the concepts developed by classical economists, according to Torn K. Smith, president of the Boatmen's National Bank, St. Louis, Mo., and president of the American Bankers Association, who, this morning addressed the convention here of the Robert Morris Associates.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 23. -- Harvard's junior varsity football team scored a 6-to-0 triumph over the Dartmouth junior varsity eleven today.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 23. -- Duquesne University, which scaled the gridiron heights in the East last week by upsetting the mighty Pitt Panthers, were jolted right out of their championship aspirations tonight by a fighting band of Bobcats from West Virginia Wesleyan who won, 2 -- 0, at Forbes Field.

In THE TIMES editorial "Gold Standard Reaffirmed" the statement is made that "in the last two years we have seen the Bank of England adding 57,000,000 to its gold reserve, in order to maintain the 'reserve ratio' against 81,000,000 increase in its note issue."

OTTAWA, Oct. 23. -- Sixteen hours of flying time for the 2,400 miles between Montreal and Vancouver is the objective of a commercial flying service across Canada, to be provided for through cooperation between the Federal Government and private enterprise, according to C.D. Howe, Minister of Transportation, on return from a ten-day survey of flying conditions between the capital and the Pacific Coast.

LISBON, Portugal, Oct. 23. -- The Portuguese Government late tonight announced that it had broken off diplomatic relations with the Madrid government. Italy and Germany are expected to follow suit immediately.
The Fordham cross-country team reversed a 1-point setback of last year by defeating the City College harriers, 27 -- 28, at the Van Cortlandt Park course yesterday.
It would be impossible to disregard the utterances of a man as sincere and honest as John W. Davis.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP). -- George Washington University narrowly protected its unbeaten slate tonight with a 13-to-12 triumph over Wake Forest before 18,000.

After being held scoreless during the first half, the strong St. Paul's football team of Garden City came back with renewed strength in the second and downed courageous Brooklyn Prep, 19 to 0, at Boys High School Field, Brooklyn, yesterday.

A few days ago NEWTON D. BAKER in an address before the convention of the American Hospital Association quoted a significant statement by General HASKELL, who administered American relief to millions in Central and Eastern Europe after the war:
FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., Oct. 23. -- Three stakes were completed in the thirteenth annual field-trial meeting of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association today.

Dispatches from Holland indicate a lack of enthusiasm there for the new tripartite gold agreement. Our correspondent reports that Amsterdam financiers regard it as "an association of lame currencies," and that there is little confidence among them in the future trend of the pound sterling, owing to the increasing adverse gap in the trade balance of Great Britain.

Passengers booked to sail today for Mediterranean ports on the Italian liner Rex include Tazio Nuvolari, winner of the recent Vanderbile Cup Race at Roosevelt Raceway, and his team-mates, Count Antonio Brivio and Dr. Giuseppe Farina, Prince and Princess Corrado Valguarnera di Niscemi, Dr. and Mrs. Giorgio Nelson Page, Charles Ballance, Marchese Guglielmo Rizzo, Countess Elena Dandini de Sylva, Mrs. A.C. Clark and Miss Elizabeth Armour.
GENEVA, Oct. 23. -- Ethiopia has appealed to the League of Nations for further aid against Italy's renewed attack. Her telegram to the League Secretariat was published today.

The Brooklyn Union Gas Company reported yesterday for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 a net income of $1,628,826, equal to $2.19 a share on the average number of shares outstanding, compared with $1,974,390, or $2.65 a share o the stock outstanding, for the corresponding period of 1935.

Cotton futures sold off into new low ground for the movement yesterday following a better opening. Liquidation through commission houses increased when it appeared as though the cold wave in the Southwest would miss the eastern Cotton Belt, but prices gave way slowly as mills continued to fix prices at each point decline.
LONDON, Oct. 23. -- Gilbert Miller completed here today his deal with Warner Brothers for the sale of the film rights for "Tovarich," "Promise" and "The Amazing Dr. Clitterhouse."

Price changes were mixed on the local commodity futures markets yesterday, with trading activity generally limited. Nevertheless, rubber, copper, silk and coffee were somewhat stronger. Cocoa and hides closed the day lower. On the cash markets Rio coffee, rubber, wooltops and tins advanced while wheat, corn, rye, oats, cotton, silk and butter declined.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 23. -- William F. Bleakley, Republican candidate for Governor, declared tonight that "heavy taxes" would be necessary to obtain a balanced budget, in a speech in which he reiterated his pledge to bring the State's fiscal affairs into balance if elected.

The Feast of Christ the King will be observed tomorrow in all Roman Catholic Churches and some of the more ritualistic Protestant Episcopal Churches. "Reformation Sunday" will be celebrated in Lutheran houses of worship. Congregations that are affiliated with the Atlantic Lutheran District will observe tomorrow as "Gift" Sunday for the Bethlehem Orphan and Half Orphan Home at Fort Wadsworth, S.I., which they support.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 23. -- A little less than half of the total vote in Oneida County this year will be cast in this city, which appears to be lost to the Republicans. While they do not admit this, they do not seriously dispute the Democratic claim that Utica is "in the bag" for President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- The Mexican Army officers, trailing the United States and Chilean riders in the team jumping competition, came into their own today at the Inter-American Horse Show at the Meadow Brook Saddle Club.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 23. -- The largest Palmer Stadium crowd of the season is expected to witness the Princeton-Navy football game tomorrow. Forty thousand tickets have already been sold and the remaining 12,000 will go on public sale tomorrow.

SPARTA, N.J., Oct. 23. -- Allan Lawrence Upjohn, 19-year-old son of a wealthy drug manufacturer, killed himself with a rifle in the mountains near here because of his failure in college, it was revealed today with the identification of parts of the youth's body and clothing here.

TENAFLY, N.J., Oct. 23. -- Shooting an 81, Mrs. Maureen Orcutt Crews of White Beeches, runner-up in the national women's championship this year, today captured low gross in the one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association at the Knickerbocker Country Club.

Mayor La Guardia and his colleagues on the Board of Estimate listened unexpectedly yesterday to a discourse on the 1937 city budget delivered by A.J. Engleman, who described himself as president of the "Pedestrian-Motorist Safety League."

LONDON, Oct. 23. -- Apparently contradicting supposedly "inside information" from Moscow last night, the Soviet delegates threw a new "bombshell" into the meeting of the international non-intervention committee on Spain today.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 23. -- Columbia's Lions, here for their intersectional gridiron battle with the Wolverines at Michigan Stadium tomorrow, were declared fit and ready today by Head Coach Lou Little following a light drill. Every one of the thirty-one members of the squad who made the trip from New York took part in the practice.

The New York University football team, with a radically revised line-up, will encounter Georgetown's undefeated and untied eleven today in the eighth game of their series at the Yankee Stadium. As a result of the fine comeback made by the Violet last week against North Carolina and the record of the invading eleven a large crowd is expected to be present.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- Receipts of 570,013 service establishments in 1935 amounted to $1,947,518,000, according to the service census made public today by the Department of Commerce.

MONTREAL, Oct. 23. -- Prevented by Montreal from holding a meeting in the city and blocked in an attempt to transfer it to a hall in the suburb of Westmount, four Spanish Loyalists decided tonight to return tomorrow to New York.

Declaring that he "deplored this campaign," Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, described it last night as an Alice-in-Wonderland affair without any real discussion of issues and asserted that democracy was doomed if it could not produce better political campaigns.
ON BOARD GOVERNOR LANDON'S TRAIN EN ROUTE TO INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 23. -- As he traveled through Oklahoma today in his campaign tour, Governor Landon made a double attack on his political opponents.

Dividends of $3 a share each have been declared on the 6 per cent first preferred stock of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, payable on Dec. 1 and Jan. 15, the latter clearing all arrears on the issue.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- American aircraft builders, reported in dispatches from London about to obtain orders for military aircraft for Great Britain, may find themselves confronted with an obstacle in a law passed June 15, 1917.

LONDON, Saturday, Oct. 24. -The news that Portugal had decided to break off diplomatic relations with the Madrid government reached London early this morning, the report adding that Italy and Germany were expected to follow suit immediately.

Net profit of the Texas Corporation and its subsidiaries for the first nine months of this year was about $28,000,000 after charges, including depreciation, depletion and amortization, according to an estimate issued yesterday by T. Rieber, chairman.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- Unless New Zealand and Australia put into operation discriminatory regulations against American shipping in the Tasman Sea no grounds for action by the United States would be warranted, officials said today. The situation, it was added, would be watched closely, but the hope was informally expressed that nothing would be done to call for action here.

PARIS, Oct. 23. -- The Radical Socialist congress at Biarritz had another feverish day of discussion today without healing the seemingly profound breach between those who want the party to break away from the Communists and thus over-throw the Popular Front government and those who desire to see this great party of the center continue its support of Premier Leon Blum.

The trend these days being eastward from Hollywood, take note of Florence Eldridge. She is in town, and in another fortnight will be rehearsing in Lillian Hellman's latest play -- still untitled, by the way -- under the auspices of Herman Shumlin.

Supreme Court Justice Charles B. MeLaughlin dismissed yesterday the complaint in a suit brought by Robert Black of 201 Lexington Avenue in behalf of himself and other stockholders of the Pan-American Petroleum and Transport Company with permission to file a new complaint.

Gunners who have been chained to their office desks since the opening of the season on small upland game last Monday will get in their first shooting this week-end. Needless to say, they will find pheasants warier than they were when their more fortunate brethren went afield earlier in the week.

Open opposition to the new city charter by the Democratic organizations, hinted at for some time, became a reality yesterday when the Queens County organization sponsored a radio address delivered by Alderman James A. Burke.

The Machlin Development Company, Murray B. Machlin, president, yesterday purchased from the 1,512 Townsend Avenue Corporation the northeast corner of Townsend Avenue and 172d Street and the adjoining property, two five story buildings each on plots 125 by 100 feet.

Substantial bail reductions were ordered yesterday by Justice John V. McAvoy in the Appellate Division for four of the nine men arrested last Tuesday in Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey's investigation of a racket alleged to have taken $2,000,000 a year from restaurant owners of New York City.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

In his speech yesterday at Oklahoma City, Governor LANDON returned to a theme which both he and Mr. ROOSEVELT have discussed on earlier occasions. This is the increase of farm tenancy in the United States. Two farms out of every five are now operated by tenants.

A report directing the Alexander Smith Company, carpet manufacturers of Yonkers, N.Y., to disband three so-called company unions and to reinstate three employes who charged that they were dismissed last January for outside union activities, was filed here yesterday with the Regional Labor Board by Walter Wilbur, trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 23. -- Because of widespread criticism of the political method of selecting the year's outstanding pictures and performances, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has undertaken to devise a system of determining awards in which the public can have more confidence.

After "Men in White" and "Dead End" comes Sidney Kingsley's third play, "Ten Million Ghosts," which he produced and staged at the St. James last evening. In it he drives headlong into his boldest subject -- the manufacturers of munitions. He has documented his program with excerpts from books and newspapers about Zaharoff, the Krupps, the de Wendels and William B. Shearer, who represented steel and shipbuilding at the 1927 Geneva conference.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's address tonight to the series of dinners arranged by the Good Neighbor League:

BERLIN, Oct. 23. -- In his first decree as economic dictator in charge of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's second Four-Year Plan, Col. Gen. Wilhelm Goering today proclaimed that he would carry out his commission "in defiance of all possible obstructions and difficulties."

A "rumor" that nine officers of the Police Department were demoted last August as the result of their interference with policy racketeers who had a "pull" was made a part of the semi-annual report of the Society for the Prevention of Crime, made public yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23. -The world's wheat markets moved downward today. Liverpool ignored yesterday's late advance in North America, which was a signal for holders of futures both here and at Winnipeg to liquidate their lines. At no time did the markets show pronounced strength.

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- The trend toward weakness on recent days was reversed on the Bourse today, and French values, rentes as well as stocks, made progress. Virtually all French stocks benefited moderately.

BERLIN, Oct. 23. -- Prices on the Boerse as a whole were mixed and variable today, but the leading stocks generally ended at declines, with some recording severe losses. Excepting the leaders the turnover continued to decrease and the market as a whole lapsed into the apathetic state that is typical of trading here when no major economic issue sets the blocked-mark accounts in motion.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23. -- A prophecy that the Republicans will gain control of the next House if Governor Landon wins the Presidency, and a certain increase of 100 seats, even if President Roosevelt is re-elected, was made today by Carl G. Bachmann, Western manager of the Congressional campaign.

J. Edward Jones, dealer in oil royalties, now under Federal indictment for alleged fraudulent use of the mails, renewed last night his attack upon the New Deal administration, with which he has been at odds for several years in connection with the Securities Act of 1933.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Oct. 23. -- More than one hundred debutantes are here for the annual Autumn Ball tomorrow night, and the festivities opened tonight with a large dinner given for 150 by Mrs. George B. St. George at her home here tonight and a dance given later by Mrs. E. Roland Harriman at Arden.

In an address over the red network of the National Broadcasting Company, Earl Browder, Communist candidate for President, compared the present fight of Spanish Loyalists to that of the American Revolutionaries in 1776 and urged Americans to demand that the United States Government sell arms to the Spanish Government.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 23 (AP). -- Baffled by a charging, scrappy Loyola line, Alabama's Crimson Tide had to take to the air today to turn back a valiant band of Wolves, 13 to 6, before 7,000 fans.

Under threat of boycott and picketing by she Non-Sectrian Anti-Nazi League and the American Jewish Congress, the management of the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse announced yesterday that it had indefinitely postponed the showing of the film "Amphitryon."

Service on the Interborough's East Side subway line was held up twice during the morning rush hour yesterday when some person or persons pulled eight emergency electric switches between Eighty-sixth and 125th Streets. Company officials were of the opinion that a disgruntled former employe might have tampered with the switches.

A warning against "cancer cures that come out of a bottle," the use of which causes patients to overlook the only methods that hold any hope of effecting a cure, was delivered yesterday by Dr. Francis Carter Wood, director of the Institute of Cancer Research at Columbia University.
MADRID, Oct. 23 (Passed by the Censor). -- Four Rebel air raids were carried out today over Madrid and its immediate vicinity, the first to be attempted in daylight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 23 (AP). -- Justice Department agents, still trailing an unrecovered $40,000 from the $200,000 George Weyerhaeuser ransom, announced today the arrest here of Edward Fliss, 30, one-time associate of William Mahan, kidnapper of the boy.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23. -- The Chicago Symphony Orchestra, Frederick Stock conducting, gave its second program of the season this afternoon in Orchestra Hall. This was the third of the orchestras west of New York which the writer has heard, functioning on its native terrain, in the last ten days.
You printed this morning a letter from David A. Clarkson summarizing reasons for withdrawing his support of Franklin D. Roosevelt as a candidate for the Presidency.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- Representatives of the Senate committee investigating campaign expenditures have reported that thousands of voters in Maine were threatened with disqualification at the polls because they were on the relief rolls, and that many of them failed to register and vote for fear of being challenged on this ground.

Late stayers among several hundred delegates to the 101st convention of the City Federation of Women's Clubs gave a rousing reception last evening to Mayor La Guardia after an hour's wait, when the tardy but energetic Executive launched into a vigorous and vivid analysis of the city's food markets, past and future.

ALBANY, Oct. 23 (AP). -- Registration of New York voters for the November election will reach an all-time high of more than 6,150,000, an increase of slightly more than 15 per cent over registration in the last Presidential year.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 23 -- Pitt and Notre Dame will clash in the seventh game of the modern series at the Pitt Stadium tomorrow.

Alfredo Salmaggi and his company last night revived at the Hippodrome Theatre Bellini's "Norma" for the edification -- and judging by the frequent demonstrations of applause -- the complete enjoyment of an audience of 3,000. The work was last given at the Sixth Avenue house in 1934 by Mr. Salmaggi with Anna Leskaya in the title role.

There are State Senators and Assemblymen to be elected this year, as well as a President, a Governor, Representatives in Congress, a President of the Board of Aldermen and a raft of judges. The legislative candidates ought not to be overlooked, even by those whose eyes are focused on Presidential Electors, or the State ticket.

Here and there throughout the football world today teams which have recently been striding through the white glare of the spotlight settle down for what they hope will be easier contests, and they should enjoy very nearly complete rest, for there will certainly be enough uproar elsewhere to draw the light from them.
Pennsylvania's educators aim to make the pupils of the State Constitution-conscious during the observance next year of the 150th anniversary of the adoption of the nation's basic law.

AMONG the great film personalities commanding that unchallengeable prestige which comes of being able to create some unique and irreplaceable illusion supremely well Lawrence Tibbett is one of those most jealously idolized by his public.

Mrs. Arthur C. Holden will be hostess at a tea on Wednesday afternoon at her home, 57 East Seventy-eighth Street, for the members of the committee arranging the performance of "The Show Is On" at the Winter Garden Theatre the latter part of next month for the benefit of the United Neighborhood Houses of New York.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 24. -- Stanley D. McGraw of New York gave a luncheon at the Cascades Club today. Among his guests were Mr. and Mrs. Elon Huntington Hooker of New York and Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. DeGreef of Mount Kisco, N.Y. Mrs. Richard Nott Dyer of Orange, N.J., also had several luncheon guests there.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Oct. 24. -- Leading among Pacific Coast ports, San Francisco showed an increase in import and export values for the first eight months of 1936 as compared with a year ago, according to figures just received from the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.

IN addition to first appearances of the season by Slenczynski, Gorodnitzki, the National Orchestral Association and other familiar artists, the WPA Federal Music Project will inaugurate this week a series of concerts devoted to music of Bach.

The Kansas City Power and Light Company reported yesterday for the year ended on Sept. 30 a net income of $3,958,944 after all deductions. This was equivalent to $98.97 a share on 40,000 shares of $6 first-preferred Series B stock. It compared with a revised net income of $3,520,213, or $88.01 a share on the same stock, the year before.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- A record year in accident-prevention work was reported today, one year after the start of the Red Cross drive against death and injuries on the highways.

THE devaluation of the guilder has been welcomed by the Dutch tourist trade. For several years past, tourism in Holland has been at a low ebb, with the result that, according to estimates by the Central Statistical Bureau, expenditure by foreign travelers in Holland in 1935 fell to 4,000,000 guilders, while expenditure of Dutch travelers abroad rose to 35,000,000, leaving an adverse balance of 31,000,000.

The first complaint issued by the Federal Trade Commission under the Robinson-Patman act bring into focus two vital questions, the answers to which may influence the fate of this law, according to Burton A. Zorn and George J. Feldman, legal authorities, who have made a careful study of the act.
WASHINGTON, Pa., Oct. 24. -- Bucknell's Thundering Herd romped through W. and J., 26 to 6, today in the sixteenth game of their series, played before 4,000 Homecoming Day fans.

LISBON, Oct. 23. -- General Francisco Franco's Rebel troops tightened their grip around three sides of Madrid this week. Yet the Rebels continue to meet unrelenting opposition. The pressure is becoming so great upon both armies that it appears one or the other must soon crack, with the odds at the moment indicating it will be the Leftists.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 24. -- An all-time record registration of 207,786 for the Nov. 3 election in Nassau County, an increase of almost 20 per cent over the 1932 registration of 178,001, was announced when the Nassau County Board of Elections completed the tabulations of returns from all the county's election districts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- The largest turkey crop on record, about 20,000,000 birds, is predicted for this year by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. Production is about a third larger than during 1935.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- Under the heading, "Here's One House the Government Failed to Save," the daily newspapers published in Westchester by J. Noel Macy print conspicuously a story about the foreclosure of the former home of Mrs. Anna Boettiger, President Roosevelt's daughter, and its recent sale to a grand-niece of Governor Lehman.

Foreign currency devaluations, reducing the purchase price of imported items, are proving far from an unmixed blessing, importers admitted ruefully yesterday. While in some cases the lower foreign costs bring a distinct advantage to buyers here and in others nullify rate concessions granted under reciprocal trade agreements with such nations as France, Switzerland, the Netherlands and Italy, in practically all instances they complicate important transactions immeasurably, it was said.

The seventy-fifth anniversary of the opening of transcontinental telegraphic service was celebrated here yesterday on the site where Samuel F.B. Morse completed the first practical instruments that made the wire communication possible.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP). -- The civil war in Spain has brought business there to a virtual halt, with staggering losses.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 24. -- The University of Kentucky football team defeated Florida today, 7 to 0. in a game played chiefly in the 'Gators' territory.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 24 (AP) -- A swelling flood of political oratory drew from Professor Peter Odegard of Ohio State University today the assertion that "it's all very interesting but it has little effect on the result of an election."

THE Swiss have strong hopes that the devaluation of their franc will greatly improve tourist business beginning with the Winter ski season. Those engaged in this business say that so far them have observed no effect of devaluation, but they point out that there has been little time and that Switzerland is now in between its main seasons.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 24 -- Yale fraternities have resumed their place in the university sun, according to an analysis of the annual elections announced this morning.

GETTYSBURG, Oct. 24. -- Opening a bag of tricks and showing a great deal of power, Gettysburg College's bullet eleven fared forth in a wide open aerial attack to march through Lehigh today and conquer the Engineers, 10 -- 7. The game was played before a crowd of 4,000 fans on Memorial Field home for alumni day festivities.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 24. -- Governor Landon's sudden dash to the Pacific Coast this week may have had a favorable psychological effect throughout the country, but it does not seem likely to win the electoral votes of California, Arizona and New Mexico, the three Far Western States visited by the candidate on the trip.

PARIS, Oct. 24. -- The latest Russian gesture in claiming a free hand to support the Spanish Leftist government to the same extent that others support the Insurgents has merely served to harden the French Government's determination to maintain a strictly neutral attitude and to refuse under any circumstances to be drawn into a quarrel that it is now fully realized bears the germ of an international war.

Tallying two goals early in the contest, the blue-and-white-clad girls' field hockey team of Rhode Island State checked a constantly challenging New York University eleven to win, 2 -- 1, at Prospect Park yesterday.

My eye was caught by a letter on the goose step in THE NEW YORK TIMES recently. THE TIMES published a letter of mine on the subject at the time of the World War. I explained the goose step as being due to the desire to inculcate courage into soldiers. When one is afraid or timid, the knees have a tendency to unknit and become weakened.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- The Democratic National Committee has spent $2,914,546.62 in seeking the re-election of President Roosevelt during the active campaign period from June 1 to Oct. 21, according to its report filed today with the clerk of the House.

VARIOUS phases of Federal art activity are particularly well represented in New York at the present time. Any one who wishes to inform himself at first hand may go to the Whitney Museum to see sculpture and mural work executed for Federal buildings under the Treasury Department Art Project.

NEVADA CITY, Calif., Oct. 24 (AP). -- The treasure hunt conducted in this mountain country by 16-year-old Jean Kuster of San Francisco has set old prospectors' tongues wagging all along the Mother Lode on a subject of which they never tire -- lost bonanzas and hidden treasure.
THE American College of Surgeons met at Philadelphia last week. Here are the high spots of the occasion which brought some 4,500 surgeons and members of hospital staffs together:

PARIS. VILLAGE wiseacres are predicting a real old-fashioned Winter for France, with plenty of ice and snow, as in the days "before the war mixed up the European seasons." This news has undoubtedly penetrated the capital, judging by the new hostess gowns and negligees designed by Paris creators.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 24 (AP). -- Ohio State turned on the power today, but was forced to take to the air to defeat a stubborn Indiana team, 7 to 0.

IN this almost heroically simple story, Margaret Wilson returns to the scenes and characters of her Pulitzer Prize novel, "The Able McLaughlins." The scene, as readers of the earlier volume will remember, is a still undivided segment of the Iowa prairie called Leader, soon to be incorporated as the town of Leader.

IS the new American opera that the Metropolitan will present during the season after the next, that is, in 1937-38, already in the mill? The answer is a hesitant affirmative, inasmuch as the Metropolitan is still concerned with the coming season, and probably not prepared to consider plans for the future until the new year has been launched.

IN the late Fall, when the tobacco has gone to market and the cotton is baled, the rural inhabitants of the South relax from the rigors of agriculture to take part in a week or ten days of gala fun-making and prideful exhibitions at their county fairs. Sharing with them in the festivities are many Southbound vacationists who are stopping off at the fair grounds.

Tall and svelte Melinda Alexander, convinced by her own admission that she is now teetering on the threshold of Congress, is unique among candidates in this or any other political campaign. She spends two hours a day, she said yesterday, in prayer, not for victory but for a fair break for her constituents in their representative at Washington.

In the color pageant of Autumn there is hardly a tree, shrub or weed but joins in the carnival. It is not surprising therefore that this crowning spectacle of the year attracts curiosity as to its causation and meaning.

Housed in a narrow building just off Fifth Avenue, at 10 East Thirty-ninth Street, the first formal school in the country devoted exclusively to industrial design is running night and day classes for a capacity enrollment of 300 students. Started tentatively last January as a part of the WPA Federal Art Project, the school has now opened its second term and has issued a challenge to the future by instituting a new three-year course.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa. Oct. 24 (AP). -- Representative William Lemke, Union party Presidential candidate, charged today that Department of Agriculture officials "are still on a mad orgy of destroying and restricting the production of the essentials of life."

Comparable only to the engagement pad of the season's most successful debutante, a calendar packed with events demanding their presence confronts Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman and Mrs. Caroline O'Day, as this significant Democratic trio enters the Manhattan area tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- An analysis of the large registration increases being reported in practically every part of the country indicated today a possible record Presidential vote of about 45,473,000. The 1932 vote was slightly below 40,000,000.

A series of twenty-three weekly broadcasts on current problems of occupations and employment will be presented by the American School of the Air, it was announced by Dr. Harry D. Kitson, Professor of Education in Teachers College, Columbia University.

The fact that legal representatives of an estate of a deceased person recognize and pay what they deem to be an obligation of the decedent does not necessarily entitle the estate to take credit therefor as a deduction from the value of the gross estate in determining the net amount subject to estate taxes.

PARIS, Oct. 23. -- High jeweled dog-collars and coiffures brushed high are reminiscent of the ladies in Helleu's portraits; they are being revived for the evening. Modernized versions in diamonds or pearls feature clear-cut geometrical motifs, or Oriental arabesques.

Plans for Governor Landon's visit, from his arrival at Pennsylvania Station at 4:30 P.M. on Wednesday until he delivers his campaign address in Madison Square Garden Thursday night, were announced yesterday by Kenneth F. Simpson, chairman of the New York County Republican Committee.

DALLAS, Oct. 24 (AP). -- Aerial machines grounded in rain and ankle-deep muck, Texas Christian and Mississippi State gave the game over to a pair of stout lines and sloshed to a scoreless tie in the Cotton Bowl today.

BOSTON, Oct. 24. -- Vigorously decrying "this pernicious charge of communism," Joseph P. Kennedy, former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, took up the cudgels tonight to strike back at those who have accused President Roosevelt of being an extreme radical.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 24. -- A respectful endorsement of President Harold W. Dodds's recent plea for abstaining from drinking at Princeton's football games was seen in the conduct of an orderly crowd of 55,000 which attended the annual Princeton-Navy game here today.

Many dinners will be given before the pre-opening performance of "Red, Hot and Blue," the new musical comedy, on Wednesday night at the Alvin Theatre, for the benefit of the Maternity Center Association. Mrs. Shepard Krech, president of the organization, has announced that every seat for the benefit has been purchased.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- A large increase in employment in the liquor industry since repeal, as contrasted with the figures in 1914, was shown today in a report made public as part of the census of manufacturers by the Department of Commerce.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 24. -- Myrtlewood, Brownell Combs's great 4-year-old daughter of Blue Larkspur-Frizeur, clinched her claim to the championship of the older division of racing fillies today by conquering Miss Merriment, crack sprinter from the East, by three lengths in a special sweepstakes at Keeneland Park.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 24. -- Thomas (Red) Harp, 155-pound halfback, pulled down a punt and raced seventy yards for a touchdown in the last period today to give Tennessee's Volunteers a 15-to-13 decision over the hitherto unbeaten Duke Blue Devils before approximately 20,000 Homecoming Day fans.

LONDON, Oct. 24. -- When King Edward opens the new session of Parliament Nov. 3 his address from the throne, conforming, of course, to the future legislative program of his Ministers, will indicate what course the Baldwin government means to take to rid the country of the nuisance caused by Sir Oswald Mosley's Fascists.
ONE of the most remarkable occurrences in modern history is the change, in a few hurried years, of friendship and cooperation between Soviet Russia and Germany to the bitterest antagonism.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- Efforts to persuade the University of Rochester to extend its program to include a research institute for bankers and a school of policemen are being made by community groups here.

GAME wardens, who used to scout through brush and forest, are becoming a familiar feature on the motor roads in New York State gunning country in the open season on game birds, deer, rabbits and squirrels. Wardens have found that they can capture more game law violators on the highways than they can in the fields and woods.

Despite a tearful plea by his attorney and outside efforts to win him a suspended sentence, Frank J. Denniston, who rose from his timekeeper's job to the directorship of the United States Shipping Board here at $10,000 a year, was sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey to serve a year and a day in prison for income tax frauds.

"Books and Myself" will be discussed by Stark Young, Lin Yutang, Irwin Edman, Carl Carmer, Marjorie Hillis and others at the first of nearly thirty authors' programs to be given during the fifteen days of THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair at Rockefeller Center.

WHEN Jacques Deval returned to Paris after visiting New York just ten years ago he broke out in a rash of calumny. New York is a "mass of banality," he confided to the columns of Le Journal: "a city of abstinence and desolation.

WARRENTON, Va. -- The Middleburg Hunt will have its official opening meet next Saturday at 10 o'clock at Benton Farm, home of D. C. Sands, who is M. F. H. jointly with Miss Charlotte Noland. The Warrenton Hunt will open on Nov. 7.
On election day, Nov. 3, New York City voters will be called upon to answer this question:

The amateur detective who solves the mystery in this story is Stephen Ransome, a young playwright. We first meet him at a luncheon given in her Washington home by Mrs. Kirby, wife of a United States Senator. There Ransome meets most of the men and women who figure in the events related in the book.

The American Woman's Association, in conjunction with the Inter-Professional Association, has arranged four major programs dealing with the national elections during the next ten days, at the American Woman's Club, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street.

ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- The 90,000 acres of scenic country in Pisgah National Game Preserve, in North Carolina, will be open to a selected group of deer hunters on Wednesday, for the purpose of reducing the herd of 1,500 animals in this part of the Appalachians.

LONDON, Oct. 24 (Canadian Press). -- Portsmouth looms as the team to beat in the English Football League. Plugging steadily upward since the season opened, the Southerners went to the top of the First Division a week ago and consolidated their position today with a meritorious 3-1 victory over Derby County, one of the leading contenders for championship honors.

In continuance of their custom of giving the public annually a concrete picture of the rehabilitative work being accomplished in the State institutions of New Jersey, the child welfare department of the New Jersey League of Women Voters, in cooperation with the State Department of Institutions and Agencies, will hold an all-day symposium on "Correctional Treatment of Women Offenders" Thursday at the New Jersey Reformatory for Women at Clinton Farms.

TWO performances of "Tannhaeuser" will be presented by the Cleveland Orchestra, under Artur Rodzinski, with a cast headed by singers from the Metropolitan Friday and Saturday night in Cleveland. The personnel includes Marjorie Lawrence, as Elizabeth;

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Oct. 24. -- The new nursery school opened this Fall at Smith College has been named the Elizabeth Morrow Morgan Nursery School, the board of trustees announced today, in memory of Mrs. Elizabeth Morrow Morgan, daughter of the late Dwight W. Morrow.

Saul Singer, "unemployed and formerly a banker," of 33 Fifth Avenue, filed a plea in bankruptcy yesterday in Federal Court. His only assets, he reported, were upward of 50,000 shares of Bank of United States and Bankers Corporation stock of "no value" and life insurance, which is exempt from creditors' claims.
NAVALCARNERO, Spain, Oct. 24. -- I have just photographed the ruins of a church interior.

Just one hundred years ago, possibly to a day, all England was reading with breathless interest the account of a hearing in the magistrate's court at Ipswich, in Suffolk. It was in the rambling corridors of the Great White Horse Inn at Ipswich that Mr. Pickwick, having dined well, lost his way at night, strayed into the wrong room, and had his remarkable adventure with the middle-aged single lady in yellow curlpapers.

If the arts of Black Magic are now no longer practiced, Halloween, nevertheless, still weaves an eerie spell over children and it is the night above all nights for story-telling. For this season Miss Harper has compiled a goodly collection of tales and poems of magic, the only one of its kind, of which I know, devoted to this holiday, but its use will doubtless not be restricted to this season alone.

ANNE DOUGLAS SEDGWICK'S lasting fame as a novelist rests chiefly upon a quiet international sophistication, a percipience and detachment which found expression in extremely interesting stories, told in a charming literary style.

The late arrival of a passenger of the United States liner Washington at the ship's pier Wednesday noon precipitated a situation in the river that held watchers in suspense several minutes but ended without serious consequences.

The volume of bonds called for redemption before maturity last week continued on a reduced scale. Public-utility refundings featured the announcements, which also included several foreign calls and some for domestic industrial and institutional issues.

The Republican cry for the return of the relief problem to local administration ought to be viewed in the light of what happened when relief was not yet taken up by the Federal Government. Events in 1931 gave rise to the following excerpts from THE NEW YORK TIMES Index for that year:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 24. -- Dartmouth's modern but still heap bad Indians stole down from their New Hampshire reservation today, scalped Harvard for the third year in succession and tonight their tribesmen are painting the old town a literal as well as figurative green.

BOSTON, Oct. 23. IF Boston is any criterion, Leslie Howard's "Hamlet" will provide ample discussion for Manhattan. Even at his first performance Monday night in the Opera House there was abundant difference of opinion. Those who had seen John Gielgud in London or New York were not averse to voicing comparisons.

THE wife of Dr. George Crile, and the famous surgeon's secretary and assistant on a scientific expedition to Africa last Winter, Grace Crile has written a record of that experience which divides itself, according to the terms of her book's title, into two parts.
HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Oct. 24. -- Peddle School today lost its first game of the season to the powerful Hun School eleven of Princeton.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- Although badly pounded in the second half, Cornell's sophomores managed to thwart Penn State's thrusts and score a 13-to-7 victory before 5,500 fans on Schoellkopf Field today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24. -- As evidence of the division in the Republican ranks is the refusal of state chairmen to agree to have former President Hoover make speeches in their States. Immediately after the conference Mr. Hoover had with Governor Landon, when announcement was made that he would speak in the campaign, the National Committee received telegrams from many State chairmen saying that they did not desire to have him speak in their States.

RALEIGH, N.C., Oct. 24. -- North Carolina State defeated Virginia Polytechnic Institute today, 13 to 0. The Virginians, with only one first down and never in State territory, showed good defensive play to prevent more State touchdowns.

Mrs. James M. Shaw, executive vice president of the Travelers Aid Society, will give a luncheon on Thursday at the headquarters of the organization, 144 East Forty-fourth Street, as part of the renewal of the $125,000 annual budget campaign.

LONDON. -- The British Government shows no concern about rumors of an alleged promise by General Franco, the insurgent Spanish leader, to cede the Canary Islands to the Germans and the Balearic Islands to the Italians. Official circles in London are confident that he has no desire to give bits of Spanish territory to any foreign power.

A CAMPAIGN, according to Webster, is (1) A trip into the country; (2) A connected series of military operations; (3) A period of continuous furnace operations; (4) The grinding season of a crop of sugar cane; (5) An organized series of operations or a systematic effort to influence voters.

MADRID, Oct. 24 (AP). -- A quarter of a million persons were mobilized tonight for defense of this capital, prepared to fight to the death if necessary, as it became apparent the hour of a battle with the besieging enemy was not far distant.

THE Blue Mountain Reservation, a 1,700-acre tract set aside in 1927 by the Westchester County Park Commission for conservation purposes, will soon be open to the public and is likely to prove attractive to campers, equestrians, hikers and naturalists.

A crowd of 10,000 watched the powerful Boys High School gridiron machine roll on to its fourth straight victory this season and extend its winning streak to eleven in a row over a period of two campaigns by downing a borough rival, James Madison High, 13 -- 0, at Boys High Field in Brooklyn yesterday.

The engagement of $3,017,000 gold in England for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York by local commercial banks. Of this amount, $2,611,000 was taken on Friday too late to be reported that day.

MOSCOW, Oct. 24. -- Absolute secrecy was maintained today regarding the next steps, whatever they may be, to be taken by the Soviet Union following its declaration in London yesterday that it was no longer bound by the agreement not to intervene in Spain as long as other signatories were flouting it.
CARLISLE, Pa., Oct. 24. -- Dickinson College won its second game of the season today, crushing Swarthmore College, 55 -- 0, before a homecoming day crowd of more than 3,000.

Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Robertson 3d and James W. Brooks entertained at dinner last night in the Salon Bleu of the Montparnasse for Miss Honour Souther and Charles W. Brooks, who will be married on Nov. 7 in St. Luke's Church, Montclair, N.J. Other guests included Mr. and Mrs. John Nixon, Mr. and Mrs. Christopher Baldwin Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Robert Krementz, Mrs. Ashley F. Wilson Jr., Mrs. John Ely, the Misses Helen Jones.

The indictments obtained by Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor in New York County, against men allegedly involved in baking, trucking and restaurant rackets, have shown again the quiet and meticulous way in which he puts together his cases in the first concerted effort to rid Manhattan of this form of extortion.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- The National Democratic Committee in its report on campaign funds listed unpaid obligations totaling $581,307 and "borrowed money as of Oct. 21" totaling $59,376.
ASPIRANT TARZAN: He has tamed Tigers. He has fought Indians. He is not afraid of Giants. Why, therefore, should the creatures of any jungle, even a Hollywood jungle, have any terrors for Lou Gehrig?

While weather conditions proved a handicap, substantial gains over a year ago featured retail trade in the metropolitan area last week. Estimates indicated a gain of 8 to 9 per cent for department stores in the city, with the current trend of trade suggesting a rise of 10 per cent or more for the month as a whole.

AMERICA'S railroads are continuing to forge ahead, with gross operating revenues hitting new peaks, more men employed, and new passenger comforts provided, despite the general reduction in fares last June. Perhaps the greatest accomplishment of the railways in their battle to regain patronage has been the establishing of de luxe day coach service of almost parlor-car standards on all principal runs in the United States.

UNIVERSITY, Va., Oct. 24. -- Scoring two touchdowns in the second quarter, Washington and Lee won from Virginia today, 13 to 0. The first tally was made by Borries, who intercepted a pass and raced 25 yards. The second followed a long pass, Dunlap to Borries, which placed the ball on Virginia's 3-yard mark.

Although there is much of football in this book, and an account of a unique program of Winter sports, this is something more than just another story of prep-school sports. Mr. Arnold has drawn on his knowledge of several modern schools to write this story of an experimental school.

UNLIKE the Chinese, the Japanese theatre is alive, varied, well-organized and prosperous. I was not able to see as much of it as I should have liked to, partly because of the season and partly because of the brevity of my stay in Japan.

THE little town of Gibara, Cuba, on the northern coast of Oriente Province and 500 miles east of Havana, will celebrate on Wednesday the anniversary of the landing of Columbus there 444 years ago. Representatives of several American republics have accepted invitations to view the pageant to be given by the townspeople.

Sixteen weeks of continuous decline in the number of home-relief cases on the rolls of the Emergency Relief Bureau were recorded yesterday when the ERB made public its case-load figures for the six weeks from Aug. 28 to Oct. 9.
LAST week's survey of the Carnegie International at Pittsburgh did not include comment upon the American section, a few words concerning which may be appropriate now.

BRUENN, CZECHOSLOVAKIA. TI-IIS city enjoyed the unusual experience of a Dvorak world premiere on Oct. 4 when that master's first symphony (actually the first and not the first of the published ones) was performed here and broadcast by the Czechoslovak radio.

BETWEEN the years 1911 and 1927 John Hall Wheelock published six books of poetry. It was poetry which now needs no introduction, for the greater part of it has been acclaimed an accredited contribution to American letters. For nine years Mr. Wheelock has put out nothing in book form, although he has, we believe, been visible occasionally in the magazines.

DAINTY footwear is the perfect complement to hostess gown or negligee. It is not difficult to make feet alluring. Dressy sandals and mules are appearing in a galaxy of bright materials. There is something to suit every one of the costume moods that robes d'interieur are subject to this Winter.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- WPA members of the Workers Alliance of America, after marching about the White House today and picketing WPA headquarters, failed in an effort to lay before President Roosevelt demands for more liberal treatment.

BERLIN, Oct. 24 -- Prices on the Boerse weakened again today, but displayed some resistance toward the closing of the session of light trading. Heavy industrial stocks fell, showing for the important stocks an average drop of 1 1/2 to 2 points.

LONDON. ENGLAND'S newest and most elegant film studios, Pinewood, at Iver Heath, two and half miles from Denham, were officially opened by Leslie Burgin, Parliamentary Secretary to the Board of Trade, in the presence of twelve hundred guests, including such stars as Conrad Veldt and Roland Young, directors, extras, technicians, journalists and politicians.

The record of the New Deal has been a force moving contrary to the character-building efforts made on behalf of American youth, Dr. Alfred E. Stearns, former headmaster of Phillips Academy, Andover, Mass., said last night at the evening session of the Non-Partisan Christian Youth Conference.

Kenneth Hunter, in a letter to THE TIMES, attempts to refute mine of the previous Sunday in which I pointed out, citing names, dates, facts and figures, the most obvious mistakes in his former letter.

PHILADELPPHIA, Oct. 24. -- The New Deal leadership was assailed tonight by Bainbridge Colby, a Secretary of State under Woodrow Wilson, as "false to the Democratic party and traitorous to the country." He spoke under the auspices of the Independent Coalition of American Women and was introduced by Harry V. Dougherty, Registrar of Wills, an "old line" Democrat.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Oct. 24. -- Thirty per cent of the class of '36 at Bryn Mawr College is engaged in graduate study, according to a survey completed this week by the college's bureau of recommendations.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa. SAID Mafongozana one fine day, "Boss, can Maquet and I have the afternoon off? We want to go and twala a wife for Velechona," and thereby hangs the tale of a native romance in the Eastern Transvaal.
CALLENDER, Ont., Oct. 22. -- ''What is Ontario?"

Frightening statistics, such as the fact that 4,200 children of school age were killed in traffic accidents during 1935 and that each year twice as many boys and girls between the ages of 5 and 14 die from accidents as from diphtheria, heart disease and pneumonia, have stirred the women of this country into what is rapidly becoming concerted action.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- After a two-hour visit with President Roosevelt today Mayor S. Davis Wilson of Philadelphia issued a statement at the White House expressing cordial regard for him.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 24. -- Sabrina, embattled goddess of Amherst undergraduates, rests now in appropriate comfort and dignity, ending her colorful adventures. She is the center of attraction in the recently opened Hitchcock Memorabilia Room, the repository of Amherst's historical and traditional relics.
NEWTON, Mass., Oct. 24. -- Boston College, after a sluggish first half, rebounded on a hapless Providence College eleven before a 5,000 crowd today to win, 26 -- 0.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Oct. 24. -- The memory of "Chief Scout Citizen" Theodore Roosevelt, whose body lies on a hillock overlooking Oyster Bay, was revivified this afternoon in the minds of 5,000 Boy Scouts and many of the late President's companions of the river and woodland trails as they made the seventeenth annual pilgrimage to Youngs Memorial Cemetery.
Naval ships and stations in the metropolitan area and throughout the country, and patriotic and civic organizations are planning extensive programs on Tuesday to celebrate Navy Day.

FORT SIMPSON, N.W.T., Oct. 24 (Canadian Press). -- Howling of his dogs when he had lain for three days, severely burned and without food, on the shore of the Mackenzie River, eighty miles north of this post, 760 miles north of Edmonton, saved the life of Captain Don Naylor of the river vessel Distributor.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 24. -- After one amazing romp to a touchdown in five plays, St. Mary's of Texas found Western Maryland too well equipped with football weapons and lost an intersectional game today. The score was 32 to 12.

WHATEVER the final outcome of this Spanish war, Madrid -- which represents all side of Spain and typifies none -- will continue to be the center of the nation's dominant cause. Whether Madrid is seen through the showers of confetti that welcomed the Republic or through the war clouds that have been hanging over it these months, no other town on the peninsula is easily conceivable as the permanent capital of Spain.

ALTHOUGH major interest and space in the National Automobile Show, which opens here on Nov. 11, remains in the 1937 motor cars to be exhibited, the trailers, which will join the show for the first time this year, appear to be coming into a more and more conspicuous position.
Shall the three-platoon system for members and officers of the Fire Department of the City of New York be adopted?

The excitement centered around public-opinion polls has reached a new high in the current campaign. Dozens of polls, both local and national, are whetting the voter's political appetite. Millions of people are watching the tabulations. But the more results they see, the more confused are they likely to become.

HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Oct. 24 (AP). -- Detective Lieutenant Leslie J. Swann announced tonight the arrest of Charles Buffington Baldwin, 41-year-old scion of prominent Huntington families, on a warrant charging the murder of his mother, Mrs. Juliette Buffington Enslow, who was found beaten and strangled by her bed a week ago.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- The cornerstone of the new James C. Colgate Student Union building was laid this morning at Colgate University with students and faculty members gathering in Memorial Chapel for service and then marching down hill for the ceremonies.

OUT in Hollywood today a petite blonde whose blue eyes fairly radiate ambition, determination and a complete confidence in herself, is disproving the harsh axiom that "they never come back." She is Mary MacLaren, one of the screen's most glamorous stars of a little more than a decade ago.

A firm over-all limitation on the general property tax, established by constitutional provision, and accompanied by an equally effective debt limitation, to prevent evasion, will provide the most effective means to obtain a wider tax base, Herbert D. Simpson, director of the Institute of Public Finance, in Northwestern University, Illinois, told the Conference of Governmental Research Association at their recent meeting in Ann Arbor.

NEARLY three and a half years have passed by since the conflagration of books in Germany. Despite that the teachings of Spinoza, Heinrich Heine and Karl Marx have not been uprooted from the minds of people, or forgotten.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 24. -- Maritime unions prepared tonight what they said was a compromise proposal for peace on the waterfront, but the threat of a strike or tie-up still overhung Pacific Coast shipping.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- Rejecting "split bids" received on twenty-eight trucks for Rural Settlement Administration projects at Ithaca, Carthage and Woodstock, N.Y., the Procurement Division of the Treasury Department has called for new bids to be opened Nov. 2 on an "all or none" basis.
LOUISVILLE. Ky., Oct. 24. -- Profiting by "breaks," West Virginia University defeated a fighting but inexperienced Centre College team today. 26 -- 13.

IN January, 1931 an Oklahoma gas man had a bright idea which he forwarded to his friend, Patrick J. Hurley, then Secretary of War. This was to relieve the hunger of the destitute unemployed by furnishing them with scrap food from grocery stores, bakeries and restaurants.

THOSE who admired the earlier novels of Francis Stuart, "Pigeon Irish" and "The Colored Dome," with their eerie mingling of naturalness and passionate mysticism, and then were disappointed by Mr. Stuart's subsequent lapse into some very ordinary work, will rejoice in the fact that in "The White Hare" he not only recaptures much of his lost magic but also has gained in maturity.

The third of the Autumn field trial meetings for cocker and English springer spaniels in the Eastern section will be that of the Connecticut Spaniel Field Trial Association this week. Four stakes will be contested on Tuesday and Wednesday in the covers of the Ingham Hill Game Farm on the outskirts of Saybrook, Conn.

IT was the veteran American producer Daniel Frohman who pointed out that the great change which had come over the stage in his long lifetime of contact with it was the elimination of the actor from first place in the theatrical scheme of things.

PARIS, Oct. 10. FOR three months the Paris theatre has been virtually dead, and so has the social life of the capital. But, as it happens every year, Paris has awakened with an amazingly unanimous suddenness on Oct. 1.
ALAMEDA, Calif., Oct. 24. -- The China Clipper roared over the Golden Gate at 12:10 P.M. and settled down to a perfect landing here eight minutes later, after a 2,502-mile are from Honolulu.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- Smashing at the line with a powerful running attack, completing long forward passes and connecting on tricky laterals, Colgate's Red Raiders rebounded from the defeat of last week by downing Lafayette today, 41 -- 0.

That Lotte Lehmann's popularity remains at high-water mark in the community was manifested by the size and enthusiasm of the audience which was on hand at Town Hall last night for her first recital of the season. So heavy was the attendance that seats had to be placed on the stage to handle the overflow.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- Judge George A. Slater of Port Chester, who seeks re-election on the Republican ticket as Surrogate of Westchester County so he may serve out the one year before his age will compel his retirement, was the object last week of a series of attacks by Democratic speakers at political meetings.

AMORAL tale if ever there was one, Miss Parrish's new story revamps the old legend of King Midas and his golden touch. It demonstrates, cannily if obviously, how tragic it may be to attain one's complete desire. Dan Briggs, who was born poor, wanted wealth and got it in abundance.

A three-day auction realizing $85,258.50 for art objects and furnishings from the former home of Mrs. Peter W. Rouss at 320 Garfield Place, Brooklyn, ended yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc.

The League of Nations proposes bombproof shelters for works of art. Excellent! We know, too, that the League's ideal is to bombproof certain principles of free society, however ineffective it has been at times.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- Society from all parts of the metropolitan district attended the annual Tuxedo Autumn ball held tonight in the club. The first of these events was held fifty years ago and except for two years during the war have been continued ever since.

The thought uppermost in the minds of people interested in the stock market is what effect the outcome of the election will have on prices of shares. Will the market continue its upward trend after a nineteen-month rise? Will the usual reaction from news discounted set in?

William F. Bleakley, the Republican candidate for Governor, has completed a vigorous up-State swing of nearly three weeks, in which he showed himself a versatile campaigner, capable of creating unusual enthusiasm among the county and city leaders of his party.

BUFFALO, Oct. 24. -- Governor Herbert H. Lehman is a Ponce de Leon in his campaign for re-election this year. But unlike the Spaniard he has found his "fountain of youth" and is now a militant orator, hitting out directly at his opponents.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 24. -- Established less than a year ago, with the aid of contributions from alumni and friends, the Nautical Association at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology now has a firm foothold and this past week regular classes in navigation and allied subjects began for students interested in sailing.

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- With a Halloween motif, the "annual outbreaking," just the opposite of a housewarming, marked the closing of Hancock Wren, the Rogers estate here tonight, by its fifteen "bachelor bankers," who are moving to New York, where they are taking the Herbert Bell house for the coming season.

AS 1937 models begin to come off assembly lines in greatly increased volume, car manufacturers are kept busy with the final round of dealer meetings prior to the November shows. Previews, which began several weeks ago, have continued up through the past week.

METHODS of communication play an important ro1e in the Boy Scouts' test-passing program, which is now in full Autumn swing. Before a tenderfoot may rank as second class he must have an elementary acquaintance with the semaphore code, the international Morse code, the Indian sign language or the manual alphabet for the deaf.

DETROIT, Oct. 24 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin asserted tonight that "America is preparing to extend money or credit as she did before to England and France for the conduct of impending bloodshed."

LONDON, Oct. 21. -- Next Monday the suburban Kew Theatre will play host to John Klein's "Charlotte Corday," with Beatrix Lehmann in the title role and Edward Chapman as Marat. (There are a couple of other Corday plays, one being Helen Jerome's, announced by Gilbert Miller.)

President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman will carry New York State by the largest majorities of any candidates in the history of the State, United States Senator Robert Wagner said last night at a dinner of election district captains and workers at the St. Moritz Hotel.
RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 24. -- V.M.I. triumphed over the University of Richmond, 20 to 0, before a Homecoming Day crowd of 10,000 today.

PROOF of Rome's intent to stimulate art life on the Italian Riviera is seen in its official patronage of an enterprise of the local casino, the so-called "Premi San Remo." The "Premi San Remo" are four prizes of 50,000 lire ($4,000) each, awarded to the winner of a national contest in music, painting, sculpture and literature, respectively.

SAN FRANCISCO'S Embarcadero is no longer the picturesque spot it used to be. Jack London and Frank Norris would not know quite what to do with it today. The three-fingered Jacks and the rolling drunken sailors from all the seven seas are gone. And, taking their places are muscular young Americans who wear union buttons and swear by Harry Bridges or Harry Lundeberg, leaders of maritime unions.

The art of electioneering remains much the same as ever, despite all its boasted modern improvements. We have just had the announcement by the national committees of both parties that they mean to keep up this fight until the very end. The evening and night of Nov. 2 will be filled with tumultuous last-minute appeals to the electorate.

AFTER a seventeen-year residence at 680 Fifth Avenue, the Kraushaar Gallery has moved up to the Heckscher Building, where, in attractive quarters on the second floor, it reopened for the season last Tuesday. Them rooms, at once spacious and intimate, are very well equipped for exhibition purposes.

WHEN William March published "Company K" a few years ago, the limited but enthusiastic group of readers that this war novel reached had good reason to suppose they had discovered a writer of considerable talent.

The significance of the title of this story becomes apparent when one learns that the dead body of a high school teacher is found with an ancient coin in his mouth to pay his fare across the Styx. Another corpse, that of a beautiful woman, has been found a bit earlier in the day, but in her case there was no coin.

Ruth Slenczynski, 11-year-old concert pianist, who made her debut at Town Hall here three years ago, arrived yesterday on the President Roosevelt of the United States Lines, accompanied by her father, Josef Slenczynski, to make a concert tour that will take her to the Pacific Coast and back.

A heroic truck driver permitted himself to be used as a cushion yesterday to break the fall of a woman whom he saw hanging from the ledge of a second floor window in Jersey City. The woman, Mrs. Annastasia Andiuszkiewcz of 234 Fourteenth Street, Jersey City, was slightly bruised.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24. -- Retail sales in local department and specialty stores showed virtually no gain over the previous week, but volume was still between 5 and 8 per cent ahead of last year. Home furnishings supplied most of the activity, and men's and women's apparel was still unseasonably behind, influenced by continued warm weather.

ALAMEDA, Calif., Oct. 24 -- The China Clipper, with eight passengers and a small cargo of mail and express, alighted this afternoon on San Francisco Bay, after a 21 hour 31 minute flight from Honolulu. It had flown 16,400 miles to Manila and back.

Charges of large-scale registration frauds were intensified yesterday when John R. Crews, Republican leader of Kings County, sent to the office of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. reports from his district leaders that unprecedentedly extensive false registration has been discovered.

One of the most striking features of the current election campaign has been the record registration figures established in New York and other large cities, partly as the result of an outpouring of men and women whose faces had seldom if ever been seen at polling places before.

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 24. -- Bronislaw Huberman, violinist and founder of the Palestine Symphony Orchestra, who was soloist last evening with the Concertgebouw Orchestra under Bruno Walter, told THE TIMES he had just conferred with Arturo Toscanini on arrangements for the opening concert of the Palestine Symphony, which Mr. Toscanini will conduct.

Judging from the large subscription already received for the opening performance of the Ballet Russe next Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Church Mission of Help, the funds for furthering the many charitable enterprises of that organization will be augmented greatly.

A GROUP of Europe's leading radio officials will be in the United States in November to study American broadcasting methods, according to an announcement from the International Broadcasting Union, the headquarters of which are at Geneva, Switzerland.

ALBANY, Oct. 24. -- William F. Bleakley, Republican candidate for Governor, tonight turned his attack upon the fiscal management of the State in capital expenditures. He asserted that millions of dollars had been spent for improvements without adequate planning or supervision and with records so scattered and poor that a check was next to impossible.

ALMOST every one knows a publisher, or some one in a publishing office, or an author or an author's friend, yet it is surprising how little people know about the publishing business and how many odd things they imagine.

POTTSTOWN, Pa., Oct. 24. -- In a one-sided contest the fast Hill School eleven defeated the Yale freshman seconds, 32 -- 6, on Dell Field today. Bernhardy, Hill fullback, accounted for two touchdowns.

Moscow. THE MOSCOW musical season is rich with promise. In the realm of opera much of interest is announced, and a State symphony orchestra of 140 pieces and a State choir, both newly formed, are to begin their activities.

A Long Island City restaurant popular with Queens judges, court workers and political leaders was robbed of $700 yesterday by three men, one of whom had persuaded the proprietor a week ago to keep extra money on hand on Saturdays to cash PWA workers' checks.

T HE recently completed clearing of the long-neglected Mall between the Capitol 'and the Vv'a.l'ngton Monument has at last brought to realization one more of the dreams for the city ou Washington which were projected more than a century ago by Major Pierre C. L'i.nfant.

GRAND COULEE, Oct. 23. -- Political weathervanes in the Pacific Northwest point to a fairly safe majority for Senator William E. Borah over C. Ben Ross when they clash at the polls Nov. 3 in one of the most spectacular election contests in Idaho's history.

With little more than a week remaining before the end of the campaign, it must be said that there is one important question on which the public is as much in the dark as it was when the speech-making started. That question is what specific action will be taken, by whichever party wins the election, to bring the national budget into balance.

It seems a pity that you felt it advisable to join in the anvil chorus which greeted "And Stars Remain." Several of my subscriber friends, members of the Theatre Guild family, liked the play immensely. We are not "blind followers'' of that banner, do plenty of hammer throwing when we are displeased with Guild productions, but in this case, felt that here was an amusing, witty, clever bit of playwriting.

ARMISTICE Day, Nov. 11, again will be the occasion for pilgrimages to patriotic shrines and services at the tombs of unknown soldiers. As in other years, two minutes of silence will be observed at 11 o'clock, the hour at which hostilities ceased eighteen years ago.

After months of conjecture and rumors, Clio of New York will achieve the distinction of being the first organization of women to discover what actually is in prospect for the feminine phases of the World's Fair of 1939, when the subject comes up for discussion at its opening meeting of the season tomorrow. The session will be held at the Hotel Astor.

LONDON, Oct. 24. -- The British Government has offered to place at the disposal of the Spanish neutrality committee for investigation evidence covering four cases of infraction of the non-intervention agreement, three involving Soviet Russia and one Italy, it was disclosed today.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 23. -- With the outcome in this region certain, and with conviction growing that the country will go this time as the South goes, many Southerners are less concerned with the election next month than with the national political attention given to the Negro.

WE have so far had from Mr. Spender a book of poems -- interesting for its poetry and significant for its direction -- and a very provocative book of criticism. Now, before we can observe his further development either as poet or critic, he has emerged as a writer of stories.
INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 24. -- Following is the text of Governor Landon's speech delivered at the State Fair Grounds hero tonight:

THERE may be a shortage of trained personnel, especially on the mechanical side, in the air transportation industry within six months. Colonel Edgar S. Gorrell, president of the Air Transport Association of America, pointed out this situation last week.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 24. -- Fourteen pairs that qualified last night and this afternoon for the finals in the semi-annual Long Island contract bridge tournament were playing at a late hour tonight at the Garden City Hotel with a prospect that the matches would not end until 1 or 2 A.M.

WITH REBEL TROOPS NEAR ILLESCAS, Spain, Oct. 24. -- Insurgent cavalry and tanks under General Jose Varela pushed the right end of their lines on the Madrid front eleven miles eastward today to end the week with an almost unbroken semicircle closing in the capital from the west and southwest.

HOWEVER mixed may be the feelings stirred by Columbia's album of Gluck's "Orpheus," when finally weighed the balance is distinctly favorable. This second addition to the long-neglected operatic series -- No. 15 -- resembles its immediate predecessor of a few months back, Charpentier's "Louise," in the manner in which it has been handled if not in its material.

MILLVILLE, N.J., Oct. 24. -- Before an audience of more than 2,500 from all parts of South Jersey the Old-Age Pension Colony at Roosevelt Park, South Millville, was dedicated this afternoon. George R. Swinton of Atlantic City, district WPA director, presided.

HOLLYWOOD THERE are strange industries within the movies but of them all probably none is more interesting than that of Joe Wilharber, purveyor of the shells of dreams. There are more bizarre businesses, for all Wilharber does is rent automobiles; the fantastic aspects of his trade center about the acquisition of his stock and its source.

ONE of the events of the coming art season will be the big Surrealist exhibition promised by the Museum of Modern Art. Meanwhile, as Miss Harris reported some weeks ago in these columns, London has been having a surrealist Summer.

The team-of-four championship of the second annual metropolitan contract bridge tournament of the American Bridge League was won last night at the Park Central Hotel by Phil Abramsohn, Jules Tilles, H.J. Fishbein and Morrie Elis with Benedict Jarmel as alternate.

If brains were the sole criterion for entrance to college, our army of undergraduates would be 60 per cent larger than it is today. Such at least is the conclusion to be drawn from a survey of 23,000 typical young people made for the American Youth Commission in Pennsylvania.

An "electrical recording" of Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg's speech of Oct. 17 at Chicago, which was terminated over part of the WABC system before the Senator finished because it included recorded remarks by President Roosevelt, is scheduled to be carried in full today over WMCA and WOR, according to announcements yesterday by both stations.

Many a place where the stereo-typed "rock garden" does not exactly fit into the scheme of things may be made more attractive by a low rock wall. Such a wall may be used against a bank where a low terrace already exists, or may readily be made.

The promotions of sixty-nine cadet officers of the New York University Unit of the Reserve Officers' Training Corps have been announced by Colonel Fred V.S. Chamberlain, Commanding Officer. Thirty-four cadets were made First Lieutenants and thirty-five were designated Second Lieutenants.

BRUSSELS, Oct. 24. -- Brussels is heavily guarded to prevent the Rexists' threatened demonstration against the government tomorrow. Leon Degrelle, leader of the Fascist group, called off the demonstration late today, but his followers are expected to join the war veterans' parade before King Leopold tomorrow morning.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 24. -- New Ashford is having a public telephone installed for the first time in its history. For years it has been the only town in Western Massachusetts and probably in the State that has had no direct telephone connection with the outside world.

TORONTO, Oct. 24. -- In the first nine months of this year Ontario's gold mines produced bullion valued at $59,284,978, compared with $54,476,043 in the corresponding period of 1935, according to the gold bulletin for September issued last night by the Ontario Department of Mines.
Prices of commodity futures lacked trend here in the week ended on Friday, with coffee, wool tops, silk and copper firm, while cottonseed oil, sugar and cocoa became easier.
THE Hudson Motor Car Company yesterday announced the introduction of the Hudson and Terraplane models for 1937. They went on display at the local distributors' showrooms.

To present a picture to consumers of the "true social and economic value of chain stores" the Institute of Distribution yesterday announced publication of its "Chain Store Manual." The manual, written by John P. Nichols, assistant managing director of the institute, traces the growth of the chains, their status in the current distribution picture, and deals exhaustively with the legislative and the major charges brought against the chains.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 24. -- The following is the text of former Governor Smith's speech here tonight:

IT is as desirable to look well at home as it is abroad. Every woman ought to shed the garb of her outside activities when she enters the privacy of her own domain, whether it be a house on the Avenue or a dinette flat. To slip into a gracious gown is to relax the mental tension of the day.

In THE TIMES of Oct. 16 and 18 you reproduce a portrait of Abraham Lincoln the negative of which was recently broken in the mails. On the second date the picture is captioned "A Forgotten Portrait," although it is probably the best known and most widely used of all Lincoln portraits.

How many times has it been said that the tempo and strain of modern life are shortening our days? Old as the story is, Dr. R.C. BUERKI retold it and adorned it anew in a public address delivered under the auspices of the American College of Surgeons.
