He would have us slacken our pace, spare our nerves, avoid the worries that beset us.

The Heywood-Wakefield Company reported yesterday for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 a profit of $472,796 after charges but before provision for Federal income taxes or Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. In the first nine months of 1935 there was a net loss of $58,981.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 24. -- The Milky Way Farm's Talma Dee, an 19-to-1 shot, captured the Selima Stakes, rich and important mile event for 2-year-old fillies, at Laurel today by a length over the King Ranch's Dawn Play.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- The German Government's decree prohibiting barter agreements has virtually ended all exports of American tobacco to that country, Department of Commerce reported today. The relatively small shipments now reaching the German market are being taken under existing contracts, it was said.

Hurled in the desperation of a last-period rally, a forward pass, Bernard Bloom to Harry Shorten, ruined Georgetown's undefeated, untied and unscored upon record in a fiercely fought battle with New York University yesterday on the turf of the Yankee Stadium.

By way of winding up with a flourish a Presidential campaign in which it has set a proud precedent in service to its party, the Women's National Republican Club will present a notable group of speakers at its seventeenth and final weekly tea on Friday.

The drive to unionize 500,000 steel workers, which has been carried on actively for the last four months by the Committee for Industrial Organization headed by John L. Lewis, has thus far been a "complete failure," executives of leading steel companies said here yesterday.

ORONO, Me., Oct. 24. -- The Maine eleven, by holding an early lead, defeated Bates today, 21 -- 19, Proctor's first period placement goal from the field giving the winning margin. The Bears completed twenty-three of thirty-nine passes for 271 yards and rushed for 148.

This story of an English master-criminal has a situation and a chief character of the sort that Edgar Wallace made especially famous, but the tale is not told with anything like Wallace's skill. A mysterious unknown occupies himself with engineering the escape of jailed criminals, for purposes as secret as his identity.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 24. -- Fielding Simmons's 6-yard plunge for a touchdown in the first six minutes of play enabled Williams to beat Tufts by 6 -- 0 before 3,000 spectators today.

EVEN though the Parisian dealer is not yet open for his Autumn season of exhibitions there are pictures in every window on both sides of the Seine. In about fifty, not as many artists are represented. Apparently a certain convention is in control.

Mingling might and magic in bewildering fashion, an alert and aggressive University of Detroit eleven sank Manhattan under a barrage of forward passes to score a 20-to-0 triumph before 12,000 spectators at Ebbets Field yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24. -- Galloping across Brown's goal line seven times, Pennsylvania's football juggernaut, stimulated by the tonic provided by the Princeton triumph last week, trounced the visiting eleven today, 48 to 6.
The Princeton freshman football team defeated the Columbia yearlings, 15 -- 0, yesterday at Baker Field.

INDIANA PARK, Pa., Oct. 24 (AP). -- Senator Guffey said in a campaign speech here tonight that one of his first acts in the next Congress would be the introduction of a new bill to regulate the bituminous coal industry. This, he said, was certain to have the "sympathy and support of President Roosevelt."

SINCE Ellen Glasgow dared peer behind the brocade in Virginia, Southern novelists have become increasingly forthright in treating of life under mimosa and moonlight. Some of them have poured out rather stiff doses of literary corn.

THE Greeks unquestionably had a word for it, but Wesley Ruggles's phrase better suits our immediate need than anything we might cull from Sophocles or Aristophanes. "The Keystone finish" is what Mr. Ruggles calls it, and he speaks out of a 22-year knowledge of picture-making.

GENEVA, Oct. 24. -- Six conventions, designed to improve the working conditions of merchant marine officers and seamen, were adopted today at the closing session of the International Maritime Commission, meeting here under the auspices of the International Labor Organization.

CRAFTSMEN'S tools and farming implements which have survived from the past often suggest the everyday character of an old-time village or farmstead more intimately than the examples of fine furniture taken from a "best room" used only on state occasions.

The Erasmus Hall High School football team remained unbeaten by scoring a 26 to 0 victory over the Brooklyn College junior varsity at Erasmus Field in Brooklyn yesterday. This was the third triumph for Erasmus in four starts, the remaining game having been a tie.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24. -- The Republican National Committee asserted today the United States was thirteenth among the nations in restoring normal conditions. The twelve which lead this country, the committee said, are free of "government spending and waste which has characterized New Deal efforts."

THE tourist trade has always been of the greatest importance in Italian economy, because it represents a large part of those "invisible exports" (tourists' spending, earnings of the mercantile marine and emigrants' remittances) that make good the deficit in Italy's balance of international payments.

The application by the railroads to the Interstate Commerce Commission for freight tariff increases to offset the expiration of the emergency freight surcharges on Dec. 31 comes at a time when they contend they require funds to buy equipment for increased traffic.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- Replying to a question raised by Presi dent Roosevelt, Dr. Andrey A. Potter, president of the American Engineering Council, said today that engineering educators "are fully appreciative of the responsibility of the engineer."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- Prior to the march of the Alliance delegation on the White House, David Lasser, president of the Alliance, told a meeting of local units that the WPA administration was guilty of the "worst of bad faith" in failing to keep promises to recognize the Alliance for collective bargaining by WPA workers.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 24. -- Dr. Karl T. Compton, president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, replying today to President Roosevelt's recent appeal to train responsible engineers, expressed in an open letter to the President the apprehension of engineers and scientists that "the attention and money devoted to relief" might interfere with the support of science.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24. -- Villanova remained in the undefeated ranks today by piling up a 25-7 score against Boston University at Shibe Park before 12,000 homecoming fans. The Boston Terriers were unscored on before coming here.

Bowery scenes of the early Nineties will be reproduced by the "gray-jackets" of the Seventh Regiment as settings for their annual Fall Military Ball, which will take place on Dec. 5 in the regiment's armory at Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

TINGED by the flame of Autumn, the hills and mountains within a radius of a hundred miles of New York lure sturdy hikers from the city. Within an arc of the circle a network of trails spreads over Palisades Interstate Park, the hills of New Jersey, the Poconos, the Catskills, the Berkshires and the Litchfield Hills of Connecticut.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 24. -- Holy Cross had a close call keeping its season's slate clean of defeat or tie today. The powerful Crusader aggregation after being outplayed at almost every turn by a grim, hard-fighting Cargenie Tech eleven took advantage of a break in the final quarter to gain a touchdown and register a 7-to-0 triumph over the Pittsburgh clan.

PARIS, Oct. 24. -- The Radical Socialist congress at Biarritz agreed unanimously tonight upon a resolution supporting the government of Premier Leon Blum. Thus a threatened political crisis has been averted and Mr. Blum has been assured of the loyal aid of France's great central party.

APROPOS of a recent article by Carl Zigrosser, in which the desirability of having large editions of prints at low prices instead of small editions at prices few feel they can afford, Robert Reynolds of Newtown, Conn., writes us:

ON the night of Dec. 31 last Edna Ferber dined with the George S. Kaufmans at their Ninety-fourth Street home. After the coffee Mrs. Kaufman remarked that she was going out with a party of friends to celebrate.

Trophies and cash prizes will be presented tonight after the last series of contests of the eleventh annual world's championship rodeo in Madison Square Garden. There are close races between contestants in the various events and the final winners of the $35,000 in prizes will not be decided until the last ride is made and the last calf is roped.

Mayor La Guardia and members of his administration will lecture in a course in municipal government to be conducted by the Trade Union Institute of the Rand School, 7 East Fifteenth Street, on Saturday afternoons, beginning Nov. 7. The new city yearbook, "New York Advancing," will be the textbook.

Reports on general business conditions last week in all of the Federal Reserve districts were optimistic in tone. Although the absence of seasonable temperatures continued to retard retail trade activity in some sections, particularly in the East, in others where cooler weather created a stronger demand for heavy apparel, there was a steady advance in sales activity.

LONDON, Oct. 9, THE appearance on successive nights this week of Wycherley's "Country Wife" and Vanbrugh's "Provoked Wife" is an odd coincidence, nothing more. It is not likely to begin a vogue. There is no great liking in London for Restoration comedy.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Oct. 24. -- The six societies at Wellesley College initiated 139 new members tonight with the traditional pomp and ceremony. Chosen from among the .two upper classes, they were pledged Wednesday morning when old members sought them out on the campus and pinned a rose on each.
Manhattan College's cross-country team opened its season with a victory over Penn State by 26 to 29 at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

Frank Malcolm Farmer, vice president and chief engineer of the Electrical Testing Laboratories, New York, has been elected chairman of the Engineering Foundation, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street, research organization of the national engineering societies, it was announced yesterday.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Oct. 24. -- Fifty-two seniors at Mount Holyoke College have registered for honor work, it was announced today by the office of the registrar. Carrying on independent work free of a large share of class routine and recitations, these students will be eligible next June for the degree with honor.

The current upswing in business if continued through 1937 at the present accelerated rate, will make a sharper dent in unemployment than at any time since the beginning of 1933, according to opinions expressed here yesterday by authorities on labor problems.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Oct. 24 (AP). -- Coupling savage ground and aerial thrusts with breaks of the game, the University of Southern California's Trojans continued pounding toward an undefeated football record today with a 14-to-7 victory over Stanford's Indians.

ONE of the important functions of a botanical garden is to secure from little explored or otherwise particularly interesting portions of the earth, new plants for botanical study and in addition, where possible and convenient, new species to enrich private and public gardens.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24. -- Continued easiness in Liverpool affected North American wheat markets early today, but there was no material pressure on the Board of Trade here and a rally followed an opening dip. The close was at about the best prices of the day, with net gains of 5/8 to 1/2 cent.
A few observations gleaned while prowling through the aisles of a leading sporting goods store:

COLD weather visited some sections of the country last week and the effect upon retail trade was immediate. Sales mounted briskly, jumping 20 per cent or better over a year ago. Other areas still suffered from unseasonally high temperatures with the result that apparel volume continued to lag.

COLUMBUS. Ga., Oct. 24 (AP). -- Some magic wrought in the Georgia dressing room at half time turned Auburn's football picnic into a nightmare today and the game's end found the rumpled Tigers glad to accept the 20-13 victory that kept their record clean.

The Board of Education is considering the establishment of free "alertness" courses for teachers and supervisors who must have certain in-service training to qualify for salary increments and promotion.
NASHVILLE. Tenn., Oct. 24 (AP). -- Vanderbilt University and Georgia Tech battled to a scoreless tie today before 10,000 fans, the superb line play annulling the offensive fireworks of both teams.

Governor Landon, at Barstow, Calif., asserted that "it [the CCC] is threatening to lead the several hundred thousand young Americans comprising the corps down a blind alley." He also said that the CCC could be made "far more effective" by adoption of an educational program.

READERS of the Coles' 1935 mystery novel, "Dr. Tancred Begins," will remember the Pendexter family, as well as the clever and likable private detective, Benjamin Tancred. This new story is a continuation -- or rather the conclusion -- of what the title-page calls the "Pendexter Saga," and it runs finally to earth the criminal who escaped the clutches of the law in the earlier book.

MANHASSET, L.I., Oct. 24. -- Three hundred persons, prelates of the Catholic Church and men and women prominent in Long Island and New York society, attended a reception in honor of Eugenio Cardinal Pacelli, Papal Secretary of State, at the home of Mrs. Nicholas F. Brady here from 5 to 8 o'clock this evening.

MONROVIA, Liberia, Oct. 24 (AP). -- One of the most cruel wars ever fought in Africa seemed near an end today. Government militia, it was announced officially, had captured King Nimley, Kroo leader, who for four years had defied the Negro republic.

MANY city people may have wondered during recent years why the Federal Government has been at tempting, with so much determination, and in so many ways, to improve the lot of the farmers of the nation.

THE liquor question, overshadowed since repeal by more pressing national problems is by no means a dead issue. Encouraged by the growing resentment against drunken driving, drys all over the country have launched a new crusade for the reclamation of wet territory by local-option vote.

STAMPS are now being issued by many countries to provide funds for charities and welfare organizations. The designs of these semi-postal issues are attractive; the amounts realized from their sale are usually substantial.

BERLIN, Oct. 24. -- The central engineering offices of the Reich Railways, whose special pride are the Diesel high-speed cars of the Flying Hamburger and Flying Cologner, seem to be willing to recognize that the American train, the Denver Zephyr, is faster.
RADIO listeners are warned that the air this week will be saturated with politics. President Roosevelt is scheduled for two broadcasts and Governor Landon for four, between now and next Sunday.

MUNICH, Germany, Oct. 24. -- Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Italian Foreign Minister, was received with full National Socialist honors when he arrived in the "capital of the movement" from Berchtesgaden this afternoon.

SOME 2,000,000 trappers in the United States are getting their traps ready for a season expected to yield them a catch of fur-bearing animals worth between $60,000,000 and $70,000,000. But trapping is not an activity confined to commercial market trappers in wilderness areas.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Two touchdown passes by Captain Ray (Buzz) Buivid gave Marquette University a 13-to-7 victory over Michigan State today and strengthened the Hilltoppers' bid for national football honors.

In the dullest trading for any Saturday since Sept. 12, stocks moved slightly higher yesterday, ending a week in which the market as a whole moved in a horizontal line with steadily contracting turnover. Foreign exchanges were quiet. The bond market was firm in the smallest trading since Aug. 29.

Three schools retained their titles while two new champions were crowned in the annual P.S.A.L. borough cross-country runs at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. Manual Training, Curtis and DeWitt Clinton repeated their triumphs of last year in the Brooklyn, Richmond and Bronx runs respectively, while Newtown replaced John Adams as Queens titleholder and Stuyvesant dethroned Textile as the Manhattan champion.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Oct. 24. -- With the approach of Summer here, prosperity through housing is the latest cry of the New Zealand Socialist Government, which, in its great long-range scheme, promises that every worker shall own a home.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 24. -- Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Thornton Baker Jr., of Princeton gave a large tea dance and reception yesterday afternoon at their home, after the Princeton-Navy football game, to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Mary Baker.

WIRELESS OVER THIRTY YEARS" is the title of an interesting book by R.N. Vyvyan, veteran Marconi engineer. Obviously it is a good-sized book, for three decades is a long time. But in such a fast moving science as radio it seems a short span, especially in the eyes of those veterans who now look back to when they started to play the wireless "game" of dots and dashes.
Katherine Bacon, English pianist, who has not appeared here for four years and who is well remembered for her excellent Schubert and Beethoven recitals, appeared yesterday afternoon at the Town Hall.

The opening dinner and entertainment in the new Crystal Garden of the Ritz-Carlton on Thursday night has been arranged as a benefit for the Bellevue Hospital Social Service. The garden is a transformation of the room known for years as the Crystal Room.

WITH plenty of election districts missing, Clerk of the Polls Dan Ferris has announced that Glen Morris, Olympic decathlon champion, is holding a slight lead over James Cleveland Owens, called Jesse, in the balloting for award of the James E. Sullivan Trophy for 1936.

ANDOVER, Mass., Oct. 24. -- A 70-yard touchdown drive in the third period enabled Andover Academy to keep its unbeaten, untied and unscored-on record clean with a 6-0 victory over Harvard freshmen today.

SHIPYARDS along New York waters are in the midst of the busiest hauling-out Autumn they have had for several years. The Summer's sudden increase in yachting results now in the job-making business of placing in Winter quarters ashore the pleasure boats that are not sailing South.

The little town of Tuckerton Corners, which may be in something of a coma a good part of the time, has been having plenty of excitement these last few pre-election weeks. Only Tuesday a famous heavyweight prizefighter, once world champion, was out on Main Street a-shakin' hands with the boys and giving out free autographs to the women-folk and toy balloons to the kids.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Oct. 24. -- One of the greatest scholastic upsets in years came today when Bloomfield High School's Bengals were held to a 6-6 deadlock by a fighting and courageous Dickinson High School eleven of Jersey City.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 24 (AP). -- The Bruins of the University of California at Los Angeles, aided by the line-smashing, place-kicking ability of Fullback Billy Bob Williams, chalked up a Coast Conference football victory today over Oregon State, 22 to 13.

Fifteen college presidents, four directors, sixteen deans and 200 other educators will assemble at New York University on Wednesday for the annual meeting of the Association of Colleges and Universities of the State of New York, Dean Milton E. Loomis of New York University's Washington Square College, announced yesterday.

PRIOR to the large one-man show that opened last week at the Museum of Modern Art, many of us were convinced that John Marin is a great creative artist. This admirably assembled retrospective directed by Alfred Stieglitz is certain to prove a means of bringing to the same decision a much larger public.

ELECTION bulletins will be flashed world-wide on Nov. 3, for both short-wave stations, W2XAD and W2XAF, Schenectady, will operate throughout the day from 8 o'clock in the morning until 12 o'clock midnight, at which time, according to the broadcasters, "it is expected there will be no question as to who is elected President."

A GREAT international airport, serving transoceanic airlines whose planes fly the flags of half a dozen nations, but under the direct control and supervision of the United States Government, was envisioned here in an informal interview last week by Major General Hugh A. Drum, commanding the Hawaiian Department of the United States Army.

Celebrities of the music world will participate on Friday in the initial observance of a "Federation Day" program by the New York Federation of Music Clubs at the Hotel Astor. Mrs. John Alexander Jardine, president of the National Federation of Music Clubs, will be a guest of honor at the noon luncheon, as will two State past-presidents, Mrs. Edna Marione-Springer and Mrs. Etta Hamilton Morris.

WHEN a pious man of the cloth stoops to folly it may mean nothing more serious than a clerical error. Sometimes he is betrayed by his very innocence, and the most unworldly of men may be made to appear worldly because of his lack of secular wisdom.

ON that May morning in 1826 when the Commerce steamed up the Hudson, carrying on its elegant new safety barge the United States Commissioner of Indian Affairs, there was probably no happier boy in the United States than 14-year-old Matthew Steele.

The third of the Museum of Modern Art Film Library's series of films will be released on Jan. 1, it was announced yesterday by John E. Abbott, director of the library. Last year the library issued two series of American films. The new series is composed of French and German films and, like its predecessors, will be circulated among museums, colleges and film study groups.

The battle lines are being drawn steadily in the conflict between the power companies and Federal and other regulatory authorities over a new system of accounting promulgated by the Federal Power Commission to become effective on Jan. 1 next.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 24. -- Princeton's football fortunes boomed again today. With 51,000 packing Palmer Stadium, the Tiger hit the comeback trail after defeat by Penn a week ago and smashed through to a 7-to-0 triumph against Navy.

In the fifty-seventh year book of the United Hospital Fund, which will be issued tomorrow, David McAlpin Pyle, its president, points out that New York has the largest hospital system of any city in the world.

THE Jooss Ballet assuredly presents an example of how excellent an ensemble can be when, on the one hand, it is composed of talented dancers under good direction and, on the other hand, it has a suitable atmosphere in which to pursue its labors.

LONDON, Oct. 23. -- These are not good days for either communism or fascism in Europe. The two movements are so much under a cloud, so much in the doldrums, that the ancient creeds of liberalism and toleration might opportunely do a little propaganda work with some success on behalf of their own well tried virtues.
LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Oct. 24. -- Pearson's substantial gains around the ends paved the way for the Lawrenceville eleven's 13-0 victory over Franklin and Marshall Academy today.

A pioneering experiment in adult education that will see 100 advanced students housed in the same building that contains facilities for their highly specialized studies has just come into being at the University of Minnesota.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 24. -- Threats to Mrs. Thomas Middleton of West Atlantic City, N.J., aunt of the Countess Barbara Haugwitz-Reventlow, the former Barbara Hutton, that her home would be blown up unless she paid $3,000 to an extortionist were disclosed today with the arrest of an ex-convict as the principal figure in the plot.
The Theodore Roosevelt High School eleven of the Bronx remained undefeated in three contests by vanquishing James Monroe, 18 -- 7, before 3,000 spectators at Monroe Feld yesterday.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 24. -- The Douglass scholarship of $750, which will be awarded to a freshman entering the college next Fall, is one of five new scholarships created for New Jersey College for Women by the trustees of Rutgers University, it was announced today by Miss Margaret T. Corwin, dean of the college.

HONOLULU, Hawaii, Oct. 24. -- Plans for two weeks of intensive naval air manoeuvres beginning at dawn Monday, which will require the services of 1,000 officers and 1,000 enlisted men from the aircraft tender Wright and the fleet airbase in Pearl Harbor, have been announced by Rear Admiral Ernest J. King, commanding the aircraft base force.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Oct. 23. -- Most citizens in Terre Haute apparently do not care for communism, and that is chiefly why Earl Browder, Communist candidate for President, was recently thrown into jail here and why, just the other day, he was greeted with a barrage of eggs and tomatoes when he attempted a return visit.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- Two college football games are on Atlantic City's entertainment program for next month, both under the auspices of the Morris Guards, the resort's city troop.

December and January cotton futures contracts on the Cotton Exchange sold off yesterday to the lowest levels since Sept. 8 under a continuation of hedge selling and tired long liquidation. Fluctuations for the day, however, were only 3 to 5 points as trade fixations absorbed contracts and a little Wall Street buying appeared at the new lows for the movement.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- Although Cornell University has been in session only three weeks, a steady stream of employment inquiries has been coming to the dean's office concerning recent graduates and, what is regarded as unprecedented, many business firms are requesting interviews with seniors during the first term of the year.
AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 24. -- A fumbled punt paved the way for Worcester Tech to win from the Massachusetts State eleven today, 7 -- 0.

LONDON, Oct. 24. -- There is still no mention of the Simpson divorce case in the self-censored London newspapers, but two Sunday publications which would rejoice if they could deal with the subject as frankly as they are in the habit of doing in less important instances betray a certain resentment over what they regard as the license indulged in by the American press.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 24. -- Entering today's game an undefeated team, but generally conceded to be the underdog, Wesleyan came through with a noteworthy 14-7 victory over Amherst. The triumph started the Cardinal warriors on a march toward a possible Little Three football championship.

REGADLESS of what hundreds of thousands of individual car owners may think as they struggle without success to start recalcitrant engines, the automobile is a year-round vehicle. Whatever troubles they encounter are their own fault.

Breckinridge Long, former Ambassador to Italy, terming the present administration's expenditure of $8,000,000,000 "a detail" for which the country has made vast gains in property values, credited the Federal Government yesterday with having "saved America." He addressed about 100 members of the Harmonic Club at a luncheon in their headquarters, 4 East Sixtieth Street.

A junior committee for the luncheon of the People's Institute-United Neighborhood Guild, to be held Nov. 17 at the Hotel Astor, is being formed by Mrs. Theodore Fitz Randolph. Mrs. M. Childs Draper is chairman of the sponsoring committee.
SYRACUSE, Oct. 24. -- Two years ago the Democrats carried Onondaga County, one of the largest political units of the State north of the Bronx and normally Republican, for Governor Lehman.

DEMOCRATIC and Republican campaign workers now canvassing the countryside in motor trailers help to direct attention to the rapidly increasing mobility of many heretofore stationary phases of social and economic life. Not only political messages but a wide assortment of commodities ranging from permanent waves to works of art are now carried on wheels into the nation's highways and byways.

For three elderly men, whose total years of employment in one company is 155, the order of the day was "work as usual" yesterday afternoon at the Park Tilford store on the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 24. -- In a fighting speech, former Governor Alfred E. Smith attacked the New Deal here tonight for interfering with private business and charged that it was using taxpayers' money for outright competition with business in defiance of democratic principles.
ALLENTOWN, Pa., Oct. 24. -- Ursinus smashed to a clear-cut victory over the Muhlenberg eleven today, 13 -- 0, with both scores coming after a scoreless first half.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- "Deep and abiding gratification" over the progress made by the navy under the present administration was expressed today by Secretary Swanson in a pre-Navy Day statement.

FEDERAL game management agents, scattered all over the duck-breeding areas, have received final instructions covering the enforcement of this season's game laws. As the ducks fly south the agents will follow them through the three zones into which the country has been divided for game law enforcement.

THERE are signs that this Fall and Winter may bring good dining to the husbands of New York and, incidentally, to the bachelors who may drop in at friendly tables. Never before have Father Knickerbocker's young brides and busy housewives turned in such large and eager numbers to the cooking schools as they are now doing.

With Bill Hutchings leading the way with two touchdowns, Hackley School of Tarrytown defeated Riverdale Country School, 27 -- 0, on Riverdale's field yesterday. Hackley made fourteen first down to one for Riverdale. The contest was in the Triangular League.

The Mary Fisher Home in Tenafly, N.J., will be aided by a card party to be held the afternoon of Nov. 6 at the Plaza. The funds realized will be devoted to the maintenance of the home, where retired teachers, artists, musicians and authors receive shelter and necessities.

A unique fashion revue entitled "Fashions For You" will be held in connection with a luncheon Tuesday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin for the benefit of the Bellevue Hospital Occupational Therapy Committee of the New York Visiting Committee.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 24. -- Mediation, arbitration, legislation to take the profits out of war, restoration of international confidence in the good faith of the American government, scrupulous fairness in dealing with others, lowering of trade barriers and aid in the reestablishment of healthy world economic conditions were listed tonight by Governor Landon as methods which the United States should use in maintaining peace.

IN a little more than a week some fifty million Americans will vote, so they think, for a President, but they will be wrong. They will actually be participating in a vestigial ceremony which is only the first step recognized by the Constitution in the process of choosing a President.

James E. Finegan, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, who recently announced that he would do all he could, as a private citizen, to oppose re-election of President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman, made public yesterday a letter in which he defends his attitude as not inconsistent with the office he holds.

THE theme of Clements Ripley's new novel is California. Not the California of the gold-rush days and the Forty- Niners, of "the red-shirted whoop- and-hurrah boys of the diggings," of the mushroom cities and fortunes made while you waited, but the somewhat soberer California of some thirty years later, by no means as well known to fiction reader.

Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., director of the Eastern division of the Republican National Committee, made public yesterday a statement by Hilda Grace Gelling, chairman of the Music Teachers Defense Committee, assailing the WPA project as a menace to private instructors in the musical arts.

At Ipswich, capital of Suffolk County, in England, not far from the royal residence at Sandringham, Sir John Anthony Hawke, justice of the High Court and judge of the local Assizes, is hearing a petition filed by Mrs. Ernest A. Simpson, born a citizen of the United States, for dissolution of her marriage with Mr. Simpson, a British subject, whose nationality was acquired by Mrs. Simpson as his wife.

The third annual "Night of Stars" performance to raise funds for the relief of Jewish refugees abroad will be held Wednesday evening at the Madison Square Garden under the auspices of the United Palestine Appeal and the Jewish Joint Distribution Committee.

AMONG new types of excursions featured by the nation's railroads this Fall are off-the-beaten-track trips into regions of scenic and historic interest seldom visited by rail travelers. Providing a one-day outing at bargain rates, these novel excursions promise to achieve a popularity as great as that of the fishermen's specials, the bike trains, the hikers' trains, the ski trains and other innovations of the last two or three years.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 24. -- By way of proving that their upset by Duquesne a week ago had been just a minor accident, the Pitt Panthers unleashed the full fury of their resentment and bitterness on hapless Notre Dame today and crushed the hitherto unbeaten Ramblers, 26 -- 0, while the East's largest crowd of the season, 70,224, gazed on in awe at the utter relentlessness of the Pitt juggernaut.

BY the very exigencies of romantic interest, Hollywood is oftener than not committed to a policy of historical inaccuracy. The cinematic pages of the past are spattered with twisted verities, shocking to the more literate portion of theatregoers, but generally shrewdly conceived to attain mass appeal.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- The United States Army team thrilled a capacity crowd of 5,000 today as it took a comfortable lead in the international military team jumping competition at the Inter-American Horse Show at the Meadow Brook Saddle Club.

Maysie Greig's latest novel is the romance of the antique dealer's daughter. Lovely, red-headed Tania Maillart met handsome, red-headed Tony Lethridge in her father's London shop. Tony announced that he was bringing suit against her father for outrageously swindling Tony's father.

Faced with a possible opportunity to move into first place in the Eastern division of the National Football League and gain, as well, revenge for an unexpected defeat in their opening game in the circuit, the New York Giants will play the Philadelphia Eagles at the Polo Grounds today with the kick-off scheduled for 2:30 P. M.

LONDON, Oct. 24. -- Members of the diplomatic corps returning to London include the Netherlands Minister and Mrs. de Marees van Swinderen, who spent the Summer in Albury Park, Surrey, and the Yugoslav Minister and Mrs. Grouitch, who have been on the Continent.

State-chartered banks and trust companies which are members of the Federal Reserve System have been declared for the first time to be "instrumentalities of the United States," in a ruling recently published by the Bureau of Internal Revenue.

EXETER, N.H., Oct. 24. -- Phillips Exeter routed the University of New Hampshire freshmen today to win by 33 -- 0. Harry Kingsley opened the scoring in the second period on a 65-yard run. A dash of 43 yards by Bob Jackson was the highlight of the third session.

PARIS, Oct. 23. -- Stock markets are generally considered excellent thermometers for taking a country's temperature. If so, there seems to be something wrong with France this week, for the Bourse has been behaving badly and the franc has been showing decided signs of weakness, particularly on the forward market.

WHITHER BRITAIN? The Times of London has raised the question: Shall there be no more cakes and ale? Already there are 100 milk bars in the London area, and a syndicate has been formed to establish 500 more. Milk drinking is increasing at what is, to any one who has an eye to Britain's ale tradition, an alarming rate.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Oct. 24 (AP). -- Phil Bieber's Chancing won the Autumn Handicap, a mile and one-sixteenth event for 3-year-olds and upward, by a head from Mrs. L.H. Ward's Tugboat Frank at Narragansett Park today.

IT'S the first time this land has a crop since the world began, an we're doin' it." The land was desert, sage-brush land, in Southwest Idaho, above the irrigation ditch -- for cheapness sake -- and the two doing it were a young woman lately widowed and Mary, her 8-year-old daughter.
Washington is in its quadrennial coma. As the country's political temperature rises higher and higher the city grows deader and deader until it reaches the quietest day of all -- election day.

While ninety-three disgruntled passengers waited aboard the liner Oriente at her pier most of the 208 members of the crew filed off the ship at about 7 o'clock last night and, proceeding in parliamentary fashion, voted that they should take the ship out for Havana, her port of destination.

Lawrence Marx, chairman of the 1936 campaign of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, announced yesterday that leaders in 115 trades and professions had accepted executive posts in the federation's campaign to raise $3,000,000 to meet the deficit of its ninety-one affiliated social welfare agencies.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- Taking advantage of every scoring opportunity, an aggressive University of Maryland eleven handed Syracuse its third defeat of the season today, winning by 20 to 0 before 14,000 fans.

The annual candidates' meeting of the Westchester League of Women Voters, which will he held tomorrow at the Briar Hills Country Club, Briarcliff Manor, will be featured by three speakers who will discuss the issues of the political campaign.

The debutante committee for the December Ball to be held on Dec. 3 at the Ritz-Carlton will meet on Tuesday afternoon at a tea to be given by Mrs. William W. Fleming, chairman of the ball, at her home, 850 Park Avenue.

The women's committee of the New York City Cancer Committee, local unit of the American Society for the Control of Cancer, will launch its tenth annual educational and fund-raising drive on Wednesday under its well-known slogan "Fight Cancer with Knowledge."

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 24. -- Mr. and Mrs. Harold Halsted of Wellington Road gave a dinner this evening for Mr. and Mrs. Foster Yawger of Rochester, N.Y. Their other guests included Mr. and Mrs. Martin Remsen, Mr. and Mrs. H.H. Salmon, Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Gleason, Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Bowman, Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Bishop and Mrs. Allan Hardie.

This is an honest, straightforward story of the life of Janice Penfield, who was born in a small Eastern town the year the Maine was sunk. It carries through to the present time and brings Janice through a fairly large assortment of bitter disappointments and griefs.

FIFTY years ago, on Oct. 28, 1886, the Statue of Liberty was unveiled in New York Harbor. Since then liberty has been lighting less and less of the world, the statue's copper gleam has turned to green, and most of those who stood bareheaded at the solemn inauguration ceremony have passed away.

HSINKING, Manchukuo. -- The Japanese Army leaders in the new Empire of Manchukuo, and equally the Japanese civilians who dominate and dictate to the Chinese officials who nominally direct the Manchukuo Government, are all obsessed with the fear that Soviet Russi has concluded a secret agreement with China.

Seeing the Laurence Rivers production of Erik Charell's "White Horse Inn" gives me a pleasant nostalgia for the European cities in which I have seen this famous musical. My initial experience with "White Horse Inn" occurred just before the World War when I was studying music in Saxe-Coburg-Gotha.

A note enclosed in the envelopes which carried tickets to subscribers for the Navy-Princeton football game created something of a stir last week. It was from President William F. Dodds of Princeton University and it requested persons attending the game to refrain from the use of alcoholic liquors.

There is considerable concern as to the political outcome of the present disturbance in Palestine, which has not been lessened by the formal calling off of the Arab strike, according to Gershon Agronsky, founder and editor of The Palestine Post of Jerusalem, the only English-language daily in Palestine.

IN the second quarter of the nineteenth century the American public had turned in greatly increased numbers to reading, but the popular monthly magazine was only at the beginning of its career. For more than thirty years the treasure of the average household's reading was the literary annual, the "resplendent gift book."

The contents of Eddie Cantor's two New York homes will be auctioned next week at the Rains Galleries, 12 East Forty-ninth Street. Because the movie, stage and radio star spends ten months of the year in Hollywood, he has decided to live there permanently.

OMAHA, Oct. 23. -- Throughout the Middle West there still survive a good many old fellows who achieved their present partisan status by "taking a walk" forty years ago from their original party affiliation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- Outlays for building construction in September were more than 54 per cent larger than September, 1935, the Department of Labor announced today. A seasonal decline of 12.6 per cent from August was recorded.

Philanthropic organizations aided by the Stuyvesant Square Thrift Shop Association will receive a generous percentage of the proceeds of the luncheon, tea and dinner hours at the formal opening Wednesday of La Salle du Bois, 36 East Sixtieth Street.

The New York Diet Kitchen Association will be the beneficiary of a series of twelve lectures on current events to be given by Mrs. Jessica Lozier Payne on alternate Wednesday mornings, beginning Nov. 4, in the ballroom of the Pierre.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 24. -- Minnesota's mighty fortress of football still stands, its guns booming defiance to the gridiron world.

BERLIN, Oct. 24. -- Virtually no attention is being paid here to the American election. News services carrying American reports have been informed by German editors that they are not interested in the campaign and want only reports of riots and other disturbances until the final result is learned.

THOMAS WILDCAT ALFORD is the great-grandson of the, noble Shawnee chief Tecumseh, and he was born and brought up in the finest and sternest traditions of his race. The story of his life is the story of much that is best, much that should be most enduring, in Indian thought and ideals.

BERLIN, Oct. 24. -- The first of what may prove to be a large and varied brood of diplomatic rabbits came out of the newly fashioned Nazi-Fascist hat today when Chancellor Adolf Hitler personally informed Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister and son-in-law of Premier Benito Mussolini, that the German Government had decided formally to recognize Italian conquest of Ethiopia.

MADRID, Oct. 24 (Passed by the Censor). -- Fighting is again going on in the streets of Oviedo, through which Insurgent relief columns filtered recently. The Basque militia, composed exclusively of Socialists and Communists, is reported to be rivaling their Asturian comrades in bravery.

NORMAN, Okla., Oct. 24. -- Nebraska surged nearer the Big Six football championship today, rumbling over what was considered the Huskers' most dangerous rival, Oklahoma, by 14 to 0 before approximately 25,000 fans.

SANTAYANA looks out of his windows in Rome and sees the Fountain of the Tritons. That, Scribner's Mr. Weber says, is why they're calling the publication of his complete works the Triton Edition. "And also because this mythological sea god may very pleasantly stand as a symbol for the general quality of Santayana's philosophy, its pagan aspect."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24. -- The Italo-American Democratic League, claiming a membership of 10,000, announced today through its president, Magistrate Charles Amodei, that it would support Governor Landon, the Republican Presidential nominee, and the rest of the Republican ticket.

A campaign for $400,000 and 20,000 new members was opened yesterday by The Seeing Eye, Inc., of Morristown, N.J., the philanthropic school established in 1929 to educate German shepherd dogs to guide the blind and to teach the blind how to use them. The drive will be carried on this Fall and Winter in the major cities of the United States.
THE Workmen's Circle Chorus, under Lazar Weiner, has resumed rehearsal for the 1936-37 season. Registration for new members is being held this month on Friday nights at the Royal Hotel.

It seems clear that there is considerably less political activity on the campus this Fall than has been usual in previous Presidential election periods. Thus far no rallies have been held in support of any candidate or ticket.

There was much jubilation in the Bronx last night, for Evander Childs High's powerful array of football warriors hurdled another pretentious obstacle in their path toward an undefeated and untied season by submerging the La Salle Military Academy of Oakdale, L.I., under a 25-0 score on the Orange and Black field yesterday.

The names of 165 students of the University Heights branch of New York University who attained the honor roll by high scholastic standing during the last academic year were announced jointly yesterday by Dean Irving H. Berg of the College of Arts and Pure Science and Dean Thorndike Saville of the College of Engineering.

The Republican National Committee, from its Eastern headquarters at 41 East Forty-second Street, replied yesterday to charges that employers favoring the election of Governor Landon were "coercing" workers by placing in or on their pay envelopes a notice of forthcoming pay deductions for old-age pensions under the Social Security Law.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 24 (AP). -- Reverting to the weapon of the Indians, ninety Wisconsin archers have received permits from the State Conservation Commission to test their skill with bow and arrow on buck deer of Sauk and Columbia Counties during a seven-day season beginning Sunday.

THREE antagonistic types of civilization clash in this ambitious novel, which centers round the owner of centers Brampton Hall. The dilapidated Colonial mansion, with its neglected estate of several hundred acres, stands not far from the little Virginia village of Brampton Forge.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Oct. 24 (AP). -- Missouri University bounded out of a four-year football depression with a 10-0 victory over Iowa State today. The Tigers won their last Big Six Conference game from Oklahoma in 1932.

THERE are two kinds of children in adult fiction -- the imaginative prankish child of "Dreamdays," for instance, as contrasted with the astute, devilishly powerful child of "The Innocent Voyage." To write of the former is a patent proposition, but the latter is a ticklish undertaking.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 24. -- The room in which the Alumnae Council of Goucher College meets next Saturday will be transformed into an undergraduate classroom where students, under the leadership of Professor Elinor Pancoast, chairman of the Department of Economics and Sociology, will discuss the problem, "The Consumer: Some Problems and Solutions."

Trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange was exceptionally slow and dull yesterday. The turnover declined to $5,502,800, the smallest since Aug. 29, on which day the sales were $5,208,200, and compared with $7,381,500 on Saturday a week ago.
ROME, Oct. 23. -- The zigzag course followed by Italo-German relations in recent years cannot escape any one taking the trouble to compare the situations on a few outstanding dates.

A GROUP of men and women with a common concern for the protection of wild life from man's depredations start out today for Montauk Point to observe the many native species of birds which seek shelter in that vicinity.

THE city of Florence, set between its fine circle of decorous hills and cleft in twain by the narrow pewter-colored ribbon of the Arno sometimes in full Summer a mere trickle, though once, Professor Schevill seems to indicate, it was noble and Rhine-like), is not merely a city -- it is a large museum wherein more art and beauty are gathered together than in any other place on this revolving globe.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 24. -- Yugoslavia hopes prosperity will follow the adoption of the plan of Dr. Milan Hodza, Czechoslovak Premiere, for the economic collaboration of the Little Entente [Czechoslovakia, Rumania and Yugoslavia] and the Rome bloc [Italy, Austria and Hungary].

Drawing a dismal picture of the possibilities for peace in a Europe in which the League of Nations has been rendered virtually impotent and replaced with powerful nationalism, the Marquess of Lothian, considered by many the leading Liberal peer of Great Britain, stated on Monday that Great Britain was united in the effort to provide adequate armament in "a world of highly armed anarchy."

BRITISH television observers are seeing a "magazine of the air" called "Picture Page" broadcast from Alexandra Palace. The London Telegraph describes it as "a brilliant success approaching cinema standards of efficiency."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- Belief that the Supreme Court agreed today whether to pass on the constitutionality of the Wagner Labor Relations Act was expressed tonight by government attorneys.

Flames had almost completely destroyed the old house which was the home both of Mortimer Crane and of his archaeological collection, and not only the rich old man but his young and improvident nephew had perished in the fire. But there is clear evidence that the younger victim had been shot through the head.

The radio has made it possible for a campaigning candidate to address the nation's millions from his fireside, but the candidates this year have not clung to their hearths. Television hasn't come yet, and vote-seekers must be seen as well as heard. Moreover, they want to see and hear on their own account.

DEVALUATION of the currencies of France, Switzerland, Holland and Italy has lifted the purchasing power of the dollar in those countries toward that which our money enjoyed in the golden age of American touring -- the decade following the World War.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 24. -- Johns Hopkins registered its first victory of the season with a 10-to-2 triumph over Haverford today.

SUFFERN, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- Potatoes, carrots, turnips and beets fill the root cellars of the School of Living Colonists a mile from here on the Haverstraw Road, following their first harvest last week.
NORTHFIELD, Vt., Oct. 24. -- President Porter Adams of Norwich University in a letter to President Roosevelt said tonight that technological progress was not responsible for unemployment.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 24. -- The Princeton University faculty will back the re-election of President Roosevelt by a slight margin over Governor Landon, according to a poll concluded by The Daily Princetonian, undergraduate newspaper.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 24. -- Acting with the Interfraternity Council, Penn State Christian Association will sponsor its annual interfraternity pledge banquet tomorrow evening for more than 500 students who were pledged to men's social and professional fraternities this Fall.
FREDERICK, Md., Oct. 24 (AP). -- La Salle College of Philadelphia defeated Mount St. Mary's College, 13 -- 6, today before 2,500 spectators.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- Azure skies and warm sunshine, tempered by the crisp Autumn air, are being enjoyed by the large assemblage of colonists at this spa. The social calendar includes parties at the Casino, at Kate's Mountain Lodge, at a number of cottages and at the Greenbrier.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler, who seldom entertains, played host at his Bavarian chalet yesterday to Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italy's Foreign Minister. Out of that meeting came a united Fascist front that may profoundly affect the future of Europe.

Blooms from tulips are as certain as taxes -- provided, of course, that the bulbs originally purchased are first-class stock from reliable growers. Within the hearts of good bulbs the perfect flowers are already formed, awaiting only the moisture and warmth of soil to bring them forth.
