BUFFALO, Oct. 24. -- Governor Lehman closed his up-State campaign for re-election here tonight with a strong plea for support of President Roosevelt and the New Deal.

Miss Eleanor Hoguet heads a group of young women aiding in the arrangements for the revue to be known as "Fashions for Madame" to be held Friday during the luncheon hour in the new Crystal Garden of the Ritz-Carlton for the benefit of the Guild Book Shop of the Saint Paul Guild.

There were only about twenty people in Sowback Island, barring children and the Summer visitors. Yet on this little island off the Maine coast mystery was piled on mystery, and one crime led to other crimes and uncovered others still. Barney Gantt, the enterprising young newspaper photographer who has been met before in John Stephen Strange's pages, is sent to supposedly quiet resort to recover from the effects of an accident.

THE first reciprocal move by the screen to aid the stage and to offset the charges of talent looting that the theatre has leveled at the movies was made this week by S.J. Briskin, who threw open the contract list at RKO-Radio to little theatres and stock companies throughout the land.

BOSTON, Oct. 24. -- Although some complaints have been heard that the unseasonably warm weather this week has hurt department store sales, particularly the distribution of Winter merchandise, current statistics indicate that retail trade as a whole in New England is still running 10 to 15 per cent over the volume a year ago.

FOR the past twenty years hypnotism has been practically abandoned in the field of mental and medical therapy, since the results obtained have proved to be only superficial and temporary. Our knowledge of hypnotism is still quite limited.

Bartholdi's majestic Statue of Liberty -- her copper robes a weathered green after half a century of life -- will celebrate her fiftieth anniversary next Wednesday in ceremonies which will be attended by President Roosevelt, Secretary of the Interior Ickes, Ambassador Andre de Laboulaye of France and scores of distinguished guests.

Charges by J. Edward Jones, dealer in oil royalties, that he had been offered immunity from prosecution in an indictment for alleged fraudulent use of the mails if he would make a $2,500 contribution to the Democratic national campaign, were denied yesterday by James A. Farley, chairman, and W. Forbes Morgan, treasurer, of the Democratic National Committee.

THIS Statue of Liberty has held high her torch to the world for fifty years. The momentous fact will not go unheeded. All democracies, whose ideal our goddess symbolizes, will join with this nation and this city, in presence or in spirit, to pay honor to her on Wednesday next, the anniversary of her unveiling in 1886.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 24. -- Aroused to a fighting pitch by weeks of unceasing criticism aimed at the coaching staff, the athletic director and the team itself, Michigan's infuriated Wolverines today answered the skeptics and, rising to heights that few in the Midwest and fewer in the East had expected, routed a potentially powerful Columbia eleven, 13 to 0.

LAKELAND, Fla., Oct. 23. -- Florida finds itself in the embarrassing position of inviting the world to come here for the Winter land then stopping thousands of would-be visitors at the State line to ascertain whether they would be good visitors.

This mystery novel introduces a new author, and a genuinely promising one. Mr. Bortner has a good story to tell and an original way of telling it. And his amateur sleuth is not only clever but refreshingly human. That is not to say that "Bond Grayson Murdered!" is a masterpiece; but it is interesting and unusual, and its author is to be welcomed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- The native Governor of Taos Pueblo in New Mexico was censured by Secretary Ickes today for the alleged "extreme, even cruel" punishment of a minority religious group in the pueblo.

MADRID, Oct. 24 (AP). -- The Spanish Government, in a note to Great Britain, today expressed "surprise that there should exist a belief that the noble citizens of Madrid are capable of collective vengeance against political prisoners!"

About 100 Hunter College students are revealing their journalistic, literary and business interests this year by engaging in publication work, one of the college's most extensive extracurricular activities. The nine Hunter publications, issued by the students, are the weekly newspaper, the yearbook, three literary magazines, three club publications and a handbook for freshmen.

THE publishers of Whitaker's Almanack issue also a monthly periodical, Current Literature, which contains a complete list of books published in the British Isles during the previous month. They have been surprised to learn that its circulation has been forbidden in Germany, not on account of the editorial contents of the magazine, but simply because of this list.
Annual Girl Scout Sunday will be observed today by members of all faiths attending in groups their own houses of worship.

Many reservations have been made for the dinner which will be given by the National Association of Audubon Societies on Tuesday night in the Colonnades Room of Essex House to mark the closing of the thirty-second annual convention of the organization. The association will be in session tomorrow and Tuesday at the Museum of Natural History.

IN my twenty-four years of association with Broadway I have had many interesting experiences. These have included the attending of the openings of at least forty new theatres and the reviewing of nearly 3,000 new plays, musical comedies and pictures for newspapers and the radio, and I had come of the opinion that I had bumped into about all the thrills Broadway had to offer.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- Using reserve players for all except a few minutes of today's game with Springfield College, Army triumphed before 25,000 spectators, a capacity crowd for Michie Stadium, by 33 to 0. The cadets scored in every period except the last.

Army's cross-country team placed six men among the first nine finishers yesterday to defeat Columbia and Princeton over a five-mile course in Van Cortlandt Park. The Cadets scored 24 points; the Tigers were second with 43, and the Lions compiled 53.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 24. -- Political affairs and numerous charity drives have engaged considerable attention from business leaders in the Eighth Federal Reserve District this week. Organizations for relief are asking for larger sums than in previous years and in most cities funds for this purpose are seriously depleted.

The International Mercantile Marine Company announced yesterday the retirement of James S. Mahool as general passenger traffic manager and the appointment of John F. Brennan as his successor. The changes will become effective next Sunday.

If the cotton goods market could be taken as an accurate barometer of American business, this country is on the verge of its greatest boom, according to opinions expressed yesterday by both mill executives and wholesale buyers. Sales volume in recent weeks have been so large that mills have built up their heaviest backlog of orders since 1919, and the end of the upswing is nowhere in sight, it was pointed out.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 24 (AP). -- Norman Thomas, making his final automobile tour of New England as the Socialist Presidential nominee, asserted tonight that the "success of the cooperative Commonwealth is our best safeguard against war and depression."

THE title of Professor Gooch's book is not without pertinence; it fits the fourth decade of the twentieth century as well as the first to which it refers. Headlines in our daily newspapers indicate that Europe is steering toward serious trouble; Professor Gooch's book describes the men, policies and events which finally led to the disaster of 1914.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23. -- Leaders of both major parties in Pennsylvania are trying to convince themselves and all who will listen that the State-wide registration figures, showing a Republican advantage of nearly 600,000, prove conclusively that their respective Presidential candidates are certain captors of this Commonwealth's thirty-six electoral votes.
CAZENOVIA, N.Y., Oct. 24 (AP). -- Wild life havens where deer and other game will find an abundance of food and shelter are in the making in New York State.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- The Maritime Commission renewed its demand today upon West Coast maritime unions that they "state their intentions."

BOSTON, Oct. 24 (AP). -- James Roosevelt, eldest son of the President, made public today the text of his answer to a question in a radio forum in which he asserted that Governor Landon had achieved economy at the expense of the Kansas school system.

In what the police listed as a suicide pact, a World War veteran and a woman died of carbon monoxide poisoning yesterday morning in a closed automobile parked in a field in a deserted district of Bayside at 216th Street near Seventy-third Road, Queens.

BERLIN, Oct. 23. -- Representatives of German publishers and booksellers' organizations gathered for a "German Book Week," organized by the Propaganda Ministry, in Weimar issued a resolution appealing to the book trade abroad to cooperate in censoring and suppressing books likely to embitter international relations.

Twice in the opening period St. Mary's scored placement field goals, worth 3 points apiece. But another placement was far more valuable yesterday. The one point resulting from that kick meant victory for the Maroon, for in the gloom of early evening a pale moon looked down on a Fordham snake dance and a score board that read: Fordham 7, St. Mary's 6.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 24. -- Science and learning must turn their attack to the "no-man's areas of knowledge," those fields that lie between the already specialized compartments of scholarship, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, declares in his annual report to the board of trustees, made public today.

Under-privileged children cared for at the Children's Village in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., will be aided by the performance of "And Stars Remain" on the night of Nov. 16 at the Guild Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the project.
When the holders of reservations for the Princeton-Navy football game received their tickets last week from Princeton they found a note enclosed:

THERE is no doubt that one is greatly handicapped in a clear understanding of recent history in the Far East unless one is familiar with that short but fateful period of Chinese history which covers the reign of the last ruler of the Celestial Empire, that of the boy emperor Hsuan-Tung (born Pu-yi), who reigned under the regency of his father, Prince Chun.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Oct. 24 (AP). -- Northwestern's powerful Wildcat used its claws just twice today to rake out two touchdowns and conquer Illinois's courageous little eleven, 13 to 2, for its third straight Western Conference football triumph, before a homecoming crowd of 27,000.

The proposed City Charter is a "menace to democratic and economical government," it was charged last night by Louis Waldman, State chairman of the People's party, in a radio address in reply to Mayor La Guardia's appeal for charter ratification at the polls.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 24. -- Professional immunity for newspaper men in court proceedings will be up for a decision by the Arkansas electorate in the Nov. 3 election.

IPSWICH, England, Oct. 24. -- The work of "clearing the jail," the process of British assize law by which criminal cases receive preference over civil cases, occupied Justice Sir John Anthony Hawke throughout today and his gorgeously uniformed marshal ushered him out of the tiny court to the accompaniment of a fanfare of silver trumpets without the Simpson divorce case being reached.

BERLIN, Oct. 24. -- Col. Gen. Hermann Goering today mobilized the entire labor service army compromising more than 200,000 men and some 10,000 girls to save the German vegetable crop endangered by sudden cold weather with threatened snow falls in several parts of the country.
SEATTLE, Oct. 24 (AP). -- The University of Washington charged another lap closer to the Rose Bowl today with a 13-to-0 football triumph over California.
TROY, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- Playing on a field made soggy by two days of rain, Union turned back Rensselaer Poly, 6 -- 0, today. It was the fiftieth anniversary of football between the schools.

The understandings being sought between Berlin and Rome will certainly be hailed as representing an effort of the forces of "law and order" to arraign themselves against "forces of destruction." In other words, the two big Fascist nations of the Old World are to proclaim they are making a solid front against communism.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- Dramatic activities for this year at Elmira College began last evening with the presentation of "The Swan," the romantic comedy by Ferenc Molnar, given by the junior members of the student dramatic organization.

FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- Giving a finished performance through three series and a water test, Squire of Chancefield today was awarded first honors in the Open All-Age Stake for springer spaniels. This was the most important event on the program of the thirteenth annual field trial meeting of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association.

BETWEEN 1887, the year of her first divorce, and 1926, when her fifth marriage met the same ending, Aimee Crocker's name was often in the newspapers; and it was sometimes said that if she ever wrote her autobiography it would make a sensation.

PARIS, Sunday, Oct. 25 (AP). -- Three French airplanes took off at dawn today at the start of a 15,000-mile round-trip race to Saigon, French Indo-China, that its sponsors declared to be the world's longest aviation course.

Distant by the span of half the world, three units of the Young Women's Christian Association will be welcomed this week in both Orient and Occident, for meetings whose themes reflect their identity of objective, as vividly as costume and background mark the cosmopolitan character of their membership.
CHICAGO, Oct. 23. -- Senator James Hamilton Lewis, seeking reelection from Illinois, is the wonder of this campaign.

The first of three groups of one-act plays by Noel Coward, with Mr. Coward and Gertrude Lawrence in the leading roles at the National Theatre has been taken over for the night of Dec. 2 by members of the board of directors of the Neighborhood Music School to raise funds for carrying on the work of that organization.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24. -- A tour of inquiry into the political prospects in a dozen States, which, with New Jersey and New York (as yet unsurveyed by this correspondent), will decide the outcome of the national election, has produced these opinions:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24. -- As far as American field hockey is concerned, the high point of the international tournament, extending over a two-week period until Nov. 1, at the Philadelphia Cricket Club will be reached tomorrow afternoon.
LONDON, Oct. 24. -- The British Government's impending orders for aircraft in the United States have introduced a new and important factor into Europe's furious race to arm itself in the air.

RADIO broadcasters in 1920 started out hand-in-hand with the phonograph. It was not long, however, before radio, realizing its power, pushed the music box aside and welcomed the artists to the studios in person. But the phonograph, now electrified itself, frequently rises to taunt and haunt the giant that casts music to the winds rather than record it on disks that may be sold.

Scholarship, once the sole obligation imposed on undergraduates by colleges, has given way to newer standards of student fitness, Dean Herbert E. Hawkes of Columbia College declares in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, which was made public yesterday.

Any one seeking a haven of neutrality these bitter and shouting pre-election days would do well to drop in at the Todhunter School, 66 East Eightieth Street. Because Anna Eleanor Roosevelt, columnist and wife of the President. is the associate principal, the school authorities have been bending over backward to avoid criticism.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 24. -- As in the beginning and all through their rivalry, Yale once again was the master of Rutgers as they resumed gridiron relations today in the Yale bowl for the first time since 1890. The Elis, never using their full strength at any juncture, rolled up their largest score of the season in blanking the plucky visitors, 28 to 0, and thus remained in the "won all" group.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24. -- Cooling weather and several special sales events brought sharp improvement in the volume of the larger department stores this week, the average gain over last year rising to about 20 per cent. Wholesale turnover held around last week's high levels, with complaints of inability to get goods from mills increasing in volume.

For those who have a Winter garden under glass to supplement the Summer garden, the flower season never draws to a close. In spite of seasonal changes, new blooms keep coming along as the indoor garden picks up the succession where the outdoor garden leaves off.

A REVIVED interest in collecting helmets worn by old-time volunteer firemen, and other equipment of former firefighters, was shown at the recent antique show held in New York City, where many of these relics were on exhibit.

The Seamen's Church Institute of New York, the largest shore home in the world for active merchant seamen, will be the beneficiary of Gilbert and Sullivan's "The Gondoliers," presented by the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company on the night of Nov. 9 at the Martin Beck Theatre.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- The Resettlement Administration's program of adjusting farm debts reduced the obligations of 2,765 farm families by $2,376,698 in September, it was announced today.

WITH the late opening of the season of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra this Fall the writer was seized with a desire to find out for himself what other American orchestras and their conductors were doing.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 24. -- Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, outlined the accomplishments of the Roosevelt administration in an address at the Central High School here tonight. The meeting was under auspices of the Good Neighbor League of New Jersey, an organization actively campaigning for the re-election of President Roosevelt.

BARCELONA, Oct. 24 (AP). -- Press dispatches tonight from the Huesca front in the North of Spain said the Rebel army made a strong attack at dawn against the town of Tardienta but failed to break the government lines under Colonel Jose P. Eduardo Villalba.

AS Gilbert Miller sped east across the Atlantic last week the story went that he and the Brothers Warner had about concluded one of the biggest deals of its kind that the entertainment business has seen. Perhaps, by now, it is really signed and sealed if not delivered.

Can it be that tea parties are coming back? There has been a remarkable demand for tea sets and tea tablecloths this Fall, according to reports from a glass and china house and from a linen shop. The heads of these concerns are sure that the modern bride intends to have her friends to tea, if they shy at cocktails.

In the first nine months of 1936, the Bendix Aviation Corporation reported yesterday, it and its subsidiaries earned a net profit of $2,136,870 after depreciation, interest, normal Federal income taxes and other charges and after a reserve of about $22,000 for possible surtax on undistributed income.

FLINT, Mich., Oct. 24. -- An all-year recreational program started here two years ago has virtually eliminated traffic fatalities among children and has reduced juvenile delinquency nearly 70 per cent. Nearly 1,500,000 young people have taken part yearly.

SO great a hold had "The Shropshire Lad" over its generation that many were almost afraid to read "Last Poems," doubting that the magic could still persist. But soon that volume had become as famous and sacred as its elder and there was nothing in it that one would wish away.

So far we have had no tin-pan beating, torch-light parading "rally'' of the type we often saw in the earlier Nineteen Hundreds. I do not wish to predict that we shall have none this year but I am certain that any one attempting to stage this type of demonstration would encounter more reluctance and that the average undergraduate's heart would not be in it to the same degree.
I wish your drama critic would cast aside his judicial frame of mind and enthuse a bit.

THE annual metropolitan tournament, which closes today at the Park Central, drew a slightly smaller crowd than in 1935, but the American Bridge League, which conducts the event, announced itself as well satisfied with the attendance.

FRENCH devaluation, bringing more francs per dollar, came too late in the season greatly to swell the Autumn tourist tide from the American side of the Atlantic toward Havre and Cherbourg. But in the coming Spring and early Summer France expects fresh travel eastward, and until that time she has deferred festivities for the return of the American prodigal.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 24. -- Alexander Forward of New York, managing director of the American Gas Association, completing final preparations of its eighteenth annual convention and exhibition here Monday, said today that sentiment in the gas industry is better than at any time since 1929.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 24. -- Traced to Detroit by a radio sketch he left behind, John Scott Haggard, 27 years old, of Ferndale, Mich., a Detroit suburb, was brought here by airplane today on an indictment charging him with first-degree burglary.

HORSE GOT HIM: In the jungles of tropical Asia, Frank Buck has trapped man-eating tigers, leopards, panthers and pythons, bringing 'em back alive for civilization's zoos. On his Long Island estate last week Mr. Buck was thrown by a newly purchased rodeo horse and kicked severely enough to warrant hospital treatment
BERLIN, Oct. 24. -- The Reich Church Ministry evidently is still determined to force the German Christian administrators into church offices.

An entertainment and fashion revue to be known as "Fashion's Big Moments" will be held Thursday afternoon in the Corinthian Room and the main ballroom of the Pierre for the benefit of the Nearly New Shop, a permanent thrift shop at 917 Eighth Avenue, which is maintained in behalf of various charitable organizations ministering to the under-privileged and destitute.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24. -- City College of New York continued its fine play today to chalk up its third victory in four starts, handing the strong Drexel eleven a 6-0 defeat.

Officers of seven nations will appear in New York this week to make final preparations for the thrilling international military jumping contests at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden. The military jumping will be a nightly feature of the National, which opens Nov. 4 and runs through Nov. 10.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 24. -- The Rutgers University Fund Council, organized in 1934 to secure annual gifts from alumni and friends of the university, announced today the election of new officers for 1936-37.
HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 24. -- Trinity today defeated the Connecticut State eleven, 8 to 0, before a crowd of 10,000.

Wholesale buying activity diminished last week due to mild weather, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc., although brisk demand was maintained for holiday-type merchandise.

The Gilhoolys are freemen who take the business of choosing a head of state in serious vein, the police of the Park Slope station found out last night when a peremptory court order, especially convening two election boards in the Twelfth Assembly district of Brooklyn, reversed their decision on the electoral qualifications of Miss Annie Gilhooly of 565 First Street.

ROME, Oct. 24. -- The German recognition of the conquest of Ethiopia was received with satisfaction here today, not so much for the fact itself, which is considered of relatively slight importance, but because it is viewed as a symptom of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's good intentions toward Italy.

CHESTER, Pa., Oct. 24. -- Franklin and Marshall today brought about the first home football defeat for Pennsylvania Military College since Coach Jud Timm assumed charge in 1930. The score was 26 -- 0.

Privileged and Seabiscuit were the stake winners before 15,000 persons at Empire City yesterday as the split-second occurrences which take place in charging around the turn cost the life of the favorite.

BESIDES being discredited by its meaningless title, "Call for a Chaperon has been maligned by its jacket-blurb. This "sheer comedy," distinguished for its "wit and superb irresponsibility," is described as dealing mainly with the great Carlo's May-December passion during his fiftieth jubilee and with the concerted efforts of his wife and his leading lady (with whom he has long enjoyed a "beautiful friendship") to bring him to his senses.

Little red fire is being burned for many Presidential candidate by college undergraduates of the East this year. Despite the alleged hair-pulling during a recent political rally at a woman's college, five out of eight college administrators questioned by THE NEW YORK TIMES report all quiet on the Eastern campuses.

COMMUTERS who live in Long Island and New Jersey, the far reaches of Westchester and the borderlands of Connecticut have settled down to their regular Winter schedule of morning trains into New York City, and evening trains out again.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 24 (AP). -- Tulane University's superior forward wall and a pass attack that clicked with precision gave it a 21-to-7 victory over the North Carolina eleven before 18,000 spectators today.

During the last few years the chrysanthemum breeders have made notable advances toward producing hybrids which fulfill three major requirements -- earliness, perfect hardiness and brilliance of color. The newer introductions, now to be seen in gardens, at Fall flower shows and at exhibition and trial grounds, give evidence that the breeders have actually attained a new "high" in their struggle to provide satisfactory plants.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- The first turkey shoot of the season will be held on the Homestead skeet field next Saturday. A bird will be offered for the highest handicapped score and the highest unhandicapped score, the event being open to both men and women.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- The United States Embassy in Madrid has been reopened as a place of refuge for American citizens, "in view of the serious military situation and the possibility of disturbances in Madrid," the State Department was informed today by Eric C. Wendelin, third secretary in charge of the embassy.

Sixty-eight students at City College have been enrolled for honor work in seventeen subjects this term, to mark the sixth year of the institution of honor courses at the college. The faculty authorized these courses in 1931.

In telegrams of protest to Mayor La Guardia and to school officials yesterday, Warren B. Ashmead, Queens Republican leader, charged that Democratic pledge cards were being circulated among children and teachers in the public schools of his borough.

NEWARK, N. J., Oct. 24. -- New Jersey is threatened with the loss of a $10,000,000 annual payroll and the removal from the State of 178 dress-manufacturing concerns which employ more than 12,000 persons. Delegates attending a meeting of the New Jersey Dress Manufacturers Association at the Hotel Douglas here today approved a resolution authorizing such "drastic action" unless a differential between wages in New York and New Jersey is restored.

MADRID, Oct. 25. -- The Spanish Government rushed heavy re-enforcements to the Valdemoro sector today as heavy fighting for possession of the Aranjuez highway and the Madrid-Levante rail communications was resumed.

Dr. Samuel A. Rutledge, chairman of the Queens division of the New York State Educators Committee for Roosevelt and Lehman, said yesterday that he had been too busy to make a check-up to see if there is any truth in the charges of Warren B. Ashmead, Queens Republican chairman, that pledge cards for the Democratic nominees had been distributed to children in Queens schools.

MONTREAL, Oct. 25. -- Canada and Germany today replaced the working arrangement for mutual trade, in force since 1933, by a provisional most-favored-nation agreement. They also concluded a subsidiary agreement designed to overcome the rigid German exchange restrictions that had nullified the advantages of their existing trade arrangement.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25. -- Five thousand Protestants, Catholics and Jews, assembled before a statue in Fairmount Park erected sixty years ago by American Jews in memory of Roger Williams, heard pleas for tolerance voiced today by speakers representing the three faiths.

Steel operations have declined 2 points to 73 per cent of capacity, and a further slight drop may come in the next few weeks, according to the weekly summary by the magazine Steel, issued yesterday. Automobile manufacturers, however, soon will release orders for their steel requirements, and operations will mount swiftly again, the article says.

Jacob Gould Schurman Jr., Chief City Magistrate, announced yesterday that twenty-one courts under his jurisdiction, each with a Magistrate on duty, would remain open until the polls closed on election day, in order to handle cases involving violation of the election law.

The New York Giants defeated the Philadelphia Eagles at the Polo Grounds yesterday and did it the hard way. The Maramen, hot and cold alternately, put on the steam in the last nine minutes, scored two quick touchdowns in that brief time and edged out the Eagles, 21 to 17.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- The Resettlement Administration, headed by Rexford G. Tugwell, lent $661 on one spotted cow and $821.30 on two black mares and three pigs, the Republican National Committee asserted in a statement issued today. The loans were cited as a waste of "taxpayers' funds" to win votes for the New Deal.

A traffic problem equal to that of a city the size of Cleveland faces the managers of the World's Fair and an elaborate transportation system is being devised to meet it, according to a statement issued yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation.

Assured by up-State party leaders that he would have a plurality of 600,000 votes outside of New York City and that this margin might climb to 800,000, William F. Bleakley, Republican candidate for Governor, yesterday planned a week of intensive stumping in the metropolitan area which will begin to day.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 25. -- Cardinal Pacelli, Papal Secretary of State, received the honorary degree of doctor of letters from the University of Notre Dame today. The ceremony took place at a special convocation in Washington Hall, which was decorated in gold and blue.
Cardinal Pacelli and party left Roosevelt Field, L.I., in a chartered Boeing two-motor transport plane of the United Airlines at 10:07 yesterday morning on a transcontinental tour.

LISBON, Portugal, Oct. 25 (AP). -- Madrid is quite safe from attack for a time through the Guadarrama Mountains, a Spanish Rebel general was quoted today as having asserted. The reason is the 6,000 troops under the leadership of the veteran General Julio Mangada.

Almost 200 of the 477 building projects undertaken by the Public Works Administration in this State are complete and in use, according to a report made public yesterday by Arthur S. Tuttle, State PWA director. One hundred others are in final construction stages and the rest are progressing according to schedule.

With full military honors, funeral services were held yesterday afternoon for Colonel William R. Wright, Chief of Staff of the Twenty-seventh Division, N.Y.N.G., in the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Ninetieth Street and Fifth Avenue.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 25. -- After a day of violence and excitement such as Brussels has not witnessed for years, order was restored late tonight, but precautions are being increased because of fear of a renewal of disturbances tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25. -- A successful penalty kick by Gauol Machlis five minutes after the start of the second half enabled the touring Maccabee soccer team from Tel Aviv, Palestine, to defeat the Illinois All- Stars, 1 to 0, today at Comiskey Park.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 25. -- The Yugoslav Government, this correspondent is able to reveal, is on the point of throwing in its lot with Germany and Italy against France and the other democratic governments in Europe unless its aims of an armed neutrality for the Balkans can be assured.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Oct. 25. -- Capturing blues in both the lightweight and open classes, the Wynfromere Farms' chestnut gelding Speedy, ridden by Miss Helen Bedford, was adjudged the champion hunter at the trials of the Fairfield County Hunt Club today on the Alfred G. Alien estate.

SARATOGA BATTLEFIELD, N.Y., Oct. 25. -- Governor Lehman joined today with Count Jerzy Potocki, Polish Ambassador to the United States, in dedicating a monument to Thaddeus Kosciusko, on the site of one of the triumphs of the Polish general in the War of the Revolution.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 25. -- Leo Kieran reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES and the North American Newspaper Alliance, arrived at Newark Airport on a United Airlines plane at 9:07 o'clock this morning. He traveled from there to the Times Building in a United Airlines bus, arriving in Times Square at 10:50:44 A.M., -- 24 days, 14 hours and 20 minutes after starting on his round-the-world journey.

Assets of the Kreuger Toll Company in this country now amount to $2,500,000 in cash, with the definite expectation of $475,000 additional, and claims against the estate are reduced to $95,370,755, according to the intermediate report of Edward S. Greenbaum, trustee in bankruptcy, filed with Harold P. Coffin, referee, and made public yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25. -- Politics and crop reports were leading factors in the world's wheat market to an unusual degree last week. Price movements were erratic and in a fair range, with the close on December and May 7/8 cent lower than the preceding week, and July 3/8 cent higher.

Mr. and Mrs. Martin Johnson explorers and wild animal photographers, returned to New York yesterday after spending a year in the jungles of Borneo, living principally on a raft in inland waterways among natives and wild beasts, in the hottest climate in the world.

LONDON, Oct. 25. -- The British Government is in possession of full details of the result of the meeting of Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister, with his German colleague, Baron Constantin von Neurath, and later at Berchtesgaden with Chancellor Adolf Hitler himself.

Solely through the efforts of Ralph Kercheval, the Brooklyn Dodgers climbed back into the National Football League winning column yesterday as the Ebbets Field invasion of the Chicago Cardinals resulted in the latter squad's sixth successive setback.

The new Corpus Christi Church and school, 121st Street, east of Broadway, was dedicated yesterday morning by Cardinal Hayes in the presence of Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler and about sixty members of the faculty of Columbia University and several colleges of the city.

I ended the first all-scheduled demonstration of around-the-world high-speed transport yesterday morning at Times Square after a record-breaking trip from Honolulu to Newark Airport over scheduled airlines in 39 hours 20 minutes and 15 seconds for the 5,281-mile journey.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 25. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 74 per cent of capacity, down 2 points from three weeks earlier, when tonnage output was the highest since September, 1929, with the possible exception of February, 1930, when a bulge occurred.

A one-legged gunman, clumping along on an artificial limb in frantic flight after a $500 holdup in the dry-goods store of Max Eilenberg at 23 Allen Street, near Canal Street, at 9:25 o'clock last night, was vainly aided by an accomplice, who did not desert him to run for his own freedom until the pursuing crowd was at their heels.

ROME, Oct. 25. -- The final communique issued after Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano's conversation with Chancellor Adolf Hitler has not come up to Italian expectations. It has disappointed the hopes of every one here that it would contain some positive information about what had been accomplished in the meeting between Premier Benito Mussolini's envoy and the German dictator.

PARIS, Oct. 24. -- That there should have been speculators who sold francs short or even persons who actually sent gold abroad is not surprising, considering the feeling of pessimism which appeared and swept over the Bourse in the recent currency crisis.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- Showing an increase of 13.6 per cent over August, the value of sales in September on all registered securities exchanges was $1,882,282,523, according to a summary made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25. -- By the slim margin of one goal England retained its top ranking in women's field hockey today. Before 7,000 wildly cheering enthusiasts at the Philadelphia Cricket Club, the cardinal-clad English touring eleven defeated the All-America team, 5 to 4.

BERLIN, Oct. 24. -- Before the appointment as raw materials dictator of Hermann Goering only miscellaneous bureaus for the carrying out of the raw materials policy existed -- in the hands of Wilhelm Keppler, Chancellor Hitler's personal deputy -- and this sometimes impeded the Minister of Economics, Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, even in his proper domains.

GREAT RIVER, L.I., Oct. 25. -- Nicholas Pinto, State chairman of the Columbian Republican League, and an array of Italian-Americans attacked the New Deal administration this afternoon for its policy toward Italy during the recent conflict with Ethiopia at a mass meeting at the Timber Point clubhouse of the Suffolk County Republican Committee.
Here is Leo Iieran' expense account of his trip around the world by established' commercial facilities, open to any traveler:

KEARNY, N.J., Oct. 25. -- The tenth annual pilgrimage of the faithful to the Shrine of the Sacred Heart at the Catholic Protectory for Boys was held here today. The colorful demonstration of faith, in which more than 2,000 Catholics from Northern New Jersey and New York took part, was held in conjunction with the celebration of the feast of Christ the King and the commencement of the forty hours adoration of the blessed sacrament.
The eleventh annual world's championship rodeo climaxed the most successful series in its history at the Madison Square Garden last night before a capacity attendance of more than 16,000 persons.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP). -- Preparing for a strenuous campaign finale, President Roosevelt spent a quiet Sunday at the White House, resting and touching up his final speeches.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25. -- Jack Manders's accurate toe preserved the Chicago Bears' perfect record today, accounting for six of the points by which the National Football League leaders defeated the Detroit Lions, defending champions, by 12 to 10, at Wrigley Field.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25. -- Jewish leaders of the United States and Canada, meeting here today as the Plan and Scope Committee for the 1936 National Campaign of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, were informed that $2,374,062, more than double the funds collected during 1935, has been raised so far, with 937 communities recorded to date.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 25. -Fassifern Farm was the scene of many luncheon parties today. The drive through the mountains, which are now a riot of color, was a great incentive.

An erratic movement in the French franc on Thursday which carried it down to 4.60 1/2 cents, a new low since devaluation, stood out as the only change of importance in the foreign currency market last week.

The American Choral and Festival Alliance announced yesterday the opening of a competition for American composers for "a choral drama of distinction," a prize of $500 to be awarded to the winner. The judges are to be Eugene Goossens, conductor of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra;

WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 25. -- After capturing the Walter P. Chrysler Trophy last Sunday at Deepdale, the Meadow Brook Club's formidable golf team returned to its home links' today and triumphed in the annual Fall interclub matches with Piping Rock, Nassau and Rockaway Hunting.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 25. -Dr. Douglas C. MacIntosh, Professor of Theology in the Yale Divinity School, said today in an open communication on the dropping of Professor Jerome Davis from the faculty that evidence indicated to his mind that economic views expressed by Professor Davis in a book, "Capitalism and Its Culture," figured among the underlying causes of failure to renew his contract.

Craftsmen of the American Museum of Natural History are preparing to carve in bold relief the skeletons of prehistoric creatures from the sandstone where they lay buried for ages on the site of the Dinosaur National Monument in Northeastern Utah, Dr. Barnum Brown, curator of fossil reptiles, announced yesterday.

TAMPA, Fla., Oct. 25. -- A band of fifteen men broke up with fists and guns a campaign meeting of Earl Browder, Communist candidate for President, on a vacant lot near the business section here today.
The New York branch of the Gilbert and Sullivan Society of London, just formed, held its first meeting last night at the English-Speaking Union, 19 West Forty-fourth Street.

LONDON, Oct. 23. -- Gold is being redistributed under the inducements and protection afforded by the tripartite agreement. In this connection it may be assumed that exports of gold to the United States largely represent movement of capital, but whether it arises from working exchange funds or other factors cannot be determined accurately.

LONDON, Oct. 23. -- Buoyancy continued this week to dominate the security markets here, although the tone was restrained in some groups and quite of boom proportion in others. The fortnightly settlement, just concluded, was the heaviest in several years.

Controller Frank J. Taylor, in a statement issued from his office yesterday, expressed his opposition to the proportional representation plan linked with the proposed new city charter. It is to be voted upon separately at the polls on Nov. 3. Mr. Taylor did not express his views on the charter itself.

David A. Clarkson, in a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES, gives twenty reasons why he no longer favors Mr. Roosevelt for President. Reason 18: "Because our banks are literally stuffed with government I O U's forced upon them in return for credit entries with which to flush the maw of inefficiency and partisan graft," can now be easily checked up against actual conditions.

The two hits among the town's new plays face each other across Forty-fifth Street -- "Tovarich" at the Plymouth and the Kaufman-Ferber "Stage Door" at the Music Box. For the latter play seems to have joined the hallowed circle.

BERLIN, Oct. 24. -- German financial circles discuss prospects of the Presidential election in the United States with reserve. The newspapers, although noncommittal, tend to emphasize President Roosevelt's chances of success. The contest is represented as primarily between the personal popularities of the candidates, in consequence of which the issue may depend on the mass of newly registered voters.

Young men "graduated" from Sing Sing, Great Meadow and the other State prisons who came under the jurisdiction of the State Parole Board in 1934 are making prison history. Their post-graduate careers may help to shape prison policy. In the old days parole statistics, for reasons which it is no longer worth while to dwell upon, were often hardly worth the paper on which they were printed.

Praising President Roosevelt as "the greatest President our nation has ever had," Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City yesterday criticized severely "certain prominent Democrats" who he said were "betraying" their party and trying to destroy it because they were "disgruntled."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- President Roosevelt's statements regarding taxation in his speech at Worcester last week were challenged by the Republican National Committee today with the assertion that the President's figures were at variance with those given out by the Department of Commerce and the Treasury.

John D.M. Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, sent a telegram from Chicago yesterday demanding an investigation, by the Senate committee on campaign expenditures, of the J. Edward Jones incident in New York. Mr. Hamilton's telegram was sent to Senator Augustus Lonergan, Democrat, of Connecticut.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 25. -- Captain Joe Szur took the lead among the East's scorers today, tallying four touchdowns as Canisius College swamped Brooklyn College, 58 to 0, for its fourth triumph of the season. The victors boosted their total to 167 points.

PARIS, Oct. 25. -- Strong in the knowledge that he has the Radical Socialist party solidly behind him, Premier Leon Blum in an address at Narbonne today announced his new legislative plans and lashed out against the defamers of the Popular Front program and the pessimists who are predicting its economic and financial collapse.

The following statement was issued yesterday by Nicholas M. Schenck, president of Loew's, Inc., parent corporation of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer: "Because of the many inquiries and published reports concerning Norma Shearer's plan for the future, I would like to make it clear that Norma is still gravely ill and has been for the past three weeks.

Rabbi Henry A. Schorr, a fellow Rotary Club member, paid tribute yesterday to the Rev. Dr. William H. Kephart, pastor of the North New York Congregational Church, 143d Street, near Willis Avenue, the Bronx, at services yesterday morning.

The government of the republic of Costa Rica is unable to meet fully the terms of the offer on service of its external bonds made on July 10, 1935, through the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council Inc., according to an announcement yesterday by J. Seligman Co., fiscal agents for the republic's 7 per cent bonds of 1926 due in 1951 and the 5 per cent funding bonds of 1932 due in 1951.

William Hohweisner, 40 years old, of 237-17 Eighty-eighth Avenue, Bellerose, Queens, was arrested yesterday in Jamaica magistrate's court as he was witnessing the arraignment of a boy who with his son Robert, 15, and another youth was charged with attempted holdup.

ROME, Oct. 25 (AP). -- Premier Benito Mussolini decided upon the Italo-Ethiopian war in 1933 and began his preparations then, according to Marshal Emilio de Bono, who commanded the Italian troops at the start of the war. This he reveals in his book on "The Preparation and the First Operations."

Samuel Fassler, Commissioner of Buildings for Manhattan, told members of the Talk of the Town Club last night that rehabilitation of old-law tenements offered a cheaper and more effective solution of the slum problem than new housing projects.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Oct. 25. -- The 10,833-ton steamer Cristobal Colon, owned by the Compania Transatlantica of Barcelona, Spain, ran high on a reef at East North Rock, eight miles north of Bermuda, at about 12:30 o'clock this morning.

To provide a place where the work of drama students, teachers, professionals and amateurs may have wider scope, a theatrical laboratory center at Columbia University is planned, according to an announcement yesterday by the recently organized Columbia Theatre Associates.

Unless it makes an immediate readjustment of social conditions, this country will find itself in the throes of a terroristic revolution, the Rev. Henry F. Hammer, assistant rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, predicted at high mass yesterday.
The American Labor party has been assigned to Row "E" on the State ballot by the Secretary of State, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, State campaign director.
SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Oct. 25. -- Stanley Worthington, a teacher at the Saranac Lake High School, met adventure tonight while returning from a hunting trip in the Middle Lake section.

The appointment of Edward R. Stettinius Jr., chairman of the Finance Committee of the United States Steel Corporation, to head the commerce and industry division of the United Hospitals Campaign Committee was announced yesterday by Stuart M. Crocker, campaign chairman. Mr. Stettinius will be assisted by John Sloane, president of W. J. Sloane, who will head the commerce section of the division.

BOSTON, Oct. 25 (AP). -- The Syracuse Braves, paced by Don Irwin, their player-coach, today gained their first American Football League success in six starts by defeating the Boston Shamrocks, 16 -- 7.

BERLIN, Oct. 25. -- Active cooperation in the future between Italy and Germany in many spheres of European politics and economics was forecast today by Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister. He made this prediction in a significant declaration to the German and the foreign press in Munich before he started for Rome with the diplomatic mission that had been conferring with Chancellor Adolf Hitler and other Reich officials.

The William E. McKenney Trophy for the mixed pair championship at the second annual contract bridge tournament of the American Bridge League was won last night by Mrs. Estelle Drescher and Morrie Elis with a score of 674 1/2 match points.

In hopeful anticipation of getting the approval of Santa Claus, the Toy Manufacturers of the U.S.A., Inc., will open today a two-week display of their contributions toward a rousing Christmas for young America. With his blessing, the manufacturers are exuberantly confident they will surpass last year's $2,000,000 holiday spending by 15 per cent, and of course add by so much to the happiness of the kiddies.

In speaking on Saturday night at Indianapolis on the conduct of foreign affairs, Governor LANDON was taking up a question on which he and his party are most vulnerable. Their platform is made up of contradictory planks which no candidate can reconcile. Governor LANDON, affirms that he is not an isolationist, but the policies of his party are so in the extreme.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 25. -- The Republican effort to recapture former strongholds in the industrial Middle West with the Landon-Knox ticket has been complicated no end, and in some States perhaps doomed to failure by the breaking away of the once solid Negro vote.

VIENNA, Oct. 25. -- The German colony in Vienna observed yesterday the Thanksgiving Day festival introduced by the German Nazis. The festival took place in the Vienna Concert Hall and was attended by Franz von Papen, the German Ambassador; Ernst Bohle, leader of the foreign section of the German Nazi party, and by Edmund Glaise-Horstenau, Minister without portfolio in the Austrian Cabinet, officially representing the Austrian Government.
A new burglary technique in which the leader of a youthful gang played the piano loudly while his companions ransacked apartments was revealed in Brooklyn yesterday.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 25. -- Several cocktail and luncheon parties were given today at the Casino. Frank K. Houston of New York was host at one held on the terrace for a group of fourteen, including Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Vanderbilt.

One of the questions local voters must answer when they go to the polls next week is whether they favor proportional representation for elections to the Council which, if the new charter is adopted, will replace the Board of Aldermen. The Charter Commission preserved a strictly neutral attitude on this issue.

The performance of "White Horse Inn" the night of Nov. 24 at the Center Theatre, Rockefeller Center, has been taken over by members of the board of managers of the Catholic Center for the Blind to raise funds for carrying on the charitable work of that organization.
Governor Lehman, on his return here last night from his up-State tour, was greeted by a crowd numbering nearly 10,000 when he arrived at Grand Central Terminal on the 9:35 train.

BERLIN, Oct. 24. -- Stocks were active and the Boerse was predominately firm in the first four days of this week, the stimulus being the declaration by the Secretary of State that the industrial boom is only beginning. A shortage of sellers led to sharp advances in shares which were followed, however, by decided reactions.

Another 5,000,000 of us will end up after election as super-experts in political history. Some people still insist that as Maine goes so goes the nation, and others deny it. But the problem is really much more complicated. It now turns out that Maryland has a better claim than Maine to the honor of showing the nation which way to go.

A reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES and the North American Newspaper Alliance, LEO KIERAN, has returned to Times Square 24 days 14 hours and 20 minutes after leaving it, having circled the world at nearly its greatest circumference. All but a few miles of the 22,000-mile journey was made on scheduled passenger air services on which the man in the street could likewise buy a ticket.

Of course, creation did not begin on March 4, 1933, upon which day President Roosevelt was inaugurated. But, as before Creation, there was chaos over the land. What is known as the economic, circle had shut itself up. The starting point of the circle had been quite lost.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 25 (AP). -- Green Bay's Packers passed their way to a 42-10 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates today in a National Football League game before 10,000 fans.

LONDON, Oct. 25. -- Joachim von Ribbentrop, the new German Ambassador to Great Britain, will arrive here tomorrow to take up duties that, using the mildest adjective applicable to the situation may be described as difficult.

WOODBURY, N.J., Oct. 25. -- Dr. G. Russell Atkinson, 35 years old, a dentist, of 522 Cooper Street, Camden; his wife, Frances, 32, and their 2-year-old son, G. Russell Atkinson Jr., died at the Underwood Hospital here tonight a short time after they had been injured in an automobile accident in Mullica Hill, N.J., twenty miles from Camden.

MONTREAL, Oct. 25. -- Accepting the "challenge of communism," 100,000 Roman Catholics here today pledged defense of their faith and declared themselves strongly against religious persecution throughout the world.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,459,957,300. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills. The list follows:

HONGKONG, Oct. 25. -- Chinese reports received tonight blamed a military officer for the worst railway disaster in China in recent years, in which at least sixty persons, including fifty-three soldiers, were killed.

John Charles Thomas appeared in his first local recital of the season yesterday afternoon, and the Town Hall was filled with devoted followers. There is no doubt that Mr. Thomas is one of the charmed circle of singers who have an immense public of their own.

Apparel orders subsided in the wholesale market here last week, but demand for accessories continued strong. Stores are anticipating highly satisfactory early Christmas sales of gift items. Deliveries on the wanted types of handbags, gloves, scarfs, jewelry and other holiday merchandise are promised for from three to four weeks.
MADRID, Oct. 25 (Passed by the Censor). -- Government forces today succeeded in holding in check the Rebel troops in all sectors around Madrid.

MADRID, Oct. 25 (AP). -- An American newspaper man, Henry Tilton Gorrell, of Washington, D.C., was taken prisoner today and two other newspaper men were missing following a day of fierce fighting south of this capital.

Although newspaper advertising this year will close with the highest linage since 1931, considerable ground has to be made up before the peak figure of 1929 is reached, according to comment here last week. With 1936 linage estimated to come close to the 1,400,000,000 mark, newspapers have shown a gain of some 31 per cent since the end of 1933 but are still about 35 per cent under the 1929 volume.

The current week in the galleries, if not so prolific of new exhibitions as the preceding weeks have been, includes an unusual proportion of outstanding events. It is further earmarked, incidentally, by a continued modern French invasion, a recrudescence which has been one of the noteworthy features of the early season.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 25 (AP). -- Results of a vote on the question of another maritime strike on the Pacific Coast will probably be posted tomorrow.

MARION, Va., Oct. 25. -- Four persons died almost instantly late today and a fifth succumbed a half hour later of injuries received when an airplane crashed just after taking off from Marion for Bluefield, W.Va.
IMOLA, Italy, Oct. 25 (AP). -- Premier Benito Mussolini, cheered by 70,000, expressed his hope today for "long periods of peace" -- but not for "eternal peace, which is absurd and impossible."

Tallying four touchdowns in his team's one-sided triumph over Brooklyn College yesterday, Joe Szur, captain and halfback of the Canisius College eleven, took first place among Eastern college scorers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- Improving on the lead gained the preceding day, the United States Army team today won the international military team jumping competition at the conclusion of the four-day inter-American horse show at the Meadow Brook Saddle Club.

The Metropolitan Opera Guild will hold a reception at the Metropolitan Opera House on Sunday night, Dec. 13, at which the membership will decide whether the fund raised by the guild for a special operatic project will be applied toward a cyclorama for the Metropolitan stage. This announcement was made by Mrs. August Belmont, chairman of the guild, at a meeting of the board of directors held last week at the Hotel Pierre.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 25 (AP). -- A strike order went into effect today at six plants of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company, employing about 6,000 men.

THE new novel by William Faulkner is worth all the effort required to read it. That is not faint praise. In fact, it is an almost inevitable primary statement. For Mr. Faulkner again is writing -- in Aldous Huxley's phrase -- as though the hounds were after him.

Unbeaten teams found the going quite difficult in a number of instances during the past week-end and several surprising results, which depleted the undefeated rank, were recorded as the scholastic football campaign arrived at virtually the half-way mark.

THOSE must have been setting-up exercises the collegiate gridiron athletes went through the other day. They certainly have set up a fine program for this coming Saturday. Navy-Penn, for instance. While losing to the Tigers by a touchdown, the Midshipmen actually surpassed Princeton in everything except points, punts and penalties.

LENOX, Mass., Oct. 25. -- Mrs. John Hubbard of Paris was the honored guest at a small dinner given by her brother, Harris Fahnestock, last night at Eastover, Lenox. Mr. and Mrs. R. Jay Flick and Mr. and Mrs. Christopher J. Mileham of New York were in the party.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25. -- Trade in lard here was light last week. A considerable percentage of the hogs are of light weight and the make of lard is somewhat restricted, yet stocks are said to be increasing. Shipments from Chicago last week were 2,733,000 pounds, compared with 2,235,000 pounds the previous week and 2,562,000 pounds a year ago.
The charge most frequently brought against President Roosevelt is that he is destroying individual initiative in business and stifling industry by governmental interference.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Oct. 25. -- Fine weather and a large fleet favored the opening of the Manhasset Bay dinghy season today.

The enthusiasm with which President Roosevelt was received on his recent trip through Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Connecticut has induced the directors of his campaign to look hopefully toward the capture of at least part of New England.
OCEANPORT, N.J., Oct. 25. -- Fort Jay's powerful football squad, champions of the Second Army Corps Area, defeated Fort Monmouth, 25 -- 0, in their annual game before a crowd of 3,000 today.
Frederick W. Rice Jr. is in the bond department of the Boston office of Goldman Sachs Co.

A further step in simplifying the debt structure of the Central Maine Power Company will be taken today with the offering to the public of $14,000,000 first and general mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds, Series H, due in 1966, by an underwriting group headed by the First Boston Corporation and Coffin Burr, Inc.

The Eastern division of the Republican National Committee, in a statement issued yesterday, charged President Roosevelt with making a complete misstatement of fact in his Good Neighbor League speech in connection with the workings of the social security law.

Eddy Brown, violinist, and E. Robert Schmitz, pianist, gave the first of three recitals devoted to Beethoven's sonatas for violin and piano, at Town Hall last night. All of the master's ten works of the kind are being presented in chronological order in this Sunday-night series.

The Jewish Teachers Association is opposed to the introduction into the public school system of plans whereby children would leave school for one hour or more a week to receive religious instruction in churches or synagogues, Simon J. Jason, newly elected president of the association, told delegates at their annual assembly yesterday in the Hotel Commodore.

ALBANY, Oct. 25. -- More than 320,000 persons in New York State contributed an average of 26 cents per capita to the campaign fund of $82,953.15 of the American Labor party, which is supporting the candidacy of President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman, it was announced here tonight.

A courageous hotel owner braved threats of two hold-up men at 1 A.M. yesterday and routed them by hurling a chair through the window of the lobby on the second floor of the Gramercy Hotel at Twenty-fourth Street and Lexington Avenue.

The 1936 salt-water fishing season proved, if nothing else, that we must revise our ideas about the haunts of big game fish. The sensational catches of white marlin off Ocean City, Md.; the development of giant tuna angling at Jordan's Bay and the introduction of rod- and-reel fishing for swordfish off Louisburg, N.S., revealed new and fascinating places for sport.

NAVAS DEL MARQUES, Spain, Oct. 25. -- Five six-inch batteries have been hammering all day at Leftist positions at Peguerinos while Rightist infantry is continuing to drive east toward the road junction where they are spreading north to Peguerinos and south to Santa Maria de la Alameda in the effort to capture Escorial.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- Political campaign warnings to workers that a Federal tax will be deducted from their wages starting Jan. 1 are nearly all "misleading" and fail to note that its payment will eventually result in "substantial" old-age benefit payments, the Social Security Board declared today.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 25. -Belgium's reply to the note of Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden of Britain concerning a five-power conference makes clear that the Belgian Government views with dismay the recent tendency toward the formation of rigid antagonistic blocs in Europe and is determined to hold itself aloof from them.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 25. -- In a thrilling jump-off for the chief award, Miss Patricia Townsend of Greenwich, Conn., won the $100 jumping sweepstake, the feature of the annual Fall horse show staged by the Hutchinson Riding Academy on its grounds today.

The 1936 salt-water fishing season proved, if nothing else, that we must revise our ideas about the haunts of big game fish. The sensational catches of white marlin off Ocean City, Md.; the development of giant tuna angling at Jordan's Bay and the introduction of rod- and-reel fishing for swordfish off Louisburg, N.S., revealed new and fascinating places for sport.

NAVAS DEL MARQUES, Spain, Oct. 25. -- Five six-inch batteries have been hammering all day at Leftist positions at Peguerinos while Rightist infantry is continuing to drive east toward the road junction where they are spreading north to Peguerinos and south to Santa Maria de la Alameda in the effort to capture Escorial.

Business in the United States continues to show the favorable features that have been observed in recent months, the Guaranty Trust Company says in the current issue of its monthly publication, the Guaranty Survey. The trend in the last few weeks, the bank says, has been characterized by stability and moderate seasonal expansion, rather than by sharp gains.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25. -- A most interesting situation exists in the corn market. An open interest exists in December corn of 28,700,000 bushels against 29,210,000 bushels a week ago. The total open interest of all corn futures is 53,614,000 bushels, while a week ago it was 53,035,000, and on Oct. 2 it was 54,119,000 bushels.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- Political campaign warnings to workers that a Federal tax will be deducted from their wages starting Jan. 1 are nearly all "misleading" and fail to note that its payment will eventually result in "substantial" old-age benefit payments, the Social Security Board declared today.
Attacks against communism, fascism and dictatorships generally were launched from pulpits of New York City yesterday by the clergy of different denominations.

The trend in the last few weeks, the bank says, has been characterized by stability and moderate seasonal expansion, rather than by sharp gains.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25. -- A most interesting situation exists in the corn market. An open interest exists in December corn of 28,700,000 bushels against 29,210,000 bushels a week ago. The total open interest of all corn futures is 53,614,000 bushels, while a week ago it was 53,035,000, and on Oct. 2 it was 54,119,000 bushels.
At the close of trading on the Cotton Exchange on Saturday active contracts showed losses of 24 to 28 points for the week. In the preceding week they were up 20 to 27 points.

As the site for a six-story elevator apartment house the northwest corner of the Grand Concourse and 181st Street, the Bronx, has been bought by a client of Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc., from the 88 River Corporation. The plot contains about 15,000 square feet.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 25. -- Samuel Goldwyn and Douglas Fairbanks will join forces for the production of "The Adventures of Marco Polo," which will be made with Gary Cooper and Basil Rathbone at an estimated cost of $1,500,000.

In your issue of Oct. 15 a dispatch from Columbus, Ohio, intimates that rural Ohio is strongly opposed to the New Deal. Your correspondent mentions two counties, Crawford and Butler, as expecting to return anti-New Deal majorities.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 25. -- The Cleveland Rams moved into a tie for second place in the American Professional Football League by swamping the New York Yankees, 27 -- 0, before 10,000 spectators today. Spectacular forward passes accounted for three of the four Ram touchdowns.

ON BOARD GOVERNOR LANDON'S SPECIAL TRAIN, EN ROUTE TO BALTIMORE, Oct. 25. -- On the last lap of his race for the Presidency, Governor Landon planned to continue this week his attack on the Roosevelt administration, with stress on the spoils system and waste and extravagance.

The celebration of the Feast of St. Gerasimos, patron saint of the Greek nation, who inspired his people to resist the invasion of Europe by the Turks in the fifteenth century, was held yesterday by the congregation of St. Gerasimos Greek Orthodox Church, worshipping in the St. Andrews Methodist Episcopal Church building, 122 West Seventy-sixth Street.

An advance celebration of Navy Day was held in Queens yesterday, with a memorial service and a parade in which 50,000 members of regular and reserve units of the army and navy, veterans' groups and junior organizations marched along a three-mile route on Hillside Avenue, Jamaica.

BERLIN, Oct. 25. -- The German people are to be compelled with "loving force" to read books of National Socialist authors, State Councillor Hans Johst, President of the Reich Chamber of Literature, announced today at a celebration in Weimar in honor of Book Week.

With its usual quota of surprising scores and unexpected results, another Saturday of intercollegiate football moved into the record pages over the past week-end and left behind an atmosphere somewhat cleared, so far as the mythical championships are concerned.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25. -- In the nine days before the election the most intensive efforts of the Republican National Committee and the State organizations in pivotal industrial States will be devoted to driving home the party's contention that the Social Security Act will force a reduction in workers' pay.

Klaus Mann, son of Thomas Mann, novelist, and himself a novelist and publicist, declared in an address yesterday morning before the Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street, that it was not possible for France and Germany to be friendly so long as one of the States remained Fascist.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25. -- Speculative trading in oats here was limited last week largely to hedging by local, Northwestern and cereal interests, with a little general speculative trade. Prices moved in a range of about 1 cent between the high and the low.

Officers and directors of St. Timothy's League have taken over a pre-opening performance of "Matrimony Pfd.," a new play with Grace George in the leading role, on the night of Nov. 10 at the Playhouse to raise funds for the league.

Passenger lines operating between New York and the Channel ports and London will make Summer rules for traffic effective on ships leaving this port during April and early May in order to accommodate a maximum of persons en route to the coronation of King Edward.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25. -- Prices of hogs declined 15 cents on last Friday and were only 10 cents a hundredweight above the low level for 1936. Increased marketing of pigs and light weight hogs had a depressing influence on the market last week.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 25. -- The outcome of the State and national elections in this State has been determined in the past by the balance between the total vote in New York City, with its normally huge Democratic majority, and the vote in the vast territory north of the Bronx boundary line and in the two populous counties on Long Island, which normally is predominantly Republican.

The Blue Ridge Corporation reported yesterday that its net assets on Sept. 30 amounted to $47,933,195, equal to $111.07 for each share of preference stock outstanding and, after allowing for the preference stock at 855 a share and accrued dividend, to $3.21 a share of common stock outstanding.

Comments on the Presidential campaign were made in pulpits throughout New York City yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Christian F. Reisner, pastor of the Broadway Temple Methodist Church, at 174th Street, said in his evening sermon:

The place for the real Christian is not the farm or the cloister, but the city, where there is the most sin and the most sorrow, the Rev. Dr. George Caleb Moor, pastor of the Madison Avenue Baptist Church, at Thirty-first Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 24. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 84, which compares with 83.9 the week before, 83.8 two weeks before, 84.1 three weeks before and 84 four weeks before.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 25. -- An all-star cast of Crimson skippers, including one former junior champion, two interscholastic champions and two Sears Bowl runners-up gained revenge for past yachting indignities today by defeating dinghy sailing teams from M.I.T., Brown and Dartmouth on the Charles River.

The controversy over the standing and prestige and principles of the various branches of the Roosevelt family was revived yesterday by the Republican National Committee, as a result of a speech by Democratic Senator Vic Donahey of Ohio, in which Senator Donahey likened Theodore Roosevelt to Franklin D. Roosevelt.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 26. -- The report here concerning Gertrude Michael, ill in Doctors Hospital in New York, is that she will return within two weeks to star in Bret Harte's "Outcasts of Poker Flat," with Preston Foster and Owen Davis Jr. Camera work is set to start at RKO Dec. 1.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 26. -In this region of lush dairy farms and, in more recent years, of progressive Republicanism, the Landon boom is said to have found for the first time in this State and in the East political soil where it could take root and flourish.

Although twenty-one names were lopped off the list during the past week, thirty-five college football teams of assorted sizes and strength remain undefeated and untied. One newcomer, Kalamazoo College of Michigan, found its way into The Associated Press records.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 26. -- Maryland, wherein reside many of the 116,000 Federal Washington jobholders, is classed as definitely Democratic by even many Republican observers. These say that the visit of Governor Landon solidified the Republican ranks but failed to cut the lead held by President Roosevelt as shown in The Baltimore Sun poll.
BILBAO, Spain, Oct. 26. -- The situation here daily grows more critical.

Charles L. Craig, former Controller of the City of New York, who died suddenly at Sacramento, Calif., on Aug. 1935, left a gross estate of $20,116, all of which was absorbed by debts, according to an accounting filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday by John A. Miller, attorney for Mrs. May Josephine Craig, widow and executor of the estate.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 26 (AP). -- Preparations to change the present rigid tenure law for New York State teachers were made today by members of the New York State School Boards Association at their annual convention.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 26 (AP). -- Calling the New Deal "a crazy quilt of broken promises and demagogic delusions," Representative Bertrand H. Snell tonight declared that the campaign against it was "a crusade to protect your home, your church, constitutional government and American liberties."

RIVERHEAD, N.Y., Oct. 26. -- The Suffolk County Board of Supervisors adopted a resolution today transferring the administration of home relief back to the County Welfare Department. The resolution, which was presented by Supervisor Warren F. Greenhalgh of Islip, chairman of the board, was adopted by a vote of six to four.

Deaths from automobile accidents in New York City last week decreased 50 per cent compared with the corresponding week in 1935, it was disclosed in a report made public yesterday by Harold Fowler, First Deputy Police Commissioner in charge of traffic. Over the weekend there were seven fewer deaths this year than in the corresponding two days of 1955.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP). -- Large profits accruing from the sale of warrants issued in connection with the formation of the National Investors Corporation of Detroit were described today to the Securities and Exchange Commission by Fred Y. Presley, president of the corporation.

BOSTON, Oct. 26. -- John B. Erskine motored from Chicago to Commonwealth Pier "just to say hello" to Edith Henderson, daughter of a Dominican planter, after learning that the girl, whom he met in South America two years ago, was aboard the Canadian National steamship Lady Nelson, due to stop at Boston this morning.
I listened to the President's speech last night with considerable interest, but was amazed at his attempts to create impressions that were questionable.

HAVANA, Oct. 26. -- Officers of the Spanish liner Manuel Arnus, which arrived here yesterday from Barcelona en route to Mexico, appealed today to Cuban authorities for protection of their lives and denounced the crew as insubordinate.

Denouncing as falsehoods the charges that the Spanish Government is communistic or that it has persecuted Catholics, speakers representing it swayed an audience of 19,000 persons to enthusiasm in Madison Square Garden last night at the first of a series of mass meetings under the sponsorship of the North American Committee to Aid Spanish Democracy.

As a further step in the refinancing program of the Southern Indiana Gas and Electric Company, designed to simplify its capital structure and to reduce interest charges and preferred dividend requirements, there will be offered to the public today 85,895 shares of the company's 4.8 per cent preferred stock of an aggregate par value of $8,589,500.

Ambrose V. McCall, Assistant Attorney General, announced yesterday that Supreme Court Referee John Caldwell Myers had signed an injunction restraining the Life Extension Institute, Inc., 25 West Forty-third Street, "from making physical examinations, diagnosing physical conditions and from practicing medicine by any means or method, whether through the agency of licensed physicians or otherwise."

Miss Frances Gordon, who heads the debutante committee working for the success of the Russian students' ball to be held Nov. 13 at the Plaza, gave a tea yesterday at her home at River House for a group of younger members of society aiding in the plans for the ball.

Newbold Morris, Republican candidate for President of the Board of Aldermen, began a campaign tour of Queens and Brooklyn yesterday by invading the home territory of his Democratic opponent, Sheriff William F. Brunner of Queens.

BOSTON, Oct. 26. -- Even though Noel Coward's Boston debut at the Colonial Theatre tonight was apparently the signal for the onset of Winter, the audience that welcomed "Tonight at 8:30," starring Mr. Coward and Gertrude Lawrence, was as warm in its enthusiasm as the breezes on Tremont Street were cold.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- Because amended petitions will be necessary to bring into evidence two affidavits which the plaintiffs sought unsuccessfully to introduce today, it became apparent in Federal District Court here that the suit of Walter E. Edge and four other New Jersey Republicans to force Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, to disclose names and salaries of administrative employes on State WPA rolls would not be heard until after the election.

" The New Deal's inept experimentation and ineffectual handling of the depression have left the United States with nearly twice as many jobless men and women as the rest of the civilized world," the Republican National Committee charged in a statement issued here yesterday.

PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 26 (AP). -- Attorney General Homer Cummings defended the administration's fiscal, policies tonight with an assertion that President Roosevelt resorted to the nation's remaining asset, Federal credit, when "our whole system was on the verge of collapse" and turned "a tragic hour into a national triumph."

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 26. -- Dartmouth's football team started its drive for the annual Yale game today under the worst practice conditions possible, a driving snow storm curtailing the work to a half hour.

BERLIN, Oct. 26. -- The Italo-German accord announced yesterday is acclaimed in the German press with moderation, and the lack of signs of irritation abroad is cited as indicating improvement in international diplomatic and editorial behavior.
