SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 26 (AP). -- Representatives of 37,000 Pacific Coast maritime workers announced today a strike would be called Wednesday midnight unless "fundamental issues" were settled.
BERLIN, Oct. 26 (AP). -- The Reichbank's statement as of Oct. 23 shows the following changes from the preceding week in thousands of marks:

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 26. -- The curtain was rung down on the 1936 Westchester tournament season today over the Broadmoor Golf Club's links as the Professional Golfers Association staged its final one-day event under most trying weather conditions.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 26. -- Declaring that the reciprocity policies of the Roosevelt administration are the most important step taken in a decade to aid American business, Joseph P. Tumulty, who was secretary to President Wilson, asserted tonight that the only alternative to these policies is economic isolation for the United States.

Wild-life conservation would be greatly enlightened if the public in general and hunters, farmers and mosquito control men in particular were informed of the existence of a sensitive balance in nature which is immediately upset by the destruction of a species of natural organisms.

Horses belonging to the British and Irish teams, which will compete in the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden starting a week from tomorrow and continuing through Nov. 10, arrived yesterday aboard the American Merchant liner American Trader.

The irrelevance of a horse player is advanced as pure reasoning when the horse wins, but yesterday was a difficult afternoon for those who point to the No. 1 post position as a place from which there is no chance.
Store leases continue to lead the way in an active Fall commercial renting market. Among the contracts for space reported yesterday were several involving home decoration and furnishing concerns.

TALAVERA DE LA REINA, Spain, Tuesday, Oct. 27 (AP). -- A strong government counter-attack on Navalcarnero was repulsed by Rebel troops only after an all-day battle yesterday, said reports reaching here early today.

Paulie Walker, veteran welterweight from Trenton, held Andre Jessurun of Washington Heights to a draw in the feature eight-round bout at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. A crowd of 2,500 spectators saw Walker, a short-ender in the betting at 4 to 1, hold his rugged rival even.

One of your correspondents exults at the "overdue demise of the canard linking President Roosevelt to elements reported to be seeking the destruction of fundamental American institutions." Canard: "Sensational or absurd story; newspaper hoax."

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 26. -- Award of a $500 prize to Franklin D. Hayes, a freshman at Worcester Polytechnic Institute, for a contrivance which he designed to save unnecessary footsteps, was announced today by Admiral Ralph Earle, president of the college.

Fordham's football forces received no time off for good behavior yesterday, but buckled down to hard work in preparation for Saturday's struggle with the ferocious Pitt Panthers. The kind-hearted Jim Crowley would have preferred to have given his young men a day's holiday for the magnificent job they did against St. Mary's over the week-end, but that was manifestly impossible.
Few deals in urban realty were reported yesterday. The foreclosure auction rooms also were comparatively inactive, with two properties each in Manhattan and Bronx bid in by mortgagees.

Any excess optimism that might have been engendered among City College's football players by last Saturday's unexpected 6-0 triumph over Drexel was promptly dispelled by Coach Benny Friedman yesterday as work started at Lewisohn Stadium in preparation for next Saturday's Ebbets Field contest with Manhattan College.

Governor Landon in his statement of Oct. 22 revives the Hoover cry of a balanced budget. He said, "We Republicans believe that if our form of government is to endure, the budget must be balanced and a pay-as-you-go tax policy adopted."

J. Waller in his letter to THE TIMES states that he has received not "one circular attempting to influence (his) vote" such as the President stated Wall Street was spending stockholders' and bondholders' money to circulate.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices m New York City:

Sea power -- as MAHAN, its great apostle, explained so brilliantly -- means far more than majestic fighting ships and the men who man them. Implicit in the term are the intangibles of life upon blue water: morale, training, discipline, the ties that bind men to the sea and to the naval service, without which ships and guns are nothing.

Tony Lornardo, 58 years old, admitted with a shrug in Coney Island Court yesterday that what the policeman said was true; he was peddling bananas in a restricted area. He also admitted he had done it on other occasions; said he had to, to support his family.

BARCELONA, Spain, Oct. 26. -- Fierce fighting has been going on for several days for possession of Tardienta, one of the government's principal bases of attack against Huesca, in the Aragon sector, about 145 miles northwest of Barcelona. The Rebels sent a great force against Tardienta, which is about thirteen miles south of Huesca, but, according to government reports, the Insurgents were repulsed.

A broad decline in secondary and convertible corporation issues was the outstanding development in trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The decline spread over a broad list of corporate loans, the profit-taking and liquidation receiving impetus from the general weakness in the share market.

YONKERS, Oct. 26. -- Invading the home territory of his Republican rival for speeches here and in Peekskill and Mount Vernon tonight, Governor Lehman condemned in sharp terms the silence of William F. Bleakley on aggressive public utility regulation and declared it obviously indicated opposition to such a program.

There's been much hysteria from above about taxes; but a calm comparison with per capita taxes in any other country about whose alleged recovery some are talking reveals ours as lowest; yet we receive more services for our taxes. It is of some concern to many thoughtful people that a very great proportion of our taxes are due to past and future wars.

Columbia started aiming yesterday for its annual encounter with Cornell at Baker Field on Saturday with players and coaches firmly resolved to put the Blue back in winning form. The session that Coach Lou Little ordered was the most intensive Monday drill the Morningsiders have experienced this Fall.

This is the Federal Theatre Project's big night, when the John C. Moffitt-Sinclair Lewis dramatization of the latter's "It Can't Happen Here" opens in almost a score of cities across the land. Over twenty productions of the play are to be given simultaneously, with three of them in New York, a fourth in Newark and another in Yonkers.
The coldest weather so far this Fall arrived last night on a gale that sent the mercury steadily downward toward the first freezing weather of the season here.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 26. -- Determined to lose no time in getting the Yale squad ready for the Dartmouth game in the Bowl Saturday, Head Coach Ducky Pond sent the unbeaten Elis through a long scrimmage today, deviating from the usual Monday procedure.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- In reply to statements regarding the Social Security Law which employers have been reported as placing in pay envelopes, President William Green of the American Federation of Labor today sent a letter to all affiliated bodies advising them of the purposes of the act; that contributions are made by employers as well as employes and that the wage-earners of the nation will get pensions through the act.

Critics are condemning our great President because they maintain his performances do not square with his promises -- do not coincide with the planks of the 1932 Democratic platform. How could he comply with such pledges when confronted with a condition, not a theory, due to the extraordinary gravity of the situation?

TALAVERA DE LA REINA, Spain, Oct. 26. -- The Insurgent forces advancing on Madrid took into custody a British military attache to Madrid, the manager of the Anglo-South American bank in that city and three newspaper correspondents who had been with the government troops.

The General Motors Corporation's net profit for the quarter ended on Sept. 30 was $34,626,078, equal to 75 cents a share on the average number of shares outstanding, it was announced yesterday by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president. This is the largest profit made by the corporation for the third quarter of a year since 1929, when the net profit was $79,266,639, equal to $1.58 a share.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 26. -- Newspaper advertising was praised here today by T.J. Strickler of Kansas City, chairman of the committee on national advertising in the American Gas Association.
CHICAGO, Oct. 26. -- John D.M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, replied today to James Roosevelt's reiterated Kansas school charges.

Because he is two months under the legal age at which he can be considered capable of committing a crime, no action was taken in the District Attorney's office yesterday against 6-year-old Thomas Delaney in the fatal shooting last Sunday of his cousin, John Michael, 4, in the home of the godmother of the dead boy at 325 East 120th Street.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 26. -- With B squad men using Colgate plays the Army varsity was put through a 45-minute drill today in preparation for the contest with the Red Raiders here Saturday.

All residents of New York State will be called upon to answer that question when they go to the polls next week. They have had little guidance from the usual sources: the rival platforms are silent on the subject, campaign speakers have had nothing illuminating to say about it, civic bodies have given it only casual or belated consideration.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26. -- Directors of Sears, Roebuck Co. today approved three financial steps, two of which were taken to meet problems created by the new Federal tax on undistributed earnings. The measures approved by the directors were:

The address by Secretary of the Interior Ickes yesterday afternoon at the dedication of the new chemistry building of Howard University at Washington, D.C., was not broadcast locally by Station WABC of the Columbia Broadcasting Systern because it conflicted with a scheduled fifteen-minute program under the auspices of the Republican National Committee.

Stockholders of Interstate Department Stores, Inc., at their annual meeting here yesterday approved compensation contracts with three members of the executive committee. The vote was 127,000 shares out of 216,762 outstanding.

ON BOARD GOVERNOR LANDON'S SPECIAL TRAIN en Route to Philadelphia, Oct. 26. -- On his way to Philadelphia today Governor Landon spoke in drenching rain to an enthusiastic crowd of about 3,000 outside the Mount Royal railroad station in Baltimore and to about the same number from the rear platform of his private car at Wilmington, home of the du Pont family, principal financial supporters of the American Liberty League.
DAYTON, Ohio, Oct. 26 (AP). -- Colonel Frank Knox, Republican Vice Presidential nominee, told Ohio labor tonight that "its best interests" lay with the Republican party.

LONDON, Oct. 26. -- Specialties were active today on the Stock Exchange, but the list as a whole was irregular. British Government issues weakened on disappointing results of the new Aberdeen municipal loan.

Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, reported yesterday 14 new cases of diphtheria for the week ended last Saturday. This was an increase of 3 cases over the previous week. Although only one death from that disease has been reported in the last nine weeks, Dr. Rice again urged that every child under 6 be immunized at once.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Oct. 26 (AP). -- The fourth and fifth races, co-featured on today's rainy-day card at Narragansett Park went to Mrs. E.A. Rotelli's Bluebeard and Mrs. Ethel V. Mars's Sangreal, respectively. Both races were at six furlongs for 3-year-olds and upward.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- Assurance that test cases on the constitutionality of the Wagner Labor Relations Act would be decided at the present term was given today by the Supreme Court through acceptance of The Associated Press and Washington, Virginia Maryland Coach Company lawsuits for argument at unnamed dates, but probably in December.

The orchestra of the National Orchestral Association, directed by Leon Barzin, opened its season at Carnegie Hall last night. Guy Maier and Lee Pattison were the soloists in Sowerby's Ballad for two pianos and orchestra. A group of sixteen voices from the St. Cecilia Club assisted in the infrequently performed "Sirenes," the last of the three Debussy Nocturnes that were played last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- The Maritime Commission today took over administration of the new Ship Subsidy Act and its first action was to send identical telegrams to both parties involved in the marine controversy on the Pacific Coast.

The first festival of Pan-American Chamber Music will be held in Mexico, D.F., from July 7 to 27, it was announced yesterday. In connection with the plan a prize of $500 has been set up for a new string quartet, the winning work to receive its first performance at the festival.

Mrs. Elsie Hirst Weidhass, who explained that her husband was a secretary of the Metropolitan Opera and Real Estate Company, 150 West Fortieth Street, asked the Missing Persons Bureau yesterday to aid her in a search for her brother, John William Hirst Jr., missing for twenty-two years.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- Ocean City, N.J., lost today in the Supreme Court in its effort to escape payment of $250,000 on a tax anticipation note issued by the city and held by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia. The tribunal refused to review a decision against the city by the Circuit Court of Appeals at Philadelphia.
With half the season still to go, already the decimation in the ranks of the major powers has been such that only nine in this category the country over have survived with perfect records.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- An unusual posthumous tribute to the late Senator Couzens of Michigan was paid by President Roosevelt today with the release of part of a letter written by him on Sept. 17, offering to Mr. Couzens the chairmanship of the new Maritime Commission.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP). -- As the major parties moved into the last week of the Presidential campaign today, Congressional records showed that together they had already spent about $9,016,973, more than twice the cost of the entire 1932 campaign.

President Roosevelt and Governor Landon will both arrive in New York City tomorrow in the final week of their campaigns. The police have made elaborate plans to escort the candidates of the two major parties about the city and have announced their itineraries in order that citizens may turn out to give both a welcome.

About 200 students of Columbia University have formed a new campus organization known as the Columbia Blue Shirts, with the principal object of combating radicalism at the university, it was learned yesterday.

Members of the du Pont family, J.P. Morgan and Alfred P. Sloan Jr. were listed as substantial contributors to the Republican county campaign funds in New York City, in preliminary statements of contributions filed yesterday with the Board of Elections.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., Oct. 26. -- Mr. and Mrs. Percy L. Hance gave a dinner tonight in the Rustic Room at Kate's Mountain Lodge for Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Bradley, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Turtle, Mr. and Mrs. E.E. Caldwell and George T. Johnson.

PLANDOME, L.I., Oct. 26. -- Jim Barnes, veteran professional at the Crescent Athletic Club, teamed with Charles H. Mayo Jr. of the Lido Country Club to turn in a fine 33 -- 31 -- 64 and win the final Long Island P.G. A. pro-amateur golf tournament of the season today at the Plandome Golf Club.

Pre-election uncertainty in the financial district was reflected yesterday in the sharpest decline registered by the stock market in more than two months. Losses ranged from 1 to 6 points as uneasy speculators sought to unload and found a thin demand for stocks.

Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State Chairman, announced yesterday that a State-wide canvass of the vote in New York had been completed by the organization, and that it showed Governor Landon would carry New York State by 250,000. It is the first State-wide canvass undertaken by the State committee since 1928, Mr. Eaton said.

Most young people in this country find communism boring, its activities dreary and pointless, and the "bad manners" of its exponents repellent, Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase informed the council of New York University yesterday in his third annual report as chancellor.

The lowest interest rate on record for an offering of New York City serial bonds was obtained yesterday by Controller Frank J. Taylor when he sold a $30,000,000 issue maturing in from one to five years to J.P. Morgan Co. on an interest basis of 1.1176 per cent.

Louis (Lepke) Buchalter and Jacob (Gurrah Jake) Shapiro, who have been subjects of recent investigations by Thomas E. Dewey, special State prosecutor, were placed on trial yesterday before Federal Judge John C. Knox and a jury on charges of racketeering in the $10,000,000-a-year rabbit skin trade during 1932 and 1933.

Price changes were mixed in generally active trading yesterday on the local commodity futures markets. Sugar, silk and wooltops were stronger, while coffee, cocoa, hides and copper declined. On the cash markets, wheat, corn, rye, butter, silk and wooltops advanced, with oats, lard, tin and cotton lower.

Three youths who went squirrel hunting in a wooded section of the Bronx on Sunday were held yesterday on charges of felonious assault, accused of wounding another boy who reproached them. The wounded boy, Benedict De Francisco, 14 years old, of 4,145 Wilder Avenue, the Bronx, is in Fordham Hospital with a shattered right thigh bone which may make him permanently lame.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 26. -- Harvard had little luck in the Dartmouth game except that its first-string players came through without injury. Saturday night both Roberts, the left halfback, passer and kicker, and Wilson, quarterback, were nursing bumps which appeared to be more than inconsequential.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26. -- Domestic wheat markets made a poor response today to the strength in Liverpool and Winnipeg, but sufficient buying developed on the Board of Trade to lift prices 1/8 to 1/2 cent a bushel above Saturday's finish with the December showing the most strength.

Skippers of motor cruisers, wind-jammers and auxiliaries finally came to anchor last night to signalize the end of the 1936 boating season with the traditional annual meeting and ceremonies of the Naval Architects and Yacht Brokers Association at the Yale Club.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- The United States has greatly reduced its dependence upon foreign sources of glycerine notwithstanding a rapidly increasing consumption, but has not yet attained self-sufficiency in the product, the Department of Commerce reported today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 (AP). -- As solemnly as a man testifying under oath, Lynn Waldorf gave his Northwestern eleven a chance today of doing the "impossible" -- a chance of upsetting mighty Minnesota Saturday.

Ernst Victor Wolff, who made his Town Hall debut as a solo recitalist yesterday afternoon, is one of the gifted, serious musicians for whom Nazi Germany had no place. He is a distinct asset to this country's musical life -- both as performer and scholar.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26. -- Inclement weather, which has held off considerately for all the matches of the international field hockey tournament at the Philadelphia Cricket Club this past week, arrived in time to spoil the conference guests' visit to Valley Forge, picnic and sightseeing trip today.

Mrs. Catherine Dodman, 50 years old, was killed; her son, Thomas, 20, and an aunt, Mrs. Mary Flood, 80, were overcome by smoke, and another son, Gerald, 17, received a broken left arm during a fire early yesterday in a three-story brownstone dwelling at 454 Marion Street, Brooklyn.
Performances of last Saturday were reviewed and hopes for coming clashes revealed yesterday by local football coaches at the weekly luncheon of the Football Writers' Association at the Lincoln Hotel.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 26 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin tonight called Franklin D. Roosevelt the "scab President" and termed him "the greatest employer of scab labor in all history."
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 26. -- Tom Hamilton surprised his Navy charges this afternoon by giving them a complete rest before starting work tomorrow.
Opposition to the proposed city charter, actively led by the five county Democratic organizations, was voiced yesterday by John Timlin, chairman of the Richmond County Republican Committee.

The French film edition of "Les Miserables" will have its American premiere at 2:30 P.M. today at the Cinema de Paris. The film was directed by Raymond Bernard and has as its chief players Harry Baur, Charles Vanel, Henry Krauss, Georges Mauloy, Petite Gaby Triquet, Max Dearly and Marguerite Moreno.
Railway transport is indispenslable to the marketing of fruits and vegetables, according to an address !by Aubrey Milam of Green I Milam, Atlanta, Ga., before the Southeast shippers' advisory board.
Subdued excitement was apparent in the staff of the Murray Hill Hotel yesterday as a four-room suite was being prepared for Governor Landon, scheduled to reach New York tomorrow.

A radio program in which Mayor LaGuardia had been announced as a speaker on a coast-to-coast hook-up under the auspices of groups seeking the reelection of President Roosevelt was changed last night by the substitution of Dr. Mary McLeod Bethune of Washington, for the Mayor.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 26. -- Legislative compromises on the Merchant Marine Act of 1936 have prevented wholesale revival of American shipping by limiting government subsidies to "cases where foreign advantage is already entrenched," Senator Copeland of New York said tonight in an address before the Middle West Foreign Trade and Merchant Marine Conference.

George Emlen Roosevelt Jr., 18 years old, and a distant relative of the President, was arrested at about 10:30 o'clock last night on a charge of disorderly conduct for refusing to pay a 50-cent taxicab fare on a trip between two night clubs.

DUBLIN, Irish Free State, Tuesday, Oct. 27. -- Lashed by a howling gale, the 7,430-ton liner American Shipper rode at anchor in Dublin Bay early today with twenty-two passengers anxiously awaiting daylight to be put ashore.

OMAHA, Oct. 26. -- How a Nebraska district judge and his son had themselves incarcerated as "convicts" in the penitentiary at Fort Madison, Iowa, for three weeks to study penal conditions at close range became known today.

LONDON, Oct. 26. -- The Cunard-White Star Line announced tonight that Benjamin Wistar Morris, New York architect of the firm of Morris O'Connor, had been retained as a consultant on the decorations of the projected new sister ship to the Queen Mary.
ALBANY, Oct. 26. -- Reports of receipts and expenditures of various campaign committees were filed with the Secretary of State today.

The police check of registration irregularities, scheduled to be completed this week, has so far resulted in the issuance of 457 warrants for the arrests of illegal registrants, Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine said yesterday. Last year, the commissioner declared, a total of 523 warrants was issued.
LONDON, Oct. 26. -- Branding the recent East-End disturbances as "monstrous," the London Diocesan Conference adopted a resolution tonight urging Christians not to tolerate anti-Semitism.

IPSWICH, Suffolk, England, Oct. 26. -- After a long day of hearing unsavory criminal cases, Justice Sir John Anthony Hawke adjourned his Assize Court tonight until 2:15 tomorrow afternoon, at which time, it is understood, witnesses in all five undefended divorce cases have been instructed to attend.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 26. -- Secretary Wallace predicted in a speech here today a sufficient national income "within a year or two" to balance the Federal budget, "provided the administration then in power has the courage to collect a fair share from the taxpayers according to their ability to pay."

John J. Delaney, president of the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, protested yesterday to the Central Labor Trades Council and the State Federation of Labor against the formation of a new union of railroad marine workers under a charter granted by the International Longshoremen's Association.

BERLIN, Oct. 26. -- The first of this Winter's mammoth street demonstrations, which form one of the typical features of Fascist systems, will take place in Berlin next weekend. Nearly six weeks have passed since the Nuremberg party congress, and apparently another gathering of clans is considered necessary.

About $43,863,000 will be distributed in fourteen States in the next few weeks to 1,063,500 contributors to Christmas clubs, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks reported, yesterday. The distributions represent savings accounts started early in the year by persons who wished to put by funds for this Christmas.

The American Newspaper Guild was upheld as the exclusive collective bargaining agency for editorial employes of The Associated Press yesterday by Walter Wilbur, trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board.

MENLO PARK, N.J., Oct. 26. -- The engineer of an eastbound Pennsylvania Railroad freight train was killed and three of the train crew were injured at 1:45 P.M. today in a collision with a westbound freight string a few thousand feet south of Menlo Park station.

Whether John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers and chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, will appoint a committee to negotiate with one appointed by the executive council of the American Federation of Labor in an effort to restore peace between the craft and industrial union factions may be determined today, when Mr. Lewis visits this city.

BRUSSELS, Oct. 26. -- The Belgian capital returned to its accustomed calm today and except among Rexist [Fascist] leaders themselves it is generally agreed that Leon Degrelle's demonstration yesterday failed signally either to frighten the government or win popular support.

Gallery-goers have copiously to adjust themselves to new locations this year. Most recent of the removals and reinstallations is that accomplished by Valentine Dudensing, whose gallery for years was at 69 East Fifty-seventh Street. The new Valentine Gallery, which opened with a private reception yesterday and will open to the public today, is in the adjoining block, at 16 East Fifty-seventh -- quarters formerly occupied by Frederick Keppel Co., print dealers.

J.W. Greene, Inc., sold to Sterling, Inc., a furniture chain, the five-story brick store building covering the block front on Grove Street, extending from Wayen Street to Railroad Avenue, Jersey City. The building has a Grove Street frontage of 210 feet, a depth of 200 feet on Wayen Street and 125 feet along Railroad Avenue.

A fourth postponement had to be granted yesterday in General Sessions of the second-degree felonious assault trial of Representative Vito Marcantonio and John Salas, 30 years old, of 77 East 118th Street because Salas's lawyer insisted he had not received the legal time to file a motion for his client.

Earnings of the General Foods Corporation in the first nine months of this year amounted to $10,617,200, equal to $2.02 a share on 5,251,440 shares of common stock outstanding, according to C.M. Chester, chairman. In the same period of 1935 earnings were $8,770,437, or 67 cents a share.
OSHAWA, Ont., Oct. 26 (Canadian Press) . -- Starting tomorrow morning, the New York Americans will work out behind closed doors, Manager Mervin (Red) Dutton said tonight.

The Rhode Island coast, famous in former years for its great striped bass fishing, last week yielded one of the most interesting catches of the season when Arthur S. Clarke of Jamestown landed a 65-pound striper off Beavertail, Conanicut Island.

PARIS. Oct. 26. -- The central bureau of the International Syndicalist Federation and the Socialist Labor International held an all-day meeting here today and passed a resolution calling upon working organizations everywhere to demand the lifting of the arms blockade against the Madrid government.

Voters in 248 communities will act on Nov. 3 on State and municipal issues aggregating $94,811,670. The most important issue to be submitted is a $30,000,000 unemployment relief loan for this State. A year ago voters in 307 municipalities were asked to pass on new loans aggregating $115,292,480.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 26. -- Carding a par-shattering 67, the Plainfield team of Johnny Kinder, pro, and Charley Whitehead, Jersey amateur champion, today won the last scheduled golf tournament of the New Jersey P.G.A., a one-day pro-amateur event, at the Twin Brook Country Club.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26. -- Following are the texts of Governor Landon's speeches in Philadelphia and Baltimore:

When Santa Claus goes on his 1936 shopping tour prior to his annual toy-laden visit, he will rub elbows with a generation of thoroughly sophisticated young people, it was revealed yesterday when the new offerings for the nursery world were exhibited by the Toy Manufacturers of the U.S.A., Inc., at 200 Fifth Avenue yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP). -- A complaint that an agent claming to represent the Democratic National Committee had used "undue pressure" in attempting to sell 1,000 copies of the party's national convention book was studied today by the Senate Campaign Funds Committee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- The action of some Midwestern employers who have been putting warning slips relating to social security taxes in the pay envelopes of workers was "shoddy politics," said John G. Winant, former chairman of the Social Security Board, in a radio address tonight.

ROME, Oct. 26. -- The Italian press dedicated almost all its space today to the trip of Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano to Germany and its results, which are represented as one of the most important events, if not the most important event, in the recent history of Italian diplomacy.

The Metropolitan Opera Association will present a subscription season of five Tuesday evening performances at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, it was announced yesterday by Adrian Van Sinderen, chairman of the Brooklyn Citizens' Opera Committee.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 26. -- Before addressing a gathering of farmers here today, Secretary Wallace issued a statement in reply to the Republican charge that the Roosevelt administration had "unnecessarily" spent a great deal of money and added to the national debt.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP). -- Secretary Ickes announced public works grants of $6,261,198 and loans of $889,000 today for 112 projects, the estimated cost of which is $15,922,269.

The annual exhibition of advertising printing and a special showing of publication printing, under the sponsorship of the New York m Employing Printers Association and the Associated Printing Salesmen, opened yesterday at the Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- Francisco de los Rios, the new Spanish Ambassador of the Madrid government, today ascribed the Spanish revolt to forces that, he stressed, were "reactionary, not conservative."
BOSTON, Oct. 26 (AP). -- Edward A. Filene, Boston merchant, asserted tonight that the New Deal had not cost a cent.

The invitation to visit any house of the Franciscan Order of Friars Minor under the jurisdiction of the community's Canadian province, which has been cited by Father Luis Sarasola, Spanish Leftist now on a speaking tour here, as evidence of his good standing in his order, was disclosed last night as an invitation to hear himself declared officially apostate.

Governor LANDON spoke modestly of the place which he would take, if elected President, in the conduct of foreign affairs. He promised not to be "talkative" about international questions. That is an excellent thing, as far as it goes. One recalls an imprudent remark by President HARDING which threw the Washington naval conference of 1922 into a temporary tangle.

Mail orders were numerous in the women's apparel markets here yesterday. The individual store volume, however, was not particularly heavy, with the demand largely covering fill-ins and special orders. Dress volume, generally speaking, has been disappointing during the last ten days.

The Long Island Railroad was ordered by the Public Service Commission yesterday to eliminate the four grade crossings in the village of Floral Park, Nassau County, partly by raising the tracks and partly by depressing the grades of the avenues.

Amendment of the rules governing expert testimony in court trials was recommended last night by Justice Meier Steinbrink of the State Supreme Court in an address before the ninth graduate fortnight of the Academy of Medicine. Justice Steinbrink pointed out that wealthy litigants were able to overawe a jury by a mass of expert testimony that less fortunate litigants were unable to match.

Although an injury kept him on the sidelines Saturday, Bob Davis, Kentucky halfback, remained the national scoring leader with 66 points in five games, five points ahead of the nearest rival, The Associated Press tabulation reveals:

MADRID, Oct. 26 (AP). -- Five Insurgent bombing planes flew over Madrid early this afternoon, dropped several small bombs on Barajas Airport and caused slight damage to buildings at the aviation field.

LONDON, Oct. 26. -- Wearing the brown shirt and black tie of the Nazi Storm Troops, of which he is a group leader, Joachim von Ribbentrop, Germany's new Ambassador to Great Britain, arrived in London this afternoon to take up his duties.

The engagement of $6,992,000 of gold abroad for shipment here, of which $5,292,000 was taken in England and $1,700,000 in Belgium, was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York by local commercial banks. The gold taken in Belgium was the second engagement since the devaluation of the belga on April 1, 1935, the first, amounting to $800,000, having been announced on Oct. 17.

Crediting advertising in Sunday newspapers and in national magazines with creating much of his company's present $10,000,000 annual market for automatic stokers, C.T. Burg, general sales manager of the Iron Fireman Manufacturing Company, yesterday told the Sales Executives Club of New York, Inc., that his experience had made him an enthusiastic advocate of practically all types of advertising.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Oct. 21 shows a small increase in total loans and investments, an increase of $176,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, decreases of $76,000,000 in government deposits, $78,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks, $18,000,000 in deposits of foreign banks and $44,000,000 in balances with domestic banks, and an increase of $102,000, 000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

" A torpid liver produces a dull sermon," the Rev. Dr. Adolph William Meyer, who has been preaching for fifty years, told his fellow clergymen yesterday afternoon at the annual Pastoral Conference of the Atlantic District of the United Lutheran Synod of Missouri, Ohio and other States.

IPSWICH, Suffolk, England, Oct. 26. -- Ernest Aldrich Simpson, former officer of the exclusive Cold-stream Guards, will leave London while his wife's case is being heard but will not go to Ipswich, friends say.

Samuel Reichmann, New York pianist, whose last public appearance here took place ten years ago at Aeolian Hall, gave a recital at the Town Hall last night. The most impressive quality of his playing was its clarity. Mr. Reichmann had apparently made a careful study of the compositions on his program, and be set them forth without ostentation and with regard for their broad outlines.

A four-way tie for first place in the standings of the National Squash Tennis Association's Class B interclub tournament existed yesterday when the City Athletic Club, Columbia University Club, Harvard Club and Princeton Club won their second series of matches.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- President Roosevelt today reaffirmed his administration's belief in a strong navy, in a letter addressed to Secretary Swanson, in connection with tomorrow's celebration of Navy Day.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 26. To permit thirty-nine transients maintained by the National Park Service at Camp Elmsford to vote would be "a flagrant violation of the Constitution of the State of New York and of the Election Law," Supreme Court Justice Frederick P. Close ruled late this afternoon.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 26. -- During his delivery of a campaign speech in which he defended the American flag in Puerto Rico, Santiago Iglesias, Resident Commissioner in Washington, was shot and wounded at Mayaguez last night by Domingo S. Crespo, a professed Nationalist and one of a crowd of 10,000 that filled the plaza.

Carrying black-bordered placards that proclaimed the failure of the New Deal to enact effective anti-lynching legislation, six veiled Negro women in full mourning attire established a picket line outside of the Biltmore Hotel yesterday afternoon.
ARLINGTON, Texas, Oct. 26 (AP). -- The Woolford Farm's Gallienne won the featured fifth race at Arlington Downs today before a crowd of 7,000.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 26. -- Led by Ambedkar, the "Untouchables" of India are seeking a religion which will remove them from the outcast class and there is a chance they may adopt Christianity, according to Mrs. Howard Wayne Smith of Ardmore, Pa., president of the Women's American Baptist Foreign Mission Society.

The general trend toward prosperity is reflected in a "marked improvement" in the hotel business, which still lags behind other industries, however, and promises even greater gains, Frank A. McKowne, president of the Hotels Statler Company, declared yesterday.

In his speech Saturday night on foreign policy, Governor Landon explained that the United States should stick to the doctrine of neutral rights in time of war and should have a fleet strong enough to dissuade any one tempted to interfere with such neutral rights as we might assert.

IN a moment of temporary mental aberration one day last week there was mention here, apropos of Dartmouth football plans, that "Coach Blaik, the Red Earl, hopes to get by Harvard this week and then take Yale in the Bowl for the first time on record." It's the United States Postoffice Department that ought to be grateful. The Compleat Letter Writers of and from Dartmouth swarmed all over that morsel of misinformation.

MOSCOW, Oct. 26. -- Because of the Soviet belief that Germany has made great progress toward obtaining active aid of Finland in case of war with Russia, reports today of two "incidents" on the Soviet-Finnish border are of unusual interest.
TAMPA, Fla., Oct. 26 (AP). -- The second unsuccessful attempt of Earl Browder, Communist candidate for President, to speak here reached the State courts today.

Vincent Astor gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Sir Reginald Hildyard, Governor of Bermuda, and Lady Hildyard, who are at the St. Regis. Mr. and Mrs. Walter Hochschild entertained at supper in the Iridium Room after attending "Stage Door," to which they had taken their guests, Mr. and Mrs. A. Coster Schermerhorn, Mr. and Mrs. Richard Merton, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Bayard Swope and Miss Georgia Schermerhorn.

Appropriations approaching $2, 500,000 have already been approved for the Olympic Village for the Tokyo games in 1940, according to an announcement here yesterday. The invitation committee, headed by Prince Iyesato Takugawa, has sanctioned the expenditure.

The National Hockey League will have the earliest opening in its history this season. The regular campaign, according to the official schedule released yesterday by President Frank Calder, will get under way on Thursday, Nov. 5 and will run through until March 21.

In consenting yesterday to pass upon two cases arising under the Wagner Labor Relations Law, the Supreme Court has brought another important act of the Roosevelt Administration within the field of its review. Adopted in July of last year, the Wagner law is intended to guarantee collective bargaining in all industries in which conditions of work "lead or tend to lead" to labor disputes obstructing the flow of commerce.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26. -- Receipts of hogs today were 27,000 head, the largest for a clay since last January, and prices declined 5 to 15 cents a hundredweight, the top being $9.60, the lowest since Dec. 21, 1935. Prices have been on the downgrade for eight straight days.

After the stock market closes today directors of the United States Steel Corporation will hold their quarterly meeting, to receive the earnings report for the three months ended on Sept. 30 and to take action on the preferred dividend. Concerning earnings, statisticians have computed on the basis of shipments that the net profit for the three months may have run as high as $1 to $1.25 a share on the common stock.

LONDON, Oct. 26. -- The Air Ministry has patched up its quarrel with Lord Nuffield, Britain's leading automobile manufacturer, and the reconciliation may be announced when Parliament reassembles on Thursday.

LONDON, Oct, 26. -- To meet the heavily subsidized American competition the British Cabinet is considering a new government subsidy of at least 1,000,000 to powerful shipping interests in the Pacific headed by the Peninsular Oriental, according to Francis Williams, Daily Herald financial editor.

After the stock market closes today directors of the United States Steel Corporation will hold their quarterly meeting, to receive the earnings report for the three months ended on Sept. 30 and to take action on the preferred dividend. Concerning earnings, statisticians have computed on the basis of shipments that the net profit for the three months may have run as high as $1 to $1.25 a share on the common stock.

LONDON, Oct. 26. -- The Air Ministry has patched up its quarrel with Lord Nuffield, Britain's leading automobile manufacturer, and the reconciliation may be announced when Parliament reassembles on Thursday.

LONDON, Oct, 26. -- To meet the heavily subsidized American competition the British Cabinet is considering a new government subsidy of at least 1,000,000 to powerful shipping interests in the Pacific headed by the Peninsular Oriental, according to Francis Williams, Daily Herald financial editor.

MOSCOW, Oct. 25. -- German and Italian characterizations of the Catalan Government as a "soviet" are authoritatively branded as "silly fables" today by Vigilis, the nom de plume of an important Communist party official who has succeeded Karl Radek as the Kremlin's spokesman on international affairs, in the newspaper Izvestia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- The foreign relations of the United States are now better than within living memory and the administration's record in foreign affairs "speaks for itself in contrast to the narrow, vague and confused generalities, as well as the unsupported attempts at criticism contained in Governor Landon's speech made last Saturday night," Secretary Hull asserted in a statement issued today.

Leading producers of copper in the United States advanced yesterday the domestic price of that metal by one-quarter cent a pound to 10 cents, the highest level since early in 1931. This was the first change in price since July 20, when it was advanced from 9.50 to 9.75 cents.

Francois de Tessan, French Under-Secretary of State, is due to arrive today on the Ile de France from Paris to represent the French Government at the celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the unveiling of the Statue of Liberty, veiling accompanied by M. Richard, Mayor of Colmer, birthplace of Bartholdi, sculptor of the statue.
Substantial improvement in the earnings of three steel companies is revealed in the financial statements announced yesterday by four companies for the quarter and nine months.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 26. -- The possibility that the Belgian Government, which until recently had a strongly pro-French foreign policy, will ask Parliament tomorrow to fortify the French frontier as it has the German border was debated in parliamentary circles tonight.

Liquidation in cotton futures increased yesterday on the Cotton Exchange here when large ginning figures were interpreted as indicating a better yield of cotton than recent expectations in the trade. With demand still mostly restricted to trade fixations on a scale-down and with outside offerings in heavier volume, prices were down 12 to 14 points by the close of the day and at virtually the lowest for the session.
PADUCAH, Ky., Oct. 26 (AP). -- More than 300 hunters braved a biting wind today to watch the first futurity cast of the forty-third annual field trials of the National Fox Hunters' Association.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 26. -- Persons on work relief have been threatened with the loss of their jobs unless they vote the Democratic ticket, William F. Bleakley, Republican candidate for Governor, declared here tonight.
Clarence M. Davis, an attorney and a member of the Bar Association of the City of New York, shot and killed himself late yesterday in his office at 342 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- Dedicating a new chemistry building at Howard University, a Federal institution maintained here for Negroes, President Roosevelt today stated as a policy that "there should be no forgotten men and no forgotten races." He commended the "prompt and eager response" of American Negroes to educational opportunities.

The Republican National Committee yesterday distributed copies of a letter, printed in yesterday's Sun of New York, written by Franklin D. Roosevelt, before election day in 1932, in which he declared that Federal insurance of deposits in all national banks was impossible.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP). -- Cotton of this year's growth ginned prior to Oct. 18 was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 8,567,676 running bales, excluding linters. Round bales, counted as half bales, included, totaled 149,147, and American-Egyptian totaled 4,158 bales.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 26. -- Miss Margaret Creston Carey has presented to the Enoch Pratt Library of Baltimore a collection of books, letters and articles belonging to Edgar Allan Poe, including the love letters he wrote to his cousin, Virginia Clemm, whom he married while she was still a schoolgirl.

TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 26. -- Frank G. Todd, Republican State Chairman, said today that James Roosevelt, son of the President, admitted in a speech last night that "the slanderous attack on Kansas schools is nation-wide and that it emanated directly from the office of State Superintendent W.T. Markham, only Democratic State official in Kansas."
MOSCOW, Oct. 26 (AP). -- The Soviet press indulged today in one of its periodic outbursts of self-criticism -- with unflattering verdicts on its own merit.
Lew Feldman, aggressive Brownsville lightweight, outpointed Pete Mascia of Greenpoint in the eight-round bout that featured last night's show at Stauch's Arena in Coney Island.
Patrolmen in commandeered taxicabs rode herd on a sad-eyed black and white bull calf in Fifth Avenue from Twenty-ninth to Thirty-ninth Street yesterday morning, while shoppers cheered.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26. -- Crowds jostling good-naturedly in a drizzle shouted and waved greetings to Governor Landon today while he made his tour of downtown streets and a visit to Independence Hall.

As an eleventh-hour move the Republican National Committee, with the cooperation of many industrial employers, has succeeded in having inserted in pay envelopes statements notifying employes of the pay deduction of 1 per cent that must be made beginning Jan. 1 next under the Social Security Act.

The city of Toledo, Ohio, has invited bids for a new issue of $3,237,000 refunding bonds, award of which will be made on Nov. 17. The bonds, dated Dec. 15, 1936, and maturing Dec. 15, 1938 to 1949, will carry a fixed rate of interest of 3 per cent.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 26. -- Scatter Brain took a photographic decision from Calumet Dick at the finish of the feature before 8,000 today. First by a short head, Scatter Brain rewarded backers with $19.80 for $2. Third in the field of six was Aladdins Dream.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- An apparent loophole in the War Department's order banning army officers from coaching football at civilian colleges was found today, but was quickly closed by General Malin Craig, chief of staff.

BERLIN, Oct. 26. -- Colonel-General Hermann Goerlng will deliver his heralded speech outlining the nature and scope of the new Four-Year Plan for German raw-material independence in the Sportpalast on Wednesday night, it was announced today.

Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Eastern Republican campaign director, charged yesterday that the Roosevelt administration was pouring millions of dollars from the AAA and the PWA into doubtful States "in a last-minute attempt to stem the Landon tide."

Both political parties have now endorsed governmental all-risk crop insurance, and the special committee on the subject appointed by the President announces that it is working as rapidly as possible to assure a complete report by December. But in spite of the general political enthusiasm for the plan, the economic difficulties remain formidable.

The stock market rebounded vigorously yesterday as a flood of favorable earnings reports and dividend declarations helped speculators forget their fears of the forthcoming election. Gains in leading issues ranged from 1 to 3 points, and the market as a whole recovered approximately half of the losses sustained in Monday's decline, the sharpest slump in two months.

NEW MARKET, England, Oct. 27 (AP). -- Sir Abe Bailey's sterling colt, Dan Bulger, closed tonight just where he started months ago -- the firm favorite to outfoot twenty-one rivals in tomorrow's renewal of the historic Cambridgeshire over one and an eighth miles.

College presidents and other leading educators of the country attended last night the testimonial dinner given by the College Entrance Examination Board for its retiring secretary, Professor Thomas Scott Fiske, at the Hotel Biltmore.

Andre Geraud, a leading European journalist and student of world affairs, said on his arrival here yesterday that Europe was approaching a period in its history more crucial than any since the World War.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- The value of products manufactured in New York State increased 31 per cent from $4,596,257,962 to $6,022,173,000 between 1933 and 1935, but last year was 39 per cent below the 1929 level of $9,892,763,168, according to figures made public today by the Census Bureau in its census of manufacturers for 1935.
A $350,000 apartment house for a site in Kew Gardens, Queens, was among the building projects filed yesterday, as follows:

The six-story Bronx house known as the Thomas Garden Apartments, built in 1926 by John D. Rockefeller Jr. was bought by a foreclosure auction sale yesterday by the Post Orchard Corporation, Eliot L. Berkwit, attorney, on a $625,000 bid. The structure, which contains 880 rooms, divided into 173 suites, is on the block bounded by Grand Concourse, Mott and Sheridan Avenues, 158th and 159th Streets.
There are many ways of losing a big fish, but the commonest (and the least excusable) is by going fishing with a defective or inadequate line.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- Charges of Mr. Hard, the Republican radio commentator, that Pennsylvania relief workers had been subjected to political coercion were termed "incorrect" and "deliberate falsehoods" in the Glavis report to the Senate Campaign Funds Committee.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27. -- Merger of the Nash Motors Company and the Kelvinator Corporation into a new concern to be known as the Nash-Kelvinator Corporation was approved today by the directors of the two companies. The consolidation is one of the most important since the wave of corporate mergers of the late 1920's.

Governor Alf M. Landon, Republican Presidential nominee, will arrive at Pennsylvania Station at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon, a day in advance of the big New York rally of his campaign, to be held tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden.

French labor troubles are greatly exaggerated in the United States and reports of an impending revolution are "purely ridiculous," according to Francois de Tessan, French Under-Secretary of State, who arrived yesterday to represent his government in the fiftieth anniversary exercises at the Statue of Liberty today.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct. 28. -- Word has been received here that Vice Admiral Sir Charles Little, the British naval commander in the Far East, has, on orders from London, postponed his courtesy visit to Japan, which was scheduled to begin on Friday.

A gigantic Federal public works project to combat water pollution, which he estimated is causing an annual capital loss of $6,250,000,000, was urged yesterday by Kenneth A. Reid, national director of the Izaak Walton League, in a paper read at the thirty-second annual convention of the Association of Audubon Societies at the Museum of Natural History.

President DODDS of Princeton has done a good service in behalf of public manners and morals, which together make for sportsmanship. And sportsmanship on the field demands sportsmanship on the part of the spectators. They, too, must "play the game" which involves self-control and, as the chivalrous "NED" (E.S.) MARTIN said in his book to a freshman son, "respect "for the rights, comfort and feelings "of others."

Thrusting his political campaign aside for the moment, President Roosevelt will come to this city today to participate in the celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the dedication of the Statue of Liberty, to lay a cornerstone in Brooklyn and to spend several hours resting at his town house.

New York University's football squad began actual preparations yesterday at Ohio Field for its encounter with the heavy Lafayette eleven Saturday at the Yankee Stadium. Coach Mal Stevens put the Violet through three hours of practice that took in every department of the game.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 27. -- The first fox hunt of the sixth season of the Bath County Hounds, Mrs. Fay Ingalls, M.F.H., meets at Dr. Torrence's camp at 7 o'clock tomorrow morning.

With the police check on the city's huge registration within two days of completion, a total of 736 cases of irregularity have been uncovered and as many requests have been made to the Attorney General for the Issuance of warrants, Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine said yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 27. -- Continued increases in industrial production in the St. Louis area, particularly in the heavy goods lines, have put a number of plants on double and triple shift, and created a shortage of competent skilled help in more than a dozen classifications.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP). -- Briefs questioning the constitutionality of New York State's Unemployment Insurance Law were placed before the Supreme Court today pending arguments on the validity of the act next month.

When the Statue of Liberty was unveiled fifty years ago today Senator WILLIAM M. EVARTS spoke of the scene as displaying a transaction in human affairs which found "no precedent" in the past and which would not be confronted in the future, as he predicted, with a "counterpart or parallel."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- Private interests must not obstruct the orderly administration of justice, Attorney General Cummings asserted in a brief filed with the Supreme Court today preparatory to arguments next month on how the government should proceed in the coming constitutional test of the Public Utility Act.

Engagements of $1,840,000 of gold abroad for shipment here were reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank by local commercial banks. Of this amount, $1,459,000 was taken in Canada, $101,000 in India and $280,000 in England, the last having been obtained on Monday.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 27. -- Here the most militant Republican machine in the entire State, perhaps, is pitted against a Democratic organization well fortified for election day by Federal, State and municipal patronage and in addition Federal WPA and PWA grants.

Two agreements recognizing the right of sea-going personnel to payment for overtime work were signed yesterday by ship lines and union officials in this port. The United Licensed Officers Association announced that it had reached an agreement with three oil companies and the International Seamen's Union revealed that the New York and Cuba Mail Steamship Company had accepted terms for the crew of the liner Oriente.

THERE is a debate going on at the moment as to which fellow hits the harder: Harry Balsamo or Marshall Goldberg. The Notre Dame team undoubtedly would vote unanimously for Goldberg. Babe Risko, former middleweight champion, will test out Balsamo's hitting power this evening at the Hippodrome, but his vote will be disregarded.

After early moderate declines, prices of cotton futures on the Cotton Exchange yesterday rallied about $1 a bale as increased resistance developed at the 11 1/2-cent level for near-by contracts. The January delivery advanced from 11.51 cents a pound to 11.72 cents and closed at the top.

Several new varieties of chrysanthemums never shown before were exhibited yesterday at the second annual chrysanthemum show sponsored by the Gardens of the Nations in Horticultural Hall, Rockefeller Center. More than 500 varieties of chrysanthemums will be on free exhibition to the public today and tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 10 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today made public a summary of thirteen additional registration statements filed with it under the Securities Act of 1933, including that of Major Metals Corporation of New York, covering $5,000,000 of 6 per cent ten-year debenture bonds, Series A, 1946, with attached estate fund certificates, Series A to be offered at par in units of $50, $100, $500 and $1,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- The Koppers Company of Pittsburgh, formerly the Koppers Gas and Coke Company, filed today a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $25,000,000 of first mortgage and general collateral trust bonds, Series A, 4 per cent, due Nov. 1, 1951.
LENOX, Mass., Oct. 27. -- Representative and Mrs. Allen T. Treadway observed their forty-third wedding anniversary last night with a family dinner party at the Elms in Stockbridge.

A "family altar" plan whereby the father or head of every house would become a "priest" and instruct his children in God's word, was advocated yesterday by the Rev. Dr. John W. Behnken of Chicago to care for the growing spiritual trend in the United States.

Secretary WALLACE has once more drawn the comparison, frequently made in the present campaign, between the national debt in the last few years and the national income. He tells his hearers that an increase of $11,000,000,000 in the national debt since 1933 has been accompanied by an increase of the national income in the same period of $20,000,000,000, and therefore that the debt increase was good business.

Forty-eight departments of large department stores in the Second Federal Reserve district showed percentage increases in sales volume in September compared with the same month last year, according to a report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

OXFORD, England, Oct. 27. -- Wearing the black and scarlet robe of a Doctor of Civil Law, Dr. James Bryant Conant, president of Harvard University, received that honorary degree from Oxford University today as a tribute to his university and to his own brilliant achievements in chemical research.

William Allen White, editor of The Emporia (Kansas) Gazette, speaking last night at a dinner of the Roosevelt Memorial Association at Roosevelt House, 28 East Twentieth Street, praised Theodore t Roosevelt and indirectly criticized President Franklin D. Roosevelt.

WITH REBEL ARMY NEAR GRINON, Spain, Oct. 27. -- Spanish Insurgents captured five towns today in a drive to bring the Rebel artillery within range of Madrid by tomorrow, with the announced hope that the capital might fall by Saturday.

LONDON, Oct. 27 (AP). -- The International Rubber Regulation Committee fixed today exportable allowances for the signatory countries for the first six months of 1937 at 70 per cent of the basic quotas for each.
CHICAGO, Oct. 27 (AP). -- The nation's traffic death total pushed to a new high level during the first nine months of 1936, the National Safety Council reported tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27 -- Marshall Field of New York announced his support of President Roosevelt today by endorsing the Wasserman-Paul-Biddle statement drawn up by a group of leaders in business and the professions after investigating the political and economic situation.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 27. -- For the second straight day Robert S. Jones, the varsity center, missed football pratice at Harvard today, and his chances of starting against Princeton here Saturday are slim.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27. -- The world's wheat markets developed a firmer undertone today, due largely to a bullion construction placed on an official Australian crop estimate and a lack of hedging pressure. Speculative interest, however, continues considerably restricted and was insufficient to absorb all the December offered for sale above $1.16 a bushel on the Board of Trade.

Although the work of many prominent architects was said to have been included in the 356 drawings submitted in the World's Fair Corporation's contest for the best design of a building for the 1939 exposition, the winners in the competition are young architects, virtually unknown, Grover A. Whalen, president of the corporation, said yesterday.
LONDON, Oct. 27. -- Without mention of another name which is on everybody's tongue and without any inferences whatever, the British press finally took notice of the Simpson divorce case today.

Aggregate bids for the first 177 lots of 635 parcels of collateral underlying $50,000,000 of Kreuger Toll Company 5 per cent debentures, of which the sale at auction began at 10:30 A.M. yesterday, amounted to $2,982,249, or $193,048 more than the upset prices fixed by the court.

Frank Shaughnessy, former business manager of the Montreal Royals and author of the "Shaughnessy play-off system," adopted by nearly all minor leagues in recent years, was elected president of the International League yesterday at a special meeting of the circuit's board of directors at the Hotel Commodore.

Missing-monkey experts of the Rockaway Beach police precinct sent out yesterday an alarm for Oscar, an 8-month-old Rhesus monkey, which disappeared about ten days ago and which is believed by them to have been invading homes and looting ice boxes.

PARIS, Oct. 27. -- A program for strengthening French air forces that dwarfs anything yet attempted in this country was passed by the Cabinet and Ministerial Council today. It is hoped to get Parliament to vote upon it as soon as possible so that work can be started without delay.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 27. -- Less complicated by State issues than other commonwealths which usually give their electoral vote to Republican Presidential nominees, New Jersey this year will have an outright test of the New Deal. Without notable exceptions those familiar with conditions believe that the election will be one of the closest in the United States.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 27. -- Church members who play the numbers game and buy sweepstakes tickets make the problem of suppressing gambling difficult, the Rev. M.M. Lewis of Orange, N.J., charged here today, before the New Jersey Baptist Convention.

Declaring there is no reason why the government should not issue an "advance construction" of indefinite phases of the Robinson-Patman Anti-Price Discrimination Act, Charles Wesley Dunn, general counsel for the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., yesterday urged organized business to unite in developing and securing amendments to the law to cure its "substantial defects."

Photographs of JOSEPH STALIN plainly show a man with a capacity for laughter. This is not belied by his written reply to a question submitted at the Kremlin palace a few days ago by The Associated Press.
HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 27. -- Dartmouth's football reserves had a long scrimmage today in biting cold weather, while the varsity ran through new formations.

John Barbirolli, 36-year-old British conductor, who will direct the first ten weeks of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra season, beginning Nov. 5, arrived yesterday morning and revealed the full details of his engagement.

The possibility that the $436,000,000 transit unification plan drafted by Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr. might, if adopted, go too far toward depriving the city of control over expansion of rapid transit facilities in the future was raised yesterday at a public hearing before the Transit Commission.

The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company announced yesterday a net income of $3,185,728 for the third quarter of 1936, after all deductions, including "a reasonable amount" set aside for payment of the surtax on undistributed earnings.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

The Cleveland Rams and the New York Yankees will clash for undisputed second-place honors in the American Football League in the contest at the Yankee Stadium tonight. The teams are now tied for the runner-up post behind the Boston Shamrocks.
LONDON, Oct. 27. -- A week ago it was Russia, today it was Portgugal that threatened to abandon neutrality and withdraw from the international committee on non-intervention in Spain.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- At a White House press conference today before setting out on the final phase of his campaign, President Roosevelt today evidenced a cheery good humor marked by frequent jocular remarks.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 27. -- Replying today to President Roosevelt's recent letter to engineering schools, Dr. C.C. Williams, president of Lehigh University, declared that "blunderbuss gunning for political game demolished in some cases industry's highly developed economic and social agencies."

DETROIT, Oct. 27. -- Detroit industry again is in high gear. Featured by the rising rate of automobile production, industrial activity continues the gain that began a few weeks ago. Manufacturers are rapidly increasing schedules made necessary by the demands of dealers throughout the country who are now awaiting the delivery of thousands of cars already ordered by a waiting public.
Two foreign military teams arrived yesterday to participate in the National Horse Show starting next Wednesday at Madison Square Garden.

The plea of Alfonso de Borbon. Count of Covadonga, former heir to the Spanish throne, for a reduction of alimony and counsel fees he was directed to pay his wife pending trial of his annulment action, was denied yesterday by Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins.

Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of General Motors; John Schumann, president of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, and H.J. Klingler, president and general manager of the Pontiac Motor Company, division of General Motors, joined yesterday in predicting that, no matter what the outcome of the November elections might be, 1937 would be a better year than 1936 for the automobile and other industries.
The text of the address delivered by Governor Herbert H. Lehman at Madison Square Garden follows:

HAMBURG, Germany, Oct. 27. -- What is apparently the worst storm in many years is raging in the North Sea. The most severe German loss to date is the lightship Elbe, familiar to tens of thousands of Atlantic travelers. It capsized this afternoon and is reported to have sunk with its whole crew of fifteen.

SAYBROOK, Conn., Oct. 27. -- My-Own-On-Time, red and white dog owned by Mrs. Francis P. Garvan of New York and handled in the field by Elias C. Vail of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., won the open all-age stake for cocker spaniels, the chief event today on the opening card of the third annual meeting of the Connecticut Spaniel Field Trial Association.
CHICAGO, Oct. 27. -- Trade and industry are flourishing and employment is showing large gains in the Chicago area, with indications pointing to increased activity in the months to come.

The country at large had its biggest theatrical opening last evening, when the WPA's Federal Theatre Project started off some twenty-one productions of "It Can't Happen Here," offering them in eighteen cities across the land. The play is the Sinclair Lewis and John C. Moffitt dramatization of Mr. Lewis's novel dealing with America under a dictatorship.

The United States Steel Corporation, largest industrial employer of labor in this country, with 216,709 workers on its payroll, announced yesterday that a plan for a revision in wages would soon be submitted to representatives of the employes. The plan, it was indicated, would provide for proportionately larger increases for workers in the lower-paid brackets than for those in other categories.

The shadow of a mighty name has been cast in curious ways over this Presidential campaign. Not since his death eighteen years ago have the words of President THEODORE ROOSEVELT been so often quoted as by speakers in the present electoral contest. Both parties claim him, or at least a part of him, for their own.

There is a sardonic wise-crack in Philip Guedella's essays to the effect that history repeats itself but historians repeat each other. That, the present reviewer feels, applies ponderably to the show of recent paintings by Chirico at the Julien Levy Gallery, which opened yesterday and will be current until Nov. 16.
BERLIN, Oct. 27. -- Prices continued to fall as activity decreased on the Boerse today. Losses in the leading stocks were between a half point and 3 points.
IPSWICH, England, Oct. 27 (AP). -- The following is the official transcript of the divorce proceedings in the case of Mrs. Ernest Simpson against her husband at the Ipswich Assizes today:

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 27. -- General business in the San Francisco Bay area is in a strong technical position to move ahead at a rapid pace, and an incipient boom is not unlikely. Retail trade, freight traffic and industrial production have shown less than a seasonally normal recession during the past month, and are well ahead of a year ago.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 27. -- Mr. and Mrs. M. Albert Linton of Moorestown, N.J., and Reginald C. McCankie were joint hosts tonight at dinner for 400 in Georgian Terrace. Mr. and Mrs. John R. Laurus of Hartford, Conn., Mr. and Mrs. John L. Stearns of Boston, Mr. and Mrs. George Graham of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Mr. and Mrs. T.A. Phillips assisted in receiving guests.
LONDON, Oct. 27. -- A new hit came to St. Martin's Theatre tonight in the form of an intelligent light comedy by Geoffrey Kerr called "Till the Cows Come Home."

Two former officials of the Protective Fur Dressers Corporation, both of whom have pleaded guilty to violating the anti-trust laws in the $10,000,000-a-year rabbit skin trade, testified yesterday for the government at the trial in Federal court of Louis (Lepke) Buchalter and Jacob (Gurrah Jake) Shapiro, accused of racketeering activities in the industry in 1932 and 1933.

Word from Washington in confirmation of the War Department ruling against the continuance of football coaching by regular army officers apparently means the closing of the sports careers of some men who have been long identified with the game.

About 100 persons, including a number of society women, attended the preview of the exhibit of paintings and sculpture by Malvina Hoffman yesterday at the English Book Shop, 64 East Fifty-fifth Street. A reception and tea in honor of Miss Hoffman followed.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27. -- Hog prices were steady in early trading today but weakened later, with weights above 180 pounds off 5 to 15 cents a hundredweight in the closing rounds. Best quality underweights, pigs and packing sows showed little change from yesterday's price.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was the largest on record, being 3,083,050 barrels, compared to 3,080,350 in the preceding week, an increase of 2,700, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 27 (AP). -- Only the urgings of the Federal Maritime Commission and the efforts of a veteran government conciliator stood tonight in the path of another threatened tie-up of Pacific Coast shipping.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 27. -- After attending a preview of Samuel Goldwyn's picturization of Edna Ferber's "Come and Get It" last night. Paramount executives discovered a girl whom they will probably cast opposite Gary Cooper in "Souls at Sea."

In the midst of an unmistakable upswing, business must give attention to the problem of maintaining the levels of activity, Willard Thorp, director of economic research of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., counseled members of the National Upholstery and Drapery Textile Association, Inc., at their annual meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.
The following paragraph appears in Turner Catledge's dispatch from Detroit:

Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey issued a temporary injunction yesterday restraining the Securities and Exchange Commission, Lamar Hardy, United States Attorney, Postmaster Albert Goldman and others from enforcing provisions of the Public Utility Act against the United Corporation of Delaware and the New York United Corporation.

MADRID, Oct. 27. -- Fierce fighting has been going on at Oviedo for the last forty-eight hours. The Loyalist miners are gradually advancing and have recaptured the old slaughterhouse on the outskirts of the city.

A banking group composed of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, Eldredge Co., Inc., and Wheelock Cummins, Inc., obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $635,000 of refunding bonds of Raleigh, N.C., on a bid of 100.119 for $200,000 as 4s and $435,000 as 3 1/2s, for a net interest cost to the city of 3.61 per cent.
Favorable earnings for the third quarter and for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 were revealed in the reports of several steel companies, announced yesterday.

Persons prominent in society thronged the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night for a dinner-dance and entertainment formally opening the room for the season. The New York Exchange for Woman's Work of 541 Madison Avenue was the beneficiary.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- The Federal Maritime Commission stated today that ship owners and union-labor spokesmen on the Pacific Coast were free to negotiate a settlement independently of the activities of the commission itself. In addition, it announced that the ship owners were willing to continue peace conferences.

Fordham took things easy yesterday on its campus gridiron. Coach Jim Crowley gave the Rams a light workout in which a signal drill was the feature. The usual limbering-up exercise opened the session, and after that the entire repertoire of plays was rehearsed.

In resuming full quarterly dividend payments of $1.75 a share on its preferred stock and in declaring a dividend of $2 a share on account of arrears on this issue, the United States Steel Corporation made yesterday a sweeping movement toward clearing up obligations ranking ahead of the common stock.

William R. Chappell, 41 years old, of 101 East Seventy-second Street, member of a socially prominent family, shot himself in the right temple at 8 o'clock last night in the apartment of his former wife, Mrs. Amos Poole, at 28 East Seventieth Street.

Prominent women leaders of philanthropic and social groups joined yesterday in support of the annual campaign of the women's division of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, at a breakfast held under the auspices of the campaign committee in the Hotel Roosevelt.
Judge Bleakley's attack on the reciprocity program shows surprising ignorance not only of the economic situation but of the actual details of the reciprocity program.

Excessive talking, drinking and smoking have been traced by psychiatrists in a number of instances to interruptions of feeding during infancy, Dr. Ernest E. Hadley, director for biological sciences in the Washington (D.C.) School of Psychiatry, told a meeting of the American Institute at the New York Museum of Science and Industry last night.

BUFFALO, Oct. 27 (AP). -- Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, appealed to President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman tonight to "vindicate the right of discussion" in the present political campaign.

The number of visiting buyers recorded in the market during the week ended yesterday was less than in the preceding week but was well ahead of the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES. For the week the arrivals published totaled 905, as against 1,042 in the previous week and 809 in the same period last year.

The end of more than two years of bitter litigation between the $700,000,000 Associated Gas and Electric Company and creditors seeking to reorganize it under the bankruptcy act was foreshadowed late yesterday with the filing of a stipulation proposing an out-of-court settlement of the proceedings.

A special luncheon and style revue entitled "Fashions for You" were held yesterday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin for the benefit of the Bellevue Hospital Occupation Committee of the New York City Visiting Committee. A generous percentage of the receipts was given to this department of the hospital, which maintains six teachers of occupational therapy.

One of the most interesting events of the early season in the New York Galleries is now in progress at Pierre Matisse's. The event is doubly interesting in that it uniquely links pre-revolutionary Russia with modern French painting and, at the same time, permits one to follow the development of an artistic idea from its genesis to its working out.

If facism starts creeping through this country, it will be over Sinclair Lewis's dead body. Last year he took a preliminary swing at it in his novel ironically labeled "It Can't Happen Here." Now, with the cooperation of the Federal Theatre, he has conspired to get it on the stage for simultaneous showing in eighteen cities throughout the country.

I write of Franklin Roosevelt the man. I write of him because I have known him since boyhood. We went to the same school. We practiced law as partners down to the outbreak of the Great War. I saw him on the western front in the Spring of 1918 when he was Assistant Secretary of the Navy.

James J. Wilson, Assistant District Attorney, and Detective McElligott of the District Attorney's office made a hurried trip yesterday afternoon to investigate the hurling of a stench bomb into a fur manufacturing shop in West Twenty-eighth Street, near Broadway.
Coach Lou Little was willing to permit Columbia's offense to remain unchanged yesterday while the Lions engaged the husky freshman eleven in a defensive scrimmage at Baker Field.
