A brewery expansion project and operators' deals in the Bronx and Manhattan featured the urban realty trading reported yesterday.

Magistrate De Luca, in Felony Court yesterday, released Solomon Silver, 25 years old, of 1,818 Madison Avenue, in $1,000 bail pending a hearing on Nov. 9 on the charge of Felix Marquez of 26 West 109th Street that Silver stabbed him three weeks ago because of his support of Representative Vito Marcantonio, Republican.

Howard Townsend, retired lawyer and philanthropist, who died on April 24, 1935, left an estate appraised yesterday at $124,148 gross and $117,183 net. The estate included Gilbert Stuart portraits of William Bayard and William Bayard Jr. valued at $10,000 each.
PARIS, Oct. 27. -- Princess Natalie Paley, screen actress and daughter of the Grand Duke Paul of Russia, filed a suit for divorce today against her husband, the well known couturier, Lucien Lelong.

Before an audience of more than 20,000 that filled Madison Square Garden yesterday at a campaign rally of the American Labor party, Governor Lehman pledged himself to continue his fight for progressive labor legislation and assailed his Republican opponent and the Republican party for promising to give industry "sweeping immunity from regulation."
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 27. -- The text of Governor Landon's address tonight follows:

Ernest Schelling, pianist and conductor of the annual series of the Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra concerts for young people, returned from Europe yesterday on the French liner Ile de France, bringing some new ideas about the theatre and a flagon of venerable brandy from the cellar kept by Paderewski in his Lake Geneva home.
The operator and two passengers in an ascending freight elevator at 49-51 Elizabeth Street were injured at 1 P.M. yesterday when the elevator fell from the third floor to the basement.

LONDON, Oct. 27. -- Although British Government securities recovered from yesterday's weakness, most sections of the London Stock Exchange were dull today. The market is going through a severe shake-out after experiencing a buoyancy that was almost boom-like for several weeks.

Robert Moses, chief executive officer of the Triborough Bridge Authority, announced yesterday that the south-bound parkway of the East River Drive from East Ninety-second Street and York Avenue to the Triborough Bridge approach ramp at East 122d Street would be opened for traffic on Saturday.

GENEVA, Oct. 27. -- David Vaage, Norwegian chief of the Industrial Safety Service of the International Labor Office, has returned from the United States "Kansas-conscious," but not because of Governor Alf M. Landon. Furthermore, he believes he has left that State tariff-conscious.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 27. -- The charge that Governor Lehman is conducting a campaign of misquotation in which "thoroughly inaccurate and dishonest" statements have been made formed a part tonight of the answer of William F. Bleakley, the Republican candidate for Governor, to Mr. Lehman's utilities attack.

Mayor La Guardia expressed his desire yesterday to have all city departments doing technical work headed by civil service commissioners. He voiced his wish as he appointed Joseph Goodman Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.

Fairly wide gains or small losses characterized trading here yesterday in markets for commodity futures. Rubber prices were strong, crude rubber futures opening 13 to 16 points higher and ending 24 to 29 up, with sales 3,290 tons.

Business failures in the retail division in the week ended Oct. 22 totaled ninety-seven, compared with eighty in the previous five business days and with 141 in the week ended Oct. 24 last year, according to report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27. -- Lifting wage scales to a level almost 20 per cent above the pre-depression high in 1929, big meat packers here announced today that a 7 per cent increase in pay would be placed in effect Monday for all hourly paid and piece-work employes.

Eighteen deaths, the same number for the corresponding period last year, have been reported from sandlot, club, high school and college gridirons thus far this season, according to The Associated Press.
President Roosevelt and Governor Landon both will be in this city today for extensive ceremonies and meetings. Their programs follow:
ALBANY, Oct. 27 (AP). -- Complete official registration figures compiled by The Associated Press disclosed today an army of 856,616 voters in a political no-man's land in New York State.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- The Lonergan special Senate committee investigating campaign expenditures has failed to find sufficient basis to charges that the WPA in Pennsylvania was being used for political purposes to warrant open hearings before the election, a representative of the committee stated today.

Reports of freight loadings and earnings and comments of railroad presidents provided proof yesterday that this year is a good one for railroading. All indications are that earnings in the rest of this year will be at the best levels since 1930.

The New York State Electric and Gas Corporation will enter the market today with a new issue of $13,906,900 of first-mortgage 4 per cent bonds dated Aug. 1, 1936, and due on Aug. 1, 1965. The bonds will be priced at 102 and accrued interest.

With a half-dozen major industries breaking all previous sales and production records and with virtually all important trade indexes rapidly approaching the 1929 level, business is launched on an upward surge which is expected to surpass all previous peaks, according to a survey yesterday of the leading lines by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

ALBANY, Oct. 27. -- Pointing out that cancer is now the second most frequent cause of death and urging the medical profession to unite in teaching the need of periodical examinations for even the well, Governor Lehman proclaimed today the week beginning Nov. 1 as Cancer Crusade Week.

A preview performance of "Red, Hot and Blue," the new Cole Porter musical, will be given tonight at the Alvin Theatre for the benefit of the Maternity Center Association. Among those who will give dinners before the performance are Mrs. Shepard Krech, president of the organization; Mrs. E. Marshall Field, who heads the benefit committee; Mrs. William Hale Harkness, Mrs. Webster B. Todd and Mrs. Olney B. Mairs.

Tammany Hall, long considered lukewarm toward both the national and State administrations, formally predicted last night that President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman would receive unprecedented pluralities in Manhattan. The forecast was made by Representative Christopher D. Sullivan, Stephen Ruddy and Charles H. Hussey, powerful district leaders.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, yesterday assailed John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers and chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, for "obstructing" peace between the craft and industrial union factions in the A.F. of L.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Oct. 27. -- The first "Day of the North" today proved that the spirit of unity, good-will and cooperation prevails among the five Northern States of Denmark, Iceland, Sweden, Norway and Finland.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27. -- The array of mascots that the South African field hockey players brought to the United States failed them badly for the first time today, for the All-America eleven had comparatively little trouble in defeating them, 6 -- 2.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 27. -- Yale's preparations for the Dartmouth game reached the heights today for intensity and endurance. For almost three hours the Blue and Gray squads were sent through various forms of attack and defense behind the closed gates of Anthony Thompson Field.

Governor Lehman scorned demands for "paper economy" in State government in speeches on Staten Island and in Brooklyn last night and insisted that humane social services of the government must be maintained on a proper scale to insure continuance of good standards in education, health and care of the wards of the State.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- The Montana Power Company has filed an application with the Federal Power Commission for authority to issue and sell $48,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage bonds due on Dec. 1, 1966, to bear not less than 3 per cent nor more than 3 3/4 per cent interest, and $10,589,500 of thirty-year debentures, bearing 5 per cent interest and also maturing on Dec. 1, 1966.

LONDON, Oct. 27. -- A naval incident in which three British sailors were allegedly abused by Japanese policemen is serious enough, in the opinion of the British Foreign Office, to warrant a note of protest by this government, which was sent to Tokyo today.

Some penthouses and large apartments were among those reported leased by brokers yesterday. A penthouse at 410 East Fifty-seventh Street was leased to Dr. Mark Gerstle Jr. through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., by the Tishman Realty and Construction Company, Inc., which also leased a ten-room apartment at 983 Park Avenue to Leo Simon through Talman Bigelow, Inc., and a ten-room furnished suite at 125 East Seventy-second Street to Chester C. Levis through Frances Tilghman.

Headed by Mrs. George H. Bostwick's Fugitive, a fine field of twelve will start in the Mount Defiance Cup at the opening of the Essex Fox Hounds meeting in Far Hills, N.J., today. The two-day meeting will be concluded on Saturday with the four-mile New Jersey Hunt Cup as the feature.

Calling upon the administration to invoke a clause in the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Law, permitting modification of trade agreements in cases where devalued currencies adversely affect industry or commerce in the United States, the American Tariff League has petitioned President Roosevelt and Secretary Hull to seek modifications of existing treaties with France, Switzerland and the Netherlands.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 27. -- Mrs. Caroline O'Day, Representative at Large, was assailed here tonight for her support of President Roosevelt by Mrs. Eugene Meyer, chairman of the Westchester County Recreation Committee.

The third annual production of "Night of Stars" tonight in Madison Square Garden, under the auspices of the United Palestine Appeal and Joint Distribution Committee, is expected to attract 20,000 persons, it was announced yesterday by Harold Jacobi, the chairman.
A Landon-Knox banner drifts lazily over Lenox Avenue north of 135th Street, but even Republican spokesmen in the teeming Negro section agree that the ticket hasn't much chance in Harlem.

WOODBURY, N.J., Oct. 27. -- The body of Urquett Harrison, 13 years old, was found at 4:30 P.M. today hanging by a rope from the banister of a stairway between the first and second floors of his home at 111 North Horace Street here.

If there is one point clearly indicated by the straw votes and the other pre-election samplings of opinion, it is that the campaign made by the newest of the American political parties has petered out. There was a day last Summer when Father COUGHLIN boasted that he could swing nine million votes to Mr. LEMKE.
Enrico Venturi, lightweight champion of Europe, outpointed Lew Massey of Philadelphia in a ten-round bout last night at the New York Coliseum before a crowd of 8,000. Each boxer weighed 138 pounds.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 27. -- John Roosevelt, the President's youngest son, urged an enthusiastic audience of 4,000 young Democrats here tonight to get out the vote and put "this State in the right column next Tuesday." Mr. Roosevelt flew from Boston, where he is a student at Harvard College, to attend the rally of the Young Democrats of New Jersey in the Krueger Auditorium, He returned by plane after the meeting.
MOSCOW, Oct. 27. -- The Soviet Government sees only three possible courses of action for the Committee on Non-Intervention in Spain on the eve of its meeting in London tomorrow.

BOSTON, Oct. 27. -- With the volume of business well ahead of that during the corresponding period last year, dealers in furniture, radios and office equipment are clamoring for merchandise. Deliveries have been seriously retarded by inventory shortages.

Baby Salvy Saban, 145 1/2 pounds, of Greenwich Village knocked out Johnny Toomey, 141, Newark, N.J., after 1 minute 45 seconds of the fifth of their scheduled eight-rounder at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night.
The navy played host to the nation yesterday and several hundred thousand Americans visited ships and naval stations here and abroad.
VATICAN CITY, Oct. 27 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin's manner of attack on President Roosevelt, it was reported authoritatively today, is thoroughly disapproved in the Vatican.

ACCORDING to Stefan Zweig, Sholem Asch's "The War Goes On" (Putnam, $3) is an event in world literature. This may be so in the sense that the publication of any serious novel likely to be translated into other languages is an event in world literature. I do not think it is so if Herr Zweig means that "The War Goes On" is another "Kreutzer Sonata," another "Madame Bovary" or another "Main Street."

TALAVERA DE LA REINA, Spain, Oct. 27 (AP). -- American newspaper correspondents, captured by Rebels on an expedition from Madrid, today described to their American colleagues semi-starvation conditions reigning in the capital and declared:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- Washington led the nation today in celebration of Navy Day and coincidentally the birthday of the late President Theodore Roosevelt, who is honored annually by the navy by "at home" on ships and at bases.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 27. -- A horse was killed, a jockey miraculously escaped injury or death, a horseman claimed a dead racer, a claim of foul was denied and Glastonbury, one-time stake horse, won the seventh event, which prayed the impromptu feature before 9,000 spectators today.

With field representatives established in seventeen territories, the Anthracite Industries, Inc., is ready to launch a newspaper advertising campaign in ten to twelve key cities in the anthracite-burning areas in about two weeks, according to an announcement here yesterday.

President Roosevelt, Secretary Harold L. Ickes, Andre de Laboulaye, the French Ambassador; Mayor La Guardia and other distinguished guests will participate today in ceremonies marking the fiftieth anniversary of the dedication of the Statue of Liberty.

IPSWICH, England, Oct. 27. -- Accompanied by one of King Edward's personal detectives, Mrs. Ernest Simpson, pale and agitated, was driven away at high speed from the Assize Court this afternoon, released from the ties that bound her to her husband: She will be free in six months, provided she lives a blameless life, to embark on any other matrimonial venture she desires.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 27. -- Asserting that President Roosevelt repeatedly had broken promises to extend the merit system in the Federal civil service, Governor Landon tonight charged him with creating through Postmaster General Farley a vast army of political mercenaries to entrench his administration in power, and with forcing government employes into a national political machine, supported by the public payrolls and controlled by the President's power of appointment and removal.
Tammany Hall put itself on record yesterday as opposed to the proposed city charter and to proportional representation, both of which will be submitted to the voters next Tuesday.
Block Hall defeated the New York A.C. and the Crescent A.C. turned back the Jackson Heights team, both by the scores of 3 -- 2, as the Eastern Squash Racquets Association season opened yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 27. -- It may be that football scouts chronically look at the other fellow's pasture through green-colored field glasses, but Princeton is taking nothing for granted in its meeting on Saturday with Harvard.

NAVAS DEL MARQUES, Spain, Oct. 27. -- One of the most extensive artillery actions of the Spanish civil war is now in progress in this sector, with a score of Rebel batteries spread over a twenty-mile front pounding away at defense positions leading to Escorial, the key to Madrid from the northwest.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- At least ten European markets for American export products feel that this country and its commercial representatives have not been sufficiently diligent in promoting trade with them, and that a greater effort should be made to meet their particular requirements, S.C. Lamport, New York cotton merchant, reported to Secretary Roper today on his return from a study on the Continent.

Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin signalized her visit to Empire City yesterday by scoring a double victory with Orient Express and Knowing, the latter capturing the featured Elmsford Handicap. Trainer Roy Waldron also came in for his share of congratulations, as both horses were well played on an afternoon when form was well sustained.

WILMINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Delaware, which remained true to Republicanism in 1932, seems likely to be carried by President Roosevelt next week, and the Democrats may elect a Senator to succeed Senator Daniel Hastings.

Mayor La Guardia appealed publicly to voters yesterday to elect Newbold Morris, Republican candidate for president of the Board of Aldermen, at a luncheon rally of independent Democratic and Republican women in the Hotel Woodstock.
LONDON, Oct. 27 (AP). -- Winds, sometimes reaching an eighty-mile-an-hour velocity, raged over England and Scotland today, causing at least five deaths and damage to shipping.

The Brooklyn Juvenile Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Alberto Sciarretti, gave the first of three concerts last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Tito Schipa, tenor, formerly of the Metropolitan Opera Association, was guest artist. The moderate-sized audience was enthusiastic.

Substantial recoveries spread yesterday throughout the list of domestic corporation bonds on the New York Stock Exchange in more active trading. Many of the convertible industrial loans recovered all of Monday's losses as gains ranging from 1 to 5 points were made by those issues.
Hidden behind a basement door at 57 West Seventy-third Street early yesterday morning, Detectives Timothy J. Hegarty and Patrick Harty heard a man knock at a panel and say:

Rumors that Southern cotton mills were rapidly adopting a third shift were denied yesterday by W.W. McLaurine, secretary-treasurer of the American Cotton Manufacturers Association, who declared that in September only 135,000 out of some 18,000,000 spindles were involved in a third shift.

The North American Company and subsidiaries report a consolidated net income of $15,534,833 for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, equal after preferred dividends to $1.60 a share on the common stock, comparing with $12,414,325, or $1.23 a share, in the preceding twelve months.
Following is the text of President Roosevelt's speech at the fiftieth anniversary celebration at the Statue of Liberty yesterday:

Governor Herbert H. Lehman will wind up his campaign with an address on Monday evening at a rally of the American Labor party in the Westchester County Center at White Plains, it was announced yesterday from the Labor party headquarters in the Hotel Claridge, Broadway and Forty-fourth Street.

LONDON, Oct. 28. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange made a brisk recovery today under the influence of the upturn yesterday in Wall Street. British Government securities were advanced once more by renewed investment demand. Iron and steel issues were strong, aviations were bought again and motors made substantial rises.
The lowly sophomore will be very much in the public eye on Saturday on local gridirons.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 28. -- Alter a colorful and ceremonious reception on his arrival here today, King Carol of Rumania conferred with President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia on problems concerning their countries.

The Bellevue Hospital Social Service, which conducts a welfare program for needy patients of the hospital and their dependents, will be the beneficiary of the opening dinner and entertainment tonight in the new Crystal Garden of the RitzCarlton.

Plans are under way for the annual meeting of the New Jersey Vegetable Growers' Association, a section of the State Horticultural Society, which will be held in Atlantic City, Dec. 8, 9 and 10, reports C.H. Nissley, secretary of the association.
A proposal to utilize basement space in school buildings for shop purposes was disapproved yesterday by the Board of Education by a vote of 6 to 1.

In a speech devoted to questions of particular interest to the voters of Queens County, William F. Bleakley, Republican candidate for Governor, pledged his support last night to legislative reapportionment and to a continuance of the mortgage moratorium.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Compensation of officers and employes of the Port of New York Authority is not subject to Federal taxation, the Board of Tax Appeals ruled today. The ruling held that that agency is an instrumentality of two sovereign States charged with the duty of improving the facilities of the port district.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 28. -- The American Labor party held a rally here tonight in the Police Auditorium, which had been refused to it less than two weeks ago. A crowd of 500 persons cheered speakers, who urged the re-election of President Roosevelt and the organization now of a labor party that would put independent candidates in the field at later elections.

Mrs. Mabel Harlow Green took the witness stand yesterday to testify that she did not know what she was doing when she signed away her interest in the $50,000,000 estate which her husband inherited from his mother, Hetty Green.
Numerous store and loft rentals were reported by brokers yesterday. Activity centered in the midtown area. Textile, fur, millinery, restaurant and book concerns were among the lessees, as follows:

In Mr. ROOSEVELT'S address yesterday on the occasion of the ceremonies marking the fiftieth anniversary of the Statue of Liberty, there was expressed one thought which is particularly reassuring in the final phase of a hard-fought campaign and on the eve of a national election.

Nominations for directors of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York to succeed Cecil R. Berry, Class A director, and Robert T. Stevens, Class B director, whose terms will expire on Dec. 31. were announced yesterday by Owen D. Young, deputy chairman of the Reserve Bank.

Jindrich Starch, Czechoslovak Consul General in New York, and Mrs. Starch gave a reception yesterday in the Basildon and Jade Rooms of the Waldorf-Astoria to mark the anniversary of the independence of the Czechoslovak Republic.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 28. -- An estate unofficially estimated as worth more than $1,000,000 is disposed of in the will of John A. Garver, who died at Oyster Bay Cove on Oct. 23. Mr. Garver was the senior member of the law firm of Shearman Sterling of 55 Wall Street, New York.

LONDON, Oct. 28. -- The International Committee on Non-Intervention in Spain, despite strenuous Russian objections, tonight acquitted both Italy and Portugal of charges of violation of the non-intervention agreement.

A group of leading social workers of the State has endorsed the candidacy of Governor Lehman and has formed a committee to work for his re-election. Mrs. Mary Kingsbury Simkhovitch is chairman of the committee.

BUFFALO, Oct. 28. -- With a record registration of 379,000 the closing week of the campaign finds the Republicans in Erie County, the largest political unit in the State outside of the City of New York, extremely hopeful of a heavy lead next Tuesday.
Frank V. Kelly, Brooklyn Democratic leader, formally announced yesterday his opposition to the proposed city charter and proportional representation, which will be voted on Tuesday.

Republicans here took up yesterday the social security issue, which has been raised all over the country by employers who have cooperated with the Republican National Committee in inserting "pay-deduction" slips in pay envelopes.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 28 (AP). -- Frederick H. Stinchfield, president of the American Bar Association, announced today memberships on important standing committees of the association for the coming year. Among those named were:

UHRICHSVILLE, Ohio, Oct. 28 (AP). -- Charles Wheland, president of the Union Bank of Uhrichsville, pleaded guilty in justice court late today to charges of making false reports and false entries which he said amounted to about $400,000. He was held to the grand jury under $25,000 bond.

The Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad has definite plans for the purchase of $8,000,000 worth of freight cars, Ralph Budd, president, announced yesterday. This would be one of the largest orders placed in recent years.

A new back-field combination was formed yesterday as the Manhattan football team speeded the tempo of its preparations for the traditional battle with City College at Ebbets Field Saturday. Scrimmage was ordered for the second successive day by Coach Chick Meehan at Innisfail Park.

Mrs. Geraldine Wilson Smith, whose stage name is Margaret Douglas, has sold the five-story residence at 111 East Sixty-fourth Street to Mrs. Joseph Steinhardt, who will occupy after the house has been altered. The property, with a frontage of twenty-one feet, is assessed at $64,000.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 28 (AP). -- Warrior Queen, a daughter of American Flag and running in the black and yellow silks of the Glen Riddle Farm, took a photographic decision from J.B.J. Townsend's Alexandrine, in a blanket finish that saw Dizzy Dame third and Bad Dreams fourth today at Laurel.

Cases of apparent registration law violations uncovered by the police reached a total of 1,173 yesterday, it was announced by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine. In each of these cases a formal request for the issuance of a warrant was sent the Attorney General.

ROME, Oct. 28 (AP). -- Premier Benito Mussolini said tonight that Italy would defend her empire with her last drop of blood. In a brief speech, broadcast throughout Italy from the Piazza Venezia, he hailed the fourteenth anniversary of the "history-making" march on Rome by his Fascisti.

About 58,000 home-relief families living in unheated apartments in New York will get coal this Winter at a price which will mean a saving of $275,000 in public funds, Miss Charlotte E. Carr, executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Wage earners were advised tonight in broadcasts by six leaders of organized labor not to be misled by pay-envelope warnings and statements of political candidates giving the impression that the worker alone will be assessed for the old age pension fund set up under the Social Security Act.

How can anybody take pleasure in another's pain? There is an almost indecent joy among the foes of virtue in Massachusetts because Mr. ROOSEVELT in his recent visit had not a word of public praise for its illustrious Governor. The omission was more marked because of the cordial good wishes he gave to Governor CROSS of Connecticut.

LONDON, Oct. 28. -- Great Britain's new 34,000-ton battleships will bear the names King George V and Prince of Wales, Sir Samuel Hoare, First Lord of the Admiralty, announced at a dinner of the Navy League last night.

The Downtown Gallery, 113 West Thirteenth Street, reopened for the season yesterday. By combining with its resources those of the Folk Art Gallery on the second floor, Edith Halpert, the director, has been enabled to present a tenth anniversary exhibition covering an extensive range.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 28. -- For the first time in its history the Princeton Glee Club will present series of concerts in Princeton this season, according to an announcement mailed today to 20,000 alumni, faculty, undergraduates and friends of the university.
TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 29. -- The mightiest fleet ever floated in Asiatic waters is being reviewed this morning by its supreme chief, Emperor Hirohito.

Major V.A.N. Kemp, adjutant of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, arrived in New York yesterday, with the National Horse Show, opening in Madison Square Garden next Wednesday, the immediate objective of his visit. He precedes a detachment of thirty-seven members of the Royal Mounted who are to give exhibition rides at the show.

L. Sherman Adams was elected a member of the board of governors of the New York Curb Exchange yesterday to fill the unexpired term of the late Walter H. Sykes Jr. Mr. Adams became a member of the Curb Exchange in April, 1920. He is not a member of any firm.

Large bidding developed for the first time yesterday, the second day of the auctioning of collateral underlying Kreuger Toll 5 per cent debentures. Milton Kramer of White Case, attorneys, representing undisclosed interests, engaged in a protracted duel with John Foster Dulles of Sullivan Cromwell, representing the Kreutoll Realization Company, for possession of a block of $23,800,000 of Hungarian bonds.

HAMBURG, Germany, Oct. 28. -- The Baron von Gablenz, technical director of Lufthansa, has announced that if all goes well Germany will place next year in experimental service over the North Atlantic a specially built, Diesel four-engined flying boat at present under construction in the Bloehm-Voss shipyards.

PANAMA, Republic of Panama, Oct. 28. -- The Presidential election in the United States has aroused greater interest in Latin-America than any other contest in the history of the country, even exceeding that of the re-election of Woodrow Wilson.

LONDON, Oct. 28. -- There is no further mention of the Simpson divorce case in British newspapers but that does not prevent its being almost the sole topic of private conversation everywhere in the social world of London.

ROME, Oct. 28 (AP). -- Twenty accusations that Soviet Russia, between Oct. 9 and 20, sent vast quantities of war materials and men to the aid of the Spanish Government were made today by Italy. The extensive charges were placed before the non-intervention committee in London by Italian Ambassador Dino Grandi.

QUEBEC, Oct. 28. -- Assertions were made today before the legislative committee investigating expenditures under former governments in Quebec Province that money voted by the Provincial Legislature was diverted from the purposes to which it had been assigned.

Max Weisberg, Auburn prison convict, who escaped on Oct. 6 from his home in Brooklyn after being questioned about the garment industry racket by Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey, was captured by the police yesterday afternoon.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 28. -- Samuel Goldwyn today purchased the screen rights to "The Real Glory," a story by Charles Clifford dealing with the American occupation of the Philippines. Although its star has not been determined as yet, the second leading role will be played by Walter Brennan, who after serving fifteen years as an extra and stand-in, has gained recognition.

A plan for the reorganization of the Savoy-Plaza Corporation, which operates the hotel of that name, was approved yesterday by Federal Judge William Bondy. It was disclosed that the termination of the proceedings under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act involves an important real estate purchase.
Mr. Landon's Indianapolis speech on foreign policy has resolved my doubts. I shall vote for Mr. Roosevelt.

Ten women who chipped in 25 cents apiece from their $20 a week salaries in an Edgewater (N.J.) cleaning and dyeing establishment won a paper profit of $150,000 yesterday when Dan Bulger, the horse they had drawn with their $2.50 ticket, galloped in first in the Cambridgeshire at Newmarket, England.

The list of the French liner Ile de France, departing today for Europe, includes Baron Hubert Lejeune, Baron and Baroness E.K. de Meerendre, Miss Edna Falk, winner of the Statue of Liberty golden jubilee essay contest; Guillaume Tronchet, French architect; Yrech Chatelain, Haitian Minister to France; Dr. M.M. Johnson, Roger Boulogne, vice president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Paris; Mrs. Helene Lyelene Pouterman, Roger Goldet, Francois Edmond Blanc, Ernest Simon and Paul Troy.

The 107th Infantry, N.Y.N.G., the old Seventh Regiment, was commended in the annual field inspection report covering the 1936 encampment at Peekskill, N.Y., it was announced yesterday by Colonel Ralph C. Tobin, the commanding officer.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Oct. 28. -- Mrs. George H. Bostwick's Fugitive, one of the best cross-country performers in the East, gained another fine victory today when he captured the Mount Defiance Cup at two and a half miles. It was the feature race on the opening card of the two-day meeting of the Essex Fox Hounds.

Striking back at charges by Colonel Frank C. Knox, Republican candidate for Vice President, and John D.M. Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, James A. Farley made public last night a letter saying the stability of life insurance companies had increased in the Roosevelt administration.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP). -- A bill to reduce the work week of railroad employes to thirty hours without a pay cut is being drafted by rail union leaders for introduction in Congress.

Silk throwing plants aggregating more than 1,000,000 spindles have signified their willingness to join a conference to overcome "chaotic" conditions in the industry through stabilization of wages and hours, it was announced yesterday by Henry J. Tynan of the Tynan Throwing Company and president of the Throwsters Research Institute.

Four concerts by the Philadelphia Orchestra and one performance by the Metropolitan Opera Association will be presented at the Mosque Theatre in Newark this season under the auspices of L. Bamberger Co. Plans were announced yesterday at a luncheon at the store attended by representatives of the orchestra, the opera and a large group of New Jersey music leaders.

Invading Queens last night in his campaign for re-election, Governor Lehman demanded that the New York City government provide full salary restorations for school teachers and city employes at "the earliest possible time." He went on to pledge himself to continue his fight for reapportionment of Congressional and legislative districts.

The support of the Jeffersonian Democrats for William F. Bleakley for Governor was announced yesterday by Colonel Henry Breckinridge, who has already been active as head of that group in supporting Governor Landon for President.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- The extent to which activities of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation have become restricted with the improvement in economic conditions was evidenced today by the corporation's report to Congress for September, which showed that in that month actual disbursements on loans were $16,650,265, while repayments on previous loans were $17,920,603.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 28. -- On the open practice gridiron, Anthony Thompson Field, in the shadow of the Bowl, where on Saturday it will face the challenge of a strong Dartmouth team, Yale continued to drill today with the painstaking care of a young man preparing for a college examination.

PARIS, Oct. 28. -- Finance Minister Vincent Auriol explained to the Finance Commission of the Chamber of Deputies today how he proposes to prepare for 1937 a virtually balanced budget for ordinary expenses by setting aside all exceptional expenditures, to be met in their turn by special finance measures.

A private marketing agreement between the American and Japanese textile industries, in order to solve the problem of Japanese exports of low-price cotton goods to this country was advocated yesterday by Dr. Claudius T. Murchison, president of the Cotton Textile Institute, speaking at the organization's tenth annual convention in the Hotel Biltmore.

The late Samuel Gompers, for many years president of the American Federation of Labor, again was quoted by Governor Landon yesterday to sustain his contention that the real interests of labor are served best by avoiding an alliance with any political party. The Republican Presidential nominee spoke at the Mosque Theatre in Newark to between 3,000 and 4,000 persons.

DES MOINES, Oct. 28 (AP). -- A municipal court bailiff arrested today Albert Penn, manufacturer of electric switches, on a charge of violating the State Election Law by distributing in pay envelopes unsigned notices "tending to create sentiment agaist President Roosevelt."
A tremendous outpouring of men, women and children welcomed President Roosevelt to New York City yesterday as he began the last week of his campaign for re-election.

NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 28. -- A large crowd cheered today as Sir Abe Bailey's Dan Bulgar led a field of twenty-two home in the Cambridgeshire Stakes, famous Autumn handicap. But the bookmakers only groaned.

Dr. Stephen Duggan writes: ''If he [the President] really entertains any 'un-American' designs upon either the Constitution or the court, he has given no specific evidence of it." To the contrary, witness:

Several score of men and one woman driver of America's fastest growing and most sensational motor boat racing class -- the 225s -- voted down every proposal to restrict speed or excitement in their division in a five-hour annual meeting of the contest board at the Hotel Lexington last night.
BRUSSELS, Oct. 28 (AP). -- Belgian Fascists and Flemish Nationalists, opponents of Premier Paul van Zeeland's government, demanded tonight that Belgium withdraw from the League of Nations.
For the first time in six years, renting of space in the buildings of the Wall Street district has turned definitely upward, a survey of the leasing situation there disclosed yesterday.

BERLIN, Oct. 28. -- Prices on the Boerse continued weak generally today, with trading inactive except in shares of heavy industrial companies, which showed strength that had a buoying effect on machine issues. Harpener gained 2 1/2 points, Rheinstahl 2 1/4, Berlin-Karlsruhe 1 and Schubert-Salzer 1 1/2.

Logic should be studied more, both in and out of school, to make our country safe for democracy. It seems to me the politicians are getting away with the most flagrant fallacies. People just don't seem to do any thinking or reasoning for themselves.

Another long and successful practice session was held by Columbia yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for its annual encounter with Cornell here on Saturday. The progress that the Blue made toward rebounding from its setback at the hands of Michigan last week was best evidenced by the smile that adorned Coach Lou Little's countenance.

IT may be that Fair Harvard will go through this football season without gaining the satisfaction of a football triumph over a major opponent, and some of the kindly coaching fraternity are shaking their heads and talking sadly of the woes of Poor Richard, the same being Richard C. Harlow, head coach of the Crimson varsity.

Governor LANDON'S speech at Pittsburgh was in some ways the most effective of his campaign. He was on sure ground: the way the Administration has turned over the bulk of the newly created Federal agencies (outside the classified service) to spoils-men like FARLEY is a dark stain on its record.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- The assets of 14,059 banks affiliated with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation on June 30 were $53,578,392,000, a gain of 13.4 per cent in the last year, it was announced today. Liabilities balanced the assets.

With Coach Jim Crowley taking great precautions to avoid overconfidence because of the victory over St. Mary's last Saturday, the Fordham regulars found some severe opposition yesterday when they battled the reserves in a scrimmage at Fordham Field.

A thorough inquiry into current conditions in any industry affected by the Walsh-Healy Act will precede establishment of minimum wage provisions governing bidders for Federal work under the statute, Gerard D. Reilly, acting administrator, Department of Labor, assured members of the Trade and Commerce Bar Association yesterday.

Small declines were the rule on local commodity futures markets yesterday, with the exception of metals, cocoa and some coffee contracts. On the cash markets, wheat, rye, oats and printcloths declined, while butter, tin, silk and rubber advanced.

The characteristics which made President Theodore Roosevelt "a great leader" were recommended for the youth of today by civic leaders who addressed the annual birthday observance held yesterday under the auspices of the Woman's Roosevelt Memorial Association at Roosevelt House, 28 East Twentieth Street.

LONDON, Oct. 28. -- Just as the American Navy now carries marines for landing duties, so every powerful air force in Europe may soon have its "troops of the air" to be dropped behind the enemy lines in time of war.

Neither the New York Yankees nor the Cleveland Rams obtained any satisfaction in their battle for second place in the American Football League race at the Yankee Stadium last night, for they played four periods to a scoreless tie before 19,000 fans.

The Transit Commission began yesterday a series of public hearings on the application of the Green Bus Lines, Inc., for a certificate of public convenience and necessity to operate a network of bus lines in Queens under a franchise recently granted by the Board of Estimate.

MANILA, Philippines, Oct. 28 (AP). -- A plot by Sakdal extremists to seize the government of Pangasinan Province was revealed today, authorities said, with the arrest of 106 persons and confiscation of bombs and other weapons.

Tammany Hall, under the auspices of which the major Democratic rally of the campaign in this city will be held Saturday night in Madison Square Garden, with President Roosevelt speaking, announced last night its preparations to handle the crowd.

Because at her debut two seasons ago Elizabeth Wysor had attracted considerable attention by singing of exceptional promise, the recital she gave last night in Town Hall was anticipated with special interest. But on this second occasion the young contralto had the odds against her from the start, inasmuch as she was blithely attempting to impress in a program largely unsuited to her temperament and type of voice.

The third annual "Night of Stars" benefit presentation to raise funds for Jewish emergency needs abroad was held in Madison Square Garden last night. Harold Jacobi, chairman of the committee that arranged the program in behalf of the United Palestine Appeal and the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, announced that more than $75,000 had been raised.

Retail package deliveries in the suburban and metropolitan areas increased 18 per cent for the week ended Oct. 24 over the comparative 1935 week, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The rise is the largest for any week since Sept. 5, when a gain of the same percentage was reported.

Cal Hubbard, 255-pound tackle from the Green Bay Packers, was obtained yesterday by the New York Football Giants and will be available for their important contest with the Detroit Lions, National Football League champions, on Sunday at the Polo Grounds.

The artistic efforts of chefs and pastry cooks were on display yesterday at the sixty-eighth Salon of Culinary Art, organized by the Societe Culinaire Philanthropique, as a part of the twenty-first National Hotel Exposition in Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue and Forty-sixth Street.

HARBOR GRACE, Nfld., Oct. 28. -- Captain James A. Mollison landed here this afternoon in his Bellanca monoplane after a flight of 6 hours and 41 minutes from Floyd Bennett Field, N.Y. As he climbed from the cockpit spectators were astonished to see that he wore a dinner jacket under his flying coat.

ABILENE, Kan., Oct. 28 (AP). -- W.T. Markham, Kansas Superintendent of Public Instruction, who is a Democrat, asserted in a radio address tonight that he had been made an "innocent victim of a vicious political attack" by "dopesters" who would "submerge the real issues."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28. -- Secretary Roper asserted at a Democratic rally tonight that Governor Landon, in referring to "so-called spending and extravagance" in his speech here Monday, "completely reversed himself on the policy he had practiced in Kansas until he was made the Republican nominee."

The first fifty-seven railroads to report earnings for September showed an increase of 19.7 per cent in their combined net operating income, compared with September, 1935. The following table shows how earnings of these companies compared with September in 1934 and 1935, with three figures omitted and with the percentage gains:

The first of a series of monthly exhibitions opened yesterday afternoon in the gallery at 324 University Hall, Columbia University. The shows are arranged in connection with the classes in painting, drawing and sculpture and the opening display is of paintings by the Modern Artists of New Jersey.

Ambroise Vollard, the Paris art dealer who staked his career on Paul Cezanne, the painter, almost fifty years ago, is paying his first visit to America. He arrived Tuesday on the Ile de France. In an interview yesterday afternoon at the Bignou Gallery on the eighteenth floor of 32 East Fifty-seventh Street he said the reason he had never come here before was that he always dreaded the trip.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28. -- With the players and delegates to the third triennial conference of the International Federation of Women's Hockey Associations turned tourist for the day at Washington, and with business meetings scheduled for the rest of the week until the next matches on Saturday morning, it is a good time to review some of the conference developments of the past ten days at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 28. -- A six-touchdown assault on the third team featured the Dartmouth scrimmage session today as the varsity went through its hardest work in preparation for Yale. For more than an hour the regulars were kept in the scrimmage under criticism from the coaches, who were not too pleased with the lack of speed shown at times.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP). -- In one of the few statements he has issued this year, Rexford G. Tugwell, Resettlement Administrator, hit out today at critics of the RA with an assertion that "the record of collections answers once and for all prejudiced and partisan criticism" of the agency.

Mrs. Joseph A. Busk of 147 East Fiftieth Street and Red Bank, N.J., entertained at a dinner dance last night in the Jansen Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria to celebrate the birthday of Mrs. Edward A. Hurd. The suite was illuminated entirely by tall Italian candles and decorated with Autumn flowers and ferns for the occasion.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- Characterizing statements made here last night by Mrs. Eugene Meyer about Mrs. Caroline O'Day, New York Representative at Large, as "little less than slanderous," Mrs. Caspar Whitney of 113 East Seventy-first Street, New York, today took Mrs. Meyer to task for her attack on Mrs. O'Day.

Gathered in the heart of the Wall Street district, about 200 business leaders, most of whom described themselves as Republicans, enthusiastically endorsed yesterday the foreign trade policy of the Roosevelt administration and pledged themselves to work for the President's re-election.

Expecting Lafayette to rely on forward passing for the most part, Coach Mal Stevens put the New York University football team through an extensive drill on aerial defense yesterday at Ohio Field as the Violet prepared for its encounter with the Leopards on Saturday at the Yankee Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Senator Norris charged today that electric power interests have assumed a "dog-in-the-manger" attitude toward the administration's rural electrification program and are attempting to "frighten and fool" the farmers in order to frustrate it.

The New Deal's attempts to preserve capitalism refute any statements by its opponents that the present administration is trying to bring about socialism, Dr. Harry W. Laidler, Socialist candidate for Governor, said last night in a radio address over station WJZ.

Plans have been approved by the Berend, including, besides news-Pontiac Motor Company for a considerably higher advertising budget for 1937, it was announced yesterday by F.A. Berend, advertising manager. The largest part of the increase is expected to go into newspapers.
A special meeting of the stockholders of the Federal Water Service Corporation has been called for Dec. 4 to consider a plan proposed by the directors for reclassifying stock and reducing capital.

" Radical" teachers' organizations, most of the members of which are young persons with no hope of advancement in the school system, have been fostered by economies in school budgets, William W. Wattenberg says in "On the Educational Front," a survey of teachers' associations in New York and Chicago published yesterday by the Columbia University Press.

Standard Brands, Inc., voted yesterday to declare an extra dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock, payable on Dec. 10 to holders of record Nov. 9. Action on the quarterly dividend is not due until next month.

The General Sessions trial of Representative Vito Marcantonio of the South Harlem district and John Salas, one of his Republican election district workers, on a second-degree felonious assault indictment was postponed indefinitely yesterday by Judge Owen W. Bohan.

Earnings and dividend rate of the United States Steel Corporation have served, ever since the company's organization in 1901, as landmarks in the period's fluctuating industrial history. The tradition adds interest to the company's action in not only resuming this week the full prescribed dividend on its cumulative 7 per cent preferred stock (not paid for three years past), but in beginning payment of accumulated arrears.

Owner Warren Wright and Trainer Frank Kearns scored another double at Empire City yesterday, each victory being by the margin of a nose and with the camera called into play to help decide the issue. The triumph of Talked About, the son of The Porter, was hardly expected, as his recent form has been such as to discourage backers.

New York City Republicans and anti-New Deal Democrats gave their standard bearer, Governor Alf M. Landon, a rousing reception when he arrived here yesterday for the Republican rally tonight at Madison Square Garden.

MOSCOW, Oct. 28. -- A relay march in gas masks for more than 2,000 miles along the border of European Russia was announced today by Osoaviakhim, the civilian defense organization. Its purpose will be to check up on anti-aircraft and gas defenses in regions most likely to be the objects of attack and to make the general populace air and gas defense conscious.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28. -- A statement by Secretary Wallace in an address Monday night at Bloomington, Ill., that he favored imports if the price of corn should go above $1 a bushel has aroused Republicans to fresh attacks in the farm belt.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28. -- Colder weather and the recent advance in cattle prices which has stimulated the demand for pork resulted in the hog market being quoted today as steady to 10 cents higher than yesterday's prices, with most sales showing advances of 5 to 10 cents.

GALLUP, N.M., Oct. 28. -- Twenty-five miles from this city, on the Navajo Indian reservation at St. Michael's Mission, Arizona, headquarters of the Franciscan Fathers, the Most Rev. Daniel J. Gercke, Bishop of Tucson, dedicated today one of the finest chapels built by the Marquette League of New York City.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 28. -- William H.J. Ely, head of the Works Progress Administration in New Jersey, charged today that Republican county committeemen were "offering reward" to former WPA employes who would sign affidavits criticizing the WPA.

About 1,000 Atlantic Coast seamen at a mass meeting last night voted to empower the Seamen's De fense Committee to call a general strike of seamen in Atlantic ports if the maritime workers on the Pacific Coast are unable to settle differences with their owners.
The text of the speech President Roosevelt delivered at Roosevelt Park yesterday follows:

The blackest portion of our entire wildlife picture in the past has been the continued disagreement between sportsman and nature lover. While the shooter and non-shooter quarreled over methods, the cause of wildlife, which both sought to serve, was the sufferer. And through it all the public at large remained indifferent.

The possibility that former Governor Alfred E. Smith, Democratic nominee for President in 1928, may introduce Governor Alf M. Landon at the rally in Madison Square Garden tonight was indicated last night when it was learned that the selection of Mr. Smith was under consideration.

Total sales of reporting wholesale firms in this district averaged 9.8 per cent higher in September in comparison with the figures for that month a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The six prize-winners among the exhibitors in the third international Leica show being held in the RCA Building, Rockefeller Center, were announced last night by H.W. Zieler, president of E. Leitz, Inc.
The text of the speech by Governor Alf M. Landon, Republican nominee for President, at Newark, N.J., yesterday follows:

Attorneys representing Joseph Speiser, lawyer, of 29 Broadway, and Frank White, an alleged "runner'' for Speiser, started an attack in the Supreme Court yesterday on the validity of the new "ambulance chasing" statute under which grand jury action has been taken against ten attorneys and disciplinary action against twenty others.

The majority of pivotal bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange were unable yesterday to carry through the recovery which had featured dealings on Tuesday. Although a few of the convertible industrial loans responded briskly to a fresh demand, the general run of secondary railroad and utility issues continued to drift aimlessly to lower levels.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 28 (AP). -- William Lemke, Union party candidate for President, said tonight that "the American people abhor dictatorship, but any one who has anything to do with any of these New Deal administrations knows that they are dictatorial beyond reason."

A loss of billions of dollars in available business in recent years has been caused by standardization of styles and depreciation of quality in women's garments, according to a statement analyzing prevalent merchandising practices, issued yesterday by the Fashion Originators Guild of America.

SAYBROOK, Conn., Oct. 28. -- Earlsmoor Dick, owned by Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Milbank of New York City, this afternoon gained his field trial championship in the final event of the third annual meeting of the Connecticut Spaniel Field Trial Association, contested in the covers of the Ingham Hill game farm.

Seven years ago today the heaviest trading in the history of the New York Stock Exchange for a full session was registered. The record of 16,410,030 shares, made on Oct. 29. 1929, still stands. It contrasts with an average turnover of around 1,500,000 shares daily at the present time.

Steel operations remain unchanged at 74 per cent of capacity, The Iron Age announced yesterday in its weekly summary. At Pittsburgh the rate is slightly lower, but this decrease was offset by gains in the Cleveland, Chicago and Detroit areas, the magazine says. It continues:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 28. -- The Ohio Supreme Court held valid today a provision of the Election Code which prevents a splitting of the State's twenty-six electoral votes among different Presidential candidates.

LYNDHURST, N.J., Oct. 28. -- Captain William T. Davidson retired today after fifty years at sea. He will live on his pension from the Clyde-Mallory Line, in whose service he sailed since 1900, and pass most of his time in his cottage at 252 Fern Avenue, overlooking the Passaic River here.

Listing thirty-six dates for the men's division and seventeen for the women, the Amateur Fencers League of America yesterday announced its schedule for the coming season. In addition, the rankings in each of the weapons, foil, epee and saber were released.
BERLIN, Oct. 28. -- The German Labor Front has now organized, largely for propaganda purposes, the German factory workers' rest periods and luncheon hours.

Dr. Livingston Farrand, president of Cornell University, declared last night that, "with such a large equipment for education under private auspices," the formation of a publicly supported college would make it impossible for these "private colleges to live at all."

Eddie (Babe) Risko, former middleweight champion of the world, halted the sensational march of Harry Balsamo, Harlem's belting brakeman, at the New York Hippodrome last night. Showing little concern for the vaunted punching power that lurks in Balsamo's right hand, Risko surprised a gathering of 6,000 fans by outboxing his foe handily and gaining the unanimous decision of the judges and the referee.

Should the election returns next Tuesday conform to the bulk of the predictions and indices, the next Administration will be sure to have real opposition in Congress for the first time since President ROOSEVELT assembled the extra session in the Spring of 1933. If Mr. ROOSEVELT is re-elected, as most of the political experts anticipate, the close popular vote that is indicated will surely erect a base for House opposition.

Both the Columbia University Club, last year's champion, and the Harvard Club squash tennis teams continued to set the pace for the second week in the Class A series of Metropolitan League matches last night.

TOKYO, Oct. 28. -- "We are now about to enter a period of 'trench 'warfare,'" said Yakichiro Suma, Japanese Consul General to Nanking, in an interview on board his train today as he was en route back here to consult on the Chino-Japanese negotiations.

IT is not strange that Constance Rourke's "Audubon" (Harcourt, Brace, $3) is one of the unusual biographies of the year. As biographer and subject Miss Rourke and Audubon make a perfect match. Audubon saw more of America in frontier times than did even Daniel Boone or Vincent Nolte -- Miss Rourke is a well-established authority on the American frontier.

BERLIN, Oct. 28. -- What was described as the opening gun in the execution of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's second Four-Year Plan was fired by Col. Gen. Hermann Goering tonight in an impassioned speech in the Sportpalast. He appealed to the entire German people to work together in the common cause even at the price of temporary sacrifices and uttered dire threats against all daring to interfere with the new aim.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- The Social Security Board today turned over to the Department of Justice for investigation a series of campaign posters attacking the Social Security Law, which, it contended, contained "fraudulent use" of the name of the board.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 28 (AP). -- Attacking the administration's social security legislation as "exceedingly unsatisfactory," Norman Thomas, Socialist party candidate for President, told a convention hall audience tonight that the whole insurance situation "requires fearless and constructive investigation."
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 28. -- That Coach Dick Harlow of Harvard will make two shifts in his varsity football team for the Princeton game on Saturday was definitely decided today.

Indictments charging first and second degree felonious assault were handed to Judge Freschi in General Sessions yesterday by the grand jury against Philip Travis and Bernard Kahn, suspected members of a "strong-arm" gang hired by union members.

The 5,000-ton British freighter Afghanistan was tossing helplessly in a gale last night half way across the North Atlantic and far above the regular ship routes. There was little hope that immediate aid could be sent to the vessel.

The committee headed by R.G. Page, vice president of the Bankers Trust Company, for St. Louis, Iron Mountain Southern Railway river and Gulf divisions first mortgage 4 per cent bonds, defaulted on their maturity on May 1, 1933, expended $5,664 between July 11, 1935, and Aug. 8 last, according to a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- The population of the United States was estimated at 128,429,000 as of July 1, in the preliminary Census Bureau estimate for the year 1936, made public today. The increase over the estimated populalation last year was 908,000, about the same as the increase between 1934 and 1935.

The largest nine months' earnings in its history were reported yesterday by the International Business Machines Corporation. Net earnings for the period ended on Sept. 30 were $5,738,406 after deducting all charges and estimated Federal normal taxes, but before provision for surtax on undistributed profits.

SAN FRANCISCO, Thursday, Oct. 29. -- The midnight deadline for calling a coastwide maritime strike passed without announcement from the joint union negotiating committee. It apparently was awaiting outcome of conferences between coast freight operators and seagoing unions.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 28. -American style soccer as played by the speedy, youthful and rugged St. Louis All-Stars proved too much for the touring Maccabees of Palestine tonight, the visitors bowing, 3 to 2, in a game cut short by two minutes when the Maccabees walked from the field following a fight between Jack Simmerman of St. Louis and their fullback, Epstein.

The listing of securities of six companies not previously traded on the New York Stock Exchange was approved yesterday by the board of governors of the Exchange. The board also ratified the listing of 33,642 additional shares of the Mead Corporation, as well as voting-trust certificates for 1,825,877 shares of no-par common stock of the Hecker Products Corporation, successor to the Gold Dust Corporation.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28. -- John D.M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, today questioned the accuracy of President Roosevelt's statement, made over the radio Friday night, that money collected under the Social Security Act would be "held in a government trust fund."

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 28. -American style soccer as played by the speedy, youthful and rugged St. Louis All-Stars proved too much for the touring Maccabees of Palestine tonight, the visitors bowing, 3 to 2, in a game cut short by two minutes when the Maccabees walked from the field following a fight between Jack Simmerman of St. Louis and their fullback, Epstein.

The listing of securities of six companies not previously traded on the New York Stock Exchange was approved yesterday by the board of governors of the Exchange. The board also ratified the listing of 33,642 additional shares of the Mead Corporation, as well as voting-trust certificates for 1,825,877 shares of no-par common stock of the Hecker Products Corporation, successor to the Gold Dust Corporation.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28. -- John D.M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, today questioned the accuracy of President Roosevelt's statement, made over the radio Friday night, that money collected under the Social Security Act would be "held in a government trust fund."

Judge Clarence G. Galston in the Federal Court in Brooklyn tentatively approved yesterday as "fair and equitable" a plan of reorganization of the Clark and Willow Streets Corporation, owner of the $5,000,000 Towers Hotel on Brooklyn Heights.

The serious drama gets down to business tonight at the Alvin, where they will be putting on the Cole Porter-Howard Lindsay-Russel Crouse musical show, "Red, Hot and Blue!" Jimmy Durante, Ethel Merman and Bob Hope are the stars, and the others in it include Polly Walters, Kay Picture, the Hartmans, Dorothy Vernon, Thurston Crane, Robert Leonard and a great many more.

LACROSSE, Wis., Oct. 28 (AP). -Addressing a special appeal to first voters, Colonel Frank Knox charged the Roosevelt administration tonight with prolonging the depression "distress" of American youth and curtailing its opportunities.

TORONTO, Oct. 28 (Canadian Press). -- On the heels of an announcement that executors of the estate of Charles Vance Millar would apply to the court on Nov. 6 to determine the validity of the "stork derby" clause of his will, a writ on behalf of relatives was filed today in a last-minute effort to upset the $500,000 bequest.

BERNARD DEUTSCH, elected President of the Board of Aldermen on the Fusion ticket in 1933, died two years later. Under the charter the vice chairman of the board, TIMOTHY J. SULLIVAN, Democrat, became Acting President. His successor is to be chosen next week to serve out the remainder of Mr. DEUTSCH'S term, to Dec. 31, 1937.

Criticising the report issued yesterday by the Department of Commerce on foreign trade in September, Francis P. Garvan, president of the Chemical Foundation, Inc., said last night that the report, which showed a favorable trade balance of $4,422,000, failed to take into consideration all items of trade which would reveal the true position of the United States for that month.

The transcendent issue of the campaign is whether America will follow "the middle road" with Roosevelt or the reactionary road to ruin, leading eventually to communism or fascism, with Landon, Secretary Ickes declared last night at a mass meeting at Carnegie Hall.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Oct. 28. -- Long-striding Pompoon, the 2-year-old champion which is being groomed for the Kentucky Derby, found the mile and 70-yard route just a bit too long today and he bowed to Reaping Reward, the slick brown colt from Mrs. Ethel V. Mars's Milky Way Farm, by almost a half length in the $25,000 added New England Futurity at Narragansett Park.

Representatives of leading educational, artistic and civic groups rallied yesterday to the support of the plan of the newly formed Inwood Pottery Association of 745 Fifth Avenue for the perpetuation of the Inwood Potteries as an educational institution of the city on a new site.

Fur dressers in the city's $10,000,000-a-year rabbit skin trade testified yesterday in the Federal Court that they had been victims of violence in 1932 and 1933 when they were not members of the Protective Fur Dressers Corporation.
EDINBURGH, Scotland, Oct. 28. -- Three men will press buttons to open the new $1,750,000 road bridge at Kincardine, on the River Forth, tomorrow, but only one will actually signal the dedication.

LONDON, Oct. 28. -- For almost six hours the International Committee for the Application of the Non-intervention Agreement on Spain wrangled again today and with scant results. Russia alone dissenting, the committee exonerated Portugal and Italy of the charges against them, holding the charges "unproved."

Today's lone newcomer from Hollywood is Katharine Hepburn's and RKO Radio's "A Woman Rebels." which will open at the Radio City Music Hall. The film is an adaptation of Netta Syrett's novel, "Portrait of a Rebel," and was directed by Mark Sandrich.

The play made out of SINCLAIR LEWIS'S novel "It Can't Happen Here," a warning against dictators in America, has for its time of action "very soon -- or never." Mr. ATKINSON, reviewing the play yesterday, gave it as his own opinion that it will be never.

Having a tender affection for "Uncle Tom's Cabin," George Abbott has adorned the old fable with a beautiful production. He calls his adaptation "Sweet River," and last evening he opened it for public inspection at the Fifty-first Street Theatre.
MADRID, Oct. 28 (AP). -- The Spanish Government tonight claimed "the most marked triumph" since the civil war began with the bombing of Insurgent airports at Seville, Granada and Caceres.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP). -- Secretary Ickes announced allocation today of $8,406,891 to 130 PWA projects in thirty-eight States. Grants totaled $7,417,891 and loans $989.000.

The stock market, in somewhat heavier trading, advanced again yesterday. There was considerably more irregularity than on Tuesday, however, and at the close stocks were declining under profit-taking. Most of the gains were recorded in the first hour, when the market was more active than at any other time.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- A foreign trade for 1936 valued at $4,800,000,000 to $5,000,000,000, the highest for any year since 1930, was forecast by the Commerce Department today, based on September figures showing the largest exports since the October, 1935, and larger imports than for any month since October, 1930.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman, guests of honor at a dinner in Brooklyn, heard Frank V. Kelly, the Democratic county leader, predict last night that their husbands will receive a plurality of 500,000 in Kings County.

WARSAW, Poland, Oct. 28. -- The mysterious disappearance from Danzig of Arthur Greiser, president of the Danzig Senate, has caused great consternation in Warsaw after the diplomatic step taken Monday by Dr. Casimir Papee, the Polish High Commissioner in Danzig, who told Mr. Greiser that the Polish Government viewed the situation in the Free City with great concern.

The National Seaway Council, comprising a group of organizations interested in the project for the completion of the St. Lawrence Seaway at an early date, made public yesterday a letter from Secretary of State Cordell Hull supporting its aims and expressing the hope that the treaty between the United States and Canada, which is essential to the development, would be ratified within a year.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28. -- The wheat market showed a firm undertone in the early trading today, but there was not sufficient outside buying to absorb the December contracts offered for sale at $1.16 a bushel and over, and when prices at Winnipeg reacted after an early advance of 1 cent, those on the Board of Trade followed, and closing sales were at net losses of 1/8/ to 5/8/ cent.

Paris style creators are aware of possible social or economic changes to take place in the near future, according to Marjorie Howard, fashion head of the Woman's Home Companion, who discussed style trends for early 1937 at a luncheon of the Fashion Group at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday.
President Roosevelt laid the cornerstone of the gymnasium at the new Brooklyn College yesterday and wished for the institution of higher education "the fine future deserves."

Beneath the up-raised torch of Bartholdi's heroic statue, its once-shining copper weathered green with fifty years of life, President Roosevelt re-dedicated the nation yesterday "to the liberty and the peace" which the Statue of Liberty symbolizes.

The progress of various projects in health, agriculture and homemaking in countries of the Near East was reviewed yesterday by members and officials of the Near East Foundation at the annual meeting in the home of Mrs. Ray P. Stevens, a newly elected vice president, at 834 Fifth Avenue.

Bank clearings in the United States were lower last week than in the preceding week, but showed higher percentage gains over the same week in 1935, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. The aggregate for twenty-two leading cities for the week ended on Wednesday was $5,782,673,000, compared with $4,840,431,000 last year, a gain of 19.5 per cent contrasted with an increase the previous week of only 7 per cent.
Instead of a New York Yacht Club syndicate financing an America's Cup defense candidate, Harold S. Vanderbilt will build the boat himself without outside monetary aid.

Construction in the metropolitan area of New York during the first nine months of this year was valued at $233,147,100, a 41 per cent increase over the $165,081,600 recorded for the corresponding period last year, the F.W. Dodge Corporation reported yesterday.
EDGEWATER, N.J., Oct. 29. -- Harmony was restored this morning to the ten women factory workers whose Irish sweepstakes ticket won $150,000 for them yesterday.
Operators were active yesterday in the purchase of apartment houses in the Bronx.

DETROIT, Oct. 29 (AP). -- Secretary Hull declared tonight that repeal of the reciprocal trade treaties by the United States would "fling in the face of the world a general declaration of economic war."

Mayor La Guardia will spend all day election day on a tour of the five boroughs to see that voting is carried out in an orderly and expeditious manner. Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine, announcing the Mayor's plan yesterday, said his action would aid the police in maintaining order.
LONDON, Oct. 29. -- Arthur Greenwood, Laborite spokesman, launched in Parliament today the Opposition demand that the government permit the sale of British arms to the Madrid government.

A surprise memorandum was produced at the hearing yesterday from the files of counsel to the late Colonel Edward H.R. Green, where it had lain since his marriage in 1917, in an effort to forestall the present claim of his widow, Mrs. Mabel Harlow Green, to his estate.

The last of the foreign military teams which will compete in the international jumping events at the National Horse Show are scheduled to be in New York by Sunday. The British and Irish are listed to arrive this morning on the United States liner Manhattan, while the Canadian officers are due from Toronto the day after tomorrow.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 29 (AP). -- Stockholders of the Atlas Corporation approved today the agreement of consolidation between Atlas Corporation, Pacific Eastern Corporation, Shenandoah Corporation and Sterling Securities Corporation to form Atlas Corporation.

John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers and chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, acting through John Brophy, director of the C.I.O., declined yesterday to comply with the requests of members of the C.I.O. for speedy action on the proposal for peace between the craft and industrial union factions of the American Federation of Labor.

Throwing down the gauntlet to his opponent for the Presidency, Governor Landon at Madison Square Garden last night challenged President Roosevelt to take the American people into his confidence when he speaks in the same hall tomorrow night and tell them what his course would be if he should be re-elected.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve bank credit outstanding during the week ended Oct. 28, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,471,000,000, a decrease of $16,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $6,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1935.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today that the Studebaker Corporation and its subsidiary, the Studebaker Sales Corporation of America, both with headquarters in South Bend, Ind., had entered into a stipulation with the commission to discontinue "certain misleading representations in connection with advertising a financing plan for use by customers in the purchase of automobiles."

LONDON, Oct. 29. -- The House of Commons debate today on non-intervention in the Spanish civil war was a flat anticlimax. The only new idea brought out either by government or Opposition speakers as Parliament reconvened was that this business of denying the Spanish Government its international right to buy arms was not to be considered as a precedent.

Governor Landon received one of the largest and most enthusiastic demonstrations of the campaign last night when he carried his drive for the Presidency into the center of the enemy's territory with a speech at Madison Square Garden.

PRINCETON, N.J., Friday, Oct. 30. -- One man was killed instantly and nineteen persons were injured at 9:09 o'clock last night when six Pullman cars of a thirteen-car Pennsylvania Railroad express train, bound for Cleveland, were derailed about 400 feet south of the Princeton Junction station.

Advertising is expected to play an important part in what is predicted will be the keenest competition ever developed in the middle-price automobile field, according to comment in local advertising circles yesterday. Starting with important price cuts on the 1937 lines, manufacturers of cars selling in the $1,000 retail class are out to get a bigger share of the total market this coming year and will rely heavily on aggressive advertising to support their drives.

The Electric Power and Light Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the year ended on Sept. 30 a consolidated net income of $7,116,041 after all deductions. This was equivalent, after preferred and second preferred dividend requirements, to 41 cents a share on 3,421,261 common shares and was in contrast to a net income of $47,032 the year before.

The estate of William C. Gotshall, engineer, archaeologist and former president of the New York Portchester Railroad, who died Aug. 20, 1935, was appraised yesterday at $1,168,585 gross and $1,010,354 net, of which he left $475,607 in public bequests, mainly to colleges for engineering scholarships.

BERLIN, Oct. 29. -- The Rev. Martin Niemoeller, most determined of the Protestant Church leaders in Germany, confessed to his Berlin followers in an address this week that the church fight had been lost and that the Protestant Church in Germany had now fallen completely under control of the State.

A 69 per cent decrease in eight months in the number of cases added to public relief rolls in this State caused the Temporary Emergency Relief Administration to inform Governor Lehman and the Legislature, in its annual report made public yesterday, that "the long awaited demobilization of relief is at last under way."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Closing today the traveling phase of his campaign, President Roosevelt delivered two sharp attacks against his Republican opponents in Wilkes-Barre and Harrisburg, Pa., received an overwhelming demonstration in the two neighboring cities of Philadelphia and Camden, and stopped at Wilmington, Del., en route here, to read a long quotation on the meaning of liberty from a speech delivered by Abraham Lincoln in 1864.

The Shell Union Oil Corporation has notified the New York Stock Exchange that, effective Nov. 2, Shell Eastern Petroleum Products, Inc., and the Shell Terminal Corporation will be dissolved and their assets acquired by the Shell Union Oil Corporation.
Increased activity by operators in Queens was reported yesterday. In addition to block front deals in residential areas, various other housing properties were included in the turnover.

If the windows in the North International Building at Rockefeller Center had been one inch narrower, visitors at THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair, opening there next Thursday, would have missed seeing the miniature paper-making machine of the Franklin Institute, in Philadelphia.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., Oct. 29. -- The Dixiana entry of Dressy and Crow's Flight ran first and third, respectively, in a six-furlong sprint for 2-year-olds that featured today's card at Narragansett Park.
With a number of nationally prominent players participating, Class A squash racquets competition began last night in the Metropolitan team league.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- A hearing has been called for Nov. 14 by the Securities and Exchange Commission on an application by the Derby Gas and Electric Corporation, a subsidiary holding company of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, a registered holding company, for a report by the commission on a plan of reorganization as provided in Section 11(g) of the Public Utility Act of 1935.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29. -- The next triennial conference and tournament of the International Federation of Women's Hockey Associations will take place in England in the Fall of 1939. The invitation, voiced by Miss H.M.
