Light, president of the All-England Women's Hockey Association, in behalf of the council of her association, was proffered and accepted at the delegates' meeting at the Philadelphia Cricket Club today.

A mixture of trends of prices of commodities in the last week is indicated by The Annalist Weeldy Index of wholesale commodity prices, which advanced to 127.3 on Tuesday from 126.8 the Tuesday previous, and now compares with 125.4 at this time last year.

The figure 2 has appeared in all of the correspondence and publicity emanating from Fordham this week. It is stamped on the notes sent to ticket purchasers for tomorrow's game with Pittsburgh at the Polo Grounds and all the officials at the university on Rose Hill have asked everybody they've talked with about the game to tell everybody else that the figure 2 was important this week.

A four-story building containing twelve apartments and six stores, on a plot 38 by 116 feet, at 2,992 West Thirty-first Street, northwest corner of Surf Avenue, Brooklyn, was bought by a syndicate represented by Charles M. Hiesiger, attorney.

Details of the salaries, commissions and rent paid by the Lehman Corporation, together with the compensation of officers of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation and three other companies, were disclosed yesterday in annual reports to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The Palestine Foundation Fund spent $28,405,000 for Jewish colonization and reconstruction activities from June, 1920, to June, 1936, according to a report submitted last night at the annual meeting of the American Palestine Campaign, Inc., in the Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP). -- A trial examiner's recommendations, compromising the demands of two opposing groups of motor carriers, was criticized today by both groups in oral arguments before the Interstate Commerce Commission in proceedings to determine the local trucking boundaries of the New York metropolitan area.

At least two foreign boats will enter the 1937 Gold Cup regatta on the Detroit River in Detroit over the Labor Day week-end, it was announced at the Contest Board meeting of the American Power Boat Association at the Hotel Lexington last night.

Testimony linking Louis (Lepke) Buchalter and Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro to the Protective Fur Dressers Corporation, allegedly responsible in 1932 an 1933 for bombings and the maiming of dealers in the city's $10,000,000-a-year rabbit skin trade was offered yesterday by the government at the trial of Buchalter and Shapiro for violation of the Federal Anti-Trust Laws.
Following is the text of the speech which William F. Bleakley, Republican candidate for Governor, delivered at Madison Square Garden last night:

The newspapers are filled daily with interviews with and speeches by the leading candidates concerning the major problems of the day, all of which is useful but which involve arguments that are far above the heads of the masses. It is fair enough for the Presidential and Gubernatorial candidates to talk about these major problems, but it is out of place for a candidate for the office of Alderman to try and discuss them.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- In a statement in simple and illustrative language to employes of industrial and business concerns throughout the country, the Social Security Board struck back today at the "pay-cut" notices distributed under Republican auspices over wide sections of the country.

A larger net profit was realized by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation in the quarter ended on Sept. 30 than in any third quarter since 1929, according to a report issued yesterday by Eugene G. Grace, president.

In three long series of questions William F. Bleakley, the Republican candidate for Governor, summed up last night the salient points of his attack upon Governor Lehman's fiscal administration and cooperation with the New Deal, and ended with nineteen pledges on what he would do if elected.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- Unmindful of the chilly weather, sixty-four players turned out today for the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association 1936 finale and Mrs. Russell Holman of Innis Arden took the gross honors in the one-day handicap event over the Westchester Country Club's south course.
LONDON, Oct. 29 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

MADRID, Oct. 29. -- Sudden developments have occurred in the military situation, which today was marked by a powerful offensive on the part of government troops, particularly on the central front, where Insurgents have been pressing in on Madrid for some time.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 29. -- The Princeton football team took the defensive against Harvard plays today in its last practice on University Field prior to the Harvard game Saturday. For nearly an hour the Black squad watched the Orange unfold Crimson plays and worked on pass defense.

HAVANA, Oct. 29. -- Ten members of the crew of the Spanish transatlantic liner Manuel Arnus from Barcelona were detained here today and lodged in Principe Fortress on a charge of insubordination following a complaint by Captain Miguel Corbera.

Class I railways placed 27,718 freight cars in service in the first nine months of this year, the largest for any like period since 1930, the Association of American Railroads announced yesterday. Included were cars built in railroad shops, sometimes with parts reclaimed from discarded equipment.

Six thousand members of the National Union for Social Justice stood with hands upraised in the Hippodrome last night and recited after the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, a pledge that each would work actively to obtain ten votes for William F. Bleakley, Republican candidate for Governor, and for the former State Senator John A. Hastings, who is campaigning against Representative John O'Connor in New York's Sixteenth Congressional District.

New York wildfowlers will open the thirty-day duck-shooting season Sunday under the most drastic regulations in the history of the sport. All of the restrictions in effect last year are continued and, in addition, three important species have been added to the fully protected list -- canvasbacks, redheads and Atlantic brant.

Consolidated operations of the Commercial Credit Company for the quarter ended on Sept. 30, as reported yesterday, resulted in a net income of $3,356,625 after charging off or providing reserves for all losses and doubtful items as well as Federal and other taxes.

There is to be an election in this city next year in some respects more important to it than even the choice of a President this year. In 1937 New York will elect a Mayor and, in effect, an entire new municipal government. It was possible three years ago by combining independent Democrats, city-minded Republicans, and a large number of citizens sworn to no party into a successful Fusion movement.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- A proclamation of "living faith" in the cause and ultimate victory of the Loyalist government in Madrid was made to the National Press Club today by Fernando de los Rios Urruti, the new Spanish Ambassador. He predicted that the fall of Madrid, if it occurred, would make little difference in the struggle, and that "the war will continue exactly as today."
PARIS, Oct. 29. -- Charles Maurras, coeditor of the Royalist Action Francaise, was arrested tonight and confined to Sante prison to serve a term for inciting to assassination.

Aroused by attacks on the Social Security Act, of which he was one of the authors, Senator Robert F. Wagner issued a statement yesterday charging that Governor Landon and his aides are attempting to wreck the social security structure in the nation.
Seven properties in Manhattan and two in the Bronx were bid in by plaintiffs at auction sales yesterday. Tenements comprised the bulk of the offerings. The results follow:

The first public hearing of the Joint Legislative Committee to Investigate Communistic and Subversive Activities in Schools and Colleges was "indefinitely postponed" yesterday, but even members of the committee could not discover why.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 29. -- It was significant that today, two afternoons prior to Harvard's game with the Princeton Tigers, Coach Dick Harlow took the Crimson varsity football players to the tackling dummies once again.

LONDON, Oct. 29. -- Palestine's six-month period of terrorism and a general strike exacted a heavy toll of life. Up to Oct. 15, shortly after the strike had been called off, there had been more than 1,600 casualties including 314 deaths.

Governor Landon will win the election by an electoral vote of 370 to 161, will carry thirty-two of the forty-eight States, and will lead President Roosevelt about four to three in their share of the popular vote, if the final figures in The Liberty Digest poll, made public yesterday, are verified by the count of the ballots next Tuesday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 29. -- Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor, announced tonight he had been informed marine union leaders had decided to call a strike at midnight (3 A.M., E.S.T.) affecting all the Pacific coast's 37,000 maritime union workers.

It was a foregone conclusion that Leonide Massine's third excursion into the field of symphonic ballets, this time with the "Symphonic Fantastique" of Berlioz, would provide the principal item in the fourth American season of the De Basil Ballet Russe, and the opening performance at the Metropolitan Opera House last night served to make that assurance doubly sure.

The continued rise of excess reserves due to the influx of gold from other countries has stirred up some talk of the possibility of another increase in reserve requirements being ordered by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. The board was authorized under the Banking Act of 1935 to raise reserve requirements to double their previous level, and on Aug. 15 it instituted a 50 per cent increase.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 29. -- Dartmouth's football team took its last home workout today in enthusiastic fashion and tomorrow a squad of thirty-five players will leave for New Haven. A short practice will be held in the Yale Bowl and the entire group will spend the night at the Roxbury School.
A first mortgage loan of $15,000 at 5 per cent has been arranged by the Charles F. Noyes Co. for the 26 W. 95th St. Corp on the apartment house at that address.

Democratic and Republican candidates for the Presidency of the Board of Aldermen, speaking before the Owners Division of the Real Estate Board of New York at the Hotel Commodore yesterday, concurred in the opinions that the 10 per cent penalty on tax arrears is too high, that assessments should be reduced in accordance with present-day values and that there should be a reduction of water rates.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Registration statements covering securities with gross proceeds of $260,080,000 became fully effective in September under the provisions of the Securities Act of 1933, raising the total for the quarter from July 1 to Sept. 30 to $909,026,000 and for the first nine months of 1936 to $3,573,973,000, according to an analysis made today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
The wind-up of the Democratic national and State campaigns will take place in this city tonight and tomorrow night, with President Roosevelt heading the list of speakers in each instance.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 29. -- An affidavit by Shelby Barton. a Negro workman on a WPA project in Glassboro, asserting that he had received an offer of $75 if he would obtain twenty-five votes for the Republican party, was made public by the Works Progress Administration here today.

The United States liner Manhattan will arrive today from Europe with General John J. Pershing, wartime commander-in-chief of the United States Army; Dolly Hass, film actress; Brig. Gen. James Leslie Kincaid and Walter A. Leonard, American Consul General at Stockholm.
When MASEFIELD wrote his lines for the launching of the great ship 534 at Clydebank, later named The Queen Mary, he made this wish for her:

DETROIT, Oct. 29. -- Three special administrators were appointed today for the estate of Senator James Couzens after Mrs. Couzens had filed a petition in Probate Court saying that her husband, who accumulated a fortune in the automobile industry, did not leave a will.
PARIS, Oct. 29 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

Subscribers to The Colophon, a book collectors' quarterly, were asked to select the living American authors whose books will most probably be read in the year 2000. Sinclair Lewis received the highest point score, with Willa Cather second, Eugene O'Neill third, and Edna St. Vincent Millay fourth The other leading authors were Robert Frost, Theodore Dreiser, James Truslow Adams, George Santayana, Stephen Vincent Benet and James Branch Cabell.

About 300 gridiron stars of the past and present convened yesterday at the Advertising Club, which played host for the day to the weekly fanning bee of the Touchdown Club. To use the expression of Hugh Gaffney, master of ceremonies, an "All-America line-up of speakers" took the dais for a series of brief talks on "The Moment in Football That Stands Out Most in My Memory."

Governor Lehman is praised as having shown "legislative leadership of a high order" in the annual report of the Citizens Union, made public yesterday, analyzing the 1936 legislative sessions at Albany.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- The texts of addresses today by President Roosevelt in Wilkes-Barre, Harrisburg, Camden and Wilmington were as follows:

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 29. -- President Franklin D. Roosevelt leads all other candidates for the Presidency in a national collegiate poll of ninety-two institutions in thirty-four States of the Union, according to a statement issued tonight by the officers of The Daily Princetonian, which arranged the poll.

AFTER giving the Fordham-Pitt and Yale- Dartmouth situations much thought, this observer has come to no conclusions whatsoever and herewith turns to an easier topic for sweet relief. It's Dizzy Dean. He and Branch the non-alcoholic Rickey have been bickering at long distance in a most amusing way. They must be doing it just for the fun of it because what either one has said so far hardly can be taken seriously.

A further rise of $30,000,000 in excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System to $2,160,000,000, the highest point since the 50 per cent increase in reserve requirements on Aug. 15 was reported by the Reserve System in its weekly statement as of Wednesday, issued yesterday.

Stench and tear-gas bombs were exploded in eight city motion-picture houses last night, all at about 9 o'clock, causing minor injuries to sixty-two persons and sending more than 13,000 into the streets. Eight thousand of the persons were attending four theatres in the Times Square section.
The address of Governor Landon at Madison Square Garden last night follows:

In Madison Square Garden last night Governor LANDON brought to a climax the campaign that began three months ago with his acceptance of his party's nomination. Point by point he reviewed the questions which in his judgment now emerge as the decisive issues of the campaign.

Governor LANDON having declared himself to be in favor of tariff reciprocity, but not the Roosevelt brand of tariff reciprocity, Secretary HULL raised last night in his speech at Detroit the question of what substitute the Republican candidate and his party could offer in case they took command of affairs at Washington.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP). -- Philip L. Carret, former president of the American British and Continental Corporation of New York, told the Securities and Exchange commission today that he believed it to be utterly futile to attempt to regulate investment trusts.

BERLIN, Oct. 29. -- The Aktivist, a weekly for politics and knowledge, accuses the literati of the Third Reich of being "cowards" because they cautiously pass over the German present and prefer to write about the safer past.

Anything goes for a laugh in "Red, Hot and Blue!" which opened at the Alvin last evening. For this is the old Lindsay-Crouse-Porter-Merman combination which set the town on its ear two seasons ago. In place of Victor Moore, they now present that whisky-voiced phenomenon, Jimmy Durante, whose travesty on culture is one of the most likable influences in show business.

PARIS, Oct. 29. -- There has been no budget in many years in France which has aroused so much and so heated controversy as that which Finance Minister Vincent Auriol presented yesterday to the Finance Commission of the Chamber of Deputies.

The appointment of S. Sloan Colt, president of the Bankers Trust Company, as chairman of the finance section of the United Hospitals Campaign Committee was announced yesterday by Edward R. Stettinius Jr., chairman of the commerce and industry division, at a luncheon meeting of campaign workers at 71 Broadway.

In your issue of Oct. 22 your London correspondent, Augur, in his article concerning the British League of Nations Union, makes certain statements concerning the World Peace Congress held at Brussels last month and the international peace campaign which came out of it.
ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- Cornell's football squad had a taste of hard work tonight, drilling under floodlights for the Columbia game.

In an atmosphere surcharged with political excitement, the stock market yesterday continued its recovery from the sharp descent of Monday. Aided materially by heavy buying of steel, motor, copper and some of the utility and amusement shares in the last fifteen minutes of trading, THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks mounted 0.77 point on the day to regain in the last three days 2.59 points of the Monday loss amounting to 2.72 points.

The auction of collateral securing $50,000,000 Kreuger Toll Company 5 per cent debentures was concluded yesterday, with aggregate bids of $9,418,041 accepted by Ira Lurie, auctioneer of Joseph P. Day, Inc., subject to approval of the New York Supreme Court, to which the bids will be submitted within four days.

Mr. and Mrs. Carroll Carstairs were among those who entertained dinner guests last night at the opening of the Crystal Garden of the Ritz-Carlton for the benefit of the Bellevue Hospital Social Service. In their party were Mr. and Mrs. Rodman Wanamaker, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Shevlin. Miss Muriel Richards and Prince Serge Obolensky.

The New York Football Giants' roster was augmented yesterday with the arrival of Cal Hubbard, 225-pound tackle, who had been acquired from Green Bay. The veteran lineman, who is an umpire in the American League in the Summer, took part in a two-hour session as the Eastern champions prepared for the invasion of the Detroit Lions, National League titleholders, on Sunday in the Polo Grounds.

Irregularity developed in fairly active trading on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. Hides and metals advanced and coffee sagged, while other staples held within a narrow range. Pre-election evening-up was believed responsible for the stability.

LONDON, Oct. 29. -- The undertone on the London Stock Exchange remained firm today, with numerous specialties making substantial gains. British Government securities were steady. Textiles became uniformly strong from encouraging reports from the industry.

As a mark of his enduring respect for the man on whose behalf he first entered active politics twenty-four years ago, Governor Alf M. Landon motored to Oyster Bay yesterday morning and laid a wreath of chrysanthemums and Autumn leaves on the hillside grave of Theodore Roosevelt.

Ceferino Garcia, hard-hitting Filipino, is a slight favorite over Izzy Jannazzo, local welterweight, in their fifteen-round bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. Betting, however, is practically even. The winner is to get a shot at Barney Ross's title on Nov. 27.

PARIS, Oct. 29. -- The question of what to do about General Francisco Franco, Spanish Rebel leader, and about Catalonia is becoming so pressing that the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs has been holding long conversations about it with the Foreign Office in London.

The Cotton Thread Institute, holding its fourth annual convention at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday, adopted eight principles of fair trade conduct and re-elected its present slate of officers for the ensuing year. Substantial business gains over 1935 were reported by practically all of the members attending the meeting.

Rising trends predominated yesterday in bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Shaking off the uncertainty that had restricted activities in the more speculative issues on Wednesday, the market for those issues responded readily to a brisk demand which carried many of the pivotal loans up sharply on the day.

Attacking alleged unfair trade practices of some manufacturers and wholesalers in the drug and toilet goods industries, a group of distributors took definite action last night at a meeting in the Governor Clinton Hotel to fight "monopolistic" tendencies.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29. -- The market for hogs declined sharply today after a steady opening, packers paying 15 to 25 cents a hundredweight less than they paid late yesterday. The extreme top of $9.60, established early in the day, was the same as yesterday's, but late in the session the packer-top was $9.25 for good light and medium weight butcher stock.

R.W. Pressprich Co. obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $450,000 of Union Free School District No. 18 of Hempstead, L.I., on a bid of 100.079 for 2.20s. The bonds will be dated Nov. 1, 1936, and mature on Nov. 1, 1937 to 1956.
How effectively several one-man shows can be presented as a group, the Brooklyn Museum has demonstrated by arranging the American series that opens there today, scheduled to remain until Nov. 29.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 29. -- Felix Caracciolo, rated third-string guard until two weeks ago, today was selected to start for Yale against Dartmouth here Saturday. He has finally displaced Henry Wright, veteran of two seasons, and Bill Dickens, who played right guard in the early games.

The following film programs, which will be shown over the weekend, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local private and public elementary and high schools:

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Oct. 29. -- Party designations and names of Presidential nominees are omitted on Florida's ballots. Voters Nov. 3 must decide from two unidentified lists of candidates for Presidential electors which are Republican and which are Democratic.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, who will close his campaign activities on behalf of Governor Alf M. Landon of Kansas with an address in Albany tomorrow night, was reported yesterday to have decided against making any declaration in the State campaign.

Directors of the American Metal Company, Ltd., declared yesterday $4 a share on the 6 per cent preferred stock against accumulated dividends. It was announced that they would meet again this year to consider further dividend action on the preferred stock.

The annual fund-raising campaign of the Visiting Nurse Service, which is administered by the Henry Street Settlement in twenty nursing centers throughout the city, approached the half-way mark yesterday toward the goal of $250,000, the amount set by the committee to meet free service under this year's budget.

BERLI, Oct. 29. -- Prices on the Boerse resumed today a decided tendency toward strength, although the turnover was at a lower level than in recent sessions. Interest centered in shares of industries producing raw materials in response to the program for raw-material self-sufficiency outlined in the speech yesterday by Col. Gen. Hermann Goering, Air Minister.

George Abbott, who gets them away fast, is removing "Sweet River" -- his own adaptation of "Uncle Tom's Cabin" -- from the stage of the Fifty-first Street after tomorrow night's performance -- a total of five performances. It opened there Wednesday night, but was not greeted with wild acclaim.

In appreciation of his long service to the League for Political Education and to Town Hall, a bronze plaque of Henry W. Taft was dedicated yesterday. He has been for sixteen years President of the board of trustees of the league and one of the most influential members of Town Hall Club.

The garage at 511-15 E. 116th St. was leased by the 511 E. 116th St. Corp. Domenico Balsamo, president, to the Lehigh Coach Auto Co., Inc., Ralph Ruggiero, president for five years from last Sept.1 at annual rents of $3,300. The lessee also is to pay the real estate taxes in excess of $1,000 in any one year.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 29. -- Despite an appreciable drop in the operating rate of the steel industry, business activity in the Pittsburgh district moved a little higher again last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP). -- Reporting campaign expenditures of $142,709 since its organization last Spring. Labor's Non-Partisan League, pledged to President Roosevelt, today disclosed the United Mine Workers as its largest contributor.

Former Mayor James J. Walker last night made his first political speech in four years. For more than an hour he denounced Alfred E. Smith and other National Jefferson Democrats for walking out on their party and extolled President Roosevelt as the man who saved the nation from destruction.

A program fitting youth for a collectivized society while maintaining the traditions of democracy was envisaged yesterday as a basic responsibility of general education in America at a conference of 500 educators in the Hotel Roosevelt.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29. -- Domestic wheat markets today made only a moderate response to the sharpest decline abroad that has been witnessed in some time Strong support developed in the December around $1.14 a bushel on resting orders which checked the downward trend, but the close on the Board of Trade was at net losses of 1/6 to 1 cent.

Governor Lehman delivered a sharp reply last night to the charge of "communism" raised against the Democrats. Visiting the Bronx and Manhattan for a series of addresses, the Governor hailed President Roosevelt for bringing recovery and declared that the Democratic party was "American in spirit and letter" and genuinely carrying the ideals of Thomas Jefferson by battling for humane and progressive government.

The current movement of holiday merchandise into this port reveals an increase of 10 to 15 per cent, compared with last year, according to unofficial estimates available among importers yesterday. Although the number of individual entries is only slightly larger, they said, the volume included in each shipment is 5 to 35 per cent greater.

IT is six months to the day since A.E. Housman died, and for the first time one is in a position to see with some clarity the extraordinary character and career that were his. His final volume of verse, "More Poems" (Knopf, $2) has appeared. A.S.F. Gow, a Cambridge scholar who knew him for twenty-five years, has written a biographical and bibliographical sketch: "A.E. Housman" (Macmillan, $1.75).
HARBOR GRACE, Nfld., Oct. 29 (AP). -- Defying adverse weather conditions, Captain James A. Mollison tonight headed across the Atlantic with the hope of breakfasting in London.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 29. -- Nearly 2,000 common stockholders in the Pittsburgh United Corporation are facing complete loss of their investment as a result of action threatened by a group of preferred stockholders.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 29. -- Every industrial center in Pennsylvania...

Laurence Stallings would be bored today if he had to look again at "What Price Glory?" which he and Maxwell Anderson wrote twelve years ago. He would much rather see "a rattling good play of Moliere."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Net railway operating income in September was $68,749,443, an increase of $12,666,339 over September of last year, the Association of American Railroads announced today after a tabulation of advance reports from 123 Class I railroads representing 97.6 per cent of the total operating revenues of the country.

Critics of the new charter have had most of the headlines this week. The triumvirate which is handling Tammany affairs during the illness of Leader DOOLING announces that it is "unanimously opposed" to it. Not to be outdone by Messrs. SULLIVAN, RUDDY and HUSSEY, shepherds of the Manhattan faithful, FRANK KELLY, the Brooklyn Democratic chieftain, denounces the Charter Commission's proposals as "thwarting the people's will," setting up a "super-power" and "subversive to representative government."

The probability that Fordham will use an abundance of reserves in its game with Pittsburgh at the Polo Grounds tomorrow became more apparent yesterday at Fordham Field as Coach Jim Crowley sent his third-string team against a freshman eleven in a lengthy scrimmage.

LONDON, Oct. 29. -- Reports from the Spanish war front indicate that General Francisco Franco is concentrating the main body of his troops south and west of Madrid and intends to launch an attack there soon, even if the northern defenses do not fall.

The Flanagan-Nay Brewing Corporation, which was discharged from reorganization proceedings after meeting its obligations last April, filed a plea in bankruptcy yesterday in Federal court. It reported liabilities of $1,151,734 and assets of $1,062,806.

As the site for a six-story elevator apartment house the property at 402-08 East Seventy-fourth Street, near First Avenue, has been purchased by Barnet Klar and Arthur Cutler from the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank. The property, which was acquired through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., consists of four six-story tenement houses on a plot 100 by 100 feet.

BOSTON, Oct. 29. -- A postal worker who observed a large "s" in Washington's name on a 2-cent stamp caused the arrest of five men today in what Federal officials said was a fake stamp racket that might have nationwide ramifications.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- The Federal Communications Commission announced today that the Columbia Broadcasting Company, when, on Oct. 17, it refused to permit Senator Vandenberg to engage in a debate with the recorded voice of President Roosevelt, was acting within its legal rights and the FCC cannot and will not take action against the broadcasting system.

ARKANSAS CITY, Kan., Oct. 29 (AP). -- General Hugh S. Johnson, former NRA Administrator, predicted informally here tonight that a new NRA "is certain to be developed in the next few years" and that it "will come spontaneously from the people, not down from Washington."

Milton Speiser, 54 years old, of 300 Central Park West, senior member of the law firm of Speiser Speiser at 29 Broadway, was arrested yesterday on a misdemeanor charge growing out of an accident suit last Summer in the Supreme Court.
General GOERING ushered in HITLER'S second Four-Year Plan with a powerful speech, and now the German people know on which side their bread is buttered. It is to be on neither side.

LONDON, Oct. 29. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin shook up his Cabinet with unexpected severity today. He sent one of his most trusted Ministers back into obscurity and promoted three of his younger colleagues to higher rank.

Governor Landon, addressing 3,200 persons at a luncheon yesterday afternoon in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, charged "extravagance and waste" by the Federal administration and complimented former Governor Alfred E. Smith, John W. Davis, George V. McLaughlin, former Police Commissioner, and Borough President Ingersoll for joining with the Republicans "to protect the American form of government."

BERLIN, Oct. 29. -- There were indications today that, despite Colonel-General Hermann Goering's appointment as economic dictator in charge of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's second Four-Year plan, the battle between conflicting economic views and interests was still proceeding behind the scenes.
The New York A.C., Jackson Heights and the City A.C. triumphed as play in Group 1 of the Eastern Squash Racquets Associations opened yesterday.
Fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange held within narrow limits yesterday and the list ended with losses of 1 to 5 points on the day.

WITH GENERAL EMILIO MOLA'S REBEL TROOPS ON THE MADRID FRONT, Oct. 28 (Delayed). -- With the Insurgents now camped outside Torrejon de la Calzada, sixteen miles from Madrid and less than eight miles from the Getafe Airfield, military officials here generally assert they can take the capital whenever they wish.
Numerous apartments on the upper East Side were included in the rentals reported yesterday, as follows:

Old Man BORAH, he ain't sayin' nothin'. This must be hard for him; but he may be consoled by the thought that it impoverishes the public stock of wisdom. HIRAM JOHNSON, safe in his seat, curiously refrains from enlightening the nation. ARTHUR CAPPER, inventor of agriculture, mends his fences noiselessly.
The 1936 convention of the Amateur Athletic Union in Houston, Texas, in December won't be a Donnybrook affair like last year's session if Jeremiah T. Mahoney can help it.

Announcing that their plan has been approved in principle by the Federal Trade Commission, leaders in the popular-price dress field took further steps at a meeting last night in the Governor Clinton Hotel to organize a control bureau to curb unwarranted returns of merchandise.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- Mayor La Guardia of New York declared here tonight that the paramount issue of the campaign was whether the preservation of the well-being of a people should be retained as the highest function of a government.

Confidence that the new city charter will be adopted at the polls despite Tammany opposition was expressed yesterday by George Brokaw Compton, campaign manager of the Citizens Charter Campaign Committee.

The City Club, the League of Women Voters, the Merchants Association, the Chamber of Commerce and the Citizens Budget Commission have united in a public appeal for the defeat of the referendum introducing the three-platoon system in the Fire Department.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 29 (AP). -- War Emblem, son of Big Blaze, scored his first victory of the year in the fourth race, which served feature purposes on today's Laurel program. With Jockey Eddie De Camillis doing the booting, War Emblem set his own pace and bounded to the finish line two lengths in front of Bijuro and Albania, members of the Mrs. Emil Denemark entry.

Herb Kopf and Sam Cordovano were passing the time of day with visitors in the Columbia dressing room at Baker Field, while changing into their football clothes. Over in the corner Lou Little, keeping his grim thoughts to himself as he got into his uniform, turned to his assistants and spoke sharply.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 29. -- The time will come when gas pipes from coal mines to metropolitan areas will take the place of the high-tension electric power lines, according to E.P. Kramer of Atlanta.

A new issue of 150,000 shares of $1-par value capital stock of the Majestic Radio and Television Corporation will be marketed today by J.A. Sisto Co., the first public financing for the corporation. Them stock, which will be priced at $3.75 a share, will be offered by means of a prospectus.

City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr. closed his testimony before the Transit Commission yesterday after six days spent in explaining and defending the $436,000,000 rapid transit unification plan drafted by himself and Samuel Seabury after negotiation with representatives of privately operated traction lines.

Titian's painting, "Education of Cupid," which was shown publicly in this country for the first time this Summer at the Great Lakes Exposition in Cleveland, has been sold for an unnamed price to Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Worcester of Chicago.

ARLINGTON, Texas, Oct. 29 (AP). -- Mrs. Irene Meripol's Beth Macaw sprinted into a comfortable lead from the barrier and held on well today to take the feature event before 9,000 racing fans at Arlington Downs.

David E. Grange, vice president of the International Seamen's Union, announced yesterday that he had submitted to the newly appointed Federal Maritime Commission and to officials of ship lines a request for uniform scales of wages and working conditions in the maritime trades on the Atlantic and Pacific Coasts.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 29 (AP). -- Counsel for J.H. O'Donnell of Pittsburgh sought a contempt of court citation today against the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, but Judge David R. Hertz continued hearing of arguments on the motion until Nov. 5, two days after the national election.
BERLIN, Oct. 29. -- Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Germany's Propaganda Minister, had a birthday today, and brass bands serenaded him from 9 o'clock in the morning until midnight.

The American Newspaper Guild made public yesterday a letter to William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, expressing conditional acceptance of the proposed agreement of the executive council of the A.F. of L. for termination of the three-month-old strike against The Seattle Post-Intelligencer.

Four new films will begin residence today at Broadway theatres. They are Metro's "Libeled Lady," featuring Spencer Tracy, William Powell, Myrna Loy and Jean Harlow, at the Capitol; Gaumont-British's "East Meets West," starring George Arliss, at the Roxy; Paramount's "Wives Never Know," with the comedy team of Charles Ruggles and Mary Boland, at the Rialto, and Universal's "The Man I Marry," which serves to introduce Doris Nolan to screen audiences, at the Palace.
A $200,000 apartment house for the Bronx and various dwellings for Brooklyn and Queens were among the building projects filed yesterday, as follows:

Irving Anderson, young apprentice rider, who may prove to be the leading jockey of the Empire City meeting, scored a triple yesterday with three colorbearers of Mrs. Ethel Jacobs -- Easiest Way, My Peter and Aperitif Hirsch Jacobs, trainer of his wife's horses, has set a new record this season for winners saddled, and it was he who gave Anderson the leg up on each of his victors.

Meyer D. Rothschild, writing under caption "Banks and Federal Bonds," contests my repudiation of Mr. Roosevelt's campaign statements as to the super-security of banks holding high portfolio percentages of government bonds and guaranteed obligations. He has premised his argument on ratios held in several of our metropolitan banks and trust companies.

An action brought by Charles Francis Coe's Vigilantes to strike the names of 943 lodging house residents from the registration rolls was dismissed yesterday afternoon by Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

John B. Glenn, president of the Harbor State Bank, announced yesterday his withdrawal as a candidate for a Class A directorship of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, for which post he had been nominated by his own bank.

OTTAWA, Oct. 29 (Canadian Press). -- The Bank of Canada reported today an appreciation this week of more than $3,000,000 each in the deposits of the Dominion Government and the chartered banks. The statement follows:

Shunning assiduously all hint of prima donna airs and graces in conducting his orchestra in the first of its concerts this season at Town Hall last night, Paul Stassevitch put self in the background and sought only to bring out the meaning of the unhackneyed works chosen for performance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Charging that statements published by the New Jersey WPA regarding expenses of projects were grossly "misleading and incorrect," four New Jersey Republicans today repeated their demands in United States District Court for access to WPA records.

Two stake events at Empire City today will ring down the curtain on the metropolitan racing season on the Jockey Club tracks. Except for the United Hunts meeting next Tuesday, getaway day at Yonkers will wind up the local campaign.

Commenting on the statement that he was slated to become United States Ambassador to Moscow, made by Father Coughlin at the Hippodrome meeting on Thursday night, David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, and a Roosevelt elector from New York State, made this statement yesterday:

BINGHAMTON, Oct. 30. -- Three counties strung along the Pennsylvania border, re-enforced by seven others grouped with them in the Sixth Judicial District, of which Broome County is the hub and this city the political center, will contribute from 80,000 to 100,000 to predicted up-State Republican pluralities at Tuesday's election, according to leaders here.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 30 (AP). -- Pickets armed with sticks took up positions here today at approaches to the Galvez Street wharf in a local strike in sympathy with the maritime walkout on the Pacific Coast.
John I. Campbell, assistant superintendent of the Railway Mail Service in New York, having passed his three score yeas and ten, will be retired today.

The development of personality rather than intelligence alone was seen as a responsibility of American schools and colleges yesterday by Percy G. Kammerer, provost of Avon Old Farms, preparatory school at Avon, Conn. Mr. Kammerer spoke at the conference of educators under the sponsorship of the Educational Records Bureau in the Hotel Roosevelt.

PHILADELHIA, Oct. 30. -- Tomorrow morning at 10 o'clock the third triennial conference of the International Federation of Women's Hockey Associations enters the final phase of its two-week meeting at the Philadelphia Cricket Club. At that time the penultimate round of games will start, with South Africa playing the mixed Etcetera team.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., Oct. 30. -- The text of Governor Landon's speech here tonight was as follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP). -- In its final report before election, the Democratic National Committee revealed today that it had expended $3,406,501 on the Presidential campaign, $561,427 in the week ended Oct. 28.

The second performance of the De Basil Ballet Russe at the Metropolitan Opera House last night produced also the second premiere of the current season. This was "Le Pavilion," which had the added interest of being the first piece of choreographic work by David Lichine to be presented in New York.

LONDON, Oct. 30. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange were again in a cheerful atmosphere today and business continued to expand. The rush to buy rubber shares sent prices soaring as a result of the steady improvement in the price of the commodity.
MADRID, Oct. 30. -- Children playing in a public park in the Gloriet del Bilbao district met death from shrapnel while their mothers looked on in the Rebel air raid today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30. -- Prepared to show its most varied attack of the season, Pennsylvania acts as host to the Naval Academy team on Franklin Field tomorrow in the twenty-first football game of the series that started in 1888.
BATES vs. BOWDOIN -- It's going to be tough getting out of the woods today. The fact is, it seems safer to stay in there and hide away from the storm. Through a leafy covering, one vote for Bowdoin.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Oct. 31. -- With the return to Shanghai this morning of Consul General Yakichiro Suma, after Tokyo conferences that are reported to have resulted in Japanese determination on inflexible insistence on all demands, China is assuming a new attitude of determined resistance.

Leaders of educational, civic and cultural groups advocated more widespread opportunities for the study and enjoyment of music at a forum meeting conducted yesterday under the auspices of the New York State Federation of Music Clubs in the Hotel Astor.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 30 (AP). -Expressing confidence that striking maritime workers and their employers could "get together if they will resume negotiations," Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins telegraphed an appeal to both sides at San Francisco tonight asking them to resume conferences.
President Roosevelt was received with open arms and a ten-minute ovation of welcome in Brooklyn last night.

About 1,000 of the country's leading physicists from universities and industrial research laboratories, attending the anniversary meeting of the American Institute of Physics at the Hotel Pennsylvania, were taken to task yesterday for concentrating their energies on atoms and on 200-inch telescopes while leaving unsolved such problems within their realm as how to provide decent shelter for the millions now deprived of it.

The more than $20,000,000 collected the first nine months from employers under the State Unemployment Insurance Law in conformity with the Federal Social Security Act may be considered by employes a wage increase and not a pay cut, Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, pointed out yesterday in a statement.

ROME, Oct. 30. -- It is understood, though the news still lacks official confirmation, that the Italian Government is about to break off diplomatic relations with Madrid and grant official recognition to Generalissimo Francisco Franco's Rebel government.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30. -- Ogden L. Mills accused President Roosevelt tonight of presenting a distorted picture of "the flood of government expenditures that are sweeping us to disaster."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP). -- Acting on complaints from the Social Security Board and a dozen labor organizations, Senate agents today investigated charges of anti-New Deal "pay envelope pressure" on workers in Midwestern steel, automobile and rubber factories.
One of football's oldest rivalries will enter its twenty-fourth chapter today when Columbia and Cornell meet at Baker Field before an expected crowd of 25,000. The kickoff will be at 2 o'clock.

Thirteen men and a "protective" association were indicted yesterday on charges of extortion, attempted extortion and conspiracy in the $2,000,000-a-year restaurant racket, organized by the late Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, and recently exposed by Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey and the extraordinary grand jury investigating rackets.

Headed by the traditional meeting between Hill and Lawrenceville, today's football schedule presents a number of prep school games of front-rank importance and many leading metropolitan high school clashes as the campaign rounds into the final half of the season.

TWO more foreign army teams, the British and Irish, arrived yesterday aboard the United States liner Manhattan to begin preparations for their appearance in the nightly international military jumping contests on the program of the National Horse Show, which opens in Madison Square Garden next Wednesday.

MEXICO, D.F., Oct.30 (AP). -- The score of 75 posted last Sunday by P.J. Clifford of Mexico City over the Chapultepec course withstood the challenges of an even dozen players from the United States today in the qualifying round for the Mexican national golf championship.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 30. -- Mr. and Mrs. Percy L. Hance departed from the Greenbrier this morning for New York, where they will entertain in their Fifth Avenue residence on election day in honor of the golden wedding anniversary of Mr. Hance's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John A. Hance.

BERLIN, Oct. 30. -- The newspapers tomorrow will carry a warning to German automobile drivers to slow down and lighten their loads in order not to wear out their tires. They will also be warned against using their present tires so long that they cannot be repaired.

A cross-section of the continent of Africa is the objective of the guns and cameras which comprise the principal features of six tons of equipment of a trans-African safari, whose leader, Lawrence Copley Thaw, broker, of 1 Wall Street, is scheduled to sail today on the Italian liner Vulcania.

The Brooklyn Department of Buildings was the center of activity yesterday when architects filed plans there for a number of projects. The largest project calls for the erection of twenty one-family dwellings costing $80,000 in East Seventeenth Street. Other operations in Kings provide for the erection of one-family homes in Avenue X and in East Forty-eighth Street.

Pitt's Panthers stalked into New York yesterday, gave a demonstration of what may be expected when they meet Fordham's Rams at the Polo Grounds this afternoon and left observers with the conviction that they are not the strong team they were last year.

The first in a series of six concerts devoted entirely to the orchestral works and concerti of J.S. Bach was given last night at the New School for Social Research before a highly enthusiastic audience which filled every part of the school's auditorium and balcony.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 30. -- Those ancient gridiron rivals, Harvard and Princeton, will meet for the thirty-second time since 1877 tomorrow, with the scales tipped heavily in favor of the Tiger and the twentieth Nassau triumph in the series virtually conceded.

A brilliant scene with features reminiscent of several decades ago was presented last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, where the Velvet Ball and Debutante Election Cotillion were held for the benefit of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children.

Publication of the "Retailer's Calendar and Promotional Guide for 1937" was announced yesterday by Thomas Robb, manager of the sales promotion division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association. The calendar indicates "what should he promoted throughout 1937 for best volume and profit results" and does not merely reflect what stores usually advertise in the various months, he said.

ORANGEBURG, S.C., Oct. 30 (AP). -- Completing a fifty-four-yard lateral pass play for a touchdown in the first period, the South Carolina Gamecocks added a safety in the third and defeated The Citadel today, 9 -- 0. It was South Carolina's tenth straight victory over the cadets.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- President Roosevelt issued a proclamation today directing that Armistice Day, Wednesday, Nov. 11, the eighteenth anniversary of the end of the World War, be observed with fitting ceremonies all over the United States.

In response to the favorable quarterly earnings statements and larger dividends declared in the last week, steel stocks advanced again yesterday. United States Steel preferred selling ex-dividend, opened with a net gain of 3 3/4 points, or exactly the amount of the dividend which came off the price of the stock.

Warner Brothers' "The Charge of the Light Brigade," with Errol Flynn and Olivia de Havilland, will begin an engagement at the Strand today. Bearing the title of Tennyson's famous poem, the film narrates certain hypothetical events leading to the suicidal attack of the English cavalry against the Russians in the Crimean War.

The Tammany clubhouse of the Seventeenth Assembly District, the Owasco Club, at 132 West 118th Street, was broken into Thursday afternoon, and among the things stolen were 500 of the club postal cards used to notify members of meetings.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 30. -- The Naval Academy will acquire the famous ocean racing ketch Vamarie, through the gift of the owner, Vadim S. Makaroff of Oyster Bay, L.I., according to information forwarded to the Academy today by the Secretary of the Navy.

Waterbury, Conn., has invited tenders for a new issue of $1,500,000 of relief bonds, award of which will be made on Nov. 12. The bonds will be dated Nov. 1, 1936, and mature on Nov. 1, 1940 to 1951. Bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 4 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30. -- Holy Cross, one of the East's five major undefeated football teams, clashes with Temple University here tomorrow in a game that has attracted considerable interest. The Crusaders, who arrived late this afternoon, have won seventeen games and been tied once since being beaten by Temple in 1934.

Bonds worked irregularly higher yesterday in less active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. While a few of the convertible industrial loans continued their brisk advance, the market generally lacked the buoyancy which had featured trading in the corporate issues on the preceding day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP). -- Making public a list of executive salaries reported by corporations, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported that William S. Menden, President of the Brooklyn Manhattan Transit Corporation of Brooklyn, received remuneration totaling $62,180 in the company's last fiscal year.

With the sudden change to cold weather stimulating the demand for all types of Winter merchandise retail sales this week increased 5 to 8 per cent over last week's volume for the country as a whole, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

In a drive to win by this evening a call for a general Atlantic Coast walkout to aid the 39,000 Pacific maritime workers who went on strike yesterday, 1,000 seamen affiliated with the "rank-and-file" Seamen's Defense Committee voted unanimously last night to extend to all ships due to leave this port today a "sit-down" strike which yesterday tied up three vessels at their sailing times.

Reporting unprecedented expansion everywhere in the sport of motor boating, the officers, committeemen and yacht club delegates who paid their annual visit to New York yesterday for the conclave of the American Power Boat Association at the Hotel Lexington began considering still newer and more elaborate plans for the future.

NANKING, China, Saturday, Oct. 31. -China's growing militant spirit reached new intensity Saturday as the nation's capital began the celebration of General Chiang Kaishek's fiftieth birthday in an atmosphere savoring slightly of fascist pageantry at Rome and Berlin.

The heaviest gains in local retail trade since Columbus Day featured the week here, store executives said yesterday. Aided by the drop in temperature which spurred consumer-apparel demand, and also by the fact that figures for the comparative week last year were poor, gains here averaging around 15 to 20 per cent were reported.

Fifteen workmen were hurled into Jamaica Bay at 3:40 P.M. yesterday when a converted beam trawler and a 104-foot oil tanker were in collision midway between Barren Island, Brooklyn, and Jacob Riis Park, Rockaway Beach, Queens.

BERLIN, Oct. 30. -- That Chancellor Adolf Hitler's second Four-Year Plan is to be carried through under a system of fixed prices designed to displace the "capitalistic" law of supply and demand with a more "socialistic" managed economy was indicated today by the promulgation of a decree bestowing sweeping powers upon Josef Wagner, the new price commissar recently appointed by Col. Gen. Hermann Goering in his capacity as economic dictator.

The recent attacks on Earl Browder in Terre Haute, Ind., and Tampa, Fla., are exhibitions of mob violence most disquieting to all who believe in maintaining orderly democratic self-government. No such breaches of the peace ought to be condoned under any government of laws.

Briefs were filed with the United States Supreme Court this week by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and associated companies and by the General Telephone Company group in suits to enjoin the enforcement of an order of the Federal Communications Commission prescribing a uniform system of accounts for telephone companies.
The senior class dance at Columbia, the first formal of the school social season, will be held tonight in John Jay Hall, which will be decorated in a Halloween motiff.
DENVER, Oct. 30. -- Herbert Hoover said here tonight that he had rejected, when President, most of the ideas subsequently adopted by the Roosevelt administration.

Mrs. Skinker Matthews gave a reception and tea yesterday in the Garden of the Ambassador for Prince and Princess Rodolfo del Drago of Rome and the latter's mother, Mrs. Francis Allen Wallace, who are passing the Winter at that hotel.
A statement by Dr. Edward C. Povdin against the new city charter, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES, contains two serious errors:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 30. -- Three checks sent today from the Resettlement Administration here purchased 288 acres of land in Northampton County, Pa., for the first community farmsteads project in the East, it was announced by Dorothy M. Beck, regional director.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 30. -- Waterfront activity in all American ports of the Pacific Coast came to an almost complete halt today as 39,000 maritime workers went on strike, but government representatives sought means of bringing the dispute to a quick conclusion.

Izzy Jannazzo, East Side contender for the world welterweight championship, and Ceferino Garcia, hard-hitting Filipino from Los Angeles, battled to a draw in the feature bout of fifteen rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.
Former Governor Alfred E. Smith condemned yesterday the proportional representation proposal to be submitted to the voters of the city on election day, terming the plan "freakish" and unworkable.

The United Gas Improvement Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the year ended on Sept. 30 a consolidated net income of $28,656,808. This was equal, after preferred dividends, to $1.07 a share on the common stock. It compared with $29,924,385, or $1.12 a share, the year before.

President Roosevelt began his final drive for re-election last night with a short but impassioned address before a wildly enthusiastic crowd which packed the Brooklyn Academy of Music as he extolled the record of his administration as "a job well done" and declared his intention of carrying forward its program of national unity in the next four years.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30. -- Harley L. Clarke of this city has retired from the presidency of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, the $400,000,000 electric generating and transmission concern that he founded more than twenty years ago, directors of the company announced today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30. -- Prices of hogs averaged about steady today, sales showing 10 cents below yesterday's early market and 10 cents above its close. The extreme top of $9.50 was off 10 cents, while the day's average was steady at $9.20. Today's top was a new low one for the year.

The Tide Water Associated Oil Company reported yesterday a net income of $8,504,933 after all charges, including Federal income tax and other charges. After dividend requirements on the 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock, this was equal to 99 cents a share on 5,722,826 average common shares.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 30 (AP). -- The Carnegie Hero Fund Commission recognized thirty-three acts of heroism today, awarding bronze medals and various cash benefits to persons in sixteen States, Canada and Alaska.

The police raided the headquarters of the Motion Picture Machine Operators Union, Local 306, an American Federation of Labor affiliate, on the fourth floor of 251 West Forty-second Street last night and took into custody thirty-two and seven women. The books of the union were seized and taken to Police Headquarters at 2:30 o'clock this morning.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 30. -- Months of friction between Irving Cummings and Twentieth Century-Fox were brought to a head today when the director requested to be released from his two-year contract, which has five more months to run. The request was granted.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 30. -- The St. Louis Symphony Orchestra, Vladimir Golschmann, conductor, performed its first program of the season this afternoon in its spacious new home in the Municipal Auditorium.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Oct. 30. -- A ball was held at the Berkshire Inn tonight in aid of the Fairview Hospital. Three hundred persons were present. Chrysanthemums, pumpkins and cornstalks adorned the ballroom. Mr. and Mrs. George L. Taylor had a dinner party of twenty at the inn and Mr. and Mrs. Donald Worthington also gave a dinner for twenty there.

New York University's football team encounters its fifth opponent of the season this afternoon when it engages the Lafayette eleven at the Yankee Stadium. It will be the fourth meeting between the two teams, with the Violet holding the edge, two to one. The kick-off is scheduled $or 2:30 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP). -- A method of avoiding recurring maritime labor troubles was suggested today as official Washington, from the White House down, closely watched threatening developments in the maritime strike situation.
CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (AP). -- Minnesota and Northwestern battle tomorrow in a conflict that will virtually decide the 1936 championship of the Big Ten.

A paid political advertisement sponsored by the Republican National Committee and describing the Social Security Act as a wage-cutting device, was removed from all cars on the city's Independent Subway System yesterday by direct order of John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Transportation.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 30. -- Complete identification of the one victim in last night's wreck on the Pennsylvania Railroad near Princeton Junction was still lacking today, according to Mercer County authorities. Meanwhile emergency crews worked throughout the day clearing the wreckage caused by the derailment of six Pullman cars of a thirteen-car express train bound for Cleveland from New York.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 30. -- Attractions at Hot Springs tomorrow include the Bath County hounds meeting at Meadow Lane Farm, the home of Mrs. Allen M. Hirsh of Montclair. After the kill, the field, staff and guests will be entertained at a hunt breakfast by John Hanna at Fassifern Farm.

I have read with deep interest THE TIMES'S story on the political trends in Harlem. May I say, for the sake of your readers, that I wish a little less emphasis had been placed on the effect of relief in determining how the Negroes of Harlem will vote.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 30. -- Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Whitehouse gave a tea at Eastbourne Lodge today for his brother and sister-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Norman Ogden Whitehouse, the guests of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Whitehouse at Stone Villa, where Mrs. Yoakum Fosdick of New York will be an election week-end guest.

It is pleasant to think that by this time everybody in New York has had his favorite throng. New York is a big place with a big heart and is in a position to provide throngs for every cause and to hail every candidate.

Smashing over two touchdowns in the second period, Columbia's freshman football team defeated Roxbury School of Cheshire, Conn., 18 to 15, yesterday at Baker Field. Not only was it the first defeat suffered by the schoolboys this season but it also marked the first time this year that they had been scored upon.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- Purchases and sales of stocks on the New York Stock Exchange by members for their own account in round lots, or those of 100 shares or more, aggregated 3,962,100 shares and represented 19.85 per cent of total round-lot trading in the week ended on Oct. 3, according to statistics made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Undefeated and unscored upon in three contests until yesterday, the St. Paul's School football team of Garden City, L.I., had its hopes for an unbeaten season shattered when it bowed to a fighting Adelphi Academy eleven, 14 -- 0, on the winners' gridiron in Queens Village.
GARY, Ind., Oct. 30 (AP). -- Opening new action on the Social Security Act sector of the campaign, Colonel Frank Knox declared tonight it was "a scheme for sharing poverty."

The former rectory of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street, will be dedicated tomorrow as the H. Percy Silver Memorial House following the regular 4 P.M. service in the church.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Oct. 30. -- Although Baghdad is quiet after yesterday's army coup d'etat, every one is concerned over the sudden change in the government. Bakr Sidky Pasha, commander-in-chief of the army, issued the following proclamation today:

The Roosevelt Social Security Act is far from being a perfect piece of legislation, but this ought not to obscure the risks involved in the furious last-minute attack on it which the Republicans are making. What is the central point of this attack? The Republicans are directing their main artillery against that feature of the law which calls for a direct contribution by the workers to the cost of an old-age insurance plan.
LONDON, Oct. 30. -- The British Government has followed a "consistent policy" to attempt to isolate the Spanish civil war, King Edward told Parliament today.

Morris Sweetwood, who in the prohibition era served two terms in Federal prison for bootlegging and who promised to reform when he was sentenced in 1931, was convicted again yesterday as a member of an illicit liquor ring. He faces another term of two years, the maximum under the conspiracy indictment.

The Curtis Publishing Company reported yesterday for the first nine months of this year a net profit of $5,239,059 after depreciation and Federal income taxes. After dividend requirements on the $7 cumulative preferred stock, on which are unpaid dividends, the profit was equal to 39 cents each on 1,790,466 no-par common shares.

Paulina Ruvinska, who made her debut a year ago in Town Hall, accompanied by the Elizabeth Symphony Orchestra, was heard in a recital in the same auditorium yesterday afternoon. The youthful pianist again made a favorable impression in a program well devised to exhibit many facets of her artistry.
VATICAN CITY, Oct. 30 (AP). -- Modern science and divine revelation have no cause for conflict, Pope Pius declared today in instituting the Pontifical Academy of Scientists.

Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Napoleon Bonaparte entertained at dinner last night in the Crystal Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Mr. and Mrs. Martin S. Watts and Mr. and Mrs. James C. Daily. In the dinner party given by Charles Garretson Meyer for Mr. and Mrs. George deForest Lord were Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Appleton Ives, Mr. and Mrs. Franklin B. Lord Jr., Mrs. Edward Maud, Miss Edith deForest Lord and Charles Garretson Meyer Jr.
Police investigation of the city's record enrollment of voters brought to light 1,910 cases of apparent illegal registration, Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine announced yesterday.

BERLIN, Oct. 30. -- Prices on the }oerse today were mixed and variable. Heavy industrial shares opened weak but regained yesterday's levels near the ciosing of the session, with some improvements made. Vereinigtestahl rose laA points.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

The closings tonight will smear more red ink over the theatre's pages, for several of them have been pretty costly affairs. Mr. Abbott's "Sweet River" ran at the Fifty-first Street less than a week, and Mr. Geddes's structural enterprise -- "Iron Men" -- lingered at the Longacre only a fortnight.

The extension of all humanitarian services now performed by the State was advocated last night by William F. Bleakley, the Republican candidate for Governor, as the answer to Governor Lehman's demand that he declare his position on social security.

New bond financing this week amounting to $49,465,900 and represented four major classifications. Corporate borrowing again accounted for the major part of the issues. Last week $63,215,000 in new bonds was placed on the market.

BERLIN, Oct. 30. -An aroused Germany could be "a nation of fanatics," Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels told a mass meeting held tonight in connection with Chancellor Adolf Hitler's Four Year Plan for economic rehabilitation.

Prices generally were slightly firmer yesterday in continued active trading in the commodity futures markets here, but cocoa and cottonseed oil were easier in light transactions. Rubber and metals were particularly firm.

ON BOARD GOVERNOR LANDON'S SPECIAL TRAIN, en route to St. Louis, Oct. 30. -- Governor Landon pressed his attack on the Roosevelt administration in a speech at Charleston, W.Va., tonight, charging it with "waste and extravagance as it affects the home" and with a lack of frankness in respect to the course it proposes to follow in the future on vital problems.

MADRID, Oct. 30. -- Insurgent planes, flying high over Madrid and the suburb of Getafe this afternoon, dropped nineteen bombs that killed at least 110 persons and wounded 135 or more. Most of the victims were women and children.

Former Mayor James J. Walker introduced Governor Lehman to an audience of Democrats last night, describing him as one who had left wealth and high station behind to serve the people of "the sidewalks of New York." Governor Lehman's action, Mr. Walker declared, was in contrast with that of one whom the Democrats of those same sidewalks had lifted to high places, only to have him turn renegade.

After an absence of many seasons from the local concert platform, Helen Jeffrey, the Albany violinist, gave a recital in Town Hall last night. The highly gifted artist returned in the full maturity of her powers to delight her large audience with some of the most satisfying playing heard in those surroundings of late.

CROYDON, England, Oct. 30. -- Shattering all speed records for an eastward crossing of the Atlantic, Captain James A. Mollison landed here today only 13 hours 17 minutes after hopping off from Newfoundland.

From all indications Tuesday evening -- election night -- is going to be the hottest time in the nocturnal resorts since last New Year's Eve. Practically every spot in town is putting on the fiesta spirit for the occasion and doing a land-office business in reservations.

Boy Scouts who saved lives under circumstances indicating unusual bravery and heroism and at the risks of their own lives were honored by the National Court of Honor of the Boy Scouts of America last night.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (AP). -- Harley L. Clarke, sponsor of Shakespearean plays and collector of watches and clocks, and who retired today as head of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, has had a spectacular career in finance. He is director of many companies. Born in Richmond, Mich., he studied law at the University of Michigan at the start of the century and entered business as a machinery salesman.

Samuel Burt, who in 1933 was manager of the Fur Dressers Department of the Needle Trades Workers Industrial Union, testified yesterday in Federal Court that Samuel Mittelman, then president of the Protective Fur Dressers Corporation, had warned him to cooperate with the Protective, and had pointed out that Morris Langer, Burt's predecessor in office, had died after the explosion of a bomb in his car.

Effective at once, the non-statutory duties hitherto performed by the Federal Reserve agent at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York have been transferred to the bank and will be carried on under the general direction of George L. Harrison, president, it was announced yesterday at the bank.

Manhattan and City College, traditional metropolitan football rivals, will meet today at Ebbets Field in the twelfth contest of an unbroken series inaugurated in 1925. The Jaspers hold a decisive edge over the Lavender, with six victories to two, three games having ended in ties. Play will start at 2:30 P.M.

The hunting sector broadens tomorrow for New York sportsmen with the opening of the deer season in ten additional counties, shooting of bucks having been under way in the Adirondack region since Oct. 15.

The estate of Miss Gertrude S. Thomas, a resident of Morristown, N.J., who died Oct. 2, 1935, was appraised here yesterday at $2,430,146 gross and $2,203,757 net, which included securities worth $2,309,130. Besides fifteen public bequests amounting to $212,500 Miss Thomas left half the residue to the New York Post Graduate Medical School and Hospital, the Babies Hospital and the Children's Aid Society.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 30. -- Mrs. William Hockenjos of Crestmont, women's State champion, brought her brilliant golfing season to a close today by capturing the final one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association at the Ridgewood Country Club.

When a wife inherits money and is able to support her indigent husband she must relieve the State of the duty of caring for him under the Old Age Security Law, the Appellate Division decided yesterday when Mrs. Isabel P. Stapleton was directed to pay $120 to William Hodson, Commissioner of Public Welfare, for funds received by her husband, John.

At least three new six-meter boats will be built this Winter, two others are under consideration and an old one will be rebuilt for the defense of the Scandinavian Gold Cup and the Seawanhaka Cup against Norway's bids next Summer.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 30. -- King Carol, who is visiting here, has been so impressed by the technical efficiency of Czech military equipment that he has had orders, especially for machine guns, placed with the Czech Skoda Works for Rumania.
The Fisk Rubber Corporation has declared a dividend of $3 a share, representing payments due on the preferred stock in July and October of this year.

Connecticut was Republican in '32 and there is no reason to suppose that it is less so in '36. What is much more momentous is that the salutary principle of re-electing a Governor of proved and exceptional fitness, irrespective of his political label, should again be sustained.

TOKYO, Oct. 30. -- Although alleged brutality of Japanese police at Keelung, Formosa, to three British sailors is still under investigation, the Foreign Office spokesman, Eiji Amau, today publicized the police version of the affair, which was afterward broadcast.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation announced yesterday that "the report from Madrid that the Spanish Government has issued a decree declaring militarization of the Spanish Telephone Company is correct.

The Harvard Club gained undisputed leadership in the Class C competition of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League last night by registering a 5-to-0 sweep against the Short Hills Club. It was the third trimuph in a row for the Crimson alumni players.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 30. -- A 30-foot stone and bronze statue of Martin Luther, Protestant reformer of the sixteenth century, will be formally presented to the city of Baltimore tomorrow. The monument is a gift under the will of Arthur Wallenhorst, a watchmaker, goldsmith and diamond merchant, long a resident of the city.
Eleven members of the National Advisory Council, which was appointed in 1934 by President Roosevelt to aid in framing the Social Security Bill, issued yesterday a joint statement supporting the act.

Judge BLEAKLEY has carried on a vigorous campaign. He has not hesitated to aim his shafts at what some observers have regarded as the strongest parts of his opponent's armor. In his address in this city Thursday night, summing up his case, he attacked Governor LEHMAN not only as a steward of the New Deal, but as a fiscal administrator.
Motion-picture theatres will invade the residential districts on upper Park and Madison Avenues as a result of decisions by the Appellate Division yesterday.

The security markets closed irregular yesterday and grains and cotton were easier. Most of the high marks for the day in the stock market were reached in the forenoon, mainly in the first hour of trading. Profit-taking in the late afternoon reduced materially or entirely nullified early gains.
Fabian Franklin's letter, in your issue of Oct. 28, as well as that of F.F. Levy in the issue of Oct. 16, prompts several observations:

CHICAGO, Oct. 30. -- Marquette's Golden Avalanche, with sharp-shooting, shifty Ray Buivid in every scoring play, rolled over the big St. Mary's eleven tonight for a 20-to-6 triumph, to retain its place among the nation's major undefeated football forces and thrill 50,000 spectators at Soldier Field.

LISBON, Portugal, Oct. 30. -- After a day of comparative calm, a fierce counter-offensive by government re-enforcements drawn from the Guadarrama and Somosierra fronts against the Torrejon de la Calzada-Sesena Insurgent line is reported to have been beaten off yesterday after a seven-hour battle.

LONDON, Oct. 30. -- The British Government admitted for the first time yesterday that it had been considering the purchase of airplanes and other war materiel abroad in case anything went wrong with its rearmament program.

Domination by politicians and special pressure groups is preventing the secondary school educational system of the nation from fulfilling its proper function, Dr. Clyde M. Hill, head of the Department of Secondary Education at Yale University, said yesterday at the ninety-first annual meeting of the New York State Teachers Association.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 30 (AP). -- Ithaca College's superior line play and faster backs produced a 32-0 victory over the East Stroudsburg Teachers eleven today, with Half- back Joe Navarro scoring two of the five touchdowns. The Pennsylvanians penetrated only once beyond Ithaca's 35-yard mark.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- Admiral H.A. Wiley, chairman of the United States Maritime Commission, instructed Admiral H.G. Hamlet in San Francisco today to proceed Monday as planned with hearings in an investigation of maritime conditions on the West Coast which he has been making at the commission's direction.

John D.M. Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, in a statement issued here yesterday, predicted the election of Governor Alf M. Landon by a majority, both popular and electoral, bigger than that indicated by the Literary Digest poll. The Digest poll failed to reflect the swing to Landon in the last few weeks of the campaign, Mr. Hamilton declared.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- Authority to start an expanded store-door pick-up and delivery service for less-than-carload freight in the territory east of the Mississippi River and north of the Ohio was conferred today by the Interstate Commerce Commission upon railroads serving the area, subject to a minimum charge of 45 cents on each 100 pounds for the service.
JERUSALEM, Oct. 30. -- Bakr Sidky Pasha, military leader of Iraq, appeared tonight as a new power behind the throne of King Ghazi after an army coup which raised a new government to power.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30. -- The Pennsylvania freshman scored a 12-0 victory over the Princeton yearlings' eleven on Franklin Field today.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 30. -- Charles A. Edison, president of the Thomas A. Edison Industries and son of the inventor, in a statement issued today advocated the re-election of President Roosevelt. Mr. Edison is recuperating here from an illness.
DETROIT, Oct. 30. -- The Duquesne and University of Detroit football teams staged their annual battle tonight, the local team winning, 14 to 7.

PARIS, Oct. 30. -- Edouard Daladier, Minister of Defense; General Maurice Gamelin, chief of staff, and other high officers of the general staff completed their visit to the northern frontier today. From what the Minister of Defense has said in the last few days it is obvious that France intends to strengthen her fortifications along the Franco-Belgian frontier.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP). -- Flowers named after Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Rexford G. Tugwell and Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Hoover nodded today at the opening of the Agriculture Department's thirty-fifth annual chrysanthemum show.
