CHICAGO, Oct. 30. -- Heavy selling of wheat futures today on the Board of Trade by houses with Eastern connections and which some brokers regarded as liquidation of a line of futures for a professional operator in New York, carried prices off 5/8 to 1 cent a bushel.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30. -- Miss Marion R. Churchman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Churchman of Chestnut Hill, was introduced to society tonight at a dance given by her uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Emile C. Geyelin at Tregarick, their Devon home.
TOMORROW is Nov. 1. Here are some notes on those books published since July 1 that are remembered by this reviewer with especial satisfaction. The order of listing is haphazard.

Nine of the ten properties in Manhattan and the Bronx offered at foreclosure auctions yesterday were taken over by banks. The scheduled sale of the fifteen-story apartment house at 235-239 Central Park West, southwest corner of Eighty-fourth Street, was adjourned to Nov. 6 by Thomas F. Burchill, auctioneer.

A number of shows opened too late in the week or, for a variety of other reasons, could not be reviewed on the Sunday Art Page of THE TIMES. Among these was a group of flower subjects and other gayly decorative water-colors by Alexandrina Robertson Harris in the Mezzanine Gallery of the Barbizon.

Although it is rather late for another world series post-mortem in the midst of the football season, I should like to bring to your attention a little detail about Ott's home run in the sixth game. First, I shall quote just what your paper of Oct. 7, 1936, said about it.

Trading on the Cotton Exchange was restricted yesterday by the approaching election and uncertainty over the November crop estimate, prices holding a narrow range throughout the session to end with losses of 2 to 5 points.
The address of the President, delivered at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night, follows:

When the Social Security Act was passed by Congress in the Summer of 1935 the legislative "emergency period" was over. Administration proposals were being debated and analyzed instead of being rushed through on emotional pleas. The excuse given by legislators for helping to railroad faulty bills to passage in 1933 and 1934 -- that the economic crises admitted of no delay -- no longer held or was offered.

Election Sunday is what tomorrow has been termed by some religious leaders. Many pastors will preach about the Presidential election of Tuesday. Tomorrow is All Saints' Day and Monday is All Souls' Day in the church calendar. These will be observed by all ritualistic churches.

Sixty WPA workers were hurled to the Fifty-ninth Street ramp of the Queensboro Bridge at 12:35 P.M. yesterday when a truck in which they were riding made a sharp turn and sent them hurtling through the wooden slats of the stake-bodied van.

Our Commerce Department's statement of the country's foreign trade, for September and for the nine completed months, shows the same general trend as in preceding months. While total foreign trade in merchandise has far exceeded that of the similar nine-month period in any of the past six years, imports have increased more rapidly than exports.

Holding that money lost in bets is recoverable under the law by creditors of the loser, Supreme Court Justice Humphrey in Brooklyn yesterday directed a purported betting commissioner to give up winnings of $16,560.

An even decade since its previous appearance in the Times Square area, the Yiddish Art Theatre has returned, again under the direction of Maurice Schwartz, who has been absent two seasons from the local stage.

Five labor union members and Hamilton Fish Armstrong, editor of Foreign Affairs, forwarded contributions to the Princeton Faculty Retirement Fund yesterday as their comment on the announcement by Martin W. Littleton Jr., District Attorney of Nassau County, that he was withdrawing his pledge of his soldier bonus because of Princeton faculty members' support of President Roosevelt.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30. -- Mayor La Guardia of New York addressed 5,000 residents of Lake County, Ind., tonight at a meeting in the Washington High School, East Chicago, sponsored by the Allied Democratic League of the county and several labor groups.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- Substantial gains in the September volume of business done by manufacturers and wholesalers compared with the corresponding month last year and small but favorable gains over the August level were shown today in a report by the Commerce Department and the National Association of Credit Men.

The governors of the New York Curb Exchange approved yesterday the listing on Monday of the following securities of the Atlas Corporation, a new consolidated company which is to succeed the present Atlas Corporation: 470,164 shares of 6 per cent preferred stock, par value $50; 4,499,265 shares of common stock, par value $5: option warrants to purchase 1,681,027 8-60 shares of common stock of $5 par value.

LONDON, Oct. 30. -- King Edward VIII had his first experience of proroguing Parliament today. He did not appear in person. His speech of prorogation, enumerating the activities of the session now closed, was read for him, according to the usual custom, in the House of Lords and afterward was repeated in the House of Commons by the Speaker.
Housing deals by operators in Manhattan and the Bronx featured the urban realty trading reported yesterday.

Speaking on the same platform with President Roosevelt last night, Governor Lehman declared that a "handful of employers," working in conjunction with the Republican party, was conducting a "malicious and misleading campaign" to frighten the wage-workers in order to destroy the social security program in the State and nation.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 30. -- Under a chilling wind, the football teams of Yale and Dartmouth worked out today in the Yale Bowl, where tomorrow, before what promises to be the greatest crowd the famous field has held since 1929, the Blue and the Green will come together.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30. -- Hopes of developing at Girard College a series of schools "which will serve as models for both boarding and day schools" were expressed in the inauguration address today of Dr. Merle Middleton Odgers, the new president of the college, founded a century ago by Stephen Girard for the rearing and education of orphan boys.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 30. -- Army will meet Colgate here tomorrow in the first and only major gridiron battle to be fought in Michie Stadium this season. It will be a renewal of a football series with the up-State collegians after a lapse of twenty-one years.

MADRID, Oct. 30 (Censored). -- Encouraged by yesterday's capture of Torrejon de la Calzada, about sixteen miles south of Madrid; Torrejon de Velasco, about the same distance but to the east of the other Torrejon, and the railway station at Sesena, twenty miles from Madrid, the government forces continued today their driving counter-attacks against the Insurgent positions on the whole central front.

More than 150,000 visitors from all parts of the country will visit this city next month to attend trade shows and conventions scheduled during that time, John R. Young, manager of the convention bureau of the Merchants Association of New York, indicated yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 30. -The New York University freshmen defeated the Yale freshmen, 6 -- 0, today in a bitterly fought battle. Bob Galu, substitute quarterback, crossed the Blue goal in the final minutes on a 5-yard gain, ending a 45-yard march.
DENVER, Oct. 30. -- Following is the text of Herbert Hoover's address here tonight:

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 31 (AP). -- The University of Chicago football team scored a 7-to-6 victory in a homecoming contest with Wisconsin today, holding the hapless Badgers in the cellar of the Western Conference standing. A crowd of 18,000 attended.

WHEN the New York designer sets out to create custom-made clothes for American clientele, she does it with a clear picture in her mind of what the woman wants and of the setting in which this woman will shop, dine or dance.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 31. -- With the minority Democratic organization struggling to offset the personal popularity of the Republican candidate for Governor in his home county of Westchester, Republican county leaders confidently predicted a plurality for Bleakley in this county of 70,000 or more as plans were completed for getting out a vote of record proportions.

VIENNA, Austria, Oct. 31. -- Great importance was attributed today in well-informed political circles to news that Austria's present Minister to Warsaw, Maxmilian Hoffinger, had been transferred to the Foreign Office in Vienna, where he will work in the German and Eastern Department.

After six years of unsatisfactory handling of resolutions, the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs will return to its old policy of backing endorsements with its boasted "woman power" at its convention, opening Nov. 9 at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The Chrysler and De Soto motor companies yesterday announced prices on their 1937 model automobiles. Reduced prices feature both announcements, the Chrysler entering a lower price field than ever before under that name, and De Soto, with a redesigned car, reducing prices from $10 to $15 a model, with added equipment, including safety glass throughout.

THE American premiere of "Nightingale," Soviet Russia's first all-color film production, at the Cameo tomorrow evening, will mark the tenth anniversary of the first showing of Soviet films in America. It was exactly ten years ago when "Potemkin," Eisenstein's first great revolutionary film, burst upon the American scene, opening unimagined vistas to a cinema that was growing slugglish with inactivity.
There being a couple of Presidential candidates in town last Wednesday, the Department of Sanitation had the pleasure of making another entry in its record of ticker-tape storms.

MEXICO, D.F., Oct. 31. -- P.J. Clifford, young British golfer, registered a hole-in-one today in defeating Al Smith of Houston, Texas, 5 and 4, in the second round of the eleventh annual Mexican golf championship at the Churubusco Country Club.

Miss Dorothy A. Frink entertained at dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Miss Mary Stewart Houston, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Houston of Philadelphia. Other guests included the Misses Marion F. Geer, Audrey Townsend, Edith Garver, Virginia C. Sherwood and Adelaide Weld; Norman S. Dike Jr., Horace Byrne, C. Lesher Geer, Frederick Francis, Arthur Sherwood, Benjamin Coates, Wayne Byrne, Edward Schroeder and Elliot H. Goodwin.

Increased payments by many of the country's largest corporations swelled the total of dividends declared in October to be the largest figure for that month since 1931. Large earnings in the third quarter of the year and the first nine months, besides the fact that undistributed income is subject to increased taxes this year, prompted directors to increase the distributions to shareholders.

ARCHAEOLOGISTS now assert that England's largest stone circle, at Avebury, Wiltshire, is the work of an ancient folk from the Low Countries. Their period of migration to Britain is put between 1900 and 1700 B.C., and their culture is described as neolithic or pre-metallic.

Young women headed by Miss Mallory Mixsell are aiding Mrs. Howard F. Shattuck and members of the executive committee in the sale of tickets for the performance of "Tovarich" Wednesday night at the Plymouth Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the women's auxiliary of Union Settlement.

HARTFORD, Oct. 31. -- Three days before election, it looks to impartial observers as if the Connecticut results of 1932 may be repeated, that the State will again go Republican for President, but may re-elect Governor Cross and three of the five district members of Congress.

IN the organization of its modern theatre, as in the organization of most of its modern institutions, Japan has taken America as its model. Show business, at least in its commercial aspects, is run on strictly American lines. And commercialism is most of the story.

Miss Abbey Thorn Kissel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Thorn Kissel, has been appointed chairman of a junior committee to assist with plans for the benefit performance of the "A" series of Noel Coward's one-act plays on the night of Dec. 2 at the National Theatre.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31. -- Although President Roosevelt is still strong in this Republican stronghold, one of the six Republican States in 1932, and the Democratic vote is destined to break all records, the trend today appears to be favorable to Governor Landon carrying the State by a small majority.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31. -- With 1,018 items on view, the annual water-color and miniature exhibition of the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts, the Pennsylvania Society of Miniature Painters and the Philadelphia Water-Color Club opened tonight at the academy with a private showing.

SAUERKRAUT: The full power of the German Ministry of Agriculture has been placed behind sauerkraut. The press, the radio and public meetings are being utilized to make the hausfrau sauerkraut-conscious, and all because something went wrong in the nation's planned and controlled farm economy.

WILMINGTON, Oct. 31. -- Some observers here are giving Governor Landon less than an even chance to carry Delaware's three electoral votes, even though this State has been unshakably Republican in recent years and was one of the handful to stand by Hoover in the Roosevelt landslide of four years ago.

Continuous gains in employment in the United States since last May brought the number of persons engaged in non-agricultural work to 31,680,000, an increase of more than 1,400,000 in the last year, Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins announced yesterday.

MOUNTED men trotted off into the countryside from Bangor, Me., one day a little while ago, headed for Chesuncook Village, 140 miles to the north in the Moosehead Lake region. These horsemen, visitors from Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Connecticut, were starting out on a two-week equestrian jaunt that typifies an interesting development in outdoor recreation in the East.

Since the Revenue Act of 1936 provides as a general rule, in connection with the administration of the surtax on undistributed profits, that a distribution made by a corporation to its stockholders in its own stock, as a stock dividend, shall not be treated as a dividend to the extent that it does not constitute income to the recipient, the question of whether stock dividends are taxable or not taxable is of the utmost importance.

Tightening of the Midamerica Corporation's control of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway was disclosed yesterday in a statement given out through the New York Stock Exchange covering the purchase of stocks by the Van Sweringen interest.
Sixty years ago today Louis Ganz, then a boy of 13, walked into the offices of Simon Manges Son in downtown Manhattan and obtained a job measuring, cutting and laying carpets.

CANBERRA, Australia, Oct. 31. -- Sir Henry Gullett, Minister Without Portfolio, introduced in the House of Representatives yesterday bills to ratify trade treaties with Belgium, Czechoslovakia and South Africa.

New York University's eleven scored for the first time this season in the opening half and proceeded to unleash a smothering attack that crushed Lafayette's Leopards beneath a 46-to-0 count yesterday at the Yankee Stadium before 10,000 persons.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 31. -- With the largest vote in the history of the State a probability, opinion was divided sharply today on whether Minnesota, normally Republican, would again line up in the Roosevelt column in Tuesday's election as it did four years ago.

THE program this season by the Music Society of Bern, Switzerland, comprises seven symphony concerts in the Casino and six chamber music evenings in the City Council Chamber. Fritz Brun and Luc Balmer will conduct the orchestral concerts, for which the soloists engaged include Helene Fahrni, soprano; Alexander Kipnis, bass; Artur Schnabel and Adrian Aeschbacher, pianists, and Bronislav Hubermann, Walter Kaegi and Stefi Geyer, violinists.

RECORDING of Britain's great occasions to provide first-hand sound pictures for the listener today and of the future is a new wrinkle in radio facilitated by the British Broadcasting Corporation's use of two new recording vans.

ARCTIC Siberia, stretching across the whole frozen north of through 120 degrees of longitude, is believed by the Soviet Government to be the greatest treasure chest of undeveloped natural resources in the world. It is also the most inaccessible, locked away from Western civilization by distance and the polar cold.

BY no means new, but singularly appropriate for introduction at the present time, are five records of Shakespearean selections, spoken by the current Hamlet of Broadway, John Gielgud, and contained in a Linguaphone Institute album.

Three days more and it will be all over. We shall have got through another season in the greatest of America's seasonal occupations, if it does come but once every four years. Three days more and the votes will be counted, the tumult and the shouting will die, the precinct captains and their superior officers up to the rank of National Chairman will depart, and the rest of us will forget; yes, we'll forget.

I REACHED London from my holiday in time to see the Komisarjevsky production of Shakespeare's "Antony and Cleopatra" with Eugenie Leontovich as the Queen of Egypt. During fifteen years of playgoing I have not seen so spectacular a failure or one for which I have felt, or have heard expressed, less pity.

LONDON, Oct. 31. -- The new chairman of the English-Speaking Union, the Marquess of Willingdon, was received by King Edward this week to accept his warrant of appointment as Chancellor of the Order of Saint Michael and Saint George.

SCHIEDAM, The Netherlands, Oct. 31. -- Seventeen persons were killed, twenty were seriously injured and several others were slightly hurt today by a series of explosions on the Greek tanker Petrakis Nomikos, which was undergoing repairs at the Wilton shipyard here.

When visitors first enter THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair they will find themselves in a striking foyer that contains the first in a series of special rooms calculated to make a strong popular appeal.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 31. -- The fifth and last of the orchestras to be heard by the writer this season outside of New York gave a performance tonight in Severance Hall, which presented instead of a symphonic program an opera. It was the Cleveland Orchestra, Artur Rodzinski conductor, which so officiated, with the assistance of a fine local chorus and distinguished soloists especially engaged for the occasion.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Oct. 31. -- Selected handicraft industries of eighteenth-century Virginia will be revived as an important activity looking toward the completion of the Restoration of Colonial Williamsburg, according to an announcement made from the offices of the Williamsburg Restoration.

A choice collection of United States coins, including a fine specimen of the 1802 large copper cent and a fine copy of the 1848 half cent, will be sold at auction next Friday and Saturday afternoons by Thomas L. Elder at 8 West Thirty-seventh Street.
BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 31 (AP). -- Washington State gained a 14-13 football victory over the University of California today with a touchdown and conversion in the last minute of play.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- By an analysis of the editorial attitude of the newspapers of the country, made under a system worked out during seven years of research, James S. Twohey, Washington statistician, today said that he had reached the conclusion that President Roosevelt will receive 56 per cent of the popular vote in Tuesday's election and is certain of 286 electoral votes.

Chicago gangsters and a Hindu cult; a Renaissance villain and a modern millionaire; a South American heroine and a fearless Scotland Yard detective -- here is the stuff of which this thriller is built. Also there is a smart London gambling den, and there are several bank robberies.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 31. -- A Bachelor of Arts degree awarded jointly by the College of Liberal Arts and the School of Journalism and eligibility to membership in Phi Beta Kappa have been made possible for journalism students at Syracuse University under a unique scholastic system set up this week.

The machinery exhibit at THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair, provided by the Book Manufacturers Institute, includes nine typical machines and also a gallery of photomurals that accounts for every principal step in the production of a book.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 31 -- Clifford Vehslage, 34 years old, of 78 Beechwood Avenue, Port Washington, L.I., died today in Nassau Hospital of injuries suffered last night when he was struck by an automobile.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 30. -- With official indication that "wage adjustments" for employes of United States Steel Corporation subsidiaries are in prospect soon, the principal question in the minds of the steel workers is the extent to which this may mean a raise.

WHEELING, Oct. 31. -- Probably never in the history of West Virginia has an election campaign been so confusing with so many contradictory elements entering into it as this one. Never was a forecast so difficult.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 31. -- A consensus of forecasts, press and political, indicates that President Roosevelt probably will carry Wisconsin next Tuesday by a majority of 50,000 to 100,000, and that Governor Philip F. La Follette will squeeze through to another term by an appreciably smaller total.
James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, believes that President Roosevelt on Tuesday will surpass his total of 472 Electoral College votes out of 531.

FROM a war-ridden world a young Russian chemist, then a combatant, managed to escape into paradise. He escaped alive, though, that paradise being on earth. Of the journey there -from the trenches to the flowering wilderness of the Manchurian Maritime Province -- he has little to say, because the real journey, about which his little book is written, didn't begin until after he had arrived.
Art property from the trust estate of Mrs. Samuel Insull, wife of the former utility promoter, will be sold next week at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries.

TROY, Oct. 31. -- The curricula of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute are being analyzed by the faculty in response to a request by President William Otis Hotchkiss that each member participate in such an evaluation and, stating his opinion as to objectives of the institute, suggest what should be added, omitted or adjusted.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Oct. 31 (AP). -- Away to adventure in the South Seas, the 92-foot schooner Yankee, owned and commanded by Captain Irving Johnson of Hadley, Mass., will sail out of the harbor here tomorrow to be gone eighteen months.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31. -- Struck almost amidship by two Pennsylvania torpedoes almost as soon as it cleared port, Navy went down today for the third time this season.

New securities offered to the public here in October were the largest in many months. Bond issues were the best for an October since 1930 and the greatest amount for any month since last June. Stock flotations made the largest total for October since 1929 and were above those of any other month since May, 1930.

BERLIN, Oct. 31. -- The Boerse closed today with prices firm and the usual limited turnover for a Saturday. Scattered losses appeared in several leading stocks near the end of the session. Vereinigtestahl dropping 1 point and Mannesmann 3/4.

THERE is always drama in the climax of a campaign. The contest may have been dull, superficial or one-sided. The candidates may be more or less commonplace fellows, elevated to party leadership by some chance conjunction of time and place. But as the hour of election strikes they are lifted out of themselves, enlarged and exalted by the size of the office they seek.

BERLIN, Oct. 30. -- The Italo-German agreement concluded between Count Ciano, the Italian Foreign Minister, and Baron von Neurath a week ago, following extensive conversations in Berlin and later with Herr Hitler at Berchtesgaden, represents a further step in the Fuehrer's newly adopted policy of tackling problems affecting the Reich's relations with other States by a direct approach.

In ordinary circumstances Lord NUFFIELD'S gift to Oxford of 1,225,000 for medical research would call for little comment in this country. It is the panoramic scope of his philanthropic vision that commands attention. He enjoins those who are to benefit by his donation "to keep in close touch with "developments in the sciences ancillary "to medicine."

Acting promptly on an appeal from Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey for the protection of witnesses who will be called in the prosecution of thirteen men charged with extortion in the $2,000,000-a-year restaurant racket, Police Commissioner Valentine yesterday sent a teletype order to every precinct commanding officer directing that all possible precautions be taken to safeguard the witness.

Voters of the city will record their preferences Tuesday for a national ticket, a complete list of State officers, a Court of Appeals justice minor judges, and State Senators and Assemblymen. Local voters, too, will elect an Aldermanic President.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 31. -- Establishment of an Institute of Local Government at the Pennsylvania State College by authorization of the board of trustees was announced here today. Its objectives were given as follows:

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Oct. 31. -- Although there has been no actual revolution in Iraq as yet, the situation is extremely critical. The assassination of General Jafar Pasha al-Askari, Defense Minister in the fallen Cabinet of Yassin Pasha al-Hashimi, has aroused great consternation and may lead to far more serious consequences.

BOSTON Oct. 31 (AP). -- Challenging the constitutionality of the Massachusetts Unemployment Compensation and Federal Social Security Acts, a stockholder of the United Elastic Corporation of Easthampton today asked Federal District Court to declare both invalid.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 31. -Hackley School's eleven won the Triangular League championship by conquering Storm King of Cornwall, 26 to 6, today. The winners carried the attack most of the way.

"Topics of the Times" states the entire truth about the importance of the September election in Maine as an indicator of the November Presidential results. You say: "Maine does not actually have to go Democratic to insure the election of a Democratic President. It is enough for Maine to go lukewarm Republican for the nation to go Democratic.

FEW countries have more picturesque pageants or more impressive religious fiestas than those of South America. And few of the fiestas in South America are more colorful than that held the second week in November at Copacabana, Bolivia, on Lake Titicaca, in honor of a Copacabana saint.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- A form circulated in the last twenty-four hours, purporting to be one issued by the Social Security Board, was branded today as a "fraud" and "a deliberate fabrication" by Arthur J. Altmyer, acting chairman.

THE Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra will begin its ninety-fifth season Thursday evening at Carnegie Hall under the baton of John Barbirolli, the new British conductor. A feature of the opening program will be the first performance of Arnold Bax's "The Tale the Pine-Trees Knew."
PARIS, Oct. 21. -- A number of well-known Americans who live much of the time in France are winding up their Summer vacations and making their preparations for the Winter.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- The New Deal has set up the most elaborate bureaucracy in the history of the government, the Republican National Committee charged today in one of its final pre-election attacks on the Roosevelt regime.

Now that Jack Frost has blown his withering breath, forewarning of icier blasts to come, gardeners are losing no time in moving indoors any of the tender bulbs -- such as dahlias, gladioli, cannas, caladiums or tuberous begonias -- that yet remain in the ground.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 31. -Harvard's alumni and senior placement service, newly reorganized under the university's direct control, began this week its mobilization of the class of '37 for the year's job hunt, sending to all the fourth year men invitations to take part in the most intensive effort in Harvard's history to place its graduates quickly after commencement.

For the second successive year the might of Fordham's line stood transcendent against one of the hardest running attacks in football yesterday and again the Ram and the Pittsburgh Panther fought each other to a scoreless deadlock as 57,000 spectators, the record for the local season, looked on at the Polo Grounds.

PEACEABLE Easterners who have shrunk from visiting the great Southwest for fear of encountering that gun-play and swift retribution which gave this section its reputation for being "wild and woolly" today may join without a qualm the annually growing throng of visitors to the land where the sun spends the Winter.

Seventy-four book publishers will be represented in exhibits at THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair, which will occupy seven salons. Much material of literary and human interest has been gathered by publishers for these displays, which will be individually distinctive and at the same time will harmonize with the general architectural plan of the Book Fair.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- More than 42,000,000 citizens of the United States will vote in Tuesday's election. The total may reach 45,000,000; but whatever it is, unless there is a complete reversal of every normal expectation, it will be the largest number of Americans ever to have voted in a Presidential election.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31. -- While the wheat market on the Board of Trade here fluctuated today in an erratic manner, there was not the pressure there or on the market in Winnipeg that was so much in evidence yesterday. Prices held within a range of around 1 cent a bushel and the undertone generally was firm.

POTTSTOWN, Pa., Oct. 31. -- A fast and aggressive Lawrenceville eleven defeated Hill School in their traditional battle today. With a judicious mixture of aerial and ground plays, the New Jersey contingent gained a well-merited 16-7 victory.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- Shipments of iron and steel products, excluding scrap, from the United States to overseas markets in September totaled 78,653 gross tons, valued at $5,725,286, falling short of the totals reached in the preceding month by 17.8 per cent in quantity and 9.0 per cent in value, according to the Department of Commerce.

The preliminaries of the 1936 campaign ended last evening, with Democratic leaders confident that President Roosevelt would carry New York State and with Republican leaders hopeful that election night would see the forty-seven electoral votes of New York in the Landon column.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Oct. 31. -- The Mount Holyoke College Debating Society, member of the Intercollegiate Debating League, will open its 1936-37 season next month with two platform and one radio appearances. The entire schedule calls for six league debates and two other contests, in addition to a fifteen-minute radio debate to take place Nov. 17 over a Springfield station.

SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 31 (AP). -The Desert News, independent daily newspaper owned by the Latter Day Saints (Mormon) Church, called in a front-page editorial today for all church members "who believe the Revelations and the words of the prophet" (Joseph Smith) to "stand for the Constitution" in Tuesday's elections.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 31. -The dinner dance at the Cherry Valley Club this evening was preceded by a number of cocktail parties. Mr. and Mrs. Charles Heissenbuttel of Locust Street had as their guests before the dance. Mr. and Mrs. James Ouchterloney, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Cameron, Mr. and Mrs. C. Walter Ulsh, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Moller, Mr. and Mrs. Harry Gorgas and Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Hogan.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 31. -Representatives of the unbeaten Central High School eleven of Valley Stream and Amityville High gained the major share of the honors at the fourth annual Long Island school girl field hockey tournament conducted under the auspices of the Long Island Field Hockey Association at Adelphi College today.
CHICAGO, Oct. 31. -- Aided by the best contributions in a decade, the Prohibition party has concluded its most vigorous national campaign since repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

The steamship industry faces a profitable period coincident with a general improvement in world trade, according to Arnold Bernstein, German shipping man. Mr. Bernstein arrived here last week after an extended absence to confer with the American agents of his lines.
A close vote on the proposed city charter was forecast yesterday by political observers. Whether or not the charter will be adopted none of them were prepared to say.

RICHMOND, Oct. 31. -- Virginia will be safely Democratic this year in spite of organized opposition by Republicans and a great deal of ballyhoo by a group of well-to-do men and women who, disgruntled by some of President Roosevelt's policies, have gone over to the anti-New Deal Jeffersonian Democrats.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Oct. 31. -Scoring a touchdown in the last two minutes of play, the Bucknell University eleven conquered a favored Villanova team today, 6 -- 0. A 46-yard run on an off tackle reverse by Lou Tomasetti, sophomore halfback, set the stage for Stuart Smith's plunge through the center of the line for the score.

IT is difficult to see in the soft-spoken, rancorless Ernst Toller, who is in this country for a lecture tour and perhaps a fling at Hollywood, the reputedly inflammatory revolutionist and radical whom repeated sequestrations in Nazi jails have failed to silence.
PARIS, Oct. 31. -- Important talks concerning the future of Europe took place today when Yvon Delbos, French Foreign Minister, received the German, Italian and Belgian Ambassadors.

Many interesting articles frequently appear in your theatrical columns relative to the play "Uncle Tom's Cabin," and often reference is made to Eliza and the kind of dogs that chased her across the imaginary Ohio River -- were they bloodhound, or were they stage-hounds, or could they possibly have been dachshunds?

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- The Federal Power Commission has called a hearing for Nov. 17 on the application of the Montana Power Company, a subsidiary of the American Power and Light Company of the Electric Bond and Share group, for authority to issue and sell $48,000,000 of new and refunding first mortgage 3 3/4 per cent bonds due in 1966 and $10,589,500 of 5 per cent debentures due in 1966.

The Ethyl Gasoline Corporation, owned jointly by the General Motors Corporation and the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, has sent a letter to refiners extending to them the option of either continuing the maximum octane rating of 70 for the regular grade, or "Q" gasoline as known in the trade, or of adopting a maximum of 73 octane for that grade of gasoline.

Many seats have been purchased for the performance of Gilbert and Sullivan's "The Gondoliers" by the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company on the night of Nov. 9 at the Martin Beck Theatre, which has been taken over by the directors of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York to raise funds for that organization.

With the surge in retail buying developing into broader proportions in most sections of the country last week, as much of the hesitancy was swept aside by the cold weather, business registered some of the sharpest gains of the Fall season.

There is always a place for a well-written, intelligently conceived dog story in which the animal hero is neither sentimentalized nor made into a human being. Such a story is this tale of Tally-Ho, the Dalmatian, born in England, but brought to America while still a puppy.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 31. -- Democratic leaders predict that President Roosevelt will carry Maryland next Tuesday by a majority of 100,000 and that six Democratic Representatives will be re-elected to the House.

A large group of persons prominent in society, including several members of the former Russian nobility, has been chosen as the cast for a pageant depicting a ball at the Court of Catherine the Great of Russia, which will feature the ninth annual Russian Students' Ball to be held on Nov. 13 at the Plaza.

ANDOVER, Mass., Oct. 31. -- Still keeping its unbeaten, untied and unscored-on record clean, the Andover football team trounced the Bowdoin freshmen by 25 -- 0 today. The Maine team was unable to advance beyond its own 40-yard line.

The National Salon of Photography will open at 4 o'clock this afternoon in the Vanderbilt Gallery of the American Fine Arts Society, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. The exhibition, which is made up of 351 prints submitted by amateur and professional photographers from all parts of the United States, is under the sponsorship of the Oval Table Society of New York.

EUROPE is afraid of radio. The military mind is always afraid of anything new, and in Europe the brass hats are far more influential, perhaps necessarily so, than in the civilian Continent of North America. Beneath all the vaudeville and the jazz, radio is a terrific weapon of mass appeal.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Oct. 31. -- In a thrilling finish that had a crowd of 6,000 on its toes, Mrs. Frank M. Gould's veteran Ostend today captured the nineteenth running of the New Jersey Hunt Cup which featured the final day of the meeting of the Essex Fox Hounds.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Oct. 31. -Dr. C. Stuart Gager, director of the Brooklyn Botanic Gardens, making the Founders Day address at Swarthmore College today, praised developments in horticulture at the college, saying:

How paper is made, a mystery of which probably not one person in a hundred has a clear idea, will be strikingly demonstrated by the miniature paper-making machine especially lent by the Franklin Institute of Philadelphia. It will be an added attraction in the machinery exhibition room.

THE first of the season's series of concerts by the New Orleans Civic Symphony Orchestra was held recently, under the direction of Arthur Zack. In the regular series of the orchestra five more programs will be presented.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 31. -- The annual Fall dances were held at Wesleyan University this weekend with twelve of the fraternities and the John Wesley Club entertaining young women guests. The largest number of visitors came from Connecticut College for Women, Mount Holyoke and Smith undergraduates also being present in considerable numbers. The guest list of the fraternities was as follows:

PERHAPS the greatest test of Scout training occurs in emergencies when life is endangered, a test that has been often and successfully met by the Scouts. In the twenty-six years of its existence the movement has awarded medals and certificates of heroism to 2,061 boys and a few leaders, who, at the risk of their own lives, have sought to save other persons.

LAST week there was brief reference to what may be seen in the gallery show windows of Paris. This week, in London, windows offer a very different and much more varied fare. It would be hardly honest to say that Negro sculpture is replaced by Chelsea pottery, but the fancy is near enough fact to present itself.

BETWEEN finishing her new novel, "Honourable Estate," which Macmillan's will publish on Nov. 10, and correcting the proofs, Vera Brittain went to Italy for a holiday. Rosa Hutchinson reports that Miss Brittain found little anti-Engliah feeling in Capri, but quite a lot of it in Rome.

The dream of the city's firemen for many years -- an eight-hour day and one day off a week -- will begin to take form as a reality on Jan. 1 if the voters on Nov. 3 give a favorable vote in the so-called three-platoon referendum, an approval that is expected to be granted by an overwhelming margin.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 31. -Mrs. Richard H. Walker of Bronxville, president of the Westchester Smith College Club, has announced that the club will hold its fourth annual series of benefit bridges on Friday, Nov. 6, for the "scholarship fund" for Westchester girls at Smith in 1937.

PLYMOUTH models for 1937, now on display in more than 12,500 showrooms in the country, provide what their engineers describe as a "hushed ride." The bodies, which are larger than those of 1936, are pillowed on short outrigger brackets of special design.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- Most of the nation east of the Rocky Mountains may march to the polls Tuesday in the rain, Uncle Sam's weather men indicated today.

FERNAND GRAVET, here from the studios of Europe to make pictures for Mervyn Leroy and Warners, is a pleasant, black-haired young man whose profile is not unlike that of Edward VIII. He is a Belgian by birth, but he spent his 'teens in St. Paul's School in England and then betook himself to Paris for a career in the films and on the stage.

BACKBONE ROCK, one of the most striking natural formations in Southeastern America, is expected to take its place among the popular tourist attractions of the nation as a result of development of the territory in the Pisgah National Forest of North Carolina, Virginia and Tennessee by Civilian Conservation Corps workers during the past year.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in October was larger than in any other month since last March. Sales, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, amounted to 43,998,322 shares, compared with 30,872,287 in September and 46,662,841 in October, 1935.

PAWLING, N.Y., Oct. 31. -- In a fast and exciting game Pawling defeated Hotchkiss, an old rival, 20 to 6, for its third victory with only a tie to mar its record in four games. Hickey, Pawling's fullback, played an outstanding game, averaging at least 5 yards on his line plunges.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 24. -- There are two innovations at Dartmouth College this Fall. One aims to give the student a healthy body for useful citizenship; the other points out what the responsibilities of that citizenship are. For the first time in its history Dartmouth students receive medical advice and treatment free and this is the first freshman class for which the study of social science has been compulsory.
G.V. Grace Co., Inc., have prepared a circular on the cumulative preferred shares of the Taggart Corporation, the St. Regis Paper Corporation and the Derby Oil and Refining Corporation.

CANADA'S "new deal" in broadcasting will be operative tomorrow, when the Canadian Radio Broadcasting Act of 1936 becomes effective, bringing government radio control under the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation.

Election of the Reichstag by proportional representation was the essential condition for the breakdown of the German republic, F.A. Hermens of the faculty of the Catholic University of America, Washington, concludes in a study published in the November issue of Social Research, quarterly of the New School for Social Research, which will be released tomorrow.

WHAT is expected in Berlin to be the dawn of a new era in Anglo-German relations has opened with the arrival here of Joachim von Ribbentrop. Hitler's new Ambassador to the Court of St. James. Whether it will turn out as hoped time alone will decide. Certainly on the German side nothing has been left undone to make his advent propitious.

LONDON, Oct. 28. -- The experimental theatres are planning for several busy weeks. The Clifford Bax play will open at the Little Nov. 3; it is now entitled "The King and Mistress Shore." The Gate, on Nov. 12, will present Valerie Taylor in "The Children's Hour."

POUGHKEEPSIE, Oct. 31. -- Vassar College has been a political test tube in the weeks before election, and now that the final temperature of the student body has been noted, it is found that 60 per cent favor the election of Governor Landon. Faculty members, however, give a plurality to President Roosevelt.

THE New York Times National Book Fair to be held at Rockefeller Center, Nov. 5 to 19, inclusive, is the first attempt by American book publishers to show the processes involved in the writing, manufacture and distribution of books, and to take the general public behind the publishing scene.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 31. -- Penn State crushed Syracuse today, 18 to 0, to register its first major triumph of the season. Paced by the brilliant running of Harry Harrison and Tommy Silvano, the Lions outplayed the Orange in every department.

ROME -- Since the lira was devalued the Italian Government has been struggling to prevent an increase in the cost of living that would in the long run completely offset the benefits of the recent alignment of Italian currency with the dollar, pound and franc.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Oct. 31 (AP). -- Big Jim Hutchins, Dick Dashiell, Crowell Little and Tom Burnette led the Tar Heels of the University of North Carolina in a second-half comeback which overwhelmed North Carolina State, 21 to 6, today after being outplayed in the first half before 17,000 spectators.

IF John Masefield has given a somewhat enigmatic title to his new novel, the second factor in the equation soon becomes apparent, although it is not until considerably later that the first is made clear. Robert Frampton Mansell, the character on whom the novel focuses, is by trade a baker.
AMONG the attractions offered by the metropolitan area to the hiker -- whose numbers increase in the Fall -- are the many glacial vestiges and markings that exist in Manhattan and its environs.

Brooklyn Prep's plucky football team celebrated the tenth anniversary of its first victory over Poly Prep yesterday when the Crown Heights boys drove over a touchdown in the last few minutes to win, 6 -- 0, at Boys High Field in Brooklyn. It was the fifteenth game of their series, which began in 1909.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 31 (AP). -- Although it was paged over a thunderous public address system, the spirit of Harry Houdini failed to appear at a public seance tonight, on the tenth anniversary of his death.

A BROAD program for the development of air facilities in the region is outlined in an airway plan drawn up by the New England Regional Planning Commission, an advisory organization acting in cooperation with the New England State planning boards.

TOKYO, Oct. 14. -- The opening ceremonies of the new buildings of the Imperial Diet in Tokyo will begin Wednesday with a solemn ritual of purification performed by Shinto priests. On Thursday the Emperor will inspect the buildings, and on the following day they will be viewed by the imperial princes and princesses.

THE sandhogs, in their underwater tunnels, are living on borrowed time, one of them said; logically, you just wouldn't expect them to be alive at all. But what is true of the tunnel builders is equally true of the other "men of danger" to whom Mr. Thomas devotes the ten chapters of his latest book.

SHIRLEY MILLARD saw them die. And as the endless burden of wounded soldiers was carried into the front-line hospital, death was almost the only thing that could be merciful. Yet when she rushed determinedly into war service, it had all been part of a picture that was splendid -- romantic, and thrilling, and noble, and transcendent.

Canadian Government, provincial and municipal, financing in October amounted to $111,881,900, of which $92,300,000 was for refunding and $19,581,900 was for new capital, according to Wood, Gundy Co., Ltd. All of the loans were placed in the Canadian market.

This will be a busy week at the Carroll Club, 120 Madison Avenue. At 4 P.M. today there will be a musicale, arranged by Mrs. W. Romeyn Benjamin, pianist. Other artists include Miss Marian Mugent, violinist; William Durieux, 'cellist, and Lady Campbell, violinist.
Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, will begin today the celebration of its 100th aniversary. It has been on the same site for ninety years.

THE late Professor Hastings Rashdall devoted twelve years of his life to a monumental work in three volumes called "The Universities of Europe in the Middle Ages." His plan was to describe "with tolerable fullness the three great archetypal universities -- Bologna, Paris and Oxford" -- and "to give short notices of the foundation, constitution and histories of the others, arranged in natural groups."

The performance of "Tovarich" on the night of Nov. 17 at the Plymouth Theatre has been taken over by members of Auxiliary No. 1 of the Berkshire Industrial Farm to raise funds for carrying on the work of that organization.

Convinced that trade missions, composed of business men alert to possibilities for both import and export trade, should be sent to Europe during the coming year, Samuel C. Lamport, head of the cotton goods export house which bears his name, yesterday insisted that such groups could open large markets for American farm and factory products.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 31. -- While Nassau County is always counted upon to supply large pluralities and often majorities for Republican candidates, the election this year has the leaders of both parties guessing. With a record-breaking registration of 207,000 potential voters, an increase of more than 18 per cent over the registration of 1932, it is considered probable that the Democrats will make a better showing than they did in the Hoover-Roosevelt contest.

Officers of the Motion Picture Machine Operators Union, Local 306, an American Federation of Labor affiliate, threatened yesterday to sue for recovery of union records seized by the police in a raid on the union's offices at 251 West Forty-second Street Friday nigh.
BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Oct. 31. -Bloomfield High School's Bengals came back to winning form today to repulse a fighting Garfield High School eleven, 7 to 0.

Four hundred persons, among them many men prominent in the business and financial life of the nation, gathered yesterday afternoon at the funeral of Thomas Cochran, a partner in the banking firm of J.P. Morgan Co. The services were held at the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, with the Rev. Theodore Cuyler Speers, the pastor, officiating.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31. -- The Pacific maritime strike extended its grip today to some overland railroad cargo, tied up more Eastern ships, spread farther along the business front and caused official concern over its possible effects upon Alaska and Hawaii.

Herewith, for the forty-fourth time, Fleming Stone steps upon the stage to solve an apparently insoluble mystery, and his admirers will know what to expect. The financier, Allenby, is in conference with three business associates, and has stepped into an adjoining office to look for something in his safe.

CRITICISM of the politics and log-rolling methods that reputedly determine the winners of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences annual awards has been so open and has cost the organization so much in prestige that those intent upon saving the body as the one important industry representative are seeking a new means to determine who shall be honored.

IT was when he heard that the Lions were loose that Coach Steve Owen of the Football Giants sent for Cal Hubbard to bolster up the local line. Cal is as big as all outdoors and weighs a short ton, more or less. He used to play at Geneva, among other places, and it was while there that Cal invented the Hubbard Squash block.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 31. -- The Apawamis Club here held a football dinner and dance tonight. Among those who attended were Mr. and Mrs. Philip Reed, Mr. and Mrs. Orlando S. Brewer, Mr. and Mrs. Frank B. Rogers, Mr. and Mrs. C. Victor Barry, Mr. and Mrs. Williamson Pell and Gordon McCulloh.

American women have gained enough self-confidence in matters of dress to demand individuality in apparel rather than stereotyped styles, according to Miss Dorothy Shaver, vice president of Lord Taylor. Fashion magazines, retail store promotions and the success of American designers, Miss Shaver said yesterday, have encouraged women to trust to their own taste in the selection of styles.

United in the Maritime Federation of the Pacific are six unions whose members are longshoremen, sailors, masters, mates, pilots, engineers, firemen, oilers, watertenders, wipers, cooks, stewards and radio men. The federation became strong in the strike of 1934, which developed into a general strike for San Francisco.
THIS year's National Automobile Show, to open at the Grand Central Palace on Nov. 11, will have more of an international character than any similar exhibition of the last several years.

Tuesday's Presidential election will be decided in the States east of the Mississippi and north of the Ohio and Mason and Dixon's line. President Roosevelt and Governor Landon alike, regardless of their strength elsewhere in the country, must carry some States in this thickly populated region to win a majority of the electors.

ONE murdered, two dead, three suspected; four suspected, really, if we include the burglar who was caught escaping from the magnificent suburban estate where the beautiful young Mrs. Emery lay dead. She had been stabbed, in the bedroom from which the housekeeper had stolen some of her jewelry, and at first glance it looked like a clear case against the robber.

A SCHOLARLY, abstemious and somewhat unapproachable dignitary, Dean Spanley; but there were moments -- when he could be induced to imbibe a sufficient quantity of imperial Tokay -- in which he suddenly remembered that he had once guarded the house against strangers, and chased cats and rabbits, and bayed the moon.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 31. -- Dartmouth fireworks burst over the Yale Bowl in the pale light of late afternoon today as the Green celebrated its second football triumph in a row over the forces of Yale.

A celebrated horticulturist once remarked that it should be a felony by statutory enactment to plant peonies at any other time than in the Fall -- one way of saying that the proper time to plant peonies is from mid-September on. At the present time the plants are dormant and in the best condition to stand the shock of transplanting.

Rocks that explode like firecrackers when subjected to enormous pressures and shearing forces such as are known to exist thirty miles below the surface of the earth, offering a new scientific explanation for the cause of earthquakes, were reported here yesterday at the closing sessions of the anniversary meeting of the American Institute of Physics at the Hotel Pennsylvania by Professor Percy W. Bridgman of Harvard University.

HOUSTON, Texas, Oct. 31 (AP). -Two sustained drives gave the Rice Owls a 12-6 intersectional victory over George Washington University today before 10,000 persons. The loss removed the big Colonials from the list of undefeated football teams.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- With the mountains surrounding the Warm Springs valley still clad in the blazing colors of Autumn and the prospect of Indian Summer --which sometimes lasts for weeks in these parts -- still to come, the social life of the Hot Springs community is nevertheless beginning to turn toward an indoor existence for a part of each day.

Two questions of wide interest will be submitted to the voters throughout the State on election day. The first, in the direct form of a question, is whether there should be a convention to revise the State Constitution. The second is in the form of a proposition: Do the voters approve the issuance by the State of $30,000,000 in serial bonds to finance the State's share of relief costs for the coming year?

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- To that small but rapidly growing portion of the British people in whose minds there is a vital connection between King Edward and the divorce granted to Mrs. Ernest Simpson this week, the official Court Circular is becoming of absorbing interest.

PARIS, Oct. 29 -- Open season for politics starts Thursday, Nov. 5, when Parliament reconvenes. It is all very normal. There is no Red revolution -- and there is not going to be any. There is a hard struggle ahead, but it is going to be fought out on the parliamentary battlefield, not in the streets.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 31 (AP). -- Nebraska's Huskers galloped along toward another Big Six football championship today by trouncing the Missouri Tigers, 20 to 0. A homecoming-day crowd of 27,000 saw the game.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31. -Degas, the only great modern French painter with roots in American soil, will be represented by more than one hundred of his works at an exhibition at the Philadelphia Museum of Art from Nov. 7 to Dec. 7.

All omens indicate that after Tuesday's hubbub at the polls, with carols of victory and dirges of defeat merging in the diminuendo of the Presidential campaign, women as voters will find themselves hardly more politically potent than when they got the franchise.

THE Prince de Talleyrand should be of more than moderate interest to contemporary American readers, first, because he has always been popularly presented as a polished villain, and the contemporary reader has a soft heart for that; second, because his residence in Philadelphia and New York and his later connection with the "X Y Z Affair," almost involving us in war with France, places him, quite definitely, within the radius of American history.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 30. -- Two months of ceaseless negotiation and strike threats, following two years of waterfront squabbling, had put San Francisco in the mood of the man who had heard "wolf" too often when the maritime strike finally took the public by surprise.

Governor Lehman closed his formal campaign for re-election at Madison Square Garden last night with a sharp attack on William F. Bleakley, his Republican opponent, whom he charged with ignorance of State affairs and with sidestepping every important issue.

The question of the percentage of indirect Federal and local taxes has been actively debated in the present campaign, with the usual result of generating more heat and confusion than light. But obviously the question of how taxes fall on various economic classes of the population deserves the most careful study.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 31. -Staging a strong second-half attack after being behind at the end of the intermission, the Blair Academy eleven of Blairstown, N.J., downed Irving School's hard-fighting team today, 19 -- 8.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Oct. 31 (AP). -- Oze Simmons, brilliant Negro fullback, three times led Iowa up to football's pay-off window today in Memorial Stadium, but the Hawkeyes cashed only one of the tickets and bowed to Indiana, 13 to 6, in a Big Ten battle before 20,000.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 31. -- Coming toward the end of his campaign trail, Norman Thomas, the Socialist candidate, gave some observations on the caliber of his opponents for the Presidency in a speech before 500 Westchester County Socialists in the Little Theatre of the County Center here tonight.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 31. -The annual Fall alumni week-end and stag party at Wesleyan University will be held Nov. 13, 14 and 15, with the Sons of Wesleyan beginning to gather Friday, Nov. 13, to witness the Little Three Cross Country run.

Proposition No. 1 on the ballots next Tuesday calls for an answer to the question whether the proposed $30,000,000 relief bond issue shall be approved. There is no doubt that the money will be needed. Funds now in hand will last only to the end of this year, and the latest estimates indicate that at least $40,000,000 will be required next year for the same purpose, even allowing for a continuation of recovery.

A nation-wide broadcast by President Roosevelt on Friday night in conjunction with a rally at Cleveland addressed by Gerard Swope will open this year's formal campaign period of the Mobilization for Human needs, according to an announcement yesterday from the organization headquarters here.
James A. Farley, Democratic State and National Chairman, predicted last night that President Roosevelt would carry his home State of New York by a plurality of 1,250,000.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 31. -- Port Chester High School's football team continued as one of the front-running aspirants for the W.I.A.A. championship today as it vanquished Yonkers Central High for its sixth straight victory of the season. The score was 13 -- 0.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- Business volumes since mid-October have shown no significant changes, the Department of Commerce reported today in its weekly summary of domestic business conditions.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31. -- Miss Jeannette Patterson, daughter of Mrs. J. Howard Patterson of Philadelphia and of the late Mr. Patterson, was introduced to society this afternoon at a tea given by her grandmother, Mrs. William Francis Hopkinson, at the House of the Colonial Dames.

A well-organized crowd of about 20,000 men and women, quick and deafening in their applause and hearty in their boos, turned out last night for the closing rally of the Democratic campaign at Madison Square Garden. Stamping, yelling and clapping, the audience greeted the major candidates, President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman beneath a sea of waving flags.

President Roosevelt closed his active campaign for re-election last night with a fighting speech before an enthusiastic, cheering, flag-waving crowd of more than 20,000 persons, filling Madison Square Garden to capacity.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Oct. 31. -Rockland County, one of the two counties in the State to be carried by Herbert Hoover in 1932, is claimed by the county chairmen of both major parties in vigorous pre-election statements issued today. Whether or not a feud between James E. Farley, National Democratic Chairman, and Democrats in his home township of Haverstraw has been settled will determine which party wins here.

COUNTRY CLUB cliques interest Miss Corliss greatly, particularly if they include pretty girls with susceptible hearts which persist in yearning over the wrong me In "It's You I Want" beautiful Whitney was the girl who couldn't make up her mind which side her heart was buttered on.

ALBANY, Oct. 31. -- In the city where as Governor for four terms he rose to the eminence of Democratic nominee for President, Alfred E. Smith tonight accused Franklin D. Roosevelt of preparing the way for a Communist-controlled America and urged his fellow-Democrats to vote for Alfred M. Landon "to suppress class warfare and revolution" in this country.

WILBRAHAM, Mass., Oct. 31. -Wilbraham Academy vanquished Westminster School today, 25 to 6. Keeping Westminster in check most of the way, Wilbraham tallied almost at will. Westminster scored late in the fourth period on a series of long passes.

A card party for the benefit of the Manhattanville Day Nursery will be held the afternoon of Nov. 12 at the clubhouse of the Men's Faculty Club of Columbia University, 400 West 117th Street. Guests have been requested to bring one article suitable for sale later at the Stuyvesant Square Thrift Shop to raise funds for the nursery.

The Charter Revision Commission made public yesterday a statement designed to refute "inaccurate statements" which have been made about the proposed city charter by its opponents. Decision to issue such a statement was reached by the commission at a special meeting yesterday.

The qualification of nineteen members of Manhattan College's senior class for membership in Epsilon Sigma Pi, scholastic honorary fraternity, was announced yesterday by Alfred Donovan, registrar. Induction ceremonies will be conducted Wednesday, with Brother Patrick, F.S.C., president of the college, presenting keys to the new members.

Magistrate Frank Oliver, sitting yesterday in Bronx magistrate's court, expressed the hope that a "Bill of Rights" would soon be embodiedin the State Constitution to prevent police officers from invading private homes without search warrants.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31. -- From the exclusive ranks of the unbeaten to the densely populated sector of the once defeated, fell Holy Cross with a resounding thud today as Pop Warner's Temple eleven, in a mild sort of upset, took the measure of Holy Cross, 3 to 0, before 20,000 persons at Temple Stadium.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 31. -- Three University of Pittsburgh students interested in journalism since high school days, are using their hobby to produce a magazine for boys and girls interested in hobbies. Founded in 1935, the magazine Careers and Hobbies has a circulation of about 10,000 copies in high schools throughout the country.

To the sorrow of many people it is beginning to look as if the Federal writers' "New York City Guide" would be something of a disappointment. Stories have been told for some time around the libraries of workers on this project who had apparently never previously used books as tools.

William F. Bleakley, Republican candidate for Governor, charged the Democratic campaign workers last night with making a "desperate effort" to influence the votes of school employes and parents of school children. He spoke at George Washington High School, 191st Street and Audubon Avenue.

VIENNA. A SHORT but delightful birds-eye view of the Bach family from 1604 to 1845 is afforded by a little collection of piano pieces edited by Dr. Karl Geiringer of the Gesellschaft der Musikfreunde, and only recently brought out by the Universal Edition.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 31. -Brown fell on an impotent Tufts eleven and hammered a 38-7 triumph today. It was more points than Brown has scored in a single game since Oct. 17, 1931, when it defeated Tufts, 38 -- 12.
ANDOVER, Mass., Oct. 31. -- Authorities of Phillips Andover Academy disclosed today that the institution had benefited by $10,000,000 in the last five years through gifts of the late Thomas Cochran.

THE coach trailer, innocently trundling along the road or resting by the wayside, becomes suddenly an object of popular interest and national concern. Five years ago it was just a convenience for motor tourists, an overnight shelter, usually home-made, a mobile bedroom dragged along behind the car.

Non-intervention in Spain has become a cruel mockery. Behind the screen of neutrality scores of women and children were slaughtered last Friday in the streets and playgrounds of Madrid, reportedly by foreign bombers in the service of the Rebels -- a grisly rebuttal to the angry protests of innocence on the part of the Fascist Powers charged with unneutral acts in aid of the Insurgents.

HELENA, Oct. 31. -- Party lines have largely been abandoned in a bitter campaign in Montana, which in its last few weeks has seen conservatives and New Dealers lined up on opposite sides. The outcome is in doubt.

LONDON, Oct. 31. -- Rigid State control of the private armaments industry is unanimously recommended by the Royal Commission under the chairmanship of Sir John Eldon Banks, whose report was issued today after twenty months of painstaking labor.

ATHENS, Ga., Oct. 31 (AP) -- The University of Tennessee's football team swept to a 46-to-0 victor over the University of Georgia on Sanford Field today. It was "homecoming day" for Georgia and about 10,000 persons witnessed the contest.

OAKDALE, L.I., Oct. 31. -- Calculating his pace with mathematical precision, Konstanty Kempisty of Manual Training High School emerged from a home stretch sprint to take individual honors in the ninth annual La Salle Military Academy interscholastic cross-country run over a rural course on the schools grounds today.

BOSTON, Oct. 31. -- Boston College came from behind to tie Michigan Stale, 13 to 13, before 10,000 spectators at Fenway Park today. The Eagles put on a 93-yard drive late in the fourth period to score their tying touchdown.

A YEAR ago Dr. George W. Hartmann, psychologist, now of Teachers College, Columbia University, ran for office in Allentown, Pa., on the Socialist ticket. Realizing that he had about as much chance of winning as a one-legged man in a 100-yard dash, he turned his campaign into a scientific experiment.

Retail sales showed decided gains last week, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. Apparel departments made the poorest showing in what would otherwise have been a splendid October volume.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Oct. 31. -- A return to traditional Republican pluralities is predicted by Republicans of Suffolk County. The number of voters who will go to the polls on Tuesday is estimated at 82,000. The Democratic strength will not exceed 45 per cent of the total.
TORONTO BETTER game-fishing is the aim of hundreds of Canadian government fishery experts who are now engaged in experiments throughout the Dominion. Fish are being interbred for sportier species.

IGNACE JAN PADEREWSKI, genius of the piano, will be 76 next Friday. He has come out of retirement to play once again for the world and, this time, through the modern miracle of the sound film, it is literally the world that will hear and see him.

The untimely death of Daniel Friedlander at the age of 18 should be recorded. A pianist of extraordinary gifts and originality, his playing was known to Artur Schnabel, Felix Weingartner, Myra Hess and Mark Hambourg. To their testimony and to that of his teachers, Siloti and Boguslavski, we add our humble own.
EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 31. -- Hysteria hit the Northwestern dressing rooms in a wave of shouting, whooping, near-delirious players and coaches late this rainy, dark afternoon.

BERLIN, Oct. 31. -- German banks have thus far advanced 100,000,000 marks for the creation of "cell wool," or artificial textile fiber, factories, to which must be added probably half as much capital stock investments, according to an article appearing in the newspaper Tageblatt.
PORTLAND, Oct. 31 (AP). -- The University of Washington gained a 7-to-0 victory over Oregon today in its rush toward the Pacific Coast Conference championship.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -Hotels, piers and night clubs have assumed their usual marine decorations and are now arrayed in pumpkins and corn stalks. Thousands of visitors came here for the week-end series of Hallowe'en celebrations.

A HORSEMAN and hiker, an engineer and a traveler in far countries, Stanton Davis Kirkham was suddenly stricken with incurable disease at the age of 43. That was twenty-five years ago. He has been a "shut-in" ever since.

AUGUSTA, Me., Oct. 31 (AP). -- Indictments against a group of defendants accused of participation in alleged Maine ERA administration irregularities were nol prossed today in the Kennebec County Superior Court.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 31. -- Ohio, one of the doubtful key States in Tuesday's national election, has ceased to waver between the rival candidates and will award its 26 electoral votes to President Roosevelt.

FREQUENTLY radio is accused of spreading rumors. When the broadcasters investigate they generally find that listeners tuned-in after the program started or heard only a few words which they interpreted incorrectly because they missed what went ahead.

What appears to be the beginning of a strong movement for amendment of the Robinson-Patman Anti-Price Discrimination Act is getting under way and convening of the next session of Congress will undoubtedly see the presentation of numerous proposals for changes in the act, it was reported in well-informed quarters here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- Registration of voters in the cities of the United States for the election exceeds that of 1932 by 15 per cent, Simon Michelet, president of the National Get-Out-the-Vote Club, said today after checking over late figures from more than 100 cities.

Chances are that President Roosevelt won't carry Hyde Park, N.Y. He lost it in 1932 by 139 votes, although he succeeded in carrying his own district, the Third, 484 to 479. Chances are he won't carry his district Tuesday. It has recently been cut into two parts and many Democrats find themselves in the new Fourth district.

Miss Beatrice Kunhardt will give a tea on Thursday at the home of her mother, Mrs. L. Stuart Wing, 116 East Sixty-eighth Street, for committee members assisting with plans for the all-star heavyweight boxing tournament to be held on Nov. 23 at Madison Square Garden in behalf of the West Side Hospital.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31 (AP). -The only undefeated, untied major team on the sunset side of the Rockies, the University of Santa Clara, upheld the prestige of Western football today with a convincing 12-to-0 victory over an outclassed Auburn eleven.

ALBANY, Oct. 31. -- The revocation or suspension of 795 certificates of automobile registration and licenses to drive were announced today by Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, in the two-week period ending Oct. 17.
EXETER, N.H., Oct. 31. -- Phillips Exeter's eleven came back after a poor first period today to register a 25-to-12 victory over Hebron Academy's football force.

A REPORT on "Art Education in the High Schools of the United States" has recently been published by the Federated Council on Art Education. The findings, based largely on questionnaires, and comprising a scrutiny of the entire field of art education in high schools, are designed to be of benefit to superintendents of schools and to supervisors and teachers of art.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 31 -- Notre Dame became the raging, fighting Ramblers of tradition for two minutes today -- just long enough to fashion one touchdown that upset Ohio State's favored Buckeyes, 7 to 2.
Betting odds quoted here yesterday favored the re-election of President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 31. -- The conference of the National Youth Administration and the Halloween play today at the Westchester County Center marked the beginning of the busiest season since the opening of the center seven years ago, John J. Brown, the manager, announced in listing some of the outstanding events on the program for this year.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 31. -- King Carol and Crown Prince Michael of Rumania left Prague last night for Southern Moravia, where they will hunt. Afterward the King will visit Brno and Bratislava, leaving Czechoslovakia for Bucharest tonight.

TORONTO, Oct. 31 (AP). -- The Millar stork derby ended at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon, ten years to the hour after the founder's sudden death at the age of 72. Six mothers claimed a tie for the prize of $500,000.

BOSTON, Oct. 31. -- John D.M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, declared in an address here tonight that the Roosevelt administration already is planning a regimentation of the country's 27,000,000 workers which will be so complete that every one will be numbered with metal identification tags similar to those worn in the World War.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31. -- It gives some idea of the extent of field hockey interest to realize that seventeen players and delegates came the thousands of miles from Australia to Philadelphia on their own to attend the third triennial international conference, which closed this afternoon.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Oct. 31. -- Members of North Shore society who have remained in the country to vote or have returned for the election day week-end are expected to attend the thirty-first annual chrysanthemum exhibition of the Nassau County Horticultural Society, which will open on Monday afternoon in the main building of the Pratt estate and in which many of the estate owners have entries.

Some persons just don't believe in signs. During the last week, in every conceivable way, the word went out and notice was posted far and wide that the game between Fordham and Pitt would start at 2 o'clock instead of the usual 2:30.

ROOSEVELT FIELD, Oct. 31. -Thrilled by the grandeur of America from the air, Eugenio Cardinal Pacelli, Papal Secretary of State, landed here at 3:28 P.M., ending a tour which took him to the West Coast. He was greeted by Mrs. Nicholas F. Brady and a small party of friends and left by automobile for the Brady estate, Inisfada, at North Hills, L.I.
LONDON, Oct. 31. -- Londoners were reminded today that although business recovery has come to most parts of the country, there remains at least one place where a depression has existed since 1921.

Fashions of the early 1890's in contrast to the styles of today will be shown in motion pictures and by models at a "Tintype Tea" to be given on Nov. 19 at the Savoy-Plaza for the benefit of the Stony Wold Sanatorium. The event will be given under the auspices of Auxiliaries 1 and 16 of the sanatorium, with Mrs. Ernest P. Davies as chairman.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31. -- With both Republican and Democratic leaders claiming Pennsylvania, and apparently with complete sincerity, the task of picking the winner next Tuesday is made extremely difficult despite a Republican advantage of nearly 600,000 in registration.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 31. -- Tulane ran up a score of 22 -- 0 on Louisiana Tech in the first half of the Wave's scheduled "breather" today, but the heavy team from up-State really made its presence felt in the second half when it outfought the Greenies but wound up on the short end of the final score, 22 -- 13.

MME. Delarue-Mardrus is both a poet and a storyteller. She appears in that double capacity in her new novel "Chenevieil" (Ferenczi, 254 p., 12 fr.). The manor house of this name stands in Normandy near the estuary of the Seine, amid oaks and birches, towering from the top of a hill over the majestic stream where it meets the sea.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 31 (AP). -- Poised, smiling and interested, Mrs. Alfred M. Landon and Peggy Anne Landon, 19, tonight attended their first political meeting of Governor Landon's campaign or the Presidency. It was his last.

Emphasis in the casual comment that shapes club programs reveals a shift during recent weeks to the always absorbing theme of the right job for the woman, and vice versa. Two authorities who have spent years of concentration on that problem have set forth their separate conclusions, by invitation, before various organizations lately.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 31 (AP). -- Stanford's Redskins tamed a highly favored University of California eleven at Los Angeles today, 19 to 6, before a homecoming-day crowd of 47,000.

THE conflicting ideas of Malwine Bree, Tobias Matthay, Rudolf Maria Breithaupt and Otto Ortman concerning the physical aspects of piano playing only went to prove that the puzzle had not been finally solved by any of these investigators.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 31 (AP). -- A wily band of fighting Illini from the University of Illinois ambushed the University of Michigan Wolverines along football's comeback trail today and scored its first Western Conference victory of the season, 9 to 6.

Why all the blather about democracy? We read about it and talk about it, but what is it? "Government by the people," say Webster et al., but a better definition is a ship without a master, or best, a pot without a bottom. We never have had it in this land, nor does it exist elsewhere.

ONE of the great mysteries of recent publishing experience was the tremendous sale of George Santayana's novel, "The Last Puritan." That it should have achieved a favorable reception from the critics was not remarkable; but what did its more than 160,000 buyers find in it?

AN unusual exhibition has been built up at his gallery by Pierre Matisse around the huge decoration called "La Danse" that his father created for the palace of Serge Stchoukine, a Russian collector, before the World War and which now is mated with a similar work called "La Musique" in the amazing Matisse Room in the Gallery of Western Art in Moscow.
