ROME, Oct. 31. -- Italy plans to increase its navy personnel from 60,000 to 100,000 men to meet any British threat in the Mediterranean, authoritative sources reported today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31. -- The United States field hockey team unexpectedly sent an entirely revised forward line into the game against Scotland today and not only lost, 2 -- 1, but dropped, at least until tomorrow's final games, its clear claim to second place in this triennial international tournament.

Efforts to assure greater market stability for coffee produced in Latin American countries, which began at a ten-day conference of leading producers in Bogota, Colombia, on Oct. 5, will be continued in a further meeting of Pan-American coffee growers to be held in Washington, D.C., late next month.

The Gutenberg Bible, the first book printed from movable type, ranks as one of the historic masterpieces of printing. It is a two-volume work, the surviving forty-five copies of which have become among the rarest and most prized of literary treasures.

Spurred by colder weather, retail trade in the local area last week made the best showing since Columbus Day. Average gains of from 15 to 20 per cent over the comparative 1935 week were reported by department store executives. While the comparison was made with fairly poor sales figures last year, the upswing in apparel volume was particularly pronounced, ranging as high as 45 per cent for some stores here.

The headlines "Trained Youth Shortage Seen" and "Shortage Seen in Trained Employes" naturally draw the attention of any one eagerly, but vainly, seeking re-employment, and the excerpts from the report of a study of current employment conditions by James E. Gray, president of the National Employment Exchange, rouse the righteous indignation of a person of training, good experience, background and record who cannot truthfully register "under 30."

National and State officials of the Daughters of 1812 will be guests of honor for the forty-first annual meeting of the State organization this week at the Hotel McAlpin. A board meeting on Wednesday, at which the retiring president, Miss Minnie B. Wade, will preside, will open the sessions.

A COMPANION volume to "Mistresses and Maids," and to Interlude for Sally," Mrs. Seymour's new novel continues the story of Sally Dunn, as well as those of the various members of the Merrall family, her friends and employers.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 31. -- John S. Thorp, Democratic leader of Nassau County, has announced his opposition to the proposed Nassau County Charter which is to be submitted to a referendum at the polls throughout the county next Tuesday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31. -- Chicago's dominant Democratic machine, which has been piling up largo majorities at depression and recovery elections, is expected to overcome the anticipated down-State Republican lead next Tuesday, place Illinois safely in the Roosevelt column, and perhaps carry all Democratic State candidates to victory.
The Flushing High School eleven remained as the only unbeaten and unscored-upon combination in Queens by virtue of a 12-0 triumph over Far Rockaway High on the latter's gridiron yesterday.

Two so-called "ferns," Asparagus plumosus and A. sprengeri, are perhaps more familiar to most persons as "greens," in boxes of cut flowers from the florist, than as the desirable house plants which they really are.

In a crib in the children's bedroom of a second floor apartment at 555 Ovington Avenue, Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, William Malarkey, 3 years old, was sleeping last night as peacefully as any three-year-old could under a pile of electric trains, mechanical trains, a gas station, mechanical boxers, G-men guns, clickety-click machine guns, telephones, a typewriter, tanks, airplanes, trucks, derricks and a host of other toys.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 31. -- Colgate's Red Raiders proved worthy of the nickname by tumbling Army from the ranks of the unbeaten elevens today.
The city's voters must decide on election day whether, if the charter proposal is adopted, the membership of the new City Council shall be elected on a proportional representation basis.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- The National Labor Relations Board has issued a summary of its activities during the first year of its existence, showing that it had acted in 1,405 cases involving 291,408 workers.

WHEN a student of society turns to the novel, the result is usually provocative or tedious. Mr. Calverton's novel, by its very freshness and intensity, is provocative. It restores something of the bite and challenge that the novel of ideas had in a less embattled era, and within a well-worn framework proclaims a serious and consistent philosophy for troubled men in a troubled world.

Football fortunes rose and fell with dramatic suddenness yesterday before 28,000 spectators at Baker Field as Columbia and Cornell, traditional rivals since 1889, met in their twenty-fourth contest, with the Lions winning by 20 to 13.

Sound leadership and considerable enthusiasm augur well for the support women's organizations will give the United Hospital campaign during the ensuing weeks. If any feminine organization is left in doubt as to the necessity, the importance or the worthiness of the drive, it will not be chargeable against Miss Lena Madesin Phillips, chairman of the division of women's clubs, or her associate chairman, Mrs. Almeron W. Smith.

BELFAST, Oct. 31 (Canadian Press). -- Fielding a team that included several players new to international soccer competition, Scotland triumphed by 3 -- 1 over Ireland today before a milling crowd of 40,000 that filled the grounds to capacity and at times encroached on the pitch.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- Workmen are installing air-conditioning equipment in the Capitol, the Senate Office Building and the two House Office Buildings.

EXCEPT for the Coast, finally struck by the long-threatened shipping strike, most sections of the country last week reported substantial retail gains as a result of cooler weather. Sales of seasonal apparel, which had been lagging, jumped ahead and took the lead in activity away from home furnishings.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- Although business recovery is continuing, wage-earners as a whole are not sharing proportionately in the returning prosperity, according to the current monthly survey of business made public by the American Federation of Labor.

THE drive of the Atlantic Waterways Association for the construction of a ship canal across New Jersey has revived hopes for the realization of a yachtsman's dream -- a trip from New York to Miami, Fla., free of any perils from the open sea.

Scientific tests and measurements have been developed to a point where educators can identify definitely individual aptitudes and determine accurately the studies that will fit the student's particular needs and capacities.

The Chinese wistaria, purple or white, is no longer the only member of this beautiful clan available for American gardens. Japanese types of recent introduction listed as W. muitijuga or floribunda in a number of blue, purple, white, red and pink sorts with clusters from two to four feet long can now be had.

A patent covering the cutting of hair by an electric dry shaving machine, held by the Schick Industries, Ltd., was infringed upon by the Dictograph Products Company, Inc., manufacturers of the Packard Lektro-Shaver, Federal Judge Grover M. Moscowitz ruled yesterday in Brooklyn.

"Winterbound" is a story for girls of two other girls who spend a long, snowy Winter in the country home to which the family has moved to save expense, taking, when their mother is called away, the responsibility for themselves and their younger brother and sister.

Net profit of Parke, Davis Co. and subsidiaries in the first nine months of 1936 amounted to $6,654,181 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges. This equaled $1.36 each on 4,891,608 shares of no par capital stock. No provision was made for Federal surtaxes on undistributed earnings.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 31. -Pay Day for the girls at Radcliffe College came on Thursday, Oct. 15, and when Pay Day comes to Radcliffe, it is the woman who pays and pays, for that is the day set apart for her to join classes and clubs.

PINEHURST, N. C. -- Several factors are contributing to an early opening of the forty-first Pinehurst season, the major item being the unusually fine weather the resort has been enjoying. Each day sees many of the regular cottage residents as well as hotel guests arriving by rail, motor and plane.
CAMBRIDGE, Oct. 31. -- Harvard tied mighty Princeton today, 14 -- 14.

CONSIDERABLE amateur interest attaches to the photography show which opens today at the Vanderbilt Galleries in the National Academy of Design under the auspices of the Oval Table Society. Amateur no less than professional photographers from all parts of the country are represented in the 274 prints in the exhibit, which continues through Nov. 15.

Howard Welch and Edmund Mezitt set a fast pace yesterday to give Cornell's cross-country team a victory over Yale and Columbia over the five-mile course at Van Cortlandt Park. The Ithacans compiled 24 points, the Elis were second with 38 and the Lions had 58.
The Niagara Hudson Power Corporation reported yesterday the earnings of its subsidiaries for the three months and nine months ended Sept. 30.

Bond prices were narrow yesterday in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Reflecting pre-election caution as well as the usual week-end dullness, the market turned extremely dull in the two-hour session. The total transactions amounted to only $4,781,400, compared with $5,502,800 on Saturday a week ago.

AFTER a heavy radio "bombardment" of political "last words" tomorrow night, the broadcasters will surrender their facilities to politics again on Tuesday night to report the results of voting from coast to coast.

Despite recent frosts which have laid low most garden flowers, chrysanthemums in the extensive collections at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden and the New York Botanical Garden are still in their glory. In addition to those being grown in the open there are many of the less hardy varieties coming into bloom in greenhouses.

Groups of young women of society have been organized to assist the "grayjackets" of the Seventh Regiment in plans for the annual Fall Military Ball, to be given at the regimental armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, on Dec. 5. The ball will take place in settings representing a street scene on the Bowery several decades ago.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 31. -- The high rural birth rate in this country is slowly declining, Dr. Samuel A. Stouffer, Professor of Sociology at the University of Chicago, said before the Population Association of America today in scoring the New Deal for not having made any survey of the number of marriages in this country.

Robert Minor, Communist candidate for Governor, urged party workers yesterday to get out a strong Communist vote to keep the structure and unity of the party for its future work. He placed the importance of the defeat of Governor Landon second only to the need for a strong party vote, but declared that "simply to throw votes to Roosevelt" was a course that would lead to "disaster."

A plan has been evolved for refinancing certain certificated mortgages guaranteed by the Lawyers Mortgage Company under which certificate holders would realize immediate payment of their certificates in full with interest according to S. Harby Plough, president of the Lawyers Mortgage Guarantee Corporation.

As is his custom, Dr. Priestley quietly collects evidence, listen to what others have to say, offers no theory of his own, and then, suddenly, on the basis of facts at hand, solve the mystery. And the murder at the motor show confronts that astute criminologist with one of the most puzzling mysteries of his career.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 30 -Because of the failure of the ill-advised Rexist coup in Brussels last Sunday the situation in Belgium is entirely changed. The manifestation failed not so much for want of support or for inexperienced handling as because of the vigilance and organized activity of the Belgian police, who prevented the rioting from getting out of hand.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 31. -- President Roosevelt will carry Indiana by 60,000 to 75,000 at the election Tuesday, according to the belief of conservative observers in this State in the closing hours of the campaign. Some Democratic leaders place the figure much higher and some Republican workers express hope for Landon victory.
Elaborate plans have been made by the police to insure an honest and orderly election and at the same time to provide adequate police protection for the city on Tuesday.

THE drivers, owners and underwriters of the great stream of commercial vehicles that flows in a ceaseless night-and-day current on interstate and across-border highways are now helping to frame a set of safety rules that will become national law to control their own operators and machines.
LANCASTER, Pa., Oct. 31. -Franklin and Marshall did all its scoring in the second and third periods to defeat Muhlenberg today, 20-2, in an Eastern Pennsylvania Collegiate Conference game.

BARCELONA, Spain, Oct. 30. -- In Barcelona life now moves with so normal and tranquil a rhythm these days that the average citizen is not worrying his head about the possibility of an enemy attack upon the city.

THE French relish their sole, the Italians their squid, the English their whitebait, the Germans their smoked salmon sandwich; but the average American eats only four ounces of fish a week. The figure is an average for persons who eat fish and those who eat none.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 31. -- The advance in trade and industry stepped up in the Eighth Federal Reserve District in the last week. Retail sales were more active as cooler weather prompted the demand for Winter goods. Wholesale sales were increased by orders for seasonable goods and for the holiday season.

THE story of a passionate love affair in modern Spain, carried on as independent of social strife as if it were instead in Arcady, strikes one with a front page at hand as slightly incredible. For a moment it seems a thorough anachronism, modern Spain having made something of a reputation for realism.

DENVER, Oct. 30. -- Excepting only Presidential candidates, Colorado voters are more interested this year in measures than in men. They must make a decision on nine constitutional amendments and initiated measures on Nov. 3, and six of these deal with changing the State's Tax Laws.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 31. -- With both sides claiming and numerous straw votes indicating victory for Republicans and Democrats alike, political observers in both the new and old schools of Missouri politics were about agreed tonight that Missouri is definitely in the Democratic ranks by from 250,000 to 300,000.

MALVERNE, L.I., Oct. 31. -- Two unbeaten and unscored-upon combinations met on the gridiron today with Malverne High finishing in front of Westhampton Beach High by a 6-to-0 score. Malverne now has taken four games and played a scoreless tie, while the Suffolk County squad has captured three and dropped one.

Gold received here in October, a large part of which had been engaged in September before devaluation of the French franc, made the highest total for a month since June. Most of the metal came from two countries -- France and Great Britain.
One hundred and twelve students at the University Heights colleges of New York University have been pledged to thirteen fraternities. Fraternities and their pledge lists include:

THE thirty-nine hitherto unknown songs of the youthful Hugo Wolf just published by the Musikwissentschaftlicher Verlag in Vienna and Leipzig and performed for the first time in public at a pair of concerts given on Oct. 5 and 6 in the Middle Hall of the Konzerthaus, ought to spread joy among recital singers.

THE war (1917-18) comes to Brailsford Junction, Wisconain, in this sentimental story compounded of homely pictures and plain people, of humor and tears, with a thread of melodrama running through the narrative and a healthy hatred of war and warmongers to give it point.

LAKELAND, Fla., Oct. 30. -- Interruption of a communistic meeting Sunday in Tampa just as Earl Browder, Presidential candidate, was beginning an address, has revived the issue of free speech, stirred labor organizations to active resentment and has further widened attacks on that city's attitude toward so-called radical groups.

TRENTON, Oct. 31. -- Besides the Presidential balloting, there will be Statewide voting in New Jersey next Tuesday for the election of a United States Senator. Each of the fourteen Congressional districts will choose a member of the House of Representatives and in seven of the twenty-one counties a State Senator will be named.
Mrs. Ira B. Downs has announced the names of nineteen young women who have accepted her invitation to receive at the thirteenth annual Debutante Ball on Nov. 25 at the Heights Casino, Brooklyn.

The end of the week coincided with the end of the month and, save for tomorrow, with the last of the pre-election markets. The political topic necessarily has been as engrossing in Wall Street as it has been in every other community in the country.
In addition to the directing board, whose members are named elsewhere, the other committee members of THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair are:

WITH the opening of the New York automobile show still ten days distant, a majority of car manufacturers already have unveiled publicly their 1937 models. Pontiac, Chevrolet and Cadillac-LaSalle will follow the coming week.

TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 31. -- Indications are that the Presidential election in Kansas will be closer than in any year since Statehood. Both of the major parties are claiming victory, the Democrats predicting a lead of from 5,000 to 75,000 for Roosevelt and the Republicans a majority of 25,000 upward for Governor Landon.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 31. -The undefeated Hempstead High eleven, one of the strongest in the history of the school, gained undisputed possession of first place in the Nassau Conference by virtue of a 26-to-18 victory over Chaminade High of Mineola.

MR. BELL'S catchpenny title is as ironic as his outward cheerfulness is deceptive. You can best destroy an illusion, he implies, by mimicking it. The illusion, however, goes much further than romantic myopia. In effect, he has written a proletarian love story, for he has added accusation to his idyll.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 30. -- Practically the entire State of Kentucky is TVA territory, a group of municipal officials on a pilgrimage to Norris Dam were told this week.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 31. -- Neilson Field was jammed today for the intersectional gridiron clash between Edison High of Miami, Fla., and New Brunswick. Among the spectators was Governor Hoffman.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Oct. 31 (AP). -- The West Virginia Mountaineers conquered Western Maryland, 33 to 20, today in a spectacular passing contest which kept a crowd of 10,000 football fans cheering wildly throughout the game.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 31. -Twenty-one leaves from the oldest known Bible have been deposited in the Princeton Library by John H. Scheide of the Class of 1896, it was announced today by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university.

BRUNSWICK, Me., Oct. 31. -- Young Republican and Young Democratic clubs which were organized on the Bowdoin College campus this Fall will bring their rivalry to a climax tomorrow and Monday nights, when they will parade on Brunswick's main street.
HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 31 (AP). -- Victor McLaglen, hard-boiled soldier of the films, has added an air force unit to his military organization, which now numbers 800 men.

PARK tandems, lady's phaetons and gigs no longer serve as the popular means of transportation, but the horse-and-buggy days have been preserved in the growing round of horse shows that -- Summer and Winter -- are spotted about the country.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 31. -- Several times penetrating deep into Rutgers territory, but repulsed when scoring appeared imminent, Lehigh turned on power in full force after the intermission and swept to three touchdowns to defeat Rutgers, 19 to 0, today.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 31. -- An underrated Union College eleven outscored Williams College in the second half but was unable to overcome its rival's early lead and lost, 26 to 13, today before more than 4,000 spectators. The victors piled up a commanding advantage of 19 -- 0 at the half.

Bequests of $2,000 to Jewish institutions in this city are directed in the will of Moritz Neuman, former leather merchant and philanthropist, filed for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court. Mr. Neuman died at his residence, 525 West End Avenue, on Sept. 28 at the age of 82.

DENVER, Oct. 31. -- Although Colorado has been classified over the country as a doubtful State, President Roosevelt's candidacy has gained considerable ground since his visit here several weeks ago and political observers are now generally agreed that the State will be in the Democratic column.
OMAHA, Oct. 31. -- "New York is asking Nebraska to give us George W. Norris in the United States Senate," Mayor La Guardia of New York told a political rally here tonight.

AREGIONAL transportation and maintenance meeting will be held during the Third Annual Motor Truck Show in Newark, T.C. Smith, chairman of the Metropolitan Section of the Society of Automotive Engineers, announced last week.

Rarely, if ever, has the progress of a campaign in this State, even in years of a Presidential election, been followed by so many watchful eyes throughout the country or the outcome of the election here been awaited with such breathless interest from coast to coast as the campaign which will close when the voters go to the polls on next Tuesday.

Warrants for the arrest of approximately 500 for fraudulent registration will be sought by Attorney General John J. Bennett, it was announced yesterday by Martin J. McLaughlin, the Attorney General's aide in charge of election activities.
IRONWOOD, Mich., Oct. 31 (AP). -- Seven persons drowned after a motor boat overturned in Lake Gogebic today, five when a rescue boat capsized and plunged them into the water a second time.

On Oct. 21 I read an article in THE TIMES written by Oswald Chew on "Pro and Con Roosevelt." I, as a Californian, wish to correct paragraph six in this article, which reads: "Through its public works, such as the TVA, Boulder Dam and others, it has provided for the future development of the country."

THIS is the life story of Kalola, head of the powerful Snake Guild of Africa, of which Messrs. Carnochan and Adamson have already written a fascinating account in "The Empire of the Snakes." It is a biographical narrative based on notes of whose scientific worth there may be no doubt, for they were secured at first hand by Mr. Carnochan on several expeditions to British Tanganyika over a period of many years.

A remarkable parallel exists between the campaign of President Roosevelt for re-election and the campaign of President Lincoln in 1864, Carl Sandburg declared last night in speaking at the annual dinner of the New York City Association of Teachers of English at the Brevoort Hotel.

The United States comes cheering, or holding its breath, to its thirty-eighth Presidential election, and the sovereign voters prepare to go forth next Tuesday to save the nation from the Democrats or the Republicans, as the case man be.

ANIMAL tails waving from the radiator caps of automobiles have come to mean nothing except that the owner belongs to the volatile fraternity of persons susceptible to new fads. Originally the bushy banner indicated something more definite. It is said to have started in Virginia, where fox hunting is a major sport.

A GARDEN book be any one of a number of things. So may a garden. And so may a gardener. This garden book by the author of "I Live in Virginia" is a genial, sometimes satiric, always entirely human picture of the family garden and the family and the neighbors, in a Virginia town.

LONDON, Oct. 30. -- Accusation and recrimination, discussion and futility -- all of these have been characteristic of another week of European diplomacy, with events overtaking the verbal exchanges which seek to obstruct them, and with public opinion getting tired of the whole mess and seeking relief in more interesting if less important matters.

Members of the New York Branch of the Southern Women's Educational Alliance will hold the first in a series of receptions for this season on the afternoon of Nov. 9 at the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Jouett P. Singleton, president of the alliance, will preside.

LONDON, Oct. 31. -- Each day the Spanish civil war continues, the greater becomes the danger to Europe, despite the whitewashing by the non-intervention committee of foreign governments and their controlled newspapers over the vast arms shipments to both sides in the Spanish struggle.

Little enthusiasm was manifest in the stock market during the brief trading period yesterday. Attendance in Wall Street was comparatively light, and while trading on the Stock Exchange exceeded that of the Saturday before, 733,000 shares against 619,000, operations were chiefly in the nature of switching and evening-up for the weekend and until after election.

PARIS, Oct. 30. -- Erik, in his new hat collection, is showing a novel use of flowers. Wreaths or coronets surround the top of the crown, or frame flat panels at the front or the back of tall conical crowns.

WHEN November arrives, thoughts of the broadcasters turn to election returns, and this always recalls that radio milestone in 1920, when the Harding-Cox election bulletins were broadcast through Pittsburgh's smoky air.

Proxies for the special meeting on Thursday of stockholders of Carib Syndicate, Ltd., are coming in slowly, Arthur H. Bunker, chairman of the board, said yesterday. The meeting was called so that the stockholders might approve or disapprove the sale of Carib's interest in the Colombian Petroleum Company to a private group for $2,000,000.

ANXIOUS to while away a terrestrial eternity, Mr. Housman has written this expiatory volume. Jests, anecdotes, incidents, descriptions, soliloquies are "shaken," to use a technical term, into the septuagenarian effervescence of an emeritus who is much amused to discover that he is still alive, yet declines, politely but firmly, to grow up.

THE St. Cecilia Club, one of the oldest of women's choruses, has begun its thirty-first season with weekly rehearsals. The chorus is under the direction of Leon Barzin and Willard Sektberg. The first concert will be given on Tuesday, Jan. 9, at the Waldorf-Astoria under the direction for April 13, under Mr. Barzin.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 31. -- The Navy plebes won their fourth football game in as many starts by beating Kiskiminetas Springs school, 13 to 6, today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31. -- The French Line offices here, through Gilbert MacQueron, Pacific Coast representative, recently called to Paris for a conference with executives of the line, announces the addition, Beginning next May, of a fast luxury liner to the present Pacific Coast fleet.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 31. -Despite the fact that Iowa has been often declared Landon territory, it is the consensus of the few political observers not allied with either party that the State is doubtful. All of the tests which normally might indicate the direction the tide is flowing this year contradict each other.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Oct. 31. -- The veteran Kent School football team defeated the Berkshire School warriors today, 37 to 0. The plucky hard-fighting losers were no match for Kent's seasoned team with its clever, shifty backs.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Oct. 31. -- Two heavily weighted favorites were defeated in today's feature races at Narragansett Park when C.V. Whitney's Roustabout took the New England Handicap by a length and a half from Don Christmas's Accolade and Art McDonnell's Party Spirit won the Ashonet Handicap by a length from Mrs. Marion Cassidy's Bill Farnsworth.

Manhattan returned to its winning ways yesterday at the expense of a surprisingly strong City College eleven. The Jasper aggregation, after yielding a touchdown in the first period, struck back to score four times and registered a 28-7 triumph over the C.C.N.Y. warriors at Ebbets Field.

Miss Marie La Montagne heads a group of women in charge of the arrangements for the annual bazaar for the benefit of the Convent of Mary Reparatrix which will be held throughout the day of Nov. 12 at the Plaza. A card party under the direction of Mrs. Howard Potter will be a feature of the afternoon.

PARTING: In 1921, when she was 17 years old and just out of high school, Caroline Miller (who won the Pulitzer Prize in 1934 for her novel, "Lamb in His Bosom") married her English teacher and principal, Will D Miller.

Political organizations are being "tremendously influenced" by the "spirit" which women are bringing to them, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said yesterday afternoon at a luncheon of the Woman's Democratic Club of the City of New York at the Hotel Commodore.

Saluting the colors with all the smartness of veterans, thirty-four newly formed Boy Scout troops of Manhattan received their troop flags on the tenth floor terrace of Bloomingdale's yesterday morning and deciphered a Morse code message relayed from the Statue of Liberty via the Empire State Building to the roof.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 31 (AP). -- Louisiana State University, defending titleholder in the Southeastern Conference, rolled on toward another championship today with an easy 19-to-0 victory over Vanderbilt to remain within the nation's unconquered ranks.

BERLIN, Oct. 31. -- The statistical office of the Berlin municipality has issued a report indicating that the number of Jews resident in the city has not decreased appreciably. The excess of Jewish emigrants over immigrants for the period from Aug. 1, 1935, to Aug. 1, 1936, was 4,000.

The affrighted air cracked almost unceasingly last week with challenges, arguments, declarations and promises designed to influence the minds of the 42,000,000 of us who will decide the question, once and for four years, on Tuesday.

IN "Stage Door," which has opened the Music Box season with its traditional hit, George S. Kaufman and Edna Ferber have made a comic show out of the grubby fortunes of the girls who aspire to the New York theatre.

Creating many problems in the relationship between employers and workers never before faced, the Social Security Act will call for more intelligent handling of personnel by industrial and business management than has ever been shown before, according to comment expressed here yesterday.

EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 31. -- The supposedly impregnable citadel of Minnesota's football power fell today before the furious charge of Northwestern's Wildcats, carrying with it the demolishment of the game's most celebrated winning streak and the 1936 championship dreams of the galloping Gophers.
John B. Burnham of Essex, N.Y., veteran sportsman and conservationist, contributes some interesting observations on game conditions up-State, with particular reference to the woodcock.

NANKING, Oct. 31 (AP). -- Nationalist China -- from humble coolie to rich merchant -- joined today in a nation-wide celebration of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's fiftieth birthday amid renewed notes of Chino-Japanese friction.

The consensus of more than 200 political observers, four or more from each of the forty-eight States and each contributor forecasting the result in the State of his residence only, is that the President will be re-elected next Tuesday by a large electoral majority.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Oct. 31. -- Smashing through an erratic Drexel defense at will, the Gettysburg eleven scored its first Eastern Collegiate Football Conference victory, 21 -- 6, today.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 31. -- Governor Landon brought his campaign outside of Kansas to a close tonight with a speech before a cheering audience which crowded the new Municipal Auditorium to its limit of 16,000 and overflowed outside.
DETROIT, Oct. 31. -- "I just can't conceive having Roosevelt for another four years," said Henry Ford.

ALBANY, Oct. 31. -- Of the three most populous counties in the capital area, Albany, Rensselaer and Schenectady, Albany probably will be the only one to return pluralities to President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman.
DETROIT, Oct. 31. -- Two question marks stand out in borderline Michigan as 2,000,000 voters make ready for Tuesday's ballot with the State's nineteen electoral votes at stake.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- The attention of the forty-eight State Governors has been officially called by the government to the existence of the Norris constitutional amendment and the consequent changes in the date upon which Presidential Electors must meet and count their votes.

The Interstate Commerce Commission reported yesterday that in August 144 Class I railroads earned a net income of $20,857,329, in contrast with a net loss of $2,304,998 in August, 1935. This gave for the first eight months of the year a net income of $16,384,500, against a net loss of $79,815,256 for the same period last year.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 31. -Rhode Island seems destined to return to the Republican fold on Tuesday, when a record vote of more than 351,000 will be cast for national, State and municipal candidates in the first State-wide use of voting machines.

WITH general public attention centered almost exclusively on the purely political results of the recent Maine election, the American Petroleum Industries Committee has issued a statement reminding motorists that the voters of the Pine Tree State also passed by a large majority a referendum bill prohibiting diversion of highway funds to other uses.

Col. Gen. Hermann Goering, the new Nazi economic dictator, is noted for -- among other things -- his uniforms, his medals and his girth. Last week, while outlining the Reich's Four-Year Plan to achieve economic self-sufficiency, he revealed that his claim to renown was diminishing in one respect. Urging the populace to deny itself certain imported foods, he said:

Women interested in the plans for the annual Christmas sale in behalf of Hope Farm, to be held Nov. 18 and 19 at the Pierre, will meet Thursday morning at the home of Mrs. Arthur W. Butler, chairman of the benefit committee, 120 East Fifty-fifth Street, to complete arrangements for the sale. Miss Anna Glenn Butler heads a group of younger members of society aiding in the plans.

AS an artist Mr. Blake delights in overpowering sensuousness -- "the rich smell of rich land well farmed and well mucked," with "midsummer rising in the land like cream." As an analyst he is acutely conscious of the passions and jealousies that spring from this golden environment.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 31. -- A new approach to the problem of preventing disorders of the heart -- based on the assumption that heart ailments among middle-aged people are due to maladjustment between development in youth and demand on the heart in later life -is being planned for the students of Rutgers University, Dr. Joseph H. Kler, university physician, announced today.

MODESTY, simplicity and honesty were the immediate impressions made by John Barbirolli, who arrived last week to prepare for his ten weeks at the head of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra. His very arrival was without ostentation.
The National Railways of Mexico have reported for 1935 an operating income of 115,510,837 pesos, against 104,211,822 in 1934.

Four stakes will be contested during the thirteenth annual meeting of the Cocker Spaniel Field Trial Club of America next Saturday and Sunday over the covers of the Verbank Hunting and Fishing Club in Verbank, N.Y., under the rules of the American Kennel Club.
AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 31. -- A highly favored Amherst eleven today won the local town football championship, defeating Massachusetts State, 13 to 7, in a game marked by sixteen fumbles.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31. -- Retail trade had another very active week under the influence of crisp, seasonal weather. Apparel lines and housefurnishings led in the further expansion of sales, with Halloween novelties also active. Grocery departments, however, reported rather slow business, consumers apparently being still heavily stocked from early Fall purchases to forestall drought effects.

Announcement was made yesterday of the committee for the senior ball of New York University's School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance, as the annual supper dance is known. It will be held at the Waldorf-Astoria on Feb. 20.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 31. -- Despite a drop from 152 to 118 in the number of scholarships granted from last year, there will be no corresponding decrease in the amount set aside by Williams College for student aid, Albert V. Osterhout, Director of Student Aid, stated this week.

On the basis of reservations, New York's hotels, restaurants and night clubs are expecting the largest election night business in years -- indeed, since the pre-prohibition and equally hotly contested election of 1916.

THIS story must perforce be prefaced by a perfectly patent observation. It is simply that Senora Marta Abba, the young Italian actress who is making her American debut in the highly successful "Tovarich," at the Plymouth Theatre, is a very lovely lady, indeed.

The drought areas continue to be among the most active regions for business despite the pessimistic predictions during the Summer, according to reports by manufacturers and wholesalers yesterday. Government payments have ranged from $4,000,000 to $8,000,000 a month and these sums have been sufficient to keep the rural purchasing power at a high level, it was said.

Twenty-nine houses of the City College House Plan held elections last week, naming 118 undergraduate leaders. Officers of the central governing council were also elected by the thirty members of the council of house delegates. Solomon Chaiken was elected president; Edward Zaslow, vice president; Wilfred Mintz, secretary.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the proposed admission on Jan. 1 of Frederick L. Moore and John G. Flint to Kidder, Peabody Co.

President Roosevelt expressed his personal thanks yesterday to the employes and volunteer workers of the Democratic organization in a speech before 2,000 men and women in the grand ballroom of the Biltmore Hotel.

MOSCOW, Oct. 30 -- Recent rumors abroad -- as usual, unfounded -of Stalin's illness, and even of his death, focus attention again on the man who is the most powerful figure in the world today and perhaps the most influential in shaping the world of tomorrow.

THE World War had left Captain Luke Hardin, late of the A.E.F., disgusted with life. After searching the country over in vain for Colonel Barkus who, he believed, had killed his brother by ordering him out on a suicide detail, he returned to his Arizona ranch to find, still more to his disgust, that his agents had turned it into a dude ranch.

Although Southern producers moved last week the largest quantity of cotton into sight for any week since the big crop of 1931, hedging operations on the Cotton Exchange fell yesterday to the smallest proportions of any Saturday of the last two months, and prices ended with a gain of 2 to a loss of 6 points.

LIMA, Peru -- The recent Presidential elections revealed the strength in Peru of the Apra (American Popular Revolutionary Alliance) and of its founder and leader, Victor Raul Haya de la Torre, although the leader is still in hiding and the party was not permitted to have a Presidential candidate.

Money rates were unchanged in October for the fifth consecutive month. Demand for credit, despite greater stock market activity and higher prices, declined during the month. The supply of funds available for collateral loans remained well in excess of demand.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 31. -- Parents who are too indulgent with their children may unwittingly prepare a foundation for nervous disturbance in later life, Dr. John A. Evans of Baltimore said today before the convention of the Eastern Homeopathic Medical Association.

SPEED rides America's rails, obliterating old records beneath thundering wheels. The other day the Burlington's Denver Zephyr streaked a little over a thousand miles at an average speed of 83.3 miles per hour, setting a world mark for long hauls. At one point the speedometer in the b of the streamlined Diesel-i motored train crept up to 116 miles I l?er hour.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31.'Before leavin for New York today Secretary Perkins announced that spokesmen for the West Coast maritime unions had informed her they were willing to resume negotiations where they had broken off when the strike was called.

An evening of diversified entertainment is being planned for the Carnival on Wheels, to be held on Nov. 13 at the Mecca Temple Casino, 133 West Fifty-fifth Street, in aid of the Vocational Service for Juniors and its subsidiary, the Junior Consultation Service.
RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 31. -Duke's Blue Devils put on a field day today and crushed Washington and Lee's Generals, 51 to 0, before a crowd of 8,000 persons.

Charging that the attitude of the New Deal toward the Negro "is an affront to our intelligence and an insult to our citizenship," Marion Moore Day, daughter of Frederick R. Moore, former Minister to Liberia, made a radio plea yesterday over the Columbia network for the election of Governor Landon.

Members of the New York Printing Pressmen's Union, Local 2, received a circular letter yesterday from their president, Andrew R. Armstrong, urging them not to be misled by slips placed in their payroll envelopes by one newspaper employer warning of payroll deductions Jan. 1 to defray the cost of Social Security.

THE Third Annual National Motor Truck Show opens at Newark, in the Center Market Building, next Tuesday morning and continues through Saturday. Sixty exhibitors of complete trucks, bodies, engines and accessories have reserved all the available space on both floors of the exhibition building and the display is announced as the largest of its kind ever held under one roof.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 3 -Halloween parties were held at the Milbrook Country Club and Indian Harbor Yacht Club tonight. At the former club a hay loft was built in the ballroom and the decorations consisted of corn husks and pumpkins.

Heads of near-by engineering schools differ sharply in regard to the suggestion recently made to them by President Roosevelt that courses be so balanced as to equip engineers to meet their "social responsibility." Seven administrators queried by THE NEW YORK TIMES as to what their schools should do and are doing to equip their students to understand "social processes and problems" reveal almost every degree of dissatisfaction and complacency with existing practices.

Irvington House will be the beneficiary of a fashion show and entertainment at the formal opening of the new lounge and Restaurant de la Paix at the St. Moritz tomorrow afternoon. In addition to the fashion revue there will be a varied program of divertissements by professional entertainers.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 31. -- Democratic and Republican leaders both are claiming New Jersey's sixteen electoral votes, while impartial observers for the most part place the State in the doubtful column.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP). -- The Bureau of Fisheries arose today to defend the catfish, long dubbed a lowbrow because of a receding forehead.

PUBLISHING began in America when the Widow Glover arrived at Newtowne, now Cambridge, with a press and types, a mechanic, Stephen Daye, and five children. The president of Harvard married the widow and received her family and her press into his home.

IT is not hard, unfortunately, to ferret out the inspiration of this inept extravaganza. In externals at least, "Sow the Wind" is another "Sun Also Rises," ten years belated, stripped of relevance and wit. The scene, for a change, is Corsica; the particular expatriates in question are a corrupt and sodden crew of unexampled nastiness.

THE subjects discussed in this unusual handbook have been chosen, literally, by the public. Mr. Howes is curator at the Bruce Museum of Natural History in Greenwich, Conn., and in that capacity he must answer a great many questions, about matters both strange and simple, in animal life.

THIS is one of those plain, old-fashioned boyish historical romances of that kind which used to delight provincial American youth when James Otis and Oliver Optic and other simplifiers of Cooper were in favor. As you have guessed, it's about the War of 1812, or, rather, the adventures on sea and land before and during that war of a six-foot Green Mountain boy adventuring under the name of Red Ford.

Power-boat drivers and rule-makers who talked and frequently shouted themselves hoarse Wednesday, Thursday and Friday at the Hotel Lexington in the yearly October pow-wows that always culminate in the American Power Boat Association annual meeting, brought out into the open a good many subsurface matters.

The Detroit Lions, champions of the National Football League, will invade the Polo Grounds today to take on the New York Giants, Eastern rulers and present pace-setters. The opening kick-off is scheduled for 2:15 P.M.

"A splendid majority" for the Republican national ticket in the East was predicted yesterday by Joseph W. Martin Jr., Republican Eastern campaign manager, in a statement released here after he had returned to his home in Massachusetts.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31. -- The normal Republican State of California will go overwhelmingly Democratic, with President Roosevelt as the banner carrier, and with more than 325,000 votes "to the good," the wise ones who bet their money on their opinion, said here today.

Quite apart from the merit of parties or candidates, this Presidential campaign has witnessed little real and high political debate, with the contestants coming to close grips with each other and with the essentials. Never were so many millions of words spoken and printed, leaving so few in the memory.

Frank Shannon, a layer of odds at New York race tracks, and three of his assistants were bound and gagged in his fifteenth-floor room in the Hotel Pennsylvania last night by four armed men who escaped with more than $3,400.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31. -- Charging that President Roosevelt seeks re-election by offering the American people "a pig in a poke," Colonel Frank Knox, Republican Vice Presidential nominee, predicted tonight that the voters on Tuesday would cast out the New Deal "amateur dictators" and "wasters and destroyers."

LONDON. -- "Only those who have come into direct contact with racial antagonisms know how deeply they are situated in the primitive organization of the human brain." So said Sir Arthur Keith in the Boyle Memorial Lecture on "Nationality and Race" delivered at Oxford in 1919.

A breezy story of the Northwest and the Canadian Mounted Police in the Nineties, told with an enthusiasm that is infectious. The author has the gift of writing graphically so that the reader feels he is an eyewitness of ceremonies and parades, of Indians driving the wild horses into the corral, of gymkhanas and riding lessons.

JIM KITTERING had been riding for the Lazy Bar X only a week when he ran smack into the feud between that outfit and the Slocums, father and daughter, who were homesteading (by permission) on a far corner of the ranch.

MARIE STERNER in her role as impresario continues to bring forth talents new to the New York art lover. This week her galleries are hosts to Herman Maril, whose show of paintings is introduced by Olin Dows, and Martha Axley, whose water-colors are sponsored in a foreword by Malcolm Vaughan, our colleague of The New York American.
WASTNGTON, Oct. 31 (AP). -When the weatherman issues tomorrow's forecast he will start the sixty-seventh year of this goverment service.

THE first copies of the revised edition of H.L. Mencken's "The American Language" were imported here in July, and most of the British reviews of it appeared in July and August. The Times Literary Supplement however, has waited to notice it until it was possible to deal simultaneously with the first installment of Sir William Craigie's "Dictionary of American English."
The 2,000-ton gunboat Erie, first of her type, sailed yesterday morning from the Navy Yard in Brooklyn for an 8,500-mile "shakedown" cruise in European waters.

Teachers from New York State, Connecticut, Massachusetts, New Jersey and Pennsylvania will attend the New York Conference of the Progressive Education Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania on Nov. 13 and 14. The theme of the conference will be "Democracy and Education."

At 1:45 o'clock Wednesday afternoon the mellow notes of a coaching horn will penetrate the far corners of Madison Square Garden to proclaim the formal opening of the fiftieth exhibition of the National Horse Show Association, which will continue through Tuesday evening, Nov. 10.

DETAILED specifications of the Willys car to be introduced when the Automobile Show opens here on Nov. 11 have not been made public, but a general description was released last week with a picture showing the front-end treatment of the car. The picture is reproduced above.

More than 1,000 members of the International Seamen's Union, at a rump meeting following an official session called by national officers, voted unanimously last night at Cooper Union to go on strike immediately in all Atlantic ports against American flag intercoastal and transatlantic ships to aid the 39,000 striking Pacific Coast maritime workers.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 31 (AP). -- Lammot du Pont, president of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., declared today that "the greatest service the people can render the country and themselves on election day is to repudiate the New Deal by voting "for Governor Landon" and for Congressional candidates pledged to support his policies.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 31. -Awards of scholarships totaling $10,500 to forty-two students in the Harvard Medical School were announced today as follows:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- Georgetown University kept its undefeated football record for the season intact today by walloping the Hornets from Shenandoah College, 47 to 0.

BEHIND the recent announcement of Transcontinental and Western Air that Lieut. Commander D.W. Tomlinson was conducting experiments with a specially fitted Northrop Gamma at altitudes of about 35,000 feet, with a view to eventual passenger operation at high levels, lies the implication that pressure cabin equipment is in the offing.
SOUTHBORO, Mass., Oct. 31. -St. Mark's conquered the Milton eleven, 41 -- 0, today.

When the National Horse Show opens on Wednesday at Madison Square Garden before a distinguished assemblage of horse enthusiasts from this city, surrounding country places and other cities in the East, it will be marked by a round of social activities arranged for the entertainment of out of town and foreign visitors and competitors in the show.
RIVERSIDE, Mass., Oct. 31. -- In an exciting intersectional battle the football teams of Boston University and Miami University played a 7-7 tie before 5,500 spectators at Nickerson Field today.

Credit and collection conditions in Latin-American nations during the third quarter of this year showed a decline compared with previous quarters of the year, according to the survey released yesterday by the foreign credit interchange bureau of the National Association of Credit Men.

DALLAS, Oct. 31. -- Business in the Eleventh Federal Reserve District continues to show substantial gains over preceding weeks of this year and also over corresponding periods of last year. The dollar volume of retail sales shows unusual gains in many cities.

Following a school-wide election, Hunter College has announced the complete list of class officers and student leaders. More than seventy girls will direct class and committee activities for the year.

Locked in the White House safe is one of the most interesting series of election forecasts made by any political leader in the United States -- President Roosevelt's own. His written guesses as of last Winter, last Spring and last month are there in an envelope, he says, and he probably will draw up another tomorrow night.

AN auction campaign as intensive as any that have been witnessed hereabouts threatens to keep the collecting world palpitating from now until Christmas. The Rains Galleries in New York have already braved the election din with a small sale of mixed character held last week.

LAST Wednesday evening the cast and management of "Dead End" celebrated their first year's anniversary as tenants of the Belasco Theatre. Ceremonies befitting the occasion were offered by Producer Norman Bel Geddes and Author Sidney Kingsley.

AMERICA'S first representative body of English law-makers met in a church -the little frame building at James-town, where the Virginia House of was called together in July, 1619. The lanterns that signaled to Paul Revere we set in a church in Boston, as we all know, and it was after a mass meeting in another church that citizens went forth disguised to their Tea Party in Boston Harbor.

Commodity futures prices were generally higher last week, with sizable gains in crude rubber, tin, copper and lead. Cocoa futures were sharply lower and sugar declined moderately. In the cash markets, coffee, rubber, silk, copper, lead, wool tops, tin and butter were higher, while wheat, corn, rye, oats, flour, cotton, cocoa, sugar and lard were lower.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 30. -- In the Far West when voters are displeased with laws provided by their Legislatures they pass new laws by means of direct legislation. Thus all along the Pacific coast this year the use of the initiative and the referendum is provoking bitter and unusual political battles.

THE Pony Express is a fascinating bit of history. To see it through the eyes of a small boy fortunate enough to live near one of the stations will make this stirring enterprise very vivid to young readers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- Adolph A. Berle Jr., Chamberlain of New York, was named by the State Department today as one of seven delegates to represent the United States at the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace, to be held at Buenos Aires, beginning Dec. 1.

UNITY of subject, technique and setting is emphasized in this season's murals for apartment homes or country houses. Murals are seen in diverse styles, from the eighteenth-century type of ornamentation with its flower motifs to original scenes from everyday life.

This is an energetically humorous book about dyed-in-the-wool DownEasterners. The scene is the little town of Hardscrabble in Southwest Maine, where most folks had a hard scrabble to make a living. But Hiram Harding, whose idea of congenial work was whittling a pine twig, planned to live in clover by marrying the Widow Pettengill and existing on her farm and her labors.

THE "Bog" of the Southern Sudan is probably the last place on earth to which one would expect a painter to go. Hot, fever-stricken, sparsely inhabited and poor, it is also flat, monotonous, swampy and, to quote this painter's uncompromising and unmistakable adjective, ugly; nor can it be said to be peopled by an "artistic" race.

AS its title makes plain, this book by an authority on home decoration is entirely concerned with what is new. But it is, for all that, almost encyclopedic. And it is essentially practical. The author takes up one detail after another, one household problem after another, from the large subjects of floor and furniture to such small items as "the newest idea in slip covers," and tells the home maker what to do.
The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin last night made a public "apology" for having called President Roosevelt a "scab President."
Defeat by the voters on election day of the $30,000,000 relief bond issue proposed by the State is urged by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

Fall opens a period of sumptuous dinners, and the carver's duties grow heavier. A carver seldom buys the knives he uses. He needs to be supplied with a sharp weapon with which to attack roasts and if he gets his carving knives in hand now he can practice on lesser fowl and be in form for dealing with the Thanksgiving turkey and the Christmas duck.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 30. -- Diplomats and statesmen are seeking an answer to the question as to what are the realities behind the appearance of confidence, mutual loyalty and sturdy readiness for defense presented by the visit of King Carol to Czechoslovakia and the conferences of the Little Entente which have succeeded one another so rapidly since Summer.

NANKING, Oct. 31. -- "The Chinese authorities are playing a dangerous game in utilizing the bogey of foreign aggression to incite the passions of the people," the spokesman of the Japanese Embassy asserted today. Commenting on the outburst of patriotic fervor accompanying Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's birthday and other recent events, he added:

Approximately 400 firms holding membership in the New York Stock Exchange enclosed with the monthly statements mailed yesterday to customers the first of a series of letters to the security-trading public signed by Charles R. Gay, president of the Exchange.

MORE motor trucks will be made and sold by American producers during the current year than ever before in the history of the industry. Figures already available point to the fact that 1929's record output of 826,817 commercial vehicles will be surpassed this year.

SAY what you will about the respective merits of stage and screen, you must admit that the cinema is considerably more generous. The Broadway season thus far has not been too distinguished, with possibly six good shows among the twenty-six which have opened since Labor Day.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 31. -Trinity stopped Wesleyan's victorious march today, decisively defeating the Cardinals on their own field, 20 to 0. It was Trinity's day, with Kobrosky and O'Malley breaking through the line and circling the ends for long runs.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 31. -- Roman Soldier, Elwood Sachsenmaier's swift-footed black colt, finding the crisp Autumn air and a fast track to his liking, today captured the Washington Handicap, closing day feature, in near-record time.

Charter Revision Commission. Mayor La Guardia, on Jan. 12, 1935, appointed as the New York City Charter Revision Commission Thomas D. Thacher, chairman; S. John Block, Mrs. William P. Earle Jr., Frederick L. Hackenburg, Charles E. Hughes Jr., Joseph D. McGoldrick, Charles G. Meyer, Thomas I. Parkinson and Joseph M. Proskauer.

BOSTON, Oct. 31 (AP). -- Joseph P. Kennedy, first chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said tonight that Republican leaders were "grossly unfair" in the manner in which the social security issue was brought into the campaign.

SCHENECTADY, Oct. 31. -- The Hoople for Happiness party formed at Union College two weeks ago has not only succeeded in gaining more than four times the membership of the old-line party clubs on the campus, but has already made its mark in other ways.

DENVER, Oct. 31 (AP). -- District Judge George F. Dunklee today ordered informations filed charging Montgomery Ward, Inc., and a Denver lumber company with violating a State election law of 1891 by "implied threats intended to influence the votes of their employes."
ALBANY, Oct. 31. -- The text of the address of former Governor Smith follows:
As a result of three months of campaigning by Governor Landon, which has extended from the Atlantic to the Pacific, members of his circle of intimate advisers are divided between confidence and hope.

A prepayment plan by which parents can begin financing their children's college education at birth has just been instituted at Bucknell University. Any amount from a dollar up is enough at any time to start an account with the university, which may mean four years in academic halls for a son or daughter later on, according to the announcement.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- It has been a hard campaign year for minority parties. In spite of months of ardent electioneering, a hospitable press, wider public interest than usual and a leadership in most cases aggressive and able beyond the average, the political groups offering specialized programs are held, in Washington's expert opinion on election eve, to have suffered more from the current battle over New Deal issues and personalities than have gained.

Plans are now being drawn up for the fifth annual Miami-Biltmore Fashion Show and Ball to be given on Dec. 11 at the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the board of directors of the Goddard Neighborhood Center in association with Colonel Henry L. Doherty, president of the Florida-Year-Round Clubs.

JACKSONVILLE, Oct. 31.-- Although the Republican candidates who are opposing Democrats for State and national offices have conducted a strenuous campaign in Florida, political observers here do not believe that they have made sufficient headway to interfere with the success of the national and State Democratic tickets at the polls on Nov. 3.
PARIS. MOLYNEUX'S new interseasonal collection expresses this creator at his best. Which is to say that it is full of clothes that women will want to own and wear, not merely admire.

SOME day, no doubt, we shall see in New York a comprehensive Picasso exhibition covering all the major aspects of the artist's career thus far; an exhibition comparable to the one held several years ago in Paris and to the one that, shortly thereafter, vied with Miss Stein's "Four Saints" to make momentous the opening of the new Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford, Conn.
LAWRENCE, Kan., Oct. 31 (AP). -- An underdog Kansas University football team battled Arizona University to a scoreless tie today in a game featured by tight defenses and loose offenses.

OUT of the tenebrous mind of William Faulkner there comes another strange tale of the people of Jefferson, that remote corner of Mississippi out of which Faulkner has carved his literary empire and which has produced such novels as "Sanctuary" and "Light in August."

Richard W. Lawrence, former president of the National Republican Club, made public yesterday correspondence between Eugene F. Grigat and Joseph E. Ridder, which, Mr. Lawrence declared, tended to show that the Democratic National Committee solicited support for Roosevelt among Nazi sympathizers in this country.

IN "Time in the Rock" Conrad Aiken again proves that he is the finest verbal musician on the stage of contemporary poets. His lines weave songs that seem to have been threaded in shadowy atmospheres; music that reflects "the picture world, which is ourselves, speaking of yesterday, and yesterday, and yesterday."
The attitude of the women who wish to learn how to invest their own money has changed radically in the last seven years, according to Miss Clara Taylor, lecturer and investment counselor.

An examination by the Columbia University library staff of the 5,000 books and manuscripts in the collection of the late George A. Plimpton which was presented to the school last May reveals much information concerning the origin and development of textbooks from the Middle Ages to the present, it was revealed yesterday.

Many dinner parties will be given before the performance of "Red, Hot and Blue," the new musical comedy, on Wednesday night at the Alvin Theatre for the benefit of the West Side Day Nursery. The funds realized will be used to provide and maintain a boy's workshop at the headquarters of the organization at 470 West Forty-third Street, and in providing vacation periods in the country during the Summer for under-privileged city children.

ROME, Oct. 30. -- The Italo-German agreement just concluded is tangible evidence of the gradual change that has been going on in the past eighteen months in Italian opinion toward Great Britain and France on the one hand and toward Germany on the other.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 31. -- Alabama's power finally wore down a fighting Kentucky team today, and after a scoreless first half the Crimson Tide put over two touchdowns to defeat the Wilcats, 14 to 0.

A PAINTING, "The Run," by John Noble, has just been acquired by Frank Phillips of Bartlesville, Okla., for his historical museum. The picture represents the rush of homesteaders for the free land in the Cherokee Strip, now part of Oklahoma, in 1893, an event in which Mr. Noble participated as young man.

It is doubtful if Mozart, Mendelssohn or any other infant prodigy of the keyboard on record could have done justice, at the age of 11 years, to the formidable program mapped out for Ruth Slenczynski's recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- One of the outstanding issues as the campaign nears a close is the Social Security Act, passed by Congress in the Summer of 1935. Republicans and Democrats have joined battle over the scope, intent and application of this law.

THE Fall issue of Transition, edited and printed in America for the first time, made its appearance recently. It includes a discussion on realism in art by Louis Aragon, Fernand Leger and Corbusier, besides narrative verse and other material.

MADRID, Oct. 31 (Passed by the Censor). -- Heavy fighting proceeded today in sector north of Aranjuez and south of Madrid. The Rebels recaptured the railway station at Sesena and again interrupted the railway to the sea. Parla, on the Toledo road, ten miles south of Madrid, was captured by the Rebels this afternoon and Getafe, about half-way to Madrid from that place, was heavily bombed by planes.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 31. -- Following is the text of the address delivered by Governor Landon in the Municipal Auditorium tonight:

The current exceptionally heavy activity in a number of merchandise lines is nothing but a period of "profitless prosperity," according to a number of manufacturers, who yesterday reported that strong efforts will be made to increase quotations for Spring, despite opposition from buyers.
AUSTIN, Texas, Oct. 31 (AP). -Southern Methodist University, combining aerial wizardry with bewildering ground tactics, defeated a stalwart University of Texas football aggregation today, 14 to 7.

The average voter has decided by now whether he will support or oppose the New Deal, but a surprisingly large number of New Yorkers still have not made up their minds about the proposed new city charter, which would bring about greater centralization of the city's form of government.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 31. -- A series of educational and political discussions under the auspices of the Westchester School of Current Affairs will begin here Monday evening at the Sarah Lawrence College, according to an announcement from the county Office of Adult Education.

The annual armistice ball of the British Great War Veterans of America, given in aid of that organization's relief fund, will be held Friday night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The ball this year is set at a date several days earlier than in the past.

The annual armistice ball of the British Great War Veterans of America, given in aid of that organization's relief fund, will be held Friday night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The ball this year is set at a date several days earlier than in the past.

THIS person and that have been toying with the notion of importing "The Two Bouquets," that musical by Eleanor and Herbert Farjeon which has been amusing London gently since last August -- a cheerful if nostalgic glance at Victorianism, old tunes (by some twenty composers) reorchestrated and fitted with new lyrics, bicycles built for two.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 31 (AP). -- Purdue's husky Boilermakers made a display of their power for three scoreless periods today, then barely edged past Carnegie Tech, 7 to 6, in a spectacular final quarter.

ANOTHER group of paintings by contemporary artists of Hungary has been brought over by the College Art Association. Assembled as a traveling show, this work makes its initial appearance in New York in the galleries of the Squibb Building.

Long shots scored in the stakes that saw the end of the Jockey Club racing season at Empire City yesterday, Thorson being first in the $6,540 Yorktown Handicap and Drawbridge winner of the $3,510 Autumn Days Stakes. Thorson was 10 to 1 in the colors of Buckley Byers, while Drawbridge was as good as 6 to 1 for the Wheatley Stable of Ogden Mills and his sister, Mrs. H.C. Phipps.

Minnesota's last defeat prior to the setback by Northwestern yesterday was by Michigan, 3-0, in the final game of the 1932 season. The Gophers' undefeated string had extended through twenty-eight games, with the last twenty-one in succession resulting in victories.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31. -- Inspired by plans for the University of Pennsylvania's bi-centennial celebration in 1940, undergraduates on the board of governors of Houston Hall, student union on the campus, will sponsor an educational program designed to acquaint the student body more fully with the history, traditions and work of the university.
BOSTON, Oct. 31. -- Political observers believe that Governor Landon, aided by dissenting Democrats, will carry Massachusetts by at least 50,000 votes.

ANOTHER group of paintings by contemporary artists of Hungary has been brought over by the College Art Association. Assembled as a traveling show, this work makes its initial appearance in New York in the galleries of the Squibb Building.

Long shots scored in the stakes that saw the end of the Jockey Club racing season at Empire City yesterday, Thorson being first in the $6,540 Yorktown Handicap and Drawbridge winner of the $3,510 Autumn Days Stakes. Thorson was 10 to 1 in the colors of Buckley Byers, while Drawbridge was as good as 6 to 1 for the Wheatley Stable of Ogden Mills and his sister, Mrs. H.C. Phipps.

Minnesota's last defeat prior to the setback by Northwestern yesterday was by Michigan, 3-0, in the final game of the 1932 season. The Gophers' undefeated string had extended through twenty-eight games, with the last twenty-one in succession resulting in victories.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31. -- Inspired by plans for the University of Pennsylvania's bi-centennial celebration in 1940, undergraduates on the board of governors of Houston Hall, student union on the campus, will sponsor an educational program designed to acquaint the student body more fully with the history, traditions and work of the university.
BOSTON, Oct. 31. -- Political observers believe that Governor Landon, aided by dissenting Democrats, will carry Massachusetts by at least 50,000 votes.

Purchase of a department store, the first in the league of cooperative department stores throughout the country sponsored by E.A. Filene, Boston merchant, has been authorized and steps were taken last week to canvass locations and begin negotiations for purchase, it was announced yesterday by Herbert E. Evans, vice president of the Consumer Distribution Corporation, the central wholesale unit for the league.
The City College junior varsity eleven scored its first victory of the season with a 7 -- 0 triumph over Benjamin Franklin High at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 31 (AP). -Showing a return to the form which netted him seven victories last Spring, Mrs. L.J. Hickman's Dusty Dawn stepped three-quarters in 1:11 3-5 to account for the South Louisville Purchase, today's inaugural feature at Churchill Downs.

OMAHA, Oct. 31. -- A three-cornered race involving the fate of Nebraska's veteran Senator George W. Norris pushed the Presidential contest into the background as the campaign drew to a close in this State.

NO one wants to know what another mail thinks of Russia. If that fact were commonly recognized, a good deal of loud talking on street corners could be avoided. But every man has his own opinion of Russia, according to the amount of his property and the pitch of his temperament, and what he really wants is for you to listen.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP). -- Expenditures of more than $13,000,000 had been recorded by today in America's costliest Presidential campaign, as the Republican National Committee's final report before election showed it had spent almost $7,000,000.

ALTHOUGH a certain timelessness is frequently attributed to art, two groups of artists have recently focused on time as a central point of their activities. Two calendars have resulted, the work of the artists taking the form of wood block or linoleum prints, lithographs or drawings, reproduced one to a page with a week of the calendar at the bottom of each sheet.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 31. -The engineering staff at Brown University is making a particular effort this year to develop further informal relationships between undergraduates and members of the staff faculty, Professor William H. Kenerson, chairman of the division of engineering, reported today.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Oct. 31. -- King Carol's divorced wife, Princess Helen, has alarmed Rumanian court circles and probably her former husband as well by announcing that she is coming to Rumania for a month's stay.

ROME is preparing to make its 1941 World's Fair the greatest ever held in Europe. The gigantic exposition will be the second undertaken by Italy within this century. The first, held in 1911, was divided between two cities.

Members of the Town Hall Club, 123 West Forty-third Street, are selecting the member who "has in the past year made the most conspicuous contribution to the enlargement and enrichment of life" for the annual Award of Honor.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31. -- Plans for the longest road trip in the history of the Mask and Wig Club of the University of Pennsylvania were announced today by the committee on production. The forty-ninth annual show, "This Mad Whirl," will have its premiere performance on Nov. 21 at the du Pont Theatre in Wilmington, Del., instead of in Philadelphia, as is customary.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Oct. 31. -- Technicians set about to determine whether an underground lake or an old mine caused the huge cracks in the earth that destroyed an entire suburb here.

With the arrival of the indoor bulb-planting season, many flower lovers, who have forced the paper white narcissus Winter after Winter are wondering if there are not other kinds to take its place. There are other bulbs, quite as easy to force indoors by the same water-and-fiber method.

Although it took three days and several hundred natives, seven of whom were injured seriously, to capture Truson, the largest orang-utan in captivity, the 300-pound ape sat in his improvised cage in the American Museum of Natural History last week, posed for photographers and grinned while he munched his favorite tidbit -- a honey-dew melon.
The following is the text of the address delivered by Governor Lehman last night at Madison Square Garden:

Sascha Gorodnitzki's indubitable gifts for the piano have developed immeasurably. He made this known yesterday afternoon in his first recital of the season at Carnegie Hall, where in 1930 he made his debut with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra as soloist.

FIVE American painters -- Leon Kroll, Alexander Brook, Guy Pene DuBois, John Sloan and Charles Sheeler -- are brought together in an exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum that contains also work by the American sculptor John Flanagan.

PARIS, Oct. 31. -- The parliamentary session which opens Thursday promises to be even livelier than expected. Maurice Thorez, Communist leader, made a violent attack on Premier Leon Blum last night, incidentally accusing Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos of not acting as a loyal adherent to the Popular Front because of his non-intervention policy with regard to Spain.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1. -- Several hundred dock workers and the crews of thirteen of the fourteen ships in port here walked out today in sympathy with the nation-wide marine strike. Picket lines were drawn up and all activity ceased along the Delaware River pier heads.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 1. -- Referring to his plans after the election, Father Coughlin tonight told 8,000 cheering partisans of the National Union for Social Justice that he would "continue broadcasting social justice as long as you want me to and Bishop Gallagher approves."

Reporters and photographers from newspapers and news services, who were sent to the strike meeting of the International Seamen's Union of America yesterday afternoon at Webster Hall and to strike headquarters at 164 Eleventh Avenue last night, were refused admission unless they had membership cards in the American Newspaper Guild.
Governor Lehman faced the windup of his campaign for re-election with supreme confidence yesterday and prepared to make a final invasion of Westchester tonight for a series of last-minute speeches.

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 31. -- Financial circles here believe that the international results of the gold agreement, so far considered, are not unfavorable to the maintenance of a rather good equilibrium in the currencies of the three countries that were parties to the agreement.

DETROIT, Nov. 1. -- Bishop Michael J. Gallagher stated today that after the present political campaign had been concluded, no priest in his diocese would be allowed to take an active part in politics.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1936, as well as last price, for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

Proposition No. 1. "Shall the pro"posed $30,000,000 relief bond issue be "approved?" Vote No. The money is needed, but there is no excuse any longer for borrowing it. The State Chamber of Commerce and the State Charities Aid Association are agreed that hereafter relief costs should be met out of the budget, just like any other item of current expenditure.

Joseph H. Choate Jr., former head of the Federal Alcohol Control Administration, announced yesterday that he intended to vote for Governor Landon. His statement was issued through the Eastern division of the Republican National Committee.

Business has registered steady improvement for three successive quarters, and every sign now points to a full year of advance, according to Banking, official publication of the American Bankers Association, in its November issue.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (AP). -- Representative Marvin Jones of Texas, chairman of the House Committee on Agriculture, issued a statement today through the Roosevelt Agricultural Committee in which he said "I am convinced agriculture will stand by the President, which means the Roosevelt administration will win."

PARIS, Oct. 31. -- The return of the Bank of France for Oct. 23 shows an increase of exactly 2,000,000,000 francs of gold in the reserves, this evidently meaning that the equalization fund sold that amount of the metal to the bank, since trading in gold by individuals and private banks is prohibited and the Bank of France no longer can buy or sell gold except from or to the equalization fund.

A 16-yard run which carried him across the goal line in the third period against St. Bonaventure yesterday enabled Joe Szur, Canisius halfback and captain, to retain first place among Eastern college football scorers. Previous to this game Szur had been tied for the lead with Sam Padjen, Dickinson fullback, who tallied three touchdowns on Saturday against Haverford.

Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, speaking at the final Democratic rally in Jersey City yesterday afternoon, again took Alfred E. Smith to task for criticizing President Roosevelt and advocating the election of Governor Landon.
