ORADELL, N.J., Nov. 1. -- Cornelius Cagney, authority on law books, was injured fatally at 10 o'clock last night in a collision between his car and another on Soldiers Hill here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP). -Gardner Jackson, chairman of the National Committee on Rural Social Planning, made public today a letter to President Roosevelt asserting that WPA field representatives in the South were using labor from relief rolls to depress wages of cotton-field workers.
LONDON, Nov. 1 (AP). -- Determined as ever to see things for himself, King Edward has announced he will visit the "distressed areas" of industrial South Wales this month.

GALVESTON, Texas, Nov. 1. -- Strikes called by rank and file members of the International Seamen's Union at Houston and Port Arthur in opposition to union officials seriously interfered with shipping at those two ports and it was expected the strike would spread to Galveston and other Texas ports in a day or two.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 (AP). -A flashy passing attack and a series of powerful drives gave La Salle College a 47-to-12 victory today over St. Mary's of Minnesota at the dedication of La Salle's new McCarthy Stadium. More than 6,000 saw the game.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1. -- Long runs and a diversified passing attack enabled St. Joseph's College to overwhelm Brooklyn College by 59 -- 0 at Finnesey Stadium today before 5,000 spectators. Carl Marhefka, substitute back, starred with three touchdowns for the victors.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 1. -- An attempted placement by Dave Cook from the 23-yard line today failed, and as the result the Brooklyn Dodgers lost to Pittsburgh, 10 -- 7, in a National Football League game.

Every Spanish Rebel who gives his life to free the Catholic Church from the oppression of an atheistic government dies a martyr saint, the Rev. Father Walter P. Kellenberg declared yesterday at solemn high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. He was preaching on the feast of All Saints, dedicated to obscure and unknown saints as well as those honored every day of the year.

LORADO TAFT, who died last week, is quoted as saying that his chief reason for making sculpture his life work was that it was "the one art that was not cursed with American casualness." It is not necessary to accept this view concerning sculpture in expressing gratitude that he chose it above the other arts, for his creations will live visibly on, most of them where they are seen by the rnny.

In his pre-election forecast, issued yesterday at Democratic national headquarters, James A. Farley, national chairman, predicted that President Roosevelt would be re-elected by a greater plurality than he received in 1932.

More than a thousand parishioners representing five generations crowded the Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, yesterday to hear the Right Rev. William T. Manning plead for faith in Christ on the occasion of that institution's centennial celebration.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 1 (AP). -- The Methodist Episcopal Church employed for the first time a worldwide short-wave radio broadcast in a "million unit fellowship movement."
NEW ORLEANS, La., Nov. 1. -- Quiet marked the third day of the strike declared here by more than 500 members of the "old" longshoremen unions of the port in support of their West Coast brethren.
CHAMBERY, France, Nov. 1 (AP). -- Five Italians, including the consul at Chambery, today were attacked by Communists after a Fascist meeting here. Several other persons were injured.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (AP). -- Colonel Frank Knox, Republican Vice Presidential nominee, said tonight in comment on President Roosevelt's New York address that it was "quite obvious from Mr. Roosevelt's temper and mood that we are just going to have four more years of dictation to business and industry from Washington if he should happen to be re-elected."

A decrease in cancer mortality among women in New York City this year, as compared with last, was reported yesterday by Dr. John C.A. Gerster, chairman of the New York City Cancer Committee, in a statement issued in connection with the opening of the State-Wide Cancer Crusade Week.
CHICAGO, Nov. 1. -- John D.M. Hamilton, Republican national chairman, tonight called President Roosevelt's address in Madison Square Garden "the speech of a beaten man."

The special feature of last night's performance by the De Basil Ballet Russe at the Metropolitan Opera House was a revival of the famous Nijinsky ballet, "L'Apres-midi d'un Faune," to the music of Debussy, with David Lichine in the central role.

National advertisers will greet the termination of the Presidential election tomorrow with a sigh of relief, as it means the ending of a number of annoyances which have hampered advertising activities. Radio program sponsors, in particular, will be glad that the period of relinquishing their time for political broadcasts has come to a finish, while a number of other advertisers, who reduced newspaper space, will bring their schedules back to normal.

The football dikes burst on Saturday and even the seemingly inexhaustible reservoir of Minnesota's manpower was unequal to the task of stemming the flood that swept loose all but three of the entire country's major elevens from their unbeaten and untied anchorage.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., Nov. 1. -- Among the 200 guests who attended the Berkshire Inn Halloween ball at Great Barrington last night were sixty visitors from Jug End Barn, South Egremont.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 1. -- A slight change of face may be expected in the next Bulldog Drummond episode, now that Paramount has bought "Bulldog Drummond's Romance," by H.C. McNeile and Gerard Fairlie. Ronald Colman made the two previous Drummond pictures for United Artists.

It now turns out that the huge campaign funds have been grossly overstated. Democrats report an expenditure of roughly $3,500,000. For the two major parties this indicates a total maximum outlay of approximately $10,000,000.

J.H. Cruickshank, president of the Big Indian Association of Ulster County, N.Y., writes this column that the body of a wildcat was picked up alongside a road on the heavily wooded grounds of the Big Indian Club last week.

ANGORA, Turkey, Nov. 1. -- Deputies in the Grand National Assembly applauded President Kemal Ataturk almost frenziedly today when, in opening the session, he declared the region of Alexandretta and Antioch, now in the Syrian mandate held by France, "in realty is ethnically purely Turkish."

The Royal Canadian Mounted Police, famed in fact and fiction, will provide a bit of preliminary pageantry for the National Horse Show, which opens in Madison Square Garden Wednesday, when a detachment of thirty-seven scarlet-coated Mounties ride through Times Square this morning between 9 and 10 o'clock.
The parade of the Massing of the Colors, the fifteenth of its kind since the signing of the Armistice in 1918, will be held next Sunday afternoon.

Controversy over the political activities of the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin reached a high point in the Summer after the Detroit priest, in a speech on July 16, referred to President Roosevelt as a "betrayer and a liar." This statement, for which the priest subsequently apologized in a letter to the President, was followed at the end of the month by a visit to Rome of Father Coughlin's ecclesiastical superior, Bishop Gallagher, of Detroit.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- A possibility that, should the Presidential election be close, there will be no legal way to count the electoral votes is seen by some chronic worriers here.
MILAN, Nov. 1. -- The text of Premier Benito Mussolini's speech here today follows:

HIALEAH, Fla., Nov. 1 (AP). -- The first perfected Australian starting gate to be installed on an American race track was tested today by Joseph E. Widener at Hialeah Park and pronounced ready for the opening in January.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,460,042,300. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills. The list follows:

GREAT NECK, L.I., Nov. 1. -- William Knox Jr., 19 years old, freshman at Yale University, son of a Pittsburgh lawyer, fell almost 200 feet to his death at daybreak today while climbing the railroad trestle over Manhasset Bay.

Police Commissioner Valentine issued orders yesterday for a round-up of known criminals and vagrants before election day in the hope of preventing disorder at the polls. At the same time he and other high police officials expressed concern over the danger that the threatened strike of maritime workers would present an additional problem on election day.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 1. -- Coalition of two committees representing preferred stockholders in Continental Shares, Inc., is being effected through organization of a seven-man board which is expected to formulate a plan for reorganizing Cyrus S. Eaton's $130,000,000 investment trust.

BERLIN, Oct. 31. -- Col. Gen. Hermann Goering tacitly has raised intricate questions of capital credit and its resultant profitability. Banks here, it is understood, consider that new enterprise must be financed through credit inflation and believe that this, in view of the present abnormal credit structure, must involve a substantial increase in the Reich's note circulation.
The mysterious disappearance of Fred B. Lloyd, 63 years old, president of the Petroleum Conversion Corporation, 100 East Forty-second Street, was disclosed yesterday by the Missing Persons Bureau.

ROME, Nov. 1. -- Premier Benito Mussolini made unmistakable peace overtures to Great Britain and France in an address today at Milan that aroused great enthusiasm among 250,000 listeners. He declared the League of Nations was virtually dead, and definitely threw in his lot with Germany for vigorous anti-Communist action.

BERLIN, Oct. 31. -- Uncertainty concerning the effect of the four-year raw-materials plan on industrial finance dominated the security markets here the first half of this week and the Boerse was reactionary. After Col. Gen. Hermann Goering's demonstrative, but entirely non-committal, speech of Wednesday, sentiment changed and some specially affected stocks rose sharply.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Nov. 1. -- A proposal that would permit professional ski instructors and coaches to compete with amateurs in open competitions was the major subject discussed at the fourteenth annual convention of the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association today at the Wendell Hotel.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 1. -- A report released today by the Bureau of Business Research of the Harvard Business School analyzing the unemployment statistics for Massachusetts states that manufacturing re-employment has increased more slowly than in the country as a whole since the depression low in 1932.

BABYLON, L.I., Nov. 1. -- Alleging it had "red" affiliations, and asserting that no conscientious Catholic can vote to support it, the Rev. James A. Smith, pastor of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church of Babylon, issued a call this morning to his congregation to vote against the present administration.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Nov. 1. -- Allan Clark, sailing penguin, won in Class D and O.H. Chalkley and Egbert Moxham Jr. tied for first honors in Class B in the second regatta of the Manhasset Bay frostbite dinghy season today.
The speech of Norman Thomas at the Socialist rally in Madison Square Garden yesterday follows:

Hill-Coleman, music publishers, announced yesterday a contest for an original work for double-bass and piano. The competition is open only to American citizens and the prize for the winning work will be $50. The judges will be Leon Barzin, Henry Hadley, Ruggero Vene and Fred Zimmermann.

HYDE PARK, Nov. 1. -- Resting in seclusion most of today at his mother's estate here, President Roosevelt laid plans for a final day of campaigning tomorrow quite as strenuous as yesterday's in New York City, with which he closed his formal drive for re-election.

With the prediction that its vote will be the decisive factor in swinging the State to President Roosevelt and assuring the re-election of Governor Lehman, the American Labor party appealed yesterday for support of all voters who wish to see "a permanent and powerful political party of labor, liberals and progressives."

Memorial services for The Right Rev. John McKim, Episcopal missionary Bishop in Japan from 1893 to 1935 who died last April, were held yesterday afternoon in St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue at Fifty-third Street.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 1. -- With Sgt. Byrne shipped from New York especially for the Monumental Purse, the Maryland Jockey Club's Fall meeting will get under way tomorrow at Pimlico with eight races scheduled and post time for the first at 1:30 P.M. Five are named for the feature, a sprint of six furlongs for 3-year-olds and upward.

THE TIMES reports that one of Tammany's objections to the new charter is that it provides for a deputy Mayor. The Tammany triumvirate must be blessed with conveniently short memories. This provision is closely patterned upon a local law which provided for an assistant to the Mayor, which was passed on March 25, 1925, during Mayor Hylan's second term.

The Eastern division of the Republican National Committee issued a statement yesterday charging that the Federal Writers' Project of the WPA is "a festering sore of communism" and that it has been used by the Communists to spread their propaganda "from a government soapbox."

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., Nov. 1. -- Many dinner parties were given this evening after the concert in the Robert E. Lee banquet Hall at the Greenbrier. Mr. and Mrs. George Pynchon Jr. entertained for Mrs. Frederick C. Havemeyer 2d, Mrs. Harry C. Black and Mrs. Pynchon's father, Gardner W. Brown.

ALBANY, Nov. 1. -- With a registration of 3,317,315 in the fifty-seven counties outside New York City, a new high record, to offset the record registration of 2,899,123 in the five counties of the metropolis, the Republicans up-State will make a supreme effort to bring aggregate pluralities to the border of the city sufficient to wipe out the large plurality expected by the Democrats there.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., Nov. 1. -Society turned out in force today for the Ox Ridge Hounds hunter trials, the proceeds of which will go to the A.S.P.C.A.

The Eastern division of the Republican National Committee charged yesterday that Secretary Ickes had bought 10,000 acres of farm land in Puerto Rico at a cost of more than $200 an acre in excess of the average price for farm land in New York State.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 1. -- Mr. and Mrs. William H. Vanderbilt, who are entertaining a large election week-end house party at Oakland Farm, gave a dinner there tonight in their honor. It was the largest social affair of the evening.

The United States cannot maintain a moral neutrality toward the Spanish situation, Dr. Algernon D. Black declared yesterday in his sermon before the Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West Sixty-fourth Street. If there is a love of right as against might, if we believe in the solidarity of all men and women in making a better world, we must help the legitimate and recognized government of the Spanish people, Dr. Black asserted.

BERLIN, Oct. 31. -- The week's market on the Boerse opened irregular, with prices predominantly lower, interest being centered on commercial banks and later on potashes, while foreign industrials declined. After Col. Gen. Goering's exposition of his raw-materials plan and announcement on the sale of Reich stock holdings in the Commerz und Privat Bank there was active buying.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 1. -- King Carol of Rumania, after having taken part yesterday in a big shoot, at which nearly 4,000 head of game were killed -- Carol and his son, Prince Michael, having accounted for more than 800 each -left Czechoslovakia tonight.

Leonora Cortez, the Philadelphia pianist, gave a recital in Town Hall yesterday afternoon. This was the tenth time that she had been heard in recital here and her playing in some respects reached a higher level of excellence than that previously attained.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 1. -- Speaking last night at a dinner at Sao Paulo, given by Governor Sallesoliveira, Finance Minister Arthur de Souza Costa, defined the government's coffee policy and declared the policy would not be changed and that its economic direction would remain under the Federal Government.

Catholics must participate in affairs today in order to combat communism and to guard our constitutional liberties, Grover A. Whalen, president of the New York World's Fair Corporation, declared in an address yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
BOSTON, Nov. 1 (AP). -- The Boston Redskins used passes to good advantage today to defeat the Chicago Cardinals, 13 -- 10, before a Fenway Park crowd of 7,000.
" If the New Deal prevails, the American way of life is through," Ogden L. Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury, declared last night in a radio address over WMCA.
William Randolph Hearst, publisher, is due to arrive this morning from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary. Also on board are:

The Anaconda Wire and Cable Company and subsidiary companies in their financial statement for the third quarter of 1936, to be made public today, show a net income of $764,266 after expenses, depreciation, obsolescence and reserve for Federal normal income taxes and contingencies.

LONDON, Monday, Nov. 2. -- Ten members of the crew of the American freighter Bessemer City, in distress off the Cornish coast, were rescued early this morning by the St. Ives lifeboat. The lifeboat returned to the vessel for twenty-three others understood to be on board.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 1. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 73 per cent of capacity, down 1 point from the preceding week, which was at a decline of 2 points from the highest rate since early in the depression.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 1. -Supreme Court Justice Frederick P. Close has issued 300 writs of certiorari in assessment reduction proceedings on property assessed at more than $16,000,000, including an assessment of more than $12,000,000 against the City of New York on its water supply facilities in five towns of Westchester County.

In a teeth-shaking, bone-crunching game that was played to the hilt for the full sixty minutes, the New York Giants turned back the Detroit Lions, champions of the National Football League, 14 to 7, at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The crowd of 26,243 thrilled to the spectacle of the best and most savagely waged struggle of the season here.

The New York Hippodrome Opera Company presented two lyric dramas yesterday to large-sized, responsive audience. The matinee production was Wagner's "Tannhaeuser," which drew one of the best afternoon audiences of the company's current season at the Hippodrome.

Speaking within an hour of each other on Saturday night, President ROOSEVELT and Governor LANDON closed their formal campaign addresses. Both of them were mainly couched in general terms. But on one subject there was a direct and sharp collision of opinion between them.

Four hundred and forty pupils of Jewish religious schools of New York City received prizes for attendance and scholastic records during the 1935-36 school year at a festival held yesterday afternoon by the Jewish Education Association at the Washington Irving High School, Irving Place and Sixteenth Street.

A survey of forty-one large corporations with many shareholders shows that for every dollar paid in dividends taxes ranging from 50 cents to $8.60 were paid to the government, according to a statement issued yesterday by Women Investors in America, Inc., which has offices at 535 Fifth Avenue.

SUFFERN, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- Playwrights, authors, actors and kibitzers organized in two teams to play the comparatively innocuous game of "touch" football, nevertheless indulged in some pretty strenuous exercise here this afternoon. In the parking lot of Robert F. Cutler's Suffern Theatre the New City Nightingales trounced the Suffern Cats by a score of 18 -- 0, winning a six-inch loving cup donated by Mr. Cutler.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1. -- Final returns in The Farm Journal's Presidential straw vote, taken among farmers in thirty-four States, show Governor Landon continuing to lead President Roosevelt.

Continued strong demand for iron and steel, despite the nearness of the national election, enabled mills to hold production steady last week at 73 per cent of capacity, according to the magazine Steel. Increases in the rate of operations at Buffalo and Chicago more than offset declines in certain other producing centers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- Lammot du Pont of Wilmington, Del., an officer of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., sold in September 15,000 shares of his direct holdings of du Pont common stock, valued at about $2,500,000, and Pierre S. du Pont of Wilmington, a director, bought and added to his direct holdings a like number of the shares, according to the Securities and Exchange Commission.
The paralysis of the West Coast's maritime strike spread yesterday over Atlantic and Gulf ports, affecting seventy-seven American flagships and threatening a more serious tie-up.
PARIS, Oct. 31. -- In spite of disturbing factors, after early hesitancy the Bourse here hardened this week, finishing yesterday on a firm note, with French and foreign shares in special demand.

It is "Forbidden Melody" that relights the New Amsterdam this evening. And that, as sponsored by Jack Kirkland and Sam H. Grisman, would be the "modern musical" with songs by Sigmund Romberg and a book by Otto Harbach. They are telling a story suggested by Carol's return to the throne of Rumania, and the featured persons involved are Carl Brisson, Ruby Mercer, Ruth Weston, Joseph Greenwald and Jack Sheehan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- Republican control of the House and "substantial" increases in that party's representation in the Senate were predicted today in pre-election statements by the heads of the Republican Senatorial and Congressional campaign committees.

Although the surprise element was prevalent to a considerable degree as usual, the extensions of winning streaks by undefeated teams rather than the recordings of upheavals constituted perhaps the outstanding features of the past week-end's scholastic gridiron results.

LONDON, Oct. 31. -- The securities markets here continue to display a strongly upward trend, the minor dips merely tending to strengthen the technical position and to give further impetus to the rise. The week opened with a weakness which appeared to be assuming major proportions.

Major Gen. William N. Haskell, commanding general of the New York National Guard, announced yesterday the promotion of Lieut. Col. Joseph A.S. Mundy of Brooklyn to full colonel and his appointment as chief of staff of the Twenty-seventh Division. He succeeds the late Colonel William R. Wright.

The Citizens Charter Campaign Committee last night sent a telegram of protest to Bishop Thomas E. Molloy of Brooklyn, protesting against the distribution of literature opposing the proposed new charter in or outside of Catholic churches in Brooklyn.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 1. -- An "outlaw" strike called by radical elements in the maritime unions in sympathy with the movement that has paralyzed West Coast shipping tied up six vessels in Boston Harbor tonight and threatened to "freeze up" the entire port tomorrow.

PARIS, Nov. 1. -- Premier Leon Blum, addressing the Socialist Press Association today, made light of the Communist attacks that have been threatening to break up the Popular Front in the past few days.

Writing under the caption of "WPA Not in Politics Here," Administrator Somervell objects to the use of my designation "Somervell Report" in referring to information in the survey which obtained national publicity in August through an alleged journalistic robbery.
Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, closed his campaign yesterday afternoon at a final campaign rally of the party in Madison Square Garden.
" A PREVIEW of American literature" is the publisher's phrase to describe "The New Caravan" (Norton, $3.95).
SCRANTON, Pa., Nov. 1. -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin referred today to President Roosevelt as "the upstart President," and called him "the reviver of the heresy of the divine right of kings."

SCRANTON, Pa., Nov. 1 (AP). -Crossing the Marylanders' goal line once in the first period and twice in the last, the St. Thomas College football team defeated Mount St. Mary's, 19 -- 0, before 8,000 spectators today.

Robert Malarkey, 9 years old, whose policeman father was injured in a Landon parade last week, sat down at a new typewriter in his home at 555 Ovington Avenue, Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, yesterday and typed out a note of thanks to Governor Landon for a "truckload" of toys.

The dedication of a memorial window and the reading of the names of those who received the rites of the church at their burial during the year, marked the All Saints Day service yesterday morning at St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue at Fifty-third Street.

MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 1. -- Johnny Goodman of Omaha and Percy J. Clifford, young British player, reached the final round of the Mexican amateur golf championship today. Mrs. Patti Newbold of Wichita and Miss Betty Jameson, seventeen-year-old San Antonio star, gained the last round in the women's title division.

Undeterred by the activities of election week, the art galleries are opening approximately thirty shows. The roster indicates that they are almost as varied as they are numerous. The chief change in the complexion of the exhibitions lies in the switch from the modern French, so evident in the opening weeks of the season, to old masters, as high spots of this week.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 1. -- With thirty coastal and other steamships virtually tied up in Baltimore Harbor, as a result of the seamen's strike, the situation here became aggravated today, when scores of ship radio operators, members of the American Radio Telegraphists Association, joined in the "sit down" strike in sympathy with the West Coast strike.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1. -- The finish of the third triennial conference of the International Federation of Women's Hockey Associations could not have been more satisfactory if it had been entirely pre-arranged, even to the scores of the last four games.

Demonology is a regular branch of politics. This year the Republican witch-finders have been unusually busy with manifestations of the Evil One. JOHN HAMILTON on his travels makes the porter search the upper and lower berths carefully for Communists. At headquarters the elevator starters and boys are warned to keep their eyes peeled for those spirits of darkness, the Fascists and the Dictators.

More than 2,000 guests attended a dinner in honor of Benjamin J. Rabin, deputy commissioner and counsel general of the New York State Mortgage Commission, for the benefit of the American Jewish Distribution Committee, at the Hotel Astor last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- An indication that President Roosevelt will press Congress for ratification of the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence Seaway if he is re-elected was seen here today in a letter of his made public by the National Seaway Council.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1. -- Prices of hogs declined late last week as the result of large supplies, giving packers, butchers and shippers an opportunity to dictate prices, which dropped 10 to 25 cents a hundred weight. On Friday the top was $9.50.

A recommendation that the East River be put "in as sanitary a condition as possible" before the opening of the World's Fair is contained in a report to be submitted on Thursday to the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York by the chamber's committee on sanitation, headed by Dr. George A. Soper.
HOUSTON, Texas, Nov. 1. -- At least eighteen ships were reported without crews tonight as the sympathy strike supporting Pacific Coast maritime workmen spread on the Gulf Coast.

Unless the proposed $30,000,000 State bond issue for relief is approved by the voters tomorrow, the entire cost of the State's share of unemployment relief next year, at least $44,000,000, must be raised from taxes, the executive committee of the Welfare Council declared yesterday.

Dean Frank C. Whitmore of the School of Chemistry and Physics of Pennsylvania State College, is the winner of the 1937 William H. Nichols Medal of the New York Section of the American Chemical Society, for distinguished service in chemical science, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1. -- Politics was an important factor in the grain markets last week, although the volume of business was greatly reduced and prices swung in about the narrowest range for many weeks, not only on the Board of Trade here but also on other markets.

Prices of cotton in the futures market moved lower last week, active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange losing 6 to 19 points. In the course of the week they reached the lowest level since early in September. There was a decline on Monday, an advance on Tuesday and a sagging trend thereafter.
Governor Lehman is contemplating an increase in taxes to achieve a fiscal balance, and has avoided saying so during his campaign, William F. Bleakley, his Republican opponent, asserted yesterday.

Newbold Morris, Republican candidate for Aldermanic President, said over radio station WOR last night that the restrictions on city spending would end with the expiration of the bankers' agreement next year, and that it would be "absolutely imperative that fiscal policies of our city be adopted and regulated by honest and conscientious city officials."

Twenty-one prominent citizens of the city yesterday issued, through the Citizens Charter Campaign Committee, a joint statement urging the adoption of the new city charter, and giving eight reasons why the elecorate should vote for it at the polls tomorrow.

ALBANY, Nov. 1. -- Gas, electric, steam, omnibus and water works corporations, having annual operating revenues of $50,000 or more, have been directed by the Public Service Commission to establish by Jan. 1 next continuing records of property used in providing service to the public.

DETROIT, Nov. 1 (AP). -- Henry Ford, in a statement issued from his home today, said he believed that Tuesday's election will determine whether industry and labor can repossess their right to proceed under free initiative or "whether they will be put still further under the control of international financiers."

Acclaiming him as the "Cardinal of Peace," Fordham University, in a simple but impressive ceremony in its gymnasium yesterday afternoon, conferred the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws upon Eugenio Cardinal Pacelli, Papal Secretary of State and the highest ranking Vatican official ever to visit this country.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1. -- Corn traders, as well as farmers, are confused by the imports of Argentine corn. A Chicago importer received a cargo of 83,000 bushels early last week, and two more cargoes are reported due in the next few days. Argentine corn is taken mostly by feed mixers, who report a good demand from various interests, and several more cargoes with 230,000 bushels are due this week.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Nov. 1. -- Santiago Iglesias, Resident Commissioner in Washington, returned to the platform tonight to close the campaign for continuance in power of the Coalition party and for his own re-election. He spoke at a mass meeting in the Plaza Principal just one week after the attempt to assassinate him at a political meeting.
Two statisticians, a Republican and a Democrat, having analyzed and "adjusted" all the straw polls, are at last ready to bet with each other:

Twenty-seven gunners opened the regular Winter season at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. The first high-over-all winner was A.L. Burns, a Class A entrant, who broke 97 out of a possible 100 targets.

Memorial services for deceased members of the Police Department of the Roman Catholic faith were held yesterday at the Church of Our Lady of Perpetual Help, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, Brooklyn.
ESCORIAL, Spain, Nov. 1. -- A government armored-train detachment, trapped for more than twelve days in the Robledo railroad tunnel, was still holding out today.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 1. -An exhibition by the Greenwich Society of Artists in which eighty-eight pictures in oil and water-colors are included opened this afternoon with a reception and tea in the art gallery of the Greenwich Library. Greenwich society was largely represented.

A service of dedication at the Church of the Incarnation yesterday afternoon opened the H. Percy Silver Memorial House, the structure adjoining the church at 209 Madison Avenue, formerly the rectory, which has been remodeled and furnished as a community house for the young people of the neighborhood.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (AP). -- A man said by police to have admitted that he was Howard Fulger, 56, one of fourteen convicts who escaped from the old Jackson (Mich.) penitentiary in 1919 by tunneling under a wall, was under arrest today.

Beginning his service as rector of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square and East Sixteenth Street, the Rev. Elmore McNeill McKee asserted in his sermon yesterday morning that our greatest need was "character."

Last week's foreign exchange market was a quiet affair. Business was small and fluctuations in rates were confined to a narrow, that is, except for two decidedly upward movements -- in the Netherlands guilder and Belgium belga.

So far as the Stock Exchange was concerned, last week's market recovered a good part of the ground lost in the week preceding. Its action was perhaps more interesting from the fact that indices of trade, although by no means unfavorable, showed that the high point of Autumn activity had been passed.

In an address before the congregation of the Free Synagogue in Carnegie Hall yesterday morning, Rabbi Stephen S. Wise vigorously denounced the political implication put forth in the present campaign that there is such a thing as a "Jewish vote," and added that there never was a campaign in which it would have been easier and more natural to shut out every reference to the Jewish race than the present one.

TORONTO, Ont., Nov. 1 (AP). -Mrs. John Nagle, tied with five others in the mothers' marathon which ended last night, has been on charity for most of the last five years, but today, cheered by the prospect of fortune, she announced a charity of her own.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 1. -Cornelius Shields in Prudence and William Dodge in Moth Ball were winners today as the Larchmont Yacht Club began its dinghy racing season with a brand new system of scoring and a new race committee chairman, Jack Dickerson.

After tomorrow's election, many facts will be plain regarding the influences that have shaped this year's dominant political sentiment; influences which were matters of mere conjecture before Nov. 3. One of these will be the part specifically played in the country's electoral response by the nationwide business recovery.

The Book of Remembrance, a permanent record of the gifts and memorials to St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street, was presented to the church at yesterday morning's service by William Williams, chairman of the committee of vestrymen which had charge of its preparation, and Judge Edward R. Finch of the New York State Court of Appeals, on behalf of the vestry.

J.P. Morgan Co. and the National City Bank, a fiscal agents for Argentine Government external 6 per cent bonds due in 1959, will receive, until Dec. 1, tenders of bonds at a flat price below par for the sinking fund, sufficient to exhaust $500,446.
The National City Bank has been appointed registrar for 210,000 shares of preference stock and 500,000 shares of common stock of the Tung-Sol Lamp Works, Inc.

There were few announcements last week of bonds called for redemption before maturity and they were for small amounts called to satisfy sinking-fund requirements. The redemptions covered a diversified list of securities and were, for the most part, for months following November.

Successful in their first field goal attempts but unable to duplicate the stunt later, Ken Strong and Harry Newman accounted for the 3-all tie played by the New York Yankees and the Brooklyn Tigers in their American Football League struggle at the Yankee Stadium yesterday.

TORONTO, Ont., Oct. 31. -- An early freeze-up in Northern Ontario and Northern Quebec called a halt to mining progress this week and threatened to cause a two-month delay in the development of promising junior properties.
Race track owners and operators, heretofore acting for the most part independently, will gather in New York Nov. 20 to discuss their common problems and possibly to form a national organization.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 1 (AP). -- The Pittsburgh Americans and the Cleveland Rams fought to a 7-7 deadlock today in a professional American League football game before 10,000 spectators.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- Henry Alsberg, head of the Federal Writers Project of the WPA, replied tonight to charges of the Republican National Committee that he is a Red and has appointed Reds to positions in his organization. He pointed out that he is barred from entering Soviet Russia because he is classed there as an "arch counter-revolutionary."

A wave of Girl Scout Mariners from Pennsylvania, New Jersey, New York and Connecticut swept over the starboard rail of the square-rigged ship Joseph Conrad yesterday morning as the vessel lay in her Brooklyn berth. The visitors were invited to inspect the ship by Alan Villiers, owner and master, and they demonstrated their ardor by swarming from bowsprit to spanker boom.

MADRID, Nov. 1. -- Heavy fighting between Loyalist and Rebel forces continued south of Madrid today, with neither side gaining any important advantage. The severest fighting was near Valdemoro, about thirteen miles from the capital.
Sales of multi-family buildings in Manhattan and the Bronx featured realty deals reported over the weekend.

A sheet of flame, the origin of which was not determined, leaped up between Solomon Sokus and two other men working with shellac and oils yesterday on the second floor of the Zimet Bedspring Company at 225 Hudson Avenue, Brooklyn.

LONDON, Monday, Nov. 2. -- Even among friends of Italy here there is disagreement about Premier Benito Mussolini's speech in Milan yesterday. The Times editorially says his evident desire for improvement of Anglo-Italian relations will be appreciated in Britain where, "despite recent difficulties, the traditional feeling of friendship toward the Italian people is still strong and widespread."

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 31. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 84.5, which compares with 84 the week before, 83.9 two weeks before, 83.8 three weeks before and 84.1 four weeks before.

Determined to have the last word in the campaign, the National Jeffersonian Democrats, composed of anti-New Deal Democrats of prominence who "walked out" on the party, announced last night that half an hour of radio time had been obtained, beginning at midnight tonight.

SAN FRACISCO, Nov. 1. -- The possibility that West Coast ship-owners might appeal to the Federal Government for aid from the navy in the maritime strike which has paralyzed water commerce loomed today as negotiations for a settlement hung in abeyance.

Negotiations are under way between Paramount and Cornelia Otis Skinner for a series of film shorts, based on sketches in Miss Skinner's repertory. Two particularly sought are "Wives of Henry VIII" and "Mansion on the Hudson." Others may be adapted from her book, "Excuse It Please."

Coming on with a burst of speed in the last quarter-mile, Jim Rafferty, Fordham captain, annexed the Metropolitan A.A.U. junior cross-country championship yesterday at Victory Field, Woodhaven, showing his heels to a starting field of forty-eight harriers in a grueling six-mile test.

Direction of the photographic section of the World's Fair of 1939 will be sought by the new Oval Table Society of New York, Pirie MacDonald, president of the organization, declared yesterday. He spoke at the opening of the National Salon of Photography in the Vanderbilt Gallery of the American Fine Arts Society, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.

TOPEKA, Nov. 1. -- Governor Landon returned here this morning from his strenuous campaigning for the Presidency to await the verdict of the people on Tuesday. He ventured no prediction but reflected the confidence he voiced at the outset of the campaign when he said that once the issues had been fairly and clearly presented to the country, he would have no doubt of the result.

DICKINSON, N.D., Nov. 1 (AP). -William Lemke, Union party candidate for President, said tonight the nation's unemployment problem could be solved partly through "the development contemplated by the mid-continent reclamation bill I introduced in Congress."

PARIS, Oct. 31. -- The attention of financial circles here was drawn this week chiefly to budgetary and fiscal projects of the government, concerning which various rumors had circulated. When the provisions of the estimates submitted by the government to the Finance Committee of the Chamber of Deputies became known, they created mixed impressions.

LONDON, Nov. 1. -- Voters representing a population of 20,000,000 will go to the polls throughout England and Wales tomorrow in municipal elections in 372 boroughs, which may indicate the trend of national political sentiment.

AVILA, Spain, Nov. 1. -- The towns of Cuevavaliente and Peguerinos have fallen to the Rebels. Following up these gains, the Insurgent artillery on the Escorial front, northwest of Madrid, today hammered Santa Maria del Alameda and Zarzalejo.

As I note an illustration of the celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the dedication of the Statue of Liberty, I am wondering how many of your readers remember that the arm of the torch was placed on Madison Square to stimulate interest in the fund for the foundation of this great gift of France to this country.

THE TIMES published a letter from Saul Defren, under the caption "Contributions to Libraries," which does not fairly express the opinion attributed to me. I would be grateful, therefore, if you would publish my statement in order that the facts may be plain.
THE Saturday afternoon scores must have put a lot of seismographs out of whack. The shocks were terrific. Minnesota went down. Army went down. Holy Cross went down. And Harvard tied Princeton!

CHICAGO, Nov. 1. -- Defeat came charging through the mud today to overwhelm the Chicago Bears, possessors of six consecutive victories, as an inspired, alert Green Bay Packer eleven forsook its vaunted aerial attack and ran its way to a 21-to-10 victory.
CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (AP). -- Dr. Francis E. Townsend, making his final pre-election appeal today, told his followers that "democratic government is at stake" and urged them to defeat President Roosevelt.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 1. -- The constitutionality of the Old Dominion's poll tax law under which payment is a prerequisite to voting will be contested by the State Federation of Labor, the organization's poll tax committee decided today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- Rising payroll and employment indices, a halt in bank failures, increased production, higher farm income and expansion of trade, construction and transportation, were noted in a statement comparing the nation's condition now and when the present administration took office on March 4, 1933, made public today by Secretary Roper.

Deficits of the city's voluntary hospitals have decreased this year for the first time since 1929, according to a joint statement issued yesterday by Stuart M. Crocker, chairman of the United Hospitals Campaign Committee, and Mrs. William Woodward, chairman of the women's committee.
BOSTON, Nov. 1. -- The Boston Celts scored a surprising 3-to-2 victory over the Maccabees of Palestine in an exhibition charity soccer game before 8,000 spectators at National League Field today.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 1 (AP). -The Boston Shamrocks of the American Professional Football League won a 13-0 decision from the Rochester Braves today, as the home club made its debut here. About 4,000 saw the game.

LONDON, Oct. 31. -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood on Oct. 28 at 74.6, compared with 73.8 a fortnight before, 73.6 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

General improvement was noted in wholesale and retail business last week, although apparel departments are still lagging in sales volume. Fur demand is on the upturn, with most of the buying activity concentrated on higher-priced coats and neckpieces.
I received this morning a post card, bearing no address, on which is printed the following:
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

The stormy end of October, bringing a blast that capsized the hopes of most major football teams with perfect records, left only nineteen, large and small, in the undefeated and untied class, The Associated Press reports.
President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman continued favorites for re-election as betting odds increased in their favor yesterday.

FREEPORT, L.I., Nov. 2. -- Nine members of the girls' hockey squad of Freeport High School and two other persons were injured at 7:30 o'clock tonight when two automobiles were in collision at Grove Street and Atlantic Avenue here. Only four of the victims were hurt seriously enough to require hospitalization, and all of them are expected to recover.
LONDON, Nov. 2. -- The new British-built monoplane ordered by Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh is now completed and has successfully undergone preliminary flying trials.

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- An important decision was handed down today by the Court of Appeal affecting the devalued United States dollar. In effect the court held that the British Government was bound to pay on its bonds of 1917, issued in the United States, such numbers of the depreciated dollars as would be equal in value to the number of dollars due of the gold standard specified in the bond.
BOISE, Idaho, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Senator Borah campaigned up to the final moment tonight in his "fight of a lifetime."

Eddie Zivic, Pittsburgh light-weight, proved too clever for Ritchie Fontaine of Montana and won the decision in a hard-fought eight-round contest before 3,000 spectators last night at the St. Nicholas Palace.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 2 (AP). -- A spokesman for the employe representation unit of the Homestead plant of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Company said tonight that the unit voted today to reject affiliation with eight other employe units in the Pittsburgh-Youngstown district.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Judge William A. Graham of the Court of Customs and Patent Appeals, upheld today the constitutionality of the Tariff Act of 1930 under which former President Hoover proclaimed a tariff against Japanese rubber-soled canvas shoes.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- In front-page editorials, addressed to the relief employes of the New Deal, the seven Westchester daily newspapers of J. Noel Macy this afternoon urged Works Progress Administration workers not to heed Democratic efforts to "intimidate voters."

BERLIN, Nov. 2. -- The Boerse showed weakness today, but resistance appeared at the close. Heavy industrials fell, Rheinstahl losing 1 point and Mannesmann 1/4. Machines were weaker after a strong opening. Chemicals were mixed, I.G. Farben holding Saturday's level. Electricals also showed some weakness, Siemens Halske losing 3/4 point.
Like your true demagogue, President Roosevelt recently assured a Worcester (Mass.) audience that he is for democracy in taxation.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 2. -- Efforts to bring about a general strike of seamen in Boston in sympathy with the West Coast maritime labor dispute met with failure today with the crews of only two boats scheduled to leave Boston walking out. In the case of one of these, only the engine room crew walked off the ship.

Holders of notes of the United States Electric Power Corporation purchased yesterday at auction, at $2.80 a share, all the 882,410 common and 8,657 Class B common shares of the Standard Power and Light Corporation securing the notes.

The Lerner Stores Corporation has notified the New York Stock Exchange of a proposed reduction in its authorized preferred stock by 15,684 shares of 6 1/2 per cent preferred stock and an increase by 32,000 shares of 4 1/2 per cent convertible preferred stock and 18,000 shares not designated as to series.
MILLSFIELD, N.H., Tuesday, Nov. 3. -- This town, voting just after midnight, was the first community in the United States to complete tabulation of votes in the Presidential election.
CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (AP). -- Northwestern's gridiron plum is "hanging ripe from the bough, ready for the knock-off."

The General Foods Corporation has notified its employes that it will retain its own retirement plan for workers, pending a decision by the Supreme Court on the constitutionality of the Social Security Act. Its retirement plan has been in effect two years.
Coach Lou Little sent the Columbia football squad back to drilling on fundamentals yesterday at Baker Field as the Lions aimed their guns toward the contest with Dartmouth at Hanover on Saturday.

ROCHESTER, Nov. 2 (AP). -- Uneasiness caused by a remark of an overnight guest caused a young optical worker to leave his job today and return to his home in the suburb of Irondequoit, where he found his middle-aged mother-in-law fatally injured and the guest hanging from a beam in the cellar.

JAMESTOWN, N.D., Nov. 2 (AP). -- Representative William Lemke, Union party Presidential nominee, closed his campaign today with the assertion that he had "voted 100 per cent for the people and against Wall Street on every issue."

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- The threat made last week by Air Minister Hermann Goering of Germany that his country was going to recover her lost colonies and Premier Mussolini's declaration yesterday to the effect that Great Britain must acknowledge the Italian conquest of Ethiopia are coupled by the British Government as of very much the same character.

A private detective was reported yesterday to have joined the hunt for Fred B. Lloyd, 63-year-old president of the Petroleum Conversion Company, 100 East Forty-second Street, who mysteriously disappeared seven days ago.
The text of the radio address of William F. Bleakley, Republican nominee for Governor, last night follows:

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 2 (AP). -- The Rev. Gerald L.K. Smith, self-styled head of the late Huey P. Long's "share-the-wealth'' movement, was arrested and jailed with three companions tonight after he had made an address here.
Governor Lehman's address, delivered last night at the American Labor Party rally at White Plains, follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2. -- Mayor S. Davis Wilson declared Philadelphia's "sympathy strike" of waterfront workers illegal tonight and ordered police to arrest all picketers. He said the order would stand until a formal strike is called by the unions.

In a precious papyrus long in possession of the New York Historical Society, written in the seventeenth century B.C., but being copied from a treatise on surgery of still a thousand years earlier, there is mention of a disease which is supposed by the translator to be cancer. It has haunted the human race through five thousand years, and even now is beyond the sure control of modern science.

Sleepy Jim Crowley would prefer to be called Insomnia James this week. Unbeaten Fordham will meet once-beaten Purdue at the Polo Grounds on Saturday and the Ram coach already has started to set a new Olympic record for losing sleep.

Co-captain Roy Ilowit, veteran tackle who is rated by Coach Benny Friedman as one of the outstanding college linemen in the East, was the lone City College casualty in Saturday's losing game with Manhattan.
SENATH, Mo., Nov. 2 (AP). -- Mrs. James Bridges gave birth to quadruplets in a two-room log cabin near here tonight and her share-cropper husband fainted when Dr. F.W. Speidel told him the news.
Racing will make its farewell bow to New York for 1936 today with the holding of the United Hunts meeting at Belmont Park. Six races all well filled, are carded in this annual fixture.

Here ostensibly for a cargo of clothing, shoes and foodstuffs for Spain, the Loyalist steamer Sil, tied up in Brooklyn, will begin taking on her cargo tomorrow morning under surveillance of United States Customs representatives.

Sunday's TIMES gave most of a column to a study of pre-Hitler elections in Germany under proportional representation, from which the author draws unfavorable conclusions. I feel sure that he is incorrect in his deductions, even as to the inferior P.R. system formerly used in Germany, but the important thing to point out is that the system used was very different from the P.R. system proposed here.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- Lieutenant Gar Davidson kept his battered Army squad in the training room today, where he had pictures of the game with Colgate thrown on the screen. The Army coach pointed out the various faults, particularly in blocking and tackling.

The Republican broadcast last night, which was the final major-party radio appeal to the voters, was made up, with the exception of the speeches of Governor London and Colonel Knox, of short talks by men and women in various parts of the country.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2. -- After issuing a proclamation asserting that "gunmen and strong-arm men" had come into Philadelphia recently from another State, Mayor Wilson today ordered police to arrest on sight and hold until after the end of tomorrow's election "all known gunmen and criminals."

The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin continued his attack on President Franklin D. Roosevelt and the New Deal last night in radio addresses in which he quoted the Right Rev. Michael J. Gallagher of Detroit as having repudiated newspaper stories to the effect that he would silence the radio priest after election day.

The State of Maine has invited tenders for an issue of $2,000,000 of tax-anticipation notes, award of which will be made on Friday. The notes will be dated Nov. 6, 1936, and will become payable on June 4, 1937.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 2. -- Joseph P. McCurdy, president of the Baltimore Federation of Labor, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, charged here today that members of the Communist party were engineering the West Coast strike.

VIENNA, Nov. 2. -- The Austrian government took elaborate measures to insure to Premier Mussolini's speech the same publicity both on the radio and in the press as it would have received had he been the Austrian Chancellor, and the comments of the government-controlled newspapers are extremely enthusiastic.

The Barnsdall Oil Company, formerly the Barnsdall Corporation, and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the quarter ended on Sept. 30 a net profit of $509,690, after charges including intangible well drilling and development and costs of leases written off in the period.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Oct. 28 shows a decrease for the week of $54,000,000 in total loans and investments, an increase of $112,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, decreases of $68,000,000 in government deposits, $43,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks, and an increase of $40,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve banks.

Native black ducks bore the brunt of shelling as the waterfowl hunting season got under way in Long Island on Sunday, but, with weather conditions none too favorable for the gunner, bags were light and shots few and far between.

Declaring that the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey "has no politics." The Lamp, the official organ of that company, says in the current issue that the stockholders' money is not being used to advance the cause of any candidacy. The publication explains that where an employe takes an active part in a campaign or contributes money toward its expenses he is doing so on his own.

Advance reservations for accommodations at the leading hotels, clubs and restaurants for tonight's festivities indicate the largest and most resplendent election night celebration that New York has witnessed in many years.

ALBANY, Nov. 2. -- Governor Lehman today proclaimed the observance of American Education Week, from Nov. 9 to 15. The people of the State, the Governor said, are asked to observe "our American schools at work." He urged the people to study the work of the schools "to the end that we may grow with our children in understanding the rights and privileges of citizenship in this democracy."

All principal security and commodity markets in the United States will be closed today for the national election. Many traders however, are expected to utilize the earliest opportunity after the receipt of significant election returns to try to turn a profit.

A sinking spell in the Netherlands guilder which was checked by the official control was the principal development in the foreign exchange market yesterday. Dealings in most currencies were quiet, the dullness that has ruled lately having been accentuated by the fact that the French market was closed in observance of All Saints Day.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 2. -- Two Princeton football players who started against Harvard Saturday and three of the second eleven have slight injuries which will keep them out of practice part of this week, it was revealed today, though they will be ready for the Cornell contest on Saturday.
J.O. Hammitt of New York City has purchased from Mrs. A. Pyott Spence her residential estate at Kahdena, Morristown, N.J., through Eugene V. Welsh as broker.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Net railway operating income of the Class I railroads for the first nine months of this year was $434,864,004, an annual return of 2.30 per cent on their property investment, compared with $321,201,769, or a return of 1.70 per cent, for the first nine months of 1935, the Association of American Railroads reported today.
I have come to my own county to vote with my fellow-townsmen. My people have voted here in Dutchess County for more than a century. I cast my first vote here in 1903.
An exhibition of work by fifteen women, all members of the Emmet family, will be opened on Friday at the Arden Gallery, 460 Park Avenue, for the benefit of the Art Workers Club for Women.

" Ten Million Ghosts," Sidney Kingsley's first venture as an author-producer, did not go on last night at the St. James Theatre. The decision to close was made suddenly at 7 o'clock last evening, the show having advertised as recently as yesterday that it would give a special matinee today.
Elaborate preparations have been made by the Democratic National and State Committees to receive the returns tonight.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 2. -- Yale's football regulars were dismissed today after calisthenics and a limbering-up workout. The Brown game Saturday is not causing the coaching staff much worry. Ducky Pond and his aides, as well as the players, are looking ahead to the Princeton battle Nov. 14.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 2. -- William Bongart, 12 years old, was on the witness stand in Domestic Relations Court here most of today answering questions by Judge Joseph Siegler and others in support of his parents' contention they are able to educate their children better than the public schools of West Orange, where the family lives.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2. -- Weakness in the wheat market at Liverpool which was brought about by unconfirmed rumors that the Argentine Government would not establish a guaranteed minimum price for the 1936-37 wheat crop was largely responsible for a decline of around 1 cent a bushel on the Board of Trade here and at Winnipeg in the early trading today.

Retailers to Convene Jan. 18-22 "Solving the 1937 Problems of Retailing in the Public Interest," will be the theme of the twenty-sixth annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association to be held from Jan. 18 to 22, inclusive, at the Hotel Pennsylvania, it was announced yesterday by Channing E. Sweitzer, managing director.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2. -- Unfavorable weather in the West cut down receipts of hogs here today, and with a fairly good demand prices advanced 10 cents a hundredweight and a large part of the offerings was sold early. The top was 5 cents higher than on Friday at $9.60 while the day's average was up 10 cents at $9.30.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The so-called "gold rate" which is to apply to Chilean importations of products considered as non-essential has been set at 35 pesos to the dollar, according to information from United States Ambassador Hoffman Philip at Santiago, reaching the Department of Commerce today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- A total for September of 835,704 civilian employes, including temporary appointments, in the executive branch of the Federal Government, an increase of 1,411 over August, was reported today by the Civil Service Commission.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2. -- Answering President Roosevelt's "defensive tirade" delivered at Madison Square Garden Saturday night, John D.M. Hamilton, Chairman of the Republican National Committee, declared tonight that "it is the New Deal that has tried to fool the workers -- not the Republican party."

Heavy Sing Sing sentences were imposed yesterday by Judge George L. Donnellan in General Sessions on four men convicted Oct. 22 of murder in the second degree in the hold-up shooting of Salvatore Benedetto in August, 1935.

The Crown Cork Seal Company, Inc., and its wholly owned subsidiaries reported yesterday for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 a net profit of $2,016,586 after depreciation interest, amortization, Federal income taxes and other charges.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 2. -- New Jersey's home-bred golf professionals again proved their superiority over the State's British-born pros today by scoring a 14-1 victory in the second annual match for the "Gaffney Bucket" at the Crestmont Golf Club.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP). -- How to get the money to run State Governments, what shall be the duties of State employes, how shall they be dealt with; these dominate the questions the States are putting before the electorate next Tuesday for answers by ballot.

Coaches and other football figures discussed the game yesterday at the weekly luncheon of the writers, and the much-abused officials came in for a good deal of the comment. Several of the coaches were of the opinion that some rule changes or clarifications would be needed before another season rolled around.

BERLIN, Nov. 2. -- Germany, the other power on the Rome-Berlin axle offered by Premier Benito Mussolini as the main support for a vehicle of European cooperation, received Mussolini's speech today with somewhat divided enthusiasm. This induced Germany to intensify her efforts for an agreement with Great Britain.

Charles Strauss, attorney and one of the founders of the New York County Lawyers Association, who died April 11, 1934, left an estate appraised yesterday at $4,019,071 gross and $3,882,002 net, of which $3,472,082 was in securities. The will made thirteen public bequests, including $100,000 to be paid to the lawyers' association upon the death of his widow, Mrs. Pauline Strauss, life beneficiary of a trust fund of $1,000,000.

Football in the past, the present and future was discussed at the weekly luncheon of the Football Writers Association at the Hotel Lincoln yesterday. A gathering of seventy-five heard the leading coaches in the metropolitan district discuss what had happened last Saturday and what they expected to happen this coming Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The Crown Cork Seal Company, Inc., of New York City filed today a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 106,717 shares of no-par value common stock. It will offer the stock to its common stockholders in the ratio of one share for each four shares held.

At the completion of the third round of competition in the metropolitan Class B squash tennis division last night foul teams remained tied for the lead. Three of the deadlocked clubs recorded victories and the fourth won by a default.

Schoolboy football teams will hold the spotlight in the metropolitan district today. More than twenty games involving scholastic elevens are listed and will constitute most of the day's principal gridiron activity in this area, with several traditional election day contests as the features.

The fundamental issue of the campaign is whether the United States will begin to move along the road of progress and democracy or will be "dragged down the bloody path of reaction, fascism and war," Earl Browder, the Communist party's candidate for the Presidency, asserted last night in his final appeal to the voters.

Copper prices abroad established another high record for the current move yesterday, when sales were made at 10.48 cents a pound c.i.f. European base ports, the best level since March, 1931. Most of the business, however, was done between 10.375 and 10.45 cents. On Saturday the price range abroad was between 10.35 and 10.375 cents.

Don't waste a vote. Mark all ballots plainly. The citizen who didn't vote last year should vote twice this year to make up for it. For the advance study of conscientious citizens the following important propositions and amendments are exposed to view:

During the last four months I have traveled through many parts of the country and over many miles. It has been my privilege to meet thousands of my fellow-citizens and to address thousands more. Everywhere I have gone I have seen great numbers of men and women who have given both time and energy in making clear, as they understand them, the issues that face the country.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 2. -- Because of a split hand sustained in the Princeton game last Saturday, Charley Kessler, first-string guard, may be lost to the Harvard varsity football team for the Virginia contest this week.

William Randolph Hearst, publisher, who left here on Aug. 8 for Europe, returned yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary. He expressed his belief that Governor Landon would be elected, but declined to estimate how many electoral votes he would receive.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 2. -- George E. Brunner, Democratic leader of Camden and a member of the New Deal-Non-Partisan League majority in the City Commission, took office as Mayor this afternoon, succeeding Frederick Von Nieda, Republican.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- Dr. Benjamin F. Barnes, Yonkers Democrat, demanded of his colleagues on the Westchester Board of Supervisors this afternoon that they either get the State of New York to take over the county parkways or place toll booths at the entrances.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Nov. 2. -- The annual fancy dress ball for the benefit of the local Boy Scouts was held in the Rustic Room of Kate's Mountain Lodge tonight. The room and surrounding lounges were decorated with Autumn foliage, corn husks and pumpkins.

HILLSIDE, N.J., Nov. 2. -- Three gunmen held up an officer, teller, bookkeeper and three customers of the Hillside Trust Company at 1,613 Maple Avenue, near Gruman Avenue, here at noon today and escaped with about $6,000 in cash.

Trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange reflected pre-election uncertainties, as prices fluctuated irregularly within narrow limits. The turnover was only $8,316.200, compared with $10,822,300 on last Friday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Women politicians are hopeful that the largest feminine bloc in history will be elected tomorrow to the House of Representatives.
NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 2. -- Last-minute efforts of New Jersey political leaders today centered on plans to get out the vote early to handle the largest registration list in the history of the State.
LONDON, Nov. 2. -- Labor has suffered a severe setback in the municipal elections for control of 372 cities and boroughs in England and Wales.

PARIS, Nov. 2 (AP). -- A crowd of anti-Fascists shouted "Down with Mussolini!" outside the Chambery Law Court tonight after two Communists had been arrested for an attack on Italian Fascist yesterday.
WINNIPEG, Nov. 2 (Canadian Press). -- Ching Johnson of the New York Rangers came to terms with the National Hockey League club today as player-coach.

On Nov. 3 the people of the city are to vote on the new charter and on proportional representation. In attempting to defeat these worthy measures, Tammany has notified several unions that the section dealing with police control of pedestrian traffic would be unfavorable to labor.

The Brooklyn College metropolitan A.A.U. champion quintet will face all of the city's major teams with the exception of Columbia University, according to the seventeen-game schedule released yesterday by Louis R. Oshins.

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- Eleventh hour predictions from the United States concerning tomorrow's Presidential election are so positive that the British people are going to bed tonight convinced that Franklin D. Roosevelt is to have a second term.

Tear gas bombers returned last night to five motion picture houses in the Broadway section and one in Washington Heights, setting off machines that exploded amid the audiences of the six theatres, causing injuries to six persons. The culprits were believed to be the same gang that set off gas bombs in eight theatres last Thursday night.

Mayor La Guardia defended President Roosevelt's spending policies last evening in a radio speech for the President broadcast over WABC. The expenditures, the Mayor said, were completely justified by the results attained.

Commodity futures were higher yesterday in quiet trading. Sugar futures recovered sharply. In the cash market raw sugar, rubber, hides and wool tops were higher, while wheat, rye, oats, flour and tin were lower.

HYDE PARK, Nov. 2. -- An appeal to citizens to vote tomorrow according to their best judgment, secure from interference because the ballot is secret, was President Roosevelt's final campaign word tonight as he spoke over a nation-wide radio hook-up.

A belief that Protestants should establish a headquarters in Washington to combat opposition to religion found there, "sometimes in the open," was voiced yesterday afternoon following a luncheon of the Clergy Association of New York and Neighborhood at the Aldine Club, 200 Fifth Avenue.

Members of the Churchwomen's League for Patriotic Service have arranged their annual card party and tea in behalf of the charitable activities of that organization for the afternoon of Nov. 17 at the Plaza. Mrs. H. Schuyler Cammann heads the entertainment committee, Associated with Mrs. Cammann in the arrangements for the benefit are Miss Marguerite E. Valentine, Mrs. Theodorus Bailey, Miss Laura T. Worthington and Miss Emie Sutton Day.

A Queens educational center was proposed yesterday by Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof, Queens member of the Board of Education. It would include the city's first high school devoted exclusively to agriculture, a new city college, an academic high school, a vocational high school and possibly a model elementary school.
MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 2. -- Johnny Goodman of Omaha won the amateur golf championship of Mexico today, overwhelming Percy J. Clifford, young British star, by 10 and 9, over the Chapultepec Club course.

The cinema's celebrated heroes, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, in the flesh, resplendent in their scarlet tunics and broad-brimmed hats, thrilled hurrying New Yorkers as they paraded through Times Square early yesterday morning.

After telling of things she had seen in the last four years that "should not happen in this United States of ours," Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt brought last night to more than 1,000 mothers from the congested areas of the city a "word of greeting from my husband" and a plea for "backing of public officials you feel are trying to do the right thing for the nation."

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 2. -- Hopeful of winning its first big game of the season when it meets Notre Dame in Baltimore Saturday, Navy today began to prepare specially for that contest, under Head Coach Tom Hamilton and his aides.

Of every three husbands who go to the polls today two will be accompanied by their wives; at least in New York City. The registration here, as pointed out in this column the other day, is, roughly, two women for every three men. Twenty years ago the wives stayed at home on election day.

Irving Sommer, operator, was a principal in two deals reported in Brooklyn yesterday. After a few weeks' ownership he resold the six-story apartment house known as Highland Towers at 220 Highland Boulevard, in the Highland Park section, to the Jowex Realty Corporation.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 2. -- Maryland's greatest produce stakes, the $35,000 Pimlico Futurity, will be run tomorrow with eleven named for the mile and a sixteenth race, including the colts that finished second and third in the Belmont Futurity, the world's richest juvenile test.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2. -- Retailers were urged today by Major Benjamin H. Namm, president of the Namm Store, Brooklyn, to unite their efforts to curb, through "self-regulation," the "three evils of predatory price-cutting, misleading advertising and labor-chiseling."

Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, reported yesterday that the general death rate in the city declined for the week ended last Saturday. The deaths from all causes totaled 1,356, a decrease of 96 compared to the previous week. The general death rate was 9.6 per 1,000 population as compared with 10.3 for the previous week.

Every important pledge in the Democratic platform of 1932, with the exception of the one promising repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, "was flagrantly repudiated" by the Roosevelt administration, former Governor Alfred E. Smith charged in a statement issued from the Empire State Building yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2. -- Governor Landon, if elected President, "would be glad to discuss the Townsend plan with Dr. Townsend in the White House," the Republican candidate stated in a letter to Edward J. Margett, California State director of the Townsend movement, it was revealed by Mr. Margett today by telephone from San Francisco.

The first of the monthly index numbers as of Nov. 1, compiled by Dun's Review, shows increase of three-fourths of 1 per cent during October. The index number is, however, 3 1/4 per cent above November, 1935, and is not only the highest of 1936 to date but is the highest average of any month since February, 1930.
The practice of aspirants to the office of the President of the United States attacking and maligning the person who happens to hold the office is most distasteful to me, personally.

In the final stage of the campaign which closed last night one issue was thrust squarely into the foreground of popular discussion by the choice of the Republican party. That issue was the social security program of the Roosevelt Administration. It fully merited the attention that could be given it, for it is a far-reaching program, one of the most ambitious and necessarily experimental measures ever enacted in the history of the United States.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Washington remained calm on election eve, with most of its residents confidently expecting the return of President Roosevelt to office.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 2. -- Mr. and Mrs. Beverley Bogert gave a dinner for more than sixty, guests tonight at Anglesea and they with others will gather at the Clambake Club tomorrow for dinner, to receive the election returns and to dance.

The Green Bay Packers, conquerors of the Chicago Bears on Sunday, increased their lead in scoring and ground gaining in the National Football League, according to the figures announced yesterday, which include Sunday's games.

The government began yesterday to introduce evidence tending to connect Harry Greenberg, accused of having led a riotous raid on the Needle Trades Workers Industrial Union, with Jacob (Gurrah Jake) Shapiro and Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, who are being tried for alleged racketeering in the $10,000,000 rabbit skin trade before Federal Judge John C. Knox.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 2 (AP). -- British naval officers charged tonight that Japanese policemen had pushed a fountain-pen point under the fingernails of a British seaman and forced ink into the wounds to make him sign a "confession" that he had cheated a taxicab driver.

As you said in your recent editorial, Governor Landon's speech in Pittsburgh on spoils under the present administration "was in some ways the most effective of this campaign," and "if President Roosevelt is re-elected he can hardly be deaf to this mounting public protest against patronage mongering."
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2. -- Shipping activities in the port of Philadelphia remained virtually at a standstill today.

BERLIN, Nov. 2. -- Lawrence B. Simpson, 34-year-old American seaman, who was sentenced to three years in the penitentiary by the National Socialist People's Tribunal on Oct. 28 for engaging in subversive activities in Germany, filed today a personal appeal to Chancellor Hitler for remission of his sentence.
Mrs. A. Wilmerding Beck gave a luncheon yesterday at Sherry's for Mrs. Harold Wall, Mrs. John Farr, Mrs. Allan C. Bakewell, Mrs. Edmund S. Twining and Mrs. Rhinelander Brown.

Collection and delivery of less-than-carload freight by the railroads throughout the East is to begin on Nov. 16, the Trunk Line Association announced yesterday. This will bring about a change which railroad managements long have considered necessary to enable them to meet new competition in transport, but which until now has been delayed by differences among themselves or with the trucking interests.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The constitutionality of the 1936 act regulating commodity exchanges -- a New Deal low -- was challenged today in two cases appealed to the United States Supreme Court.

Rear Admiral Harris Laning commissioned another high-speed destroyer at formal exercises in the New York Navy Yard, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon. The ship, named for Captain Samuel Chester Reid, a naval hero of 1812, has a displacement of 1,500 tons and an armament of five five-inch guns in addition to the latest torpedo devices.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Nov. 2. -- Considerable concern has been caused by the reappearance after several months of large foreign airplanes flying nightly over the north of Finland, evidently steering toward near-by Swedish territory, where the important Bodet fortress and other military establishments are located.

TOPEKA, Nov. 2. -- In his final appeal to the people on election eve, Governor Landon urged in a radio address tonight that all possessing the suffrage go to the polls tomorrow and vote as Americans without distinction of class and "for the future of America."

Preparing for the invasion of Ebbets Field by the University of Kentucky Saturday, Manhattan's football team engaged in its longest and stiffest Monday drill of the campaign at Innisfail Park yesterday. Spurred by a shake-up which saw five regular positions change hands, the Jaspers displayed impressive power in a scrimmage that lasted until dark.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2. -- Dr. Francis E. Townsend, head of the Townsend National Recovery Plan, issued a final appeal to his followers today to defeat President Roosevelt.
