Dr. Townsend pointed out that the issues were "clearly defined" in the election and asserted that "a vote for Roosevelt is a vote for communism and fascism, therefore Mr. Roosevelt must be defeated."

Herbert Wilcox, one of Britain's top flight motion picture producers, arrived on the Queen Mary yesterday to follow up negotiations that have been conducted thus far by cable for players and story properties for a new 1,000,000 company, which plans to make fourteen pictures a year in England for distribution here.
Many of the candidates and leaders of political parties made known last evening where and when they would vote.

Mayor La Guardia pledged his support yesterday to the proposition on today's ballot providing an eight-hour day for city firemen and asked all voters to approve all five propositions to be voted upon locally.
Final appeals for adoption of the proposed City Charter were made last night by Mayor La Guardia and Thomas D. Thacher, chairman of the Charter Revision Commission.

A meeting of stockholders of the E.L. Bruce Company, manufacturer of flooring, has been called for Nov. 20 to vote on a plan of reorganization and recapitalization aimed at eliminating the profit-and-loss deficit in liquidating accumulated dividends on the preferred stock.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 2. -- The pleasant feelings aroused in many Yugoslav hearts yesterday afternoon at the moment of hearing Premier Mussolini's friendly reference to themselves faded overnight and left a widespread feeling of indignation and alarm.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 2 (AP). -- Former Senator James A. Reed of Missouri, head of the National Jeffersonian Democrats, brought his anti-New Deal campaign to a close tonight with an address in which he asserted that "a vote for Mr. Roosevelt is a vote for governmental chains upon every citizen of the United States."
Law-enforcement agencies completed yesterday their plans to assure an honest and orderly election in the city today, when a record number of voters will go to the polls.

British Celanese, Ltd., decided to pay on Dec. 15 half-year's dividends to holders of the 7 1/2 per cent participating second-cumulative preference shares, bringing dividend payments on this issue up to Oct. 31, 1930.

Mrs. John Williams Morgan was hostess at a luncheon yesterday in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for members of the Penland Board of the Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street, which is planning to give a bridge and tea on Nov. 17 on the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis.
The following statement was released by R.J. Baker, president of the American Steamship Owners Association, last night:

Mr. Romberg and Mr. Harbach have been putting their heads together over a new operetta, "Forbidden Melody," which was staged at the New Amsterdam last evening. Not hard enough together, a despondent theatregoer might exclaim, for "Forbidden Melody" is one of the most entangled musical stage books a librettist ever strangled a play with.
SALEM, N.J., Nov. 2. -- Leon (Goose) Goslin, Detroit outfielder, early today rescued two men who had been adrift in a disabled boat on the Delaware River for more than twelve hours.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2. -- With the exception of a few bruises, Pennsylvania came out of the 16-6 victory over Navy in good physical condition. All the starting players and five others who saw service were excused from work today as Coach Harvey Harman put the second stringers through a scrimmage against the freshmen.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 2. -- About 245 Princeton undergraduates, who voted three to one for Landon on a campus poll several weeks ago, will take part in the Presidential election tomorrow either through the use of absentee ballots or by special permission of the university to vote in their home towns.

A great-granddaughter of Thomas Jefferson will cast her ballot this morning for President Roosevelt in the polling place on Eighty-sixth Street near Park Avenue. She is Miss Sarah Randolph Anderson, living in The Croyden, 12 East Eighty-sixth Street.

The committee on harbor and shipping of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York has drafted a report, to be submitted to the chamber at its monthly meeting Thursday, urging the abolition of wharfage charges for lighters and barges in the port of New York.
Apartment house deals made up the bulk of the Bronx realty transactions reported yesterday.

Many leading Wall Street brokerage offices will open late tonight or early tomorrow to receive orders for execution in London, when the market will be open for trading at 10 A.M. on Wednesday (5 A.M. New York time).

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Nov. 2. -- The speech of Premier Mussolini of Italy has released a wave of delirious excitement here, which may have awkward consequences abroad, for the most fantastic hopes are now entertained of an early acquisition of territory by Hungary.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 2. -- In place of the picture they were to have made at Astoria, but which Paramount canceled, Ben Hecht and Charles MacArthur have submitted "The Kid From Paradise," for which negotiations should be completed this week.

The last month has witnessed a continued substantial movement of European money to this market for investment in American securities, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York says in its monthly review for Nov. 1, issued yesterday. Discussing the international monetary situation, the Reserve Bank refers several times to this European demand for investments here.

When Mr. HUGHES ran for the New York Governorship in 1906 against Mr. HEARST, whom he defeated by some 60,000 votes, he made a spirited campaign. He spoke in all parts of the State and kept it up until the very eve of the election. When a friend asked him why he had made such strenuous exertions he replied:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2. -- The first of this season's series of Piccadilly dances was held tonight in the Rose Garden of the Bellevue-Stratford as an election eve party. Guests were received by Mrs. William Justice Strawbridge and Miss Helen W. Fox, chosen from the committee which manages the series.
MADISON, Wis., Nov. 2 (AP). -- Senator Robert M. La Follette closed his campaign for President Roosevelt's re-election tonight with the plea:

OTTAWA, Nov. 2 (Canadian Press.) -- Two historic government departments, Marine, dating back to confederation, and Railways and Canals, established twelve years later, disappeared today, and there emerged the new Department of Transport, in accordance with legislation passed at the last session of Parliament.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 2. -- Benjamin Graham, lecturer in finance at Columbia University and president of the Graham-Newman Corporation, denies in the November number of The Yale Law Journal that the corporate surplus tax, which Governor Landon called "cock-eyed," need embarras corporations. Corporations can still set up reserves by capitalizing any desired portion of their earnings either by paying stock dividends or by a number of other readily available devices, he points out.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 2 (AP). -- Striking Pacific Coast maritime unions extended their blockade order tonight to all United States ports.

The regional office of the Social Security Board branded as a forgery yesterday reproductions of what purported to be a Social Security registration form and identification tag issued here by the Eastern headquarters of the Republican National Committee, 41 East Forty-second Street.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 2. -- Acting on complaints filed by Newark, Hoboken, Camden and other municipalities, the State Board of Tax Appeals ordered today that J.H. Thayer Martin, State Tax Commissioner, reapportion within ninety days $3,624,625 of gross receipts taxes levied for 1935 against the Public Service Electric and Gas Company.

William F. Bleakley, the Republican candidate for Governor, ended a vigorous campaign last night at an open air meeting at Lexington Avenue and ll6th Street with a final plea for the overthrow of the New Deal in the State. The candidate, as well as his campaign managers, expressed confidence that he would win.

Advertising directors of two companies prominent in the automobile field paid tribute yesterday to the effectiveness of newspapers as an advertising medium. William A. James, advertising manager of the Hudson Motor Car Company, said that "newspapers are the most elastic and versatile type of advertising media for the motor car manufacturer," adding that for many years Hudson has spent a greater percentage of its advertising appropriation in newspapers than any other automobile company.
HYDE PARK, Nov. 2. -- In his final "campaign trip," President Roosevelt drove more than seventy-five miles today, making brief speeches in five cities in Dutchess, Orange and Ulster Counties.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- The text of President Roosevelt's extemporaneous speech here tonight follows:

An average gain of at least 20 per cent over a year ago in retail sales in the next three months and a sharp upswing in the heavy industrials next year are forecast in the current issue of Sales Management by Peter B.B. Andrews, economist of Hemphill, Noyes Co.
Assemblage of a West Side corner for improvement with an apartment house featured the Manhattan realty activity reported yesterday.
In the most critical campaign, since that of 1860, the zero hour is at hand.

CHICAGO. Nov. 2 (AP). -- Betting at the six race tracks in the Chicago area during the six-month season just ended was $2,157,232 under the total amount wagered during the 1935 season, the Illinois Racing Commission announced today.

While trading on the Cotton Exchange was restricted yesterday, with professional operators disinclined to make commitments over election day, buying by mills imparted price steadiness and the list ended with a loss of 1 point to a gain of 4 points.

Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State Chairman, in a statement yesterday, declared that President Roosevelt's "bitter and ill-tempered" speech last Saturday night in Madison Square Garden had cost the Democrats in the State hundreds of thousands of votes. Mr. Eaton said that he was revising upward his estimate that Governor Landon would carry the State by more than 250,000.

The Bayes Theatre, which perches in an astral fashion on top of the Forty-fourth Street, was reclaimed last evening from the dust of the depression. Mr. Gustav Blum was the impresario, and the drama, chalking its cue, found the eight ball and then briskly set down behind it a little number called "Don't Look Now."

A peculiarly rewarding Picasso exhibition, to which some preliminary reference was made on the art page Sunday, opened yesterday at the Seligmann Galleries, 3 East Fifty-first Street, to remain until Nov. 26. Nearly all of the pictures have been lent, either by museums and galleries or by private collectors.

LONDON, Nov. 2 (AP). -- Francisco Caheiros, Portuguese delegate to the London non-intervention committee on Spain, at today's subcommittee meeting termed Russia's proposed blockade of Portuguese ports an "insult."

With Governor Landon speaking over the radio from Topeka and with President Roosevelt following him in a final appeal to the voters, broadcast from his home in Hyde Park, the 1936 Presidential campaign ended last night.

Assailing the campaign just ended as one conducted "on a disgracefully low level of discussion of issues," Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, speaking last night from Station WJZ, charged both major parties with complete misunderstanding "or contempt" of real democracy.

If it were not for free transfers, the three-track railroad which runs under Forty-second Street from Times Square to Grand Central Terminal would undoubtedly rank as the greatest traction gold mine in the world. It is less than a mile long. It joins two of the most important traffic centers of the metropolis.

A new scoring leader bounced into the national college football picture last week. Art Buck of undefeated Carroll College, Waukesha, Wis., emerged from obscurity to take his place at the head of the parade with 92 points in six games, The Associated Press reveals.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Nov. 2. -- Premier Mussolini's speech came as a shock here and has turned even Rumanian Fascist groups against Italy -- a result that Mussolini can hardly have anticipated.

The United States' first free trade zone, scheduled to open on Staten Island yesterday, will begin actual operation on Feb. 1, Richmond Borough officials said yesterday. The later date, made necessary because preparations for establishing the port have not been completed, was authorized last week by Washington officials upon application of the borough executive, who estimated that at least three months would be required before the pier repair, building and other work can be completed.

Hudson County Democratic headquarters in Jersey City last night raised the estimate of Mayor Frank Hague as to the plurality Hudson County will give President Roosevelt over Governor Landon today. Mayor Hague had set the figure at 125,000.

The "sit down" strike on ships in New York directed by the Seamen's Defense Committee, an insurgent organization, was extended to sixteen more ships yesterday as the International Seamen's Union, denouncing the strike as an "outlaw" movement, announced its determination to smash it by furnishing full crews for idle vessels.

In a battle of ballots almost as fiercely fought as their struggle in the mud at Evanston, Northwestern displaced Minnesota yesterday as the No. 1 college team in the national football ranking poll conducted by The Associated Press.

The tone of the stock market yesterday was subdued. There was little buying enthusiasm except for copper issues and some specialty stocks, but at the same time there was no liquidation of importance. Utility holding company shares, as a group, closed lower.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 2. -- In an election eve wind-up tour of Westchester, Governor Lehman assailed the Republican "pay envelope" campaign tonight as a "malicious, selfish and un-American scheme" to frighten the workers of the State and nation. He characterized the Republican tactics as a "monstrosity."

LONDON. Nov. 2. -- For the first time in modern British history there was a prospect tonight that nonconformist churches representing almost one-quarter of the population of the United Kingdom would take part in the crowning of King Edward.
MADRID, Nov. 2 (Passed by the Censor). -- Heavy fighting was going on today in various sectors near Madrid, particularly south of the city.

Bainbridge Colby, Secretary of State under President Wilson, having the last word in a broadcast of the National Jeffersonian Democrats over a coast-to-coast network last midnight, replied to the final addresses of President Roosevelt, Senator Wagner and James A. Farley, declaring them "the attorneys for the defense" of the New Deal.

MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 2. -- With another vessel, the Point Gorda of the Gulf Pacific Line, added to two boats tied up in port by West Coast seamen sympathizing with the action in the Pacific area, Mobile's shipping otherwise was not interrupted Monday as working agreements continued in effect.
As chairman of the City Fusion party, Kings County, the especial opportunity has come my way to appraise the reactions of the independents and liberals in the present Gubernatorial campaign.

Principals and assistant superintendents were instructed yesterday by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, to provide free lunches for all children in the public schools who needed them, whether or not their parents were on relief.

GLEN COVE. L.I., Nov. 2. -- J.P. Morgan, showing in almost every section, won eight blue ribbons and six red for his entries in the thirty-first annual chrysanthemum exhibition of the Nassau County Horticultural Society which opened this afternoon in the main building of the Pratt estate.
BERLIN, Nov. 2. -- The Olympic village was occupied by troops this morning.

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 2. -- Coach Earl Blaik called the usual light Monday workout for his Dartmouth football squad today as calisthenics, relay races and signal drill sent the team to the showers early.

A keenly contested five-game match won by Ivy Lee Jr. of the University Club and Gordon C. Thayer of the home club featured the opening of the Heights Casino invitation squash racquets doubles tourney in Brooklyn yesterday.

William F. Brunner of Queens was designated for president of the Board of Aldermen because the five county Democratic leaders, determined to give united support to President Roosevelt, agreed that a Queens man should be selected.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP). -- The nation's bill for political campaigning continued to mount on election day as organizations filed additional reports of receipts and expenditures. Final reports are due in thirty days.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 3. -- Comparatively few election complaints were made in Indiana today as probably the largest vote in many years was cast.
Those who have been worrying over the menace of an increasing cancer death rate can ease their fears, according to a survey report made public yesterday by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

MADRID, Nov. 3. -- Madrid's terrified inhabitants watched today from their housetops the fight for possession of their city's suburbs. The familiar warning sirens sounded every half hour as enemy planes flew over the capital.

Saul S. Streit, successful Democratic candidate for judge of the Court of General Sessions, has not previously held judicial office, but served for one year as an Assistant District Attorney and for ten years as Assemblyman from the Seventh District of New York County.

Its vaunted running attack operating with precision and speed throughout and its line a wall of granite from end to end, De Witt Clinton's football forces crushed Stuyvesant, 28 -- 7, in the twenty-seventh renewal of their traditional rivalry yesterday.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Nov. 3. -- Gaining momentum as the game progressed, the Great Neck High School football team conquered Port Washington High, 9 to 0, today before 1,000 spectators in the annual meeting of the rivals.

The Messrs. Shubert raise their 'Masque Theatre's curtain at 8:35 o'clock this evening on "Green Waters," a play by Max Catto, which they have fetched from London. Denis O'Dea, Doris Dalton and Reginald Bach are its featured people, Mr. Bach also doubling as co-director with Milton Shubert.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Nov. 3. -- When President Roosevelt, speaking to a crowd that assembled at his home tonight to celebrate his victory, said this was the sixth election home celebration for him between 1910 and 1936, a man in the crowd shouted:
Rain clouds moved over the city last night with a threat of dampening election night celebrations, as a day of record warm temperatures responded to the approach of much colder weather.

Coming back on the rebound after having been beaten in its last two tests, the Brooklyn college eleven rose to unexpected heights yesterday to crush the Nassau Collegiate Center forces of Garden City, 71 -- 0, at Erasmus Field, Brooklyn.

After holding out hopefully until 1:15 o'clock this morning, William F. Bleakley, Republican candidate for Governor, conceded his defeat by Governor Lehman. He sent a telegram of congratulations to his opponent.

WITH REBEL ARMY, Outside Madrid, Nov. 3. -- The Insurgents and government troops are fighting virtually on the outskirts of Madrid. Colonel Tella's column has established itself less than ten miles south of Madreon Ridge, dominating the Getafe air field.

Representative William Lemke, the Presidential candidate of the so-called "lunatic fringe," made scarcely a dent in the great totals the nation piled up for President Roosevelt and Alfred M. Landon in yesterday's voting.
MONTREAL, Nov. 3 (Canadian Press). -- Prices in the stock market pushed forward to new six-year peaks today as the closing of Wall Street failed to put a damper on buying enthusiasm here.

Banks could have avoided suffering from the unfavorable public opinion prevalent in the early 1930's if the public had previously become acquainted with banking as a friendly and beneficial activity, according to Miss Julia Glenn, director of public relations of the Green Point Savings Bank of Brooklyn.
BOSTON, Wednesday, Nov. 4. -- President Roosevelt carried Massachusetts over Governor Landon by a margin that probably will exceed 100,000 votes.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 3. -- The Gilbert and Sullivan operas, long contemplated by the cinema, will reach the screen next year if negotiations between Paramount and William Morris Jr. and Harry Foster, representing the D'Oyly Carte Company, are successful.

SYOSSET, L.I., Nov. 3. -- A field of eighty riders followed the Meadow Brook hounds this morning in a fox hunt that started at the kennels on the estate of Bradley Martin at 8 o'clock with Harvey Dow Gibson and Harry T. Peters, co-masters, in charge.

Late in the opening quarter Harry Fisher tossed a 40-yard pass to Bill Bassell and the latter stepped over the goal line for the touchdown that enabled James Madison High School's eleven to defeat Abraham Lincoln, 7 to 0, before 7,000 persons at Lincoln Stadium yesterday.

TOPEKA, Wednesday, Nov. 4. -- Previous to conceding his defeat at an early hour this morning in a message to President Roosevelt, Governor Landon had indicated that he preferred to await much later returns in the expectation that they would reverse the trend of the first reports, sweeping as they were.
WASHINGTON (AP). -- Epicureans craving a taste of Maryland soft shell crabs, or perhaps lobsters from Maine, have a promise of cooperation from the Postoffice Department.

Members of Boards of Elections in some of the heaviest voting districts throughout the city were unanimous last night in the opinion that the three-hour extension of time, from 6 to 9 P.M., for the voting, had been unnecessary.

NEWARK, N.J.. Wednesday, Nov. 4. -- President Roosevelt was leading Governor Landon by 95,964 votes to 65,088 on the basis of complete returns for 314 districts out of 576 in Essex County, a traditional Republican stronghold in New Jersey, early this morning.

Herbert H. Lehman, a business man who undertook public office as Lieutenant Governor in 1928 because of his friendship for Alfred E. Smith, and continued as Governor in 1932 because of his devotion to Franklin D. Roosevelt, found himself on election day the key figure in the battle of both major parties for the forty-seven electoral votes of New York State.

Early yesterday morning, long before the polls opened, election day came to Times Square. If Broadway and Seventh Avenue is not the "crossroads of the world," it at least became for several hours the crossroads of opinion.

Leaders in the campaign for charter revision faced obstacles that must often have seemed insuperable. There were, especially at first, sharp divisions in their own ranks. They knew that they could not undertake to bring within their net so sprawling a thing as the government of a great city like this without offending many sensibilities: the danger was ever present that the critics of this change or that might unite to defeat the whole undertaking.

ALBANY, Nov. 3 (AP). -- The State Milk Control Division reported today that New York farmers would receive increases in all classifications for milk delivered in October this year compared with prices for the same month in 1935.

The Socialist party, headed by Norman Thomas, its Presidential candidate, lost its standing in yesterday's election as the leading minor party of the State. This position was captured by the newly formed American Labor party, supported by hundreds of trade unions, right-wing Socialists and progressives.

Franklin Delano Roosevelt is the third Democrat to occupy the White House since the Civil War. His two predecessors of identical political faith, Grover Cleveland and Woodrow Wilson, both served two terms, President Wilson continuously, Grover Cleveland with a Republican interregnum of four years, in which Benjamin Harrison of Indiana was President of the United States.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 3 (AP). -- The first returns on today's election in this State came from 120 listricts out of a total of 282 and gave to President Roosevelt 28,841 votes, against 21,606 for Governor Landon.
LONDON, Nov. 3. -- According to The Daily Express, Captain Robert B. Irving will succeed the late Sir Edgar T. Britten in command of the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.

Democratic assurance that President Roosevelt would carry the up-State industrial centers in the larger cities was borne out by the returns last night. President Roosevelt's margin over Governor Landon in thirty-two up-State cities was nearly 100,000 votes.

The ever-mounting expenditure for armaments is only a too accurate gauge of the world's growing fear of war. The figures published recently by the League of Nations in connection with the issuance of the current Armament Yearbook are appalling. More than $9,000,000,000 was spent last year in the preparation, on an unprecedented scale, for destruction of life and property.

TRENTON, Nov. 3. -- Low bids causing a saving of $20,402 on three road projects were received yesterday by E. Donald Sterner, State Highway Commissioner. Figures were submitted by twenty-three contractors.

" Today's Challenge to Catholic Womanhood" will be the slogan of a campaign by the Catholic Daughters of America from Nov. 15 to Dec. 6. The organization, an insurance and fraternal order, has a membership of 200,000.

PROVIDENCE, Wednesday, Nov. 4. -- President Roosevelt captured Rhode Island's four electoral votes with a plurality of 40,121 votes over Governor Landon, exceeding his Margin of four years ago by 8,782 and sweeping in the Democratic State ticket.

Less than a minute before the end of a hard-fought contest Angelo Fortunato, reserve halfback, hooted a placement field goal from the 14-yard stripe to give the Fordham freshman eleven a 3 -- 0 victory over the New York University yearlings yesterday at Ohio Field before a crowd of 4,000 persons.

A plan under which parking of automobiles will be restricted to one side of certain crosstown streets in mid-Manhattan will be put into operation by the Police Department this week as an experiment in relieving traffic congestion, it was learned last night.

Celebration and the spirit of gayety returned to Tammany Hall last night, with the Colonial mansion fronting on Union Square ablaze with light and the faithful from the neighborhoods drifting in as soon as they were free from duties at and near the polls.

The Police Department yesterday increased from 150 to 225 the number of detectives assigned to guard motion-picture theatres against further tear-gas bomb explosions. Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine declared the situation was very "serious."

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 3 (AP). -- Indiana, a State in which the Republicans battled hard for fourteen electoral votes, turned toward the Democratic column as the count progressed of the ballots of today's election.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 4. -- In Republican Union County President Roosevelt was leading Governor Landon by 3,477 votes in returns from seventy-two of the county's 266 election districts, according to figures given out here by election authorities.

Officers of the seven military teams entered in the international jumping events at the National Horse Show, which will open today in Madison Square Garden and run a full week, will be seen in action for the first time tonight, when they will compete in the first event of the high-score competition.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Nov. 3. -- An all-Philadelphia field hockey team that included nine of the All-America players who competed in the International Federation tournament the last two weeks today made the first goal against the English touring team in a specially arranged match at the Merion Cricket Club.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman was re-elected Governor of New York yesterday for a third term. The indicated plurality for the Governor over former Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley, his Republican opponent, was about 600,000.

HYDE PARK, Nov. 3. -- With wire returns indicating a landslide for President Roosevelt far in excess of the majority necessary to re-elect him, President Roosevelt said tonight that he thought the "sweep" might carry every section of the United States.

WINDSOR, Ont. (Canadian Press). -Queen Elizabeth was on the throne; the towering galleons of the Spanish Armada had been destroyed the year before; Mary, Queen of Scots, was but two years in her grave when "the deputies of Christopher Barker, printer to the Queene's Most Excellent Majestie" produced the "Breeches Bible" now owned by Mrs. H.G. McCoy of Windsor.

LONDON, Nov. 3. -- King Edward VIII, opening his first Parliament today, made two specific references to his coronation next May in the address from the throne in the House of Lords. Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin also referred to the coronation later when the debate on the address began in the House of Commons.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 3. -- Efforts by striking seamen to cause all longshoremen to strike in the Port of Baltimore failed today when hundreds of members of the International Longshoremen's Union continued to load and unload steamships.

President ROOSEVELT asked the country for a vote of confidence. He has received it, pressed down and running over. The sweep of his victory crosses sectional lines. It ranges under the Democratic banner many States which are normally regarded as Republican. It leaves no doubt of the President's great personal popularity.

GEORGE WELLER is the Athens correspondent of this newspaper. Some years ago he wrote a much-praised novel of Harvard life (he is Harvard '29) called "Not to Eat, Not for Love." The appearance of his second novel, "Clutch and Differential" (Random House, $2.50), marks him as an unusually gifted writer of fiction.

Unaware that their 4-year-old son slept peacefully in the back of their sedan, Mr. and Mrs. Leo Perry of 2,859 Cortland Street, Coney Island, drove to the Coney Island Police Station at 6 A.M. yesterday and told the police they feared the child, Leo Jr., had been kidnapped because he was missing from his crib.

The New York University varsity cross-country team scored its fourth victory of the season yesterday, defeating the City College harriers in a five-mile race at Van Cortlandt Park, 18 to 37. In a triangular meet the Violet freshmen won from Morris High School and Drake Prep over a three-mile course, with 37 points to Morris' 41 and Drake's 42.

The re-election of President Roosevelt, which placed James A. Farley at the peak of his political prestige, may soon be followed by the permanent retirement of the Democratic chairman from the Roosevelt Cabinet, The Associated Press reported early today.

STUDYING the nation-wide returns from the football fields, it appears that Alabama is still on top -- alphabetically. And not far down by any other method of measuring. The Crimson Tide, coached by stout Frank Thomas, who used to play quarterback for Notre Dame, is undefeated but was tied by Tennessee.

The popular pink and black silks of Mrs. Payne Whitney were carried to an impressive victory yesterday as her Sailor Beware and Jungle King finished one, two, to capture the thirteenth running of the Temple Gwathmey Memorial Steeplechase Handicap, feature of the annual Autumn meeting of the United Hunts Racing Association at Belmont Park.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Wednesday, Nov. 4. -- On the basis of returns from 100 of 366 election districts in Bergen County, Democratic leaders predicted this morning that Governor Landon's plurality in this traditionally Republican county would not exceed the 13,000 plurality of Herbert Hoover in 1932.

Marcel Pagnol's latest Gallic film production, "Les Amours de Toni," will have its American premiere today at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse. The film was directed by Jean Renoir, son of Auguste Renoir, the French impressionist artist. Its producer, M. Pagnol, has to his credit such French films as "Topaze," "Fanny" and "Marius."

Manhattan transactions reported yesterday included a sale of a five-story tenement at 237 Henry Street by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to the Sharradin Construction and Realty Company, Inc., I. Radinowsky, president. The building is to be altered into small suites accommodating four families on each floor.

BERLIN, Nov. 3. -- The re-election of President Roosevelt is accepted in Germany as a foregone conclusion even before the ballots are counted. All expressions in political circles and the press are based on that assumption and the American election dominates the front page of today's press.

CLERMONT-FERRAND, France, Nov. 3 (AP). -- France's "Incredible Philibert," a former Deputy who once worked in American shipyards, was held in jail today pending a psychiatrist's report on a sanity examination ordered by a court.
ATHENS, Greece, Nov. 3 (AP). -- King George II of Greece, who prefers the well-thumbed books of his library to royal pomp, completed the first year of his second reign today.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Nov. 3. -- J.P. Morgan, with a total of 49 points, won the sweepstakes award this afternoon in the final day's judging of the thirty-first annual chrysanthemum exhibition of the Nassau County Horticultural Society, which closed tonight in the main building of the Pratt estate.

NYACK, N.Y., Nov. 3. -- President Roosevelt carried Rockland County by 279 votes, the balloting being 15,819 for Roosevelt and 15,540 for Landon. William F. Bleakley, Republican nominee for Governor, carried Rockland by 2,077 votes over Governor Lehman.

Democratic National Headquarters in the Hotel Biltmore presented a scene of joyful pandemonium around 9 o'clock last night, when early election returns, brought to National Chairman James A. Farley over an elaborate system of communications from all parts of the country, indicated a victory for President Roosevelt.
DETROIT, Nov. 3. -- President Roosevelt went into the lead tonight as the first scattered returns began to trickle in from Michigan's 3,470 election precincts.

Coach Jim Crowley gave the Fordham squad a light workout yesterday as drills for the Purdue meeting at the Polo Grounds on Saturday were resumed on the campus gridiron. With Monday a day of rest, it was the first workout for the squad since its scoreless, battle with Pittsburgh.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 3. -- Head Coach Ducky Pond today drove the Yale varsity and reserve squads through the first stiff scrimage since the Dartmouth battle.

An election bonfire, with flames roaring thirty feet in the air, in front of 214 Monroe Street, between Gouverneur and Scammel Streets, in the lower East Side, spread into an unoccupied five-story tenement at that address a little before 8 o'clock last night causing a blaze that burned out the four lower floors.

Newbold Morris, defeated Republican candidate for President of the Board of Aldermen, said this morning that Sheriff William F. Brunner would "have a tremendous opportunity for public service." Nil'. Morris made his statement in his I-Iotel Astor headquarters after a ten-week campaign for the Aldermanic presidency.

LINCOLN, Nov. 3 (AP). -- Senator George W. Norris, veteran Nebraska independent, pulled away steadily from two strong Senatorial opponents in the count of Nebraska election returns. Leaving the Republican ticket for the first time in thirty-three years in Congress, he polled a heavy Democratic vote, sponsored by President Roosevelt personally.
PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, Nov. 4. -- Pennsylvania, the Keystone State of Republicanism, was swept yesterday by the Democrats for the first time in a Presidential election since the Civil War era.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 3 (AP). -- Democrats swept the normally Republican stronghold of Connecticut in today's election by precedent-shattering majorities, giving the State's eight electoral votes to President Roosevelt and re-electing Governor Wilbur L. Cross for the fourth successive term.

Most of the prominent New York figures in city, State and national affairs voted early yesterday. In the queues that stood before the voting booths in the morning and early afternoon were Senators, a Governor, candidates for many offices and leaders of the Democratic and Republican parties.

Boys High School's powerful football machine hurdled another barrier in its path toward an undefeated and unscored-upon season as it easily downed Alexander Hamilton High in the thirtieth game between the Brooklyn rivals at Boys High Field yesterday.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 3. -- Sweeping through villages and townships and gaining momentum as he entered the cities, President Roosevelt was carrying Ohio by a substantial margin as the count proceeded.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP). -- A stamp depicting two chained figures and a printed plea to "end peonage" in Arkansas held the attention of postal inspectors today as they studied the possibility of a postal law violation.
Under the patronage of Cardinal Hayes the Catholic Club of New York will give a reception to Cardinal Pacelli, Papal Secretary of State, this evening at 8:30 o'clock in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 3. Returns from many sections tonight indicated that Wisconsin has given President Roosevelt a decisive majority in today's election, with the State exceeding its 1932 record total of 1,114,815 votes, of which Roosevelt is credited with a major quarter.

Surrounded by members of his family, Governor Lehman received the early returns from New York State last night at his home at 820 Park Avenue and obtained the complete data at the headquarters of his Independent Citizens Committee in the Chanin Building later in the evening.
New York's first experiment in restraining its election-day thirst until 9 P.M. ended in success last night.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3. -- After two-hour conference this afternoon with representatives of factions in the seamen's and waterfront strike, Mayor S. Davis Wilson announced that three of six unions involved were participants in "a sanctioned strike."

A crowd estimated by the police at "a million" persons kept Times Square and the theatre district in continual uproar last night as news of the President's re-election flashed from THE TIMES tower with the hoisting of a lighted ball.

Flashing a brilliant aerial attack the High School of Commerce football team overwhelmed the Textile High, 25 to 0, before 1,000 persons at Dyckman Oval yesterday. Frank Chatterton and Eddie Haaren crossed the goal line twice each for Commerce's four touchdowns.

SENATH, Mo., Nov. 3 (AP). -- Death reduced by half today a set of quadruplets born to a sharecropper's wife in a dim-lit log cabin, while medical science worked heroically to save the surviving infants.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Nov. 3. -- Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Blodgett gave their fourth Presidential election dinner and bridge party tonight at Great Pine Farm. Election returns were received by radio. There were nearly forty guests.

Agent of the Department of Justice yesterday arrested Julius Krompier, brother of Martin Krompier, a lieutenant of the late Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, on a charge of conspiracy to defeat the National Bankruptcy Act. He was accused of attempting to dispose of furs concealed from creditors in a bankruptcy proceeding.
CHICAGO, Wednesday, Nov. 4 (AP). -- John D.M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, issued the following statement at 1:45 A.M. today:

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 4. -- For the first time in more than a quarter of a century in Nassau County, the normal Republican pluralities were cut in half in yesterday's voting in the county's 273 election districts.

Engineering construction awards for the past week, a short week due to the election, totaled $30,071, 000, according to Engineering News-Record. Of this volume, private work accounted for $7,233,000 and public work for $22,838,000.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 8. -- Noticeable improvement was apparent in the Princeton blocking today as three Black elevens displayed their entire offensive attack against the scrubs in a half hour's scrimmage.
SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Nov. 3. -- Placement of "safety crews" aboard strike bound ships in Pacific ports, held the immediate key to the maritime situation, but was held up here today.

New Jersey's sixteen electoral votes seemed at 5 o'clock this morning in possession of President Roosevelt. Reports from 1,719 of the State's 3,581 election districts gave him 493,071 votes to 295,794 for Governor Landon.

No man's record suffered greater misrepresentation during the campaign than that of Governor LEHMAN. His critics would have had the voters believe that he was a spendthrift (though niggardly with appropriations for the schools), a second-rate administrator, a foe of the civil service, an executive indifferent to the plight of industry and a tyrant who loved nothing better than to bully the people's representatives.

CHICAGO, Wednesday, Nov. 4. -- President Roosevelt swept the West in an overwhelming victory over Alfred M. Landon on the basis of incomplete returns early this morning, and if his present lead in the twenty-four States of the Western tier continues to hold there will not be a single one of them in the Republican column.

Lou Little and his assistants sent Columbia's football forces through one more workout yesterday in preparation for the Dartmouth game in Hanover Saturday. There was nothing much done in the way of contact work, but there was plenty of concentrated study and action on the plays of Dartmouth, as reported by George McCabe and Ralph Furey, scouts who watched the Green defeat Yale last Saturday.
PARIS, Nov. 3 (AP). -- Premier Leon Blum summoned the Cabinet today to act on a Communist attack against the French Popular Front, dissolution of which would topple his government.

Patrolman Alfred Bruhwell, 30 years old, attached to Motor Cycle Squad 2 and assigned to run elections returns from the West 123d Street station to police headquarters, was seriously injured about 11:30 o'clock last night when he ran into a taxicab at Thirty-ninth Street and Park Avenue.
WITH REBEL ARMY, South of Madrid, Nov. 3. -- The Insurgents tonight captured Mostoles, ten miles southwest of Madrid, and Villaviciosa, between Brunete and Mostoles.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 3. -- Sam Wetherill came close to turning in a perfect score to take the honors in Class X and Frank Campbell won among the Class X and Frank one-designs today in the Election Day Dinghy Regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club.

MADRID, Nov. 3 (Passed by the Censor). -- Reorganization of the Cabinet of Premier Francisco Largo Caballero, forecast several days ago, appeared imminent tonight. The revision was planned to give portfolios to the powerful Syndicalist organization known as the CNT (National Confederation of Labor), which hitherto has declined to be represented in the government because of the confederation's original non-political character.

INDEPENDENCE, Kan., Nov. 3. -- Coming here to vote today, Governor Landon was met at the train by Mayor Ralph Mitchell and a crowd of home town neighbors who cheered his appearance as a 19-gun salute boomed. As he has done scores of times in his campaign, the Governor leaned over the back platform railing of his private car to grasp hands.

M. William Bray, re-elected as Lieutenant Governor on the Democratic ticket, has held that office for two terms under Governor Lehman. His earlier experience included farming, law and political organization. He managed the first Gubernatorial campaign of Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1928 and the New York State part of Alfred E. Smith's Presidential campaign in the same year.

Much has been said of the economic and material side of the Roosevelt leadership. But here in England the intellectual and spiritual influence of the great President on the citizens who visit this land is so patent that on every side one hears how vastly the Americans have altered.

LONDON, Nov. 3. -- After five months' deliberation, the film censor, Baron Tyrrell, today pressed the motion-picture version of Marc Connelly's Pulitzer Prize play, "The "Green Pastures," despite the fact that the stage version was prohibited in England in 1931.

Harlan W. Rippey, Democrat elected to the Court of Appeals, is widely known up-State as a lawyer and as the Democratic leader of Monroe County. He was appointed a Federal district judge by President Roosevelt in 1934.
COLUMBUS, Wednesday, Nov. 4. -- President Roosevelt jumped into an early lead over Governor Landon and added to it with every report of new returns.

Mrs. Caroline O'Day, re-elected yesterday as Democratic Representative-at-Large, has long been a leader in social service work in the State. It was while in this field that she became interested in politics and occupies a status in her party similar to that occupied by her Republican opponent, Natalie Couch.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- The national capital, which probably has a greater personal stake in the outcome of the election than any other community in the United States, showed little outward jubilation tonight as returns that flowed in from every section of the country indicated the re-election of President Roosevelt.

BELMONT PARK, L.I., Nov. 3. -- Many persons of society who have their country homes open for election day attended the final meeting of the season of the United Hunts Racing Association at Belmont Park this afternoon and gave luncheons at the Turf and Field Club before the program.

The voters of New York City, disregarding the pleas of the otherwise victorious Democratic organization, yesterday adopted the proposed new charter for the city, and voted also for the use of the system of proportional representation in picking the members of the City Council who will function under the new code.

The polls in Harlem, usually the scene of mass demonstrations on election day, were virtually deserted yesterday because of an order issued by Father Divine commanding his followers not to vote. Father Divine's message follows:
New York City polled a record vote yesterday in one of the most orderly elections in the city's history.
As to the new short-cycle traffic light system, there are two points of view, that of the motorist and that of the pedestrian. On both counts, I submit, it is worse than the system it replaced.

FARGO, N.D., Nov. 3 (AP). -- President Roosevelt held a lead of more than two to one tonight in Representative William Lemke's home State of North Dakota with 379 of the 2,245 precincts reported, and Democratic forces claimed an overwhelming Presidential victory.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- Eager to end a trade war, the United States has sent a note to the Government of Australia suggesting that improved economic conditions should permit it to abandon discriminations against American products.

In your issue of Oct. 30 it is indicated that the first public hearing of the joint legislative committee to investigate communistic and subversive activities in schools and colleges was "indefinitely postponed" and the general opinion for the reason is that it was too close to election day to start the inquiry.

BERLIN, Nov. 3. -- Prices on the Boerse today failed to develop any tendency. Activity was limited at the opening and some signs of weakness were noticeable at the finish, besides scattered evidence of strength.

HYDE PARK, Nov. 3. -- Whether Mrs. Roosevelt spends the next four years at Washington or at Hyde Park was of less immediate concern to her in the fading hours of election day than whether there would be enough sandwiches and coffee ready later in the evening when the press and personal friends of the family invaded Hyde the President's home.

LONDON, Nov. 3. -- Transactions on the London Stock Exchange today were about normal in volume, with price movements small and irregular. The chief feature was the decline in activity in rubber shares, most of which finished lower because of profit-taking. British Government issues were firm, all closing fractionally higher.

New York University's football squad spent two hours yesterday at Ohio Field practicing for its eleventh annual meeting with Carnegie Tech on Saturday at the Yankee Stadium. Assistant Coach Leo Collins, who scouted the Plaid, utilized most of the time teaching the plays to the Violet.

The first in a series of twelve lectures on current events by Jessica Lozier Payne to be held on alternate Wednesday mornings throughout the season for the benefit of the Children's Health Service of the New York Diet Kitchen Association will take place this morning in the ballroom of the Pierre.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Nov. 3. -- With the dining room table of Hyde Park House turned into an oversized desk, laden with ringing telephones and sheafs of telegrams, President Roosevelt heard the election returns tonight.
