Accepting the President as the issue, nearly eight million more voters than ever before had gone to the polls in the United States -- about 45,000,000 persons -- yesterday gave to Franklin Delano Roosevelt the most overwhelming testimonial of approval ever received by a national candidate in the history of the nation.

Fire, one of the most valuable forces in building civilization, has demonstrated from the earliest times how easy it is to have "too much of a good thing," says a bulletin from the National Geographic Society. More valuable than ever in this machine age, fire still, from time to time, breaks out of bounds, runs wild and destroys some of man's most cherished property.
The National Preaching Mission in twenty-eight American cities will come a climax in this city Dec. 6 to 8. The mission under the auspices of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 8. -- Governor Landon led President Roosevelt by 14,966 votes in complete returns from Suffolk County. Justice Bleakley ran ahead of Governor Lehman by 18,204.

Jack Hubbell, Dartmouth Club, and Horatio Gray of the Heights Casino proved a winning combination in a hard-fought match in the invitation squash racquets doubles tourney at the Heights Casino yesterday.

Countess Laszlo Szechenyi, with her daughters Nadine and Sylvia, and Mrs. Robert W. Bingham, wife of the United States Ambassador to Great Britain, are among the passengers sailing today for Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.

The Evander Childs football team overpowered a previously undefeated Theodore Roosevelt High eleven on the former's gridiron yesterday, 46 to 0. A crowd of 10,000 persons packed every available bit of space to watch the teams in action, and it was estimated that more than 4,000 fans were turned away.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3. -- Lively competition for relatively light receipts of hogs today caused advances of 10 to 15 cents in the price level, all classes sharing in the upturn. Eleven leading Western markets today received 48,000 hogs, or 50 per cent less than a week ago.

CHICAGO, Wednesday, Nov. 4. -- President Roosevelt, riding a Democratic surge, defeated Governor Alf M. Landon in Illinois yesterday by an indicated plurality of 700,000. It was far in excess of his 449,548 plurality of 1932. In the landslide, Senator James Hamilton Lewis, Governor Henry Horner and the rest of the State ticket swept to victory.

Matthew J. Merritt, re-elected as Representative at Large, is a Democrat of the new school. He is a native New Yorker, born in this city on April 2, 1895, and for the last twenty years has lived in the Flushing district.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 3. -- A sweeping Democratic victory in Virginia was indicated tonight on the basis of incomplete returns giving President Roosevelt a majority that surprised his most ardent supporters, assured Senator Carter Glass of his return to office over Socialist and Communist opponents, and made it appear that all nine Democrats will be re-elected to Congress.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 3. -- An arm that reached too far in the rush and heat of a bitter finish, caused the $25,300 purse of the Pimlico Futurity to be switched today from Warren Wright's Privileged to the owner of Matey, when the stewards disqualified the former.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 3. -- Purchase of 121 acres of land and the former Falcon-Knight plant of the Willys-Overland Company at Elyria, Ohio, by the Bender Body Company, was announced today by Herman Bender, president of the latter concern. The deal, involving $100,000, will require the expenditure of $150,000 more to rehabilitate and equip the plant, which is serviced by four spurs from the New York Central Railroad.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States decreased 39,550 barrels last week, amounting to 3,043,500 barrels, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. Daily average production east of California decreased 23,650 barrels to 2,475,900.

Owing to the tremendous interest in the Presidential balloting, the votes in the hundred-odd Mayoralty elections in New Jersey were not counted until late in the morning, and the complete results probably will not be known until some time late this afternoon.
VIENNA, Nov. 3. -- The Schuschnigg Cabinet was surprisingly reshuffled tonight, all the members who belonged to the now defunct Heimwehr leaving it.

Downtown New Yorkers will be among the sponsors of the Public Education Association's luncheon on "The School Child and His Health," at the Hotel Commodore on Tuesday, Nov. 17, according to an announcement yesterday. The association, headed by William B. Nichols, is concerned with the health and welfare of New York's school children.

The island of Trinidad, largest producer of crude oil in the British Empire and the source of most of the natural asphalt used throughout the world, is buying more goods from Canada, particularly fresh vegetables, paper manufactures and oats, reports the Canadian National Railways.

BOISE, Idaho, Nov. 3 (AP). -- Senator Borah, leaping ahead of a lagging Republican ticket, pulled away from his Democratic opponent, Governor C. Ben Ross, in returns reaching toward record proportions in Idaho tonight.

Mayor La Guardia toured the city yesterday from the dark hours before dawn until long after dusk, a Haroun Al Raschid on wheels. He popped into station houses, polling places, into and out of City Hall, sat as a committing magistrate, voted, and even went in for a bit of timely humor.

TORONTO, Nov. 3 (Canadian Press). -- The market for base-metals stocks on the Toronto Stock Exchange was strong today and several issues of the group climbed to prices previously untouched in a half-dozen years. Gains up to 1.20 were posted, and, as a result, the miscellaneous-mines index was carried 4 points higher to a new top at 172.63.
James C. Sheridan, Democratic leader of Queens County, issued a statement late last night with reference to the election results in Queens.
SANTA FE, N.M. (AP). -- The feminine hand that two decades ago rocked the cradle of aviation in its infancy is designing prize-winning homes in New Mexico.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3. -- The first returns from a nation-wide peace poll, conducted by the Emergency Peace Campaign to show public opinion against war, were made public here today at the campaign headquarters, which distributed about 600,000 enrollment cards.

EDMONTON, Nov. 3 (Canadian Press). -- Calling the action retaliation for the Alberta government's step in cutting bond interest rates, the city of Edmonton today reduced interest payments by 50 per cent on Edmonton bonds held by the Alberta government.

Corner apartment properties figured in several of the realty transactions reported yesterday in the Bronx. The deals included several buildings in the western section of the borough. In a number of cases the buyers were listed as investors.
Republican hopes of making heavy inroads upon the huge Democratic majorities in Congress were apparently smothered under the pro-Roosevelt landslide in yesterday's election.
One fireman died of injuries received in a fire in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn, early this morning and three others were removed to hospitals suffering from smoke suffocation.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 4. -- The Republican sweep of Westchester was marred by several upsets among the State legislative candidates. Governor Landon, although he carried the county by 10,638, lagged far behind William F. Bleakley, former Yonkers jurist, whose majority attained the unprecedented total of 53,191.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3. -- Increasing competition between Argentina and Australia in an effort to dispose of the new wheat crop in Liverpool carried prices off sharply today in the world's leading markets. In Liverpool, wheat futures declined 1 3/8 to 1 5/8 cents a bushel as the result of pressure from the Southern Hemisphere and this affected Winnipeg, where prices receded 1 to 1 1/8 cents to a new low on the current downturn.

Returns indicate that more Americans than ever before went to the polls yesterday to participate in the choice of a President, a new Congress and State and local officials. The heavy vote reported from all sections of the country is no doubt in part the consequence of intensive efforts by party managers to rally the electorate to the support of one candidate or another.

I have just finished a trip from Bayside to New York via the Queensboro Bridge. This bridge is one of the most glaring examples of inefficiency of a project which has been undertaken by the WPA and city administration that has even been my misfortune to observe.
TOPEKA, Nov. 3 (AP). -- A red, white and blue frosted "Landon victory cake" remained uncut late tonight on the sideboard in the Executive Mansion.

For the third successive year the Barnard School for Boys triumphed over the Fieldston School eleven yesterday at the latter's field, 21 -- 6, before a Fathers' Day gathering of 2,000 persons. Barnard led all the way.
LONDON, Nov. 3. -- The text of King Edward's speech before Parliament today follows:

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 3. -- Returns from 1,106 districts out of a total of 1,460 gave President Roosevelt 297,077 votes, Governor Landon 165,895. On this basis Mr. Roosevelt's plurality over Mr. Landon may reach 150,000, and it already exceeds the Roosevelt plurality four years ago over Herbert Hoover, when Mr. Roosevelt ran ahead of Mr. Hoover by 130,000.

PARIS, Nov. 3. -- After three days of idleness the Bourse was irregular as operations were resumed today. Outstanding in the trading was the strength in rubber and copper shares, which were influenced by yesterday's developments in London.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 3 -- Vice Chancellor John O. Bigelow in an opinion filed today awarded to Mrs. Carl E. Lindenmeyr of 605 Valley Road, Upper Montclair, the custody of her daughter, Margot Ann, who will be 4 years old on Sunday. Mr. and Mrs. John J. Howlett of 47 Norwood Avenue, Irvington, with whom the child had lived since she was 8 weeks old, had sued for her custody.

There are different ways of being happy and of communicating happiness to others. Colonel KNOX and Mr. GARNER followed directly opposite methods in the campaign. Colonel KNOX spoke earlier and more often and in more places than any other candidate for high office. His mileage and the mileage of his speeches were enormous.
UVALDE, Texas, Nov. 3 (AP). -- Vice President John N. Garner "dropped one in" today for President Roosevelt, himself and the whole Democratic ticket.
President Roosevelt piled up the largest vote and plurality ever accorded to a candidate for any office in the history of New York City at yesterday's election.

Wearing his brown derby and smoking a cigar, Alfred E. Smith voted early yesterday in a vacant store at 678 Madison Avenue, casting what was presumably his first ballot for a Republican candidate for President. Old friends booed and new friends cheered his appearance outside the polling place.

The many "sympathy decisions" given by judges and juries in accident and sickness disability insurance cases in favor of the insured are unjust and unfair to all insurance-minded people. A typical example is the decision rendered recently in the Bronx against two life insurance companies.

Faced with the possibility of joining the thickly populated ranks of the defeated, Erasmus Hall High School's unbeaten football team rallied at Ebbets Field yesterday to gain a 6-all tie with its old rival, Manual Training.

A national campaign to send medical supplies, ambulances, doctors and nurses to the Spanish Loyalists will be launched Saturday evening at a conference at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

Line-up changes and experimentation marked Manhattan's football practice for the second successive day as the Jasper eleven went through a two-hour morning drill at Innisfail Park in preparation for its intersectional battle with powerful Kentucky at Ebbets Field Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- Larger receipts, smaller expenditures, a reduced deficit, heavier gold stocks and a substantially increased public debt, compared with the corresponding period of 1936, were disclosed today in the Treasury's "daily statement" of financial transactions of the government for the first four months of the 1937 fiscal year.

Generally disappointing crowds, compared with expectations, were notable in the hotels, restaurants and night clubs of the Broadway and East Side areas last night and in the early hours of this morning. Ruefully regarding their tables, which in some places were no more populated than they usually are on an ordinary weekday night, the proprietors, with few exceptions, concluded that election nights in the old-time sense are no more.

Attorney General John J. Bennett, since his election for the first time in the State campaign of 1930, has become known throughout the State, because of visits he has made to many communities. These visits were largely the result of invitations from business, fraternal, religious, political and veterans groups.

A controversy threatening the opening game of the National Hockey League between the New York Americans and the Chicago Black Hawks arose yesterday as an aftermath of the recent forfeiture of the Amerks' franchise by the loop.

DUBLIN, Irish Free State, Nov. 3. -- Before a packed assembly of his party at the Mansion House here tonight Eamon de Valera, President of the Executive Council, outlined the provisions of his new Constitution, which is to come before the present session of the Dail Eireann.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 3. -- The Harvard players, who battled their way to a tie against Princeton last Saturday, continued to rest today, except for the session which Coach Dick Harlow ordered at the tackling dummies. Although the varsity, tackling was better against the Tigers than in any of the previous engagements.

After a lapse of four years, Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School returned and won the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association cross-country championship again when its team captured first place in the eleventh annual run at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

William Murray, 34 years old, of 19 Kearney Avenue, Keyport, N.J., was shot in the right knee yesterday morning by a New York State game warden while fishing in the Lower New York Bay, off Princes Bay, S.I. He was taken to the Richmond Memorial Hospital, Princes Bay.

Pig iron production in October, as estimated by The Iron Age from reports received on Nov. 1, totaled 2,992,968 gross tons, compared with 2,730,293 tons in September, the daily rate having been 96,547 tons, against 91,010 tons in the previous month, a gain of a little over 6 per cent.

The nation-wide strike of approximately 50,000 seamen and maritime workers was moving yesterday to a showdown between the companies and the men as violence and additional walkouts marked the tie-up on the Pacific Coast and elsewhere and steamship lines were preparing to sail their ships with substitute crews.

GLADSTONE, N.J., Nov. 3. -- John L. Winston's Dromore today won the Charles Pfizer Cup point-to-point race for the second year in a row, beating Mrs. Manning Jacob's Coq Major by about a length and a half. Third place was taken by G. Scott Jr.'s Sea Me, a length behind Coq Major, in the fourth annual running of the race.
Voters in each of the five boroughs indicated their approval of the eight-hour day for city firemen yesterday by voting for the change 6 to 1.

PASADENA, Calif. (Science Service). -- By picking up a special telephone on their desks scientists at the California Institute of Technology and the Astrophysical Observatory, home of the 200-inch telescope on Mount Palomar, about 100 miles away, can establish in stant radio communication.

A Negro who has served three prison sentences was subdued and arrested yesterday afternoon by two Negro detectives, one of whom he had tried to shoot. The prisoner, Joseph Doran, forty years old, of 36 West 113th Street, was locked up at the West 123d Street station and was charged with felonious assault, possession of burglars' tools, criminally receiving stolen property and violation of the Sullivan law.
MADRID, Nov. 3 (Passed by Censor). -- A government armored train today attacked Insurgents at Siguenza, putting to flight two Moorish cavalry squadrons.

ALBANY, Nov. 3 (AP). -- The wife of a Republican candidate for the House of Representatives and several other persons were under arrest here tonight on charges growing out of election day controversies. Governor Lehman refused a request to detail State police to the city's polling places.

Mayor Frank Hague, Democratic leader of Hudson County, predicted last night that his machine would give a plurality of 160,000 to President Roosevelt in the county, and that such a lead would put New Jersey's sixteen electoral votes safely in the Democratic column.
TOPEKA, Wednesday, Nov. 4. -- Alfred M. Landon, worst-defeated Presidential candidate in history, will not have the slight consolation of having carried his own State.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- Indications tonight were that the Roosevelt administration would shortly bring pressure to bear on governmentally subsidized West Coast shipping companies to accept the compromise proposal for ending the strike which was reported as satisfactory to some of the employers several days ago.

An unemployed boilermaker was in the crowd around the Philadelphia City Hall last week when President ROOSEVELT rode by. In a frenzy of enthusiasm the boilermaker snatched his $40 gold watch from his pocket and tossed it to Mr. ROOSEVELT.

The Democrats will control the State Senate by a subsantial majority and the Republicans will have a bare working majority in the Assembly, according to complete returns from the legislative elections.

Creation of a new department in the Board of Education whose duties would be limited to the study of juvenile delinquency and maladjustment as they affect the city school system is suggested in a report submitted by Dr. Samuel M. Levenson, president of the Queens-boro Teachers Association to James Marshall, vice president of the Board of Education and chairman of the board's committee on juvenile delinquency.

PATERSON, N.J., Wednesday, Nov. 4. -- Early Democratic pluralities were diminishing at 3:30 o'clock this morning as the returns from the rural districts of Passaic County began to come in, but the Democrats were confident they would hold the ground won for most of their candidates.

Seth Gordon, secretary of the Pennsylvania Game Commission, writes that he has just completed a State-wide survey of game conditions, and that while everything points to a good crop of most species, hunters "should think more of the sport and less of the bag" this year.

Members of the international military teams which are in New York to compete in the National Horse Show, opening today in Madison Square Garden, were guests last evening of the show officials at a dinner at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

BOSTON, Nov. 3. -- The "outlaw" strike of seamen, which has hampered shipping in Boston, forced the Eastern steamship Arcadia, due to leave Boston for New York tonight with a passenger list of 350 persons and cargo of freight, to cancel the sailing when officials were unable to obtain four more men for the engine room crew.

A resplendent scene of society and fashion marked the first night of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night. The large attendance and enthusiasm over the superb performances in the ring indicated that the show this year has taken a stronger hold on society than for many years past.

Even though your readers should regard this letter as a scold, a sermon, or a lamentation, it is intended to be a call to repentance, now that the tumult and the shouting are over and a saner mood has returned.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP). -- Interpreting the Roosevelt victory as an endorsement of the administration's farm plans, Secretary Wallace plunged tonight into the task of drafting an all-risk crop insurance program for submission to Congress.

Stockholders of the Mengel Company will vote on Dec. 1 on a plan of recapitalization, providing for a new 5 per cent convertible preferred stock of $50 par and authorizing additional common stock for conversion of the preferred stock and the 5 per cent convertible bonds to be issued in exchange for the present 7 per cent bonds.

The Columbia Club, last year's champion, and the Harvard Club remained in a tie for the lead in the Metropolitan League's Class A squash tennis competition last night, each with three victories in a row.

LONDON, Nov. 4. -- The non-intervention committee spent five hours in inconclusive debate on Russia's denials and German and Italian accusations that the Soviet supplied arms to the Madrid government. On some charges the committee found that proof was lacking, on others further explanations were required by the accusing or defending governments.
TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 4. -- Governor Landon dug into a final two months of his duties in Kansas today, smiling away questions on his defeat while planning an early duck-hunting vacation.

With a revolving floor, the largest installation of invisible glass in the country, and other innovations, the new automobile salon of the Chrysler Motor Corporation was opened yesterday for inspection by newspaper men. It occupies part of the first and second floors of the Chrysler Building, at Forty-second Street and Lexington Avenue.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 4. -- Dr. Hetty Goldman, who was recently appointed a regular member of the staff in the School of Humanistic Studies of the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, will arrive here tomorrow to take up her duties.

BOISE, Idaho, Nov. 4 (AP). -- Senator William E. Borah, keen-eyed veteran of six successful Senate campaigns, smilingly reflected upon the most spectacular of all tonight and said, "New I want to rest."

While visiting a patient in one of the largest State hospitals here during the last heat wave, I noticed that there was not a single electric fan in any of the rooms. The atmosphere was unbearably stifling; the patients suffered horribly and the attendants looked exhausted. I was told then that no provision is being made to alleviate the heat even in those hospitals which are being built now.
The 1937 New York State Legislature, as is that of 1936, will be a house divided against itself.
DETROIT, Nov. 4 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, commenting on the Democratic landslide, told reporters today that "President Roosevelt can be dictator if he wants to."
CHICAGO, Nov. 4. -- As election returns from the Western tier of twenty-four States continued to flow in late today, the staggering proportions of the Roosevelt victory began to assume definite form.

Business failures in the retail division in the week ended Oct. 29 showed a drop of seven below the total in the previous week, while in the manufacturing and wholesale branches there were declines of two and four, respectively, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
Among bankers, most of whom had opposed the President, the New Deal's sweeping victory evoked yesterday a confused and bewildered response.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 4. -- Argentine newspapers are unanimous in describing the United States election as an outstanding example of democracy in contrast to South American elections, where a majority vote often is overruled by the clique in power.

An event of some interest is promised for today with the local premiere at the Radio City Music Hall of the English-made film transcription of William Shakespeare's "As You Like It," with Elisabeth Bergner as Rosalind. The film was directed by Miss Bergner's husband, Dr. Paul Czinner, from a screen treatment suggested by Sir James M. Barrie.
MADRID, Nov. 4 (AP). -- The Leftist Cabinet was shaken up today to include the extremist Syndicalist group. There already were two Communists in the Ministry.

The National Horse Show Association entered a new half century yesterday in Madison Square Garden. The opening of the fifty-first annual exhibition was characterized by all the brilliance and beauty that distinguished the famous shows of bygone days.

The corridors of the New York School of Fine and Industrial Arts, 257 West Fortieth Street, became so clogged with student "sit-down" strikers yesterday morning that George K. Gombarts, the principal, felt it necessary to call the police. With their aid the demonstration was speedily ended.

What remains perhaps as the last perplexing problem before the baseball public in the waning months of a gay and turbulent year is slated to be solved today when the Brooklyn Dodgers cast aside the air of secrecy that has enveloped Ebbets Field the past month and announce their new manager for 1937.

As Governor of Massachusetts, JAMES M. CURLEY insured unconsciously but most effectively his defeat as a candidate for Senator. A man of versatile talents and engaging qualities, he was unable to bear the test of administration. Possession of power seemed to go to his head.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

The voters of the State apparently approved, at Tuesday's election, the proposal to hold a constitutional convention to revise the State Constitution. The issue had hardly been mentioned during the campaign, and the only reason it was submitted at all was that the present State Constitution requires that the question be presented to the people every twenty years.

Disapproval in the California referendum on Tuesday of the law levying a license tax on chain stores running up to $500 a unit was hailed yesterday as a "warning to pressure groups of middlemen and politically minded retailers that against their organized minorities stands the heretofore unorganized majority of the consumer" in a statement issued by Wheeler Sammons, managing director of the Institute of Distribution.

The opening guns of the National Hockey League campaign will be fired on two fronts tonight, Chicago and Toronto. In the Windy City the New York Americans, their franchise still a matter of dispute, will be the guests of the Chicago Black Hawks, while in Toronto the Maple Leafs will serve as hosts to the world champion Red Wings of Detroit.

Dr. Francis Carter Wood, director of the Institute of Cancer Research at Columbia University, announced yesterday the preparation of "an extensive diagnostic atlas of tumors" as a means of promoting further study of this disease on an international scale.

The local election contained no greater surprise than the victory for proportional representation. It is doubtful if any large number of those who voted for P.R. understood the complexities of the count; they were told not to bother their heads about such details. What most of them saw in it was a device to give minorities a voice and shake the stranglehold of the machine.
The Guaranty Trust Company has been appointed co-transfer agent here for 800,000 shares of $3 par common capital stock of Gar Wood Industries, Inc.

The new city charter adopted by the voters of the city at Tuesday's election, goes into effect on Jan. 1, 1938, and the city officers who are to serve under it will be chosen at the Mayoralty election in 1937.

Finally acting on applications for allowances in the bankruptcy and reorganization proceedings of the McCrory Stores Corporation, Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson yesterday slashed requests for fees and expenses aggregating $1,603,156 to about $500,000, a cut of more than 68 per cent.
At a hotel dinner in Atlantic City in 1930 the Kiwanians of that community awarded the "Good Deeds" scroll to the man its membership unanimously had voted to be the year's "most useful citizen."

The Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank sold to the 87 Madison Street Corporation, Harry Turek, president, a five-story brick building at 87 Madison Street, on the lower East Side. The site, 29 by 100 feet, is a block from Knickerbocker Village.

The invisible filterable viruses, rated among man's most dangerous enemies, which produce a wide range of disabling or fatal diseases such as the common cold, influenza, yellow fever and infantile paralysis, can at last be isolated in pure, concentrated form by means of a new powerful apparatus devised at the laboratories of the International Health Division of the Rockefeller Foundation.
Apartment house deals featured the Bronx realty turnover reported yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 4. -- Although rain drove Harvard's varsity football forces into the baseball cage for most of today's drilling, Dick Harlow nevertheless finished the workout with nearly an hour's scrimmage out in the open.
OTTAWA, Nov. 4 (Canadian Press). -- The Royal Canadian Navy is going into sail.

The Association of Workers in Public Relief Agencies Council of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employes began a test case in Supreme Court yesterday to determine whether the 11,000 employes of the Emergency Relief Bureau were now in the civil service and whether the Municipal Civil Service Commission had the right to order a competitive examination affecting their jobs.

RENO, Nev., Nov. 4. -- Declaring that Nevada is the nation's "only sound State," Julian T. Bishop, New York stock broker, announced today that because of the re-election of President Roosevelt he would move to this State and dispose of his interests in the East, including a quail farm in North Carolina.

Federal Judge John C. Knox reserved decision yesterday on a motion by J. Arthur Adler, attorney for Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, to dismiss the indictment against his client, which charges conspiracy to violate the Sherman anti-trust laws through racketeering in the $10,000,000-a-year rabbit skin trade.

With steel operations increasing and with the outlook favorable for moderately good business for the rest of this year, the uncertainty that prevailed in the steel industry before the election may soon disappear, the magazine Iron Age says in its weekly summary, issued yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 4. -- Leading Jews in London are interested in the visit of Colonel Josef Beck, Foreign Minister of Poland, who will arrive here Sunday at the invitation of the British Government to discuss the international situation.

The Communist party appeared to have lost its standing in Tuesday's election as a legally constituted party entitling it to a position on the ballot. Incomplete returns revealed that the party failed to obtain the requisite number of votes.

Knoedler's is opening today an exhibition of American portraiture of the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries. About thirty canvases have been assembled, most of them borrowed for this occasion. Nearly half of the portraits are by Gilbert Stuart.
John M. Franklin, president of the International Mercantile Marine Company, issued the following statement yesterday:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- President Roosevelt's landslide, it was indicated here today, might put Edward F. McGrady in the Cabinet as Secretary of Labor, with Secretary Perkins transferred to a new post in the Cabinet, about to be created for her, that of Secretary of Public Welfare.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Nov. 4. -- Mr. and Mrs. Murdock M. Johnson gave a dinner in the Colonnades of the Greenbrier tonight for Mr. and Mrs. Richard Mitton and Mrs. Walter M. Evatt. Mr. and Mrs. John Mulroy entertained there for a small group.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- The Montana Power Company of Butte, Mont., filed today a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $48,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage bonds, series due in 1966, $42,685,894 of the net proceeds to be used for refinancing and the remainder for additional working capital.

PARIS, Nov. 4. -- France will not only fortify the Belgian frontier but intends to extend the Maginot Line of fortifications along the Swiss frontier, Defense Minister Eduard Daladier announced today before the army commission of the Chamber of Deputies after his visit to the northern border.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- One result of the Democratic landslide will be the speeding up of the administration's foreign trade agreements policy, Secretary Hull said today in a statement which interpreted the Roosevelt victory as "an unequivocal endorsement" of the foreign policies of the administration.

Hearn Department Stores, Inc., will enter the market today for its first public financing with an offering of a new issue of 40,000 shares of common stock through the First New Amsterdam Corporation. The stock will be priced at $15.50 a share.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas increased 23 per cent for the week ended Oct. 31, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The gain, which was the largest for any week since July 25, compares with an increase of 18 per cent for the preceding week.

In recognition of the fine work of the police in carrying out their duties on election day, Police Commissioner Valentine ordered yesterday that "every member of this department be granted one additional day's vacation." Mayor La Guardia, in a letter to the Commissioner, also praised the work of the force.
A drop in temperature to about 40 degrees by this morning, with probably freezing weather by tonight, was forecast yesterday by the United States Weather Bureau.

About 100 passengers on the municipal ferry Dongan Hills saw a fifteen-minute struggle last night in the murky waters of New York Bay between a woman who had jumped off the craft and her rescuer, a policeman.

Residents in the Mary Fisher Home at Tenafly, N.J., whose working years were identified with the artistic professions will benefit by the annual bridge to be given tomorrow at the Plaza. Sixty-five tables have been reserved.

DETROIT, Nov. 4. -- Returns from all but a few scattering precincts indicate that Frank Murphy, Democrat, High Commissioner to the Philippine Islands and former Mayor of Detroit, was elected Governor of Michigan yesterday by a majority of 33,000 votes.
LONDON, Nov. 4. -- The immensity of President Roosevelt's triumph has left the British people breathless and scarcely able to believe it, although they never doubted he would win.

A fight for control of what remains of the Republican State organization after its disastrous defeat on Tuesday was indicated yesterday when Melvin C. Eaton placed his resignation as chairman of the State committee in the hands of Lafayette B. Gleason, its secretary, and instructed Mr. Gleason to call a meeting of the committee to be held at the National Republican Club on Dec. 14 to elect his successor.

Eight teams have entered for play in the Metropolitan Indoor Polo League this Winter. Officials of the league, in making known this entry, also announced that the competition would start on Dec. 19, to continue through the early part of March.

Ace Gutowsky, former Oklahoma City University star, now playing with the Detroit Lions, traveled 137 yards last Sunday to win credit for the biggest individual gain of the season. This achievement placed him in second place in the National Football League.
With only eight election districts, all up-State, missing, President Roosevelt carried New York State by a plurality of 1,114,972.

Wall Street, which is regarded as harboring more foes of the New Deal than any other area of its size in the country, showed yesterday no outward signs of anguish at the results of the election. On the contrary, the brisk rise of stocks, bonds and commodities brought to the financial community the atmosphere of cheerfulness and activity that usually is encountered on days when the trend is upward.

Sportsmen planning a hunting trip to Maine will be interested in a report of conditions relayed to this column by Gene Letourneau of Waterville. Gene has just returned from two weeks in the big woods with some of his coon hunting pals. Their net bag, he writes, amounted to "twenty-four raccoons, several birds and ducks." Obviously, the emphasis was on coons and not birds.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 4 (AP). -- Only 12,000 tickets were still available tonight for Saturday's Navy-Notre Dame football game in Baltimore Stadium. A total of 48,000 has been sold.

In a colorful ceremony amid thousands of books, Mayor La Guardia opened the national book fair of THE NEW YORK TIMES last night on the mezzanine floor of the north International Building of Rockefeller Center at 630 Fifth Avenue.

President Roosevelt's smashing victory in Tuesday's election, with his unprecedented city-wide plurality of 1,360,172, meant the definite end of Tammany Hall's dominance of the Democratic organization in New York City, according to well-informed observers who studied the returns yesterday.
CHICAGO, Nov. 4. -- Citizens in twelve Western States voted yesterday on constitutional amendments and referenda affecting questions of schools, old age benefits, labor and other proposals.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4. -- Supplies of hogs today were curtailed sharply, and with a fairly broad demand prices here were strong to 10 cents a hundredweight higher than yesterday. The demand was stimulated by an advance of 1 cent a pound in fresh loins, which sold as high as 19 cents a pound wholesale.
The Standard Oil Company of California declared an extra dividend of 5 cents and the regular quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share on the capital stock.

BOSTON, Nov. 4. -- As a result of the election, Massachusetts Republicans are left with one seat in the Senate, two additional seats in the House, two State constitutional offices, control of both branches of the Legislature and the executive council and nearly a full complement of county officers.
Weary but jubilant, James A. Farley, Democratic State and National Chairman, received the congratulations of more than thirty newspaper reporters yesterday for his accuracy as a forecaster.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP). -- Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. of New York, filed in the Supreme Court today a brief upholding the validity of the State's unemployment insurance law.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 4. -- Democratic leaders in Suffolk County were disappointed today with the party's showing in the election yesterday. County Leader Charles H. Sullivan of Northport had hoped to keep the Republican pluralities for the national and State tickets to 5,000.

JONES BEACH, L.I., Nov. 4. -- Fire of undetermined cause destroyed the State police station and its garage on High Hill Beach, two miles east of here, early this morning. The flames burned up the belongings of twenty-six troopers, four police automobiles and one private car, besides three police motorcycles in the garage and a bungalow adjoining the station house.

The results of the Presidential election are expected to exert a profound influence on marketing research, because of the tests to which various methods of obtaining consumer views and reactions were put, according to opinions expressed here yesterday by research experts.

Plans for the 1936 annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America are being drawn to accommodate the largest attendance since 1929, according to Orrin G. Wood of Estabrook Co., Boston, president of the association, who announced yesterday the general outline of the program for the convention.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 4. -- When Ernst Lubitsch completes "Angel" with Mariene Dietrich this Winter he will go into production immediately with "Bluebeard's Eighth Wife," with Claudette Colbert as star, Paramount disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- Commodity futures commission merchants numbering 738 with principal offices in thirty-four States, the District of Columbia and one foreign country and maintaining approximately 1,300 branch offices have been registered under the Commodity Exchange Act, the Commodity Exchange Administration announced today.

Declaring that he was an ardent admirer of the President and his New Deal ideas, Francois de Tessan, French Under-Secretary of State and Minister for Alsace-Lorraine in the Cabinet of Leon Blum, interpreted the sweeping Democratic victory yesterday as a political event of international importance.

BOSTON, Nov. 4. -- A Federal Government plan to break up the steamship strike on both coasts by tying up all Shipping Board vessels for six months and providing navy crews to operate privately owned ships is contemplated by Washington officials, a Boston steamship operator revealed here tonight.
MADRID, Thursday, Nov. 5. -- Government gunners poured shells early today into the lines of Insurgent forces that had advanced within six miles of the capital.

Eleven intercollegiate double-headers have been scheduled for Madison Square Garden for the coming season, according to an announcement made yesterday by Ned Irish, director of basketball at the arena, at a luncheon tendered to basketball writers, officials and coaches at the Lincoln Hotel.

Convertible industrial bonds and United States Treasury obligations shared the spotlight in bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Both groups responded to a brisk demand which carried quotations sharply higher in heavy trading.
Plans for a variety of buildings in scattered sections of the city were filed yesterday by architects. The projects include houses, garages, a factory and a court house in Brooklyn.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4. -- Miss Marguerite de L. Newbold, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Newbold, was presented to society today at a buffet luncheon which her mother and aunt, Mrs. Edward Osborne Troth of Alden Park Manor, Germantown, gave at the Cosmopolitan Club.
BERLIN, Nov. 4. -- The Boerse fell today. Reports of expected further restrictions on foreign security holders caused a virtual collapse of prices in that field.

The thing above all others that struck the ordinary citizen resuming his daily chores the morning after the election was the temper in which other ordinary citizens hailed the result. People were cheerful; in a sense peculiar to the ebullient electorate of America, they were happy.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 4. -- Three steps toward possible peace in the maritime and warehouse strikes were taken here today.
A long list of Manhattan properties comprised auction room offerings of real estate yesterday.

ARLINGTON, Texas, Nov. 4 (AP). -- The Three D's Stock Farm entry ran one, two, three today in the $3,500 Southwest Thoroughbred Breeders' Futurity, Gin Daisy galloping home one length ahead of Heelfly at Arlington Downs. Pansy's First was third.

The official publication of the Harvard Athletic Association, The H.A.A. News, is also the program for the games which are played in the famous old stadium in Cambridge. A couple of years ago, the publication had an experience with another publication and found, on the day of the game, that the rival had on sale the line-ups with the official numbers, made available to them through advance copies of The H.A.A. News.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- The Idaho Power Company, a subsidiary of the Electric Power and Light Corporation of the Electric Bond and Share System, has filed with the Federal Power Commission a petition for an order suspending the proposed uniform system of accounts prescribed for public utility companies and licensees subject to the Federal Power Act, scheduled to become effective on Jan. 1.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 4. -- Lafayette battled Army to a 1-1 tie at soccer today, each team scoring in the third period. Army kept the action in Lafayette territory practically throughout the game, but brilliant goal tending by Landis, who had sitxeen stops to his credit, held the Cadets back.

Political expenditures for talks given over WOR during the 1936 campaign amounted to $51,906, Alfred J. McCosker, president of the station, said yesterday. The amount represents an increase of 52.6 per cent over that of 1932, when all parties spent $34,000 for talks over the station.

Charges that a "reign of terror" was being spread by groups of Communist "racketeers" active behind the "sit-down" strike of seamen in this city were made yesterday by John M. Franklin, president of the International Mercantile Marine Company.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 4. -- In the wake of the surprising show of strength by the Democratic organization of Nassau County in yesterday's election, the Republican organization took consolation today in the fact that the New Deal gains were not so great here as in other normally Republican counties of the State.
"The tumult and the shouting," as Mr. Kipling said, "dies," and having done so, one wonders now what all the fuss was about.

Proposed legislation to provide a thirty-hour week on railroads was condemned by Harry A. Wheeler, president of the Railway Business Association and chairman of the transportation conference, in a statement issued yesterday.

Fordham's football squad cut its drill short yesterday afternoon at Fordham Field, readily admitting its weariness as a result of the harrowing schedule which has occupied the Rams for the past two weeks.
TOKYO, Nov. 4. -- As soon as the votes for President Roosevelt began piling up in proportions foreshadowing a sweeping victory, the newspapers here started issuing extras.

AN entertaining and revealing footnote to history, offering intimate views of royalty in that period when royalty was one large, not very happy, family, and when the German Kaiser was repeatedly running to his grandmother with complaints as to the behavior of his uncle, Edward, Prince of Wales, and trumpeting threats of war, is offered by E.F. Benson, biographer of Queen Victoria and King Edward VII, in "The Kaiser and English Relations" (Longmans, Green, $3.50).

A motion for reduction of the $50,000 bail on which Max D. Krone, a private detective, is being held in the Tombs, pending the start of his trial with A. Henry Ross, a Brooklyn lawyer, on an extortion charge, was withdrawn before Supreme Court Justice Wasservogel yesterday.
CALGARY, Alberta, Nov. 4 (Canadian Press). -- Formation of "the People's League of Alberta," a non-partisan organization for the "maintenance of democratic institutions," was announced here today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 4. -- The Princeton football squad continued its program of hard work in preparation for the Cornell game on Saturday as three varsity elevens faced the scrubs for more than an hour of stationary scrimmage today.

Wall Street wasted no time yesterday lamenting the record-breaking Democratic sweep at the polls on Tuesday. The election odds for weeks had forecast the re-election of President Roosevelt; the main hope of the financial community had been that anti-New Deal representation in Congress would be increased.

When The Herald Tribune says the Roosevelt triumph is the greatest in 116 years it refers, of course, to the re-election of JAMES MONROE in 1820. On that occasion Mr. MONROE received 231 electoral votes out of a total number of 232.

BERLIN, Nov. 4. -- A variety of conclusions is deduced by German commentators from the results of the American Presidential election. While it is uniformly conceded that the outcome represents an unprecedented personal triumph for President Roosevelt no less than a victory of optimism over numerous handicaps, implications of a profounder political nature are distinctly read into the returns.

The electric utility industry today is faced with many problems, but the outlook for it is encouraging, in the opinion of E.F. Hutton Co. as expressed in a statement issued yesterday. The conclusions were reached after a broad survey conducted before the election, but predicated upon a Roosevelt victory.

ROME, Nov. 4. -- President Roosevelt's re-election at the end of a campaign that was followed in Italy with closer attention than preceding ones has been received in Rome with satisfaction in no way decreased by the fact that it was fully expected.

PARIS, Nov. 4. -- Envisaging a possible lightning German attack against France, Defense Minister Edouard Daladier today urged immediate fortification of the Belgian and Swiss frontiers and a speed-up in the manufacture of war materials.

The De Basil Ballet Russe, last night introduced the last of its novelties for this season at the Metropolitan Opera House in the form of Massine's divertissement to music of Cimarosa called, appropriately enough, "Cimarosiana." It is a bright and charming bit of choreography, eminently worth rescuing from the repertoire of the Diaghileff company, for which it was composed in 1920.
TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 4. -- Governor Landon resumed actively his duties as Chief Executive of Kansas today and accepted with good humor his crushing defeat at the polls.
As the count of ballots cast Tuesday in the 1936 Presidential election moved toward completion yesterday, these facts appeared:
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Nov. 4. -- President Roosevelt's victory was welcomed here, newspapers contending it was of great international importance, especially to Pan-Americanism.

Stocks, bonds and commodities rose sharply yesterday on the news of President Roosevelt's victory. The upturn was interpreted in Wall Street as presaging continued recovery in business during the President's second term.

The first of the daily author's programs which will be a leading feature of THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair will begin this afternoon in the auditorium. "Books and Myself" will be the subject of the first program, at which J. Donald Adams will preside.

Jacob Maged, the Jersey City tailor who became a martyr of "rugged individualism" in the Spring of 1934 when he went to jail for cutting the NRA code prices for pressing clothes, changed his mind about the NRA yesterday -- for the fourth time, to public knowledge.

Manhattan College's varsity squad was sent through a vigorous two-hour practice session yesterday at Innisfail Park as Chick Meehan's charges continued preparations for their intersectional meeting with Kentucky at Ebbets Field on Saturday.

Scheduled to open tonight at the Majestic Theatre, Brooklyn, the Brooklyn-Queens production of "It Can't Happen Here" was abandoned yesterday after three weeks of rehearsals. The employment of six principals by the commercial theatre, and the project's inability to replace them, was the reason given for dropping the show.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- Following is a textual copy of the dispatch regarding the election sent today to The London Times by Sir Willmott Lewis, its Washington correspondent:

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Nov. 4 (AP). -- Arthur W. Aleshire of Clark County, a sufferer from paralysis, who conducted his campaign from a wheel chair, stood out today as the first Democrat to be elected to Congress from the Seventh Ohio District as it is now constituted.
CHICAGO, Nov. 4. -- At headquarters of the Republican National Committee in the Railway Exchange Building the staff was preparing today to vacate the offices.

Eugenio Cardinal Pacelli, Papal Secretary of State, was guest of honor at a reception given by the Catholic Club of New York under the sponsorship of Cardinal Hayes last evening in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. More than 2,500 members of the club, their wives and specially invited friends attended.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4. -- A strong upturn in foreign wheat markets and the buoyancy in stocks and commodities in general was largely responsible for more aggressive buying of grain futures on the Board of Trade today. Bearish influences exerted little influence.

On the face of the returns it is evident that the Democratic party has not only held its huge majorities in Congress but actually increased them. Of the chief spokesmen of the Administration, all who were candidates for re-election have been returned to office. The principal ally of the Administration among the Senate progressives was likewise successful: GEORGE NORRIS, running as an independent, with the President's endorsement, was victorious over two opponents in Nebraska.
In your leading editorial today you made two errors of fact in stating that "there are sounder methods" of attaining the objectives of the relief bond issue and the constitutional convention.

Re-elected for a third term -- although by hundreds of thousands of votes less than President Roosevelt's total in the State -- Governor Lehman laid plans yesterday for a militant fight to obtain enactment of a full State social security law at the coming session of the Legislature.

Plans for the huge North American Winter Sports Show, which will be presented at Madison Square Garden from Dec. 9 to 12, in conjunction with the international ski meet, are nearing completion, and indications point to a spectacle that is expected to attract vast crowds.

Professor Jacques Greber of the City Planning Institute, University of Paris, and chief architect of the 1937 Paris Exposition, arrived yesterday on the steamship Champlain of the French Line to attend a series of receptions to be given in New York, Philadelphia, Boston and Washington.

PARIS, Nov. 4. -- President Roosevelt's overwhelming re-election was received here with genuine expressions of satisfaction. The French have rarely been so interested in an American Presidential election and rarely so content with its results.

Passengers due to arrive today from the Channel ports on the North German Lloyd liner Europa include Mr. and Mrs. Devereux Milburn, Captain Edward Molyneux, Earle Bailie, banker; Mr. and Mrs. William Odom, Major Truman Smith, Military Attache of the United States Embassy in Berlin; Dr. Kurt von Boeckman and Dr. Ladislav Sourek.

Where does the Republican party go from here? Certainly it should have had enough of "country boy" management and candidature. The electors which the Republicans must win to recapture Congress and the Presidency will continue to live in greatest numbers east of the Mississippi, and, when the ghastly wounds of Tuesday's battle have begun to heal, control of the party organization will undoubtedly head back in that direction.

NYACK, N.Y., Nov. 4. -- President Roosevelt carried Rockland County by a plurality of 316, according to complete unofficial returns today. Only two other Democrats received pluralities in Rockland County yesterday.

R. Walton Ford, 35 years old, an interior decorator, was strangled to death between 3:45 A.M. and 4:30 A.M. yesterday in his room on the fifth floor, rear, in the Hotel Sutton at 330 East Fifty-sixth Street by two unidentified men who were his guests.

LONDON, Nov. 4. -- Following yesterday's protest by the British Government to Berlin over Air Minister Hermann Goering's declaration that Germany's colonies had been stolen from her, Ambassador Joachim von Ribbentrop complained to Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden today about a speech made last week in the House of Commons by a Communist member, William Gallacher.
From the disaster of the opening game against Ohio State, Dr. Marvin A. Stevens has nursed New York University back to a recovery that he could hardly hope to surpass in the field of medicine.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4. -- Longshoremen estimated to number 10,000 walked through picket lines on the waterfront today and returned to work under a forty-eight-hour truce, announced after their leaders had conferred with Mayor S. Davis Wilson.

Mayor La Guardia, in a statement yesterday on the election, said that the "crimeless" voting and the adoption of the new city charter showed that honest non-partisan government was in the city to stay. He said:

GENEVA, Nov. 4. -- President Roosevelt's re-election, with an increased majority in Congress behind him, is very warmly welcomed as one of the hopeful events in the world situation by the League of Nations, the International Labor Organization and the World Bank.
VIENNA, Nov. 4. -- Austrians followed the American Presidential election with great interest, many sitting up all night to listen to the returns broadcast by several continental stations.
PARIS, Nov. 4. -- The Havas Agency made the following announcement today:

PARIS, Nov. 4. -- The French newspaper world had a major sensation today when Pierre Guimier, the director of the Havas Agency, in charge of advertising, was forced to resign his post under pressure from Premier Leon Blum.

MADRID, Nov. 4 (Passed by the Censor). -- Rebel troops today captured Leganes, six miles southwest of the heart of Madrid, and pushed on three miles to the suburb of Carabanchel, where heavy fighting is in progress.

New Jersey gave a plurality of about 365,000 to President Roosevelt in Tuesday's voting, as compared to 31,000 four years ago. William H. Smathers, Democrat, who supported the New Deal in his campaign, defeated United States Senator W. Warren Barbour, Republican, who sought re-election, by a plurality of about 185,000.
HYDE PARK, Nov. 4. -- With his re-election accomplished by a vote obviously exceeding his own expectations, President Roosevelt turned today to laying the groundwork for his future program.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 4. -- A New York horse, Marching Home, owned by Mrs. William Ziegler Jr., was the first favorite to win at Pimlico today, when she dashed along to lead all the way and finish three lengths in front at the end of the six furlongs.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 4. -- The police, moving to clear New Orleans of marine strike pickets, jailed more than 100 seamen today on charges of vagrancy or loitering.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP). -- New assignments for seven brigadier generals of the line were announced today by the War Department as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4. -- The full extent of the Democratic sweep of Pennsylvania was disclosed today as members of all parties, confronted with nearly complete election returns, surveyed with amazement the results of one of the greatest political upheavals in the Commonwealth's history.

Consolidated net profit of the Pure Oil Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on July 31 was reported yesterday as $7,591,526 after depreciation, depletion, amortization, minority interest and provision for normal Federal income taxes, but before any provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings applicable to the operations for the first seven months of 1936.

If "Green Waters," which was acted at the Masque last evening, is strangely inscrutable and elusive it is not because the author is a shoddy artist. He is Max Catto by name, and "Green Waters," which was originally acted abroad, is reported to be his first play.

President ROOSEVELT, as is usual with him, has taken a great electoral victory with quiet dignity. No flash of boastfulness has been emitted by him. Not a taunt at his political opponents has fallen from his lips. After the greatest personal tribute that any election in our history ever paid to a President, his thoughts seem to be those of a man thinking less of past achievements than of future opportunities.

With Sid Luckman, star sophomore halfback, still hobbling around with an injured knee, Columbia yesterday started to groom Joe Vollmer for the left halfback position in preparation for its game with Dartmouth at Hanover on Saturday.
Editorial views of representative newspapers in key cities of the country on the outcome of the election reveal varying reactions. Some of these comments follow:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 4. -- For the third consecutive afternoon Head Coach Ducky Pond today drove the Yale eleven through a heavy scrimmage. Power plays were stressed following yesterday's defensive session.

Sharp gains were made in brisk trading yesterday in the local commodity futures markets, the consensus of the various trades being that continuance of the present national administration was conducive to higher prices for staples. Rye, rubber and lead reached new high levels in the cash markets, where wheat, corn, oats, cotton, lard, printcloths, wool tops, cocoa and tin also gained.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court unanimously granted late yesterday afternoon the request of Lyon Boston, Assistant District Attorney, for an order on Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer and others to show cause why Justice Steuer should not be prohibited from signing an order granted by himself last week in an ambulance-chasing case.
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Nov. 4. -- On the basis of yesterday's election returns Puerto Rico prefers to go along with Uncle Sam rather than set up shop for herself as an independent republic.

With uncertainties removed by the outcome of the election, activity developed on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and prices moved upward in sympathy with outside markets. Consumers resumed buying, which had been suspended in great measure last week, and an advance of $1 to $1.50 a bale lifted all current crop months above 11 3/4 cents a pound.

Within the next three or four days the Police Department will begin to enforce new regulations establishing a loading zone and the prohibition of parking of any but commercial vehicles in the midtown area of Manhattan, it was announced yesterday by Deputy Chief Inspector Patrick McCarthy, in charge of traffic.
VIENNA, Nov. 4 (AP) -- A Cabinet shift tonight raised monarchists' hopes for the restoration of Archduke Otto to the former Hapsburg throne in Austria.

As the result of action taken at a meeting of the State Athletic Commission yesterday, it is very likely that Izzy Jannazzo of New York will get the chance to meet Barney Ross for the welterweight title at Madison Square Garden on Nov. 27.

Members of the football squad representing Politecnica Nacional of Mexico City, which is scheduled to play two games in the metropolitan area, arrived yesterday from New Mexico. The invaders will oppose Monroe High School in New York City Nov. 14 and the following Saturday will meet Baldwin High at Baldwin, L.I.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 4 (AP). -- An almost constantly ringing telephone gave Oregon's first woman Representative-elect hardly time for her usual breakfast of lemon juice today, but she and her family were too happy over the election to find other than pleasure in the disturbance.

PARIS, Nov. 4. -- The news of the American election was received today by the French public with a feeling of unmitigated joy. A high official of the Quai d'Orsay, who is one of those diplomats least to be suspected of sentimentalism, summarized for me the reaction of the public here with this striking phrase:

LONDON, Nov. 4. -- News of the sweeping Roosevelt victory in the United States caused a spurt in activity today on the London Stock Exchange, with operations centered in international stocks and considerable selling of transatlantic securities followed by a late recovery.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 4. -- William F. Bleakley, Republican candidate for Governor, commenting today on his defeat, said he believed he would have done better by concentrating his campaign in New York City rather than up-State.
If the object of the World's Fair event is to show the progress civilization has made, let us not forget the important part entertainment has played in enabling people to live happily.

OTTAWA, Nov. 4. -- Seldom have Canadians been more pleased with the result of an American Presidential election than that which has sent President Roosevelt to the White House for a second term, but, then, never before have Canadians had so great a stake at issue in such a contest.
LONDON, Nov. 4. -- The Jarrow marchers achieved parliamentary recognition of their plight today as a result of presenting their petition to the House of Commons.

HYDE PARK, Nov. 4. -- President Roosevelt sat in a big upholstered chair today in his home at Hyde Park, with his family around, and proudly watched the christening of his downy-haired 8-month-old granddaughter, Kate. She had his undivided attention.

The Public Service Corporation of New Jersey has raised from $5,000,000 to $8,000,000 its bid for the 712,411 shares of Jersey Central Power and Light Company stock securing debentures of the National Public Service Corporation, the debenture holders' protective committee revealed yesterday.
A Democratic net gain of at least five, and possibly six, seats in the Senate and fourteen in the House were revealed yesterday to be part of the election upheaval of Tuesday.

The adoption of the new city charter, with approval of the system of proportional representation in the election of City Councilmen under it, at Tuesday's election was regarded yesterday as a blow to the prestige of the Democratic party organizations in the city, and as appearing to assure greater minority representation in the city government than has been the rule.
The Guaranty Trust Company has been appointed co-transfer agent for 400,000 shares of no-par common stock of the Black Decker Manufacturing Company.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 5. -- A wage increase, hinted in industrial circles as amounting to 10 per cent, is under consideration for the 8,000 employes of its manufacturing division by the Tennessee, Coal, Iron and Railroad Company, a United States Steel subsidiary.

MADRID, Nov. 5 (Passed by the Censor). -- Madrid's new supreme defense Cabinet, including four Anarcho-Syndicalists, one of whom is Spain's first woman Cabinet Minister, sat into the late hours of this morning. Its deliberations were accompanied by a rumble of heavy cannonading just outside the capital, which began a little before day-break.

United States Government issues led all classes of bonds yesterday to higher levels on the New York Stock Exchange. The advance in the Treasury list was 4-32 to 19-32 point, the sharpest witnessed in many weeks as banks and other large institutional investors acted upon their belief that the result of the national election means continuance of easy money rates.

GENEVA, Nov. 5. -- The United States Government, it is believed here, will invite the International Labor Organization to hold in the United States the conference on the textile industry which the I.L.O.'s governing body is expected to convoke at its session next week.

A large and brilliant assembly of society viewed the spectacle of horsemanship and exciting performances in the ring at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night. In comparison with the resplendent opening, the second night of the exhibition showed no falling off in the array of social notables and fashion.

For five hours yesterday the police made an intensive search through cellars, alleys and tenement houses for Jean Bocca, 12 years old, of 142 West Fourth Street. While they searched, Jean sat unconcerned in a cellar reading her catechism by candlelight.

Arnold Wood Jr. of the Princeton Club, sixth in the seedings, jumped a round ahead of the field yesterday as the Princeton Club opened its seventeenth annual squash tennis tournament. The hard-hitting Wood disposed of Vincent Furno of the Columbia Club, 15 -- 10, 15 -- 7, in the lone second-round encounter of the day.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 5 (AP). -- Steel circles freely predicted today an impending wage boost for the industry's 450,000 wage-earners on the strength of announcements by company executives that negotiations for a "wage adjustment" were "progressing."

MADRID, Nov. 5. -- The Insurgent attack, for weeks an ever-narrowing semi-circle south of Madrid, was converged into a solid front driving toward the heart of Madrid through Getafe, eight miles south of the capital, where one of Madrid's two major airdromes was located.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP). -- The Department of Agriculture predicted today that carry-over stocks of raw wool in this country for the season starting next April would be smaller than for the current year.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Nov. 5. -- A memorandum containing a threat to shoot King Carol and members of his government under given circumstances was presented to the King today in the name of Corneliu Zelea Codreanu, leader of the Iron Guard, which carried out the murder of the Liberal Premier Ion Duca and other political assassinations.

Burleigh Grimes, one-time spitball pitching ace and the last of that tribe of hurlers to ply his trade in the major circuits, is back in the National League and is the new manager of the Brooklyn Dodgers.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 5. -- President Roosevelt's re-election was hailed here today by the newspaper Tiempo as a resounding victory for the democracy and liberalism that two of Europe's principal dictators believed dead. It says:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP). -- Department of Justice agents were ordered today to search for Representative John H. Hoeppel of California and his son, Charles, at the request of Leslie C. Garnett, United States Attorney.

William F. Bleakley is emerging as eager to become the new leader of the Republican party in this State. Already, buoyed up by the fact that he ran 500,000 votes ahead of the Republican nominee for President in the State, he is credited by some leaders with willingness to run for Governor on the Republican ticket two years from now.

Major John Tupper Cole, riding the chestnut gelding Wampum, and Lieutenant J.O. Curtis, mounted on the bay gelding Renzo, captured the second division of the High Score competition, the international jumping event which featured last night's session of the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden.

An agreement was reached yesterday between the Siamese Government and the International Tin Committee for the extension of the tin restriction agreement which was to expire at the close of this year, according to dispatches from Paris.

The twenty-ninth annual Autumn exhibition of the Horticultural Society of New York opened last night with a private view at the American Museum of Natural History, Seventy-ninth Street and Central Park West.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP). -- The Prohibition National Committee today reported campaign receipts of $11,514.07 and expenditures of $11,581.79.

PARIS, Nov. 5. -- A burst of invective between Rightist and Leftist Deputies forced temporary suspension of today's initial session of the French Chamber of Deputies, a few minutes after it had been convened.
Properties along the West Side, from the Chelsea section to Washington Heights, attracted buyers yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5. -- The old New York Americans -- playing under the ownership, technically, of William Dwyer -- battled the Chicago Black Hawks to a 1-1 tie at the Chicago Stadium tonight before 13,500 fans.

Many readers of THE TIMES yesterday must have been impressed by evidence of the deep satisfaction with which news of President ROOSEVELT'S re-election has been received in many foreign countries. The comment of leading newspapers like The Times of London and La Nacion of Buenos Aires, and of Premier BLUM of France and other men in public office, was more than merely friendly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- Secretary Morgenthau indicated at his press conference today that he regarded the present financial situation of the country as satisfactory and that no change in policy would be necessary unless there was a change in conditions.

The following film programs, which will be shown over the week-end, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local private and public elementary and high schools.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York toek Exchange rose $3,402,018,198 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. Average price a share of all listed stocks on Nov. 1, was $43.36, compared with $40.88 at the beginning of October.

LONDON, Nov. 5. -- In his speech in the House of Commons today Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden answered in some detail Premier Benito Mussolini's challenging Milan speech on Anglo-Italian relations and the implications of the speeches by Colonel General Hermann Goering, German Commissar for the Four-Year Economic Plan, and Dr. Joseph Goebbels, German Propaganda Minister, that Britain was responsible for Germany's economic difficulties.

The $1,000 John Anisfield award has been given to Julian Huxley and A.C. Haddon for their book, "We Europeans: A Survey of Racial Problems. With a Contribution by A.M. Carr-Saunders," it is announced by The Saturday Review of Literature. The award is made annually to encourage the production of good books in the field of racial relationships.

The New York Giants will take no chances of losing ground in the National Football League race due to scarcity of capable reserve material, it was indicated yesterday with the addition of Lawrence Johnson, 223-pound full-blooded Menominee Indian.

As Columbia went through its final heavy workout yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for its encounter with Dartmouth at Hanover tomorrow, it was clearly evident that Sid Luckman, star sophomore halfback, would not start against the Indians.

TORONTO, Nov. 5 (AP). -- The world champion Detroit Red Wings opened the 1936-37 National Hockey League season tonight just where they left off last Spring by beating the Toronto Maple Leafs. The Red Wings came from behind to defeat the Leafs, 3 to 1, in the season's opener here.

Another section of the Scottish National Dictionary (Vol. II, Part 1, which has just been published in Aberdeen) begins with a harsh word in speech that has had extensive use in the days of the campaign -- "bitter-barkit," applied to persons having a "bitter tongue." In the illustrative sentence even King ROBERT the BRUCE is called a "sma' bitter-barkit crater."

France will be formally represented at the New York World's Fair of 1939, Francois de Tessan, French Under-Secretary of State and Minister for Alsace Lorraine, announced last night at a dinner in his honor at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, arranged by the Franco-American Committee for the 1937 International Exposition in Paris.

The volume of bank clearings was curtailed slightly in the week ended on Wednesday, including Election Day, with the total for twenty-two leading cities for the five-day period $5,298,156,000, against $4,987,404,000 last year, a gain of 6.2 per cent, according to Dun Bradstreet. Inc.

Postmaster Albert Goldman announced yesterday that distribution of forms to be filled out by employers and employes under the Social Security Act would be started by the postal authorities on Nov. 16.
The employers' application form contains on the back the following instructions:

LONDON, Nov. 5. -- A few hours after having waved good-bye to Earl Peel and the members of his Royal Commission at the start of their journey to Jerusalem, W.G.A. Ormsby-Gore, Secretary of State for Colonies, announced today one of the most sweeping reductions ever made in the number of Jewish labor immigrants to Palestine.

LONDON, Nov. 5. -- Various references to President Roosevelt were made in tonight's debate in the House of Commons on international affairs by Labor members, who expressed the hope that his overwhelming majority was a prelude to his taking an active part in promoting world peace.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- An extraordinary inter-American conference was first proposed by President Roosevelt early this year, with its objective the safeguarding of peace in the New World and a greater accord on economic matters.

The Harvard and University Club teams triumphed again last night in the Class A squash racquets matches of the metropolitan league and occupy the top rung with two victories each. The Yale Club, in its initial test of the season, also prevailed.

Reporting shortages already developing in the wholesale markets, P.A. O'Connell, head of the E.T. Slattery Company, Boston, who was in the market here yesterday, said that his organization has anticipated its holiday merchandise requirements 100 per cent.

COLLEGE STATION, Texas, Nov. 5 (AP). -- Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, told 4,000 students at Texas A. and M. College today that the way to prevent business depression had not been found, but that America was full of opportunities for youth.

Mayor La Guardia and Park Commissioner Moses were among those who paid tribute to Charles B. Stover, Park Commissioner under Mayor Gaynor and a pioneer in playground work, at the dedication of a stone bench to Mr. Stover's memory yesterday afternoon in Central Park.

MENHAM, N.J., Nov. 5. -- The boys down at the firehouse got so excited when they heard at 4 o'clock yesterday morning that Mayor William W. Cordingley had been defeated for re-election that they ran out their favorite fire truck and drove it all over town, blowing the siren, ringing the bell and yelling hurray.
MOSTOLES, Spain, Nov. 5 (AP). -- The left wing of General Jose Varela's Insurgent army advanced today to a small hill dominating the Cuatro Vientos Airport, about seven miles southwest of Madrid.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 5. -- Yale lightened its football program today, punting, passing, calisthenics and relay running occupying the squad. A dummy drill in defense against Brown's formations ended the session.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 5. -- Secretary of Commerce Daniel C. Roper declared today that the United States has no intention of entering into an alliance with Germany or any other nation in connection with the commercial development of lighter-than-air craft.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5. -- Speculative interest in the grain markets on the Board of Trade broadened materially today, especially in corn futures, which advanced 1 1/2 to 2 1/2 cents a bushel to the highest price since late in August. The close was practically at the top.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- An enthusiastic capital was in the midst of sudden, last-minute preparations tonight to welcome President Roosevelt on his return to the White House tomorrow.
The back of the employes' application form contains the following instructions to aid employes in supplying the required information:

Real estate tax payments for the second half of the current year exceed the total collected a year ago on the same date by $12,262,411 despite the fact that the current second half levy was $8,000,000 less than that of a year ago, it was announced yesterday by Controller Frank J. Taylor.
Nine of the ten remaining major teams that have thus far escaped defeat will defend their records tomorrow, with Santa Clara idle until its meeting on the 15th with St. iary's.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Nov. 5. -- The junior class of Wellesley College will present a satire in swing time in Alumnae Hall tomorrow night, the first original musical comedy to be given on the college stage. "In One Ear and Gone Tomorrow" will feature five new songs, the music for which was composed by four members of the class.

Plans to render increased charity services through local neighborhood councils were submitted for study yesterday at the regular meeting of the Welfare Council of New York City at the council headquarters, 122 East Twenty-second Street.

Kielman A. Schuddekoff, 34 years old, a contractor, of 322 West 108th Street, was found guilty by Justices Brady and Bayes in Special Sessions yesterday of compelling five painters in an apartment building he was renovating at 385 Central Park West last Aug. 10 to "kick back" $50 of their wages.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5. -- Trade in hogs was slow early today, with quotations steady to 10 cents lower, but leading packers came into the market later and prices strengthened and closed about in line with the finish yesterday. The top price declined 5 cents to $9.65, while the day's average was unchanged at $9.50, the spread being the smallest since the 15 cents on Feb. 10.
PARIS, Nov. 5 (AP). -- Ecclesiastical authorities tonight ordered an investigation of the strange tales told about Mrs. Blavingnac and the saintly ghost of her grand-uncle, Father Borie.
