WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- In applications filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission for unlisted trading privileges in seventeen securities registered on either the New York stock or the New York Curb Exchange, the Los Angeles Stock Exchange argued that under present conditions the investors in the vicinity of its Exchange frequently suffered hardship because of the time differential between the two cities.

BERLIN, Nov. 5. -- The Boerse weakened again today. Heavy industrial shares fell throughout the early operations, but showed resistance later, Vereinigtestahl losing 5/8 point on the day, Rheinstahl 1 1/2 and Mannesmann 5/8. Potash issues were mixed and variable.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- Active post-election competition in the investment market for securities which the Reconstruction Finance Corporation purchased from the Public Works Administration for resale was evidenced today when 266 bids were received on $4,624,000 of 4 per cent equipment trust certificates of the New York, Chicago St. Louis Railroad and forty-eight issues of municipalities, counties and school districts, all paying 4 per cent and with face value of about $3,150,000.

Advances continued yesterday in most of the local commodity futures markets, but in some instances profit-taking appeared and irregularity ensued. In the cash markets there were no declines, but rye, lead, tins and wool tops made new highs, and wheat, corn, oats, cocoa, lard, cotton, eggs and silk moved up.

The charge that "science has laid ruthless waste to the cultural and moral heritage of mankind and has left it spiritually bankrupt" was made last night at a panel meeting of the American Institute on "The Price of Human Progress" by Dr. Iago Galdston, executive secretary of the Medical Information Bureau of the New York Academy of Medicine.

It is Henry Hull who comes back to town this evening in the leading role of Sophie Treadwell's "Plumes in the Dust." The play is based on the life of Edgar Allan Poe, with the creator of Jeeter Lester acting that role and with others of the company including Mary Morris, Charles Kennedy, Fredrica Slemons, Amelia Romano, Ruth Yorke, Don Shelton and Iris Whitney.

Michael Vito Dimasello's old horse wagon lost an argument with a taxicab in Forty-second Street near Eighth Avenue yesterday morning, and the resulting tie-up diverted the midtown crowd for about half an hour.

Jacob Pesditsch, former inmate of Manhattan State Hospital on Wards Island, admitted at the line-up yesterday, according to the police, that he killed Charles Matuna, whose body was found in front of 3 West 109th Street late Saturday night.

The announcement yesterday by Benjamin F. Fairless, president of the largest operating subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, that negotiations looking to an increase in wages were progressing was interpreted in Wall Street as assuring a pay rise in the near future for most of the steel industry's 500,000 workers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- An increase of 8 per cent in imports of food products and beverages in the first nine months this year over the same period last year was reported today by the Department of Commerce. The value of such imports in this year's period was $539,326,000, against $500,725,000 last year.

A quiet week-end is in store for the cinema along Broadway, only two openings being scheduled. They are "The Girl on the Front Page," a Universal melodrama featuring Edmund Lowe and Gloria Stuart, at the Roxy, and the Lawrence Tibbett-Twentieth Century-Fox production, "Under Your Spell," at the Palace.

Extensive use of research for the development of new processes and improvement of old is essential to American industry if competition from other countries, particularly Japan, is to be met. Elvin H. Killheffer, vice president of the United States Institute for Textile Research, Inc., warned institute members at their annual dinner last night in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

William B. Joyce, former chairman of the old National Surety Company, was examined yesterday before trial in the $20,000,000 accounting suit by creditors of the surety company against the former officers and directors to compel them to account for an alleged waste of funds of the company during the depression.

The appointment of Arthur A. Ballantine, former Under Secretary of the Treasury, and Clarence Francis, president of the General Foods Corporation, as divisional chairmen in the United Hospital Campaign Committee, was announced yesterday.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 5 (AP) -- Memories of Winter racing at Guttenburg, Newport and Delmar Park were revived today as racing was resumed at Churchill Downs after an unprecedented lapse of one day due to yesterday's heavy snowstorm.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5. -- A shake-up in the Republican city committee as well as in the party's State leadership appeared likely today as President Roosevelt, in late returns from Tuesday's election, increased the size of his Pennsylvania plurality.

The Big Indian Company, controlled by Christian Fleissner Jr., has bought from the Howard Savings Institution a parcel at 115, 121 and 127 Pulaski Street, and 307-09 Oliver Street, Newark, through Leslie Blau, Inc. Mr. Fleissner operates the Standard Embossing Plate Company, adjoining on the south.

To escape the Federal surtax payments on undistributed earnings as provided in the Revenue Act of 1936, a large number of companies declared yesterday substantial extra or special dividend payments. All will be made this year, most of them before Christmas.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 5. -- Determined to prevent a repetition of the success Harvard gained with its passing attack last week, Fritz Crisler sent the Princeton eleven through a long defensive drill on Cornell aerials today in preparation for Saturday's contest here.

JOHNSTON, Pa., Nov. 5 (AP). -- The Pittsburgh Pirates cut loose in the final period of a dull National Football League game tonight in Point Stadium and beat the Philadelphia Eagles, 6 to 0. The official attendance was 7,891.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- Iron and Steel imports into the United States in September amounted to 51,061 gross tons valued at $2,208,830, the Department of Commerce reported today. This represented a quantity increase of 6 per cent and a value increase of 5.5 per cent, compared with August of this year, and gains of 21.8 per cent in quantity and 39.4 per cent in value, compared with September, 1935.

Among the rewards or consolations of this Presidential election, most citizens will have already made up a "little list" of political nuisances of which they have now got rid. One of these is The Literary Digest poll. It will scarcely venture to show its face again in the Congressional elections of 1938 or the Presidential campaign four years from now.
PARIS, Nov. 5 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Nov. 4, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,474,000,000, an increase of $3,000,000 compared with the preceding week and a decrease of $8,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1935.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 5. -- There ought to be much rejoicing in Flatbush tonight -- surly, snappy, scrappy Burleigh Grimes is coming back to the Dodgers, and he's coming back fighting.

The scarlet-costumed field hockey players of Manhattanville yesterday maintained their reputation as the metropolitan district's strongest women's college team by soundly defeating the New York University eleven, 8 -- 1, on the Central Park Sixty-seventh Street field.

Dr. James Alexander Miller, Professor of Clinical Medicine of the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University and an outstanding authority on internal medicine and tuberculosis, last night was nominated for the presidency of the New York Academy of Medicine.
WITH INSURGENT ARMY OUTSIDE MADRID, Nov. 4 (Delayed by Censor). -- This night's advances by General Jose Varela's army may prove crucial in the Spanish Civil War.

LONDON, Nov. 5. -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden pledged Great Britain today to rely on the League of Nations and indicated his country regarded with no favor the apparent German desire to exclude Russia from any European settlement.

A resolution requesting the Department of State to explore the sources of European propaganda against the Liberian Government was adopted yesterday at a meeting of the Advisory Committee on Education in Liberia in the offices of the Phelps-Stokes Fund, 101 Park Avenue.

LONDON, Nov. 5. -- Influenced partly by reports of heavy buying in Wall Street, prices on the London Stock Exchange continued their upward movement today. Chief interest centered in copper shares after it had been announced that the production quota would be increased from 95 to 105 per cent of basic tonnages.
" Information of general interest" contained in the instructions sent out by the Social Security Board follows:

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 5. -- Despite a moderately large drop in operations of the steel industry, business in the Pittsburgh district moved upward again last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. Business in the district has risen for five consecutive weeks, during which time the bureau's adjusted index has advanced from 95.6 to 98.3.

OTTAWA, Nov. 5 (Canadian Press). -- Deposits with the Bank of Canada in the week ended yesterday by the Dominion Government rose $2,396,249 and deposits by chartered banks went up $8,751,832, said the weekly statement, which follows:
The Crescent Athletic Club team defeated the New York A.C. by 3 to 2 on the New Mooners' courts as play in group one of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association was resumed last night.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Nov. 5. -- Cardinal Pacelli, Papal Secretary of State, visited President Roosevelt at Hyde Park House for two hours today, combining what was in effect a State visit with an informal talk about many topics of a general nature.

Stores in four of the city's boroughs yesterday abruptly cut the price of Grade B milk from 11 to 9 cents a quart, 2 cents below the minimum established by the State Department of Agriculture. The stores were buying their milk from independent dealers at 8 cents, a cent and three-quarters below the established wholesale price, and selling it for a cent more.

Jack Altman, executive secretary of the Socialist party, and Frank N. Trager, State secretary, issued a statement yesterday, on the basis of up-State figures received at the party's headquarters, 21 East Seventeenth Street, saying the vote received in Tuesday's election by Norman Thomas, the party's Presidential candidate, would be about 75,000 in this State and the total for Harry W. Laidler, Socialist Gubernatorial candidate, 90,000.

PARIS, Nov. 5. -- The Bourse continued to advance strongly today, with greater evidence of optimism than France had seen for many months. Wall Street's rise contributed to the favorable atmosphere, as did an increase in commodity prices.
WITH INSURGENT FORCES, near Parla, Spain, Nov. 5 (AP). -- Their paths cleared by artillery and aviation, three lines of Insurgents advanced tonight in triangular formation on Madrid.

The Associated Gas Electric Coporation and subsidiaries report a balance of $6,761,770 for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30 after depreciation, taxes, underlying charges and dividends, minority interest and charges of the corporation, this compared with $4,761,497 in the preceding twelve months.

The Railway Association's report on earnings of the 140 Class I railways in this country during September and the nine first months of 1936 gives a clear view of the recovery in the transportation industry. Gross receipts, both for September and for the nine months, were substantially the largest for the corresponding period since 1930.
Gates Fahnestock, 84-year-old member of a wealthy family, was found dead last night in a private room of the Peck Memorial Hospital in Brooklyn, his mouth and nose taped with adhesive.

LONDON, Nov. 5. -- No amount of armor can ever make battleships immune from air attack, yet Britain must continue to have them to keep her sea lanes open in time of war. That was the verdict of a Cabinet committee under Sir Thomas Inskip, Minister for Defense Coordination, which spent months studying the great technical controversy of "bombers versus battleships."

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 5. -- One of the tightest finishes of the meeting saw Billy Bee from Detroit carry the Bomar Stable colors to victory today over the 1-to-2 shot, Jay Jay, in the $3,020 Baltimore Handicap, featured event at Pimlico.

ALBANY, Nov. 5. -- Announcing that he had received official reports of a milk price war in New York City, Commissioner Peter G. Ten Eyck of the Department of Agriculture and Markets tonight ordered Burr W. Miller, Assistant Director of the Division of Milk Control in charge of the New York City office, to use his entire force "to see that the law is upheld without discrimination."

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings, the reserve note circulation and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the higest point of the year to date.

A banking group headed by Lehman Brothers obtained yesterday the award of an issue of $10,067,000 of first mortgage 3 1/4 per cent bonds, Series A, of the New England Power Company. The bonds are dated Nov. 15, 1936, and will mature on Nov. 15, 1961.
LONDON, Nov. 5. (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes:

In your editorial comment on what the election may mean and on the solemn obligation imposed on Mr. Roosevelt to interpret that meaning aright, you seem to me to have touched upon an aspect of life and government such as is deplorably missing in the American consciousness.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 5. -- A plea for industrial democracy through the cooperation of capital, management, labor and the public was made by Sullivan A. Jones, Assistant Federal Coordinator for Industrial Cooperation, in a talk today to members of the Yonkers Rotary Club at luncheon in the Elks Lodge here.

Examination of about fifteen advertising allowance contracts adopted in the last two weeks by manufacturers in the food, drug, soap and similar fields revealed yesterday only superficial uniformity among such contracts, with individual producers inserting certain clauses which they felt were needed.

The 1936-1937 season of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra opened last night in Carnegie Hall with a brilliant audience in a festive mood, and it introduced to the American public the young English conductor, John Barbirolli.
HARRISBURG, Nov. 5 (AP). -- Conneaut Lake voters wielded the local option mop to dry up the Crawford County Summer resort, one of Pennsylvania's largest.

BERLIN, Nov. 5. -- Dr. Franz Guertner, Reich Minister of Justice, issued today a draft summary of the new National Socialist Criminal Code, which has been in preparation for three years and which has now passed its second reading in the commission appointed to create it.

One minor but significant election result was the defeat in the California referendum of the license tax on chain stores running up to $500 a unit. This was clearly a punitive and not a revenue-raising tax, as it applied to the chains alone and not to their competitors.

The battle for control of the Jersey Central Power and Light Company has taken a new turn as a result of the opinion of Irwin Kurtz, who was appointed special master by Federal Judge Mandelbaum to consider the matter, that the Federal court cannot take jurisdiction in the reorganization proceedings for the National Public Service Corporation under Section 77b of the National Bankruptcy Act as proposed by the Associated Gas and Electric interests.

A contract for the sale of two large Bronx housing properties was announced yesterday when the New York Life Insurance Company disposed of buildings having accommodations for 167 families. The houses, at 1,705 and 1,710 Andrews Avenue, were bought by an operator represented by Charles M. Rosenthal, attorney. A. Robinson Co., Inc., negotiated the transaction.

After a pistol fight in which ten or more shots were fired, Patrolman William J. McElarney, who had been on post, and two radio patrolmen captured one of three men who held up a bowling alley in Brooklyn last night.

Preparing or their second Southern visitor of the season, Manhattan College's football players went through a strenuous session at Innisfail Park yesterday, hoping they would have as much success with Kentucky on Saturday as they had with North Carolina State.

r Mr. and Mrs. Iingdon Gould gave a reception yesterday afternoon at i their home, 160 East Seventy-sec!ond Street, for their dbutante f daughter, Iiss Silvia Gould, who will be formally introduced to society at a dance on Thanksgiving !night at Sherry's.
PARIS, Nov. 5. -- The Winter session of Parliament started today on a subdued note, with the Popular Front government stronger than it has ever been.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP). -- A three-cornered contest for the Democratic leadership of the House was in full swing today. The speakership was not at issue because of the expected re-election of Representative Bankhead of Alabama. The developing contest was for floor leader.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- Tax records disclosed today that gangsters and some ordinary citizens were flouting the National Firearms Act, which requires registration of purchases of sawed-off shotguns and sub-machine guns.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 5. -- Home teaching methods again were described before Judge Joseph Siegler in Juvenile Court today, when Mrs. Benno Bongart of 123 Watchung Avenue, West Orange, and Robert Bongart, 11 years old, one of the two sons she is teaching at home, were called to the stand in the hearing on the complaint by the West Orange Board of Education against Mr. and Mrs. Bongart.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 5. -- Passenger sailings on ships of the Baltimore Mail Line from Baltimore to European ports were canceled until further notice, it was announced here tonight by officials of the line. The City of Hamburg, Baltimore Mail liner, without passengers but well loaded with freight, left port tonight two hours late because of the seamen's strike.
New building projects in Manhattan and the Bronx last month showed totals under October, 1935, but the aggregates for the first ten months in each year gave the lead to 1936 in both boroughs.

The Citizens Budget Commission, in a report submitted to the Transit Commission yesterday, found serious flaws in the $436,000,000 transit unification plan drafted by Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- A gain of 0.1 per cent in wholesale commodity prices during the week ended on Oct. 31 was reported today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The all-commodity index rose to 81.2 per cent of the 1926 average.

In accepting gracefully the results of the Presidential election, the loser -- who, in fact, could hardly have expected to win -- have shown a good-humored sportsmanship which we like to think characteristic of Americans. Governor LANDON kept his poise in defeat, sent his congratulations to the President, will fill out his term as Governor, and then retire cheerfully to private life.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP). -- Some American Federation of Labor leaders said today that they expected to ask the next Congress to shift the entire social security payroll tax to employers.

Price advances in wool goods and feverish activity in cotton gray cloth yesterday were regarded by many mill men and selling executives as definite confirmation of their belief that the textile industries are heading upward. President Roosevelt's re-election, regarded as assuring continuation of a certain amount of commodity control, gave a fillip to markets, already strong because of heavy demand and the prospect of shortages of raw material.

LONDON, Nov. 5. -- T.O.M. Sopwith told THE NEW YORK TIMES tonight that as a result of "a great sporting gesture by a number of friends," his old boat, Endeavour I, now owned by H.A. Andreae, will accompany his new America's Cup challenger, Endeavour II, across the Atlantic next Spring and, after the cup races are over, will join Endeavour II in all the big Class J races on the Atlantic seaboard.

A bid of $10,000 above a mortgage of $1,050,000 was made yesterday by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company in taking over at foreclosure auction the eighteen-story apartment house at the northeast corner of Seventh Avenue and Sixteenth Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- Administration spokesmen revealed today that in agricultural matters it would now proceed cautiously and only after a definite course of action had been proposed or sanctioned by farmers themselves.

Racing on New York tracks during the 1936 season, which came to a close Saturday at Empire City, experienced a banner year, according to a report issued by the New York Racing Commission yesterday. The totals for New York racing this year showed a gross attendance of 1,138,089, with receipts of $.3,041,882.

The National City Bank of New York obtained the award yesterday of an issue of $5,000,000 of New York City tax notes on a 0.30 per cent basis, plus a premium of $200. The notes are dated Nov. 5, 1936, and will be payable on Nov. 5, 1937. There will be no public offering of the notes, the bank having purchased them for investment.

Major Lester Gardner, secretary of the Institute of Aeronautical Sciences, returned from a survey of European air armaments yesterday, arriving on the North German Lloyd liner Europa after an absence of thirty days.

Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, assured the new Italian Ambassador, Fulvio Suvich, at a welcoming dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night, that all the world has been forced to admire the success of Premier Mussolini in "disciplining the nation."

Of all feathered creatures hunted by man for sport, probably none is more elusive than the duck. Even in the bygone days when waterfowl in flight blackened the skies, consistent success came only to the gunner who was master of this most difficult form of wing shooting.
PROVIDENCE, Nov. 5 (AP). -- Three empleyes of The Pawtucket Star and the publication itself were adjudged in contempt by Judge William M. Connell in Tenth District Court today.

Biblical terms dropped smoothly yesterday morning from the lips of John Lamb, a white follower of Father Divine, who testified in the County Court Building in a supplementary proceedings examination, part of a process to collect $7,245 in judgments obtained against the Negro cult leader.

Plans for a $200,000 Bronx apartment house, two multi-family structures for Brooklyn sites to cost a total of $535,000 and two houses for a Jackson Heights site at an aggregate cost of $600,000 were among the building projects filed yesterday, as follows:
Min, a 300-pound Russian brown bear, broke away from her trainer last night at the opening of the new WPA circus and caused a short-lived excitement.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5. -- Unless there is definite indication of a willingness by both sides in the Pacific Coast maritime strike to discuss peace suggestions by noon tomorrow, Assistant Labor Secretary McGrady plans to return to Washington immediately.

LONDON, Nov. 5. -- The Baldwin government was asked tonight in the House of Commons by a Liberal member, Geoffrey Mander, to clear up an implication which, he said, appeared in a book on the Far East by Henry L. Stimson, American Secretary of State in the Hoover Cabinet.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- Hearings on the application of Crane Company of Chicago to withdraw its preferred and common stocks from registration and listing on the Chicago Stock Exchange were closed today before the Securities and Exchange Commission, with the Chicago Exchange contending that such action would be against the interest of investors in its vicinity.

HENDAYE, France, Nov. 5. -- According to authoritative information here, the Spanish Insurgents' heavy artillery has begun to shell the center of Madrid and their tanks are penetrating the city's suburbs. From various points in the Insurgent lines flames and smoke can be seen rising from buildings in the capital.

PARIS, Nov. 5. -- French rejoicing over President Roosevelt's victory found exceptional expression when as one of the first acts upon convening here today the Chamber of Deputies unanimously voted to address a message of felicitations to American democracy and "respectful congratulations to President Franklin Roosevelt."

MADRID, Nov. 5. -- All roads leading into this city have been barricaded effectively. A space has been left in the middle of each main road for traffic, but side roads have been piled with sandbags and cobble-stones from end to end.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 5. -- Supreme Court Justice Graham Witschief signed an order tonight for Humphrey J. Lynch, legal adviser to Westchester Democrats, impounding all records of the election on Tuesday in the 375 election districts of the county pending a court hearing on Monday.

William Randolph Hearst, who attacked President Roosevelt as dictatorial and communistic during the campaign, said yesterday that "perhaps" the President had given democracy "a new lease of life" in his overwhelming victory at the polls.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- Four New Yorkers and one resident of New Rochelle were among seventeen American citizens brought from Valencia, Spain, to Marseilles by the cruiser Raleigh today, the State Department was informed by John J. Hurley, Consul General at the French port.

Reflecting the strong movement of funds here from other countries to seek investment in the security markets, the principal foreign Exchanges yesterday turned acutely weak in terms of the dollar. The pound sterling was under pressure throughout the day but was supported by the British Equalization account.

VIENNA, Nov. 5 (AP). -- The Austrian Government today named local commanders for a new Industrial Militia, modeled on the American National Guard, to take the place of the disbanded privately owned armies.

The constitutionality of the Federal Social Security Act and of the unemployment compensation laws passed by fourteen States and the District of Columbia must be settled before the present social security plan becomes secure in this country, the American Retail Federation stated yesterday in a bulletin listing and discussing pending cases.

The Federal grand jury indicted yesterday thirteen of a gang of alleged international smugglers, including four women, who were accused of employing members of the crews of transatlantic liners to bring large quantities of crude gum opium here from Paris. Two of the women pleaded guilty after the indictments were handed up to Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- Not since 1869 has any party held such a large percentage of the Senate's membership as the Democrats won in Tuesday's election, and records as far back as 1855 show no House majority to equal that assured in the new Congress.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 5. -- A second vehicle for Harold Lloyd -- "The Walls of Jericho," by Francis and Marion Cockrell -- has been purchased by Paramount. The first, as yet untitled, is to start production in December. The Cockrells also have disposed of a story, "Take It Easy," to RKO, this one being designed for Gene Raymond and Ann Sothern.

Judge Charles S. Colden in Queens County Court upheld yesterday the constitutionality of the law which requires that a defendant give details of an alibi defense to the prosecuting attorney before trial.

Broadcasts from an ocean liner, the top of Pike's Peak, the bottom of a coal mine, from Navy airplanes and a submarine, and from two fast streamlined railroad trains -- one in this country and the other in Germany -- are among the microphone pick-ups to be attempted on Sunday in what is described as the "most elaborate special events program in the history of radio."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP). -- Late returns from Tuesday's election emphasized today the epochal endorsement of Roosevelt policies at the polls. With final tabulations being slowly accumulated, the total popular vote reached 41,872,227.

A line was waiting outside the entrance of THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair in the International Building, Rockefeller Center, yesterday when the doors were opened to the public at noon, following the official opening by Mayor La Guardia on Wednesday evening.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Nov. 5. -- Minister of Finance Souza Costa challenged speculators today as he inducted Luiz Piza Sobrinho of Sao Paulo, former Secretary of Agriculture, into the office of president of the National Coffee Department, which directs Brazil's coffee business, the basis of the nation's economy.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 5. -- All buses operated in urban transportation in New Jersey by the Public Service Coordinated Transport are gas-electric drive vehicles, engineers of the company said tonight in explaining why the interiors of these buses are free of fumes.

BOSTON, Nov. 5 (AP). -- The Massachusetts Parole Board cleared the way today for George E. Gilbert, 41, to resume the "model life" he lived in California for four years until an amateur sleuth discovered that he was an escaped convict.

Miss Eleanor Carroll, formerly associate editor of the Delineator, has been appointed assistant professor in the Columbia University School of Journalism, it was announced yesterday by Dean Carl W. Ackerman. Miss Carroll, a graduate of Wellesley College in 1919, holds a Master of Science degree from the Columbia School of Journalism in 1924.

The October New York County grand jury, which was held over to continue its investigation into the serviceability of the Criminal Courts Building, in which the grand jurors convene, reported yesterday its findings to Judge John J. Freschi in General Sessions.

MOSCOW, Nov. 5. -- President Roosevelt's stupendous victory is interpreted here as a victory for moderate liberalism, by which, in the words of the newspaper Pravda's New York correspondent, the President, "a true and loyal servant of his class, became more than he expected -- and more even than he wished to be -- a symbol of bourgeois democracy in the struggle with Fascist reaction."

The American Rolling Mill Company, in its financial statement as of Sept. 30, announced yesterday consolidated net earnings of $2,063,603 for the third quarter of the year, after deductions for depreciation, interest and Federal taxes, but not including provisions for the Federal undistributed profits tax.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

SHANGHAI, Friday, Nov. 6. -- Another terroristic anti-Japanese attack in the Hongkew area of this city, expected daily since three sailors were shot on Sept. 23, occurred last night when Shigeru Kagoshima, a civilian, was stabbed.
READING, England, Nov. 5 (AP). -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh took to the air as pilot of his own machine today for the first time since he came to Europe.

All most people will remember of what happened in Tuesday's election are that the President polled the largest vote ever given to a candidate in the United States, carried 46 of the 48 States, increased his 1932 vote by more than 6 millions, had a majority over Mr. Landon of about 11 millions and carried into office with him an increased party majority in Congress.

PARIS, Nov. 5. -- A prediction that the three great democracies -- France, Great Britain and the United States -- are on the verge of great prosperity but a warning that such prosperity must have wide distribution among the lower income brackets was voiced today at a luncheon of the American Club of Paris by Sir Robert M. Kindersley, a director of the Bank of England.

In the broadest and most active market since Feb. 19, stocks were bid up yesterday to new high levels in the recovery from the depression. Nation-wide optimism for continued strong improvement in trade and industry encouraged a steady stream of buying orders from all parts of the country; there was a not inconsiderable demand from London and Paris, much more so, apparently, than on Wednesday.

The total of money in circulation in the country rose $76,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the Federal Reserve reports published yesterday. This increase, which was more than 50 per cent greater than the normal seasonal expectancy for the period of $48,000,000, lifted the circulation figures to a new high record for normal times at $6,378,000,000, or $624,000,000 above the level of a year ago.

Thomas E. Dewey, special rackets prosecutor, declined yesterday to intervene in the seamen's strike, after a conference with John M. Franklin, president of the International Mercantile Marine Company, who had charged that the "sit-down" protest here was engineered and directed by "racketeers" and Communist groups of "terrorists."

Efforts to obtain the early enactment at the next session of Congress of a new food, drug and cosmetic bill were pledged yesterday by Senator Copeland at a conference dealing with this legislation at the Bar Association and attended by seventy representatives of the food industry.

For the second consecutive day since the re-election of President Roosevelt, stocks, bonds and commodities soared yesterday. The rise was aided by favorable dividend announcements by twenty-two large corporations, which declared increased or extra payments to stockholders, or resumed distributions after a lapse of several years.

SO Burleigh Grimes has signed a one-year contract to manage the Brooklyn Dodgers. Then who is going to handle the team next season? According to recent baseball history, when a Dodger manager has a year to go on a contract they generally pay him off in advance and hire somebody else to take his place.

GETAFE, Spain, Nov. 5 (AP). -- Insurgent troops here today took a day's rest only five miles from Madrid, their objective, their leaders stating they believed the capital's defenders were ready to yield with little or no resistance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- R. Walton Moore, Assistant Secretary of State, will be appointed by President Roosevelt as Acting Secretary of State during the absence of Secretary Hull with the American delegation to the Inter-American Peace Conference at Buenos Aires, it was ascertained from reliable sources today.

ALBANY, Nov. 5. -- Governor Lehman returned to Albany today to face an impromptu reception that had been planned while his train was speeding along the Hudson River. Just before 11 o'clock word was sent to every State department in the Capitol, State Office Building and State Education Building that the Governor was due at 11:15.

HYDE PARK, Nov. 5. -- In bidding a jovial good-bye to about 200 residents who gathered to see him depart tonight for Washington, President Roosevelt said that he was "going back to Washington to try to balance the budget, thereby carrying out the first of the campaign pledges."

Under the Federal Social Security Act the wage-earner is the victim of a payroll tax for a government revenue pool that represents "the most colossal pork barrel ever conceived by any one," in the opinion of R. Smith Payne, chairman of the New York State Employers Conference.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP). -- The capital began making plans today for its first mid-Winter Presidential inauguration, to be held on Jan. 20.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 5 (AP). -- Hamp Draper, Chief of the State Convict Department, said that at least ten convicts at Kilby Prison escaped tonight after seizing the power plant and plunging the prison into darkness for forty-five minutes.
After a light day on Wednesday, because of its obvious weariness, the Fordham squad took the field yesterday and ran through a two-hour drill on Rose Hill with a zest which bespoke its rejuvenation.

A dinner and dance were given for Fulvio Suvich, recently appointed Italian Ambassador to Washington, and Mrs. Suvich last night in the Jade and Basildon Rooms of the Waldorf-Astoria by the Italy America Society and the American Society of Royal Italian Orders.

A further rise occurred in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday under a steady demand from both foreign and domestic consumers and the list ended with a gain of 9 to a loss of 6 points. The December was the strongest position and went to a premium of 10 points over July.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Nov. 5. -- As the result of a survey made by Mayor E.B. Collins which indicated that this city may be out of many essential supplies at the end of thirty days, the Fairbanks Chamber of Commerce has adopted resolutions protesting against the closing of the Alaska Railroad.

We have scarcely begun to realize the extent of the Roosevelt sweep. It grows from hour to hour and no one can say where it will stop. It now appears that in addition to forty-six States in this country the President has carried Great Britain, where his victory is deemed inspiring.

A strong foreign demand for dollars with which to buy securities in this country drove the principal foreign exchanges down again yesterday. The pound sterling fell to $4.87 5/8, the lowest since May 15, 1935, in spite of intervention by the British Equalization account.

Pastors will preach Armistice Day sermons tomorrow deprecating war. Peace Sabbath will be observed today in the synagogues and tomorrow in the churches. This observance will be a prelude to the Armistice Day celebration to be held Wednesday evening in Madison Square Garden under the auspices of the Emergency Peace Campaign.
Mr. Block, in commenting upon the complaint, said:

Four new playgrounds, one new recreation building and two renovated buildings will be opened today by the city Park Department, making 184 new playgrounds opened since the beginning of the present administration, the department announced yesterday.

DETROIT, Nov. 6. -- About 8,000 dealers, from every part of the United States and Canada and many from foreign countries, were in Detroit today as guests of Henry and Edsel Ford and the Ford Motor Company, for the presentation of the Ford V-8 1937 models.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 6. -- Canceling an airplane reservation to Washington which he had made the previous day with the announced intention of leaving unless there was "willingness" on the part of strikers and employers to negotiate further toward new agreements, Assistant Secretary of Labor Edward F. McGrady turned his immediate attention today to the warehouse strike and efforts to untangle it.

Following two days of steady improvement, prices on the Cotton Exchange eased 4 to 9 points yesterday, influenced by a report that the American Cooperative Association placed the indicated crop at 12,300,000 bales. Strength of the December delivery, however, tended to sustain the balance of the list, which felt hedging pressure and closed at the low figures.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today summaries of twenty-five registration statements filed recently under the Securities Act of 1933, including one by the Ohio Associated Telephone Company of Erie, covering $1,770,000 of first mortgage bonds, 4 1/2 per cent series, due in 1966, to be used for refunding.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- Spurred on by President Roosevelt's huge vote, organized labor groups and certain business leaders who favor some form of government-labor-industry cooperation began laying plans today for instigating independent legislation in the next Congress designed to deal with the nation's outstanding economic and industrial problems.

In addition to its regular newsreel program this week, the Embassy Theatre is presenting a Columbia short, "Krazy Kat's Newsreel," in which the cartoon character does imitations of such newsreel commentators as Lowell Thomas, Lew Lehr, Ed Thorgersoson and Louis Vance, the stylist.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6. -- After a lapse of seventeen years, Michigan returns to Franklin Field tomorrow for its fifteenth game with Pennsylvania.

Revere Copper Brass, Inc. and wholly owned subsidiaries reported yesterday for the first nine months of this year a net profit of $1,413,956 after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and surtax and after crediting $182,111 to metal stock reserve account.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6. -- All interests were in the market for supplies of hogs today and, despite heavier receipts than expected, prices advanced 10 to 15 cents to the highest level in more than two weeks. The top was 15 cents higher at $9.80, with the day's average up 10 cents at $9.60.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- The Argentine Republic filed today a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $23,500,000 of sinking-fund external conversion loan 4 1/2, per cent bonds due on Nov. 15, 1971. It was the first of the South American countries to seek, through an offering to the public, to effect a saving in interest rates by providing for the retirement of an outstanding issue.

The Maccabees, soccer champions of Palestine, who play their final contest in this country tomorrow at the Yankee Stadium against a selected combination, were tendered an official farewell at City Hall yesterday by Mayor La Guardia. The Mayor, in return for the city flag of Tel-Aviv, which he had received when the team arrived, gave the players a New York City flag to take back with them.

Steel ingot production in the United States last month totaled 4,545,001 gross tons of steel ingots, the largest volume for any month since August, 1929, according to an announcement yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute. The total for October was exceeded by only seven other months in the history of the steel industry.

Her sleek hull spotless under a new coat of battleship-gray paint and her brightwork glistening in the dull light of a cloudy day, the 10,000-ton "treaty cruiser Indianapolis was the center of activity yesterday at the navy yard in Brooklyn.

Activity in the market for new issues of securities came virtually to a standstill this week, only one municipal loan of $450,000 being offered. This was the smallest volume of new financing for one week in several years. It was attributed in part to the election day holiday and in part to the fact that no important corporate issue registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission became eligible for offering.

After President Roosevelt had declined in Washington yesterday to intervene at present in the maritime strike which has tied up shipping for more than in week in Atlantic, Pacific and Gulf ports, a strike committee here voted for a general strike, effective at last midnight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- Suppression of competition in the women's apparel trade through a merchandising plan and contracts said to have been entered into with more than fifty retailers in larger cities throughout the country is charged in a complaint issued today by the Federal Trade Commission against National Modes, Inc., National Modes Holding Corporation, Inc., and John Block, all of 130 West Thirty-first Street, New York.

PARIS, Nov. 6. -- Senator Jacques Louis Dumesnil, a former Minister of Marine, succeeded in the Senate today in exciting to a frenzy the hitherto smoldering feeling of the Opposition toward the Blum Popular Front regime.
AVILA, Spain, Nov. 6. -- Generalissimo Fancisco Franco has made the most minute plans for the immediate replacement of the officials in Madrid if the Insurgents capture the capital.

Drastic action to stop price cutting in milk here was taken yesterday by Burt W. Miller, Deputy State Commissioner of Agriculture, who issued about 300 subpoenas ordering milk dealers and grocers to appear in the Milk Control office in the State Building to explain the apparent infraction of the law.
Scattered sales and leasehold deals in Manhattan were reported yesterday.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 6 (AP). -- Beating back along the comeback trail after two straight defeats, Duquesne's Night Riders overwhelmed the Washington University Bears, 26 to 0, tonight before 14,000 fans.
The Francisco Sugar Company has advised the Exchange that the time for depositing 7 1/2 per cent bonds pursuant to the plan of reorganization dated July 15 last has been extended to Nov. 30.

The Roosevelt Construction Company, Alexander Seclow, attorney, has sold a new three-story, thirteen-Family house at 34 Kensington Avenue, between Bergen Avenue and Hudson Boulevard, Jersey City. The buyer, the Kenton Holding Company, Frederick C. Henn, attorney, gave in part payment an eight-room house at 419 Summit avenue, Jersey City, and a two-family dwelling at 17 Roosevelt Avenue, Jersey City.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 6. -- New York City's $225,000,000 Delaware River water project passed its first major legal test today when Supreme Court Justice Frederick P. Close granted the city's motion for appointment of commissioners of appraisal.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Nov. 6. -- Watersplash, a 4-year-old filly racing for Childs and Walker, won the Viking Claiming Stakes, a mile and a furlong event, by a length and a half from Don Guzman today at Narragansett Park.

Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State Chairman, will not leave that office until after his return from Europe about the middle of December. Accompanied by Mrs. Eaton, he will sail today for a brief stay on the French Riviera.

Thomas Cochran, partner in the banking firm of J.P. Morgan Co., who died on Oct. 29, last, named as his principal beneficiaries his brother, sister and sister-in-law. They share equally in his residuary estate and in trusts totaling $800,000.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday at City Hall that he would name a fact-finding committee today to survey conditions in motion picture theatres in this city with the object of settling difficulties responsible for the recent tear-gas bombing in certain houses.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Nov. 6. -Edward Ballard of French Lick Springs, Ind., circus promoter and hotel operator, was shot dead here this afternoon by Robert Alexander of Detroit, former partner of Ballard in a Miami venture, who then shot himself fatally.

Continued sharp gains in Winter apparel volume featured retail trade here this week. The apparel increases, while not as heavy percentage-wise as was the case last week due to comparison with good sales figures last year, ranged up to 25 per cent or more over the comparative 1935 period.

MADISON, Wis., Nov. 6. -- A second sweeping indictment charging twenty major oil companies, four subsidiaries and forty-six individuals with violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Act in the gasoline business in ten Midwestern States was returned by a Federal grand jury here late today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP). -- In the midst of speculation about possible alterations in the Social Security Act by the new Congress, the government practically completed arrangements today to begin the listing of old-age pension accounts for 26,000,000 workers ten days hence.

For the past forty years I have been connected with the game of football as player, prep school coach and just plain spectator, so I believe I can lay claim to a knowledge of conditions in the sport. Football today, no matter what explanations are offered, is, in most colleges, on a thoroughly commercialized basis.

Donna Matilde Suvich, wife of Fulvio Suvich, new Italian Ambassador to the United States, was the guest of honor at a luncheon given yesterday in the Assembly Suite of the Waldorf by La Margherita Society, of which the Marchesa delle Chuise is president.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6. -- Corn held the limelight in the grain markets on the Board of Trade today, prices soaring 13/5 to 2 1/8 cents a bushel, with the $1 quotation returned to the blackboard on the December delivery for the first time since Aug. 19.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

RIO JANEIRO, Nov. 6. -- News that President Roosevelt had definitely decided to visit Buenos Aires to open the Pan-American Peace Conference spread like wildfire throughout this city, relegating Spain's' war news to a secondary place.

Magistrate Aureli0 in Tomb's Court held two motor-truck drivers for the grand jury on felony charges yesterday on complaints that they had transported into this city from Pennsylvania "bootlegged coal," dug by otherwise unemployed miners.

The local Works Progress Administration will begin next week "a survey of the present need of employment of all WPA employes who have certified as eligible for relief," it was announced yesterday by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, WPA Administrator.
The impressive forces of the New York Police Department and the majesty of the law were stirred to motion yesterday to avenge an insult to a hat.
BERLIN, Nov. 6. -- The German Government floated today another public loan, amounting to 500,000,000 marks, "for further execution of the tasks assumed by the Reich."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- Washington gave President Roosevelt a "home-coming" ovation today. It jammed the route from his train to cheer him on his first appearance in the capital after his landslide election triumph. Estimates of the crowds ranged from 150,000 to 300,000.

Gains once more were the rule among local commodity futures yesterday for the third successive day since the election, although certain staples were set back slightly by profit-taking normal after fairly extensive advances. On the cash markets, wheat and cotton declined, while rye, print cloths, rubber and copper made new highs and corn, cocoa, coffee, lard and eggs advanced.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 6. -- Following last week's surprising tie with Harvard, the Princeton football team will attempt a comeback tomorrow in Palmer Stadium against the strongly manned sophomore eleven from Cornell.

The five Magistrates Courts in Queens will be redistricted Dec. 1, when one court will become a felony court and another a traffic court, according to an announcement yesterday by Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr.

The lure of Johann Sebastian Bach's music was again evident last night at the New School for Social Research when the second in a series of six concerts devoted to his works attracted another capacity assemblage. The series, which embraces rarely heard as well as familiar works of Bach, is being sponsored by the WPA Federal Music Project.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- Manufacturers, shippers and freight bureaus joined hands today in protesting to the Interstate Commerce Commission against proposed permanent increases in a large number of class and commodity freight rates through which the railroads hope to avoid a loss of about $100,000,000 a year because of the expiration on Jan. 1 of emergency surcharges.

For the third time in his life Morris Sweetwood, former partner of Mannie Kessler, once known as "king of bootleggers," heard himself sentenced yesterday in Federal court to a term in prison for his illicit dealings in liquor.

The persistent advance in United States Government bonds again was the feature of trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. No less than eighteen of the Treasury's long-term issues went to new record high levels on net gains of 1-32 to 12-32 of a point.

New York's first television performance of a complete program planned for entertainment value as well as a demonstration of progress in the art of telecasting was flashed across Manhattan yesterday afternoon.

Four properties in Kings, Queens and Richmond, all assets of title and mortgage guarantee companies in rehabilitation or liquidation, have been sold by the State Insurance Department, it was announced yesterday.

Football activity begins tapering off in the Eastern prep school ranks today, for a few teams, notably Lawrenceville and Mercersburg, will come to the end of the 1936 trail a week earlier than most of the other major elevens. Both those schools will culminate their schedules with important contests, which are among the headline attractions on the day's program.

Higher prices for cattle and hogs lifted The Annalist Weekly Index of Wholesale Commodity Prices 0.6 point, the index rising to 127.9 last Monday, from 127.3 on the Tuesday previous. Beef, eggs, cocoa, potatoes, wool, lead, tin and rubber also advanced, while losses were reported for the grains except barley, flour, hams and pork, butter, coffee, apples, bananas, sugar, cotton and gasoline.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 6. -- Yale outscored Penn, 25 to 6, in an intercollegiate 150-pound game today. All Yale's scoring came in the first half on touchdowns by Paul Wargo, who tallied twice, and Berger and Gary, and McCrary kicked one goal following a touchdown.

J.J. Lordi of the New York Athletic Club, one of the seeded players and who holds high rank in Class A, met with a surprise yesterday in the invitation squash tennis tournament at the Princeton Club when he barely escaped defeat at the hands of E.P. Field Jr. of the Princeton Club.

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 6. -- Dartmouth's football team went through its usual light Friday workout today, the final practice for the Columbia game tomorrow. A near capacity crowd of 11,000 is expected, including the Fall house party guests.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- James A. Farley will remain in the new Roosevelt Cabinet until the administration's legislative program is enacted, one of the President's advisers said today.

LONDON, Nov. 6. -- Great activity in tin shares was the principal development today on the London Stock Exchange following announcement of the production agreement with Siam. Tin issues went forward briskly while the price of the metal rose for both cash and forward delivery.

A proposal to petition the Interstate Commerce Commission to continue temporarily the freight surcharges due to expire on Dec. 31 was discussed yesterday at the annual meeting of the Association of American Railroads in the Biltmore Hotel.

MANHASSET, L.I., Nov. 6. -- Mayor La Guardia and former Governor Alfred E. Smith today visited Cardinal Pacelli, Papal Secretary of State, at Mrs. Nicholas F. Brady's estate here, the Cardinal's headquarters during his month's visit to the United States.
MADRID (Saturday), Nov. 7. -- With the fall of Madrid apparently only a matter of hours, the Leftist government early today definitely decided to abandon the capital.

In the Oriental setting of the Lin Sing Association club rooms, 47 Mott Street, Thomas H. Lee, 32 years old, American-born Chinese, told yesterday how he came to be the first person of Chinese descent to be admitted to the New York bar.
Several housing properties were included in the Brooklyn realty turnover reported yesterday.

Today is "Red Cross Sabbath" in the synagogues and tomorrow will be "Red Cross Sunday" in the churches. The annual roll-call of New York chapter always opens the Sunday before Armistice Day. More than 300 synagogues and churches have planned appeals at today's and tomorrow's services for support of the Red Cross.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 6. -- Anticipating flocks of forward passes and laterals from the University of Virginia eleven which will play in the stadium tomorrow, the Harvard coaches today supplemented the usual Friday signal and kicking drills with another session against all varieties of overhead play.

ANNAPOLIS, Nov. 6. -- The regiment of Midshipmen, from the five-striper in command to the youngest plebe rookie, is back of the Navy team to win from Notre Dame in Baltimore tomorrow. Three defeats in a row have not weakened its loyalty or confidence.
Once again Fordham holds the center of the football spotlight as the Ram defends its unbeaten record against another strong invader in Purdue at the Polo Grounds.

Exports and imports from and into the United States by classified groups in September have been announced by the Department of Commerce; they are here compared with those of the preceding month and with September, 1935. Exports as given in the tables that follow cover only domestic exports, not foreign goods re-exported.

Dictagraph records filed by J. Edward Jones, oil royalties dealer, with Lamar Hardy, United States Attorney, failed yesterday to result in any indictment. The records related to a conversation Mr. Jones said he had had in his office with John J. O'Donnell, special representative of the Democratic National Convention.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 6. -- In speeches here today declaring that the nation must unite to provide funds for welfare work in every locality this Winter, Gerard Swope officially opened the drive of the 1936 Mobilization for Human Needs in 330 cities.

Additional testimony was given yesterday by William B. Joyce, former chairman of the old National Surety Company, in the $20,000,000 accounting suit brought in behalf of creditors against Mr. Joyce and other former officers and directors because of alleged waste of funds in 1932, including the delivery to three banks of securities worth $5,934,967 as collateral on loans to the Natsurco Realty Company, a National subsidiary.

Profit-taking appeared in considerable volume in the stock market yesterday, mainly professional in character, and a little more than offset the fresh buying from various parts of the country and from foreign sources. The closing was irregularly lower.

To the stirring strains of "La Marseillaise" the French Army team last night won the splendid trophy presented by President Arturo Alessandri of the Chilean Republic in the first major military event of the fifty-first annual National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden.
Van Raalte Company, Inc., declared yesterday a dividend of $2 a share on common stock. On Sept. 1 $1 was distributed.

The Chemical Industry Medal for 1936, given "for valuable application of chemical research to industry," was presented last night to Dr. Walter S. Landis, vice president of the American Cyanamid Company, at a joint meeting of the Society of Chemical Industry and the American Chemical Society, held at the Chemists Club, 52 East Forty-first Street.

The fight between truckmen carrying commodities to freight stations and railroads seeking to give shippers free pick-up service was carried into Federal Court yesterday when the Merchant Truckmen's Bureau filed suit against the government, the Interstate Commerce Commission and the nine major railroads operating in the metropolitan area.

ST. JOHNS, Que., Nov. 6. -- The Hudson-Champlain seaway was the chief topic of discussion at the annual meeting of the Champlain Valley Council when the members went into session today as guests of the St. Johns Board of Trade. It was stated by council leaders that the re-election of President Roosevelt greatly enhances the opportunity for favorable discussion and consideration of the seaway plan.
WAHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- The text of the statement made by Secretary Hull to the delegation from the People's Mandate to End War was as follows:

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 6. -- Philip Murray, director of the steel union organization drive, told leaders of John L. Lewis's rebel labor unions, arriving for a meeting tomorrow, that the industry had decided before the Presidential election to increase pay.

There is nothing wrong with using a picture of Santa Claus in connection with holiday liquor sales, in the opinion of Henry E. Bruckman, chairman of the State Liquor Authority. Although the question has not come before the board, Chairman Bruckman gave this as his personal view in discussing the action of some States in prohibiting the use of the figure of Santa Claus in liquor sales.

Beset by a rising tide off resignations from its membership in protest against its action in mailing out to manufacturers and employers a circular on social security a few days before election, the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce denied charges of politics yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- President Roosevelt called upon the nation today to share its "increasing prosperity" with the needy by supporting the 1936 Mobilization for Human Needs.

In discussing the background of American writing last night at THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair in the International Building in Rockefeller Center, John Farrar of Farrar Rinehart, called the newspaper the "common denominator of all American writing backgrounds."

The cold wave that was expected to reach New York has missed this section and, greatly dissipated, centered last night in Northern New England. New York City, with a normal temperature yesterday, may expect little change in temperature today.

The formidable Chicago Bears, tied with the Packers for the Western division lead in the National Football League, will arrive in New York, led by their hard-plunging back, Bronko Nagurski, this morning. They will meet the New York Giants at the Polo Grounds tomorrow.

Among the apartment lessees reported yesterday was Joseph Wilshire, president of Standard Brands Inc., and a resident of Greenwich, Conn. He took a suite of thirteen rooms and six baths in 760 Park Avenue through Albert B. Ashforth Inc. Other rentals were as follows:

A jury in Federal court was ordered locked up for the night at 11 o'clock last night when it had reached no decision on the guilt or innocence of Louis (Lepke) Buchalter and Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro, alleged racketeers accused by the government of having caused a reign of terror in New York's $10,000,000-a-year rabbit skin trade four years ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- The goal of the twenty-one nations participating in the Buenos Aires peace conference will be not alone to banish war from the Western Hemisphere but to establish machinery which will serve as a model for world peace, Secretary Hull said today on the eve of the United States delegation's departure for South America.

In submitting their unification plan to the Transit Commission, Messrs. SEABURY and BERLE estimated that it would result in savings amounting to something like $9,000,000 a year. It is now established, out of the mouth of competent witnesses, on the whole friendly to unification, that there is little hope of realizing any such material gain.
Apropos of Commissioner Mulrooney's recent ruling abolishing gate receipts at Sing Sing football games, won't you please help us to have this order rescinded?
LONDON, Nov. 6. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler's capacity for bunching his hits when doing things that irritate the British is having a fresh demonstration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- British imports of American products in the first nine months of 1936 in so far as they are shown separately, were valued at $276,625,000, or 12 per cent over the first three-quarters of 1935, a report from the American Consulate General in London to the Department of Commerce indicated today.

The strike of 3,400 coal trimmers halting the delivery of between 6,000 and 7,000 tons of coal daily here was ended last night. The workers are expected to return to their jobs today as a result of the agreement of the Coal Trimmers Union and the Coal Merchants Association to submit their dispute to arbitration.

Requests for forms to be filled out under the Social Security Act began pouring into the New York Postoffice yesterday as Postmaster Albert Goldman and his aides made plans to handle the distribution with the least possible delay.

Baby Kate Roosevelt, a new seedling orchid, was named yesterday for President Roosevelt's young granddaughter, who was christened Wednesday at Hyde Park, N.Y. The orchid was on exhibition at the twenty-ninth Annual Autumn flower show of the Horticultural Society of New York, which opened with a private view Thursday night at the American Museum of Natural History, Seventy-ninth Street and Central Park West.

R.A. Julian in a letter to THE TIMES quoted figures from an election poll at the College of the City of New York, and interpreted them as a proof of Communist tendencies among the students. His use of these figures makes it necessary to determine their validity and their right to be called representative of the student body.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- President Roosevelt confessed today that he was a bad political prophet, having erred by 163 electoral votes in estimating the number he would capture in the national election.

A substantial increase in shoe sales for 1937, particularly in quality styles, was predicted yesterday by George Miller of I. Miller Sons, Inc., and president of the Shoe Fashion Guild of America, speaking at that organization's semi-annual luncheon, held in connection with its showing of Spring and Summer lines at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 6. -- Scoring twice in the last three minutes of play, the Lafayette 150-pound football team downed the Princeton lightweights, 19 -- 7, on University Field today.

GETAFE, Spain, Nov. 6. -- It is reliably reported here that 10,000 Civil Guards are being brought up to police Madrid after its capture. Whatever cleaning up is needed, including street fighting, after the Insurgents' entry, will probably be Continued on Page Six

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- Collections on open accounts receivable by department stores were 42.8 per cent for September of this year, compared with 42.1 per cent in the preceding month and 40.6 per cent for September of 1935, according to a report today by the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.

Discussion of the advisability of extending the hours of trading on the Stock Exchange from 3 to 4 P.M. was stimulated yesterday by an announcement that the Los Angeles Stock Exchange had applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission for unlisted trading privileges in seventeen issues listed on local markets.

The Harvard Club team maintained its lead in the Class C competition of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League last night by scoring its fourth victory of the season. The Crimson players swept their match with the Elizabeth Town and Country Club, 5 to 0, to remain unbeaten in the series.

In the first transfer of the property in forty-five years the vacant plot, 50 by 100 feet, on the north side of East 196th Street, between Morris and Creston Avenues, was sold by the Schroeder estate to P. A.D. Rubin, Inc. The buyer plans to improve the site with a six-story apartment house, according to Charles W. Brown, broker.

Society in brilliant array again filled the boxes at the third night of the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden. Representatives of the various hunt sets were in evidence for the parade and contesting of hunt teams.

COOKEVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 6 (AP). -- The question whether the power program of the Tennessee Valley Authority can be tested in a single lawsuit was raised today by Federal attorneys seeking dismissal of such a case brought by 19 private utilities.

Representatives of employer, employe and consumer groups, meeting yesterday in the office of Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, decided that "ways must be found to maintain the economic standards of working women,'' in spite of the invalidation by the Supreme Court of the State minimum wage law.

Led by the steel industry, which announced a graduated increase in wages averaging 10 per cent, large American corporations yesterday materially increased the purchasing power of more than 600,000 employes through pay rises and bonuses.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 6. -- The Essex County Board of Elections, sitting as the County Board of Canvassers, adopted a resolution today under which sealed ballot boxes in certain election districts would be opened and the tally sheets compared with those filed with County Clerk Russell Gates.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- President Roosevelt will not intervene at present in the marine controversy which has crippled shipping on the West Coast, it was announced this evening by Secretary of Labor Perkins.

TOKYO, Nov. 6. -- At a Cabinet meeting today General Count Juichi Terauchi, the War Minister, denied widespread reports that the army seeks to divorce the Cabinet from the Legislature and curtail the powers of the latter.

Radio has elevated political campaigns by "debunking" them and forcing candidates to stick to the campaign issues, Mayor La Guardia told twenty-five foreign radio officials when he welcomed them at City Hall yesterday in connection with the tenth anniversary of the National Broadcasting Company.

LONDON, Nov. 6. -- The Opposition Labor amendment to the government's motion accepting the address from the throne outlining the Cabinet policies and legislative plans was offered to the House of Commons today. The amendment is the prescribed form in which the Opposition launches its attack on the government's program by expressing regret that as outlined by the King it is inadequate in this or that particular.
MADRID, Nov. 6 (Passed by the Censor). -- An intensive bombardment of villages immediately southwest of Madrid by Insurgent heavy artillery began early this morning and was still going on tonight.

With several changes made in the starting line-up during the past week scheduled to remain intact, Coach Benny Friedman will send his City College football team into action against Gallaudet College of Washington at Lewisohn Stadium at 2 P.M. today.

Last June the Radio Corporation of America announced that television was to be taken out of the laboratory into the field, meaning that some scores of receivers were to be distributed in the metropolitan area to televise scenes transmitted from the top of the Empire State Building.

Let it be said in behalf of The Literary Digest that all the scientific prognosticators were wrong. Today we might just as well admit that a statistical election prophet is without honor save in Maine and Vermont. The experts who work with averages and percentages and curves, the cool calculators who brood over trends and subsurface forces, were not much better off than the postcard samplers and sidewalk buttonholers.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 6. -- Yale will present all eleven in which seven changes have been made since the defeat by Dartmouth last Saturday when it faces Brown here tomorrow. The game is the forty-first in a series begun in 1890, in which Yale has won thirty-three and Brown five games and two have been ties.

The American Power and Light Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the year ended Sept. 30 a consolidated net income of $10,161,200. This was equal, after dividends on the $5 and $6 preferred stocks, to almost 17 cents a share on 3.005,454 common shares, compared with $6,923,129, or almost $3.91 a share on the combined preferred stocks, in the preceding year.

Directors of the B.F. Goodrich Company approved yesterday a proposal to refinance the company's mortgage debt and to increase working capital through the issuance of $27,000,000 of 4 1/4 per cent first mortgage bonds, due in 1956. The issue will be underwritten by a banking group headed by Goldman, Sachs Co.

BERLIN, Nov. 6. -- The Boerse recovered today. It is a peculiarity of government-influenced markets in Germany that they always show strength on the day a Reich loan is announced. Records show that every statement of a government loan since 1933 was followed by a rising, though not a very active, Boerse.

Whether it is real or fancied, competition from trailers has begun to attract the attention of hotels throughout the country, and an educational advertising campaign is now under consideration by the American Hotel Association, reports here yesterday indicated.

A five-room apartment in Astoria, Queens, was empty last night after five children, the eldest 12 years old, had tried for days to keep it going without their parents. Neighbors, who fed the children and got the three oldest off to school each day, gave up the struggle, and yesterday the brothers and sisters were taken into custody by the Queens Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 6. -Robert Taylor has signed a new seven-year contract with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer under which he will receive $2,000 a week, with the sum graduating to $5,000 for the last two years. While the customary maneuvering was indulged in by the studio, the actor's agents experienced less than ordinary resistance to the increase.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 6. -- The Committee on Budgets and Appropriations of the Westchester Board of Supervisors submitted today departmental budget requests for 1937 totaling $12,372,860, or $1,451,585 more than this year's budget.

New York State has registered pluralities of more than one million one hundred thousand for President Roosevelt and more than six hundred, thousand for Governor Lehman, and at the same time has elected enough Republicans to give the Republican party a majority of one in the Assembly.

ONE of the illustrations in "The Autobiography of G.K. Chesterton" (Sheed Ward, $3) shows the author at the age of 6. Long wavy hair hangs down over the shoulders of a child in sailor suit; upon the face is an expression of sweet and confiding hope. Another illustration shows the author at the age of about 60, shortly before he died.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Both Sophie Treadwell and Henry Hull have a respect for Edgar Allan Poe that verges on awe in "Plumes in the Dust," which was acted at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre last evening. She is the author of this three-act sketch of the life of America's most singular genius, and he acts the raven-headed poet whom disaster followed like one of the Furies.
GLEN COVE, L.I. Nov. 6. -- The eighth annual Nassau Country Club invitation squash racquets tournament got under Way tonight and five players advanced to the third round.

A complete sell-out in less than three weeks of the entire 25,000 copy edition of "U.S. Camera -- 1936," is reported by William Morrow Co. The edition will not be reprinted. This year's edition was almost twice as large as that of 1935, also a sell-out.

WASCHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- President Roosevelt today personally confirmed his hope of attending the peace conference opening session, and a short time later Hugh Gibson, American Ambassador to Brazil, said that Mr. Roosevelt had definitely decided to go and would stop at Rio de Janeiro Nov. 26 on his way to Argentina.
DETROIT, Nov. 6. -- Sixty-seven thousand employes of the Chrysler Corporation will receive a bonus of $4,000,000 in December, the third such distribution this year, company officials announced today.
Bank exchanges in October totaled $28,511,682,865, an increase of 8.4 per cent over September, and 8.3 per cent over October, 1935. The turnover was the largest since last March.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6. -- Wage agreements signed by Carnegie-Illinois Steel Company today involve employes at three of its plants in the Chicago district, as well as plants in the Pittsburgh district. The plants affected here are the South Chicago works with about 14,000 employes, the Gary works with 15,000 and the Joliet plant with 700.

New York University's football team will clash with Carnegie Tech this afternoon at the Yankee Stadium in the eleventh game of the series which started in 1926. The Violet holds the edge with ten victories to two for the Plaid. The opening kick-off is scheduled for 2 P.M.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 6. -- The fight between George A. Slater, Republican incumbent, and William J. Sheils, Democrat, for election as Surrogate of Westchester County was still deadlocked tonight with both sides claiming the victory.

A plea to all members of the Veterans of Foreign Wars and the American Legion to support the fight of war veterans employed in the Emergency Relief Bureau against their clasification as competitive Civil Service employes will be made as the result last night of a meeting of the ERB War Veterans Association.

Coincident with the declaration of an extra dividend of 75 cents a share and the regular semi-annual distribution of 50 cents a share, the directors of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey yesterday announced the distribution of about $4,500,000 as extra compensation to employee from 1936 earnings.

Staving off a desperate goalward rush by the home eleven in the last four minutes of a keenly fought contest, St. John's Prep turned almost certain defeat into victory and the Brooklynites topped the Horace Mann School for Boys, 7 -- 6, at Horace Mann Field yesterday.

The progress of trade was uneven this week, with retail distribution fluctuating with the vagaries of the weather, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. In those districts where snow and cold prevailed distribution widened steadily, but the lag in other parts of the country held the gain to 1 to 3 per cent over the level reached in the preceding week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- Revival of activity in the automobile trade and further expansion in the coal industry, which resulted in the extra seasonal rise in freight traffic, were influencing factors in general business conditions in October, the Department of Commerce reported today in its survey of business for October.

Generally contributing 20 to 25 per cent of the total, manufacturing is the largest source of the national income, according to a study just published by the National Industrial Conference Board. In 1935, the board announced yesterday, receipts from manufacturing in salaries, wages, dividends, interest and other payments were estimated at $12,000,000,000.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 6. -- Yale won from both Harvard and Princeton and Harvard defeated Princeton in varsity cross-country today. In the freshman race the Crimson conquered both rivals and the Tigers beat the Elis. There were twenty-seven starters in the varsity and twenty-four in the freshman meet.

MOSCOW, Nov. 6. -- Joseph Stalin in the flesh tonight belied the recent series of foreign rumors of his illness and death and of rivalry among his chief aides for his mantle. He appeared in his usual health and vigor at a huge mass meeting opening the celebration of the Soviet Union's revolutionary anniversary at the Bolshoi Theatre.

LONDON, Nov. 6. -- The international effort to take the horror from submarine warfare was carried a stage further this morning when the protocol laying down rules for the conduct of submarines was signed on behalf of all signatories of the Washington Naval Treaty of 1922.

A dispute between adult WPA students and regular vocational school pupils as to which was rightfully entitled to the use of classrooms in the New York School of Industrial Arts at 257 West Fortieth Street was virtually settled yesterday afternoon at a meeting of Board of Education and WPA officials at the board's headquarters, 500 Park Avenue.

PARIS, Nov. 6. -- Premier Lon Blum followed up his attack against public figures unsympathetic to his government by forcing the resignation today of Francois Latour, Assistant Commissaire-General of the 1937 Paris Exposition.

HAVANA, Nov. 6. -- President Gomez this afternoon broadcast a message to the Americas over an international radio hook-up concerning the coming Pan American peace conference at Buenos Aires. The President said:

BALTIMORE, Nov. 6. -- Largely because of his decisive victory in the Washington Handicap at Laurel, the old campaigner Roman Soldier looms as the favorite tomorrow in the $7,500 added Riggs Handicap, distance feature at Pimllco. He is top weight of the field of ten with 122 pounds and is reported recovered from the soreness which followed his previous start.
