WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- Disposition to the highest bidders for forty-eight issues of municipal securities listed in today's NEW YORK TIMES was announced today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. The bonds thus sold had a combined face value of $2,284,500 and brought a premium of $81,224, representing an average price of more than 103.55, according to the RFC.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Nov. 6. -- Public schools of this city of 70,000 population closed this afternoon in compliance with a Board of Education order which followed defeat of a 3-mill special levy at Tuesday's election.

Connecticut gunners report the arrival of one of the heaviest flights of woodcock in years. The gamekeeper of a preserve near New Haven says the long-billed timber-doodles were "whistling all over the place" as the flight came in last Monday night.

Pledging itself to even greater efforts toward human service in the years to come, the New York chapter of the American Red Cross yesterday celebrated its thirtieth anniversary. A capacity audience of about 500 men and women filled the chapter house at 315 Lexington Avenue to hear speakers extol the Red Cross as "a glorious symbol of humanity'' and a movement deserving "the fullest support" of the community.

Professor Turner, public health authority of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who has just returned from a visit to twenty-five foreign lands, is quoted as saying that all nations are now vigorously pursuing health education and stressing proper food as the first weapon in the prevention of diseases of body and mind.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 6. -- Hun School's football team, unbeaten and untied this season, scored its fourth straight victory today by swamping the Pennsylvania Military College freshmen of Chester, Pa. The score was 52 to 0.

Nobody can surely analyze the motives of great masses of voters, but some of the considerations that may have contributed to the continuance and increase of confidence in the President may be suggested:

WASHINGTON, Saturday, Nov. 7. -- J. Edgar Hoover, head of Federal agents, announced early today that Representative John H. Hoeppel of California and his son, Charles, had been arrested at Richmond, Va.

GETAFE, Spain, Nov. 6. -- This writer has visited the Getafe battlefield, where the center of the defense was a ridge west of the town from where trenches ran for miles to the east and west, making a flanking movement impossible.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 6 (AP). -- The weather had moderated considerably and a fair crowd was on on hand for the racing at Churchill Downs today. There was a great deal of interest displayed for tomorrow's running of the Kentucky Jockey Club's stakes.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6. -- With Leopold Stokowski conducting, the Philadelphia Orchestra presented at the Academy of Music today the Third symphony in A minor by Sergei Rachmaninoff, heard for the first time anywhere.

Until recently football coaches had been known as the most lugubrious of all gentlemen. No matter how good their teams were or whom they were playing they practically conceded defeat before the game and if victory occurred, as was generally expected, the winning coaches appeared surprised.

LONDON, Nov. 6. -- Charlie Brown, known to countless thousands of Americans as chief carver of Simpson's in the Strand retires tomorrow after fifty-eight years of presiding in London as dean of the carving blades.

A revised Manhattan eleven will face the University of Kentucky, which is invading the East for the first time, in an intersectional battle at Ebbets Field today. A crowd of more than 15,000 is expected to attend the game, which will start at 2 P.M.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 6. -- Pingry School took to the air in the second half today and defeated the Newark Academy eleven, 12-7. It was the final contest of the season for the Newarkers, who won three out of five games.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 -- Thanks to the Louvre and Musee de Pau in Paris, to more than half a score of important museums and art galleries in this country, and to numerous private collectors both American and European, it has been possible to put together a superb exhibition of the work of the great nineteenth-century French artist, Edgar Degas, which will open to the public tomorrow at the Pennsylvania Museum.

The Lutheran Church of St. James, which has stood at the southwest corner of Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street for almost fifty years, and of which the Rev. Dr. Charles Trexler is the pastor, "is in imminent danger of closing its doors," according to an announcement made at the church yesterday.

Indication that the reduction in the basic Pullman fare on June 1 from 3.6 cents a mile, plus a surcharge which brought the rate to about 4 cents, to 3 cents a mile stimulated this form of travel is provided in a statement issued by Pullman, Inc., yesterday.

The British Great War Veterans of America gave their annual Armistice Ball last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Patrons included many men and women prominent in official, civic and social circles, as well as high ranking officers in various branches of the service and heads of many British organizations here.

Four more attractions are going the way of temporal things after giving their last performances today. Oldest -- in fact, dating back to last Spring -- is "New Faces," which leaves the Vanderbilt after playing 192 times in a quarter of a dozen editions.

BOSTON COLLEGE vs. North Carolina State -- Guessing a football result in advance is merely a matter of figuring out the proper relativity. That seems to call for Dr. Einstein. In his absence, one light vote for Boston College.

Mr. and Mrs. Hubert G. Larson entertained at dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Mr. and Mrs. Frederick D. Suydam, Mr. and Mrs. John W. Davis Jr., Mr. and Mrs. James Burns Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Chapin Dearden of Merion, Pa.; Mr. and Mrs. Philip P. Smith of Ardmore, Pa.; Norman Grant and Parker Morrell.
Fordham's annual stumbling block, Purdue, confronts the unbeaten Rams today and a deft clearance of the obstacle by the mighty Maroon will bring into closer focus the picture of an undefeated season.

For some years baiting the chairman of the New York State committee has been a favorite amusement of one section or another of the Republican party. Each new holder of the office got from different sources the same store of maledictions. It seems a little queer that anybody could be found to take so uncomfortable a post.

Local field hockey enthusiasts will have a chance to see two of the international teams which competed the past fortnight in the third third Triennial International Conference at Philadelphia in action against district association players this afternoon.

P. Polumbaum, executive vice president of the American Sumatra Tobacco Company, received for the fiscal year ended on July 31, last, a salary of $44,333, the company's annual report to the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed yesterday.

The new revenue law which taxes corporations is mainly criticized on the ground that if profits are not plowed back into new factories, then new jobs will be cut off at the source. But will the law have that effect?

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $18,826,220 for fifty-four municipalities, against a revised figure of only $12,199,513 this week. The weekly average this year stands now at $27,241,051.

Something spectacular in the way of special added attractions will be offered at the French Casino next Sunday evening with the introduction of none other than Rudy Vallee and his Connecticut Yankees as makers of dance music and entertainment at the supper show.
WARRENTON, Va. -- The Middleburg Race Meeting will be held on the Glenwood course next Wednesday and Saturday. Two hundred or more horses are expected to compete.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 7 (AP). -- Stopped on the ground, Villanova passed to a 14-to-0 success over South Carolina today to make its record six victories and one loss.

IT has become platitudinous to remark that English novelists, no matter how much or how little they have to say, have a prose style that is agreeable and fluid. Mr. Speaight's manner of writing carries on his countrymen's tradition, and while his style is never brilliant, it is never careless or jarring.

ROME, Nov. 7. -- It is understood that, when the Chamber of Deputies convenes this month-end, its President, Admiral Costanzo Ciano, will announce that Marie Jose of Piedmont, wife of the heir to the Italian throne, is expected to give birth to a child in January.

AUTOMOTIVE research has reached the stage of exact science. By research, I refer more particularly to the research through which the trends of public preference are determined. Later comes the research work in the laboratories, the experimental departments and the proving grounds.

LAST Sunday Transcontinental and Western Air, operating between New York and Los Angeles, with a branch into Chicago, cut its rates drastically. In announcing the cut Jack Frye, president of the company, pointed out that since TWA operated the shortest route between the coasts it was perfectly reasonable for the company to charge less for its transportation.

WHILE Hamlet and Laertes, the Montagues and Capulets are busy thrilling Broadway theatregoers these days with their duels to the death, a flock of fencers of much different ilk are polishing their blades in preparation for the opening of the annual season of the Amateur Fencers League of America this week.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Nov. 7. -- New emphasis is being placed on week-end activities at Bryn Mawr College, with the result that fewer students are spending their week-ends at home than at any previous time in the recent history of the institution.

MUNICH, Germany, Nov. 7 (AP). -- On the eve of the commemoration of Adolf Hitler's "beer cellar putsch" thousands of Germans paid homage tonight to the sixteen Nazis who lost their lives in that unsuccessful uprising.

A YEAR has passed since the Motor Carrier Act of 1935 officially became effective: Some of the provisions of the motor carrier law, placing regulation of interstate operation of motor trucks under the jurisdiction of the Federal Government, are still not being enforced. Indications however, are that, within another month or two, all requirements provided for in the act will be in full force and effect.

HANOVER, N. H., Nov. 7. -- Dartmouth College held its annual Fall house parties today, with 577 guests attending from many States and colleges. Dances were held in fraternity houses until an early hour this morning, and were resumed again tonight to climax the weekend.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 7. -- Thanks principally to Captain Larry Kelley, who twice distinguished himself in grand style in the first half, Yale conquered the courageous and stubborn Brown football forces by 14 to 6 today before 10,000 spectators in the Bowl, but, as subsequent developments proved, the Elis were somewhat lucky to win.

Before and after the National Horse Show opened last Wednesday, 20,000 unexhibited horses went about their business in the five boroughs. At least that is the total reported in the latest survey by the A.S.P.C.A. The trend is toward more riding animals and fewer for draught, so that the city's horse population now remains fairly constant.

Mrs. Lowe Fiske heads the group in charge of the campaign for $50,000 to be inaugurated this month by members of the Cooperative Committee of the Big Sisters, an organization comprising the Catholic, Jewish and Protestant Big Sisters.

Twenty-two seniors in Columbia College have been named to the "Hall of Fame" of the Columbian, annual student publication, for outstanding contributions to extra-curricular activities, it was announced yesterday.

When a girl who has longed all her life to go sea-voyaging finally sets out on a two-week cruise to Newfoundland she counts on the trip to give her something to remember. Susan Jones, a romantic young kindergarten teacher from a little town in New Jersey, found her vacation memorable, but in a different way from what she had expected.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- The third annual conference on labor legislation, to be attended by labor representatives from thirty-nine States and Puerto Rico, will be held in Washington three days beginning Monday, the Labor Department announced today. The object will be to stimulate the raising of labor standards throughout the United States.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 7 (AP). -- The date for the 1937 running of the Kentucky Derby was set for May 8 by Colonel M.J. Winn, executive director of Churchill Downs, today. He made the announcement at a luncheon meeting of the Kentucky State Racing Commission.

HANS FALLADA, best known for "Little Man, What Now?" has temporarily brushed aside the depressing themes with which he once concerned himself and written, of all things, a delightful fairy tale in modern dress.

Tributes will be paid to Childe Hassam, Edwin Howland Blashfield and Edwin Arlington Robinson at the annual meeting of the American Academy of Arts and Letters, 633 West 155th Street, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the academy.

Federal agents, aided by the police, raided the Bodker Specialty Shop, a fur store at 284 Grand Street, Brooklyn, yesterday, seized furs valued at $30,000 and arrested the proprietor, Lewis Bodker, on a charge of conspiracy to violate the National Bankruptcy Act through the concealment of assets.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- An intensive campaign for adoption by the Seventy-fifth Congress of the proposed Equal Rights Amendment to the Constitution will be formulated and launched by the National Woman's party at its biennial convention, which will open Friday at the Hotel Roosevelt in New York.
Against the wishes of Democratic party organizations, the voters of the city last Tuesday approved by an overwhelming margin a new city charter and a system of proportional representation.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 7. -- Stimulated by its strongest showing in more than a quarter of a century at the polls last Tuesday, the Democratic organization of Nassau County announced today plans for solidifying its gains by concentrating on campaign work on an all-year-round basis.

A luncheon will be given tomorrow in the Blue Room of the Hotel Lincoln for the debutante, junior and women's committees active in plans for the all-star amateur heavyweight boxing tournament to be staged by Jack Dempsey at Madison Square Garden on Nov. 23 for the benefit of the West Side Hospital.
BRUNSWICK, Me., Nov. 7. -- The passing combination of Johnny Frye and Dave Fitts accounted for 23 points as Bowdoin retained the State championship with a 14-7 victory over Maine today.

IN the field of music the Mexican revolution is achieving perhaps its most pronounced success. The imitativeness that formerly characterized so much of musical composition is steadily passing, and out of the disappearing mists it is now possible to determine the broad outlines of the new musical spirit that is taking shape.

Down in the South Street saloons and around the East River pierheads, sailors who, fifty years ago, would have been jawing about the merits of an old skysail yarder, or the tough fists of some Down East mate, are now discussing the rights of man.

YANG AND YIN" is the third of a series of four novels designed by Alice Tisdale Hobart to present a picture of Chinese civilization as it has been modified, during the past three or four decades, by the impact of Western ideas.

ANDOVER, Mass., Nov. 7. -- Staving off two last-period touchdown threats the Andover eleven defeated the Tufts Freshmen today, 33-0. Andover registered three touchdowns in the first three minutes of play and is still undefeated and untied and has not been scored upon this season.

VICTOR CHERNOV is one of the arresting and picturesque figures of the Russian revolutionary movement. As the standard bearer of the Socialist Revolutionary party he was for years a bitter enemy of the imperial regime and worked relentlessly for its downfall.

BIRMINGHAM, Nov. 6. -- The landslide which leaves the country temporarily with only one political party may give the South two, in the post-election opinion of some observers. Features significant to the future of the Democratic party in this region are, first, the fact that the party could have won even without the "Solid South," and, second, the fact that the Negro vote in .pivotal States turned Democratic.

The recital to be given by Kirsten Flagstad, soprano of the Metropolitan Opera, on the night of Dec. 9 at Carnegie Hall will benefit the educational department of the New York Women's Trade Union League, which maintains educational and recreational facilities on a scholarship basis for working men and women at the league clubhouse, 247 Lexington Avenue.

MOSCOW, Nov. 7. -- New types of mechanized military equipment, putting all arms on wheels and caterpillar treads, apparently solving the baffling problem of how to build units having extreme mobility and heavy striking power, were disclosed by the Red Army today in the Red Square parade celebrating the nineteenth anniversary of the Bolshevist revolution.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission is proceeding with added assurance, as a result of the sweeping electoral victory of the administration, in the perfection of its program for administering provisions of the two securities acts and the Public Utility Act of 1935.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 7 (AP). -- Sensational last-period touchdowns gave Temple and Michigan State a 7-to-7 tie before 20,000 shrieking fans today.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Nov. 7. -- "The revival of prosperity in the country has been reflected most obviously in this college by the revival of the recreation of riding horseback," President Neilson of Smith College declared at a student assembly when he spoke on new additions to the college.

RADNOR, Pa., Nov. 7. -- Mrs. Taylor Dunn of Radnor introduced to society this afternoon her two daughters, lIiss Elizabeth Dunn and Afiss Alice A. Dunn, at a tea which she gave at the Barclay, Philadelphia.
BIG, roomy, comfortable cars are demanded by the modern American motorist. He has unmistakably indicated his preference and shown a willingness to pay for what he really wants.

No less than the expected happened when the Irish women's field hockey team, which participated in the recent international tournament in Philadelphia, defeated the New York Association eleven, 4 -- 0, on the Fordham University field yesterday.

No doubt a warm welcome awaits President ROOSEVELT if events make it possible for him to visit Buenos Aires on Dec. 1 in order to attend the opening session of the forthcoming Pan-American Peace Conference. The conference is his own work, in the sense that it is the result of personal letters sent by him last February to the heads of all the Latin-American Governments suggesting such a meeting.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 7. -- A touchdown by Rus Lawry in the last two minutes of play gave Boston University a 7-0 victory over Rutgers before a crowd of 5,000 today.

I was interested to read in THE TIMES the review of "St. Helena" and have since seen the play itself. I believe that congratulations are in order to Mr. Gordon for having brought the play to the New York stage. The play in general is quite authentic, and many of its scenes are excellent and sparkling.

A board of survey to serve as a fact-finding and industrial relations committee to correct conditions which have resulted in the tear-gas bombings of motion-picture theatres recently was appointed yesterday by Mayor La Guardia.

Mrs. Mary Childs Draper, chairman of the sponsoring committee for the first annual benefit luncheon of the Peoples Institute-United Neighborhood Guild, to be held on Nov. 17 at the Hotel Astor, announced this week that 500 reservations had been made for the luncheon.

NEXT Wednesday a new National Automobile Show comes to Grand Central Palace. Little outward fanfare marks the event. Doors swing open, people begin to filter in, and after a while great crowds will tm eddying slowly about the exhibits, intent upon examining the newest achievements of the automobile manufacturer's art.
ENGINEERING has done a big job for the motoring public in the 1937 cars. Perhaps one of its biggest accomplishments is that the American automobile of 1937 is a safer car.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 7. -- Led by Bill Guckeyson, the University of Maryland eleven defeated the University of Richmond, 12 -- 0, today.

WHAT is known as the overdrive, as explained by Chrysler engineers, is in effect a fourth gear which automatically comes into action at a predetermined speed of from thirty-five to forty-five miles an hour, depending on the car model in which it is installed.
Returns, not yet complete or official hut ample, indicate that "Question No. 1" -- whether a constitutional convention shall be held in 1938 -- was answered affirmatively by the voters on Tuesday.

Addressing a gathering of 800 parents and educators yesterday in the Hotel Astor, Mayor La Guardia chided those who resort to "misrepresentation, exaggeration and overstatements" in calling attention to public school problems.
STONY BROOK, L.I., Nov. 7. -- The St. Paul's School football team of Garden City vanquished Stony Brook School, 25 to 0, in their annual game today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 7. -- The newly appointed Italian Minister, Mario Indeli, today presented his credentials to Prince Paul, First Regent. They were addressed to the King of Yugoslavia and signed by the King of Italy, not mentioning the title of Emperor of Ethiopia.

GENEVA. -- A draft international agreement to prevent tax evasion is proposed by the League's Fiscal Committee. The committee was led into this field by an Assembly resolution offered by France, whose delegates pointed out that this question is closely related to the whole problem of stabilization, exchange controls and trade barriers.

Brooklyn Tech's first squad won the team honors with a total of 1,019 points in the eleventh annual New York Stock Exchange interscholastic rifle shoot staged yesterday on the Crescent Athletic Club range. The Jamaica High first team placed second with 1,000 and the Abraham Lincoln Firsts third with 986.

Two men, one a paroled convict, were arrested last night on Fifty-fifth Street, near First Avenue, and charged with the murder of R. Walton Ford, 35 years old, an interior decorator, whose body was found last Wednesday morning in his room at the Hotel Sutton, 330 East Fifty-sixth Street.

Unnamed European interests have made under-cover attempts to foster insubordination and reports of disorder in Liberia, the sole remaining independent State in Africa since the Italian occupation of Ethiopia, it was said yesterday by Walter F. Walker, Liberian Consul in New York.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Nov. 7. -- The Port Chester High School eleven assumed undisputed possession of first place in the Westchester Interscholastic A.A. race today by registering a 13 -- 6 victory over A.B. Davis High in a hard-fought game before 2,000 spectators at Howard Field.

DETROIT. DETROIT, as in past seasons, has been, and still is, spending vast sums of money in an effort to make the streets and highways safer for automobile travel. Among the most important projects is the widening of trunk lines leading into the heart of the city.

THIS is a strange autobiography, a book not well written but clearly illustrative of a man's psychological confusion, a kind of case history. Those who have known Edgar Lee Masters's poetry will read it for facts about "Spoon River," for the history of the rise and the fall of a poet's amazing popularity.

The 103d Anniversary Fair of the Orphan Asylum Society of the City of Brooklyn will be held in the Masonic Temple, Clermont and Lafayette Avenues, Nov. 19 and 20. Mrs. Anna E. Brader, president, announced yesterday the names of those who have accepted committee assignments as follows:
LET'S not forge the fundamental meaning of the word automobile in our enthusiasm for the new mechanical marvels introduced at the Automobile Show.

TOKYO, Nov. 7 (AP). -- Anxious to give visiting athletes and foreign spectators the best possible impression of Japanese life at the Olympic Games in 1940, the police have begun a campaign to improve cabarets, dance halls, geisha houses and other places of entertainment.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- President Roosevelt tonight, in an international broadcast, arranged by the National Broadcasting Company, coincident with the scheduled sailing of the American delegation to the Inter-American Peace Conference, expressed the fervent hope that the conference at Buenos Aires would demonstrate to "the war-weary peoples of the world" that "the scourge of armed conflict can and will be eliminated from the Western Hemisphere."

UP to Oct. 1 the Division of Highways of the New York State Department of Public Works received bids or made awards on 165.71 miles of new construction, costing $12,181,696.92, including ninety-nine bridges or separation structures at a bid price of $3,123,041.98.

MOUNDSVILLE, W.Va., Nov. 7 (AP). -- Extra guards were on duty tonight at West Virginia's old vine-clad penitentiary while State police and Federal agents investigated a reported plot to kidnap the warden and liberate two inmates.
Led by the December delivery, which made a new high mark for the week, prices on the Cotton Exchange moved upward sharply yesterday to close with gains of 8 to 11 points.

THERE were always travelers, by land and sea." And "among primitive peoples there has always been friendliness for the stranger." These two sentences, taken together, form the general theme for a book of personal narratives, written by a man who himself has lived among the kind of backgrounds he describes.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 7 (AP). -- The Stillwater Worsted Mills, with plants in this State, Connecticut and Virginia, announced today wage increases running as high as 25 per cent for all workers. The present forty-hour-week will be maintained.

GENEVA, N.Y., Nov. 7. -- The art department of Hobart and William Smith Colleges has opened its season of exhibitions and demonstrations, designed to act as both a "laboratory" to supplement the theory courses and a means of acquainting the community with the work of leading contemporary artists.

MOTORISTS of the United States have been treating the petroleum industry to one of the best of recent years. Benefits have been mutual, and from the standpoint both of industry and customer the conditions scarcely could have been more favorable.

WHEN supporters of the automobile fought for it a third of a century ago, against skepticism, petty legislation and bad roads, they themselves could not foresee how completely the nation would become motorized.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- Why did the radical minority parties, with the possible exception of the Communists, fizzle out so drearily in the 1936 campaign and what will be the effect of the new status of radical movements on the politics of the next four years?

That the real author of the tariff epigram ascribed in his recent Philadelphia speech by Alfred E. Smith to Abraham Lincoln was Robert G. Ingersoll is fairly well known. How the mistaken ascription came to be made is known to only a few even of Lincoln students.

BALTIMORE. VOLUME in traffic here has increased to such a degree during the ten months of the year that city and State officials have been brought face to face with the most serious traffic conditions in the history of the city. During the past three months Mayor Howard W. Jackson and Police Commissioner Charles D. Gaither have reached the conclusion that prompt measures must be taken.

PAWLING, N.Y., Nov. 7. -- Although Pawling outrushed a weaker Hackley football team today, the game ended in a scoreless tie. Hickey and Fernald were outstanding for Pawling on the offense, while Blumenthal, and Stanley excelled on defense.

Theatrical and radio performers have promised to attend the military ball to be held in the Belvedere Room of the Astor on Nov. 14 after the Army-Notre Dame football game. The ball, in which more than 400 cadets from the Military Academy at West Point will participate, is under the auspices of the Guild of the Most Holy Trinity for the benefit of the Catholic chapel at West Point.

UNION, N.J., Nov. 7. -- The search for the persistent vandal who has been daubing police cars, street signs and school walls with paint for the last month ended just before midnight last night at the rear of police headquarters here where a 20-year-old blond girl graduate of Union High School was taken into custody.

BATON ROUGE, La. Nov. 7 (AP). -- Louisiana State University beat down probably the strongest opposition it has faced this season and kept marching toward the Southeastern football title today by whipping Mississippi State, 12 to 0, before 22,000 spectators.

A MOVE toward the reduction of tariffs and the elimination of other trade barriers already under way in many European countries, coupled with the steady improvement in world business, gives definite promise that 1937 will be a banner year for automotive exports.
MADRID, Sunday, Nov. 8. -- Leftist militiamen, fighting off Insurgent forces marching against the capital, massed tanks and guns today to withstand an Insurgent attack expected at dawn.

Corporation Counsel Paul Windels announced yesterday that six commissioners of appraisal have been named by Supreme Court Justice Gilbert V. Schenck at Albany, to determine compensation to be paid by New York City for property in Ulster County to be taken for the city's new water supply system.
LONDON, Nov. 7 (AP). -- Mrs. Wallis Simpson, newly divorced from her British husband, has begun going out again to dinner and the opera.

DETROIT, Nov. 7 (AP). -- The University of Detroit's gridiron Titans smothered a game team of sophomores from Bucknell University, 33 to 7, today, getting three of their five touchdowns through the air.

IN the year 1604 James I, lately come to the throne of England on the death of Elizabeth, called a conference from which resulted the appointment of a company of the most learned men in the kingdom to undertake a new translation of the Bible into the English language.

The 111th anniversary ball of the Old Guard of the City of New York will take place on Jan. 29, at the Commodore. For the nineteenth consecutive year Colonel Edward Havemeyer Snyder, commander of the Old Guard, oldest veterans' organization in the country, is in charge of arrangements for the event.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- The Roosevelt tidal wave this week left only flotsam behind for most of the country's publications or institutions which believe in foretelling public opinion through the method of taking polls or straw votes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- A group of large oil companies, as well as the National Coal Association and the National Bituminous Coal Commission, were among fifty-seven organizations which today filed briefs with the Interstate Commerce Commission opposing proposed permanent increases in a large number of class and commodity freight rates intended to offset losses which the railroads otherwise would suffer as a result of the termination on Jan. 1 of emergency freight rate surcharges.

A pre-opening performance of "Johnny Johnson," a new play with music, by Paul Green, dramatist, and Kurt Weill, European composer, the night of Nov. 16 at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre has been taken over by members of the League of Women Shoppers to raise funds for carrying on the philanthropic projects of that organization.
GASSAWAY, W. Va., Nov. 7 (AP). -- A giant kettle filled with boiling tar exploded in the midst of a group of children today, burning thirteen of them.

LONDON, Nov. 7 (AP). -- General Evangeline Booth, the 71-year-old leader of the Salvation Army, left today for Port Said, Egypt, on the first leg of a five months' world campaign that she will conclude in Chicago and New York next April.

This is a melodramatic and badly written story which is based upon a reliable formula and a fairly good idea. The formula is that of murder within a more or less closed group. The fairly good idea has to do with the murderer and the motive, and cannot be disclosed here.

THE author of "Mary Peters" is possessed of a salty humor as well as a broad and well-balanced understanding. In her book about England the humor is kept engagingly to the fore. But behind the humor lies always a deep sympathy.

WARSAW, Nov. 6. -- When the Polish republic came to life eighteen years ago after the defeat of the Central European empires and after Russia's withdrawal from the World War, the fashionable phrase, "Buffer State" was used for the purpose of defining the place Poland held in European polities, located as she was between Russia and Germany.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- While the "basic construction and replacement plan" authorized by the Vinson-Trammell act to bring the navy up to treaty strength is well under way, Secretary Swanson strongly urged the building up of an adequate fleet auxiliary and Federal support of a merchant marine as a secondary line of defense.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- Nearly $21,000,000 in contracts incorporating Walsh-Healey Act labor provisions were awarded by the government during October, Secretary Perkins announced today.

In a letter to Cardinal Hayes, expressing appreciation of "their unselfish service to the public," David McAlpin Pyle, president of the United Hospital Fund, informed the Catholic prelate yesterday of the acceptance of eight more Catholic hospitals as members of the fund.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 7. -- Hobart's undefeated eleven swept to a 52 -- 2 victory over the University of Buffalo today in their twenty-eighth annual game staged before a home-coming crowd of 5,500 fans. Fullback Fred King registered five touchdowns.

The staffs of the various school and college year books at New York University were announced yesterday by Harold O. Voorhis, secretary of the university. Editorial boards were appointed to The Violet of the School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance.

THOSE who believe that the writing of poetry is a lost art will find confirmation of their pessimism in the official statement that there is to be no award of the King's Medals for Poetry for 1935. These prizes were instituted in November, 1933, when it was announced that there would be offered every year a gold and a silver medal for poetry in English published in volume form within the empire by British citizens.

ONE wishes that this magnificent novel were published here as it was in England -- blurbless and without a foreword. One wishes that from the first imperious knocking of fate in the opening chapter to the terrible climax in the last the reader were left the privilege of discovering each twist in the tragic sequence of events for himself.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 6:

THIS is a slight little book which, at the very least, needed greater distinction of style to set it off. It is the story of the Joneses of Suburbia -- in this case, the Crawfords of Granton, N. J. -- a typical American family in a typical suburban town.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Nov. 7. -- Approximately a hundred student and faculty delegates from thirty-one colleges and universities in the Middle Atlantic area gathered today at the College of St. Elizabeth, Convent, near here, for the Student Peace Federation Conference.

IN the development and encouragement of good reading among the youth of America, the Boy Scouts have played a not inconsiderable part. Recognizing the influence of reading on boys, the organization has devoted much attention to a reading program. It has cooperated with parents, educators, librarians and publishers in an effort to direct youthful minds in sound reading habits.

VIENNA, Nov. 7 (AP). -- King Carol wants his mother, Dowager Queen Marie, to leave Rumania because of a new quarrel between them, Balkan diplomatic circles reported today. The cause of the quarrel was said to be a letter accusing Carol of responsibility for "bad conditions in the country."
ST. LOUIS. OPERATION of a new driver's license law, inaugurated last December, is believed to be largely responsible for a decrease in traffic accidents this year in St. Louis.

SHARP gains in retail trade were reported over the country during the week as cold weather expanded volume on seasonal lines of merchandise. The month opened up with the average increases moving higher in most sections, aided by Election Day business.

Convinced that the tax on undistributed corporation surpluses is sure to be amended at the forthcoming session of Congress, directors of a number of companies have authorized the entire payment of 1936 earnings to stockholders in the form of dividends, reports here yesterday indicated.

Horses, dogs, cats and even pigs surpass the wisdom exhibited by humans in avoiding disease, according to Dr. L.J. Steinback, dean of Universal Chiropractic College, Pittsburgh, as reported by The Toronto Globe. Human beings do not appreciate the splendid health influence of lying down on the back and rolling and twisting the body to loosen the muscles and ligaments, thus restoring the proper relationship of bones after a day of toil.
WELLINGTON, N.Z. -- Dictatorial powers over all industry have been assumed by the Labor government here in its latest move to make a "rationalized State."
Auditions for new singers for the Women's Chorus of the New York Madrigal Society, under the direction of Marguerite Potter, will close on Tuesday.

Miss Nancy Hoguet has enlisted the aid of several debutantes to assist Mrs. Thomas Jefferson Mumford and members of the executive committee in the sale of tickets for the performance of some of Noel Coward's one-act plays the night of Dec. 2 at the National Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Neighborhood Music School.
District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Kings County sent aides to Lawrence, Mass., yesterday to help "break" a strange murder case.

The gardener who can afford acquisitions of the handsome, giant family of eremuri, or Foxtail-lilies, will find repayment in their extended season of bloom. Care in picking the varieties will make this stretch from the last of May into July. Seeds are available at little cost; while a half-way method of obtaining these beautiful specimens cheaply is to buy year-old seedlings.

Following the close of the outdoor flower season at the New York Botanical Garden comes the first of the succession of displays in the main conservatory and the adjacent greenhouses. An interesting collection of flowering plants and many unusual decorative plants are already on exhibition.

BERLIN, Nov. 7. -- The new government loan of 500,000,000 marks, announced yesterday, is officially represented as proof that Germany does not intend to depreciate the domestic value of her currency, and in that sense it also forms an answer to the invitation of Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, to Germany to join the currency entente among France, Britain and the United States as one means of ending the economic isolation of which she complains.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP). -- The men of H.M.S. Bounty who mutinied in 1789 and established a colony in 1790 on lonely Pitcairn Island in the South Pacific have provided new scientific evidence that close inbreeding does not necessarily cause a decline in physical and mental vigor of offspring.

THE sports lover found keen satisfaction in recent dispatches from Switzerland saying that snow has been falling for some two months in the Alps. With an early Winter season predicted, foreigners are thumbing guide books and Swiss citizens are repainting gayly colored sleighs and polishing silver bells against the arrival of the vanguard of Winter pleasure seekers

New Yorkers on their way to work on Armistice Day will see hundreds of white flags bearing a crimson cross -- the symbol of the American Red Cross -- flying from buildings at the city's major crossroads. During the seven days that follow buttons bearing the same symbol will appear on the lapels of thousands of persons, indicating that they have answered the organization's twentieth annual roll-call, of which Owen D. Young is general chairman.
DOORN, The Netherlands, Nov. 7. -- Doorn's imperial exile emerged today as Wilhelm Hohenzollern the author.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 7. -- Union College launched a scoring drive in the closing minutes of the first half to defeat the University of Rochester, 7 to 0, today.

MARION, Mass., Nov. 7. -- The Tabor Academy football team defeated the Loomis forces on Hoyt Field today by a score of 6 -- 0. The game was marked by vicious tackling, hard running and good kicking on the part of both elevens.
IT was with pleasure that we looked forward to reading this book. We are among the many who respect the name of the author. The subject is of universal and supreme importance.

A booklet entitled "A Dozen Jersey Children," compiled last Spring by Dr. Anna Spiesman Starr, State president of the New Jersey division of the American Association of University Women, will be an important adjunct of the organization's program for the year.

WELL-BEHAVED: The Roosevelt grandchildren, according to members of the family, all have good dispositions. Take Kate Roosevelt, the President's 8-month-old granddaughter, who was christened last Wednesday at Hyde Park House.

Last of the Eastern States to swing into line, New Jersey will open the hunting season next Tuesday on small upland game. Shooting of quail, rabbits, grouse, gray squirrels and pheasants will be legal until Dec. 15. Deer may be taken during the five-day period, Dec. 17 to 21.
READING, Pa., Nov. 7. -- Albright battled Western Maryland to a 6-6 deadlock today in renewing a gridiron feud that dates back fifteen years.

BOSTON, Nov. 7. -- "The American people have abdicated their political responsibilities in the re-election of Franklin D. Roosevelt," Professor Robert E. Moody, Professor of American History at Boston University's College of Liberal Arts, declared today.

COMPLETING what is probably the first large-scale scientific investigation of accident-prone drivers with known records, Dr. Harry R. De Silva of the Bureau for Street Traffic Research at Harvard University has unearthed new facts that promise a better understanding of these troublemakers of the highway.
SALTSBURG, Pa., Nov. 7. -- Putting on a powerful attack which saw the home team take a 14-0 lead at the halfway mark, Kiski School's football team turned back Mercersburg, 21 -- 0, today.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 7. -An amazingly powerful Alabama eleven brought its name to the forefront with the nation's gridiron leaders today with a smashing 34-to-7 victory over completely outclassed Tulane.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- The extent of the overwhelming endorsement of President Roosevelt at the polls on Tuesday was not without its seasoning of misgivings to the man to whom it meant the most, Mr. Roosevelt himself.

Although Harlem River Houses, the PWA Housing Division's project for Negroes at 153d Street and the Harlem River, will not be ready for occupancy before July, 1937, the rush of applicants for the apartments has been so great that the Federal officials will have a problem on their hands in picking out the most worthy families, it was learned yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 7. -- President Roosevelt's trip to Buenos Aires to attend the opening session of the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace seemed assured this afternoon with an official announcement by the Argentine Government that President Agustin P. Justo had cabled a formal invitation to him to come here.

Confident that the Inter-American Peace Conference in Buenos Aires would achieve positive results on which may be founded a lasting peace in the Western Hemisphere, Secretary of State Cordell Hull sailed yesterday afternoon on the Munson liner American Legion.

Topics of The Times recently discussed the much debated subject of telepathy and declared: "Whatever the explanation for 'telepathy' may be, an increasing number of psychologists are beginning to regard it not as a mere superstition of the soft-headed but as an established scientific fact."
TORONTO, Nov. 7. -- Falconry has been revived, on a 1936 pattern, by Don MacKinnon, a broker, who spends his days in Bay Street and his nights training and "manning" a peregrine falcon.

ATLANTA, Nov. 7 (AP). -- With a bit of luck and an advantage in the breaks of the game, Auburn's Tigers barely withstood a determined bid for victory by Georgia Tech today to triumph over the Engineers, 13 to 12, before a crowd of 18,000.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- The November schedule of the Bath County Hounds is crowded. The card calls for three hunts a week -- two live fox hunts and a drag a week alternating with two drags and one live fox the following week.
WE have tried to do our best by Charlie Washburn. We've permitted him to witness all the agonies of play making, of management and of casting. We've tried to show him the light -- and we have failed.

THERE has recently zoomed across the horizon a new industry -- manufacture of coach trailers -- which enthusiasts contend will soon do a business of $100,000,000 annually. It is an industry so new that few authentic figures are available regarding its far-flung activities.

NEWARK, Ohio, Nov. 7 (AP). -- Eighteen men, hardened to athletic perfection by months of farm labor and tanned by the Summer sun, will match their prowess Tuesday in the thirteenth annual national corn husking championship.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Nov. 7. -- Work has been started at Mount Holyoke College toward the construction of a new chapel (architect's drawing shown above), made possible through a recent anonymous gift of $250,000 for construction and an additional $100,000 for maintenance.

The third annual marine exhibition under the auspices of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York will open Thursday afternoon at the Maritime Exchange Building, 80 Broad Street, with Mayor La Guardia the guest of honor and principal speaker.
EVERY once in a while you hear some student of the automobile industry ask: "What's going to happen to the medium and high priced cars?"

Seventy of the paintings collected by James A. Raynor, one-time president of the Erie Railroad, will be sold at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries next week. They form part of the collection of art objects belonging to the estate of the late Mrs. W. Storrs Wells, daughter of Mr. Raynor, which will be dispersed Thursday evening and Friday and Saturday afternoons.

CLARE LEIGHTON, the well-known English graphic artist, has distinguished herself not alone as a maker of prints, but also as an intelligent expounder of the medium in which she likes best to work. A few seasons ago she contributed to the Studio's "How to Do It" series a book dealing with the technique of wood engraving and woodcuts.

THIS book should be a guide and a consolation to countless men as well as women who are ignorant and apprehensive of the fundamental characteristics of change of life. As Dr. Stopes rightly says, comparatively little has been written on this topic and some of the medical authors who have touched on it are responsible for a great deal of the gross misunderstanding entertained by the general public.

THIS first novel presents a not unusual combination of hard-boiled language and soft-boiled people. The favorite epithet is genealogical; but butter never melted in the sun more rapidly than do hearts, both male and female, under the glare of Philip Cloud's dark blue eyes, "alight with hidden stress."

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Nov. 7 -- Federal Judge Paul J. McCormick at Los Angeles ordered United States Marshal here to take possession today of the strike-bound Panama Pacific liner California en route to San Francisco from New York and remove her banana cargo.
MADRID, Nov. 7. -- The supreme defense Cabinet formed Wednesday by Premier Francisco Largo Caballero left by plane for Valencia today.

I AM intensely interested in the work being done in the Four Arts Department of the WPA. Mine is a first-hand enthusiasm, for I have been acting in the Drama Division for over a year. Much has been said about the work done -- and left undone -- by our units, and perhaps the inside story would now prove interesting.

IT was a journey without maps both literally and figuratively. Although Graham Greene found two maps of the Liberian hinterland in existence, one was almost completely blank, and the other, less frankly ignorant, was so imaginative as to be dangerously inaccurate.

It is expected that Mayor La Guardia or his representative, Byrnes MacDonald, will address the forty-fifth annual meeting of the Needlework Guild of America on Tuesday afternoon at 1,780 Broadway. New garments for men, women and children, assembled by the guild's section presidents and members for distribution to hospitals and other charitable institutions, will be shown.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 7. -- Running right back to his smashing victory in the New England Futurity, in which he defeated the mighty Pompoon, the Milky Way Farms' Reaping Reward annexed the seventeenth running of the $5,000 added Kentucky Jockey Club Stakes at Churchill Downs today.

Dean Virginia Gildersleeve of Barnard College spoke of the teachers' loyalty oaths as "a very serious beginning and a grave tendency," and criticized the McNaboe committee's investigation of radicalism in the schools at a gathering yesterday morning of the Association of Private School Teachers, meeting at St. Agatha's School, 553 West End Avenue.

Pouncing on Purdue fumbles as though they were round-trip tickets to Pasadena and the Rose Bowl, Fordham's unbeaten football forces vanquished the Boilermakers at the Polo Grounds yesterday before a crowd of 40,000 and made California seem a lot closer to New York than the 3,000 miles the geography books say it is.

New York University's unusual experiment in adult education, begun two years ago, now comes to fruition with a trebled enrollment and a building of its own. Within a few weeks renovators will put the finishing touches to 20 Washington Square, once a spacious residence, and what is perhaps the first -- and certainly the largest -- segregated private university center for adult learning in the country will be in full operation.

LONDON, Nov. 6. -- Europe looked up from its quarrels this week and stared across the Atlantic at a spectacle the Old World had never seen before. A nation of 125,000,000 covering 3,000,000 square miles had been swept from ocean to ocean by one man in an election fought without threats of concentration camps, without the help of a servile press and against the opposition of important financial and economic forces.

THE flower of the Red Army (the largest regular force under arms in Europe) and the organized proletariat celebrated yesterday in the Red Square of Moscow the nineteenth anniversary of the Bolshevist Revolution. That celebration was also a tribute to Stalin, the Red leader, whose authority and influence are greater than those of any Czar.

Members and guests of the Decorators Club will crowd the ballroom of the Cosmopolitan Club tomorrow evening for the first of a series of symposia which will headline the Winter's program for the sponsoring organization. The theme of the opening discussion will be "The New York World's Fair of 1939."

LEXINGTON, Va., Nov. 7. -- Tallying in every period but the final, Washington and Lee's football team defeated Virginia Polytechnic Institute, last year's State champions, 27 -- 0, today before a homecoming day crowd of about 5,000.

The rush of foreign capital into American security markets last week, following the sweeping triumph of President Roosevelt in the election, called attention to a movement of international economic importance which has been gathering force since May, 1935.

Civil war in Spain actually started in 1931 with the formation of the republic over the wishes of the majority, who voted monarchist and have since been ruled by a powerfully organized minority, Jose M. Torres-Perona, former assistant publisher of La Prensa and correspondent for Spanish newspapers, declared yesterday.

Having focused the attention of the public and business men on the importance of pre-determining consumer reactions, straw polls in the last election will prove the biggest boon to market research the profession has received in years, specialists asserted here yesterday.

Last week Dr. FRANCIS CARTER WOOD announced that the atlas of cancer tumors proposed last September at the Brussels Congress was to become a reality. Because this is to be a cooperative effort there is cause for rejoicing. At present cancer research is conducted by brilliant individualists.

COLONEL BATES has been engaged for a number of years on an exhaustive biography of General Custer. This pamphlet, prepared for circulation at the recent celebration of the sixtieth anniversary of the tragedy on the Little Big Horn, is its forerunner.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP). -- Secretary Perkins revealed today that Administrator Harry L. Hopkins of WPA once crashed the gate to her private elevator in the new Labor Department Building and then had trouble getting out of it.

THE French inundation, which has already played so large a role in our present New York season, is being steadily reinforced. The Cezanne show at Bignou's, to which we shall return in a moment, opened last Thursday. The two large Picasso shows, at the Valentine and the Seligmann, remain current until Nov. 21 and Nov. 26, respectively.

PERHAPS the greatest reason for the fact that the automobile industry is outstanding among those which are enjoying the greatest measure of recovery is the fact that it did, during the height of the depression period, so refine and improve its products that the appeal to the purchaser has been irresistible.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 7. -- Analysis of Cornell's record enrollment just completed reveals three trends which have gratified university authorities. An increasing number of children of Cornellians have entered the university; the geographical distribution of students is maintaining its national characteristic on a broader scale; while an increase in the number of students from foreign lands is enhancing the international atmosphere of Cornell.
At the expense of the team from the land of the blue grass, Manhattan scored its greatest football victory yesterday at Ebbets Field, beating Kentucky, 13 to 7.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 7. -- Pittsburgh and Penn State renewed their ancient football rivalry before 20,000 spectators at Pitt Stadium today with the Panthers winning, 34 to 7. Despite the one-sided score, the Nittany Lions thrilled a Pitt homecoming crowd with their most brilliant local display since their last victory over the Panthers, in 1919.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- Impressed with the overwhelming endorsement of its farm program in the national election, the administration plans to propose at the next session of Congress that it be again authorized to control agricultural production and maintain farm purchasing power along the lines first employed by the invalidated Agricultural Adjustment Act.

Eleven definitions of mathematical terms in Webster's New International Dictionary are challenged as erroneous in the current issue of Science, official organ of the American Association for the Advancement of Science. The challenger is Dr. George A. Miller, Professor of Mathematics at the University of Illinois and former president of the American Mathematical Association.

The first Christmas tree has already appeared, twinkling with colored lights, in a New York shop window. Crowds along the shopping thoroughfares are thickening. These signs serve as a warning to prudent folk who like to get their Christmas shopping out of the way while there is still walking space in the aisles of the stores and before sales girls' nerves get jumpy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- The case of the Seattle Newspaper Guild strike against The Seattle Post-Intelligencer will be heard here before the National Labor Relations Board on Monday, the board announced today, with testimony to be presented by Heywood Broun, president of the American Newspaper Guild; Sir Willmott Lewis, Washington' correspondent of The London Times; Clyde Beals, editor of The Guild Reporter, and I.L. Kenan, head of the Guild's Cleveland chapter.

The situation in the so-called milk war in this city was described yesterday as much better by Burt W. Miller, Deputy State Commissioner of Agriculture. He said most of the dealers and retailers who sold milk below the minimum price set by the State had stopped the practice.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- President Roosevelt's plan to attend and address the opening session of the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace, at Buenos Aires on Dec. 1, following on the heels of his great electoral victory, has given new impetus to the preparations for this gathering.

MANY who have followed the career of Stravinsky have formed the idea and promulgated it that he has largely written himself out in his music and that his career from now on must be downward. That is not his idea, and his writing of this book is by no means to be taken as indicating his belief that he is nearing the end or has even reached the climax.

BIG GAVITY had been working as a cowboy on Bryan Ross's Slash R Ranch, where he had fallen completely in love with "that small, dark, lovely and utterly desirable girl, Betty Ross. Bryan's daughter." So when Ross left the ranch to make his fortune in the new boom town of La Fe on the Rio Grande, Gavity threw up his job and followed, hoping only to find Betty and persuade her to marry him.

With its leader ill and its management temporarily in the hands of a triumvirate, Tammany Hall, as a result of last Tuesday's election, has definitely lost its place as the dominating Democratic organization of New York City and seems to have no chance in the near future of getting it back.

THE San Francisco Symphony, directed by Pierre Monteux, celebrates its silver jubilee this season. Efforts are being made, in connection with the anniversary, to increase the personnel of the orchestra to ninety players. The first pair of concerts will be given Friday afternoon, Jan. 8, and Saturday night, Jan. 9.

NEW OLD COSTUME: East Prussia has no folk costume, a condition deplored by true Nazis, who are proudest of the good old ways. So Nazi experts, after delving into the past, have designed a new old East Prussian dress. For men -- short jackets with amber buttons, large bandanna kerchiefs, breeches and buckled shoes.

THIS brief expression might serve to indicate the change in Auslander's poetry, evident in this new volume. In the foreword to the poet's first book, published twelve years ago, Padraic Colum said: "* * * It goes some way toward restoring a quality that has been left out of a great deal of verse that is being written in the New World in our time -- the quality of delight.

AT first glance November might be supposed to be an "off" month for tourists in Europe. It comes long after the Summer season is ended and a bit too soon for Winter activities. Accordingly, if the seasonal view of Europe is to be taken seriously, November can only be written off as a gap in the tourists' calendar.

PINEHURST, N. C. -- Most of the cottage colony here has already settled down for the Winter. All hotels are open and their registration is steadily increasing. The Professional Golfers Association tournament, scheduled to begin on Monday, Nov. 16, with 121 qualifiers in the field, is the outstanding factor in the early activities.

IN more than one respect, the Automobile Show just opening in New York, and the similar exhibitions that will be held this year in some forty or fifty other cities throughout the country, might be termed "America's Show Windows of Progress."

The climax of the round of varied entertainments given thus far in conjunction with the National Horse Show, was the annual Horse Show Ball, held last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. It was one of the outstanding social functions of the early season in this city.

One of the picturesque entertainments of the near future is the ninth annual Russian Students' Ball which will be held on Friday in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Featured by a costume pageant depicting a levee at the Court of Catherine the Great in St. Petersburg in 1780, the event will bring forth a display of authentic reproductions of the gowns worn in that period.

Checking up the survivors of the Democratic tidal wave of last Tuesday proved a brief enough business for the feminine contingent. Their minority in Congress was reduced by one, leaving only five women Representatives, of whom four are Democrats.

The waterfront strike which began eight days ago on the Pacific Coast, spreading from there to the Gulf of Mexico and the Atlantic, made little progress toward settlement last week. On the Pacific, all 37,000 men were out; in the Atlantic and Gulf ports, about half of the 33,000 seamen remained idle in token of sympathy for the Pacific seamen.

SYMPHONIE FANTASTIQUE, Leonide Massine's third symphony, for which Hector Berlioz has supplied both music and scenario, is beyond doubt the choreographer's most effective adventure in the turning of orchestral works into stage spectacles.

AN arresting retrospective exhibition of sculpture in many media, by Jose de Creeft, provides an auspicious reopening for the gallery of Georgette Passedoit in the French Institute Building, 22 East Sixtieth Street.

The land slid into the Roosevelt column last week, reckoning by electoral vote or popular vote, by Congressional contests or State elections. Never since its foundation has the Republican party suffered such ubiquitous rout. The old-line minority groups met a similar fate, and the loud pre-Nov. 3 threats of those newer organized dissidents -- the heirs to what an earlier Roosevelt called the lunatic fringe -- subsided into a pale piping.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- Business activity is being well sustained despite seasonal factors which usually make for declines in November and December, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey.

THEY were telling such tall tales of those paid post-graduate football fellows from Chicago, the Great Big Bears, that stout Steve Owen of the Giants took fright and went out and hired an extra man to hold them off.

DANZIG, Nov. 7. -- A strong protest has been lodged with the Danzig Senate by the Polish Commissioner, Casimir Papee, following the refusal by the Free City police to allow his representative to interview the three Poles in Schoneberg who were victims of an assault by Nazi Storm Troopers on Sunday.
These clear eyes, belonging to a German shepherd dog, will serve some sightless human master when the dog's training has been completed at The Seeing Eye in Morristown, N.J.

MR. CHESTERTON was "firmly of the opinion that he was born on the 29th of May, 1874, on Campden Hill, Kensington." He was baptized "in the little church of St. George opposite the large Waterworks Tower that dominated the ridge."

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 7. -- The crushing defeat of the Democratic party in the polls on election day has given rise to reports that Charles H. Sullivan, county leader, will be superseded in authority. Mr. Sullivan, however, considers the reports "ridiculous," and will face any opposition should it appear on Tuesday at a meeting of his executive committee in Riverhead.

FOR the first time in nearly a quarter of a century of picture making, Hal Roach (throwing off all restraint) has announced a change of policy. Bowing to some vast, unseen power -- possibly the Zeitgeist -- the producer of comedy "shorts" who has held out, against all odds, since the pale dawn of the films will become an entrepreneur, a publisher of feature-length musicals, before the year is out.

The annual card party and tea under the auspices of the Penland Board of the Church of the Ascension will take place Nov. 17 on the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis for the benefit of the Appalachian School at Penland in the mountains of North Carolina.

LONDON, Nov. 7 (Canadian Press.) -- Sunderland, English League champion, showed its strength in today's round of soccer matches by toppling Portsmouth, 3 -- 2, at Roker Park. The victory put the northern club in third position, only 2 points back of Portsmouth. Brentford became runner-up with 17 points, downing Birmingham, 2 -- 1.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 7. -- Vassar College is proposed as the socio-intellectual center for mid-Hudson River Valley counties in a report by Professor Joseph K. Folsom to Dr. Henry N. MacCracken, president of the college.
Scoring in three periods, Benny Friedman's City College eleven went on a touchdown spree yesterday to rout Gallaudet College of Washington, D.C., 34 -- 0, in Lewisohn Stadium.

Louis (Lepke) Buchalter and Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro, accused of having caused a reign of terror in New York's $10,000,000-a-year rabbit skin trade four years ago, were found guilty early today on all four counts of an indictment charging violation of the Anti-Trust Laws by a jury in Federal court, which had been deliberating thirty-three hours.

OLD masters moved unostentatiously yet confidently into the limelight of the local art world last week. At the Durlacher, now resettled at 11 East Fifty-seventh Street, you will find a small but very rewarding one-man show of paintings by the Flemish master, Quentin Massys (the name is spelled in several ways, and it really doesn't much matter which we accept).

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 7 (AP). -- The St. Thomas College football team of Scranton, Pa., defeated Springfield College 7 -- 0 today in a game which created considerable excitement when a last-minute pringfield touchdown was nullified because time had run out just before the ball was snapped.
MANCHESTER, N.H., Nov. 7. -- St. Anselm of Manchester continued in the ranks of undefeated college football teams after a victory over Northeastern, 19 -- 0, before more than 7,000 today.

Mrs. Henry Goddard Leach, having finished her campaign work as manager for the re-election of Representative Caroline O'Day, will return this week to her duties as president of the Cosmopolitan Club. Until her second term expires next April, with the annual club elections, she will be occupied with the leadership of this organization.
NEW LONDON, Conn., Nov. 7. -- Connecticut College and the Lyman Allyn Museum, which adjoins the college, will open a cooperative project in the study of modern painting and etching this year.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 7. -- A new and much more promising era in government and business is dawning for the college graduate with a broad training, Professor De Witt Clinton Poole, director of the School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University, declared today in his annual report to the advisory board of the school.

Additional details of the proposed increase of capital funds by the Harbor State Bank were announced yesterday by John B. Glenn, president of the institution. The changes, involving an increase in capital from $200,000 to $600,000 and in surplus from $75,000 to $125,000, include the sale of 10,000 new shares and a subsequent stock dividend of 6,000 shares.
WARSAW, Poland, Nov. 7. -- Foreign Minister Josef Beck left today for London, where he will spend three or four days as the guest of the British Government.

OUTLOOK COLD: Now that the election is over, Washington, always forehanded, is looking toward the inauguration, which everybody expects to be the coldest in history. Weather Bureau records show that the average temperature on Jan. 20 -- which, as a result of the Norris Lame Duck Amendment, becomes inauguration day -- is 33 degrees for the last forty-nine years.

THE Chinese people, who so love the theatre and who would fall for any sort of entertainment, are falling for the movie today. This is true not only of the treaty ports, but even of the inland cities, where American movie pictures are making the same inroads the kerosene lamp made three decades ago.

MOST of the literary forms which the races of Europe have come to look upon as typical and universal stem directly from the Greeks. Inheriting no traditions, without any background, and long centuries before our own crude beginnings in "Beowulf," they proceeded to turn out finished pieces of rhetoric and oratory, and epic, lyric and dramatic prose and verse.

ONE of the reasons, no doubt, why we continue to have lives and studies of Robespierre is that the most rational and detached students of the man and his revolutionary time and it impossible to reach common conclusions as to his personality and its significance.
IN an effort to preserve the dying traditions of old Hawaii one man, known to the islanders as King David, is devoting his life to stimulating a love of their ancient customs and handicrafts.
MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Minnesota's gridiron machine, disabled by Northwestern a week ago, knocked Iowa out of its come-back path by a 52-0 score. The half-time score was 33 to 0.

ROME, Nov. 7. -- Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano, accompanied by his wife, the former Edda Mussolini, and a large delegation, left this evening for Vienna where the three-power Italo-Austro-Hungarian conference, decided upon during the presence in Rome of the new Austrian Foreign Minister, will be held.

THE eyes of the world are focused on Francisco Franco, the debonair generalissimo of the Spanish revolutionary forces. And the world is asking questions: What manner of soldier is Franco? How did he rise to power? There is still another question -- the most important of all -- as to whether Franco is powerful enough to dominate the diverse elements in the revolutionary party.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- The nation-wide strike of about 50,000 maritime workers threatens to develop into the most extended shipping tie-up in the nation's history unless Federal pressure for renewal of conferences is successful.

Leaders in the railroad industry and in banking, commerce and finance will be among the speakers on Thursday at the fifty-sixth annual meeting of the Academy of Political Science at the Hotel Astor, it was announced yesterday. The development of transportation in the United States will be discussed.
WITH present operations in the automotive parts and equipment industry at wide open throttle, prospects are for an even greater activity throughout 1937.

BOSTON, Nov. 7 (AP). -- Boston's bewhiskered Republican Congressman, George Holden Tinkham, the man who never campaigns, won re-election in the Democratic Tenth District with 13,409 votes more than President Roosevelt received.

CONTINUING improvement in the automobile industry seems definitely indicated for 1937. Of course, the welfare of our market parallels closely the general trend of national affairs. But I look for a minimum increase of 10 per cent in automobile output if social, political or economic disturbances -- not now visible -- do not cloud an improving national picture.

URBANA, Ill., 7 (AP). -- Miss Sybil Woodruff, who, in a spotless laboratory at the University of Illinois delves into foods to find out just what is in them, has unknowingly created a new title for herself, chief soybean taster.

TWO series devoted to chamber music will be launched in the course of the week, both of considerable significance. At the Town Hall the New Friends of Music, Inc., a nonprofit-making organization, will begin its sixteen concerts with a Beethoven program.

LYNBROOK, L.I., Nov. 7. -- The Class A championship in the South Shore League was retained by the Baldwin High School eleven when it turned back a stubborn Lynbrook eleven by 13 to 0 today. It was the third straight triumph for the visitors.

SMALL wonder that in Alaska there is more flying in proportion to the population than in any other country in the world, and that air travel in America's northern empire has gained by approximately ten times during the past six years.

I HAVE never been more optimistic about she automobile industry than I am today. Automobile transportation is now a necessity. Automobile designing, manufacturing and selling are in the hands of forward-looking, capable men and I believe they are competent to handle their problems and opportunities with a very high regard for the public interest and safety as well as the needs of their customers.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Nov. 7 (AP). -- William H. Gallagher's Rudie won the second renewal of the Wannamoisett Handicap, a mile-and-seventy-yards event for 2-year-olds, at Narragansett Park today, beating Mrs. L.H. Ward's Prince Sador by three lengths.

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 7. -- Washington and Jefferson took advantage of every scoring opportunity offered in the first two periods against Lafayette today and then fought off. Maroon rallies after the intermission to win, 31 to 6.
WITH INSURGENT ARMY IN MADRID SUBURBS, Friday, Nov. 6 (Delayed). -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco's army today captured all the most important suburbs south of Madrid.

KINGSTON, Ont., Nov. 7 (AP). -- An appeal for the moderate man was made today by Lord Tweedsmuir in an address at Queen's University, where the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws was conferred upon him.

ON the fourth floor of the Grand Central Palace, in connection with the National Automobile Show, will be assembled the first comprehensive exhibit in the East of trailers -- those homes on wheels which are seen today in ever-increasing numbers on the highways of the nation.

ALTHOUGH greater progress has been made in road building in the last ten years than in the preceding twenty, more yet is required. Government highway officials estimate that close to 27,000,000 motor vehicles are now on the highways and that there may be 3,000,000 more by 1940.

COUNT JOHANN HEINRICH VON BERNSTORFF was born in London, Nov. 14, 1862, where his father, Count Albrech, was attached to the then Prussian Embassy. Today, considering his age and his voluntary exile at Geneva, he can hardly hope to produce a more comprehensive work.

LEXINGTON, Va., Nov. 7. -- Raymond Clapper, Washington political columnist, and Edward S. Stanley, an executive assistant of The Associated Press, will be two of the speakers at the annual convention of the Southern Interscholastic Press Association, which will be held under the auspices of the Lee School of Journalism of Washington and Lee University Nov. 20-21.

The promotion and appointment of 118 students enrolled in the advance courses of the City College unit of the R.O.T.C. has been announced by Colonel Oliver P. Robinson, chairman of the Department of Military Science and Tactics. William G. Rockwell of 32-40 Eighty-second Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, was raised to the highest ranking student officer in the corps when he was promoted to be cadet colonel. The list of promotions and appointments follows:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- Admiral William Harrison Standley, chief of naval operations, will be retired at his own request on Jan. 1. Secretary Swanson made public today the Admiral's formal application, which cites that he will be 64 years old Dec. 18 and that, were he not chief of operations, his retirement would be automatic.

Every country in the world is pushing health education to teach its people to conserve their mental and physical health, according to Professor C.E. Turner, teacher of biology and public health at Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He has just returned from a round-the-world tour of twenty-five countries to speak before a meeting of the American Dietetic Association at Boston.

LONDON, Nov. 6. -- There is a cartoon in the current issue of Punch picturing Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin, in the ancient uniform of a beefeater, making the traditional annual search of the cellars of the House of Commons to assure himself that no Guy Fawkes has filled the place with gunpowder to blow up Parliament.

WITH the slogan, "The Automobile Industry -- Pacemaker for American Industry," the forthcoming Automobile Shows will give visual evidence to millions of people who visit them, of the strides that have been made by the automobile industry in producing better products, in making technical and manufacturing advances that give the industry the stamp of business leadership and of recognized public responsibility.

LOS ANGELES. TEACHING of safe driving methods in the schools, construction of a modified form of high-speed safety highways, practical tests of habitual traffic violators to determine their driving weaknesses and establishment of time-and-distance police controls over dangerous road passages comprised efforts to cut down traffic fatalities in the Los Angeles area this year.

THERE was every good reason for publishing the Salavin cycle in America; indeed, it might well have been published here sooner. For though it lies just on the boundary between minor and major fiction, shuttling between the moderately whimsical novel of character and the thought-provoking novel of ethics, it partakes of the virtues of both categories and makes excellent reading to boot.

PROBABLY the most pronounced change in body styles since touring cars gave way to sedans almost twenty years ago has been the trend of the last two years toward the touring sedan. If the popularity of this type, with its spacious built-in trunk, continues to increase at the present rate it will be only a matter of another year or two until the straight sedan will be almost a thing of the past.

An Armistice Day appeal to the thousands of church congregations throughout the country to dedicate the holiday to the furtherance of peace causes was issued yesterday by the Federal Council of Churches.

The departure of the Munson liner American Legion, carrying Secretary of State Cordell Hull and the rest of the United States delegation to the Pan-American peace conference at Buenos Aires, was delayed for nearly eight hours yesterday by the seamen's strike.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Nov. 7. -- The Coast Guard Academy eleven beat Massachusetts State. 26 -- 20, in a New England small college football upset today at Jones Field as the Cadets concluded their 1936 campaign.

FORECASTING the future of television and discussing plans for telecasting in London, Gerald Cook, director of radio-vision of the British Broadcasting Corporation, asserts that "television is essentially a medium of topicalities."

LOOK for something different in the selection of an opening night opera at the Metropolitan Opera House. It is whispered that Edward Johnson is ready to abandon the time-honored practice of starting with a French or Italian work.

The Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, concentrating its activities on four major fronts not reached by government relief, will launch tomorrow its campaign for $650,000 toward the $1,550,000 which will be required for its widespread activities through the coming year.

IT may interest you to know that Olivia de Havilland is a very pleasant young lady with no airs about her, even though she is a full-fledged screen star at 20. And the most charming discovery we made in talking over this matter and that with her at the Crillon, and later atop the Empire State, was that she still suffers terribly from stage fright.
