PARIS, Nov. 7. -- President Roosevelt's victory has stirred new fires in the breasts of the citizens of the little town of Lannoy, near Lille. They are convinced that the President's ancestors, through his mother's line of Delano, originally came from there.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 7. -- Close upon the heels of the election returns numerous concerns in the Eighth Federal Reserve District reported extra dividends, good earning prospects, bonuses for employes and similar items long absent from financial statements.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 7. -- A supposed cripple, Roman Soldier, did more or less on three legs what the other horses were unable to do on four -- win the $9,320 Riggs Handicap before 18,000 persons at Pimlico today. The black colt is none too sound, and his training was interrupted both at 3 and at 4 by the ailments of a horse whose underpinning is suspicious.

In what may be a preview of the National Football League championship play-off, the New York Giants, co-leaders in the Eastern division, will clash with the Chicago Bears, co-leaders in the Western sectional race, at the Polo Grounds this afternoon.

IT is half a century or so since Sven Hedin made his first journey into Central Asia, but he comes of tough stock and has an adventurous soul that has long outlived his first youth. The late Winter of 1934 therefore found him bound westward across the Gobi Desert into Sinkiang with a mission from the Chinese Central Government in Nanking "to mark out two motor roads between China proper and that remote province."
Public education officials here are studying a plan for a widespread use of radio communication as a "potent instrumentality" in the teaching of children.

Flashing the same form that he displayed last week in winning the Catholic High Schools championship, Harry Wilson, 17-year-old cross-country star of Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School, added the Athletic Association of Private Schools title to his list of victories when he triumphed in the annual run at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

To many readers of last week's news, the immediate rise on the Stock Exchange, when Tuesday's election news was known, seemed to be not only unexpected but difficult to explain. The community collectively described as "Wall Street" had been classified all along as hostile to Mr. ROOSEVELT and his policies.

The Emergency Relief Bureau is exerting its influence as the "largest rent payer in the city" to force improvements in run-down buildings occupied by home relief families, Miss Charlotte E. Carr, executive director of the bureau, disclosed yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 7. -- Seeking peace in the bitter inter-union struggle which has split the American Federation of Labor into two warring camps, members of the Committee for Industrial Organization moved today for direct conferences between William Green, federation president, and John L. Lewis, chairman of the C.I.O.

LISBON, Portugal, Nov. 7. -- Conflicting reports here resolve themselves into the fact that Madrid is not wholly occupied by the Spanish Insurgents. Violent fighting has been going on all day along the entire Rebel semi-circle around the capital.

MR. BUSHNELL was happily inspired when he conceived the notion of taking the same walk through Northern England and Scotland that Keats and his friend Brown took 118 years ago, treading in their footsteps, with their letters and journals for guidance, and generally duplicating their adventure as far as possible under changed modern conditions.
PITTSBURGH. SETTING the pace for traffic accident-reduction activities in Pittsburgh, a school program is being conducted this Fall that is reaching every child in every grade of school.

No cry was more often heard in the Presidential campaign, or was more bitter, than the warning that this country stood face to face with a war between classes. It was specifically charged that the New Deal had developed, whether it intended to or not, class hatred in the United States to a degree and intensity never before dreamed of here.

Eight horses are being put through mysterious manoeuvres in the elephants' house at the Regents Park Zoo in London nowadays. They are being led, ridden and driven up to, past and around the elephants while a small but interested crowd looks on. Occasionally the roles are reversed.

The momentum of the general advance carried almost all classes of bonds higher during the two hours of trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. With the exception of the Treasury obligations, the trading pace was maintained, with total transactions amounting to $8,371,900, compared with $4,781,000 on last Saturday.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 7. -- A driving Williams attack shattered Wesleyan University's ambitions for the Little Three championship today when Eddie Stanley and his mates defended their title by bowling over the Cardinals, 32 to 7. Seven thousand spectators saw the Purple give its best performance of the year in this forty-fifth encounter with the Wesmen.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 7. -- Amherst trounced the University of Vermont, 48 to 0, today, scoring in every period on a muddy field. Vermont made only one first down, and was hopelessly mired against the long line of regulars and substitutes which Amherst sent into the contest.
EMPORIA, Kan., Nov. 7. -- It was not an election which the country has just undergone but a political Johnstown flood.

Morgantown, W.Va., Nov. 7 (AP). -- Georgetown's undefeated football team converted three intercepted passes into touchdowns in the final period today to spoil homecoming day for 12,000 West Virginia University fans and beat the Mountaineers 28 to 0.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7. -- November retail trade started off excellently, although not quite at the brisk pace of last month. Sales of leading department stores ranged from 14 to 25 per cent above the first week of November, 1935, with 17 per cent probably a fair average for the group.

PAUL BROWN has, for the time being at least, stabled his trick circus horses and polo ponies, and turned to the Western plains to tell the story of a wild range colt in the days when the Comanches and the Cheyennes were fighting for the supremacy of the prairies.

An analysis of the vote last Tuesday in the Harlem districts, stronghold of Father Divine, indicates that his command to his followers to refrain from balloting had little effect on the total vote cast. Comparison of the registration and the vote shows that the estimate of A. Honaeel, editor of Father Divine's paper The Spoken Word, that 50,000 would remain away from the polls was extremely optimistic.
LAWRENCE, Kan., Nov. 7 (AP). -- Nebraska's Huskers uncorked a four-touchdown drive in the first half, to crush a plucky Kansas football team, 26 to 0, today before 10,000 spectators.

FROM a camp at timber line below Lyell Glacier, the largest in the Yosemite region, the glacier committee of the United States Geological Survey is making expeditions to take measurements of the advance or recession of Lyell, Dana, Maclure and Conness Glaciers, remnants of the Ice Age.

SOME fifty years ago Knut Hamsun wrote his highly original "Hunger," the story of a struggling free-lance writer who did not rail at society for neglecting him because in the very solitudes of starvation he had experienced the ecstasy of creation.

Insisting that Tuesday's election was a mandate to the administration to continue its reciprocal trade treaty program, foreign traders here yesterday pointed out that in every district where the foreign trade policy was made an issue, those opposing the treaties were defeated in contests for Congressional seats.

BERLIN, Nov. 7. -- Formally opening the semester in the German universities over the radio, Dr. Bernhard Rust, the Minister of Education, today delivered an address that indicated a tendency to retreat from his recent order to the students to rest their feet and get to work.
WHEN Joseph Pennell's "Adventures of an Illustrator" was published, he was asked to speak at Wanamaker's annual book week. He answered directly to the president of the corporation and wrote:

WHAT the police call "selective law enforcement" is the new weapon being tried in several parts of the country to reduce street and highway accidents and to catch serious offenders. Such cities as Syracuse, Cincinnati, Wichita, Kan.; Berkeley, Calif.; Evanston, Ill.; Louisville, South Bend, Ind., and New Haven, Hartford and Bridgeport are experimenting with the new method.

THE ancient town of Bath is the scene of this new adventure of Evan Pinkerton, the timid little Welshman who is the devoted satellite of Inspector Bull of Scotland Yard. With his well-known capacity for doing the wrong thing.

MR. SHERWOOD, for many years a salesman of woods for furniture, knows from long experience the hundreds of interesting things about the woods which go to make the furniture we use every day. Few facts of the "romance of wood" are known to the average person, so they prove most interesting reading, particularly when told in Mr. Sherwood's delightful manner.

Chief Commander Harold H. Funk of Brooklyn, head of the United States Power Squadrons, has summoned all members for the November conference of delegates which will be held Saturday at 3:30 P.M. at the Hotel Astor following a meeting at 1 o'clock of the governing board.

THE December number of Poetry will be a memorial to Harriet Monroe, who died on Sept. 26, in Peru while on her way home from the P.E.N. Congress at Buenos Aires. Miss Monroe founded Poetry in 1912 and edited it from that time until her death, making it the most influential poetry making in this country, if not in the world.
BOSTON, Nov. 7. -- For the first time in its history the State Parole Board is confronted with the problem of what to do with a model State prison inmate who has refused to be paroled.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 7. -- Bob Nowell, a 165-pound speedster, scored both touchdowns for his team today at the Senior High School field as the New Rochelle eleven registered a 12-to-0 triumph over the Politecnica Nacional unit of Mexico, D.F.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP). -- A prediction that the population of the United States will begin declining within fifteen years was made today by Dr. O.E. Baker, economist of the Department of Agriculture.

BRAZIL has no folksongs, but incontestably has folk-melodies, according to Mario de Andrade in The Brazilian American of Rio de Janeiro. That is, Brazil possesses no traditional folk-tunes even a century old. But there is a great abundance of songs and dances having all the characteristics exacted by science for placing a musical expression in the category of folklore.

In observance of the seventeenth anniversary of the founding of Zonta International, which restricts its membership to women executives, 3,600 business and professional women in many communities in the United States, Canada and Europe will hold varied club programs tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA. THE emphasis this year in the Philadelphia traffic situation has been on the reduction of accidents through educational methods and revision in the procedure of dealing with violators, rather than on new highway construction.

At Madrid's Comillas Field last January Manuel Azana addressed the largest political meeting in the history of Spain. His oratory there helped rouse the enthusiasm which brought victory at the polls in February to the coalition of the Left, pledged to relieve the impoverished peasants, separate Church and State and preserve the Spanish Republic against the forces of monarchy and fascism.

TOMORROW a new system of contract bridge bidding will be offered to the public. Called the "Distributional System," it is the product of several years' analysis by Howard Bissell, who asserts that the systems of bidding now widely used place too much emphasis on aces and kings and that the opening bid should be used to show the distribution of the hand rather than its honor-trick content.
MADRID, Nov. 7. -- While the bombardment of Madrid was going on today, about eighteen Loyalist planes flew over the city and dropped leaflets, the text of which follows:

THE conviction has been growing on me for some time that the attitude of the American playwright toward the American theatre is based on a set of premises which have ceased to exist, and that a new point of view is strongly indicated.

While it is not yet too late to plant bulbs, there is no time to be lost if they are to be set out soon enough to make some root growth before the ground actually freezes up. Such root growth, once started, will continue for a considerable period after the surface of the soil first freezes.

THE huge metropolitan highway building program, given impetus by the Federal Government's splurge in public works spending, achieved spectacular advances in the last twelve months. In several instances the year marked the completion of projects which have been in the making for a long time.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 7. -- Social and economic considerations are replacing the emphasis on esthetics and structure in the educational budget of the modern school of city planning and will continue to be more and more important items in the training of city planners of the future, according to Professor Frederick J. Adams, head of the Department of City Planning of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 7. -- North-western's Wildcats crashed to their first undisputed football title in Western Conference history today -- but left Dyche Stadium shell-shocked and reeling from a withering aerial barrage laid down by Wisconsin's gallant Badgers.

Bills to be presented at the next session of tile State Legislature will be explained by Miss Gertrude Rogers of New Britain to the Connecticut State Federation of the American Association of University Women at its annual Fall meeting at the College Club in Bridgeport on Tuesday.
TORONTO, Nov. 7. -- The New York Americans took undisputed leadership of the International group of the National Hockey League tonight when they defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 -- 2.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 7 (AP). -- The joint policy committee of striking Pacific Coast maritime unions lifted tonight the blockade on vessels away from but bound for home ports, including seven ships tied up in Honolulu. Six hundred passengers were reported stranded at Honolulu.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 7. -What is happening to the world's money?

THE modern Olympic Games did not at first receive much attention from the American public generally, in spite of the magnificent triumphs of the American athletes. Not until 1912, at Stockholm, did these international sporting events of track and field become, as such, "front-page news."

PARIS, Nov. 6. -- The midseason openings have revealed two new and outstanding general trends. The first is the modified Mme. Bovary or 1857 silhouette; this has a draped overskirt effect, is made with a pouf or similar back fullness, and, in some instances, actually leads to the 1875 bustle-bow styles.

BERLIN, Nov. 7. -- Prices on the Boerse returned to weakness today after yesterday's showing of the strength that now automatically accompanies the announcement of any government loan. Trading activity was strictly limited.

Women of Brazil are making effective use of their political equality with men, written into the Constitution only two years ago. There are today two women in Congress, Dr. Bertha Lutz and Dr. Carlota de Queiroz. Distributed throughout the country are ten women Mayors, ten Assemblywomen and thirty Councilwomen, and eight women serve the nation as consuls in foreign lands.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 6. -- The recent coup d'etat in Iraq, the impending Parliamentary ratifications of the Anglo-Egyptian treaty and the Franco-Syrian treaty, and the lack of whole-hearted sympathy in neighboring Arab countries for the recent Palestine-Arab disturbances are evidence that the newly created post-war States are far more interested in their own local politics than in any confederation of Arab countries.

DETROIT, Nov. 7. -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin announced tonight that his National Union for Social Justice, which he said was "thoroughly discredited" as the result of Tuesday's national election, will cease to be active and that he was "hereby withdrawing from all radio activity in the best interests of all the people."

For his initial Saturday night students' concert, John Barbirolli chose to lead the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra through its paces in a program the first half of which was devoted entirely to music by his compatriots. This English division, preceding the intermission, consisted of a suite for strings, arranged by Mr. Barbirolli from various works by Henry Purcell; the Bax symphonic poem, "The Tale the Pine-Trees Knew," and Elgar's "Enigma" variations.

Richest of all specialty events anywhere in monetary returns to the exhibitors, the fifteenth annual specialty show of the Cocker Spaniel Breeders' Club of New England will be given Friday and Saturday, Nov. 20 and 21, in Horticultural Hall, Boston.
CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (AP). -- Four men who, according to police, were associates of a robber slain in a Wild West hold-up at the Pow Wow roadhouse early today were held for questioning tonight.

"National Art Week," sponsored by the American Artists Professional League, will begin today. New York City itself will scarcely be affected, but throughout the nation art will be the subject of lectures, radio broadcasts, sermons, gallery talks and women's club meetings.

UPHELD on the one hand as a vital factor in accident prevention, condemned on the other as a needless annoyance and expense to the motorist, the system of motor vehicle inspection goes into the 1937 season greatly extended in scope. In one form or another periodic inspection of certain classes of vehicles is required in eighteen States.

Further sharp gains in seasonal- apparel sales featured local retail trade last week. Increases ranging up to 25 per cent in Winter garments over the comparative 1935 period were scored by some department stores here. Average volume for the week ranged around 11 per cent above last year.

ALTHOUGH Sinclair Lewis is our foremost man of letters, he does not trade on his eminence nor act the literary grandee. He has not lost the neighborly American habit of pitching in when there is a community job to be done.

ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- Events on the program of Armistice Day, Nov. 11, include a skeet shoot at the Bingham Heights Club on Wednesday afternoon. That evening several cocktail and dinner parties will be held in private homes, the country clubs and hotels.

BEFORE long, it seems, everybody in town will own a turtle. One "turtle shop" is selling nearly a hundred a day. Little things about the size of a dollar, with their backs painted any color you like, and their names written right across them.

Many reservations have been made for the card party and supper of the Ladies of Charity of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York on Tuesday at Schrafft's, Fifty-seventh Street and Broadway. Proceeds will be donated to the general fund of the organization.

RICHARD ALDRICH is up to very large -- if still slightly mysterious -- things. Already his schedule called for six productions, and last week he tacked on another, making a portfolio about as distended as the Shuberts'.

RADIO'S big blow of words for 1936 is over; the quadrennial Presidential campaign on the air has gone with the wind. Radio as a verbal battlefield of politicians was as "clean" the morning after election as it was when the campaign opened.

Three hundred women attended a luncheon held yesterday by the Women's Committee of the American League Against War and Fascism at the Parc Vendome, 344 West Fifty-seventh Street. Hubert M. Herring of the Cultural Relations Committee with Latin America and Margaret Forsythe of Teachers College were the principal speakers.

THE future success of the automobile industry rests upon the successful running of the used-car business. New-car sales and service are hampered when any dealer becomes overstocked with cars that are traded in when new automobiles are bought.

THE standard of living in America is constantly on the upgrade. This ability of Americans to better their conditions is one of their inherent greatnesses. It is the force that makes for progress, that keeps us in world leadership, that makes us a nation of individualists instead of a nation of peasants.

PARIS, Nov. 7. -- In introducing the budget proposals now being distributed to members of Parliament, Vincent Auriol, Finance Minister, stressed that the deficit for 1937 will not be dangerous provided it is honestly presented and measures are taken to insure a return to a balanced budget.

When it comes to supplying cheerful, sunny tints to the early Spring garden no group of plants, in all the wide range of available material, can compare with the daffodil. Almost every gardener, even the greenest, realizes this; but some amateurs do not realize how easily daffodils can be grown, and how long, once planted, they continue to give returns in ever-increasing beauty.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 7. -- The Transbay Bridge, completed at a cost of twenty-four lives and $77,200,000, will open Thursday to commuting motorists of San Francisco and her sister cities.

ROME, Nov. 5. -- Although Premier Benito Mussolini in his speech in Milan last Sunday damned the League of Nations, disarmament, collective security and indivisible peace as dangerous illusions and did not suggest anything to take their place, his address was not lacking in constructive qualities.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 7. -- The Westchester Supper Club opened its third season tonight with a dinner dance at the Larchment Country Club. Eight dances will be given this Winter by the club. George M. Isdale, Edward H. Oakford and Russell M. Peters comprised the committee in charge.

BERLIN, Oct. 20. THE great Olympic cyclone that swept over Germany in the Summer, ingurgitating all and every one of its sundry forces, also hit up the theatre into a hectic but brief activity. For the sixteen days of the Olympiad every theatrical house had cleaned up its front doorstep and automatically fell into playing whatever last season's piece had best stood the ultimate test -- that of the box-office.

A memorial tablet and a fund to be known as the McLaughlin Memorial Fund will serve to commemorate rate the services to City College of Professor Frederick O.X. McLaughlin, who died June 28, 1936. President Frederick B. Robinson will make the model for the tablet personally as a tribute to his former colleague and friend.

A COMMEMORATIVE half-dollar will be issued on the occasion of the official opening ceremonies of the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge, on Thursday. Although 100,000 of these coins have been authorized, only 25,000 have been ordered, and these are being struck off in the San Francisco mint.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 7. -- Among the unusual courses open to women graduate students at Radcliffe are those in languages not ordinarily included in a college curriculum. Two young women are studying Chinese and Japanese, one as an aid to the study of Oriental history and one for use in fine arts.

WHEN a season ago James Hanley came out with his novel "The Furys" there was no intimation that the story, apparently complete in itself, was to form the first unit of a family saga. Perhaps Mr. Hanley had not then formed the idea of a continued treatment of his Liverpool dockers, or a further presentation of the remarkable character he had drawn in Mrs. Fury.

IN an age of critical loyalties men turn to parable to convey critical emotions; in an age so visibly uprooted as ours, men turn to satire to vent their bitterness -- or their nostalgia. By turning to both, Mr. Watson has not succeeded at either.

DALLAS, Texas, Nov. 7 (AP). -- Southpaw Jim Shockey and his Texas A. and M. team-mates stormed the Southern Methodist mustang corral with their own aerial thunder today for a crushing 22-6 triumph before 27,000 fans.

Once in a while the author of a book seems to have surprised children at play. recording an imaginative experience which other boys and girls will find infinitely beguiling. Sometimes it is an adult's sympathy with children that creates this make-believe, on rare occasions the writer looks straight back into his own childhood and catches himself there, deeply engrossed in his play world.

MR. HARLOW is a yarning historian, interested in oddities and in people. There is an engaging homespun quality about his books. Well and soundly made, they axe not so standardized as to have no space for absurdities.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7. -- Scoring in all but the second quarter, the undefeated Penn freshmen added Columbia's first-year eleven to their list of victims, 20 -- 0, today. The rugged Penn line kept the Lions' offense in check throughout most of the game.

OMAHA, Nov. 6. -- Corn Belt supporters of President Roosevelt are now wondering at the conservatism of their estimates of his strength in these States, while supporters of Governor Landon are asking themselves what made them think he had a chance in the Middle West.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 7. -- The Gettysburg College Bullets dissappointed their dads today when they dropped a hotly contested battle on Memorial Field in celebration of Dad's Day to the Dickinson Red Devils by a score of 21 -- 13.

PHILADELPHIA. Nov. 7 (AP) -President Roosevelt's address and the program for the Mobilization for Human Needs campaign were not broadcast last night over Philadelphia Radio Station WCAU because the local musicians' union objected to the Philadelphia Orchestra's taking part in the program over the station.

THE Fall migration of the water-fowl is on. High in the cold blue sky of Autumn the flocks of ducks and geese, swans and brants appear, winging southward in flying wedges and like formations, keeping perfect line behind strong and knowing leaders and going at the speed of the wind.

NOVEMBER is International Month to the meteorological services of the world. In all civilized and some uncivilized regions scores of sounding balloons will be released every day to float up to heights of fifteen miles and more -- all freighted with instruments which will automatically write down temperature, humidity, pressure.

STRIKING smartness in appearance is certainly attained in the latest offerings of automobile manufacturers. There are many evidences also of greater comfort, such as riding ease and plenty of space for passengers and luggage. Greater power in proportion to weight has also been gained.

New York's interest in books and their makers brought more than 7,000 persons yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair in the International Building, Rockefeller Center. The attendance was so heavy at afternoon and evening programs that for two hours in the afternoon and again at night visitors were admitted in groups of twenty-five to prevent jamming.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- A steady, general business recovery, notably lacking in "spectacular bursts here and there" was hailed today by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States as full of promise for the period ahead.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 7. -- Harvard again served notice today that it has developed into a power to be reckoned with in the football world. The Crimson eleven, fresh from its startling performance in holding the vaunted Princeton team to a tie last week, exhibited a wealth of strength this afternoon to crush a game University of Virginia aggregation, 65 -- 0.

A general increase of $2 to $3 a ton in prices of semi-finished and finished steel is expected to be announced by leading steel companies within two weeks as a result of the increase of about 10 per cent in wages to about 500,000 steel workers, which will become effective on Nov. 16.

A bridge party followed by tea on Nov. 12 at the Men's Faculty Club, Columbia University, 400 West 117th Street, will constitute the annual event for the benefit of the Manhattanville Day Nursery Association, 131st Street and Old Broadway.
IN general business and in the automotive industry, continued expansion is indicated for the new year, unless some unpredictable national calamity overtakes us.

ROCHESTER, Nov. 7. -- Skeletons of cats and elephants, stones for amateur lapidaries, meteors, snails from France and solenodons from Central America are offered for sale by the University of Rochester.

Sunshine every day in the year has been ordered for the pupils of the Boylan Street Open Air School in Newark, N.J. It is to be provided by one of the largest ultra-violet-ray group lamps ever to be installed in a public school. The machine is so big that it gives even distribution of light over sixteen children lying on cots and floods a room twenty-five feet square with its rays.

Although Konstanty Kempisty and Wilson Weyand of Manual Training finished first and second for the individual honors, Newtown High School barely beat the Park Slope team for the City P.S.A.L. cross-country championship at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

Many luncheons and dinners are being arranged for discussions of plans for the United Hospital campaign which will open on Nov. 16. Mrs. Douglas Gibbons of 430 Park Avenue will be hostess at a luncheon tomorrow at the St. Regis for members of committees of the woman's campaign division.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 7. -- Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Coffin of Elm Street gave a dinner tonight for Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Koons, Mr. and Mrs. Louis Naisawald, Mr. and Mrs. Frank Barnitz, Mr. and Mrs. George Harrington, Mrs. Charles Hoyt and Mrs. Henry Wandless.
BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Nov. 7. -Bloomfield High School's eleven turned back Irvington High, 20 -- 7, today before a crowd of more than 9,000.

One of those friendships which occasionally stud a fortunate child's life with shining hours, a friendship with an adult who without condescension can enter into a child's play, or, with equal flattery, treat a little girl with all the dignity due a grown-up, is the basis of this story.

Activity in the wholesale markets picked up last week, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. Mail requisitions were heavier than in the previous week and retailers generally reported brisk business on election day. The report continues:

Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of New York University, announced yesterday the promotion of Professor Sampson K. Barrett of the College of Engineering to assistant dean of the college. Mr. Barrett will be in charge of the Evening Engineering Division.

The Yorkville Civic Council, a group of civic, religious and welfare agencies operating in the Yorkville district, will be the beneficiary of a luncheon and fashion show on Tuesday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin.

The stock market resumed yesterday its post-election advance, following Friday's profit-taking, and leading industrial issues made net gains of 1 to 3 points. Railway shares, however, made little headway as a group. The turnover on the Stock Exchange in the half-day trading period reached 1,745,000 shares, or the largest Saturday total since Feb. 1; the Saturday before, trading aggregated but 733,000 shares.

The American Art Association Anderson Galleries will hold its second book sale of the season Tuesday afternoon and evening. It will include books from the collections of Paul M. Herzog and the late Henry Gilsey of Huntington, L.I., and autograph letters and documents from the collection of the late Walter T. Arndt.

The estimated deficit for the last fiscal year at Columbia University has unexpectedly been considerably reduced through the "wholehearted and able cooperation" of administrative officers and heads of departments, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, announced yesterday.

"The Roosevelt landslide last Tuesday was a hard blow to reactionary forces moving toward Fascism, also a mandate to the toiling masses responsible for the landslide to press forward aggressively for their immediate economic and political demands," it was declared by Earl Browder, Communist candidate for President, and William Z. Foster in a joint statement issued yesterday.

THE racegoer, like the swallow, has started for the Southland. With the running of the last race at Empire City on Nov. 1, and the one-day United Hunts meeting at Belmont on election day, thousands of persons immediately began packing bags for the first move on a racing itinerary which will take them to Maryland, Louisiana, Florida, Texas and California before they return for the opening of the New York season next April.
LONDON, Nov. 7. -- The Federation of American Women's Clubs Overseas has planned "peace luncheons" to be held early this month.

THIS is not the first novel in recent seasons to make dramatic capital of the conventional religious attitude, and particularly the attitude of the Roman Catholic Church, toward the question of divorce. But unquestionably it is one of the most sincere.
ALBANY, Nov. 7 (AP). -- Parents in New York State turned their thoughts today to observance of National Education Week, which will begin Monday.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 7 (AP). -- Two important independent steel operators, the National and the Republic, announced today that they will grant pay increases, virtually assuring increases to all of the industry's half-million workers on Nov. 16.

A radio fur-fashion show, to be broadcast tomorrow afternoon over a coast-to-coast hook-up of the Columbia Broadcasting System, will mark the opening of National Fur Week, Nov. 9-14. Furs reported to be worth $1,000,000 will be described for the radio audience by Prunella Wood, fashion writer for King Features Syndicate.

Mrs. Ira B. Downs has announced members of the dance committee for the annual Debutante Ball, to be held Thanksgiving Eve at the Heights Casino, Brooklyn. Patronesses for the ball are Mrs. Downs, Mrs. Cameron Duncan and Mrs. W. Wilson Holden.

PHILADELPHIA. Nov. 7. -- Michigan's long string of triumphs in intersectional clashes came to an abrupt and stunning end today as the powerful Pennsylvania juggernaut ground the Wolverines into the turf of Franklin Field in the presence of 40,000 spectators.

WHEN it was first announced in England that Dr. Albert Schweitzer was to record from the organ works of Bach, the project was classed as a "society" issue. Judging by precedent, this was taken to mean a limited edition to be subscribed for cash in advance, with no mercy for those who might find such terms temporarily inconvenient or did not care to buy a pig in a poke.

Carl Holt, 15 years old, of 319 Ninety-first Street, Brooklyn, was accidentally shot and killed at 11:30 A.M. yesterday while he was examining a 45-calibre automatic pistol in the home of a friend, Richard Greene, 17, at 214 Ninety-fourth Street.

CANTON, N.Y., Nov. 7. -- A step in college and community cooperation toward what may develop into an Institute of North Country Relations was taken last week when some 200 delegates from five northern counties met at the St. Lawrence University here to consider problems affecting the welfare of Northern New York.

THE first of five concerts for the benefit of the scholarship fund of Bennington College will be given tomorrow night at Town Hall by the Philharmonic-Symphony Chamber Orchestra, under the direction of Hans Lange. Again, as in his similar series for the same cause last season,. Mr. Lange has planned programs of wide variety and historical interest, composers represented on the opening schedule ranging from the seventeenth century Johann Rosenmueller to Ernest Bloch.

KEEPING pace with record-breaking automobile manufacture, the building and improvement of roads in the United States during the past year have provided motorists with many thousand more miles of modern highway. It also has furnished employment for hundreds of thousands of men.

THERE need be no qualification of the statement that 1937 will be the best post-depression year in the automobile industry. So many signs point to a continuation of the uptrend that any sales projection resolves itself into an estimate of how extensive will be the increase over 1936, the year in which the industry raced around the recovery curve at a pace nearly 26 per cent above the 1935 lap.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 7 -- The traditional Princeton-Yale Freshman football game on University Field today resulted in a 0-0 tie after four closely contested periods in which neither team ever came within the enemy 20-yard line.

A REDISCOVERY of our American decorative heritage is in progress, with examples of folk crafts and other local art expressions, hitherto little known, supplying motifs for designers and new material for collectors.

PRODUCTION of Latin pictures which boomed for a time, but about which little has been heard of late, shows signs of revival. During the early years of sound nearly every lot made Spanish language versions of some of its fare.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 7. -- Before a colorful crowd of 23,000, Holy Cross today conquered a favored Colgate eleven, 20 to 13. The game was replete with thrills and not until the closing minutes of the final quarter, when Bartolomeo went over from the 4-yard marker, was the game pulled out of the fire.

STABILITY and profit making marked operations in the automobile tire industry during the past year and both tire manufacturers and retailers look forward to a continuance of the successful performance in 1937. Not in years has the industry been so soundly optimistic about the future.

WHEN Shakespeare allotted to melancholy Jacques the deathless "All the world's a stage," he probably was not thinking of the future of his own plays. For not even from his lofty vantage point could he have foreseen that 320 years later his stage would indeed be all the world "from the East to Western Ind," through the medium of the motion picture.

EARLY risers these days who turn on their all-wave receivers should find clear signals audible from many quarters of the globe on the 9-megacycle, or 30-meter band, which is now particularly efficient for long-distance tuning.

THREE major characteristics must be built into the automobile of today in order to satisfy the exacting requirements of modern conditions. These three requirements are safety, comfort and ease of control. Many other qualities are desirable beyond these three, but without them they are meaningless.

FIFTEEN years ago next Wednesday we buried our Unknown Soldier in the most impressive military ceremonial in our history. World-famous statesmen and allied commanders followed his body in the funeral procession along Pennsylvania Avenue. Former President Wilson rose from his invalid's chair to ride from the Capitol to the White House.

THE Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Medal for services to chamber music was conferred this year on Edwin T. Rice, the fifth recipient of the award. Mrs. Coolidge made the presentation to Mr. Rice at the recent Founders Day concert given in the Library of Congress.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Nov. 7. -- Two long marches, brilliant in their execution and irresistible in their power, gave the undefeated Choate aggregation a sterling 13-12 victory today over a courageous Lawrenceville football team in the fifth annual meeting between the two rivals.

In marked contrast with the small volume of notices in the preceding three weeks, announcements last week of bonds called for redemption before maturity were more numerous and for larger amounts. Redemptions by public utility corporations predominated.

Miss Ruth Hammond, 25-year-old writer, was in Polyclinic Hospital yesterday after she had attempted to end her life, according to the police, by swallowing some capsules which she had obtained in a Broadway drug store.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Nov. 7. -- Discussions about the uncertain political situation in the Baltic region and the dangers to small North European States from a possible Russo-German war are expected to be resumed because of the crowing inclination of Eastern Baltic States to establish closer political relations with Scandinavia and Finland.

HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., Nov. 7. -- Seventy girls from New York City and vicinity are among eighty-five students who were initiated into the three sororities of Centenary Junior College this evening. Those initiated are:

VALENCIA, Spain, Oct. 29. -- The truth about the atrocities of which both the Insurgents and that part of the government forces known as Reds are accused, is not an easy matter to gauge, while the taking of hearsay reports is always dangerous.

During the week beginning Nov. 22 the Outdoor Cleanliness Association will conduct a "beauty benefit" at 715 Fifth Avenue, where a collection of paintings and sculpture pertaining to physical beauty and a private collection of miniature period rooms will be placed on exhibition.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7. -- Retail business in local department stores moved sharply upward during the week under the impetus of colder weather and the result of the Presidential election and was reported between 15 and 20 per cent ahead of last year.

Soaring retail sales figures, heavy commitments for merchandise in the wholesale markets, and announcements of wage increases, bonuses, extra dividend disbursements, gains in employment and plans for expansion of manufacturing facilities, featured developments in the trend of business last week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- Supreme Court attaches said today that unless the illness of Justice Stone was unexpectedly prolonged he could participate in the decisions. With the court closely divided on apparently fundamental issues affecting New Deal legislation, his absence might be decisive.
LANCASTER, Pa., Nov. 7. -- Franklin and Marshall College conquered the Geneva eleven by 39 -- 18 today before a crowd of 6,000.

When General Francisco Franco ordered his field guns to open fire on Madrid on Wednesday a new chapter in modern history was written. Speaking over a field telephone from his headquarters in the ancient university town of Salamanca, the Rightiest chieftain put a modern capital with more than a million inhabitants under a close-range rain of destruction and death for the first time.

THE new cars for 1937, described from material furnished by the manufacturers, are listed in alphabetical order below. Four of the English entries in the show are not included, because only general information is available at the time of going to press.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oakland and much of Northern California will celebrate this week the opening of the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge, which stretches across the bay for eight and a half miles to connect downtown San Francisco with the mainland of California at Oakland.

NOTWITHSTANDING the numerous accident-prevention campaigns undertaken during the year by the States, cities and a large number of national and local organizations, it would seem that motor-vehicle fatalities for 1936 will not be reduced below the total for last year.

THE Philadelphia Youth Orchestra, started two years ago by Leopold Stokowski and conducted by Sylvan Levin and Saul Caston, has been reorganized and is directed by Jacques Singer of the Philadelphia Orchestra. The Youth Orchestra, composed of musicians from 13 to 25 years of age, plans to give an initial concert soon.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 7. -- Retail business in the Ninth Federal Reserve District experienced the best week in several months, according to reports from store executives. Country stores reported a smaller gain than the urban merchants, but all over the district cold weather brought a sudden surge of buying.

While the third triennial conference and tournament of the International Federation of Women's Hockey Associations at the Philadelphia Cricket Club must remain for those fortunate enough to attend any of the games the high point of the present hockey season, and indeed several seasons to come, much of the most constructive work of the conference is being accomplished now.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 7. -- Undergraduate honors were won by 101 students at New Jersey College for Women during the past academic year, it was announced today by Miss Esther W. Hawes, registrar at the college. Students having an average of 1.8 or better in any year receive honors.

ELLIOT ORR, who is represented in the Brooklyn Museum and also in the Phillips Memorial Gallery, provides the material currently shown (until Nov. 16) at Macbeth's. As a catalogue foreword observes, the work of this young American artist is "mystical" in feeling.

COLLEGEVILLE, Pa., Nov. 7. -- The Drexel Dragons upset the Bears of Ursinus in the eighth annual meeting of the two Eastern Intercollegiate Athletic Conference teams today on Patterson Field, 7 -- 6. Tworzydlo, end, scored for Ursinus on a pass from Costello in the first period.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 7. -- Army rolled up the biggest score of its 1936 season today, defeating the Muhlenberg eleven by a 54 to 7 count. The Cadet line-up was composed of substitute players for the greater part of the afternoon, although some of the varsity men saw brief action.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP). -- American-born Mme. Jules Jusserand, whose late husband was French Ambassador here for more than twenty years, today placed Europe's hope for peace in its very disagreements.

SEEKING the comforts and advantages that Florida offers during the Winter months, visitors have begun to appear in every section of the peninsula, bringing golf clubs, bathing suits, fishing tackle and other accouterments of diversion.

Remembrance of previous deeds alone should be enough to inspire fulfillment of the annual roll-call of the American Red Cross. Owen D. Young, chairman of the New York Chapter of the Red Cross, said yesterday in announcing the group chairmen who will conduct the fund raising in the industries, professions, businesses and governmental units.

Anything but a static atmosphere is in prospect for the forty-second annual convention of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs, for which hundreds of delegates will invade the city this week. The program for the event at the Hotel Pennsylvania, opening tomorrow and continuing through Thursday, reflects the disposition of member groups to alter attitudes to keep pace with the pattern of progress definitely outlined a year ago at Syracuse.

William Henderson, 32 years old, a Negro laborer, unemployed at present but temporarily trying his skill at salesmanship, brought his first day at the new trade to an inglorious finale last night after he attempted to sell one of his wares (a .38-caliber pistol) to a patrolman.

Cardinal Pacelli, Papal Secretary of State, sailed for Rome yesterday on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia after spending several weeks in this country. He visited the ecclesiastical provinces and had a two-hour conversation with President Roosevelt.

Steadily increasing activity in manufacturing industries is paving the way for the most intensive period of factory construction in the history of the United States, according to George A. Bryant Jr. of Cleveland, executive vice president of the Austin Company, industrial engineers and builders.

WAREHOUSES of New York are now bulging with nuts in anticipation of the heaviest selling season of the year. Since August domestic and foreign crops have been arriving in generous quantities; within a few weeks the storage plants will disgorge their stocks to the holiday buyers and call for still more consignments.

The opening feature of the "Tintype Tea" to be held at the Savoy-Plaza on Nov. 19 will be the showing of motion pictures taken recently at a committee meeting at the home of Mrs. Ernest P. Davies, chairman of Auxiliaries 1 and 16 of the Stony Wold Sanatorium, which is the beneficiary of the tea.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 7. -- The Upsala College eleven won its second game of the season at Viking Field today, defeating Alfred, 13-6, in a hotly contested battle. Bill Wilson's 70-yard run in the first period put the ball on the Alfred 20, and Vito Miele smashed the line for the first score in five line plays.

Homeless children who are aided by the Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association will be the beneficiaries of a gala dinner and supper dance to be held on Wednesday in the Guard Room of the Park Lane. Many novelties and surprise features have been planned for the occasion.

UNTOLD millions of dollars and the most intensive efforts of many thousands of persons have gone into the huge task of making American motor cars better for 1937. It has been a task successfully accomplished. The new models are better cars.

BRUSSELS. THE work of linking up the northern and southern railway stations in Brussels and opening a junction in the centre of the city is proceeding apace. Buildings in ancient quarters of the city are being leveled to make room for the new line, partly overhead, partly under ground.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- The White House program of official entertainments for the coming social season was announced today by Mrs. Roosevelt.

ANNVILLE, Pa., Nov. 7. -- Gathering momentum after a scoreless first half, the St. Joseph's College eleven conquered Lebanon Valley, 15 -- 0, today. It was the Hawks' first victory over Lebanon Valley since the institutions started athletic relations in 1916 and the first defeat ever sustained by Lebanon Valley on home-coming day.

To celebrate the opening of the new annex to the Jones Memorial Children's Center of the Children's Aid Society, 405-11 East Seventy-third Street, an open house and tea will be given at those quarters on Thursday afternoon. Near-by residents of the East Sixties and Seventies are invited.

MADRID, Nov. 7 (AP). -- As Spain's Leftist Cabinet fled today before insurgent forces a military council headed by General Jose Miaja took command of Madrid's defenses, replacing the civil government.

A SKEPTIC, inclined to cynicism, yet studious, Fulton Oursler made a stopover visit to Palestine. He traveled with his family and a guide from Haifa to Nazareth and the Sea of Galilee; to Cana, and Capernaum, and Magdala, and to Jerusalem.
American Education Week, proclaimed by President Roosevelt and beginning tomorrow, will be celebrated by the three city colleges under the jurisdiction of the Board of Higher Education.

WE are like dwarfs," said Bernard of Chartres. "seated on the shoulders of giants. We see more things than the Ancients and things more distant, but it is due neither to the sharpness of our sight nor the greatness of our stature; it is simply because they have lent us their own."

NEW CITY, N.Y., Nov. 7. -- Members of the September Rockland County grand jury handed in a formal resolution to County Judge John McKenna today which recommended that Rockland legislators promote legislation to legalize dog race track betting.

Reporting that a forward surge in Christmas shopping is already evident, after an earlier start than for any year since 1929, the National Retail Dry Goods Association yesterday announced the results of a survey, which disclosed a "genuine belief among merchants that consumer spending will now be unleashed in full force for a tidal wave of holiday spending."

MRS. BELLOC LOWNDES serves another delectable dish of romance and intrigue in the lofty atmosphere of the English upper classes. Ancient titles, gentlemen swindlers and medieval castles with inadequate plumbing, set off the ingenuous charm of the American heroine.

A touchdown plunge of four yards by Albert Groh in the last minute enabled Fordham Prep to hand Mount St. Michael High its first setback in five games at Fordham Field yesterday. The score was 12 -- 6.

It was a dreary journey from England to the little stockaded town of Plymouth for the Red Cow, but hers was a distinguished lot. Donated by Mr. Shirley of the English Company to the poor of Plymouth, she was the first cow to really belong to the colonists of New England.

America, land of daring endeavor in industry and finance, is too seldom acclaimed as the country of greatest achievement in education. Some years ago the United States Office of Education and the National Education Association set aside a special period to take stock of the work of our schools, to make their methods known to all the people and to promote a finer understanding between parents and teachers.
TWO veteran comedians return to the air this week, namely, Jack Pearl and Ed Wynn.
No trip to a scientific museum can make the development of modern conveniences such a personal and vivid affair as does this little story of their gradual introduction into American family life.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- There is every indication that the Fall and Winter season in the Poconos will be one of the most successful in the history of the section; all of the larger hotels are making preparations to care for record crowds throughout the next few months.

Commodity futures were much higher in the week ended on Friday, due principally to bullish interpretations placed on the election results, but some minor profit-taking occurred at the end of the period. The cash markets reached several new high points for the year, with virtually the entire list advancing and no declines showing.

Under the theory and practice of the Federal tax on undistributed profits of corporations, a lack of funds with which to pay dividends does not generally excuse a corporation from the imposition of the surtax. In the absence of available liquid funds, the law encourages and even contemplates the making of distributions in property, in obligations of the corporation, in taxable stock dividends and stock rights.

ON Sept. 14 last, residents of the State of Maine flocked to the polls and by an overwhelming majority voted for an initiated law prohibiting diversion of special motor vehicle taxes to non-highway purposes. This was one of the outstanding developments from the motorists' standpoint during 1936.

ANOTHER bear-hunting season is in full swing in the deep forests of the North Carolina and Tennessee highlands. Hungry bruins are lumbering down from the wind-swept peaks to feast on acorns and chestnuts until their ribs are blanketed with a layer of fat for their long Winter's nap.

PARIS, Nov. 6. -- Now that Parliament has opened its Winter session with Premier Leon Blum firmly in command, political pundits are trying to figure out how long he will remain there and whether his restive majority will hold together long enough to pass his ambitious program.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- President Roosevelt paid tribute to the late Jean Jules Jusserand, France's Ambassador to the United States for more than twenty years, at the dedication of a memorial in Rock Creek Park today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- A varied sports program gets under way in Atlantic City this week and continues throughout the Winter. With the closing of the football season, ice hockey, wrestling and basketball will become the center of interest.

SAN FRANCISCO. WITH a record, certified by the Department of Commerce at Washington, of the lowest traffic fatality rate of any large city in the country, San Francisco is justly proud of the measures it has taken to protect both motorist and pedestrian.

The gross debt of the Province of British Columbia on Oct. 31 was $180,309,467, an increase of $800,699 since Nov. 1, 1935, according to John Hart, Minister of Finance of the Province. Sinking funds amounted to $34,694,548, an increase of $1,037,613 in the twelve months, and the net debt after that was $145,614,919, a decrease of $236,913, he said.

AS a part of the British Empire scheme for air transport of all first-class mail at ordinary postage rates, which will go into effect ere long, British paper-making firms are producing special lightweight stationery which will enable banking houses, shippers and business firms to take full advantage of bulk transport by air.

Plans for the annual Christmas tree celebration for pets and their owners to be held Dec. 24 at headquarters of the Humane Society, 313 East Fifty-eighth Street, have been made by members of the society. During the past year the society aided 3,000 pets through its relief and protective work, free clinic and maintenance of watering stations in the Summer months.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 7. (AP). -- A mighty University of Washington football team and an underrated Stanford eleven locked today in a thrill-filled encounter which resulted in a 14-14 tie.

MRS. KEYES is a popular novelist with an evident skill for evolving long novels in which the principal idea is to put well bred characters through their paces until the main love interest is fulfilled. Her characters behave charmingly -- a little too charmingly, perhaps.

Ten million grown-ups -- fathers, mothers, sisters, cousins, aunts -- will swarm through school buildings from coast to coast this week. Some of them will hear junior recite in one-room schoolhouses, little changed from those they themselves attended twenty-five years ago.

JOHN DOE, ESQ., is a moderately successful broker. He owns and knows the joys of a modern home and its comforts; ordinarily his life runs in a well-worn groove. At present he is sitting on a cold piece of concrete, out in the open air, his shoulders wedged against the shoulders of those near him.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7. -- An ovation greeted the playing of Sergei Rachmaninoff's new Symphony No. 3 by the Philadelphia Orchestra tonight under Leopold Stokowski. At the conclusion of the famous pianist's latest orchestral work, the audience at the Academy of Music stood and applauded with great enthusiasm as Mr. Stokowski and the orchestra members acknowledged the reception.

COOKEVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 7 (AP). -- The disputed right of nineteen Southern power companies to make a mass attack on the whole Tennessee Valley Authority power program won approval of Federal District Court today.

VIENNA, Nov. 6. -Among the repercussions of Mussolini's truculent speech at Milan, commonest in Central and Southeastern Europe, is bewilderment. This is true even in Hungary, where Il Duce's postulation of satisfaction of her demands as a prime condition for the regulation of Danubian affairs has stirred up the always extravagant Magyar hopes.
PALMER, Alaska, Nov. 7 (AP). -- Matanuska Farm colony housewives have no time for contract bridge; they are too busy this Winter with Homemakers' Club work and practical handcrafts.

THIS week the automobile industry is presenting its 1937 models. They are introduced with the belief that the improvements in the new line will provide the public with better and more economical automotive transportation than ever before.

CHICAGO. THE highway construction carried on in the Chicago area in the past year was composed chiefly of widening and repaving city streets. The aim of this program is to establish a primary system of arterial streets connecting with State highways entering the city.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 7. -- A Navy son of a Navy family brought a white-crested surge of Navy blue down on the gridiron of the Baltimore Stadium late today to engulf the goal posts and celebrate the first major victory of the season for the Naval Academy's football team.

THE automobile for 1937 is a conventional car; a description which served in the past to depict many a box-like voiture which presented flat surfaces to the direction of travel, with straight, flat sides and a flat back all tied together and crowned with a flat roof.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., Nov. 7. -- The New York Aggies held the Brooklyn College football team to a 6-all tie today on the Aggies' gridiron. Archie Lehr, right halfback, counted for Brooklyn in the second quarter and Nick Pecora, quarterback, went over in the third for the home team.
LONDON, Nov. 7. -- Britain wonders with mounting interest today what President Roosevelt will do with his unprecedented victory.

THE fact that New York City leads the nation among cities of more than 500,000 population in the reduction of traffic accident fatalities is not a matter of luck. The consistent, intelligent and relentless drive by the members of the Police Department, combined with the whole-hearted cooperation of civic, business and social organizations, has succeeded in awakening the public to the seriousness of the traffic problem.
BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Nov. 7. -- Indiana University preserved its share of Big Ten intersectional football prestige today as it eked out a 9-7 victory over Syracuse before a crowd of 10,000.

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 7. -- Three touchdowns, one on a spectacular 51-yard dash by Bob MacLeod and the others on short plunges by John Handrahan, were more than Columbia could match today and Dartmouth almost erased bitter memories of last year by taking the game, 20 to 13.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- Fourteen companies manufacturing school supplies, seven of them in and near New York, and the trade association of which they are principal members, were cited today by the Federal Trade Commission on a charge of combination in restraint of competition.

A better understanding between school principals and parents associations is promised by a joint statement of conclusions regarding relationships between them which has been prepared by the United Parents Associations and the New York Principals Association.

MELODRAMA, a certain amount of sociological study and a good deal of mingled love story and comedy of manners are the principal elements in Phyllis Bottome's new novel, "Level Crossing." The comedy of manners comes first, and, with the love story, takes up more than half the book.

THE reliability of today's motor vehicle is taken for granted. Two decades ago it required a day's tinkering to make the Sunday jaunt successful. Better materials, improved manufacturing methods, the experience of cars in service and the results of laboratory work have changed all this.

URBANA, Ill., Nov. 7 (AP). -- One of the things the American farmer needs today is a new type of hog -- one that is "streamlined with fat on its belly instead of its back," declares Professor Sleeter Bull, associate chief in meats at the College of Agriculture of the University of Illinois.

ENGLAND need have no fears for its empire so long as Hollywood insists upon being the Kipling of the Pacific. The film city's pious regard for the sacrosanct bearers of the white man's burden continues to be one of the most amusing manifestations of Hollywood's anglophilia.
Local officials of the Federal Social Security Board turned to Washington yesterday for the solution of their first major dilemma under the Security Act.

A carillon concert of international melodies will precede a vesper service this afternoon at 4:30 o'clock at the Riverside Church, opening the customary week of world fellowship and prayer under auspices of the Y.W.C.A. in fifty-two countries.

Identical programs will be heard at two all-day conferences to be held by the New Jersey Committee on the Cause and Cure of War at the Methodist Episcopal Church, Dover, tomorrow and at the Presbyterian Church, Mount Holly, on Tuesday.

DEVOTEES of the camera and its work have six exhibitions at once on the calendar to delight them. Approximately 350 prints by 250 photographers from all parts of the country have been selected from among some 2,000 prints submitted by more than a thousand contributors to form the National Salon of Photography, sponsored by the Oval Table Society of New York.

A CLUE to the uniforms which King Edward wears in confusing number may be found in a copy of the British Army List, published monthly by His Majesty's Stationery Office. Not only is the King a field marshal, but he is colonel-in-chief of almost a score of regiments, each of which has a distinctive dress.

John Ely Burchard of Boston, who has "laid impractical aims to physicists," displays a lack of understanding of the proper relation of pure and applied science. He apparently thinks that the physicists should turn gladly from their fundamental researches to the solution of the problems of an antiquated and reactionary industry -- building -- diverting for the purpose the very slender resources available for fundamental research.

FROM the point of view of the average reader, the trouble with most war literature is that the writers attempt too much or too little. There seems to be no mean between running through a terse chronology of unconnected events and sticking to a half-acre of Flanders mud, and for a couple of hundred pages trying to keep track of illogically numbered and lettered masses.
KENT, Conn., Nov. 7. -- Kent School's football team brought an end to Taft's sensational record of having been unbeaten in nineteen clashes since late in 1933 when it upset its rival, 6 -- 0, today.

BERLIN, Nov. 7. -- Compensation trade, one of the mainstays of German-American commercial relations, has been virtually done away with. In the future no compensation deal between a German importer and a foreign exporter will be allowed unless more than 50,000 marks worth of German exports is involved in a single deal.

THE National Horse Show opened with a gala performance. The first night was like a fanfare announcing the launching of the brilliant social season. Smart women turned out in glamorous attire. At this, the earliest of the Winter's big public events, they showed their intention to dress extravagantly and to reflect in their appearance the more generous days at hand.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Nov. 7. -- Falling short in their brilliant last-quarter rally, Curtis High's eleven went down to a 13-to-12 setback before Marblehead High today. The Staten Island eleven scored two touchdowns in a thrilling final period, but failed to make the conversions.

ORONO, Me., Nov. 7. -- Seeking to carry the challenge of intellectual curiosity and initiative to freshmen. the University of Maine is this year extending its preparatory experiments of the last few years to a completed honors program. First-year students who show genuine academic distinction will at the end of the present term be selected to direct their future studies toward an honors degree.

VIENNA celebrates its great harvest home festival on Nov. 15. It likewise observes St. Leopold's Day, on which for nearly 800 years Austrians have commemorated the birth of their patron saint. This day also is known as "Gaenze Tag," or Goose Day, for the feast is consummated at night with a hearty meal of fat goose.

With preparations for the Christmas holiday season marked by a greater percentage of advance buying by many merchants than that which marked even the 1929 period, and with price rises in effect or scheduled on a wide range of merchandise for Spring, the reversal of hand-to-mouth buying practices by the rank and file of retailers is slowly but surely getting under way, merchandisers here agreed yesterday.

Paul Moss, Commissioner of Licenses, will receive a delegation of prominent clubwomen at 11 A.M. tomorrow to discuss the effect on children's eyes of restricted seating at motion picture performances. Mrs. Edward T. Herbert, chairman of motion pictures for the State Federation; Mrs. Willis P. Miner, who holds the same office in the City Federation, and Mrs. Edward M. Wolff, president of the Women's Auxiliary to the Greater New York Optometric Society, will attend.
BOSTON, Nov. 7. -- Honor awards were conferred upon three seniors and one sophomore of Simmons College by President Bancroft Beatley at the annual Founders' Day Convocation this week.

There is a growing field of opportunity for the student who has been trained for social service work, according to Professor Agnes M.H. Byrnes, chairman of the pre-social work course of study at Hunter College. Professor Byrnes surveyed possible opportunities in more than 1,000 public and private welfare agencies in New York City which are looking for trained specialists, and the Home Relief Bureau, with a staff of 11,000 workers.

In a letter published recently in THE NEW YORK TIMES P. Mas aims to give Spain the sole credit for the discovery of America by Christopher Columbus, even to the extent of excluding subsequent discoveries in the Americas under Dutch, French and English auspices.
AMONG the Far West's principal scenic attractions this season are the great Federal irrigation and power projects at Grand Coulee, Boulder, Fort Peck, Casper-Alcova and Bonneville.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 7 (AP). -- Ohio State soared into the first division of the Big Ten standing today by smothering a weak Chicago team, 44 to 0, as the Buckeye offense clicked on all cylinders.

VARIETY of unusual usages of standard and special models of Dodge trucks and commercial cars this year has been the greatest in the history of the country, according to Joseph D. Burke, director of truck sales for the Dodge division of Chrysler Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- President Roosevelt's election triumph was so overwhelming that it can hardly be attributed to any one factor or any one class of voters, but leaders in agriculture and labor circles here attribute much of its decisiveness to the backing of farmers and wage-earners.

THIS reporter of musical events seated himself in Carnegie Hall last Thursday evening, when the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra gave its opening concert of the season, with the pleasant feeling of being home again and present at an uncommonly interesting inauguration of the New York orchestra's season. Of the part in that opening taken by John Barbirolli, who then made his debut in America as a conductor, much has been said in earlier columns than this one.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 7. -- The poetry of the college undergraduate, taken seriously for once, has provided, through the files of the Yale Literary Magazine for an actual century, the only opportunity yet given for reviewing the last hundred years of American verse presented through a single medium.

The recent death of Commodore Sir Edgar T. Britten, master of the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, has resulted in several temporary changes in the assignments of members of the staff and widespread discussion of the probable successor to the rank of commodore of the fleet.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 7. -- The fact that China continues steadfast in refusing to give favorable consideration to Japan's demands for creation of a special area in North China and cooperation against Communist activities is believed here to have an intimate relation with the renewal of attacks upon the Eastern Suiyuan Province border.

THE automobile industry has already answered with action the question, "What About Business for 1937?" Not in the last decade have manufacturers' expenditures for new plants, new equipment, tools and dies run as heavy as they have in preparation for 1937.

ROBERT HALLOWELL RICHARDS was the seventh student to register in the Massachusetts Institute of Technology when that school was first opened in 1865. In 1914, at the age of 70, he retired from the professorship of mining engineering, which he had held since 1873, and became professor emeritus.

LONDON, Nov. 4. -- On Monday the Embassy Theatre will present John Watts-Phillips's "Decree Nisi," with Joyce Bland, staged by Campbell Gullan. The same evening will witness the new edition of "Blackbirds of 1936," at the Adelphi. Tuesday will see the eagerly awaited "Muted Strings," which opens at Daly's with Keneth Kent in the leading role as Beethoven.

A startling passage occurs in a recent daily book column. The highly competent reviewer is speaking about the new edition of Boswell's Tour of the Hebrides, which he happily describes as a dress rehearsal for the famous "Life of Samuel Johnson."

WHILE it is true that joyriders and jaywalkers are still collaborating with the juries in maintaining automobile insurance rates at a high, almost prohibitively high, figure as far as liability insurance is concerned, the fact remains that the joyriders and jaywalkers are the least important factors when the time comes for the underwriters to revise the rate schedules.
AUGUSTA, Ga. -- Although the hotels here have not yet opened for the season, Winter residents have already begun to open their homes and many will participate in several social events this week.

The 1,405 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $45,018,484,420 par value as of Nov. 1, had a total market value of $43,179,898,054, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. On Oct. 1 there were 1,404 issues, aggregating $45,210,851,030 par value, and $43,305,464,747 in market value.

Unable to cope with Carnegie Tech's powerful running attack, N.Y.U. went down to its third defeat of the current campaign yesterday, trailing the heavily-manned Skibos, 14 to 6, before 9,000 persons at the Yankee Stadium.

The Railway Association's report of earnings of Class I railways during September, and for the nine completed months, was published last week. The figures make the following interesting comparisons with previous years. September earnings were as follows, net railway operating income being computed after deducting taxes:

THAT 1937 will be a great year for the automobile industry is reliably predicted with indices pointing to a more than 4,000,000-car production year, and sales likely to top the record year of 1929. But of greater importance to the public, 1937 will also be a banner year from the standpoint of the public which buys new motor cars.

FEW accountants are able to reduce to dollars and cents the value of customer good-will. Most business men realize how tremendously important it is to their welfare. They will, if good business men, do almost anything to get it or to retain it.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., Nov. 7. -- The crack Amityville High School football combination set a new Suffolk County scoring record while increasing its consecutive winning streak to sixteen games as the result of a 70-to-0 victory over Patchogue High today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7. -- A new high level for the season was reached today by the December and July deliveries of corn futures as the market continued the advance that has been under way a week. December corn soared 4 cents a bushel, the maximum permitted in a day, as the result of general short-covering and on buying induced by reports that shipping sales of cash grain had aggregated 152,000 bushels.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Nov. 7 (AP). -- The passing arm of Slingin' Sam Baugh tossed the Texas Christian Horned Frogs to another football triumph today, this time bewildering the Texas University team with a 27-to-6 victory.

MANILA. -- previous records were shattered by Philippine gold production during the month of September. The total bullion output of the nineteen producing mines in the Philippines lacked $6,000 of reaching the $2,000,000 mark.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6. -- Up and down Pennsylvania, into every one of its-sixty-seven counties, there has ridden during the last few months a genial, boyish-faced, rather sleepy looking traveler of 45, calling upon his fellow-citizens to turn the "Republican rascals" out of the State Senate and enable this Commonwealth to adopt a New Deal program of economic reform.

The old-age insurance section of the Social Security Act, painted in such lurid colors by recent Republican oratory, is now about to go into effect. Forms are to be distributed by the postal authorities this month. Lovers of the dramatic will be somewhat disappointed.

The Williams College Museum of American Music and the pension fund of the Philadelphia Orchestra will be the beneficiaries of the concert of American music to be given on the night of Dec. 1 at the Hippodrome by Paul Whiteman's Orchestra and the Philadelphia Orchestra.
The children's matinee, a feature of the annual book exhibition of the National Arts Club, is being revived this year and will take place on Saturday at 2:30 P.M. in the club, 15 Gramercy Park.

HERE in New York State is the world's greatest motor problem, with gross receipts for the present calendar year to Aug. 31 of $44,600,000. We have a gain in money over last year for the same period of $2,707,000. Up to Sept. 1 we had registered 2,414,000 vehicles of all kinds -- an increase over the same period last year of 124,500.
FROM Irving Fineman of Bennington College, Bennington, Vt., the following letter has been received. The point raised deserves thoughtful consideration. Mr. Fineman writes:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- Does President Roosevelt's overwhelming victory mean that organized labor is now on the way toward discarding its nonpartisan political policy -- "to defeat labor's enemies and reward its friends" -- and embarking on independent political action?

MOTORING safety today is more than ever in the public eye. Safety surveys are being made by many interested organizations. Magazines and newspapers have been full of the topic for months and public interest is at a high level.

Early in September you printed editorial comment on Surrogate Foley's interpretation of a will which had been made more than seventy-five years ago. What you had to say concerned solely the meaning of the expressions used in the instrument, but it seems to me that there was implicit in the situation a matter of even greater significance.

ENLARGED in size arid enriched in variety, with an industry enthusiastic for next year behind it, the thirty-seventh annual National Automobile Show will open at 2 o'clock on Wednesday afternoon, Armistice Day, at the Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue, between Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Streets.

LEGANES, Spain, Nov. 7 (AP). -- Spanish Insurgents this evening awaited the signal to fall upon Madrid as they commanded the approaches to four bridges across the Manzanares River, only a few hundred yards from the capital's city limits.
GENERAL MOTORS this year introduces the new "unisteel" turret top body by Fisher, a body that is a single unit of steel, as the name implies.

Daphne, or garland-flower, is one of the evergreen shrubs that has been most in demand at nurseries and roadside stands in the last year or two. Certainly this daphne (D. cneorum) has many recommendations, chief among them the fact that it is a neat, clean shrub covered with rose-pink flowers in May.
PARIS, Nov. 7. -- The flight of the Spanish Republican Government from Madrid to Valencia and the imminent occupation of the capital by the Rebels place France, and indeed all Europe, in a dilemma.

Society filled the boxes on the fourth night of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden. The display of fashion last night was more brilliant than usual on account of the horse show ball and supper which followed the evening performance.

RYE, N.Y., Nov. 7. -- At the Westchester Country Club here on Thursday night the annual meeting and dinner of the Westchester County Children's Association will be held. Dr. Lewis A. Wilson, Assistant Commissioner of Education of the New York State Department of Education, will give the principal address on "A Vocational Plan for Westchester County."

A partial list of committees for the annual benefit theatre party of the Maternity Center Division of the Brooklyn Visiting Nurse Association has been announced. The play selected for the benefit, to be held Dec. 11, is "The Country Wife" and the theatre is the Henry Miller.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 6. -- After months of negotiation between corporation legislatives and employe representatives, or company unions, the long-expected wage increase for the upward of 500,000 workers of the steel industry, an advance averaging 10 per cent, was officially announced today.
