WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP). -- Sitting up until 2:30 A.M. today to sign mail caused Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt to declare for a less strenuous life -- If possible -- for her "second term" as "first lady."

CHOCK full of engaging anecdotes about interesting people, and with the affairs of a new 1,000,000 film company perched lightly on his Irish shoulders, Mr. Herbert Wilcox landed in New York from London last week and shook down at the Ritz.

There was nothing unexpected in the tone or substance of Mr. EDEN'S latest statement on foreign policy. The British line remains what it has been -- to keep alive the League idea, to prevent the division of Europe into two camps by refusing to take sides with either, to go forward with the program to equip England to defend the interests of the Empire by armed strength.

NEEDHAM, Mass., Nov. 7. -- Scribbled notes found beside the body of Dr. Harold H Beiermeister, 53, retired physician, left to the medical profession today a record of sensations he experienced for two hours before his death last night.
POTTSTOWN, Pa., Nov. 7. -- Fighting to a 25-0 victory, the Blue and Gray eleven of Hill School overwhelmed a stubborn Princeton second freshman team from Tigertown today.
ANY appraisal of American business at this stage of recovery is most encouraging and produces the inevitable conclusion that nothing can stop the forward stride during 1937.

AGAINST Kipling's fiction Mr. Beresford here sets his own truth. "We may," he says, "be amused at the strange sight of the British public imagining that in 'Stalky Co.' it was having an apercu, a little peep, at Gigger's real biography.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 7. -- The pent-up dynamite of Princeton's attack exploded like bursting shell fire in Palmer Stadium today and the thirsting Tiger went on a scoring rampage that buried Cornell under a 41-13 score.
BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 7 (AP). -- The Boston College Eagles came through here today to defeat Hunk Anderson's North Carolina State Wolfpack, 7 -- 3, in a game marred by frequent fumbling.

MANY will welcome this surprising novel for various and peculiar merits, but it is doubtful whether any will acclaim it for what it is in reality, a contemporary work bordering upon greatness. Coming as it does at this time out of a Germany where the art of literature, at all events, is practically at a standstill, it looms as all the more remarkable.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa. -- The Nationalist party, which is the official Opposition in the House of Assembly, the Union Parliament, is making determined preparations to contest the next general election two years hence. Its slogan is "Away from the British Empire -- South Africa for the South Africans."
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 7 (AP). -- A row of huge sunspots, more than 1,250,000 miles long and resembling a titanic necklace, appeared today on the face of the sun.
AM I made wrong?
GRINNELL, Iowa, Nov. 7. -- Senior students at Grinnell College are having a chance this college year to earn two credits toward a diploma by learning how to land a job.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP). -- Because wages for the hired man are advancing and seed and feed costs have jumped, the Agricultural Department forecasts that things the farmer buys will average "a little higher next year."

ENCOURAGED by the unusually good business enjoyed by resorts within and close to the metropolitan area during the past Summer, plans are already in the process of formulation for further improvements to handle traffic and parking problems next year.

The financial week just completed was concerned with two main topics: the election result and the flood of dividend announcements. The one complemented the other, and higher security and commodity prices were the result. Easy money conditions are to continue -- witness the fact that in the last four days twenty of the twenty-five issues of the Treasury bond group advanced sharply to establish new high records.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- Justice Harlan F. Stone will not return to the bench of the Supreme Court Monday when several New Deal cases are argued. Mrs. Stone revealed today in an announcement issued at the court.

More than 500 reservations have been made and 500 more are expected for the tenth annual friendship dinner at the American Women's Club Nov. 16 at 7:30 P.M. The New York Counties Registered Nurses Association will be the hostess organization this year.

WAKE FOREST, N.C., Nov. 7 (AP). -- A score soon after the game started, made by the second team, and two third-quarter touchdowns by the varsity spoiled home-coming here today as the Duke Blue Devils whipped Wake Forest, 20 to 0.

SUBSTANTIAL progress has been recorded by the great mass of automobile dealers during the year 1936. As leaders in the fight for business recovery, this trade group, which is second only to the food group in point of dollar volume, has established records in all departments that were exceeded only in the banner year of 1929.

The undergraduates of Barnard College are organizing a "Campus Carnival" as their part in the 1936-37 drive to raise funds for the fiftieth anniversary projects of the college. The carnival will be held Friday and Saturday, Dec. 4 and 5, in Barnard Hall.

The new Iridium Room of the St. Regis during the cocktail hour on the afternoon of Nov. 19 will be the setting for an elaborate fashion show to aid the Kips Bay Boys Club. A large group of young matrons and former debutantes will appear as manikins.
PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 7 (AP). -- Cosmic ray studies obtained 92,000 feet in the sky -- 20,000 feet higher than man has ever soared -- were disclosed briefly today by Dr. Robert A. Millikan.

DETROIT may be the "Motor Capital" of America, but every city and hamlet actually contributes to the modern motor car. More than 5,000,000 men and women workers are absorbed in making, selling and servicing motor transportation, while one out of every six American workers derives his daily bread, either directly or indirectly, from the automobile industry.

LONDON, Oct. 23. ANTONY AND CLEOPATRA," of which I wrote last week, collapsed, as it deserved, after four nights. On Saturday evening in the week of production the bills outside the New Theatre were already announcing Margaret Rawlings in "Parnell," a sign that the long persuasion of the censorship has at last been successful.

Mr. and Mrs. William A. Brainard of 238 West Seventy-fourth Street gave a luncheon yesterday at Sherry's for their debutante daughter, Miss Marjorie Mabel Brainard. Miss Brainard, who was graduated this year from the Spence School, wore a coronation red crepe gown trimmed with sable, a matching turban and a corsage of gardenias.

Riding as he seldom has ridden before, rising to great heights when his mount faltered, Captain Pierre Clave of the French Army team last night brought forth the thunderous plaudits of 15,000 excited horse show fans in Madison Square Garden when he won the Bowman Challenge Cup with a perfect performance, making the circuit of the course in the remarkable time of 33 seconds.

The annual dance in aid of the Grosvenor Neighborhood House, which will take place on Dec. 3 at the Ritz-Carlton, will be known this year as the December Ball Flower Carnival. A colorful floral decorative scheme and a flower fashion show has been devised.

THERE is every indication of continued high volume in the commercial car and truck business during 1937. This forecast is based partly upon the industry's accomplishments of the past twelve months and partly upon analyses of the market for the coming year.

PERHAPS no man in America has a career more abruptly divided into two distinct parts, or more consistent and coherent in its entirety, than Justice Louis Dembitz Brandeis of the United State Supreme Court, whose eightieth birthday falls next Friday, Nov. 13.
PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 7 (AP). -- Cosmic ray studies obtained 92,000 feet in the sky -- 20,000 feet higher than man has ever soared -- were disclosed briefly today by Dr. Robert A. Millikan.
DETROIT, Nov. 7. -- The text of the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin's radio address tonight follows:

FOR the past fifteen years I have had an active interest in street and highway safety I must confess, however, that this interest has been largely directed toward the construction of safer and better roadways. I have been fascinated by the spectacular reductions in accidents which have resulted from the construction of divided roadways, the West Side Elevated Highway in New York and the highway grade separation program.

GENEVA, Nov. 6. -- Is the League of Nations practically dead as Premier Mussolini of Italy once more shouts? Or may the League once more tackle an aggressor "with diabolical method and diligence," which Mussolini in the next breath, but for the first time, concedes Geneva showed against him?

CHICAGO, Nov. 7. -- A bill for approximately $12,500,000 was laid before 3,500 Illinois stockholders of the defunct Central Republic Bank and Trust Company today, as their share toward paying back the $90,000,000 "Dawes loan."
GALLUP, N.M. TWENTY-SEVEN miles from Gallup, N.M., a new capital has come into being with the strange name of "Nee Alneeng."

THE mountain has moved. In a vote more representative of the whole people than has been cast in any election in recent years, the country has given an unparalleled endorsement to President Roosevelt. Heretofore the New Deal has been improvised, imposed, reviewed by the Supreme Court and accepted or rejected by the citizens of the nation according to their condition and the temper of their minds.

Mr. and Mrs. William A. Brainard of 238 West Seventy-fourth Street gave a luncheon yesterday at Sherry's for their debutante daughter, Miss Marjorie Mabel Brainard. Miss Brainard, who was graduated this year from the Spence School, wore a coronation red crepe gown trimmed with sable, a matching turban and a corsage of gardenias.

Riding as he seldom has ridden before, rising to great heights when his mount faltered, Captain Pierre Clave of the French Army team last night brought forth the thunderous plaudits of 15,000 excited horse show fans in Madison Square Garden when he won the Bowman Challenge Cup with a perfect performance, making the circuit of the course in the remarkable time of 33 seconds.

The annual dance in aid of the Grosvenor Neighborhood House, which will take place on Dec. 3 at the Ritz-Carlton, will be known this year as the December Ball Flower Carnival. A colorful floral decorative scheme and a flower fashion show has been devised.

THERE is every indication of continued high volume in the commercial car and truck business during 1937. This forecast is based partly upon the industry's accomplishments of the past twelve months and partly upon analyses of the market for the coming year.

PERHAPS no man in America has a career more abruptly divided into two distinct parts, or more consistent and coherent in its entirety, than Justice Louis Dembitz Brandeis of the United State Supreme Court, whose eightieth birthday falls next Friday, Nov. 13.

The city will have trouble in meeting the requirements of the new charter for a gradual pay-as-you-go policy in financing improvements which are now paid for with serial bonds, Mayor La Guardia predicted yesterday in a lecture before 500 at the Rand School, 7 East Fifteenth Street.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 7 (AP). -- California rose in fighting fury today and defeated the favored and previously unbeaten Trojans of Southern California, 13 to 7.

Paul Switzer's 7-yard dash around right end in the first quarter gave Poly Prep a 6-0 decision over Irving School of Tarrytown on the Poly Prep field in Brooklyn yesterday. The victory was the third in five starts for Coach Harry Meislahn's Dyker Heights team.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- The maritime strike will be a "showdown scrap," Federal authorities believed today, with West Coast seamen's unions refusing to withdraw their demand for control of seamen's hiring halls and for overtime pay and ship owners refusing to write these terms into new contracts with their employes.

PHOENIXVILLE, Pa., Nov. 7. -- In as close a finish as has been seen during the amateur hunt racing season, Cherry Brook came through the winner in the point-to-point challenge cup race at the Pickering Hunt Club Fall meet today.

Members of the Lincoln Fellowship Society, comprising authors who have written about Lincoln as well as students and collectors of Lincolniana, will give a dinner Nov. 19 in the Blue Room of the Hotel Lincoln to celebrate the seventy-third anniversary of the presentation of the Gettysburg Address.

The Chicago Bears skidded to a 25-7 victory over the New York Giants on the Polo Grounds quagmire yesterday while a crowd of 35,000 braved rain and chill to watch a game of football played under the most execrable conditions imaginable.

Armistice Day will be ushered in with an impressive ceremonial tomorrow night when the Victory Ball is given at the Plaza under the auspices of the Welfare Committee, New York County, Inc., of the American Legion. For many years one of the most colorful events of the Autumn in this city, the ball once again will benefit the work of the committee in bringing relief to disabled and needy war veterans and their dependents.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,459,859,300. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills. The list follows:

MADRID, Monday, Nov. 9. -- Insurgent airplanes bombed Madrid early this morning, following aerial and artillery bombardments of the capital yesterday, in which it was semi-officially estimated 30 were killed and 170 wounded. Unofficially, however, it was estimated that almost 200 were killed yesterday.

The excursion steamboat Cherokee, owned by the McAllister Navigation Company of 24 State Street, sank at her moorings about 8 o'clock yesterday morning in the shipyard of Sullivan Brothers. Seventh Street and the East River. As the 150-foot double-decked craft settled in the water, a thirty-foot lighter with a forty-foot derrick boom, which had been made fast to the steamboat, broke adrift and floated out into the river.

BOSTON, Nov. 8. -- "The Show Is On," after two postponements, opened last night at the Shubert Theatre. Patience on the part of the disappointed spectators and tact by the box-office staff smoothed things over so that the only sign of a hitch was an opening night curtain delay of forty-five minutes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- President Roosevelt has started conferences on the legislative program he will submit to Congress, a program which together with major bills which members themselves will press, promises a session made busy with many measures on many subjects.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 8. -- While Parliament examines the new Military Bill designed to augment Belgium's power to resist invasion, Belgians have been reviewing the recently proclaimed foreign policy with which rearmament is linked.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1936, as well as last price, for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

Our Washington dispatches report that organized labor groups and certain business leaders who favor some form of governmental control of industry have begun to shape plans to be submitted to Congress, for what might be called a new NRA. After the experiment with the old one, there ought to be no haste in this matter.

BERLIN, Nov. 6. -- Although the result of the Presidential election in the United States failed to react on the German markets, which for domestic reasons were depressed, it was on the whole welcomed by business here in the belief that it would assure a relatively liberal policy regarding international trade.

VIENNA, Nov. 8. -- Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister, arrived tonight for preliminary discussions before the conferences of the Rome protocol nations beginning Wednesday. The conferees represent Italy, Austria and Hungary.

MUNICH, Germany, Nov. 8. -- The celebration of the anniversary of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's beer-hall putsch on Nov. 9, 1923, was opened tonight with a reunion of the "Old Guard" in the now historic Buergerbraeukeller.

MADRID, Nov. 8 (AP). -- With almost 35,000 well-armed men operating in the war zone at the southern outskirts of this capital, the Defense Council that has supplanted the government of Premier Francisco Largo Caballero expressed confidence today that the Insurgent advance was checked from that direction.

The Chase National Bank has been appointed registrar for the preferred stock of Remington Rand, Inc., and transfer agent for the capital stock of Dainty-Maid Slippers, Inc., and the Symington-Gould Corporation.

LENOX, Mass., Nov. 8. -- Giraud Foster observed his eighty-sixth birthday here tonight with a dinner party for thirty-six at his Summer home, Bellefontaine. The decorations were old gold chrysanthemums. For forty years Mr. Foster's birthday dinner has been a society event of the late season at Lenox.

The fifteenth annual massing of the colors, held each year on the Sunday before Armistice Day, took place at 4 P.M. yesterday at the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Thomas, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street. Before the ceremonies members of military, veterans' and patriotic organizations paraded down Fifth Avenue from Seventy-eighth Street in a slow drizzle of rain.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 8. -- Deelan O'Keefe, giant tackle, booted a field goal from the 14-yard mark with only a few seconds left and gave the Cleveland Rams a 15-to-14 triumph over the Brooklyn Tigers in an American Football League game before 10,000 spectators today.

LONDON, Nov. 8. -- The new Lord Mayor of London, Sir George Broadbridge, was formally installed yesterday and will ride through crowded streets in a gilded coach tomorrow in the traditional Lord Mayor's show. The procession will reveal the seriousness with which Britain regards the inability to recruit men under the new rearmament program.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8. -- Active buying of all livestock with prices advanced sharply to around the best levels of the season was a feature last week in all livestock markets. Hogs here advanced 30 to 65 cents a hundredweight in the week with the top on Friday at $9.80, a gain of 25 cents from Monday's top, and the best price in fifteen days.
BERLIN, Nov. 8. -- Thousands of alien words are being dropped by the Nazis to make room for German words. Even the words "import" and "export" are to be replaced by "Einfuhr" and "Ausfuhr."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- Violation of the anti-price-fixing provisions of the Robinson-Patman amendments to the Clayton Act are charged in four complaints which have been issued by the Federal Trade Commission. The complaints, involving twelve companies, also charge violations of the provisions of the Federal Trade Commission Act prohibiting unfair competition.

LONDON, Nov. 6. -- Judging from the steadiness which characterized the pound sterling in the last fortnight and which was disturbed only temporarily by the outcome of the election in the United States, the tripartite gold agreement appears to be functioning smoothly.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 8. -- Fog, an overcast sky, threatening rain and lack of wind held down the sailing dinghy fleet this afternoon at the Larchmont Yacht Club. Seventeen hopeful skippers took out craft in spite of the conditions and they were rewarded with a fine southwest breeze.
Although the season is only a few weeks old, the squash tennis and squash racquets teams of the Harvard Club are already well up in the metropolitan race in both sports.

Department of Justice agents arrested Lucille Malin, widow of Jean Malin, female impersonator and night club entertainer, on Saturday night in a raid on her apartment at 320 East Fifty-seventh Street on a charge of violating the White Slave Traffic Act, it was announced last night by Rhea Whitley, agent in charge of the bureau of investigation here.

The felicitations of the people of Hungary to the citizens of the United States on the re-election of President Roosevelt were conveyed yesterday by Dr. Alexis de Boer, Professor of Economics on the law faculty of Kecskemet, Hungary. He spoke at the First Magyar Presbyterian Church, 233 East ll6th Street.

PANAMA, Nov. 8. -- Although he has announced he does not want to continue in office, the possibility of President Oscar Raimundes Benavides of Peru holding his post is seen by the newspaper El Commercio of Lima, which has just arrived here.

BERLIN, Nov. 8. -- The burden which the National Socialist regime is imposing on the German people through its rearmament and "labor creation" program, for which it is raising a new loan of 500,000,000 marks, is illustrated by a survey just published by the Institute of Business Research.

Comparing Christ to an orchestra leader who brings out the best that every member of the orchestra has in him, the Rev. Dr. Francis J. McConnell, Bishop of the New York Methodist Area, spoke yesterday morning in St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 8. -- Hagerty's Fascinating Model, a well-proportioned dark brindle puppy, until today in the novice class, scored a remarkable victory in the second annual Newark Boston Terrier Club specialty exhibition when he was named best in show in a field of 101 terriers at the Essex House.
Football, in its first November Saturday, produced nothing in the way of sensational surprise, at least none nearer to this seat of operation than the Pacific Coast.

Lilly Dache, now at 485 Madison Avenue, announced yesterday that she had purchased the property at 78 and 80 East Fifty-sixth Street for improvement with a building to house her millinery business. The buildings now on the site, 35 by 100 feet, adjoining the southwest corner of Park Avenue, will be razed and a modernistic structure erected for occupancy about June 1, 1937.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Nov. 8. -- Commodore Egbert Moxham of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club and Ted Clark, one of the frost-bite racing veterans, tied for first place in the one-design Class B series today in the Manhasset Bay Dingy Association Championship competition.
Governor Lehman last night scored the theory that government, through social security or relief activities, could ever take the place of private welfare agencies.

In a statement last night R.J. Baker, president of the American Steamship Owners Association, declared that the claims of the seamen's strike organization as to the extent of the walkout were greatly exaggerated.

LONDON, Nov. 8. -- With the arrival of Earl Peel's Royal Commission at Haifa on Wednesday Palestine will take a larger place than ever on the stage of British imperial affairs. The bloodshed of the past six months is ended, but the grievances that provoked it and the tension still prevailing between the Arabs and the Jews have not been relieved.

The recent downward trend of prices on the New York Cotton Exchange was reversed last week and active futures registered a net advance for the week of 19 to 28 points. The implication of the results of the national election with respect to the cotton trade was a strong factor in the movement of prices.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Nov. 8. -- About 200,000 persons, mostly peasants, were brought here today by special trains with the government's approval, to take part in an anti-Semitic and pro-Fascist demonstration arranged by the National Christian party, which is an amalgamation of the Fascist and anti-Semitic groups of Octavian Goga and A.C. Cuza.

The football stories in yesterday's paper were at first sight bewildering. We are still too near last Tuesday's election. It was odd to read of Pennsylvania defeating Michigan on Saturday; or Georgia beating Florida, Louisiana defeating Mississippi State, Minnesota trouncing Iowa, Kansas losing to Nebraska.

Rosa Ponselle has been re-engaged for the coming season of the Metropolitan Opera Association, it was announced yesterday by General Manager Edward Johnson. For some months there had been considerable doubt regarding Miss Ponselle's return to the company, of which she has been a leading member for eighteen years.

In one of the most elaborate radio programs ever arranged the National Broadcasting Company turned in a nation-wide audience yesterday to conversations ranging from a submarine under the sea to the top of Pike's Peak, and separated more than 8,000 miles, from planes flying over San Diego to a speeding train in Germany.

DETROIT, Nov. 8. -- The champion Detroit Red Wings scored their second victory of the National Hockey League campaign by outclassing the New York Rangers, 5 to 2, before 12,000 spectators tonight. They hold a clear lead in the American group.

With current sales rising steadily all over the country and signs pointing to the heaviest holiday trade in years, retailers placed a substantial volume of orders and reorders for all types of merchandise in the wholesale markets here last week. While fewer buyers arrived here, due to the holiday, fill-in orders for apparel and accessories were more numerous.

In spite of rain and the hour of 5:30, not considered an ideal one for an afternoon concert, the New Friends of Music opened its season of sixteen Sunday afternoon concerts of the chamber music of Beethoven and Brahms yesterday in Town Hall, with its entire series 97 per cent subscribed and some who had purchased standing room for the occasion.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 8. -- Development of an instrument which, by measuring bodily electrical changes as small as five-millionths of a volt, indicates alterations in physiological activity before they can be detected by any other methods was announced today by Drs. Harold S. Burr, Cecil T. Lane and Leslie F. Nims of Yale University.

Controller Frank J. Taylor announced yesterday that he had submitted to the committee on local laws of the Board of Estimate favorable reports on proposals to relieve property owners subjected to special assessments.

MUNICH, Germany, Nov. 8. -- Michael Cardinal von Faulhaber discovered today that public ovations in his honor were not permitted. He preached in the famous old Frauenkirche this morning. Not only was the great church itself filled but a crowd gathered outside as well.

LONDON, Nov. 6. -- President Roosevelt's election triumph stood out as one of the leading factors behind this week's remarkable buoyancy and activity in London's security markets. That it did so was largely due to Wall Street's trend.

Captain Pierre Clave of the French Army team captured the $1,000 International Military Stake with Volant III at the special performance sponsored by the National Horse Show Association in Madison Square Garden last night.

Apparently we are to have another State constitutional convention. The returns on the State-wide referendum are not yet all in, and up-State voted heavily against it, but hardly in such numbers as to overcome the half-million favorable majority recorded in this city.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP). -- Increases in both officer and enlisted strength for the navy were sought today by Rear Admiral Adolphus Andrews, chief of the Bureau of Navigation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- The oldest desk on the Senate floor -- once occupied by Daniel Webster -- will remain in Republican hands during the next Congress, despite the election tidal wave which sent fourteen Democratic Senators over to the Opposition side of the Chamber.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Nov. 8. -- Playing from a handicap of minus two, Herbert Lancaster, University Club stylist, today won the singles division honors of the Nassau Country Club's eighth annual invitation squash racquets tournament on the club courts.

A defense of what he defined as true liberty and an attack on the "new morality" of the present generation were made yesterday by the Rev. Dr. William W. Bellinger, vicar of St. Agnes Chapel, Trinity Parish, at Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway at Wall Street.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 8. -- After being interrupted by the All Saints Day holiday here on Monday and the election-day closing on Tuesday, the cotton market here was active the balance of the week. While there was no great advance in prices, a firm undertone developed on the idea that, with the election out of the way, there will be a greater disposition to trade.

The golden jubilee of St. Raphael's Church, Forty-first Street and Tenth Avenue, was celebrated yesterday with a solemn high mass at which Cardinal Hayes presided. More than 1,100 persons, many of whom were former parishioners, attended the service.
BOSTON, Nov. 8 (AP). -- The highflying Green Bay Packers put on one of their famed aerial displays to defeat the Boston Redskins, 7 -- 3, today before 10,000 at Fenway Park.

The letter of Ellen Prigohzy on the Hades-like atmosphere of our State hospitals during the Summer struck a responsive chord within me. There are also other things the matter with the places where we, as civilized human beings, are supposed to care fondly for our sick and ailing.

MADRID, Nov. 8 (Passed By the Censor). -- The Madrid government, which has moved to Valencia, held its first meeting this afternoon, after which it issued a statement explaining its reasons for having Fascists."

Your editorial comment on President Roosevelt's unprecedented victory last Tuesday tends to temper the convictions even of those who doubt that the fine sentiments you express in explanation of this victory are shared by the President himself.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8. -- Trading in lard here early last week was limited to evening up by speculators and processors. The advance in corn and hogs also had a strengthening influence on prices, especially late in the week. December lard closed at $11.92 1/2 a hundredweight, a net advance of 47 1/2 cents.

ALBANY, Nov. 8. -- The death rate for New York State during September, 9.3 per 1,000 population, was the lowest ever recorded for the month, and has been lower only twice before in any month (August of 1934 and 1936). Dr. J.V. De-Porte, director of the Division of Vital Statistics of the State Department of Health, reported today.

ALPINE, N.J., Nov. 8. -- Two Irish wolfhounds, each weighing more than 100 pounds, rushed over the brink of the Palisades some time Friday, apparently while chasing a rabbit or squirrel. One was crushed to death on the rocks 300 feet below and the other, stopped miraculously on a narrow shelf jutting from the face of the cliff thirty feet from the top.

Three Pulitzer Prize winners were among the seven leading poets who read and interpreted poetry yesterday afternoon at THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair in the International Building, Rockefeller Center.

Undoubtedly, the most striking picture in last week's financial panorama was the vigorous rise on the Stock Exchange when election results were known, with the largest trading since last Winter. Inasmuch as the great majority of observant investors or financiers had been convinced of Mr. Roosevelt's victory from the start, the impulsive advance of prices on the actual news might seem surprising.

TIMMINS, Ont., Nov. 8 (Canadian Press). -- Five children, all under 10 years of age and all of one family, were burned to death or suffocated here Saturday night in a fire which destroyed their home Their father, Arthur Charbonneau, a Hollinger miner, is in hospital here in a serious condition from burns.

Three explosions of manhole covers on the upper East Side about 10:45 o'clock last night sent at least 100 tenants scurrying to the street in nightclothes and caused considerable excitement. The explosions, occurring a few seconds apart, took place on 102d Street between Third and Lexington Avenues and on Lexington Avenue between 101st and 102d Streets.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 8. -- President Roosevelt's forthcoming visit to Buenos Aires has aroused an enthusiastic satisfaction, both in government circles and in public opinion, not equaled by a visit of any other distinguished person in the last twenty-five years.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 8. -- Approval of the original plan of the bondholders' protective committee for the reorganization of Botany Consolidated Mills, Inc., is recommended by John Grimshaw Jr., Federal Bankruptcy Referee, in a report which has been forwarded to Federal Judge Guy L. Fake in Trenton.

PARIS, Nov. 8. -- At the end of the annual congress of the Alliance Democratique -- a Moderate party of eighty-three Deputies politically just to the right of the Radical Socialists -- Pierre-Etienne Flandin, who leads the group, held out a cautious olive branch to Premier Leon Blum.

Trustees, patrons and friends of the Grand Street Settlement yesterday afternoon attended the formal opening of its new six-story building at 283 Rivington Street. The old building which stood at 311 East Broadway was inadequate and was condemned last Spring by the Fire Department.

An Armistice Day memorial service for members of the 307th Infantry Regiment who died in France was held yesterday morning at the Grace Lutheran Church, 123 West Seventy-first Street. Officers of the regiment attended in a body aid Lieut. Col. George U. Harvey, Borough President of Queens and newly appointed commanding officer of the regiment, spoke on national defense.

The Messrs. Bushar and Tuerk get around to starting their season this evening, the occasion being "Black Limelight" and the theatre the Mansfield. Murder in a London suburb seems to be the topic of tonight's discussion, with a large cast participating under Robert Milton's direction -- Winifred Lenihan, Alexander Kirkland and George Curzon in featured roles, and Brenda Forbes, A. P. Kaye, J. Malcom Dunn, Olive Reeves-Smith and others.
MADRID, Nov. 8 (Passed by the Censor). -- Scores were killed and at least 200 wounded in a four-minute Insurgent air raid on Madrid today.

PARIS, Nov. 8. -- Speaking for nearly two hours in frank and confidential terms before his associates in the Socialist National Council tonight, Premier Leon Blum won unanimous party support by submitting to them his record.

Paying the first visit of his life to a barroom in the hope that a drink might settle his upset stomach, Isaac Shean, 56 years old, a delicatessen keeper of 579 Hopkinson Avenue, Brooklyn, blundered into a hold-up at 3 A.M. yesterday and was shot and killed when he mistook one of the thugs for a practical jokester.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 8. -- The possibility of direct negotiations to discuss the basis for peace in the American Federation of Labor-Committee for Industrial Organization dispute collapsed today when John L. Lewis, chairman of the C.I.O., notified President William Green of the A.F. of L., that a conference between them would be "futile" since Mr. Green lacked authority "to change the policy outlined by (the) executive council."

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 8. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 74 per cent of capacity, up 1 point in the week and 2 points under the recent rate, which was the highest since the depression started.

Up to now the cry among freshwater anglers has been: "Let's stock more fish." In the future, if current signs are a criterion, the slogan will be: "Let's improve our waters so the fish we put in can multiply."

Efforts by underwriters to make formal offering of a new issue of securities promptly at 12:01 A.M. on the effective date of its registration have led to the loss of a substantial part of the newspaper circulation employed in advertising the security, a survey of investment banking houses disclosed last week.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 6. -- President Roosevelt's re-election was welcomed here as the reward of great achievements which, although not always appreciated here, undoubtedly have led the way toward world recovery. The large plurality of votes for him puts the whole governmental machine in President Roosevelt's hands, thus leaving the way open for many fresh experiments.

The pamphlet report of the General Motors Corporation, issued for publication today, shows that on Sept. 30 cash, government and other marketable securities amounted to $284,397,262. This compares with $199,435,633 held at the end of 1935 and $219,802,942 on Sept. 30, 1935.

The Maccabees of Palestine, in their final match before leaving for home Wednesday, lost at the Yankee Stadium yesterday to a powerful eleven representing the American Soccer League. The final score was 4 -- 1, with a crowd of 20,000 in attendance.

The threatened tie-up of West Coast shipping and the impending shutdown of the Alaska Railway has elicited a not unnatural protest from the Fairbanks Chamber of Commerce. For this tie-up of the Territory's one and only line of steel between the Coast and the capital must obviously spell hardship for all Alaskans.

After the foreweek trading in the foreign exchanges had been quiet with rates moving over a narrow arc, some of the principal currencies were subjected to pressure and declined to new lows for the year and beyond.

SUMMIT, N.J., Nov. 8. -- Mrs. Arthur R. Jones of Far Hills, N.J., well known as a horsewoman, died today at Overlook Hospital of injuries suffered when her mount fell on her in a field near Lamington while she was following the Essex Hounds on Saturday.

A few tickets are still available for the pre-opening performance of the new play, "Matrimony Pfd.," staring Grace George tomorrow night at the Playhouse, which has been taken over by St. Timothy's League for the benefit of the East Harlem Nursing and Health Service.

The Fort Hamilton eleven, led by Lloyd Barr who made two touch-downs, turned back Tenth Cavalry of West Point by a 19-6 score at the Fort Hamilton Reservation yesterday. Most of the game was played during a rain.

Because he regards Night Court as one of the "filthiest and most wretched places I know of," Magistrate Frank Oliver said yesterday he intended to request Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. to have the location of the court transferred from its present quarters.

The Christian principles of fellowship and good-will must be adopted universally by the nations before permanent peace can be achieved, Miss Charlotte T. Niven, former general secretary of the World's Young Women's Christian Association, declared yesterday afternoon.
In The Fortnightly a sometime clerk in a bookshop offers this tempting bait to seekers of security:

There are increasing signs that the heavy goods industries are catching up with consumers' goods industries. No more striking testimony of this could be furnished than the figures for steel ingot production in October. They reached the largest volume for any month since August, 1929.
WITH THE INSURGENT ARMY, In Madrid's Suburbs, Nov. 8. -- At this writing Madrid's main bridges seem to be nearly in General Francisco Franco's grasp.
LONDON, Nov. 6. -- The trade forecast of the Federation of British Industries for the fourth quarter predicts a continuation of the present boom.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The most stunning upsets of the Far Western football season were posted in the records today, but reversals which rocked the Coast Conference failed to topple University of Washington from its lead in the championship race.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8. -- A1though tension in the maritime strike was eased today with a growing movement for the release of perishable cargoes in strike-bound ports, the walkout spread as shipyard workers of eleven crafts in three plants of the Bethlehem Ship-building Corporation prepared to stay away from their jobs tomorrow.

Registration of wage earners through the Postoffice Department, as contemplated by the Federal Social Security Board, will prove "complex, costly and thoroughly unnecessary," in the opinion of the American Association for Social Security, a pioneer advocate of security legislation in this country.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 8 (AP). -- John Barrymore and Elaine Barrie boarded a chartered plane at Grand Central Airport tonight for Yuma, Ariz.

LONDON, Nov. 8. -- Information that has reached this correspondent from three well-informed sources goes far to contradict the stories and articles, appearing since the Simpson divorce action, asserting that King Edward would marry Mrs. Wallis Simpson next June.

BERLIN, Nov. 6. -- Uncertainty concerning the Reich's Four-Year Plan for raw materials dominated activities on the Boerse this week. Industrial leaders are grumbling because they feel that the Reich's supervision of the proposed supplementary production program promises to be too drastic and that, moreover, private business, without help, must bear the financial burden and the responsibility for the plan.

It was said of the late Ambassador JUSSERAND that in whichever direction he crossed the Atlantic he was going home. The memorial in Washington will give visible evidence that he is still affectionately remembered on this side -- his other home. It has been provided by friends who cherish memories of his many years in America.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 8. -- All of the thirty-four players Coach Harlow sent into Harvard's point-a-minute game with Virginia on Saturday came through uninjured.
The New Jersey Central Railroad sent a six-car excursion train over a 325-mile tour of historic country yesterday, with the line's general passenger agent, B.D. Branch, acting as invisible barker.

Announcing grants totaling $3,770,000 last year to cultural institutions in the United States and British dominions and colonies, Frederick P. Keppel, president of the Carnegie Foundation, declared in his annual report, made public yesterday, that "doubts and fears concerning taxation" serve to stimulate private philanthropy rather than to deter potential donors.

In the midst of the election furor, Topics of The Times commented wittily on the "Happy Milk Farmer," quoting recent governmental figures to prove that we took in more money during the first nine months of 1936 than for any similar period in five years, or well over a billion dollars.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8. -- Three conciliatory moves in quick succession eased tension and brightened the prospect of peace in the maritime strike tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- The creation of a large enlisted trained reserve force to offset the aging of World War veterans is recommended by General Malin Craig, chief of staff of the army, as a means of preparing the country for any possible defensive emergency.

Edwin P. Maynard, chairman of the Brooklyn United Hospital Campaign Committee, announced yesterday that the members of a newly formed executive committee would meet for the first time this afternoon at 177 Montague Street, Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 (AP). -- The Chicago Cardinals won their first National Pro League game in eight starts this season by defeating the Philadelphia Eagles, 13 to 0, at Wrigley Field today. The defeat was Philadelphia's ninth in ten games.

Schlater, Noyes Gardner, Inc.; Burr Co., Inc., and MacBride, Miller Co. of Newark will offer today $184,000 of borough of Mountain Lakes (N.J.), Morris County, 4 per cent school bonds, due on May 1, 1937, to 1963. They will be priced to yield 1.50 to 4.00 per cent, according to maturity.

Armistice Day should be called International Loyalty Day, a day when churches and their people could renew their loyalty to the cause of peace, the Rev. Elmore McNeill McKee said yesterday on his second Sunday as rector of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square and East Sixteenth Street.

The truce declared within Tammany Hall several months before election has ended, it was reported yesterday, and some leaders are understood to be eager for a showdown on the policy of the organization.
MUNICH, Nov. 8. -- Adolf Hitler told his old comrades-at-arms today that "for the first time in these many years I observe this day without deep anxiety for Germany's future."

FORDHAM is safely past Purdue. That's on the road to Pasadena according to some of the football map-makers. The Rose Hill players seem to be Rose Bowling along. That's the way it is viewed from the Bronx. The Coast sponsors like to have an Eastern team make the grand tour and Fordham is shining along the Atlantic Coast like a lighthouse belfry on a dark night.

Approval of the $436,000,000 transit unification plan drafted by Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr., without first amending it to provide for a flexible rate of fare would be "costly and unwise," Harold Riegelman, counsel for the Citizens Budget Commission, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- Representative Hamilton Fish, as the ranking Republican member of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, served notice today that he would block unanimous consent to any future appropriations to send American delegates to international conferences because no Republicans were included in the delegation that sailed yesterday for the Pan-American Peace Conference at Buenos Aires.
I sent twenty miles yesterday for a copy of THE TIMES to see your editorial treatment of the election. I was not disappointed.

Five Polish girls in native costumes yesterday afternoon placed a wreath at the foot of a sycamore sapling in City Hall Park in a ceremony marking the sixty-ninth anniversary of the birth of the late Mme. Marie Sklodowska Curie, co-discoverer of radium.

Borrowing a chapter from English rowing, local oarsmen held a Head of the River race yesterday on the Harlem, with ten eight-oared crews paddling to the starting line but only nine finishing the mile-and-a-half event.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 8. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman declared himself willing to be reconciled with the factions of the Republican party that have opposed him in New Jersey, and at the same time pleaded tonight for party harmony as a first step toward strengthening the State organization.

EDGAR LEE MASTERS, poet, worked as a lawyer in Chicago, was conscientious, able, honest, felt sorry for himself almost all the time. He both hated and liked the work -- depending on the case; enjoyed and hated the people -- depending on how they behaved and what their "auras" were. His intimate associations rarely turned out well. Some women were poison, others were deadly bores.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 8. -- Prince Paul, first Regent of Yugoslavia, without any previous announcement of his plans, left suddenly today for London. No official announcement was made concerning his journey and information in official quarters was not available.

Apparently no longer able to keep out of the amateur night business, the cinema, through Dr. Otto A Peters's Gold Seal Productions, will produce in New York a dozen shorts acted, written and designed exclusively by amateurs. Some will be acted by a cast of children.
CHICAGO, Nov. 8. -- Northwestern, dark horse of the race, has finished a spectacular gallop to its first clear Big Ten football title.
Armistice Day this year is to be devoted by veterans' organizations, churches and peace societies to a common resistance to "the next war" more emphatically than to commemoration of the last one.

PARIS, Nov. 7. -- The gold reserve of the Bank of France was unchanged on Oct. 30, but the ratio sagged from 64.95 to 64.09 per cent. Operations of the equalization fund are being kept secret and it is impossible to ascertain the exact scope of its action because, in order to influence exchange rates, the fund can intervene in London and even in New York as well as in Paris.

At a service which marked the final day of the centenary celebration of the Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, its rector, the Rev. Samuel M. Shoemaker, declared yesterday morning that "the church must literally remake the world into a God-controlled society."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- Notable gains in business, accompanied by improved financial and banking conditions but marked by failure of employment to keep pace, were noted in the Federal Reserve Board's commercial and industrial review of 1936, made public today.

A revival of Giacometti's juridical tragedy, "La Morte Civile," was the second offering of the seventh season of the Teatro d'Arte under the direction of Commendatore Giuseppe Sterni, at the Vanderbilt Theatre, yesterday afternoon and evening.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8. -- A belief that the present Social Security Act would be revised was voiced tonight by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, speaking at Temple University.

ROME. Nov. 8 (AP). -- Occupation of Madrid by Spanish Insurgents should lead to dissolution of the European Non-Intervention Committee in London, the authoritative writer, Virginio Gayda, contended today in the newspaper Voce d'Italia.

Adverse weather was responsible for only twelve gunners reporting at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. H. Thoens dominated the competition, scoring in six contests. He began his good work by winning the high scratch laurels with 98 out of 100 targets, then gained a leg on both the doubles scratch and the doubles handicap cups.

Phil Duey, a baritone who has gained popularity as a radio singer, made his first appearance on the concert platform in a recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon. Mr. Duey's long experience in singing before studio audiences made him seem perfectly at home in his new surroundings, and his poise, coupled with a pleasing personality, helped him from the start to establish himself in the large audience's good graces.
MADRID, Nov. 5 (Delayed). -- Following repeated bombings, Madrid's so-called "murder gangs" have reappeared. Open spaces, where the blood has dried, have been the scenes of more recent tragedies.
The conviction of two important fur racketeers by a Federal jury early yesterday was characterized by Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey as "an important contribution to law enforcement."

Judging from the large subscription that has been received for the performance of Gilbert and Sullivan's "The Gondoliers" by the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company tonight at the Martin Beck Theatre, which has been taken over for the benefit of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York, the funds for carrying on the work of the institute will be augmented greatly.

Tallying five touchdowns and one conversion in his team's one-sided victory over Buffalo on Saturday, Fred King, Hobart fullback, rose from a tie for fourth to first place in Eastern college football scoring. King now has a total of 75 points, nine more than Joe Szur, Canisius captain, last week's leader.

Roi B. Woodley, who was associated with Dr. Miller McClintock of the Advertising Research Foundation, has been appointed manager of marketing and research for Electrical Merchandising, Radio Retailing and Electronics. Wallace B. Blood has joined the sales promotion and marketing staff of the same organization.
New York University showed an operating surplus for the sixth successive year, according to a report for the fiscal year ended June 30, made public yesterday by William M. Kingsley, treasurer.

WITH THE SPANISH INSURGENTS OUTSIDE MADRID, Nov. 8. -- Four Insurgent columns today tried to storm four bridges over the Manzanares River -- the Casa de Campo, Segovia, Toledo and Princesa Bridges. With the attack, the Insurgents said, one of the biggest battles of the Spanish Civil War was being fought.

More than thirty exhibitions are on the calendar for the week, including a number of outstanding interest. The shows range from Chardin to Soviet artists, with the widest variety of subject-matter and media. Large group displays and one-man exhibitions, widely known artists and youngsters making their debuts are all to be found.

Never before in our political history did the Electoral College appear, on casual inspection, to be so obsolete as in this year's Presidential election. Governor LANDON received in the neighborhood of 17,000,000 votes, but came out with only eight electoral votes. This disparity seems gross and grotesque.
Organized fake charity solicitation has been temporarily suppressed, William Hodson, Commissioner of the Department of Public Welfare, declared in a report to Mayor La Guardia made public yesterday.

BRIELLE, N.J., Nov. 8. -- Over a three mile route and through a pelting rain, Chief of Police George W. Legg of Brielle, wheeled Wilbur (Pete) Moore in a wheelbarrow this afternoon in payment for his faith in Landon's election.
DETROIT, Nov. 8 (AP). -- The Detroit Lions, after losing three consecutive times, defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 28 to 3, in a National Football League game today.

Newton D. Baker, Secretary of War 1916 to 1921, examines the conflicting evidence as to why we joined the Allies in warring against Germany in 1917, in his book, "Why We Went to War." The study will be published by Harper's, for the Council on Foreign Relations, on Nov. 17.
OLEAN, N.Y., Nov. 8. -- Factor, St. Vincent's star right halfback, led his team to a 14-0 triumph over the St. Bonaventure eleven today.

BEACON, N.Y., Nov. 8 (AP). -- A therapeutic theatre, the first in the United States, where the players will act spontaneously to try to rid themselves of mental worries or serious phobias, was dedicated here today.

Parity for seamen and maritime workers in Atlantic and Gulf ports with those on the Pacific will be sought by seamen on strike in New York, an audience of 2,000 strikers was told last night at a meeting at the Mecca Arena, Fourteenth Street and Avenue A.

ESSEX, Conn., Nov. 8. -- The winners in the Essex Yacht Club's annual Fall dinghy regatta held here today were Sam Wetherill in the Class X, Jim Brickell in the Wishbone Class B and Bill Swan in Class D.

Many of the 1,400 nursing schools in the United States do not maintain high entrance requirements and lack classroom facilities and well-trained teachers, according to a nursing study conducted under the auspices of the Russell Sage Foundation and made public yesterday.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 8. -- Dr. Edmund Ezra Day, director of the social science programs of the Rockefeller Foundation and the General Education Board, will be the next president of Cornell University, succeeding Dr. Livingston Farrand, who retires on June 30, 1937.

Bishop William T. Manning officiated yesterday morning at the dedication of the new All Saints' Chapel of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street. Previous to the dedication of the small chapel, which is located between the north side of the church and a tall Fifth Avenue apartment house next door, the Bishop confirmed a class of twenty communicants during the regular morning service.

A campaign for the adaptation of the most advanced educational methods in the teaching of correct ballroom dancing for beginners, both adults and children, was started yesterday by the New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc., at its November meeting at the Hotel Astor.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 8 (AP). -- The Pittsburgh Americans' brilliant halfback combination of Dick Beltz and Bob Snyder led their team to a 14-6 triumph today over the Boston Shamrocks.

PARIS, Nov. 7. -- On the Bourse this week numerous investment purchases were noted and the rise in prices was sharp. Not much attention was paid to the recrudescence of strikes, nor to the agitation in political circles, while the triumph of President Roosevelt was favorably received.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 8. -- Mel Porter, veteran campaigner from Newark, N.J., and one of the topnotch distance runners in this country, outlasted a brilliant field to capture the grueling Yonkers Marathon sponsored by the Chippewa A.C. today.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 8. -- Wool prices here reached new high levels last week under a keen export demand which took up large consignments of both coarse and fine crossbreds as fast as they came onto the market. New price records were established for both classifications early in the week only to be immediately surpassed on two occasions before the week ended.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 8 (AP). -- President William Harridge of the American League in a telephone conversation with The Globe-Democrat today said he believed the new owners of the Browns had set aside funds to rebuild the club. The Browns, only major league baseball team never to have won a pennant, finished seventh this year.

Little semblance of adversity was crammed into the past weekend's football results in so far as concerned unbeaten prep school squads, for with very few exceptions they once again acquitted themselves in triumphant style under fire.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., Nov. 8 (AP). -- The Onion Anti-Defamation Committee of America dragged three university professors and a goat into its campaign to eradicate onion breath yesterday and sought to enlist the aid of Congress.

Two children who slept while flames and smoke threatened them early yesterday morning were rescued by a patrolman and a milkman who braved the fire which badly damaged a rooming house at 69 East Twelfth Street at Fourth Avenue.

LONDON, Monday, Nov. 9. -- Battling mountainous seas, rain and high winds, the liner Queen Mary wirelessed early today that she was racing to the assistance of the crew of the German motor ship Isis, which is believed to have sunk 200 miles west of Land's End, the southwestern tip of England.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 7. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 84.7, which compares with 84.5 the week before, 84 two weeks before, 83.9 three weeks before and 83.8 four weeks before.

BERLIN, Nov. 7. -- This week's stock market here was unfavorably affected by the uncertainty over the government's raw materials plan and the impending Reich loan. While minor industrial stocks moved irregularly, with numerous gains evident, certain leaders receded and closed considerably lower for the week.

LONDON, Nov. 8. -- It has been nine years since London has been so worked up over a prizefight as it is about the 15-round light heavyweight championship bout tomorrow between the American Negro titleholder, John Henry Lewis, and the hardy perennial, Len Harvey.

By way of indicating that it is ready to fire away with all barrels at the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. cross-country championship next Monday, Manhattan College completely dominated the metropolitan intercollegiate test over the new five-mile Van Cortlandt Park course yesterday.

Four persons were injured about 1 P.M. yesterday when pieces of plaster fell from the ceiling of the Regun Theatre, a movie house at 60 West 116th Street, near Lenox Avenue. About 150 persons who were watching the show stampeded from the auditorium, frightened by a crash resulting from the collapse of a heavy projection booth on the roof of the one-story building.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9. -- Stockholders of the defunct Central Republic Bank and Trust Company, known as the "Dawes Bank," prepared today to appeal the decision of Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson, issued on Saturday, holding them liable for the payment of about $12,500,000 to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation on stock assessments.

The Republic of El Salvador has made available here for holders of its external bonds $1,355,000 during the four-month period from July through October of this year, it was announced yesterday by the El Salvador Bondholders Protective Committee in a letter to depositing bondholders.

Although he had been subjected to an electric shock so severe that fellow-workers said his heart stopped beating, Ernest Heglund, 25 years old, of 42-32 Seventy-ninth Street, Elmhurst, Queens, was able to leave Bellevue Hospital yesterday with no more serious effects than burns on his arms.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 9. -- A count of official returns in the Essex County election, submitted by County Clerk Russell Gates today to the county Board of Elections, sitting as the board of canvassers, showed Assemblyman Henry Young Jr., Republican, to have been elected, displacing one of the twelve Democratic candidates whose election had been indicated by unofficial returns.
In the awesome expanse of the Starlight Roof Room in the Waldorf-Astoria last night more than 200 men and women of the Wine and Food Society had a wine and cheese tasting session.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9. -- Furniture is selling rapidly and, therefore, is changing rapidly in style. These two factors will make the Fall market opening at the American Furniture Mart and the Merchandise Mart more successful than all the previous midseason shows, officials said today as the market began its week's run.

The administrative code for the city to be used under the new city charter is more than half completed, it was indicated yesterday in a report filed with the secretary of the Board of Estimate. The report will be printed this week in The City Record.
MADRID, Nov. 9. -- This afternoon the writer watched from the top of Madrid's skyscraper telephone company building the effect of the Insurgents' heavy artillery shelling of the city.
GENEVA, Nov. 9. -- The Mandates Commission of the League of Nations examined Japan's representative all day today on the administration of the mandated Pacific islands.

Woman suffrage continues to have hard sledding in the Province of Quebec. Last Spring when the Liberal Government was on its last legs a bill giving women the right to vote was beaten by nearly 2 to 1. The Government forces were united in the negative.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- A broader base on which to test the legality of the Wagner Labor Act was provided today when the Supreme Court consented to hear arguments on attacks by the Jones Laughlin Steel interests and two other concerns.

CUTCHOGUE, L.I., Nov. 9. -- After drifting about Long Island Sound for two days and three nights in a twelve-foot rowboat without oars, John Edwards, 55 years old, a clam-digger of Saybrook Point, Conn., was washed ashore here early this morning.

Space on the eighth floor of the International Building, Rockefeller Center, has been taken by the Mexican Government for a tourist information bureau and arts and crafts exhibition. Angel Rosas will be in charge of both.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 9. -- Jim Barnes, the veteran campaigner from the Crescent Athletic Club, enjoyed a field day on the links of the Garden City Country Club today as the Long Island Professional Golfers Association staged its final one-day affair of the season.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 9 (AP). -- A disagreement over the release of strike-bound ships in Hawaii caused a temporary halt today in attempts to resume negotiations to settle the Pacific Coast's general maritime strike.

Mrs. Amorette E. Fraser of Brooklyn, a centenarian and for forty-three years active in the club life of the borough, opened the four-day convention of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs with a plea for solidarity among clubwomen at a dinner last night of the Helmuth Fellowship at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Representing to a large extent financing to produce capital funds, a new issue of $25,000,000 of Republic Steel Corporation general mortgage 4 1/2 per cent bonds, Series C, due on Nov. 1, 1956, will be offered to the public today by a banking group headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co. and Field, Glore Co.

BOONTON, N.J., Nov. 9. -- The 150 employes of the Boonton Molding Company factory at 326 Myrtle Avenue here will receive all the advantages of the Social Security Act, but it will not cost them a cent. The directors of the company announced today through Herbert L. Dixon, secretary, that the 1 per cent salary donation required by the Federal law would be assumed by the company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- The general executive board of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union adopted a declaration today favoring "an amendment to the Constitution of the United States which would invest Congress with adequate power to legislate for the protection and advancement of the wage-earning masses throughout the country."

LONDON, Nov. 9. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin, speaking at the Lord Mayor's banquet in Guildhall tonight, said that the main object of the economic policies of the United States of America and Great Britain was the same -- that both countries were trying to liberate the world from the shackles impeding free development of international trade.

Presiding Justice Francis Martin of the Appellate Division told 204 young lawyers whom he admitted to practice here yesterday that no consideration, either personal or party, could outweigh the obligation of lawyers to defend the American Constitution.

Today's lone newcomer to Times Square is "Our Relations," a Hal Roach-Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer comedy featuring the Messrs. Laurel and Hardy and Betty Healy. Its home for the next seven days will be the Rialto.

MADRID, Nov. 9 (Passed by the Censor). -- Aerial and artillery bombardments of Madrid by the Insurgents today continued to wear thin the nerves of the capital's inhabitants. It was impossible tonight to estimate the day's casualties with any accuracy.

The vast and undisciplined growth of Harlem's population seems at times to crush the spirit of its community life. There is an alarming shortage of living quarters within the area. There is vast overcrowding of buildings in the 400 blocks.

BERLIN, Nov. 9. -- Germany's determination to carry out Chancellor Adolf Hitler's second Four-Year Plan for raw-material independence was emphasized anew when Colonel General Hermann Goering, the economic dictator, issued six new ordinances which in effect draft iron, metal and building construction workers into the service of that plan at an official wage scale.
MOSCOW, Nov. 9. -- An unusual aviation accident in which five persons were killed and several injured marred Moscow's celebration of the Bolshevist anniversary Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- Three decisions of importance to the business and financial worlds were handed down by the Supreme Court today. One held that a section of Iowa's chain store tax law is unconstitutional and another upheld the California law licensing importers of beer but exempting wholesalers of local beer from licensing.
The Manufacturers Trust Company is registrar for 150,000 shares of 5 per cent $100 par cumulative preferred stock of the Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- President Roosevelt is understood to have tentatively planned governmental reorganization as item No. 2 on his program for the new Congress, second only to the budget recommendations which he is expected to complete, in the main, before his projected Southern cruise on Nov. 17.

Sixteen States are represented in the third biennial exhibition of American painting, which opens today at the Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street, to remain until Dec. 10. There are 123 artists on the list, and each has contributed one picture. For these biennials no jury of selection is appointed.

MUNICH, Germany, Nov. 9. -- Julius Streicher, anti-Semitism's high priest, led through the streets of this city today the survivors of Adolf Hitler's 1923 beer-hall Putsch, gathered in honor of the sixteen men who fell in the Odeonsplatz when Reichswehr troops opened fire on the would-be revolutionaries on Nov. 9 thirteen years ago.
Four snow plows and two snow-loading machines were hauled out of a Brooklyn garage early yesterday morning, away from their 300 companion pieces, to go to work on the streets of Flatbush.

Samuel S. Walker, chairman of the Joliet Chicago Railroad Company stockholders' protective committee, makes known in a letter to stockholders the "successful termination of fourteen years of litigation and negotiation" to be consummated at a special meeting in Chicago on Nov. 30, for which proxies are asked by the committee.
ALBANY, Nov. 9. -- Designating tomorrow as Marine Corps Day, Governor Lehman tonight paid tribute to the personnel of the corps, saying:

The 270,000 employes of the Bell System companies were notified yesterday that the companies, while complying with the pension provisions of the Federal Social Security Act, would continue to maintain the system's company-financed retirement plan in such manner that, should the Federal program remain unchanged until 1942, workers will receive an amount equal to the full company pension and one-half the government pension.

While total automobile advertising for the coming year may still fall short of the 1929 peak, a number of companies which have sprung into prominence in the last decade will launch their largest campaigns. Plymouth and De Soto divisions of the Chrysler Corporation yesterday announced the biggest newspaper advertising drives in their history.

Two new plans designed to supplement the efforts of the Metropolitan Opera Guild in spreading an "enthusiasm for opera" and bringing the public and the management of the opera into closer relationship were announced yesterday by Mrs. August Belmont, the Guild's chairman, in a talk before 200 members of the Brooklyn Woman's Club at 114 Pierrepont Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- Exports of American automotive products in September were valued at $13,295,700, the Department of Commerce reported today, compared with $13,088,001 in the previous month and $13,938,366 in September, 1935.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 9. -- The controversy over the election of a Westchester Surrogate became more complicated late this afternoon when members of the Board of Supervisors, sitting as a board of canvassers, authorized themselves to inspect voting machines in any of the 375 election districts of the county where discrepancies appeared.

The proposed settlement out of court of the two-year legal battle between the Associated Gas and Electric Company and the group of creditors who demanded its reorganization seemed nearer yesterday when Federal Judge Julian W. Mack granted a two-month adjournment asked by each side.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 9. -- Cooperative procedure between the Federal Power Commission and the State commission and adaptation of the Interstate Commerce Commission's safety regulations to highway traffic within the various State boundaries, will be advocated at the forty-eighth annual convention of the National Association of Railroad and Utility Commissioners.

More than 200,000 new terms and meanings have come into existence in the American vernacular in recent years, Dr. Frank A. Vizetelly estimated before last night's audience at THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair in the International Building, Rockefeller Center.

MADRID, Tuesday, Nov. 10 (Passed by the Censor) -- The Rebel forces attacking this capital still were held outside the city early today, despite repeated efforts to storm Loyalist positions on the banks of the Manzanares River.

BASLE, Nov. 9. -- The impression left by talks among the central bank governors here a few days ago at the monthly meeting of the board of the Bank for International Settlements is that they foresee, with regret, little serious extension or development of the tri-power monetary accord in the coming weeks.

In his letter to THE TIMES Edwin Hopkins renews his advocacy of the Corporation Tax Law and reasserts his belief in the doctrine of what is in essence compulsory corporate extravagance. With a disregard for the requirements of normal expansion and those contingencies and emergencies against which universally recognized prudence demands a reasonable provision, Mr. Hopkins calls for a distribution of all profits in the form of dividends.

Reflecting the rise of 1 1-16d, announced in the price of silver in London yesterday, the price of the metal mined outside of the United States was advanced here to 47 1/2 cents an ounce, a gain of 2 3/4 cents. Since May the price here has held at 44 3/4 cents, based on the price of 45 cents that is being paid by the United States Treasury Department for silver mined in foreign countries.

Lieutenant J.A. Talbot-Ponsonby of the British army team last night won the international individual military championship in Madison Square Garden, taking the trophy presented by Alfred B. Maclay amid one of the most exciting situations that have marked a jumping contest at the National Horse Show.

Charles Hayden, philanthropist and member of the firm of Hayden, Stone Co., yesterday was elected a member of the board of trustees of the American Museum of Natural History. Mr. Hayden gave $150,000 toward the erection of the Zeiss projector and the solar system exhibit in the museum's planetarium, which was named Hayden Planetarium in his honor.

PARIS, Nov. 9. -- Sharp clashes between about 2,000 Communists on the one hand and policemen and Mobile Guards on the other occurred this evening in St. Denis Arrondissement in Paris, where Jacques Doriot, former Communist but now leader of the nationalistic French Popular party, was presiding over a party congress.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- The three Neidecker brothers, native-born Americans, won in the Supreme Court today their battle to prevent extradition to France on charges of larceny arising from the closing of the Travelers Bank of Paris in July, 1935.

LONDON, Nov. 9. -- Despite the fact that the Lord Mayor's show this year was designed to encourage recruiting for the British Army, it was the traditional gay carnival procession. The paraders indulged in their usual jovial mummery, while the crowds enjoyed the reminders of their colorful past as well as the fun of a masquerade.

Trial of defendants in the alleged restaurant racket, scheduled for next Monday, was postponed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Philip J. Cook on the filing by the defense of a demurrer to the forty-nine-count indictment. The court reserved decision on the demurrer, after hearing argument, and announced that a new trial date would be set Monday.
MADRID, Nov. 9. -- Insurgent bombing and pursuit planes shook the city in three distinct sorties today, diving unscathed through the popping of futile anti-aircraft fire.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 9. -- Apprentice Irving Anderson and the visiting contingent to Pimlico showed the local folk how to get winners today as Handicapper Frank Bryan's graded handicaps were run through the mud but with a big crowd attracted by the bright sun.

HARDLY a week passes without some solemn-eyed inquirer's asking whether modern American literature does not show a trend in such and such a direction. I always avoid the question because I feel that it is totally unrealistic. No honest observer is any more able to discern literary trends while they are trending than he is able to recognize the curvature of the earth from a white church steeple.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9. -- Mayor S. Davis Wilson left his seat in the Forrest Theatre tonight during the local premiere of the revue "New Faces" and, stalking to the rear of the auditorium, ordered the manager to stop the show or remove a skit containing a role to represent Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

An ultimatum to lawyers that further delays in proceeding to trial with their clients' cases would no longer be tolerated was issued yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Henry G. Wenzel in Brooklyn, after nearly all the attorneys in 124 cases called before him proffered excuses for one reason or another.
In one of your recent editorials you attribute to Mr. Farley the astounding and disquieting statement, "that none who opposed the election of the President need have the slightest fear of reprisals."
A packet of eleven bills totaling $2,300 appeared to have been lost yesterday somewhere within an area of less than two blocks near First Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street.

PARIS, Nov. 9. -- The price trend was reversed on the Bourse here today and stocks and bonds declined. It was chiefly a case of profit-taking after the sharp rise last week and there was enough resistance to keep the losses moderate, thus permitting consolidation of most of the previous gains.

HAVANA, Nov. 9. -- A plot to assassinate Colonel Jose Pedraza, chief of the National Police, has been discovered and four persons arrested, according to a statement by the military intelligence service this afternoon. Two automobiles -- one with a Florida license -- which authorities say were to be used in the planned attack were seized.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation endeavored during 1935 to build up the capital structure of the banks for the protection of depositors and other creditors, declined to admit unsound institutions into the insurance fund and sought the cooperation of States in strengthening banks outside of the jurisdiction of the Federal Reserve System, Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the corporation, said today in his report to Congress covering that year.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9. -- Federal District Judge George A. Welsh, in resuming a hearing on a petition of five local ship owners to restrain striking maritime workers from interfering with crews on their vessels, declared today his intention of making a thorough investigation into the unauthorized "rank and file" strike involving seamen and dock workers in many American ports.

The Detroit Lions, champions of the National Football League, moved ahead of the Green Bay Packers in the race for ground gaining honors, while the New York Giants achieved distinction as the best passing team, Pittsburgh's Pirates dropping to the runner-up position, according to the figures released yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP). -- Commerce Department officials said today they were drafting recommendations for the appropriation of $15,000,000 to $20,000,000 for an accurate count of the nation's jobless.

MOUNT VERNON N.Y., Nov. 9. -- John G. Shattuck Jr., 22 years old, of The Hilleriest Drive, Pelham Manor, son of the vice president of the Frank G. Shattuck Company of New York, operators of the Schrafft chain of restaurants, and grandson of the founder of the confectionery concern, died at 9 o'clock tonight at Mount Vernon Hospital of injuries received in an automobile accident.

Miss Eweretta Kernochan will give a tea this afternoon at her home, 155 East Seventy-second Street, for a group of women aiding in the plans for the forthcoming performance of "The Flying Dutchman," in which Mme. Kirsten Flagsted will make her debut as Senta, the afternoon of Jan. 7, at the Metropolitan Opera House.
LONDON, Nov. 9. -- The quarrel between Great Britain and Italy, which had been rankling for months as a most serious by-product of the Ethiopian war, is now on the verge of settlement.

Plans for new housing, including multi-family structures and dwellings, were filed in three boroughs yesterday. A $70,000 apartment house for the Bronx and a $120,000 multi-family building for Brooklyn were among the projects. A $93,000 taxpayer for Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, also was listed.

The first number of Volume 11 of The Colophon, New Series, appears today, containing thirteen contributions of interest to book-collectors. This number is bound in cloth. The complete edition of no other regular periodical published in America has ever been in cloth, as far as the editors are aware.

A pianist of the first rank made his entrance on the American scene last night. He was Simon Barer, a Russian, who gave his initial recital at Carnegie Hall. He will probably be heard here again before long. He is a mature artist who possesses the attributes of head, hand and heart that are the perquisites of the authentic interpreter.
The State of Colorado invited bankers yesterday to submit bids for an issue of $15,000,000 of highway fund revenue anticipation warrants. The award will be made on Nov. 17.
Stuart M. Crocker, general chairman of the United Hospital Campaign, announced yesterday the appointment of five division chairmen in the drive of the organization for hospital funds.
