Sixteen students of the WPA adult education project in the New York School of Industrial Art, 257 West Fortieth Street, were arrested yesterday morning when they refused to leave a classroom in their protest against a proposal to cut their hours and double up classes to make room for more students.
With five more bowing out in the week-end's fireworks, the nation's list of undefeated and untied football teams shows only fourteen survivors in The Associated Press compilations.

For the second time this season the Crop Reporting Board of the Department of Agriculture gave the cotton trade a surprising estimate of this year's yield yesterday by raising the figure 791,000 bales instead of revising it upward only slightly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP). -- The National Labor Relations Board announced today that it had certified the United Electrical and Radio Workers as the representative for collective bargaining purposes of certain classes of employes of the Camden plant of the R.C.A. Manufacturing Company.

A corporation and fifteen individuals, who include a Philadelphia. newspaper publisher, two brokers, one of whom was a member of the New York Stock Exchange, and two attorneys, went on trial yesterday before Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard and a jury on a twenty-two count mail fraud conspiracy indictment.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- The populace of Yonkers, N.Y., incurred a per capita debt of $69.21 last year for operation and maintenance of the city's general departments, compared with a debt of $66.55 for the preceding year, the Census Bureau reported today.

A wage increase of 5 cents an hour and a Christmas bonus of $10,000,000 were voted yesterday by directors of the General Motors Corporation for more than 200,000 of its employes. The wage increase alone amounts to about $20,000,000 a year.

While giving the Manhattan eleven credit for its impressive triumph over Kentucky, Coach Chick Meehan did not let up one whit as he sent the Jaspers through one of their hardest Monday drills of the season yesterday in launching preparations for Saturday's battle with undefeated Georgetown at Ebbets Field.

With reference to the editorial "Good Nature and Good Sense" in your paper for Nov. 6, how dare Mr. Farley even whisper that none who opposed Mr. Roosevelt need fear "reprisals"? This is a free country and every one has, as a right, his choice of opinion.
The presidents of 157 women's clubs in the State were asked in a questionnaire by the State Liquor Authority for opinions on the results of liquor control. Only thirty-five replied.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 9. -- The Princeton varsity football team was excused from practice today, following the usual procedure for Monday workouts, while the scrubs and a few members of the third team were taught the Yale formations for use against the first eleven later in the week.
Leaders of the Charity Organization Society gathered at luncheon in India House yesterday to open a campaign for $278,000 to balance the budget of the fifty-four-year-old family welfare society.

LONDON, Nov. 9. -- Ease in the metals shares today again featured activity on the Stock Exchange here, prices of tins and coppers forging ahead sharply as a result of heavy buying. British Government securities were firm, with little change.

VIENNA, Nov. 9. -- Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano of Italy after having completed the usual formalities of laying wreaths and calling on Dr. Guido Schmidt of the Foreign Office, Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg and President Wilhelm Miklas, began his conferences with Dr. Schuschnigg and Dr. Schmidt this afternoon.

Although the general advance in bond prices lost some of its momentum over the week-end, high-grade issues, including United States Government loans, extended their gains yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange in somewhat less active trading.

The Queens County Bar Association and other legal and civic groups expressed opposition yesterday to the plan of Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. to reorganize the five magistrates' courts in Queens and convert the Jamaica Court into a Traffic Court and the Ridgewood Court into a Felony Court.

Determined to put an end to the tear-gas bombings of Broadway motion picture theatres, Mayor La Guardia threatened yesterday to close the theatres involved unless the Board of Survey he appointed last Saturday could reach a final solution on the labor troubles that produced the bombings.

The brilliance and large attendance of society at the opening night of the National Horse Show were surpassed last night. With only one more night session left, the assembly of social notables began early, and most of the boxes were filled for the second event on the program, the contest in the ring for the Country Club Horse Show Trophy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- Reflecting average yields only a fraction under 200 pounds to the acre, the 1936 cotton crop was forecast today by the government crop reporting board at 12,400,000 bales, an increase of 791,000 bales over the board's estimate of a month ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- Asserting that further delay would cause "paralyzing losses," counsel for the North American Company and the American Water Works and Electric Company urged the Supreme Court today to direct "prompt trial" of their suit challenging the Utility Act.

BERLIN, Nov. 9. -- The red and gold colors of the Spanish Insurgent Government flew over the Spanish Embassy here today. The building, which for several months was jointly occupied by Francisco Agramonte, "Ambassador-on-strike," and Jose Rovira, diplomatic agent of the Madrid government, has passed into the de facto possession of the Burgos government -- for the time being.

Standing at the center of a 456-acre tract at the World's Fair site, while before him a battery of caterpillar-treaded "bulldozers" leveled off heaps of earth as rapidly as a procession of trucks dumped it, Francois de Tessan, French Under-Secretary of State, exclaimed "C'est magnifique. Epatant!"
WITH INSURGENT ARMY, OUTSIDE MADRID, Nov. 9 (AP). -- Insurgent troops struggled tonight to cross the Manzanares River, the last barrier between them and Madrid.
The Princeton Club remained undefeated in the Metropolitan Class B squash tennis league by defeating Harvard, 3-2, on the latter's courts yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, resuming today its investigation of investment trusts and investment companies, began an inquiry into the operations of the Lehman Corporation, an investment trust sponsored by the New York banking house of Lehman Brothers.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9. -- A coronation pageant, showing gowns for the British coronation ball in May and hunting regalia of English character, will be given at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel here on Nov. 16, under the direction of Mrs. George Horace Lorimer.

With General Francisco Franco's army at the very gates of Madrid, Spain is faced with rule by an absolute government for the first time since King Alfonso fled through the garden gate of the royal palace on a moonless night in April, 1931.

ARLINGTON, Texas, Nov. 9 (AP). -- A crowd of 4,000 race fans braved rain and cold today to see Rosselli, carrying the colors of J.C. Palmer, run the mile and a sixteenth in 1:47 3-5 to take the feature event at Arlington Downs by half a length.

LONDON, Nov. 9 (AP). -- Seventeen-year-old Fritz Roethke, cabin boy and sole survivor of the forty persons who were aboard the Hamburg-Amerika motorship Isis, which foundered and sank 200 miles off Land's End, England, tonight related the grim story of the vessel's loss.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

The Central and South West Utilities Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 a consolidated net income of $1,686,401, in contrast with a loss of $214,646 the year before after all taxes, depreciation, charges and underlying preferred dividends paid or accrued.

Mrs. Axel Wenner-Gren gave a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. John Motley Morehead, Mrs. Rufus Patterson, Mrs. Howard Cole, Mrs. Robert Rubin, Mrs. Jeremiah D. Maguire, Mrs. Ivor Thord-Gray, Mrs. Clem C. Keyes and Mrs. H. Lawrence Bogert.
LONDON, Nov. 9. -- Official notification of the removal of the Spanish Government to Valencia was presented to the British Foreign Office today by Ambassador Pablo de Azcarate y Florez.

I learn through the columns of your paper that representatives of Protestant churches have concluded that in the architecture of their church structures much is left to be desired. I hope that many responsible persons of all creeds will take a cursory glance around America and, having reached the inevitable conclusion, will strike their breasts and join the deliberators of Morningside Heights in an avowal of guilt.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 9. -- Outright gifts of $925,000 to charitable, religious and educational institutions are contained in the will of Miss Mary Colgate, philanthropist and church worker, who died on Oct. 24 at her home, 147 Ravine Avenue, Yonkers.

The second of the season's presentations of "Hamlet" arrives in town -- it would be at the Imperial Theatre -- tonight in the person of Leslie Howard. This particular version of the Shakespeare play is in three acts, suitably arranged by Schuyler Watts, and joining Mr. Howard in the cast are Mary Servoss, Pamela Stanley, Aubrey Mather, Wilfrid Walter, Clifford Evans, Joseph Holland, Albert Carroll, Stanley Lathbury, O.Z. Whitehead and others.

No change in the condition of the patient; Broadway is still suffering from pernicious anemia. And Gordon Sherry's "Black Limelight," which was put on at the Mansfield last evening, is not what the doctor ordered to restore Broadway to the more abundant life that the current administration has promised.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Nov. 8. -- District Attorney George V. Dorsey disclosed this afternoon how Trooper Patrick F. Gale of the so-called Scotland Yard unit of the State Police frustrated a jail delivery planned for this morning.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- William Fox, film producer, lost today in the Supreme Court in his fight against an order of the Federal District Court for Southern New York holding him in contempt. His appeal was refused.

EVERY time a football coach gets near a blackboard these days he chalks up a fancy design and goes to talking about mouse traps. Though there is still some literary scrimmaging going on over the matter, it seems that the solemn Sage of Concord, Ralph Waldo Emerson, was the original mouse-trap man.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9. -- The capture of Philadelphia by the Democrats at Tuesday's election was celebrated tonight with a "victory parade," in which at least 100,000 Roosevelt supporters marched a mile and a half from Logan Circle on the Parkway past City Hall to Broad and South Streets.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- Although the value of agricultural imports in the year ended on June 30 was $1,140,000,000, it was still only slightly over a half of the average annual value of such imports for the pre-depression years 1924-25 to 1928-29, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics reported today.

LONDON, Nov. 9. -- A boat picked up at sea, containing a 17-year-old deck boy too exhausted to talk, is the only clue to the fate of the crew of the German motor ship Isis, which signaled desperately for aid last night as a raging gale swept the North Atlantic.

PEIPING, China, Nov. 9. -- Declaring that Communist "cells" had been established in four Peiping universities, including Yenching, which is supported by American missionary funds, the Hopei-Chahar Political Council has issued orders to all provincial and municipal authorities under its control directing the suppression of all movements and organizations likely to stir up anti-Japanese or pro-Communist activities.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 9. -- Starting a week of intensive work to prepare the Harvard eleven for the Navy game, Dick Harlow was pleased to find all his players in shape today.

Four economists who were brought together last night to address a dinner meeting of the American Statistical Association on the "Outlook for International Currency Stabilization" disagreed in all directions.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9. -- Corn continued the center of interest in the grain markets on the Board of Trade today, although trading was not as heavy as it was late last week. The December delivery sold at $1.04 1/4 a bushel, a new high price since 1929 for that contract, but reacted on profit-taking sales to end 3/8 cent higher at $1.03 1/4.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- While the United States Court of Appeals today left the Senate Lobby Committee free to retain and disclose at public hearings the telegrams of William Randolph Hearst which it obtained from telegraph company files, it rebuked the Federal Communications Commission for what it termed the illegal act of copying thousands of messages in telegraph company files in 1935 and turning them over to the Senate committee.

Further sharp gains occurred in most commodity futures here yesterday. Cocoa, cottonseed oil, copper and rubber were easier. In the cash markets hides, wool tops and rye sold at new high prices and wheat, corn, zinc, tin and silk also advanced. Declines were made by cocoa, lard and cotton.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today a new list of brokers and dealers who have applied for registration on Foms 3-M and 4-M. Those in New York follow:...

The Federation of British Industries, in its quarterly forecast of business, indicates its belief, according to our London cable, that the former multilateral system of international trade is no longer possible. Such a conclusion seems unduly pessimistic. It is important to keep in mind the real nature of the forces working against the free flow of world trade, so that we may be better able to judge their probable duration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- Payroll deductions under the Social Security Act are not "deductions" within the meaning of the Walsh-Healey government contract law and will not constitute violations of that act even should they result in reducing wages below the legal minimum, according to a ruling of the Department of Labor which was approved today by Secretary Perkins.

It's going to take a lot of points by any other ambitious touchdown-maker to take the nation's football scoring honors away from Quarterback Art Buck of Carroll, Wis. Buck brought his total to 102 points Saturday by adding a touchdown and four extra points as Carroll closed its season undefeated and untied, says The Associated Press.

Frederick J. Perry, the world's foremost amateur tennis player, has signed a professional contract to go on tour with Ellsworth Vines, and Great Britain has lost the mainstay of its Davis Cup defense.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 9. -- A budget of $8,414,602.57 for the 1937 governmental expenses of Nassau County was adopted today by the Nassau County Board of Supervisors without protest. Compared with last year's budget, the 1937 document shows a decrease of $291,644.71 in the next county tax levy, due principally to the fact that the county will not deposit $500,000 in its reserve fund next year.

Leon Cotnareanu, owner of the Paris Figaro for the past three years, arrived yesterday with his wife on the French liner Normandie, on his first visit to America, to study the newspaper business and methods of obtaining news. He will spend the most of the two weeks here.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Nov. 9. -- I Two horses owned by Miss A. Doris of Philadelphia triumphed at Narragansett Park today, Great Haste winning the featured fifth event and Dixie Princess taking the opener. Jockey Bobby Watson rode both victors.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 9. -- The veil of secrecy was drawn over Yale's football practice today as the Elis began their drive for the game with Princeton Saturday. Head Coach Ducky Pond said that his men would continue to work behind closed gates for the rest of the week.

William E. Coyle Jr. of the Short Hills Club, who is much better known for his squash racquets skill, provided the first major upset in the current invitation squash tennis tournaments at the Princeton Club yesterday when he eliminated the fourth-seeded star, Frederick B. Ryan Jr. of the Yale Club, in a second-round encounter.
BERLIN, Nov. 9. -- Trading on the Boerse was limited today. The market as a whole opened weak but rallied, showing at the close in many cases advances over Saturday's closing.

The weekly luncheon of the Football Writers Association at the Hotel Lincoln took a technical turn yesterday. With no visiting publicity impresarios on hand to beat the drums, the coaches held forth in professorial roles at the blackboard and the conversation was sprinkled with such meaty gridiron terminology as "mouse-trap," "weak-side" and "wing-back" rather than with hyperbolic description of All-America hopes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- President Roosevelt told the third National Conference of Labor Legislation today that he was thoroughly in sympathy with the "leveling upward of labor standards" proposed in the last two annual sessions of the conference and declared that last week the country gave a mandate "in unmistakable terms" to its legislators and executives to better the condition of working people.

French and English audiences are more friendly toward American performers than they used to be, according to Molly Picon, Yiddish comedienne, who returned yesterday on the French liner Normandie after a European tour which was planned for two weeks but was extended to twenty-two because of its success.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9. -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt tonight urged that every person become an "ardent" citizen, learn the individual needs of his community, and become identified with that political party which most closely represents the things he wants to achieve.

The United States Lines announced last night that the President Harding, 14,000-ton passenger and freight ship, which was scheduled to sail tomorrow noon for Plymouth, Havre, London and Hamburg, would not attempt to leave her pier because of the strike of seamen in Atlantic and Gulf ports.

Returning to the scene of a holdup that had netted him $80, Thomas Carmen, 39 years old, of Providence, R.I., ran into a clerk who ignored his pistol and put up a fight in the Nunn-Bush shoe store at 179 Broadway about 9:15 A.M. yesterday.

The police of the Missing Persons Bureau reported yesterday that no trace had been found of Gloria Berry, 14-year-old Washington Irving High School student, who left her home at 698 West End Avenue on the morning of Oct. 23. According to Mrs. Helen Berry, her mother, the girl left a note saying she was "unable to face her fellow students since a teacher had criticized her gymnasium bloomers."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia denied the appeal today of William Randolph Hearst from a lower court ruling dismissing his petition for an injunction to restrain the Black Senate Lobby Investigating Committee from making use of telegrams sent to and received by his papers.
PARIS, Nov. 9. -- Turkey's right to remilitarize the Dardanelles, actually admitted last July, was formally recognized by seven nations today.

The directors of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company authorized yesterday the filing with the Securities Exchange Commission of a registration statement for an issue of $160,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent thirty-year debentures.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 9 (AP). -- The Pittsburgh District Council of United States Steel Corporation employe representatives reorganized today and its new officers announced tonight that they would meet representatives of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, United States Steel subsidiary, tomorrow to reopen the wage question.
CHICAGO, Nov. 9 (AP). -- America's professional golfing brigade will fire at a $200,000 target next year.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9. -- Receipts of hogs here today were 35,000 head, the largest since December, 1934. Early sales were at a decline of 10 cents a hundredweight from Friday's figures, but the market firmed quickly and, with most offerings selling about steady with the close of last week, the top of $9.75 showed 5 cents lower, while the day's average was unchanged at $9.60.

ALMA, Wis., Nov. 9 (AP). -- Dr. Joseph G. Mayo, 34, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles H. Mayo of Rochester, was killed early today when his automobile was struck by the North Coast Limited. Northern Pacific passenger train, at a crossing about two miles south of Cochrane, Wis.
A special dividend of $1 on the common stock of the Archer-Daniels-Midland Company was declared yesterday. On Nov. 6, the usual dividend of 50 cents was voted.

An increase in the number of cases of scarlet fever and tuberculosis in the city for the week ended last Saturday was reported yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health. Seventy-six new cases of scarlet fever were reported, the largest number in any seven-day period since the week ended July 11.

The Democratic campaign to re-elect President Roosevelt cost about $3,300,000 and left the party with a deficit of about $500,000, it was revealed yesterday as National Chairman James A. Farley completed final plans to sail tomorrow for a vacation in Ireland.
International broadcasting executives joined last night in a salute to radio's progress at the National Broadcasting Company's tenth anniversary celebration and dinner at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
Anybody planning a military coup or civil war to overturn an existing Government and set up his own regime may count upon the ready sympathy of El Salvador, one of the Central American republics.

George J. Engelman, 34 years old, a lawyer with offices at 44 Whitehall Street, and living at 677 West End Avenue, and Joseph A. McNamara, 37, of the Seamen's Institute, 25 South Street, were arrested yesterday on ambulance-chasing charges, developed under Bernard Botein, Assistant District Attorney in charge of the new Accident Fraud Bureau.

PARIS, Nov. 9 (AP). -- General Gonzalo Queipo de Llano, a Spanish Rebel leader, said in a broadcast from Seville tonight that the Insurgents had not entered Madrid "because the moment has not yet arrived."

The action of General Motors directors in declaring a "year-end" dividend of $1.50 a share and in voting a wage rise and a $10,000,000 bonus for employes was interpreted yesterday in Wall Street as indicating that not all of this year's earnings will go to the shareholders.

John D.M. Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, declared yesterday that he saw no need for a basic change in the political philosophy of the Republican party. He pledged a militant four-year campaign to consolidate the ranks of party members.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9. -- Surveying the more or less troubled athletic landscape from his ornate tower office, America's Olympic chieftain, Avery Brundage, today warned the Amateur Athletic Union against a renewal of factional warfare in the convention at Houston next month.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 9. -- With something obviously up its sleeve, Paramount today announced its plan to produce a spectacular chronicle of the progress of aviation from the time of Leonardo da Vinci through the China Clipper period.

Nine intercollegiate and fourteen interscholastic records were bettered officially during the season of 1935-36, it was revealed yesterday when Philip S. Harburger, chairman of the National Collegiate A.A. committee on swimming records, gave out for publication the list approved for registration.

Sales of General Motors cars to consumers in the United States amounted to 44,274 last month, against 68,566 units in October, 1935, and 85,201 in September, 1936. The decrease reflects the change-over in production from 1936 models to 1937 models.

ROME, Nov. 9. -- Rome is seething at present with reports of a Hapsburg restoration and of an imminent announcement of the engagement of Archduke Otto of Hapsburg and Princess Maria of Savoy, the Italian sovereign's youngest daughter.

A delightful program, consisting principally of hitherto unknown works by early composers and interesting and individual compositions by living Americans, was given last night in Town Hall when Hans Lange and the Philharmonic-Symphony Chamber Orchestra, assisted by several soloists, gave the first of five concerts whose receipts will swell the scholarship fund of Bennington College.

BERLIN, Nov. 9. -- A new German surprise in rearmament was revealed today when it was officially admitted that Germany was building aircraft carriers. With these her naval aviation will enter a new phase of development.

LONDON, Nov. 9. -- John Henry Lewis easily disposed of the challenge for his light heavyweight championship offered by Len Harvey tonight when he battered the Briton around and did everything but knock him out in a fifteen-round bout in Wembley Stadium.

MOSCOW, Nov. 9 (AP). -- Japan and the Soviet Union concluded today an eight-year renewal of a fishing agreement, which diplomats predicted would have a far-reaching effect on Far Eastern and world politics.

The split in the ranks of organized labor showed signs of widening yesterday following the refusal of John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, to meet William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor to seek a formula by which peace might be restored between the two factions.

A Harlem investment purchase, leasehold deals and ten foreclosure auction sales were among the Manhattan realty transactions reported yesterday. The auctioned properties, including a twelve-story loft building at 158-62 West Twenty-seventh Street and the sixteen-story Rohogee Building at 306-08 West Thirty-eighth Street, were bid in by mortgagees to protect their liens.

ROME, Nov. 9. -- Adhesion of some, if not all, of the Little Entente governments to the Rome protocols of 1934 and 1936 is foreshadowed by Virginio Gayda, authoritative writer, in an important editorial revealing the principal problems with which the Vienna tri-power conference is to deal.

The stock market at times yesterday showed signs of endeavoring to follow the brisk improvement of last week, and the news of the day was mainly on the side of the advance, but many leading stocks proved to be in good supply so that the closing was irregular.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 9. -- Practically the entire colony spends its time out-of-doors in perfect Indian Summer weather. Charles T. Rundlet of Larchmont, N.Y., drove a party of guests in a buckboard to Fassifern Farm today to view the foliage and have luncheon.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 9 (AP). -- The fight of Representative John W. Hoeppel of California and his son, Charles J. Hoeppel, against removal to Washington, where they face jail sentences for conspiring to sell an appointment to West Point, was continued in the Federal court today.

Reports of shortages of gift items for the holiday season are increasing. Imported items are among the first to be mentioned as being in limited supply in the popular price ranges. Novelty glassware from Central Europe, buyers said yesterday, is meeting a brisk demand, with little stocks available on short notice.

Passengers listed to arrive from Europe today on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania include Margaret Countess of Suffolk and Berkshire, Sir Humphrey Rolleston, Sir William Letts, Lieut. Col. E.S. Gillett and Miss Ania Dorfmann, pianist.

The annual report of FREDERICK P. KEPPEL, president of the Carnegie Corporation, has a hopeful word to say about the effect of "present and coming" taxation on contributions for social and educational purposes. He questions the basis for the fear expressed by a number of influential citizens that there will be drying up of the springs of such contributions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- Money in circulation at the end of October amounted to $6,351,265,033, the Treasury announced today. This was an increase of $84,725,587 over the total on Sept. 30, and of $638,668,103 over Oct. 31, 1935.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today approved applications for exemption from the registration provisions of the Public Utility Act of 1935 for the following: Essex and Hudson Gas Company of New Jersey; New Brunswick Light, Heat and Power Company of New Jersey; Newark Consolidated Gas Company of New Jersey, and Monarch Mills, a South Carolina corporation.

The Standard Oil Company of California, in its report for the third quarter of this year, issued yesterday, shows a net profit of $7,685,528 after deductions for expenses, depreciation, depletion, amortization, provision for estimated normal Federal income tax and dividends paid on the preferred stock of its subsidiary.

An investing group headed by William M. Girden purchased the six-story Devon Hall apartment house at 77-44 Austin Street, Forest Hills, from the Prudential Life Insurance Company. The Leonard S. Gans Company, Inc., was the broker.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 10. -- Europe is beginning to show signs of nervous anxiety regarding the possible outcome of the Buenos Aires Peace Conference next month, since it has become known that President Roosevelt probably will attend.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Asserting without reservation that additional regulation of investment trusts is necessary and desirable, Robert Lehman, president of the Lehman Corporation, presented a twelve-point program today during the inquiry into investment trusts by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

As a member of the International Olympic Committee representing the United States, last December I made every effort in the interest of fair play and for the preservation of the Olympic ideal to protest the participation of our American athletes at the Berlin Olympiad, in view of the fact that we could not be assured that the athletes would not be discriminated against, due to their racial background or their religious beliefs.

MOSCOW, Nov. 10. -- The highest Soviet authority gave a subtle but unmistakable answer today to recent rumors that Maxim Litvinoff, Foreign Commissar, had fallen into disfavor. This was done by calling him to the Kremlin and conferring upon him in Joseph Stalin's presence the Order of Lenin, the Soviet Union's highest decoration.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 10. -- With a cold, piercing wind blowing from the north as the harbinger of Winter, Army's badly depleted football squad went through a workout of intensive activity today in preparation for the meeting with Notre Dame on Saturday at the Yankee Stadium.
Winners of the architectural contest for the design of a typical building for the World's Fair of 1939 were announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair corporation.

The gradual removal of uncertainties regarding exchange, trade and war are encouraging developments for the automobile export trade. Consequently, it has been possible, despite adverse conditions in several countries during the last year, to keep up the volume of overseas sales. It is expected that they will exceed 500,000 units.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Christmas liquor packages must contain liquor and nothing else.

After hot debate the Federal Grand Jury Association last evening adopted a resolution calling upon the President to form a commission to study illegal immigration with a view to arresting and deporting all persons who "jumped" ship or were smuggled into this country.
SALAMANCA, Spain, Nov. 10. -- Most of the villages between Toledo and Madrid have been destroyed, but even the others are uninhabited.

LONDON, Nov. 10. -- British Airways, Ltd., has obtained government sanction to negotiate with the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation of the United States for the delivery of a number of Lockheed Electra airliners. They would be used for service on the new night mail service between London and Sweden, which the British Government is subsidizing to the extent of 20,000 yearly.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 10. -- A 26-year-old unemployed waiter was seized here today after five fires in the early morning and nineteen others, one of which caused the death of a man, had terrorized part of this city since last May.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10. -- Prices of hogs here today were steady to 10 cents a hundredweight lower than yesterday, the market showing stubborn resistance to a decline, despite the largest aggregate receipts the last two days since December 1934. In two days the eleven Western markets have received 214,000 hogs, or 100,000 in excess of the same period last week and 119,000 more than last year.

MADRID, Nov. 10. -- Insurgent airplanes dumped forty explosive and incendiary bombs on the defenders of Madrid today, rocking wide sections of the capital in the heaviest aerial bombardment the inhabitants have experienced.

How the automobile industry regards the future is indicated by the substantial expenditures made during the current year for new machinery, new plants and improved manufacturing methods. Perhaps more money has been spent this year on improvements and expansion than in any other one year for a very long time.

Noise absorption in the new cars with the "unisteel" turret-top body by Fisher has been carried to the point where it has been necessary for General Motors to increase the power of its automobile radios. This was revealed yesterday by J.O. Almen, head of the dynamics section of the corporation's research division, in announcing the results of a series of proving-ground tests, which show the unisteel turret-top body to be the quietest ever developed.
LONDON, Nov. 10. -- The House of Lords will consider next month whether a person suffering from an incurable disease may die at his own request rather than suffer.

Recognition of the automobile industry as the pacemaker for American industry will be attested during the weeks to come by the millions of people who will throng to the National Automobile Show in New York and its counterparts in cities and towns throughout the United States.

Two more new playgrounds, both in the Bronx, will be opened today by the Department of Parks. They bring up to 186 the total number of playgrounds opened since the beginning of the La Guardia administration.

Judge James G. Wallace of General Sessions ruled yesterday that a jury would have to be chosen in one day for the trial of three former officials of the Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company, if he had to stay on the bench late into the night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- H.M. Byllesby Co. of Chicago have filed an application with the Securities and Exchange Commission under Section 2 (a) (7) of the Public Utility Act of 1935 for an order by the commission declaring it not to be a holding company.

Residential construction started last month in the thirty-seven States east of the Rockies was valued at $79,736,200, a 45 per cent increase over the $55,100,300 aggregate for October, 1935, the F.W. Dodge Corporation reported yesterday. Last September's figure was $80,670,800.

James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, called last night upon all those who backed President Roosevelt in the election to remain united in order to insure success of his policies during his second administration.

Following a fairly strong start, the share market yesterday had a moderate amount of profit-taking to contend with, together with evening-up operations incident to today's holiday, and it moved irregularly through to closing. Merchandising and silver groups were among the strongest of the list, the former on the prospect of an immediate boom in retail sales and the latter on the further rise in the silver price in London.

One hates to find fault with anything in Professor FURNAS'S excellent speech at the Book Fair Monday night, but there is a passage in it that may be resented by the senior class: "No one has solved the problem of senility." Old age as a fact has to be swallowed, but what must be the feelings of the Aged One when he finds that he is a problem?

A partial reorganization of the Federal Theatre Project for New York City, designed to centralize responsibility, pool production resources and cut red tape, was announced yesterday by Philip W. Barber, regional director.

A FELLOW came along with a yachting cap and a rolling gait, and when he took off his cap he turned out to be Onkel Franz Frisch, manager of the St. Louis Cardinals. It was a surprise to find him still ashore, because a couple of weeks ago he announced that the Frisch-Weaver-Redbird Expedition would be rolling down to Rio in pursuit of nautical adventure and tropical fish "in a couple of days."

Magistrate August Dreyer gave a few pointers yesterday afternoon in Jefferson Market Court to thirty-seven members of the Unemployed Teachers Council on how to go about seeing Colonel Brehon B. Somervell, WPA Administrator, in their quest for jobs.

Several members of the younger set are assisting in the sale of tickets for the performance of "And Stars Remain," the night of Nov. 16 at the Guild Theatre, which has been taken over by the directors of the Children's Village to raise funds for carrying on the work of that organization.

Last year, every minute of each day and night, American motor vehicle owners paid $1,503 in gasoline taxes. In 1934 this tax had been $1,400, and in 1933 $1,332 per minute. Which proves, if you please, that the corner around which recovery lay waiting is being turned with increasing speed.

The new Lincoln V-12 for 1927, commonly referred to as "the big Lincoln" to distinguish it from the Lincoln-Zephyr, will go on public display here today for the first time at the Ford-Lincoln show in Hotel Astor, at the Ford-Lincoln Salon at the Park Lane and at the Ford Motor Sales Company's headquarters, 1,710 Broadway.

The texts of Shakespeare's plays are still "hopelessly or almost hopelessly corrupt" in many places, despite all the work of eighteenth, nineteenth and twentieth century editors and scholars, Dr. Samuel A. Tannenbaum, physician and Shakespearean scholar, told yesterday afternoon's audience at THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair in the International Building, Rockefeller Center.

With the addition of the 60-horsepower series to the Ford line, a new base price for the company's V-8 cars was announced last night. This is $480 for the five-window coupe. The price of this model in the 1936 line, powered by the larger engine, which was the only one available this year until now, was $510.

AUSTIN, Texas, Nov. 10 (AP). -- Coach Jack Chevigny of the Texas football team announced tonight he would not be coach of the Longhorns next Fall. Under fire because of his team's consistent losses, he said he would not seek to renew his contract on its expiration Feb. 1.
The Philadelphia Orchestra, conducted by Leopold Stokowski last night in Carnegie Hall, gave the first performance in New York of Sergei Rachmaninoff's Third Symphony.

The political millennium may be said to have arrived when, a few days after the victory of the Democratic party in a national election, the news columns are the sluices of a golden shower of dividends, bonuses and wage increases. For nearly forty years Republican success at the polls was generally accepted as the precursor of that sort of thing, and Democratic triumph was supposed to be the avant-courier of the reverse.

Health protection will be the theme of an advertising campaign to be run by stores in some forty cities for the new Jones Health Underwear, just being introduced by the Augusta Knitting Corporation. Based on scientific medical principles, the underwear has a lightweight fabric above the waist and a heavyweight cloth below, on the grounds that the torso and legs need better protection than the upper body.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10. -- Mayor Wilson agreed today to permit restoration to the revue "New Faces" of a skit caricaturing Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, which he ordered deleted last night on the ground that it "poked fun at the President's wife."

Employes of the General Electric Company, employed since Jan. 1, 1936, will be subject solely to the Federal Social Security Act pension plan on the first $3,000 in pay, according to notices sent to employes several weeks ago but not announced publicly.

Striking evidence of the growing popularity of the automobile trailer coach -- sleek successor to the ramshackle house on wheels in which the "tin-can tourist" took to the roads only a few years ago -- is to be found at the 1937 automobile show at the Grand Central Palace.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Secretary Perkins asserted today that more and better labor laws have been passed under the New Deal than in any other three years in American history.

In an attempt to halt the drive by the State milk-control authorities against cut-rate milk, fifteen independent wholesale milk dealers started suit yesterday for a Supreme Court restraining order against Peter G. Ten Eyck, Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets, and Kenneth F. Fee, director of the Division of Milk Control. Supreme Court Justice Thomas C. Kadien Jr., in Brooklyn, reserved decision.

GENEVA, Nov. 10. -- The total of world unemployed now is below the 1930 level, according to index figures that Harold B. Butler, director of the International Labor Office, will submit to its governing body at the regular Fall session opening tomorrow.

The General Motors Show of 1937 will open at 2 P.M. today at the Waldorf-Astoria. Occupying the entire third floor of the hotel, the show will include displays of the 1937 models of Chrevolet, Pontiac, Oldsmobile, Buick, La Salle and Cadillac motor cars, and also animated exhibits of car operation and of other products of the General Motors Corporation.

After a day of rest, Columbia's football forces gathered yesterday at Baker Field to practice for the game with Syracuse on Saturday. The Lions are seeking their second major victory of the campaign and the drill was long and strenuous.

Federal Judge Samuel Mandelbaum reserved decision yesterday on the proposed reorganization of the National Public Service Corporation under the Bankruptcy Act after hearing arguments on the opinion of Irwin Kurtz, special master, who said "there is nothing to reorganize."

Moving a step nearer the final, Harry F. Wolf of the New York A. C., national champion and winner of the event a year ago, gained the quarter-final round of the Princeton Club's annual squash tennis invitation tourney yesterday. Wolf scored by 15-5, 15-4 against D. K. Clifford of the Heights Casino and will meet a clubmate, J. J. Lordi, when play is resumed on Friday.

A nation-wide acceptance of the 1937 Chevrolet surpassing that which greeted the introduction period last year, was reported yesterday by W.E. Holler, vice president and general sales manager at his headquarters in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

CAPE MAY COURTHOUSE, N.J., Nov. 10. -- The Board of Canvassers of Cape May County were restrained by court order today from certifying the election of William C. Hunt of Wildwood, Republican, apparently elected State Senator by 432 votes. Edward Miller, Democratic county chairman, predicted a recount would show Jesse D. Ludlam, Democratic candidate, had defeated Mr. Hunt by 500 votes.
BERLIN, Nov. 10. -- Within the last year an organization has been growing up quietly in Germany that in some future crisis of the regime may play a decisive role.

Our Washington dispatches report that President ROOSEVELT is considering plans which would bring the whole question of governmental reorganization squarely before the new Congress. His purpose would be to rearrange the activities of the huge Federal establishment on a "functional" basis, by consolidating and transferring bureaus, by deleting useless or outmoded units, perhaps even by making changes in some of the regular Cabinet positions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- President Roosevelt said at his press conference today that he intended to stick to his purpose, announced during the election campaign, not to recommend new taxes at the coming session of Congress, hut he avoided all commitments as to attempts to balance the budget at this time.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10. -- Federal Judge George A. Welsh notified Mayor S. Davis Wilson tonight to have police in readiness for any violence in the seamen's strike in this port.

Refutation of criticism that the "camera eye," used to judge finishes on New York race tracks, favors the outside horse, was made yesterday by the Bureau of Standards of the United States Department of Commerce in a report to the New York State Racing Commission.

VIENNA, Nov. 10. -- After having spent most of the day in military inspections and entertainments, Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister, resumed this afternoon his conferences with Dr. Guido Schmidt, Austrian Foreign Under-Secretary, and Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg.

The eighteenth anniversary of the signing of the Armistice ending the World War will be celebrated today in all parts of the city. Civic organizations, veterans' associations, peace societies and representatives of the city, State and nation will take part.

Persons now nearing middle age can look back to the day when the approach of Winter was the signal for the retirement of the automobile. It was locked up in the garage -- or, in those days, in the barn -- until the return of Spring.

The next step in traffic regulation on Manhattan Island, now under consideration by advisers to the Police Department, is to make the avenues one-way thoroughfares, just as the streets have been for a decade.
Charley Gomer, Baltimore light-weight, outpointed Baby Casanova, hard-hitting Mexican, in the ten-round feature bout before 2,500 fans at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night.

RED BANK, N.J., Nov. 10. -- The body of Mrs. Nellie Mills, 28 years old, of 56 Wallace Street, Red Bank, a drug store clerk here, was found at 7:15 o'clock tonight with bullet wounds in the head and back on a lonely part of Prospect Avenue on the outskirts of this town.

LONDON, Nov. 10. -- The text of the government's much discussed new public order bill, aimed at curbing the activities of Sir Oswald Mosley's Black Shirts and similar groups, was made available today to members of the House of Commons.

Striking a note of optimism for the future of industrial development, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of General Motors Corporation, told about 250 leaders in the fields of business, science and journalism at a luncheon in honor of Charles F. Kettering, head of the research division of the corporation, that the automobile industry was not content now to stand still.

The word "highway" has dif ferent meanings to various people. To the drivers and passengers in the country's 22,500,000 cars it is a pleasure riding and travel route. To civil engineers and road builders it is a problem in construction and dynamics.

A woman and eight men, owners of five millinery manufacturing firms, were arrested yesterday on Special Sessions warrants in an investigation of the "ash-can hat" racket by James J. Wilson, Assistant District Attorney, in charge of the Commercial Frauds Bureau.

Though the relative strength of the December position offered some resistance, prices on the Cotton Exchange worked lower again yesterday to end with losses of 10 to 13 points. The unexpectedly large crop estimate unsettled professional sentiment and narrower differences between here and Liverpool created less foreign demand.
BERLIN, Nov. 10 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's position on Nov. 9, in marks, is shown in the following statement, with changes from a week before:

S.S AMERICAN LEGION, at Sea, Nov. 10. -- The United States delegation to the Pan-American Peace Conference took up today detailed study of a neutrality proposal it will offer to the gathering at Buenos Aires on Dec. 1 as its most important contribution toward carrying out President Roosevelt's professions regarding peace when he suggested the conference months ago.

American railroads have entered a new period of progressive development as a result of the attitude of the Roosevelt administration, the merging of radical and conservative ideas and the restoration of public confidence in the industry, W.A. Harriman, chairman of the Union Pacific Railroad Company, told the Lions Club at a luncheon yesterday in the Hotel Astor.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

John Bermudez, 16 years old, lost his life about 12:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon when he returned through a smoke-filled hallway during a fire in his home at 308 Hicks Street, near State Street, Brooklyn, to rescue a cat that was trapped on the top floor.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 10. -- Seventy-four undergraduates have been retained in the Princeton University Glee Club, it is announced by James A. Giddings Jr., who is beginning his third year as director of the club.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 10. -- The latest success story on the race track reached some sort of a climax at Pimlico today when Grand Duke captured the Southern Handicap to give Mrs. Emil Denemark of Chicago her twenty-sixth victory of the Maryland season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Regulations relating to the employers' and employes' tax under the Social Security Act will be distributed soon to interested parties through collectors of Internal Revenue, the Treasury announced today.
The other day I overheard two of our young engineers talking. They agreed that the trouble with our present-day automobile driver is that "he takes his car too darned casually."

For the first nine months of this year the New Jersey Zinc Company reported yesterday a net income of $3,593,585 after Federal taxes, depreciation, depletion, contingencies and other charges. No mention was made of Federal surtax on undistributed profits.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Nov. 10. -- Dr. Wilbour E. Saunders, headmaster of Peddie School, announced today that a final-whistle program to curb "the trend toward violence" at football contests would be invoked at the annual Peddle-Blair Academy game Friday.

Advocates of a project for the widening and deepening of the Flushing Bay channel by the government received yesterday thirty days in which to submit figures to the War Department on the increased commerce which could be expected as a result of the proposed improvement.

The strife which for several weeks has beset the New York Americans of the National Hockey League was peacefully adjusted yesterday after an all-day session of the directors of the circuit at the Commodore Hotel.

Stimulated by lower temperatures, further sharp increases in retail trade have been registered in many sections of the country this week, reports in the local market yesterday indicated. Consumer buying of seasonal apparel today is expected to be heavy, with the volume for the day ranking well with the early peak of the season on Columbus Day.

Administration of the Public Schools Athletic League, governing body of sports in the city's public schools, was taken over by the Board of Education yesterday. The action, which has been pending for several years, was taken at a meeting held at the board's offices at which the league's board of directors surrendered control.

MEMPHIS, Nov. 10. -- Senator McKellar called today for a Senate investigation into The Literary Digest's 1936 Presidential poll, and said that he would sponsor legislation to place future straw votes under strict Federal supervision.

This alphabetical society is not a new one. It is the oldest of the organizations for promoting the welfare of needy families in New York. The need for its activities has not been superseded by Government relief for the unemployed. Moreover, there is to be no joint fund-raising campaign this year, such as has been made for the last six years, from which it may have an allotment.

Leonard Del Genio, Harlem, gained a close decision over Maxie Berger, Montreal, in the feature eight-round bout at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx last night. Many in the crowd of 7,000 opposed the decision. The Harlem lightweight, who still has hopes of meeting titleholder Lou Ambers, earned the award on superior infighting.

LONDON, Nov. 10. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange were generally quiet today, excepting considerable buying of Mexican Eagle Oil shares following the news of the settlement of the prolonged strike at the company's plants. Other oils, following the trend of Mexican Eagles, were also generally stronger.

The late Roy D. Chapin, president of the Hudson Motor Car Company, and A.E. Barit, vice president, who succeeded him, received each in 1935 salaries of $57,600, the company's annual report to the Securities and Exchange Commission showed yesterday.

A spectacular rise in United States Government obligations again was the outstanding feature of bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Prices throughout the Federal list soared in more active trading as twenty-two of the twenty-five long-term issues listed reached the highest levels since their issuance.

Retail sales of motor trucks in the United States for the first ten months of this year have already exceeded the entire twelve months' priod of 1929, the previous peak year for production and sales. Reports indicate sales of approximately 575,000, as compared with the entire 1929 sales figure of 527,057 units.

MONTREAL, Nov. 10. -- The revamped New York Rangers, featuring the rookie trio of Neil and Mac Colville and Alex Shibicky, spoiled the Maroons' National Hockey League opening tonight by defeating the Montrealers, 4 -- 1, as 4,500 looked on.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Further slight improvement in crop prospects in October that averaged about 2 per cent over the condition of the preceding month was reflected today in the preliminary analysis of principal crops by the government Crop Reporting Board. Mild weather that aided in maturing late-growing crops was held responsible for the improvement.

Mrs. Vincent Astor, acting president of the Musicians Emergency Fund and chairman of its newly organized membership committee, yesterday announced the names of the committee which will assist her in obtaining annual memberships to the organization.

LONDON, Nov. 10. -- Colonel Josef Beck, Foreign Minister of Poland, has scored off the Germans on the question of Danzig. This was revealed during his conversations here with Foreign Minister Anthony Eden yesterday. The German Government has given assurances that it will not intervene in the dispute between the Danzig Senate and Poland.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Nov. 10. -- While E.F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor, drove steadily ahead today toward resumption of peace negotiations in the maritime strike, peace in the San Francisco warehouse strike seemed near.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Great Britain and other foreign countries which purchase fighting planes in this country of types manufactured for the United States armed services and embodying secret military devices will encounter delays of approximately two years in deliveries as a result of a policy adopted by President Roosevelt today after consultation with the State, War, Navy and Justice Departments.

This evening's candidate at the Golden Theatre is the farce-satire called "Double Dummy," by Tom McKnight and Doty Hobart. It is also James R. Ullman's fourth production of the season, this time in association with Mark Hellinger, and the plans are elaborate -- two stage levels, some twenty-eight changes of scene, and a plot that touches on contract bridge, racketeers, higher learning and the parole system.

The directors of the New York County Lawyers Association have approved the report of the association's special committee disapproving the "Good Will Court" broadcasts in which "a few lawyers and judges participate."
LONDON, Nov. 10 (AP). -- Letters revealing sidelights on the life of Colonel T.E. Lawrence, the "Uncrowned King of Arabia," were sold for $500 at auction today.

Highly attractive styling stands out prominently on the new cars displayed here this week, but those interested in mechanical features and their effect on performance find plenty of refinements in construction to gain their attention. Startling departures in mechanism are lacking this year, but improvements in detail, making for better value and general user satisfaction, are more numerous than in some past years.

DALLAS, Texas, Nov. 10 (AP). -- Elliott Roosevelt, son of the President, said today that he acceded to a request by Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Jr. not to introduce her to a Fort Worth Town Hall audience last night, to avoid an "embarrassing" situation.

When Philip II stuck a pin in the dead center of a map of Spain and found that it lay close to the tiny village of Madrid, which he consequently created his only court, he could not dream that it would become the huge modern city that is being shelled, bombed and attacked today.

All security and commodity markets, save a few local livestock markets, and all banks will be closed today in the United States and in the Dominion of Canada in observance of Armistice Day. Abroad a bank holiday will be observed in France and Belgium.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,973,800 barrels, compared to 3,043,500 in the previous week, a decrease of 69,700, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Decreases of 37,950 barrels in the daily average output of Oklahoma and of 37,250 in Texas were the important changes.

By unanimous vote, the Board of Aldermen adopted a resolution yesterday asking the Board of Transportation and the Transit Commission to place a limit on the size of bundles that may be carried in the subways.

The large six-story apartment house at 108 Clark Place, corner of Walton Avenue, in the Bronx, has been resold by Max Rosenfeld, operator, to the Walclar Realty Corporation. The buyers were reported to have paid cash above a mortgage of $229,500.

Mid-November's parade of traditional fixtures, which annually mark the end of the football campaign for major prep schools, gains momentum today with several features, headed by the forty-eighth Groton-St. Mark's game at Groton, Mass., and the contest between the New York Military Academy and Admiral Farragut Naval Academy at the Polo Grounds.

In a heart-breaking finish, the international military team championship, which was the sensational feature event of the final session of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden, was won last night by the British Army team after two jump-offs. The final score was Great Britain, 3; Irish Free State Army team, 4;' United States Army team, 7.

Ten simple rules for turning 100 per cent of the gasoline used in a motor car into comfortable and economical transportation have been worked out by L.K. Marshall, general service manager of the Pontiac Motor Company.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10. -- Army contracts were awarded at the Quartermaster Depot today for 929,126 pairs of cotton "shorts," on which bids were opened yesterday here under Invitation 109. The successful bidders were:...

Ten German correspondents in this country will be affected by the ordinance issued yesterday by Max Ammann, director of the Reich Press Chamber, forbidding German journalists abroad to belong to foreign clubs or international associations.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10. -- The Philadelphia Museum of Art, with the aid of a Federal grant, is about to embark on an interior construction project to result in the opening of thirty or more rooms and galleries for the display of art objects worth more than $1,000,000, which for the most part now are in storage.

For the second time in two days, the State Federation of Women's Clubs listened yesterday to an endorsement by non-religious professional men of "old fashioned" religious and moral ideology as a beneficent influence on physical health.

The continued upward trend in retail business is clearly reflected in the activities of automobile dealers, according to replies to a questionnaire received by the National Auotomobile Dealers Association covering the operations for the first nine months of 1936, compared with the same period in 1935, it is reported.

TOKYO, Nov. 10. -- The army's plan for renovation of government machinery, designed to give Japan a stronger and more highly centralized administration suitable to difficult times, was published today.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 10 (AP). -- The Gulf Oil Corporation declared today a dividend of 75 cents a share, an increase of 50 cents, on its 4,800,000 shares of outstanding stock, payable on Dec. 10 to stock of record Nov. 20. It will bring the year's disbursement to approximately $7,200,000.

The doors of the Grand Central Palace, in Lexington Avenue, between Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Streets, will be opened at 2 o'clock this afternoon for the thirty-seventh National Automobile Show. The exhibition of automobiles, trucks, trailers, accessories and safety equipment will continue daily through Wednesday of next week.

Despite Mayor La Guardia's backing of a plan to establish three additional glass-enclosed public markets, the local laws committee of the Board of Estimate laid the plan over without recommendation yesterday after hearing vigorous opposition to it from property owners in the areas involved.

The Victory Ball, which for many years has marked the commemoration of the signing of the armistice, was held last night in the ballroom suite of the Plaza, and once again it took its place as one of the city's most impressive armistice celebrations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Two large national unions, those of the women's and men's clothing industries, acted today to stimulate revival of legislation similar to the NRA, providing minimum wages and maximum hours. Both declared that wage standards had dropped and hours had been lengthened since the demise of the NRA.

Supplementing its exhibit at the Grand Central Palace, the Chrysler Corporation will have a special showing during show week of its full line of motor cars, including Chrysler, Plymouth, Dodge and De Soto models at its new permanent salon in the Chrysler Building, Lexington Avenue and Forty-second Street.

Continuing its drive for the game with undefeated Georgetown at Ebbets Field Saturday, Manhattan's football squad engaged in its second successive scrimmage at Innisfail Park yesterday. For almost two hours the Jasper varsity tested its offense against scrub and freshman elevens.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 10 (AP). -- Alexander "Motzie" Di Nicola, 42, characterized by the government as the overlord of a chain of Connecticut vice resorts, was sentenced today in Federal District Court to seven years in the Federal penitentiary at Lewisburg, Pa., and fined $1,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Fearing another wheat surplus next year such as already has been indicated, seven farm leaders from the Great Plains States assured Secretary. Wallace today of their desire for a crop insurance plan that could be made effective in 1937.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10. -- A model statute outlawing below-cost or "loss-leader" selling at retail will be presented to State Legislatures in the coming year by the National Food and Grocery Conference Committee, according to a unanimous decision reached by the group at a meeting here today.

Tired and travel-stained, but clinging for dear life to two suitcases filled with newly acquired finery, two little girls who disappeared Monday from their homes in Brooklyn with $4,000 that had been left in a dresser drawer were picked up yesterday morning by detectives cruising in a police radio car.
CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (AP). -- Oil men heard reports of a good year in the industry today at a general session of the American Petroleum Institute, then divided into groups to discuss technical problems.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Admiral William D. Leahy, commander of the battle force of the United States Fleet, was appointed today, with the approval of President Roosevelt, to succeed Admiral William H. Standley as Chief of Naval Operations, and Brig. Gen. Thomas Holcomb was named to become a full general Dec. 1 and to succeed General John H. Russell as commandant of the Marine Corps. General Russell is to retire Jan. 1.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 10 (AP). -- Chrysler shares sold at $139.50 on the San Francisco Stock Exchange today, its highest level, after directors declared the $5.50 dividend. The stock closed at $135.50, with the volume 3,200 shares.

More than 250 radio stations have scheduled a series of three broadcasts devoted to "building safety into the American highway system" in a nationally organized campaign to expand the highway safety program of the American Road Builders Association, it is reported.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 10. -- Twenty-two men reported to Coach Ken Fairman for the first practice of the season for Princeton varsity basketball candidates in the university gymnasium tonight. Captain Bud Sauter, center, was the only letterman on hand in the absence of Johnny Vruwink and Ken Sandbach, varsity forwards at present engaged in football.

We look at the sleek bodies of the new cars, watch six, eight, twelve cylinder engines as they are turned over by some hidden mechanism, talk knowingly about miles per gallon of fuel and about hypoid gearing. So this is the "horseless carriage" at which we hooted a generation ago despite the avidity with which we read JULES VERNE and despite our longing for speedy transportation.

NEWARK, Ohio, Nov. 10. -- The tall corn State produced another national corn husking champion today when Carl Carlson of Audubon County, Iowa, brother of the 1935 winner, sloshed his way to victory in a field half knee deep in mud.

LONDON, Nov. 10. -- A good trial scene is expected to win success for John Sheppard's "Decree Nisi," at the Embassy Theatre. The early acts show a possessive husband determining on a flimsy pretext to frame an allegation of misconduct against his wife and the happily married friend of her schooldays; and subsequently consulting with a modern Dodson Fogg regarding the effective management of a divorce suit based on perjured evidence.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10. -- The presence on the sun of the greatest display of spots seen in several years was announced today at the private observatory of Dr. Gustavus Wynne Cook in Wynnewood. There have been observed two chains of dark solar markings, one 300,000 miles long and the other possibly even longer.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Nov. 10. -- South Jersey gunners opened the 1936 upland game season today under ideal weather conditions. The morning was mild and windless, with a bright sun shining from a clear sky. Around noon a bracing breeze came in from the northeast, bending low the brown Indian grass and filling the air with whirling leaves.

One hold-up man was wounded and another halted after both had exchanged shots at 8 A.M. yesterday with policemen on the East Side, following a hold-up in Samuel Kaplan's second-hand clothes shop at 193 Division Street.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 10. -- Three Princeton elevens scrimmaged for an hour today against Yale offensive and defensive formations as unfolded by the scrubs during a two-hour session, which included a long kicking drill and work on new plays.

The final night session of the National Horse Show presented a brilliant social spectacle. The boxes were filled, and the usual last-night crush on the promenade and the parade of fashion made a scene of animation and color.

Trends of prices were mixed in the local commodity futures markets yesterday, with hides, rubber, cocoa, cottonseed oil and tallow firm in generally active dealings, while most other staples barely were steady. On the cash markets silk, rubber, lead and tin reached new high points and cocoa advanced, while wheat, corn, rye, cotton and lard declined.

As 1936 passes into automotive history, it becomes increasingly apparent that this will be the first year since the advent of the motor car that highway fatalities have not increased under the pressure of growing car mileage. The best available estimate indicates that this year's car mileage will be at least twenty billion miles in excess of the total for 1935.

Few of the thousands of persons who swarm about the sleek new cars on exhibition at the National Automobile Show in the Grand Central Palace will pause to speculate on the quantity of midnight oil that has been burned by inventors in order that these modern editions of the "horseless carriage" might stand forth in all their glistening perfection.
Purchases of apartment houses to be remodeled were included in the Manhattan realty turnover reported yesterday.

Many tables have been reserved for the bridge party which will be a feature of the afternoon's entertainment at the bazaar in behalf of the Convent of Mary Reparatrix to be held throughout tomorrow at the Plaza. Mrs. Frank A. Otis heads the executive committee in charge of arrangements, and assisting are members of a junior committee.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 10. -- Making no changes in his varsity, Coach Dick Harlow drove his three elevens through an unusually hard session today for the Navy game. The list of injuries was tossed into the discard, as every member of the varsity is again in first class shape.

The Chrysler Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of $5.50 a share on its common stock, payable on Dec. 14 to stockholders of record of Nov. 20. This is the largest dividend ever paid by the corporation. Total dividend payments for this year will amount to $12 a share, compared with $2 last year.

A plea for "a resumption of cordial business relationships with those stores whose cooperation was temporarily withdrawn" was made yesterday by Maurice Rentner, chairman of the Fashion Originators Guild of America, in commenting on the decision announced in Boston on Monday by Ripley L. Dana, special master appointed by the Federal court, in favor of the guild and denying the application of William Filene's Sons Company for a permanent injunction.

New Yorkers will have their first opportunity today to see the new Ford V-8 cars and the custom Lincoln models for 1937 when the Ford-Lincoln automobile show opens in the Hotel Astor at noon. The show, which runs concurrently with the National Automobile Show at Grand Central Palace, where the products of the Dearborn manufacturer are not exhibited, will be open free each day from 10:00 A.M. until midnight through next Wednesday.

Purchasers of automobiles during 1937 will benefit not only from the mechanical improvements developed in recent years, but will also receive the benefit of generally reduced prices, made possible by a 25 per cent increase in sales of motor cars last year, Lee J. Eastman, president and general manager of the Packard Motor Car Company of New York, said yesterday.

Japanese research men, trained to analyze foreign markets and give suggestions which can be developed with profit by manufacturers in Japan, are touring even the remote sections of Africa constantly, C.F. Unverzagt of the Joseph Dixon Crucible Company told members of the Export Managers Club of New York at a luncheon meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

Your editorial "Popular and Electoral Votes" recognizes the absurdity of the present machinery for choosing our President and Vice Presidents and, on the other hand, points out clearly the delay and possible complications which might ensue if the election were to be decided by the popular vote of the nation.

MADRID, Nov. 10. -- A strong column of reinforcements arrived here from Catalonia this afternoon with a number of pieces of heavy artillery and a full complement of rifles and machine guns of the latest types.

Northwestern maintained a slight margin over Minnesota yesterday in The Associated Press national college football ranking poll. Fordham remained more securely in third place and Alabama leaped from fourteenth to fourth in the biggest gain of the week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Amended regulations intended to prevent amusement tax evasion by ticket scalpers and others who deal in admissions to theatres, sporting events, night clubs and establishments of this character at prices in excess of the ordinary cost, were issued today by the Internal Revenue Bureau.
The Kings County grand jury that has been attempting to determine why the city's streets are so untidy placed the blame yesterday on the citizens themselves.

According to public announcements, the lowest-price automobile in the show is the new Willys car, with which the reorganized Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., is seeking this year to return to volume production. Ward M. Canaday, chairman of the board of the company, in a recent statement, set forth the Toledo firm's present position and plans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Secretary Perkins said today that average living costs for families of wage-earners and lower salaried workers in thirty-two cities of the United States increased 0.4 per cent from July 15 to Sept. 15.

When he attended the opening of the second Poultry Industries Exposition in the Port Authority Building, Eighth Avenue and Fifteenth Street, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday afternoon that he was not yet satisfied with the distribution of poultry in the city, but, nevertheless, praised the efforts of the Department of Markets to eliminate racketeering in the poultry market.

Postmaster General James A. Farley, Governor Philip La Follette of Wisconsin and Mrs. La Follette, Francois de Tessan, French Under-Secretary of State; Rear Admiral Cary T. Grayson, chairman of the American National Red Cross, and Earl Beatty, son of the late admiral of the British fleet, are among the passengers scheduled to sail for Europe today on the French liner Normandie.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 10. -- Leaving the greater part of her $3,500,000 estate to church and charities, the will of Mrs. Mary S. Jacobs of Newport and Baltimore was filed in the Orphan's Court today. The will provided $100,000 annuity for her husband, Dr. Henry Barton Jacobs and bequests to relatives, friends and employes.

Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, Regional Director of the Federal Social Security Board, and members of her executive staff were kept busy yesterday clarifying complexities of the old-age benefit program for more than 1,500 persons who telephoned or came in person to the offices at 45 Broadway.

Miss Irene Ruppert gave a piano recital yesterday afternoon in the Town Hall, playing among others compositions by Vivaldi-Bach, Bach, Brahms, Schumann, Reger and Liszt. Miss Ruppert, probably hampered by nervousness, showed an extensive but not a secure and completely rounded technique, and qualities of temperament of which she will probably be able better to avail herself in future years.

John Doe, automobilist, and Jack Smith, pedestrian, may properly ask: "What is being done to reduce the number of traffic accidents?" As each citizen, because he must be either a motorist or pedestrian, believes himself at least an amateur "traffic expert," it is only natural that he should inquire as to what the professionals -- officers, engineers and educators -- are doing about it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- With representatives of other powers joining in the Armistice Day ceremony, President Roosevelt will place a wreath on the tomb of the unknown soldier at 11 o'clock tomorrow morning.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- All persons were urged to join the Red Cross in a statement issued by President Roosevelt today in connection with the annual campaign by that organization to raise funds. The campaign begins tomorrow and will continue until Thanksgiving Day.

DOVER, N.J., Nov. 10. -- Three accidents, one serious, marked the opening of the New Jersey hunting season today. The major casualty was Willard Van Clear, 27, of South Amboy, who was badly wounded in the right chest and right arm by an unidentified nimrod.

A comprehensive exhibit of the activities of the Port of New York Authority will be placed on display tomorrow at the opening of the third annual marine exhibition of the Maritime Association, at the Maritime Exchange Building, 80 Broad Street.

With Rutgers as the next objective and games with City College and Fordham still on the program, the New York University football team began preparations yesterday at Ohio Field for these contests. Coach Mal Stevens put the Violet through a three-hour drill. Today being a holiday, the practice session will begin earlier than usual, with another long workout planned.

BERLIN, Nov. 10. -- Reports elsewhere that the Schuschnigg gov ernment intends to project the Hapsburg restoration issue into the conference of the Rome protocol powers is discounted here and the official German position seems to be that any such manoeuvre would meet with Italian opposition.
CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (AP). -- A campaign by the Professional Golfers Association to give the game back to the duffer has borne fruit in savings to clubs totaling $320,000.

Business failures in four of the five trade groups into which the record is divided showed declines from their forty-four week average in the five business days ended with Nov. 5, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has made, effective as of today, a new rule requiring issuers with securities registered on national securities exchanges, except in the case of foreign governmental and foreign private corporate issues, to make reports concerning certain special changes, particularly those having to do with capital structures, which may occur between the filing of annual reports.

No one will expect that the celebration of Armistice Day this year could be charged with the sentiments of 1918. There are hundreds of thousands who were not born at that date. There are other hundreds of thousands who were too young to know what the war meant. To them the thrill which stirred every heart in the land on Nov. 11 eighteen years ago was never personally felt.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 10 (AP). -- President Benjamin F. Fairless of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation told a group of employes' representatives tonight there was some doubt that the announced pay increase would go to workers whose representatives failed to accept the sliding scale pay plan based on the Federal cost of living index.

Trailers have become so suddenly popular and so many large and small manufacturers have entered or expanded in the production field that there is no comprehensive organization of the producers and users of the homes on wheels. Feeling the need for an organization of manufacturers, at least, a group of producers have filed papers in Illinois for the incorporation of the Trailer Coach Manufacturing Association.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 10. -- Yale staged its final scrimmage for its engagement at Princeton next Saturday with more than an hour's contact work on Anthony Thompson Field today. The practice was secret.

ALBANY, Nov. 10. -- In a proclamation issued today, Governor Lehman asked for the whole-hearted cooperation of the people of the State in the annual Red Cross roll-call "in acknowledgment of its fine services in the past and in preparation for the exigencies we hope against but which are ordained to be inevitable."

MADRID, Wednesday, Nov. 11, 2:15 A.M. (Censored). -- Shortly after midnight the clouded, starless sky over Madrid was brightly illuminated by a big fire near Segovia Street, in the western quarter of the city.
GENEVA, Nov. 10. -- Italy plans to seek a deal with the United States whereby in return for sweeping trade advantages she would resume war debt payments, according to good information here.
