After talking of "Hamlet" for two or three seasons, Leslie Howard has come to the point of playing him in a handsome production that filled the stage of the Imperial last evening. Since Hamlet has been for some time his personal idol, Mr. Howard has laid all his actor's resources at the feet of the greatest part in the Shakespeare procession.

The American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $4,704,186 after all deductions for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.67 a share on 2,092,483 average number of no-par common shares outstanding, in comparison with $3,083,661, or $1.08 a share on 1,741,008 common shares, in the preceding year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- The contest between the Roosevelt administration and the power corporations over the government's right to make grants and loans for publicly owned hydroelectric plants as part of the relief program was fought for four hours in the Supreme Court today in arguments on the Duke Power case.

LONDON, Nov. 10. -- Sir Samuel Hoare, First Lord of the Admiralty, made the surprising statement in the House of Commons late tonight that Great Britain had no commitments at the present time comparable to those of 1914 which would compel her to send troops to the Continent in the event of another war.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 10. -- Supreme Court Justice Graham Witschief voided this afternoon the action yesterday of the Westchester Board of Supervisors in appointing a committee of three Republicans and two Democrats to investigate alleged discrepancies in the vote for Surrogate.

" Scientific Books for Our Times" will be the topic at tonight's auditorium program at THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair in the International Building, Rockefeller Center. W. W. Norton will be chairman of the program.
CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (AP). -- Dr. Alan Roy Dafoe went for a swift ride tonight on the merry-go-round of Chicago night life.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10. -- The edge was taken off the bull movement in corn today. General professional and commission house selling of futures developed on the Board of Trade on reports that 173,000 bushels of cash corn had been purchased for deferred shipment from the country, including fair amounts from Michigan, Indiana and Ohio which normally ship their surplus grain eastward.

Mayor WILSON of Philadelphia comes forward to allay many people's fears about an America ironed out into deadly uniformity. Mayor WILSON took violent umbrage at a little skit about Mrs. ROOSEVELT in a popular revue and ordered the number expunged from the program.

Syracuse, N.Y., has invited tenders for a new issue of $1,300,000 of certificates of indebtedness, award of which will be made on Friday. The certificates will be dated Nov. 16, 1936, and become payable on May 16, 1937.

James E. Finegan, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, warned employes of the Emergency Relief Bureau yesterday that participation in an ERB strike would mean "disqualification for future civil service." Six thousand ERB workers recently voted to go out on strike if the Civil Service Commission persisted in its announced intention of giving open, competitive examinations for jobs in the relief agency.

Archie Ignatow, New York University sophomore, came through a field of twenty-six last night to win the prep foils tournament on the New York Athletic Club strips. It was the opening competition of the season of the Amateur Fencers League of America.

Reflecting profit-taking by foreign investors in the security markets here, it was believed, the foreign exchanges yesterday engaged in a broad rally against the dollar. Sterling rose to $4.88 3/8 and closed at $4.88 1/8, up 9-16 cent from Monday, while the franc advanced to 4.64 3/4 cents, where it closed, up 7/8 point.

BERLIN, Nov. 10. -- The new edition of the German Naval Calendar, just released, reveals the formidable character of the German fleet now under construction or projected within the limits of the Anglo-German naval agreement. The biggest surprise is the announcement that the Reich will begin construction on a 35,000-ton battleship to replace the Hanover of 13,000 tons, built in 1905.

WEBB MILLER has one of the most exciting jobs in the world, and yet he is dissatisfied. He says that he would much rather sit on the shores of Walden Pond than dash about as foreign correspondent for the United Press. He has witnessed hangings, guillotinings, wars, invasions. He has interviewed princes, premiers, dictators, bandits.

With a quota of $325,000 and a carefully pared budget for relief work and other necessary activities in the coming year, the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross begins today its twentieth annual membership roll-call in Manhattan and the Bronx.

A marked increase in public approval of the modern trend toward streamline design in motor cars was expressed this year in tabulations of the General Motors Customer Research questionnaires, mailed annually to more than 1,000,000 motorists throughout the country who own all makes of cars.
Quietness of operation will be a key phrase in describing the polished and shining versions of 1937's automobiles, according to James R. Glazebrook, automotive engineer for Johns-Manville.
It is by now a truism that our traffic accident problem is one in which sixty-mile-an-hour cars are being driven on forty-mile-an-hour roads by thirty-mile-an-hour drivers.

Attracted by the lowest fares in the history of highway and rail transportation in this country, John Q. Fablic went to work last Summer to outdo all previous travel records and did a good job of it, too, judging by all available statistics.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 10. -- To discourage unwarranted legal contests by utilities over rates fixed by public service commissions, it was suggested here today at the opening of the forty-eighth annual convention of the National Association of Railroad and Utilities Commissioners that such costs be borne by the stockholders of their utilities instead of by their customers.
AKRON, Ohio, Nov. 10 (AP). -- Bombs shattered porches of three homes and imperiled at least ten lives today as a result, Detective Gilbert Mosely said, of labor trouble among rubber workers.

The fifteenth exhibition at the Temporary Galleries of the Municipal Art Committee opens today with four groups represented. It may be said that the present show is in some ways one of the best yet arranged. It will be current through Nov. 29.

Two apartment house purchases by Charles Walzer, operator, were included in the New Jersey deals reported yesterday. A five-story building with twelve stores at 260 Gregory Avenue, corner of Broadway, Passaic, was bought for cash above a $310,000 five-year first mortgage, at 3 per cent.

The crew of the Grace liner Santa Maria, consisting of 141 men, quit their vessel on her arrival from Valparaiso yesterday and joined the strike of the rank and file group of the International Seamen's Union in Atlantic and Gulf ports.

PARIS, Nov. 10. -- Charges of furnishing arms to one side or the other in the Spanish conflict have been made many times by partisans in France without the government's taking any notice, but today two more serious accusations were made and may have to be considered by Premier Leon Blum.

FREDERICK J. PERRY, the world's foremost amateur tennis player, has at last decided to exchange glory for income. He has signed a contract whose reported terms -- a minimum guarantee of $50,000 and the possibility of a total of $100,000 from the gate receipts of a proposed tour -- indicate that professional tennis has entered the realm of big business.
TOLEDO, Spain, Nov. 10. -- Intense fighting in the battle for Madrid was raging today in the southeastern suburbs of the city as a result of unceasing counter-attacks by Leftists.

Four old automobiles coughed and Jounced down Central Park West, across Fifty-seventh Street, then south on Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon, in a "race" through traffic with old-time racing drivers at the wheels.

Margaret Sanger, leader of the birth control movement, will receive the annual Award of Honor of the Town Hall Club, it was announced yesterday. The award is voted to that member who has made the "most conspicuous contribution to the enlargement and enrichment of life."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 10 (AP). -- On the eve of Armistice Day, Manuel D. Silva, labeled a deserter from the army during the war, received formal notice tonight that he had been restored to good standing and made eligible for an honorable discharge.

Mounds of indecent books, playing cards, postcards and pamphlets having a total market value of approximately $10,000 will be burned by the Police Department tomorrow morning in a lot adjoining the department warehouse at the foot of Thirty-sixth Street, Brooklyn.

Mounds of indecent books, playing cards, postcards and pamphlets having a total market value of approximately $10,000 will be burned by the Police Department tomorrow morning in a lot adjoining the department warehouse at the foot of Thirty-sixth Street, Brooklyn.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 10. -- The conference of Prince Paul, the Chief Regent, and Vladimir Matchek, Croat leader, on Sunday failed to remove the old obstacle to agreement between them, the Constitution imposed by the late King Alexander after he began his dictatorship in 1929.
I read your editorial regarding the Forty-second Street shuttle and noted the letter from W.H.B. in today's issue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- President Roosevelt has ordered certain agencies of his administration to make independent studies of the possibility of achieving the principal goals of the outlawed National Industrial Recovery Act -- abolition of child labor, protection of the rights of workers to organize and bargain collectively, and maintenance of standard labor conditions -- through a sweeping Federal Incorporation and Licensing Law.

The twenty-first lawyer was arrested yesterday in the new Accident Fraud Bureau's investigation into ambulance-chasing and fake indemnity suits involving attorneys, their "runners," litigants, physicians and others. Thus far in the investigation more than 100 men and women have been arrested on indictments or Special Sessions "information."

More than 100 makers of accessories and parts will have their products on display when the National Automobile Show opens at Grand Central Palace this afternoon. While some of the equipment, such as lace covers for steering wheels, definitely comes under the head of "gadgets," many of the parts shown have an essential function in the safe and efficient performance of the car mechanism.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 10. -- Already an institution at some studios, the annual musical revue is to become a part of RKO Radio's program. "Radio City Revels" was announced today as the first venture of the new Jesse L. Lasky production unit, and Alex A. Aarons, former Broadway producer and associate of Sam Katz in the making of "Broadway Melody of 1936," has been engaged to assist Mr. Lasky.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 11. -- All may now be quiet on the western front, but so far as Yale is concerned the war has just begun.

The opening of the National Automobile Show at the Grand Central Palace yesterday afternoon was marked by a message of congratulation and good-will from President Roosevelt addressed to Alvan Macauley, president of the Automobile Manufacturers Association.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- A marked recovery in trade between the United States and Canada, covering the flow in both directions since the reciprocal trade agreement came into operation on Jan. 1, 1936, was reported by the State Department today on the basis of an analysis by government experts.

Public utility companies desiring to consolidate their operating units will be required to make an affirmative showing that the proposed mergers will not handicap public regulation, the Public Service Commission announced yesterday.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Nov. 11 (AP). -- Oze Simmons, University of Iowa football star, who this afternoon announced he had quit the Hawkeye football team, late tonight told The Associated Press he will report for practice tomorrow and play against Purdue Saturday. Simmons's latest

COLUMBUS, Nov. 11 (AP). -- A pledge that the National Grange would cooperate with President Roosevelt came today from L.J. Taber, master of the organization, with an assertion, however, that farmers themselves preferred to control any permanent government farm program.

October showed the lowest sooty air-pollution average for New York City in seven years and set a new low temperature record for a day in October in sixty-eight years, according to data made public yesterday by David R. Morris, meteorologist of the New York Meteorological Observatory in Central Park, maintained by the Department of Parks under the direction of the United States Weather Bureau.

BUFFALO, Nov. 11 (AP). -- The church's most difficult social service task lies in the rural field, the Rev. George W. Dawson, canon missioner for social service of the Newark diocese, told the Protestant Episcopal Synod of the New York and New Jersey province today.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Nov. 11. -- The boys were sitting around the stove in Roy Shields's gas station last night and exchanging the usual opening day post-mortems. During the hunting season the mob always hangs around Roy's place. It's the nightly headquarters of the Hot Stove League in these parts.

Two large apartment houses on Ridge Boulevard, Brooklyn, figured in deals reported yesterday. The six-story building occupying the westerly blockfront between Eighty-seventh and Eighty-eighth Streets was bought by the Herridge Realty Company from the Willmur Realty Company for cash above a $260,000 mortgage.

Hampshire House, thirty-four-story apartment hotel, which has stood unfinished and unoccupied at 150 Central Park South for more than five years, may be completed soon and operated by the trustees of Series C-2, New York Title and Mortgage Company, for the benefit of the 7,500 investors in that mortgage certificate issue.

" Theodora Goes Wild," a Columbia production starring Irene Dunne and directed by Richard Boleslawsky, replaces "As You Like It" at the Music Hall this morning. Miss Dunne is assisted in the romantic comedy role by Melvyn Douglas, Thomas Mitchell, Rosalind Keith and Spring Byington.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- Major legislation to integrate the power program of the government and prevent possible conflict in various developments was discussed today by President Roosevelt in conference with Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

GROTON, Mass., Nov. 11. -- Thrills a plenty were packed into the Groton-St. Mark's School football game on the former's field today as the visitors, through a pair of 13-point clusters, obtained a 26-20 victory in the forty-eighth edition of this old and colorful gridiron classic.

LONDON, Nov. 11. -- A bill proposing modification of English divorce laws -- one of several recent attempts to widen the present narrow grounds for the dissolution of marriages -- was presented to Parliament by an independent group of members today.

" Can you spare a few pennies to help fight the war against cancer?" Quietly a little silvery-haired woman gave voice to these words. Through the lower level of Grand Central Terminal the walls re-echoed her plea. We have a few pennies -- we have more than a few pennies; but we're in a hurry.

The Seas Shipping Company, operator of the Robin Line, announced yesterday that it had increased its rates on general cargoes 100 per cent with a few exceptions and would extend through December its current rates on automobiles.

NANKING, China, Thursday, Nov. 12. -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek is prepared to go the limit in defending Suiyuan, which is the gateway to China's vast Northwest, against the Mongol and Manchukuo armies "equipped and manipulated by Japanese."

Those who wonder why the cost of funerals is so high need only read the latest bulletin from the State Department of Health to find the principal cause. The overhead is too high. The funeral industry is overcrowded. The Health Department Survey shows that last year there was a funeral establishment for every 4,154 persons in the State.
While non-striking union seamen continued to man ships sailing from New York yesterday, the strikers began talk of negotiations for a settlement.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 11. -- The general principle on which the Interstate Commerce Commission is undertaking the reorganization of forty-four railroads placed under its jurisdiction by Congress was laid down here today by Charles D. Mahaffie, chairman of the commission.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- The third National Conference on Labor Legislation, called by Secretary Perkins, today declared itself in favor of Federal and State minimum wage laws and endorsed "the proposal of an amendment to the Constitution to permit without question effective State and Federal minimum wage legislation."

The motor cars now on exhibition at Grand Central Palace represent the greatest values ever offered by the industry, in the opinion of C.W. Nash, chairman of the board of Nash Motors Company, who arrived in New York yesterday to attend his twenty-seventh New York automobile show.

While Spanish Rebels bombarded, Madrid yesterday afternoon, 5,000 children from all parts of New York City took part in a mass peace demonstration and parade through the streets of the Spanish section in lower Harlem.

Nearly 400 persons, including social workers from various welfare organizations, attended a house-warming and tea yesterday to mark the opening of the new quarters of the Foster Home Bureau at 329 East Sixty-second Street.

Each year the American Academy of Arts and Letters holds a large exhibition devoted to the work of one of its artist members. This time tribute is paid to Anna Hyatt Huntington, famous American sculptor, more than 170 of whose figures, large and small, have been assembled in the exhibition room of the American Academy of Arts and Letters, on Broadway between 155th and 156th Streets.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 11. -Public opinion can and will abolish war when it gives the order, Mrs. Carrie Chapman Cart, veteran peace advocate, told 400 men and women at an Armistice Day program of the Woman's Club of Upper Montclair at the clubhouse here tonight.

Dictators under fascism, nazism and communism were denounced at an Armistice Day service yesterday as "ruthless destroyers" of the ideals of democracy gained from the World War, and their actions assailed as resulting in preparations for another war.

An appeal for a strong national defense as the best safeguard of peace was the keynote of Armistice Day speakers yesterday at ceremonies in Borough Hall, Brooklyn, where nearly 1,000 persons watched more than 5,000 veterans, members of the women's auxiliary, Boy Scouts and regular military units march in the annual parade of the Kings County American Legion.

Anticipating a growing market for sheets, tin plate and other light-weight finished steel, the Bethlehem Steel Corporation will spend an additional $35,000,000 on the construction of new finishing plants by the end of 1937, it was announced yesterday by Eugene G. Grace, president.

PEARL RIVER, La., Nov. 11 (AP). -- A 2-day-old baby boy left in a WPA worker's yard in legendary fashion by a big black dog, was carried to New Orleans late today over the protests of Mrs. Louis E. Crawford, who found the infant.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- With volume of trading increasing and prices of securities on the Exchange rising, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal Reserve Board are maintaining a close watch on activities in the post-election market to determine whether developments which may arise call for any action.

DES MOINES, Nov. 11. -- Lieut. Gov. Nels Kraschel of Harlan will be the next Governor of Iowa, a final check-up of election returns from ninety-eight of the State's ninety-nine counties revealed today.

Although Charles Nordhoff's and James Norman Hall's "The Bounty Trilogy" will not be published until Dec. 1, 35,000 copies have been printed, Little, Brown report. The publishers say a sixth printing of Timothy Fuller's mystery story, "Harvard Has a Homicide," has been ordered and that "Drums Along the Mohawk," by Walter D. Edmonds, is now passing the 100,000 mark in sales.

A complete and fully finished motor car cut in two longitudinally to reveal every element of its construction was among the attractions which held the attention of a capacity crowd yesterday at the opening of the General Motors free show at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Former Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Proskauer, speaking last night at Armistice Day exercises of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States, declared that the principal reliance of the anti-Semite is the statement that the Jews are Communists.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 11 (AP). -- H.N. Arnstein, vice president and counsel of Consolidated Retail Stores, Inc., announced today that the directors had voted to withdraw a plan for recapitalizing the company's preferred stock to eliminate arrears of dividends and existing defaults in stock retirements.

LONDON, Nov. 11. -- In the House of Commons today Walter Runciman said that provision would be made for decrease or disappearance of the shipping subsidy if the average level of freight rates approached or surpassed the level of 1929.

Ed Danowski of the New York Giants, leading forward passer of the National Football League last year, again went to first place for his specialty when he passed Ed Matesic of the Pittsburgh Pirates in the ninth week of play. The former Fordham player has completed 41 of 81 tosses for a mark of 50.6 per cent, while Matesic has made good just half of his 108 passes.

To honor the fortieth anniversary of America's oldest automobile manufacturer, the Oldsmobile Company, more than 1,200 guests gathered for dinner last night in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Commodore. Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of General Motors Corporation, of which Oldsmobile is a subsidiary, was the principal speaker.

Establishment of a journalism foundation in the Graduate School of Journalism of Columbia University that would seek to advance "by study, interpretation and action" the public services of the newspaper, the forum and the radio was recommended by Dean Carl W. Ackerman of the School of Journalism in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, made public yesterday.

TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 11 (AP). -- American Federation of Labor leaders talked today of expelling the John L. Lewis rebel unions from the federation. Only a few of those here for the federation's annual convention still talked of peace.
SCRANTON, Pa., Nov. 11 (AP). -- A discussion of the cause of world peace by the Board of Bishops of the Methodist Episcopal Church formally began today the "Million Unit Fellowship" movement.

ARLINGTON, Texas, Nov. 11 (AP). -- Bachelor Dinner crossed the wire a length and a half ahead of a fast-closing field this afternoon to win the Armistice Day Handicap, a $2,500-added-race, before one of the largest crowds of the Fall meeting.

Charles Frederick Smith, who as a boy over on Thirty-eighth Street, between Ninth and Tenth Avenues, used to do his homework with a kerosene lamp at his side and who started his career as a messenger boy, rounded out yesterday fifty years of continuous work for the same company, the New York Central System.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 11. -- The ocean-racing schooner Vamarie was formally presented to the regiment of midshipmen at the Naval Academy this afternoon by Mr. and Mrs. Vladim S. Makaroff of Oyster Bay, L.I., at a special dress parade.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Nov. 11. -- C.V. Whitney's Roustabout upheld the public's confidence today by coming from away back in a seven-horse field to win the $7,500 added Rhode Island Handicap, last rich purse on New England's six-months' turf program, at Narragansett Park.

Going to the fore following the opening kick-off and increasing its lead steadily as the game wore on, the Admiral Farragut Naval Academy eleven conquered the New York Military Academy, 26 -- 7, in the third engagement of their "Little Army-Navy" series at the Polo Grounds yesterday.
ALBANY, Nov. 11. -- Elmer F. Andrews, Stale Industrial Commissioner, said tonight that factory employment and payrolls in New York State were at their highest levels for six years.

OTTAWA, Nov. 11 (Canadian Press). -- Ottawa paid its annual tribute to Canada's 60,000 World War dead at a service around the temporary cenotaph on Parliament Hill today in the presence of Lord Tweedsmuir, the Governor General; Prime Minster Mackenzie King and others.

PARIS, Nov. 11 -- War debts, trade relations and immigration were among the subjects discussed in a question and answer interview that William C. Bullitt, United States Ambassador, accorded to the Agence Economique et Financiere as a guide to the policies to be expected in Franco-American dealings during President Roosevelt's second term.

On the basis of what is described as an "unofficial check-up," the Department of Commerce estimates that nine million people are still unemployed. This is six million less than a similar estimate for March, 1933. But both figures are necessarily guesswork. There has been no real count of the unemployed, and will not be, until the Census Bureau is authorized to make such a survey and given whatever funds it needs for the purpose.

MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 11. -- Approximately 55,000 acres of British-owned cotton lands in the State of Coahuila have been taken over by the government and distributed among agrarian and other labor elements, according to telegraphic advices reaching here.

LOWELL, Mass., Nov. 11. -- The Lowell Textile eleven made a gallant but unsuccessful attempt to win its first football game of the season before 6,500 spectators today, losing to Brooklyn College, 7 to 6.

The company of French players, known as the French Theatre of New York, encouraged by the appeal made by their brief sojourn at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel Theatre a year ago, opened a second season there last evening with a schedule fixing Wednesday, Thursday, Friday evenings and Saturday afternoons for performances until March 6.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 (AP). -- The Professional Golfers Association will continue to pay the railroad fares of the qualifiers for its championship tournament to and from the battle scene instead of turning the money, amounting to between $3,000 and $4,000, into the prize fund.

Testifying before the Securities and Exchange Commission, ROBERT LEHMAN, president of the Lehman Corporation, added his voice to those of other reputable investment trust executives in not merely agreeing to but urging a greater degree of governmental control over these organizations.

JERICHO, L.I., Nov. 11. -- Miss June Hanes's imported chestnut gelding Molyneux today captured the championship ribbon in the hunter trials of the Meadow Brook Hounds, held over the estates of Daniel Underhill and Mrs. Middleton S. Burrill before a crowd of several hundred members of the Meadow Brook Hounds and Long Island society.

First mortgage Series A 3 1/4 per cent bonds of the New England Power Company of a principal amount of $10,067,000 will be placed on the market today by a group headed by Lehman Brothers and including Hallgarten Co., Graham Parsons Co., Arthur Perry Co., Inc.; E.H. Rollins Sons, Inc.; Dick Merle-Smith, Burr Gannett Co., G.M.-P. Murphy Co., Newton Abbe Co. and Schoellkopf, Hutton Pomeroy, Inc.
BELLEVILLE, N.J., Nov. 11. -- Five thousand dollars spent in "putting the town's best foot foremost" has convinced Mayor William H. Williams that it pays to advertise Belleville.

Frequent rise of the S.R.O. sign and nerve-tingling jump-offs in international military events featured the fifty-first National Horse Show which came to a close at Madison Square Garden Tuesday night. More than 115,000 spectators are estimated to have attended the exhibition.

Higher prices for semi-finished and finished steel and pig iron are forecast by the magazine Iron Age in its weekly summary issues yesterday. These advances, the publication says, are indicated as a sequence to the advances in steel wages, which will add upward of $60,000,000 annually to the steel industry's payroll.
VALENCIA, Spain, Nov. 11 (AP). -- President Manuel Azana of Spain is expected to arrive here tomorrow to summon Parliament into session.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 11 (AP). -- Dr. Richard E. Shope of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research told the Yale Medical Society tonight that recent experiments had convinced him that influenza apparently is produced by the concerted activity of two agents -- a bacterium and a filtrable virus.

Harry Fisher, substitute quarterback, tossed a 15-yard forward pass over the goal line into the outstretched arms of Bill Bassell to give James Madison High a 17-13 victory over Manual Training's eleven before 3,500 persons at Lincoln Field yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 11 (AP). -- The peoples of the far-flung British Empire, led by their 42-year-old King, paid tribute today to their World War dead.

LONDON, Nov. 11. -- Official explanations today took most of the mystery from the statement by Sir Samuel Hoare, First Lord of the Admiralty, in the House of Commons yesterday that Great Britain had "no such commitments" as she had in 1914.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Nov. 11. -- Services were held here today for Mgr. John J. Curran, priest and mediator. By proclamation of Mayor Charles N. Loveland the day was set aside as a holiday. Not since the funeral of Mayor Daniel L. Hart has Wilkes-Barre witnessed a demonstration as stirring as the one for Mgr. Curran.

Plans for the annual Thanksgiving parade for children were announced yesterday by R.H. Macy Co. This year the major characters will be those of the older juvenile fables rather than the modern favorites, such as Mickey Mouse and the Big Bad Wolf, which have been used in recent years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- Exports of industrial machinery from the United States in September were valued at $13,083,350, compared to $12,171,532 in the preceding month and $9,889,000 in the corresponding month last year, the Department of Commerce reported today.

A decision to defer Spring openings to "the latest possible date conistent with retailers' requirements'' was reached yesterday afternoon at a meeting of the steering committee of the Medium Price Coat Associates at the Garment Center Capitol.

Excellent scores again were returned by Harry Thoens at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. The shoot was a special one for Armistice Day and brought eighteen gunners to the firing line. Thoens, leader last Sunday, started his good work by taking the high-over-all cup with 99 out of a possible 100 targets.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 11. -- On the recommendation of their school headmasters, fourteen graduates of preparatory schools in New England have been chosen for prize scholarships totaling $3,150 for their freshman year at Harvard College, the dean's office announced today.
OCEAN CITY, N.J., Nov. 11. -- An invention which apparently succeeded in doing its work and then failed, nearly cost the life of its creator last night, police revealed today.

Miss Helen Hull Jacobs of Palo Alto, Calif., who was recently dethroned as national tennis champion by Miss Alice Marble after having held the title four successive years, sailed yesterday for England on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 11. -- Indications are that Paramount may cancel the $5,000,000 suit against Samuel Goldwyn involving the services of Gary Cooper. There are reports that negotiations are under way by which Cooper will make an additional Paramount film as a conciliatory gesture and the action, colossal even for Hollywood, will be dropped.

More than 2,000 persons attended yesterday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral a solemn high mass in memory of the members of the United States armed forces who died during the war. It was the second memorial service under the auspices of the Catholic War Veterans.

NANKING, China, Nov. 11 (AP). -- Chinese military authorities viewed with grave concern tonight the United States policy, enunciated by President Roosevelt, of restricting exports of American military airplanes until government requirements are fulfilled.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor and a member of the United Mine Workers of America, was cited today to appear before the miners' executive board on Nov. 18 to answer complaints that he had taken part in a "conspiracy" to suspend his own union from the A. F. of L.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- Prices of hogs weighing 200 pounds or more advanced 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight today as the result of a broad demand. Lighter weights sold slowly, with many loads carrying late bids of 5 to 10 cents under yesterday's level.
Apartment, dwelling and business properties were included in the Manhattan realty turnover reported yesterday.

Gale Gilmore, 36 years old, of 1,418 Castleton Avenue, Port Richmond, S.I., was brought from Baltimore to police headquarters in Tottenville, S.I., last night to face an indictment for the murder of William Moritz, 54, owner of the fishing sloop Georgianna.

The Columbia University Club team, defending Class A squash tennis champion in the Metropolitan League, retained the lead by toppling the Yale Club last night, 3 -- 2, for its fourth triumph in as many starts. The New York A.C., also undefeated, moved out of a second-place tie with the Harvard Club by defeating the latter, 4 -- 1, on the Crimson courts.

Indications of an increased response this year to the annual Red Cross appeal were reported yesterday as the twentieth annual roll-call of the New York Chapter got under way. Mrs. David Challinor, roll-call director, reported to Owen D. Young, general chairman, that several divisions showed a marked increase of enrollments as compared to the opening days of recent roll-call drives.

In the face of a threatened strike by 11,000 Emergency Relief Bureau employes if 3,000 investigators are compelled to take competitive civil service examinations to hold their positions, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday that the examinations would be held as scheduled by the Municipal Civil Service Commission.

VIENNA, Nov. 11. -- The conference of the signatories of the Rome protocols started today after a church service honoring King Victor Emmanuel's birthday. The service was attended by Chancellor Schuschnigg and other members of the Austrian Government, Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister, and Koloman de Kanya, Hungarian Foreign Minister.

Dorothy Minty, young California violinist, made her first appearance in recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. She disclosed accomplishments rare in a debutante -- poise, temperament and musicianship, as well as a sound technical equipment, a firm base for the other qualities.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 11. -- St. George's made sixteen first downs to Middlesex's six in the thirty-second game of the series between these traditional opponents today, but it was held to a 6-6 draw. On seven occasions Middlesex checked St. George's inside the 20-yard line.

PORTLAND, England, Nov. 11 (AP). -- King Edward will make an informal call on the navy tomorrow. The customary naval guard of honor at the train when the King arrives at Portland will be replaced by a guard of ex-service men.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 11. -- Pursuing burglars in a nightmare, Phil F. Cope of the University of Southern California, co-holder of the world's record for the high hurdles, leaped through his bedroom window this morning, severely cutting himself.

Postmaster General James A. Farley, sailing for Europe yesterday, predicted that the coming Christmas season would be the most prosperous in the country's history and that the nation was on the verge of an unprecedented business revival.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11. -- The American family in the business class is of the Puritan type, however faint the resemblance may seem to be at times, Joseph K. Folsom, Professor of Sociology at Vassar College, declared today at the biennial conference of the National Council for Parent Education.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 (AP). -- Representative Samuel B. Pettengill of Indiana told oil men today that "business men generally have lost the confidence of their own workers" and that provision must be made for "human obsolescence."
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 11 (AP). -- Gridiron raiders from Texas A. and M., who did everything with a football but balance it on their ears, routed the University of San Francisco, 38 to 14, today.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 11. -- A new process for refining some of the oils used as motor fuel to remove much of the gum which clogs motors was announced today by Dr. W.A. Patrick of Johns Hopkins University before the American Institute of Chemical Engineers.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 11 (AP). -- The derailment of a Big Four passenger train fifteen miles southeast of here today, killed a baggage-man and an express agency employe and injured almost a score of other persons.

Visiting buyers recorded in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a substantial increase over the preceding week and the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES. The arrivals published in the last week numbered 1,006, against 703 in the previous week and 670 in the same period last year.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Nov. 11. -- Miss Virginia Morgan Pennoyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul G. Pennoyer of Locust Valley and New York, and Miss Jane N. Nichols, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Nichols of Cold Spring Harbor and New York, will be introduced to society formally at a party to be given by their grandfather, J.P. Morgan, during the Christmas holidays, it was learned here today.

An Armistice Day crowd so dense that it was almost impossible to get close to the shining cars and accessory exhibits attended the Ford Motor Company's show at the Hotel Astor yesterday. In the first four horn's of the opening day 15,884 persons entered the grand ballroom and its adjoining salons where Ford V-8, Lincoln Zephyr and Lincoln cars are on display.

The Commercial National Bank and Trust Company has been appointed registrar here for common stock of the Black Decker Manufacturing Company. It also has been appointed successor trustee for Cinema Building Corporation first mortgage sinking fund 6 per cent gold bonds due on Aug. 1, 1945, and trustee for $7,000,000 of Savoy-Plaza, Inc., general mortgage twenty-year sinking fund income bonds, due on Oct. 1, 1956.

GENEVA, Nov. 11. -- There was much agitation today in International Labor Organization quarters over whether the I.L.O., which opens its seventy-seventh session tomorrow, should elect a Spanish Government delegate as president for the coming year in accordance with the rotation schedule arranged for this office last year.

LONDON, Nov. 11. -- William Forrest, special correspondent of The Daily Express, who was "missing" from Madrid about the time the Largo Caballero government hurriedly left the capital, telephoned an uncensored dispatch tonight that it was the activities of the Insurgents' "Fifth column" -- the enemy within the gates -- that precipitated the Ministers' flight to Valencia.

Settlement of the labor troubles that caused the tear-gas bombings of Times Square motion picture theatres in the last two weeks was announced yesterday by the Board of Survey appointed by Mayor La Guardia last Saturday to end the trouble.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 11. -- Brooklyn, owned by E.R. Bradley of Kentucky, won one of Maryland's most famous stakes for juveniles when he was first by a length today in the $10,870 Walden Handicap after one of the closest battles the event ever has seen.

Half a dozen Negroes stood on a street corner in Harlem yesterday and plotted a hold-up. Near them a policeman, off duty and in plain clothes, listened somewhat incredulously. As they started away he followed them.
VIENNA, Nov. 11. -- Austria and Hungary, in both of which Italy exercises a strong influence, tacitly recognized tonight the Italian conquest of Ethiopia.

Dr. Allan Roy Dafoe, who brought the Dionne quintuplets into the world, arrived here last night for a few days' rest and relaxation after a flight from Chicago, where he had a brush with a process server intent upon serving him with papers in a $1,000,000 suit for breach of contract.

BERLIN, Nov. 11. -- The Boerse weakened slightly today on a small turnover. The opening of the market looked rather strong, with trading heavier than yesterday's and quotations rising. Stagnation and falling quotations, however, set in soon.
Ten years ago, Vic Hanson was the toast of Syracuse, an all-America end and the greatest all-round athlete to wear the Orange.

MIDDLEBURG, Va., Nov. 11. -- Welbourne Jake, 6-year-old gelding owned by the Montpelier Stables, captured the R. Penn Smith Jr. Challenge Plate, feature of the opening program at the Middleburg Hunts meet at Glenwood today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP). -- Farm families will have more cash to spend "on living costs next year," according to an Agriculture Department estimate today that their gross cash income from this year's operations will reach $7,850,000,000.

Preparing for their forthcoming battle with the Green Bay Packers, the Brooklyn Dodgers engaged the Stapleton Buffaloes, an independent eleven, in an exhibition game at Ebbets Field yesterday, with the heavier and more experienced Dodgers winning, 14 to 7. Fewer than 5,000 witnessed the encounter.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 11. -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals laid down broad principles today governing the conduct of directors and stockholders of banks, giving two important decisions in the cases of closed banks in Louisville, Ky., and Detroit, Mich.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- The New York Unemployment Insurance Law was attacked in the Supreme Court today as arguments began on three demands to test the constitutionality of the State's social security program.

Television will span the Atlantic soon, Guglielmo Marconi, inventor of wireless, predicted in a record-breaking four-way short-wave broadcast which linked his yacht in the Mediterranean with David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation, in New York and a group of foreign broadcasting executives in two American Airlines cabin planes flying between Niagara Falls and Washington, D.C., yesterday afternoon.

With the possibility more apparent that Sid Luckman, star back, will be unable to start against Syracuse on Saturday, Columbia yesterday started to prime Howard Westphal for a halfback role at Baker Field.

The long-awaited test of the constitutionality of the Public Utility Act of 1935, regarded in the utility industry as comparable in importance to the Schechter case that destroyed the NRA, was begun yesterday in a full court room before Federal Judge Julian W. Mack.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 11. -- The Long Island Field Hockey Association first eleven showed the same characteristics as other local teams against foreign competition, namely a strong defense and a weak offense, as it went down to a 7-0 defeat at the hands of the touring South African players on the Adelphi College field today.

The American Legion can perform no higher service than to consider means of keeping America out of war, William Regan, New Jersey commander of the American Legion, declared yesterday at a ceremony attending the presentation of a bronze tablet memorializing the old Fourth Regiment of the New Jersey National Guard.

G. Howard Ferguson, who retired this year as Canadian High Commissioner in London, appealed yesterday for an extension of the Monroe Doctrine to include the British Empire as a means of furthering the cause of world security and peace.

LONDON, Nov. 11. -- Conditions were quiet today on the London Stock Exchange with prices sagging in most groups. Closing of the Wall Street and Paris markets because of Armistice Day helped to restrict business here.

Labeled by Mayor La Guardia as "the meanest kind of a fraud," Robert Brausdorf, a Home Relief Bureau investigator, was locked up in the Gates Avenue police station in Brooklyn last night on a charge of having extorted $5 from Mrs. Enrica Speciale of 268 Sumpter Street, Brooklyn, one of his relief clients.

Joe Gould, manager of James J. Braddock, the heavyweight champion, said last night he had tentatively accepted an offer for Braddock to meet Joe Louis, Detroit's Brown Bomber, in Atlantic City Feb. 22 in a twelve-round no-decision bout.

Two exhausted and hysterical men who had watched two companions drown a half-mile from shore, were found clinging to an overturned rowboat last evening in Eastchester Bay off the Bronx by Henry Wenderoth, commodore of the Morrisania Yacht Club.

Speaking as a veteran of the World War at the Eternal Light in Madison Square yesterday morning, Mayor La Guardia held that maintenance of peace was the responsibility of every citizen and pleaded for support of the government's policy of neutrality.

GETTING into legal tangles must be one way of sharpening skates. Look where the star-spangled Americans are in the hockey standings! They are topping the International Group. It might be for years, but it couldn't be forever, and the haunting suspicion in this corner is that it may be only pro tem.
The first week of THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair in Rockefeller Center attracted 35,094 visitors, attendance figures compiled last night showed.

Whether a detective drove the automobile which struck a middle-aged woman on Tuesday evening, as the detective's own report says, will be determined by a department investigation, Police Commissioner Valentine declared yesterday.

Eighteen years from the day when the thunder of guns ceased along the Western Front, solemn tributes to the fallen were paid yesterday in Washington, London, Paris and throughout the lands of which they are the capitals.

Noted war fliers and leaders in aviation were among the 175 persons at an armistice celebration held in the Ritz-Carlton Hotel last night under the auspices of Aviators Post 743, American Legion, of which Colonel Harold E. Hartney, leader of the First Pursuit Group in France, is commander.

Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of New York University, announced yesterday the appointment of Professor A. Anton Friedrich as director of the division of unified studies in the university's Washington Square College. Professor Friedrich succeeds Harlan Logan, who recently obtained leave of absence to become editor of Scribner's Magazine.

With the question of their ownership settled to the satisfaction of all concerned, the New York Americans will open the local season of the National Hockey League at Madison Square Garden tonight with the Chicago Black Hawks as their opponents.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 11 (AP). -- Pennsylvania Military College upset La Salle in an indoor football game tonight, 6 to 2, before 8,000 spectators in Atlantic City's Convention Hall.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 11. -- Charles F. Zimmerman, president of the First National Bank of Huntingdon, Pa., spoke in an address before the Adams County Bankers Association here tonight against legislation which, he said, Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, was understood to be planning for the next Congress.

A group of Frenchmen stood on the unprepossessing site of our 1939 World's Fair and registered admiration and enthusiasm. The visitors were in the same line of business. Among them is the chief architect of next year's big fair in Paris. Arrangements have presumably been made with HITLER not to destroy the French capital from the air until the show is over.

PARIS, Nov. 11 (AP). -- Yvon Delbos, France's Foreign Minister, proclaimed today a policy of armed strength -- "because the weak are no longer respected" -- as the nation observed the eighteenth anniversary of the end of the World War.

MADRID, Nov. 11 (Censored.) . -- Re-enforced government fighters today hurled back fresh assaults by Rebel forces besieging this capital, although the city again suffered damage from intense artillery fire.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 11. -- Although Army's casualties have not increased in the last two days of practice, Coach Gar Davidson took no chances and continued the dummy scrimmage routine today against the B squad. Having only two teams to use against Notre Dame's large squad Saturday, the Army coach kept them going at full speed.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 11. -- Sailing with a fine southwest breeze in the afternoon, Corny Shields and Sam Wetherill topped the other skippers in the dinghy racing at the Larchmont Yacht Club today.

BREMEN, Germany, Nov. 11. -- The North German Lloyd announced today the retirement, at the age of 62 years and after forty-seven years of seafaring, of Leopold Ziegenbein, one of the best known captains on the North Atlantic, commander of the liner Bremen and commodore of the company's fleet.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Nov. 12. -- Dispatches from Kweihua, capital of Suiyuan Province, report that the combined Mongol-Manchukuoan invaders, 30,000 strong, yesterday attacked the Suiyuan defense lines at several points in the Pailingmiao area but were easily repulsed after several engagements.

American Labor party members from the Third Assembly District conducted an outdoor Armistice Day meeting, dedicated to the cause of lasting peace, in Chelsea Park, Twenty-seventh Street and Ninth Avenue, yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- Cotton cloth totaling 7,098,000 square yards valued at $762,000 was imported by this country from all sources in September, according to a report today by the Department of Commerce. The month's imports brought total foreign purchases by the United States during the first nine months to 81,372,000 square yards valued at $7,502,000.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 11. -- Army's plebe eleven overwhelmed the Dean Academy team by a 33-to-0 score before a large holiday crowd on Howze Field today.

While the chief problem of trailer manufacturers at the present time is a production one, current lack of knowledge about their market must be overcome before advertising campaigns can be inaugurated on a sound basis, according to opinions expressed yesterday by representatives at the automobile show.

Arturo Godoy fought a draw with Al Ettore in the main bout of ten rounds at the New York Hippodrome last night. Godoy, who recently came from Chile, and his blond rival from Philadelphia waged a savage, rough battle that, though dull in spots, proved sufficiently entertaining to the crowd of 4,500 onlookers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- With the Presidential salute from the guns of Fort Myer reverberating over radio channels to millions of listeners, President Roosevelt bared his head for two minutes of silence in front of the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier at 11 o'clock this morning.

A drastic neutrality and peace program which is to be submitted to Congress this Winter was outlined by Senator Gerald P. Nye, chairman of the Senate Munitions Committee, at an Armistice Day mass meeting held last night in Madison Square Garden under the auspices of the Emergency Peace Campaign and more than seventy labor unions.

BOSTON, Nov. 11 (AP). -- The Cleveland Rams whirled into first place in the American Professional Football League today by defeating the Boston Shamrocks, 34 to 26, in one of the wildest pro games Boston fans have ever seen.

The following film programs, which will be shown over the week-end, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local private and public elementary and high schools:

President ROOSEVELT plans to be away from Washington for about a month, beginning next week. His trip to Rio de Janeiro and to Buenos Aires may be regarded partly as a vacation which is his due, though he would doubtless put first the aim of lending his official prestige to the meetings of the coming Pan-American Congress in the Argentine.

Retail prices in October advanced for the fourth consecutive month, according to the Fairchild Publications index. The index on Nov. 1 at 90 (January, 1931=100) is the highest figure since Aug. 1, 1931. Prices during the month advanced eight-tenths of 1 per cent and also showed an increase of 2.7 per cent above the corresponding period a month ago.
Is there really nothing we can do in the face of the horror in Spain -- we who are the only power which could safely move to help with some form of friendly intervention on behalf of humanity?

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- "Piracy of the news" was discussed before the Supreme Court today when the justices heard arguments in the suit of The Associated Press to enjoin radio station KVOS of Bellingham, Wash., from broadcasting news from the association's member newspapers before its distribution to the public.
GENEVA, Nov. 11. -- The world has at least 1,700,000 more men permanently under arms this Armistice Day than it had in 1913, the League of Nations announced today.

To allay the fears of those who have heard -- or believe -- that the President is going to Buenos Aires with some grandiose peace plan that might involve the United States in a foolish adventure, it may be useful to call attention to some general ideas about international relations which prevail in the government at Washington.

A city-wide campaign to sell debentures amounting to $27,928,500 to finance construction of the World's Fair of 1939 will be started in a few weeks, Harvey D. Gibson, chairman of the fair's corporation finance committee and president of the Manufacturers Trust Company, announced yesterday.
MADRID, Thursday, Nov. 12. -- An Insurgent force launched an attack on Madrid from Los Franceses Bridge toward University City, on the northwestern outskirts of the capital, late last night.

Miss Ruth V. Twombly and Wilton Lloyd-Smith will head the women's and men's campaign groups in the special fund-raising committee of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, it was announced yesterday by Barklie Henry, president of the association.

The International Nickel Company, Ltd., reported yesterday for the three months ended on Sept. 30 a consolidated net income of $9,572,105 after charges, taxes and reserves for depreciation and depletion, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 62 cents a share on the 14,584,025 common shares outstanding.

Frank Neborsky, 16 years old, won the title of "Best Poultry Boy of the Year," it was announced yesterday at the Poultry Industries Exposition, which will continue through Saturday at the Port Authority Building, Fifteenth Street and Eighth Avenue.

A Chicago dog, Mr. and Mrs. J.C. Siebert's Honorable Mister Lu Tang, annexed the best-in-show award yesterday at the annual specialty exhibition staged by the Chow Chow Club under American Kennel Club rules on the roof garden of the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Herbert Patrick Lee, 37 years old, a reporter for The Sun, was struck by a freight train in the Degnon Terminal, Forty-seventh Avenue and Thirtieth Street, Long Island City, early yesterday. He died a few hours later at St. John's Hospital, Long Island City.

Reporting the largest dollar volume for any month this year, twenty-five chain store systems had total sales in October of $281,638,034, an increase of 19 per cent over the same month last year, according to the monthly compilation issued yesterday by Childs, Jeffries Thorndike, Inc., and Hammons Co.

Nearly eleven tons of South Sea coral and specimens of twenty-six different species of South Pacific marine life, including several octopi, have been brought back to this country by an expedition of the American Museum of Natural History to the South Sea Islands, it was announced yesterday.

State Trooper William A. Turnbull of the New Jersey State police, formerly a United States marine, was kidnapped and carried fifty miles from Somerville, N.J., to Freemansburg, Pa., by two men and a woman he had stopped for speeding early yesterday afternoon.

Because a good neighbor followed the precept, "Love thy neighbor," things are looking brighter for the Terano family of 1,555 West Seventh Street, Brooklyn, it was reported yesterday by the Municipal Committee for the Relief of Home Owners, 149 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- National and State legislative committees will be set up shortly by Labor's Non-Partisan League, it was announced today by Major George L. Berry, John L. Lewis and Sidney Hillman, members of the league's governing board.

Nathan Lapayover of 1,348 Findlay Avenue, the Bronx, and Stanley Layman of 159 West Ninety-fifth Street, were arraigned before Magistrate Frank Oliver in Night Court last night, charged with attempted extortion, conspiracy to obstruct justice, and coercion and suppression of evidence in an attempt to intimidate one of the witnesses in the restaurant and cafeteria rackets investigation conducted by Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey, which resulted recently in forty-eight indictments.

Evander Childs High's powerful football machine, which had crushed all opposition by large scores this season, had its running attack completely smothered by De Witt Clinton in a struggle between the Bronx rivals yesterday.

Time, Inc., publisher of Time and Fortune magazines, has leased the second and third floors in a building being constructed for the March of Time motion picture and radio organizations in 371-73 Lexington Avenue, and also a floor in an adjoining building at 369 Lexington Avenue, in all about 10,000 square feet.

With the assistance of Charles D. Brown, who is the comic menace with the protruding jaw, Tom McKnight and Doty Hobart have written a comedy about bridge, "Double Dummy," which was put on at the Golden last evening. Since Mr. Brown is the head man in a topsy-turvy anecdote, you can be certain that it is a low comedy, liberally cluttered with gags.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 11 (AP). -- Dr. G.F. Warren, Cornell University professor and former monetary adviser to President Roosevelt, told delegates to the annual meeting of the New York State Farm Bureau Federation today that the outlook for farmers in the next few years was for "better returns."

Yesterday's TIMES relayed a snatch of conversation from the Balkans, a region where too many interesting conversations go unreported. "Can you keep a secret? "VLADIMIR MATCHEK of Zagreb asked a reporter pressing to know what occurred at a meeting between the Croat leader and Prince PAUL, chief Regent of Yugoslavia.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11. -- Three masked bandits bound a jewelry store proprietor and his two employes on the fourth floor of a central city office building today, stripped the two-room suite of jewelry and precious stones valued at $50,000 by the police and escaped while an Armistice Day parade passed nearby and crowds filled the streets.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- The Federal Reserve Board announced today that department store sales had increased from September to October by more than the usual seasonal amount, which was regarded as a further indication of improved business conditions.

A letter signed "W.H.B." appeared in THE TIMES relative to the shuttle service operated through Forty-second Street as a connecting link between the Broadway-Seventh Avenue line and the Lexington-Fourth Avenue line of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, and declaring that through service could be substituted for the shuttles.

Having lately sped the three men and their horse, from Forty-eighth Street's Playhouse, Mr. Brady this evening will put one of his own shows there. Call it "Matrimony Pfd.," which has been adapted by Grace George and James Forbes from the French of Louis Verneuil, and in the company are Miss George, A.E. Matthews, Rex O'Malley, Sylvia Field, Jose Ruben, Rosemary Ames, Victor Morley, A.J. Herbert and May Marshall.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 11 (AP). -- One unit withdrew today from the recently organized seventeen-mill company-sponsored District Labor Council of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, while the industry's leaders pondered the possible significance of President Roosevelt's remarks about synchronized wage-cost of living plans.

Although Jascha Heifetz's recital at the Town Hall inaugurated the seventh annual endowment series of that institution, the program chosen by the violinist for the occasion was chary of display pieces, such being relegated to the ultimate portion of the second half of the list.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Segregation of investment-trust companies from investment bankers might force the liquidation of some of the best-managed investment trusts in the United States, Raymond D. McGrath of Lazard Freres, who is a director and the secretary of General American Investors, Inc., said today to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 12. -- Criticism of the United States Supreme Court for the stand that it has taken on the valuation of public utilities was voiced today by Clyde L. Seavey, a member of the Federal Power Commission, at the convention of the National Association of Railroad and Utilities Commissioners, meeting in the Marlborough-Blenheim.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12. -- Grain markets rallied sharply today following an easy opening. Closing trades on the Board of Trade were about the top, with wheat showing net gains of 3/4 to 1 cent a bushel, while corn was 3/8 to 3/4 cent higher. Oats were unchanged to 1/4 cent higher.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- The Spanish Rebel cruiser Almirante Cervera captured the Russian freighter Sojusbod Nikov in the Mediterranean yesterday and escorted her to Ceuta in Spanish Morocco, where she was interned, according to reports from responsible sources received here today.

MOSCOW, Nov. 12. -- With the arrest of a group of foreigners, principally Germans, for alleged activities against the Soviet Government, the Rev. A. Streck, only remaining Protestant minister in Moscow, has disappeared. Although no official information concerning him was available, the belief was general in foreign embassies and legations, whose members attended his services in the SS.
Irvington House opened a thrift shop at Third Avenue and Forty-fifth Street yesterday afternoon with success that threatened to get out of hand.

SEATTLE, Wash., Nov. 12. -- Eugene O'Neill awoke this morning in a house on a bluff overlooking fog-curtained Puget Sound to have his wife tell him that he was the winner of the Nobel Prize for letters.

The bootleg liquor business is still as highly organized as it was during prohibition and at present is producing 40,000,000 gallons of illegal spirits yearly, according to the report of a two-year "first-hand" study of the liquor situation since repeal, made public yesterday by Luther Gulick, director of the Institute of Public Administration, 302 East Thirty-fifth Street.

Contributions totaling $43,063.86 toward the $200,000 goal of the 1937 budget campaign of the Y.W.C.A. were announced yesterday at the first report luncheon of the drive at the Central Branch, 610 Lexington Avenue.

ROME, Nov. 12. -- Negotiations are actively progressing between Rome and London for a solution of the Mediterranean question and have already reached a point so near agreement that it is thought Foreign Minister Count Galeazzo Ciano will soon receive invitation to go to London and seal the re-establishment of Anglo-Italian friendship.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 12. -- Rejecting a demand by the Democratic minority for an inspection of all Westchester voting machines to determine the election of a county Surrogate, the Board of Supervisors voted this afternoon to start a limited investigation on Monday.

There appeared in THE TIMES of Nov. 6 an article regarding the Life Saving Service of the City of New York, under the headline "Life Saving Work Will Be Expanded." Mention is made of us and I wish to place before you the position of our organization.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- The United States Maritime Commission announced today that it would consolidate its investigation of the strike and marine situation to em brace the walkouts on three American coasts, Atlantic, Pacific and Gulf.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 12. -- Maryland's and the East's final race meeting of the 1936 season opened today with a Maryland victory in the featured Bowie claiming stakes when G.R. Bryson's Calumet Dick came around his field to score by three lengths going away.

Stone Webster, Inc., reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30 a total income of $970,495, compared with $868,562 in the preceding year, and a net income of $195,306 after expenses, taxes and charges, against $159,419 the year before.

Aroused to the vital necessity of reducing street and highway accidents, both on humanitarian grounds and to permit expected expansion of their business, leaders in the automobile industry met yesterday at luncheon at the Hotel Commodore with the representatives of a dozen organizations working together in the interest of safety, whose memberships total some 7,000,000 persons.

The rather vague discussion of the stupendous reserves to be set up under the Social Security Act has left unnoticed the greatest danger of all. This is the cumulative reduction of consumer purchasing power brought about by the Special taxes, which will eventually amount to 9 per cent of payrolls of the people affected.
BERLIN, Nov. 12. -- Prices on the Boerse fell considerably today in inactive trading, foreign stocks leading the way down because of further rumors of restrictions.

Confidence in the ability of consumer cooperatives to create a scientific system of mass distribution, to parallel mass production, was expressed by two speakers yesterday at the marketing conference of the American Management Association, in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12. -- The second general assembly of the Presbyterian Church of America, which broke away from the parent denomination, the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, opened here today with the election of a new moderator and a sermon by the retiring moderator, the Rev. Dr. J. Gresham Machen, in which that fundamentalist leader warned against "stifling discussion for the sake of peace."
Auctioneers were kept busy with forced sales of Manhattan real estate yesterday.

The City Bank Farmers Trust Company has been appointed co-registrar for 5,000 shares of convertible preferred stock and 1,000,000 shares of common stock of the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation.

Twentieth Century-Fox's musical satire on football, "Pigskin Parade," featuring such funsters as Patsy Kelly, Stuart Erwin, Jack Haley, Johnny Downs, the Yacht Club Boys, Arline Judge and Dixie Dunbar, makes its Broadway bow today at the Roxy .

Of the models made for the new America's Cup defense yacht for Harold S. Vanderbilt, one was selected yesterday and a start was made of laying down the boat at the Bath Iron Works in Bath, Mo. That means the chalking on a floor of the lines of the racer for the bending of her frames, the steel for which already has been ordered.
The Smith College Club of New York will give a tea this afternoon at its club rooms in honor of John Barbirolli, British conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra.

Steady advances in prices on a wide variety of foreign products are depriving importers here of the benefits of recent currency depreciations, they complained yesterday. In France, particularly, higher quotations on such textile products as laces and dress goods have more than taken up the saving which the franc devaluation afforded.

After having sagged for two months prior to the election. The Annalist Weekly Index of Wholesale Commodity prices has advanced sharply to the highest level since the end of 1935. The index rose to 129.2 last Tuesday from 127.9 on Monday, Nov. 2.

Asserting that "the institution of customers' men has at present an unestablished value," William O. Douglas, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, told students of the New York Stock Exchange Institute yesterday that the opportunity to make the vocation "a valuable investment-service adjunct to organized Exchanges rests in the hands of your generation."

Mayor La Guardia made two strong appeals yesterday for support of his housing program at exercises in connection with the laying of the cornerstone of the $239,660 district health and training center at 250 Baltic Street, Brooklyn, the first of its kind in the borough.

Sitting more or less idle and surveying the surrounding football populace with a certain amount of complacency, the undefeated Fordham football forces finally have a Saturday to themselves, having arranged this breathing spell to follow the prodigious battles which have lifted them into national prominence.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- The daily average retail sales in small towns and rural areas in October were 21 per cent higher in dollar volume than in October a year ago and 42 per cent higher than in 1934, preliminary estimates of the Department of Commerce showed today.

ROME, Nov. 12. -- Major Ramon Franco, the aviator brother of the leader of the Spanish Insurgent movement, arrived in Naples this morning aboard the liner Vulcania, accompanied by his wife and daughter. They landed a few hours later amid the cheers of a small group of Spaniards who had gone to meet them and the clicking of the camera shutters of numerous press photographers.

Lord HUGH CECIL'S appointment to the Provostship of Eton left vacant his seat in Parliament as one of the two representatives of Oxford University. Lord HUGH is the Conservative of Conservatives. His former colleague, Mr. A.P. HERBERT of Punch, is the Independent of Independents.

Arguments on the constitutionality of the Public Utility Act of 1935 were concluded yesterday with a vigorous defense by counsel for the government. When attorneys for the Electric Bond and Share Company and twenty-one other defendants assailing the New Deal law failed to renew their attack upon it, Federal Judge Julian W. Mack reserved decision.

In their monthly bulletins the national Chamber of Commerce and the Federal Reserve Board write in a distinctly cheerful view of this Autumn's industrial recovery. Both place the present position of production, earnings and trade activity in general at the highest since 1930.
John D. Rockefeller Jr. hailed James A. Farley's election night radio talk as "one of the most statesmanlike utterances on either side during the entire campaign," it was disclosed yesterday.

The New York Americans, resplendent in new uniforms, opened their twelfth home season in the National Hockey League at Madison Square Garden last night, against the sturdy Black Hawk sextet from Chicago, and after 70 minutes of play the teams had to skate off the ice with nothing more to show for their efforts than a scoreless tie.
A canvas by Corot, "Les Baigneuses a, l'Enfant," was sold for $9,000 last night at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries. Frank Schnittjer was the purchaser.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP). -- October imports of gold and silver increased over September, the Commerce Department reported today, but were considerably under imports for October, 1935. Gold imports last month totaled $218,928,514, of which $95,012,681 came from France and $72,155,922 from the United Kingdom.

Louis (Lepke) Buchalter and Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro, industrial racketeers, whose annual "take" has been estimated at more than $1,000,000 each, must serve two years in jail and pay fines of $10,000 each for creating a reign of terror in the city's rabbit fur dressing industry.
MADRID, Nov. 12. -- Three Rebel bombers and six pursuit planes sprayed machine-gun bullets on government lines from the Toledo Bridge to University City early this evening.
Your editorial setting forth the pros and cons of abolition of the Electoral College was much to the point.

The center of interest in the intricate game of Chino-Japanese relations has now shifted from Shanghai and Nanking to the frontier province of Suiyuan, "the gateway to China's vast northwest." There a Japanese-supported movement of Mongolian-Manchukuoan armed forces, by attacking the provincial Chinese authority, is pressing toward the recognized Japanese goal -- control of all Inner Mongolia.

A banking group headed by Hornblower Weeks will offer today 285,000 shares of 5 per cent convertible preferred stock of $30 par value of Butler Brothers, wholesale distributors of popular-priced dry goods and general merchandise. The stock will be priced at $31 a share.

For the striking failure of its Presidential poll to forecast accurately the result of the election, The Literary Digest has no explanation satisfactory even to itself. Precisely the same methods which had been used on earlier occasions were followed in this case. In the past they frequently enabled The Digest to come close to the mark in predicting the result of an election.

Criticism of the automobile industry for the increased use of laborsaving devices was answered yesterday by M.E. Coyle, president of the Chevrolet Motor Company, in a speech at the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue.

BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 12 (AP). -- Governor Richard W. Leche headed arbitration efforts today in a strike of Louisiana Arkansas Railroad workers while two train derailments were added to a long list of mishaps on the line since the strike started Sept. 19.

OTTAWA, Nov. 12 (Canadian Press). -- Deposits with the Bank of Canada by the Dominion Government fell $1,575,182 and deposits by chartered banks rose $4,284,154 in the week ended on Tuesday, the bank announced today. The weekly statement follows:

VIENNA, Nov. 12. -- The Clerical Reichspost, which is closely allied with the Holy See and which is used often as the mouthpiece for the church in delicate political matters concerning Central Europe, published today a message from Rome to the effect that Michael Cardinal von Faulhaber's recent audience with Chancellor Adolf Hitler at Berchtesgaden lasted three hours.

Despite a decline from the preceding week, bank clearings for the five days ended on Wednesday continued to run ahead of those last year, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Settlements through the banks were restricted during the latest period, which included the Armistice Day holiday.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 12. -- Hundreds of bus passengers were forced to resort to railroad trains and several thousand others were delayed during the morning and evening rush hours today by a strike of drivers employed by two bus companies operating between Journal Square here and points in Bergen and Passaic Counties.
PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 12 (AP). -- Dr Carl David Anderson, 31-year-old physicist, tonight gave his associates major credit for the work which brought him a share of the Nobel award in physics.

People have turned their backs on what happened a week ago last Tuesday and are now talking about what will happen in the next four years. Which way will President ROOSEVELT go -- Right or Left? What will JOHN L. LEWIS do about that new Labor party?

The governors of the New York Stock Exchange approved yesterday listing applications of ten companies. Five companies had not heretofore had issues traded on that market. They were National Malleable and Steel Casting, San Diego Consolidated Gas and Electric, Butler Brothers, Florence Stove and Masonite Corporation.

Curley Lambeau, who coached Jimmy Crowley, the No. 1 citizen of Green Bay, Wis., in that young man's senior year in high school, arrived in town yesterday with his latest coaching masterpiece, to wit, the Green Bay Packers. Deadlocked with the Chicago Bears for the leadership of the Western division of the National Football League, the Packers hope to have that crown fairly well clinched before they leave New York a fortnight hence.

LONDON, Nov. 12. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin, making the closing speech in the defense debate in the House of Commons tonight, was very much on the defensive. He had to speak after a slashing attack by Winston Churchill and produced nothing in reply that satisfied the many members who are convinced the present British program of rearmament is inadequate and badly administered.
The American Academy of Arts and Letters awarded yesterday its annual gold medal for good diction on the stage to Ina Claire "for her charm, elegance and naturalness in speech."

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- Business on the London Stock Exchange was at a low ebb today, with prices in most departments weakened by profit-taking. British Government securities were steady, but industrials generally lost ground.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- After conferring here today with two leaders of the "revolt" of employe representatives in the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation against the company's request that the employe representatives sign a twelve-month agreement to peg wages to the cost of living in connection with a proffered wage increase, Secretary Perkins agreed to "break new ground" in the controversy involving some of the company union leaders and the steel corporations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Neither banks nor broker credit has been supporting the current upward trend in the stock markets, Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today as he left the White House after a conference with President Roosevelt.

As soon as the rumor spread that James J. Braddock would fight Shufflin' Joe Louis some time next Spring, the ringsiders dropped all discussion of Indian Quintana and Sixto Escobar, and even Colonel John Reed Kilpatrick of Madison Square Garden began sparring for time.

The body of Morris Erde, 71 years old, so-called "Pumpernickel King" of the East Side, who vanished Sunday night, was found at 4:30 A.M. yesterday in a courtyard of the Amalgamated Dwellings, Inc., cooperative apartment house at 504 Grand Street, where he had lived.

The exhibition of Ford and Lincoln cars at the Hotel Astor, which opened last Wednesday, continued to attract large crowds yesterday. Checkers on the various entrances reported that 18,000 persons had visited the show yesterday up to 6 P.M.

The Alleghany Corporation has acquired for $144,837 an additional 1,500 shares of the Chesapeake Corporation's capital stock, it was disclosed in a statement to the New York Stock Exchange made public yesterday. The stock was accumulated through purchases in the market.

The radio was seen as a potential danger in the public schools yesterday by James Marshall, vice president of the Board of Education, in opposing the installation of radio equipment in the Bronx Industrial High School.

John Barbirolli gave his second Thursday night concert with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra yesterday in Carnegie Hall, and with marked success. It is a pleasure to say that on this occasion Mr. Barbirolli had much better control of the orchestra, and apparently was more in his element, than on the trying occasion of his first appearance in New York a week previous.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Despite slight increases last month in the number of relief clients, bringing the total up to 3,498,012 on Oct. 15, and other increases anticipated with the coming of cold weather, Harry L.
