Hopkins, WPA Administrator, announced today a 28 per cent decrease from the "peak" load of 5,316,000 cases reached in January, 1935, and predicted that this Winter would find 1,000,000 fewer persons on relief than last year.

I noted in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 6 the lament of Dr. Iago Galdston over the progress (shall we say?) of the scientific idea in the world in advance of what he concludes to be the moral idea and his venturesome prognostications.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. Awards made by the Treasury Procurement Division today on cotton textiles were announced as follows:

A decline in brokers' loans, a renewed rise in commercial loans and an increase of $34,000,000 in the total of all loans and investments were reported for the week ended on Wednesday in the condition statement of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City, published yesterday.

ARLINGTON, Texas, Nov. 12 (AP). -- Mrs. V. Wyse's Eastport established a new track record today at Arlington Downs by running the mile and seventy yards in 1:43 1-5 to win by a length the feature race. The attendance was 6,000.

The Literary Digest still does not know why its Presidential poll was so far out of line with the actual vote, but promises to do better next time. It predicted 370 electoral votes for Governor Landon, and he received 8 to President Roosevelt's 523.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 12 (AP) -- President Roosevelt told the National Grange Convention in a message today that a "fight to achieve real equality for agriculture" would be pressed forward.

Next Monday will be the last day of the grouse season in New York State, with the exception of Long Island, where general upland shooting continues until Dec. 31. Small-game hunting opportunities will be narrowed further on the mainland with the close of the squirrel season Monday.

Tonight's "Carnival on Wheels" in the Mecca Temple Casino, West Fifty-fifth Street, will offer a varied program of entertainment as a benefit for the Vocational Service for Juniors. A potato race on roller skates, open to both men and women; general skating to the musio of a dance orchestra, skating exhibitions by professionals and a cabaret floor show will be among the features.

Out of respect for Grace George it would be very nice to be very nice about Louis Verneuil's "Matrimony Pfd.," which was acted at the Playhouse last evening. For she is an endearing little lady who has tiptoed through a whole library of French piquancies without ever committing an indelicate gesture.

TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 12 (AP). -- A proposal for a concerted drive by all craft unions to combat John L. Lewis's Committee for Industrial Organization came today from leaders of the American Federation of Labor's building trades department.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Justice Louis D. Brandeis, who will be 80 years old tomorrow appeared today almost as he has for the last decade. The imminence of his birthday did not change the attitude of the justice or his customary habits.

BERLIN, Nov. 12. -- The reception by Chancellor Adolf Hitler of the Argentine Minister in his new rank as Ambassador received an unusual degree of publicity and emphasis. Hitler, who is seldom in Berlin, recently received Dr. Eduardo Labougle in the Presidential Palace, the one of his three official Wilhelmstrasse residences reserved for affairs of State.
PARIS, Nov. 12. -- Three new "Immortals'' were elected today. Four seats were vacant in the Academie Francaise, whose full quota of members is forty, but one could not be filled.

Forty-five bids were made yesterday for a two-story brick dwelling at 2,629 Grand Avenue before the property went for $16,000 to Inter-urban Apartments, Inc., a client of Kadel, Van Kirk Trencher. The property had been offered in foreclosure by James R. Murphy, auctioneer, in an action by Ellen M. Phillips against Merina C. Castiglia.

Statisticians of recovery have no lack of figures to prove their case. They can point to increased earnings, to restored or enlarged dividends, to bonuses and higher wages for many employes, to bank clearings and to the rise in the stock market. But one thing they are not able to tabulate or state in the form of percentages.

The Pennsylvania Railroad continued yesterday its record of uninterrupted cash disbursements since 1847 by declaring a dividend of $1 on capital stock from 1936 earnings, and the Western Maryland Railway announced its first dividend since it was reorganized in 1917 -- a disbursement of $7 on its 7 per cent first preferred stock.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12. -- Continued heavy receipts of hogs, with an unusually large percentage of light weights, were largely responsible for a decline of 25 cents a hundredweight in the latter. Other hogs sold 10 to 15 cents lower. A fairly active demand appeared at the lower level of prices, and a fairly good clean-up of holdings of light weights was reported when the market closed.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 12. -- Nelson Eddy signed a new seven-year contract with Metro today. According to the terms, he will work at the studio twenty-eight weeks a year with time off from January to May for his concert tours.

MONTREAL, Nov. 12 (AP). -- The "old men" of the Montreal Canadiens, brought back together this season, showed something of their old-time stardom tonight as they gave the flying Frenchmen a 2-to-1 victory over the Maroons in the season's first intracity battle of the National Hockey League season.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday continued to show the effects of Monday's unexpectedly large crop estimate and lost 4 to 16 points. A sharp break in silver, contraction of exports due to the shipping strike and active hedging operations by the Cooperative Association and other spot interests also operated against the market.

For the fourth time within a week police were called yesterday to disperse a group of WPA art students who have been engaging in "sit-down" strikes at the New York School of Industrial Art, 257 West Fortieth Street. Yesterday's disturbance resulted in the arrest of seventeen men and twelve women, the majority of whom have ben arrested twice before for the same offense.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- American General Corporation, Jersey City, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $15,000,000 of fifteen-year 5 per cent debentures, due on Dec. 1, 1951, to be issued under an exchange plan for securities of the International Securities Corporation of America, the Second International Securities Corporation and the Reliance Management Corporation.

The name of Walter S. Gifford, president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, was the first drawn from the green urn last night at the fourteenth annual "Founders Draw" of the Grand Central Art Galleries, 15 Vanderbilt Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Modifications of regulations of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation eliminating in certain cases the provision that banks must say in advertising that they are insured were issued today.

Industrial purchasing agents, preparing at present to place several billion dollars' worth of contracts for industry's production needs in the first quarter of 1937, are balking at attempts to include "up-and-down" clauses in buying agreements, a canvass of local executives indicated yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 12. -- The Princeton-Yale football game on Saturday will be played before the largest Palmer Stadium crowd in six years, it was revealed today with the announcement by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics, that 57,000 tickets had been sold.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 12. -- Harvard put in a solid day's work today preparing for the Navy team. Coach Dick Harlow made the final practice hard, although there was no scrimmaging. Tomorrow there will be a short stadium workout, but it will be mainly on punts and kick-offs and a thorough rehearsing of plays.

The practical value of research has been proved by many corporations which employ technicians to engage in such work, but local governments have yet to learn that research is a pillar of progress. New York spends over a half billion dollars yearly, but does not have a coordinated or comprehensive research program or staff.

A preliminary report issued yesterday by the Association of American Railroads showed that ninety-two Class I railroads, with earnings equivalent to 79.3 per cent of the total for all Class I lines, had gross revenues of $312,072,915 in October, against $270,300,144 in October, 1935, an increase of 15.5 per cent.

The stock market was heavy in tone most of yesterday and closed generally lower, many of the leaders losing from fractions to 3 points. The amusement, merchandising and some of the specialty stocks showed independent strength, but even these issues closed well under the day's best prices.

Winston Guest, only ten-goal player in the indoor game, gave up his position as president of the Indoor Polo Association of America last night at the annual meeting of the organization at the Metropolitan Club. Elbridge T. Gerry was elected his successor.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- The marked effect of the Spanish civil war on United States trade with that nation was shown today by figures made public by the Department of Commerce. Total exports from this country to Spain in September were valued at only $245,000, compared with $3,734,000 in September last year.

The election solved many problems for America and answered many seemingly puzzling questions -- among others, the question of the so-called Red menace. The entire Communist vote was somewhere in the neighborhood of 57,000 -- a small fraction of I per cent of the total.

Speaking on "What Machines Have Done for Mankind" at the annual dinner of the Society of Automotive Engineers at the Hotel Commodore last night, Dr. James Shelby Thomas, president of Clarkson College of Technology, said that culture and comfort had been immeasurably advanced by the inventions of this mechanical age.

Without its ocean commerce the City of New York would "lie idle," Controller Taylor asserted yesterday at the opening of the third annual exhibition of the Maritime Association in the Maritime Exchange Building, 80 Broad Street.

GENEVA, Nov. 12. -- The Governing Body of the International Labor Office decided today to convoke silicosis experts for medical foundation work preparatory to executing the resolution of the June International Labor Conference adopted on the United States Government's motion.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12. -- C.C. Fleming of the Life Insurance Company of Virginia, Richmond, Va., was elected president of the Life Advertisers Association at the opening of its annual convention here today. C.T. Stevens, Phoenix Mutual Life, Hartford, Conn., was elected vice president; L.J. Evans, Northwestern Mutual, Milwaukee, secretary, and Karl Ljung Jr., Jefferson Standard, Greensboro, N.C., treasurer.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 12. -- The tense atmosphere that always surrounds West Point before the annual meeting with Notre Dame made itself particularly evident today when the entire corps of Cadets paraded behind the Military Academy band to the practice field and cheered on the varsity during its last practice before Saturday's contest.
LONDON, Nov. 12. -- The officers and men of the Home Fleet, the mightiest arm of Great Britain's sea power, received King Edward today on his first inspection tour since he came to the throne.

MADRID, Nov. 12 (Censored). -- After five days of futile attempts to fight their way into Madrid, the Rebels' main line outside the capital tonight ran from Villaverde through Carabanchel to Campamiento. It appears that the Insurgents will not launch a new offensive until they have concentrated their forces nearer to the city.

Employes of the Emergency Relief Bureau are threatening to strike unless the Municipal Civil Service Commission rescinds its order for an open competitive examination for permanent positions on the city's relief staff, Mayor LA GUARDIA has warned them against taking forcible action of that kind.

The annual championship show of the Empire Cat Club opened yesterday morning at the Hotel Pennsylvania in conjunction with the show of the Siamese Cat Society of America. Both shows were held in the same room on the eighteenth floor.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Nov. 12. -- Five of the leading chess experts in Puerto Rico have entered the international masters tournament sponsored by the Puerto Rican Chess Federation, a unit of the national body in the United States.

The exhibition of art from Soviet Russia, which has been traveling about the country for nearly two years under the auspices of the College Art Association, opened here last evening in the galleries on the thirty-third floor of the Squibb Building.

LONDON, Nov. 12. -- Sir John Simon, Home Secretary, told Parliament today that the government had information indicating that both Fascists and Communists in this country were receiving financial support from abroad. He refused to tell questioners in Commons what, if anything, he intends to do about it.
Bins for $104,123 submitted to the city by Hiram C. Todd and J. Edward Lumbard Jr. for their work on the Drukman case in Brooklyn were slashed yesterday by Controller Frank J. Taylor to $42,000.

The union of Emergency Relief Bureau employes asked Mayor La Guardia yesterday to arrange a conference between union officials and the Municipal Civil Service Commission in the hope of averting a strike of the 11,000 persons administering home relief.

LONDON, Nov. 12 (AP). -- The Week, a privately circulated and mimeographed magazine, concludes there is little possibility that King Edward will either abdicate or marry Mrs. Wallis Simpson, a copy of the magazine revealed today.

ABOARD THE S.S. AMERICAN LEGION, AT SEA, Nov, 12. -- The question of equal rights for women may yet come up at the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace opening at Buenos Aires on Dec. 1, according to information reaching the delegations aboard this ship bound for the gathering.

Sixto Escobar will risk his bantamweight championship of the world tonight, when he meets Carlos (Indian) Quintana of Panama in a fifteen-round bout at Madison Square Garden. Escobar, who established a clear claim to the 118-pound crown last Summer by stopping Tony Marino, is favored, at odds of 7 to 5, to retain his laurels.

The Philadelphia Orchestra will be the featured attraction of the 1937 Westchester Music Festival, which will be held the nights of May 20, 21 and 22 in the County Center, White Plains. This will be the first time that one of the major symphony orchestras has participated at these festivals, now entering their thirteenth season.

The American Cyanamid Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the first nine months of this year a net income of $2,803,266 after depreciation, depletion, research and process development expense, interest, Federal income taxes, minority interest and other charges.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Proposals for a balanced program of industrial stabilization and advancement of the general welfare will be discussed at a two-day meeting here Dec. 10-11, it was announced today by Major George L. Berry, Coordinator for Industrial Cooperation.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 12. -- The British Royal Commission, which arrived yesterday, held a ceremonious reception at Government House this afternoon. Present were the heads of government departments, dignitaries of religious communities, except Moslems, members of the consular corps and a few selected notables from different parts of the country.

LONDON, Nov. 12. -- The award of the Nobel Prize to Eugene O'Neill came as a surprise to most theatre-goers in London, who have never been enthusiastic over his work. Except in intellectural circles here his dramas are not widely appreciated.

BERLIN, Nov. 12. -- Joachim von Ribbentrop was able to register his first diplomatic success as the new German Ambassador to the Court of St. James when the London Philharmonic Orchestra, led by Sir Thomas Beecham, arrived in Berlin today and was officially welcomed at the City Hall with appropriate ceremonies and speeches.

The prospect of government ownership of the railroads, to bring about long-delayed consolidations, was condemned here last night by Thomas W. Lamont, partner of J.P. Morgan Co., and was recommended by Joseph B. Eastman, Interstate Commerce Commissioner and former Federal Coordinator of Railroads.

A swift and successful move on the part of friends of Mrs. William Dick Sporborg of Port Chester yesterday plunged the State Federation of Women's Clubs, in convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania, into the sphere of general federation politics.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12. -- The $7,000,000 bridge over San Francisco Bay, between San Francisco and Oakland, the longest in the world over navigable waters, was dedicated today by Governor Frank Merriam, and President Roosevelt pressed a button in Washington at 3:30 P.M., Eastern standard time, officially opening the great structure to traffic.

With the scholastic football season fast drawing to a close, many of the East's topnotch elevens will be seen in action against one another today. Traditional meetings hold the spotlight, and those between Hill and Hotchkiss, Blair Academy and Peddle, Gilman and Tome Schools and Poly Prep and St. Paul's of Garden City, L.I., top the card.

Building plans filed yesterday included a $350,000 apartment house project for Richmond Hill and a $175,000 multi-family project for Long Island City. Details of the filings in the several city boroughs were as follows:

The Harvard Club and the University Club are tied at the top with three victories apiece, following triumphs last night in the Class A competition of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets League. Also remaining undefeated, the Princeton Club annexed its second match of the season, defeating the Yale Club, 3 -- 2.

Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of rackets, sent three policemen yesterday morning to stop the picketing of the Alden Sandwich Shop at 307 West 125th Street by representatives of Local 302 of the Cafeteria Countermen's Union. The policemen dispersed the pickets and remained on guard to prevent a renewal of their activities.
TALAVERA DE LA REINA, Spain, Nov. 12. -- The Loyalist forces used poisonous gas against Insurgent troops who captured Carabanchel Bajo today, an official witness reported.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- The existence of the New York Unemployment Insurance Law is in no way dependent upon the Federal Social Security Act, Henry Epstein, Solicitor General of New York, told the Supreme Court today as arguments closed on the test of the New York case.

Prints by 100 of the leading print makers of the United States, each depicting some facet of contemporary American life, have been selected from almost 500 entries and will be published in a book entitled "America Today: A Book of 100 Prints," on Dec. 10 by the Equinox Cooperative Press.
PARIS, Nov. 12 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

LONDON, Nov. 12 (AP). -- The international committee on non-intervention in Spain tonight acquitted Russia of three Italian charges she had aided the Madrid government. The decision followed a bitter denunciation of Russia by Dino Grandi, Italian Ambassador to London.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP). -- Banking on an enlarged bloc of Northern Democrats to demand a hand at the helm of the new House, Representative Better today entered his fellow-Representative from New York, James M. Mead of Buffalo, in the contest for Democratic floor leader.

Steady progress in its efforts to accumulate a promotion fund for cotton goods, through one-cent a bale contributions by both shippers and mills was reported here yesterday by the Cotton-Textile Institute. With practically all of the leading shippers committed to the plan, pledges from mills representing more than 25 per cent of the country's active spindles have been received at the institute's offices, it was said.
Boston will offer for sale next Monday an issue of $6,000,000 of short-term notes. The notes will be dated Nov. 19, 1936, and mature on Nov. 2, 1937.
LONDON, Nov. 12 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

The Shippers Conference of Greater New York voted yesterday to oppose the proposal of the railroads to increase fifth and sixth class freight rates and to take no action on the proposed changes in rates on individual commodities.

Among the rich possessions of the American people which most of them did not seem greatly to worry about on election day were personal liberty and the Constitution. To the Republican campaign argument that both were menaced by the President the voters registered an emphatic disbelief.

Mayor La Guardia expressed hope last night at a dinner of the Board of Higher Education at the Hotel Biltmore that the city in its capital outlay budget for 1937 would be able to make at least a start in meeting the needs of Hunter College, and said that the question of a college for Queens was already receiving consideration.

Declines occurred in most commodity futures markets yesterday, although gains appeared in cocoa, silk, tallow and coffee, with the turnover large in nearly all the staples. On the cash markets cotton, butter, rubber and tin declined, while wheat, corn, oats, cocoa and eggs rose, and silk, hides and rye reached new high marks.

Matthew J. Hoey, 55 years old, who rose from office boy to a member of the Stock Exchange only to lose a fortune in 1922 and again in 1929, was found dead in bed yesterday in a room at the Park View Hotel, 208 West Fifty-sixth Street, by a hotel employe at 11:10 A.M.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12. -- The St. Louis Browns, for years the weak link in the American League, were placed in the care of new owners today.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12. -- Between 500 and 600 new jobs for golf professionals are in the making.

" Plumes in the Dust," Sophie Treadwell's play about Edgar Allan Poe -- a role that is filled by Henry Hull -- will cease its life at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre after tomorrow evening's performance. It then will have played eleven times in New York.

PARIS, Nov. 12. -- One of the most important openings of the theatrical season took place on Monday night when "Napoleon Unique" by Paul Raynal and directed by Jacques Copeau was presented at the Porte Saint-Martin Theatre. Long heralded and brilliantly acted, it has already proved the chief topic of conversation in the theatre world of Paris, where opinions seem divided as to whether it is a masterpiece or merely dull and pretentious.
Sid Luckman walked out on Baker Field yesterday, took a pass from center and sent the ball spiraling thirty-five or forty yards into the empyrean.
Purchases of apartment houses in Manhattan by investors who plan to alter the properties were included in yesterday's realty turnover.

Roy K. Ferguson, president of the Taggart Corporation, sent yesterday to stockholders a letter setting forth a plan for reclassification of stock and adjustment of unpaid dividends in arrears on the preferred and Class A stocks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- A rule prescribing special financial requirements for registration under the Securities Act of 1933 of securities issued by an individual, instead of by a corporation, was adopted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Hope for an early solution of dementia praecox, described as "perhaps the largest problem in our present-day society," was seen yesterday at the twenty-seventh annual meeting of the National Committee for Mental Hygiene in the Hotel Roosevelt.

The striking seamen in Atlantic and Gulf ports, who are opposed by their own union officials as well as the shipowners, won a victory yesterday when the American Range Lines, Inc., made a tentative separate agreement with the strike strategy committee.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Peace-time records for production of coins at American mints were reached in the ten months ending Nov. 1 with the making of 499,554,280 pieces, valued at $32,297,238, the Treasury announced today.

VIENNA, Nov. 12. -- The representatives of Italy, Austria and Hungary, the three States of the Rome bloc, decided during their conference here, which ended this afternoon, to express their full agreement with the attitude of the Hungarian Government in demanding the right to rearm, it was announced tonight in a communique on the conference's results.

The pointed intimations from Washington that Federal Reserve authorities, in collaboration with the Securities and Exchange Commission, are keeping a close watch upon the tendency of security and commodity prices to "get ahead of the parade" were received with unusual interest in Wall Street.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 12. -- The Westchester County Children's Association held its annual meeting for election of officers and a dinner tonight at the Westchester Country Club, Rye. About 150 were present.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and the reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date. The ratio of reserve for the New York Bank also reached a new high figure for the year.

John (Pat) Byrne, who scored both of Manhattan's touchdowns against Kentucky, was named by Coach Chick Meehan yesterday to start in the back field against undefeated Georgetown at Ebbets Field tomorrow. Tubby Savage, Ed Kringle and George Gerek will be Byrne's running mates.

ALBANY, Nov. 12. -- Elmer F Andre, State Industrial Commissioner, reported here today that the prospective investment represented in industrial construction plans submitted to the State Department of Labor during October totaling $3,513,915 is the greatest for any month in the past six and a half rears.

Plans for the proposed fight between James J. Braddock and Joe Louis advanced no further than the conversational stage yesterday, as Mike Jacobs, Joe Gould and Herman Taylor discussed all angles of the bout.

The Crane Company, in its initial report of reacquired stock to the New York Stock Exchange, disclosed yesterday that it holds in its treasury 50,000 shares of its common stock purchased to provide for an option permitting Charles B. Nolte, president, to buy this amount of stock prior to March 1, 1940, at $10 a share.

Apart from a proposal of marriage and an average of 100 or more visitors daily the Dionne quintuplets continue to lead "a fairly normal life," Dr. Allan Roy Dafoe, their physician and mentor, reported yesterday, following his arrival in this city on Wednesday evening.

A silver-haired woman writer, speaking with intensity and precision, warned the afternoon audience at THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair yesterday that the flood of published books was carrying away the individual author's chance of survival.

An increase of $120,000,000 in member-bank excess reserves to $2,260,000,000, the highest total reached since the 50 per cent increase in reserve requirements on Aug. 15, was reported for the week ended on Wednesday in the Federal Reserve statement, published yesterday.

Crowds larger than those of last year on the same day flocked to Grand Central Palace yesterday on the second day of the National Automobile Show. They expressed the enthusiasm of the public for the 1937 offerings of the motor-car industry not merely by placing orders in many price classifications, but by evincing intelligent interest in the mechanical and comfort features of the new models.

In the calmest annual meeting of the company held since Nathan L. Amster and his associates won control from the Interborough Rapid Transit management four years ago, stockholders of the Manhattan Railway Company unanimously reelected yesterday the board of directors, with 267,299 out of 600,000 shares represented at the meeting.
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 12. -- Governor Landon and John Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, met today for the first time since the election, to lay the groundwork for their party's future.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- A spokesman for the Resettlement Administration said today that Dr. Rexford G. Tugwell, its director, would like to see unemployed workers put to building a "great number" of suburban housing developments for low income families.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- A slight upward movement in wholesale prices was recorded during the week ended on Nov. 7 by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 weekly average as 100, rose to 81.3, compared with 81.2 the preceding week and 80.1 a year ago.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 12. -- The Nobel Prize in Literature was awarded today to Eugene O'Neill, noted American dramatist.

The first day's attendance figure at the General Motors show on the third floor of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, which opened Wednesday, doubled that of a year ago for the same exhibition, it was reported yesterday. No definite figure for yesterday's attendance was available last night, but the crowds observed in the various rooms devoted to the display indicated that the record would be broken again.

The advance in United States Government loans and other high-grade investments gained momentum yesterday in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. In a somewhat heavier turnover, twenty-two of the government long-term bonds rose to their highest levels since issue, with net gains of 1-32 to 14-32 of a point.

NEW CASTLE, Ky., Nov. 12 (AP). -- The arrest of Brig. Gen. Henry H. Denhardt on a warrant charging him with the murder of Mrs. Verna Garr Taylor, sociany prominent La Grange widow, cut off an inquest into her death here today.

Beginning the first of the year, the hours of the city firemen will be reduced and they will receive one day off in nine as the first step in the installation of the three-platoon system, Fire Commissioner McElligott announced yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12. -- Tapping of telephone wires and use of industrial spies by steamship companies in the waterfront controversies was charged today before the Maritime Commission by Henry P. Melnikow, representative of six maritime unions now on strike.

George Schaefer, 79 years old, a prominent real estate developer of Queens, died last night while playing pinochle at the home of Fred Schumacher on the latter's estate south of Flushing at North Hempstead Turnpike and Parsons Boulevard.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13. -- After nearly four hours of debate, during which references to advisability of a factional split in the new organization were heard, the Presbyterian Church of America late today completed its credal framework.

In the report of your Washington correspondent of the arguments before the Supreme Court of the United States yesterday on the constitutionality of the New York Unemployment Insurance Law, I am reported as having said "that the statute should be held invalid because it failed to require a pauper's oath from beneficiaries who were really not always in need."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 13. -- After a twenty-eight-year lapse, the football forces of Harvard and Navy will meet again in the Harvard Stadium tomorrow, with about 50,000 persons, the largest local crowd of the season, expected to watch the game.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 13 (AP). -- Investigators of the mysterious death of Mrs. Vera Garr Taylor, 40-year-old socially prominent La Grange widow, whose bullet-pierced body was found in a Henry County roadside ditch a week ago tonight, exhumed her body tonight for re-examination of wounds.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 13. -St. Paul's School today was amply repaid for its long wait for victory over its time-honored foe, Poly Prep, when the strong Red and Black eleven routed the Dyker Heights team, 32 -- 0, in their twenty-seventh combat since their rivalry began in 1892.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

An emergency milk pasteurization plant which could handle up to 10,000 quarts a day in the event of a milk shortage is established in the Bronx Terminal Market under the terms of a lease submitted by Mayor La Guardia to the Board of Estimate yesterday.

PARIS, Nov. 13. -- The Bourse weakened today all along the line, with losses that frequently proved considerable. Technical reasons were partly responsible, but the principal cause was anxiety over the political situation aroused anew by the Communist attitude on the Spanish situation and fiscal affairs as well as renewal of the government's attack on "big business." International securities suffered with French stocks.

LONDON, Nov. 13. -- The stock markets here were subdued today until shortly before the close, when a brisk rally occurred in several of the industrials. British Government securities also rallied after early dullness.
The Allegheny Steel Company has notified the New York Stock Exchange of the election of E.J. Hanley as secretary, succeeding F.H. Stephens, resigned.

EAST ISLIP, L.I., Nov. 13. -- Under the most favorable auspices, the annual field trial meeting of the American Chesapeake Club was opened this morning over the estates of Jay F. Carlisle and Charles L. Lawrence and will be continued tomorrow and Sunday.

With every factor which influences the trend of the money market in this country today pointing to continued low interest rates, the outlook for the money market depends primarily on the attitude of the only force that can change these factors, namely, the government, Dr. Marcus Nadler, Professor of Finance at New York University, told members of the Municipal Bond Club of New York at a luncheon yesterday at the Bankers Club.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Nov. 13. -- Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister, received today the most enthusiastic welcome ever obtained by a foreign statesman in Hungary. When his train reached the frontier the population of the surrounding district gave him a tremendous welcome and at all stations en route to Budapest huge crowds cheered as the train sped past.

WITH GENERAL FRANCO'S FORCES IN THE SUBURBS OF MADRID, Nov. 13. -- The situation on the Madrid front has resolved itself into a temporary stalemate, the duration of which depends on many factors, chiefly the weather, which was worse Wednesday and yesterday, hampering aviation and artillery operations.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13. -- Concentrated buying of wheat futures accredited to Eastern speculators today advanced prices on the Board of Trade a cent a bushel in the early trading, with December touching $1.16 1/4, or within 1 1/8 cents of the best figure of the season.

PARIS, Nov. 13. -- The Chamber of Deputies witnessed today the most violent scene that has occurred there since the riotous days of February, 1934. Members of the extreme Right and Left milled around the tribune, fighting, pushing and shouting until Edouard Herriot, President of the Chamber, suspended the session and cleared the public and press tribunes.

Ira A. Campbell, counsel to the American Steamship Owners Association, told the ship safety conference held yesterday in connection with the third annual maritime ex hibition of the Martime Association of the Port of New York that the new Federal Maritime Commission was acceptable to the shipowners as an instrument for the settlement of the strike.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- The Consumers Power Company of Jackson, Mich., a subsidiary of Commonwealth and Southern Corporation (Delaware), filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a statement for $12,000,000 of first mortgage 3 1/4 per cent bonds, series of 1936, due in 1966. The price to the public and underwriting commissions are to be furnished later by amendment.

Sporting circles are quite anxious to know who will be appointed as commissioner of boxing. Many names are being discussed by the customers of the boxing ring, or squared circle, as to the most competent, most fitted and best adapted for this important position.

Sixto Escobar needed only 1 minute 49 seconds to push the championship aspirations of Carlos (Indian) Quintana, dusky Panamanian challenger for the world's bantamweight championship, into the land of dreams last night.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 13. -- Briefs on a demand for the removal of O.P. Van Sweringen and other officers of the Van Sweringen Corporation and the Cleveland Terminal Building Company are to be submitted Nov. 27 to Charles I. Russe, special master for the United States District Court in the proceedings by which the two companies are seeking reorganization.
LONDON, Nov. 13. -- Financial London was uneasy tonight over news that the Roosevelt administration was considering how to check foreign speculation in American markets.

In the attack on the constitutionality of the New York Unemployment Insurance Act, counsel for the complainants contended that "the law takes the property of one class, the employers, for the benefit of another class, the employes."

More than 500 men of the automotive specialized service industry, which plays an ever-increasing part in keeping the everyday motorist's car running at concert pitch, held a regional meeting and luncheon at the Hotel Astor yesterday. They heard C.C. Carlton, president of the Automotive Parts and Equipment Manufacturers Association and secretary of the Motor Wheel Corporation of Lansing, Mich., urge more intensive organization for safety as a prime requiste of their business.

Although selling from producing sections held prices on the Cotton Exchange within narrow limits yesterday, the market displayed resistance around 11 1/2 cents a pound for the March and May deliveries, and a rally left the list unchanged to 7 points higher than on Thursday.

SHANGHAI, Saturday Nov. 14. -- Charges that three airplanes bombed the town of Pintichuan, Eastern Suiyuan (Inner Mongolia), were contained in official telegrams today from Kweisui, Suiyuan's capital.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 13. -- Mrs. Ernest Hatheway Turnbull of Greenwich won the first prize at a character costume party of the Connecticut pioneer branch of the League of American Pen Women, held at the home of Mrs. Mary Perry King in New Canaan tonight.

New bond financing this week totaled $47,363,000, against only $450,000 placed on the market last week, the smallest volume recorded for such a period in several years. A year ago this week, $41,416,390 of new bonds was offered.

RICHMOND, Nov. 13 (AP). -- Legal complications again balked the removal today of Representative John H. Hoeppel and his son Charles to Washington, where they are under sentences of four months to a year for conspiring to sell an appointment to the Military Academy.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 13. -- A special session of the New Jersey Legislature to act on unemployment insurance will be called by Governor Hoffman unless he receives assurance that the time limit for States to enact statutes complying with the Federal Social Security Act, and thereby receive the benefits of the tax collected in 1937, is extended beyond Dec. 31.

AMHERST vs. WILLIAMS -- A fellow who studies the stars said that Amherst would take this one. He also mentioned casually that the temperature of the sun was 12,000 degrees Fahrenheit. He might have been guessing a little bit. Guessing again, one wispy vote for Williams.

With both teams featuring stalwart defenses, the Brooklyn Prep and Adelphi Academy football squads had to be content with a scoreless tie in their meeting before 2,000 persons at Boys High School Field yesterday.

Army and Notre Dame meet at the Yankee Stadium today and it is the old story. Not a ticket is in sight, speculators along Broadway are asking as high as $40 a pair for choice locations and as close to 80,000 as can squeeze their way in will be on hand when the teams take the field.

Democracy, to continue in this country, requires "a tremendous reorganization" of materials, instruction and administration in the schools, Dr. John Dewey, Professor of Philosophy at Columbia University, told the Eastern States regional meeting of the Progressive Education Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania last night.

LONDON, Nov. 13. -- Twelve huge monoplane airliners, each big enough to seat forty-two passengers and powerful enough to fly 200 miles an hour with a full load, are being built for Imperial Airways to replace 120-mile-an-hour machines now in use on the regular British routes to the Continent and the East.

The proposed removal of the administrative offices of the Board of Education from 500 Park Avenue to the former Elks Club at Livingston and Schermerhorn Streets, Brooklyn, was blocked temporarily yesterday when several members of the Board of Estimate voted against the change.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13. -- Irregularity developed in the market for hogs today, and while sales were generally regarded as steady to 10 cents a hundredweight higher, the main strength was in weights under 170 pounds and on heavy butchers. Some sales of 180 to 230 pound offerings were regarded as 10 to 15 cents lower in the late trading.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 . -- Rexford G. Tugwell, Under-Secretary of Agriculture, head of the Resettlement Administration and original "brain truster," has become the central figure in another undercover fight within the Roosevelt administration revolving around his proposal that the Resettlement agency be permanently incorporated in the set-up of the Department of Agriculture.

Consolidated net income of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company and subsidiaries for the first nine months of this year was $9,940,132, according to a preliminary statement to be made public today. The income, which is after interest, estimated taxes, provision for depreciation, and obsolescence, but before depletion, equals $1.15 each on 8,674,338 shares of capital stock outstanding.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today called for bids to be opened at its offices here on Dec. 1 on fifty-seven issues of 4 per cent securities of municipalities, counties and school districts in nineteen States of an aggregate face amount of $4,133,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 13. -- ''Carmen,'' hardy perennial of the past, is to reach the screen again, this time under the sponsorship of Frank Lloyd of Paramount. He and Scenarist Howard Estabrook conferred with Adolph Zukor today on plans for an elaborate version of the opera, which Lloyd hopes to make following "I, James Lewis."

Following an attempted hold-up by four armed men of a dozen card players in the Novelty Athletic Club at 672 Broadway, Brooklyn, at 12:30 o'clock this morning, Patrolman Mark Mandell, one of the card players, who was off duty and in civilian clothes, chased several men whom he saw running away and shot and killed Norman Dorlich, 18 years old, of 22 Bartlett Street, Brooklyn.

LAKEVILLE, Conn., Nov. 13. -The annual Hill-Hotchkiss football game was played today before 1,500 spectators who braved the cold to see Hill win, 12 to 6, on a muddy field. Neither team had a strong record this season, but, as in most Hill-Hotchkiss games, the teams waged a hard, close battle.

ROME, Nov. 13. -- Abolition of all civil and criminal law courts in Italy has been decided upon by Premier Benito Mussolini, official sources disclosed today. The courts will be replaced by special boards or committees from various divisions of the corporate State, these sources declared.

Announcement was made yesterday that a new ice boat championship trophy had been offered by the Rumson Country Club of Rumson, N.J., competition for which would be open to craft of every description. With it came the word that the club would defend it with two boats, one to be built for E.C. Fiedler, commodore for many years of the Rumson fleet, who owned the champion Drub.

AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 13. -- The appointment of a paid resident manager of fraternities was recommended this morning at the annual meeting of the Amherst College Alumni Council by a committee headed by Richard H. Gregory, '98, of New York, which has been studying the problem of fraternity business management here.
The Emergency Relief Bureau employes' union announced last night that it depended "entirely upon Mayor La Guardia whether there will be a strike of 11,000 persons administering home relief."

There is no situation better calculated to make cynics out of sane people than the current predominance of football in what is supposed to be a higher educational system. It is pretended that football is a sport, when every one knows that it is usually run as a business.

The Park Department's plan for reshaping Inwood Hill Park and Spuyten Duyvil is a matter of deep regret to those who cherish the old traditions of New York and the preservation of historical places. Although rehabilitation may be necessary in the case of unsightly structures that accumulate through the years, it would seem a sacrilege to alter the shoreline so characteristic of the island.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13. -- The Penn varsity 150-pound team defeated the Villanova lightweights in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game on Franklin Field today, 6-0.

Newspaper correspondents in Southeastern Europe still seem to think it necessary to assure the world that a Hapsburg restoration in Austria or Hungary is not among the serious probabilities. The assurance is not needed. It is pretty thoroughly understood that the bogy of Hapsburg restoration is a tattered scarecrow.
A discouraging picture of the fish and game situation in this State was painted last night by Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne in a message to the Genesee Conservation League of Rochester.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had obtained an ex-parte restraining order from Judge Brewster in the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts to prevent eight individuals from alleged manipulation of shares of the Suburban Electric Securities Company on the Boston Stock Exchange.

William McFee, son of a ship's master, nephew of five others, a ship's engineer himself for many years, and a writer of stories of the sea, declared last night there was a dire lack of convincing characterization in American fiction and that a mistaken romantic approach had devitalized the sailor as an individual character.

The transatlantic liner American Farmer of the American Merchant Line sailed on schedule at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon from her pier at West Forty-seventh Street, but was delayed in clearing the port because of the insurgent seamen's strike.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- The weekly statistics of member trading on the New York Stock and New York Curb Exchanges for the week ended Oct. 17 in which there were only five trading days showed a considerable decrease in volume from the preceding week, and in the case of the New York Stock Exchange, where comparative figures were available, decrease in member trading compared to total volume.

ROME, Nov. 13. -- Governmental circles strongly deprecated this evening alarmist reports based by some foreign agencies on the strongly worded attack against Russia that Ambassador Dino Grandi delivered in London yesterday.

Stocks showed a fair degree of steadiness early, then turned irregular, and sold off in the final hour. The closing was lower, with many leading issues down from fractions to 2 points; a few, more than that. The volume of trading on the Stock Exchange was 2,480,000 shares, against 2,482,000 the day before.

Sports writers seem to be eternally digging beneath the surface and suddenly bobbing up with some hitherto undisclosed fact. That is why I am truly amazed that no one as yet has excavated Glen (Judge) Carberry. The ponderous "Judge," I might add, would be quite an excavation, too.

Mr. HOPKINS'S latest report on the relief situation confirms on a national scale what earlier reports have established locally. As a result of the improvement of business and the re-employment of many men in private industry, there has been a substantial reduction of the relief rolls compared with the high point reached some time ago.
Harry F. Wolf of the New York A.C. defeated a clubmate, J.J. Lordi, to gain the semi-final round of the Princeton Club's annual invitation squash tennis tourney yesterday.

A resumption of activity in the market for new State and municipal loans is indicated for next week with scheduled financing of $37,465,000 for two States and forty-one municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $20,383,200 for this week.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 13. -- Alert to capitalize on every break, the Princeton junior varsity football team downed the Yale jayvees, 11 -- 6, on University Field today.

Evidence of a new cooperative spirit between industry and the government, as an aftermath of the recent Presidential election, was seen yesterday in the announcement by the National Association of Manufacturers that its members would cooperate with the administration in ushering in a "new era of good feeling between industry and the government."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- In an informal opinion, Secretary Perkins held today that employe representatives of the workers in the plants of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation were without authority to sign and bind their fellow-workers to the wage-scale agreement proposed by the corporation.

The fight of the trucking industry against the government and nine major Eastern railroads to prevent free store-door pickup and delivery service by the railroads was aired yesterday afternoon before a special statutory court of three Federal judges.

THERE are two ways of enjoying Max Eastman's "Enjoyment of Laughter" (Simon Schuster, $3.75). One is to roll up your sleeves and grapple manfully with the author's theories and explanations. The other is to pass over his theories and explanations in favor of his quotations from such geniuses as Wodehouse, Lardner and Groucho Marx.

While Will Hays is scurrying around Rome trying to arrange dispensations for American film producers from the ruling that not more than a third of a film's earnings may be exported from Italy, the government-subsidized Italian film industry is proceeding with plans to invade the world markets with a filming of the exploits of Scipio Africanus and the defeat of Hannibal.

BERLIN, Nov. 13. -- The Deutsche Allgemeine Zeitung, which continues to enjoy a certain significance as the organ of business interests, takes especial occasion today to draw attention to Italy's confiscation of its citizens' foreign securities holdings during the imposition of sanctions and their repayment in life.

Commodity futures were generally higher in fairly active trading yesterday. Cocoa futures sold at 9 cents a pound for the first time since March, 1930. In the cash markets wheat, corn, rye, oats, cocoa, cotton, eggs, tin, print cloths, silk and rubber were higher, while butter was lower.

Already included in the group of six American artists, work by each of whom occupies an alcove of its own in the exhibition scheduled to remain at the Brooklyn Museum through Nov. 29, Guy Pene DuBois is now paying a concurrent visit to the Kraushaar Gallery, in the Heckscher Building, where his annual one-man show will continue until Nov. 28.

BERWYN, Md., Nov. 13. -- Driving over dirt roads between clusters of half-completed modernistic houses, President Roosevelt viewed for the first time today the government's $9,600,000 experiment near here in creating a model community.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses received a gold medal yesterday morning as "the ideal civic leader" at a special assembly in Richmond Hill High School, Eighty-ninth Avenue and 114th Street, Richmond Hill, Queens. Mr. Moses was chosen by vote of the membership of Arista, the honor society of the school. The presentation was made by Vincent Coen.
Appearing and vanishing in phantom-like fashion, a robber stole $2,350 at 2 P.M. yesterday, causing excitement at Broadway and Washington Place.

Judge George L. Donnellan, in approving a not-guilty verdict yesterday afternon in the trial of two Negroes in General Sessions on a first-degree murder indictment, denounced police brutality in the arrest of the defendants. It was charged during the trial that the police had beaten them unmercifully to force them to make false confessions that they had killed Morris Flores, a city marshal, last July 23 in his office at 149 East 121st Street.

The junior class dance, the formal event which annually follows the Syracuse-Columbia football game, will be held this evening at Columbia in John Jay Hall, which will be decorated in orange and black, the colors of the up-state college.

The writing of new life insurance last month was 1.3 per cent less than in October a year ago, while the total for the first ten months this year was 2.1 per cent, correspondingly under 1935, according to the Association of Life Insurance Presidents in a report to the United States Department of Commerce.

Two new highway and parkway projects of the Long Island State Park Commission, one giving New York City motorists a direct connection with Southern State Parkway in Nassau County and the other leading from Southern State Parkway to Bethpage State Park will be opened today by the State Park Commission.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 18. -- Gouverneur Morris, novelist, and his wife, officials of the District Attorney's office said tonight, will appear tomorrow to make voluntary statements concerning the death of Reid Russell, 28, whose body was found on the grounds of Mr. Morris's beach home last Sept. 25.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13. -- A sales promotion program should be designed to build quality business, according to W.T. Plogsterth of the Lincoln National Life Insurance Company, who addressed the Life Advertisers Association session here today. Improvement in the quality of business means higher agency profits, lower mortality and greater incentives for agents.

The New York University football team meets one of its oldest rivals this afternoon when it clashes with Rutgers at the Polo Grounds. It will be the seventh game of the season for the home team and the thirty-fourth contest in the series between the teams.

ANDOVER, Mass., Nov. 13. -Fully determined to keep their unbeaten, untied and unscored-upon record unmarred and become the first Andover gridiron combination to have a perfect slate, the Blue's football forces terminated their preparations for tomorrow's traditional game with Exeter on Brothers Field by engaging in a short drill on the same turf today.

NANKING, China, Saturday, Nov. 14. -- Reports have been received here from Tokyo of the conclusion of a Japanese-German accord. They follow rumors of negotiations which have trickled into Nanking from time to time, but representatives of both nations, when questioned by the government, have given flat denials.

While pedestrians scurried into doorways for cover, a patrolman chased an alleged Negro robber along the west side of Seventh Avenue, between 111th and ll2th Streets, last evening and fired two bullets at him, one lodging in the Negro's right hip and the other slightly wounding a 60-yealold woman pedestrian.

The statement of President Roosevelt in Washington yesterday that the Federal Reserve authorities were studying the need of legislation to control foreign buying of American securities was received with mixed feelings by the Wall Street community.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 13. -- Jascha Heifetz, violinist, was enthusiastically received tonight by an audience of 2,500 when he appeared as the second attraction in the seventh season of artistic presentations at the County Center by Mrs. Julian Olney.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- Steel workers' representatives opposing a proposal by the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation to fluctuate wages with living costs were encouraged today by an expression from President Roosevelt.

Down through the years the English-speaking peoples have maintained a delicate balance that has been of grave importance in the lives of all men. The English political instinct to achieve a balance of power among the struggling nations -- a balance that has often worked out mastery, but nevertheless a mastery far more impersonal and generous in their records than any other victor race.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 13. -- Arrangements for a boxing bout between James J. Braddock, world heavyweight champion, and Joe Louis in Atlantic City's Convention Hall the night of Feb. 22 were "99 1/2 per cent settled" tonight.

I have just read the letter of Emily G. Balch in THE TIMES urging intervention by this country in Spain. Its author is motivated by the most valid reason for action possible -- sympathy for the suffering of fellow-beings.

Prep school elevens on the Eastern front will stage their final busy Saturday program today, and then scholastic football virtually will have been concluded for the season. Holding the spotlight is the game between Exeter and Andover at Andover, Mass.

The decision of the American Distilling Company to use newspapers exclusively for its Old American Brand whiskies, has been "thoroughly justified," Russell Brown, president of the company, reported yesterday, after a month's intensive advertising campaign in 233 cities.

Mr. JOHN LEWIS, the ambitious labor and political leader, has flatly ordered the steel workers and the automobile workers not to accept the bonuses and increased wages which have been offered them by their employers. He evidently regards these betterments as designed to head off his own plans for industrial unions.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 13. -- The opening feature on Yale's ninety-four-event indoor sports schedule, announced today, will be the game with the St. Nicholas hockey team of New York here on Dec. 5. The event has become a tradition with both teams, extending back some thirty seasons.

Columbia and Syracuse, football rivals since the turn of the century, will face each other in their sixteenth meeting at 2 P.M. today at Baker Field. Interest in the contest has been increasing during the past few days, and a crowd of 20,000 is expected to attend.

At the age of 81 Mrs. ANNA AGNESE has arrived from her home on the beautiful if volcanic island of Ischia, near Naples, to visit her descendants in New York City. Second, third and fourth generation, they number more than twoscore.

Unbridled exuberance and excess of youthful vitality gave plenty of excitement to the playing heard from Samuel Carmell, a native New York violinist, at his debut recital in Town Hall last night. The strenuousness and animation of his performances roused the large audience to frequent outbursts of enthusiasm, but the unflagging energy and rhapsodical wildness of much of this playing often worked with detrimental effect, resulting in decided unevenness.
OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 13 (AP). -- H.H. Michels, a partner in William Cavalier Co., issued a statement tonight denying he was connected with any pool operations in Atlas Tack or any other stock.

With the opening of two more playgrounds in the Bronx this week the number of public playgrounds in New York has been increased during the present administration by 186. Here is another of the good uses of adversity. Until now this metropolis developed almost as if it had no children.

ALBANY, Nov. 13. -- A decision of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals is not binding upon the courts of this State, the Appellate Division, Third Department, has held in a case in which Justice Christopher J. Heffernan wrote a brief opinion.

Directors of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company declared yesterday an extra dividend of 50 cents in addition to a quarterly disbursement of 37 1/2 cents a share. Both are payable on Dec. 24 to stockholders of record of Nov. 30. On June 30, the company paid a dividend of 25 cents and on Sept. 30 one of 37 1/2 cents.

When the Republican State Committee meets on Dec. 14 to select a new State chairman to succeed Melvin C. Eaton, a resolution will be offered setting up an executive committee consisting of regional directors, it was learned yesterday.
From my experience it would appear that the management of the Yankee Stadium has learned nothing from the scandalous handling of tickets that brought such poor support to the spoken drama.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- Prudential Investors, Inc., of New York, an investment trust sponsored by J. Henry Schroder Co., Tucker, Anthony Co. and Laird, Bissell Meeds, the last two New York Stock Exchange houses, disclosed its operations to the Securities and Exchange Commission today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- President Roosevelt today proclaimed Nov. 26 as Thanksgiving Day with a message to the public in which he relegated the depression to the past.

The extent of present unemployment that is caused by technological factors is still a matter of dispute, but at least there has been a diminution in the number of those who believe that the unemployment caused by the introduction of labor-saving machinery is permanent in nature.

Attendance for the first two days at the special General Motors show on the ballroom floor of the Waldorf-Astoria was 50 per cent greater than on the same days last year. Yesterday, the third of the show, which will continue free each day until midnight through next Wednesday, visitors continued to throng the aisles about the 1937 motor cars and the associated exhibits.

BERLIN, Nov. 13. -- Another official German philippic against the "folly, stupidity and egoism" of the creditor powers, especially France, Great Britain and the United States, was delivered today before the congress of public accountants and business trustees at Weimar.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 13 (AP). -- A nationwide improvement in general business conditions, an almost universal "pick-up" in employment, and higher prices for farm products are reasons given for average increases of 5.8 per cent in the country's retail store collections and 14.1 per cent in credit sales for October, as compared with the same month a year ago.

Organized labor in New York City pledged its cooperation yesterday to the postal authorities and the Social Security Board in the distribution of millions of social security registration forms beginning on Monday.
VATICAN CITY, Nov. 13 (AP). -- In "buoyant spirits," Pope Pius XI spoke for a full hour today, quieting rumors of mounting feebleness and serious illness.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- The Department of Commerce made public tonight the text of two letters written by President Roosevelt praising the celebration of the 100th anniversary of the American patent system, which is to take the form of dinners in large cities on Nov. 23.

By adopting a rezoning plan for the West Side covering, generally, the district from Fourteenth to Fifty-ninth Street and from Seventh to Tenth Avenue, the Board of Estimate yesterday brought that area into conformity with business and residential trends which have been the subject of a four-year study by the West Side Association of Commerce.

Jacob J. Lesser, attorney, of 70 Pine Street, whose wide experience in bankruptcy practice was cited here by Republican leaders as a qualification when he was a candidate for appointment to the Federal bench in 1924 and 1929, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury for concealing assets of $30,000 from a receiver in bankruptcy.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 13 (AP). -- Upton Sinclair said today that President Roosevelt assigned Los Angeles Secret Service men to protect him because of an assassination threat when he was the Democratic nominee for Governor in 1934.
ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 13. -- The favored Dartmouth Indians headed for Watkins Glen tonight as their gridiron foes of tomorrow, Cornell, drilled under floodlights on Schoellkopf Field.

Aside from the routine departure of "The Gondoliers," the evening's only closing so far is that of "Plumes in the Dust." Its withdrawal from the Forty-sixth Street Theatre leaves Arthur Hopkins without further plans for the immediate season.

GENEVA, Nov. 13. -- The first big world labor conference to be held in the United States since the International Labor Organization was organized there in 1919, will be held about April 5 in Washington for the textile industry, it was announced here today by the I.L.O. governing body.
ROME, Nov. 13. -- According to unconfirmed reports, several important changes in the highest governmental posts and the Fascist party are about to be announced.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. Nov. 13. -- Four Negroes, including a former Newark policeman, were arrested tonight and held for investigation in the fatal shooting early today of John Fleming, 62 years old, watchman and special policeman.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 13 (AP). -- James M. Hutton Sr., head of W.E. Hutton Co., the brokerage firm charged by the Securities and Exchange Commission with manipulating Atlas Tack stock, issued a denial of the charges late today.

Business conditions and market potentials were regarded as more important factors influencing sales than salesmen's ability by an audience of business men at the marketing conference of the American Management Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 13. -- The invention of a preparation from the whites of eggs that, when injected, reduces the clotting time of the blood is declared here to have brought a considerable advance in the treatment of haemophilia, or susceptibility to profuse bleeding.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- The fiscal agencies of the government at the direct order of President Roosevelt, undertook today studies of legislation to protect exchange rates and domestic markets from possible demoralizing effects in the event that foreign investors, who have poured about $7,000,000,000 into the United States, should decide upon sudden withdrawals of large sums.
The Book Fair at the International Building, Rockefeller Center, will open at 10 A.M. today and one of the fullest programs yet arranged has been scheduled.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Nov. 13. -- Two New Yorkers, Frank J. Marshall, former United States champion, and Isaac I. Kashdan, holder of the New York State championship, were the first to win their games as the international chess masters' tournament got under way today at the Club Nautico.
Of high value is Arthur Krock's advocacy of extending the Presidential term to six years, with no re-election.

TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 13 (AP). -- The metal trades department of the American Federation of Labor proposed today to expel John L. Lewis's ten "rebel" unions of the Committee for Industrial Organization. Simultaneously, President William Green predicted the Lewis revolt would collapse completely.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- An upward trend in exports of American rubber manufactures was reported today by the Department of Commerce, shipments for the first nine months this year being valued at S17,531,000, compared to $16,369,676 during the corresponding period last year.

A Fordham eleven schooled in Notre Dame football used Pittsburgh plays yesterday and found the strange combination highly agreeable. In their sixth successive victory in two years the Maroon yearlings concluded their second unbeaten season with a 30-to-0 triumph over the Bergen County Junior College forces at Fordham Field.

A picturesque scene revivifying episodes at the court of Catherine the Great in eighteenth-century Russia was staged last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza, where the ninth annual Russian Students Ball was given for the benefit of the Russian Alumni and Students Association.

It was Trailer Day at the National Automobile Show in the Grand Central Palace yesterday and the largest number of visitors since the opening last Wednesday passed through the doors. Most of them went to the fourth floor, where the trailers are on display, and spent hours inspecting the fifty houses on wheels.

LONDON, Nov. 13. -- After having reiterated that British policy was to promote foreign trade through bilateral agreements, Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, told the House of Commons yesterday that he intended to keep in touch with the United States, France and other governments to seize any opportunities that might arise.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 13. -For the sixtieth time in the past sixty-two years the football teams of Yale and Princeton will face each other tomorrow in Palmer Stadium, and this afternoon the actors and their tutors were putting the finishing touches to the setting which will bring to this picturesque little town its biggest crowd in years.

Department store trade here this week was the best for any similar period in months, possibly since Easter, retail executives said yesterday. Estimates put average sales increases for the week at 20 to 25 per cent above the comparative 1935 week, with some stores here having gains up to 40 per cent.

Two men charged with having received thousands of dollars' worth of goods from local and out-of-town manufacturers without payment by representing that they were buyers for 200 or more concerns were seized in the District Attorney's office on charges of grand larceny last night.

Profit-taking on a somewhat broad scale, in all classes of domestic loans yesterday halted the spectacular advance in the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange. United States Government and other high-grade investments, as well as the more speculative railroad and corporate loans yielded to the readjustment in values, although, in the former list, trading appeared to diminish on the downside and the Treasury group, as a whole, closed mixed.

The new Bible House, Park Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, the home of the American Bible Society, will hold dedicatory exercises through next week. The dedication proper will take place tomorrow at 3 P.M. The president of the board of managers, John T. Manson, will preside, and Dr. William Mather Lewis, president of Lafayette College, Easton, Pa., will discuss "The Bible and Modern Problems."

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 13. -- Memory Book and Jean Bart, two 3-year-olds which early in the season were considered potential champions, will be the main contenders tomorrow in the featured Prince George Autumn Handicap at a mile and a sixteenth.

LONDON, :Nov. 13. -- Winston Churchill's demand on the government last night to create a parliamentary commission representing all parties to inquire into the rearmament situation will be ignored by Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin unless circumstances force him into the admission that his present defense policy is inadequate.

A decided forward movement occurred in nearly all trade branches this week, with the volume of retail sales for the country as a whole being estimated at 15 to 25 per cent over the total for the corresponding period last year, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

No one will look for hidden motives in the award of the Nobel Prize to EUGENE O'NEILL. He deserves it. Although American playgoers have had to bear with him during two or three periods of transition, and have had to suffer two or three disastrous plays from his pen, he has long dominated our theatre on the basis of vigorous work performed.

BERLIN, Nov. 13. -- Trading on the Boerse continued stagnant today, with a tendency to weakness demonstrating the general atmosphere varying between nervousness and listlessness. The market was dominated by numerous seemingly well-founded rumors of new restrictions on foreign stock holdings, or even the enforced surrender of such holdings and the exclusion of most foreign securities from trading.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- A registration statement covering issues aggregating $44,500,000 was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Securities Act of 1933 by the Oklahoma Gas and Electric Company of Oklahoma City.

Frieda Hempel, concert singer and former Metropolitan Opera star, won from the Appellate Division yesterday an order requiring August Heckscher, 88-year-old philanthropist and real estate owner, to continue to pay her $15,000 a year for the rest of her life.

Every people, of course, has its "tradition"; but the stress laid by critics and historians upon the continuity of the French tradition in painting seems a little more emphatic than that which has been made to apply elsewhere, unless perhaps to English art.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Nov. 13. -Peddie's team of opportunists, supplementing its alertness with a powerhouse attack, subdued a courageous Blair eleven today by a score of 19 -- 7 in a bitterly fought game on Alumni Field before a crowd of nearly 4,000 spectators.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13. -- Justice Brandeis was described today as "one of the really significant men in American history and perhaps the most significant since Lincoln," in an address by Dean Leon Green of Northwestern University Law School, before the Chicago Bar Association.

Mr. and Mrs. Stuart G. Gibboney entertained with a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Mr. and Mrs. Edwin A. Stillman, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Ennis, Mr. and Mrs. Oscar E. Stevens, Mr. and Mrs. Oswald Jimenis, Mrs. Joseph Hewitt, Mrs. Douglas Campbell, Lamar Hardy and Lister Chambers.

A heavy raccoon coat saved Miss Helen Lantz, 29 years old, of 6,819 Seventh Avenue, Brooklyn, from serious injury yesterday when she was wounded in the abdomen by Carl Hermanson, 42-year-old merchant marine officer, as she crossed Thirty-fourth Street near Twelfth Avenue.

Apparently quite unsurfeited by two days of opportunity to look and listen, crowds in such numbers as to make it difficult to get around the exhibits attended yesterday the special showing of Ford V-8, Lincoln Zephyr and Lincoln motor cars, staged by the Ford Motor Company in the grand ballroom and adjacent salons of the Hotel Astor. They found some added displays to enlist their further interest.

LONDON, Nov. 13 (AP). -- "Aunt Bessie" Merryman has come to London to chaperon her niece, Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson, during the six-month period until Mrs. Simpson's divorce becomes final, it was disclosed tonight.

MADRAS, India, Nov. 13. -- The 24-year-old Maharajah of Travancore struck a blow at the ancient caste system of India today by decreeing that none of his 4,000,000 subjects should be barred from State temples hereafter for reasons of "birth, caste or community."

Thousands of fans develop eye (and mental) strain during the football season in an attempt to determine the betting odds on various games. Therefore, many of them probably would like to know the general method employed by bookmakers in fixing their odds and, accordingly, I here have set down a few notes on that subject.

The two letters in your issue of Nov. 10 headed "Mr. Farley's Reassurance" seem to me to have missed the point. F.G. Brown asks: "How dare Mr. Farley even whisper that none who opposed Mr. Roosevelt need fear 'reprisals' * * * or even to hint that there may be any 'reprisal' for his opinion?"

Three Masonic lodges in Massachusetts will receive a total of more than $150,000 from the estate of George F. Upham of Bronxville, who died Nov. 20, 1935, according to the transfer tax appraisal, filed yesterday. The estate was appraised at $214,883 gross and $202,680 net.

The Bronx was the leading borough in new construction projected yesterday when architects filed plans for housing operations to cost close to $1,000,000. One structure, a twelve-story apartment in Kappock Street, will cost $800,000. A Boston Road theatre to cost $160,000 also was projected.

Feline pets whose fur was so thick and soft that they felt like feather pillows were displayed yesterday at the final session of the annual championship cat show held at the Hotel Pennsylvania by the Empire Cat Club in conjunction with the Siamese Cat Society of America.

Plans for a hall for municipal exhibits at the New York World's Fair of 1939, to provide several acres of floor area and to be built at a cost estimated at more than $1,000,000 so that the structure may be converted later into a recreation center were announced yesterday by Park Commissioner Robert Moses.
Housing and business property deals in the Bronx and Manhattan were reported yesterday.
The Board of Estimate voted unanimously yesterday to cut the bills of Hiram C. Todd and J. Edward Lumbard Jr. for their work in the Drukman murder investigation in Brooklyn from $104,123 to $42,000.

Stanley Galowin, New York University junior who won last season, became one of two to enter the third round as the Eastern Squash Racquets Association's amateur tournament got under way yesterday on the New York A.C. courts with an entry of forty-two.

The International Paper and Power Company contemplates the scrapping of idle properties in such measure as will mean a material writing down of property account, with a corresponding charge to be made to surplus at the end of the year, Richard J. Cullen, president, announced yesterday in a quarterly earnings statement.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 13. -- Conceding that many Westchester election inspectors did not follow the letter of the law and asserting that the "sloppy" handling of the returns was due to the large number of women inspectors, William D. Cunningham, counsel for Surrogate George A. Slater, agreed in Supreme Court today to a partial recount of the Surrogate vote.
The Board of Estimate voted unanimously yesterday to cut the bills of Hiram C. Todd and J. Edward Lumbard Jr. for their work in the Drukman murder investigation in Brooklyn from $104,123 to $42,000.

Stanley Galowin, New York University junior who won last season, became one of two to enter the third round as the Eastern Squash Racquets Association's amateur tournament got under way yesterday on the New York A.C. courts with an entry of forty-two.

Manhattan's football team will pit its new-found power against the undefeated record of Georgetown today at Ebbets Field. The keen spirit of rivalry that prevails between the institutions, which are meeting for the fourth time, is expected to bring forth a crowd of 20,000.

Tomorrow in the churches will be marked by observance of anniversaries of parishes and of pastors and the celebration of anniversaries of leaders in church history and current life. There will be in some churches a commemoration of the life and ideals of Desiderius Erasmus, the four-hundredth anniversary of whose death is being observed.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- The text of the order of the Securities and Exchange Commission in the case of W.E. Hutton Co. is as follows:

Winfield W. Greene, president of the Casualty Actuarial Society, recommended a balance between private enterprise and governmental regulation in the insurance and other fields in an address yesterday at the annual meeting of that organization, held in the Hotel Biltmore.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 13. -- The Federal Communications Commission has no power to regulate exchange service even across State lines and is limited in jurisdiction to interstate toll service, according to a paper by Floyd L. Bollen, utilities commissioner of Nebraska, read at today's session of the forty-eighth annual convention of the National Association of Railroad and Utilities Commissioners.

"The income to the poultry farmers in this State is exceeded only by income of the dairy farmers, who represent the largest annual revenue-producing line of agriculture in New York State, as well as in the entire United States," Peter G. Ten Eyck, State Commissioner of Markets, said yesterday at a luncheon of the Northeastern Poultry Producers Council in the Hotel New Yorker.
