WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- Something new in orchestral arrangement, one in which a leading philharmonic orchestra will play "The Accompaniment for the Myriad of Sounds That Come From the Production of an American Motor Car," will be tried out here on Nov. 23 in connection with the centennial celebration of the patent system of the United States.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Nov. 13. -- Mr. and Mrs. John Sloane of 48 East Ninety-second Street, New York, gave a small dance tonight at Pastureland, their home here, for their daughter, Miss Grace Elsie Sloane, and members of the younger set.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- Plans for a seaplane base 1,200 feet square and eight feet deep in the harbor at Midway Island, about 1,200 miles west of Hawaii, were approved today by Major General Edward M. Markham, Chief of Engineers, in a report sent to Chairman Mansfield of the House Rivers and Harbors Committee.

The International Paper and Power Company contemplates the scrapping of idle properties in such measure as will mean a material writing down of property account, with a corresponding charge to be made to surplus at the end of the year, Richard J. Cullen, president, announced yesterday in a quarterly earnings statement.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 13. -- Conceding that many Westchester election inspectors did not follow the letter of the law and asserting that the "sloppy" handling of the returns was due to the large number of women inspectors, William D. Cunningham, counsel for Surrogate George A. Slater, agreed in Supreme Court today to a partial recount of the Surrogate vote.
EASTON, Pa., Nov. 14. -- Spectacular running by Teddy Mazza and the superb forward passing of Marvin Haney enabled Moravian to upset Ernie Nevers's Lafayette Leopards today, 28 -- 7.

Coupled with the Postoffice Department's annual appeal for early Christmas mailing, announcement was made yesterday by Harllee Branch, Second Assistant Postmaster General, of the latest closing dates for mail intended for delivery in foreign countries before Christmas Day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- Representatives of the governments, employers and workers in at least twelve foreign countries are expected to attend the international conference on the textile industry which the International Labor Office yesterday voted to hold in the United States next April, Secretary Perkins said today.

Obsessed, according to their distracted parents, with the idea of becoming Texas Rangers, and of wearing the clothes such gentlemen are accustomed to wear in the movies, three Brooklyn boys disappeared from their homes Friday night and have not been seen since.

At the Palazzo Venezia, in Rome, on March 17, 1934, Benito Mussolini, the late Engelbert Dollfuss, then Chancellor of Austria, and the late Julius Goemboes, then Premier of Hungary, signed three important agreements. The Rome protocols, as the documents are called, contained two main provisions.

THE New School Chorus is examining unpublished choral works by American composers with a view to performance at its Spring concert. Arthur Leif, director of the ensemble, is receiving the manuscripts.

BARRING accidents, Jan. 1 should find the George S. Kaufman-Moss Hart "You Can't Take It With You" well launched on its Broadway life and, indeed, should see Mr. Hart settled in Hollywood for sixteen weeks of film writing.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 14. -- Trinity overwhelmed a hopelessly outclassed Norwich University eleven today, 60 -- 0. Captain Kobrosky, elusive Trinity halfback, raced for half the length of the field for Trinity's first score on the second play of the game, and tallied five times before the game ended.

To inaugurate a widespread campaign for funds through increased membership and special contributions. The Seeing Eye will hold two meetings here this week in the interests of the important as well as unique service for the blind which is directed by that appropriately named organization.

The trucking industrial lost yesterday its eight-month fight on two fronts to prevent the Interstate Commerce Commission, railroads and steamship lines from giving free store door pick-up and delivery service to merchants on less-than-carload shipments.

Nineteen out of thirty-six departments in local department stores showed increased use of advertising space during October, according to the "breakdown" issued yesterday by Media Records. A total of 3,980,569 lines was used during the month, against 3,821,463 lines in the same month of 1935.

TOTAL number of trucks which will be produced and sold in the United States for all of this year should be at least 830,000 units, in contrast with the 694,690 in 1935, it is estimated by Joseph D. Burke, director of truck and commercial car sales for the Dodge Division of Chrysler Corporation.

It rather amused me, in reading L. Effingham De Forest's letter in THE TIMES recently, to note that he begins his comment by offering the opinion that a new and revised chronology of important events in New York City's history "is rather unnecessary," and then, about ten lines further down, states that "in the last twenty years the history of this city has been largely rewritten," while much new material has been added.

BOSTON, Nov. 13. SO FAR as Boston is concerned, the combination of Beatrice Lillie, Bert Lahr and Reginald Gardiner in Vincente Minnelli's new revue, "The Show Is On," seems as lusty a success at the box office as it is on the stage.

CAMPAMENTO, Spain, Nov. 14 (AP). -- Daring bands of "Red raiders," as they are called by the Insurgents, harassed Insurgent war lines today. In lightning thrusts, small parties supported by tanks flung themselves forward in sporadic attacks.

YEAR by year New York motorists are finding it easier to escape the hustle and bustle of city streets and to reach the many resorts that lie within or just outside the metropolitan area. Steadily existing roads are being improved, new ones are being built and beaches, parks and mountain playgrounds are becoming more accessible.

The Public Education Association, in cooperation with thirty-seven public service organizations, is sponsoring a luncheon discussion of "The School Child and His Health" on Tuesday at the Hotel Commodore. The speakers will include Dr. Howard W. Haggard of Yale University, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools; Health Commissioner Rice and Dr. Louis I. Dublin of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- The red letter day on the calendar of local visiting sportsmen has dawned. The season for many kinds of game opens with unusually good prospects. For the next five days, however, only deer will be deemed worthy of consideration.

TO mark the completion of his first twenty-one years of publishing. Alfred A. Knopf will issue on Dec. 1 an omnibus volume containing some of the most notable works of fiction and non-fiction published by his house.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 14. -- Some of the motion picture magnates who are always seeking a scenario with a thrilling climax should have been at Princeton today.

VIENNA, Nov. 13. -- It is too early to say anything concerning any startling decisions taken at the Vienna conference of the Foreign Ministers of the Rome bloc -- Italy, Austria and Hungary -- except that if there were any their secret has been well kept.

The belief of Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, president of the University of Chicago, on higher education, as set forth in his book "Higher Learning in America," that the curriculum and not the individual student was the important item in education, was scored by Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase of New York University last night.

CARNEGIE HALL, having arrived at the venerable age of forty-five years, must have a history. The hundredth anniversary of the birth of Andrew Carnegie determines this as an appropriate time for the publication of this book.

THE Poet Laureate is nominally a member of the King's household, and his office is among those that fall under the administration of the Lord Chamberlain He is commonly supposed to have fulfilled all the duties required of him when he has written odes or other suitable verses in celebration of events intimately associated with the royal family.

IT is hard to tell, in the case of this beautifully illustrated and printed book, whether it is the pictures or the text that ought to be reviewed first. The reproductions of Mr. Baldridge's paintings are, at any rate, fairly breath-taking, and his forceful and animated sketches fairly besprinkle the text of Miss Singer -- who is also Mrs. Baldridge.

LONDON, Nov. 11. -- The London theatrical season, already off to an auspicious start, continues with the promise of several eagerly awaited offerings. At the Savoy on Thursday, Constance Cummings returns to the London stage by playing the lead in "Young Madame Conti," a melodrama adapted from Bruno Frank's play by Hubert Griffith and Benn W. Levy.

In American politics this is axiomatic: A first-term President works for re-election, a second-term President works to establish his place in history. Our re-elected President's place in the history of last week concerns various matters, four of them outstanding.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Nov. 14. -- In answer to the demand for expert training aroused by widespread interest in choral speaking and speech correction, Mount Holyoke College will sponsor a Coeducational Summer School in Speech here in the Summer.

Eight of the fifteen known paintings by Georges de La Tour, court painter to Louis XIII of France, arrived in this country yesterday. One was brought from Germany on the liner Hamburg. The remaining seven arrived on the United States liner George Washington.

BALDWIN, L.I., Nov. 14. -- Displaying one of the finest aerial attacks ever seen on a schoolboy gridiron in these parts, an alert Baldwin High School eleven turned a closely fought thriller into a rout to vanquish Hempstead High, 19 to 6, before 6,000 spectators today.

Handiwork and artcraft novelties from many nationalities will be offered for sale at gayly decorated booths at the annual International Bazaar which opens Thursday afternoon at the International Institute of the Young Women's Christion Association, 341 East Seventeenth Street, and will continue there through Saturday evening.

DALLAS, Nov. 14 (AP). -- Long-legged Jack Robbins and his bold Arkansas Razorbacks made the fall of mighty Southern Methodist complete today with a 17-0 rout that rocketed them into temporary leadership in the Southwest Conference.

BERLIN, Nov. 14. -- The Boerse today was even more than yesterday dominated by possibly exaggerated but in any case vigorously discussed rumors of new restrictions on trading in foreign stocks and the possibility that such stocks would be confiscated by the government against payment in some sort of Reichsmark treasury certificates.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 13. -- Chastened Townsend plan leaders -- none more so than the Long Beach doctor himself -- this week began picking up the pieces of a movement that had claimed 650,000 adherents in California alone and 12,000,000 in the nation.

DETROIT, Nov. 13. -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin's announcement of the suspension of his National Union for Social Justice has not greatly changed the picture in the business offices of the Shrine of the Little Flower, in Royal Oak. A flock of secretaries is still attending to mail that pours in.

THE position of extraordinary favor held by Francis Augustus MacNutt at the Papal Court, even from the time of his first appearances there when he was still a young man, was certain to antagonize powerful laymen who resented this American in their midst.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Nov. 14. -- Clearing up a 25-year-old misunderstanding, the Appellate Division handed down an opinion today that public intoxication was a crime.

Adoption of "round-number" price points by garment manufacturers-$11 and $17, instead of $10.75, $16.75, , as at present -- may be necessary in order to enable the women's apparel industries to defray the social security taxes, according to Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Coat, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- Preparations are being made in the Poconos for the entertainment of a large crowd over Thanksgiving Day. Family parties will be one of the features at the Buck Hill Falls, where Thanksgiving dinners will be served in family style.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 14. -- The Upsala eleven defeated Juniata at Viking Field today, winning by a 13-6 score for the second successive week. A lateral-forward pass that gained forty-five yards and took Tortorella over gave Upsala a touchdown in the first quarter, with Wilson converting on a drop kick.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 14. -- Pistols were drawn by Princeton University undergraduates in 1859 in the course of a stormy meeting for the election of junior orators, according to an account of college life contained in a student's letter which has just been presented to the university library.
THOSE who eavesdropped on the Old World's long waves on Armistice Day in 1918 and on the European short waves on the eighteenth anniversary of that event heard quite a different "song."

A proposal that the government should retire from the lending field by disposing of a large part of its current assets to the banks and using the proceeds to retire an equal amount of government debt, was advanced last week by J. Herbert Case, formerly chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and now a partner in R.W. Pressprich Co.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- This business of political press agentry, contrary, perhaps, to the general impression, is neither inspirational nor deeply subtle. It is wholly opportunistic. Hence no all-embracing rules can be laid down, for very campaign presents a different front, and that front is likely to change from day to day.

PEIPING, Nov. 14. -- The United States Embassy ordered an investigation today of the death of an American missionary in North China and a survey of reported fighting in the area allegedly invaded by Japanese troops.

DAY by day, as we explore the turbulent channels of film reviewing, we are impressed by the fact that pictures succeed as much by their omissions as their commissions. Avoidance of the obvious, whether in plot or dialogue, direction or performance, may be a negative virtue, but it must be regarded as a positive asset to any picture.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP). -- A smiling friar of the Franciscan Order returned happily to his monastic life today after a brief sortie into court-room atmosphere he formerly knew well.

THE nation's Gilbert and Sullivan fans will pay their respects this week to the memory of Sir William S. Gilbert, born a century ago, on Nov. 18, 1836, in London. Thousands of enthusiasts in all parts of the country, including a large contingent of collectors of Gilbert and Sullivan mementos, count themselves among the admirers of the great librettist and his equally famous collaborator, Sir Arthur Sullivan.

The Henrietta Wells Livermore School of Politics of the Women's National Republican Club will start its eleventh season this month. The sessions, which take place Monday mornings at 11 o'clock and are open to all Republican women, will begin tomorrow under the leadership of Mrs. Henry R. Caraway, president of the club.

NORTON, Mass., Nov. 14. -- Closer cooperation between town and gown is sought constantly at Wheaton College, where new projects for mutual college and community benefit are being carried out this year.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 14. -- Fullback Simpson's accuracy at place-kicking for an extra point gave the University of Kentucky Wildcats a 7-6 victory over the Clemson College eleven today before 8,000.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Nov. 14. -- Exceptionally lenient sentences were passed at Kerestinec yesterday after a five-week hearing of the charges against twenty-eight peasants accused of having played prominent parts in a massacre there early this year.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 14. -- Regular political workers and an army of citizens new to the local political field are mustering their forces for a show-down on the question of a city manager government for this city at a special election Thursday.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 14 (AP). -- Playing brilliant offensive football, Marquette's undefeated and untied eleven swept to a 33-to-0 victory over Mississippi in the final home game today before 17,000.

IF America should erect a monument to corn on the cob, Boston baked beans, or buckwheat cakes, that would be the equivalent of what France has done for her gastronomic specialities. Like other countries, France is punctuated with religious, patriotic and literary shrines, but she is virtually alone in creating memorials to good things to eat, such as foiegras, Camembert cheese, and Peach Melba.

There is a story by Andersen about "The Galoshes of Fortune" which had the power of instantly transporting any one who put them on to the place where he desired to be. Looking at Rex Whistler's illustrations for this new edition of "Fairy Tales and Legends," we are tempted to believe that the artist has managed to get hold of these same galoshes, and has journeyed straight back to Andersen's own day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP). -- A "profit" of $100,000,000 or more may be realized by the Treasury this fiscal year, officials said today, from the unemployment insurance tax under the Social Security Act.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- Budget-making was the chief business of government this week for the President, the acting director of the budget, and heads of administrative departments.

The military ball for the benefit of the Holy Trinity Chapel at West Point, N.Y., was held last night in the Belvedere Room of the Astor. The event, held in connection with the Army-Notre Dame football game, was attended by representative groups from the military academy and the university.

Once more we meet Inspector Cuthbert Higgins of Scotland Yard. Higgins is no miracle worker; he frequently makes mistakes and as frequently curses his own dumbness. But he keeps on, and eventually he gets his man. The present story has complications enough to give any policeman a good excuse for blundering.

The second annual metropolitan coin exhibition was opened yesterday with a private view for the exhibitors on the seventh floor of the British Empire Building in Rockefeller Center. The exhibition will be open every day this week to the public, beginning at 10 o'clock tomorrow morning.

Despite the jeremiads of college presidents who fear that present tax policy is operating to reduce colleges' income by drying up sources of large gifts, colleges and universities generally report increasing prosperity. Last year 300 of them in all parts of the country averaged 12.6 per cent more receipts than in 1933-34, according to a survey just completed by the United States Office of Education.

A mock tragedy of a torn judicial robe was unfolded in Harlem Court yesterday forenoon by Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio for twenty-five Barnard College girls who visited the court in connection with their college course on studies in American city government.

Cardinal Hayes, Bishop William T. Manning, Rabbi Stephen S. Wise and Charles H. Tuttle, president of the Greater New York Federation of Churches, have individually endorsed the campaign which the Big Sisters recently launched for the purpose of raising $50,000.
GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 14. -- Mrs. R. Lawrence Oakley is chairman for the junior informal dance to be given at the Round Hill Club on Dec. 29.

THE gentlemen -- and ladies -- of Washington's thronging bureaucracies passed a pleasant election evening. They gathered at one another's homes, at their clubs, at their favorite cabarets and cocktail lounges, and, except that the tried and true administration appointees were possibly a trifle more exuberant and the Republican "career men" possibly more softly spoken than the national average, celebrated the occasion a good deal as did all other Americans.

In an effort to "shake sedentary women out of their office lethargy" and interest them in physical exercise, the New York League of Business and Professional Women is concentrating on sports and sportswomen for a luncheon program Saturday at 1:15 P.M. at the Hotel Biltmore.

HONORIA LAWRENCE was the wife of Sir Henry Lawrence, the British general who had so much to do with the making of British India -- especially the North-West Frontier -- and who died at the siege of Lucknow in 1857, during the Mutiny.

HAVING gone rustic from London to the Chilterns, and gone rambling and afield from there, Cecil Roberts has now gone sunwards to America. In other words, his new book is about Florida. It is a pleasant and readable book, in the same pattern as its predecessors, although not quite so continuously entertaining as they.

EACH day between dawn and dark thousands of Americans fold the menus on the tables before them and say to restaurant waitresses or dining-car stewards, "I'll have salmon." By these orders they collaborate remotely in high adventure on the western rim of the continent.

In announcing the result of operations of the American Commercial Alcohol Company, Russell R. Brown, president, said that business and profits during the nine months ended on Sept. 30 were the greatest the corporation has known.
BIRMINGHAM, Nov. 14 (AP). -- Louisiana State swept to its fifth consecutive Southeastern Conference victory today by conquering Auburn, 19 to 6, before more than 25,000.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- Registrations and reservations at all of the hotels here have reached a new high for this stage of the season, in anticipation of the National Professional Golfers Tournament, which starts tomorrow and runs through the week, to end next Sunday.

FROM the addition of La Scala's complete recording of Verdi's "Falstaff" to American lists -- it comes in Columbia's two-volume Operatic Set No. 16 -- it is to be gathered that the resumption of activities in this department will not be confined to abridged versions.

Sixteen patrolmen and eight detectives were sent to the Hall of Records, Center and Chambers Streets, at 6:18 o'clock last night after a frantic voice had informed police headquarters that there was a burglar in the building.

THE Metropolitan Opera has always been considered something of a prosperity index. If the thesis has merit, then recovery is indeed on the increase, at least for those persons who are interested in attending the Metropolitan.

Plans for extending the Meadowbrook Parkway from Southern State Parkway to Northern State Parkway, affording a direct link between the North and South Shores of Long Island, are being prepared by the State Division of Highways, it was disclosed yesterday by Robert Moses, president of the Long Island State Park Commission.

AMBROISE VOLLARD, the celebrated French dealer, collector and pioneer in modernism, sailed home to Paris at noon last Wednesday after a visit that reached its climax of welcome in a feast of wit and reminiscence and altogether phenomenal Scotch at the Barnes Foundation in Merion a week ago today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 14. -- Part of the greatest crowd that has seen a Princeton-Yale game here since 1930 watched the play from the improvised benches on the end of the field, and still others perched in trees.

Atlantic liners have been coming slowly into port in the past few days, their schedule disrupted by severe Atlantic storms, their passengers telling of unusually high seas. The Hamburg of the Hapag Lloyd Line and the United States liner Washington were among the tardy arrivals yesterday.

HOUSEHOLDERS in Colonial times counted on rare pieces of Chinese pottery and colorful lacquered furniture to give the finished, sophisticated touch to their rooms. We today add to these treasures from China other types of Oriental art -- a wooden figure from Bali in the South Seas, it may be, or a carved stone from the temple of Angkor Vat, in Cambodia, or a fresco from Shensi, China.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- Resettlement spokesmen said today that about $100,000,000 had been allotted to the "land use" program, with a large part of it for rehabilitation and development of land after acquisition.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 14. -- Twenty fraternity chapters and clubs on the Rutgers University campus renewed rushing activities this week after a two months' period during which, according to newly adopted regulations, none of the societies was permitted to receive prospective freshman pledges.

SHOLEM ASCH has dramatized here the inflation years in Germany. He has dramatized them on an impressive scale, and he has been at pains to reveal them, not as a moment in time, but as part of a historical process, reaching back to their origin in the war, and forward to their influence over the development of the Nazi State.
MR. THOMAS E. TALLMADGE, in his "Story of Architecture in America" (W.W. Norton Co., $4), has told an inspiring story of constructive genius.

AN exhibition entitled "Nineteenth and Twentieth Century American Figure Paintings" occupies at present the walls of the Milch Galleries (on until the end of the month). Work by more than a score of artists has been assembled, and this prompts much that is interesting in the way of comparison.

ANDOVER, Mass., Nov. 14. -- Aided by a peculiar break on a swift touchdown drive late in the final period, Andover's football team shaded its old enemy, Exeter, 12 to 7, on Brothers Field today and became the first undefeated and untied gridiron squad to frequent picturesque Andover Hill in more than three decades.
The interest of students in subject matter, as a barometer of economic conditions, indicates, at least at the New School for Social Research, that the depression is over.

The plan of reorganization of the Deep Rock Oil Corporation, amended in line with an order by the Oklahoma Northern District Federal Court on Nov. 9, has been sent to Security holders by the John J. Shinners reorganization committee, which urges deposits under the amended plan.

The Junior Committee of the Brooklyn Free Kindergarten Society, of which Mrs. John Van Pelt Lassoe is chairman, held its annual Five o'Clock Frolic yesterday afternoon at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. Mrs. Elsie Schreiber Carter was chairman of the party.

ON the receipt of a mysterious letter James Eaton Legg quits his job as a bookkeeper in San Francisco and sets out for Blue Wells, Ariz., determined to become a cowboy -- as Jimmy Legg. As he nears his destination his train is held up by three bandits who rob the express car of $30,000.

ROMANCE" is exactly the word for that entity which we know simply as "Lloyd's." But the progress of this name "from coffee-house to palace" is only one part of it, and not the most intriguing part. Almost everything about Lloyd's bears an aura of romance and fascination.

GENEVA, Nov. 14. -- The International Labor Office's Government Body closed its seventy-seventh session today by selecting for the agenda of its regular 1938 conference a provisional list of nine questions. These include factory inspection, which the United States Government especially urged; performers' rights as regards broadcasting, safety provisions of coal mines and regulation of hours of work and rest periods in road transport.

BLACKSBURG, Va., Nov. 14. -- Little George Sodaro, senior quarterback, put a perfect placement kick through the uprights to give Virginia Tech a 7-to-6 victory over the University of Virginia in the annual home-coming game today.

THIS is a book about Pennsylvania. But it is not a guide or travel book. It is, indeed, a little difficult to classify. But it is probably most correctly judged in calling it a book of essays. As such it is excursive, episodic, flavorous, individual and entertaining, and appreciatively dedicated to the spirit of place.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 14. -- Pittsburgh's mighty power cracked Nebraska's football barriers today and generated the momentum for a decisive victory over the Cornhuskers, 19 to 6, in a hard-fought intersectional battle on Memorial Field.

BUDAPEST, Nov. 14. -- "Hungary cannot accept the Little Entente standpoint of making armament equality depend on the previous consent of foreign States," says the newspaper Magyarorszag in commenting on the Little Entente's joint communique.

Like many another recent international conference, that of the representatives of Austria, Hungary and Italy in Vienna on Thursday did not live up to the high expectations fostered by its advance publicity. The detailed forecasts of significant decisions looking toward the revision of Hungary's frontiers and new political and economic alignments in the Danube Basin are not borne out by the official communique summarizing the results of the meetings.

THE new Federal Maritime Commission, which widened its investigations of maritime labor conditions last week, faces a vast and complex task, being obliged to concern itself with virtually every phase of American water-borne shipping.

LET us briefly summarize Moore's achievement: "Esther Waters," the first truly realistic novel in English; "Hail and Farewell," certainly one of the most entertaining autobiographies in any language, chockfull of character, incident and charm; the almost final simplicity of "The Brook Kerith" and "Heliose and Abelard" the only two prose epics in the English tongue.

Public Works Administrator Harold L. Ickes has awarded to the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company an order for 16,697 electric refrigerators, the largest single order of its kind ever placed, and involving more than $1,000,000, according to Arthur E. Allen, vice president in charge of merchandising.

The dinner tomorrow night at the Commodore marking the opening of the United Hospital Campaign is expected to draw an attendance of 1,500 men and women prominent in the social and professional life of the city. The function will serve to climax the preliminary activities of the last few weeks and at the same time inaugurate a varied round of entertainments in the interest of raising funds for the city's eighty-eight voluntary hospitals.

IN the selection of a motor car, every one wants to get the most satisfactory car for his money; satisfactory not only in sheer dollar's worth of value, but also in those elements of taste and feature which are the foundation of continued appreciation and the confirmation of good judgment.

CANBERRA, Nov. 13. -- A recent discussion of the high court of Australia seems to have raised a momentous issue. For the first time in the Commonwealth's history two judges, Evatt and McTiernan, declared that the Commonwealth was empowered under its external affairs jurisdiction to pass legislation ratifying international conventions which would be ultra vires if tested only by the Commonwealth's specific constitutional powers.

SEATTLE, Nov. 14. -- The University of Washington virtually clinched the Western bid to the Rose Bowl, trouncing Southern California, 12 to 0, today to move within one game of the Pacific Coast Conference football title.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 13. -- Civil war in Spain has practically ruined the market in that country for Western Kentucky and Tennessee dark fire-cured tobacco, of which the Spaniards manufacture popular low-priced cigarettes. The Spanish Government controls the tobacco monopoly, and until normalcy is restored it will buy nothing.

RIVERSIDE, Mass., Nov. 14. -- Boston University took advantage of two big breaks to beat Clarkson Tech., 14 -- 7, today. The Terriers scored their two touchdowns before Clarkson made theirs in the last period.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 14. -- Navy was pressed to the limit to defeat a good Harvard football team today. The Middies, running up against opposition that proved more formidable than advance information indicated, turned back the gallant Crimson band by 20 to 13 in a game that was packed through with thrills and which left the large gathering of 42,000 fans limp with excitement when it was over.

The goal posts came down at the end of the Notre Dame-Army game yesterday, but it was not Rambler alumni who leveled them. Instead, four young men jerked four chains and in five seconds the posts were neatly interred in coffin-like boxes in the ground.

A good volume of reorders was received in the wholesale markets last week, according to a special report prepared for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. Retailers in almost all sections of the country reported good business. An acute delivery problem in some industries has caused stores to make substitutions in their orders.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 14. -- In one of the closest games staged in Westchester during the current campaign, the New Rochelle and White Plains High School football teams battled to a 7-7 deadlock before a crowd of 12,000 on Senior Field today.

YONKERS, Nov. 14. -- A countywide peace rally and conference, supported by clergymen, labor leaders, educators and others in Westchester County, was held today at the Yonkers Young Women's Christian Association building on South Broadway.

Current and prospective price advances due to higher raw materials, labor costs and taxes are beginning to accentuate the price lining difficulties of both manufacturers and retailers, and may bring about a revision of the established price ranges as they have been utilized since the early 1920's, comment in merchandising circles here yesterday indicated.

Sales in October by chain-store and mail-order companies, which report from month to month the volume of business transacted, showed without an exception, for the second consecutive period, increases over the corresponding months last year.

Erasmus Hall's hope for an unbeaten season was rudely shattered by a hard-driving Boys High aggregation at Erasmus Field in Brooklyn as the Red and Black eleven scored an impressive 7-0 victory in a stubbornly fought encounter.
WITH the approach of cool weather the Summer outdoor sports program begins to wane and into prominence comes volley ball, one of the few pastimes in which age may compete on even terms with youth.

THE cowboy with the thin bow legs and the rangy face is fast becoming extinct on Western "dude ranches." In his place is a handsome fellow who rides with the grace of a circus performer and who has something of the showman about him.
PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 14 (AP). -- Stanford stampeded Oregon State in the last three minutes to win a spectacular 20 to 14 football victory today.

WHEN the first national jamboree of the Boy Scouts of America opens next June 30 in Washington, D.C., many thousands of Scouts, their foreign guests and their leaders will be encamped in a "city" of their own on the banks of the Potomac.

The prospect of a renewal in vigorous form early next year of the old American banking controversy over branch banking reappeared last week when, simultaneously with the appearance of a study of branch-banking laws in the current Federal Reserve Bulletin, the assertion was made that Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, had ready to place before Congress a bill to extend "trade-area branch banking."

Fifty New Jersey women, distinguished in their chosen fields, will be honored at a "citizenship achievement" dinner on Saturday at the Shackmaxon Country Club, Westfield, under auspices of the New Jersey Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs.

ALMOST two years ago a stocky little Pennsylvanian was telling President Roosevelt and Congress what was the matter with the Mississippi Valley and what could be done to save this great area for the nation. Today that same engineer is entrusted with the stupendous task of drafting concrete plans to carry out the substance of his report
HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 14. -- The selective process of admission to the freshman class at Dartmouth College has been shown to advantage in a recent survey of the class, made public today.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 14. -- Prosperous days, returning to the tune of announcements of pay increases and dividends, were reflected today when 14,000 Bostonians bought six times as many cars at the opening of the annual automobile show at Mechanics Hall as had been purchased a year ago on the show's inaugural day.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 14. -- Growth of the New York State College of Forestry at Syracuse University into the largest educational unit of its kind in the world will be marked by celebration of the college's twenty-fifth anniversary on the university campus Nov. 19-21.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14. -- The Rev. Dr. H. McAllister Griffiths, who, as presiding officer at its first general assembly last June officially declared the Presbyterian Church of America "duly constituted," has renounced the jurisdiction of the new organization and proclaimed himself an independent minister.

Large gains were the rule on the local commodity futures markets for the week ended on Friday, with copper and cottonseed oil moderately lower for the period. On the cash markets cotton, flour, butter and lard declined, while gains were registered in all the grains, in sugar, cocoa, hides, rubber, silk, wooltops, printcloths, lead, zinc and eggs.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14. -- Department store sales this week were approximately 18 per cent ahead of those in the corresponding week last year. Furs and other Winter apparel sold in better volume than heretofore and there was a substantial advance in domestics and home furnishings.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP). -- An effort to determine the constitutionality of the New York Unemployment Insurance Act and consideration of rulings on two New Deal controversies constituted the principal business before the Supreme Court today at its regular Saturday afternoon conference.

The time is rapidly approaching when garden makers who live in zones or districts where the mercury drops to zero or lower must give thought to the Winter protection of their roses, for -- with the exception of the very hardy species or shrub types -- all rose plants need some form of protection not only from the severe cold but especially from late Winter and early Spring winds and storms.

A leading cosmetician has evolved rules for making the throat, shoulders, back and arms look their best in low-cut evening gowns. With black or dark colors the skin should look warm and radiant to offset the sober effect of the gown.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 14. -- Twelve of the nineteen local chapters of national fraternities at Brown University are opening the Autumn social season this week-end with a series of dances, teas and receptions, which began yesterday afternoon. Tomorrow several chapters are planning dinners and informal gatherings in Providence and at shore resorts along Narragansett Bay.
In a game of tremendous importance to both teams, Columbia defeated Syracuse, 17 -- 0, yesterday before 20,000 persons at Baker Field.

The Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup contract bridge championship tournament for 1936 will be held at the Hotel Commodore Wednesday, Thursday and Friday evenings and on Saturday afternoon and evening. This event, regarded by bridge players as one of the leading tournaments of the year, attracts the outstanding bridge players of the country.
GENEVA, Nov. 14. -- Belgium is demanding that the League of Nations be reformed in such a way as to lay more emphasis on prevention of war.
A SHEVILLE. N.C. -- Social interest in Asheville this week is centered on the annual Thanksgiving buffet and supper and keno party to be held on Saturday evening at the Biltmore Forest Country Club.

BUSINESS conditions in general and in the automobile industry in particular seem to indicate for 1937 a continuation of the encouraging expansion which America enjoyed in 1936 and a renewal of efforts to overcome any effects of the depression still remaining in this country.
Keating Hall, Fordham University's new Graduate School building completed at a cost of $1,000,000, will be dedicated on Dec. 6 by Cardinal Hayes.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14. -- New York City voters, by their two-to-one approval of a new city charter, provided one of the significant manifestations of the popular will as expressed Nov. 3, a bulletin by the Public Administration Clearing House of the University of Chicago declares.
PARIS, Nov. 14. -- Notification that Germany has denounced the clause of the Versailles Treaty concerning the internationalization of her rivers has caused astonishment and anger here.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 14. -- For a little while today the police, already fearful that 7-year-old Rachel Ianniello, Bronx mute, had been kidnapped here, suffered a second such scare when another 7-year-old Bronx girl said here that she had been abducted.

SOON the snow-clad hills will be calling. The holidays are near at hand. Skis will be checked and skates sharpened. Bobsleds will cast off their Summer covering of dust. It is time to consider what will go into suitcase or rucksack.

Martin Flavin suggests that New York playwrights get into the habit of having their new plays first produced by universities, civic, community and little theatres, preliminary to Broadway production. He seems to accuse the playwrights of withholding new manuscripts from the non-commercial theatres.

CAPTAIN BLOOD, who has brought the breath of swaggering heroics to the pages of previous Sabatini volumes, is again sailing his buccaneer craft on the Caribbean Sea. As always, he is the gentlemanly pirate playing a Robin Hood role in mulcting the wealthy of their excessive gains and lending a powerful helping hand to the downtrodden and distressed.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14. -- With Eugene Ormandy and Jose Iturbi as the conductors, the Philadelphia Orchestra will make a second transcontinental tour at the close of the Winter season, it is announced by Alfred Reginald Allen, the manager.

COUNTY fairs in Central America are notable for the striking contrasts of primitive native handicraft with the products of modern industry, and the November exhibition that opens today in Guatemala City is no exception to the rule.

The 50,000th visitor to THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair in Rockefeller Center passed through the turnstile shortly after 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the midst of the busiest day since the exhibition opened on Nov. 5.

The first of the Dolphin dances, a series of subscription entertainments for girls who will be introduced to society within the next three years, will take place on Dec. 19 at the Pierre. A second dance is planned for the Easter season.

PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 14. -- A piece of lead placed in a tube one August night four years ago played a part in bringing the 1936 Nobel Prize to Dr. Carl D. Anderson, brilliant young Professor of Physics at the California Institute of Technology, for his discovery of the positron.

Mrs. Russell Hills Iler, chairman of the annual "Colony House Capers," to be presented under the auspices of the Senior and Junior Guilds of Colony House, 287 Dean Street, Brooklyn, the evenings of Jan. 22 and 23 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, yesterday announced early plans for the event.

Persons who heretofore have esteemed their own voices may be shocked into disillusionment if they submit themselves to a test for which an opportunity has been afforded by the New York Telephone Company in its building at 210 West Eighteenth Street, near Seventh Avenue. On the other hand, the experiment may heighten one's appraisal of his own tones.

Poor Gimpty in "Dead End" bewails his fate because "you can't be an architect until you've built a house, and no one will let you build him a house until you're an architect." Well, Gimpty my lad, architecture isn't in it with the theatre!

The national exhibition of high school art opening today at the American Museum of Natural History is a revealing spectacle for the citizen whose memory of schoolroom "art" classes goes back fifteen or twenty years.

The author of this book introduces to us a detective, Peter Bernadone, who is more than a mere man-hunter. He is also judge and jury -- not by any authority invested in him, but because he arrogates to himself the right to decide whether or not a murderer shall be punished for his crime.

Reeling on the defensive before an Army advance of 73 yards to its 6-yard line in the opening minutes of play, Notre Dame underwent an amazing transformation and proceeded to outplay the West Point Cadets yesterday clearly to earn a 20-6 victory as the season's record gathering of 80,000 looked on at the Yankee Stadium.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14. -- Breaking a tradition extending back forty-nine years, the Mask and Wig Club of the University of Pennsylvania is engaged in costume rehearsals in preparation for the premiere next Saturday night of its new show, "This Mad Whirl."

Now, when so many new residences are being planned or started, it is well for the owner to make provision for the protecting of existing trees and shrubs during building operations. Experience demonstrates that this cannot be left to the contractor.

In accord with the trend of the times, the weather forecaster recently declared an extra dividend in the way of ideal conditions for late work in the garden. Even though all Fall planting may have been finished, forehanded gardeners have taken advantage of good weather to prepare beds and borders for next Spring's planting.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Nov. 14. -- Scoring his second consecutive victory, Frank J. Marshall of New York, former United States champion, assumed the lead today in the international chess masters tournament when he defeated Pedro A. Gotay, champion of the Club de Ajedrez de San Juan.

FOR years the London bobby has been a man of the people, beloved for his courtesy, his good humor and his human outlook on life; admired for his encyclopedic knowledge and for his capacity to turn the nastiest situation into quiet, controlled order; respected for his record in keeping London free of the crime waves which have swept other great cities.

POISONED: Vincent A. Clarke Sr., father of the late Lieut. Commander Vincent A. Clarke Jr. who commanded the dirigible Los Angeles, is 72 years old, conducts a marine boat works at Ocean City, N.J., and experiments much of the time with various inventions.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 (AP). -- The Hoosiers of Indiana University, with Quarterback Vern Huffman giving one of the greatest individual performances seen at Stagg Field this season, defeated a stubborn band of Chicago Maroons, 20 to 7, before 20,000 spectators today.

Certain displays at the special General Motors show at the Waldorf-Astoria, which continued yesterday to draw attendance 50 per cent larger than last year, have been arranged to show the analogy between the modern automobile and the living room at home.

LONDON, Nov. 14 (AP). -- The Madrid Government, The Sunday Referee asserted today, has sent an urgent appeal to members of the British Parliament to save the Spanish capital from the insurgent siege and "prevent the most horrible massacre in modern history."

Louis E. Stern's collection of engravings and etchings, Count August Lafon's collection of paintings by French modernists and the second part of Mrs. John Slade's collection of lithographs by Currier Ives are among the art collections which will be auctioned here during the week.

WHATEVER else may be said of Karl Marx, he meets the test of being more important half a century after his death than he was when he died. Because he really did possess a great creative mind, or because he had the good luck to be accepted as a symbol, he counts for much in every country which has even an abortive revolutionary movement and in Russia he is in theory the whole show.

OIL and automotive engineers have solved the problems of lubricants arising from the use of newer bearing materials, H.C. Mougey of General Motors Research Laboratories states in a report to the American Chemical Society.
THE many improvements in actual riding ease are among the outstanding evolutions of the modern automobile, according to H.G. Moock, vice president of the Plymouth Motor Corporation.
Fifty students at the City College main center have been pledged by eight fraternities, according to an announcement by the inter-fraternity council.

This title of one of the works of CHARLES DICKENS might well be given to the forecasts of the second Roosevelt Administration which are put forward in many quarters. In the last number of The Nation there is a sort of symposium, contributed by persons who are usually identified with reformers and radicals, under the caption. "What I Expect of Roosevelt."

MOSCOW, Nov. 13. -- Soviet diplomacy has always had to steer a difficult course in a world that is suspicious when not actively hostile, but it never has been face to face with such trying situations as those of today.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 14 (AP). -- New members of the Arkansas General Assembly will go back to school Wednesday in what its sponsors say is the first institute of legislative procedure in the country.

TOLEDO, Spain, Nov. 14. -- Improved weather conditions today enabled the Insurgents on the Madrid front to continue operations. Colonel Barron's column at Campamento, about four miles west of Madrid, again bore the brunt of the fighting and was the object of an artillery attack.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14. -- Wheat prices were on the upgrade today as the result of aggressive buying of futures attributed to houses with Eastern connections, of relative strength in Liverpool and of reports of a marked improvement in the domestic demand for flour. One Eastern baker was credited with having bought 90,000 barrels of flour, equivalent to 405,000 bushels of wheat.

CHICAGO is now building two practice driving fields where embryo motorists will learn to operate a car under professional instruction and where they will not endanger the lives of others, as often happens when this is tried on the public highway.

LONDON, Nov. 14. -- After making all preparations the British Broadcasting Corporation decided not to broadcast the sequences of the film "The Green Pastures." The reason given was that an item of this nature could not properly be included in the mixed program arranged for Monday, but no alternative date was suggested.

BERLIN, Nov. 14. -- The direction of the central association of all German research scientists has been placed in the hands of a professor of armament technique in the Berlin Technical Institute at Charlottenburg, Dr. Willi Menzel. Professor Stark, Nobel Prize physicist, who was the organization's president, will retire.

THIS strange arm of the sea might be described as the Venice of the Pacific. Not the Venice of gondolas, songs and bridges, but a place of strife, determination and trade. The Southern Summer -- Winter in the Northern Hemisphere -- finds tourists flocking here to enjoy its beauty.
GREENVILLE, Me., Nov. 14. -- Maine is afflicted with a plague of bears, and one hunter now estimates that there are more than a thousand bears within a radius of fifty miles of this town.

JACKSONVILLE, Vt., Nov. 14. -- William E. Bird, a sturdy laborer, who offered himself to the medical profession as collateral for a $2,500 loan to feed and clothe his young wife and three children, faced the future cheerfully today because he had a job.
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Ed Howe, the "Sage of Potato Hill," said today he was going to be a mute philosopher and "quit expressing opinions" -- then expressed his views on several subjects.

I agree with the contention expressed in your editorial that polls should be abolished as an unnecessary evil. I fail to see how any one benefits from them except their sponsors, who receive publicity.

The executive committees planning the Miami Biltmore Fashion Show and Ball to be held on Dec. 11 at the Waldorf-Astoria will have the assistance of several groups of young women of society which already have been organized to assist with many details.

Garden enthusiasts from New England, Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Northern New York State will be among the 350 women who will attend the first garden lecture benefit of the season to be sponsored by the Women's Auxiliary of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden tomorrow morning at the Waldorf-Astoria.

MONTREAL, Nov. 14 (AP). -- The Detroit Red Wings came from behind to gain a 2-2 tie with the Montreal Maroons before 5,000 fans tonight and remain undefeated in the current National Hockey League season. The draw gave the Maroons their first point in three starts.
ATLANTA, Nov. 14 (AP). -- Alabama weathered a savage second-half attack here today to protect its unbeaten record with a 20-16 victory over Georgia Tech before 25,000 persons.

ARLINGTON, Texas, Nov. 14. -- Navanod, a 32-1 shot from the C.E. Davison Stable, bolted like a startled deer at the finish to defeat fourteen rivals and take the plum of Texas racing, the $15,000 added Waggoner Memorial Handicap, today.

A bazaar under the auspices of "The Helpers," an organization devoted to charity, will be held on Tuesday in the small ballroom of the Plaza. Funds are needed by the organization for its hospital work, care for the ailing in their own homes and to conduct its settlement house.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- Since President Roosevelt's re-election there has been a tremendous revival of interest in the possibility of the administration's fostering at the next session of Congress a bill designed to attain the objectives of the defunct NRA.

Song books for children should have gayety and individuality, and so today, when the flood of mechanical music is blurring taste and discouraging musical effort, Mr. Van Loon's and Miss Castagnetta's "The Songs We Sing" is particularly welcome.

A nation-wide commemoration of the teachings of Desiderius Erasmus of Rotterdam, Holland, who died 400 years ago, will be held this week under the auspices of the Netherland-America Foundation, it was announced by the foundation's president, Thomas J. Watson, head of the International Business Machines Corporation.

IN the galleries of the Pennsylvania Academy, Philadelphia, the thirty-fourth annual water-color exhibition and the thirty-fifth annual display of miniatures are current. These may be visited until Dec. 6.

THE NEW YORK TIMES, Nov. 4, contains an article headed "Trade Bid by United States Sent to Australia," in the course of which the hope is expressed that the existing quota system be abolished. This may be all right as far as this country is concerned, but it cannot make any special appeal to Australia.

BERLIN, Nov. 14. -- The German Government followed up today its many threats to check trading in foreign securities by taking action. At the same time responsible officials made plain to the financial community that further restrictions were really to be expected.
IN late Fall, during the seasonal lull at Arizona's Grand Canyon, work is speeded up in the 1,000-square-mile national park there in preparation for the expected rush of Spring visitors.

Rising to the heights in a magnificent second period burst, Manhattan pushed across two touchdowns and then held firm to drop Georgetown from the ranks of the undefeated, 13 to 0, at Ebbets Field yesterday.

TAKE a generous portion of built-in comfort and strength add a spurt of power, season with liberal dashes of design to produce "that greyhound-inflight look," bake in a pan well greased with safety features and there you have it -- the 1937 composite of "the most beautiful, comfortable and the safest car ever built."

RIDING into the town of Lazy Wolf, to deliver a message and $1,000 in cash to Eunice Emery (unknown to him) and hoping to land a job, sorely needed, young Larry Stowell ran smack into a bank robbery, with the cashier murdered.

SAVOYARDS whose delight is Gilbert and Sullivan are celebrating a triumphant centenary. It is just one hundred years next Wednesday since William Schwenck Gilbert, the founder of their merry cult, was born.

IMPROVING on its gains, retail trade in the week ranged from 15 to 25 per cent above last year except on the Pacific Coast, where the shipping and warehouse strike has affected sales. Armistice Day business in this area was the best since last Easter, with some stores running 40 per cent ahead of the 1935 figures.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 14. -- With Andy Beno, chunky All-State back, in brilliant form, New Brunswick High School's powerful eleven crushed the Instituto Politecnica Nacional of Mexico City on Neilson Field today, 34 to 0.

The Federal Social Security plan for old-age retirement benefits for workers over 65 gets under way tomorrow, looking ahead to Jan. 1, 1942, when payment of benefits -- monthly pensions of $10 to $85 -- will begin.

AUTUMN in England is the season of provincial festivals. They are of two kinds: the old traditional festival with professional orchestra and soloists imported from London and the competitive festival which aims, above all, at improving the standard of the amateur.

NOW that motor car prices for 1937 models have been revealed, the fact becomes clear that automobile buyers will get more for their money the coming year than ever before. This is true, no matter what price class one considers.

LONDON, Nov. 14 (Canadian Press). -- Defeating Huddersfield Town by the only goal of the game, Portsmouth held its lead in the English Football League today. Sunderland vaulted Brentford for the runner-up position by a great 3-1 victory over Chelsea at Stamford Bridge.

Despite the favorable outcome of the California referendum and the Supreme Court decision in the Iowa case throwing out the graduated tax, chain store executives will cast a watchful eye upon the forty-four State legislatures which will convene in 1937.

CANST thou by searching find out God? Canst thou find out the Almighty unto perfection?" From time immemorial individual man has tried to answer in the affirmative the question that was put to Job; and from time immemorial individual man has glorified by this designation his personal pursuit, not necessarily of the highest good or the supreme wisdom, but of peace and satisfaction for his own restless soul.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 14 (AP). -- Major Bob Neyland's versatile Tennessee Volunteers, striking suddenly and decisively on land and in the air, conquered the Vanderbilt Commodores, 26 to 13, today before a sell-out crowd of 22,000.

Anonymous among a gay throng of her colleagues, some professional woman will be summoned from an unobtrusive place at table during the Friendship dinner tomorrow night, to be decorated with the gold medal of achievement of the A.W. A.
OMAHA, Nov. 13. -- The recent agricultural news at Washington represents in some degree the release of emotions bottled up since the Supreme Court's AAA decision.

A Thanksgiving show, to be held in Horticultural Hall, Rockefeller Center, from Thursday through Saturday, will attract entries from members of garden clubs in the metropolitan district. A class of special interest will be a competition in Thanksgiving dinner tables decorated with fruits, vegetables, berries or flowers.
Philanthropic work of the Infants Welfare League will benefit by its major social event of the season, a dinner dance to be held on Saturday at 7 P.M. at the Waldorf-Astoria.
AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 14. -- Amherst defeated Williams today and the victor's traditional goddess, Sabrina, was honored tonight by every son of Amherst within earshot of the result.

The Bronx Woman's Club is holding a morning and an evening conference on "Family Relationships" on Tuesday. The program has been arranged by the heads of three sections of the club: Mrs. Bertram S. Bickelhaupt, chairman of civics; Mrs. Stanley F. Bond, chairman of the American Home, and Mrs. Vandervoort Walsh, chairman of fine arts.
The more or less historic desks used at New York campaign headquarters by National Chairmen James A. Farley and John D.M. Hamilton are on their way to new and quieter homes.

THE motion picture, youngest and liveliest of the arts, is about to acquire a key to the treasure trove of its recorded past and its projected future through the efforts of the WPA Federal Writers Project in New York City.

Miss Althea McCammon and Mrs. Charles Singleton will assist at a tea to be given by Mrs. Palmer H. Jadwin on Wednesday afternoon at the Central Branch of the Y.W.C.A., 30 Third Avene, Brooklyn, in the interest of the 1937 budget difference campaign of the Y.W.C.A., which opened Tuesday.

TORONTO, Nov. 14 (AP). -- The Toronto Maple Leafs tonight blasted their way into the National Hockey League's victory column for the first time this season, routing the Chicago Black Hawks, 6 -- 2. The teams meet again in Chicago tomorrow.

For more than a century (the first translation was made in 1823), the Grimm Brothers' Household Tales have been a part of the experience of English-speaking boys and girls. Hansel and Gretel, Snow White and Rose Red, the Musicians of Bremen, and many more, have peopled children's imagination and added to the gayety and interest of early reading experiences.
MOSCOW, Nov. 14 (AP). -- An American diplomatic wedding was performed on schedule today despite the arrest of the intended pastor.

As if to symbolize the change of eras, the Fifty-first National Horse Show -- featuring harness horses and harness ponies with appropriate vehicles, three and five gaited saddle horses, military jumpers and the Royal Canadian Mounted Police -- ended its week in New York on Tuesday, and on Wednesday the city turned to the opening of the Thirty-seventh National Automobile Show.

Helen Hunt West, Congressional secretary of the National Woman's party, predicted yesterday to the convention of that group in the Hotel Roosevelt that the next Congress would adopt the Equal Rights Amendment for which they have worked for thirteen years. She spoke before 150 delegates, representing thirteen States.

Last week the American Academy of Arts and Letters commemorated appropriately the centenary of the birth of THOMAS BAILEY ALDRICH. It seems probable that his permanent remembrance will be derived from a few exquisite lyrics. His novels are forgotten. So are his short stories, except perhaps "Marjorie Dawe."

AMONG countless novels of the Civil War, "Long Remember" is one of the few which may outlast its brief hour. Never as popular as "Gone With the Wind" or "So Red the Rose," it had a solidity and brilliance which neither of these books can overshadow.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand. -- A step toward the solution of the native problem here was taken by Prime Minister Savage, leader of the new radical government, at the great Maori "hui," or celebration. when he promised equality between native Maoris and white man.

TELEVISION demonstrations up to 1936 were made to reveal scientific progress. The more recent "shows" stress the amusement value; the technical aspects are being moved into the background. The research engineers are working behind the scenes and the entertainers are stepping upon the stage to be televised.

THE notes of bugles herald the approach of a column of Czechoslovak infantry now passing the fifteenth century Powder Tower and marching along Prague's Graben. Young men in khaki, sweating under the weight of heavy packs, on their way to home barracks from the annual manoeuvres, straighten their packs, lift their chins and gaze steadily ahead.

IT is with authority and independence that Mrs. Millin has written the second and more important volume of what will be accepted by historians as the standard and contemporary life of General Smuts. Mrs. Millin has had free access to the papers of General Smuts, public and private -- Smuts has himself revised her statements of fact.

PARIS, Nov. 13. -- Final midseason showings endorse the trends already noted and make definite some others of which there had been but a slight suggestion. A revised version of the Spanish influence is important. It brings back toreador boleros, some fitted and buttoned, others loose and garishly embroidered.

Picketed by air and sea, as well as by land, the liner Washington of the United States Line arrived from Southampton and Hamburg yesterday to provide a crucial test of the insurgent seamen's strike in this port. She is scheduled to sail on her return trip on Wednesday, and a struggle to gain the adherence of her crew of 500 began as soon as she approached port.
WOOSTER, Ohio, Nov. 14. -- The Washington and Jefferson eleven downed a lighter Wooster College team 33 -- 6 today after the home team scored first.

HERE'S a brief, bright tale about a little Spanish island, off the regular trade routes, and about a cargo ship carrying a handful of passengers which visit it to pick up the accumulation of excellent olive oil and pleasant native wine which it produces for export on such occasions as a tramp ship comes to call.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Nov. 15. -- Japan's assumption of superiority in proposing to give China the position of "subordinate partner" in a new league against communism is regarded here as a certain bar against acceptance of the project by Nanking.

One of New York's most unusual philanthropic organizations, Toyery, Inc., will be the beneficiary of a "Pageant of Living Dolls" to be presented during luncheon in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre on Dec. 7. Toyery, which was organized a few years ago, establishes free lending collections of toys for children of indigent parents in underprivileged sections of the city.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 14. -- Finance Commissioner Anthony F. Minisi announced today a $300,000,000 city tax assessment on the assets, exclusive of realty, held in the State by the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, a New Jersey corporation.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 14 (AP). -- Tulane's Greenies fumbled their way to defeat today, bowing to the oft-beaten but gallant band of Bulldogs from Georgia, 12 -- 6, before a homecoming crowd of 18,000.

EVERYBODY knows the importance of style lines in the automobile industry's selling picture. It is this that has built up our business, and it is one of the fundamentals of our success. We get out new car models every year and offer them to an anticipant public.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art today will open a small exhibition of some of its priceless Chinese textiles. The show, which will continue until Dec. 10, contains a series of mandarin squares, two tapestries and twenty-one robes. Most of the material was acquired by the museum within the last year.

Five caravanners in search of a fairy tale, this gay American family dubbed itself, and set out in an automobile and big, blue trailer to see Denmark. No one of them, except the Mother-in-Chief, knew very much about the snug little country, but Nancy, the youngest of the four children, knew the most important fact: "It's Hans Christian Andersen's country."
VATICAN CITY, Nov. 14. -- Cardinal Pacelli arrived in Rome this evening and was immediately received by Pope Pius, to whom he made a detailed report on his journey to America.

IN the last ten years our engineers have built more than 300 different engines, experimenting to find the most efficient power plant. Only a few of those engines were used, for we have one rule that is never violated. The new developments for our car must compete with each other and pass the practical tests that the car owners meet in everyday driving.

ANY who may have doubted that this would go down in history as a French season had better make up their minds to the fact now! Four fresh events on the calendar swell, by just so much, the impressive record to date, and herald the imminence of vastly more.

VIENNA, Nov. 14. -- For Italy and Austria there is no imminent danger to European peace unless it should arise from the Spanish situation. This was the chief point made in talks accorded the writer by Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg and Count Galeazzo Ciano at the conclusion of the three-power conference here.

BECAUSE of the enormous influence of Calvinism, it has been customary for historians of the Reformation to regard the author of "The Institutes of the Christian Religion" and his Geneva Consistory as some gigantic central fire of Protestantism, which, by virtue of its sheer magnitude, dominates the orbit of Protestant progress.

BERLIN, Nov. 14. -- The formerly all-powerful cartels of German industry, which under the Republican regime were technically under State supervision but actually dominated by the State, have now been placed under the control of the industrial group organizations through which the National Socialist regime exercises its control over industry.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14. -- In a daring hold-up two bandits late tonight kidnapped John F. Cuneo, wealthy president of the Cuneo Press, and his wife, Mrs. Julia Shepherd Cuneo, in front of their home at 3,300 Lake Shore Drive, drove them a few blocks away and robbed them of more than $35,000 in jewelry.

THIS shore excursion had its original inspiration in an incident atop a Fifth Avenue bus. There on a windy Spring day a pretty girl lost her beflowered hat and her hitherto invulnerable heart to a handsome Italian on a following bus. John Casablanca returned the hat to Imogene.

Willy Nilly was a penguin who wanted to be different; when the other penguins were parading, he went diving; when the others were diving, he went swimming. Once he even thought he would try to be a gull, and when he found he couldn't fly, he pretended to be a sea otter, which was all very well until a real sea otter nearly put an end to Willy Nilly's games.

HERE are eight stories, four of them by Alice Hegan Rice (are there readers so youthful that they need to be reminded of "Mrs. Wiggs of the Cabbage Patch"?) and four by Cale Young Rice. The stories by Mr. Rice and Mrs. Rice are printed alternately.

WILLIAM PLOMER, in his introduction, says that since Nesbitt was on the South African Rand in 1912-1915 there have been alterations and improvements, but that the system today remains essentially the same as it was then.

THE Philadelphia Orchestra, under Leopold Stokowski, at its third New York concert of the season, Nov. 24, in Carnegie Hall, will play three new works for the first time in this city. These compositions are a symphony by Chrennikoff, a young Russian composer; "Arizona," by Victor Young, and "Two American Frescoes," by Bernard Rogers of South Orange, N.J.

THE National Automobile Show, which no doubt will take its place as one which represented a culmination in recent automobile engineering, is now attracting record crowds to Grand Central Palace, Forty-sixth Street and Lexington Avenue.

Thirty-eight extra-curricular groups at Hunter College have elected their officers for the school year, it was announced yesterday. Designed to develop student interests outside the classroom, the organizations include departmental clubs, student committees, discussion groups, and religious, athletic and dramatic societies.

The article by W.A. Warn in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 8 plainly carries the implication that the provision in the New York State Constitution "excluding aliens" from the count of the State population for representation in the Legislature was "inserted for partisan purposes by the Republican-controlled Constitutional Convention in 1894," and therefore will be stricken out by a prospectively Democratic-controlled convention.

Lieutenant Ripley Reeve, who is the master sleuth in this story, does not believe that Larry O'Neill is responsible for the death of his uncle, Percival Maxon, but it looks dark for Larry, nevertheless, until it is learned that the greater portion of Maxon's fortune has been bequeathed to the leader of a mysterious Eastern cult.

THROUGHOUT Arctic Siberia, across the vast north of Asia, the Soviet Government is supporting a pioneering movement of magnitude perhaps unexampled in history. Along the Northern Sea Route, a route never before used by man, the Russians plant new ports and new industrial towns to open the greatest region of natural resources remaining untapped on the globe.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 14. -- As Harvard prepares for expansion of its national scholarship plan on the basis of gifts to the tercentenary fund earmarked for this purpose, the dean's office reveals that the records of twenty students who entered under this plan last year and the year before entitle them to a renewal of their stipends, which this year will total over $18,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- A far-reaching program to enable thousands of tenant farmers to become owners of their lands, and calling for an expenditure of $50,000,000 a year "until the job is done," was outlined today by Rexford G. Tugwell, Under-Secretary of Agriculture and head of the Resettlement Administration.

The Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30 a consolidated net income of $12,442,512, after all prior deductions. This was equal, after preferred dividends, to 47 cents a share on the common stock.

Frank N. Trager, State secretary of the Socialist party, has sent a protest to Governor Lehman against the impending loss by the Communist party of its automatic place on the State ballot. Under the new election law a party that fails to poll 50,000 votes is not automatically entitled to a place on the ballot and the Communist party apparently failed to reach that total in the State.

THE announcement last week that an important British air line is to be equipped with Lockheed Electras has brought a certain amount of satisfaction to the hearts of American plane designers and builders. For years they have had to listen in Congress and elsewhere to earnest orators declaring that the British are superior to us in every branch of aviation.
ATLANTA, Nov. 14 (AP). -- The Georgia Supreme Court today allowed to stand a ruling that the late Julia M. Hungerford, owner of a large block of Coca-Cola stock, was an Atlanta resident.

FOR the automobile industry -- a great 1936 and an even greater 1937. This prediction has been made by every automobile manufacturer of note and by other industrial leaders who can read in the successes of the past twelve months an indication of what is to follow.

Many tables have been reserved for the card party and tea on Tuesday in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis under the auspices of the Penland Board of the Church of the Ascension for the benefit of its school in the mountains of North Carolina.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 14. -- Recently discharged from the infirmary, Lou Pennauchi, plunging fullback, crashed across for three of Lehigh's four touchdowns in the Engineers' 26-to-6 victory over Muhlenberg before 9,000 spectators in Taylor Stadium today.
THE Roosevelt second inaugural is already on the radio calendar for Jan. 20, 1937, and the broadcasters report they are planning for "the most elaborate coverage" of the event.

THE warmth of color and romantic attitude which won friends for Menkes in his first American show last spring are very much to the fore in his current exhibition, chiefly of flower pieces and still-lifes, at the Guild Gallery (through November).

One question which must be answered soon by the Roosevelt Administration is what policy to recommend to Congress with respect to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. Under existing law this agency will lose on Jan. 31 power to make new loans to the banks, insurance companies and other groups of private credit agencies which borrowed so heavily from it during the dark days of the depression.

TRAVELERS looking for something different in the cruise world will find it in the thousand-mile journey up the Amazon River. Cargo ships of the Booth Steamship Company en route to South American ports stop at Para, in the mouth of the Amazon, where passengers change to other Booth vessels sailing from Liverpool to Manaos.

ANNUAL conventions of business and professional men provide an important inducement to travel in the United States. Men who would otherwise turn down the urging of wives and children for a "trip somewhere" often find it easy to agree when, by crossing half the continent, they can attend a meeting of the business organization to which they pay dues.

TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 14. -- A proposal by George L. Berry, president of the Printing Pressmen's Union, for arbitration of the controversy between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization was rejected today soon after it had been made.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 14. -- Mr. and Mrs. Eugene du Pont announced tonight from Owl's Nest, their home at Greenville, the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ethel du Pont, to Franklin Delano Roosevelt Jr., third son of the President and Mrs. Roosevelt. Mr. Roosevelt is a week-end guest at the du Pont home.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- On a low point-after-touchdown placekick which barely cleared the crossbar, Catholic University scored a 7-6 victory over North Carolina State today.

PAUL HINDEMITH, the celebrated German composer, who expects to make his first visit to America this season, has accepted the invitation of the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation in the Library of Congress to appear as composer-performer at the festival of chamber music to be given in Washington April 9, 10 and 11.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 14. -- It is lucky for the prestige of the local association field hockey teams that the touring South African players are sailing for home next Wednesday. In their final American appearance today they defeated the Stuyvesant eleven on the Greenwich Academy Field, 11 -- 0.

IT may be a somewhat amazing bit of theatrical news to some persons who may have missed the advance notices that there will be presented in New York -- all but "on Broadway," indeed -- during the current season a series of plays by outstanding French authors, such as Edouard Bourdet, Jean-Jacques Bernard, Andre Birabeau, Maurice Rostand, Jean de Letraz, Jean Sarment, Tristan Bernard, and others.

MANILA. -- On Nov. 15 the Philippine Commonwealth will celebrate its first anniversary. The year has marked the transition from the previously existing government under an American Governor General to a more autonomous Philippine State under an elected President.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 13. -- With both sides drawing the name of President Roosevelt into the discussion, the issue between John L. Lewis's independent industrial organization movement and the company union plan flared up strongly this week in connection with the cost-of-living conditions attached by the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, largest subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, to its offer of an average wage increase of 10 per cent to its nearly 90,000 mill workers.

Our recent journey to the quail country of South Jersey was a particularly satisfying experience. The bag of bobwhite was light, but that was a minor consideration. The greater reward came merely from being around these pert and attractive birds, an opportunity unfortunately denied to most New York sportsmen.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 13. -- When the Arab High Committee, after having changed its decision three times, finally resolved on non-cooperation with the British Royal Commission, it was thought in political quarters here that the British Government would find itself in a dilemma.

WITH the new 2-cents-a-mile fare attracting travelers in greater number to railroad ticket windows, additional interest attaches to the fact that this is the centenary of the kind of railway ticket in use today.
Scoring a goal in the last three minutes of play, the Connecticut State College field hockey team conquered New York University, 2 to 1, at Prospect Park in Brooklyn yesterday.
