The first of a series of twelve forums on the economic status of artists in this country will be held next Sunday night at the Daly Theatre, 22 West Sixty-third Street. The series is being sponsored by the WPA Federal Art Project and Holger Cahill, national director of the project, will open the first meeting.

A powerful Curtis High School eleven overwhelmed Tilden of Brooklyn, 51 to 0, yesterday at Thompson's Stadium, S.I., to gain its fourth victory of the year before 3,000 spectators. Walter Scholl led the scorers with 20 points.

Working bareheaded in the chill winds sweeping through Riverdale, seven Horace Mann students, members of well-to-do families, to whom the sound of a cross-cut saw is a greater lure than social gatherings, stayed until after sundown one day last week to complete a two-car garage near the school grounds.

LEGENDS of the saints, like the ancient tales of kings and heroes, belong to boys and girls, for the freshness of wonder is in them, the flavor of a world that is young and eager, with bravery and steadfastness an everyday affair and friendship between men and animals a matter of course.

Lady Campbell, wife of Sir Gerald Campbell, British Consul General in New York, will be in charge of a consulate booth at the sixteenth annual bazaar of the Daughters of the British Empire in the State of New York, opening Wednesday at 2 P.M. in the Hotel Biltmore.

IT would seem that a modest approach to collecting would be to try to assemble all the editions of one favorite book. One might reasonably expect such a field to have its limits. But Dr. Homer B. Vanderblue, Honorary Curator of Early Economic Literature at the Baker Library, is here to prove the contrary.

PARIS, Nov. 14. -- On behalf of the French Employers Confederation, C.J. Gignoux has addressed an open letter to Premier Blum protesting threats directed in a radio broadcast by the Minister of National Economy, Charles Spinasse, against obstruction by employers to the government's social and economic program.

ROME, Nov. 13. -- The point perhaps not sufficiently appreciated about Premier Benito Mussolini's speeches, such as the one he delivered at Milan the first of this month, is that due allowance should be made in interpreting his words for his lack of temperament and for his Latin turn of a phrase.

An exhibition for the purpose of establishing, with a collection of not more than thirty pictures, the relationship between the art of the first half of the seventeenth century and the permanent character of French art, will be held at the galleries of M. Knoedler Co., Inc., beginning Nov. 23, as a benefit for the Blerancourt Museum in France and the Lycee Francaise of New York.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses was sworn in yesterday by Mayor La Guardia as chairman of the Triborough Bridge Authority to succeed the late Nathan Burkan. Mr. Moses has been a member of the Authority for more than two years.

The Transit Commission served the Long Island Railroad yesterday with an order requiring it to show cause why it should not be punished for contempt of a court order, requiring the line to charge no more than two cents a mile for rides between points entirely within the city limits.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14. -- Mayor Angelo Rossi of San Francisco will leave by plane for Washington tomorrow afternoon to discuss the Pacific Coast maritime strike with Secretary of Labor Perkins and possibly with the President.

The rich, voluminous tone, the breadth and sparkle which are always Mischa Elman's when in his best form were in evidence throughout his recital in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. If last Spring the violinist made strenuous but often vain attempts to produce full, round sounds from the strings, there was no such frustration of effort at his latest appearance.

MR. BULKELEY was a Welsh country squire of the eighteenth century, and the pirate was no other than the celebrated privateersman, Fortunatus Wright, who became, by one of fate's strange whimsies, that provincial gentleman's son-in-law.

Directors of the Beech-Nut Packing Company yesterday declared a special dividend of $1 a share on the common stock, in addition to an extra dividend of 25 cents and the regular quarterly of $1. On Oct. 1, dividends of 75 cents quarterly and 50 cents extra were disbursed.

EL PASO, Nov. 13. -- The recent decision of the Mexican authorities to complete the work on the Ratamal intake on the Rio Grande has made the agriculturists and city dwellers of the lower Rio Grande valley, where citrus fruit growing. is the largest industry, apprehensive of the future water supply.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 14. -- Just eighteen years and a day after Egypt first demanded independence from Great Britain the Egyptian Parliament today ratified the Anglo-Egyptian treaty making Egypt an independent nation with Britain as her ally.
MANILA, P.I., Nov. 14. -- Francis Burton Harrison, former American Governor General of the Philippines, became a naturalized Filipino today.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., Nov. 14. -- Concentrating their power and deception in one sustained march for their touchdown in the second quarter, the Choate School football forces conquered Kent, 7 -- 2, in concluding one of the most successful seasons of their gridiron history today.

Problems of the clubs in isolated sections of the Empire State will be of paramount interest to the new president of the State Federation of Women's Clubs. Mrs. Clare J. Hoyt, who last week succeeded Mrs. Almeron W. Smith and whose proudest boast is that she is "a country woman," admits that her chief concern will be the rural club woman.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP). -- Housing officials disclosed today statistics on which they said that Stewart McDonald, the housing administrator, had based his prediction to President Roosevelt this week that 1937 would bring an increase in home construction.

I WILL make, if possible, a book that a child shall understand, yet a man will feel some temptation to peruse should he chance to take it up," wrote Sir Walter Scott, as he planned his stories from Scottish history, called "Tales of a Grandfather," one of the first volumes for young people which adults found enjoyable.

The recent vote in Oregon on a bill proposing the abolition of compulsory military drill in schools, which was placed on the ballot through the efforts of college students, calls attention to their growing political activity on campuses throughout the country.

THE ninth annual competition for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup will begin on Wednesday night at the Hotel Commodore. Mr. Vanderbilt's trophy was the first ever offered for a national contract bridge tournament. Entries have always been limited to teams of four, and the championship is decided by individual matches between the teams which enter, this being considered the fairest test of contract bridge skill.

Country week-ends and trips to football stadiums are getting to be chilly affairs, now that the thermometer has settled down for the Fall. Knitted wool sweaters and vests of embroidered felt from Norway are declared to be just the thing for chilly days in the open.

THE automobile industry constitutes the largest and most important group of manufacturing enterprises in our economic structure. Most people realize that it is a gigantic industry but usually think of it in terms of huge plants concentrated in a comparatively small area. As a matter of fact, its domain is a far-flung one, reaching out into every section of the country and into nearly all fields of activity.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Nov. 14. -- Coming from behind in the final quarter to score two touchdowns, the Virginia Military Institute put a damper on the University of Maryland's homecoming-day celebration by beating the Terrapins, 13 to 7, today.

MARSEILLES, France, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Reports received here today said the Spanish Government freighter Manuel had been torpedoed and sunk by the Rebel cruiser Canarias with a loss of eighteen lives. Nine members of the crew were saved in a lifeboat.

LONDON. BRITAIN'S newest film dictator, John Maxwell, who, now that he has control of the Gaumont British Corporation as well as of his own Associated British Picture Corporation, has at his command assets totaling around $120,000,000, including 633 theatres in Britain, and studios at Elstree and Shepherds Bush, is a tall, bespectacled Scot in his early sixties, who began life as a lawyer in Glasgow.

SIMLA, India. ONE of the strangest inhabited islands in the world is growing its first vegetable garden. About 200 miles south of Bombay, India, there rises sheer from the sea an islet known as the Vengurla rocks.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP). -- Despite the Akron and Macon disasters the navy high command is studying recommendations for resuming the development of big, lighter-than-air dirigibles.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 14. -- Fourteen fraternities of Union College entertained Hamilton College students at dances in their chapter houses after their traditional football game this afternoon. The annual social week-end of the two New York State colleges began last night with songfests, and will continue tomorrow with a recital by Dr. Elmer A. Tidmarsh in the Memorial Chapel.

MILAN. DISPATCHES from Rome announce that Premier Mussolini has just approved, after some modifications, the final program for the Third Florentine Musical May, to be held in Florence during the six weeks from April 27-June 10.

MIDDLEBURG, Va., Nov. 14. -- Sunny Thoughts, F. Ambrose Clark's 4-year-old bay gelding by Sun Charmer-Parm Achenee Bell, with J. Miller in the saddle, won the Glenwood National Steeplechase, a three-mile brush race and feature of the two-day meet of the Middleburg Hunt, which closed today on the Glenwood course.

COMPETITIVE engineering, sound manufacturing policies and economical distribution make it possible for the independent automobile producer in America to claim a full share of the motor market. This has been true in the past; it is true now.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 14. -- With minute attention to detail, Trinity Church Parish House, this city, is being made over into a modern hotel lobby in preparation for the annual fair on Wednesday. The church, one of the oldest in the nation, was founded 248 years ago by the small band of Huguenots who settled New Rochelle.
A special concert for its pension fund will be given by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of John Barbirolli, on Monday evening, Nov. 23, at Carnegie Hall.

One of the most important functions this season on the schedule of the Drama Study Club will be the tea and bridge to be held in the new ballroom of the Hotel Astor at 2 P.M. Friday afternoon. More than 700 reservations are anticipated for the event, which marks a departure in character of entertainment for the organization. Mrs. Clare M. Senie is president.

AMERICA has reason to feel proud of the generosity and the vision which many of her men of wealth have given to music. Orchestras, libraries of books and scores, and heavily endowed musical institutions are the results of their munificence and public spirit.

Spurred by the heavy volume of retail distribution, which in some instances reached the highest level of the Fall season, all of the major branches of business throughout the country forged ahead at a fast pace last week. Further announcements of wage increases and the expansion of production in many lines of industry, as orders continued to pile up, acted as a strong stimulant to retail buying.

THIS book is only incidentally a book about "antiques." And in so far as it touches upon "antiques" it does so from a peculiarly interesting point of view. For Mrs. Rawson writes less about the things than about the men who made them.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- Thousands of visitors are expected to celebrate the Thanksgiving holiday period in Atlantic City and special programs for the occasion are being prepared. Theatres, hotel grills, night clubs, ocean piers and the Municipal Convention Hall will compete with the beach and boardwalk in their entertainment programs.

MR. EASTMAN -- the Joe Miller of the barricades -- has written the wittiest book on laughter I know. His learned doctorate is shrapneled with the most irresponsible stories you can remember. The pages bloom in bright and savage caricatures and cartoons by Thurber, Steig, Bacon, Wortman, Covarrubias, Young, Arno.

MAILAMM, the American Palestine Music Association, will give a concert in memory of Ossip Gabrilowitsch Monday night, Nov. 30, at the Society for the Advancement of Judaism, 15 West Eighty-sixth Street. Mr. Gabrilowitsch was honorary president of the association.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 13. -- Public ownership advocates in the Pacific Northwest suffered a setback when voters of both Oregon and Washington rejected proposals which would have authorized the States to float bond issues to finance the development and transmission of hydroelectric power.

FEW of the Americans who have seen the towering Queen Mary proceeding to sea saw her, a few years back, a half-finished and apparently forever-abandoned hull on the ways beside the Clyde. And those who did probably knew little of the thousands that the depression in shipping had made idle, of the general misery of which that rusting shell we a mute symbol.

THERE is a forthright lady -- to that blessed region born -- who says that the loveliest sight in all the world is a plowed field of Piedmont Virginia's rich red soil against the green of the rolling pasture land around. This story is about that same country -- which harbors Thomas Jefferson's Monticello on its flattened mountaintop and his university, nestling in the lesser hills below.

AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 14 (').-Professor Stephen B. Leacock of McGill University, addressing the annual meeting of the Amherst Alumni Council today on the subject "How Soon Can We Start the Next War?" said that the world had long outgrown the idea of separate nationalities but did not realize it.

EXPLOITED for years by unscrupulous white men as they made their last stand in the fastness of the Everglades swamp, Florida's 580 Seminole Indians at last find friends coming to their rescue -- exactly 100 years after the beginning of the Seminole War.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP). -- The Board of Tax Appeals ruled today that Almours Securities, Inc., a Florida corporation of which Alfred I. du Pont, his wife and brother-in-law were principal shareholders, was liable for more than $2,000,000 income taxes in 1928 and 1932.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- American universities are turning to a closer study of patents and the American patent system in an effort to prevent themselves and the public from exploitation, Dr. Karl T. Compton, president of Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said today in a letter to the centennial committee of the patent system.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- On the eve of the annual convention of the American Federation of Labor, which opens in Tampa next Monday, all wings, groups and factions of organized labor are discussing the possible effects of the recently collapsed "peace movement" in the dispute between the executive council of the A.F. of L. and the Committee for Industrial Organization and its bearing on the pending convention and the future of labor.

Car owners and would-be car owners are interested in economical car operation, to judge by the crowds which press around the exhibit at the special Ford show at the Hotel Astor. Yesterday they were thick before this display, which occupies the cast wall of the grand ballroom, where the new models of the Ford V-8 are shown.
THE Buick Motor Company this week came within a few cars of an all-time high in daily production, it was announced last week by Harlow H. Curtice, present, who is in New York for the vow.

An appeal to radio broadcasting companies to "keep the air clean" was made by Anning S. Prall, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, at a dinner in honor of Donald Flamm, president of the Knickerbocker Broadcasting Company and owner of WMCA, last night at the Hotel Plaza.

IN the excitement over the newly disclosed mass of songs by Hugo Wolf altogether too little attention seems to have been paid to other Wolf works which have come to light simultaneously with the Lieder. Unlike the latter, to be sure, they have not yet been published and when some day or other they are the general public will perhaps be less interested in them than the musician, the historian and the student.

We are now a few days away from Christmas, 1949 (wrote the Chinese historian Hai-Ho-Hum). More than thirty years have elapsed since the end of the Great War. In all that time the peace of the world has remained untroubled. How strange it is to look back to mid-November, 1936, and find Mr. WINSTON CHURCHILL predicting war in a few months! There has been no war.

BERNARD SHAW is a dramatist, a novelist, a philosopher, a Fabian Socialist, a literary critic, a theologian, a musical expert, and what not," says Dr. Sen Gupta of the Presidency College in Calcutta in beginning his study of the art of Bernard Shaw, which, by the way, forms "a substantial portion" of a Ph. D. thesis in the University of Calcutta.

THE romantic age of New England industry was not altogether romantic, of course. And even in a pleasant and picturesque historic picture, such as this book affords, there are some dark shadows and unhappy contrasts.

Two new units were admitted and granted charters at yesterday's convention of delegates of the United States Power Squadrons at the Hotel Astor, bringing the total now to twenty-one branch squadrons. The new Bayside unit, which will hold a meeting Tuesday night at 137-77 Northern Boulevard, is headed by Commander Graham V. Lowe, and the new unit centering among yachtsmen living in Maplewood, N.J., has as its temporary commanding officer Dr. Harlin S. DeVoe.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 14 (AP). -- Minnesota bull-dogged the Texas Longhorns in typical Gopher fashion today and when the sun had set on Memorial Stadium 45,000 spectators saw the brand of a 47 -- 19 defeat on the invaders from the Southwest.

Techniques of peace action and organization problems will be the subject of an all-day discussion by the New York Branch of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom on Saturday, when an institute convenes in Willard Straight Hall at Cornell University, Ithaca.

Traffic on the surface car and bus lines of the Third Avenue ]Railway System has shown an increase since July of about 3 per cent over the same period last year, stockholders of the Third Avenue ]Railway Company were told last week at their annual meeting.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14 (AP). -- Temple pushed over a last-period touchdown to beat its traditional rival, Villanova, 6 to 0, before 35,000 today. Chris Pappas plunged over for the score from the 2-yard line to complete a 29-yard march.

EAST ISLIP, L.I., Nov. 14. -- Princess Anne, a keen worker on land and in the water, today won the Amateur Handlers' Stake in the annual field meeting of the American Chesapeake Club. This was the only event to be completed during the second day of the trials on the estates of Jay F. Carlisle and Charles L. Lawrence.

A plea for some "approximation of the truth" in the teaching of history was made yesterday by Hendrik Willem van Loon, historian and author, at the closing session of the Eastern States regional conference of the Progressive Education Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

"Although my husband is a politician, my interests in politics are restricted," said Countess Marthe de Fels, French writer and art critic, whose husband Count Andre de Fels is publisher of the Revue de Paris, a member of the French Chamber of Deputies, and a leader of the Alliance Democratique, a centre party.

LIKE Eliot's "Murder in the Cathedral," Mr. Williams's play was written for production at Canterbury Cathedral during the annual week of music and drama. It is also a poetic play, stylized and simplified in its setting, capable of presenting a historical dramatic event in a swift dramatic unity, chiefly through the feelings and emotions of a single central character.

WHAT the woman in the family thinks about a new automobile counts somewhere between 50 and 95 per cent in the decision as to its purchase, according to guesses made by salesmen and demonstrators at the National Automobile Show.

REVIVED efforts for the purchase from the Republic of Mexico of its territory of Lower California have been launched in the West. A proposal that formal investigation of the possibility of adding 58,000 square miles to continental United States, so as to revive the "American frontier" and provide a "new State in which New Deal policies may be given a real test," was launched in the final weeks of the last Congress.

GHENT, N.Y., Nov. 14. -- Tillie, Myrtle and Jennie, elephants owned by Mr. and Mrs. Louis E. Reed, earn their board whether they're appearing on the vaudeville stage, in a circus ring or in a Columbia County hay field.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- Representative Caroline O'Day will be the ranking member of a group of ten women who will fly from Washington to Buenos Aires to present to the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace the petitions against war and preparations for war which have been circulated in this country during the past year by the Peace Mandate Committee.

In its latest bulletin the Public Administration Clearing House reviews results on local and State issues throughout the country on election day. While these showed no marked trends, they did reveal a number of significant attitudes. Voters of several cities and one county favored proposals submitted to them for strengthening the merit system.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered further yesterday and ended unchanged to 3 points higher on the day. An improvement in Liverpool, figures showing the largest domestic consumption for an October on record; a reduction of 225,000 bales in a private estimate of the Indian crop and an increase in the December premium to 28 points over the July combined to counteract developments in the stock market.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- The first of the new destroyers to be completed in the naval building program will be named for the late Admiral William S. Sims, commander of the United States fleet in European waters during the World War, according to Secretary Swanson.

The West Sixty-third Street Community House will be the beneficiary of a dinner dance to be held Wednesday in the Embassy Room and garden of the Ambassador. Several young women headed by Miss Isabel Livingston Fountain are helping in the arrangement for the benefit.

IN those days when the far past, now so new to us, was all but entirely forgotten, a few once famous names lingered on in men's memories, often because of their association with some biblical character. One of these was that Ur of the Chaldees whence came Abraham.

Play-clothes are the big "news" in cruise and resort fashions, according to a special style report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES. by Tobe, fashion authority and merchandising consultant. America is all ready to play this Winter, and stores should be prepared with adequate stocks and suitable promotions to profit by the volume of business in tropical wear which will be available.

More than 1,000 leaders in the fields of science, engineering and industry are expected to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the founding of the American patent system at a special assembly in Washington, on Nov. 23, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Charles F. Kettering, chairman of the national centennial committee.

Without any intention of doing so I left an implication in my article that the insertion in the State Constitution of the provision excluding aliens from being taken into account in the apportionment, on an inhabitant basis, of Senate districts had been the handiwork of the 1894 Constitutional Convention.

THERE is no question that the motor car of today far outstrip, from an engineering point of view, the average highway over which it is driven. Throughout the country seventy-mile-per-hour vehicles must roll under wraps along thirty-mile-per-hour highways.

BOSTON, Nov. 13. -- There are many indications of progressively better times for the mill towns of New England. New industries are replacing old ones and old concerns are resuming dividends. Many cities now have no factory space unoccupied.

One of the largest collections of United States silver coins that has been offered at auction for a long time will be sold next Thursday and Friday afternoons in the Morgenthau Galleries, 1 West Forty-seventh Street, under the direction of Wayte Raymond and J.G. Macallister.
Your editorial, "High Cost of Funerals," should have been elaborated so as to furnish the reason for the overcrowding of the undertaking profession.

THIS homespun novel masquerades as fine silk. The subject itself is commonplace enough, being the enduring love of a pioneer wife for the restless husband who abandoned her, but it is pursued in such lyrical terms that it seems more like a myth than a sociological fact.

IN this tale of a Scotch family in India the American reader is introduced to a novelist of stature. Hilton Brown, though long a contributor of short stories and verse in English magazines, including Punch, has done little hitherto in fall-length fiction, and what he has done has not been published on this side of the Atlantic.

H. DE MOUTHERLANT has a genius for being at once stimulating and puzzling. He ascends summits of passion or thought, subjugates the reader by the depth or subtlety of his observation, the strength of his pathos, the originality of his style; then, the next moment, he seems to make fun of human truth, human passion, human dignity and the tragic entanglements he has called up.

"Bouncing Betsy" is a Spring picture which forms a perfect companion piece for "Who Goes There?", the lovely story Dorothy Lathrop wrote last year of the little creatures of the wood in the first snowfall.
NEED there be war? Millions in many lands are asking this, and none can answer. My own answer, a mere matter of personal opinion, is "No, not if certain conditions be fulfilled."

A flexible, simplified National Industrial Recovery Act, confined to regulation of hours and wages and elimination of child labor, will be welcomed by many executives in the various branches of the textile industry and will not be opposed strongly by those usually against government intervention, a canvass of the leading factors in the industry revealed yesterday.
Two pass interceptions, a fumble and a 60-yard run-back of a punt were the starting points of all the scoring sorties in Notre Dame's victory over Army by 20 -- 6 at the Yankee Stadium yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14. -- Miss Elizabeth Jane Jordan, daughter of Mrs. T. Carrick Jordan of Chestnut Hill, was the guest of honor tonight at a dinner dance given by her uncle, C. Mahlon Kline, at the Bellevue-Stratford.

LIMA, Peru, Nov. 14. -- Peru solved today the embarrassing problem of holy to prevent the election of Dr. Luis Antonio Eguiguren as President by extending the term of Dr. Oscar Raimundes Benavides three years until Dec. 8, 1939.

Mrs. Frederic B Pratt, chairman of patronesses for the annual Yuletide ball to be held for the benefit of the Brooklyn Free Kindergarten Society on Dec. 29 at the Heights Casino, Brooklyn, announced yesterday an initial list of patrons and patronesses for the ball.

"Roller Skates" is a refreshingly lively and genuine story of a 10-year-old in the Nineties, who was left, while her family went to Europe, with Miss Peters, and her sister, Miss Nettie. Miss Peters taught and Miss Nettie did sewing, and they were both, as Lucinda found out during that heavenly year of freedom, people of great understanding, no nonsense and no interference.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14. -- Newspapers should be basic medium of insurance companies in attempting to make their name a household word, said J.P. Lyons of the Manufacturers Life Insurance Company, Canada, at the closing session of the Life Advertisers Association here today.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 14. -- In a surprise raid on a three-story house at 225 Private Way, in the heart of the Winter resort colony here, about 4 P.M. today Sheriff Walter H. Applegate, Under-Sheriff Charles H. Feeney and nine deputies arrested three men on charges of maintaining a gambling place and held a fourth as a material witness.

Friday the 13th was an occasion of good fortune for Mrs. Mary Flanagan, wife of a carpenter and farmer of Montrose, W. Va., and mother of ten children, it was revealed yesterday by Miss Adele Springer.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 14. -- The Yale freshman eleven finally found itself in the last game of its campaign and downed the Harvard yearlings, 26 to 14, in the Bowl today.

SETAUKET, L.I., Nov. 14. -- In one of the closest contests seen in field trials this year, Henry L. Ferguson's Fleet of Falcon Hill today won first award in the open all-age stake for English springer spaniels at the American Spaniel Club meeting at Strong's Neck.

Newtown High School kept the City P.S.A.L. cross-country title and possession of the Lieutenant John Overton trophy when its entire team came home among the first twenty-four to finish in the re-run of the championship at Van Park yesterday.

ONE waited the appearance of this novel with some trepidation. Janet Beith's first novel -- or rather, her first published novel, for she seems to be one of those conscientious literary craftsmen who discard various manuscripts unsatisfactory to themselves before presenting one to the world -- was "No Second Spring," winner of a $20,000 international prize award.

A supper dance with a special entertainment program is being arranged for the night of Dec. 7 in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria as a benefit for the Big Brother Movement. Committees are being organized for the fete, which is expected to draw a large attendance of persons prominent in society.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- President Roosevelt took preliminary steps today aimed at placing under the merit system employes of temporary agencies which will become parts of the permanent establishment. He also conferred with advisers making studies of simplification and reorganization in the Federal establishment itself.

MARTINSDALE, Mont., Nov. 14. -- A pair of baby buffalo are among big game animals receiving a course of training here for exhibition at the World's Fair in New York in 1939. The animals are being trained by their owner, Courtland Durand of Martinsdale.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- The contest for Majority Leader of the House, with Representatives Rayburn of Texas, Rankin of Mississipi, and Mead and O'Connor of New York as chief candidates, has brought to the face the dissatisfaction among Northern Democrats against Southern dominance of House Committee chairmanships and other important congressional posts.

Holiday House in their little "stocking books" and their Nursery Rhyme Broadsides, provide a link between the present and the past. For, in size, "Puss in Boots" and "The Old Woman and Her Pig" suggest the old chapbooks in which children, two hundred years ago, made their first acquaintance with fairy tales.

These two little books written and illustrated by the young son of the American painter, Guy Pene du Bois, are an irresistible bit of fun. They have that solemn and perfectly reasonable absurdity which little children adore, and which, when it is as well carried out as is the case in the Otto books, delights grown-ups as well.

THE late Dr. Utter of California University, to whom this book owes its inception, and Mrs. Needham, who collaborated with him, have produced what is one of the most original and exhilarating studies in English literature that the twentieth century has seen.

Women interested in the work of the Girls Service League will meet tomorrow at the Pierre for luncheon and discussion of the Winter program of the organization. Mrs. Alexander M. Hadden, president; Mrs. Robert L. Gerry Jr., Mrs. Sidney C. Borg, Mrs. Raymond W. Lewis, Mrs. Julius Ochs Adler, Mrs. Frank Altschul, Mrs. Darwin P. Kingsley, Mrs. Paul Baerwald and Mrs. Howard W. Vernon will act as hostesses.

Several young women headed by Miss Anna Glen Butler will assist Mrs. Bromwell Ault at the tea table at the annual Christmas sale for the benefit of Hope Farm on Wednesday and Thursday at the Pierre. They are the Misses Lucy Saunders, Barbara Field, Beatrice Butler, Grace Sloane, Helen Wilmerding, Emily Winslow, Margaret Rives, Mildred Godwin, Eileen and Phyllis Gillespie, Flora Garvin, Lisa Renshaw, Anna Schenck, Sara Clucas, Louise Whitehouse and Pauline du Pont.

CARAVANS of trucks laden with commodities of every description are thundering over the highways of America in numbers that have never before been approached. Created originally to take the place of horse-drawn vehicles in the field of light hauls and short runs, the truck has widened its sphere until it has become a formidable competitor of the railroad, transporting tons of freight between points as far distant as Florida and New York.

UNDER the leadership of Serge Koussevitzky, the Boston Symphony Orchestra will open its fifty-first season in New York Thursday evening. At the second concert, to be given in Carnegie Hall Saturday afternoon, Mr Koussevitzky will give the first performance in New York of Olivier Messiaen's "Les Offrandes Oubliees."

Fascism and communism in Europe are only new names and methods for exaggerated nationalism and the dictators of Europe represent a craving for national self-preservation, Mrs. Anne O'Hare McCormick told the New York Principals Association last night at a dinner at the Hotel Biltmore.

PARIS, Nov. 23. -- The fifteenth aviation salon opened here yesterday in the presence of President Albert Lebrun, America, Britain, the Netherlands, Poland, Czechoslovakia and Russia were represented, but Italy and Germany were missing.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Proposals for spending $2,041,000 on seaplane bases at two tiny mid-Pacific islands were disclosed today, but State Department officials hastened to assert they had no military significance.

A folio edition of Audubon's "The Birds of America," published in London between 1827 and 1839, is, among the items to be sold this] week at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, where on Tuesday and Wednesday Part 1 of J the library formed by Mrs. lfllton E. Getz of Beverly Hills, Calif., will be dispersed.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 14. -- Holy Cross routed Brown today, 32 to 0.
GETS ABOUT: The Presidential luggage, which gets a lot of wear, is being packed again. This week Mr. Roosevelt leaves for a cruise which will add more thousands to his impressive mileage total.
College notes, rather neglected this Fall because of international field hockey, have been piling up.
MIDDLETON, Conn., Nov. 14. -- Wesleyan downed a hard-fighting Rochester team today, 35 to 19.

TEN years have passed since the Paramount Theatre, first of Broadway's cinema cathedrals, opened its doors to a distinguished invited gathering on Nov. 19, 1926, while that glamorous high priestess of the night-club era, the late Texas ("Hello Sucker") Guinan vainly offered $200 for a pair of seats.

PANAMA has been called "the crossroads of the New World." More than ever it is living up to that title. The Panama Canal in September transferred a record tonnage for that month from ocean to ocean. In the coming Winter the Canal Zone will be host to an exceptional number of visitors from "The States."

MOSCOW, Nov. 14. -- Phenomenally favorable weather in the great cotton regions of Soviet Central Asia, continuing long past the date when killing frosts normally arrive, has reduced the likelihood that American growers will sell any great amount to the Soviet this year.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 14 (AP). -- The Otsego County Board of Supervisors left to its finance committee today a decision whether to accept either or both of two offers of property and cash involving more than $200,000 from the wealthy Clark brothers, rivals in charitable undertakings.

'DAMNABLE': In the revue "New Faces," which had a Broadway run of seven months, there is a skit which pictures Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt haranguing the Girl Scouts. The first Lady and the President think it's funny; their sons have laughed over it; Chairman Farley likes it.
TOKYO, Sunday, Nov. 15. -- Although there is no formal alliance between Japan and Germany, there is an agreement that is more than a mere declaration against communism.

SIMSBURY, Conn., Nov. 14. -- Westminster closed its 1936 season by falling before an undefeated Pawling eleven by the score of 26 to 0 today. The visitors scored in every period and continually carried the attack to the Simsbury team, keeping the ball in Westminster's territory most of the game.

LONDON, Nov. 14. -- A barrage of balloons to defend London -- mentioned in a speech by Sir Thomas Inskip, Minister for Coordination of Defense, in debates this week in the House of Commons -- is an idea suggested at the close of the World War. Sir Thomas said:

OUT to the southwesternmost part of the United States, where the Rio Grande cuts its way through mountains of limestone to establish a border line between the United States and Mexico, nature lovers will travel in the next few years to enjoy the splendors and scenic beauties of what eventually is expected to be the largest international park on this continent.

HERE is a book of human encouragement which lays no claim to being inspirational, and which -- since it neither flatters its readers nor soft-pedals the difficulty and malaise of our time -- can perhaps not even be called optimistic in the generally accepted sense of that word.

Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer M. Singer gave a tea dance yesterday afternoon in the Louis Sherry Room of Sherry's for Mr. and Mrs. James R. Bartholomew, Colonel and Mrs. Wade Hampton Carpenter, Mr. and Mrs. Harold H. Burns, Mr. and Mrs. George Breen and Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Heather, who were their guests at the Army-Notre Dame football game at the Yankee Stadium.

The many lovers of "The Tale of Mr. Tootleoo," which has been a favorite with children over a long period of years, will be ready to give a most hearty welcome to another book about this jovial sailor. Life on shore having proved wearisome to such an intrepid adventurer, Mr. T. takes a berth on board a sailing ship.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14. -- Retail trade made a better showing than wholesale this week, with gains averaging 15 to 18 per cent ahead of the like period last year. Sales totals were also somewhat better than in the week preceding. Demand was broad, although the return of mild weather slowed heavy apparel lines somewhat.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentine, Nov. 12. -- No Pan-American conference ever met under such promising auspices as those surrounding preparations for the forthcoming Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace, which opens here Dec. 1.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 14 (AP). -- On the lawn swing at the Gouverneur Morris beach home where his body was found last September, detectives Monday will try to re-enact the death of Reid Russell, 28, first called a suicide, but now the center of a reopened investigation.

"We must see that the Republican point of view is fairly presented," said John D.M. Hamilton at Kansas City last week, just before his first conference with Governor Alfred M. Landon of Kansas since the election. The Republican National Chairman was discussing his party's immediate future.

THE standard formula for prize ring novels allows no departure from the general principles, only too familiar, which invariably dictate the construction of stories in this category. Mr. Tully has here abided by those principles, but he has manipulated them with so skillful an artistry that the resultant work acquires a freshness and vitality which one had long thought extinct qualities in pugilistic fiction.

Spills aplenty marked the Park Department's first roller-skating carnival on its new rink, Circle Lawn, in Central Park yesterday afternoon, when 250 youthful skating champions from all parts of the city gathered to compete for medals and other prizes.

BERLIN, Nov. 14. -- The German Government today ripped another page out of the Treaty of Versailles when it notified the signatory powers immediately concerned that it no longer considered valid and binding the provisions governing the internationalization and control of Germany's principal waterways.

LONDON, Nov. 14. -- Chancellor Hitler's denunciation of the last remnant of the Treaty of Versailles, while unlikely to affect Great Bri tain, is resented here as another illustration of the "tearing up method" of destroying pacts and solemn obligations which has become only too common in Europe.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Nov. 14 (AP). -- Purdue's Boilermakers steamed over Iowa, 13 to 0, today to add a final dismal touch to the Hawkeyes' dreary Big Ten season. Fifteen thousand saw the Boilermakers, their ground attack halted, forced to aerial tricks to score two first-period touchdowns.

PARIS, Nov. 13. -- Spain is getting more and more like a vortex that threatens to suck all Europe into itself. Madrid's heroic defense has aroused doubt here of the ultimate success of the Rebels but for practical purposes the presumption is that they will take the capital sooner or later, and when they do it will be judgment day for the chancelleries of the great European powers.

IF it were possible to translate the life of Edgar Allan Poe into a drama, Sophie Treadwell, Henry Hull and Arthur Hopkins could do it. She is the author of "Plumes in the Dust," a three-act sketch of Poe's haggard career that closed last evening; Mr. Hull acted the part with considerable pride in the integrity of an honorable man of letters, and Mr. Hopkins blessed the play with one of his finest productions.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Nov. 14 (AP). -- In one brilliant offensive period, Sammy Baugh threw two touchdown passes today and then retired to watch his inspired Texas Christian University team-mates trounce the Centenary eleven, 26 to 0, today.

Ellis Credle has the gift of telling a story of real children with perfect naturalness and, in text and drawings together, she manages to present a genuine bit of the American scene. Her first picture story book has as a background the Blue Ridge Mountains, and the second a tobacco plantation in the South.

A very rapid decline in the birth rate and a rapidly increasing divorce rate are two factors now changing the character of the American family, Dr. Louis I. Dublin, third vice president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, told an audience of women last week at a meeting of the Child Study Association, 221 West Fifty-seventh Street.

The task of registering employers and employes under the Federal Social Security Act will begin tomorrow, with the distribution through the postal service of applications for employer identification numbers.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 14. -- Scholarships have been awarded to 142 Massachusetts upper-class men of high scholastic standing in Harvard College for the current academic year by the Harvard Corporation, it was announced today. The awards are valued at $34,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14. -- The St. Joseph's College eleven struck twice to defeat C.C.N.Y. today, 13 to 0, before a home-coming crowd of 5,000 spectators. The football meeting was the first between two institutions.
Second of the important retriever field trial meetings in the Eastern district will be that of the Labrador Retriever Club, which will start at 10 o'clock tomorrow morning at Peapack, N.J.

No single group or family of plants stands out quite so distinctly in the late Summer garden as the hardy lilies. Though towering above most of their companions, they are entirely free from any of the coarseness or weediness characteristic of many tall plants.

THE brief, direct, clear-cut type of unsophisticated story, the type whose simplicity is childlike but not childish, and whose pathos does not slop over into bathos, is none too easy to write, nor is it very frequently met with in our modern fiction, but an excellent story of this kind is here presented by a new writer, Melanie Earle Keiser, under the rather clumsy title, "God Returns to the Vuelta Abajo."

AN outcast from its once lordly estate as drawing-room companion of kings and nobles, snuff nevertheless goes valiantly on. Last year, even with a slight falling off in demand, sales of the three principal snuff-manufacturing companies totaled more than $3,000,000.

Theatre parties are among the popular ways of raising funds for charitable organizations, and several have been arranged for the near future. The performance of "And Stars Remain" tomorrow night at the Guild Theatre, for which there has been an encouraging subscription, will benefit the Children's Village.
DETROIT, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Max Tushman, who fired five shots at "the face at the window" as he guarded his pre-Thanksgiving turkey stock, was thankful today that he did not kill the policeman.

Miss Anne Crawford Allen, State Forest Fire Warden for Kent County, R.I., arrived here yesterday by air on a still hunt for women who have the courage to accept social invitations with the proviso that they may have to leave on a moment's notice.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP). -- President Roosevelt was said by authoritative administration sources today to be considering new legislation to tighten restrictions on campaign spending.

GLADYS GEORGE, realizing that one outstanding role is all that is necessary to insure lasting fame in the cinema, is endeavoring to persuade executives at Metro to permit her to journey to the Samuel Goldwyn lot for "Stella Dallas.

Four 18-year-old youths strolled at 12:30 o'clock yesterday morning toward a Brooklyn ice cream parlor. They conversed casually about the imminent football games. And with no other thoughts in the world at the moment they blundered into a bedlam of scattering men and a fury of shouting and an exchange of shots.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 14. -- Central High School's eleven won the championship of the Newark High Schools Football League by scoring a 13-0 triumph over South Side High today. It was the first time since 1933 that a Central team has won the title.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 14. -- Michigan's ailing but valiant Wolverines staged a heroic struggle against Northwestern's powerful gridiron machine today in Michigan Stadium, but the Wildcats, sparked by chunky Steve Toth, rolled on to a 9-to-0 victory to complete a sweep of their Western Conference football activities for the season.

The Four-Year Plan is to assure Germany's economic independence. So says the Fuhrer; so says GOERING. The research laboratories are to consider only national needs; chemists, physicists, metallurgists, specialists of a hundred kinds are to be organized in a mighty effort to meet the exigencies of totalitarian peace and of the war to come.

PEIPING. -- No inquiring traveler can visit Chahar, Suiyuan and Inner Mongolia today without being impressed with the certainty that the Japanese military mind, as exemplified by the Kwantung Army, is now engaged on the creation of a new Great Wall of Asia.

THE hoary riddle about the priority of the hen and the egg is no more suggestive of argument than a priority problem of a far different kind that Hans Kohn raises in his stimulating new book on the Near East.

BERLIN, Nov. 1. THE outstanding theatrical event of recent weeks was the season's opening at the Deutsches Theater, which, at one fell swoop, tied up three whole evenings. For ever since Heinz Hilpert has taken over the management of this house, Reinhardt's former stronghold, his annual commencement exercises have consisted of three complete productions brought out on successive evenings, a policy which he undoubtedly inaugurated with a practical eye toward his large subscription list.
With attendance continuing far beyond even the hopes of the management and exhibitors, the National Automobile Show at the Grand Central Palace had another busy period yesterday.

Over in Spain the most ambitious young bulls want more than anything to be chosen for the bull fights in Madrid. Consequently all the little bulls prepare by running and jumping and butting their heads together -- but not Ferdinand. He preferred to sit quietly under a tree and smell the flowers, and as his mother was an understanding mother, even though she was a cow, she let him just sit there and be happy.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 14 (AP). -- Boyd Brumbaugh, a 170-pound halfback from Springdale, Pa., soared to the heights of stardom today as he led Duquesne University to a 13-to-0 triumph over Carnegie Tech in a hard-fought battle staged before 35,000 sharply partisan fans.

FIVE years ago Sylvia Pankhurst devoted a volume of 525 pages to the suffragettes. She now tells the story in a book of one-third that size and the tale is clarified by compression. This is a lucid and accurate account of what happened.

WARRENTON, Va. -- The open season for shooting quail and other game in Fauquier County begins tomorrow, and will continue until Dec. 31. Hundreds of licenses have been sold in the county. All gunners, except those who shoot only on their own land, must be licensed.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 14. -- The governments of the Little Entente issued a joint statement today at Prague, Belgrade and Bucharest concerning that part of the communique published at the close of the Vienna conference of the Rome protocol signatories devoted to armament equality with obvious reference to Hungary.

Miss Marion Decker Fountain is chairman of debutantes participating in the sale of seats for the performance of "You Can't Take It With You," the new comedy by George S. Kaufman and Moss Hart, the night of Dec. 16 at the Booth Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the United Neighborhood Houses.

"Good-day-to-thee, Melissa-Louisa-Amanda-Marinda-Cynthia- Jane-Farlow!" Uncle Mark would gasp, breathless and red-faced, while the little girl who answered to that stupendous name would laugh at the best of all possible jokes. "Good-day to thee, Amanda-Miranda" the two pretty aunts as alike as peas-blossoms would say.

WHEN the first volumes in this series began to appear a decade or so ago, they were received with a deal of favorable comment that among many historians amounted to actual enthusiasm. At last, it was felt, there was to be available an up-to-date and convenient social history of America.

A DISSERTATION on nonsense from the pen of Richard Boleslawski, who, when he is not writing best sellers about the Lancer situation, is a film director of importance, charts the way of modern screen comedy. Mr. Boleslawski has but recently concerned himself with affairs of the venerable sock, having been occupied for most of the year with Selznick International's joust with the spectrum.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- What may prove to be the oldest remaining dwelling on Manhattan Island has been discovered by the Historic American Buildings Survey, and a movement for its preservation has been started.

Federal Judge Samuel Mandelbaum refused yesterday to permit the bankrupt National Public Service Corporation to reorganize under Section 77B of the Bankruptcy Act as had been proposed by Associated Gas and Electric interests, which are creditors.

Commercial educators throughout the country are looking with interest at a professional-looking shop set up in the entrance hall of the city's Central School of Business and Arts, 214 East Forty-second Street. Run by students as part of the merchandising course, the store will open by Thanksgiving as a gift shop for the Christmas trade of the 8,000 pupils.

THE coincidence that the demands of war and the desires of underwriters are the same in so far as inspections and replacements in planes are concerned was pointed out last week by Jerome Lederer of Aero Insurance Underwriters.

NEWTON, Mass., Nov. 14 (AP). -- Boston College defeated Western Maryland by 12 to 7 today and hardly had the gun barked to end the game when spectators swarmed onto the field to surround Gil Dobie, Boston coach, and Linesman J.R. Gilroy, who were arguing over a ruling which led to the visitors' only touchdown.

LONDON, Nov. 14. -- United States Ambassador and Mrs. Bingham were guests at Lord Camrose's reception for the book exhibition at Dorland Hall this week. Other guests were Thornton Butterworth, Miss Susan Ertz, Mr. and Mrs. Peter Fleming, Mr. and Mrs. Mark Hambourg, Edward Knoblock, Sir John Lavery and Brig. Gen. and Mrs. E.L. Spears.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 14. -- Memory Book won and Jean Bart finished second in the Prince George Autumn Handicap today as 15,000 spectators were unable to make up their minds between two sulkers. Both were considered top-class 3-year-olds at the beginning of the season, but moody performances worried their trainers, not to speak of the players.

WE are so accustomed to the foreshortenings, condensations and intensifications of contemporary narrative that we come upon "Bitter Victory" with something of a shock. For here is a novel projected in the grand style of the nineteenth century, a mountain of a novel, sprawling, incomplete and sometimes even inept, out of which, nevertheless, there emerges a great tragic figure.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- The murals representing the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution of the United States, painted by Barry Faulkner for the National Archives Building, were shown this week for the first time in the Exhibit Hall of the new building.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Nov. 14 (AP). -- Turning on the power in the third period, Ohio State, on two quick thrusts, smashed over two touch downs to trample Illinois, 13 to 0, today before a dad's day crowd of 18,000.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 14. -- The clubhouse of Patchogue Lodge, Benevolent Protective Order of Elks, sold today at the annual Suffolk County tax sale at the County Court House here for unpaid taxes for 1935, was bid in by the A.A. Abbott Co. Realty, Inc., of 330 West Forty-second Street, Manhattan.

ROME, Nov. 14. -- Among constitutional reforms expected to come up before the meeting of the Fascist Grand Council next Wednesday night is a matter concerning Premier Benito Mussolini's position in the new corporative State.

Substantial reduction in property investment by the railroads is disclosed by the 1936 year book of railroad information, issued last week by the committee on public relations of the Eastern railroads. E.E. Loomis, president of the Lehigh Valley Railroad, is chairman of the committee.

In one of its most impressive showings thus far this year, retail trade in the local area forged ahead notably last week. Featured by heavy Armistice Day shopping, department store sales showed an average increase over the 1935 comparative week of from 20 to 25 per cent, with some stores reporting increases of 40 per cent or more.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14. -- A big and powerful Penn eleven which was generally rated three touchdowns better than Penn State required a last-period goal-line stand to turn back the Nittany Lions today in their thirty-fifth meeting since 1890.

THERE are few great artists in this day and age who have refrained from broadcasting. Fritz Kreisler, violinist, is one of them; Ruth Draper, monologist, stepped out of that class the other evening to bring her character sketches to the radio in an American Red Cross program.

There were six Moreau daughters, all dressed alike, with initials running from A to F, according to age, and though there was one brother to carry on the family tradition of diplomacy, they too had been trained to remember always that they were diplomats as well ladies.

Although Henner's Lydia lives not far from Lancaster, in the Conestoga Valley, she has never been, when this story opens, much further from home than Hertzler's flour mill. Lydia's people are Amish, and they do not believe in pleasures too freely given.

Boris Todrin '37, co-editor of the Columbia Review, literary monthly of Columbia College, has won this year's Mariana Griswold Van Rensselaer Prize for the "best example of English lyric verse" written by a Columbia student, it was announced yesterday by Professor John H. Lyon of the Department of English.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Nov. 14 (AP). -- Benjamin F. Lister's Old Comrade won the Portsmouth Handicap today at Narragansett Park, where a near-capacity crowd of 35,000 watched the close of the New England horse racing season.

IT looks like a rough day leading up to a brisk evening. The Green Bay Packers are about to walk into the Brooklyn Dodgers. After that rumpus dies down and night comes on, an ice war that always has been waged with cold fury will be resumed when the star-spangled Americans skate out on the ice to meet the romping Rangers.

TOKYO, Nov. 14. -- Japanese naval authorities attach great importance to the reports that Major Gen. Edward M. Markham, chief of the United States Army Engineers, recommended on Thursday that a seaplane base be constructed at Midway Island for use in the Pan American Airways transpacific service.
PARIS, Nov. 14 (AP). -- The widow of Edgar Andre, German Communist executed last week at Hamburg, called for a "world crusade against fascism" in a speech tonight before 10,000 Leftists.

LONDON, Nov. 14. -- Although the Stock Exchange here was closed today and it was only a half day for banks and other financial houses, the chief topic of speculation in the City was the report from Washington that President Roosevelt would ask Congress for legislation to curb foreign investment in American securities.
MANHATTAN, Kan., Nov. 14 (AP). -- A high-geared Kansas State football team edged toward a tie for the Big Six title today by trampling Iowa State before 10,000 fans, 47 to 7.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- Business activity, allowing for seasonal variations, is maintaining at least the levels of October, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly-survey.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Nov. 14 (AP). -- Captain Ace Parker ran 105 yards returning a kickoff today and played otherwise brilliantly to lead Duke University to a 27-to-7 victory over North Carolina, virtually to clinch Southern Conference and State championships.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 14. -- Eighty-eight thousand steel workers in the Pittsburgh area will receive a pay increase averaging 10 per cent when they go to work Monday morning.

BERLIN, Nov. 13. -- Every year, during the week in which the larger part of the world observes the anniversary of the armistice that ended the World War, National Socialist Germany commemorates with equal solemnity the anniversary of Adolf Hitler's ill-starred putsch in Munich in 1923.
CHICAGO, Nov. 14 (AP). -- Major Gen. Frank Parker, retired, asserted today that cavalry had not been superseded by modern war machines.

MADRID, Nov. 14. -- Insurgent aviators killed fifty-three persons and wounded at least 150 today in sudden bombing of a crowded capital plaza where workers had gathered to discuss the defense of Madrid.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 14. -- A Yale team that absolutely refused to believe it was licked when most of the crowd of 57,000 in Palmer Stadium were convinced came back today to defeat Princeton, 26 to 23, in as wildly exciting a game as football has seen on any field.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 14. -- The "Black Flamingo," by Sam Jenny, was presented last night and tonight by the Drama Department of the Bronxville Women's Club. An informal dance followed the performance tonight.

The principal foreign currencies continued yesterday to appreciate in terms of the dollar, apparently reflecting a reversal of the recent strong movement of foreign money into this country. The pound sterling rose 11-16 cent to $4.89, at which level it showed a gain of 1 5-16 cent from a week ago.

The details of the plans for the 1939 New York World's Fair, and the methods for financing it, will be explained to more than 2,000 men and women invited to attend a dinner given by the officers of the fair at the Hotel Astor on Monday evening, Nov. 23.

Residents of Madrid watched last week the most spectacular form of modern warfare -- battle in the air. Loyalist and Insurgent planes traded machine-gun bullets as they manouevred above the city in a series of dogfights in which both sides suffered losses of men and machines.

Howard S. Cullman, vice chairman of the National Committee on Safety at Sea, made public yesterday a letter to President Roosevelt, urging the creation of a separate Federal body to deal exclusively with maritime labor problems, distinct from such questions as ship subsidies, mail contracts, and building plans.
In celebration of its fifteenth anniversary the Children's Welfare League is sponsoring a dinner dance at the Waldorf-Astoria on Saturday evening jointly with the Jewish Settlement of the East Side.

ARE we ever to hear the last of the Marceau Case? Mr. Keeler has previously written two novels, each giving a different solution of the mystery surrounding the death of Andre Marceau. This third book is not a new solution, but one of the characters is a member of the Marceau family, and the plot of the story hinges upon one of the previous solutions of the mystery.

Sports and games are the favorite hobbies of this year's Barnard freshmen, according to a report presented to Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve by Miss Agnes R. Wayman, head of the physical education department.

The projected invasion of Suiyuan, China, has been reported for several weeks, accompanied by Chinese accounts of resistance against the Manchukuoans and Mongols from Chahar Province. Suiyuan provincial forces were reported on Wednesday to have repulsed 30,000 attackers, whose equipment was said to have included fighting planes, armored cars and tanks.

Following a weak opening yesterday at which leading stocks were down from fractions to 3 points, the stock market steadied at the end of the first hour and met moderate support in the second. At the end of the brief trading period, however, the list was slightly lower on the day.

The Green Bay Packers, fighting to hold their co-ownership of the Western division leadership of the National Football League, will meet the Brooklyn Dodgers at Ebbets Field this afternoon in the only National League game in the city. The New York Giants will journey to Detroit for their all-important encounter with the champion Detroit Lions.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 14 (AP). -- Exit the "collegian" with the coonskin coat, enter the kind of student that college deans have been praying for.

A LARGE exhibition of sculpture by Anna Hyatt Huntington opened to the public yesterday at the American Academy of Arts and Letters, Broadway, between 155th and 156th Streets. It will remain current until next May.

The feature yesterday of trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange was strength in the United States Government issues. During the short session fourteen of these loans established price records, with gains in the list ranging from 1-32 to 14-32 point, while sales amounted to $1,283,300, compared with $514,700 the Saturday before.
History teaches this -- that peoples and governments have never learned anything from history.

Kidnapped late Wednesday night, a prize Maryland turkey hen, owned by John J. Raskob, the industrialist, and valued at $500, was returned alive and well yesterday to officials of the Poultry Industries Exposition through the questionably good offices of a jovial inebriate, who, although under suspicion, survived the mystery, a free man.

LEON TROTSKY is again looking for a visa on his passport. Almost any visa will do, except, of course, a Russian visa. The Stalin-Trotsky feud makes a Russian visa out of the question. Time was when Trotsky was the hero of every man who lived under the Red flag, the incarnation of militant communism and Lenin's inevitable successor -- a Bolshevist Napoleon with a most un-Bolshevist air of military precision about him.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP). -- Cotton consumed during October was reported by the census bureau today to have totaled 646,499 bales of lint and 72,546 of linters, compared with 629,727 and 67,859 during September this year, and 552,840 and 67,279 during October last year.

FORTY-FIFTH STREET is the street of hits and you can call that a tradition. If you are collecting traditions this morning, there is also this one: nobody is supposed ever to admit his surprise at anything on Broadway, lest there be a state of general and foolish perplexity conducive neither to art nor to commerce.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 14 (AP). -- Secretary Wallace, comparing the Agricultural Adjustment Act to an automobile, told the National Grange today, "right now we are drawing plans for a 1937 model."

BRUNSWICK, Me., Nov. 14. -- A brilliant Tufts team took to the air lines twice to defeat Bowdoin, champions of Maine, today, 13 -- 0. It was Bowdoin's first defeat on Whittier Field in two years under Adam Walsh.

How the plans for the conquest of Ethiopia were made in 1933, how they were executed in 1935-36, are for the first time officially revealed by the protagonists in two books; "Preparations and First Operations," by Marshal Emilio de Bono, who began the campaign, and "The War of Ethiopia," by Marshal Pietro Badoglio, who completed it.

A NEW chapter is opening, as a chapter is ended, in the history of New Hampshire's largest and most important industrial city. For years the life of Manchester has revolved about the Amoskeag Manufacturing Company, whose mills, taken together, comprised what was proudly called the world's greatest cotton textile plant.
LONDON, Nov. 13. -- "Business as usual" continues to be the motto of the British Government as it sees clouds gather over Europe and tries desperately to rearm itself in time.

A spectacular new act in the far-flung epic of Japanese expansion has now emerged upon the open stage of the Asiatic Continent, this time in Inner Mongolia. This act, unless halted by an aroused Chinese "audience," is destined to add a new member to the world's family of nations.

BERLIN, Nov. 14. -- Peter Joseph Wilhelm Debye, winner of the Nobel Prize in chemistry, is a research scientist who has succeeded completely in escaping the notice of the general public of the city where he has lived for years. He is now a professor at the University of Berlin and one of the great figures at the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, where he carries on his research.

THE ever-growing interest in the paintings of Cezanne, Gauguin, Van Gogh, Picasso and others of this extraordinary group of painters focuses attention on the visit of Ambroise Vollard to this country. For M. Vollard was not only one of the first men to appreciate the works of these painters but he was also the intimate friend of most of them.

Raskob, the industrialist, and valued at $500, was returned alive and well yesterday to officials of the Poultry Industries Exposition through the questionably good offices of a jovial inebriate, who, although under suspicion, survived the mystery, a free man.

Before a crowd of 8,500 yesterday at Memorial Field, the undefeated and unscored-upon Flushing High School football team registered a 6-0 victory over the Jamaica eleven in the nineteenth contest between the Queens rivals.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 14. -- Before a crowd of more than 4,000, the Union College football team completed its first season under Coach Nelson Nitchman today by easily defeating its ancient rival, Hamilton, 18 to 0. It was the fourth victory of the season for Union.

THIS rhymed protest was chanted underneath the windows of a college kitchen by a group of Western co-eds. They -- like many students in many colleges -- didn't like the food. But when they expressed their dislike in verse they used milder words than their fellow-collegians usually employ.

LEADERS of American radio, together with prominent executives of European broadcasting, met in New York during the past week to celebrate the tenth anniversary of the National Broadcasting Company. Progress of the decade was reviewed and some of the speechmakers were inspired by the records of the past to glimpse ahead.

IN the sections of the annual report of the Bureau of Aeronautics released for publication today there is very little reference to the new weapon which is being forged for the navy, the fleet of giant patrol boats now being constructed at the San Diego factory of Consolidated Aircraft.
"Sword of the Wilderness" is a fine historical story of the days when the Indians were apt at any moment to fall upon Maine settlers, plundering, killing and carrying off captives.

He is now a professor at the University of Berlin and one of the great figures at the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, where he carries on his research.

For M. Vollard was not only one of the first men to appreciate the works of these painters but he was also the intimate friend of most of them.

Still smarting from losses incurred through an uncontrolled price war here six months ago, liquor retailers, wholesalers and distillers were convinced yesterday that they have made a repetition of that development impossible. Through the combined efforts of distillers, jobbers and retailers during the last four months, more than 1,000 retailers have bound themselves under Feld-Crawford act contracts with distillers not to sell brands below a pre-determined minimum price.

New York University's football team, gaining momentum against a hapless Rutgers eleven as the battle advanced, crushed the invaders from the shores of the Raritan, 46 to 0, at the Polo Grounds before a scattered gathering of 6,000 persons yesterday.

To Lionel Reid and R. Denison, who were responsible last year for "Bobo Dee," we again owe a debt of gratitude. Author and artist see eye to eye and text and drawings are equally gay and clever. In "Miss Carlotta" they have given us another picture book that is refreshing in its originality and unexpectedness.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 14. -- In strict conformity with traffic signals, where green means "Go" and red indicates "Stop." the Big Green Dartmouth eleven today romped up and down Schoellkopf Field to topple the Big Red Cornell team, 20 -- 6, and left here tonight more than ever regretful about that one lapse of the season against Holy Cross.
IF people would keep in mind a few facts bearing on the safety problem, we could reduce our accident toll by an impressive figure. Here are some of the things to be remembered:

Several debutantes, under the direction of Mrs. Robert Emmet Allen, have formed a committee to assist with details for the "Tintype Tea" to be held Thursday at the Savoy-Plaza under the auspices of Auxiliaries 1 and 16 of the Stony Wold Sanatorium.

MADRID, Nov. 14 (Censored). -- Fifty-three persons were killed and about 150 wounded when three Insurgent planes today dropped five bombs on Atocha Square in central Madrid near the Andalusian railroad station.

Before a crowd of 8,500 yesterday at Memorial Field, the undefeated and unscored-upon Flushing High School football team registered a 6-0 victory over the Jamaica eleven in the nineteenth contest between the Queens rivals.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 14. -- Before a crowd of more than 4,000, the Union College football team completed its first season under Coach Nelson Nitchman today by easily defeating its ancient rival, Hamilton, 18 to 0. It was the fourth victory of the season for Union.

THIS rhymed protest was chanted underneath the windows of a college kitchen by a group of Western co-eds. They -- like many students in many colleges -- didn't like the food. But when they expressed their dislike in verse they used milder words than their fellow-collegians usually employ.

LEADERS of American radio, together with prominent executives of European broadcasting, met in New York during the past week to celebrate the tenth anniversary of the National Broadcasting Company. Progress of the decade was reviewed and some of the speechmakers were inspired by the records of the past to glimpse ahead.

IN the sections of the annual report of the Bureau of Aeronautics released for publication today there is very little reference to the new weapon which is being forged for the navy, the fleet of giant patrol boats now being constructed at the San Diego factory of Consolidated Aircraft.
"Sword of the Wilderness" is a fine historical story of the days when the Indians were apt at any moment to fall upon Maine settlers, plundering, killing and carrying off captives.

THE idea of this long narrative poem is a good one. The poet tells the story of the gold rush to California as symbolic of men's and the country's mad lust after wealth. With several friends and one woman among them, the poet, a student at this time and in college, sets forth on the Western trail.

Anticipating a rapid home-building development in Queens between Flushing and Jamaica, John J. Halleran, Borough Commissioner of Public Works, has directed that a survey be made for future highways, sewers, water mains and electric light lines, it was revealed yesterday.

Your correspondent in Vienna made it known on Nov. 12 that according to the decision reached at the conference held in that city by the States of the Rome bloc, these were in full agreement with the rearming of Hungary. This is the fourth member of that coalition known during the Great War as the Central Powers who defy the peace treaties.

CROSSVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 15 (AP). -- Four employes of the Cumberland Homesteads, Rural Resettlement Administration project near here, have appealed to President Roosevelt for an investigation of their charges of coercion and unfair tactics in connection with its operation.

After a first day of weakness in foreign exchanges, as this was carried forward from the irregularity in the preceding week due to the heavy flow of capital from abroad, quotations tightened on Tuesday and continued strong over the remaining days to close at a substantial gain over the preceding week.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15. -- College football's dizziest campaign in years today faces the semi-final stage with championship conflicts still to be settled conclusively in six of the eight major zones of rivalry.

LONDON, Nov. 15. -- Further reaction today in financial circles here concerning President Roosevelt's proposal to put a curb on foreign investments in United States securities drew from one international banking authority the assertion that such investing was the most important single factor in the proper regulation of Anglo-American currency exchange.

The chief significance that the recent elections have for business is that they show that the American people firmly desire to have their government actively participate in their economic problems, Colonel Leonard P. Ayres, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company, has written in the current issue of the company's business bulletin.

"Hedda Gabler," in which she made her English-speaking debut in 1906, brings Alla Nazimova to the Longacre this evening. Supporting Ibsenites are McKay Morris, Harry Ellerbe, Edward Trevor, Viola Frayne, Leslie Bingham and Grace Mills, all under Mme. Nazimova's direction and against settings by Stewart Chaney.

A week's celebration of the eighty-fifth anniversary of the Mott Haven Reformed Church, 348 East 146th Street, the Bronx, was begun yesterday morning. The church, oldest of its denomination in the vicinity, was organized Nov. 17, 1851, on land granted by Jordan L. Mott, after whom the Mott Haven section is named.

The new six-story Bible House at 450 Park Avenue, the third headquarters of the American Bible Society in its 120 years, was dedicated yesterday afternoon at a service in which Protestant leaders took part.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- The price of peace for the nations of today's war-torn world is either acquiescence in the German ideal of a Mitteleuropa or assumption of responsibility for the maintenance of existing treaties in Central and Eastern Europe, Andre Geraud (Pertinax), French publicist and writer, tonight told more than 1,200 men and women, including the diplomatic representatives of several European powers.

Ch. Little Sahib, the brilliant orange pomeranian which possesses one of the heaviest and fluffiest coats ever cultivated by a dog of his type, topped 145 toys in the fourth annual Progressive Dog Club exhibition at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday. Eleven breed winners competed for the best-in-show award.

LONDON, Monday, Nov. 16. -- A Spanish Insurgent communique reports that three columns of the left flank of General Jose Varela's army crossed the Manzanares River into Madrid yesterday and occupied a position defended by Loyalists, according to a Reuters dispatch from Madrid.

The increase of 800,000 bales in the prospective cotton crop announced on last Monday by the Department of Agriculture was a surprise to the cotton trade, and last week prices on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 17 to 35 points net.
The three-year reign of Michigan State in Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. cross-country running will hang in the balance this afternoon.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 15. -- Margaret Garland Sullavan, stage and motion-picture actress who now is the leading lady in "Stage Door" at the Music Box Theatre in New York, was married here this afternoon to Leland Hayward of New York, literary agent and movie scout.

Savoyards from both sides of the Atlantic gathered at a dinner last night at the Park Central Hotel to pay tribute to a leader of their cult, Sir William Schwenck Gilbert, librettist of the Gilbert and Sullivan light operas and author, among many other things, of the "Bab Ballads."

Fellowship of the spirit transcends denominational boundaries and unites various churches in the preaching of the same fundamental truths, the Rev. Elmore McNeill McKee, rector of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, said yesterday at the second annual fellowship dinner of the parishioners of Grace Church, held at the Hotel Brevoort.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 15. -- The Essex County Tax Board is expected to reject, at its meeting tomorrow, the petition filed yesterday by the Newark City Commission asking permission to add to its ratables, as an "omitted assessment," $300,000,000 of personal property of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), incorporated in New Jersey as a holding company for the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, a Delaware corporation.

J.P. Morgan, banker, and Dr. Ernest Muir, the new general and medical secretary of the British Empire Leprosy Relief Association, are among the passengers due early today from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.

High winds handicapped the gunners at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. Under the circumstances, the top score of 98 registered by C.S. Wills in the scratch shoot at 100 targets was unusually good. His card was 98 -- 6 -- 100. Wills is a Class A gunner.
The time has come for the investiture of one of football's current heroes with the raiment of the ancient and ivy-garlanded order of gridiron immortals.

BERLIN, Nov. 14. -- Under the influence of rumors of the intervention by the government in the foreign securities market and of expectations of new and drastic expropriatory measures, heavy selling prevailed on the Berlin Boerse nearly all this week, with prices falling sharply.
