Dawnlight bathed the stained windows of Holy Innocents Church at Beverly Road and East Seventeenth Street, Brooklyn, at 6 A.M. yesterday as three Texas Rangers, hungry, grimy and shivering, crept in through the front door and stumbled to rear pews.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15. -- Higher prices ware registered for all grains in leading markets of the country last week, with a moderate increase in buying and a greater disposition by traders, particularly local and Eastern interests, to take the buying side on all weak spots, causing numerous sharp rallies.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 15. -- Priscilla Murphy, 16-year-old daughter of Dr. William P. Murphy of Brookline, Mass., who shared the Nobel Prize in medicine in 1934, was killed and two other persons were injured tonight in the crash of a big monoplane at Navarino, south of here.
Joseph Walker Sons have prepared an analysis of the 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock. Series A, of the Kansas, Oklahoma Gulf Railway Company.
The creation of a bureau of criminal investigation within the Police Department to cope with rackets is proposed by the courts committee of the City Club in a report made public yesterday.

ALBANY, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Employment in wholesale and retail trades in New York State continued during October the upward trend begun in July, the State Industrial Commissioner, Elmer F. Andrews, said tonight.

While zoning changes are sometimes difficult to dramatize, they are often extremely important. The Board of Estimate's new plan for the district from Fourteenth Street to Fifty-ninth Street between Seventh and Tenth Avenues may well mark a turning point in the history of the whole West Side.

MADRID, Nov. 15 (Censored). -- Notwithstanding reports emanating from sources outside Spain's capital the enemy is not yet fighting in Madrid's streets, according to government sources. The Moors, Foreign legionnaires and Spanish Fascists fighting in the Rebel ranks, apparently have been unable to force their way across the Manzanares River, bordering the city on the west and almost marking the city limits on the southwest.

At least six times yesterday the New York Yankees were within the opposition's 20-yard line. They outrushed the Boston Shamrocks almost 4 to 1, and were so far ahead in first downs -- actually 22 to 3 -- that one might suspect an overwhelming victory for the home club.

IRVINGTON, N.J., Nov. 15. -- Lester Finger, Newark real estate broker, announced today completion of plans for the sale of a half-block strip of business property on Springfield Avenue, near Irvington Center, and the erection of a new building there of five units to be air-conditioned throughout.

BERLIN, Nov. 15. -- Speculation about the fate of foreign securities traded in within Germany came to an end today when it became known that the German Government would shortly issue a decree compelling the owners of such securities to deposit them with the Reichsbank or its subsidiaries, subject, however, to the owners' orders.

An East Side housing alteration will result from the sale over the week-end of the two buildings at 174 Second Avenue and 299 East Eleventh Street, northeast corner, which were bought by a syndicate represented by Joseph Levy, attorney, from the New York Savings Bank. The Halford Realty Corporation acted as broker in the transaction.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 15. -- A pair of top-flight Interclub Class skippers continued their rivalry in dinghy sailing today and placed first and second among the Class B one-design boats in the weekly regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15. -- Activity in the corn market here last week, with an advance to the highest price level of the season, drew out profit-taking by holders of futures who have been in the market for some time. It also created a new situation that the trade has not been up against in recent years.

Some activity was noted in the better dress field last week. Prints were ordered to improve present stocks, and demand for formal attire in all price ranges was active. Resort lines created considerable interest, and prints and pastels were ordered for December selling.

A marble altar only three and one-half feet square and one and a half feet in depth was dedicated yesterday afternoon in the St. Thomas Chapel, known as "the tiniest chapel in the world," at Fourth Avenue and Pacific Street, Brooklyn.

The National Woman's Party ended its biennial convention at the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday afternoon in a spirit of "no compromise" until its objectives have been won. The party is pledged to fight for an amendment to the Constitution guaranteeing equal rights to men and women in all fields.
Amateur hockey returned to Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon and appeared to have lost none of its public favor during a seven-month absence from the local scene.

The general belief among expert commentators both here and in Europe is that the President's fears of the potential dangers of foreign funds in our markets have little foundation, while the "protective legislation" which he seems to desire is not merely unnecessary but might be itself seriously disturbing.
A special program has been planned for the final of THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair in the International Building of Rockefeller Center on Thursday, it was announced yesterday.
MADRID, Nov. 15. -- The largest fleet of Rebel war planes yet to bomb Madrid swept over the city today. Scurrying residents counted twenty-six planes.

The enlistment of medical directors, chemists, biologists, bacteriologists, pharmacologists and other specialists comprising technical staffs of manufacturers of packaged medicines throughout the country, to aid the Proprietary Association in its campaign of voluntary advertising control, was begun last week, following the mid-year meeting here of the scientific section of the association.
Manhattanville College's powerful field hockey team concluded its regular season in brilliant fashion by routing the North Jersey Field Hockey Association, 3 -- 0, at Central Park yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 15. -- The churches of America were urged to stand together as a bulwark against war and other menaces in addresses today by Bishop James E. Freeman of the Washington Episcopal Diocese and Bishop William T. Manning of the New York Diocese.

To start their first New York City invasion in two years, the Green Bay Packers visited Ebbets Field yesterday, but the Brooklyn Dodgers were soon wishing the Westerners had not called. While more than 25,000 fans watched, the Packers paraded to a 38-to-7 victory and remained deadlocked with the Chicago Bears for the Western division leadership in the National Football League.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 15. -- Princeton students who have been puzzled by the disappearance of overcoats from their eating clubs were informed today that the mystery had been solved and were asked to identify six coats that had been recovered.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Nov. 15 (AP). -- Italian columns are on the move again in Ethiopia to complete conquest of the land of the ousted Emperor Haile Selassie.

Cardinal Hayes, Bishop William T. Manning, Rabbi Stephen S. Wise and Charles H. Tuttle, president of the Greater New York Federation of Churches, have endorsed the $50,000 campaign of the Cooperative Committee of Big Sisters, Mrs. Lowe Fisk, chairman of the drive, announced yesterday.

GREENVILLE, Del., Nov. 15 (AP). -- The wedding of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., son of the President and Mrs. Roosevelt, and Miss Ethel du Pont, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene du Pont of Greenville, will take place next June in historic Christ Episcopal Church, Christiana Hundred, Miss du Pont said today.

Before leaving last night to preside at the United States Conference of Mayors in Washington, Mayor La Guardia indicated he would seek government intervention to settle the seamen's strike in this and other Atlantic ports.

Captain Ralph W. Robart, past national commander of the Army and Navy Legion of Honor, made public yesterday the names of sixteen persons who will serve with him on a "board of award" to select this year's winner of the organization's gold medal for valor.
ALBANY, Nov. 15. -- Among the projects for grade-crossing elimination carried over to 1937 by the Public Service Commission are two in Nassau County.

GENEVA, Nov. 15. -- Germany's denunciation of the river navigation parts of the Versailles Treaty does not affect the League of Nations directly, as the international commissions are not under it and it is not expected the League members who are affected will raise the issue here.

CHAMBERSBURG, Pa., Nov. 15. -- After an all-night search by parties of undergraduates, the body of Miss Kathryn Murray, a senior at Wilson College here, was found hanging today from a tree about three-quarters of a mile from the college campus.

The Rev. James Honeyham, 45 years old, a Roman Catholic priest, died in Fordham Hospital at 6 A.M. yesterday of injuries received three hours earlier when the automobile in which he was riding with his nephew, Tatian Noonan, 21, of 914 Havemeyer Avenue, the Bronx, struck an elevated pillar at White Plains Avenue and Bronx Park East.

Down to the end of another football trail marched many of the East's leading prep school elevens during the past week, with favorites to a large degree climaxing their campaigns in victorious fashion. Some few faltered at the last barrier, but from most of the major battles the anticipated winners emerged successfully.

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 15 (AP). -- The pro links stars of the nation will start in pursuit of the nineteenth championship of the Professional Golfers Association tomorrow, with six former titleholders in the field of 117 scheduled competitors, over the Pinehurst Country Club's difficult No. 2 course.

TIENTSIN, China, Nov. 15. -- A frank admission that Japan was in sympathy with the aims of the Mongols at present attacking Suiyuan Province was made here yesterday by Major Gen. Gun Hashimoto, chief of staff of the Japanese forces in North China.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 15 (AP). -- Representing a cross-section of the American agricultural point of view, a dozen masters of State granges urged today enactment of legislation which would make crop insurance a permanent part of the national agricultural policy.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses announced yesterday that all concessions in the city's parks have been placed on a sound basis, paying the city a fair rental based on their volume of business, selling food to the public at reasonable prices and under carefully supervised sanitary conditions, and being housed in attractive buildings.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 15. -- Alice, 800 pounds of her, was doing nicely today following a rarely performed bit of surgery -- and a "major operation" for eight men who took part.

The Fall avalanche of exhibitions continues to fill the local galleries. More than a score of shows open today, a number of them presenting unusual angles of interest and the rest quite making up in variety for any lack of size or external factors of importance.

A service in commemoration of Desiderius Erasmus, who lived from 1466 to 1536, was held yesterday afternoon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine under the auspices of the Erasmus quadri-centennial committee of the Netherland America Foundation.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 15. -- John Ford will direct "Hurricane" for Samuel Goldwyn. Negotiations were completed today by radio between the producer and Ford, who has been cruising in the South Seas. Upon completion of "The Plough and the Stars" for R.-K.-O. last month, Ford left on what was ostensibly a vacation in Hawaii.

MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 15. -- Labor troubles in Mexico's most important and remunerative industry -- petroleum -- will be discussed in a few days by unions and employers in an effort to end almost interminable strikes.

IT can be said for the athletes of Eli Yale that they put on a thriller in the Palmer Stadium. It wasn't so much that they beat a good big Princeton team, but it was the way they did it. They came from away back and up out of the swamp to bag a victory that seemed beyond hope.

LONDON, Nov. 13. -- Activity in the financial markets here continues at an unusually high level, finding expression in almost all constructive directions. The fortnightly Stock Exchange account which ended this week probably was the most active, and certainly the most interesting, of the year.

Dolls and toy soldiers, among the latter ten of 1,000 once owned by Napoleon, raised by their antiquity and the ingenuity of their design to the distinction of objets d'art, will be placed on exhibit today in the Museum for the Arts of Decoration of Cooper Union, Fourth Avenue and Eighth Street.

Leila Bederkhan, Kurdish dancer, whose only previous New York appearances were in the Spring of 1931, returned last night for a recital in the Guild Theatre, assisted by Nicolas Kopeikine, pianist, and a small instrumental ensemble.

Enemies of Jesus, in opposing Him, oppose themselves, Bishop William T. Manning asserted yesterday. He preached at the morning service at St. Mary's Protestant Episcopal Church, 521 West 126th Street.

The decision to keep the automobile show at the Grand Central Palace open on Sunday for the first time in many years was rewarded yesterday by a record attendance. It was estimated that the largest crowd that ever attended any exhibition in the Palace passed through its doors during the day.

Lanny Ross, the popular radio singer, made his debut as recitalist yesterday afternoon at Town Hall before a large and extremely demonstrative audience. He employed his light lyric tenor voice of much sweetness of quality with admirable taste and refinement.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15. -- Trading in oats here last week was spasmodic and in moderate volume, prices being influenced mainly by the action of wheat and corn. Processors were moderate buyers. Closing prices were at net gains of 1/8 to 5/8 cent, December leading.

While the police are making plans to extend midtown parking restrictions, in the interest of a freer traffic flow, they would do well to give renewed attention to the better enforcement of existing restrictions. The overtime parker is an old offender. Lately a new kind of curb hog has put in an appearance: the chap who parks his car in the space reserved for passengers to get on and off buses.

SETAUKET, L.I., Nov. 15. -- In one of the largest fields of cocker spaniels set down this year, Mrs. A.R. Moffit's Rowcliffe Blue Streak captured the open all-age stake, feature of the closing day of the American spaniel field trials at Strong's Neck.

With the approval of Mayor La Guardia and other city officials the Fifth Avenue Coach Company will begin today a series of competitions, open to the public and to its own operating staff, and designed to promote traffic safety.

"The Charge of the Light Brigade," currently housed at the Strand, is breaking national attendance records, according to the New York office of Warner Brothers. "Anthony Adverse," which up to last week was the leader, has been superseded in Detroit, New Haven, Bridgeport, Hartford and Springfield and Worcester, Mass.

WITH GENERAL FRANCO'S ARMY, in the Madrid Suburbs, Nov. 15. -- With both sides determined to do or die the Insurgent attack on Madrid is rapidly developing into a siege that might well last far into the Winter.

ROME, Nov. 15 (AP). -- Official denial was made tonight that Premier Mussolini intended to abolish law courts and substitute corporative committees. It was said officially that the law courts would not he changed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- Nineteen corporations, which are said to represent almost all of the manufacturers of metal window products in the United States, have been named in a complaint charging maintenance of a price-fixing combination to restrain, monopolize and eliminate competition, according to a Federal Trade Commission announcement today.

EAST ISLIP, L.I., Nov. 15. -- At the conclusion of the most thorough and severe test ever given to retrievers in the United States, first prize in the open all-age stake of the annual field trial meeting of the American Chesapeake Club was awarded today to the dog Sodak's Gypsy Prince, owned by the Chesacroft Kennels of Anthony A. Bliss, Westbury, L.I., and handled in the two-day competition by Lionel Bond.

When "The Eternal Road" finally opens at the Manhattan Opera House, a premiere now scheduled for New Year's week, the Scottish Rite Consistory of New York will have had a large share in speeding up the production. Now cooperating with Crosby Gaige and Meyer W. Weisgal, the producers, are Robert Willson, Commander-in-Chief; John W. Dawson and former Governor of New York William Sulzer, trustees of the consistory, which controls the house.

PANAMA, Republic of Panama, Nov. 15. -- The extension of the term of President Oscar Raimundes Benavides until Dec. 8, 1939, unless he calls an election in the meantime, gives Peru another Chief Executive who can hardly be described as constitutional.

Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, Chancellor of New York University, announced yesterday the appointment of Dr. Donal Sheehan of Victoria University, Manchester, to succeed Professor Emeritus H.D. Senior as Professor of Anatomy and director of the anatomical laboratories of the College of Medicine, effective on Sept. 1, 1937.

The siege of Madrid by the Rebel forces of General Francisco Franco came to its ninth day yesterday. At the beginning of this period the Insurgents had been expected to enter the capital with comparative ease. The end of it found them, in general, in the rear of the positions they had gained at the height of their assault.
Civic and religious leaders joined at church services yesterday to pay tribute to Supreme Court Justice Louis D. Brandeis, who celebrated his eightieth birthday last Friday.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 15. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 74 per cent of capacity, unchanged from the preceding week and 2 points under the recent high rate, the highest in point of tonnage since February, 1930.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Nov. 15. -- Republicans, failing to receive 30 per cent of the vote in Florida's Nov. 3 general election, lost the right under existing law to have names of party candidates printed on the ballot in 1938.

NANKING, China, Nov. 15. -- The reported German-Japanese anti-Communist agreement may result in some cooling of China's attitude toward Germany, but it is unlikely to seriously affect the present amicable economic and political relationship between the two countries unless the agreement also involves German recognition of Manchukuo, authoritative quarters here contend.

Clyde Keutzer, young Illinois tenor, gave his first New York recital at the Town Hall last night. His program began with songs in English by Rowland, Handel and Maurice Green. Two groups in German by Jan Phillip Schinhan, Cornelius, Schumann, Marx, Strauss and Grieg followed.

Miss Hope Gatins heads a group of younger members of society who are interested in the success of the annual anniversary bicycle breakfast, inaugurated last season, to be held on Dec. 6 at Le Coq Rouge for the benefit of the Children's Welfare Federation.

PARIS, Nov. 13. -- This week's bank return gave no indication of the operations of the equalization fund. The fact that the bank's gold reserve did not vary simply proves that the amount of metal acquired by the fund since its inception does not exceed 7,000,000,000 francs, which figure represents the amount of gold sold by the fund to the bank.

LONDON, Nov. 13. -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood on Nov. 11 at 75.5, compared with 74.6 a fortnight before, 73.8 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

BERLIN, Nov. 15. -- The travels of European statesmen during the past week and the British parliamentary debates apparently have engaged official consideration less than the Spanish civil war, which is being viewed here with considerable apprehension.

The papers of late Saturday and of Sunday had sorrowful news to carry to those who knew CLARK HOWELL, for he was much beloved South and North, East and West. He was first of all CLARK HOWELL of Atlanta and of The Atlanta Constitution and CLARK HOWELL of Georgia, but such was his influence in national and world affairs that he came into a wider fame as CLARK HOWELL the man.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,459,459,300. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest~ bearing discount hills. The list folloxvs:
BERLIN, Nov. 15 (AP). -- Germany and Italy played a 2-2 tie today in a soccer game scheduled "to cement the nations' friendship."

The well-known portrait of ERASMUS by HOLBEIN shows him with pen in hand writing an unfinished inscription addressed "to all mortals" (cunctis mortalibus). He died four hundred years ago this year, but he is still speaking to mortals out of his own immortality. His was a Ptolemaic world.

We must turn to the moral verities of the past, rather than to political, social and economic change, if we are to achieve recovery, the Right Rev. James Edward Freeman, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Washington, D.C., declared yesterday morning in a sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. He said the prime struggle of the present age was between Christianity and communism.

BARCELONA, Spain, Nov. 15. -- General Llano de la Encomienda, who was appointed commander in chief of the Spanish Government's northern armies, has left Barcelona for Bilbao to direct the forces fighting in the Provinces of Oviedo, Santander and Vizcaya.

When Mrs. Cecelia Stockman is told by a furniture dealer that certain purchases will be sent at a certain hour, she expects that promise to be kept. That's why she appeared in Jamaica Court in Queens yesterday, before Magistrate Benjamin F. Marvin, as complainant against Julius Cucinello and Anthony Buccola.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15. -- The St. Bonaventure College eleven handed Coach Marty Brill's La Salle College team a surprising 14-7 defeat at McCarthy Stadium today before a chilled crowd of 5,000 fans.

BERLIN, Nov. 13. -- Financial sentiment here has been uneasy all week in spite of satisfactory developments in home trade. Stocks have declined steadily. Friction between Poland and Danzig and the arrests of Germans in Moscow have wiped out optimism concerning the Reich's diplomatic situation which was induced by the rapprochement with Italy.

LONDON, Nov. 14 (AP). -- The following are the Board of Trade's foreign trade figures for the month of October: Total imports. 80,530,000; exports of British products, 41,760,000; re-exports. 4,470,000; total exports, 46,230,000; excess of imports, 34,300,000.

Establishment by the Carnegie Corporation of New York of three trust funds totaling $145,000 as part of the New York Community Trust was announced yesterday by Ralph Hayes, director of the latter foundation.

The screams of a 6-year-old boy clinging to the face of the Palisades 120 feet above ground level, near Buttermilk Fails yesterday afternoon, brought three Boy Scout leaders to the rescue as he was on the verge of toppling to almost certain death.

The enlarged Harlow Galleries are exhibiting a considerable group of etchings by the British artist Gerald Brockhurst, including portraits, the finely detailed "Black Silk Dress" and an arresting drawing of the artist's wife, most of the prints familiar but well standing re-acquaintance.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 15 (AP). -- Governor Landon said tonight in an appeal for public participation in charity drives that it is an "American characteristic" to forget differences in critical times to achieve worthwhile ends.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 14. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 85.3, which compares with 84.7 the week before, 84.5 two weeks before, 84.0 three weeks before and 83.9 four weeks before. The present average is the highest of the year to date; the average of May 25, 80.5, was the lowest since January, 1935.

I notice that in his request to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler for a public opinion foundation, as printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES NOV. 12, Dean Ackerman of the Columbia School of Journalism states: "No foundation, no educational institution and no church is making, and none is prepared to make, studies of the spoken or printed word in its relationship to 'man and the social order.'"

CHICAGO, Nov. 15. -- John F. Cuneo, wealthy president of the Cuneo Press, and his wife, the former Julia Shepherd, who were held up by two bandits in front of their home on Lake Shore Drive and robbed of jewelry valued at more than $25,000 late last night, later identified as one of the bandits John Benedetto, who was found shot to death in an automobile some distance from the scene of the robbery.

Twenty-one new singers will join the personnel of the Metropolitan Opera Association during the coming season, it was revealed yesterday when the annual prospectus was made public. Seventeen artists whose names were listed in last year's prospectus are not on this year's roster.

BERLIN, Nov. 13. -- An English banker recently in Berlin on a mission of inquiry is reported to have gleaned the impression that it will be difficult to negotiate a renewal of the standstill agreement for 1937. Officially, it is declared that the world economic tendencies which recently improved Germany's trade balance continue to operate.

WITH INSURGENTS IN CASA DE CAMPO, Outside Madrid, Nov. 15. -- Advance units of General Francisco Franco's Insurgent troops tonight fought their way into the University City section on the northwestern outskirts of Madrid.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 15 (AP). -- The University of Santa Clara maintained an undefeated, untied football record today by defeating its oldest rival, St. Mary's College, 19 to 0.

The total number of unemployed workers in the United States in September, 1936, was 8,975,000, according to new estimates of the National Industrial Conference Board, made public yesterday. This compares with a maximum of 15,939,000 unemployed in March, 1933, the board pointed out.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 15. -- The American educational system was both criticized and praised by Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, president of the University of Chicago, before the eighty-second annual convention of the New Jersey State Teachers Association in the Convention Hall here tonight.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (AP). -- The Toronto Maple Leafs and the Chicago Black Hawks battled to a 1-1 tie before 14,000 fans tonight in a National Hockey League game enlivened by a general fight in the closing seconds of the overtime period.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art will reopen its Room of Recent Accessions today to show off some of its latest acquisitions. In the featured position is a painted terracotta portrait bust of an English ecclesiastic of the early sixteenth century.

Announcements of bonds called for redemption before maturity were curtailed last week because of the election day holiday. Notices numbered the fewest in many weeks and, except for one large real estate and public utility retirement, were mostly for small lots of bonds.

Revised programs for teaching reading in the city schools have helped cut the proportion of pupils deficient in reading ability from 51 per cent to 38.75 per cent, the result of a standard reading test given to 12,543 pupils of 7B grade indicated yesterday.

Cardinal Hayes presided yesterday at a solemn high mass in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, 404 East Eighty-seventh Street, celebrating the sixtieth anniversary of the ordination of the pastor, the Rev. Mgr. Gallus Bruder. The service also marked the Monsignor's silver jubilee in his present pastorate and the sixtieth anniversary of the founding of the church.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 15. -- Seven Yale alumni, prominent in letters and other fields, have strongly protested to President Angell for the university's failure to reappoint Professor Jerome Davis to the faculty. They call the action "tantamount to an expulsion for social and economic views."

DETROIT, Nov. 15. -- The New York Giants were manhandled in scandalous fashion by the champion Detroit Lions in the biting cold of the University of Detroit Stadium today and subjected to the worst defeat in their history. At the end of the massacre the score was 38 to 0.

The Rev. Albert L. Neibacher yesterday morning was ordained a minister of the Lutheran Evangelical church and installed as pastor of St. Luke's Evangelical Lutheran Church, 308-16 West Forty-sixth Street.

Directors of Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., will announce today an offering to stockholders of rights to subscribe to 207,711 additional common capital shares of the company at the rate of one-third share for each share now held. The price will be according to market conditions when the offering is made, and it is expected that it will yield between $2,250,000 and $2,500,000.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 15. -- A rude awakening is being prepared for those distinguished diplomats who sat around the governors' board of the Pan American Union in July, hoping to avoid the feminine influence at the forthcoming peace conference in Buenos Aires by scratching the women's rights question off the agenda.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 15. -- Trading in the cotton market here last week was somewhat more active than in the preceding period. The feature of the week was the surprisingly large forecast of the final yield of the crop and issued on Monday. The total given was 12, 400,000 bales, an increase of 890,000 over the estimate issued a month before, whereas the trade had expected an estimate of about 12,000, 000.

MANILA, Nov. 15 (AP). -- The Philippine Commonwealth began the second year of its existence today with President Manuel Quezon expressing a desire for "changes in national economy" looking toward "betterment of the working class without serious injury to capital and without endangering our social and political institutions."

Roger W. Straus, chairman of the northeast region of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, told 1,500 persons at the sixth annual convention of the regional group yesterday that Americans must stand by religion if democracy is to be preserved.

PERSONS not acquainted with Frank Swinnerton or his work are likely to find that many of the chapters of "Swinnerton: An Autobiography" (Doubleday, Doran, $2.75) read as though they had been talked from behind a mask. For Mr. Swinnerton, frankly though amiably, pictures himself as an able novelist, critic and publishing-trade expert, a dear friend of the great and the prominent.

MADRID, Nov. 15. -- I wonder how many of you know Madrid through having been here or through books or through pictures? Here is a short description of the city. Madrid was chosen as a capital by Philip II, who plunged his forefinger in the center of the map of Spain.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., Nov. 15. -- Led by the veteran Lou Gregory, the Millrose Athletic Association swept to its ninth successive team triumph in the Metropolitan A.A.U. senior cross-country championship at Bethpage State Park today.

In an article in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 11 John W. Worthing calls attention to the high taxes on gasoline and quotes statements from the National Highways Users Conference and others criticizing the diversion of gasoline taxes for purposes other than road building.

The proposal to amend the Constitution so as to limit the President to one term of six years raises some fundamental questions as to our form of government. Mr. Arthur Krock states his personal opinion -- to which, as an admirer of his column, I attach weight -- that the change "would increase the efficiency and decrease the politics in the Presidency."

Discussing last Thursday before the Academy of Political Science "The Railroad Problem," Mr. THOMAS W. LAMONT and Mr. JOSEPH B. EASTMAN, formerly Railway Coordinator, both referred to possible recrudescence of the movement for Government ownership. Mr. LAMONT warned of the dangers of such an expedient, but intimated that high-handed coercion in the direction of railway consolidation might, under certain circumstances, "mean Government ownership."

TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 15. -- The American Federation of Labor will open here tomorrow the most crucial convention in its history. Confronting the session is an issue which will probably have far-reaching effects upon the future of the labor movement in this country.

TOKYO, Nov. 15. -- The army has submitted to the treasury a six-year program involving a total expenditure of 6,200,000,000 yen, according to the newspaper Asahi. Apparently 3,000,000,000 yen is allocated for ordinary yearly expenditure, which will be more than doubled, and 3,200,000,000 yen for the rearmament program.
NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 15. -- Some 2,800 election officials in New Jersey face a thankless Thanksgiving Day as far as their pay of $15 each for long service on election day is concerned.

The time has arrived when there can be no middle ground between communism and Christianity, the Rev. Dr. John F. O'Hara, C.S.C., president of the Notre Dame University, declared in a sermon yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle, Columbus Avenue and Sixtieth Street.
Mail pouches in all parts of the country will bulge today with 3,000,000 blank cards, first tangible symbol of the Federal Government's promise to insure the old age of the nation's wage-earners.

The New York Americans played the role of an ungrateful neighbor last night as they helped inaugurate the Rangers' home hockey season at Madison Square Garden. Red Dutton's Spangled skaters handed the revamped Blue Shirts a 2-to-1 defeat, scoring both their goals in the final chapter.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15. -- The Palestine Maccabees' farewell doubleheader at the Sparta Stadium today finished with the honors going to the local soccer teams, as Chicago's Maccabees defeated the visitors' second-string eam, 4 to 0, and the Sparta Garden City held the Palestine All-Stars to a 1-1 tie.

Several debutantes of this season, headed by the Misses Barbara Eastman and Marie Rose Cassard, are active in the arrangements for the mothers and daughters fashion show and tea in behalf of the Bellevue Hospital Occupation Committee, which will take place on Dec. 3 in the Viennese Suite of the Crillon.

PARIS, Nov. 13. -- The Bourse has been irregular this week with an alternation of rises and falls, the latter finally prevailing and continuing through Friday. The reaction was natural after the rapid rise of the last few weeks, particularly as, apart from investment buying, there has also been much speculative buying and many speculators took profits at the approach of the fortnightly settlement.
Chester J. LaRoche, of Young Rubicam, Inc., has been appointed chairman of the committee on radio broadcasting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15. -- Miss Mary Hope Hunter, a Baltimore debutante, was killed early today when an automobile in which she, another young woman and two Yale students, were riding was struck by a car which sped away afterward. Later an arrest was made.

For its second, given in Town Hall late yesterday afternoon, the New Friends of Music, Inc., put forward another Beethoven program, featuring this time the string quartets Op. 18, No. 6, and Op. 132, between which the three Equali for trombones found a place.
Snowflakes were seen in Times Square last night -- the first snow of the season. But they were scattered and few and melted before they reached the ground.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 14. -- The foibles of Hollywood and of college undergraduates will provide the theme for the 1936-37 production of the Princeton Triangle Club, a musical satire titled "Take It Away," according to an announcement today by William H. Borden '37, of Rumson, N.J., president of the club.
In your editorial regarding the possibility of a relief workers' strike, there seems to be a definite prejudice in favor of the examination.

MOSCOW, Nov. 15. -- A tempest swirled up in Moscow's literary world today when the arts committee of the Council of People's Commissars unexpectedly suppressed the new, lavishly produced comic opera by Demian Byedny at the Kamerny Theatre on the grounds that it was ideologically false and historically incorrect.
PARIS, Nov. 15. -- Speaking at Soissons today, Premier Leon Blum proclaimed his opposition to war and his faith that European peace could be preserved.

SCRANTON, Pa., Nov. 15. -- Before crowded congregations in churches of Northeastern Pennsylvania and Southern New York, the Board of Bishops of the Methodist Episcopal Church, North, at services this morning and this evening formally organized the Million Unit Fellowship Movement.

BOSTON, Nov. 15 (AP). -- Chicago's powerful Bears overwhelmed the Boston Redskins, 26 -- 0, before 12,000 at Fenway Park today to remain tied with the Green Bay Packers for the lead in the western division of the National Football League.
Although he was idle during the week, Fred King, fullback on the unbeaten Hobart eleven, held the lead in Eastern College football scoring.

Steel operations have risen 1 point to 74 per cent of capacity as a result of increased buying by automobile companies and other consumers, according to the weekly summary of the magazine Steel issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- Rabbi Isaac Landman of Congregation Beth Elohim, Brooklyn, and Benjamin Stolberg, economist-journalist, debated tonight at the National Temple Forum, under the auspices of the Washington Hebrew Congregation, the subject.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 15 (AP). -- Los Angeles defeated Philadelphia of the National Football League today, 10 to 7, when Fullback Gordon Gore kicked a 44-yard field goal in the fourth quarter before 9,500 persons.
VIENNA, Nov. 15. -- Reflections upon the results of the three-power obvious that Italy has paid a high price for keeping Austria and Hungary under her protection.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15. -- Livestock markets here were unsettled last week. Receipts were unusually heavy. Consumption of pork, beef and lamb has been fair to good. Packers paid $12 to $12.10 a hundredweight for steers on four days last week, the top price being 10 cents higher than the previous week.

The Television Corporation of America, its president, Oliver C. Harriman, and eight other individuals must appear in the Supreme Court of New York County on Nov. 24 with the corporation's books and records for an examination under the provisions of Article 23a of the General Business Law.

LONDON, Nov. 16. -- The stock market opened the new account quietly today. British Government stocks weakened on almost complete failure of the new Dewsbury municipal loan, while international issues turned dull on the prospect that foreign dealings on the New York Stock Exchange might be officially restricted by Washington action.

" The Yellow Cruise" is the new tenant of the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse. This film record of a 20,000-mile automobile journey through Syria, Afghanistan, the Himalayas and the Gobi Desert was directed by Andre Sauvage.

An intensive manufacturer-retailer controversy on "unwarranted returns" of garments by stores developed on several fronts in the women's apparel industry yesterday. The National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board announced it is setting up machinery "to reduce the percentage of returns to the lowest point in the history of the industry."

An increase of $2 to $3 a ton in steel prices, effective on Jan. 1, is expected in Wall Street, now that the rise of 10 per cent in wages has become effective for about 500,000 steel workers. The increase in the payroll will be about $75,000,000 a year, on the basis of current steel operations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Opposed by the issuing corporation and the over-the-counter brokers and dealers, the New York Curb Exchange today pressed before the Securities and Exchange Commission its application for unlisted trading privileges in the $53,000,000 issue of 3 1/2 per cent, Series A, sinking-fund first-mortgage bonds, due in 1965, of the Edison Electric Illuminating Company of Boston.

Foreign purchases of American securities can be classified into two groups, according to the gist of brokerage consensus yesterday. One category is actual foreign buying in New York by nationals in their own countries, and the other can include American orders which are routed through London.
The Continental Bank and Trust Company has been appointed registrar for 1,000,000 shares of $1 par Class A common stock of the Mergraf Oil Products Corporation.

Alexander V. Dye, director of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, Department of Commerce, predicted an increase in trade between the United States and Latin America in an address yesterday at the third annual marine exhibition, 80 Broad Street.

Cornelius Stewart of the Don Bosco Club of Port Chester and Victor Romatowski, Roman Sports Club became the finalists in the open 135-pound class of the All-America A.A.U. boxing tournament at Stauch's Coney Island Arena last night. A crowd of 1,500 watched the show, conducted by the Trinity Club of Brooklyn.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 16. -- The frequently-rumored engagement of Mary Pickford to Charles (Buddy) Rogers was confirmed today by the actress. She said no date for the wedding had been set, except that it would be held in the Spring.

LONDON, Nov. 16. -- King Edward leaves tomorrow night for a tour of the South Wales coal country to inspect conditions in the section afflicted by many years of unemployment and consequent poverty and misery.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP). -- A unanimous verdict for the government was recorded at the Court of Claims today in the suit of Robert A. Taft of Cincinnati to compel the United States to pay him $1.07 interest on a gold Liberty bond called in advance of its maturity date.

Bonds maintained a firm undertone yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange despite the marked decrease in trading volume. Although some irregularity developed among higher-grade investments, net changes were small. Many of the recently favored convertible industrial loans attracted renewed speculative interest and advanced sharply in good volume.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- A united appeal "to all parties concerned" in the Pacific Coast maritime strike that they agree to submit all their differences to arbitration by a board to be appointed by President Roosevelt was made today in an open letter signed by Mayors of Atlantic, Pacific and Gulf seaport cities.

Leon Barzin, conductor of the National Orchestral Association, has been developing not only competent instrumentalists through his training orchestra but also has sought to instruct young musicians in the business of conducting. The first graduate of his conductors' class appeared as guest director at last night's concert of the National Orchestra at Carnegie Hall.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 16 (AP). -- Captain Clyde Plummer of the District Attorney's office said tonight that the pistol discovered in the lap of Reid Russell when his body was found in the yard of Gouverneur Morris's Manhattan Beach home Sept. 25 appeared not to have been fired recently.

The Special Sessions trial of Dr. Anna Swift on an "information" that she operated a house of prostitution at 8 West Seventieth Street last June 18, began yesterday before Justices Bayes, Hackenburg and Salomon with the testimony of Mrs. Ermegart Wright, 28 years old, one of the inmates.

Twenty years ago a Kings County grand jury indicted Benjamin Chaytin for robbery. He was accused of stealing jewelry from the pockets of his room-mate, who had died of heart disease. Chaytin disappeared, but last March he was arrested in California and yesterday he was taken before County Judge Brancato in Brooklyn to stand trial on the old indictment.

Following the now well-recognized Hitlerian formula, the German Government last Saturday again utilized a week-end to absorb the shock of its denunciation of one more provision of the Treaty of Versailles. This time the Reich announced that it will "no longer recognize" the internationalization and control regulations set up by the treaty for the Rhine, Elbe, Oder and Danube Rivers.

With a series of all-time records for attendance already established the national automobile show at the Grand Central Palace ended its sixth day last night. The show will close tomorrow night. Alfred Reeves, manager of the show and vice president of the Automobile Manufacturers Association, in response to a request for facts and figures, issued the following statement:

Fresh from their brilliant victory over the Rangers on Sunday night, the New York Americans will seek to maintain their unbeaten record in the National Hockey League when they skate against the Canadiens of Montreal tonight at Madison Square Garden.

A fine of $50 and the loss of his driving license were the penalties a man was called upon to pay yesterday because, last Friday, he had refused to help a dog which he had run down and fatally injured with his automobile. Magistrate Capshaw made no comment as he imposed the fine.
The effect of the United States Supreme Court ruling in the Bush Terminal Company case is to put the reorganization proceeding back into the hands of the Federal court in Brooklyn.

This afternoon's auditorium program at THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair in the International Building, Rockefeller Center, will be devoted to the topic "Local Color" and will be under the auspices of the Booksellers League of New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- William Lemke, presidential candidate of the Union Party in the recent campaign and co-author of the $3,000,000,000 rural mortgage currency inflation proposal, demanded today that the Supreme Court pass upon the constitutionality of the amended Frazier-Lemke Farm Mortgage Moratorium law.

Former State Senator Courtlandt Nicoll, president of the Museum of the City of New York, gave a dinner last night at the Union Club. Among his guests were trustees of the museum, representatives of other New York museums, city officials and men interested in the history and government of the city.

The trial in General Sessions of three officials of the defunct Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company, accused of being responsible for misleading advertising on the company's financial condition in 1932, continued yesterday with the reading of correspondence between one of the defendants and an employe in the Staten Island branch.
The Postal Service completed in six crowded hours yesterday the monumental task of distributing social security registration forms to the nation's employers.

Louis Nelson, 41 years old, of 765 Broadway, Brooklyn, manager of the Joint Council of the Knitgoods Workers Union, surrendered yesterday in Special Sessions and pleaded not guilty to an "information" charging him and four others of the union with coercion and conspiracy in alleged assaults and threats to non-union workers in two shops in the Madison Square district.

Last season it was "Ghosts." This season it is "Hedda Gabler," which was revived at the Longacre last evening. In either case, it is Nazimova, the mistress of the doomed Ibsen heroines and an actress of extraordinary powers. Hedda is one of her oldest parts; and the play, like a good deal of Ibsen's realism, makes a great pother about social trivialities.

PARIS, Nov. 16. -- The French efforts to get the affected nations to make a concerted protest against Germany's repudiation of the river internationalization clauses of the Treaty of Versailles do not seem to have made much progress today.

BASLE, Nov. 16. -- The biggest sensation of the Swiss theatrical season has been "Frieden's Tragoedie" ("Tragedy of Peace") by Albert Steffin, which is based on Woodrow Wilson's life. It is a play built around the League of Nations and concerns the failure of an idea -- Wilson's idea -- to found a society in which peace would be abiding.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Safeguarding of advantages provided by Congress for more liberalized conditions for American citizens, even if it has to be done in "the American way" by a change in the Constitution, and a closer cooperation between the Federal Government and cities, were advocated by Mayor La Guardia today in his speech opening the Sixth Annual Conference of Mayors.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 16. -- Difficulties are looming in the substitution of Lloyd Nolan for George Raft in Paramount's "Souls at Sea." Nolan is being held in readiness while attempts are being made to get either Lee Tracy or John Barrymore for the vacated role.

i 1WEWARI,i, N. J., Nov. 16. -- Dr. Logan had been Superintendent of Schools here since 1927, succeeding ! the late Dr. David B. Corson. Prior i to that he had been State Commisi sioner of Education from 1925 to 1927. IKe was appointed to the State post by Governor George S. Silzer.

Charlotte Symons, who joined the Metropolitan Opera Association last season, made the transition into the local recital field with a fair measure of distinction at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. A large audience for a midweek matinee received her warmly, and she sang encores.

After holding within a narrow range for several hours yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange rallied sharply about $1 a bale and closed with net gains of 11 to 15 points. Strength in the outside markets, an early premium of about 30 points on the December delivery and steady buying by consumers following last week's heavy sales of cotton goods, developed active trading the last hour.

LONDON, Nov. 16. -- In an effort to protect British traders and manufacturers who hope to reap rich profits from the coronation period, the treasury ordered today a 100 per cent ad valorem duty on all goods that might be used in connection with the coronation, to be imposed from Dec. 15 to July 31.

Four automobile drivers were arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Anthony Savarese in Long Island City, Queens, on charges of homicide growing out of automobile accidents over the weekend. Those arraigned were Edmund Brodzienski, 23 years old, of 94 Clay Street, Brooklyn; Harry Chefetz, 41, of 144-34 Northern Boulevard, Flushing; Franz Beermann, 30, of 35-05 Ninety-fourth Street, Jackson Heights, and Frank Arra, 25, of 90-22 201st Street, Hollis.

I have no quarrel with THE TIMES conclusion that funerals are costly far beyond a sane and equitable measure of their dollar-and-cents value. A few years ago John C. Gebhart, in a survey sponsored by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, listed the average cost of funerals in various cities of the country.

The Western clubs in the National Football League are waging a close battle for offensive laurels. The Detroit Lions still are the pacesetters in average ground gaining, and have jumped ahead of the Green Bay Packers for the best scoring percentage.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16. -- What is believed to be the first scientific portrayal of America's traditional Thanksgiving bird, the wild turkey, has been brought to light and is reproduced in the news issue of Frontiers, a magazine of natural history, which will be published on Wednesday by the Academy bf Natural Sciences of Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Nine claimants against the Irving Trust Company of New York as trustee of the United Cigar Stores of America won a review in the Supreme Court today in their effort to recover sums ranging from $12,000 to $107,000 as a result of the rejection of unexpired real estate leases.
Aldo Spoldi, Italian lightweight, added Ritchie Fontaine of Montana to his lengthening list of victims in eight rounds before 3,500 at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

A campaign to enroll new members in the Seeing Eye, Inc., the school that trains dogs to guide the blind, was opened yesterday at a luncheon of 100 women on the New York City enrollment committee at the Hotel Ambassador.

With hides, cocoa and rubber futures advancing briskly in heavy trading, other commodity futures were irregular on local exchanges yesterday, silk and some of the metals alone showing losses for the day. On the cash markets raw sugar eased 2 points to 3.65 cents a pound and silk and tin declined, while gains were scored by all the grains, cotton, wool tops, rubber, hides, cocoa and lead.

PARIS, Nov. 16. -- The best picture of the struggle of the opposing air forces in Spain that has been presented here appears in today's Paris-Midi. It is in the form of an interview with a French aviator who fought with the Loyalists for several months and who left Spain ten days ago for a brief rest in France.
Only two teams remained unbeaten in the Metropolitan Class B Squash Tennis League yesterday as the Columbia Club dropped a 5-0 decision to the Princeton Club on the latter's courts.
Only East Tennessee Teachers fell by the wayside over the weekend as thirteen football teams from coast to coast remained in the undefeated and untied set, The Associated Press reveals.

They finally decided yesterday afternoon that two weeks had taken care of all those who would be seeing "Don't Look Now!" and so closed it before last night's performance. It had opened election eve under the auspices of Gustav Blum at the Bayes, with Joseph Buloff making his English speaking debut.

Public offering will be made today, by means of a prospectus, of a new issue of $1,500,000 of first mortgage 4 per cent series B bonds of the Shenango Valley Water Company of Sharon, Pa., by H.M. Payson Co. and W.C. Langley Co. The bonds are dated Oct. 1, 1936, and will mature on Oct. 1, 1961.

COLUMBUS, Nov. 16 (AP). -- Wheeler McMillen, editor of the Country Home, urged farmers today to continue the agricultural conquest of America, rather than to fall in line with what he called the philosophy of "adjustment and defeat."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16. -- Asserting that the success of social legislation "lies entirely in its administration," A.J. Altmeyer, acting chairman of the Social Security Board, urged here tonight a "well-organized and well-trained" personnel to administer the Social Security Act.

WITH INSURGENT FORCES ATTACKING MADRID, Nov. 15 (Delayed) (AP). -- Ten tons of aerial bombs crashed into government fortifications along the Manzanares River as Insurgents continued their efforts to blast a pathway into Madrid today.
That man Jesse Owens is out in front again, this time in the race for the 1936 James E. Sullivan Award.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- The Greyhound Corporation, parent company for the network of highway motor carriers of that name, asked authority of the Interstate Commerce Commission today to merge and consolidate nineteen operating subsidiaries into six separate corporations so as to eliminate intermediate holding companies and promote economies and efficiency of operation.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 16. -- A proposal for streamlined through train service from Westchester County to lower New York by way of the New York, Westchester Boston Railway and the Third Avenue elevated was applauded tonight by about fifty taxpayers who attended a public hearing at City Hall.
The fact that your editorial of Nov. 12 is entitled "High Cost of Funerals" instead of merely "Cost of Funerals" would lead the reader to expect a well-substantiated basis for the adjective "high."

LANSING, Mich., Nov. 16. -- Representative Prentiss M. Brown, Democrat, who has represented the Eleventh Michigan Congressional District for two terms, was appointed Senator today by Governor Frank D. Fitzgerald, Republican, to fill the vacancy created by the death of Senator James Couzens.

Mayor La Guardia has suggested that the Emergency Relief Bureau and employes of the bureau, who have been threatening a strike unless they are transferred to civil service without a competitive examination, cooperate in drawing up an "agreed state of facts" for presentation to the Appellate Division.

With Georgia and New York University still to be encountered, Fordham's undefeated eleven yesterday began its final drive toward a record clear of defeat. On Saturday the Rams, who had an open date last week-end, will meet the Southern team at the Polo Grounds and on Thanksgiving Day they will play their traditional game with the Violet at the Yankee Stadium.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Nov. 16. -- While Frank J. Marshall and Isaac I. Kashdan of New York, favorites for first prize, were play-in a third-round match today Dr. Adolf Seitz of Augsburg, Germany, recorded his third consecutive victory and took the lead in the international chess masters' tournament at the Club de Ajedrez de San Juan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- A concerted effort within private business to absorb during the next year the remaining unemployed industrial workers, estimated at about 4,000,000, is expected to result from a number of post-election conferences of leaders of finance and industry to be held between now and President Roosevelt's second inauguration Jan. 20.

BERLIN, Nov. 16. -- The Boerse again was weak with most issues registering heavy losses and a general exodus from stock market positions appears to have set in. The financial press carries inspired statements protesting this reaction to government measures in the foreign securities field.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- The President came nearer today than at any time before to the awaited official statement that "the emergency is over" -- the emergency during which he first took office, which was the excuse for the haste, conflicts and blunders of 1933 and 1934, and is the limitation set by Congress on certain loans of legislative power to the Executive.

Approximately 7,500,000 members of Christmas saving clubs throughout the country will receive within the next two weeks $355,000,000 from 5,500 banks, according to an estimate given out yesterday by Herbert F. Rawll, founder of Chrismas Club, Inc.

ATLANTA, Nov. 16. -- Major Clark Howell Jr. will have control of The Atlanta Constitution, the will of his father, Clark Howell Sr., revealed when filed for probate here today. No value was placed on the estate.

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 16. -- Pay Coleman, curly haired, 31-year-old Californian who during his amateur days was looked on as one of the country's best, left a brilliant field in his wake in today's opening eighteen-hole qualifying round of the Professional Golfers Association championship.

CHARLES MICHELSON, director of publicity for the Democratic National Committee, says that Chairman FARLEY'S perfect score in his electoral vote forecast is nothing to marvel at. Mr. FARLEY received daily reports from every State chairman, who, in turn, had his bulletins from the county chairmen, who got their figures from the district and precinct captains.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16. -- The horse and man are both divergent modifications of the same type, following a central organic design called "the self-moving grappling bridge," it was declared by Dr. William K. Gregory of the American Museum of Natural History, New York, in a public lecture tonight before the National Academy of Sciences.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 16 (AP). -- Charles P. Howard, president of the International Typographical Union and secretary of the Committee for Industrial Organization, charged here tonight that the action by the executive council of the American Federation of Labor "in suspending delegates" of the C.I.O. unions "savors of dictatorship to retain control."

The major railroads of the East serving New York City began the free store-door delivery of freight yesterday while the Merchant Truckmen's Bureau of New York considered the advisability of carrying to the United States Supreme Court its fight against the new system.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- The first hearing to determine minimum wages under the Walsh-Healey act will open Friday morning in Room 4217 in the Department of Labor Building, it was announced today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16. -- A gift of $100,000 to the American Hospital Association to be used during five years for the study and development of voluntary hospital insurance was announced by Edwin R. Embree, president of the Julius Rosenwald Fund, following the annual meeting here.

Directors of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. yesterday declared a year-end dividend of $2 a share on the common stock, payable on Dec. 15 to holders of record of Nov. 25. Regular quarterly dividends of 90 cents a share were paid in the last three quarters of this year.

In recognition of the remarkable plurality turned out by Tammany Hall for President Roosevelt on election day, James A. Farley, national Democratic chairman, has allocated more than 3,000 temporary holiday season jobs in the post-office to the Manhattan organization, it became known last night.

The National Union Radio Corporation has asked the Federal court for permission to amend the complaint in its $15,000,000 damage action against the Radio Corporation of America and others so that the suit, instead of being brought under the Clayton Anti-Trust Act, will provide a test of important provisions of the Robinson-Patman Price Discrimination Act, it became known yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 16 (AP). -- Widespread and effective use of allantoin in the treatment of ulcers, burns, gangrene and other ailments which failed to heal under other treatment was announced today on the eve of the annual meeting of the Southern Medical Association.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 16. -- The Argentine Presidential Secretariat said tonight that President Roosevelt's decision to come to Buenos Aires for the opening of the Inter-American Peace Conference was "highly pleasing."

PEAPACK, N.J., Nov. 16. -- With the largest entry in its history, the Labrador Retriever Club today inaugurated its sixth annual field trial meeting, which will be continued through tomorrow and Wednesday.

Monetary and momentary fame in motion-pictures has introduced a new element in insurance, it was disclosed yesterday at the opening of a three-day Fall meeting of the Home Office Life Insurance Underwriters Association at the Hotel Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Strong objections to the orders of the Federal Communications Commission requiring the installation of a new accounting system were voiced today before the United States Supreme Court by counsel for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Nov. 10 shows increases for the week of $42,000,000 in total loans and investments and $173,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted, decreases of $20,000,000 in time deposits and $30,000,000 in United States Government deposits, and increases of $47,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks and $138,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 16. -- Every Yale player who fought the Tiger to a successful 26-23 outcome in Princeton Saturday was in uniform and at Anthony Thompson Field today, but Trainer Frank Wandle eased off the matinee to calisthenics, a light run and signal rehearsal for half an hour.

MOSCOW, Nov. 16. -- The German Government through its embassy here has protested vigorously to the Soviet Government against a series of arrests of German citizens, among other foreigners, who have been picked up in the past few days in a new spy hunt by the Soviet political police.

LONDON, Nov. 16. -- Another precedent in the constitutional history of the British Empire was established today when King Edward appointed Patrick Duncan, South African Minister of Mines, to be Governor General of the Union of South Africa as successor to the Earl of Clarendon.

Sam (Chowderhead Cohen) Harris, and four other men arrested on a vagrancy charge last Friday at Forty-second Street and Broadway, were dismissed by Magistrate Brodsky in Jefferson Market Court yesterday for lack of evidence.

The will of Alfred W. Erickson, late chairman of the board of McCann -Erickson, Inc., advertising agents, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday provides for a bequest of $100,000 for the "Erickson Trust" which the decedent founded, and which owns and operates the Desert Sanatorium of South Arizona at Tucson.

TORONTO, Nov. 16. -- In what sounded remarkably like a call for the formation of a new political party, Major W.D. Herridge, former Minister to Washington, appealed in a Canadian club speech here today for a new national policy of planning.

Before an audience of more than 200 culinary herb enthusiasts, Oscar Tschirky, host at the Waldorf-Astoria, warned yesterday against serving "delicatessen dinners" to young husbands and urged mothers of brides-to-be to instruct their daughters in the art of preparing good, wholesome, home-cooked meals.
CHICAGO, Nov. 16. -- A spoken diary of life in the White House, including close-ups of President Roosevelt, was given tonight to more than 3,000 people at Sinai Temple by Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 16. -- The critical Suiyuan Province situation, made obscure by many contradictory reports, was clarified this evening by Major Gen. Seiichi Kita, Japanese Military Attache in Shanghai, when he explained his country's participation in this curious Inner Mongolian crisis.

Thoughtful observers of the stock market agree that it is at present greatly influenced, not merely by general economic conditions, or by the foreign purchases that have recently caused misgivings in Washington, but by two Federal taxes -- the undistributed profits tax on corporations and the capital gains tax on individuals.

OBSERVATIONS on that gargantuan and fascinating table, "The 700 Books for a Home Library," published on page 16 of last Saturday's issue of this paper. The books themselves are now on display in the modern library living room at the Book Fair.

ERIE, Pa., Nov. 16. -- Under the will of Charles H. Strong, Erie utilities operator and newspaper publisher, who died last week and which was probated here today, Yale University will receive a large portion of his estate, estimated at several million dollars.

Joseph Curran, chairman of the Atlantic Coast maritime strikers' committee, left for Washington last night to confer with John L. Lewis, head of the Committee for Industrial Organization. It was said that they would confer on financial aspects of the seamen's strike.

A banking group headed by the Chase National Bank and Graham, Parsons Co. obtained yesterday the award of an issue of $6,450,000 of refunding bonds of Greensboro, N.C. It paid 100,029 for $350,000, due from 1940 to 1944, as 4 1/2s; $3,300,000, due from 1945 to 1956 as 4s, and $2,800,000, due from 1957 to 1962 as 3 1/2s, making the net interest cost to the city 3.721 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, reviewed its work and offered ideas of government in an address at a luncheon given in his honor today by the conference of Mayors.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- President Roosevelt will leave Washington tomorrow evening and sail from Charleston, S.C., on Wednesday, for Buenos Aires, where on Dec. 1 he will address the opening session of the Pan-American Peace Conference.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16. -- The United Air Lines, Chicago, will emphasize the accomplishment of 100,000,000 miles of flying experience in its Winter advertising campaign and will also stress the fact that last year it completed 95.5 per cent of its scheduled miles of Winter flying, according to Harold Crary, vice president in charge of advertising.

A contract to design and manage the construction of a $4,350,000 addition to the Williamsburgh Power Plant Corporation, principal source of electric supply of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit System, has been awarded to the Stone Webster Engineering Corporation, James H. Manning, president of the engineering concern, announced yesterday.
A seaplane, police launches and private craft searched last night off Staten Island for two men who were reported to have left Bayonne, N.J., Sunday morning and failed to return.

MUKDEN, Manchukuo, Nov. 16. -- Weakened by exposure and hunger after nine months in the hands of Chinese bandits, the Rev. Joseph Clarence Burns of the Maryknoll Mission, Ossining, N.Y., accompanied by his Chinese servant, reached Tunghua, 135 miles northeast of Antung today, according to messages relayed to the United States Consul General here.

The Newhouse Gallery (formerly the Ehrich-Newhouse, at 578 Madison Avenue) received visitors yesterday in sumptuous quarters at 5 East Fifty-seventh Street, to which it has just removed. The main exhibition room is decorated in modified Moorish or Spanish style, with white walls, rough in texture, arches and a deeply paneled ceiling.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 16. -- A retirement plan that will take in all of Harvard University employes from the president to the waitresses and "goodies" [Harvard for chambermaids] will be put into effect soon after the first of the year, it was stated today.
An aggressive drive by friends of nine men awaiting trial as racketeers to compel restaurant owners and employes to contribute $275,000 toward a defense fund was revealed yesterday.

The imposing University City in Madrid, which has become the focus of the battle for possession of the capital, is situated about two and a half miles from the heart of the capital and is approached by the Avenue of the Republic.

The possibility of repealing at the next session of the Legislature the part of the State Mortgage Moratorium Act that applies to large structures, where the interest rate has been reduced to less than 5 per cent, was suggested here yesterday at the reopening of hearings in the Bar Association by the Joint Legislative Committee to Investigate the Guaranteed Mortgage Situation.

A symposium by past presidents, including Paul T. Cherington, Louis D.H. Weld, Paul H. Nystrom and Frank M. Surface, will be a feature of the annual meeting of the American Marketing Society to be held in the Hotel Claridge, Atlantic City, on Friday and Saturday, Nov. 27 and 28. Frank R. Coutant, president, will be chairman.

The deck and engine room staffs of the United States liner Washington quit their posts yesterday morning, joining the rank and file group of the International Seamen's Union, which is engaged in a general port strike in protest against the union leaders.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- The Supreme Court granted permission today to the government to participate in a case to be argued soon involving new phases of the Gold Clause Resolution of 1933, rescinding promises to pay in gold.

In his admiration for W.S. Gilbert, as expressed in his article in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine, P.W. Wilson stretches the facts a good deal. He wishes to show as an accepted fact that "we no longer need to ask whether Gilbert's words or Sullivan's music keep the operettas alive"; that it is Gilbert's words.

The West Fifty-second Theatre Company, Inc., owner of the theatre at 245 West Fifty-second Street, where the Theatre Guild, Inc., has been a tenant since April 6, 1925, asked permission yesterday in Federal court to reorganize under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act.

WARSAW, Nov. 16. -- Colonel Roman Abraham, commander of a cavalry division at Scarogard, near the Danzig frontier, is mentioned as the future Polish Commissioner to the Free City of Danzig, succeeding Dr. Casimir Pappee, who will be transferred to Vienna.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (AP). -- An extra dividend of 30 cents and a quarterly disbursement of 25 cents have been voted by directors of Woodall Industries, Inc., of Detroit, it was announced here today. The quarterly payment compares with a dividend of 20 cents on Sept 15.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP). -- Replying to William Green's invitation for a return of his Committee for Industrial Organization unions to the American Federation of Labor, John L. Lewis said today:

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 16 (AP). -- Seven Governors, whose States are among thirty-three that have until Dec. 31 to comply with the unemployment insurance features of the Federal Social Security Act, began concerted efforts today to obtain a retroactive extension of the deadline from the next session of Congress.

BALDWIN, L.I., Nov. 16. -- The Instituto Politecnica Nacional football squad of Mexico, D.F., arrived today to begin preparations for its game with Baldwin High at the Freeport Stadium on Saturday. The party, numbered forty-nine, including Coach Robert P. Martin.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16. -- "Prelude to Exile," the new play by William McNally based on an episode in the life of Richard Wagner, opened at the Chestnut Street Opera House here tonight for a two weeks' engagement. A few cuts had been made since its premiere at Princeton on Saturday night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- An invitation was extended to foreign countries by President Roosevelt today to take part in the World's Fair which will be held in New York City in 1939 to celebrate the 150th anniversary of the inauguration of the first President in that city.

PARIS, Tuesday, Nov. 17. -- An explosion that killed at least forty and seriously wounded 100 persons destroyed the great explosives factory of St. Chamas near Marseilles yesterday afternoon. Reports from Saint Chamas at 3 o'clock this morning said many of the injured were expected to die.

A frank statement of the futility of Republican opposition to the New Deal principles in State legislation is contained in the Weekly News Letter, official publication of the Republican State Committee, released for today.

ALBANY, Nov. 16. -- The appointment of Sydney A. Syme of Bronxville as a justice of the Supreme Court to succeed William F. Bleakley, who resigned to run for Governor, will be made by Governor Lehman, it was announced tonight by Acting Governor M. William Bray.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 16. -- The Republican majority of the Westchester Board of Supervisors voted down this afternoon a move by the Democrats for proportional representation on board committees on the ground that the Democratic-controlled State Senate does not give Republicans representation on the basis of their numerical strength.

BERLIN, Nov. 16. -- Something is brewing in the way of new treason trials and "race pollution" prosecutions. The Minister of Justice has officially announced that a discussion of the matter of enforcing the treason laws has taken place among the active head of the secret political police, State Secretary Heydrich and high officials of the Justice Ministry.

The secret of the appeal of the mystery story is that "almost every one is a potential criminal and anybody might commit murder if the occasion arose," Mrs. Marie Belloc-Lowndes told the evening audience at THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair at the International Building, Rockefeller Center, last night.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 16. -- Mrs. Ida L. Churchill, 83 years old, wealthy widow, was overcome with fatigue after testifying for ninety minutes today in an examination before the trial of her Korean house servant, Chang Soo Lee, 36, for the attempted murder of her niece.

Winter laid a firm hand on New York City and the metropolitan area yesterday and left with a promise that the weather early today would be even more severe. Late this afternoon or tonight, however, the temperature was expected to rise.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16 (AP). -- Herman Taylor, Philadelphia promoter, said today he expected details of the proposed non-title bout between Heavyweight Champion Jim Braddock and Joe Louis, to "be settled" at a conference in New York tomorrow.

A new ten-goal player was added to the list of United States polo yesterday when the board of governors of the United States Polo Association released the new handicap list. At the head, as now constituted, Thomas Hitchcock Jr. is joined by the stocky Stewart B. Iglehart, No. 3 of the American team which played in London last June and the most sensationally improved player of recent years.

A series of resolutions, which would tend to bring about several important changes in horse racing was adopted by the New York State Racing Commission yesterday at a meeting called to consider improvements for 1937.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Mrs. Ethel E. Gleason of Manchester, N.H., asked the Supreme Court today for an order prohibiting the Federal District Court in New York from retaining jurisdiction in an action against H.M. Byllesby Co., New York Stock brokers.

John S. Harrison, youthful representative of the Dartmouth Club, upset the third seeded player, D. Lee Norris of the Yale Club yesterday in the amateur squash racquets tourney sanctioned by the Eastern Squash Racquets Association at the New York Athletic Club.

For the third quarter of this year the Federal Mining and Smelting Company reported yesterday a profit of $363,732, including $187,379 profit on metal stocks sold, but before deductions for depreciations, depletion and Federal income and excess-profits taxes.

TOKYO, Nov. 16. -- The last chapter of a strange spy story was filed in the archives of the Foreign Office today when Giichi Sako, Japanese Ambassador to Moscow, reported the failure of his protest against a ten-year sentence passed on Kaichiro Naka, a 24-year-old Japanese, for espionage at Vladivostok.

A mother whose grand jury testimony caused her wandering son to be indicted for grand larceny refused to testify against him in the trial yesterday, because, she explained, she can take care of him "in her own way," now that he has been returned to her.

John G. Jackson, prominent New York attorney, who has served as president of the United States Golf Association for the past year, will be returned to office at the annual meeting to be held some time after the first of the year.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 16. -- The Westchester County Board of Supervisors, sitting in its capacity as County Board of Canvassers, went on record today as favoring a complete recount of the disputed vote for Surrogate and for State Senator in the Twenty-sixth district.
LONDON, Nov. 16 (Canadian Press). -- Great Britain is inquiring into some strange doings in the Island of Majorca, held by the Spanish Insurgents.

Over the wind-swept hills and flatlands of Van Cortlandt Park, Ken Waite of Michigan State College plowed to victory in the twenty -- eighth annual cross-country championship run of the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. yesterday and led the Spartans to their fourth consecutive team title.

Assailing certain types of fraudulent advertising practices to which he referred as "window larceny," Assistant District Attorney James J. Wilson, in charge of investigating commercial frauds, announced yesterday he would seek a city ordinance limiting retail "going-out-of-business sales" to periods of thirty days, with a thirty-day extension where it is proved necessary.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

The stock market showed rallying tendencies from the start yesterday and various industrial groups picked up strength as the day wore on, with heavy buying of metal issues the feature in the final hour. The closing was strong. The turnover on the Stock Exchange, however, was less than on Friday -- 2,374,000 shares, against 2,482,000.

Two money orders, with a total value of $150, tumbled out of a letter received yesterday by Miss Charlotte E. Carr, executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau.
