In the accompanying letter, a Manhattan woman, whose name was withheld by the bureau, explained that she had found a job and wanted to return relief funds extended her by the city in her period of destitution.

LONDON, Nov. 16. -- James A. Farley, tired after an arduous political campaign and a rough crossing on the liner Normandie, was not too tired to face a barrage of questions from a roomful of reporters today. The United States Postmaster General arrived here this morning on his way to visit Ireland for a vacation.

Disputing the contention of Brooklyn civic groups that business is being driven out of that borough by high city taxes, William Stanley Miller, president of the Department of Taxes and Assessments, said yesterday that such reports were "pure myth."
HOUSTON, Texas, Nov. 16 (AP). -- Secretary Wallace, discussing a proposed crop insurance program at the annual meeting of the Land Grant College Association, predicted today a new era in agriculture.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- John G. Winant returned today to the chairmanship of the Social Security Board, from which he resigned at the height of the recent political campaign to reply to what he considered unfair charges made by critics of the social security program.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 16. -- Tom Mountain, reserve halfback, is lost to Princeton for the Dartmouth game next Saturday, it was revealed today by Dr. Harry R. McPhee, while the availability of three other varsity players is in doubt. Mountain sustained a Broken shoulder blade when he was tackled last Saturday after returning the second-half kick-off to the Yale 28.

Jaunty as ever and certainly lacking none of his old confidence of his ability to handle a tough job, Burleigh Grimes, one-time fiery spitball pitching ace, breezed into wind-swept Ebbets Field yesterday and forthwith took over the assignment of managing the Dodgers for 1937.

A total of $58,500 has been raised to date in the $200,000 budget difference campaign of the Young Women's Christian Association of New York, it was announced yesterday at a report luncheon at the Central Branch, 610 Lexington Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- A change in the "spirit of the membership" of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States toward the New Deal was reported today by its president.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- The world economic situation demands the extension by the next Congress of the powers of the President to devalue the dollar and also calls for maintenance of the $2,000,000,000 stabilization fund, Secretary Morgenthau said today.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 16. -- Practically left at the post but first at the finish, James Butler's Caught today ran the best race of his career to take the featured Eden Handicap in the presence of a windswept crowd that continued to see favorites fall by the wayside.

Dr. John L. Rice, City Health Commissioner, speaking at the twenty-fifth anniversary dinner of the Lutheran Hospital of Manhattan last night, urged hospitals to take greater interest in preventive education and in the treatment of diseases in the early stages. The dinner, held at the Hotel Astor, was attended by 500 persons.

CLIFTON, N.J., Nov. 16. -- Detectives investigating the disappearance of Mrs. Frances Zangara, 54 years old, reported missing ten days ago, found her body today in a shallow grave back of her home at 137 Scoles Avenue in the Allwood district of Clifton.

OSLO, Norway, Nov. 16. -- The growing likelihood that Carl von Ossietzky, German pacifist, will receive the Nobel Peace Prize is understood to have caused the resignations of the Norwegian Foreign Minister, Halvdan Koht, and the former Prime Minister and Foreign Minister, Johann Ludwig Mowinckel, from the Nobel peace committee.

TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 16. -- The American Federation of Labor, as it opened here today a convention which will deliberate on the gravest schism the labor movement in this country has ever known, received from President Roosevelt a message of optimism for labor and for the nation as a whole.
LONDON, Nov. 16. -- Anthony Eden, Foreign Secretary, administered a gentle scolding to Germany today for having repudiated the Versailles Treaty regulations governing her inland waterways.

TORONTO, Nov. 16 (AP). -- Justice W.E. Middleton said tonight that he would decide within a week "if at al! possible" on the validity of Charles Vance Millar's will leaving his $500,000 estate to the winner of Toronto's weird stork derby.
WITH INSURGENTS OUTSIDE MADRID, Nov. 16 (AP). -- Attacking Insurgents tonight massed tanks and infantry troops to make Madrid's streets and plazas the next battlefields of the Spanish civil war.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 16. -- Harvard's football drill today was the longest of the year and would have been longer had the practice field been lighted. With its three varsity teams in such good physical condition that there is not a name now on the "doctor's list," the Crimson set sail for Yale with colors flying.

Bankers' acceptances outstanding in the United States on Oct. 31 amounted to $330,205,152, according to the monthly acceptance survey given out by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York for publication today. This is $15,204,562 more than the amount outstanding a month before, but $32,779,134 less than on Oct. 31, 1935.

Although the nation's list of football scoring leaders compiled by The Associated Press underwent drastic revision over the week-end, none was able to overhaul Art Buck, quarterback at Carroll of Wisconsin.

Clinging tenaciously to its slender margin with the same bulldog spirit that carried it to triumph in the Big Ten and an all-winning season thus far, Northwestern led Minnesota yesterday in The Associated Press college football ranking poll.
Six of the seven surviving members of the old Wilson Street School alumni, all more than 80 years old, held their annual Fall meeting last night at the Hotel Margaret, Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16. -- Grain markets were on the up grade today and when the session on the Board of Trade closed December wheat and all deliveries of rye, barley and soy beans were in new high ground for the season. Corn and oats futures in most deliveries were near their previous high levels.

Although his sympathies were with Mrs. Serena Alves, 36-year-old Negro, Magistrate Louis Brodsky indicated yesterday that the law would compel her to relinquish the 5-year-old white girl she had raised from infancy.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 16. -- A demand for Federal aid for schools and a broadening of the tax base and opposition to tax rate limitation were expressed in a series of resolutions adopted at the closing session of the eighty-second annual convention of the New Jersey State Teachers Association here today.

The investigation of the Television Corporation of America by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. was extended yesterday to sales of the corporation's stock in Albany and here, Ambrose V. McCall, head of the Bureau of Securities of the Attorney General's office, announced.

AS he sat down at the luncheon table the esteemed Colonel John Reed Kilpatrick of Madison Square Garden said that he was going to discuss a hospital case, and to brace himself for it he ordered a thick soup.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16. -- Receipts of hogs today at 38,000 head were the largest for a Monday in more than four years, and prices dropped 5 to 15 cents a 100 pounds. All interests bought freely at the lower level. Top sales at $9.65 were off 15 cents from Friday, while the day's average declined 5 cents to $9.40.
LONDON, Nov. 16. -- Party divisions disappeared in the House of Commons today when the new Public Order Bill passed its second reading and entered the committee stage for minor changes.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 16. -- Wages for 16,000 "rebel" steel workers were lifted 10 per cent today by Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation.

MADRID, Nov. 16 (Censored). -- Madrid was again illuminated tonight by a red glare in a moonless sky. It reflected scores of fires caused by incendiary bombs dropped by Rebel planes between 7 and 8 o'clock.

The Beethoven Association opened in Town Hall its nineteenth season last night when this organization, which from its beginning has la bored ceaselessly for the glory of art, commemorated three great musicians, all of them members, who have died within the last year.

American business, as a trustee for the general public, must henceforth provide "intelligent, courageous and substantial support of social betterment programs" that have been maintained largely by private citizens, Stuart M. Crocker, chairman of the United Hospital Campaign Committee, said last night in opening the annual drive at a dinner at the Hotel Commodore.

Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College received last night the sixth annual gold medal awarded by the American Woman's Association for outstanding achievement in her own field by a woman in the metropolitan area during the year.

No game in recent years has clung so to popular imagination -- even with those who didn't see it -- as the Yale-Princeton thriller of last Saturday. Publicly and privately, the most repeated name is Larry Kelley's, which is, of course, perfectly justified.
BEIRUT, Syria, Nov. 16. -- Moslem-Christian tension here in the past few days culminated last night in serious clashes, continuing today.
BEIRUT, Syria, Nov. 16. -- Moslem-Christian tension here in the past few days culminated last night in serious clashes, continuing today.

Twelve WPA art students, arrested Nov. 9 for participation in a "sit down" strike, received suspended sentences on charges of disorderly conduct yesterday when they appeared before Magistrate Louis B. Brodsky in Jefferson Market Court.

" The small college is probably coming to the fore," said Dr. William Ernest Weld, president of Wells College, speaking last night in the Town Hall Club, 123 West Forty-third Street, at a dinner of almost 100 New York alumnae of the up-State college.

Often after a great battle time is required to measure the size and consequences of the victory won. This was true of the first Battle of the Marne. It was also true of the Battle of Gettysburg. We are now two weeks away from our unexampled battle of the ballots on Nov. 3, and public opinion has been slowly forming conclusions about its real significance.

MADRID, Tuesday, Nov. 17. -- Madrid was aglare early today with bright flames and red smoke after an Insurgent artillery and air bombardment had killed at least sixty persons and set fire to about fifty houses.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 16. -- John Kuzma, 25 years old, of 48 Washington Avenue, was held for the grand jury here today on a charge of manslaughter following the death late last night of Arthur J. Pendleton, 70, a Past Exalted Ruler of the Elizabeth Lodge of Elks and prominent for many years in music circles here.

The general upland game season in New York State, outside of Long Island, virtually came to a close yesterday as grouse and squirrels joined the species that gain the immunity of the law until another Fall rolls around. Sunday was the last day for the deer hunters, but bear may be taken legally until Dec. 31 in the counties of Clinton, Delaware, Essex, Franklin, Greene and Ulster.

Lady Doverdale, who will sail tomorrow on the Queen Mary for her home in London, gave a farewell luncheon yesterday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador. Her guests included Princess Torlonia, Baroness de Villiers Terrage, Mrs. James L. Tailer, Mrs. Edmund Randolph, Mrs. Herbert Shipman, Mrs. William B. Scaife, Mrs. Norman Whitehouse, Mrs. Paulding Fosdick, Mrs. John D. Kennedy, Miss Natica Waterbury and Miss Lucile Thornton.

Abandonment of the metric system as a means of reckoning track events in favor of the old yardage method was forecast for the Amateur Athletic Union yesterday when Secretary-Treasurer Daniel J. Ferris made public the more important legislative changes that the A.A.U. has placed on the agenda for its forty-eighth annual convention at Houston, Texas, on Dec. 4, 5 and 6.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP). -- President Roosevelt turned away from the idea of a doorbell-ringing census of the unemployed today and suggested instead that the jobless be counted monthly by voluntary registration.

Maria Carreras, pianist, who was last heard here several years ago, gave her first recital of the season yesterday afternoon at the Town Hall. Her program consisted of Beethoven's Thirty-two Variations in C minor, based on an original theme, the "Appassionata" Sonata; Brahms's Sonata in F minor, Op. 5; Ravel's "Jeux d'eau," Busoni's Fantasie on Bizet's "Carmen" and Albeniz's "Navarra."

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 17. -- Faced with the most serious injury situation of the season on the Princeton football squad, Fritz Crisler devoted his attention today to improving the play of a few substitutes he will have to use as reserves, if not as replacements, against Dartmouth on Saturday.
MADRID, Nov. 17. -- Rebel war planes dropped at least ten bombs on Madrid late tonight in their third raid within twenty-four hours while a dozen fires flared in the center of the city.

Under the Federal old-age benefit system, which will become effective Jan. 1, it appears that only those individuals whose annual wages are $2,000 or more are qualified to enjoy the benefits therefrom when they shall have attained the age of 65 years.

Canada's foreign trade for the nine months ended last Sept. 30 exceeded $1,000,000,000 for the first time since 1930, Sir Robert L. Borden, president of Barclays Bank of Canada, told stockholders at their ninth annual general meeting in Montreal yesterday, according to a report issued here.

VATICAN CITY, Nov. 17. -- Pope Pius gave a private audience this morning to Will H. Hays, American movie coordinator, discussing with him for about fifty minutes the motion picture situation in the United States, with special reference to the activities of the Legion of Decency.

Leaders of the seamen's unions on the Atlantic and Pacific Coasts joined yesterday with spokesmen of Atlantic shipowners in rejecting the plea of the Mayors of eight seaboard cities that the maritime strikes be arbitrated by boards appointed by President Roosevelt.
An active market in Westchester realty was reported yesterday.

Bob Pastor, Washington Heights heavyweight, gained a ten-round decision over Izzy Singer of the Bronx, in the feature bout at the New York Coliseum last night. A crowd of 7,000 watched the exciting battle.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 17. -- Coach Dick Harlow changed his plans for the Harvard football squad today and ordered a scrimmage for his charges. While he did not have the varsity show its attack against the scrubs or freshmen, he did work his first and second string players on the defense.

Three detectives and four gunmen exchanged more than a dozen shots in a running pistol battle last night at Perry and Bleecker Streets. The gunmen, one of whom was believed to be wounded, escaped by driving an automobile on the sidewalk, after crashing into two other cars.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- Legislation which would require fiscal agents in municipal defaults or refunding situations to file a report or prospectus with a Federal agency, presumably the Securities and Exchange Commission, making full disclosures of their activities. was recommended by William O. Douglas, a member of the SEC, in an address to the United States Conference of Mayors here today.

The law committee of the Merchant Truckmen's Bureau of New York conferred yesterday afternoon with its counsel. Parker McCollester of the law firm of Lord, Day Lord, regarding further procedure in its suit for a permanent injunction to halt the store-door delivery of freight begun on Monday by the major Eastern railroads under an order of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

The Silver Cross Day Nursery will hold its semi-annual luncheon, fashion show and card party at the Astor tomorrow for the benefit of its work. Located at 249 East 117th Street, the nursery cares for children from 1 month to 12 years whose mothers are employed during the day, and is maintained through membership and voluntary contributions.

Lincoln Ellsworth, explorer: Sir Humphrey Rolleston, British surgeon: the Earl and Countess of Granard and the Earl of Jersey are among the persons sailing today for Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.

LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 18. -- Telephoning to The Daily Express from Madrid, its correspondent says that flames have broken out in three of Madrid's greatest buildings -- the fifteen-story telephone skyscraper, the Duke of Alba's palace and the Central Market Hall.

The present objectives of the city's voluntary hospitals are higher standards, lowered costs of treatment and increased facilities for the care of the chronically ill and the convalescent, Dr. Howard W. Haggard. Professor of Applied Psychology in Yale University, said last night in a United Hospital Campaign broadcast from radio station WJZ.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (AP). -- Paul G. Hoffman, president of the Studebaker Corporation, South Bend, Ind., reported today sale of 2,787 passenger cars and trucks in the first ten days of November, com pared with 1,137 the corresponding period of 1935.

Retail failures in the five business days ended Nov. 12 showed an increase from 90 to 103, compared with the preceding period, but were under those in the corresponding period last year, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The suit brought by 217 home owners of Sunnyside, Queens, to compel officers and directors of the City Housing Corporation to reduce the purchase price of their homes was declared invalid yesterday by the Appellate Division in Brooklyn.

Further improvement in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday carried the December option back to the price at which it sold before the last government crop estimate. Evening up of obligations in the near month and hedge selling by spot houses wiped out part of the gain in the last hour and the list ended 1 point lower to 2 points higher than on Monday.
Sales of apartment houses by operators and a new housing project featured the Bronx realty trading reported yesterday.

BOSTON, Nov. 17. -- The New York Rangers' speedy youngsters out-skated the burly Bruins for a 6 -- 1 triumph in a wide-open game tonight before 9,000 at the Boston Garden. The victory enabled the invaders to move up from a third-place tie with Boston to second in the American group of the National Hockey League.

The newest addition to the Mae West cinema catalogue, "Go West, Young Man," Miss West's free version of the stage success "Personal Appearance," makes its bow at the Paramount today. Warren William, Randolph Scott, Lyle Talbot, Alice Brady and Isabel Jewell support Miss Wrest.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- The Florida ship canal project stirred one of the most bitterly fought issues in the last session of Congress. The project had been started by President Roosevelt out of work relief funds, but Congress failed to appropriate additional money and work was stopped.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,040,400 barrels, compared to 2,973,800, a gain of 66,600, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A gain of 60,500 barrels in the daily average output of Oklahoma was the most important change.

Respite from a cold snap of below-freezing weather came to the city yesterday with clear skies and rising temperatures, but another wave of cold is on the way. It probably will develop this afternoon and turn the mercury down to freezing tonight, according to the forecast of the Weather Bureau.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 17. -- The Montclair Athletic Club and the Elizabeth Town and Country Club teams were victors today in Class B competition of the Women's New Jersey Squash Racquets Association.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- Apparently willing to go the whole way in accepting primary responsibility for returning 4,000,000 industrial employables to work, business leaders were hoping tonight for a word of encouragement from President Roosevelt in a statement which he indicated he would make before departing from Charleston tomorrow for Buenos Aires.

The fear that a cumulative reduction of consumer purchasing power will result from the payment of Social Security Act taxes arises in H.S. Gilbertson's mind apparently from a failure on his part to view the entire operation of the act in relation to the taxpayer.

More comprehensive and accurate research on advertising to determine results was urged yesterday by one marketing expert, who declared that while scientific marketing is making rapid strides the study of advertising itself is falling behind.

Miss Susanne Murray and a group of young matrons and former debutantes are aiding members of the Seventh Regiment in plans for the annual Fall military ball to be given in the regimental armory at Park Avenue and, Sixty-sixth Street on Dec. 5. The ball this year will be set in decorations suggestive of the old Bowery.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- The New York Curb Exchange has filed an application for continuance of unlisted trading in the following securities:
Multi-family buildings figured prominently in the Manhattan real estate transactions reported yesterday.

Stanley Galowin of the City A.C., seeded first, advanced to the quarter-finals in the Eastern Squash Racquets Association's amateur tournament at the New York A.C. yesterday, but found F.D. Rogers of the Yale Club a stubborn, skillful rival.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17. -- Grain futures soared to new high levels for the season on the Board of Trade today on the crest of a wave of general speculative buying. December wheat, July oats, and all deliveries of corn, rye, barley and soy beans with the exception of old May corn were in new ground for the year and in a majority of instances sold at the best figures for this season since 1929.

William F. Carey, Sanitation Commissioner, told members of the New York Board of Trade and nine cooperating civic associations yesterday that inability to complete the department's equipment program this Winter would make a "strictly first-class job" of snow removal impossible, but promised that the sanitation forces would do a "fairly good job" anyway.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- Renewal of the interrupted work of building the Florida ship canal has been approved by a special board of army engineers as "justified in the public interest." The general terms of an advisory report by the board were announced by the War Department today.

After all these years of having his say about other people's plays, George Jean Nathan has written one himself. Random House will publish it on Feb. 1, and, until then, every one concerned is going to try to be pretty secretive about it.

On the one hundredth anniversary of W.S. GILBERT'S birth a good many light-hearted people will attend the performance of one of his operas, and nearly every one else will wish that he could. The opera itself, "H.M.S. Pinafore," is only fifty-eight years old, which is nothing, but in another forty-two years, which is nothing, it will celebrate its centenary, and the house will be crowded and crackling.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 17. -- The awarding of five historic Harvard scholarships, all of them more than 200 years old and this year totaling $3.125, to eight upperclassmen in the college was announced today as follows:

Magistrate Leonard McGee in the Felony Court dismissed yesterday a felonious assault charge against Solomon Silver, 25 years old, of 1,818 Madison Avenue, a temporary postoffice clerk and Tammany election district watcher in the registration last October.
MOSCOW, Nov. 17. -- Press reports of a Japanese-German treaty aimed at the Soviet Union were declared true in a statement by Tass, the official Soviet news agency, tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17. -- Named by Mrs. George H. Earle, wife of the Governor, the 10,000-ton cruiser Philadelphia slid into the Delaware River at the Navy Yard today while several thousand spectators cheered, navy planes dipped low in salute and other ships tied their whistles down in greeting.

Robert Lee, 30 years old, of 677 Cortlandt Avenue, the Bronx, was fatally injured and two other men were seriously hurt early yesterday when the automobile in which they were riding mounted the sidewalk on Morris Park Avenue, the Bronx, and crashed into an electric light pole near Unionport Road.

Sterling and the franc weakened in the foreign exchange market yesterday in response to further transfers of funds here, but other currencies were fairly steady. The pound dropped 3/8 cent to $4.88 1/6 and the franc was off 1/8 point to 4.64 7/8 cents.

Jim Grandi, 190-pound sophomore who has been used principally as a blocking back, came to the fore as a ball-carrier yesterday as Manhattan's football squad performed its daily scrimmage chore at Innisfail Park in preparation for the battle with Villanova at Ebbets Field Saturday. This game closes the Green's home season.

The city's claim against a business for sales taxes is a prior lien above all other claims, the Appellate Division in Brooklyn ruled yesterday. The city acts in a capacity, the court held, which devolves from the ancient common law principle that the King and Crown have prior rights in the collection of taxes above the claims of all other creditors.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 17. -- The Navy football team started its final lap today as it worked against a B Squad eleven arrayed in army jerseys which bore the names of the cadet players. Practice was secret, as the team worked on the special plays which it will use against the Army.

The year-end flow of extra dividend payments, wage increases and bonuses continued yesterday to pour into the hands of stockholders and employes of scores of corporations, insuring larger purchasing power for the Christmas shopping season than in any year since 1929.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- President Roosevelt appointed a committee of thirty-eight members today to make a study of farm tenancy with a view to recommending "ways of developing a land tenure system which will bring an increased measure of security, opportunity and well-being to the great group of present and prospective farm tenants."

ATHENS, Greece, Nov. 17. -- An advocate of republican government -- which Greece had from 1924 to 1935, when King George returned to the throne -- Mr. Papanastassiou once decorated his office with pictures of George Washington and Abraham Lincoln.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- President Roosevelt announced today the appointment of Charles Edison, son of the late Thomas A. Edison, the inventor, to be Assistant Secretary of the Navy.

SAINT CHAMAS, France, Nov. 17 (AP). -- Defense Minister Edouard Daladier, offering the government's sympathy to the families of fifty-three killed in yesterday's powder plant explosion, announced tonight a national funeral would be held Friday.

Offering will be made to the public today of a new issue of $15,000,000 of 4 1/2 per cent first-mortgage pipe-line sinking-fund bonds of the Southern Natural Gas Company, due in 1951, at 100 and accrued interest by a banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.

Hopeful news comes out of the West. The thirty-day duck gunning season in the northern zone ended ten days ago and old-time wild-fowlers in a number of States reported to officials that ducks were more numerous than last year. Some said it was the best season in a decade.

LONDON, Nov. 17. -- The parliamentary debate on rearmament, which was the major business of the House of Commons last week, was taken up today in the House of Lords. Little had been left for Viscount Swinton, the Air Minister, to tell the peers in behalf of the government's program.

LONDON, Nov. 17. -- A loan of 100,000,000 sterling which, it is emphasized, is not for rearmament, will be raised tomorrow by the government. It will be called the "2 3/4 per cent funding loan of 1952-57" and the general belief here is that the proceeds will be used to fund Treasury bills, thereby reducing the government floating debt or obviating any increase in it.

Favorable dividend announcements were issued yesterday by fifty-three large corporations, and in most instances, the news caused a rise in the shares affected by the distributions. Fourteen companies increased their dividends, twenty-two voted extra dividends, three voted initial dividends, and six ordered accumulated dividends.

Rapid development of communication in the United States has ended the isolation of certain communities that formerly gave subjects to writers specializing in "local color," Helen Hull said yesterday at THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair in the International Building, Rockefeller Center.

After the carload of thrills provided by the Yale game, it isn't likely that any one who returns to Palmer Stadium will have any expectation of seeing anything like that wild and woolly melodrama repeated Saturday or any Saturday for a long time to come.

Many seats have been purchased for the performance of "White Horse Inn," with Kitty Carlisle and William Gaxton in the leading roles, the night of Nov. 24, at the Center Theatre, Rockefeller Center, which has been taken over to raise funds for carrying on the work of the Catholic Center for Blind.

Sir Harry McGowan, chairman of the British Imperial Chemical Industries, arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary with Lady McGowan on his way to Australia via Canada. He was optimistic about business conditions, said he believed that worldwide recovery had set in and that, "barring war, economic improvement should continue."

ONE Notre Dame alumnus had gone over the Notre Dame-Northwestern situation thoroughly and had taken himself off with a confident air. He had won the coming game for his alma mater by two touchdowns and had removed Northwestern from the undefeated class without consulting the team, the coach or the faculty of the institution.

Several bazaars and sales of useful and decorative articles are being held this week for the benefit of various philanthropic organizations. Members of the Ladies Auxiliary of the Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital are holding their annual Economy Sales today and tomorrow at 2,000 Broadway, corner of Sixty-eighth Street.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 17. -- Making every effort to bring the Army varsity back to the form it showed early in the season, Lieutenant Gar Davidson ordered a long scrimmage today, using teams at each end of the field in order that as many men might see action as possible.

PEAPACK, N. J., Nov. 17. -- Land work in the amateur stake of the sixth annual field trial meeting of the Labrador Retriever Club was completed today. As was the case in the derby stake Sunday it was found impracticable to conduct the water test and this was postponed until tomorrow.

ARLINGTON, Texas, Nov. 17 (AP). -- Quasimodo, a 5-year-old bay gelding sporting the silks of R. R. Greenlee, accounted for the feature at Arlington Downs today when he ran the Waggoner course in 1:18 1/5. He broke first from the gate and continued there throughout, scoring by a two-length margin.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- President Roosevelt started at 8 o'clock tonight for Charleston, S. C., where he will board the cruiser Indianapolis and head south to Buenos Aires, where on Dec. 1 he will address the opening session of the Inter-American Conference for the Promotion of Peace.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 17. -- One of the Horatio Alger stories of the turf, the final chapter of which will be written on Friday, reached a high point at Bowie today when Tony Aste, former bootblack on the ferryboats that plied the East River in the days when there was only one bridge, scored a consecutive triple with his Ascot Stable horses, Apprentice taking the feature at $57.70 for $2.

Although she has acquired a large collection of rejection slips and experienced many rebuffs from editors, Miss Fannie Hurst, the novelist, declared yesterday that she was "just as interested in writing as when she started."

Members of the Pen and Brush Club will hold their annual bazaar in behalf of the organization's philanthropic projects Dec. 10, 11 and 12 at their clubhouse, 16 East Tenth Street. There will be a Mexican supper served from 6 to 8 o'clock, an Oriental booth under the direction of Mrs. Louise Brigham Chisholm, and a booth devoted to silhouettes.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 17. -- While awaiting an official acceptance of Brazil's invitation to President Roosevelt to visit Rio de Janeiro, the government is proceeding to prepare a reception program. At the Foreign Office, Minister Mauri Cicionabuco, who is in charge of the program, declared today that everything is being held in abeyance.

Herman Taylor, the Philadelphia promoter who is seeking to sign James J. Braddock and Joe Louis for a twelve-round no-decision bout at Atlantic City on Washington's Birthday, offered Joe Gould, Braddock's manager, $100,000 in cash yesterday to sign for the bout.
ROME, Nov. 17. -- Well-informed Italian circles declared themselves unaware this evening of the conclusion of any anti-Communist understanding between Italy and Japan.

President ROOSEVELT'S appointment yesterday of a special committee to study the question of farm tenancy and report its findings by next Feb. 1 clearly foreshadows reference of this problem to the new Congress. The problem itself is a familiar one: farm tenancy, increasing gradually over a long period of years, has now reached a point at which 40 per cent of the country's farms are operated by tenant farmers.

The New York City police denied a request last night for a police escort through the city for Lessing J. Rosenwald, merchant and philanthropist, who was speeding from Philadelphia with his wife to the bedside of their son, Robert, 15, critically ill in Waterbury, Conn.
ALBANY, Nov. 17 (AP). -- The Court of Appeals affirmed today the death sentence for six men convicted of murdering a New York subway collector Sept. 2, 1935.

Registration of visiting buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday was less than in the preceding week but was well above the figures for the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings of THE TIMES. For the week the arrivals numbered 872 as against 1,006 in the previous week and 697 in the same period last year.
Seeking to end the holding of fictitious special retail sales, the Board of Aldermen adopted a local law yesterday assessing a $25 fee for each such sale.

Anthony Garlaus, confessed holdup man who was indicted for first-degree murder yesterday, had the grim pleasure shortly after his arrest of acutely embarrassing the detectives who were questioning him concerning the killing of Isaac Shean in a hold-up on Nov. 8.
LONDON, Nov. 17. -- Although the precise terms of Japan's understanding with Germany remain obscure, there is little reason to doubt that Japan has not enhanced her reputation for sagacity here.

Letters will be sent today to stockholders of the Nash Motors Company and the Kelvinator Corporation notifying them that the directors of each company had approved a merger of the companies and asking approval of the plan by the shareholders.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- Following is the address of Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, before the Mayor's Conference today:

BALTIMORE, Nov. 17. -- Due to the recent death of Mrs. Mary Frick Jacobs, wife of Dr. Henry Barton Jacobs, a trust estate estimated at about $500,000 will be divided between Johns Hopkins University and the Peabody Institute.

As he landed from the liner Queen Mary yesterday, after a business trip to Europe, Samuel C. Stampleman of Boston, president of the Gillette Safety Razor Company, received a subpoena to appear as the principal State witness Tuesday at the General Sessions trial of two men on his extortion charge.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 17. -- The Cincinnati, New Orleans Texas Pacific Railway Company declared an extra dividend of $23 a share to common stockholders today. The dividend will result in distribution of $2,063,100 to the holders of 89,700 shares outstanding.

Following an investigation conducted by agents of the Treasury Department and by the United States Attorney's office, eleven of the eighteen active agents of the Federal Bureau of Narcotics here were disciplined yesterday by order of Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, acting on charges that they had been inefficient and had filed false statements and reports.

MOSCOW, Nov. 17. -- For the first time since the revolution the Soviet State has begun manufacturing wedding rings. They are on sale now at the Central Mostorg, the city's biggest government-owned department store.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 17. -- Yale today held its longest scrimmage of the week for the Harvard game here Saturday. The session was given over largely to new plays which the coaches believe will prove most effective against the Crimson.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- Opening the exhibit of murals and sculpture for Federal buildings at the Corcoran Art Gallery today, Secretary Morgenthau said that he was "proud of this showing of the work of American artists in the decoration of the United States Government buildings."

MOSCOW, Nov. 17. -- Russia tonight charged Germans now under arrest with participating in a widespread plot to overthrow the Soviet regime. An official statement alleged the Germans, recently arrested in Moscow. Leningrad and elsewhere, had plotted to steal secret military information, to wreck industrial plants, and to kill government leaders.

James S. O'Brien of Elmhurst, Queens, received the Distinguished Service Cross yesterday at exercises at Fort Totten, Bayside, thirty-five years after he earned the award for heroic services in the Philippine insurrection on Feb. 5, 1901, when he rescued a wounded comrade under fire.
LONDON, Nov. 17. -- The centenary of Sir W.S. Gilbert tomorrow brought a stream of flowers and messages today to the rambling country house near Harrow where Gilbert wrote many of his later operas.

New York's most impressive football team of the year, Fordham, is coming back to the wars this week following its rest of the past week when it coasted through a Saturday with no game. The holiday was needed and thoroughly enjoyed and all hands yesterday in practice at Fordham showed the effects of it.

LeRoy Haynes, Negro heavyweight from Philadelphia, will meet Abe Feldman, sturdy East Side battler, in the feature bout of ten rounds at the New York Hippodrome tonight. The fight will be Feldman's big opportunity, for if he succeeds in defeating Haynes decisively he very likely will get the call to face Joe Louis next month.

Ernest S. McDonald, a vice president of the Bank of the Manhattan Company, in charge of the Jamaica office of the institution, was called, as a witness by the government yesterday at the trial in the Federal court in Brooklyn of the National Title Guaranty Company and eight of its former officers.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday that its net income from all operations in the twelve months ended on Oct. 31 showed a gain of more than 20 per cent over the preceding twelve months. Gross revenues in the year amounted to $12,714,238 and net revenues to $4,071,034.

LONDON, Nov. 17 (AP). -- The friendship of King Edward and Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson, without mention of the name, came before Parliament today. Miss Ellen Wilkinson, Socialist member of the House of Commons, brought up the subject.

A four-volume folio edition of Audubon's "The Birds of America" was sold yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries for $6,600, which is the highest price the book ever has bought. The book was the featured item in Part 1 of the library formed by Airs. Milton E. Getz of Beverly Hills, Calif.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 17 (AP). -- A determination to get out of debt was credited to "thousands of farmers" today by A.S. Goss, Federal Land Bank Commissioner, in an address at the convention of the National Grange.

Dr. Rexford Guy Tugwell has been the target for constant attack by the President's political opponents almost since the day when he left the faculty at Columbia University to become a member of the Presidential "brain trust."

Two hundred persons attended the funeral at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street, yesterday morning for David Brooks, who was killed early Sunday morning when he fell fourteen stories from his apartment in Mayfair House, Park Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.

The active cooperation of the shipping industry with the New York World's Fair, 1939, "for the advancement of the City and Port of New York" was asked yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation.

Pacific Mills, large textile manufacturers, yesterday leased four important cotton spinning units of the Amoskeag Manufacturing Company and purchased a substantial portion of the company's looms at Manchester, N.H., according to an announcement from that city.

Supreme Court Justice Conway in Brooklyn reserved decision yesterday on the application of Municipal Court Justice Nathan Sweedler of Brooklyn for a temporary injunction to restrain the broadcasting of a "Good Will Court" program sponsored by Standard Brands, Inc., distributors of Chase Sanborn Products.
The Erie Railroad reported yesterday as follows for October and the ten months:

BERLIN, Nov. 17. -- Carl von Ossietzky, German pacifist and radical journalist, who has been interned in German concentration camps since the Spring of 1933 and has been mentioned as the probable winner of this year's Nobel Peace Prize, is again free, although he is physically a broken man.

BERLIN, Nov. 17. -- It may be too early to draw conclusions, but foreign trade with the principal European countries, especially the countries that recently devalued their currencies, took a turn during October, the first post-devaluation month, that could not have been anticipated and that for the moment seems to justify the German thesis that as a weapon in the foreign trade struggle devaluation is not what it is cracked up to be.

Coming to the close of a long trial in the Bronx Court of Special Sessions yesterday, during which Assistant District Attorney Walter X. Stanton had found it necessary to impeach the testimony of two of his witnesses, Justices Walling, Hoffman and Gresser found that they must decide whether one man was guilty of conspiracy when his two co-defendants had been acquitted.

New York University's football team received an additional set of plays yesterday at Ohio Field as it continued preparation for its last two games of the season. The Violet is slated to go against City College on Saturday at the Yankee Stadium and on Thanksgiving Day meets its traditional foe, unbeaten Fordham.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- Rexford G. Tugwell has submitted his resignation as Under-Secretary of Agriculture and Resettlement Administrator to President Roosevelt. President Roosevelt was reported to have accepted, and an announcement to that effect was understood to have been ready at the White House today, but the President left for a Southern trip without releasing it.

James A. Hatch, Republican leader of the Tenth Assembly District, has resigned, it became known yesterday. His successor will be selected at a meeting of the County Committee of the district at the clubhouse, 8 West Twenty-eighth Street, tonight.
BERLIN, Nov. 17. -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Nov. 16 shows the following changes from the preceding week in thousands of marks:

ALBANY, Nov. 17. -- The order of the Appellate Division authorizing Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, to sell the stock of the National Surety Company to the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation for $10,031,000 was upheld today by the Court of Appeals without costs and without an opinion.

A reception in honor of the Rev. Elmore McNeill McKee, the new rector of St. George's Episcopal Church, Sixteenth Street, east of Third Avenue, and Mrs. McKee, was given last night in the assembly room of St. George's Memorial House by the vestry and junior vestry.

Holding its first meeting since it became an incorporated body last week, the Allied Transit Committee of the Borough of Queens, representing about 100 Queens civic organizations, ousted John H. Morris, who was president of the committee for the last seven years when the committee functioned as an unincorporated group.
A ship's wireless operator, marooned in the radio shack by wind and high seas that swept the decks, reported the deaths of three men on the British freighter Tweed-bank yesterday morning.

A resurgence of buying enthusiasm sent the stock market substantially higher yesterday, with most stock groupings participating in the advance. Gains ranged from fractions to 5 points, and the closing approximated the day's best levels. One feature was the strong demand for many low-priced issues.

LONDON, Nov. 17 (AP). -- Authoritative British sources disclosed today that the Spanish Government was planning a major counter-attack against Insurgent troops south and southwest of Madrid, using 70,000 men in an attempt to cut the Rebel rear guard.

PARIS, Nov. 17 -- France's foreign trade in October, which was the first month of the devalued franc, showed improvement on the whole, but only because prices rose in terms of the franc. Imports amounted to 2,247,000,000 francs, compared with 1,862,000,000 in the preceding month and 1,731,000,000 in October, 1935.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 17. -- Counsel for Chang Soo Lee, 36 years old, Korean servant at the home of Mrs. Ida L. Churchill, wealthy Prospect Park widow, obtained an order this afternoon requiring District Attorney Walter A. Ferris to show cause in county court on Thursday why defense physicians should not be permitted to examine Mr. and Mrs. George Reeves in White Plains Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- While industry is rapidly absorbing workers from relief rolls, labor-saving machinery and the influx of 500,000 young persons of "work age" each year make it necessary that shorter hours for active workers be arranged, and aid must be given young persons and over-age workers before ultimate recovery is attained, Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, told the United States Conference of Mayors today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 17. -- Ernestine Schumann-Heink, beloved operatic and concert singer, died at her home in Hollywoodlands tonight at 7:21 o'clock (10:21 P. M., Eastern standard time). She was 75 years old.

A new issue of $15, 000, 000 State of Colorado highway fund revenue anticipation warrants was awarded yesterday to a nation-wide group of eighty-eight banking houses headed by Lazard Freres Co., Inc. The bankers paid par for $11,690,000 of the warrants, due on June 1, 1939 to 1951, as 3s, and $3,310,000, due on June 1, 1952 to 1954, as 2 3/4s.

Business gains ranging from 51 to 32 per cent over last year, delayed deliveries ranging up to six weeks in some instances, and the placing of advance orders well into 1937 were reported yesterday by purchasing agents at the exhibit of products made by member companies of the Purchasing Agents Association of New York in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Nov. 17. -- Held back hitherto by his adjourned games, two of which still are pending, Isaac I. Kashdan, New York State chess champion, made the most of his opportunity when, in the fourth round of the international tournament at the Club de Ajedrez, he defeated Rafael Cintron of San Juan, national titleholder, in twenty-one moves today.

Soviet authorities have just suppressed a satirical opera by the most celebrated of Moscow's proletarian poets on the ground, virtually, that it offends religious susceptibilities. The libretto burlesques the conversion of Russia to Christianity under VLADIMIR of Kiev at the end of the tenth century.
HONOLULU, Nov. 17. -- A serious food shortage in Hawaii was predicted by business men here today unless the maritime strike is settled soon. The territory imports about 80 per cent of its food.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 17. -- Dissatisfaction with the receivership of Continental Shares, Inc., appeared in Common Pleas Court today when a committee representing 1,000 shareholders petitioned for "opening of the books."

After spending the Summer in England and Scotland recuperating from the illness he had at Glen Cove, L.I., last May, J.P. Morgan returned yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary. He looked in the best of health and spirits.

A few days ago, after officials of the Department of Commerce had announced that they were preparing to recommend a census of the unemployed, General HUGH S. JOHNSON appeared in his syndicated column with a characteristic blast against the idea. The department was "moiling over the "correct definition of the word 'un-"'employment,'" he wrote, as if that was the most ridiculous idea in the world.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- The "unofficial list" of members of the Seventy-fifth Congress, which will meet on Jan. 3, 1937, is fresh from the printer and it reduces to human factors one of the most important results of election day. That was not so much the numerical Democratic gains in the House and Senate as the specific changes in personnel which were ordered by the voters when they replaced twenty-five Republicans with Democrats.

Referring to the Gettysburg address of Charles F. Zimmerman, president of the First National Bank of Huntingdon, Pa., published in THE TIMES of Nov. 12, the unit system has been the curse not only of the banking system of the country, as Senator Glass once said, but of our entire economic structure.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Watson gave a dinner last night in honor of Radoye Yankovitch, retiring Yugoslav Consul General at New York, and Mrs. Yankovitch, at the River Club, 247 East Fifty-second Street.

Determination of the Red Cross to continue its record of the past with new vitality in the future was expressed last night by Miss Anne Morgan, president of the American Woman's Association, and General James G. Harbord, chairman of the New York Chapter of the Red Cross, in a broadcast over WEAF.

WASHINGTON, Nov. /?. -- The opening conference of a series to bB held by the Securities and Exchange Commission with a committee representing the New York Stock Exchange in connection with proposals by the commission for partial seDTegation of the brokerdealer functions on the floors of national securities exchanges will be held here tomorrow afternoon.

TRENTON, Nov. 17. -- Pending preparation of a report on unemployment insurance by the State Social Security Commission and President Roosevelt's reaction to Governor Hoffman's request that the deadline for compliance with the federal act be extended beyond Jan. 1, Republican State Senators decided at a conference here today to defer formulation of plans either for a special session of the 1936 Legislature or organization of the 1937 law-making body.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 18. -- Reports that Germany and Japan have signed a military alliance are absolutely mistaken. Phraseology of an agreement is still being discussed in Tokyo, but it will not be ready for submission to the Privy Council for more than a week.
TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 17. -- Eight resolutions offered at the convention of the American Federation of Labor today took the side of John L. Lewis in his conflict with the federation's chiefs.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 17. -- The statement that one of the most important functions of education is that of furnishing means whereby to assay the intellectual and personal powers of each youth in the community was made by President Angell of Yale tonight at a school-health conference of the Connecticut Department of Education.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 17. -- Advices from Tokyo state that it is understood that Italy will announce her adherence to the Japanese-German anti-Communist agreement and that Germany and Italy will recognize Manchukuo, while Japan, in return, will recognize Italy's conquest of Ethiopia.

A request for a capital outlay of $4,652,000 to construct buildings for Hunter College on the site of the old institution at Park Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street will be made within a short time to the Board of Estimate, it was announced last night.
HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 17 (AP). -- The body of John Bowers, silent screen hero, was washed ashore today near the film colony at Malibu Beach.

Data on sales of the F.W. Woolworth Company and subsidiaries, filed confidentially with the Securities and Exchange Commission, were disclosed yesterday in amendments to the company's annual report to the commission. Also released yesterday were the salary lists of two other companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

ALBANY, Nov. 17. -- The law which made possible sentences aggregating from thirty to fifty years for Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania, reputed head of a New York City vice ring who was convicted of compulsory prostitution, was attacked tonight in the Appellate Division, Third Department, as unconstitutional as to its retroactive features.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Nov. 17. -- Great disappointment in Hungarian political circles has been caused by a recent article by Dr. Alfred Rosenberg, Nazi leader, in the Voelkischer Beobachter in which he wrote that Germany would not support the revisionist claims of the countries defeated in the World War.

JONESPORT, Me., Nov. 17 (AP). -- Dozens of Down East coasting schooner skippers broke out long-unused gear today in preparation for a revival of coastwise traffic which many old seamen had mourned as gone forever.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 17. -- Puerto Rican Nationalists, with two delegates in Buenos Aires, hope to gain admission to the Pan American Peace Conference with the island's proposal for independence. Vicente Geigel Polanco, president of the United Front for Puerto Rican Independence, took a plane which carried Federal Secret Service men south, and Marta Lomar, president of the Women's Organization for Independence, has arranged to fly this week.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 17 (AP). -- A "sit-down strike" at the Bendix Products Corporation culminated today in an order from J.P. Mahoney, vice president and works manager, to 4,300 employes to turn in their tools and leave the plant of the automotive accessory concern.
The Treasury Department disclosed yesterday that stringent penalties could be invoked to compel registration of employers and employes under the Federal Social Security Act.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- President Roosevelt reported today that his re-election cost him exactly $670.

Predictions of business condition two or three years hence are "pure guesswork" and "without proper regard for the uncertainties of the future," Dr. Lionel D. Edie, economist and investment counselor, warned yesterday. He said that major factors indicated general recovery for at least another twelve months, but added that the government was wrong in thinking it would be able to keep money cheap.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- Terminating its Fall session, the Federal Advisory Council conferred today with the Federal Reserve Board, engaging in a general discussion of the domestic and international credit and monetary situation.

IN "The Return of the Weed" (Harper, $2) Paul Horgan has written a series of delicate little stories of New Mexico, none of great force or impact but each of unusual quality. The theme common to them all is as old as literature -- man's eventual defeat by his environment. The illustrations are reproductions of lithographs by Peter Hurd.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- Hope that the United States, while participating in an international stabilization conference, may have at its command the weapon of retroactive taxation to defeat monetary speculators was expressed to the Supreme Court today by Robert H. Jackson, Assistant Attorney General.

LISBON, Portugal, Nov. 17. -- Despite the government's heavy counter-attacks, Spanish Insurgents maintained their positions in Madrid today, holding the Moncloa quarter and University City, on the northwestern edge of Madrid, with a footing in the West Park and Bombilla.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Nov. 17. -- Directors of the Youngstown Sheet land Tube Company today ordered nearly one-half of the back dividends of the company's preferred stock paid in cash. Directors ordered a payment of $8.25 per share, representing a year and a half of unpaid dividends on the preferred issue, on Dec. 15 to holders of record Dec. 5.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 17.Fay ]Bainter, who was brought to Hollywood from the Broadway stage for RKO's "Quality Sireet," the next Katharine Hepburn film, may remain under contract to RKO. In the meantime, having finished her part of "Quality Street," she will start immediately to work on "Michael Strogoff," with Anton Wa]brook.

A demonstration of how the model for the new America's Cup yacht to be built for Harold S. Vanderbilt was chosen was given yesterday in the tank of the Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken. It was arranged by Drake H. Sparkman of the designing firm of Sparkman and Stephens, which has designed the racer in collaboration with W. Starling Burgess.

Don Hutson, former Alabama all-American end who starred in the 1935 Rose Bowl classic, bids fair to shatter the National Football League's record for receiving forwards. The Green Bay Packer has already caught twenty-five passes, one short of the circuit's mark of twenty-six made last season by Tod Goodwin of the Giants, according to the statistics released yesterday.

When the automobile show at the Gland Central Palace closes at 11 o'clock tonight, it will pass into automotive history as "the most successful national show of all time," it was asserted yesterday in behalf of the management. And "successful" applies to both sales and attendance, according to the report.

The site of the old Mansion House, for years was a well-known hostelry New Brunswick, N.J., until torn in down a few years ago, has been purchased by the Philkay Realty Corporation of New York from the West Side Trust Company of Newark.

A telegram requesting a joint conference to discuss the curbing of "unfair returns" of garments by retailers was sent yesterday to Channing E. Sweitzer, managing director of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, by the Emergency Committee on Returns, comprising the executives of virtually all of the women's apparel trade associations.

The plan for parking autos during certain hours on only one side of the street to relieve traffic congestion went into effect for a trial period on Monday in several thoroughfares between Forty-fifth and Fifty-fourth Streets and Ninth and Lexington Avenues, it was announced at police headquarters yesterday.

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 17. -- While a new star came shooting across the golf firmament today, an old one -- one that has shone most brilliantly for more than twenty years -- was vanishing, leaving behind a record that will probably live as long as the game is played.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17. -- Employment in Pennsylvania factories was 10 per cent greater in October than a year ago and the level of payrolls was 24 per cent higher, according to indexes compiled by the Federal Reserve Bank.
MADRID, Nov. 17. -- The Rebel artillery and aerial bombardment off Madrid has become more violent. In five air raids since last night seventy persons have been killed.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Ambassador Dino Grandi left London today for Rome to report to Premier Benito Mussolini on his conversations with Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden concerning a betterment of Anglo-Italian relations. He took with him earnest protestations by the British Foreign Office that a restoration of the traditional good-will between the two nations was greatly desired by this country, but he did not carry any definite proposals on how to bring that about.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 17. -- The Public Service Corporation of New Jersey ordered an extra dividend totaling more than $1,000,000 at the regular quarterly meeting of its board of directors. In addition to the quarterly dividend of 60 cents a share on common stock, the directors announced an extra dividend of 20 cents a share.

Bond prices advanced in more active trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. United States Government securities were mostly higher and six issues in this group reached record prices. High-grade corporation bonds were steady, while more speculative issues, particularly those with conversion privileges, taking their cue from the advancing stock market, rose sharply, the net gains running up to 8 points.

An incomplete tabulation of appeals from 1937 real estate valuations filed with the Board of Taxes and Assessments indicates that at least 12,000 fewer were filed this year than in 1935, William Stanley Miller, president of the board, announced yesterday. Monday was the last day for filing appeals.

MOSCOW, Nov. 17. -- The offenses for which numerous German citizens have been arrested in the Soviet Union recently range from distributing Fascist literature to preparing terroristic acts against the Soviet Government, Maxim Litvinoff, Foreign Commissar, told Count Friedrich Werner yon Schulenburg, German Ambassador, in a long conversation at the Foreign Office here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP). -- Mayor S. Davis Wilson of Philadelphia said tonight he had guarantees of "100 per cent cooperation" from Federal Works officials for an extensive improvement and maintenance program in his city during the coming year.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 17 (AP). -- Plans for a spectacular military and naval display to greet President Roosevelt on his South American visit were announced tonight by President Agustin P. Justo of Argentina.

LONDON, Nov. 17. -- King Edward, accompanied by Ernest Brown, Labor Minister, and Sir Kingsley Wood, Health Minister, left London tonight for a two-day tour of South Wales coal centers, where unemployment has caused national alarm.

HARRISBURG, Nov. 17. -- Governor George H. Earle of Pennsylvania, where the unemployed have seized idle coal lands and worked them for their own profit in defiance of law and property rights, said yesterday that unless the anthracite operators reopened enough closed collieries to re-employ a large proportion of idle miners, the Federal Government might be forced to do so.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- Rumors of the impending resignation of Stephen Early, assistant Secretary of the President, gained renewed impetus today. It has been understood for some time that Mr. Early had received several offers of positions outside the government service and it was reported today that he was seriously considering an offer from Paramount Pictures, effective after Jan. 1.

The Coca-Cola Company reported yesterday for the quarter ended Sept. 30 net earnings of $8,931,315 before reserve for taxes. This compared with $6,367,141 in the third quarter of last year. After taxes and dividends on Class A shares, net earnings applicable to the common stock in the third quarter amounted to $6,776,748, equal to $1.69 each on the 4,000,000 no-par common shares.

Edward Egan of the Saltus Fencing Club swept through all five of his bouts in the final round robin to win the novice saber competition on the strips of the New York A.C. last night. The victor received the Dr. Graeme M. Hammond saber.

Addressing the conference of Mayors, Mr. LA GUARDIA urged the adoption of a constitutional amendment granting power to the States to fix minimum wages for women. He favored this course of procedure because, as he said, it was "the American way." So many and sometimes contradictory things are described as truly American that this might be also.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 17. -- Granted a slight break in the severe weather prevailing here, Syracuse's football squad went through a two-hour workout today, grooming its attack for the climax game with Colgate. With Johnny Gorecki on the sidelines with an injury, Coach Vic Hanson experimented with Jimmy Nolan, Art Morison and Charlie Krout at the wing-back post.

Attempted "interpretations" of the election multiply. It appears to be agreed that the majority of the American people are still unsatisfied; that they still want something. Just what they want is not clear.

No trace has been found of Fred B. Lloyd, president of the Petroleum Conversion Corporation, 100 East Forty-second Street, since he disappeared on Oct. 27, despite an extensive search by the police of the Missing Persons Bureau and private agencies. Arthur W. Rinke, his personal attorney and attorney for the oil company, said yesterday that no clues had been developed.

Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt appealed to the courts again yesterday in a new attempt to regain the custody of her 12-year-old daughter, Gloria Laura Morgan Vanderbilt. The new appeal came just four days before the second anniversary of the signing by Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew of the order giving principal custody of the girl to her aunt, Mrs. Gertrude Vanderhilt Whitney.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17. -- Statistical evidence garnered from Who's Who and similar publications was presented before the National Academy of Science today to show that the time of the year in which a child is conceived so influences the human embryo that on it depends whether the future adult is to become a genius, a dementia praecox type of lunatic, or a dangerous criminal.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP). -- An American boycott on King Edward's coronation and "his proposed marriage to an American divorcee" was urged today by Representative Raymond J. Cannon, Democrat, of Wisconsin. He is the first United States official to take formal cognizance of Great Britain's royal romance.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 17. -- Directors of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company declared today an extra cash dividend of $1 per share on 7,746,000 shares of outstanding common stock and $2 per share in preference stock, Series A, both payable Jan. 11, 1937, to shareholders of record Dec. 15.

Two young men wearing cheap, smoke-colored glasses with white rims and who had their hats pulled well down on their faces, held up four persons in a second-floor apartment at 538 East Twenty-first Street, Brooklyn, last night, bound and gagged their victims and got away with $80 in cash and some jewelry.

Charles T. Gwynne, executive vice president of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, made public yesterday a reply to criticism by Park Commissioner Robert Moses of a report published by the chamber.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- The Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore filed today a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $23,000,000 of Series N 3 1/4 per cent first refunding mortgage sinking fund bonds due Dec. 1, 1971.

Joseph Dillon, a naturalization clerk at $1,320 a year in the Bronx County Clerk's office, was dism issed, it was announced yesterday, after he had failed to account "satisfactorily" for $17,356.62 of $33,376.62 which he banked between Aug. 2, 1927, and Dec. 31, 1932.

The belief that British democracy will outlive European dictatorships was expressed yesterday by Miss Irene Ward, member of the British Parliament, in a lecture before the League for Political Education in Town Hall.

Gains were numerous on the local commodity futures markets yesterday in brisk trading. Spot coffee declined and hides and cocoa eased moderately. In the cash markets wheat, rye, oats and rubber sold at new high prices, and flour, cotton, lard, butter and silk advanced.

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 17 (AP). -- The Resettlement Administration announced today the purchase of three farms to be included in "Northampton Farms," first community farmstead project in the Northeastern United States.

TORONTO, Nov. 17 (by the Canadian Press). -- Board of directors of Lake Shore Mines announced today a 100 per cent dividend together with a 100 per cent bonus will be paid Dec. 15 to shareholders of record Dec. 1. The disbursement will be $2, the stock having a par value of $1.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 17. -- Ernest T. Weir disclosed today that steel operators are divided in their views on pegging wages of the industry's 500,000 workers to the cost of living.

The result of the campaign now on for the hospitals will, as was said by Chairman STUART CROCKER at the opening of the campaign night before last, do much toward determining whether the system of volunteer hospitals will be continued under private responsibility and support or be turned over to the Government.
Business and residential projects were included in the building plans filed yesterday, as follows:

A new gallery, displaying the combined arts of easel painters and interior decorators, was opened privately yesterday afternoon at 554 Madison Avenue. Known as the Decorators Picture Gallery, it will be opened to the public today.

ALBANY, Nov. 17. -- New York City won a $36,000,000 law suit today when the Court of Appeals, without opinion, unanimously affirmed a lower court ruling holding that the city's 3 per cent utility tax payment may not be deducted from franchise taxes paid by the utilities.

In the correction of physical defects, automobiles receive far more attention than the school children of the nation, Dr. Howard W. Haggard, Professor of Applied Physiology at Yale University, declared yesterday. He spoke at a luncheon discussion of "The School Child and His Health" under the auspices of the Public Education Association and forty public health, welfare and civic organizations in the Hotel Commodore.

A new gallery, displaying the combined arts of easel painters and interior decorators, was opened privately yesterday afternoon at 554 Madison Avenue. Known as the Decorators Picture Gallery, it will be opened to the public today.

ALBANY, Nov. 17. -- New York City won a $36,000,000 law suit today when the Court of Appeals, without opinion, unanimously affirmed a lower court ruling holding that the city's 3 per cent utility tax payment may not be deducted from franchise taxes paid by the utilities.

In the correction of physical defects, automobiles receive far more attention than the school children of the nation, Dr. Howard W. Haggard, Professor of Applied Physiology at Yale University, declared yesterday. He spoke at a luncheon discussion of "The School Child and His Health" under the auspices of the Public Education Association and forty public health, welfare and civic organizations in the Hotel Commodore.

Harry F. Wolf of the New York A.C., national champion, and winner of the tourney a year ago, gained the final of the Princeton Club's annual squash tennis tournament yesterday at the Princeton Club's courts.

WITH INSURGENTS IN NORTHWESTERN MADRID, Nov. 17 (AP). -- Insurgent airplane bombs set fire late tonight to the famous Montana Barracks of Madrid, while three columns of Insurgent troops within Madrid advanced slowly through the western section of the University City region.

On account of your vast circulation it is inevitable that you receive thousands of letters, generally and specifically, censuring "The 700 Books for a Home Library" published this morning. A cursory glance reveals not only errors of judgment but of fact.
LONDON, Nov. 18. -- Diplomatic and political circles buzzed with talk today about an editorial in The Times of London on the reported Italo-German-Japanese anti-Communist accord.
Several building projects, including a twelve-story apartment house for a West Side site and two business buildings for midtown, were announced yesterday in connection with Manhattan sales.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18 (AP). -- Tickets for the Army-Navy game on Nov. 28 will be refused at the gate if it is determined they have been resold by their original purchaser.
VIENNA, Nov. 18. -- Dr. Guido Schmidt, the Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, left tonight for Berlin with four officials of the Foreign Office.

Headed by Colonel Albert Sidney Williams, commanding the Sixteenth United States Infantry, army officers gathered at the Hotel Astor yesterday to start a drive for the promotion of the charity football game between the Fort Jay Hawks and the Fort DuPont Engineers.

TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 18. -- Major George L. Berry, Federal Coordinator for Industrial Cooperation, told the annual convention of the American Federation of Labor today that unless the Supreme Court changed "its present philosophy" and henceforward favored "liberal legislation" a way "would be found" to meet the situation.

Engagement of $2,119,000 gold abroad for shipment here, $1,695,000 in Switzerland and $424,000 in England, was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The engagement in Switzerland, which was actually made several days ago, will bring the first import of Swiss gold to this country since September, when $524,000 was received.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 18. -- European countries show a tendency to align themselves as they were before 1914, James G. McDonald of New York City told Vassar College students tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- High officials of church and State, members of the diplomatic corps and representatives of 300 educational institutions in all parts of the country were among the more than 5,000 persons who attended the inauguration today of the Right Rev. Joseph Moran Corrigan of Philadelphia as the sixth rector of Catholic University.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- The effect which disputes over place or policy have upon the personal relations between two men is nearly always exaggerated in Washington. An argument quickly runs to a "feud" in printer's ink, and two administrators who are merely aggressive competitors become "bitter rivals" in many a dispatch.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 18. -- Pass defense was stressed by the Princeton varsity football team today, with the practice curtailed to little more than an hour because of the cold weather.

The conclusion of a new international agreement has come to mean less and less in a world where too many pacts between nations seem made only to be broken. The reported accord between Germany and Japan, coinciding as it does with the German repudiation of the last clause of another treaty, belongs in the same category as the recent agreement between Germany and Italy.

MOSCOW, Nov. 18. -- The Soviet today followed up last night's accusation that Japan and Germany had signed an anti-Soviet treaty with a charge that a Japanese-inspired offensive against Chinese troops in Suiyuan Province was an imperialistic manoeuvre toward encircling the Mongolian People's Republic (Outer Mongolia), possibly as far as Sinkiang Province, pointing deeply into the Soviet's flank.

IN the years when there were proud bohemians here, happily substituting love for fuel and talk for dinner. Mabel Dodge of Buffalo returned from Europe and went head-hunting through New York. She acquired an apartment, discarded a husband, and set up a salon. The four large rooms that were her headquarters faced south, the corner windows looking down Fifth Avenue from the uptown side of Ninth Street.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 18. -- In the argot of the race track a horse is "going" when a trainer feels he is fit and ready to win, and on such happy occasions every dutiful trainer communicates with his owner so that all concerned may have the glad tidings.

Individual Tammany district leaders were informed yesterday that they would be permitted to see James J. Dooling, Tammany leader, some time in the near future. Mr. Dooling, who has been ill all Summer, was taken the day after election from his Summer home in Belle Harbor to his residence on West Forty-third Street.

Tenders will be considered tomorrow by officials of Sharpsburg, Pa., for a new issue of $100,000 of borough bonds. The bonds are to be dated Oct. 1, 1936, and mature Oct. 1, 1937 to 1951, optional in 1941. Bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 3 1/2 per cent.
The most successful National Automobile Show to date closed at 11 o'clock last night at the Grand Central Palace. Sales and attendance continued large till the end.

Protests against providing for 620 new positions in the 1937 city budget, at a cost of $1,000,000, were laid before the Finance Committee of the Board of Aldermen yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission in City Hall.
PARIS, Nov. 18. -- The French knew that Germany and Italy were going to recognize the Spanish Rebels, but they did not expect it so soon.

A special meeting of the stockholders of Stone Webster, Inc., has been called for Dec. 7 to vote upon a proposed reduction in capital from $50,000,000 to $20,000,000 in order to place the directors in a position before the end of the year to declare a dividend.

Useful and decorative articles, as well as novelties from Paris and England, suitable for holiday gifts, are being offered for sale at the annual Christmas sale and tea in behalf of Hope Farm, which opened yesterday afternoon in a colorful setting at the Pierre and will continue there today.

DUBLIN, Nov. 18. -- United States Postmaster General James A. Farley, in his search for a vacation from politics, arrived here this evening accompanied by his executive assistant, Ambrose O'Connell, and Edward Rodden.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Nov. 19. -- The eyes of the entire Chinese nation were focused yesterday upon Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, who has made a surprise trip from Loyang to Taiyuan, capital of Shansi Province, supposedly to confer with Governor Yen Hsi-shan about sending more troops to reinforce Suiyuan Province's long defensive line.

Dave Levin's efforts to regain the world's heavyweight wrestling championship from Dean Detton failed at Madison Square Garden last night. Detton did not pin the Jamaica butcher boy to keep the crown he won last September. That was unnecessary, for Levin eliminated himself after 30 minutes 41 seconds of fast grappling.

LONDON, Nov. 18. -- The stock market continued bullish today, with shipping shares leading a general advance following the announcement of a resumption of dividends on the deferred capital stock of the Peninsular and Oriental lines. The dividend on this stock, amounting to 4 per cent, is the first since 1931.

STOKE, England, Nov. 18 (Canadian Press). -- A fighting English international soccer team boosted England's stock in representative tilts to a new high today. By a well-deserved 3 -- 1 victory over Ireland, the Englishmen redeemed themselves after an early setback by Wales. Nearly 40,000 persons flocked to see the first international contest here since 1893.

Isabel French, soprano, from Boston, who gave a song recital in the Town Hall last night, may well claim to stem from aristocratic musical forbears. For one of her great-grandfathers was Pierre Duport, music teacher of Marie Antoinette's children, and the other, Alexander Reinagle, was a leading light in the musical life of Philadelphia for several decades after his arrival there late in the eighteenth century.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 18. -- Faced with the prospect of a broad expansion in residential construction in many parts of the country, realty men and builders attending the convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards here today studied the problem of aiding government agencies in setting up safeguards to community values which would put home ownership on a more stable basis.

The Police Department is pleased with the results of its acceleration of the traffic light intervals in Manhattan, officials said yesterday. No constructive adverse criticism has been received, they said, adding that there has been a good deal of praise.
