MADRID, Thursday, Nov. 19. -- Rebel aviators dropped at least twelve bombs in the center of Madrid early today. One of the bombs landed near the Telephone Building, shattering many windows.

The complete list of college games scheduled for the Hippodrome during the coming basketball season was announced by Jack Murray, prominent referee who is doing the promoting at the arena, at a luncheon tendered to basketball writers, coaches and officials at the Hotel Lincoln yesterday.
You published recently a letter from Leonard Hacker as to Inwood Hill Park, which was full of inaccuracies.

John G. Winant put principle above party when he resigned his position as chairman of the Social Security Board to answer Republican attacks. He did more; by this action he subjected his personal position and reputation to misinterpretation and attack. Regardless of one's personal opinion as to the wisdom of this action, it is evident that it took real courage and showed that the social security program meant more to him than anything else.
A small billy goat, which harassed officials are sure is somebody's pet, caused a lot of excitement yesterday by becoming New York's first caprine subway passenger.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 18. -- President Getulio Vargas predicted tonight that "a defensive but not an offensive bloc" of twenty-one American nations would emerge from the inter-American peace conference.

ALICANTE, Spain, Nov. 18. -- Jose Antonio Primo de Rivera, Spanish Fascist leader and son of the former dictator of Spain, was sentenced to death by the People's Tribunal here today for complicity in the Spanish insurrection. His brother Miguel was simultaneously sentenced to thirty years in prison and Miguel's wife, Margarita, to six years.

MEMPHIS, Nov. 18. -- Rexford G. Tugwell, the man whom Secretary Wallace has termed "a good lightning rod" of the Roosevelt administration, was a happy man today at the prospect of returning to private life as an executive of the American Molasses Company.

The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday removed one of the obstacles to the proposed exhibition bout between James J. Braddock and Joe Louis at Atlantic City on Feb. 22 when it advised Joe Gould, manager of the world's heavyweight champion, that it was chiefly concerned with his posting a $5,000 guarantee to cover his match with Max Schmeling next Summer.

Young matrons and debutantes of recent seasons will act as manikins in the fashion revue for the benefit of the Kips Bay Boys Club today during the cocktail hour in the new Iridium Room of the St. Regis. The fashion pageant will include a group of Beaux Arts Ball costumes which will be displayed by Mrs. Fergus Reid Jr., Mrs. Alan Jackson and the Misses Ann Foster, Peggy and Edna Brokaw.

PARIS, Nov. 18. -- While Premier Leon Blum mourned beside the body of his friend, Roger Salengro, Minister of the Interior, feeling ran high in the corridors of the Chamber of Deputies, where Leftists said that many of their followers demanded anti-Fascist demonstrations in Paris and Lille.

MOSCOW, Nov. 18. -- The possible suppression of the Kamerny Theatre, which next to the Moscow Art Theatre and possibly Meyerhold's enjoys the greatest fame abroad of any Soviet acting company, was excitedly discussed in theatrical circles here today.
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Nov. 18. -- Long-drawn-out matches featured the play in the international chess masters tournament at the Club Ajedrez de San Juan today.

TRENTON, Nov. 18. -- Bernard Maxwell of Wildwood, a Cape May County Republican leader, was committed to the Mercer County jail tonight in default of $10,000 bail by United States Commissioner Marvin A. Spaulding for a further hearing next Wednesday on a charge of vote-buying at the recent general election.

The share market endeavored, in the early trading yesterday, to resume the brisk advance of Tuesday, but stocks soon were in fairly good supply and the list assumed a mixed appearance through to closing. Prices ruled irregularly lower at the finish.

Outpour of money by corporations, in the form of increase both in wages and increased dividends to shareholders, has attained in the fortnight past a magnitude not often reached in our history, even during 1929. So rapidly have these announcements crowded on one another, that the total amount to be thus disbursed can only be estimated.

ROME, Nov. 18. -- Premier Benito Mussolini made a two-hour exposition of the international and domestic political situation before the Fascist Grand Council tonight, following formal recognition by Italy and Germany of the Spanish Fascist government.

The Merchant Truckmen's Bureau of New York and the Master Truckmen's Association, representing the bulk of the trucking business in the city, began yesterday their preparations to take to the United States Supreme Court their fight against store-door delivery of freight by major railroads serving the city.

The legal residence of the late Colonel Edward H. R. Green was made a matter of primary importance yesterday before Surrogate Harry E. Owen, in the contest of Mabel Harlow Green for a wife's share of the $50,000,000 estate that her husband inherited from his mother, Hetty Green.

Wage increases for all hourly employes, equal to 10 per cent of the payroll, were announced yesterday by the Ludlum Steel Company. H.G. Batcheller, president, announced the increase in a letter to all employes in which he related that the company had appropriated expenditures of $1,095,000 for plant expansion in order to maintain the increases in employment which it has been able to give its employes over the past two years.

Re-establishment of a genuinely cooperative relationship between government and business on "a sound, friendly and sympathetic basis" was urged yesterday by Thomas W. Pangborn, president of the National Founders Association, at the opening session of the association's fortieth annual meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 18. -- A complete recount of the vote for Surrogate in Westchester County was ordered today by Supreme Court Justice Graham Witschief, setting in motion the first countywide rechecking of election returns in the memory of veteran county officials.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 18. -- County Medical Examiner Amos O. Squire of Westchester decided this afternoon that Mrs. Grace Van Name, 42 years old, wife of Fred W. Van Name, head of a New York advertising firm which bears his name, died accidentally of monoxide gas poisoning in the garage of her home this morning.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18. -- By working together, business and government will promote world peace as well as prosperity, President Roosevelt assured business men engaged in foreign trade in a message sent to the National Foreign Trade Convention.

A resumption of the advance in United States Government obligations was a feature of bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Trading interests appeared to switch from the recent speculative features in the corporate list to the higher grade loans.

Mr. Barbirolli and the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra presented their third midweek program last night in Carnegie Hall. It consisted, for the orchestra, of the Bach Brandenburg Concerto No. 6, in B flat: the delightful symphony of Haydn, infrequently played, numbered 1 in the catalogue of the series of twelve which Haydn composed for the manager, Salomon, for performance in London, and Richard Strauss's tone-poem, "Don Quixote."

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. I8. -- Efforts of the Committee for Industrial Organization to completely organize the Bendix Products Company plant here today were met by President Vincent Bendix's statement that "this plant cannot operate as a closed shop and will never be operated as such."

ROME, Nov. 18. -- The Italian Government today officially recognized the Insurgent government of Generalissimo Francisco France in Spain, giving as its justification the fact that his movement "has taken possession of the greater part of Spain and the development of the situation shows ever more clearly that in the remaining parts no responsible government any longer exists."

The employers of a trusted bookkeeper who banked $122,000 in twenty-five years on a salary that never exceeded $40 a week sued yesterday to determine whether in some of the savings were the concern's funds.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 18. -- Clifford Odets, who seems to have suffered an incomplete realization of his cinema ideals in his first film, "The General Died at Dawn," will return to Hollywood next week accompanied by Lewis Milestone and a script of what he believes a motion picture should be.

LeRoy Haynes, Philadelphia Negro heavyweight, proved entirely too strong for Abe Feldman of New York in their scheduled ten-round bout at the Hippodrome last night. He knocked out Feldman in 1:41 of the second round after he had the New York boxer on the floor four times.

News that the SEC would push its proposed segregation of the functions of brokers and dealers was received yesterday long after the stock markets had closed. It has been apparent for some time that the financial community was expecting bad news from this direction.

POTTSVILLE, Pa., Nov. 18. -- An organized army of the unemployed is engaged today in digging the grave of an ailing industry that no longer can give them work. They are the bootleg miners of Eastern Pennsylvania's rich anthracite fields, where thousands of tons of coal are being mined, shipped and sold each day under the acquiescent eyes of the law-enforcing agencies of the State.

LONDON, Nov. 18. -- Winston Churchill, in a speech to the United Associations of Great Britain and France, described Britain, France and the United States tonight as having common interests in the preservation of democracy and individual freedom.

LONDON, Nov. 18 (AP). -- James Maxton, extreme Laborite member of Parliament, said today that King Edward was seeking the support of the masses for his friendship with Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson, and even marriage if he wished. He asserted the King was rallying support to combat opposition from the aristocracy.

ABOARD THE STEAMSHIP AMERICAN LEGION, en Route to Buenos Aires, Nov. 18. -- The final touches to the United States' proposals of neutrality and cultural relations to be presented to the Buenos Aires Peace Conference were agreed upon by the American delegation today.

A couple of days after it was supposed to, "Johnny Johnson" gets under way this evening at the Forty-fourth Street, and with it begins the Group Theatre's season. To say it again, this is the play-with-music by Paul Green and Kurt Weill, with Russell Collins in the title role and some thirty-five others elsewhere in the cast, Direction by Lee Strasberg; settings by Donald Oenslager; curtain at 8:30 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- President Roosevelt gave public recognition today to the renewed drive within private industry for re-employment and at the same time offered a suggestion as to how it might be further accelerated, by making jobs available to a greater number of workers over 40 years of age.

Clarification of picketing rights will be sought by the League of Women Shoppers, it announced yesterday, in commenting on the Court of Appeals decision on Monday finding two of its members guilty of disorderly conduct for picketing without police permission.

The New York Curb Exchange suspended dealings at 1 P.M. yesterday in the $2-par capital stock of Dictograph Products, Inc., when the committee on unlisted securities decided that "the market would not absorb selling orders without demoralization."

Scrimmage work, apparently a prerequisite to victory for Manhattan's football forces this Fall, constituted the main portion of yesterday's practice at wind-swept Innisfail Park, as the Jaspers continued preparations for Saturday's game with Villanova at Ebbets Field.

Miss Nina Wilmerding Beck was among those who entertained with luncheons for debutantes yesterday. Her guests at Sherry's included the Misses Florence Cameron, Virginia Rainier and Audrey Pile. At the luncheon given by Miss Edith Altschul at Le Coq Rouge were the Misses Betty Brady, Helen-Cronkhite and Betty Bughman.
